title: Postal Service Losses in 1987 Put at $200 Million
description: The Postal Service finished the fiscal year 1987 with a loss of more than $200 million, emphasizing the need for the higher rates expected to take effect next spring, Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch said today.

title: FRANKLIN B. TUTTLE
description: Franklin B. Tuttle, an insurance executive and former chairman of the Atlantic Companies, died Tuesday at the Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Kinderhook, N.Y.

title: Battery Park Revenues To Back Housing Bonds
description: With this week's bond sale by the Housing New York Corporation, New York City is taking a major step toward converting the financial success of the Battery Park City development in lower Manhattan into low-income housing in other parts of the city.

title: Lack of Pilots Idling New Army Helicopters
description: A lack of trained pilots has forced the Army to park dozens of new AH-64 Apache helicopter gunships, each costing $11.5 million, officials say.

title: ABM Hand Unmasked
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has discovered the lawyer at the root of the Reagan Administration's much-disputed new interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. It is not Abraham Sofaer, the former Federal judge who is State Department counsel, but rather a man whose name is familiar to students of last summer's Iran-contra hearings: Bretton Sciaroni.

title: Repurchase Offer By Florida Bank
description: Hugh F. Culverhouse, the Tampa, Fla., investor, disclosed that Florida Commercial Banks Inc. had offered to repurchase his 1.54 million shares of the Miami-based bank holding company for $30 a share. In a filing Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Culverhouse said that he had been contacted last Thursday and last Friday by two different directors of Florida Commercial.

title: Ward Taken to Hospital After an Asthma Attack
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward suffered a severe asthma attack at his home early yesterday, was hospitalized, but by midday was in stable condition, signing papers and joking, the authorities said.

title: Prince Is Back on Broadway
description: With the opening of ''Roza'' tonight at the Royale Theater, Harold Prince returns to Broadway with a vengeance, after an absence of more than two and a half years.

title: The K.G.B. Doesn't Need a Library Card
description: To the Editor:

title: No Grievance
description: Alan Wiggins, the second baseman who was suspended without pay on Aug. 31 by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for improper conduct and was unconditionally released by the Baltimore Orioles on Tuesday, will not file a grievance over either his release or his suspension. ''We have no objection to the release; it's what Alan really wanted,'' said Gene Orza, the associate general counsel of the Major League Players Association.

title: Critic's Notebook; The World on Windows, in 'Site Specific' Drama
description: TONIGHT, weather permitting, Dick Beebe's ''Naked Chambers'' will be presented al fresco, on a streetcorner in TriBeCa. This is a ''site specific'' play, a mode of theater popularized by the En Garde Arts company, which uses nontheatrical settings as environments for theater. As an audio-visual show that takes place on and around the facade of a new high-rise apartment house, ''Naked Chambers'' might be considered an experiment in performance architecture.

title: Today's Artisans: In the Spirit of the Past
description: IN farmhouses, studios and workshops across the United States, artisans are making a living by handcrafting furniture and accessories based on designs from earlier times. They sell to architects, decorators and individual clients, as well as to museum shops and department stores.

title: Forstmann Will Sell Sybron
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a New York investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, will sell the Sybron Corporation for $390 million to a corporation formed by the Dallas-based Hicks & Haas; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and certain members of Sybron's management.

title: As the People Meters See It, 'CBS Evening News' Leads
description: ''CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather was back on top of the network news ratings last week, and ''NBC Nightly News'' with Tom Brokaw was third, for the first time in more than a year, according to figures released by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: BERMUDA STAR LINE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $59,000 tax credit. c-Net loss The company said its latest first quarter's operating results include a loss of $81,000, representing its pro- rata portion of preoperating general and administrative start-up expenses of Memory-Tech Inc., a 40 percent owned venture with Mitsubishi Corp.

title: Possible Mine Sightings Mount in Persian Gulf
description: A new mine scare sent commercial shipping on a circuitous route through the northern Persian Gulf today as two convoys under United States Navy escort steamed north and south through the waterway.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Aug. 26 about an exotic-game ranch in Texas gave an incorrect location for the Mansion on Turtle Creek, a restaurant. It is in Dallas.

title: Advertising; Grey Advertising Gets Schaefer Assignment
description: Schaefer, the best-selling beer in Puerto Rico, has just been assigned to Grey Advertising by the Stroh Company of Detroit.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 1, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.N. Changes Losing Support As Congress Delays on Funds
description: The likelihood that Washington will withhold funds from the United Nations again this year is undermining support for administrative changes that give the United States more influence over the organization's finances and activities, according to diplomats and senior officials.

title: Executive Changes At Harper & Row
description: William M. Shinker was appointed publisher of Harper & Row's trade division yesterday. Edward L. Burlingame, who had been publisher and editorial director of the division since 1980, has been appointed publisher of a line of books to be issued by Harper under his imprint.

title: REAGAN INTENSIFIES CAMPAIGN TO WIN BORK NOMINATION
description: President Reagan sharply attacked opponents of Judge Robert H. Bork today, opening a newly aggressive White House campaign to support the judge's nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Talking Deals; The Liquor Consolidations
description: FACED with declining worldwide liquor consumption, the international liquor industry is turning to consolidation as a way to prop up sagging sales. Indeed, analysts say that by the end of the decade the industry, traditionally the domain of small, independent operators, will consist of a handful of conglomerates.

title: A Merrill Offering To Yield 10.63%
description: Merrill Lynch Mortgage Investors Inc. is offering $71.5 million of 10.20 percent mortgage pass-through certificates due 2002, at a price of 98.27, to yield 10.63 percent, or about 1.4 percentage points more than Treasury notes due 1992.

title: Armchair Trips, From Italy Westward
description: READERS of this fall's new design books will embark on a vicarious journey.

title: MERET INC reports earnings for Year to July 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $660,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $503,187, gains of $1,848,112 from debt restructuring and $415,000 from a tax credit.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN ADULTERY. By Alexander Theroux. 396 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $370,000.

title: Key Leaders Won't Oppose Rise in Medicare Premiums
description: Key members of Congress said today that they had reluctantly agreed not to oppose the largest increase ever in Medicare premiums next year, as proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: TV Reviews; Heston In 'Proud Men'
description: WHILE the new CBS series ''Tour of Duty'' continues tonight to exploit the Vietnam story with standard war games and buddy stories, a made-for-TV movie on ABC at 9 P.M. makes a more oblique yet considerably more powerful attack on the same subject. ''Proud Men'' is set not in Vietnam but in the American Northwest. Charlton Heston plays Charley McLeod, a weathered, tradition-steeped cattle rancher who is told he is dying. His wife, Laura (Nan Martin), phones their son, an increasingly successful photographer in France, to come home. Charley Jr., portrayed by Peter Strauss, went AWOL 15 years earlier in Vietnam.

title: Veteran Gives Cowboys New Look
description: When someone asked Joe Walton how it had been to coach castoffs and has-beens this week while his regular players are on strike, the head coach of the Jets hesitated for a moment and said: ''It's been an adventure.''

title: Travels in the Ages
description: On the road to Letoon - which runs among conical stacks of drying sesame and the peaked wooden frames over which Turkish farmers spread cover for winter-grown tomatoes - travelers suddenly discover the ruins of an ancient amphitheater seeming to rise from the white-tipped rows of a cotton field.

title: Giving an Old Pot A Brand-New Lining
description: ''FIFTY, 60, 70 years ago, the gypsy used to come around and pick up pots and re-tin them,'' said Fred Bridge, owner of the Bridge Kitchenware Corporation. Since gypsies no longer roam the streets, the household cook must find this service elsewhere.

title: America's Future With Canada Is Now
description: The United States and Canada have five days to make history. Monday is their deadline for agreement to meld the world's largest trading partnership into a single zone of freer trade. Success or failure will shape both countries' economic development and North America's role in the global economy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, said Robert J. Clark, president of the Commercial Insurance division, had advised the company that he would be resigning because of ''personal reasons.''

title: What We Learned
description: Twice, during the hearings on the Bork nomination, foreign visitors remarked to me that they found the process deeply impressive. Watching the Senate Judiciary Committee at work, one said, he understood that the American system was ''regenerative in its openness.''

title: Stage: 'Lenny Bruce Revue'
description: ''THE Lenny Bruce Revue,'' at the Harold Clurman Theater, 412 West 42nd Street, is a biographical tribute to the late comedian that bills itself as ''a burlesque of comedy and dance.'' Written and directed by Fred Baker, the show presents a chronologically arranged sequence of Bruce monologues, dramatized by a nine-member ensemble and accompanied by slides and dancers. Instead of having a single actor impersonate the star, Mr. Baker has dispersed the words of Lenny Bruce among the cast members in the futile hope of theatrically opening up the monologues by turning them into skits.

title: F.B.I. Says Surveillance Of Writers Has Stopped
description: The F.B.I. said today that it had stopped keeping files on American authors 11 years ago. Documents on which two articles being published this week are based show that the bureau monitored the activities of such writers as Ernest Hemingway, William Faulkner and John Steinbeck.

title: Late Adjustment for Pena
description: When he appeared for work on Tuesday afternoon, Tony Pena of the St. Louis Cardinals had a batting average of .210, a seat on the bench and a pair of eyeglasses. The average had deteriorated steadily since the end of June. The seat was an unpleasant, but not an unexpected result of his extended problems in the batter's box. The glasses may be the answer.

title: Waterhouse Sets New Unit
description: Price Waterhouse said yesterday that it would establish an affiliate registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission that would act as an investment adviser to its executive clients.

title: U.S., Canada Keep in Touch
description: Canadian and American officials continued to exchange notes and phone calls today, seeking a basis for resuming talks on a free trade agreement that Canada suspended a week ago.

title: Music: History, A Trio
description: HIGH-TECH, low comedy, John Cage, Spike Jones, the Carter Family and R. Crumb all filter through the History of Unheard Music, the group that opened the New Songs series Monday at Dance Theater Workshop. For History of Unheard Music, the modern soundscape is a heap of rubble to be scavenged; when the trio uses a song form, it's like something heard from a distant, static-filled radio station, evoking a kind of addled nostalgia. Pop hits, noise and oddball stage moves - not to mention puns, masks, ventriloquism and, in the opening number, things that went bump in the dark -all figured in the group's performance on Monday.

title: ERIC H. HAIGHT
description: Eric H. Haight, the founder of the Westchester Community Health Plan, died Sunday at the Northern Westchester Community Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Reagan Sees 'Fiction' in Book on C.I.A. Chief
description: President Reagan said today that ''an awful lot of fiction'' had been written about William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence for most of Mr. Reagan's Presidency.

title: Interior Dept. Is Voted $10 Billion By Senate but Veto Is Threatened
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved its second appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1988, a $10 billion package for the Interior Department and related agencies such as the Forest Service.

title: Time for Federal Laws on AIDS Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: California Accepts Steel Shot Regulation
description: When, in 1976, the Fish and Wildlife Service started its program to get the lead out of waterfowlers' shotgun shells, bitter debates and much heel-dragging by many states resulted. But this year, all save California had either accepted or accelerated the Federal timetable that will make steel shot mandatory for duck and goose hunting throughout the nation by 1991. California's last-ditch stand ended Monday when Judge Raul Ramirez of the United States District Court in Sacramento rejected the state's Fish and Game Commission's effort to block expansion of California's steel shot zones.

title: Housing Market Shows Unexpected Resiliency
description: The housing market proved stronger at summer's end than had been expected, as sales of new homes rose 2.7 percent in August, the Government said today.

title: HERS
description: AUNT CEIL went through life thinking she got the small half. She perceived hurts where there was no intent. She wrote off people with abandon. She was a self-made outcast, the perennial victim, and sooner or later everyone failed her.

title: Drug Subsidies for Elderly Starting in New York State
description: A New York State program to subsidize prescription-drug purchases for elderly people goes into effect today, but only a small percentage of those eligible have enrolled.

title: House Acts to Oppose Sale of Arms to Saudis
description: A majority in the House signaled President Reagan today that his Administration's plan to sell $1.4 billion of arms to Saudi Arabia is doomed in its present form because it would further destabilize the Persian Gulf region.

title: Grumman Buys Fairchild Unit
description: The Grumman Corporation announced here today that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Long Island engineering center of the Fairchild Republic Company.

title: G.M. Hughes Adds
description: The G.M. Hughes Electronics Corporation said that it had acquired M/A-COM Telecommunications of Germantown, Md., for $105 million. The company, which was a subsidiary of M/A-COM Inc., of Burlington, Mass., manufactures digital communications equipment used in satellite systems that link subscribers - mainly businesses with widely dispersed branches - in much the same way that telephone systems do. Donald J. Atwood, president of G.M. Hughes Electronics, said M/A-Com Telecommunications, which has been renamed Hughes Network Systems, would complement Hughes Communications Inc., a manufacturer of satellite equipment.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: b-After a charge of $8,217,000 related to the retirement of debt.

title: Long Road For Tokyo and Bonn
description: Are Japan and West Germany, the countries with the biggest trade surpluses in the world, doing as much as they should to further international economic expansion?

title: Led by Construction, New York Area's Economy Continue to Grow
description: The New York regional economy continued its rapid pace of growth in the first half of 1987, pushed forward by high levels of construction and a continuing decline in unemployment, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Film Festival; Axel's 'Babette's Feast,' From a Dinesen Story
description: TAKING a longish tale, ''Babette's Feast,'' from Isak Dinesen's last collection, ''Anecdotes of Destiny'' (1958), Gabriel Axel has made a very handsome, very literary movie that does justice to the precision of the Dinesen prose, to the particularity of her concerns and to the ironies that so amused her.

title: Why U.S. Walked Out On Iranian at U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter and full-year results include the operations of the company and certain licensees acquired in December 1986 as well as the operations of Sealy of Michigan since its acquisition in April.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Japanese Instruments In a Western Concert
description: East is east, west is west, and sometimes the twain do meet, with mixed results. Tsutomu Sakamoto, a koto player and composer from Japan, gave a concert Tuesday at the Kampo Cultural Center, 31 Bond Street, that began with his ensemble of five kotos (Japanese zithers) and one shakuhachi flute trotting jauntily through his arrangement of Stephen Foster melodies.

title: Infantry's Antitank Weapons Are Faulted in Study
description: Antitank rockets purchased by the Army for use by individual soldiers in combat may not be effective against Soviet tanks, a Congressional study has reported.

title: Music: Japanese Series
description: THE Hidden Fortress:

title: 'Loophole' Tax Plan Criticized
description: Congressional tax writers said today that they need to go far beyond the Reagan Administration's suggestion of closing ''loopholes'' in the income tax code if they are to raise $12 billion in new revenues to meet 1988 budget needs.

title: Doctor in Texas With AIDS Virus Closes His Practice Amid a Furor
description: Dr. Robert J. Huse took his diplomas off the wall today, cleaned out his desk and closed his practice. At the age of 44, he assumes that his career in general pediatrics is over.

title: Schoolboy Caught Smoking Accused of Shooting Teacher
description: A 16-year-old student has been charged as an adult with attempted murder and unlawful use of a weapon in the shooting of a teacher who had caught him smoking.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Theatrical Reprise

title: Plane Crash Kills 6
description: A twin-engine airplane with six people aboard crashed in heavy fog today while attempting to land at the Tijuana airport, killing everyone aboard, the authorities said. The Mexican-registered Cessna 340 went down shortly after 8 A.M. on the United States side of the border. The flight originated in Mexico, but United States officials could not say where.

title: Cardinals' Loss Keeps Reeling Mets Barely Alive; Orosco Beaten By Home Run
description: The Mets were knocked closer to oblivion tonight on one swing of the bat when Luis Aguayo pinch-hit a 10th-inning home run off Jesse Orosco and the Philadelphia Phillies buried the Mets, 4-3.

title: Israel and China Aides Agree On Ties at U.N.
description: The foreign ministers of Israel and China met for the first time today and agreed to maintain regular contacts between their two governments at the United Nations.

title: 3 Partners to Buy Lorimar TV Units
description: Joseph Goldfarb, a Lorimar Telepictures Corporation executive, said he and two partners had agreed to buy three television stations from the parent company for $23 million and that he plans to resign when the deal is completed.

title: Ford Workers Approve Contract by Wide Margin
description: Workers at the Ford Motor Company approved the recently negotiated labor contract with the company by a margin of nearly 3 to 1, the United Automobile Workers reported today.

title: Bork Panel Ends Hearings; Vote Scheduled on Tuesday
description: Confirmation hearings on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court ended today on an acrimonimous note.

title: Crocicchia Steps In for Simms
description: The biggest football game Jim Crocicchia ever played happened last year, when his Penn team (9-0) met Cornell (8-1) in the season finale for the Ivy League championship. Crocicchia had a good game and Penn won, 31-21.

title: U.S. Optimistic on World Cup
description: The United States' bid for the 1994 World Cup was presented to soccer's governing body in Zurich yesterday and there was optimism about the chances of getting the tournament.

title: RUBICON CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a total gain of $409,000 from a tax credit, debt restructuring and early extinguishment of debt.

title: MIGENT SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Swat by Helms
description: Senator Jesse Helms has taken another swipe at his bete noire: the State Department. But this time, he had the support of most of his colleagues in the Senate.

title: September, The Rush To Spend
description: A Federal shopping spree ended today -abruptly, as it does every year in September's final hours.

title: Settings That Sparkle
description: ''SEPARATE TABLES,'' a show of table settings designed by seven architects and interior designers with Steuben crystal, is at the Steuben store at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street through Oct. 31. The designers are Mario Buatta, Suzie Frankfurt, Michael Graves, Albert Hadley, Mark Hampton, John Saladino and, at left, Edward Zajac, of the Manhattan interior design firm Zajac & Callahan Inc. Shown above is Mr. Zajac's English grog table or open bar, set for guests to help themselves.

title: Jessica Hahn Is Called To Testify on Wedtech
description: Jessica Hahn has been subpoenaed to appear next week before a Bronx grand jury investigating the Wedtech Corporation, according to people familiar with the case.

title: A Lack of Harmony
description: David Checketts, president and general manager of the Utah Jazz, is trying to accommodate the trade demanded by Kelly Tripucka, but Checketts said no team had showed any interest.

title: Elizabeth Eden, Transsexual Who Figured in 1975 Movie
description: Elizabeth D. Eden, whose desire for a sex-change operation led to an attempted bank robbery portrayed in the film ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' died of pneumonia resulting from AIDS Tuesday at Genesee Hospital in Rochester. She was 41 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: Peace Is Central American Refugees' Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SELECTING the right home insulation from the numerous brands and products can be bewildering. What follows is a guide to the kinds available.

title: Accord Raises Honduran Misgivings on U.S. Ties
description: The Central American peace accord has raised new misgivings here about Honduras's heavy dependence on the United States. It has also provoked a debate over this country's human rights record and its support for Nicaraguan rebels, Honduran politicians and foreign diplomats said.

title: Coffee Talks Deadlock
description: International negotiations on new coffee export quotas to bolster falling world prices were stalled today, delegates at the meeting said. The talks at the International Coffee Organization include both nations that produce coffee and those that consume it.

title: TV Reviews; NBC News Broadcasts From China
description: CHINA is changing, no question about that. Tom Brokaw has been saying so since he first stood in front of the Court of Supreme Harmony in the old Forbidden City last Friday. Since then, Mr. Brokaw has interviewed Zhao Ziyang, and Connie Chung has met her cousin, and Keith Miller has floated down the Yangtze. Jane Pauley and Bryant Gumbel have watched a chef make noodles. China has been all over NBC News, and NBC News has been all over China.

title: Advertising; How PC's Help Out An Agency
description: IN the advertising trade press, Karp Newton Van Brunt is an unknown.

title: K. JACK BAUER
description: K. Jack Bauer, a naval historian and a professor of history at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, died Sept. 17 at St. Mary's Hospital in Troy, N.Y., of complications from a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived in Brunswick, N.Y.

title: PLAN ON GULF ROLE STALLS IN SENATE
description: The Senate remained deadlocked today over a Democratic proposal that would require Congressional approval for continuation of the Administration's policy of escorting Kuwaiti tankers in the Persian Gulf.

title: Presser Trial Date Set
description: A Federal district judge has set Feb. 15 as the date for the racketeering and embezzlement trial of Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two associates. The judge, George White, set the date at a pretrial hearing Tuesday.

title: ARTISTS WANT WORK PROTECTED
description: Representatives of movie directors, screen writers and painters urged Congress today to adopt an international copyright convention that grants ''moral rights'' to artists and forbids changes in their works without their consent.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Canterbury Trio At the 92d Street Y
description: It took only one phrase Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y to ascertain that the Canterbury Trio has healthy musical life in it. The program began with Haydn's bright C-major trio (XV:27), and the performance began with an outburst that drew back in an instant like a teasing cat.

title: Fraud Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. in a Nod Toward Gold

title: Mackinaw City Journal; In Search of a Past At Northwest Outpost
description: To the archeologists who have been excavating the small, sandy plot here, the site is known simply as ''house C of the southeast row house,'' the buried ruins of an 18th-century fur traders' dwelling.

title: Belle Linsky, Philanthropist And Art Collector, Dies at 83
description: Belle Linsky, an art collector and philanthropist, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: Peter George Whigham, 62, British Poet and Translator
description: Peter George Whigham, a British poet and translator, died Aug. 6 in an automobile accident in Orleans, Calif. He was 62 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Panel Ponders Running Lilco For the Public
description: To the nine men and women who will ultimately decide whether New York State tries to take over the Long Island Lighting Company, one important question appears already to have been decided.

title: Calendar; Lectures, Exhibits And Tours
description: Blueprints by Computer

title: MARGOT L. MAREK
description: Margot L. Marek, an author and specialist in learning disabilities, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan and Hillsdale, N.Y.

title: Blue Jays Defeated, But So Are Tigers
description: Robin Yount hit a tie-breaking triple, and Dale Sweum added a two-run home run to lead the Milwaukee Brewers to a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight and a sweep of their three-game series.

title: Stage: Billy Connolly
description: BILLY CONNOLLY, a 44-year-old Scottish comedian who sold out the Vivian Beaumont Theater on Sunday night, has been toiling in the comedy world for nearly 20 years. But it is only very recently that he has cultivated a large American audience for his brand of boisterous barroom humor.

title: Iran-Contra Draft Is Assailed
description: Two Republican members of the House Iran-contra committee complained today that the panel's draft report is loaded with anti-Administration innuendo and that it implies President Reagan might have known of the diversion of Iran arms-sale money to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Pop: Paul Kelly and Band
description: PUB-ROCK, the mid-1970's, back-to-basics wave of British rock, yielded one fiery songwriter, Graham Parker, and one ironic craftsman, Nick Lowe. More than a decade later, an Australian rocker has emerged who's tough enough and smart enough to join them: Paul Kelly, who led his band, the Messengers, on Monday at the Bottom Line.

title: Rumors of War on the Arms Treaty
description: The battle lines are forming in the Senate on what promises to be a major fight of 1988 - approval of a treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union banning intermediate-range missiles.

title:
Market Place;
High Fliers That Plunged
description: LEAD: WHILE the stock market seems to be holding its own, some individual issues have taken stunning drubbings in recent weeks.

title: Clippers, N.B.A. Settle
description: Multimillion-dollar lawsuits between the National Basketball Association and Donald T. Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, were averted when the parties reached an out-of-court settlement that will allow the Clippers to remain in Los Angeles, according to a report yesterday in The Los Angeles Herald Examiner.

title: Dance: Butoh by Natsu Nakajima
description: NATSU NAKAJIMA founded her dance company, Muteki-Sha in 1969 - it is, then, one of the older Butoh dance groups from Japan to be seen in the United States. Yet because Miss Nakajima's miniature format eschews the spectacular side of Butoh groups like Sankai Juku and Dai Rakuda Kan, which preceded her here, Muteki-Sha - unjustly - has received less attention.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Los Angeles County Coliseum Commission filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against the Los Angeles Raiders, but a lawyer for the commission said the intent was not to block the team's move to nearby Irwindale. Marshall Grossman, the attorney, said the commission was seeking more than $50 million in damages because the Raiders had violated their lease agreement with the coliseum by failing to construct luxury boxes as promised. . . . Mark Brannon will replace Jose Mosqueda as Pernell Whitaker's opponent tonight at the Felt Forum. Earlier this week, the New York State Athletic Commission refused to approve Mosqueda as a worthy opponent for Whitaker. . . . Coach Bo Schembechler of Michigan, who was treated for kidney stone problems at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Tuesday, has been released and is expected to coach the Wolverines in their opening Big Ten football game of the season against Wisconsin on Saturday.

title: Advertising; New Yorker Increasing Its Rate Base by 3.8%
description: The 63-year-old New Yorker magazine, under new ownership since May 1985, is raising its circulation rate base by 20,000 with its Jan. 4 issue. It will be the largest increase in the history of the magazine and will bring the total to 545,000, a 3.8 percent rise.

title: Judge Rejects Effort to Stop Shift of Otters Off California
description: A Federal district judge has rejected a request for an injunction to halt the transfer of sea otters into prime fishing territory off the California coast.

title: Pretoria Sanctions Didn't Work, Reagan Report to Congress Says
description: The White House plans to inform Congress that the economic sanctions the Administration had to impose last year on South Africa have failed to achieve any desired changes and that President Reagan will refuse to recommend new sanctions, according to Administration officials.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Instruments of the Devil
description: Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker, deposed heads of the Praise The Lord ministry, have an awful lot of explaining to do. There are those missing funds and gold-plated bathroom fixtures, as well as other revelations. Loss of their television empire this spring temporarily left the Bakkers holding their tongues. Now the evangelist couple have found another electronic way to spread the good word about themselves and fetch a pretty penny, too. It's called Dial-the-Bakkers.

title: Dow, in Seesaw Session, Gains 5.71
description: Stock prices ended moderately higher after a seesaw session yesterday amid continued nervousness over bond prices and the dollar.

title: Metro Matters; A Victim's Peril: Lack of Money For a Divorce
description: The prosecutor, Solomon Landa, was desperately scratching for another seed of doubt the other day that he hoped would germinate when the jury finally got the murder case against Karen Straw.

title: IF TOY GUN LOOKS REAL IT'S BANNED
description: The City Council voted Tuesday night to ban the sale of realistic-looking toy guns. The 4-to-1 vote came six weeks after a man using such a toy ordered David Horowitz, the television consumer reporter, to read a bizarre statement on the air.

title: 32 Straight For Santiago
description: San Diego's Benito Santiago doubled to extend his rookie-record hitting streak to 32 games tonight, but Cincinnati's Tom Browning allowed eight hits and doubled in a run as the Reds beat the Padres, 3-1.

title: Approaching the End
description: It finally came down to this, waiting in the dampness and the gloom of the last hour of September, darkness falling on them from all directions, things finally out of their control.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $1,154,000 for the latest year and $1,222,000 for 1986. The latest year earnings have been restated to reflect a change in accounting methods. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Aug. 24.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: There were 12 weeks in the third quarter and 36 weeks in the 9 months.

title: WOMEN IN COMBAT FOCUS OF HEARINGS
description: A House subcommittee plans to open hearings Thursday on the most sensitive social issue confronting the armed forces today: the status of women in the service, particularly their role in combat.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: PRESIDIO OIL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income for the latest year and year-ago quarter, therefore, there were no share earnings.

title: Waldheim to Visit Pakistan
description: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria will visit Pakistan Nov. 23-25, a Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. Mr. Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, has not received similar invitations from other countries, and has been placed on a list of foreigners barred from visiting the United States because of a furor over his World War II record.

title: China Seizes Illicit Books
description: The police detained 44 people and confiscated nearly 80,000 pornographic books and magazines in connection with an illegal publication ring operating in eastern China, an official report said today. The ring was based in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi province, and had branches in 23 provinces, 470 wholesale outlets and 600 sellers, the state-run New China News Agency said.

title: Judge Rejects Lawsuit Over Abortion Policy
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that challenged President Reagan's policy of denying aid to foreign organizations that promote abortion as a method of family planning in other countries.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Up by 1.6%
description: The prices that farmers receive for raw products rose 1.6 percent in September, recovering more than half of the losses of July and August, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Saving Native Dogwood and White Ash
description: Plant specialists and gardeners are frustrated at the decline and death of the native flowering dogwood tree (Cornus florida). But Dr. Craig Hibben, a plant pathologist at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Research Center at Kitchawan, N.Y., said that proper care can strengthen a tree's resistance to the disease.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1987
description: The Economy

title: ORACLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Treasury Prices Rise Slightly
description: After Tuesday's sharp selloff, Treasury bond prices stabilized yesterday and eventually rose more than half a point in afternoon trading.

title: ICN BIOMEDICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $617,000.

title: Panel Named to Help New York City Pick Schools Chancellor
description: After a monthlong delay, caused in part by difficulty in finding people willing to serve, an advisory panel was named yesterday to help the New York City Board of Education choose a schools chancellor.

title: Canadian Bank To Buy Broker
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said today that it would buy a Toronto-based securities house, McLeod Young Weir Ltd., a move that should catapult Canada's fourth-largest bank into the top ranks of the nation's brokerage industry.

title: Shevardnadze, in Brazil, Backs Latin Peace Plan
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, on a tour of Latin America, has assured his hosts that Moscow strongly supports the new Central American peace plan and will put no obstacles in its way, Brazilian officials said today.

title: MAGELLAN PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $7,639. c-Net loss

title: Baker Hints at Gold As Guide on Policy
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told world financial leaders today that the Reagan Administration ''is prepared to consider'' using the price of gold in trying to steer its own and the world economies.

title: Alarmist Critics Who Cry Beowulf
description: LEAD: Diane Ravitch and Chester Finn Jr., writing in their new book ''What Do Our 17-Year-Olds Know?'', conclude on the basis of a fairly extensive questionnaire about literature and history that American adolescents know mighty little.

title: Reader's Digest Gets Dorling Stake
description: In a move to acquire greater access to worldwide publishing markets, The Reader's Digest announced that it had purchased a 50 percent interest in Dorling Kindersley, a London-based publisher and packager whose books are sold throughout the world.

title: Survey of Electorate Finds Weak Political Parties and Conflicts Over Change
description: The political coalition assembled by President Reagan ''could easily crumble'' at the end of his term, but the Democratic coalition is at least as precarious and the party is handicapped by doubts among its own supporters about its ability to manage the Government, a major new study of the electorate says.

title: Very Exciting, Very Usual: The I.H.T.
description: ''Dear Newspaper, I like you very much but . . .'' Thus Vladimir Nabokov would begin his letters to The International Herald Tribune, conveying a sentiment felt worldwide: The I.H.T. seems like an old friend. A surprisingly old friend: this week it turns 100.

title: Pactel Offers Stock in Unit
description: California telephone operating company, said today that it would issue up to 15 million common shares in Pactel Personal Communications, the company's cellular telephone and paging unit. Further details of the offering were not announced, pending the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commisssion next week.

title: Two Lawyers Selected To Restore S.E.C. Office
description: The announcement Tuesday that two veteran Washington lawyers from the Securities and Exchange Commission would be temporarily heading the New York office demonstrated the deep concern that the agency's headquarters had for its most important branch.

title: Japanese to Get La Costa Hotel
description: A Japanese country club operator said today that it planned to pay $250 million for the La Costa Hotel and Spa, a 400-acre resort in Carlsbad, Calif. The proposed deal is the second in two weeks by the Sports Shinko Company, based in Osaka.

title: Turning a Hotel Suite Into a Home
description: INSTEAD of buying apartments, some well-to-do people who frequently find themselves in New York stay in luxurious hotel suites, which they have decorated to their own tastes.

title: Two Top Aides to Dukakis Resign As One Admits Role in Biden Tape
description: Two top aides resigned from the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today after the Governor acknowledged that one of them, his campaign manager, had given reporters a videotape that helped destroy the candidacy of a Democratic rival, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. The departure of John Sasso, the campaign manager, and Paul Tully, the Dukakis campaign's political director, dealt a serious blow to the candidacy of the Massachusetts Governor. Mr. Sasso especially is widely regarded as a gifted tactician and has played a central role in Mr. Dukakis's political ascendancy.

title: Management Shifts At McGraw-Hill
description: In a series of management changes at McGraw-Hill Inc., John G. Wrede was named yesterday as president of its book company and Harold McGraw 3d has been named to head the publications company.

title: Meese Role Charged in Navy Contract for Wedtech
description: A former executive for the Wedtech Corporation said in an affidavit released today that he believed Edwin Meese 3d had interceded with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to help the company gain $135 million in Navy contracts without competitive bidding.

title: Simon Comedy Opens St. Bart Theater Season
description: A production of Neil Simon's comedy ''Come Blow Your Horn'' this evening at 7:30 is to open the 60th season at the St. Bart Playhouse, 109 East 50th Street. The show will run through Oct. 11.

title: BRIEFS
description: Baltimore Federal Financial said that it would immediately begin talks about the potential acquisition of the company after Home Shopping Network said its planned purchase of the company would not proceed.

title: At the Smithsonian
description: To some mixed emotions, the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History opens an exhibit today celebrating the United States Constitution. Six years ago it decided to commemorate the signing of the Constitution with a $1 million study and exhibition that documents the experience of 120,000 United States citizens and residents of Japanese dissent who were interned in isolation camps in World War II and of the 30,000 Japanese-Americans who fought with United States forces in the war. The exhibit is meant to be a reminder of the ''imperfection of our efforts to produce perfect fairness,'' said the museum's director, Roger Kennedy.

title: SKY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $641,429 for the latest year and $38,926 for 1986.

title: Migration Shift: A Return to Normal
description: After a volatile decade in which economic dislocations forced millions of Americans to move to other regions, migration within the United States generally appears to have settled back into a more stable pattern, according to new Census Bureau estimates and other Government data.

title: 36 Foreigners Leave a College After 2 Arrests
description: Georgetown University has taken 36 Central American students out of an ''Experience America'' program at a community college here amid charges of harassment and ethnic bias.

title: Indians and Pakistanis Clash in Kashmir
description: Indian officials asserted today that Pakistani troops tried to drive the Indian Army from the strategic Siachen Glacier in Kashmir last week but were repulsed with heavy losses in three days of fighting.

title: Olympia Stake Stirs Santa Fe
description: Trading in the stock of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation surged yesterday as speculation mounted that Olympia & York, which has disclosed that it has a 6.2 percent interest in Santa Fe, was preparing to make an offer for the company. There were also rumors that

title: In New York, Democracy Can Be Frustrating
description: To the Editor:

title: Banker Expects Steady Policy by Argentina
description: A top banker said today that Argentina, despite fiery rhetoric by its President, has no plans to halt interest payments on its $52 billion foreign debt.

title: On His Last Day, It's Hail to the Chef
description: At 3 o'clock this afternoon, Henry Haller collected his knives and assorted utensils from the White House kitchen. It was his last day as executive chef. After preparing meals for five presidents over 21 years, Mr. Haller is retiring ''to make some money,'' as he puts it.

title: Bush, at Talks, Assures Kohl On U.S. Arms Commitment
description: Vice President Bush assured Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today that the United States would maintain its military commitment to West Europe once all medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles are eliminated.

title: Queens Woman Acquitted in Killing of Husband
description: Karen Straw, a Queens woman whose trial in the stabbing death of her estranged husband had come to symbolize the anguish faced by battered women, was acquitted last night.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Advertising; A Weekly Magazine For Manhattan Lawyers
description: The first issue of Manhattan Lawyer, a weekly whose preview edition was sent free in May to all 35,000 of the borough's lawyers in a bid for paid subscribers, is being delivered this week to the 9,500 interested parties.

title: SHULTZ SEES CHINA AND SOVIET VOTING FOR IRAN ARMS BAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that he thought the Soviet Union and China would endorse an arms embargo against Iran if further diplomatic efforts failed to get the Iranians to accept a cease-fire in their war with Iraq.

title: Sales of Appliances Surpass Predictions
description: Appliance manufacturers saw the boom coming as far back as 1973. Every 12 to 15 years, in a replacement cycle as predictable as the seasons, Americans replace their refrigerators and ovens, dishwashers and dryers. What manufacturers did not count on was a boom that kept coming, through the record year of 1985, through 1986 and now 1987.

title: It's Tulip Time, Even Though the Blooms Wait Till Spring
description: A seasonal reminder is in order now, although I don't want to get bossy about it, hectoring people to send off their bulb orders before they draw another breath. The time to admire tulips in their great splendor is many months away, but the time to think tulips is upon us already.

title: Stein & Day in Reprint Deal
description: Stein & Day, a book publisher that filed in June for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, said today it had closed a deal with Barnes & Noble Bookstores to reprint 50 titles in hard cover.

title: Advertising; DFS Compton Drops American Home Brands
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton has dropped off the American Home Products agency roster because a realignment of divisional responsibility for the brands would have caused a conflict with Johnson & Johnson, a much bigger client.

title: For Young Fan, Fantasy Began in Section 31
description: By the time a police car took him home from Yankee Stadium late Tuesday night, 12-year-old Michael Smith of the Bronx had lived a baseball fantasy. He had met all the Yankees in the clubhouse after the game, received a bat autographed by Don Mattingly and eaten hot dogs in a luxury box with Joe DiMaggio.

title: New York State Democrats Pass Ethics Code
description: The Democratic State Committee approved yesterday a model code of ethics for party officials in New York State and challenged Republicans to do the same.

title: KEY RATES
Music: Noted in Brief; Catharine Crozier, Modern Organ Works
description: Catharine Crozier, among the leading organists in the country and the recipient of the 1979 International Performer of the Year award from the New York City chapter of the American Guild of Organists, performed on the Aeolian Skinner organ in Trinity Church on Tuesday evening before a small but appreciative audience.

title: Cardinals' Loss Keeps Reeling Mets Barely Alive; Expos Win, 6-1
description: The celebration had begun in the stands at Busch Stadium the moment the Cardinal fans learned the news from Philadelphia. The Cardinals had clinched a tie for their third National League East championship in six seasons. The Mets had lost to the Phillies.

title: Newmont Mining
description: A Court of Appeals issued an injunction blocking the attempt of an investor group to take over the Newmont Mining Corporation. The move by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit prevents the Ivanhoe Acquisition Corporation, led by T. Boone Pickens, from pursuing a tender offer or other efforts to try to gain control of the mining company until further court order. The court said the case would be handled quickly, with oral arguments scheduled for Oct. 9. Earlier yesterday, the Pickens group asked a Delaware court to allow people who last week sold Newmont shares to Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. to rescind the sales.

title: DIAGNOSTIC VENTURES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: How Commodity Indicator Works
description: As an example of how today's proposal to stabilize currencies would work, interest rates would rise if prices for commodities, including gold, move higher.

title: Study Ties Genetic Defect to Form of Lung Cancer
description: Scientists have found evidence that a genetic defect contributes to the development of an important form of lung cancer that makes up at least 20 percent of all lung cancers.

title: COMPUTER COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $400,000 charge for a bad debt writeoff.

title: Giving Up Mikey: One Foster Family's Heartbreak
description: For Michael Schatz and his wife, Pat Iuto, the end came abruptly: A message on their answering machine that another family had been found for Mikey, the boarder baby they took into their home two months ago and had come to love with a tenacity that took them by surprise.

title: CHAUNCEY MITCHELL Jr.
description: Chauncey Leeds Mitchell Jr., a former investment counselor and vice president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, died of cancer Tuesday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Opera: Cavalli's 'Calisto,' Updated
description: OPERA AT THE ACADEMY was founded in March 1985 and is devoted to the training of singers and actors, the presentation of contemporary productions of the classics and, eventually, the creation of new works of music theater.

title: Suit to Bar Times Sq. Plan Is Prepared by 5 Officials
description: A Congressman, State Senator, Assemblyman and two City Councilwomen said yesterday that they planned to file a lawsuit to block the city and state plan for redevelopment of Times Square, citing changes in the project and the cost of tax subsidies that are being offered to developers.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $162,000 for the quarter and $322,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $13,000 and $89,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sending the Right Message to Iran
description: The Senate was right to vote unanimously to bar imports of Iranian oil. At the same time, it should be understood that an oil embargo - even one supported by our allies - won't have much effect on Iran's ability to sell oil and buy arms. The embargo will simply mean slightly less profit for Iran and slightly higher costs for the United States. Still, the message that the U.S. embargo sends to Teheran is worth the price.

title: Antarctica Ozone Loss Is Worst Ever Recorded
description: The ozone shield over Antarctica dwindled this month to the lowest level observed since measurements began more than a decade ago, researchers reported today.

title: 2 Farm Banks Need Bailout
description: Two regional banks in the farm lending system could fail unless the Government steps in with a rescue package, according to a letter to Congress from the Farm Credit System.

title: Ortega Declares a Unilateral Truce in Some Areas
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said tonight that the Nicaraguan Government is declaring a one-month unilateral cease-fire in certain parts of northern Nicaragua in its war against the contras.

title: Bid for Sakowitz
description: Australia's Hooker Corporation would acquire 80 percent of financially beleaguered Sakowitz Inc., the Houston-based retailer, under an amended plan of organization filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court. The remaining 20 percent share of Sakowitz, which went into reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws in August 1985, would go to certain creditors, according to the plan. The plan, the second submitted under Chapter 11, must be approved by creditors. Sakowitz is the nation's last remaining high-fashion speciality retailer controlled by a founding family member.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1987.

title: Leading Indicators Rise 0.6%
description: The Government reported today that its economic-forecasting index climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in August.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; People
description: Jane Pack, Theresa C. Bonaccolta, James Dragoumis and Donald A. Peppers, all senior vice presidents, have been given the additional title of group director at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt and Beaver.

title: Howard Robison Dies at 71; Served 17 Years in Congress
description: Former United States Representative Howard W. Robison, who in his 17 years in Congress eventually became dean of New York State's Republican Congressional delegation, died of a heart ailment Saturday at his home in Rehoboth Beach, Del. He was 71 years old.

title: Vote by Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid to Influence Bork Vote Is Denied
description: Reports that an Alabama judge is a leading candidate for a Federal judgeship have prompted accusations that the Reagan Administration is trying to influence a key Senator in the Supreme Court confirmation battle. A Justice Department official has hotly denied those assertions.

title: Rangers Obtain Ogrodnick
description: These are tumultuous times for the Ranger players, with the team saddled with nine more players than it can protect in next Monday's waiver draft. Yesterday, that tumult cost George McPhee, Terry Carkner and Jeff Jackson their jobs and it delivered John Ogrodnick from Quebec.

title: Yields Post More Gains
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday, marking yet another rise in an advance that has lasted more than a month.

title: Bridge: Americans Gain Experience In First World Junior Event
description: The players from New York University who represented the United States in the first World Junior Championships in Amsterdam in July found the European teams, from the Netherlands and France, more experienced and better organized.

title: GENERAL BUILDING PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Presidents Veto Playoffs
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Presidents Commission voted today to oppose a Division I-A football playoff.

title: GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Four Plan to Sue On Monitoring By Police Dept.
description: Four black civil rights advocates have taken steps to sue the New York City Police Department, charging that their rights were violated when the department monitored their activities and recorded their appearances on a radio station oriented to blacks.

title: Gas Station Owner Is Sentenced in Tax Case
description: The owner of the 50 Gaseteria discount gasoline stations in the New York metropolitan region was sentenced yesterday to six months in Federal prison and must forfeit his business holdings to pay taxes, interest and penalties amounting to ''substantially more'' than $15 million to the New York State and Federal governments.

title: The Distant Early Leaf-Watching Line
description: George Buzzell describes Vermont's foliage with spirit. He sometimes says that the colors are ''Monet-like'' and that viewing on some days ''makes me thirst for a glass of fresh cider.''

title: Walbro Continues To Reject UIS Bid
description: The Walbro Corporation's board of directors reiterated its rejection of UIS Inc.'s unsolicited $27.25-a-share buyout offer and announced two steps designed to frustrate it.

title: Governor of California Vetoes Tuition Prepayment Proposal
description: Gov. George Deukmejian has vetoed a bill that would have allowed parents to prepay their children's college tuition at California's public colleges and universities at current tuition rates.

title: Kota Kinabalu Journal; With Houses on Stilts and Hopes in Another Land
description: Tensions over the presence of thousands of Filipinos living illegally in the state of Sabah have intensified recently as local residents anxiously watch events in the Philippines and express fear of a new influx.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption on Sept. 5 with a picture grouping of Ling Ling, a panda at the Bronx Zoo, described the animal incorrectly. Ling Ling is male.

title: JACOB H. SINGER
description: Jacob H. Singer, a cantor, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center after a long illness. Mr. Singer was 70 years old and lived in Queens.

title: N.F.L. Owners and Players Digging In
description: With the National Football League players' strike well into its second week and games resuming Sunday after a one-week absence, fans around the country may find themselves with more to watch than they might have imagined.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''As a Southerner who has observed personally the long and difficult years of the struggle for civil rights for black and other minority people, I find Judge Bork's impressively consistent opinions to be particularly obnoxious.'' - Jimmy Carter. [ B9:5. ]

title: Chinese Report Protest By Lamas to Free Tibet
description: In a rare Chinese acknowledgement of public dissent in Tibet, the Chinese press agency has reported a march by a group of Buddhist lamas calling for Tibet's independence.

title: 20% of Bear Stearns To Be Sold
description: In the latest move reflecting the attractiveness of Wall Street firms as an investment, the Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that it would take in a foreign partner: Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong.

title: Wisconsin Haven For Hand Weavers
description: THIS tiny northern Wisconsin community (population 500 or so) has been turned into a hand weaver's haven by 87-year-old Walter E. Schutz. He has created a thriving business in handmade looms, and from May through October, people arrive from all over the country to learn about weaving, spinning, quilting, basketry and silk-screening.

title: Choosing a Finish To Suit the Wood
description: LEAD: WHEN staining and finishing woods, whether in cabinetwork or in decoration like trim and paneling, keep these objectives in mind:

title: 2 Senators Press AIDS Panel
description: The President's commission on AIDS was urged by two Republican Senators today to engage President Reagan himself more fully as a leader in the fight against the disease.

title: IMMUNOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
CYANOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Shultz View: Key Points in the Gulf Standoff
description: Following are key sections of answers by Secretary of State George P. Shultz at an interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times: On the War In the Persian Gulf

title: CBS Board to Meet On Records Unit
description: CBS stock soared $9.75 yesterday to close at $225.75 as Wall Street eagerly awaited today's early morning board meeting to discuss the sale of the CBS Records unit to the Sony Corporation for an estimated $2 billion.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income of $369,000 from discontinued operations. National Medical said that the year- ago data has been restated.

title: Takeover Bill Gains
description: The Senate Banking Committee, after a day of heated debate, approved legislation tonight that would overhaul the regulation of corporate takeovers.

title: It Takes Police to Quell S.I. Republicans
description: A normally sedate, conservative and routine Staten Island Republican meeting turned into a pushing, shouting melee late Tuesday night that required a dozen police officers to clear the hall.

title: N.B.A. Moratorium Will End Today
description: At Madison Square Garden, Al Bianchi, general manager of the Knicks, will meet with Mark Jackson's agent in an effort to get the team's top draft choice under contract. In Pontiac, Mich., Jack McCloskey, the Pistons' general manager, will begin negotiations for Fred Banks, Detroit's top pick. In Salt Lake City, the Utah Jazz are expected to announce the extension of Karl Malone's contract. In Denver, Pete Babcock, the Nuggets' general manager, will try to get Darrell Walker, the former Knick guard, under contract.

title: Jazz: Carroll And Short
description: ONE of the only New York hostelries to offer music in an atmosphere of unchanging elegance is the Carlyle Hotel (76th Street and Madison Avenue). Here, on most nights of the week, the singers and pianists Bobby Short and Barbara Carroll ply their trade respectively at the semiformal Cafe Carlyle and its more casual next-door neighor, the Bemelmans Bar.

title: Q&A
description: Q.We have condensation in our attic, causing moisture to drip down into a closet. We think this is due to an inadequate vapor barrier. A Home Improvement column mentioned a vapor-barrier paint, but paint stores in my area have never heard of it. Can you tell me more?

title: Body of Woman Is Found on S.I.
description: A body believed to be that of a 19-year-old Staten Island college student who disappeared Sept. 9 was found partially buried yesterday afternoon in a wooded area behind a Staten Island high school, the police said.

title: Clemens-Leiter Matchup Is No Contest
description: On the Yankees' pitching staff, Al Leiter is conspicuous by his youth, potentially extraordinary by virtue of his fastball. Last night, however, he was simply ordinary by comparison.

title: SHOWCASE COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Welfare of All the Poor
description: LEAD: As the 1988 Presidential campaign heats up, it is becoming apparent that social policy issues will at least be discussed by the candidates - a welcome change from recent campaigns. Less welcome, however, is the emergence of child welfare as a central theme. The proper focus is on the welfare of the poor - of whatever age.

title: Plot to Export U.S. Weapons to China Is Charged
description: A businessman linked to Chinese diplomats at the United Nations attempted to export missiles and plans for F-14 fighter aircraft to China, the United States authorities charged in documents disclosed in court today.

title: 'BELLY OF AN ARCHITECT,' FROM PETER GREENAWAY
description: STOURLEY KRACKLITE (Brian Dennehy), the central figure in Peter Greenaway's ''Belly of an Architect,'' is at one point seen reflected in the central panel of a triptych mirror in his Rome apartment, wearing a blood-red robe and flanked by multiple Xerox copies of classically sculpted abdomens, copies he has made from photographs of Roman statuary. It's a perfect moment, or at least the kind of perfect moment Mr. Greenaway favors: orderly, symmetrical and obscure, offering great compositional beauty but no compelling reason why its riddles require solution.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Albert W. Frey, 89; Professor And Dean of Business School
description: Albert W. Frey, a former dean of the University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Business and a former president of the American Marketing Association, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at his home in Dresden, Me. He was 89 years old.

title: Value of New Issues Up 20% in Quarter
description: Although rising interest rates made it more expensive to tap the bond market for capital in the third quarter, the dollar amount of new securities underwritings exceeded that of the quarter a year earlier.

title: A Chilean Dispute Over University Turns Violent
description: A dispute over Government efforts to reduce state financing and dismiss some faculty members at the University of Chile turned violent in recent days as students took to the streets of Santiago in support of professors.

title: Baseball Notebook; How Valuable Was Dawson?
description: Andre Dawson chose a controversial solution to his free-agent dilemma last spring and now he's the subject of another controversy: Should he be named the National League's most valuable player even though his team will finish in last place or close to last?

title: MELAMINE CHEMICALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Space Shuttle Experiments Will Include 2 by Students
description: The first space shuttle to fly since the Challenger disaster will carry 10 scientific experiments, including 2 designed by students, the space agency has announced.

title: NEW JERSEY STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,931 and $32,931 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $482,460 for the quarter and $802,611 for the year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1987
description: International An arms embargo against Iran may be endorsed by the Soviet Union and China if diplomatic efforts fail to get the Iranians to accept a cease-fire in their war with Iraq, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said.

title: Economic Expansion in U.S. Continues Into a 59th Month
description: The United States enters its 59th consecutive month of economic growth on Thursday, marking the third-longest expansion of the economy since monthly records were first kept in 1854.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Doug DeCinces, infielder, who was released Sept. 24 by the California Angels. BALTIMORE (AL) - Asked for unconditional release waivers on Alan Wiggins, infielder, who was suspended Aug. 31 by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth. HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Reassigned 17 players to the Binghamton Whalers of the American Hockey League: Gary Callaghan, Greg Dornbach, Dallas Gaume, Roger Kortko and J. M. McKenzie, centers; Chris Brant, left wing; Todd Channell and Yves Courteau, right wings; Shawn Cronin, Jim Culhane, John McLean, Bill Root, Mike Vellucci, and Mark Vichorek, defensemen; and Sean Evoy, Peter Sidorkiewicz and Kay Whitmore, goalies. Announced retirement of Wayne Babych, right wing. BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Named Stu Inman player-personnel director.

title: Afghan Chief Changes Name
description: Najib, the leader of Afghanistan's Communist Government, is restoring the Islamic element in his name and reverting to Najibullah. The Afghan press agency, monitored here, instructed all Afghan information outlets today to describe him henceforth as Comrade Dr. Najibullah. He has a medical decree from Kabul University. ''Najib'' means ''noble.'' The suffix ''ullah'' means ''of God.''

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Radicals Seen As New Peril For Tunisians
description: Despite the sentencing of 7 Moslem fundamentalists to death and 69 others to long prison sentences, fundamentalist groups are expected to remain a threat to the stability of Tunisia's pro-Western Government.

title: Ferries, Vindicated
description: The idea that modern commuter boats charging premium fares could develop into more than a fair-weather novelty was untested in July 1986 when a private ferry operator inaugurated daily rush-hour service between Highlands, in Monmouth County, N.J., and Pier 11 near Wall Street. Now it's clear that this modest experiment has succeeded, ushering in a promising new era for local waterborne transit.

title: Music: Chet Atkins and Band at Carnegie
description: THE best part of Chet Atkins's concert Tuesday at Carnegie Hall wasn't on the program: three duets, on jazz standards, for Mr. Atkins on guitar and, up from the audience, Toots Thielemans on harmonica. With Mr. Thielemans, he loosened up and let himself swing.

title: U.S. Fights Rumors on Manila Coup
description: The American Embassy is not sure whether it ever issued a visa to Col. Gregorio Honasan, the fugitive leader of last month's attempted coup. But just to be on the safe side, it has canceled any such visa he may have.

title: A Law Review on Bork
description: Law reviews, the student-edited magazines produced by law schools, are known less for relevance than for examining arcane legal subjects.

title: Novel Celebration of the Constitution
description: While most celebrations of the United States Constitution involve a kind of self-congratulation, the celebration by the Smithsonian Museum, ''A More Perfect Union: Japanese Americans and the U.S. Constitution,'' which opened today, is just the opposite.

title: Glee in the Dole Camp
description: Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has been buoyed by some new support.

title: Shelter Decree Is Upheld
description: A judge ruled yesterday that New York City must continue to abide by a consent decree setting sanitary standards for shelters where it houses more than 9,000 homeless men and women every night.

title: U.S. Proposals Hearten I.M.F. and World Bank
description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund wound up their joint annual meeting today on an optimistic note, invigorated with new approaches for coping with global debt.

title: Kuwaiti Company Leases U.S. Tanker In First Such Move
description: The United States Government agreed today to charter a 264,000-ton oil tanker to the company that manages Kuwait's oil traffic in the Persian Gulf. It is the first ship manned by American citizens to be added to the Kuwaiti vessels qualifying for naval escorts there.

title: Club to Admit Women if Law Is Upheld
description: With humor and resignation, members of the Century Association, one of Manhattan's oldest and most exclusive male clubs, voted overwhelmingly last night to admit women, if a city law barring discrimination in public accommodations was held constitutional.

title: Mozambique Meeting
description: In an event laden with symbolism, President Reagan is expected to confer at the White House Monday with Joaquim A. Chissano, the President of Mozambique, who will be in Washington on a private visit.

title: 'Cultural Potpourri'
description: Gospel, jazz and Latin music will be featured during a weekend of free outdoor performances at the West 125th Pier, at the Hudson River. The event, called ''Cultural Potpourri,'' is sponsored by the New York State-Harlem Urban Development Corporation. Hours are noon to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Information: 870-4100.

title: Tommy Flanagan
description: Tommy Flanagan, a pianist, is leading a trio with George Mraz on bass and Al Foster on drums tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: They Might Be Giants
description: They Might Be Giants will perform tonight at 9 and midnight, with Watchface opening, at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $10; information, and a sample song, at (718) 387-6962.

title: Secret Life of a New Mitty
description: Maybe the most intriguing characterization of all during this N.F.L. players' strike came from Texas E. Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys football team.

title: New Line Is Planned By I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to bring out a line of work stations for engineers and scientists that will initially be incompatible with its new personal computer line, a senior company official said yesterday.

title: African Culture Month At History Museum
description: A monthlong series of music and dance performances and seminars devoted to African culture begins tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street. Appearing tomorrow will be Kayraba, a West African dance company; Schroeder Cherry, a puppeteer, and Charlotte Ami Amezor, an artist. The program on Sunday features all events except the puppet show and includes a demonstration of geles, which is the art of turning fabric into a head wrap. Each day's events run from 1 to 4:30 P.M. and are free with museum admission - $3.50 ($1.50 for children, students and the elderly).

title: 'Star Wars' vs. a New Era
description: The world should be holding its breath, hoping that the leaders of the United States and Soviet Union will have the vision and guts to bring about a new era in superpower relations.

title: Rotterdam Ensemble
description: The Rotterdam Philharmonic, conducted by James Conlon, is to perform works by Tchaikovsky, Martinu and Rachmaninoff Sunday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, with Bella Davidovich as the piano soloist. Tickets are $14 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: Bond Prices Fall Modestly
description: Bond prices declined modestly yesterday as investors remained inactive amid widespread forecasts of higher interest rates in the future.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think things are really changing this time. The fact that someone could ask that question, and I can answer it here, is proof. This could not have happened five years ago.'' Yuri Nikulin, a Soviet circus performer, when asked publicly aboutthe future of glasnost. [ A6:6. ]

title: Factories' Orders Fell In August
description: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in August as lower demand for aircraft and military goods brought the first setback in manufacturing since January.

title: Stewart Seeks Honor
description: The Oakland Athletics' Dave Stewart, who became the first 20-game winner in the major leagues this season when he beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3, Wednesday night, said yesterday that he deserves the American League Cy Young award but doesn't expect to get it. A castoff pitcher with a losing career record 17 months ago, Stewart has mastered a forkball in posting a 20-12 record. ''There are some guys who are deserving of the Cy Young, like Roger Clemens, Jimmy Key and Jack Morris, but I can't see any of those guys being more consistent than I was all year,'' Stewart said. ''But I think Jimmy Key of Toronto has the inside track. Players in the East always have an edge over guys in the West, plus he's on a winning club.''

title: YOUNG GUARD: PARTIES FOR A CAUSE
description: It's fall in New York and the benefit party circuit is in full swing. Men dressed in black tie and women in their evening regalia are showing up at galas to help the city's many cultural and charitable institutions. Nothing unusual in that. But what's different this season is the age of these revelers-with-a-cause, who are in their late 20's and early 30's. It is a younger generation, and it is infusing a venerable Gotham tradition with energy and sparkle.

title: Dance: Feld's 'Embraced Waltzes'
description: ELIOT FELD'S ''Embraced Waltzes,'' which had its premiere Wednesday night at the opening of the Feld Ballet's new season at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, is one of the choreographer's especially imaginative responses to familiar material.

title: About Real Estate; Rebuilding Century-Old Town Houses
description: Like many of the tree-shaded side streets of Manhattan, the section of East 30th Street between Second and Third Avenues still manages to retain some century-old town houses tucked in between the taller, more modern buildings that dominate the streetscape.

title: Russians Cut Staff at the U.N.
description: The Soviet Union has complied with a United States order to further cut the size of its United Nations missions by today, according to American officials.

title: Chip Industry Sees Big Gains
description: Amid a recovery, the semiconductor industry projects sales growth of 17.9 percent in 1988, to $37.8 billion, an industry committee reported today. Citing substantial growth in application-specific integrated circuits and other new technologies, the committee also forecast sales of $40.6 billion in 1989 and $45 billion in 1990.

title: 'St. Elsewhere' Told to Carry Disclaimer
description: A judge has ruled that the NBC television show ''St. Elsewhere'' must carry a disclaimer because its fictional story line has come a little too close to the truth.

title: Open All Candidates Before Election
description: LEAD: Forget what candidates say they will do if elected. Never mind what public offices they have held. Look instead to the kinds of people they are. It is bedrock human nature, not campaign promises (talk is cheap) or track records (resumes predict nothing), that gives the surest forecast of a Presidency.

title: In Air and Underground: 'It Seemed Like Forever'
description: When the earthquake struck, Edward Fontaine was perched precariously 300 feet above downtown Los Angeles. Sitting in the control cabin of a construction crane atop the framework of a new 26-story office building, he was thrown violently to one side as the crane began swaying ominously.

title: Book Editors Oppose Bork
description: Nearly 300 top book editors and publishers in New York and Boston have sent a letter to members of the Senate Judiciary Committee opposing the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court.

title: Dow Soars as New Quarter Begins
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday as the new quarter began with a surge of investor interest in blue-chip and technology issues and growing expectations that forthcoming earnings reports would be strong.

title: Shaky Blue Jays on a Precarious Perch
description: The signs do not bode well for the Toronto Blue Jays, even though they are in first place by a game in the American League East heading into their decisive three-game series against the Tigers in Detroit beginning tonight.

title: A.H. Robins Requests Rorer Merger Approval
description: The A. H. Robins Company asked a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday for authorization to sign a final merger agreement with Rorer Group Inc.
