title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The dB's,Go Betweens and Dash Rip Rock, the Ritz, 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800). The dB's play pop-rock with Southern roots and ''Rubber Soul''-Big Star influences; Go Betweens, from Australia, play their own thoughtful, gently lyrical pop-rock blend. Both bands have plenty of indelible songs, and Dash Rip Rock, Georgia-based newcomers, have songs of their own, plus energy. They're all playing tonight, beginning around 11. Tickets are $13.50.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday QUOTABLE QUOTES

title: Man Who Ate Seeds Is Freed
description: A Federal inmate who was ordered back to prison after eating poppy seeds against regulations completed his term and was set free today. The inmate, Anthony Clarizio, completed his two-year sentence on loansharking and false-statement charges and was released from the Federal prison in Danbury, a prison spokesman, Lee Enzor, said. Mr. Clarizio was completing his sentence at a halfway house in Hartford when he failed a drug test and was ordered back to prison Aug. 24. A condition of his release to the halfway house was that he not eat poppy seeds, which can affect the results of urine tests.

title: 2 Say They've Solved Jack the Ripper Mystery
description: Jack the Ripper, the Victorian murderer who terrorized London 99 years ago and was never caught, was a failed barrister and schoolmaster named Montague John Druitt, two writers say in a book published today.

title: 'Spreading Vicious Truths'
description: What if Gov. Michael Dukakis's Presidential campaign manager, John Sasso, invented a story that Senator Joseph Biden swiped quotes and even personal history from other politicians and passed them off as his own? More, what if Mr. Sasso slyly peddled the story to the media, which then gullibly reported it as true? Then what if Senator Biden, hapless victim of a vicious smear, was compelled to quit the race?

title: Advertising; Zayre Gives Account To AC&R/DHB & Bess
description: AC&R/DHB & Bess, a Saatchi & Saatchi company with great strengths in the retail area, has become the agency for the Zayre Discount Department Stores Corporation, based in Framingham, Mass.

title: Professor Wins Battle to Clear Name
description: A retired Columbia University journalism professor has won a long battle to eradicate Government records that labeled him a national security risk.

title: Sofia Journal; A Lifetime Spent Waiting for Things to Get Better
description: The old man sat down heavily, making the park bench creak, and addressed a remark to a stranger already there. Hesitant for a moment when the other said he did not speak Bulgarian, the man offered a greeting in German.

title: New Faces; GINO QUILICO: A BARITONE'S SON MAKES MET DEBUT
description: WHEN Gino Quilico was 8 years old, he begged his father, the baritone Louis Quilico, not to sing again in ''Don Carlo'' because he hated seeing him shot to death.

title: Robertson, Returning to Brooklyn Home, Enters Race
description: Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who gave up his ministry to run for President, formally declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination yesterday. He made his announcement in front of the Bedford-Stuyvesant brownstone where he lived 27 years ago when he said the Lord called him to minister to the poor.

title: The 3 Targets Of the Players
description: The antitrust suit filed yesterday by the National Basketball Players Association called the league's college draft ''one of the longest running continuing restraints on competition for player services.'' A team owns the rights to a player it selects in the draft, and he cannot negotiate with another team.

title: Architecture: Max Protetch's New Look
description: THE Max Protetch Gallery, which has for several years not only exhibited paintings and sculpture but also served as the city's principal commercial gallery displaying the work of architects and designers, has moved from its home on West 57th Street to more spacious quarters on lower Broadway, at Prince Street. Its new building, 560 Broadway, once housed sweatshops and now includes galleries capitalizing on the SoHo art community's inevitable eastward drift.

title: Gastineau and Jets Skirmish on Line
description: The verbal feuding between Mark Gastineau and his striking Jets teammates escalated into a shoving match this morning.

title: At an Open-Minded Meeting In Moscow, Anything Goes
description: If a war of ideas is developing in the Soviet Union, the front line Wednesday evening was at the Oktyabr Theater in Moscow.

title: 33 in Congress Urging New Curbs on Pretoria
description: A bipartisan group of 33 members of Congress urged President Reagan today to impose new economic sanctions against South Africa as a means of forcing the Pretoria Government to change its racial policies.

title: U.S. PROTESTS TEST OF SOVIET MISSILES NORTH OF HAWAII
description: The United States has protested two Soviet long-range missile tests this week that sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii, the State Department said today.

title: Democracy Doesn't Need Bork's Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: A Patriotic Halloween
description: Parents who say Halloween celebrates paganism and the ''dark side'' have persuaded an elementary school to ban traditional Halloween activities this year. Instead, the 641 children at Coal Creek Elementary in Louisville will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution. The principal, Ellen Goering, said Wednesday that colonial dress would be the only costume permitted Oct. 30.

title: At the Movies
description: 'They Hardly Kissed'

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: LEAD: RECORDED lutes played softly at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan, befitting a party in Gothic chapels, Romanesque halls and remnants of five medieval monasteries. Some 300 guests, who dined on coulibiac of salmon, apricot-glazed ham and fresh strawberries, gathered Monday for the pre-anniversary celebration: next year the Cloisters, a branch of the Metropolitan Museum of

title: Phone Company To Issue 'Plain Language' Bills
description: Telephone bills across New York State will be printed in ''plain language'' under an agreement reached between New York Telephone and the State Public Service Commission.

title: Advertising; European Travel & Life Raises Rate Base
description: European Travel & Life, acquired a year and a half ago by Murdoch Magazines, is increasing its circulation rate base to 230,000, from 200,000, with the January issue and will then add another 100,000 to that, according to John B. Evans, president of the company.

title: Economic Scene; Gold Tiptoeing Back Onstage
description: THIS week Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed to lay another brick in the foundation of a new world monetary system - a gold brick. The United States, he told the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, is ready to consider using, as an ''additional indicator'' for guiding the coordination of national economic policies, ''a basket of commodities, including gold.''

title: Dodgers' Welch Hurls One-Hitter
description: Bob Welch continued his success against the playoff-bound San Francisco Giants tonight, pitching the third one-hitter of his career in a 7-0 victory by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Betty Carter and her trio, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Betty Carter, the Brooklyn-based jazz singer with a rich, elastic alto and a be-bop background, never sings the same song twice in quite the same way. Her iconoclastic interpretations turn familiar standards into psychic explorations in which bent notes, meditative pauses, lightning accelerated passages, and abrupt changes in timbre virtually reinvent the material. Though Ms. Carter has her romantically moody side, her singing is often suffused with playful humor and an acute intelligence that lends her exuberant improvisations a sense of narrative purpose. Opening for Ms. Carter is the Mingus Dynasty band featuring Randy Brecker and James Newton. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30, and tickets are $12.50.

title: Democracy Doesn't Need Bork's Protection; Resetting the Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Hints of Delay in Talks On an Arms Ban Against Iran
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Russians had taken ''a significant step forward'' in agreeing in principle to discuss a possible arms embargo against Iran.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 400 money market mutual funds decreased $707.5 million, to $243.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 106 institutional funds were down $111.2 million, to $64.28 billion. Assets of the 201 general-purpose funds were up $165.6 million, to $72.06 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds decreased $761.9 million, to $107.41 billion.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Stackhouse Retains Title: Ricky Stackhouse of Atlanta retained his Continental Americas middleweight championship when he won a unanimous 12-round decision from Kevin Moley of Selden, L.I., at the Felt Forum last night. A bout between Pernell Whitaker, the undefeated lightweight, and Mark Brannon was canceled when the New York State Athletic Commission did not pass Brannon for medical reasons. Hockey Rangers Finish at 5-1-2: The Rangers used two goals from James Patrick in defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 6-2, in their exhibition finale, which left them with a 5-1-2 record. Devils Beat Sabres, 6-3: John MacLean had two goals and Pat Verbeek a goal and two assists in leading the Devils to an exhibition victory over the Sabres last night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Devils finished with a 4-4 exhibition record. Golf Frost Leads by 2 Shots: David Frost made nine birdies in gaining a seven-under-par 63 and a two-stroke lead after yesterday's first round of the $400,000 Southern Open. (AP) U.S. Advances: The United States, Spain, Scotland, Canada, Ireland and England moved into the quarterfinals in the $1 million Dunhill Cup team tournament in St. Andrew's, Scotland, without losing a match. Australia and Japan, last year's finalists advanced by 2-1 margins. (AP)

title: The Wind They Call Mercouri
description: As diplomats posted here are all too aware, it is tough to catch the ear of State Department officials and members of Congress.

title: Suspect Held in Killing Of Top Custodian Dies
description: A suspect in the killing of the president of New York City's school custodians union died yesterday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx of complications after brain surgery, a hospital official said.

title: Jackson's Swan Song?
description: Stewart's teammate, Reggie Jackson, leaving no doubt about his intentions to quit, punctuated his final game at the Oakland Coliseum yesterday with a base hit off an 0-2 pitch as a pinch-hitter in the Athletics' eighth inning. Jackson then threw waves and kisses to a standing, cheering crowd. Jackson, 41 years old, said he was not making an official announcement of his retirement after 20 seasons, but he never made it so definite as he did yesterday. ''This was my last at bat,'' he said. ''I'd like to be around next year, but it won't be as a player.'' He has said he is considering a coaching or management role with the club, or possibly investing in the club and becoming a part-owner.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other rules remain in effect.

title: Firefighters' Delicate Days
description: Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat stays mail carriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds. Nor will they stay firefighters from performing their essential duty. But the elements will stop a New York City firefighter from inspecting a potentially dangerous building.

title: Minimum Pay Rises to $3.75 In Connecticut
description: One of the highest minimum wages in the nation, $3.75 an hour, took effect in Connecticut today, along with a new law greatly expanding the kinds of jobs that 15-year-olds can hold.

title: Some Perceiving Self-Destruction For Democrats
description: Are the Democrats going to throw away their chances in the 1988 Presidential election?

title: The Matchmaker
description: Senator Rudy Boschwitz is an incurable matchmaker.

title: Suspect in 2 S.I. Slayings Charged in Rape of Girl
description: A 21-year-old Staten Island man with a criminal record as a sex offender was charged yesterday with raping a 15-year-old girl on the island in June, and is also a suspect in the slayings of two women there in the last three weeks, the authorities said.

title: Film: Rupert Everett in 'The Right Hand Man'
description: THE special thing about Harry Ironminster, the hero of ''The Right Hand Man,'' is that he suffers from diabetes. It's 1860, when languishing figures of fiction usually expired from weak lungs, but this is Australia.

title: A Shaken Dukakis Tries to Put His Presidential Campaign Back on Track
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, grim-faced and still shaken by the loss of his top adviser, today began the job of repairing the damage his Presidential campaign suffered from its role in a rival's downfall.

title: Koko Taylor
description: Koko Taylor will sing the blues on a double bill with James Cotton, a harmonica player, Sunday night at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664). Shows are scheduled for 9:15 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge
description: A steep decline in Japanese bond prices sent stocks in Tokyo falling sharply today, ending six consecutive sessions of higher prices. The market index fell by 289.14 points, to 25,721.74.

title: Film: Dudley Moore In 'Like Father Like Son'
description: ''LIKE FATHER LIKE SON'' has a road map of a plot: thanks to an Indian brain-transference serum, a middle-aged doctor and his teen-age son trade minds but not bodies. It's easier to believe such a potion exists than to imagine anyone could make this movie live, but Dudley Moore and Kirk Cameron are so clever and charming as the mismatched pair that they turn a potential dud into a sweetly engaging film.

title: Officials of 2 States Cross Hudson In Search of Jersey Shore Polluters
description: New York officials videotaped trash in New Jersey and New Jersey officials threw plastic bottles into the Hudson River and other waterways today as both states tried to pinpoint the sources of recent Jersey Shore pollution.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES ARCTIC PEACE ZONE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, proposing that the Arctic become ''a zone of peace,'' called today for East-West cooperation to reduce military activities and tap natural resources in the area.

title: Hill Samuel Takeover Is Expected
description: Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the beleaguered British merchant bank, appears to be ready to succumb to a bid involving a takeover followed by an auction of various parts of the business, according to London bankers and analysts.

title: PANEL TOLD WOMEN FACE SERVICE BIAS
description: Representatives of women's groups told a House subcommittee today that many men in the military still wanted to exclude women from the armed forces despite their achievements over the last 15 years.

title: Film: 'Surf Nazis Must Die'
description: TROMA INC., the small independent company responsible for outstandingly irreverent features made on budgets that are lower than low, is in a good position to make films that are cheap, impudent and funny. But two out of three won't do. And ''Surf Nazis Must Die'' isn't funny in the slightest, the title notwithstanding. It's a standard, thoroughly stupid gang-war exploitation film intercut with occasional low-energy surfing footage, featuring characters named Adolf, Eva and so on who chant slogans, wear swastikas on their wetsuits and burn surfboards from time to time. Not even the actors' relatives will find this interesting.

title: Virginia Tech Report
description: Two Virginia newspapers, citing unidentified sources, have reported that Coach Charles Moir could step down as early as tomorrow as basketball coach at Virginia Tech. ''That is a possibility,'' Moir said by telephone yesterday. Since the university initiated an internal inquiry of the basketball program last spring, observers have predicted Moir would resign. The inquiry uncovered 13 National Collegiate Athletic Association violations, for which representatives of Virginia Tech will appear today before an N.C.A.A. committee.

title: ART: WILLIAM TUCKER AND HIS GREEK TITANS
description: IN his show at the David McKee Gallery, William Tucker has in effect turned his sculpture inside out. In the abstract, largely geometrical works that established his reputation, an armature gave shape to a void inside it that eventually became more urgent than the armature itself. Now the bony armature has become a support, and geometrical shapes are fleshed out around it in plaster.

title: Sheep That Earn Their Keep
description: A four-foot-tall toy sheep is ensconced in an antique chair at the entrance to Susan Keane's living room. Above the doorway hangs a lamb marionette. Tiny sheep are tucked into peg holes in the overhead beams. Wooden and ceramic versions stand on tables and windowsills. The rug has a blackface sheep's image in the pattern. This is not a knickknack collector's obsession; there are 10 live sheep in a pen behind the Keanes' house, a converted red barn on a wooded lane in Frenchtown, N.J.

title: German Said to Have U.S. Backing to Run NATO
description: The United States and its major North Atlantic allies have reportedly joined in backing a West German to become NATO's next Secretary General, according to diplomats and Government officials here.

title: Senate Votes for Adherence to 1979 Arms Treaty
description: Over the opposition of President Reagan, the Senate registered its support today for a proposal requiring adherence to weapons limits in the unratified 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Democracy Doesn't Need Bork's Protection; Not End of Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Decides to Give Buildings to Squatters
description: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved a program yesterday to turn over 58 city-owned buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn to a group of squatters.

title: People
description: Denis F. Visich is joining BBDO, New York, as executive vice president, senior management representative.

title: IT'S OVER FOR METS: CARDINALS CAPTURE DIVISION TITLE
description: The tease was put to an end tonight. The possible permutations and combinations that had taken place in and around Shea Stadium, the what-ifs and the wishful thinking, are now footnotes to a third St. Louis Cardinal division championship in the last six seasons.

title: Warren Zevon and X
description: Warren Zevon, a pianist, singer and songwriter, and X, a Los Angeles rock band, will perform Sunday at 9 P.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $17.50 in advance, $18.50 Sunday.

title: Our Towns; Miracle Sought From the Mets By Young Fans
description: To be 10 years old, to be a Mets fan, to have had your team fighing for the pennant the last weekend of the season - nothing like it. Jason Yeager's jitters have jitters. ''Worried?'' said Jason. ''No! I am a little bit.''

title: A U.N. Nuclear Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Sellars to Head Los Angeles Festival
description: Peter Sellars, the 29-year-old director who is fond of shocking theater audiences, has been named director of the biennial Los Angeles Festival.

title: Study Assesses Women And Responses to Love
description: A sampling of women's attitudes on their relationships with men by an author of best-selling books on sexuality has found that 84 percent of women queried were ''not satisfied emotionally'' with their marriages or romantic involvements.

title: Pope Opens Synod of Bishops on Role of the Laity
description: Pope John Paul II opened a Synod of Bishops in St. Peter's Basilica today by asking the prelates to address ''the proper and specific tasks'' assigned to ordinary lay people.

title: Triple Steal For Braves
description: Atlanta completed a triple steal in the fourth inning against the Houston Astros tonight. With Jeff Blauser on first, Ken Oberkfell on second and Gerald Perry on third, the Houston catcher, Ronn Reynolds, threw the ball back to the pitcher, Danny Darwin, just as Perry broke for the plate.

title: Persian Gulf
description: Persian Gulf, a rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Rodeo Bar at Albuquerque, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street (683-6500). There is no cover or minimum.

title: TV Sports; McCarver Brings Candor to Booth
description: As the games dwindle to a precious few, it's time to take note of the unique brand of information and entertainment that Tim McCarver has once again brought to Mets telecasts. And to recognize that he pays a price for his refreshing candor.

title: Restaurants
description: IN spite of the admirable strides made in recent years by many hotel restaurants, diners at large still have a psychological block about frequenting them - images of rubbery surf and turf with foil-wrapped baked potatoes dissipate slowly. Trumpet's, the showcase dining room at the Grand Hyatt on East 42d Street, near Grand Central Terminal, has been trying diligently to establish an identity as a first-class dining room, and some of the efforts are paying off.

title: National Stock Up As Deal Advances
description: The shares of the National Semiconductor Corporation rose sharply after Federal regulators cleared the way for its acquisition of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation. The stock gained $1.875 a share, to $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Powerful Forces Tug California Rim
description: Although yesterday's California earthquake was a small foretaste of the big one that experts expect there, it apparently had little or no bearing on when that larger earthquake might take place.

title: North Carolinians
description: The North Carolina Symphony, conducted by Gerhardt Zimmermann, is to perform works by Robert Ward Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Soloists include James Houlik, a saxophonist; Victoria Livengood, a mezzo soprano, and Eugene Perry, a baritone. Mr. Ward will conduct the vocal selection. Tickets are $11 to $20. Information: 247-7800.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; 2-Year-Olds: A Small Club
description: The Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park tomorrow is New York's third Grade I race this year for 2-year-olds, and the third with a surprisingly small field.

title: INSIDE
description: Back on the Streets A reader in Managua with a copy of La Presna, with the headline ''The People Triumph,'' as the Nicaraguan opposition newspaper resumed publication yesterday. Page A3. Trade Talks to Resume After a last-minute proposal by the United States, Canada said its negotiators would return to Washington to resume free-trade talks. Page D1.

title: Lawyer Withdraws Bid for Retrial Based on Recanting in Mob Case
description: A lawyer for a mob leader convicted in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial asked a Federal judge yesterday to ignore a co-counsel's application for a new trial based on a recantation by a witness.

title: ''MYSTERY!'' PRESENTS DOROTHY SAYERS'S LORD PETER WIMSEY
description: THE first time around in adaptations of several Dorothy L. Sayers stories, Lord Peter Wimsey was played by Ian Carmichael and seen on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater.'' Now the monocled aristocrat and haughty sleuth is being portrayed, far more authentically, by Edward Petherbridge and, beginning tomorrow at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, can be seen for the next 10 weeks on ''Mystery!,'' another series underwritten by Mobil.

title: Median Age of Americans Climbs to 31.7 Years, Study Finds
description: Americans are growing older, on the average, with the median age reaching 31.7 years in 1986, up from 30 in 1980, the Census Bureau reports.

title: Craig Journal; Living in Dread of Turning Into a Ghost Town
description: Slowly, David Simpson ticked off the list of casualties. There were Cosgriff's Hotel, Barrett's Clothing Store, Taco Johns, KQZR radio, Grako Tires, Jer's Liquor Store, Action Video and Polich Brothers Auto Parts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Dart Financial Corp., Landover, Md., a division of the Dart Corp., appointed Linda Haft senior vice president.

title: At Columbia, Low Hopes
description: A student on the Columbia campus said that if Barnard suited up a football team, it could beat Columbia.

title: Suriname Clears Way For General Elections
description: Suriname has overwhelmingly approved a new constitution, setting the stage for elections to return the country to democracy after seven years of military rule, the electoral commission said today.

title: Robert Hayes: Anatomy of a Crusader
description: The fury in Robert M. Hayes's voice is barely under control: It has become clear that he will not get all that he wants from his latest court settlement on behalf of homeless families.

title: Bridge: France-Netherlands Match Had Award-Winning Play
description: Some of the finest plays in the game are extremely simple, but since they run against instinct some creative imagination is needed.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 2, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee (Working Group on Migrant Workers' Rights) - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. Legal Committee - 10 A.M. Council for Namibia - 3:30 P.M.

title: Econocom Target: Decision Industries
description: Econocom International N.V., a Netherlands-based holding company, has offered to buy all of the shares of the Decision Industries Corporation that it does not already control for $11 a share in cash, or a total of $89 million. In a Wednesday letter to the Decision Industries board, contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Econocom said its offer was subject to a friendly agreement between the companies and set an Oct. 10 deadline for a response.

title: Alexander's Again Is a Trump Target
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, has quickly shifted his attention back toward Alexander's Inc., a chain of 14 department stores in the New York City area.

title: 4 Die in Mexican Stampede
description: Three girls and a woman were killed and 35 people were injured when thousands of fans stormed a gate at an outdoor concert, the city Attorney General's office said today. The stampede took place late Wednesday afternoon before a concert by three of Mexico's most popular pop-music groups at the city's Sports Palace. The surge of people apparently was touched off when the concert was delayed by more than 90 minutes. Those killed were a 7-year-old girl, two 14-year-old girls and a woman believed to be about 35, the Attorney General's spokesman said. Hospital officials said 10 people were still in serious condition.

title: New York Officials Assert Fraud Scheme To Dilute Corn Oil
description: Bottles of corn oil sold in New York groceries may have been diluted with soy oil and other substitutes as part of a multimillion-dollar nationwide scheme, state agricultural officials said today.

title: When Children Commit Murder
description: Paula Cooper, an 18-year-old murderer sentenced to death in Indiana, has become the rallying point for a movement in Europe to end capital punishment in America. In one respect she would make a poor martyr: No one disputes that she committed a horrible crime. But in another, her case is compelling: When she committed the crime, she was still a child.

title: Advertising Club To Assist Unemployed
description: The membership of the Advertising Club of New York, concerned about the number of unemployed agency people over 45 who are the unfortunate victims of industry shrinkage, is beginning a program to do something about it.

title: Irving Bank To Fight Bid
description: The Irving Bank Corporation sent a letter to its shareholders yesterday that said the bank would fight a hostile takeover bid made by the Bank of New York Corporation.

title: Diner's Journal
description: I AM usually wary of restaurants that wave the flag of health food vigorously, especially the new breed of upscale salubrious eateries that calculate cholesterol and sodium on the menu and offer didactic little discourses about your slowly clogging arteries and surging blood pressure. To my way of thinking, sound nutrition begins at home; health consciousness in restaurants is a most welcome trend, but too often flavor gets thrown out with the salt shaker - if I want bland food, I'll make it at home.

title: Families Must Know of Organ-Donation Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Beethoven Cycle
description: The second installment in Richard Goode's seven-concert cycle of the complete Beethoven piano sonatas is to be presented Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The program includes the ''Pathetique'' and ''Les Adieux'' sonatas. Tickets are $12.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Vast Speedup of Data Transmission Is Hinted
description: A small prototype device has shown that communications lines made from the new generation of superconductors can transmit data at speeds up to 100 times as fast as today's state-of-the-art optical fiber networks, scientists said yesterday.

title: Mets Get a Start as Spectators
description: When it was over, the Mets took it without spite or whimper, as they stood in a private box high behind first base in Busch Stadium and watched 48,763 fans roar for the new champions.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Los Angeles County announced plans yesterday to issue $1 billion of short-term securities through various securities dealers, who would then re-invest the money at slightly higher interest rates for the county.

title: Art: 'Sculpture,' the Works of Five Women
description: WITHOUT being polemical, the current exhibition at the Pat Hearn Gallery proposes some loose and interesting connections among the work of five artists who happen to be women. The artists in question span several generations: Louise Bourgeois has nearly a 50-year career and a Museum of Modern Art retrospective behind her; Eva Hesse, who died in 1970 at the age of 36, made a lasting contribution to that personalization of form known as Post-Minimalism; Mary Heilmann, whose roots are in Post-Minimalism, has been exhibiting painting and ceramics in New York since the early 1970's, and Annette Lemieux, an American, and Rosemarie Trockel, who is from West Germany, are both emerging young artists whose work has lately aroused a great deal of interest.

title: 12 From Queens Picked for Jury In Black's Death
description: The selection of the 12 jurors in the Howard Beach murder trial was completed yesterday as three more Queens residents were chosen to hear the evidence in the racially volatile case.

title: Unlocking Soviet Cells
description: Sometime soon the Soviet Union will release most of its political prisoners. That is the expectation in the Reagan Administration, although Washington has said nothing public about it yet.

title: Nina Ricci Account To O'Rielly, 'Brien
description: Nina Ricci has assigned its fragrances to O'Rielly, O'Brien, Clow/ RSCG, a French-owned New York agency whose parent company handles the brands abroad.

title: Cards Win Title As Mets Watch
description: The Cardinals defeated the Montreal Expos by 8-2 last night in St. Louis, clinching the National League East title and ending the Mets' chances of repeating as World Series champions.

title: Anti-Sandinista Paper Reopens, Defiant and Exultant
description: The embattled opposition newspaper La Prensa was back on the streets today, 451 days after it was shut by the Sandinista Government.

title: Clark Terry
description: Clark Terry, a trumpeter, will lead a jazz group tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: South Africa Woman Gives Birth To 3 Grandchildren, and History
description: A 48-year-old South African, acting as a surrogate for her daughter, gave birth to three grandchildren today.

title: New Chairman Seeks A Stable Computerland
description: Despite its pre-eminence as the world's largest retailer of personal computers, the Computerland Corporation has its share of problems, including lengthy litigation, fractious franchisees and declining margins. But to William Y. Tauscher, who took over as chairman last week, the chain, based in Hayward, Calif., seems a good investment.

title: Film: 'Big Shots,' A Comedy
description: IF all those movies about black-white teams of hero-adventurers strike you as kid stuff, you haven't seen anything yet. ''Big Shots,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is kid stuff with kids.

title: Advertising; Diamandis Group at The Helm Advertising; European Travel & Life Raises Rate Base
description: ALL the papers were signed yesterday, $650 million changed hands and the CBS Magazine division became Diamandis Communications Inc.

title: Plessey in Venture With British G.E.
description: The Plessey Company and the British General Electric Company said they plan to combine their worldwide telecommunications businesses in a joint venture that would have annual sales of more than $:1.2 billion ($2 billion).

title: Television as a Canvas Explored in 'Spectaccolo'
description: ''Last year, I saw a picture of myself in front of a TV set when I was 3 years old,'' Kit Fitzgerald recalled the other day. ''In the picture, my eyes were so lit up and engaged they were like beams. But I've always had a love-hate relationship with television. There were periods when my parents didn't allow me to watch it. And when I was allowed to, I used to talk back to the set.''

title: Networks Are Losing Some Ads
description: Advertisers, led by the three largest American automobile makers and a brewer, are pulling out of this weekend's National Football League telecasts because of the players' strike.

title: Warwick Abandons Calvin Cooler Account
description: Warwick Advertising said yesterday that it had resigned the Calvin Cooler business, which bills about $2 million.

title: Southland in Deals Worth $132 Million
description: The Southland Corporation said it would receive $52 million in cash from the sale of its Movie Quik movie-rental division and $80 million for 270 of its 7-Eleven stores in the Houston area. The divestitures, announced earlier this week, are part of a previously announced plan to help finance a $5.1 billion leveraged buyout of Southland by its founders, the Thompson family.

title: Prosecutor Depicts Zaccaro and Manes as 'Partners in Crime'
description: John A. Zaccaro was depicted yesterday as a ''would-be bagman'' for the late Donald R. Manes who had tried to extort a bribe from a cable television concern seeking a franchise in Queens.

title: Film Festival; 'Anna,' on Stardom Of Czechs
description: A NUMBER of hard-to-believe things happen right at the beginning of ''Anna,'' a first film directed by Yurek Bogayevicz and written by Agnieszka (''Angry Harvest'') Holland. No. 1: though the title character, a once-celebrated Czechoslovak actress (played by Sally Kirkland), lives amid the kind of gloomy decor in which one might expect to find an elderly lady, she emerges as a leggy, chic-looking creature. No. 2: also emerging, apparently from a mud puddle near the Brooklyn Bridge, is an even leggier and more chic-looking figure dressed in rags.

title: PING-HSUN CHANG
description: Ping-Hsun Chang, a former Chinese diplomat and consul general of the Republic of China in New York City for more than a decade after World War II, died of a heart attack Sept. 14 at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 84 years old and lived in Taipei.

title: PATRICK DEMPSEY, 2 FILMS, 2 LOOKS
description: HE looks like a cross between Woody Allen and Sean Penn.

title: Salvador Rebels Postpone Talks
description: Salvadoran rebel leaders, angered at a remark by El Salvador's President, have postponed a meeting scheduled for Sunday with Government officials to discuss ways to carry out a new regional peace plan.

title: SUNDAY'S PLANS FOR FANS, PLAYERS
description: On Sunday, National Football League games will be played by teams made up of replacements for the striking players, and players who have crossed the picket line. Below is a team-by-team breadkown of players who have returned to work, the number of refunds issued to ticket-holders and the players' plans for activities outside the stadiums. American Conference Buffalo Bills Players who have crossed: None. Number of refunds: 13,800. Parking lot schedule: Players' picket line. San Diego Chargers Players who have crossed: None. Number of refunds: Not home this week. Parking lot schedule: Not home. Seattle Seahawks Players who have crossed (1): Stan Eisentooth, c. Dallas Cowboys Players who have crossed (4): Tony Dorsett, rb; Don Smerek, dt; Danny White, qb; Randy White, dt. Number of refunds: Not home this week. Parking lot schedule: Not home. Number of refunds: 5,290 Parking lot schedule: Players' picket lines. Giants Players who have crossed: None. Number of refunds: 20,000 Parking lot schedule: Possible flag football game with striking players from Jets. Philadelphia Eagles Players who have crossed: None. Number of refunds: 40,000 Parking lot schedule: Players' picket line. Parking lot schedule: Players' picket line with heavy support from A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Hotel and Restaurant Workers union, whose members make up most of the support personel at R.F.K. Stadium. *On injured reserve.

title: G.O.P Thwarts Tax Bill Plans
description: Efforts by the House Ways and Means Committee to begin drafting a tax bill today were scuttled after Republicans disputed the need to raise $12 billion from new taxes and refused to consider any specific revenue-raising proposals.

title: 33 Straight for Santiago
description: Benito Santiago of San Diego got his first major league bunt single at an opportune time.

title: American Brands Units
description: American Brands Inc., a diversified company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it plans to sell its Sunshine Biscuits and Pinkerton's subsidiaries.

title: The Tape: What Sin?; Puzzlement at Case Of Dukakis's Aide
description: In the aftermath of an episode that led to his resignation as Presidential campaign manager for Michael S. Dukakis, many political operatives and observers are wondering exactly what it is that John Sasso did wrong.

title: Stephane Grappelli
description: The violinist Stephane Grappelli leads a group tonight through Monday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 8:30 and 10:30 P.M.; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: A Ban on Children Is Upheld
description: A mobile home park can deny housing to families with children under 18 years old, the California Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Educators Call Regents' Booklet Racist
description: An official state booklet on high school dropouts has become the center of a dispute among many New York educators, who say it implies that black students are less capable of learning than whites.

title: Israeli Rebuffs Soviet Offer To Set Up Diplomatic Ties
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel was reported today to have rejected an offer from the Soviet Union last week to open quasi-embassies in Tel Aviv and Moscow, maintaining that Israel would not settle for less than full diplomatic ties, American officials said.

title: Art People
description: Talk, Talk, Talk

title: Della Femina Gets Dr. Scholl's Products
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners will be creating the advertising for Dr. Scholl's line of foot care products. Dr. Scholl, a subsidiary of Schering-Plough, will continue to use Schering's in-house agency, Lake-Spiro-Schurman in Memphis, for all media placements.

title: 29 Injured by Arson at a Welfare Hotel in Harlem
description: A fire set in a Harlem welfare hotel early yesterday injured 29 residents, eight of them critically, and left six families homeless, the authorities said.

title: Building Spending Rises 1.6%
description: A rebound in apartment building helped spur construction spending, which rose 1.6 percent in August, the biggest increase in four months, the Government said today.

title: Dean Foods Post Returns to Family
description: The Dean Foods Company, which was started in 1925 as a maker of evaporated milk, has named a third-generation Dean as chief executive. He is Howard M. Dean, who has been serving as president and chief operating officer.

title: Chamber Opera
description: The American Chamber Opera Company is to present a double bill of Peter Westergaard's ''Mr. and Mrs. Discobbolos'' and John Harbison's ''Full Moon in March,'' tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Marymount Manhattan Theater, at 221 East 71st Street. Tickets are $10, $5 for the elderly and students. Information: 781-0857.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1987
description: International

title: Affordable Housing Today Means Tracts of Single-Family Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Target of Players' Antitrust Suit
description: On the day the moratorium on signing draft choices and free agents ended, the National Basketball Association tried to go back to business as usual yesterday. But the players' union took the unusual step of suing the owners.

title: Broadway
description: Sada Thompson as a Saleswoman

title: Moscow Virtuosi
description: The Moscow Virtuosi, under the conductor and violinist Vladimir Spivakov, is to make its first New York appearance Sunday at 3 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. The program includes works by Bach, Shostakovich and Tchaikovsky. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: 64 Seized in Drug Raids
description: Sixty-four people were arrested yesterday when narcotics officers raided five buildings on West 164th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights at about 4:30 P.M. Most were charged with possession and sale of cocaine, the police said. The raids were at 562, 559, 548 and 505 West 164th Street and at 2091 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Next Ruling On Newmont
description: A Delaware judge said today that he would rule next week on whether to grant a preliminary injunction to stop maneuvering by the Newmont Mining Corporation and its British ally. They are trying to thwart an unfriendly takeover effort led by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

title: Taylor Says He Might Return to Giants Next Week
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' all-pro outside linebacker and their highest-paid player, said yesterday he might abandon the strike of National Football League players and report to the team next week. Gary Kovacs, his agent, said Taylor would definitely not play Monday night against the San Francisco 49ers at Giants Stadium.

title: BORK NOMINATION WILL BE OPPOSED BY 4 KEY SENATORS
description: A key Republican Senator and three Southern Democrats today announced their opposition to Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, a development raising serious doubts about his chances for confirmation.

title: U.S. Bureau for Water Projects Shifts Focus to Conservation
description: The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation, which for 85 years built the dams and water projects that spurred the development of the American West, today announced a radical change in its mission.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Two Soviet long-range missile tests have been protested by the United States, the State Department said. The tests earlier this week sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii. Page A1 Moscow's intellectual elite gathered last week for an unfettered discussion of hotly disputed issues including censorship and religious persecution. The event was sponsored by Ogonyok magazine, a leading proponent of glasnost. A1 Israel rejected a Soviet offer to open quasi-embassies in Tel Aviv and Moscow, U.S. officials said. Shimon Peres reportedly said Israel would not accept anything less than full diplomatic relations. A8 George Shultz said the Russians had taken ''a significant step forward'' in agreeing in principle to discuss an arms embargo against Iran. But a Soviet official said Iran should be given more time to embrace a cease-fire. A8 The opposition newspaper La Prensa was back on the streets in Nicaragua yesterday, 451 days after it was shut by the Government. Its return was one of the most tangible effects of the August peace accord. A3 The joint meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund ended on an optimistic note yesterday, invigorated by U.S. proposals for coping with global debt. D1 A woman acting as a surrogate for her daughter gave birth to three grandchildren in South Africa yesterday. She was the first woman to successfully carry her daughter's transplanted embryos. A9 The Pope opened a Synod of Bishops yesterday by asking the 232 bishops to consider ''the proper and specific tasks'' of lay people in the Roman Catholic church. The Synod is also scheduled to consider the role of women. A9 Queen Elizabeth II said she regards the Governor General of Fiji as the sole legitimate authority of the island. She was responding to a declaration by a rebel leader that he had taken charge. A3 Sofia journal A4 Soviet proposes Artic peace zone A6 Senate votes for adherence to 979 arms treaty A6 German said to have U.S. backing to run NATO A7 NATIONAL A10-17 Four Senators said they will vote no on the nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. The announcement by the three Southern Democrats and a key Republican has raised serious doubts about Judge Bork's chances. A1 An earthquake rocked Los Angeles yesterday morning, tearing glass from skyscrapers, jolting cars on freeways and killing at least six people. It was the first major earthquake in Los Angeles since 1971. A1 Powerful forces tug California rim A12 Are the Democrats throwing away the 1988 Presidential election? After months of disclosures, charges and countercharges, some Democrats and Republicans say that may be exactly what is happening. A1 News analysis: John Sasso, who was Michael Dukakis's campaign manager, admits distributing a videotape that damaged Joseph Biden's Presidential effort. But was there anything wrong with that? A16 Dukakis begins to repair campaign A16 Pat Robertson became a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination yesterday. The television evangelist formally announced his candidacy in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. A16 The swearing-in of William Sessions as the new F.B.I. Director was postponed indefintely yesterday after Mr. Sessions fainted from a small ulcer. The ulcer is expected to heal in a matter of weeks. A10 The Federal Bureau of Reclamation, which built the water projects that spurred development in the West, is to be completely reorganized. The staff may be cut by 50 percent as the agency concentrates on managing existing projects. A11 To cope with a school strike, parents on Chicago's South Side have organized their own alternative school program for neighborhood children. The strike is in its third week and no end is in sight. A10 Women in the armed forces are denied equal opportunities for promotion by some men who want to keep women out of the military, representatives of women's groups told a House subcommittee. A17 Data can be transmitted much faster over communications lines made from the new generation of superconductors than today's state-of-the-art networks, scientists said a small prototype device has shown. A1 Craig Journal A10 Senate unit backs an airline smoking ban A10 New Hite book looks at ''Women and Love'' A13 WASHINGTON TALK A14 As the Administration nears an end, the bailout begins The wind they call Mercouri REGIONAL

title: IBP Completes Public Offering
description: IBP Inc., the nation's largest producer of fresh beef and pork products, completed one of the largest initial public offerings on record, selling a 47 percent stake in the company for $408.5 million. The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, which bought IBP, based in Dakota City, Neb., in 1981, will continue to maintain control of it.

title: 11th-Hour Shift on Trade Pact
description: Canadian officials, on the verge of announcing a final collapse of free-trade talks with the United States, said today that a last-minute proposal by the United States had dramatically changed the situation, opening the way for a resumption of talks in Washington on Friday.

title: Honolulu Offers $50 Million Bonds
description: The City and County of Honolulu offered $50 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: 6 Die as Severe Earthquake Hits Los Angeles Area
description: A severe earthquake shook the Los Angeles area today, tearing glass from skyscrapers, jolting cars on freeways, killing at least 6 people and injuring more than 100 in a half minute of violent tremors.

title: An Oasis Turning to Seed, Riverside Park Wins Friends
description: Riverside Park needs green. Not green as in grass, but green as in greenbacks.

title: Paquito D'Rivera
description: Paquito D'Rivera, a Cuban alto saxophonist, will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Dayton Proxy Fight Is Seen
description: The Haft family said today that it hopes to wage a proxy fight in an attempt to gain control of the Dayton Hudson Corporation.

title: SHEILA McCARTHY: 'MERMAIDS' HEROINE
description: UNLIKE the girl in ''A Chorus Line'' who was told she'd be very attractive when she grew up, ''different, with a special something,'' Sheila McCarthy doesn't believe that pretty is necessarily what it's about.

title: Parents Angry as Chicago School Strike Lingers
description: Like many other parents here, Elaine Gamble never thought the Chicago school strike would go on so long. For the first two weeks her children stayed home, reading, watching television and pretending, for the most part, that they were still on summer vacation.

title: Stake Is Raised In Crazy Eddie
description: An investment group consisting of Entertainment Marketing Inc. and Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P., disclosed that it had raised its stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. to 15.6 percent, from 14.6 percent.

title: ELECTIC BENEFIT FOR DOWNTOWN CLUB
description: HE Knitting Factory, a club and cafe on 47 East Houston Street, had almost singlehandedly revived New York's downtown arts scene in its first six months of operation.

title: Editors' Note
description: A profile on Monday of Ann F. Lewis, a strategist for the Democratic Party, quoted Robert S. Strauss, a former national Democratic chairman, as saying that he would vote against Ms. Lewis if she ran for that post because she represented ''a point of view that the Democratic Party must get away from.'' The article omitted the context of Mr. Strauss's remark. While he said he thought her liberal political views should not dominate the party, he also said, ''On the basic issues, and the basic values, we have everything in common, and I think she is one of the very credible and sensible political voices in this town and country.''

title: 2 Rock Bands
description: Glass Eye, from Austin, Tex., and Blue Movie, from San Francisco, will play a rock double bill tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $6.

title: PTL Gives Court a Plan Severing Business Side
description: The PTL ministry has filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan that would divide the evangelical empire into profit-seeking and nonprofit entities.

title: A Savings Bank Decides to Keep New York Base
description: A large savings and loan institution that was considering moving its regional headquarters from Manhattan to New Jersey will instead relocate to Queens, New York City officials announced yesterday.

title: Yanks' Big Efforts Wither in Defeat
description: When they look back, the Yankees surely will not want to remember games like the one they played last night at the Stadium. They hit three home runs, stole three bases, owned a four-run lead in the seventh inning and lost.

title: Atlanta Zoo Accepted
description: Accreditation was returned to Zoo Atlanta today. The American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums, which lifted the zoo's accreditation in 1984, restored it after the zoo met all the agency's requirements in an inspection last month. Zoo Atlanta has spent millions of dollars on repairs and renovation, hired a veterinarian and made other changes.

title: Deal for Rail Track
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company has agreed to sell 208 miles of track in Wisconsin to the FRVR Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Itel Rail Corporations. A news release by Chicago and North Western's parent company, the Chicago-based CNW Corporation, said final conditions of the $66 million deal remained to be worked out. The transaction is subject to the approval of regulators and both companies' boards of directors. Itel Rail, a subsidiary of the Itel Corporation, is one of the nation's largest independent transportation equipment lessors.

title: The East Is Moving
description: Whatever happened while Mikhail Gorbachev was mysteriously out of sight for nearly two months, he is back and things are starting to happen in the East again. So far they are mostly words, and such startling words that the temptation is to write them off as the familiar extravagance of Communist Party propaganda.

title: Democracy Doesn't Need Bork's Protection; Judges Make Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide; After Theater
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ALO ALO, #1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) - **(June 21, 1985) The whimsical dining room is in grand cafe style at this colorful and convivial East Side restaurant, and the glass fishbowl effect creates a glittery urban night. The food is as uplifting as the setting and the menu offers options conducive to late-night dining. You might try the grilled vegetable platter; pastas - from spaghetti with tuna and spinach to large shells with Bolognese sauce, mushrooms and rosemary; broiled red snapper with fennel oil and asparagus, or poached Canadian duck breast with Arborio rice. Main dishes $10.50 to $19.50. Fridays to Sundays, 11:45 A.M. to 11:45 P.M. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, #200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - **(May 9, 1986) Just a few blocks north of Lincoln Center is this stylish and serious restaurant with a gleaming zinc bar up front and a sleek tiled dining room with Parisian cafe chairs and red banquettes. The kitchen features essentially American food; and after theater, you might choose crab cakes sauteed with tomato coulis and pesto sauce or smoked salmon and vegetable salad with green beans, asparagus and baby carrots with sherry vinaigrette. Entree selections include grilled warm breast of chicken salad with sweet pepper julienne; steak frites, and grilled tuna with a light aioli sauce and roasted red peppers, fennel, zucchini and eggplant. Entrees $15 to $28. Fridays and Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to 1:30 A.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. CAFE UN DEUX TROIS, #123 West 44th Street (354-4148) - *(May 15, 1987) One of the better bets for Broadway theater-district dining is this big, bustling brasserie with faux marble columns and mustard-colored walls that look as if they're peeling and a generally seedy-by-design look. The short regular menu is supplemented by daily specials, and appetizers include duck liver mousse; chicken and veal sausage, and beef sate, tender strips of beef with a brassy peanut sauce. For a main dish, you might order breaded chicken breast in mustard sauce; mixed grill with calf's liver, boudin blanc and lamb chop, or grilled steak. Dinner entrees $7.50 to $18.50. Fridays, noon to 4 P.M. and 4:30 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. LOLA, #30 West 22d Street (675-6700) -

title: Beck's Career May Be Over
description: The Rangers received a shock yesterday morning when they learned that Barry Beck, who was attempting a comeback, reinjured his left shoulder Tuesday night in Denver and almost certainly will not be able to resume his career.

title: Market Place; CBS Puts Off Records Deal
description: DISAPPOINTING investors who expected a decision on the future of its records group, CBS Inc. said yesterday that it would take a little longer to make up its mind.

title: As the End Nears, The Bailout Begins
description: As if the loss of the Senate, the Iran-contra affair, the troubled Robert Bork nomination and a lame-duck status were not demoralizing enough, the Reagan Administration must now try to plug an inevitable, but nonetheless debilitating, end-of-term loss of personnel.

title: Wheat Crop Forecast
description: The International Wheat Council has cut its estimate of this year's world wheat crop to 506 million metric tons from 518 million predicted in July, citing poorer harvest prospects in Western Europe, Canada and the Soviet Union. The council, a trade body, put the world wheat crop at 535 million tons last year.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ONE of the most important collections of Dutch and Flemish Old Master paintings formed in this country in recent years - including works by Frans Hals, Jan Davidsz de Heem, Jan Jansz den Uyl and Jacob van Ruisdael - will be auctioned at Sotheby's in January.

title: Queen Elizabeth Asserts Role As True Fijian Head of State
description: Responding to a defiant declaration by a Fijian coup leader that he had taken charge, Queen Elizabeth II declared today that she continued to regard the island nation's Governor General as the sole legitimate authority.

title: Stage: 'Roza,' a 'One-Woman Unicef' From Prince
description: ''ROZA,'' the new musical at the Royale, overflows with so much gooey humanity that it's easy to leave the theater feeling like W. C. Fields on a misanthropic day: one's first impulse is to find and kick a very small dog.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Made in Singapore
description: People who fear that the Japanese are taking over the world economy, leaving Americans with nothing left to do but defrost microwave pizzas, are behind the news. Japan's export growth is on the wane, as the high-flying yen makes it ever more difficult for Japanese industry to compete on price.

title: The Battle of the Spreadsheets
description: In the first phase of the personal computer boom, the industry's two software heavyweights - the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation - thrived largely by staying out of each other's way. That polite, unspoken arrangement ends next week.

title: Senate Panel Passes Smoking Ban For All Flights of 2 Hours or Less
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved legislation that would ban smoking on all domestic airline flights of two hours or less and impose penalties on violators.

title: Senate Votes to Let Insurerss in Capital Reject AIDS Clients
description: The Senate voted Wednesday to allow insurance companies to deny insurance to people in the District of Columbia who test positive for exposure to the AIDS virus.

title: FROM HUDSON VIEWS TO SULEYMAN, A FEAST OF ART AT THE MET
description: AS of this coming Sunday, Gluttony will hold court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Enthroned on a Gothic Revival armchair (newly acquired by the Met) that was made around 1860 for a large and grand town house in Yonkers, he can hold tight to a jeweled orb from the age of Suleyman the Magnificent, which is part of a new and keenly awaited exhibition at the Met. Candelabra by the great English designer Paul Storr can light his way to dinner, and we may be sure that the Met's kitchens will be working for him round the clock. This is not a coarse brute -your everyday commonplace Gluttony - but a man of birth and breeding who expects only the best and finds it none too good.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHAT DO OUR 17-YEAR-OLDS KNOW?

title: Art Blakey
description: Art Blakey, a drummer, and the Jazz Messengers are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; No-Name Defenses, And Offenses, Too
description: There are two prison guards from death row. A player is wearing the number of his brother, who is picketing, and there is a tenor who sings opera in the locker room.

title: A New School For Stuyvesant To Be Speeded
description: New York City will build a new home for one of its premier high schools, Stuyvesant, in time for the start of the 1991-92 school year under a schedule that seeks to show that its public schools can be built fast and well, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: New Chief of F.B.I. Falls Ill, Postponing His Swearing-In
description: The swearing-in ceremony for the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, was postponed today after Mr. Sessions fainted in the aisle of a Washington-bound jetliner.

title: Philharmonic: Sanderling Conducts
description: KURT SANDERLING first led the New York Philharmonic in 1984 and must have impressed someone in authority at that time. The German conductor, much of whose career was pursued in the Soviet Union and East Berlin, returned to the orchestra last evening to begin a two-week guest engagement. He is not by any means a keg of excitement. In fact, he displayed in this opening program the sturdy competence of a provincial kapellmeister, hardly more. We have long since become resigned to the scarcity of first-rank conductors in today's world, but the continued paucity of interesting second-rankers does become a problem. Within their memory, our elder citizens swear, the woods were full of these latter creatures.

title: Music: Blair String Quartet
description: THE Blair String Quartet's recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday evening lasted well over two hours but seemed much longer.

title: KEY RATES
9% Deposit Notes By Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 9 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of 99.85, to yield 9.08 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Paxson of the Portland Trail Blazers, whose trade to Cleveland this summer was nullified because of an injury to the player he was exchanged for, will undergo toe surgery today. . . . Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, has ruled himself out of today's Australia's Davis Cup tennis semifinal against India in Sydney because of a jarred right knee.

title: BENJAMIN GRUND
description: Benjamin Grund, a former director and partner in Seidman & Seidman, an international accounting firm based in New York City, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old. In 1920, Mr. Grund was hired as a file clerk by a founding partner of the firm. Two years later, he was made acting head of the New York office's tax department. In 1960, Mr. Grund - then the firm's first national director of taxation - was named one of the firm's first general partners, a position he held until his retirement in 1975.

title: Trammell's 3 Hits Help Tigers
description: The Detroit Tigers moved within one game of first-place Toronto heading into their season-ending showdown as Alan Trammell had three hits, including his 200th of the season, in a 9-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: IN NYACK, N.Y., SCENIC WALKS AND A PARADISE OF VICTORIANA
description: NYACK, about 25 miles north of New York City, is nestled in a niche of the Palisades that tower over the west bank of the Hudson River. Its location, akin to a cleft in a prominent chin of land, accounts for the village's history and contributes to a variegated present, including a reputation as a mecca for antiques fanciers, a haven for art and theater lovers, and a paradise of Victorian architecture and river views for walkers and hikers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Washington Post Is a Staunch Believer in Collective Bargaining
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FINDING MADE ON AIDS DETECTION
description: A new study of gay men in Finland has found that some who became infected with the AIDS virus through sexual intercourse did not form antibodies for more than a year, far longer than most experts had expected.

title: Margaret M. Kennedy Weds Matthew Carey
description: Margaret Mary Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William Kennedy of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Matthew Emmons Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hale Husted Carey of Montclair, N.J. Msgr. John J. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Edwin C. Bockstiegel, a Presbyterian minister.

title: What Value Education? Counting the Ways
description: For high school students, graduating means $352 a month in extra earning power. And students who finish four years of college earn $672 a month more than those who attend college but do not get a degree.

title: Berkshire-Salomon
description: Salomon Inc. and Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said they had consummated their previously announced agreement for the sale of 700,000 shares of Salomon's series A cumulated preferred stock for $700 million. The transaction was part of an agreement reached last weekend under which Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, is acquiring a 14 percent stake in the investment banking firm.

title: Avoiding Tax On Life Policy
description: A FEW years ago, Carol Contos, a Manhattan teacher, bought a $300,000 life insurance policy. Instead of putting the ownership of the policy in her name, however, she set up an irrevocable life insurance trust and transferred the ownership to the trust.

title: RLR FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
California Begins Cleanup After Quake
description: Californians began cleaning up the wreckage from Thursday's earthquake today amid expressions of relief that this had not been the long-feared ''big one.'' Early estimates put the total damage in the tens of millions of dollars.

title: Weirton Steel Fails In Talks With Korf
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation, ending a year of negotiations, said it had failed to reach an agreement with Korf Engineering of West Germany to construct an iron-making demonstration plant here and is withdrawing from the project.

title: Mayor of Pittsburgh Has Incurable Illness
description: Mayor Richard S. Caliguiri acknowledged today he is suffering from a rare, incurable disease.

title: TV: CBS's 'Mistress,' And Series
description: ''Mistress,'' the made-for-TV movie on CBS tomorrow at 9 P.M., opens with one of those little scenes that can make prime-time entertainment memorable. Victoria Principal, formerly Pam Ewing on ''Dallas,'' is in acting class doing a scene from Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard.'' The effort is excruciatingly inadequate but, this being television, the beaming teacher turns to Ms. Principal and says, very seriously, ''Beautiful, very real!'' Delicious. Well, at least the rest of ''Mistress'' does better on the reality meter. Ms. Principal plays Rae Colton, a once-aspiring actress who has been living, rather luxuriously, with a married man for some nine years. He dies, and Rae is not mentioned in the will. She is back at square one, and at the age of 38, that's no joke in the town called Hollywood - or anyplace else, for that matter. Ms. Principal is serious about Rae and, except for one or two overwrought scenes beyond her grasp, she does a credible job under the direction of Michael Tuchner.

title: EPISCOPAL PANEL WILL INVESTIGATE NEWARK BISHOP
description: The presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church has appointed a panel to investigate whether Bishop John S. Spong of Newark contradicted official teachings by urging the church to give its blessings to homosexual and other unmarried couples.

title: L.I. Teen-Ager Held in Kidnap And Torture of 15-Year-Old
description: A 15-year-old boy escaped from the home of a classmate after being beaten, stabbed, chained at the feet and repeatedly asked, ''How do you want to die,'' the police said.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: Both latest periods' results include the operations of McKesson Envirosystems Co. and Breslube Enterprises since the acquisitions on March 31, 1987 and May 29, 1987, respectively. The 1986 share earnings has been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on March 5, 1987, effected in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend.

title: Bush Lauds Soviet Workers And Is Assailed by U.A.W.
description: Marveling at the ability of Soviet mechanics, Vice President Bush said today that when they ran out of work in the Soviet Union, Moscow should ''send them to Detroit.''

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Chemicals, Fruit and Coolies
description: ''We are just meeting the needs of the market, like importing chemicals or slippers. It happens that the need of the market now is for labor.'' So says Cheeon Fung, manager of a new cooperative venture, by the Chinese Government and a Chinese-American company in New York, to bring farm workers to America.

title: JUDGE REDUCES SENTENCE OF MAN IN BRINK'S CASE
description: A Federal judge has reduced the prison sentence of a defendant convicted of hiding a key suspect in the 1981 Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County.

title: McGEE BEATS OUT THE UNCERTAINTY
description: In the midst of the silliness going on in the St. Louis Cardinal clubhouse, the towel that was wrapped around Willie McGee's head made him appear as if he had arrived at the occasion on a camel. After two seasons filled with injuries, a decline in productivity, the resulting self-doubt and the thought that he could be shipped elsewhere, McGee had finally found his oasis.

title: INSIDE
description: A.C.L.U. to Aid P.L.O. The American Civil Liberties Union will defend the right of a Palestine Liberation Organization agent to run an information office. Page 7. Payment for Greenpeace An international tribunal ordered France to pay $8.1 million to Greenpeace for sinking the environmental group's ship in 1985. Page 2.

title: ALL AMERICAN TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RANGERS LEAVE BECK TO DRAFT
description: The Rangers, increasingly known for surprising personnel moves, followed a more predictable course yesterday in submitting their list of protected players for next week's National Hockey League waiver draft. As expected, the Rangers said that it was likely that Barry Beck would abandon his comeback attempt after reinjuring his left shoulder, and they left the defenseman unprotected.

title: Senate Defies Reagan on Arms Issues
description: The Senate, taking an unusually defiant stand on arms control, approved legislation today that Republicans said would tie the President's hands in negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: ALEXANDER'S STOCK SCORES A 10% GAIN
description: Alexander's Inc. stock jumped 10 percent yesterday, benefiting from speculation that Donald J. Trump might bid for the retailer and from news that another large investor had added to his investment in the 14-store chain.

title: REVCO D S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
description: The year-ago first quarter results are on a pro forma basis. The pro forma results have been prepared as if the merger and planned divestiture program had been completed June 1, 1986.

title: Crazy Eddie Stake Raised to 16.85%
description: An investment group consisting of Entertainment Marketing Inc. and Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. disclosed that it had raised its stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. to 16.85 percent, from 15.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Oppenheimer said that it purchased 376,500 Crazy Eddie shares on the open market for prices ranging from $4.875 to $4.915 a share.

title: A Coach's Plea
description: Saddled with three straight losses this season and a 2-14 won-lost record since he took over last year as coach of the Kansas State football team, Stan Parrish made a plea for help from the Wildcat student body and the townspeople of Manhattan, Kan., in an open letter published yesterday by the Kansas State Collegian and the Manhattan Mercury. ''We are in the midst of battling an attitude of 'can't win, can't do, never get it done,' '' wrote Parrish, whose team plays Tulsa (0-4) today. ''Our team needs your support to help us become winners. Granted we haven't played as well as we had hoped so far, but we have eight games left. We can't give up now. We need your support, so stand tall and let the positive people in Manhattan and Kansas State be heard this Saturday.''

title: For Tibet and China, a Turbulent History
description: The mountainous region of Tibet, for centuries an important seat of Buddhism under successive Dalai Lamas, was an independent kingdom from the seventh to the ninth century. It fell into disunity, but was reunited in the 17th century, and underwent periods of greater or lesser Chinese control until the Chinese Revolution of 1911-12, when the Chinese were expelled.

title: Catholic Radio Reopens in Managua
description: The radio station of the Roman Catholic hierarchy, which was closed down by the Sandinista Government 21 months ago, resumed broadcasting today.

title: IF A BANK DEPOSIT IS LOST
description: AT some point after the check was handed to the teller, but before it reached its destination - the customer's checking account - the deposit was lost. Had it fallen into the wastebasket at the teller's foot? Had it been misdirected and credited to someone else's account? Did a computer gobble it up? What happened?

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Back Seat for Glasnost Amid Bulgarian Drive
description: Far-reaching governmental and economic restructuring is under way in this orthodox Communist country, but the striving for openness, which accompanies this process in the Soviet Union, is lagging behind.

title: Weinberger Won't See Soviet Aide in Geneva
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has rejected an invitation from the Soviet Defense Minister for a meeting next week in Geneva, restating his own suggestion that the two should meet this month in Washington.

title: Geoffrey Jackson, 72, Envoy Held 8 Months by Tupamaros
description: Sir Geoffrey H. S. Jackson, the British diplomat who spent eight months in a dungeon in 1971 after being kidnapped by Uruguayan guerrillas, died on Thursday, his family said today. He was 72 years old.

title: Yellowknife Journal; For Faraway Places, Strange-Sounding Names
description: With his bushy beard and muscled forearms, Randolph Freeman looks a little like one of the explorers who left their traces across the Canadian north. The appearance is appropriate, since Mr. Freeman, who is 35 years old, spends much of his time trekking across the same forbidding terrain in a quest as daunting, in its own way, as the explorers'.

title: SOVIET-IRAQI TIES HIT SNAG ON IRAN
description: A Soviet proposal on securing a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war and other Soviet gestures toward Iran have strained Iraqi-Soviet relations and heightened anxiety among some Persian Gulf states, according to senior Iraqi and Arab officials.

title: THE MAKING OF A MOLEHILL
description: When the press people failed to notice that Senator Biden was out in Iowa using Neil Kinnock's great campaign speech as his own, the campaign manager for Gov. Michael Dukakis called it to their attention.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Dun & Bradstreet Corp. and Information Resources Inc. said they each had received a request for additional information and documents from the Federal Trade Commission, in connection with the previously announced acquisition of Information Resources by Dun & Bradstreet. Both companies said they intend to comply with the requests promptly. Exxon Chemical Co., a Houston-based unit of Exxon Corp., has purchased the NL Treating Chemicals unit of NL Industries. Terms were not disclosed. Pullman-Peabody Co., Princeton, N.J., said it had sold its Ryan Instruments subsidiary to an investors group for $18 million in cash and notes. Tenneco Inc., Houston, said it had formed Tenneco Turkey Inc. to explore business opportunities in Turkey and countries neighboring it. Toronto Sun Publishing Corp., Toronto, said it had agreed to buy the Financial Post division from Maclean Hunter Ltd. for $46 million (Canadian) in new common shares. Washington Post Co. said it would post an after-tax gain of about $45 million on the sale of its interests in two cellular telephone system concerns.

title: Soviet Says Food Prices Will Rise
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union must enact major food price increases to improve its economy, and he promised to use the results of such changes to improve social services.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I only feel happiness, I am unable to think right now.'' - Ida Nudel, allowed to leave the Soviet Union after 16 years. [ 3:5. ]

title: FAY KOSHELLE
description: Fay Koshelle, a founder with her husband of a children's camp in the Catskills, died Wednesday at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md., where she was a resident. She was 102 years old. Mrs. Koshelle, a onetime Bronx resident, and her husband, the late William Koshelle, founded the Maple Lake Camp in Livingston Manor, N.Y., in 1925, and operated it for more than 30 years. At its peak the summer camp served approximately 150 children a season.

title: Lyons, Klecko Cross the Line
description: Two striking Jets crossed the picket line today to join Mark Gastineau and the team's replacement players.

title: CLARCOR reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company was formerly J.L. Clark Manufacturing Co.

title: New Pirate Contracts
description: As a reward for transforming the Pittsburgh Pirates from a last-place team in 1985 with a 57-104 record to a competitive franchise that has come close to a .500 record this season, Malcolm (Mac) Prine, the team's president, yesterday signed General Manager Syd Thrift, Manager Jim Leyland and five coaches to contracts that run indefinitely, although payments were set for definite periods.
