The coaches retained were Ray Miller, pitching; Milt May, hitting; Gene Lamont, third base; Tommy Sandt, first base, and Rich Donnelly, bullpen.

title: THE STARS OF A RISING MARKET
description: Starring in the stock market's third-quarter advance was an assortment of companies that earned top billing on the safety of gold, the allure of takeover plays and the attraction of a raging bull market in Mexico.

title: New Boeing Unit For Space Ventures
description: The Boeing Aerospace Company has formed a new subsidiary to foster commercial ventures in outer space. The subsidiary, which is based in Arlington, Va., has been named the Boeing Commercial Space Development Company. It was incorporated in Wilmington, Del., in July.

title: YANKEE COS.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $29,683,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $4,883,000 on disposal of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary charge of $569,000. c-Net income and after net of $11,418,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Fannie Mae, Meet Farmer Mac
description: Small rural banks, battered by the farm crisis, want a way to provide farm credit without bearing great risk. Creditworthy farmers, shadowed by the sense of general rural depression, are eager for a link to investors willing to lend long term at relatively low, fixed rates. Washington policy makers see benefit in spreading out the risks of gyrating crop prices and interest rates.

title: S.M.U. Picks Single
description: The troubled athletic agenda at Southern Methodist University was placed yesterday in the hands of an administator who has already resurrected one floundering sports program. Named as the new athletic director at the Dallas school was Doug Single, who was athletic director at Northwestern University from 1980 until this August. He resigned after transforming Wildcat sports teams from perennial doormats into respected competitors with a 95 percent graduation rate for athletes. S.M.U., which was rocked last year by a recruiting scandal that resulted in cancellation of football for the next two seasons, had been without an athletic director since the resignation last year of Bob Hitch. Kenneth A. Pye, the S.M.U. president, called Single, 36 years old, ''an individual of exceptional integrity and commitment to academic values,'' as well as a man with ''an impressive track record in bringing a sports program from obscurity back to national prominence and respectability.''

title: Tense Times for Aliens as U.S. Clamps Down
description: Tension, turmoil and confusion are mounting for illegal aliens here and around the country as the Immigration and Naturalization Service begins to carry out the harsh second phase of the historic amnesty law: penalties against employers who hire illegal aliens.

title: Film Festival; 'Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll,' Chuck Berry Documentary
description: A 60th-birthday tribute to the great rock innovator Chuck Berry may sound like an occasion for celebration., But Taylor Hackford's documentary ''Chuck Berry Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll!'' is anything but a valentine.

title: Nomura Unit In Kidder Talks
description: Nomura Securities International Inc., the New York arm of Japan's biggest investment banker, said yesterday that it had met this week with the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc., a leading Wall Street firm, but it denied that the two were discussing a possible combination or joint venture.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method to Determine Amount of Oil in a Well
description: LEAD: A method of examining earth formations in a well to determine the presence and quantity of oil was patented this week for Lalos & Keegan, a Washington law firm. Patent No. 4,696,903 was granted to Murl Owen, a Kansas engineer who has reported that the process has undergone field tests.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $1,140,000 from the reversal of a tax credit.

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Eased Bank Laws Urged
description: A House of Representatives committee has recommended sweeping changes in the nation's banking laws, criticizing present laws that bar banks from the securities business and other industries as anti-competitive and potentially dangerous to their financial soundness.

title: Small Quake Felt in Utah
description: A small earthquake was felt in Utah's remote western desert today, but seismologists said it was unrelated to the major quake that hit the Los Angeles area Thursday. The epicenter of the quake, which measured 3.5 magnitude on the Richter scale of ground motion, was 22 miles west of Brigham City.

title: For a Made in U.S.A. Supercollider
description: To the Editor:

title: France Must Pay Greenpeace $8 Million in Sinking of Ship
description: An international arbitration tribunal ordered France today to pay more than $8.1 million in damages to Greenpeace, an environmentalist and antinuclear group, for the deliberate sinking two years ago of the group's ship, the Rainbow Warrior.

title: COX TO OPEN PLAYOFF
description: The St. Louis Cardinals began their countdown to the National League playoff tonight when they named Danny Cox to pitch the opening game here against the San Francisco Giants next Tuesday, with John Tudor starting Game 2.

title: Publishing: A War Memoir by William J. Casey
description: ''The Secret War Against Hitler,'' a memoir of World War II that William J. Casey wrote before becoming Director of Central Intelligence, will be published next April by Regnery Gateway, a Washington publishing house.

title: Coming and Goings
description: Pedro Guerrero, the Los Angeles Dodgers' outfielder, suffered a sprained wrist Thursday when he attempted to save the television set in his home from being smashed during the earthquake that struck the Los Angeles area. A club spokesman said the player's availability was a ''day to day'' proposition. . . . Jimmy Mann, a right wing for the Pittsburgh Penguins, was expected to be lost to his team for at least eight weeks after surgery on his right elbow at St. Francis Hospital in Pittsburgh.

title: Darline Kulhan, Podiatrist, Marries Dr. Louis Corsaro
description: The marriage of Dr. Darline Kulhan, a podiatrist in New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Louis A. Corsaro, a pediatrician with the Katonah (N.Y.) Medical Group, took place yesterday at Alex and Henry's Restaurant in Scarsdale. Town Justice Robert McGoey of North Castle, N.Y., officiated.

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film Festival; 'Anita - Dances of Vice' by von Praunheim
description: Rosa von Praunheim's ''Anita -Dances of Vice'' is a surprisingly tame movie to be made by the German director responsible for ''It's Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, Rather the Situation in Which He Lives'' (1970) and ''A Virus Knows No Morals'' (made in 1985 and released here this year). The former is a memorably savage satire on gay liberation conformism, while the latter is a grim examination of what might be called gay liberation's aftermath, in the era of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: Teachers Approve Contract
description: New York City public school teachers have approved a new contract, with 86.5 percent of the members of the United Federation of Teachers who voted favoring the pact, a spokeswoman, Naomi Spatz, said yesterday. The contract, which gives a starting teacher an annual salary of $25,000 in the third year of the pact, was approved by 50,000 of the 70,000 members eligible to vote, she said. It allows for a $50,000 salary in the third year of the contract for a teacher with 20 years of service.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $215,000 for the quarter and the year includes income from discontinued operations of $295,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,217,000 for both the quarter and year, and extraodinary tax benefits from loss carryforward of $98,000 and $281,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Madeleine Carroll Dies at 81; Film Actress of 30's and 40's
description: Madeleine Carroll, the cosmopolitan actress of the 1930's and 1940's who starred in the Alfred Hitchcock classics ''The 39 Steps'' and ''Secret Agent'' and more than three dozen other movies, died yesterday afternoon at her home outside the resort town of Marbella, Spain, a spokesman for the Marbella Hospital Clinic said. She was 81 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Centronics in Deal
description: The Centronics Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Ekco Group Inc., based in Franklin Park, Ill., for about $124 million. Ekco, which makes bakeware, kitchen tools, gadgets and other household products, is being sold by a leveraged buyout group led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen. Centronics, based in Nashua, N.H., said the acquisition would allow the company to ''build a significant marketing-directed consumer products business.''

title: Colt Is Back Over the Line
description: Walter Murray, the Indianapolis Colts wide receiver who first joined the National Football League players' strike, then rejoined the Colts, then returned to the pickets, was back in the team's uniform today.

title: Bid Sweetened For Bow Valley
description: British Gas P.L.C. said today that it was raising its offer to $940 million (Canadian), or about $712 million (United States), to increase its stake in Canada's Bow Valley Industries to 51 percent.

title: WORK SKILL FOR MOTHERS ON WELFARE
description: If welfare reform has a future in this country, it may look something like the fourth floor of the Federation Employment and Guidance Service on West 14th Street in Manhattan. There, Lois Stewart and other single mothers with young children learn about the world of work.

title: Jersey Beach May Be Beached in Mixup
description: Tucked in a valley at the northern tip of the new Monksville Reservoir is a 500-foot-long beach that appears to be doomed before the first swimmer arrives. The state wants the beach and its 75 tons of sand dug up.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-6

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. Other rules remain in effect.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Concert: Kurt Weill
description: One felt a euphoria at Wednesday night's conclusion to the two-week Kurt Weill Festival at Merkin Concert Hall. It seemed to bounce from stage to audience and back again. What is it in this music - with its jeering, raucous tone, its studied vulgarity - that so excites our senses?

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Net loss

title: FADING MEMORIES: ALBUMS DAMAGE PHOTOS
description: The photo album, storehouse for the treasured memories of many of the nation's 64 million families, often damages the images it holds. The materials and construction of many new imported albums, as well as millions of albums purchased in years past, create a harsh environment for photographic prints, research has shown.

title: COMPUTER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $700,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $152,000 and $267,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a $778,000 forgiveness of debt. The company has recorded at June 30, 1987 $4,126,000 representing the income, net of applicable legal fees and other costs, from settlement of its litigation with Codex Corp. The net settlement amount with related to lost sales revenues amounted to $2,806,000 and has been recorded in revenues; the balance of $1,320,000, related to accrued interest, has been recorded in interest income.

title: Quick, the Ethics Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results would have increased more over a year-ago except for an increased income tax provision of 42 percent for the 1987 quarter compared with 25 percent in the 1986 quarter. The increased provision was a result of changes in investment tax credits, lower capital gains rates and other adjustments.

title: Stocks Rise in Tokyo
description: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed higher today, sparked by Thursday's rally on Wall Street, brokers said. The market index gained 140.71 points, to 25,862.45, after falling on Thursday. Turnover came to 850 million shares, down sharply from a heavy volume of 1.5 billion shares on Thursday.

title: Ushers Walk Out In Pittsburgh
description: Ushers walked off the job tonight at Three Rivers Stadium in a dispute with their employer, Spectacor Management.

title: Koch Seeks Nonprofit Groups' Aid for Schools
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he planned to urge the city's nonprofit groups to become more involved in aiding the public school system.

title: Tougher Scrutiny Seen For Local Officials, Too
description: The emergence of character as a factor in evaluating United States Presidential candidates will prompt greater scrutiny of local politicians as well, according to ethics and campaign finance officials who met here.

title: MAKING A NAME IN BREAD
description: It's called the Tom Cat Bakery, a name not chosen lightly. Noel Comess, formerly chef de cuisine at the Quilted Giraffe, explained the name of his new shop this way: ''I figured we were doing a product like no other on the market, and I didn't want people to think of it as a French bread or an Italian bread.''

title: Messier Suspended
description: Mark Messier, the Edmonton Oiler center who had 37 goals and 107 points last season, has been suspended indefinitely by Glen Sather, the team's general manager and coach, for failing to report to the team. The action came after four days of fruitless contract negotiations between Sather and Messier's father, Doug Messier, who is acting as his son's agent. Sather imposed the suspension after the agent said his son would not be reporting until he had a contract. Messier joined Paul Coffey, the Edmonton defenseman who is also holding out in a contract dispute, on the Oilers' suspended list. Messier had been scheduled to join the team Sept. 25 in Indianapolis after participation in the Canada Cup. Sather said the suspension would carry a $250-a-day fine.

title: Books of The Times; Gershwin's Music
description: GERSHWIN. By Edward Jablonski. 436 pages. Doubleday. $21.95.

title: Japan's Prince Waits and Happily Studies Gobies
description: Two months short of his 54th birthday and nestled in comfortable middle age, Crown Prince Akihito of Japan waits for his life's work to begin.

title: ABSENCE, AWARDS AND ALYSHEBA
description: There is one thoroughbred prizefight that every racing fan wants to see this year: Java Gold vs. Alysheba, at 10 or 12 furlongs on a dry track, for the undisputed championship of the nation's 3-year-olds and the Horse of the Year title.

title: FORD LEADS GROUP DEAL FOR HERTZ
description: An investor group dominated by the Ford Motor Company signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car-rental company, from the Allegis Corporation.

title: EHRLICH BOBER FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $15,000 for the quarter and $33,000 for the year.

title: A FAMOUS AVIATOR IS SAID TO HAVE DIED IN OBSCURITY IN SPAIN
description: It was never quite the mystery that still surrounds the disappearance of Amelia Earhart, but the whereabouts of Jean Batten - an aviator whose epic flights were once the focus of headlines around the world - had been a source of concern and puzzlement for five years.

title: Report of Senate Details Cuts Under Deficit Plan
description: In an effort to increase pressure for a compromise on spending cuts and new taxes, Senate leaders released a breakdown today of how much specific programs would be cut if Congress and President Reagan fail to agree on an alternative savings plan before Nov. 20.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TIBETAN PROTEST FOR INDEPENDENCE BECOMES VIOLENT
description: A march for independence by thousands of Tibetans turned violent Thursday, with demonstrators stoning the police and setting a police station afire, witnesses said today. Six people were reported killed.

title: Sessions to Leave Hospital
description: The Director-designate of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, will be released from George Washington University Medical Center Saturday, but he may rest for a week or more before going to work, law-enforcement officials said today. Mr. Sessions was hospitalized with a bleeding ulcer hours before he was to be sworn in Thursday. Officials said that it was still undetermined when he would be sworn in.

title: METS' PITCHERS BEGAN THE SLIDE
description: Pitching, which won for the Mets in 1986, lost for the Mets in 1987.

title: TO PROTECT PICTURES, KEEP THEM COOL AND DRY
description: For those who want to keep treasured photographs from deteriorating, the first step is perhaps the easiest.

title: DUKE REVIVES WITH SPURRIER
description: Steve Spurrier, the coach of the Duke team that will play Rutgers at 8 o'clock tonight in Giants Stadium, is distinctive among Heisman Trophy winners.

title: OPERA: 'THE MAN WHO MISTOOK WIFE'
description: Harry Partch's ''Revelation in the Courthouse Park,'' to be performed next week, is the big, newsworthy event of this year's American Music Theater Festival. But it will have to be pretty good to surpass the more modestly scaled but still intensely moving appeal of Michael Nyman's hourlong chamber opera ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat.'' The opera was given its United States premiere Thursday night at the Forum Theater of the WHYY Studios in Philadelphia, after two days of previews. It will continue there through Sunday, and then excerpts (one presumes extensive) will be presented in concert form by the same performers at the Guggenheim Museum in New York City Monday and Wednesday evenings.

title: Witness in Mob 'Pizza' Trial Says He Lied in Recanting Testimony
description: The mob hit man who swore last week that he had lied in court testimony against a Mafia boss reversed his story again yesterday. Appearing in Federal Court, the witness, Luigi Ronsisvalle, said that he had falsely recanted his court testimony because of death threats to his family.

title: Ford Given Private Funeral; Public Service Is Next Week
description: The family of Henry Ford 2d mourned the automobile executive at a private memorial service today, a week before a public service for the man who rescued the Ford Motor Company from near bankruptcy.

title: Legislature in Florida May Revise Gun Law
description: Bad publicity and police complaints prompted supporters of Florida's new gun law to agree today to delay carrying out a provision allowing guns to be carried openly.

title: G.E. Credit to Buy Gelco at $35 a Share
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Gelco Corporation, a management service and leasing company focusing on transportation markets, in a transaction that will ultimately cost G.E. about $414 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis India Leads in Davis Cup: Behind Vijay Amritraj and Ramesh Krishnan, India took a commanding 2-0 lead yesterday over Australia, the defending champion, in their Davis Cup tennis semifinal in Sydney. India, which has never won the prestigious international team trophy, can reach the final by winning the doubles match today or one of two singles matches tomorrow. Amritraj, 33 years old, who first played in the Davis Cup 18 years ago, defeated Wally Masur, 1-6, 6-3, 12-10, 6-4, after Krishnan, 26, beat John Fitzgerald, 6-1, 6-2, 3-6, 8-6. The winner of this three-of-five-match series will play the winner of the semifinal between Sweden and Spain in the final in December.(AP) Sweden Closing In: Mats Wilander and Stefan Edberg gave Sweden a 2-0 lead over Spain in their Davis Cup semifinal in Barcelona. Wilander beat Emilio Sanchez 8-6, 3-6, 6-0, 6-2, and Edberg defeated Javier Sanchez, Emilio's younger brother, 6-4, 6-2, 6-4. That gave Sweden a chance to wrap up the three-of-five-match competition today when Wilander and Anders Jarryd are scheduled to play doubles against Emilio Sanchez and Sergio Casal.(AP) Golf Australian Sets Course Mark: Rodger Davis of Australia fired a course-record 63 yesterday and Greg Norman needed five extra holes in a playoff as Australia, the defending champion, scrambled into the semifinal of the $1 million Dunhill Cup in St. Andrew's, Scotland. In other quarterfinals, the United States edged Japan after another playoff and Scotland beat Ireland, 2-1.(AP) Brown Ahead by Two Shots: Ken Brown of Britain shot a six-under-par 64 yesterday to take a two-shot lead after the second round of the $400,000 Southern Open golf tournament in Columbus, Ga. Brown's 36-hole total of 129 over the par-70, 6,791-yard Green Island Country Club gave the European Ryder Cup member the lead over Mike Hulbert, who had a 66 for 131.(AP) Moody Leads Seniors: Orville Moody finished off a four-under-par 66 with birdies on three of the last five holes and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Vantage Championship for seniors in Clemmons, N.C. A stroke back were Dave Hill and Gay Brewer, each with 67. (AP) Boxing Italian Wins in Upset: Gianfranco Rosi of Italy upset Lupe Aquino last night to take the World Boxing Council super-welterweight title on a unanimous 12-round decision in Perugia, Italy.(AP) Horse Racing No Crown for Mack Lobell: Napoletano took the lead for good in the final strides of the second heat of the Kentucky Futurity at the Red Mile in Lexington, Ky. yesterday, foiling Mack Lobell's bid to become the first winner of the Triple Crown of trotting in 15 years. Napoletano, driven by Bill O'Donnell, got to the end of the mile a half-length in front of Mack Lobell after a sizzling duel over the final quarter-mile in 26 2/5 seconds. The winner's time was 1:57 3/5. Completing the order of finish were Waikiki Beach, Nevele Olympian, Whata Speed, Sir Taurus, Cotton Hanover and Crown's Best.(AP)

title: EDGAR C. CAMPBELL Sr.
description: Edgar C. Campbell Sr., a court clerk and former City Council member who was one of the first blacks to wield political power in Philadelphia, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old.

title: TECH: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that for the last two years it has been in a research and development stage.

title: Policemen Sue Gooden
description: As an additional thorn for Dwight Gooden on the day after the Mets were eliminated from the division race, three members of the Tampa (Fla.) Police Department filed suit yesterday against the pitcher. The policemen are seeking $1 million apiece in damages for injuries they claim to have suffered during a scuffle last Dec. 13 when Gooden, after being stopped on a traffic violation, was charged with resisting arrest and with violence and battery on a law-enforcement officer. Gooden pleaded no contest on Jan. 23, was placed on three years' probation and ordered to perform 80 hours of community service. The three men, Cpl. James Thompson and Patrolmen Jeff Smith and Scott Wolf, were also seeking at least $5,000 apiece in compensation for emotional suffering, according to their attorney, Jeff Stull, who told The Tampa Tribune that his clients had requested a jury trial. Gooden's agent, Jim Neader, said the pitcher would have no immediate comment.

title: U.S. Moves to Fine Hotel for Employing Illegal Aliens
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service today accused a Virginia hotel of employing illegal aliens and served notice of its intent to fine the hotel $16,500. It was the first such action under the new immigration law.

title: Iran Is Said to Have Executed 2 Members of Baha'i Religion
description: Officials of the Baha'i International Community said yesterday that two members of their religion had been executed in Iran on Monday.

title: Letter: On U.S. Justice; The Case of Leonard Peltier
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Hunt for Lesson From Officers' Deadly Lovers' Quarrel
description: They were the ugly sounds of violence, sounds that police officers in certain parts of New York City would say are not uncommon.

title: U.S. Unemployment Rate Dips to 5.8%
description: The unemployment rate edged down to 5.8 percent in September, the lowest level in nearly eight years, as a substantial increase in factory jobs pointed to a fresh, long-awaited source of economic growth.

title: JAPAN WILL GIVE UP A JET FIGHTER PROJECT AND BUY FROM U.S.
description: Japan has abandoned its ambition to design and build a new home-grown jet fighter for its armed forces. Instead, it will adopt slightly modified American aircraft, Defense Minister Yuko Kuriharo announced today.

title: TIME RUNNING OUT ON VOTE FOR BORK, HIS BACKERS ADMIT
description: President Reagan stepped up his direct involvement today in the fight to win Senate confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, but he apparently failed to reverse the trend that is running strongly against his nominee.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-Net income Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: Santiago Reaches 34
description: Benito Santiago, San Diego's rookie catcher, extended his hitting streak to 34 games tonight when he doubled in the first inning against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Correction
description: The Weekender Guide in Weekend yesterday misattributed a quotation - ''My candle burns at both ends'' -in a report about an exhibition at the New York Public Library. The author was Edna St. Vincent Millay.

title: 5 MINERS RESCUED AFTER 30 HOURS
description: Five miners trapped 800 feet below ground for more than 30 hours were pulled to safety Thursday after rescuers cut a passageway through tons of timber, rock and machinery blocking a shaft.

title:
PATENTS;
Weighing Live Fish
description: LEAD: Apparatus for weighing live fish was patented this week by Manny Homen, president of Weigh-In Inc. of Tucson, Ariz. Patent No. 4,696,360 says the equipment provides rapid, accurate and efficient means to weigh a struggling live fish, for use particularly by sports fishermen in tournaments or for merchants.

title: PANEL URGING CUT IN HOURS FOR PHYSICIANS
description: The working hours of interns and residents in New York State's teaching hospitals would be substantially reduced - to a maximum of 80 hours a week - under recommendations by a key Health Department advisory committee.

title: TIGER TIE BLUE JAYS FOR DIVISION LEAD
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have begun to unravel at the most inappropriate time of the season. And tonight, their troubles continued against Detroit, the only team that can benefit from their untimely slide.

title: Bridge; Play in Albany Went Against Some Old Advice on Ruffing
description: Textbooks on play regularly advise declarers to cash side-suit winners before embarking on a crossruff. This is sound policy, but as with almost all generalizations about the game, there are some exceptions.

title: OCCUPATIONAL MEDICAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $450,000 related to two facilities. c-Net income The company said the fourth quarter results include audit adjustments of $998,000 to adjust certain balance sheet items, including adjustments for unamortized assets, and increased debt reserves.

title: TRANSIDYNE GENERAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $48,000 for the quarter and $83,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $183,748 for the quarter and $244,248 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' results also included a pre-tax gain of $9,500 from the sale of securities. The year-ago periods included pre- tax gains of $937,000 for the quarter and $203,885 for the 9 months from the sale of securities.

title: California Officials Hail Population's Response to Emergency
description: The earthquake that rocked Southern California Thursday morning gave state and local emergency officials a chance to test their best-laid plans.

title: Correction
description: The Weekender Guide report about ''The Mahabharata,'' by the Theater of Understanding, misstated performance dates. The production runs through Nov. 1 at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street.

title: Futures Markets Don't Inflate Stock Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income of $1,256,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of Baird Corp. common stock for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: NETWORKS PAY FEES DESPITE THE STRIKE
description: The players' strike notwithstanding, the television networks made a full payment of about $100 million this week to the National Football League.

title: A.C.L.U. TO ACCEPT P.L.O. SPEECH CASE
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, anticipating intense and widespread opposition among its supporters, has decided to defend the right of an agent of the Palestine Liberation Organization to run an information office here.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $22,000 for the latest quarter and $120,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Rustin Fought Quotas, Not Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Mediators Plan Meeting For NBC and Union
description: The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service has called for a meeting next week between NBC and the union representing writers, editors and technicians, who have been on strike for three months.

title: Film Festival; 'Under Satan's Sun,' On Faith and Its Testing
description: Maurice Pialat directs in an ordinary-looking style, yet he approaches film making in an extremely unconventional way. That paradox is more apparent than ever in ''Under Satan's Sun,'' the film that won this year's top prize at the Cannes Film Festival and was roundly booed for doing so.

title: TUNISIA'S LEADER REPLACES PREMIER
description: President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia today in effect named a new successor by dismissing the Prime Minister and replacing him with an army general.

title: Russian Lasers Reported Aimed At U.S. Planes
description: The Pentagon said today that a Soviet naval vessel operating in the target area for the recent Soviet missile tests in the Pacific apparently directed a laser at two American aircraft.

title: After 16 Years, Soviet Jew Is Told She Can Go to Israel
description: A prominent Jewish campaigner, denied permission to emigrate to Israel for 16 years, was told today that she could leave the Soviet Union.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
GULF SHIPPING HIT BY IRAN AND IRAQ
description: Iraqi jets and an Iranian warship attacked Persian Gulf shipping today, bringing to 375 the number of vessels attacked by Iraqi and Iranian forces since the gulf war began seven years ago, Lloyd's of London said.

title: STEP-SAVER DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a charge from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $5,973 for the quarter and a tax credit of $26,000 for the year.

title: Deaver Cites Alcoholism as Perjury Trial Defense
description: Michael K. Deaver may have given false information to a Federal grand jury because of alcoholism and use of the tranqulizer Valium, his lawyers suggested in court documents made available today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1987
description: International

title:
PATENTS;
A Power Rake
description: LEAD: A Soviet immigrant who now lives in Forest Hills, Queens, has invented a power rake. Patent No. 4,696,348, granted this week to Boris Novoselsky, says the rake is especially useful for large-scale cultivation.

title: VICTORIA CREATIONS reports earnings for Year to June 30
TREASURY DEBT ISSUES UP SHARPLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply yesterday afternoon, recouping most of the declines that occurred earlier in the week.

title: Guatemala to Meet With Rebels
description: The Government and leftist rebels announced today that they would meet next week in Madrid in the first peace talks held in the 25 years of political violence here.

title: PROGRESS IN TRADE TALKS CITED
description: American and Canadian negotiators today made what a Canadian official described as ''modest and meaningful movement'' toward a monumental free trade pact.

title: Slovak Leader Tried To Outdo the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Producing Chemical Materials
description: LEAD: AN improved method of treating organic compounds for production of chemical materials useful in medicine, agriculture and industry was patented this week. The inventor is Darryl D. DesMarteau, head of the department of chemistry at Clemson University, Clemson, S.C.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $159,140 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss

title: A Correction
description: An editing error altered the meaning of a thought in an article by Joseph Goldstein last Sunday. The sentence should have read: ''Judge Bork will not forget, as Justice John Marshall stressed in McCulloch v. Maryland, that his task will be to expound a written Constitution - 'intended to endure for ages to come, and, consequently, to be adapted to the various crises of human affairs.' ''

title: Longer Sentences Do Not Deter Crime
description: The facts of crime and punishment in the United States are staring us in the face.

title: The U.S. Wants Big Subsidies Reduced, But Canada Worries About Vulnerability
description: When American negotiators sat down in Canada's capital 16 months ago to begin free trade talks, the Canadians decorated the room with a photograph of a little girl and an elephant.

title: Filipino Civilians Uprooted By an Anti-Rebel Offensive
description: Rito Ocbian, his wife and their seven children gathered their meager belongings, including a squealing hog and three chickens, packed them in jute sacks and loaded them on a bamboo sled drawn by their water buffalo.

title: Correction
description: An article on Wednesday about comic books appealing to young adults carried an incorrect description from First Comics Inc. about its sale of television rights for one series.

title: JOHN GOES DISTANCE TO GET 13TH
description: All season, Tommy John has defied the popular belief that he was either too old or too fragile to pitch effectively for the Yankees. Last night at the Stadium, he proved it again.

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITICORP SELLING PART OFFERS HEADQUARTER
description: In another step toward recapitalizing itself after huge losses, Citicorp said yesterday that it would sell large parts of its headquarters complex to a Japanese insurer.

title: Dukakis, in Iowa, Is Contrite Over Aide's Move Against Biden
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis walked a trail of contrition through Iowa today, apologizing at almost every stop for what his campaign manager did to Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. From a high school here to a center for the elderly in Onawa, a somber Mr. Dukakis voiced his dismay at the actions of his campaign manager, John Sasso, who resigned this week after taking responsibility for circulating a videotape that helped deflate the rival Biden campaign.

title: Music: Vienna Tonkunstler
description: Having got the music of Mozart, Beethoven, Weber and Haydn out of the way, the Tonkunstler Orchestra of Vienna could settle down after intermission Thursday evening to the principal business of its program at Carnegie Hall: the bubbly, feel-good music by the brothers Johann and Josef Strauss. Immersed in the oompahs and waltzing rhythms, the ensemble and its conductor, Alfred Eschwe, loosened up like so many weight-loss advocates indulging secretly in cream puffs and chocolate.

title: Coke and Tri-Star
description: The Coca-Cola Company's board has approved a plan to spin off its entertainment holdings and merge them with the much smaller Tri-Star Pictures Inc., which it helped to start five years ago. Coca-Cola said Tri-Star's board had also approved the plan, which was announced Sept. 1. The merger must still be approved by Tri-Star shareholders and Federal regulatory agencies. It would create one of the nation's biggest entertainment concerns, worth about $3 billion.

title: SCAASI TAKES ON COLOR
description: The show opened with a zebra-striped calfskin coat rimmed in silver fox. After a few suits with fitted jackets, flaring peplums and ostentatious puffed-sleeve blouses, the key to Arnold Scaasi's fall couture collection appeared. It was a simple floor-length coat of cerise satin lined in a Renoir bouquet of orange and yellow roses. Under the coat was a floor-length dress, draped to one hip. It had an off-the-shoulder fichu neckline.

title: Bank's Main Stockholder Is Charged in Fraud
description: The principal stockholder in the Central National Bank of New York was charged yesterday with defrauding the bank, which was declared insolvent and closed last month, of $31.4 million from customers' accounts, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said.

title: Dow Edges 1.79 Higher As Volume Pulls Back
description: Stocks rose slightly yesterday, gaining some support late in the session from a strengthening bond market and a firmer dollar. The market was also bolstered by a strong demand for technology and oil issues.

title: An Alliance In Theater Is Over
description: A dispute over the allocation of financial resources and performance space has led to a split between the American Place Theater, one of Off Broadway's longest-lived companies, and the Women's Project, one of its best-known programs.

title: In His Despair, Rabbi's Strength Revives Temple
description: Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer has his cheerier moments.

title: Berisford Bidder To Press Takeover
description: Associated British Foods P.L.C. said it would go ahead with a $1.24 billion takeover bid for S.&W. Berisford P.L.C. even though the target company has rejected the offer. Associated, a bakery products concern that already owns 23.7 percent of Berisford, a commodity and sugar company, made its offer Thursday.

title: PHARMACONTROL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The increase in revenue in fiscal 1987 was attributed to the May 29 acquisition of Private Formulations Inc. Consolidated results for Pharmacontrol included about four weeks of operations of Private Formulations.

title: TSB Offers $1.3 Billion To Acquire Hill Samuel
description: TSB Group P.L.C., owner of the Trustee tee Savings Banks, which were formed 174 years ago as philanthropic savings banks for poor Scots, said today that it had agreed to buy Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the beleaguered merchant bank, for $:777 million, or about $1.3 billion.

title: Democrats Lose Place on Ballot In L.I. Election
description: Five Democratic candidates for State Supreme Court on Long Island, including two sitting judges, were removed from the election ballot yesterday by the State Board of Elections because Democratic leaders failed to file their nominations on time.

title: LEECO DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year results include $100,000 for sale of certain product distribution rights.

title:
PATENTS;
Inventions to Aid Nuclear Industry
description: LEAD: Inventions for the nuclear industry were patented this week by people in the United States, France, West Germany, Japan and Switzerland.

title: 2 Assert E.M.S. Delay Caused Death of Friend
description: Two New York City hospital employees asserted yesterday that a friend of theirs died after an ambulance failed to arrive at his Harlem home yesterday morning despite repeated calls for about 90 minutes to the city's emergency telephone number.

title: Austria Investigating Iran Arms
description: Iran has probably obtained 110 heavy Austrian artillery guns destined for Brazil and Libya over the last two years, apparently in violation of Austrian law, the Austrian Foreign Minister said today.

title: ADTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OVONIC IMAGING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
David Proffitt Is Dead at 96; Ex-Leader of Presbyterians
description: David W. Proffitt, a former leader of the United Presbyterian Church in the United States, died Wednesday at his home in Maryville, Tenn. He was 96 years old.

title: Bid to Exclude Parts of Zaccaro's Past
description: The attorney for John A. Zaccaro filed a letter with a State Supreme Court justice yesterday that contains information about his client's past that he says should not be introduced by the prosecution in Mr. Zaccaro's extortion trial.

title: About the Homeless Men on My Doorstep
description: ''Hey, sweet lady, no smile today?''

title: Resolution Keeps Alive Hopes of S.I. Port Foes
description: Opponents of the Navy base planned on Staten Island as the home port of the battleship Iowa have failed in an attempt to block the use of $10.5 million in city money for the project.

title: The Front Line of Defense and Peace
description: Unless Congress decrees otherwise, the United States will soon be closing 15 overseas diplomatic posts, including two embassies, and laying off 1,300 employees from a State Department payroll of 22,000. Congress proposes to slash a crippling 23 percent, or $767 million, from the department's budget. And this is being inflicted by the same lawmakers who piously bewail Washington's declining global influence and risky dependence on cheaper-to-hire foreign nationals.

title: 42d Street Shuttle: Cars for Reviled Line
description: Gleaming stainless-steel subway cars will have their debut today on the 42d Street shuttle, the latest attempt to spruce up a nearly 70-year-old line that opened to bad reviews and has mostly been getting them since.

title: New Pretoria Sanctions Are Denied by Reagan
description: President Reagan rejected additional economic sanctions against South Africa today, prompting sharp criticism from some members of Congress and promises of tougher measures against the white minority Government.

title: A New Leaf (and Old Ones) at Moscow Book Fair
description: LEAD: More than 40 English-language books were confiscated at this year's Moscow Book Fair, which was held last month. Yet it was an enormously exciting fair for those who see publishing as a marketplace of ideas. This was a paradox in the extreme, revealing in microcosm the fundamental contrasts in this most nationalist of nations, which proudly publicizes glasnost while contradicting its new openness with gratuitous acts of injustice.

title: New York City's Jobless Rate Falls to 17-Year Low
description: The unemployment rate in New York City fell to its lowest monthly level in 17 years last month, dropping to 4.5 percent in September from 5.1 percent in August, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Eating Out With Comrades
description: During the quarter of my life that I have spent abroad, I have learned a good many things that have eased my passage, though some of them, I think, may have taxed my soul. I have, for instance, been able to secure four empty seats on 747's much of the time. I have broken the blockades of desk clerks and have gone over the heads of hotel managers to secure shelter.

title: TROLLEY CENTENNIAL TRUNDLES IN EAST HAVEN
description: A TROLLEY-CAR parade, a re-enactment of a comic strip about trolleys and, of course, trolley rides highlight next weekend as the Shore Line Trolley Museum kicks off a yearlong celebration marking the 100th anniversary of trolleys.

title: SEARCHING FOR PASSION
description: Russell Baker's comments on too little passion came too close for comfort to me, and brought a tear of recognition. The piece spoke to me of my political life, my social life and, particularly disheartening, my romantic life, with its cool acceptance of a physical relationship without a real commitment. It spoke of what has become a great source of discontent deep within me, where the human sense of justice insists on right or wrong rather than accepting that everything about us has a gray area.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HAPPY BIRTHDAYS
description: LEAD: CHILDREN are home from camp, school is back in session and the birthday party circuit has begun again. Mothers are wracking their brains for clever ideas, kids are thinking up invitation lists, grandparents are being summoned from the city and other points to join the celebration. On a busy weekend, a youngster might have two, even three birthday parties on the social calendar.

title: OAXACA'S NIGHT OF THE RADISHES
description: When you drop out of the clouds into Oaxaca, a gentle valley between some fairly serious mountains, you have the feeling you've found a secret that lies behind closed doors, something akin to that ripple of discovery in ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.'' And if it is December, you fall into the soft grace of a summer not punishingly hot, but light-struck and temperate.

title: Maria Ivogun, Leading Singer Of German Opera for 20 Years
description: Maria Ivogun, the leading coloratura soprano of German opera in the period between the World Wars, died yesterday. She was 95 years old and lived in Beatenberg, Switzerland.

title: GUILD HALL OPENS '2D SEASON'
description: IS there theater life in East Hampton after the summer folks have gone? Kelly Patton, the artistic director for public programs at the John Drew Theater, is all set to prove there is.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I am deeply shocked and grieved by the loss of life and the persons injured during the recent demonstrations by the Tibetan people against Chinese rule.'' - The Dalai Lama. [ 1:4. ]

title: INVENTING THE FUTURE
description: Nicholas P. Negroponte predicts ''Newspapers as we know them won't exist.'' The computer age will bring newspapers ''printed for a readership of one,'' delivered on computer screens. Mr. Negroponte may meet some resistance.

title: A HOT LOCAL INDUSTRY: SELLING POLITICIANS
description: POLITICS, Will Rogers commented in the 1930's, ''has got so expensive it takes a lot of money even to get beat with.'' The Rogers observation is even more accurate in the 1980's. In the last two years more than $450 million has been spent on Congressional elections alone. And $500 million was spent on races for state offices.

title: Bush, on the Defensive, Ends Mission to Europe
description: As Vice President Bush greeted NATO ambassadors here Friday with a chipper ''How are you, pal?'' one representative inquired how his 10-day diplomatic mission to Europe had gone?

title: SUFFOLK DEBATES TOXIC-ASH BILL
description: LEAD: THE weeks of debate over the Suffolk County Legislature's toxic-ash testing bill will culminate Oct. 13, when the Legislature is scheduled to put the measure to a vote.

title: MOVIES
description: Heartbreak Ridge Produced and directed by Clint Eastwood. Starring Mr. Eastwood, Marsha Mason, Eileen Heckart. 1986. Warner Home Video. 130 minutes. $89.95.

title: FICTION
description: FIRST BORN. By Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $17.97.) Doris Mortman, author of the best seller ''Circles,'' clearly believes that more of everything is better. Her new novel's locales stretch from Phoenix to Paris, her descriptions of fashion and decors take up a considerable portion of the book's 674 pages, and she has created not one but four heroines, all named after the grandmother they share. The first of these Frances Rebeccas, known as Jinx, is a young hotel executive obsessed with the idea of finding her father, Ben Rostov, who abandoned her and her mother when she was a baby. Although her mother pretends that Ben is dead, Jinx discovers he is still alive and is determined to make him acknowledge her. Violently opposed to her plan is Becca, daughter of Ben's second marriage, a competitive socialite who also learns of the past her father has kept secret and resents sharing his love with a half sister. Frankie is plagued with familial problems as well. Her mother, Ben's sister, is a conniving former movie star who takes over Frankie's career as a model and actress with a ruthlessness that makes ''Mommie Dearest'' seem like a primer for maternal devotion. Finally, Cissie, another of Ben's nieces and a big-time boutique manager, suffers from spousal rather than parental neglect. Her husband is a once-idealistic politician whose romantic escapades recall recent headlines. The story follows the women for almost two decades, through accidents, affairs and even a murder plot. Though the result is hardly literary - neither Ms. Mortman nor her editor appears to know the difference between ''compliment'' and ''complement'' or ''peak'' and ''pique'' - the book provides some airy weekend amusement.

title: AMHERST SWAMPED BY BOWDOIN, 29-7
description: Greg Bohannon rushed for 116 yards today to lead Bowdoin to a 29-7 victory over Amherst.

title: Not Guilty Pleas in Murder
description: Two people have pleaded not guilty to charges of kidnapping and murdering a member of a prominent family who was buried alive in a foiled extortion attempt. Daniel J. Edwards, 30 years old, and Nancy D. Rish, 25, both of nearby Bourbonnais, were indicted by a Kankakee County grand jury earlier Thursday and then entered their pleas in the killing of Stephen B. Small.

title: CAMPAIGN REFORMS STUDIED IN SUFFOLK
description: LEAD: REFORMS in the way political candidates and parties raise money for campaigns, a hot topic across the state, would be nowhere more sweeping than in Suffolk County, under proposals that an ethics committee has recommended to the County Legislature.

title: TOKYO
description: AN EVENING OUT IN Tokyo can be many things. For Japanese from the provinces, where everything closes more or less at dusk, it may be the bright lights along the Ginza. For Tokyo businessmen, especially if they are entertaining clients, it may be an evening at a geisha establishment followed, perhaps, by a visit to an expensive bar.

title: KATHERINE ASHTON TO WED BRIAN YOUNG
description: The engagement of Katherine Ashton and Brian David Young has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Ashton of New York. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Young of Wilmington, Del. The couple plan to marry next month.

title: 'Quilters': Swatches Of Overstatement
description: NOT so sensible or cheering, in selection or in execution, is the WPI Theater's first production this season, the pseudomusical, ''Quilters.'' Here is a case of a small theater company overextended.

title: A LA CARTE
description: ALL-YOU-CAN-EAT buffets conjure up visions of drab motel dining rooms crowded with hungry bargain hunters. The Garden City Hotel's seafood buffet shatters this stereotype.

title: City Hall Notes; Yankees-City Agreement Goes Into Extra Innings
description: Vincent Tese, the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, is evidently a positive thinker. In September 1986, he announced that an agreement in principle had been reached with the New York Yankees, under which the baseball team would extend its lease at Yankee Stadium until the year 2022 and the city and state would build a new garage and other amenities.

title: Soviet Courts South America With an Eye for Trade
description: A SHIFT of focus has appeared in Moscow's relations with Latin America.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Public Development Corporation; An Agency With Large Successes in Small Projects
description: ALTHOUGH song and dance is a new endeavor for the New York City Public Development Corporation, its renovated rehearsal hall in downtown Brooklyn may yet emerge as a hit.

title: Paris When It Shimmers
description: HOW WONDERFUL TO SEE RAINY STREETS once more, wrote the Goncourt brothers in their joint diary after a stay in intolerably sunny Rome. The Paris winter sky reflects wet sidewalks, or seems to, gray on gray. A photograph by Alfred Stieglitz, ''A Snapshot, Paris,'' 1913, has it, exactly. There is a print of the photograph in the Musee d'Orsay. When you leave the museum and walk up Rue de Bellechasse, you are still in the picture.

title: New Setback for a Costly Bomber
description: WHEN news first reached the Pentagon on Monday that a B-1B bomber had crashed in Colorado on a low-level training flight, officials could not help but suspect the worst.

title: Cape Ann, Where Corners Are Vistas
description: LEAD: Samuel Chamberlain, that dedicated documentor of New England scenery and architecture, wrote of Cape Ann that ''a more varied and enchanted stretch of shore could hardly be found on the Atlantic seaboard.'' Although a good deal more built-up than it was when he wrote almost 50 years ago, this small corner of Massachusetts, bulging into the Atlantic 40 miles northeast of

title: Mexico Asks the Candidate's Name
description: Amid growing public impatience, leaders of Mexico's ruling party gathered at their headquarters here today for a meeting that is expected to pave the way for a formal announcement of the party's candidate for President in next year's election.

title: MISS BALDWIN WEDS R. E. ZIMMERMAN
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen Louise Baldwin, the daughter of Mrs. Frederic Houston Williams of New York and Cedric Benjamin Baldwin of Honolulu, to Richard Ervin Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ervin Zimmerman of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy officiated.

title: 'Dying' Waterbury Fights Its Way Back
description: WHEN Kim and William Madden sold their Danbury house this year and moved to a new three-bedroom, $130,000 home in Naugatuck, their families and friends were apprehensive. ''They told us that Naugatuck is next to Waterbury - that it's a bad area,'' Mrs. Madden said. ''We love it.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sioux Falls, S.D.;
Mixed-Use Near a Mall
description: LEAD: LLOYD CLARKE, a developer based in West Des Moines, Iowa, is sinking $50 million into 100 acres next to the biggest shopping draw in South Dakota.

title: TOURISM PROMOTERS HAIL A BANNER YEAR
description: LEAD: IT'S difficult to calculate exactly how many people visited Long Island last summer, but if the attendance at Jones Beach is any indication, it was indeed a healthy summer from Malverne to Montauk.

title: Forgotten Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RUTGERS WADES TO ITS 500TH VICTORY
description: A storm, complete with swirling winds and relentless rain, reduced tonight's game between Rutgers and Duke to the basics, elevating simple execution to an art form. As a result, Henry Henderson ended more than 54 minutes of minimalist football with no small thing of beauty as he plunged 2 yards for the game's only score and a 7-0 victory for Rutgers.

title: BROWN DEFEATS PRINCETON, 13-7
description: Kirk Little ran for 109 yards and one touchdown today to spark Brown to a 13-7 Ivy League victory over Princeton. The victory raised the Bruins' record to 3-0 over all and 2-0 in the league. Princeton is 2-1 and 1-1.

title: OPPORTUNITY SEEN IN SOVIET CHANGES
description: A bipartisan group of 40 prominent Americans, including advisers to several presidential candidates, has expressed concern that the United States and other Western countries are failing ''to respond creatively to the opportunities offered by the new directions in Soviet policy.''

title: WOLFF MEETS A FELLOW TRIUMVIR
description: LEAD: HUGH WOLFF, music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, met for the first time here last weekend with the conductor, performer and scholar Christopher Hogwood to discuss the future of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra.

title: NEW MATERIALS FOR SPEAKERS
description: THE TENSION BETWEEN traditionalists and innovators enlivens many areas of endeavor, including the perennially polemical field of loudspeaker design. Both camps are well represented among current models, but conventional designs often go unremarked. This is regrettable because quite a few such speakers are sonically very satisfying.

title: Bangkok Hotels
description: To the Editor: Marian Burros's ''Living in Luxury in Bangkok'' (Travel, July 19) brought to mind my experiences at the Oriental Hotel and the Sheraton Royal Orchid.

title: 2 Queensboro Bridge Ramps to Close for a Year
description: Two entrance and exit ramps at the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge will be closed for a year for repairs, the city's Department of Transportation said yesterday.

title: THE APPARITION OF NORTHERNNESS
description: One dark wet November afternoon a few years ago, I flew in a small plane from Copenhagen to Aarhus, Denmark, and landed in a cold and pelting storm. The wind drove more powerfully than any wind I had ever known before; it struck with a mythic moan, like that of the wind in the nursery rhyme: ''The North Wind will blooowww, and soon we'll have snooowww.'' Afterward, shivering over tea in the refuge of a snug little hotel, I looked around the dining room, all shining mahogany, and felt myself a desolate stranger. I was traveling alone. The hotel had once been a way station for missionaries heading for foreign parts; no New Yorker, I thought, could be at ease in such a place. I was banished, lost. I ached with forlornness. The people in the dining room seemed enviably at home. They shuffled their newspapers and hardly spoke, and when they did, the alien syllables shut me decisively out.

title: Peter Brook Creates a Nine-Hour Epic
description: IN HIS LOFT IN A WORKING-CLASS SECTION OF Paris, Peter Brook, the British theater director famous for his ''Marat-Sade,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and his more recent, controversial ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' sits at a white enamel table in his kitchen drinking Perrier water. Photographs of his wife, the actress Natasha Parry, and their two children, Irina and Simon, now in their 20's and pursuing film careers, hang on the whitewashed walls. The loft, hidden by an alley and numerous passageways, is Brook's hideaway, and it is sparse, serene and casual.

title: BUILDING BRIDGES THROUGH WORLD SPORT: U.S. PURSUES 1994 WORLD CUP SOCCER
description: LAST Wednesday in Zurich the United States took the first step in an ambitious plan to bring the world's biggest sporting event to America.

title: CHRISTOPHER STOUT, A BANKER, IS WED TO LISA C. ULRICH
description: At the First Congregational Church in Chappaqua, N.Y., Lisa Caroline Ulrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Ulrich of Chappaqua, was married yesterday to Christopher Kellogg Stout, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Prentice K. Stout of Wakefield, R.I. The Rev. Richard Ryder performed the ceremony.

title: INSPECTING CHIMNEYS AND FIREPLACES
description: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces. The heating season is over, acids formed by combustion residues have not yet had a chance to corrode chimney parts seriously and plenty of time is available for repairs before cold weather sets in again.

title: America's Debt to Japanese-Americans
description: Through two world wars in which the United States and Germany were adversaries, anti-German feelings ran clear through society. In World War I, hamburger was renamed Salisbury steak and sauerkraut was called Liberty cabbage. In World War II, Spike Jones and his band regularly spit in Der Fuhrer's face over the radio. But the Government never came close to locking up German-Americans as security risks.

title: Music: 'Influence of Jazz'
description: THE International Society for Contemporary Music opened its 1987-88 season Thursday at Symphony Space with a program tracing ''The Influence of Jazz'' in compositions for chamber ensembles, soloists, electronics and tape. It was a diverse, uneven, but frequently illuminating evening, especially when composers and performers penetrated beneath the surfaces of jazz to grapple with some of the music's processes.

title: After a Rocky Past, New York City's Pension Systems Prosper
description: New York City's public employee pension systems have made a strong recovery since their financial soundness was seriously questioned in the early 1970's, according to a consensus of experts and public officials who monitor and administer the systems.

title: Headliners; Self-Defense
description: Perhaps at one time Karen Straw had thought about saving her marriage. But in her last confrontation with her husband, she was mainly concerned about saving her life. Ms. Straw would testify later that her husband, Clifton, had beaten her frequently, beginning five months after their wedding in 1981. And, as many battered wives have complained, the law offered little protection. Ms. Straw finally moved away, but not far enough. She said her husband broke into her apartment last Dec. 18, and, after a night of violence during which he raped her in front of her two children, she stabbed him in the chest. He died; she was charged with murder. Last week, in a decision cheered by battered women and their advocates, a jury in Queens ruled that she had acted in self-defense.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HOME GROUND, by Lynn Freed. (Penguin, $7.95.) By casting Ruth Frank, the narrator of this novel of South Africa, as a member of a family of theater people, the author provides ''a potent metaphor'' for the stage-managed world of apartheid, Janette Turner Hospital said here last year. ''What is extraordinary about this book is its perspective. . . . Lynn Freed's guileless child-narrator takes us inside the neurosis'' of the country. THE WELL-TEMPERED ANGLER, by Arnold Gingrich. Illustrated by John Groth. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) The arts of editing and fly-fishing have much in common: they require a passion for precision, a patience for detail and an appreciation for solitude. It's not surprising, then, that a literature of fishing has emerged, which includes Izaak Walton's ''Compleat Angler'' (1653) and, more recently, Norman Maclean's novella ''A River Runs Through It.'' When Arnold Gingrich, who was the publisher of Esquire and one of its most talented editors, contributed to the genre in 1965, his book was praised by one reviewer as ''a joy and a delight.'' The prose is written with a ''disarming simplicity and artless ease that plainly shows . . . how long and lovingly the man must have toiled over it.'' GROUP SEX: A Romantic Comedy, by Ann Arensberg. (Washington Square Press/Pocket Books, $5.95.) Some editors, particularly those like Frances Girard who work at small publishing houses, might argue that the job requires a tolerance for abuse that borders on masochism. Frances, who is abused by her authors, her colleagues and her landlady, seeks transcendence through an affair with a mad director of avant-garde plays, who ends up abusing her. Last year Tama Janowitz said here that the plot of the novel irked her but the book ''rings true.'' The author ''has a talent for entertainment and wit.'' The same publisher has reissued Ann Arensberg's first novel, SISTER WOLF ($5.95), the story of a woman who loves animals more than people and lives alone on her own private wildlife sanctuary in the Berkshires. In 1981, The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt called the book ''highly original, extravagantly romantic, intensely imagined. . . . [ It ] leaves a deep impression on one's memory.'' THE GREAT CHINESE REVOLUTION: 1800-1985, by John King Fairbank. (Bessie/Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.50.) Having long established his credentials as a Sinologist, John King Fairbank decided that as ''an ex-professor who is not up for tenure, and who doesn't care about reputation,'' he was entitled to engage in ''a bit of irresponsibility.'' Abandoning footnotes and other academic accouterments, Mr. Fairbank draws bold, sweeping parallels between the China of today and its recent dynastic past. ''Though the result can be savored by scholarly connoisseurs,'' Frederic Wakeman Jr. said here last year, the book is ''meant to be appreciated by general readers. . . . The style is brisk, the historical examples are vivid, and the generalizations are both profound and provocative.'' WORLD WITHOUT END, AMEN, by Jimmy Breslin. (Penguin, $4.95.) When this novel about a corrupt, alcoholic cop from Queens who visits his homeland in Northern Ireland was published in 1973, our reviewer, Harvey Gardner, said Jimmy Breslin's tough, wise-guy style seemed inappropriate to ''the horrors of Belfast and Derry.'' But on his own turf, the author captured ''a New York idiom with a shrewdness all his own.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Breslin's first novel, THE GANG THAT COULDN'T SHOOT STRAIGHT ($4.50). The story of feuding Brooklyn Mafiosi is a ''hilarious put-on about internecine friction within a Cosa Nostra family,'' one reviewer said in 1969. RE-MAKING LOVE: The Feminization of Sex, by Barbara Ehrenreich, Elizabeth Hess and Gloria Jacobs. (Anchor/Doubleday, $8.95.) Beginning with Beatlemania, sexual liberation has been more a women's than a men's revolution, the authors argue, and one that is often at odds with feminism as well as fundamentalism. ''This intelligent, thought-provoking social history makes very lively reading,'' our reviewer, Judith Viorst, said last year, though she thought the authors went too far in celebrating casual sex. DARK ARROWS: Great Stories of Revenge, edited by Alberto Manguel. (Clarkson N. Potter, $10.95.) ''Life being what it is, one dreams of revenge,'' Paul Gauguin says in an epigraph to this strange mix of stories. Using one of the more regrettable yet powerful of human instincts as a theme, the anthologist, Alberto Manguel, binds together such disparate authors as E. L. Doctorow, Rudyard Kipling, Nadine Gordimer, Jorge Luis Borges, William Trevor and Robert Louis Stevenson. In 1985, one reviewer said the book was ''excellent'' and should appeal to ''a very wide audience. . . . We are all greatly indebted to Manguel's exceptional skill.'' STALIN: The Man and His Era, by Adam B. Ulam. (Beacon, $15.95.) More than any one man, Joseph Stalin is responsible for the totalitarian monolith that Mikhail Gorbachev is chipping away at. This comprehensive book by one of America's pre-eminent Soviet scholars ''is much more than a biography,'' Paul Avrich said in these pages in 1974. ''It is also a history'' and ''will make instructive reading for specialist and layman alike.'' METROPOLIS: New York as Myth, Marketplace, and Magical Land, by Jerome Charyn. (Avon, $8.95.) The novelist's nonfiction portrait of New York City includes among its many characters Mayor Koch, the artist Julian Schnabel and the spider lady of Times Square. It is a ''roller coaster-written, hypnotic, ambitious, often brilliant, often utterly wrongheaded and fascinating book,'' Daniel Stern said here last year. ''It is delightful to come across a volume that is at once a metaphysics and a poetics of city life.''

title: A 'Bright Adventurer' in American Music
description: PROUD AND IMPROBABLE, THE Watts Towers thrust out of a slum neighborhood in Los Angeles. Constructed by a poor, Italian-born laborer, Simon Rodia, they are classic examples of ritualistic folk art, spires pieced together by hand from Coke bottles, seashells and every sort of found object -also known as junk - that Mr. Rodia could lay his hands on. They are airy and fanciful, yet built as solid as a modern skyscraper. When he had finally finished his towers, after decades of labor, Mr. Rodia simply moved on.

title: Big Business Under the Big Top
description: LEAD: EIGHTEEN elephants barreled down an outdoor runway from their tents, veered into the backstage of the St. Louis Arena last month and staggered to a halt. Kneeling so that sequined riders could clamber aboard, they rambled onto the circus floor and filled the three rings of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus.

title: Barefoot Hotels Come Close To Asia's Soul
description: We were well on our way to missing the heart of Asia before we got lost in Bangkok.

title: 'The Middle Ages' at the McCarter
description: ''IT'S like some movie,'' exclaims Eleanor in disbelief, when Barney, having gone AWOL from the Navy, sneaks in through the window of an exclusive club just to disrupt her wedding party - and to carry her away.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STING OF THE BEE. By Seth Rolbein. (Joan Kahn/ St. Martin's, $16.95.) When 26-year-old Martinson Sanders, a black American assistant curator in a Cambridge, Mass., library, arrives in Montego Bay, he is mistaken by local hustlers for a tourist. He is in Jamaica, however, not for sun, fun and ganja, but to visit the dying father he has barely known.

title: A SPICE OF BRAZIL: AMADO'S TALES
description: Brazil is so large, so varied and so unfinished that books about the country, both literary and academic, tend to offer a glimpse of a region or a slice of the past rather than a global vision of the future or an all-illuminating insight into the present. There are innumerable tomes about the Amazon, for example, but they principally mirror the country's chaotic rush to colonize and exploit its hinterlands. There are also treatises about Brazil's long struggle to achieve political stability, but they tell little about the lives of real people.

title: INSIDE
description: New Brand of Football Pro football, of a sort, starts up again today as the N.F.L. tries to do what it has never done: continue play despite a players' strike. Some non-striking regulars will join replacement players; striking players are expected to man picket lines at the stadiums. Section 5.

title: COLUMBIA TIES THE RECORD FOR MOST LOSSES IN A ROW
description: As expected, Columbia tied a record it doesn't want or need, losing yesterday to Penn, 23-0, despite some early moments of hope for their followers. The defeat was the Lions' 34th in a row, which equals the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I record set by Northwestern from 1979-82.

title: U.S. Refines Its Eligibility Rules for the Indian Health Service
description: New rules setting more precise eligibility requirements for people receiving medical treatment from the Indian Health Service have been announced by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Troubling Signs Over Antarctica
description: EVERY year when sunlight returns to the Antarctic, scientists can chart a thinning patch in the earth's ozone sunscreen. Every year the measurements are more precise and more ominous, and this year they were worse than ever.

title: Life in a Metal Box In Alaskan Tundra
description: OLD shipping containers - 8-by-24-foot metal boxes - were being rented as apartments for $200 a month in Bethel, Alaska, with no shortage of tenants.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: For a half-day outing in Madrid appealing to sightseers and art lovers alike, I recommend a visit to the Spanish Museum of Contemporary Art followed by a walk in West Park. The museum is on Avenida Juan de Herrera in University City in the northwest sector of Madrid (not on the Paseo de Recoletos as reported in ''What's Doing in Madrid,'' July 5). Those feeling mildly adventurous could try the clean and well-maintained subway (the fare is 40 cents) as an alternative to the cab. A short trip on the yellow line from midcity to the end-of-the-line Moncloa station brought us out at the Plaza de la Moncloa where the Calle de la Princesa becomes the Avenida del Arco de la Victoria. From the plaza the museum is a 10-minute walk along Triumphal Arch Avenue with West Park on the left followed by a left turn onto Juan de Herrera; the museum is at the corner.

title: New Jersey Drivers Fret Over the Cost Of Their Insurance
description: NEW Jerseyans have known for some time that they pay the highest auto insurance premiums in the country. But as the cost continues to rise, while neighboring states seem able to restrain increases, the high price of coverage is emerging as an important political issue.

title: Miss Those Witch Hunts?
description: ''Remember, there once was a Congress,'' said President Reagan last week to The Washington Times, ''in which they had a committee that would investigate even one of their own members if it was believed that that person had Communist involvement or Communist leanings. Well, they've done away with those committees,'' he continued. ''That shows the success of what the Soviets were able to do in this country with making it unfashionable to be anti-Communist.''

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch last Sunday about Bob Woodward's new book on the Central Intelligence Agency erroneously suggested the sequence of reports on indirect American links to a car bombing in Lebanon in March 1985. The Washington Post first disclosed the links on May 12, 1985; The New York Times's reporting, which appeared the next day, confirmed that of The Post.

title: THE SNOW ABOVE, THE SAND BELOW
description: As a New Yorker transplanted to California in the mid-1970's, I have rarely missed the traditional cycle of East Coast seasons, least of all winter. But winter is now my favorite time of year - a season when southern California's skies, mountains, beaches, even man-made landscapes, seem renewed.

title: Voters Will Decide Fate of Nuclear Plant in Maine
description: Voters have twice rejected the idea that Maine's only nuclear power plant is too dangerous to operate, but a plan to dispose of high-level radioactive waste in Maine has created such a backlash that a third vote to shut the reactor may pass.

title: LISA B. BRINKMAN ENGAGED TO WED
description: Richard Gene Brinkman of Wilton, Conn., and Jensen Beach,. Fla., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa Benson Brinkman, to Michael Charles Jensen Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jensen of New York and Peekskill, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LITTLE MISUNDERSTANDINGS OF NO IMPORTANCE. By Antonio Tabucchi. Translated by Frances Frenaye. (New Directions, $16.95.) How ambiguities, so-called ''little misunderstandings of no importance,'' determine the way things happen is the theme of this outstanding collection of 11 short stories by the Italian writer Antonio Tabucchi.

title: Sailing Again Legendary Gulfs and Seas
description: To the Editor:

title: Costlier Insurance Said to Cover Less Liability
description: Liability insurance is costing more and covering less, a researcher on insurance law reports.

title: Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine Part 2
description: Legendary cities, from Camelot to San Francisco, including:

title: UPDATING MOTHER GOOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Replaces Moir
description: A DAY after Charles Moir agreed to step down as Virginia Tech's basketball coach in the wake of the school's discovery of National Collegiate Athletic Association violations in his program, his assistant and former player, Frankie Allen, was named interim coach. Moir, who compiled a 213-119 record over 11 seasons, resigned on Friday after signing an agreement that The Roanoke Times & World News said would bring him $250,000, about what he would have earned in salary and extras over the remaining two years of his contract.

title: Lost Cities of Britain: The Quest for Camelot
description: THERE ARE IN BRITAIN VANISHED cities, lost villages, disappeared kingdoms even, some with their names still on the map. Trying to reach them isn't quite as hopeless as trying to reach the rainbow's end, but the point at which their legend and their geography meet is sure to be buried in a thicket of poetry. Digging into both the literature and the earth can produce a few hard facts, although one soon comes to accept that these much pined-for places can exist only in the imagination. Hence the centuries of storytelling, which keeps them alive when they are no more.

title: PRE-COLUMBIAN SCULPTURES
description: THE Lehman College Art Gallery's present attraction is a group of small sculptures, pottery and textiles. Most are pre-Columbian, the rest are African or Melanesian and all were drawn from the college's Testut-Obstfield Collection. On view through Oct. 24, it is a show with no title and precious little documentation and, confined to the smaller of the gallery's two spaces, it could easily be overlooked. This would be a pity, because while the collection may not be in the top 10 of its kind, it contains some choice items.

title: WE KICKED THE TIRES, AND A WHOLE LOT MORE
description: THE ads for end-of-the-year automobile sales appeared simultaneously with our nine-year-old chariot playing dead in the garage. High-tech resuscitation I knew, would be painful and cost-ineffective. I muttered about pouring money into a bottomless pit. My husband resorted to selective deafness, until, suddenly a week later, he jumped up from his desk chair and appropos of nothing, asked, ''Well, are we buying a new car or what?''

title: Bucharest: Between Two Worlds
description: It used to be called the Paris of the Balkans, and it is still possible to see why, at least in part: the broad, tree-lined avenues and the buildings designed by French Beaux-Arts architects make Bucharest one of the handsomest cities in Eastern Europe. But the animation, the excitement and, of course, the showy upper class are long gone.

title: AS ACADEMICS IN U.S. SEE IT, ALL SOVIET TV IS EDUCATIONAL
description: EACH day, at Columbia University and at more than a dozen other academic and research institutions around the nation, people gather in front of television sets for another broadcast day.

title: West Milford Tops Orange
description: Shannon Walker had a 16-yard touchdown run and Mark Layton followed with a conversion pass to Andy Kulawiak with 7 minutes left yesterday to give West Milford a 16-15 victory over Orange in Orange, N.J. The winning drive for West Milford (1-0-1) covered 61 yards in 8 plays following a punt.

title: A KINGDOM WAS BUILT OF CHICKENS AND CHORES
description: THE cock crowed and those who overslept the dawn sighed. There was little time left to collect the winter's eggs and seek the warmth behind the big barn doors. And once departing, time returns no more.

title: IONA SOBRIETY PROGRAM ADDRESSES A LOCAL ISSUE
description: SOME students at Iona College here will begin a ''Week on the Wagon'' tomorrow in an effort to focus attention on alcohol abuse, amid growing community concern about activities in the nearby North Avenue bar area.

title: Bush Supporters Drop Challenge in Michigan
description: Supporters of Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign have abandoned a plan to challenge a conservative coalition that controls the state Republican Party.

title: MY GRANDFATHER, LEONID ANDREYEV: HEARD AGAIN, LOUD AND CLEAR
description: AS a child I lived with my parents in a small modern apartment in a remote suburb of Paris. My father's study, with its single window overlooking well-tended vegetable gardens, was a sunny, quiet room, walled with books and journals.
