The thin, light-colored ones were collections of contemporary poetry in French and Russian. There were heavier books in dark bindings, among them four identical volumes bound in violet cloth. My father told me that these were the works of his father, my grandfather, which I would read when I was older. In the meantime I could look at pictures of him and of my father as a young boy. I spent hours leafing through albums and holding up glass plates to the light. They opened for me the world my father had known when he was a child.

title: 'MOTOR AGE' TOWN THRIVES IN THE SPACE AGE
description: LEAD: ONLY 10 percent of this planned Bergen County community was built the way it was envisioned in the 1920's, but it was enough to let Radburn survive the Great Depression and several real-estate booms.

title: The Dutch Repolish A Small, Precious Gem of a Museum
description: THE RECENT REOPENING OF the Mauritshuis in The Hague after a five-year closure is an event of international importance. It was heightened by the arrival of the new acquisitions (18 from the present year alone), each one of which is conspicuous for the cockade of red, white and blue ribbon that it temporarily bears. But what is most in evidence is the rehabilitation of the Mauritshuis itself, which was built 350 years ago and had begun to show its age. The five years were well spent, and where the great town house had grown sad and slack, it now sparkles.

title: IN FROM THE COLD
description: Couple of years ago, after Director of Central Intelligence William Casey threatened to try to jail editors and reporters who dared to print information stamped ''secret,'' I received a call from a Federal law enforcement source.

title: LEGENDARY CITIES
description: How many miles to Babylon; Three score and ten; Can I get there by candlelight? Aye, and back again.

title: Can the Contras Go On?
description: THE AIRDROP CAME suddenly. Bright parachutes popped open a few hundred feet above the cluster of bare thatched huts and green tents that served as the contras' border command post. Within moments, the wooden ammo crates thudded to the ground. Having dispensed another load of American bullets to the Nicaraguan contras, the rebel supply plane ducked over the jungle tree line and headed back to its C.I.A. landing strip.

title: When a Big House Engulfs a Small Opera
description: TO PARAPHRASE GEORGE BER-nard Shaw, I have been to the Metropolitan Opera three times in a week and I still live. To open the 1987-88 season, the company offered ''Otello'' as an hors d'oeuvre for Verdi lovers, then lured us to Massenet's ''Manon'' and Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' Only the ''Ariadne,'' though vocally uneven and often downright frustrating, stays brightly in mind, which might seem odd. After all, of the three, the Strauss is the one least at home in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: FOR LEGAL AID UNIT, A NIGHT FOR HONORS
description: LEAD: MYRON S. ISAACS can't remember a time when the pace was slow for Westchester Legal Services Inc., the White Plains-based organization he helped found 20 years ago to represent indigent people in civil disputes.

title: 'Tosca' in Philadelphia
description: Eva Marton will sing the title role in Puccini's ''Tosca,'' Tuesday at 8 P.M., when the Opera Company of Philadelphia season opens at the Academy of Music, Broad and Locust Streets. Vladimir Popov is to sing Cavaradossi; the other leads are Sherrill Milnes as Scarpia and Italo Tajo as the Sacristan. Alessandro Siciliani will conduct. There will be a second performance on Friday at 8 P.M. Remaining tickets, at $58 to $12, are available at the Academy box office (215-893-1930), or through Phil-a-Charge (215-735-5266).

title: PENN STATE WINS; THOMAS NETS 218
description: Earlier this week, Coach Bruce Arians of Temple admitted he had made a mistake by trying to recruit Blair Thomas from a Philadelphia high school to be a defensive back.

title: BUSLOADS OF NURSES DESCRIBE PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: TWICE last month, busloads of nurses came here to tell their stories. They urged the state's Hospital Rate Setting Commission to provide more money for salaries, maintaining that New Jersey's successful efforts to contain hospital costs had come at the expense of nurses.

title: A New Baker Plan For World Aid
description: The World Bank and I.M.F. meetings ended on a note of hope after the Reagan Administration took what seemed to be a more active role in helping spur the world economy and solving the third-world debt problem. The spotlight was shared by President Reagan and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. Mr. Baker agreed to advocate such long-sought ideas as easing the often-stringent conditions imposed on debtors by the I.M.F. and supporting huge increases in funding for the World Bank. One surprise came when Mr. Baker said the United States might consider the price of gold in a basket of commodities that could be used to regulate economies around the world. The United States has been moving away from a gold- based economy for years.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HEALTH COALITION
description: LEAD: Nonprofit health agencies serving people with various illnesses have formed a new coalition to addresss problems common to all of their clients. The agencies, which will get together periodically to offer seminars and workshops are the American Cancer Society, Westchester division; the county's chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society of Southern New York; the Leukemia Society of America; the American Lung Association; the Epilepsy Institute; the Westchester Independent Living Center, an organization for people with physical handicaps, and the Mental Health Association of

title: INVENTING THE FUTURE
description: If it is the premise of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (''Inventing the Future,'' by Edward Dolnick, Aug. 23) that such a think tank holds the key ''to invent [ ing ] the future of newspapers, cinema, television and music,'' it is - or at least I hope it is - a mistaken one.

title: BRIGHTER DAYS AT CANDLESTICK
description: ROGER CRAIG emerged from the tunnel connecting the locker room and the dugout. He was wearing a heavy San Francisco Giants windbreaker that concealed his uniform shirt, a synthetic warm-up, a cotton sweatshirt and a T-shirt. As he watched batting practice under a gray, misty sky, his right hand gripped a paper cup filled with coffee, steam escaping as if from a smokestack.

title: A Master at Touching Up the Masters
description: IN JOHN BREALEY'S LABORATORIES, a spacious complex at the Metropolitan Museum of Art where dulled and damaged paintings are brought back to vivid pictorial health, a few dozen pictures on easels are surrounded by rooms crowded with such tools of the restorer's trade as computers, microscopes, centrifuges, spectrophotometers, racks of test tubes and rows of black rubber hoses springing from stoppered bottles.

title: 'Operatives' Get Politics Out of the Back Room
description: The back room of politics is now as public, and as crowded, as a bus station.

title: MS. KRULIK TO WED DAVID SAXE, A JUDGE
description: Phyllis Krulik, a litigation associate at the New York law firm of Colton, Hartnick, Yamin & Sheresky, and Acting Justice David B. Saxe of State Supreme Court in Manhattan plan to be married in December.

title: A SEASON OF PLENTY FOR LOVERS OF DANCE
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S dance lovers may well be overwhelmed by the fall season's cornucopia of events.

title: CALIFORNIA TRIES CARING FOR ITS GROWING RANKS OF LATCHKEY CHILDREN
description: Every evening at about 5, regular as the fog that rolls in over this blue-collar suburb south of San Francisco, working parents descend on the Sharp Park Children's Center.

title: J.D.L. TO CONTINUE PATROLS IN MERRICK
description: LEAD: A SPATE of anti-Semitic incidents in Nassau County recently prompted Jewish Defense League members from New York City to patrol a South Merrick neighborhood. They plan to continue the surveillance near Temple Israel of South Merrick, despite the wishes of the rabbi there.

title:
MUSIC;
CARNEGIE HALL SEATS FIND A NEW HOME
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH parts of what used to be Carnegie Hall seats are still stacked on the stage of the Count Basie Theatre here, most of the 1,460 seats have been installed, and the newly plastered and painted theater is scheduled to open its season Oct. 16 with a performance by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: MARYRUTH RANDALL MARRIES ROBERT CORKER JR. IN JERSEY
description: Maryruth Randall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Randall Jr. of Hillsdale, N.J., was married at Grace Episcopal Church in Westwood, N.J., yesterday to Robert J. Corker Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corker of Washington Township, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. Gaylord Hitchcock Jr., assisted by the Rev. Thomas J. Norton, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: All Hispanic Americans Are Definitely Not Alike
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSAN C. AASEN, PRODUCER, WEDS
description: The marriage of Susan Clare Aasen, an associate producer for the ABC News program ''World News Tonight,'' and R. Bruce Carlisle Jr., a vice president and an account supervisor at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, a New York advertising agency, took place yesterday at the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins performed the ceremony.

title: LIVING WITH MS
description: I am the friend with MS in Rand Araskog's story. Perhaps the column should have been called ''About Woman.'' Dee has lived with my problem for 25 years plus, raised our four children, been gardner, handyman, etc., with few complaints. With a disease like MS, it is really tougher on the partner. Over 90 percent of MS marriages break up. Dee has been a real saint. The roughest part of this long illness was in 1974-75. Our son David was diagnosed as having cancer. We spent most of the year at the Mayo Clinic, in Rochester, Minn. David, age 16, a top student and athlete, died Aug. 16, 1975. What a tragic loss. PAUL GUST JR. Fargo, N.D.

title: 5-Year-Old Bronx Boy Killed In Fall Down Elevator Shaft
description: A 5-year-old boy playing with friends in his apartment house elevator was killed yesterday when he fell down the elevator shaft, the police said.

title: Big Spending for a Spent Fuel Bribe
description: Washington has reached rock bottom in its five-year search for an underground site to store spent fuel from nuclear reactors. The latest scheme, devised by Senator Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, would make Nevada the unlucky host, recompensed with a $5 billion bribe. Congress's other ideas being even worse, this one deserves attention.

title: A TIME FOR PRAGMATISTS
description: FREE AT LAST What Really Happened When Civil Rights Came to Southern Politics. By Margaret Edds. 277 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $18.95.

title: Whistle-Blower In a Lonely Fight
description: KENNETH PRILL, a Michigan truck driver, wasn't looking to set any legal precedents when a company tractor-trailer with faulty brakes jackknifed with him driving in Tennessee. He simply refused to drive the rig after the accident and reported its condition to state authorities.

title: PROPOSAL TO RESTRICT NUDITY IS ASSAILED
description: The proposal to ban nude sunbathing on the beach in the vicinity of the Fire Island Lighthouse is the result of a common misconception concerning children and nudity.

title: POSTINGS: The Victorian Touch; Double Cachet in Tuxedo
description: Developers are famous for pinning the names of fashionable communities on their condominiums or town houses to help them sell. But the Related Companies of Manhattan, in a joint venture with Helmer-Cronin Construction of Stony Point, N.Y., has taken the practice a step further, and in a more authentic direction.

title: Next Week; How Should The World Series Use The D.H.?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Quake Aftershocks Continue; Damage Rises to $75 Million
description: Minor aftershocks continued today as the earth gently adjusted to stresses created by the powerful earthquake that struck Thursday, and damage estimates rose to $75 million.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CONCERTS & CROISSANTS

title: Cody
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Jim Robbins's article on Cody, Wyo. (Travel, July 26) and certainly share his enthusiasm. When traveling the West, I always try to arrange accommodations at original hotels in the area. In the case of Cody, Buffalo Bill constructed the Irma Hotel, named for his daughter. It is wonderfully authentic, with old furniture, moose and elk heads, and other appointments. The dining room has very good food, including the best prime rib I have ever had, and a wonderful carved bar along one side of the room given to Buffalo Bill by Queen Victoria in appreciation of his Wild West show in England. JOHN H. HUNEKE Summit, N.J.

title: Arthur Graham Carpenter Is Married To Alexandra K. Wettlaufer in Buffalo
description: Alexandra Ker Wettlaufer and Arthur Graham Carpenter were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Buffalo. The Rev. David C. Toomey, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony.

title: Closing P.L.O. Office Tells Where U.S. Stands
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: PLANS to incinerate hazardous waste on ships off the New Jersey coast will be delayed at least until 1989, in part because of a recent court decision.

title: The Interactive World of Toys and Television
description: HE-MAN AND SHE-RA WILL BE fighting a host of invaders this month over market share - and children's attention - with the introduction of a number of serious rivals at home video stores. The challengers include Disney's ''Lady and the Tramp''; the first video cassette of Barbie, the long-lived doll from Mattel and three ''battle training'' video cassettes for Captain Power, the hero of one of this season's new television shows, ''Captain Power and the Soldiers of the Future.''

title: Why Some New Condos Founder
description: A SAVINGS-AND-LOAN association in Pine Bluff, Ark., fails and one of its investments, a vacant new condominium project on Park Avenue, remains empty for years while the Federal Government tries to untangle the bank's finances.

title: Syndicated 'Star Trek' Puts Dent in Networks
description: More than 50 stations affiliated with ABC, NBC and CBS have scheduled a syndicated program, the two-hour premiere of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation,'' during prime time this week.

title: G.M. and Union Meet for Talks
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation met for an hour Friday, their first bargaining session since late August when the union decided to settle first with the Ford Motor Company.

title: Ah, Sweet Mystery of Screen Acting
description: BURIED NEAR THE CENTER OF the multipart comedy ''Amazon Women on the Moon,'' an uneven series of sketches sending up late-night television, there's a small, priceless plum. It's ''Son of the Invisible Man,'' an intentionally washed-out black-and-white film parody with Ed Begley Jr. as Jack Griffin Jr., the son of the late, demented scientist played by Claude Rains in the 1933 movie.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE New York Rangers goalie, John Vanbiesbrouck, suffered a broken jaw during a practice session yesterday, but is expected to miss only a game or two of the regular season. . . . At the age of 38, Steve Garvey may be playing his final major-league game today. The first baseman's contract with the San Diego Padres expires after the game, the last of the season, and the club's president, Chub Feeney, said it would not be renewed. . . . Not so with Dwight Evans. The Boston Red Sox have renewed the contract of the outfielder-first baseman for next season. Evans, who will be 36 years old Nov. 3, is winding up his finest season in 15 years with the Red Sox, hitting .306 with 34 homers and 122 runs batted in. . . . When Rob Murphy of the Cincinnati Reds relieved in yesterday's 6-4 loss to Houston, it marked his 87th appearance of the season, breaking the major-league mark for left-handers set by Wilbur Wood with the 1968 Chicago White Sox. . . . Derrick McKey, a former University of Alabama forward and a first-round draft choice of the Seattle SuperSonics, has signed a contract with the club for undisclosed terms. . . . Bill Rodgers, a four-time winner of the New York City Marathon, has entered this year's race, scheduled for Nov. 1.

title: NEBRASKA RALLIES
description: Keith (End Zone) Jones rushed for 129 yards and two fourth-quarter touchdowns today as Nebraska scored the final 17 points to beat South Carolina, 30-21.

title: The Coverage On Rental Cars
description: On March 6, Michael Weiner, a 21-year-old Columbia engineering student, went to Florida for a vacation and rented a car there. His father, Frank J. Weiner, a lawyer in Boston, had selected Value Rent-A-Car for Michael because it was then offering a rate of $129 a week, with payment for the collision damage waiver included. The collision damage waiver, usually with an extra cost of perhaps $9 a day, is not insurance, all rental companies insist, but merely waives their right to recover from the renter the cost of any collision repairs.

title: The Bork Battle: Visions of the Constitution
description: ON the eve of Judge Robert H. Bork's confirmation hearings, the question was whether the liberal opposition had a realistic chance of defeating the distinguished Supreme Court nominee. Three weeks later, as the Senate Judiciary Committee finished its inquiry and prepared for a vote this Tuesday, the question became whether the Reagan Administration could salvage the nomination.

title: China Denounces Tibetan Leader As Responsible for Violent Protest
description: China issued a harsh attack on the Dalai Lama today, two days after a crowd of Tibetans stoned and burned a police station in Lhasa and at least six people were reported killed.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
description: LIVING WITH CHRONIC ILLNESS Days of Patience and Passion. By Cheri Register. 316 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: A BIG-BOAT TEST FOR WOMEN
description: In Margarita Nylen's view of yacht racing, age is on her side. The 32-year-old sailor from Stockholm and four of her Swedish teammates are in Newport, R.I., this week to compete in the Rolex International Women's Keelboat Championship.

title: MOVIES
description: The Morning After Starring Jane Fonda, Jeff Bridges and Raul Julia. Directed by Sidney Lumet. 1986. Lorimar Video. 103 minutes. $79.95.

title: Crack Dealers' Armored Van Is Seized in Queens
description: An ''impenetrable'' steel-plated van used as an armored car to protect drug dealers in Queens against attempts to muscle into their territory has been seized by the police.

title: The Truth Is Also on Trial In a Texas Death Row Case
description: A death row case that has been dominated by emotional issues of race is now centering on vexing questions of who is telling the truth and who is not.

title: BUSINESSMEN FAULT DEFENSE SPENDING
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S 2 Senators and 14 Representatives, as well as all the Republican and Democratic candidates for President, will get advice from the state's business leaders in the months ahead on how to better plan for the nation's defense.

title: Ecuador Airline to Be Fined For Jet Seized in Drug Case
description: Ecuatoriana Airline will have to pay a fine to regain a DC-10 seized here in a cocaine case, the authorities said today. The amount of the fine has not been determined.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY LINDA WALKER
description: Linda Jean Walker, a vice president in the fixed-income division of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, and Peter Charles Bernard Bynoe, the founder and the chief executive officer of Telemat Ltd., a real-estate development company in Chicago, plan to be married Nov. 20.

title: VINEYARD'S LINEAGE TRACED TO 19TH CENTURY
description: It is not quite accurate to describe the Hargrave vineyard in Cutchogue [ ''Grapes and Starling Wars,'' Aug. 30 ] as a Long Island first. In the 19th century and perhaps before then, the adaptability of Long Island soil to grapery was already well recognized. Grape arbors were common features of gentlemen's country seats, as in the case of F.S. Woodbridge's 1850 residence on Bethpage Turnpike in Hempstead. Many serious Long Island farmers also cultivated grapes. When Effingham Lawrence's farm in Flushing was put up for sale in March 1844, ''a choice variety of grape vines'' was listed as one of its attributes.

title: MAKING USE OF END-OF-SEASON HARVEST
description: FALL may have arrived but there is still plenty of ripe tomatoes, basil and summer squash around. So when a weekend visitor recently announced his passion for vegetable soups, we set to work in the kitchen. The result of our labor were three soups that were both attractive and refreshing and helped to use up the last of the summer crop.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S CHRYSANTHEMUM TIME
description: LEAD: JUST about everyone's favorite fall garden flower is the chrysanthemum. One of the last plants to bloom, it heralds the end of the growing season.

title: GATHERING THE BIG ROSEBUD
description: THE old metaphysical poet, John Donne (1573-1631), has achieved the ultimate sign of immortality. There he was, paraphrased on the blackboard in the Detroit Tiger locker room, usually reserved for more contemporary quotes and imprecations.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: October 4, 1987
description: weeks On Fiction List 1 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) 7 Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, 12 $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 3 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Ballantine, 5 $4.95.) Two men, two women, passion and power- brokering in Washington. 4 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. 6 (Avon, $4.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a woman's coming-of-age in 18th- century England and France. 5 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, 1 $4.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 6 CALL TO ARMS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Jove, $4.50.) 4 The Marines from Pearl Harbor to Midway; second volume of "The Corps." 7 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A 13 rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 8 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 73 Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 9 * VALE OF THE VOLE, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, 1 $3.95.) Esk, the son of an ogre and a nymph, defends the inhabitants of a paradise. 10 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. 9 (Pocket, $4.95.) A top model's encounters with three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 11 * SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Bantam, 6 $4.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 12 DREAMS ARE NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline 1 Briskin. (Berkley, $4.50.) A California family dynasty out to conquer the world. 13 PERFUME, by Patrick Suskind. (Pocket, $4.50.) 4 An olfactory vampire kills people to steal their scents. 14 TWILIGHT EYES, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, 6 $4.95.) While sought by police for murder, Slim MacKenzie stalks a force called the Others. 15 KENDER, GULLY DWARVES, AND GNOMES, 4 edited by Margaret Weis and Tracy Hickman. (TSR, $3.95.) Stories about the people of Krynn; part of the "DragonLance Tales" fantasy series. Weeks On Nonfiction List 1 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $4.95.) An 6 unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. 206 (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 32 (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 4 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) 23 Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star and father of five. 5 * KAFFIR BOY, by Mark Mathabane. (Plume/ 5 NAL, $8.95.) A young black man tells of his coming-of-age in apartheid South Africa. 6 * WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. 48 (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 7 DREAMGIRL, by Mary Wilson with Patricia 4 Romanowski and Ahrgus Juilliard. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) A behind-the-scenes account of the lives of the Supremes, by a member of the singing trio. 8 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle 15 Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's oldest profession. 9 McMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. 5 (Warner, $3.95.) An updated autobiography of the outrageous Chicago Bears quarterback. 10 * THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Avon, 2 $5.50.) The commercial confrontation between America's Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan. Weeks Advice, How-to and On Miscellaneous List BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by 6 Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More "Bloom County" cartoon strips. 2 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 70 Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 3 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. 17 (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 4 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge 31 Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 * FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 19 Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness.

title: At Home With Lord Vishnu
description: AND WHERE WILL YOU BE FOR NEW Year's?'' people asked, as always. ''In Tiruchirapalli,'' we said in answer, holding tight to the six vowels and slithering over the consonants as best we could. If pressed (which did not happen often) we got out the New Oxford Atlas and pointed to where the name, picked out in big black letters, was draped like a watch chain across the ankles of India. Even when they saw the name, it had no echo.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption about Andre Previn on the music page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect performance day for the Royal Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert is Friday at 8 P.M.

title: Bringing the Bounty into the Bank
description: TODAY'S food banks rarely reflect their often-makeshift origins. New Jersey's Community Food Bank, which found its first home in founder Kathleen DiChiara's automobile, has a new 43,000-square-foot warehouse.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD BANKS
description: ON Oct. 16, the seventh annual observance of the United Nations-sponsored World Food Day takes place. Its purpose: to draw attention to the issue of hunger. In the United States there is a growing number of people dedicating themselves to one partial solution to this problem at home. They call themselves food bankers.

title: Outbreak of Rabies Prompts Quarantine in Part of Florida
description: A rabies quarantine has been declared in this Atlantic coastal area, where two rabid animals have bitten people and six infected animals have been found.

title: Frozen In Time
description: THE MARKINGS ON THE WOODEN packing case were deceptive. ''Horlick's Malted Milk Tablets,'' they said. And the box was long thought to contain supplies for Roald Amundsen, the Norwegian explorer who not only discovered the South Pole but also was the first to fly across the Arctic. When the box was turned over to the organizers of an Amundsen exhibition last year by the widow of the explorer's nephew and heir, it was found to hold not supplies but something much rarer: more than 200 lantern slides of Amundsen's polar expeditions - photos thought to have disappeared when his airplane was lost over the Arctic in 1928. Shown here are slides of the South Pole expedition.

title: U.S. and Spain Still Far Apart in Talks on Bases
description: Facing a Nov. 13 deadline, United States and Spanish negotiators remain as far apart as ever in their search for an agreement on the future of American military forces in this country.

title: RUSSIA, IN THE LENS OF A BETHEL WOMAN
description: LEAD: ''OLD woman. Feet anchored in heavy boots. I smile at you. You do not smile back at me. You have lost all your men in wars. Where will your grandson die? In Kiev? Or in Connecticut?''

title: Korea Politician Vows To Avoid a Party Split
description: A leading South Korean opposition figure said today that he would not ''betray the wishes'' of the people to avoid an opposition split in December's presidential elections and promised he and his major opposition rival would agree on a single candidacy.

title: INTRODUCING VIDEO TO ACTING COURSES
description: ''MTV is here to stay,''

title: Many States Return Tax Windfall to Citizens
description: More than four-fifths of the windfall that states could have gained because of Federal tax revision in 1986 has gone back to state residents in the form of tax relief, a national survey has found.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Westchester Weekly today about the county Rent Guidelines Board gives an incorrect date for a vote on new rent levels. The vote, which was scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed.

title: STILL HERE AT THE NEW YORKER
description: IT is a common enough occurrence for news as it grows old to turn into history but in my experience it is rare for history as it grows old to turn into news. Rare or not, something of the kind appears to have happened with respect to ''Here at The New Yorker,'' which, having been published back in 1975, may be said to have passed into history, but which has lately become news on the strength of the many changes that have been taking place at the magazine over the last couple of years. But perhaps I should begin by mentioning what hasn't happened at the magazine, since an absence of conspicuous happenings has long been characteristic of our way of life on West 43d Street.

title: U.C.L.A. TROUNCES STANFORD
description: Gaston Green sprinted 91 yards for a touchdown and set up another on a 54-yard pass play as U.C.L.A. trounced Stanford, 49-0, in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

title: 'QUILTERS' STAGED IN OLD GREENWICH
description: NOT as sensible or cheering, in selection or in execution, is the first production this season of the WPI Theater in Old Greenwich: the pseudomusical ''Quilters.'' This is a case of a small theater company, overextended.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MODERNISM AND THE HARLEM RENAISSANCE. By Houston A. Baker Jr. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) Some remember the Harlem Renaissance as an isolated phenomenon that failed to produce anything ''modern.'' In his study ''Modernism and the Harlem Renaissance,'' Houston A. Baker Jr., a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania, challenges such notions and proposes new ways of seeing and interpreting that artistic awakening.

title: RAYMOND S. DINSMORE
description: Raymond S. Dinsmore, a real-estate developer and world traveler who, in the late 1950's, was president of the Circumnavigators Club, an organization of travelers who have circled the globe, died Monday at the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Atlantis, Fla., of complications from a stroke. He was 87 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Drop in Drama
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: KENYA: THE ROAD TO ILMOROG
description: Ngugi wa Thiong'o, the Kenyan novelist and playwright, is a major figure in contemporary African literature. For readers seeking to become familiar with the realities of Kenya after Independence and willing to go beyond the mythopoeia and nostalgia offered in the literature of white settlers, Mr. Ngugi's powerful novels are essential.

title: Asbestos Problem Returns in Glen Cove
description: LEAD: JUST when Glen Cove School District officials expected a two-year, $250,000 asbestos and reroofing project at the Connolly Elementary School to be over, a piece of ceiling tile the size of a quarter has forced them to start all over again.

title: LOIS E. HARRISON ENGAGED TO WED
description: The engagement of Lois Eleanor Harrison, the daughter of Lois Cowles Harrison-Hooks of Lakeland, Fla., and John Raymond Harrison of Atlanta, to William Kendall Mintz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Mintz of Hollis, Queens, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A May wedding is planned.

title: WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
description: I would gladly attend one of the sub games that the N.F.L. proposes on the condition that I receive live television coverage of my Sunday night poker game.

title: PLENTY WHOLESOME AND A LITTLE PERVERSE
description: LEAVING HOME By Garrison Keillor. 244 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title:
ART;
Heckscher Maps Modern Path
description: LEAD: FOR the many aspiring artists who received training and encouragement at the Art Students League in New York City, the current exhibition at the Heckscher Museum will bring back fond memories. More than an exercise in nostalgia, however, the show of selections from the league's extensive collection illustrates in capsule form the development of

title: Tribune Fete: An American In Paris at 100
description: With pomp and flourish, The International Herald Tribune, an American newspaper abroad, celebrated its 100th anniversary in Paris this week.

A metabolism diet for women over 35, developed at the Kaiser Permanente clinic.

title: N.F.L. STANDBYS TAKE OFF
description: AFTER 12 days of negotiations, demonstrations, accusations, union meetings, owner meetings, sponsor pullouts, picket lines, egg-throwing, name-calling, team-restocking and growing public dissatisfaction with the football industry in general, the National Football League returns to action today. Sort of. Hundreds of players known only to their families, friends and college sports information directors will join a smattering of non-striking regulars in 13 games today and another tomorrow night that league owners say will count in the standings. Before the walkout began Sept. 23, each team had played twice.

title: Radium: From Wonder Drug to Hazard
description: Radium, a naturally occurring element isolated from uranium by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1898, was considered a wonder drug when the Radium Chemical Company was founded in New York in 1913.

title: SEWAGE AND SLUDGE IN THE OCEAN
description: THERE has been much agitation recently to get floatable plastics and sludge out of the ocean. As chairman of one of the larger municipal sewerage-treatment partnerships - the Joint Meeting of Essex and Union Counties -I want to call upon Richard T. Dewling, Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, and all ecological friends of the ocean to help us reach that objective.

title: Sadness in Maine Over a Van Gogh
description: A small, obelisk-shaped building here has been home for 10 years to one of the world's most valuable paintings, ''Irises,'' by Vincent Van Gogh.

title: JAPANESE CARS FOR CADILLAC TASTES
description: MICHAEL CARPENTER of Pacific Palisades, Calif., considered buying a BMW this summer, but instead he traded in his 4-year-old Cadillac Eldorado for a $27,000 Acura Legend coupe. ''It is a beautifully appointed and styled car,'' said Mr. Carpenter, the 47-year-old publisher of Adweek/West magazine. ''Boy, is it fun to drive.''

title: Message Takes Time For Special Delivery
description: The letter from the Governor of Georgia to his counterpart in Maine took 5 1/2 months to arrive and was slightly crumpled, but no one complained.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: Homefront, U.S.A. and The End of the Tunnel, 1973-75 Vietnam: A Television History - Vol. 6. Sony Video Software. 120 minutes. $29.95.

title: MUSICIAN TAKES TIME TO RELAX - ON STAGE
description: ''I WAS put on this earth to make music happen,'' said Yuval Waldman. Indeed, Mr. Waldman is an indefatigable organizer of music events both here and abroad.

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: Much as I liked Paul Hofmann's article on Viennese streetcars (Travel, Aug. 23), two additional features need mentioning:

title: MELISSA EPSTEIN, BIOLOGIST, TO WED A PHYSICIAN NOV. 7
description: Melissa Epstein, a junior scientist at the Lifecodes Corporation in Elmsford, N.Y., and Dr. Elliot Regenbogen, a resident in otolaryngology at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx, plan to be married Nov. 7. Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Epstein of Yonkers have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Helen Regenbogen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Irving Regenbogen.

title: HE LEFT HIS HEART IN SIBERIA
description: PARTINGS By Leonid Borodin. Translated by David Floyd. 221 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Flowers and Glassware At Cut Prices Flowers by Frank Laning in Chappaqua instituted a half-price Flower Market six years ago that continues to draw customers from 4 P.M. to 6 P.M. Thursdays for cut flowers of all sorts, including imports and exotics, with payment by check or cash, not credit cards, and no deliveries. The cider, cheese and crackers are on the house.

title: NONFICTION
description: LOOKING FORWARD. By George Bush with Victor Gold. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Vice President George Bush establishes the ground rules for his autobiography at the start, warning that it is not an ''inside story'' of his role in the Reagan Administration. That caution is evident throughout, so much so that the book could easily be titled, like President Reagan's autobiography, ''Where's the Rest of Me?'' Mr. Bush elected to call his book ''Looking Forward,'' clearly hoping that it would erase lingering confusion about the political attitudes of the Republican Presidential candidate. But part of his dilemma is inherent in the nature of the book - one written by a sitting Vice President with larger political aspirations. The book, written with Victor Gold, a longtime political adviser, does provide some glimpses of the Vice President's personal history - the bleeding ulcer he suffered and vignettes of his public life, such as his meetings with some of the world's most powerful leaders. But it adds little to our knowledge of what has molded him as a politician or as a man. Mr. Bush leaves uncertain, for example, what is meant by his brand of moderate-conservative politics and why he has maintained a life of public service for nearly three decades, despite personal affronts and major political setbacks. Similarly, he provides some gripping details of personal crises, such as the death of a daughter and his brush with death as a World War II Navy fighter pilot, without explaining their impact on him. Mr. Bush mostly uses the book, whose release coincides with a new push for the Presidency, to argue that he has been an active and effective No. 2.

title: IN FAMILY COURT, HARD CHOICES
description: THE proceedings of the Family Court in White Plains are generally closed to the public, but any rider on the County Courthouse elevator knows the stop. It is where all the children get off. The adults hold the doors an extra moment each morning so the children can wedge past the knees and bulging briefcases of the lawyers.

title: TO RUSSIA, WITH TONGUE IN CHEEK
description: Travel in the Soviet Union stretches to the utmost your sense of wonder, your patience and your sense of humor. Even preparation for the trip can be daunting. Some of the best introductions to Russia's history and psyche - like James H. Billington's ''The Icon and the Axe'' (Random House) or Dostoyevsky's ''Brothers Karamazov'' - are substantial tomes that may take weeks to finish.

title: Henry Ford 2d
description: The death of Henry Ford 2d at the age of 70 is not expected to affect the management of the big auto maker, but it will leave a void in the corporate culture. A man who believed the boss should be the boss, Mr. Ford nevertheless was not one to dismiss counsel lightly; indeed, when he seized control of the company in 1945, he listened carefully to those who knew more about running it than he did, until he had a firm grasp of its operations. Over the years, he kept Ford in step with the times, and had the satisfaction of seeing it pass General Motors in profitability. His personal life, too, was controversial: A hard-drinking man who enjoyed and frequented the company of women, his philosophy of life was also his philosophy of business: ''Never complain, never explain.''

title: MS. O'LEARY WED TO T. F. KELLER 4TH
description: The marriage of Constance Ann O'Leary, a daughter of William John O'Leary of Bethlehem, Pa., and the late Joan Nugent O'Leary, to Traugott Francis Keller 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keller 3d of Ridgefield, Conn., and New York, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: DAWSON OF CUBS GETS HIS 49TH HOME RUN, BUT EXPOS WIN
description: Tim Wallach's seventh-inning bases-empty home run gave the Montreal Expos a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today, taking a little of the glitter off Andre Dawson's 49th home run of the season.

title: Ivory From the Eskimo Heritage
description: MOST OF WHAT IS known about ancient Eskimo art has been discovered over the last 60 years. And the vast majority of the evocative, highly sophisticated works, carved between 300 B.C. and A.D. 1200, assembled in ''Ancient Eskimo Ivories of the Bering Strait,'' opening Friday at the Museum of Natural History, were excavated more recently - since about 1970.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DENVILLE FESTIVAL The Morris County community of Denville annually attracts more than 50,000 visitors to its Harvest Festival, which this year will be held Saturday. It is the major fund-raising event for St. Clare's-Riverside Medical Center, a 401-bed hospital sponsored by the Sisters of the Sorrowful Mother. Since it began in 1974, the festival has raised nearly $1.6 million. It features barns that housed cows, chickens and pigs, as well as arts and crafts, a flea market, homemade preserves, jellies and baked goods and handmade silk and dried-flower arrangements. The featival will be held from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M., rain or shine, at the St. Francis Health Resort Farm on Pocono Road. Admission is 50 cents. Information: (201) 625-2539 or 627-7681.

title: AURAL HISTORY
description: THE DRAMATIC SYMPHONY And THE FORMS OF ART By Andrei Biely. Translated by Roger and Angela Keys and John Elsworth. 183 pp. New York: Grove Press. $16.95.

title: MIAMI RALLY DEFEATS FLORIDA ST., 26-25
description: Steve Walsh passed for three touchdowns in the final 16 minutes today, including a 73-yard play to Michael Irvin with 2 minutes 22 seconds left, that rallied Miami to a stunning 26-25 victory over Florida State.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAN-MADE MINDS: The Promise of Artificial Intelligence. By M. Mitchell Waldrop. (Walker & Company, $22.95.) ''But we will still be human.'' With these six words the science writer M. Mitchell Waldrop ends his lucid account of the attempt to endow computers with the ability to learn, reason and act in our stead.

title: No Headline
description: INSIDE THE PHILIPPINE REVOLUTION By William Chapman. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: 5 Are Convicted of Threats Against I.R.S. Agents
description: Five members of a tax protest group with links to right-wing extremist organizations have been found guilty of threatening the lives of Internal Revenue Service agents and a Nevada state judge.

title: THEIR VERY OWN QUAGMIRE
description: DILEMMAS OF SECURITY Politics, Strategy, and the Israeli Experience in Lebanon. By Avner Yaniv. Maps. 355 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Seeking a New Route To Economic Cooperation
description: THE Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, derides those who would belittle the President's capacity to pull any more rabbits from his hat, at least on matters of economics. Making his point in just five days, Mr. Baker, whose own innovative image had seemed to be fading along with Mr. Reagan's, has dramatically transformed the look of economic policy. It could be he has altered the content as well. An Administration whose pre-Baker Treasury preached belligerent indifference to the condition of others' economies, has now decreed a world of partnership.

title: Zoning Issues Spur Lawsuits in Queens
description: LEAD: SIX gracious single-family houses surrounded by century-old trees stand empty on 215th Place and 43d Avenue in Bayside, Queens. All will probably be demolished. Plans have already been filed to replace two of them with four three-family, brick attached houses.

title: SHARP RISE FOUND IN SYPHILIS IN U.S.
description: Federal and state officials report a dramatic increase in syphilis that is concentrated among minority heterosexual men and women in a few urban areas.

title: CHOICE FOREIGN ISSUES FOR THE HOBBYISTS
description: THE Universal Postal Union declared Friday as World Post Day. While the event spotlights the delivery of mails by postal services worldwide, it also reminds collectors that many nations publicize the hobby through such events.

title: Hold the Borscht, Here Comes Mort Sahl
description: MORT SAHL, A SATIRIST rooted in the comedy clubs of the urban hip, has worked the Borscht Belt only once - and that time was a disaster. There was a police convention in the house, and just as he got rolling on his Richard Nixon jokes, the officers stood up and started singing ''God Bless America.''

title: BABY MAKES TWO
description: LEAD: ABBOTT AND AVERY By Robert W. Shaw. 307 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95

title: Headliners; Defending the Realm
description: It appears that the sun may have set on a bit of the Commonwealth, to the evident dismay of Queen Elizabeth II. The Queen was unusually outspoken last week on the subject of Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, who led a coup in the Pacific island state of Fiji, which, as a Commonwealth member, recognized the monarch as its nominal head of state. Colonel Rabuka, declaring that he, not the Queen, was running things in Fiji, removed the island's Governor General, who is her representative. The Queen, whose powers in the Commonwealth are mostly those of persuasion, issued what was regarded in London as a pretty tough statement. She condemned the Colonel's ''illegal action'' and said that anyone siding with him was ''repudiating his allegiance and loyalty to the Queen.''

title: Carol Cheswick Engaged to Wed Richard T. Ross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Reid Cheswick of Darien, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Ann Cheswick to Richard Thomas Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Ross Jr., also of Darien. The couple plan to be married Nov. 21.

title: Fanning French Fears
description: THE USUALLY SOMNO-lent and sybaritic beach towns of France were the scenes this summer of a closely watched, deadly earnest political road show, a sort of itinerant political revival meeting that came complete with circus tents, impassioned speeches and rousing choruses of ''La Marseillaise.'' It marked something rarely seen in that country, at least in the relatively civil decades since World War II.

title: Mets and Cards: The Difference
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 27 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Shoreham Workers Await Their Fate
description: The uniformed guard, one of a 160-member security team, ushered the car past the gatehouse with a polite ''welcome to Shoreham,'' but could not resist adding a tart ''have a good day.''

title: 23 in the Foreign Service Fight to Retain Jobs
description: Twenty-three career Foreign Service officers have filed a grievance with the State Department charging that they are being wrongly forced out of their jobs.

title: Martha Graham's Gift to Drama
description: LEAD: A SINGLE GESTURE. IN our memories of Martha Graham's dances, there often remains one stabbing, bright moment that reveals the secret heart of the dance.

title: A Simpler Way to Improve Bryant Park
description: ''HE WHO HESITATES IS sometimes saved,'' was the moral at the end of one of James Thurber's ''Fables for Our Time,'' and so it has long been with Bryant Park. Some years ago there was the temptation to add a few dollars to the city's coffers by permitting the construction of an underground garage beneath the park, and one can only be grateful for hesitation there. But so, too, with the widely publicized plan announced in 1983 to redesign the park under the aegis of the nonprofit Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, which planned to lease the park from the city, rehabilitate it and maintain it with the profits from a huge, glass-enclosed restaurant-cafe that was to have been constructed at the park's east end, on the terrace behind the New York Public Library.

title: The Chamorros: Nicaragua's Remarkable Press Family
description: WITH the reopening of the opposition newspaper La Prensa last week, Nicaragua regained one of its most celebrated institutions, and the remarkable Chamorro family once again stepped to the forefront of national life. Both the newspaper and the family have become icons of Nicaraguan history, and both are certain to play important roles as the country advances tentatively toward liberalization under provisions of the new Central American peace accord, to go into effect Nov. 7.

title: Puerto Rican Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Rift Over Lockers At a Paper Plant

title: YALE PROFESSOR TURNS TO SPORTS
description: ONE of the first omens that Donald Kagan was going to take some strange turns in life manifested itself at the age of 9 while he was growing up in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Musicians in Quest of Language
description: JAZZ MUSICIANS IMPRO-vise, but is improvisation what defines their music as jazz?

title: Music: In Philadelphia, A Festival of Americana
description: Perhaps uncharacteristically, given its love of tradition, Philadelphia is full of avant-garde music at the moment. Along with the annual American Music Theater Festival, there is, starting Friday night, the New Music America festival, which travels to a different city each year and which will last until Oct. 11. In addition, there are various ancillary symposiums and conferences attracted by the two main festivals.

title: Recent Sales
description: Brightwaters $172,500 524 Peters Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old high ranch; den with fireplace, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Mastic $133,000 27 Main Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; den, finished basement, fireplace, pool; taxes $2,000. Medford $110,000 3003 Eagle Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. Curtis of Bridgewater, N.J., and the late Mr. Curtis. The Rev. James Doyle performed the ceremony at St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Edgar Lambert Piret, 77, Scientist and Inventor
description: Dr. Edgar Lambert Piret, a chemical engineer who held a number of patents and who was one of the first scientists attached to United States embassies abroad, died Sept. 24 at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., of complications following a stroke. He was 77 years old.

HOME VIDEO;
