title: Minister Rallies West Siders to Battle Crime
description: Surrounded by vice and violence, the Metro Baptist Church in the Clinton section of Manhattan is under seige. And its 47-year-old pastor is preparing to fight back.

title: 'JUDICIAL RESTRAINT' AND AN 11-YEAR-OLD MURDER CASE
description: IN PRISON parlance, Vincent James Landano was sure he would ''walk.''

title: Vietnamese Rejoins Her U.S. Mother
description: For eight years, Mai Barlow kept the existence of a daughter in Vietnam a secret from her husband. When she told him, it began a six-year quest that ended with a chance encounter with the right Vietnamese official at the right time.

title: Chicago Teachers Reach Accord in 4-Week Strike
description: Negotiators reached a tentative contract agreement today that would end a four-week-old strike by Chicago school teachers over pay and class size.

title: HONOLULU
description: I DON'T USUALLY HUNT FOR ROMANTIC PLACES to dine. I take my chances. I let each place possess me in its own way, and wait for surfacings of special delight and poignance that will cause me to return.

title: Ortega Shows a Stronger Hand in Nicaragua
description: In the weeks since the Central American peace accord was signed, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has appeared more fully in control of the Sandinista Government than ever before.

title: Article 602887 -- No Title
description: THE Windy City is adding a touch of its own to the downtown White Plains Urban Renewal Area this fall when construction starts on a $40 million office tower planned by Chicago's Homart Development Company at the corner of Martine Avenue and Bank Street.

title: Springsteen Looks at Love
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN doesn't trust myths. For a decade, his songs have been whittling away at the notion that the American birthright is unlimited opportunity and rising expectations. Now, with the new ''Tunnel of Love'' (Columbia 40999 LP, cassette and CD, scheduled for release tomorrow), he's confronting another illusion: the myth of love as perfect bliss and panacea.

title: The Freedom Hurdle Nicaragua Must Leap
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Patient Eases Path From Streets to Health
description: At least three dozen men are slumped or sleeping in molded plastic chairs in the center for the homeless. It is 8 P.M., and they are waiting to be assigned beds for the night. Several say they have been waiting all day.

title: Viral Meningitis Cluster Hits Small Massachusetts College
description: Curry college has been struck by an outbreak of viral meningitis that has afflicted 21 students in the past two weeks.

title: Sibelius Isn't the Only Scandinavian Composer
description: SCANDINAVIAN SYMPHONIES, excepting those of Sibelius, have not become staple items on orchestral programs outside that geographical area, although some have long been available on recordings. Setting aside value judgments on the works themselves, there are two likely reasons for this neglect: the relatively primitive nature of Scandinavian musical life in the early part of the 19th century, and the (continuing) peripheral location of the Scandinavian countries in relation to the major dissemination centers of new music.

title: Headliners; JUMPING THE FENCE
description: What with the exigencies of fund-raising and budget management, the calling of museum director these days can be rather akin to, well, being in trade. Which is not to say that Sir Roy Strong has not thoroughly enjoyed his years as director of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, but that he appears happy to be leaving that post behind him. Discussing his plans to begin a new career next year as an art commentator, the 52-year-old Sir Roy last week bemoaned the ''dog eat dog'' nature of museum administration in an age of tight budgets. ''It was just our historical bitchery in the past,'' he said, ''but now it's on a megaplane with all of us fighting each other in Tokyo trying to get our hands on the loot from the different Japanese companies. Pretty low down.''

title: FATHER OF HIS COUNTRY
description: THE CHINESE EMPEROR By Jean Levi. Translated by Barbara Bray. 341 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: Beatrice
description: To the Editor:

title: AN INDOMITABLE GROUP MARKS SCOUT FOUNDING
description: While reading Lynne Ames's nostalgic story about the Girl Scouts [ ''About Westchester: Scout Memories,'' Sept. 20 ] , older Westchester residents may have recalled the summer of 1937. It was then that Girl Scouts from all 48 states and many foreign countries celebrated 25 years of America's Girl Scout movement with a two-week conclave at Camp Andree Clark in Briarcliff.

title: Piraeus Tries to Escape From Athens Shadow
description: Against the odds, this city by a polluted sea is trying to shed a status compared by its Mayor to a ''concealed mistress'' condemned to obscurity in the shadow of Athens.

title: THE JAPANESE INTERNMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SENDER RAHMANI
description: Sender Rahmani, a Westchester real-estate developer, died of lung cancer Tuesday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 87 years old and a resident of White Plains.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE PITCHERS STRUCK OUT IN RACE FOR CY YOUNG
description: The American League has some legitimate candidates for the Cy Young award: Dave Stewart of Oakland, the only 20-game winner in the major leagues; Roger Clemens of Boston, who has compiled a 15-3 record since June 12 for a season total of 19-9; Ted Higuera of Milwaukee, who has a 13-3 record since June 24 for a season mark of 18-10; Jimmy Key of Toronto, who has only one loss since July 11 and a 17-7 record that could be significantly better if not for a collection of low-scoring losses and no-decision starts.

title: HISTORICAL ROOTS AT MORRISTOWN SHOW
description: THE indebtedness of contemporary crafts to native American traditions often is acknowledged by artists who use those traditions as design or technical resources.

title: AS THE YANKEES END A SEASON, PINIELLA MAY BE FINISHING A JOB
description: The final days have not been easy ones. Sometimes it seemed as if they were moving at an annoying pace, as if someone had slowed them to half-speed. Players were spent; the manager appeared worn.

title: ORIGINAL INTENT
description: William Safire is in good company, but I'm not sure he's right (On Language, ''Hermen Eutic's Original Intent,'' Sept. 6). Many writers have claimed a connection between Hermes and hermeneutics, but the evidence is in short supply. Onions's etymological dictionary sees no connection, tracing hermeneutics back to the Greek hermeneuein, or interpret, and saving Hermes for the origin of hermetic (by way of Hermes Trismegistus, the author of occult science). The link in question seems more than logical, especially to those who see interpretation as somehow slippery and elusive, and I think for that reason it has come into vogue. But as you know, there's a wide gulf between what ought to be and what is.

title: Fantastic Voyages
description: As Emily Dickinson would have it: 'There is no Frigate like a Book/ To take us Lands away . . .' OZ Follow the yellow brick road to the Emerald City, capital of the land mapped out by L. Frank Baum in ''The Wonderful Wizard of Oz'' (1900). The Emerald Citizens, among them a vivacious Patchwork Girl and a loquacious Wogglebug, are friendly, but visitors to the colorful hinterlands are warned that enchantments abound. Come as you are, leave as something else. SHANGRI-LA Age cannot wither nor custom stale the luckier inhabitants of the Himalayan theocracy invented by James Hilton in 1933. Snug in the lamasery at the foot of Mount Karakal, surrounded by books and music, the moderately heretical lamas remain, like ''Lost Horizon'' itself, evergreen. Guests are advised to anticipate a long stay, and to take it easy on the tangatse berries. ATLANTIS In the Critias, Plato (427?-347? B.C.) described the great continent-city, rich with temples and royal residences, ringed with canals. After a military defeat by Athens, however, it was engulfed by earthquakes, and sank into the sea. It may still be there, its Temple of Poseidon rivaling the Parthenon. Travelers can put on their scuba gear and look for themselves. Or they might prefer to ponder the Socratic question: Would Plato lie?

title: FORDHAM (4-0) TOPS ST. JOHN'S
description: Eddie Pearson, a sophomore halfback, scored three touchdowns, one on a 68-yard punt return, to lead undefeated Fordham to a 34-23 triumph over St. John's in a Liberty Conference game yesterday at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: Where Wild Goose Goes in London: 2 Miles
description: Autumn is settling over London, bringing all its familiar glories and one distinct surprise for any American with a homesick ear.

title: Victor Mollo Is Dead; Contract Bridge Expert
description: Victor Mollo, one of the world's leading writers on contract bridge, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in London. He was 78 years old.

title: JOHNSON TO STEP DOWN AFTER '88
description: The Mets ended months of wrangling and one week of speculation today when Frank Cashen announced that Dave Johnson would return as manager next year but not in 1989.

title: FOR RESORT, A MONTH TO RBMEMBER
description: LEAD: SEPTEMBER may well be remembered as the most productive month for the future of this city since the casino referendum of 1976.

title: MARGARET GRACE FARRELL WEDS VINCENT PLUVINAGE
description: Margaret Grace Farrell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Farrell of Oakdale, L.I., and New Smyrna Beach, Fla., and Vincent Pluvinage, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre Pluvinage of Brussels, were married yesterday. Msgr. John T. Fagan performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Massachusetts Girl, Abuse Case Figure, Is Found in Carolina
description: An 8-year-old girl whose mother took her out of Massachusetts last year, saying she feared that her ex-husband would abuse the child, was found Friday by the authorities in Durham, N.C.

title: NURSING HOMES SEEK MEDICAID RATE RISE
description: LEAD: SAYING they were hard-pressed to hire enough nurses to care for their elderly residents, nursing homes around New Jersey called last week for a $5 increase in the state-set daily rate they receive for Medicaid patients.

title: IT'S A GUESSING GAME FOR JETS
description: The replacement Jets completed a light workout at Giants Stadium this afternoon in a final preparation for Sunday's game with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: 2 American Tourists Are Still in Chinese Custody
description: Two Americans detained by the Chinese in Tibet during violent demonstrations a week ago remain in custody, a State Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Brazilians Skeptical of New Development Plan
description: Sounding more like a candidate campaigning for office than the head of a government already 30 months old, President Jose Sarney has unveiled an ambitious long-term development program that, if carried out, would transform Brazil's badly bruised social profile.

title: FICTION
description: FROM ROCKAWAY. By Jill Eisenstadt. (Knopf, $15.95.) The misadventures of a group of going-nowhere teen-agers in Jill Eisenstadt's first novel, ''From Rockaway,'' would seem to confirm every parent's worst nightmares about what his or her children do when left to their own devices. The book's central characters are a handful of college-age (though not necessarily college-bound) kids, for whom the tedium of their small, dreary world is relieved only by self-destructive rebellion and atavistic ritual. Their realm is the beach in Rockaway (''Rotaway,'' as they refer to it), where many of them work as lifeguards, blowing up seagulls and faking drownings on slow days. What binds Timmy, Peg, and Chowderhead is the suffocating banality of their days on the beach and nights in bars, their friendships cemented by their shared boredom in fast-food emporiums and pizzerias (one of them aptly titled ''The Slice of Life''). They talk about getting out in the way that inmates talk about escaping. Their summer at Rockaway is marked by several hauntingly cruel adolescent rites (not quite rites of passage because nothing is learned or gained). Using shock effects with some skill, ''From Rockaway'' introduces the reader into a little-known subculture on the fringe of New York City. While Ms. Eisenstadt writes fluently and has a sure grasp of her subjects' streetwise vernacular, the novel's relentless focus on this tiresome brat pack fails to generate psychologically valid insights. Possibly, however, this gang is not worth getting to know.

title: Cable TV
description: Three fine films on cable this week are interesting examples of novels lifted from the page to celluloid. In its television debut, E. M. Forster's ''Room With a View'' (1986) arrives on Sunday at 8 P.M. on Showtime, repeating on Thursday at 11:30 P.M. The rarely shown thriller made from John Le Carre's ''Spy Who Came in From the Cold'' (1966) reappears on Sunday at noon and Thursday at 4 P.M. on WHT, and Saturday at 2 P.M. on Cinemax. And Booth Tarkington's ''Magnificent Ambersons,'' bearing the distinct 1942 imprint of director Orson Welles, is due Friday at 3 P.M. on WHT.

title: ALISON SMITH HAS WEDDING
description: At St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn., Alison Vincent Smith, a daughter of Kathleen M. Hodgsdon of Fairfield, Conn., and Peter B. Smith of New York and Sharon, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert John Marcinek, a son of Martin S. Marcinek of Windsor Locks, Conn., and the late Mrs. Marcinek. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll performed the ceremony.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. In the basement of our 80-year-old house the pipes are covered with asbestos and in some places the asbestos is cracking and flaking. We do not use this basement for anything except storage and doing the laundry, but we are still concerned. Should we have this repaired, and if so, by whom?

title: Bulgarian-Turkish Tensions on Minority Rise
description: Tensions between Bulgaria and Turkey over the fate of this country's Turkish minority have risen sharply as a result of remarks by Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey.

title: The East Village of Paris
description: As rents rise and gentrification comes to the once-rundown neighborhoods of Les Halles and the Marais, Paris is moving east. The latest rendezvous of the fashion figures, artists and assorted late risers who set the trends in Paris is the neighborhood stretching east from Place de la Bastille. At its heart is Rue de Lappe.

title: VIRGINIA KNETZGER WEDS J. H. UNGER IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: At St. John Vianney's Roman Catholic Church in Gladwyne, Pa., Virginia Haynes Knetzger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Leonard Knetzger Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., Warwick, Bermuda, and New York, was married yesterday to James Harold Unger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Calvin Unger of Paoli, Pa. The Rev. Anthony Genovese performed the ceremony.

title: 'THE DEADLY GAME,' A THRILLER
description: ''THE DEADLY GAME,'' now at the Arena Players, is an adaptation by James Yaffe of a Friedrich Duerrenmatt's novel. The play is a thriller that milks its chills not from dramatic action, but rather from the subtle interplay of warped intellects. It is a drama that demands its audience pay attention to every word, because the tension builds with the slow, steady, intricate movement of a courtroom drama.

title: In a Quandary
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COLLEEN MARY BARKLEY WED TO MARK D'AUGELLI
description: Colleen Mary Barkley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Barkley of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Mark D'Augelli, the son of John Thomas D'Augelli of North Hills, L.I., and Jene Rose D'Augelli of Williston Park, L.I. The Rev. Patrick Emmanuel and Msgr. Daniel V. Flynn officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Yonkers.

title: NONFICTION
description: MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS: Voice of the River. By Marjory Stoneman Douglas with John Rothchild. (Pineapple Press, $17.95.) Since arriving in Miami in 1915, Marjory Stoneman Douglas has been a writer: first a society reporter and editorial-page columnist at The Miami Herald, then a short-story writer of the Saturday Evening Post era, later and most notably the author of ''The Everglades: River of Grass.'' Now Mrs. Douglas has written about all that and about the many other stories in her life. Her autobiography speaks of the Everglades and her fierce advocacy of South Florida's environment, but it says more about other things: Wellesley College in 1910 and the Balkans after World War I, the fight for suffrage, the houses of Coconut Grove, men in general and hundreds of people known and remembered, in mostly fond detail. Now 97, she is nearly blind, and the book resulted from 200 hours of tape that she dictated and the writer John Rothchild edited. She tells a story plainly. She is crabby, sociable and curious, self-deprecating in some respects (''he was kind of unattractive, so we made a good couple'') and not in others (''with those three words I . . . educated the world as to what the Everglades meant''). Without getting overly involved in them, she states her opinions: for example, that families are commonly terrible, that old age is better than middle age and that she cannot accept the dualism of Western religious thought. She also offers advice, the most important of which is probably to be skeptical, of everything.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEKGAINS IN 3 SHORE DISTRICTS
description: LEAD: IT has been four years since a Democrat has been elected to the Westchester Board of Legislators in one of the three Sound Shore districts, but the party is optimistic that a Mamaroneck Town Councilwoman and two political unknowns will have better luck this year.

title: CORPORATE FACILITATOR: Elmer W. Johnson; Why G.M.'s Rising Star Wants to Shine in the Labor Talks
description: THE stakes are high as always and the issues as difficult as ever, as negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers Union hunker down in G.M.'s headquarters building here for some tough collective bargaining sessions this week.

title: Gripping Realism
description: KAMERADSCHAFT (Brotherhood) Directed by G. W. Pabst from a screenplay by Karl Otten. 1931. From the Janus Collection. Embassy Home Entertainment. 78 minutes. $29.95.

title: Bob Fosse Exits With Tip of Hat to Friends
description: To 66 artists, writers, entertainers and other people who had ''at one time or another during my life been very kind to me,'' Bob Fosse, the choreographer and director who died last month, has left $25,000 ''to go out and have dinner on me.''

title: A SEASON OF GOLDEN CALM IN ANCIENT JERUSALEM
description: Autumn in Jerusalem is a season of deep and generous pause in the ritual and agricultural life of this holy city. Now the sun, the color of old burnished gold, hangs steady in the sky before beginning its slide into winter's silver depths. Soon the sapphire-blue skies of the waning dry season, as if in response to autumnal prayers rising from synagogues the world over, will give way to mists, heralds of winter rains to soak the new-laid seeds and bring on the crops of spring.

title: INTERNATIONAL TONE FOR WEEK
description: THREE offbeat programs with an international flavor highlight the week's concert schedule, beginning today at 3 P.M. when the fine young clarinetist (and Yonkers resident) Esther Lamneck plays a free recital at the White Plains Library that includes a piece for a Hungarian relative of the clarinet called the tarogato.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Scotland vs. England: Scotland beat the United States, 3-0, and England upset the two-time defending champion, Australia, 2-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the Dunhill Cup team tournament in St. Andrew's, Scotland. Nick Faldo, the British Open champion, sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole to clinch England's place in the final after Rodger Davis of Australia, who had shot a course-record 63 Friday, squandered a three-stroke lead over the final three holes. The United States team never recovered from sluggish starts in all three matches. Curtis Strange trailed Sam Torrance by three strokes at the turn; Mark O'Meara fell four behind Sandy Lyle after eight, and D. A. Weibring was two strokes behind Gordon Brand Jr. after three holes.(AP) Brown Increases Lead: Ken Brown of Britain, closing in on his first PGA Tour victory, conquered the wind to shoot a one-under-par 69 and increase his lead to five strokes entering today's final round of the Southern Open in Columbus, Ga. The 30-year-old Brown, who had earlier rounds of 65 and 64, was at 12-under-par 198 over the par-70, 6,791-yard Green Island Country Club course. Mike Hulbert, who was two shots behind Brown entering yesterday's play managed only a two-over-par 72 and was tied for second at 202 with Hale Irwin, who had a 69, including a 35-foot par-saving putt on No. 18.(AP) Littler Has 1-Shot Lead: Gene Littler shot three consecutive birdies yesterday to score a 67 and take a one-shot lead at 137 after two rounds of the Vantage Championship in Clemmons, N.C., the richest event on the PGA Senior Tour. Littler started his surge with a 6-iron that nestled about a foot from the flag on the 15th. He followed with a 4-iron to within 8 feet on the 16th and stroked a wedge to within 4 feet on the 17th. Gay Brewer, who hasn't won on the Senior Tour for three years, managed a 71 and was one shot behind Littler at 138. The winner will go home with a $135,000 first prize.(AP) Tennis String of Upsets Ends: Jim Pugh ended Todd Nelson's run of upsets yesterday with a 6-3, 6-7, 6-4 victory in the semifinals of the Transamerica Open in San Francisco. In the finals, the unseeded Pugh will face the winner of the Ivan Lendl-Peter Lundgren match scheduled for last night. Lendl fought off a serious challenge in the quarterfinals and defeated Dan Goldie of McLean, Va., 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, on Friday night. Nelson, with a world ranking of 165, was the most unlikely semifinalist. He had failed to earn a spot in the draw playing in the qualifying tournament. Nelson was included when Paul Annacone had to drop out because of back trouble.(AP) McNeil to Face Evert: Chris Evert earned a rematch against Lori McNeil, the player who ousted her from last month's U.S. Open, with an injury-induced triumph yesterday in the Virginia Slims of New Orleans. Evert beat Wendy Turnbull, who was forced to retire with a pinched nerve in the big toe of her left foot with the score at 3-2 in the fir

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DANCE
description: LEAD: An Evening With Jiri Kylian and the Nederlands Dans Theater Home Vision. 89 minutes. $39.95.

title: DIANE ADAMS MARRIED TO RICHARD H. R. TOLAND JR.
description: Christ United Methodist Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Diane Lynn Adams, the daughter of Mrs. Halstead J. Adams of New York and Quogue, L.I., and the late Mr. Adams, to Richard H. R. Toland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Toland of Malverne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. David James Randolph performed the ceremony.

title: Iran Sea Attack Reported Foiled
description: Dozens of Iranian Revolutionary Guard speedboats raced in darkness toward a joint Saudi-Kuwaiti oilfield this morning that sends more than $4 million a day to Iraq's war efforts, according to diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

title: MATH AND READING FOR JOBLESS MOTHERS
description: TRYING to help single mothers leave welfare and join the work force or job training is often thwarted by the fact that many of the women cannot read above a fourth-grade level.

title: WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
description: Absolutely not. The idea is repulsive, revolting. If we fans boycott the games, we really sock it to the owners. Oh, how they deserve such sabotage. Not that the players are any better. Like most professional athletes, they earn far too much to complain about anything whatsoever.

title: Hackers, Thieves and Carelessness
description: THE hackers who break into a company's computers are usually on the intellectual equivalent of joyrides. Using their home computers and modems, they prowl the electronic avenues searching for an unlocked computer with the ''key in the ignition'' - one with an easily defeated security system. Once inside, they take the computer for a spin.

title: Varmint Golf
description: COYOTES are curious and at least one would appear to have a yen for golf. Mary Hoover, who competed in the Women's Southwest Golf Association match play tournament at the 49er Country Club in Tuscon last week, said that after she hit a ball in Wednesday's round, a coyote came out of the rough, chased the ball until it bounced to a stop, then rolled on top of it and picked it up.

title: LIVING WITH MS
description: I am a 31-year-old woman who has lived with multiple sclerosis for six years, and I know some who have lived with it for 20. I read with dismay Rand V. Araskog's article ''Award of Honor'' (About Men, Sept. 6). Its depiction of MS was confusing and misleading. MS is a neurological illness that varies considerably from person to person, and even within the same person. It is certainly not a terminal illness, nor is a downward course inevitable. It is true that it can rapidly progress to life in a wheelchair for about one-third of all patients. On the other hand, many people with MS have exacerbations followed by remissions, when symptoms decrease considerably. The unpredictability of the illness is its most common feature, and one that makes MS an emotional battle as well as a physical one. Nevertheless, MS patients can live full and productive lives.

title:
GARDENING;
TO PREPARE FOR THE FROST THAT LIES AHEAD
description: LEAD: YOU might wake up any morning now to find the garden covered with frost. Cold air first settles in low places, so gardens in valleys and low-lying pockets usually are the first to be affected. Since large bodies of water retain heat more effectively than land, gardens near the ocean, Long Island Sound, the Hudson River or a large lake will remain frost-free longer than those inland.

title: POSTINGS: Dobbs Ferry Mansion; Lot Divided For Clusters
description: When the history of suburban real estate development is written, Springhurst Park in Dobb's Ferry, N.Y., could be footnoted as having risen from one of the longest-running approvals struggles ever. It began in 1960, when the late Edward C. Iannace, a Westchester County developer, started seeking cluster zoning for his own eight-acre lot, which supported the family mansion - a nine-bedroom, 7,000-square-foot colonial. He died in 1980, but his son, E. Carl Iannace Jr., now 40 years old, pressed on and finally won the zoning change in 1985.

title: JOANNA DWAN MURRAY WEDS WILLIAM F. BECK
description: Joanna Dwan Murray, a daughter of John C. Murray of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and the late Emmalyn Bishop Murray, was married yesterday to William Fiske Beck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Childress Beck of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph H. Carey performed the ceremony at St. Paul-on-the-Lake Roman Catholic Church in Grosse Pointe Farms. He was assisted by the Rev. Edward A. M. Cobden Jr., an Episcopal priest.

title: New Year Postponed
description: The United States Naval Observatory says 1987 will run long, with one extra second being added to the end of the year. The addition is known as a leap second and is being added to keep clocks in accord with the Earth's rotation, which has slowed ever so slightly.

title: Kean, Seeking New Business, Joins the Asian Parade
description: Governor Kean has returned from a two-week trip to Japan and China, where he learned he was part of a parade.

title: STATE PLANS AND LOCAL PERSPECTIVES
description: WHEN government operates on the level of rhetoric, it is often surprisingly easy to achieve consensus. When, however, it must move from rhetoric to specific policy recommendations, that consensus can evaporate quickly. Often, the discrete meaning of rhetorical principles depends upon one's perspective.

title: Oklahoma O.K.
description: THE University of Oklahoma athletic director, Donnie Duncan, said that the N.C.A.A. had conducted a preliminary investigation of the Sooner football program last month, but he said that the preliminary inquiry had not prompted a follow-up investigation, the usual procedure when apparent infractions are uncovered.

title: WHEN RADICALS WERE IN FLOWER
description: LEAD: STANDING AT ARMAGEDDON The United States, 1877-1919. By Nell Irvin Painter. Illustrated. 402 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Sailing Again Legendary Gulfs and Seas
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TIES WITH CUBA IN WARMING TREND
description: The icy relationship between the United States and Cuba has warmed slightly over the last few months, with both countries softening their positions and indicating a willingness for at least some compromise in hopes of reinstating a key immigration agreement.

title: MAYAN MYSTERIES
description: When did it consciously begin, this delight in decayed or wrecked buildings? Very early, it seems. Since down the ages men have meditated before ruins, rhapsodized before them, mourned pleasurably over their ruination, it is interesting to speculate on the various strands in this complex enjoyment, on how much of it is admiration for the ruin as it was in its prime . . . how much esthetic pleasure in its present appearance . . . how much is association, historical or literary, what part is played by morbid pleasure in decay. . . . - Rose Macaulay, ''Pleasure of Ruins''

title: Street Fashion; Some Spots, for a Change
description: LEOPARD spots are certainly leaving their mark on New York. The distinctive buff and black rosette patterns, which occur naturally on leopards, are now being reproduced artificially on all sorts of things. They're woven into wool and chiffon, stenciled onto leather and calfskin, and even dyed on the top of closely shorn heads (that hairdo should be interesting as it grows out).

title: FOR DRIVER, 2d PLACE WOULD PUT HIM SECOND TO NONE
description: To win the International Motor Sports Association's 1987 Camel GT sports car driving title, all Chip Robinson needs to do at today's Columbus Ford Dealer's 500 is to stay close behind Price Cobb.

title: Pro-Marcos Activity Persists but Ranks Thin
description: Several dozen children were christened Ferdinand and Imelda at a small but emotional rally the other day to mark the 70th birthday of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DEBATE INTENSIFIES ON WAYS TO CURB GROWING DEER POPULATION
description: THE state's deer population, which is on the rise, is providing thrilling sights for nature lovers. It is also causing annoyance to gardeners, economic problems for farmers and severe danger to motorists, particularly Fairfield County motorists.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: GROWING UP IN 'ONE BIG APARTHEID'
description: ''BUCKINGHAM PALACE,'' DISTRICT SIX By Richard Rive. 196 pp. New York: Available Press/Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: SEARCHING FOR PASSION
description: In his essay ''Bottom-Line Days'' (Sunday Observer, Sept. 6), Russell Baker bemoans a current lack of passion in reference to Labor Day and other mores of our society.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CALL ME ANNA: The Autobiography of Patty Duke. By Patty Duke and Kenneth Turan. (Bantam, $17.95.) The pivotal event in Patty Duke's life was her childhood stint on Broadway as the young Helen Keller in ''The Miracle Worker.'' As soon as the search for the actress to play Helen was announced, 12-year-old Patty began practicing walking with her eyes shut for hours, under the supervision of her managers, John and Ethel Ross.

title: POSTINGS: 20 Shops With Offices Above; A Retail 'Mews' for Greenpoint
description: If the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission grants a development team approval, a three-building complex in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn will become a retail ''mews,'' with about 20 shops on the first two levels and office space above. Situated in a historic district, the buildings, at 126-132 Greenpoint Avenue off Manhattan Avenue, functioned most recently as sewing and embroidery factories.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about autumn activities in New England gave incorrect dates for the Connecticut Antiques Show. It will be held at the State Armory in Hartford on Friday from 5 to 10 P.M., Saturday from 1 to 9 P.M. and next Sunday from noon to 5 P.M.

title: ARTICLES ON COLLEGES? REMEMBER ST. JOSEPH'S
description: I am writing to protest the continuous omission of St. Joseph's College from your articles concerning Long Island colleges. The most recent examples appeared on Sept. 6 - [ ''Some College Enrollments Rise and So Does Tuition'' ] .

title: Overtures to Both Sides
description: THE Soviet Union is moving to repair its troubled relations with Iran and at the same time expand Soviet influence among the Arab countries. After the 1979 revolution, Iran cut its economic ties to its superpower neighbor, shutting down a gas pipeline to the southern Soviet Union, and closing Soviet consulates. From 1981 to 1983, thousands of Moscow's Iranian allies, including members of the socialist Mujahedeen Khalq guerrillas and the Communist Tudeh Party, were executed.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: YALE CONCERT Eleazar de Carvalho, the Brazilian conductor and composer, will celebrate his arrival at Yale University by conducting the Yale Philharmonia in a free concert at 8 P.M. Friday in Woolsey Hall. In his new post as professor of music and conductor in residence, Mr. Carvalho will teach advanced students and serve as conductor of the Philharmonia, succeeding Otto-Werner Mueller. His concert will replicate his first appearance in the United States with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in 1947. He will conduct William Schuman's Symphony for Strings, Arnold Schonberg's Chamber Symphony No. 1 (Op. 9), and Hector Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique.'' A student of Serge Koussevitsky, Mr. Carvalho has taught several distinguished conductors, including Seiji Ozawa, Zubin Mehta, Claudio Abbado and Gustav Meier.

title: R. W. DUKER WED TO ALEXIA A. LARR
description: Alexia Aisha Larr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Larr of Rye, N.Y., and Richard Walker Duker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Duker Jr. of Rye, were married there yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Edward Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
description: Yes. The strike creates a fascinating set of ''laboratory conditions'' under which the true worth of the coaches and their systems can be evaluated. Now they are denuded of their star players, and the advantage of a more experienced defensive or offensive line.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
HOW COME THERE'S NEVER A DISCOUNT ON LOVE?
description: LEAD: THE aftermath of a particularly upsetting disagreement between my 10-year-old daughter and me found us facing each other across the kitchen table like two divorce lawyers at the first settlement conference.

title: A LITERARY TRIUMPH: SCARSDALE'S BOOK FAIR
description: IN the life of a book, a book fair is perhaps the final chapter. Removed, perhaps still unread, from the dusty shelf on which it has spent most of its existence, the book joins many of its kind on a table where, under usually chaotic conditions, it is inspected and most likely sold at a fraction of its original retail value.

title: RAVENNA'S JEWELED CHURCHES
description: RAVENNA IS A PLEASANT NORTHERN ITALIAN TOWN practically on the Adriatic coast. The city and its surroundings are flat, which makes for easy walking and accounts for the city's bicycle cult. Bicycles are parked thickly, leaving the streets comparatively free of standing cars.

title: IT'S TIME FOR THE JETS TO SACK MARK GASTINEAU
description: IF the Jets hope to create the locker-room love that a Super Bowl contender needs, Mark Gastineau must be sacked as soon as possible. He is no longer a ''teammate,'' if he ever was. He must be shipped away, preferably in a trade that will enhance the Jets' future.

title: DOING GOOD BUT NOT WELL
description: THEIR PRIDE AND JOY By Paul Buttenwieser. 442 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $18.95.

title: A Mark of Greatness
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: MUSIC TALKS:

title: FICTION
description: CAFE NEVO. By Barbara Rogan. (Atheneum, $19.95.) The Cafe Nevo is a seedy, dusty Tel Aviv bistro that operates as a stage for the handful of querulous artistic souls who regularly collect there to concoct literary schemes, flaunt extramarital liaisons and achieve respite from the omnipresent reality of the war in Lebanon as well as the past sorrows of the flight from Germany that carried many to the Middle East. Named after the mountain from which Moses espied the Promised Land, the cafe provides a sort of spiritual sustenance for those who frequent it - eating and imbibing are but an afterthought. Nevo is presided over by Emmanuel Sternholz, a crusty, septuagenarian waiter whose dreams died with his wife and child in the Holocaust. Sternholz is an insomniac with an active conscience that more than compensates for the less than astute morals of his clientele; having repressed his own personal life, he now avidly monitors the private lives of his regular customers. Transients - especially women, whom he suspects of stirring things up - are not welcome at Nevo, though there are exceptions, like the aging courtesan, Llana, a woman journalist and a prescient artist. Sexual terrorism, literary one-upmanship and disillusionment over the fate of the Jewish state constitute the conversational mix of Nevo's habitues. Everyone has a weighty problem, and the author rushes along, not always convincingly, trying to connect them all. Eventually Nevo becomes the redemptive vehicle for an often cumbersome array of characters. Sternholtz, the most intriguing of the lot, realizes that thanks to the Mecca that is his cafe, life has its core after all.

title: Glimpses of Old China in Modern Beijing
description: EVERY TIME I RETURN TO BEIJING AND SEE its skyline growing with cell-blocklike high-rise apartments, drive through its charmless streets and have to breathe the polluted air, I am reminded of how far the city has drifted from its past and wonder how the myth of Beijing as a beautiful city redolent of history has managed to survive its modern esthetic impoverishment.

title: THE HOUSE THAT NAILS BUILT
description: AMERICA BY DESIGN By Spiro Kostof. Illustrated. 388 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: A Fight in D.C.; The Return Of the Bottle Bill
description: BECAUSE it is being waged in the District of Columbia, both sides say there is more than usual at stake in the latest battle over whether to require a deposit on bottles and cans: If the District's voters say yes to Initiative 28 on Nov. 3, other states may be encouraged to go forward with similar measures.

title: Hempstead's Streak at 31
description: After two weeks of play, the talent-laden Long Island high-school football scene has presented fans with plenty of theatrics.

title: NOVELIST TAKES A SOCIAL INITIATIVE
description: AT 64, the novelist William Denby has lived through the despairing and the joyful contradictions fate can hurl a man or a woman:

title: SHOWY FLOWER FOR A COOL SEASON
description: HIGHWAYS and country roadsides boast plumes of wild flowers, seed pods and grasses that might be clipped and gathered in bunches to hang dry upside down. They can be used later in floral arrangements for the house during winter. Keep up with harvest from the vegetable and fruit gardens. Finish digging, dividing and replanting the early-blooming perennials. Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing. Prune watersprouts and suckers from magnolias, dogwoods and mountain ashes. An Aster

title: THE GOD WHO HAS EVERYTHING
description: ''EVERYTHING,'' AN operagoer who had just made first contact with Wagner's Wotan was overheard saying, ''is in there.'' The spontaneous exclamation resonates well with both the generalities and the particulars of the role, one of opera's richest and most difficult. Wotan - the Norse god Odin, All-father, War-father - wants to shape the world and everything in it as Wagner wanted to remake not just music but all of art. The part is not only the pinnacle of the heroic bass-baritone's repertory but something beyond, a challenge of Shakespearean proportions for the actor, and a symbol for experience so universal that analysis and discussion of him is no more limited to the sphere of operatic criticism than the contemplation of Hamlet is left to theater buffs.

title: Woody Herman Gravely Ill
description: Woody Herman was in critical condition today at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. The 74-year-old band leader was on a life-support system in the intensive care unit, the spokesman, Ron Wise said. Mr. Herman was hospitalized Thursday because of congestive heart failure, emphysema and pneumonia, said his attorney, Kirk Pasich.

title: LIVING WITH MS
description: At a time when nurses are valiantly struggling to gain the professional recognition they have long deserved, we encounter the viewpoint of Rand Araskog, chairman and chief executive officer of I.T.T., who states ''the nurses were young, attractive and friendly.'' Why wasn't any mention made of the intelligence, efficiency and competence of these nurses? I find it disheartening that a man of Mr. Araskog's stature and influence in the corporate world could neglect to see beyond the stereotypical image of nurses. How will nurses ever achieve the pay and respect commensurate with their responsibilities and educational background if we don't abandon this archaic image? THOMAS HOOKER Selden, N.Y.

title: HUNTINGTON SUED ON HOUSING
description: LEAD: THE TOWN of Huntington, having defeated a suit charging racial discrimination in housing, is now being sued for its public housing proposal in the Melville area.

title: 68 Seized in France in Effort Against Basque Separatists
description: Hundreds of police officers seeking to stop terrorist operations by Basque separatists based in France arrested 68 people today, officials said.

title: About Men; The Dark Playground
description: I MET LEE SIX MONTHS after she had been raped.

title: Honduran Bombing Suspect Is Given Asylum by Mexico
description: Mexico has granted permanent asylum in its embassy here to a man suspected of planting a bomb that exploded in a Chinese restaurant in August, slightly wounding six United States soldiers and a Honduran civilian.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Merrimack, N.H.;
Society Hill Moves North
description: LEAD: THE largest builder in New Jersey, the K. Hovnanian Companies of Red Bank, has made its opening move into the New England real-estate market.

title: ABETTING A BAD IMAGE OF NORTHEAST STUDENTS
description: ''Taking a Freshman to College: An Education in Itself'' [ Aug. 16 ] is the kind of article that feeds directly into Secretary of Education William J. Bennett's negative conception of the upper-middle-class college student attending private institutions in the Northeast. The particular situation smacks of a materialism so crass as to exclude the experience of a great many entering freshmen and their parents.

title: Poll Shows Jackson and Bush Holding Solid Leads in the South
description: Five months before the South picks a quarter of the Presidential convention delegates for both parties, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Vice President Bush hold substantial leads in the region, according to a poll of 6,452 Southerners conducted for The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.

title: Film:'Near Dark,' a Tale of Vampires on the Road
description: IS ''Near Dark'' a mainstream commercial movie, tinged with blood, about an Oklahoma farm boy seduced and abducted by vampires? Or is it a fast-money thriller with artsy photography, about rowdy bloodsuckers who live like bikers and drive by night?

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CONSTITUTIONAL PARADE The village of Mamaroneck celebrates the bicentennial of the Constitution at 1:30 P.M. today with a parade. According to the organizers, it replicates an impromptu parade on Sept. 17, 1787, when the citizens of Philadephia turned out in droves and marched through the streets in support of the Constitution, which had just been signed. People from all walks of life are expected to participate, carrying the tools of their trade in imitation of their forebears. Plumbers, teachers, merchants, lawyers, doctors, municipal officials, clergymen, carpenters, fishermen, and whosoever else may turn up, should provide a colorful spectacle as they walk or ride in appropriate vehicles from the Mamaroneck Avenue School to Harbor Island Park, where the Lions Club will treat them all to refreshments.

title: HELEN F. MICHALIS IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Helen Fahnestock Michalis to Michael Hayden Bonebrake, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bonebrake of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. A January wedding is planned.

title: DONNA JEAN TESI WEDS BRIAN LAFFERTY, LAWYER
description: The marriage of Donna Jean Tesi to Brian P. Lafferty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Lafferty of Hicksville, L.I., took place yesterday at the home of Jean Needy, the mother of the bride, in Hyde Park, N.Y. Town Justice Matthew P. Fitzgerald of Hyde Park performed the ceremony.

title: Even Revolutionaries Smile for the Camera
description: FOREIGN SPOKESMEN, APOLO-gists and officials are speaking to us directly, and more often than before.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Hauppauge Epilogue: A New Social Hub
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING its opening in 1971, the Colonie Hill hotel, catering facility and golf course in South Hauppauge became the Island's premier center for social events. Its glittering 40,000-square-foot banquet room and ballroom, able to accommodate 4,500 diners, drew most of the major political and charity functions.

title: Theater: 'Ambition,' By Halasz
description: IN considering ''Ambition,'' a new play written, directed and designed by Peter Halasz, one must make a clear distinction between technique and both script and performance. As an experiment in the use of film as a scenic, three-dimensional background for live theater, ''Ambition'' is inventive. However, the design elements of the production are vitiated by Mr. Halasz's play, an artless adaptation of Andre Maurois's story ''Palace Hotel Thanatos,'' and by the general ineptitude of the cast. A presentation of Squat-Love Theater (a spin-off of Squat Theater), ''Ambition'' is running at La Mama.

title: EXPANSION OF MARINE POLICE IS URGED
description: THE Marine Bureau of the State Police has been described as an agency so underfinanced that it could not respond to many accidents, keep its own records or serve as a visible deterrent to crime on the state's waterways.

title: Shortage of Drug Treatment Imperils AIDS Control
description: A shortage of space in drug treatment programs around the country is leading to expected waits of as long as a year, a problem not just for addicts but also for a society threatened by the spread of AIDS.

title: TWO GERMANYS, MANY VOLUMES
description: Germany: one people, two nations, a rich and tortured past. How to grasp it all? Start chronologically with the 19th century, I suppose. Bismarck's memoirs were best sellers in their time and offered modern Germans a vision of what they would like to be. Thomas Mann's ''Buddenbrooks'' portrays the self-confident German middle class before the catastrophes of the 20th century. Mark Twain's travel writings on Germany remain hilariously contemporary on the foibles of the up-tight citizenry. Hermann Hesse's eternally popular ''Steppenwolf'' and ''Narcissus and Goldmund,'' written just before Hitler came to power, dwell on man's dual nature. Alfred Doblin's ''Berlin Alexanderplatz'' catches the raucous tone of prewar Berlin.

title: Hardship Is a Byproduct of Prosperity
description: For the past 35 years, Cole Farms, a restaurant in Gray, about 15 miles north of here, has been open every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: PALY-OFF PREVIEW
description: ALL the signs point to an American victory in the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl due to begin in a week's time in Ocho Rios, Jamaica. The United States has the same experienced squad that won two years ago in Sao Paulo, Brazil: Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas, and four California players, Chip Martel of Davis, Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Hugh Ross of Oakland, and Peter Pender of San Francisco. Pender has been in poor health, however, and he and Ross are likely to be on the sidelines much of the time.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $167,000 10 Stanley Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 25-year-old split level; wall-to-wall carpeting, central A/C, pool, family room; taxes $2,496. Livingston $172,000 19 Redwood Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, expandable attic, newly painted, 1-car garage; taxes $2,092. title: PRODUCER OF MODEL T PLAYERS
description: Sometimes, by the time Vinnie O'Connor travels from his job as supervisor of health and physical education for Public School District 19 in Brooklyn to his job as head football coach at St. Francis Prep in Queens, practice is already under way.

title: GROSHANS' 'MYSTERIOUS REALISM' AT THE JERSEY CITY MUSEUM
description: IT USED to be that everyone understood what was meant by realism; however, for much of the 20th century, the term has been in doubt. After all, the new realism that raged in Germany in the 1920's is not to be confused with the new realism that was Pop or, for that matter, with metaphysical, magical or romantic realism. What a thing to do to language! Now comes ''Mysterious Realism.'' At least, this is how Prof. William Gerdts of the City University of New York's Graduate School describes the paintings of Werner Groshans (1913-86) now at the Jersey City Museum.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TIME SIFTERS
description: LEAD: A GROUP of Westchester archeologists are holding an open house today, and they said they were hoping that as many people as possible drop by their digs.

title:
INVESTING;
A Fund With Three Strategies
description: LEAD: IN the last year or so, Wall Street has sold value funds, country funds, hot-manager funds, sector funds, bond funds and even a fund investing in emerging countries. What most of these closed-end investment companies have in common, apart from tidy fees for their underwriters and an annuity-like stream of income for their managers, is losses for those who invested at the initial offering prices when they came to market.

title: AIDS BRINGS EXPANDED DEBATE ON RIGHTS OF THE TERMINALLY ILL
description: IT seemed the stuff of a nightmare from fiction: a fatal disease ravaging the man's body from within, his decision to forgo heroic, life-prolonging steps and the doctors' decision to ignore those wishes and perform their medical magic on the comatose body.

title: A REVERIE FOR THE GYPSIES OF THE AIR
description: PERHAPS it'll happen like this: I'll be strolling by a lake, feeding the ducks some crusts of brown bread from my lunch. I'll be laughing and trying to toss a big piece to the poor little female in the back while all the swift, fat mallards clamor around greedily, biting one another's tails.

title: The Unregulator
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Maurice' Brings A Small Book Into Sharp Relief By Focusing on Images of an Era
description: THE PAPERBACK OF E. M. Forster's ''Maurice'' that has been brought out to coincide with the film of the novel bears a time-honored slogan on its cover: ''Now a Major Motion Picture.'' I don't think such a claim would have appealed much to Forster himself, who always made rather a point of not being a major anything; and since ''Maurice'' is by common consent the least successful of his novels, even his warmest admirers are likely to quail at the thought of a movie inflating the book beyond its proper dimensions. ''Now a Minor Motion Picture'' would have been more reassuring.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Amherst, Mass.;
Storm Over A Golf Course
description: LEAD: THE serene beauty of the nine-hole golf course in a northern section of this university town belies the storm that has risen since its owner, David E. Maxson Sr., decided to sell the 99-acre parcel almost two years ago.

title: POST-POLIO VICTIMS FIND HELP
description: LEAD: FOR years Edward Bollenbach was in top physical condition.

title: BARNUM MEMORABILIA TO BE EXHIBITED AT YALE
description: It won't be the greatest show on earth, but a display headed for Yale University will offer a sampling of P.T. Barnum's famous circus.

title: 'THE JAILYARD SCHOOL'
description: NOTHING BUT THE BEST The Struggle for Perfection at the Juilliard School. By Judith Kogan. 239 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title:
GARDENING;
TO PREPARE FOR THE FROST THAT LIES AHEAD
description: LEAD: YOU might wake up any morning now to find the garden covered with frost. Cold air first settles in low places, so gardens in valleys and low-lying pockets usually are the first to be affected. Since large bodies of water retain heat more effectively than land, gardens near the ocean, Long Island Sound, the Hudson

title: MODEST SLICES OF CANADIAN LIFE
description: Margaret Atwood, one of a group of contemporary writers whose works have made a deserved mark outside Canada as well as at home, offered an explanation some years ago for the ennui with which foreign publishers have often reacted to Canada's best writers.

title: Elena Sofonova: From Russia, With Love
description: ELENA SOFONOVA DOES IT ALL with her eyes. She suffers with them, smiles with them, searches with them - now for love, now simply for self-respect. Soft and deep-set above the high Slavic cheekbones, they seem by far the strongest of her tools as an actress. For her last two films, first the 1985 Soviet film ''Winter Cherries'' and now the widely admired Italian-Soviet offering, ''Dark Eyes,'' they have given her a way to evoke eloquently and almost silently the emotions of a charming and charmable woman who wants something more out of life than charm.

title: Farrell Pounds Holy Cross, 30-6
description: Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island, last season's Catholic High Schools Football League champion, won its second game of this season in much the same way it won all the games on its schedule last year. The Lions were led by their fine quarterback, Gary Wilkos, over Holy Cross, 30-6.

title: Arthur Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography
description: Mark Feldstein has all the instincts of a street photographer but none of the usual reliance on inherited stylistic ideas. Since giving up painting for photography more than a decade ago, he has progressed from an early fascination with the medium's ability to describe surfaces to a sophisticated understanding of the ways in which chance and ambiguity shape the meaning of images.

title: NASA's Manned-Space Nonsense
description: Today marks the 30th anniversary of the Sputnik launching, which prompted a shocked United States Government to make a major investment in engineering and space exploration. One has to wonder what sort of shock it will take to return our misdirected space effort to the right path. Clearly, the Challenger tragedy wasn't enough.

title: Add a Tax Surcharge and Loosen Money
description: THE President and Congress must deal with the consequences of a decade of experiments in political economics. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, will share this responsibility, as will leaders in Europe and Japan. Collectively they have a genuine opportunity to rebalance the global economy by the end of the next Presidential term.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended Sept. 19 MANHATTAN East Midtown $355,000 140 East 56th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,242-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, two exposures; common charge $750, taxes $3,600 (Broker: Arthur P. Brooks Realty) Greenwich Village $340,000 14 East 4th Street (Silk Building) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,115-sq.-ft. condo in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen, hardwood floors; common charge $315, taxes $600 (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Greenwich Village $85,000 60 East 9th Street 400-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, renovated lobby, separate kitchen; maintenance $285, 50% tax-deductible (Broker:

title:
HOME VIDEO;
TRAVEL
description: LEAD: Vidal in Venice Written and hosted by Gore Vidal. A.C. Video. Part I, 55 minutes; $29.95. Part II, 55 minutes. $29.95.

title: TEXAS TECH SUPRISES A&M, 27-21
description: Tyrone Thurman, who is only 5 feet 3 inches and 130 pounds, returned a punt 74 yards for a touchdown to launch Texas Tech to a 27-21 Southwest Conference upset of Texas A&M today.

title: Picture Darkens for Would-Be Apple Pickers
description: Contrary to statements a week ago, the state's apple industry will apparently not need any additional help from hundreds of migrant workers who have been living on handouts while waiting for work.

title: ALASKA SEEKS HALT TO PLUTONIUM PLAN
description: Alaska has filed suit against the Federal Government to block proposed shipments of plutonium from Europe to Japan that might require a fuel stop in the state.

title: Caring For the Condor
description: ''THEY'RE ALLOPREENING,'' says Donald J. Sterner, hopefully, of the two California condors shown above. The endangered birds are circumspect breeders, a problem for Sterner, whose job it is, as lead condor keeper at the San Diego Wild Animal Park, to assist the perpetuation of the species. Allopreening, a ritual that frequently precedes the male's formal courtship of the female, consists of ''bits of behavior that bring them closer, nibbling each others' feathers, head and neck rubbing,'' Sterner says. ''It's kind of a slow form of foreplay.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: VERSATILE VIRTUOSI To open its new season in Brookville today, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony drops a well-known name in classical music: Menuhin. Jeremy Menuhin, that is, the pianist son of the celebrated violinist father, Yehudi. Mr. Menuhin plays Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 (''Emperor''), and the orchestra, under the baton of Kenneth Klein, performs Mozart's ''Impresario Overture'' and Haydn's Symphony No. 44 in E minor (''Mourning Symphony''). The concert is at 7 P.M. at the Hillwood Commons Theater on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University. For ticket information call 626-3378.

title: Mary Ballard Adler Engaged To Marry Vikram Malhotra
description: Announcement has been made by Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Mary Ballard Adler to Vikram Malhotra, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jagdish C. Malhotra of New York and Bombay, India. A May wedding is planned.

title: Even Offstage, These Performers Are Onstage
description: MARTHA GRAHAM HAS often told us that ''theater is not a noun, it is a verb.'' The term ''theater'' derives from the Greek, signifying a place where things are to be seen. The connotations of activity and of display in these definitions are especially applicable to dance as a theatrical art. Nobody feels constrained to use the word ''proscenium'' to define the essence of theater.

title: SUMMER'S HEAT DAMAGES POTATO CROP IN LONGEST DRY PERIOD SINCE THE MID-60'S
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND potato farmers were hard hit by a summer drought this year, causing some to lose more than one-third of their crop, despite spending tens of thousands of dollars on irrigation.

title: On Language; The Penumbra Of Desuetude
description: AS ALWAYS, TELE-vised hearings churn up new uses of old terms. As the Senate deliberated the nomination to the Supreme Court of Judge Robert H. Bork, logophiles weighed the words of the solons and the nominee.

title: RECISION IN MICHNER
description: To the Editor:

title: DECLINE IN STUDENTS AT MEDICAL SCHOOLS
description: FEWER students are applying each year to the University of Connecticut School of Medicine in Farmington and at the Yale School of Medicine in New Haven, Connecticut's two medical schools.

title: Q and A
description: Fee for Check on a Tenant Question: To lease our Manhattan apartment, the condominium's by-laws require us to obtain a waiver of the Right of First Refusal from the building's board of managers. To receive the waiver the board requires that a copy of the tenant's lease and financial information on our renter be sent to the managing agent. For this process the managing agent has requested a fee of $300 each time there is a new renter. Is this legal and, if so, is the fee excessive? . . . M. L., Manhattan Answer: This type of fee is both legal and customary.

title: Used Well, These Tests Can Save Lives
description: HOW many lives have been saved or improved by home diagnostic tests? How many babies have been carried to term because their mothers used home pregnancy tests early on? And how many people are alive and well because results from occult blood tests prompted them to seek treatment?

title: LIFE IN THE SLOW LANE
description: THE DAY OF JUDGMENT By Salvatore Satta. Translated by Patrick Creagh. 300 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: FOOD BANKS SEEING FRESH PRODUCE RISE
description: LEAD: LAST spring, a colleague at a Boston food bank asked Kitty Schaller, associate director of the Newark-based Community Food Bank, if she was interested in fresh pineapples.

title: Bacteria Resistant to Drugs Spreading Illness, U.S. Says
description: The National Centers for Disease Control say that a drug-resistant strain of shigellosis that was first reported to have afflicted thousands of people at a July gathering in North Carolina has now apparently spread to four other settings.

title: Suspect Shot by State Trooper
description: A man stopped for suspected drunken driving led the police on a high-speed chase, hurt a deputy with a rock, and was wounded several hours later by a state trooper after aiming a shotgun at officers, the police said.

title: Syracuse Reaches 5-0
description: Don McPherson completed 11 of 23 passes for 211 yards, including a 71-yard touchdown pass play, as Syracuse won its fifth consecutive game by defeating a turnover-plagued Missouri squad today, 24-13.

title: Contra Chief's Harvard Appearance Disrupted
description: A leader of the Nicaraguan rebels was supposed to speak at Harvard Law School on Friday but was driven off the stage before he could utter a word.

title: WHAT IS ART? IN OLD SAYBROOK, IT'S JUNK
description: AT first glance, the heaps of tools, scrap iron, old hoses, nails and screws seem like, well, heaps of junk. But, here and there, a car jack has sprouted eyes, or a pair of hedge clippers, claws. These are not simply rusting old tools; all are in various stages of transformation from junk into creatures known as ''critters by Otis,'' as named by their creator, Theodore Otis Soule.

title: SWITCHING OVER TO STEEL SHOT
description: WATERFOWLING seasons are approaching, and although you may plan to hunt where lead shot is still allowed, you should start using the nontoxic steel shot that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service will require for duck and goose hunting nationwide by 1991.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN THE SHADOW OF THE STATE HOUSE
description: LEAD: RESTAURANTS in the Chambersburg section of Trenton draw customers from Philadelphia, as well as Princeton and other nearby New Jersey towns. Until recently, most of them were known for their southern Italian cuisine, but now practically every region of Italy is represented in the area's dining establishments.

title: Beyond the Boom: Where Do We Go From Here?
description: A REPORT by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last week reaffirmed that the 10-year expansion of the metropolitan area's economy has continued this year, fueled by a sustained boom in construction and resulting in the lowest unemployment rate in nearly two decades. But the analysis, like several other recent assessments, also asked if the expansion is becoming more than the area will be able to handle.

title: CEMETERY OF JACKSON POLLOCK AND OTHER ARTISTS MAY EXPAND
description: What put Green River Cemetery on the map was the burial there of the Abstract Expressionist painter Jackson Pollock after a car accident in 1956. The 50-ton memorial boulder, hauled to his knoll-top grave site by friends and fellow artists, drips green with lichens. The stone-imbedded bronze plaque bearing a facsimile of his signature is green now, too, with age.

title: Dance: From France, Monnier and Duroure
description: MONNIER/DUROURE is the latest group to make a notable splash on the experimental dance scene in France. Having just performed at the Los Angeles Festival and Montreal's International New Dance Festival, it made its official New York City debut Thursday night, presented by Dance Theater Workshop at the Bessie Schonberg Theater (219 West 19th Street).

title: Data Update: October 4, 1987

WINE;
SANGRIA: POPULAR, VERSATILE
description: LEAD: IN a recent series of wine and food pairings, sangria was found to provide ideal accompaniment to a wide range of fare. In fact, this popular punch from Spain - the forerunner of the cooler - mated perfectly with specialties often difficult to marry with higher-priced wines. Also, great variance was noted in the quality of commercially prepared sangria sold at area retail outlets.

title: GOLDEN CITY BY THE BAY
description: I HAVE VISITED SAN FRANCISCO AT least once a year for the last 20 years, yet the trigger of memory still evokes that pristine vision: an ocean liner moving out into the Pacific against the bare hills of Sausalito and, above it, rising from the fog, mystic, wonderful as the sword Excalibur, the graceful red span of the bridge. And I, standing on the wharf on that autumnal day, beside a kiosk that was offering out-of-date Australian newspapers, told myself that now I was as far from home as I had ever been, at the farthermost tip of the Western world, the gateway to an Orient known to me only from books and films and dreams.

title: Newark College Reaches Accord in Racial Dispute
description: A white fraternity and four minority groups at the New Jersey Institute of Technology that clashed over an advertisement for a party have reached an agreement to settle the dispute and ease racial tensions, school officials said Friday.

title: Spivakov on the Joys Of Musical Glasnost
description: PERHAPS it was the aura of glasnost surrounding him, but Vladimir Spivakov, elegant in his pinstriped blue suit, looked remarkably fresh on Friday night - coming directly from 22 hours in the air and a drive into Manhattan from Kennedy Airport. The Soviet violinist and conductor is here from Moscow with the chamber orchestra he formed eight years ago, the Moscow Virtuosi. The ensemble makes its United States debut this afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall and then sets off for concerts in 13 other American cities.

title: IN THE ARMS OF MORPHEUS
description: LEAD: DAUGHTER OF THE SWAN By Joan Juliet Buck. 336 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: JAN BENZEL, AN EDITOR, MARRIES STUART ROHRER
description: Jan Winslow Benzel, an editor in the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times, and Stuart Allen Rohrer, an electronic-media consultant in New York, were married yesterday at the Ventana Inn in Big Sur, Calif., by the Rev. Richard Eldred Jr., a minister of the Universal Life Church.

title: A Tip of the Hat to Bob Fosse
description: BEFORE THE DAY'S RE-hearsal of ''Dancin','' his 1978 Broadway show, Bob Fosse stopped to answer a few questions, but his mind was not on conversation; his feet wanted to work. Then he put on a pair of white gloves and faced his dancers, all of whom were wearing identical white gloves and straw hats at a rakish Fosse tilt (over one eye, as if to ward off the glare of artificial light). In imitation of the director, the cast stepped into ''I Want to Be a Dancin' Man.'' As he danced, and as he led dancers, he was at home - and he was flowing with creative energy. Fosse, who died Sept. 23 at the age of 60, was a dynamo, and his personal magnetism electrified the dozen Broadway musicals that he directed and/or choreographed.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
PROOF SET AUCTION FEATURES A RARE SILVER DOLLAR
description: LEAD: THE King of Siam proof set, one of the most coveted sets in numismatics, will be offered for sale at auction Oct. 14 in New York. There is a reserve bid of $2 million. If the set is sold for that amount or more, it will set a record.

title: Rainfall Damages Mighty Wurlitzer of Brooklyn
description: What screaming rock fans and cheering basketball fans and even the incendiary devices of George Metesky, the Mad Bomber of the 1950's, did not do in 60 years, has been accomplished by months of rainfall - the silencing of the mighty 1928 Wurlitzer theater organ at the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater.

title: CENTRAL PARK WEST TOWER APPROVED
description: Amid vociferous community opposition, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved a scaled-down plan for a condominium tower attached to the abandoned Towers Nursing Home building on Central Park West at 106th Street.

title: SCHOOL BUS ISSUE HEATING UP
description: LEAD: SAYING they fear for the safety of their children, parents in a newly formed group in Hastings-on-Hudson want the state to order their school district to resume door-to-door busing of all students in nonpublic schools.

title: REAGAN IMPLORES THE PUBLIC TO AID IN FIGHT FOR BORK
description: Reviving a tactic that has served him many times in the past, President Reagan today urged supporters of Judge Robert H. Bork to flood Capitol Hill with appeals to confirm him for the Supreme Court.

title: Art
description: ''History painting'' as a mode of contemporary art is the pretentious premise for a show of big figurative canvases at New York University's Grey Art Gallery (through Oct. 24). The term refers to the highest genre of art from the Renaissance to the mid-19th century - the rendering of elevated themes from classical or Biblical sources that served as vehicles for moral commentary. History painting faded out as its universe of symbols was shattered by the increasingly divergent beliefs of modern society, and as interest developed in art as a more personal form of expression.

title: Fire at Reactor in Colorado
description: A 15-minute fire caused minor damage at a turbine building at the Fort St. Vrain nuclear power plant here today. No injuries were reported and officials said no radiation had been released.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Compleat Forecast

title: GROWTH AND GARBAGE ADD UP TO PROBLEMS ALONG ROUTE 18
description: WHEN Route 18 was widened to four lanes nearly 30 years ago, this part of Middlesex County was relatively undeveloped and the highway functioned largely as a local road.

title: MASTER REPUBLICAN
description: JAMES MADISON The Founding Father. By Robert Allen Rutland. 287 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: RIDING THE RAILS TO NEW YORK CITY
description: IF Ivan Lendel commuted from Greenwich to the U.S. Open, I wonder whether he used Metro-North. I've never seen him on the platform and I'm sure I'd notice someone carrying five tennis rackets.

title: Aaron L. Jacoby, Ex-Chief of P.S.C., Dies at 94
description: Aaron L. Jacoby, a once influential Democrat who held a series of public offices including that of New York State Public Service Commissioner, died of complications of a stroke early Friday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 94 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: New Tamil Raids in Sri Lanka
description: Tamil separatists continued a rampage against majority Sinhalese residents today in attacks that have left more than 2,500 homeless in the last three days.

title: Eastern Europe for Westerners
description: Not all that long ago, a correspondent reporting from Central and Eastern Europe would get the occasional letter from enterprising but somewhat timorous readers that made him feel that he ought to be asking his editor for hazard pay. Such writers would inquire, in direct or circumlocuted terms, ''Is it safe for an American to come as a tourist to such dangerously Communist places as Poland or Hungary?'' My standard answer was, I recall, something like: ''It's safer for an American than for a Pole or Hungarian. Come ahead.'' Such letters don't arrive any more. Instead, Americans do, in increasing numbers. So do Western Europeans, who also were not immune to anxiety in the past. Curiosity has got the better of them.

title: USE, BUT NEVER ABUSE
description: HEMLINES are rising, ties widening, lapels thickening. We live, it seems, in a world of fashion, and photography is not immune to its influence. Fashion is especially a factor when it comes to how we tote our cameras around.

title: SUFFICIENT WARNING
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Different PTL THE Bible breaks will continue at the PTL Equipment Company in Huntington Station. Executives of the elevator-fixtures manufacturing company have no plans to change their operations or their name because of the PTL scandal or Jessica Hahn's recent Playboy magazine article.

title: Dr. Fred J. Benjamin Is Dead; Radio Health Program Host
description: Dr. Fred J. Benjamin, a general practitioner and radiologist who practiced in Brooklyn and Manhattan and was the host in recent years of a radio program on health, died of a heart attack on Sept. 26 at New York Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Inmates Working as Medics in Rural Illinois
description: The Johnson County ambulance crew makes emergency runs like any other team of medical technicians. But at the end of the day some members of the crew do not go home. They go to prison.

title: UNBEATEN HOLY CROSS ROLLS
description: Undefeated Holy Cross showed its strength today in a 49-7 rout of Colgate, the team regarded as the foremost rival on its schedule. This was the fourth victory for the Crusaders; it was the second defeat in five games for Colgate, a Colonial League rival.

title: JANE BUCKLEY HAS WEDDING
description: Hylda Jane Buckley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael B. Buckley of Watertown, Conn., and Christopher Newell Hurd, the son of Edward A. Hurd of Chicago and Nancy Whitney Lutz of Redding, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Blanchfield performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Waterbury, Conn.

title: South Africa Floods Kill 174 And More Rain Is Predicted
description: Floods in Natal Province may have killed more than 250 people, with the official death toll at 174 and 86 people missing, officials reported today. More rain was forecast.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, a sentence in Travel Advisory last Sunday about sales tax refunds appeared at the end of an item about a food festival in Lyons, France. The sentence, which said refunds take six to eight weeks to be processed, should have appeared at the end of the item about the provincial sales tax in Ontario, Canada.

title: PROPOSAL TO RESTRICT NUDITY IS ASSAILED
description: I oppose Kenneth Herman's recent suggestion that the clothing-optional area be restricted [ ''Nudity Ban Sought at Fire I. Light,'' Aug. 23 ] .

title:
GARDENING;
TO PREPARE FOR THE FROST THAT LIES AHEAD
description: LEAD: YOU might wake up any morning now to find the garden covered with frost. Cold air first settles in low places, so gardens in valleys and low-lying pockets usually are the first to be affected. Since large bodies of water retain heat more effectively than land, gardens near the ocean, Long Island Sound, the Hudson

title: KATHRYN M. RADCLIFFE WEDS FRANCIS LAWRENCE MUSTARO
description: Kathryn Marie Radcliffe and Francis Lawrence Mustaro were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Carl B. Nelson.

title: A Family Of Firsts
description: IN MY FAMILY, SUCCESS IS WEIGHED BY A single standard: The ability to be first. It does not matter what you are first at as long as you are first at something.

title: Rain Is Called the Best Cure For Chesapeake Oyster Beds
description: There is no miracle cure in sight for the Chesapeake Bay's disease-ravaged oysters, but stocks would rebound in five years or less with a year or two of normal rainfall, marine scientists say.

title: REDISCOVERING BERYL MARKHAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Controlling the Risk in Mutual Funds
description: FOR investors eager to get in on the bull market but skeptical of their ability to pick good stocks, most brokers, advisers and financial columnists in recent years have advised buying a mutual fund, particularly one with a superior, long-term track record. Often the broker or adviser has just such a fund at hand, which may be managed in-house or carry a generous sales commission. Disinterested advisers usually add the words ''no load,'' or no sales charge, to the list of characteristics that make a fund attractive.

title: ARTISTS CRAFT WORLDLY SOUNDS
description: SOME people not only follow the beat of a different drummer, but create different drums -and other instruments - as well. They make hand-crafted musical instruments that range from wooden drums played for relaxation to classical Turkish lutes used by musical scholars.

title: ANN SHANNON BECOMES THE BRIDE OF BYRON REIMUS
description: Ann Shannon, a daughter of Dorothy A. Shannon-Adams of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Raymond A. Shannon, and Byron Reimus, a son of George H. Reimus of Doorn, the Netherlands, and Marika Wallach-Chiotakis of St. Louis, were married yesterday at the Union Club in New York. The Rev. Robert S. Bilheimer, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Social Events; Standard, Ethnic and Novel
description: Evening at Maxim's

title: DATA BANK: September 27, 1987
KEY VOTE DUE ON RENT LEVELS IN COUNTY
description: THE Westchester Rent Guidelines Board is expected to decide tomorrow night on rent levels for 57,500 apartments in 18 communities, with a seriously ill member voting by telephone and two other members participating months after their terms have expired.

title: Cuomo Assails Rumors of Past Misdeeds in Family
description: Governor Cuomo of New York said today that rumors were being spread that he was not running for President because of past misdeeds by his family, including his wife's parents.

title: GETTING AHEAD IN POLITICS
description: Howard Baker (''Howard Baker: Fighting the President's Final Battles,'' by David Eisenhower, Sept. 6) is quoted at the end of Mr. Eisenhower's article on his advice to ''a young man deciding to enter politics.'' Just take a look at the picture of his advisers on pages 18 and 19; seven men with nary an ethnic name nor a hint of color among them. Neither Mr. Eisenhower nor Mr. Baker chose to be explicit about bloodlines and gender being the best predictors of success in Republican politics.

title: TEJANO BREEZES TO VICTORY IN COWDIN
