description: Tejano dueled with Tsarbaby for half a mile and then drew off to an easy 4 3/4-length victory in the $172,200 Cowdin Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: REVALUATION FORCES A SCRABMLE FOR ASSESSORS
description: BY law, Connecticut towns must reassess the properties on their tax rolls every 10 years to make sure each owner of a house or business is paying his fair share of taxes.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington, D.C.; Easing Strains At Conventions
description: THE Washington Convention Center attracts nearly 300,000 people a year, taxing the eight hotels in the area to the limit. But three new hotels within a block of the center will soon ease the strain.

title: DrawingTIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: TIMING IT JUST RIGHT; SILENT, SOLITARY: THE CAPE IN WINTER
description: The long winter season on Cape Cod is a period more often than not of terrible weather. New England temperatures, averaging a raw 29 degrees, are coldest between Jan. 7 and Feb. 9, with ferocious northeasters blowing mercilessly across beaches as lonely and remote as their names: Truro, Cahoon Hollow, East Chop, Shank Painter Swamp.

title: Freddie Laker, at Slower Speed
description: LAST year, Sir Freddie Laker traveled to Ayers Rock, a remote spot in Australia's midlands that is considered the best location from which to view Halley's Comet. He had completed the 4,800-foot climb to the peak, he recalls, when a woman came up to him and said, ''You're Freddie Laker.''

title: STREETSCAPES: The Central Park Tennis House; A Neo-Classical Structure in an Unstructured Setting
description: THE Central Park Tennis House controversy - whether to build new or renovate - has been joined since last spring. Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern had scheduled his decision for Oct. 5, but now says it may be delayed until later this year.

title: From Asia's Steppes
description: THE ULAN BATOR BEAT, A new sound, perhaps, for those who have heard everything, will echo through the land, our land, this month. In a program called ''Music and Dance from Mongolia,'' eight outstanding soloists billed as the first all-Mongolian group to tour the United States. Their appearance at this time from the deserts and steppes of central Asia is not by mere chance; it marks the start this year of diplomatic relations between the Mongolian People's Republic and the United States.

title: ITALIAN, IN A SMALL AND COZY SETTING
description: ETHNICITY in the form of new restaurants has expanded at a gallop in the Danbury-New Milford axis.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Rehabilitation; 'Public Housing' in Abandoned Buildings
description: ELSEWHERE in the country the construction of new housing for low-income people depends upon Federal subsidies. But New York City has a golden goose at Battery Park City.

title: HOTEL FARE, THOROUGHLY ITALIAN
description: EUROPEAN hotel dining rooms have long been meccas for marvelous food. In the last few years, American hotels have begun to blossom with highly rated restaurants. Restaurant Giorgio in the Garden City Hotel is in this new sumptuous mode.

title: TALKING: Investors; Buyouts Of Tenants In Co-ops
description: AS an increasing number of New York City rental buildings were converted to co-op ownership in the 80's, it became common for investors to buy from the sponsors units that tenants did not want to purchase. State law permits rent-controlled or rent-stabilized tenants in most conversion situations to remain as renters.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in; Riverhead By JOHN RATHER
description: TRAVELERS on the Long Island Expressway know Riverhead, if in no other way, as the town whose name appears repeatedly on traffic signs pointing east.

title: JORGENSEN FEATURES STAR TURNS AND SERIES
description: COLLEGES and conservatories have long been a prime source of inexpensive, often free, concerts by students, faculty members and visiting artists. But at the Jorgensen Auditorium of the University of Connecticut, music has become big-name business.

title: ARTISTS IMPROVISE A JAZZ BAND
description: LEAD: THE members of the East Thirteenth Street Band are the first to point out that theirs is not an ordinary jazz ensemble. Now, while no serious musician - and each of the seven band members considers himself a professional - likes to think of himself as run-of-the-mill, these players legitimately can claim special status.

title: Stevenson Wins, 24-6
description: Glenn Fields and Dexter Thompson, the two most heavily recruited players for Adlai Stevenson High School in the Bronx, got their football team back on the winning track yesterday by leading the Ambassadors to a 24-6 victory over Beach Channel in the Bronx-Queens B-Division opener for both at Stevenson.

title: Alpaca Sweaters Woven in La Paz
description: In a courtyard near El Prado, the main thoroughfare of La Paz, Bolivia, Isabel Mamani kneels on the floor as she grinds cochineal on a stone mortar, the kind of mortar used in most Bolivian homes to grind hot pepper, garlic and spices. Cochineal, an insect that feeds on cactus, is also the name of a dye produced from female cochineal; a spectrum of reds, from scarlet to rust, is the result, and the colors are used to dye a line of scarves, sweaters and shawls produced by Artesanias Millma.

title: FIFTH ROW ON THE AISLE WITH DONAHUE
description: WHEN you watch Phil Donahue's special on the Constitution next spring, look for me. I'm the guy in the fifth row on the aisle. No speaking lines, but I manage to look very intent and I boo and yell ''Right!'' with all of the other cast members.

title: BOND PROPOSALS AWAIT VOTERS
description: VOTERS will be asked to decide six public questions at the polls on Nov. 3, including three that seek the authority to issue a total of $483 million in bonds for new prisons, a baseball stadium and recreation, cultural and historic-preservation projects.

title: 1943 Draftee Retires
description: Chief Warrant Officer Charles B. Russell, the last marine on active duty to serve in World War II, retired Friday. The 62-year-old marine, who survived two South Pacific battles in World War II but was seriously wounded in the Vietnam War, was given the Marine Corps's meritorious service medal at his retirement ceremony. He was drafted into the Marines in 1943 and discharged in 1946, but re-enlisted in 1954.

title: FICTION
description: JIG. By Campbell Armstrong. (Morrow, $18.95.) ''Jig'' brings the war between Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic nationalists and Protestant loyalists home to America, reportedly the principal source of the funds that keep the Irish Republican Army in business. When $10.2 million of this money is stolen on its way to Ireland, the I.R.A. sends its celebrated superassassin, Jig, to the United States to reclaim it. At the same time, a loyalist terror squad travels here to commit several atrocities that will be laid to Jig and the I.R.A. The loyalists expect a shocked America to respond by sending troops to Ulster on their behalf. Attempting to draw distinctions between terrorists, Campbell Armstrong's improbable plot finds itself in a murky moral landscape. Jig's pursuer is Frank Pagan, a Scotland Yard detective, whose own wife was the random victim of an I.R.A. bomb years earlier. He reluctantly admires Jig's meticulousness in avoiding unnecessary casualties, crediting him with having ''introduced dignity into the whole Irish conflict.'' Jig, like Pagan, despises the ordinary I.R.A. ''home-made grenade groups, the. . . . sad, misguided men who dreamed the dreams of hooligans.'' The reader, however, is more likely to see that one kind of murderer simply serves the writers of thrillers as a romantic protagonist while the other kind doesn't. In his new novel, Mr. Armstrong (the pseudonym of Campbell Black, a former London book editor) writes with glib competence, but nearly every page of this bulky thriller presents the reader with some stunning implausibility. Set in and around New York, ''Jig'' provides ''the troubles'' with much more glamour than they usually wear in the melancholy streets of Londonderry and Belfast.

title: BIG LOSS PUTS JAYS IN A HOLE
description: The one remaining pennant race in major-league baseball was enhanced on this chilly afternoon by a gripping 12-inning encounter between the two surviving teams, Detroit and Toronto.

title: New Orleans ... and All That Jazz
description: IF YOU LIVE IN NEW ORLEANS, EXPECT guests. My family and I moved here in 1985. The guests came and there was never any problem entertaining them. The city took care of that. Though economically battered, New Orleans is still one of the world's great party towns - the result of a languorous climate, an abundance of food, especially from the sea, and a confluence of tolerant, somewhat exotic cultures on their unworried way to decadence.

title: Recent Sales
description: Guilford, Conn. $209,000 20 Barnshed Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; private tree-covered lot, cathedral ceilings, eat-in kitchen, 1.4 acres; taxes $2,088. Killingworth, Conn. $228,500 26 Lovers Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; huge closet space, private setting, 2.5 acres; taxes $2,640. Wilton, Conn. $427,500 221 Sharp Hill Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, converted 1800 barn; beams, vaulted ceilings, 3 acres; taxes $2,887. Bronxville, N.Y. $212,000 26 Barrington Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; cul de sac, walk to station; taxes $2,200. Somers, N.Y. $450,000 Cobbling Rock 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; eat-in kitchen, cathedral ceiling, 2-car garage, 2 acres; not yet assessed. Tarrytown, N.Y. $415,000 18 Powderhorn Way 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old frame split level; eat-in kitchen, study, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $6,297. OTHER AREAS Monmouth Beach, N.J. $575,000 16 Lori Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 14-year-old waterfront ranch; 2 fireplaces, 2-zone heating, deck; taxes $4,008. Monroe Township, N.J. $188,000 766 Marlton Road 2 bedroom, 2 bath, 2-year-old ranch; formal dining room, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $1,700. Shirley, L.I. $118,000 183 Concord Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 13-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900.

title: IOWA UPSET, 19-14BY MICHIGAN ST.
description: Bobby McAllister's only pass completion of the second half, an 8-yard touchdown to Mike Sargent in the fourth quarter, gave Michigan State (2-2) a 19-14 upset of Iowa in a Big Ten opener.

title: Dukakis Aides Quit; The Truth Hurts Two Campaigns
description: POLITICAL professionals were of several minds last week about how much damage was caused the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis by the disclosure that it was two of his top aides who supplied a videotape that contributed to the downfall of a rival.

title: 'DAY IN HOLLYWOO' IN FAIRFIELD
description: THE Boston Post Road Stage Company has crossed over into musical comedy with the greatest of ease.

title: Mysterious Tremor Strikes Miami
description: Office towers in downtown Miami shivered in the sun this week. Windows rattled and floors quivered several times a day. The weather bureau was flooded with calls. Workers were sent home early. The National Earthquake Information Center in Colorado reported no earthquake activity in the region. It noted that South Florida, unlike California, where a severe earthquake killed six people Thursday, is one of the most unlikely places in the United States for an earthquake.

title: PREMATURE CHILD: STARTING LIFE AS A sURVIVOR
description: DAVID was born weighing 1 pound 12 ounces in the 28th week of the pregnancy.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DONOVAN SCARES THE MONSTERS By Susan Love Whitlock. Illustrated by Yossi Abolafia. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 4 to 8) MAGGIE AND THE MONSTER By Elizabeth Winthrop. Illustrated by Tomie dePaola. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE MONSTER BED By Jeanne Willis. Illustrated by Susan Varley. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Mixed Feelings About U.S. Role in the Gulf
description: THE widening war in the Persian Gulf has polarized and frightened much of the Arab world. With radio warnings from anxious skippers filling the air and American, British and French warships and Dutch, Italian and Belgian minesweepers patrolling gulf waters, worried Arabs have joined the United States, the Soviet Union and China in demanding a cease-fire.

title: Food; AFTER QUICHE
description: REMEMBER quiche Lorraine, that savory cheese and bacon tart that once spoke for all that was chic, French and gourmet? Like many other perfectly decent and delicious French foods - boeuf bourguignon, fondue, the souffle - quiche simply wore out its welcome and became a cliche. In time, America's favorite brunch food met its demise through pure and simple banalization. So what's come about to fill the void? The French have the answer. Although the quiche remains a popular French snack food, that old standby shares the stage with an array of superbly varied open-faced tarts, prepa-rations representing nearly every region of the country. Whether you call it a quiche, a tarte, tourte, galette, pizza or a pie, these quick, uncomplicated dishes remain among the most universally appealing. Depending on the setting and the time of day, an open-faced tart makes a fine first-course offering or an ideal main luncheon dish. It is equally appropriate as picnic fare or a late-evening snack. None of these tarts is very complicated to make, and most can be prepared in advance.

title: Bangkok Hotels
description: To the Editor: As old Bangkok hands who have lived in that city and visited there many times, we read with keen interest your article on Bangkok. We have known the old Oriental Hotel for 30 years and have been unhappy to see it grow from a charming old hostelry to the touristy behemoth it is today. Of the four hotels mentioned, we would evaluate only the Regent as excellent.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: NEVER. Maybe. Sometimes. Why?

title: COUPLE HELP THE POOR HELP THEMSELVES
description: GLEN and Mildred Robbins Leet help thousands of small entrepreneurs in 91 countries who look to them for help in eking out a living. And even when the couple leave their work in Manhattan, a portable computer travels to Weston with them on weekends, so they can keep track of their network in such places as Kenya and Lesotho in Africa, Guatemala and Costa Rica, the Philippines and small islands in the Caribbean.

title: Greeks Raid Terrorist Group Linked to Blast at U.S. Base
description: The Greek police said today that they had raided hide-outs of a left-wing terrorist group that took responsibility for a bomb attack on an American military post exchange store here six days ago.

title: Call for a Boycott
description: IF college athletic directors don't start hiring more black head coaches, the National Football League strike may not be the last unified action by athletes this year - not if Harry Edwards has his way. Edwards, the Berkeley sociologist who advises the commissioner of baseball on racial matters, said that if blacks were not given more college coaching opportunities, he would urge black scholarship players to boycott this season's football bowl games and basketball playoffs.

title: SPORTS
description: Super Hatches A fisherman's guide to fly hatches east of the Mississippi. With Carl Richards and Dick Pobst. Thornapple Angling Classics. Ada, Michigan 49301. 44 minutes. $39.95.

title: Verbatim: The Deer Problem
description: ' People say isn't it wonderful, having deer in their backyards. But after a while, after the deer start browsing, they start looking at them like rats. Their attitude really changes. ' Nathaniel R. Dickinson, a wildlife official with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, on the increasing deer population in the New York metropolitan region.

title: CARDS WERE GOOD WHEN THEY HAD TO BE
description: Shortly after noon today, as the Cardinals fans in their red jackets and sweaters and sweatshirts and hats filed into Busch Stadium for a happily meaningless game against the Mets, they paused to celebrate one last remarkable success.

title:
FIVE ENCHANTED EVENINGS;
DUBLIN
description: LEAD: THERE IS NO NICER nice person than a nice American. And he or she does not deserve to suffer. Nor be affronted by this broken tumbledown unkempt city struggling into the 20th century as the natives emerge from their centuries-old deprivation and poverty. Nor be brought to what may be the most overpriced place in Western Europe.

title: MISS QUILLEN WED TO T. M. LOHRENZ
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del., Carol Everhart Quillen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Quillen of New Castle, Del., and Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Terry Michael Lohrenz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis D. Lohrenz of Tulsa, Okla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Taylor, the interim rector of the church, and the Rev. Ralph R. Johnson Jr., a Presbyterian minister.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 20 about greeting cards incorrectly described the relationship between the American Greetings Corporation and Rousana Cards. American Greetings bought certain distribution rights and inventories from Rousana, which remains an independent company.

title: WELFARE PLAN PREVIEWS IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: REACH, the state's new welfare program that was begun in Bergen and Middlesex Counties last week, makes one basic assumption: Welfare recipients really want to work.

title: POSTINGS: Madison Planting; 63 Trees
description: Move over Park Avenue.

title: THREE BRIDGES WILL SOON CROSS ONLY MEMORIES
description: ''IT'S not exactly the Brooklyn Bridge,''

title: SIMPLE FARMHOUSE GIVES GLIMPSE OF PAST
description: LEAD: WHEN members of the Scarsdale Historical Society first decided to restore the 18th-century Cudner-Hyatt House on White Plains Post Road here, ''we pictured an adorable little pre-Revolutionary farmhouse,'' according to Betty Greenebaum, the society's vice president. What they wound up with, Mrs. Greenebaum said, was something the county needed more: a restoration depicting life in a simple farmhouse in the years 1836 through 1886.

title: CRAWFORD HURT IN ARMY LOSS
description: Army's chances appeared hopeless today when Tory Crawford, the Cadets' best runner and passer and the nation's second-leading scorer, went out with a knee injury early in the second quarter.

title: Brothers' Fund Is Passing to a New Rockefeller Generation
description: The Rockefeller Brothers Fund, one of the country's wealthiest and most prestigious philanthropies, is passing on its leadership to a younger generation of the family that plans to bring a fresh outlook to the foundation's work.

title: At Air Base, No Comment
description: Sometimes, when taking off or landing at Barajas Airport here, American fighter planes from Torrejon Air Base can be spotted in the distance on training missions.

title:
Fashion Preview;
MILAN'S MOOD
description: LEAD: IN THE SPRING-SUMMER 1988 COLLEC-tions that get under way in Milan this weekend, the mood is short and sweet.

title: WITHOUT GORBACHEV, GLASNOST PAUSES
description: IF there was any doubt left in the Soviet Union or the West about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's singular role in changing Soviet society, it was put to rest last week.

title: KIRSTEN STEARNS WEDS
description: The marriage of Kirsten Chara Stearns, the daughter of Dr. Jay Stearns of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Marsha McCullough of Detroit, to David William Bock took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Bock, parents of the bridegroom, in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Anthony Pieragostini, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony.

title: Treasury's Blunder in Paradise
description: TAX policy can be a riot of conflicting interests. The Government wants to collect more taxes, individuals and companies want to pay less, and tax advisers get into the act to craft ways of keeping tax bills down. Most of the time, Congress serves as the central battlefield.

title: Dance: Three Works by the Eliot Feld Company
description: THREE ballets exemplifying Eliot Feld's choreographic eclecticism were on view at Thursday night's performance by the Feld Ballet at the Joyce Theater.

title: 100th Victory For Perrelle
description: Nick Perrelle, the popular and successful coach who emerged from an eight-year retirement this year, tallied his 100th victory on Friday afternoon as Horace Greeley defeated Mahopac, 10-7.

title: WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
description: No Way! Baker Field and Columbia Lions, here I come Bob McLouchlin New York

title: ANNE BROUGHTBN WED TO STEPHEN R. DUVALL
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., Anne Pierson Broughton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip C. Broughton of New York and Old Lyme, was married yesterday to Stephen Rogers Duvall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Duvall of Potomac, Md.

title: Q AND A
description: Leningrad Trips

title: MELISSA DEAN MARRIES
description: Melissa Hall Dean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fairbanks Dean of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Eugene Lawrence Reilly, a son of Isabelle C. Reilly of Darien, Conn., and the late Eugene Leo Reilly 3d. The Rev. William Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y. The bride is an alumna of Pine Manor College. The bridegroom, a regional sales representative for the Honda Corporation of America in Baton Rouge, La., graduated from Denison University.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETS A LIST OF DEMANDS FOR NICARAGUANS
description: After weeks of debate over the Reagan Administration's Central America policy, the White House has settled on a list of demands it says the Nicaraguan Government must accept if the Sandinistas hope to forestall a request to Congress for renewed military aid to the contras.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Montville Turns to Multifamily Housing
description: LEAD: FOR the last two decades, Montville has steadily been changing from a farming area to suburbs as residential developments have sprung up within its 19 square miles.

title: Maine Man Loses Citizenship For Concealing a Nazi Past
description: An 80-year-old man who the Government says served in a Nazi battalion in 1941 was stripped of his American citizenship and faces deportation for refusing to answer questions about his past.

title: SIBLINGS DIVORCED
description: FIRST LIGHT By Charles Baxter. 286 pp. New York Viking. $17.95.

title: Vermont Court Scandal Leaves Bitter Residue
description: Almost nine months after three justices of the Vermont Supreme Court were accused of repeatedly violating judicial ethics, the scandal is fading from public view. But its residue of damaged careers and tarnished reputations lingers.

title: ASBESTOS DEFENSE: INFORMATION, TRAINING
description: Phyllis Bernstein should be congratulated for the excellent coverage of the hazards of asbestos on Long Island [ ''Businesses Seek to Comply on Asbestos,'' July 26, and ''School Allays Asbestos Fears,'' Aug. 30 ] .

title: THE DAY NEW YORK BECAME HARMLESS
description: ON Columbus Avenue near 61st Street, a young man sits beside a bridge table stacked with copies of what a poster describes as ''an original novel.'' The slender volumes, which he has apparently published himself, are attractively priced at $2. The young man is handsome, not visibly eccentric. He regards me with an open, frank expression - an unusual attitude for a novelist.

title: MOVIES
description: Running Scared Starring Gregory Hines and Billy Crystal. Directed by Peter Hyams. 1986. MGM/UA Home Video. 107 minutes. $79.95 ($19.95 as of Oct. 13).

title: Bush Nudges And Poses as His Cameras Roll
description: VICE PRESIDENT BUSH visited Poland last week, bringing gifts to encourage economic and political change and camera crews to record his trip for possible showing in his campaign for the Presidency.

title: WHERE THE INMATES ARE DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: LEAD: ON a sunny day last week, a man in chinos hosed a flowerbed while two other casually dressed men raked leaves that had fallen from the oak trees around them. Not far away, half a dozen other men talked around a picnic table.

title: Dial-a-Teacher For Help at Home
description: NEW YORK CITY elementary school pupils can let their fingers find the answers if a homework problem stumps them. By dialing (212) 777-3380, they reach the Dial-a-Teacher program, which offers help in eight languages.

title: Katherine Rasberry Weds Rodney Pitts
description: Katherine Elizabeth Rasberry, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Albert Rasberry Jr. of Wilson, N.C., and Rodney Creamer Pitts, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Reid Pitts of Charlotte, N.C., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Wilson. The Rev. George Johnson officiated.

title:
DINING OUT;
RIVER VIEW IN COLD SPRING
description: LEAD: ON balmy evenings the old river town of Cold Spring lifts the spirits. Beneath the looming shoulders of Storm King Mountain, the riding lights of freighters and the long shadows of hulls float silently down the friendly river in the dusk, and darting speedboats cross and recross their paths.

title: A Music Man Returns to an Early Love: The Revue
description: IN A SMALL, SPARE STUDIO ON Lafayette Street, filled with folding chairs and four huge mirrors, 10 cheery vocalists are chirping the same show tune: ''One basic costume. One unit set. This is it, my dearies. This is all you're going to get.''

title: For Sale by U.S.: '63 Ferrari, Red, V-12, Asking $1.5 Million
description: Federal marshals are selling one of the most valuable cars in the world, a Ferrari 250 GTO, and the bidding starts at $1.5 million.

title: An Industry Built on Dubious Results
description: THE Food and Drug Administration has been boasting that medical test kits for home use are 95 to 99 percent effective before they can be approved for sale. The F.D.A. also claims home tests are as effective as their counterpart diagnostic kits used in ''clinical settings'' - tests performed in commercial laboratories, doctors' offices and hospitals. The unfortunate truth is that the F.D.A. has no effectiveness standards for professionally performed tests, let alone at-home tests.

title: WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
description: Curiosity compels me to watch scab football. Conscience commands that I don't.

title: THE END GAME HOLDS CREATIVE POTENTIAL
description: IF you have not won in the opening and or the middle game, it is time to serve your opponent an end game.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NOTES OF AN ENFANT TERRIBLE
description: LEAD: ''Cinema is my life,'' Francois Truffaut declared time and again, and while this is scarcely the whole truth, his commitment to film was passionate. Enfant terrible of the Cahiers du Cinema critics, Truffaut began reviewing in his teens. He made ''The 400 Blows'' at 27, and when he died three years ago - at 52 and very much in his creative prime - he had directed 25 movies.

title: GIANTS FALL SHORT IN PRO REPLACEMENTS
description: The Giants have four players on their replacement team with National Football League experience, and the two with the most experience worked in construction for a year before joining the team.

title: NEW SITES PLANNED AT FORT HILL
description: ALTHOUGH well endowed with historical graveyards and tiny family-owned plots tucked away in the woods, East Hampton does not have enough cemetery space, according to Town Councilman Pat Trunzo.

title: ANDROCRATS GO HOME!
description: LEAD: THE CHALICE AND THE BLADE Our History, Our Future. By Riane Eisler. Maps. 261 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HENRY AND MUDGE The First Book of Their Adventures. By Cynthia Rylant. Illustrated by Sucie Stevenson. 40 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $10.95. (Ages 6 to 8)NM> HENRY AND MUDGE IN PUDDLE TROUBLE The Second Book of Their Adventures. By Cynthia Rylant. Illustrated by Sucie Stevenson. 48 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $10.95. (Ages 6 to 8)

title: TOWN TO REGULATE HOUSEHOLD WASTES
description: LEAD: STONINGTON residents will face fines up to $500 for disposing of such household items as paint thinner, batteries, aerosol cans and oil and many common household cleansers at the municipal landfill.

title: SARAH A. MAGRINO, COPYWRITER, WEDS
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York, Sarah Ann Magrino, a daughter of Mary Cross of New York and Joseph L. Magrino Jr. of Orient, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard John Miller 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller Jr. of Strasburg, Pa. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr., assisted by the Rev. Trevor E. G. Thomas, performed the ceremony.

title: DIANE LOUISE EKEBLAD WED TO F. R. PAINE 2D
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Glen Cove, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Diane Louise Ekeblad, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Ekeblad of Glen Cove, and Frederick Rodney Paine 2d, a son of Mrs. Robert E. Dougherty of Princeton, N.J., and Thomas H. Paine of Rowayton, Conn.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Poetry at Play To a fan, sport is poetry in motion - and for some, poetry too is a sport. This is Robert Francis's ''Swimmer,'' from ''This Sporting Life'' (Milkweed), an anthology of American poems about sports and games, edited by Emilie Buchwald and Ruth Roston. Observe how he negotiates his way With trust and the least violence, making The stranger friend, the enemy ally. The depth that could destroy gently supports him. With water he defends himself from water. Danger he leans on, rests in. The drowning sea Is all he has between himself and drowning. What lover ever lay more mutually With his beloved, his always-reaching arms Stroking in smooth and powerful caresses? Some drown in love as in dark water, and some By love are strongly held as the green sea Now holds the swimmer. Indolently he turns To float. - The swimmer floats, the lover sleeps. Safe in a Landscape Aldous Huxley's cautious old-world description of Tuscany is quoted as a contrast to African landscape in ''Africa Then'' (Knopf), edited by Nicholas Monti.

title: Saffron, Kashmir's Pot of Gold
description: Kashmir is an emerald set in a ring of Himalayan mountains. Here, in one of the world's most majestic settings, celestial benevolence has decreed that the world's most expensive spice should flourish. At its current price in the United States, one ounce of saffron is literally worth its weight in gold.

title: BEHOLD THE RITUALS OF THE POMPON
description: ''YOU won't have any trouble finding me there,'' Diana Governale says cheerfully, after reeling off directions to the practice field. ''I'll be the one yelling the loudest.''

title: THE QUAKERS THEN AND NOW
description: As a Quaker who is very much alive on Long Island today, I read with pleasure about the current exhibition of the Nassau County Museum at the Sands Point Preserve [ ''Recalling Quakers' Impact on L.I.'' ] . I also appreciate the care the author took in indicating that Friends have a continuing presence as well as an illustrious past in this area.

title: Below the Skirts
description: ACCEPTANCE of short skirts has been abetted to a large extent by the fact that in the beginning - last spring - they were almost always presented with opaque panty hose, usually black. Many women switched in summer to sheerer stockings. These continue to be important with short evening dresses, but another category of panty hose is coming to the fore as cool weather approaches: a heavier style that can provide some warmth. Henri Bendel is selling a lot of ribbed cotton stretch panty hose at $14. Black is the best seller, followed by brown and putty. Opaque nylons continue to be important, including a one-size-fits-all style for $1.49 at F. W. Woolworth, available in black, navy, brown and white.

title: ASSESSING THE LESSONS OF SCHROEDER'S BRIEF RUN
description: WHEN Representative Patricia Schroeder announced last Monday that she would not become a candidate for her party's nomination for President after all, the Colorado Democrat gave these reasons.

title: SANCTIONS WON'T END APARTHEID
description: LEAD: A year ago the European Economic Community, the Commonwealth countries and the United States introduced economic sanctions against South Africa. The effects of these sanctions are now under review.

title: TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY: AN INTERNATIONAL EXCHANGE OF IDEAS
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH teen-age pregnancy is a growing concern in some parts of the world, delegates from the World Council of the Young Women's Christian Association who visited White Plains recently suggested that the problem was of greater magnitude in the United States.

title: ROAD AN ISSUE IN MT. PLEASANT
description: LEAD: THE race for supervisor in the town of Mount Pleasant may turn on one issue: whether a small stretch of road will be widened.

title: LONDON
description: TWENTY YEARS AGO, THE BEST LONDON RES-taurants - and there weren't many of them - specialized in a kind of Edwardian-French cuisine: strong tastes, lavish portions and an emphasis on creatures that can be shot - in other words, classic cooking for the hungry squirearchy. Then nouvelle cuisine arrived to decimate the portions, overrefine the flavors and generally ruin our fun in the name of preserving our waistlines. At most London restaurants these days you spend a small fortune for the Boy Scout pleasure of getting up from the table feeling you could eat some more.

title: Tap-Dancer Among the Literati
description: THE BOB FOSSE I KNEW WAS insecure, self-doubting, tormented, tense in his victories, angry in his defeats - everything I trust in an artist.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE EVOLUTION OF A LOCAL SHOW - AND OF ITS PATRONS
description: LEAD: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, when a grain-painted, dovetailed blanket chest with spongework highlights could still be found for less than $50, and barns, attics and old homes were still regularly yielding treasures at lightweight prices, local antiques shows were as much a novelty for the curious as they were showcases for collectors.

title:
THE VIEW FROM:PUMPKINSEED HILL FARM;
ANOMALY IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY: LAND THAT PRODUCES PRODUCE
description: LEAD: ON a lush green Shelton hillside criss-crossed by old stone walls and dotted with red-and-white barns, Terry Jones is doing what four generations of Joneses have done before him: working the land.

title: ROME
description: AN ENCHANTED EVENING IN ROME DEPENDS on convivial company and good food and drink. As in France, eating out here tends to be a religious ritual, but generally it's low church rather than high, and occasionally closer to a fundamentalist revival than to a solemn benediction. There is no hush of holy sacrament, no delicate gourmet sipping and pecking. Instead, there are loud hymns of praise or blame and other sounds of robust appetites satisfied. Still, it's possible to dine in elegance without falling in with a gaggle of expense account executives or diplomatic stuffed shirts.

title: MAURA A. RICCOBENE PLANS TO WED JONATHAN BULKELEY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Riccobene of Franklin Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maura Anne Riccobene to Jonathan Brereton Bulkeley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bulkeley of Bloomfield and Old Saybrook, Conn. The couple plan to marry Dec. 20. Ms. Riccobene, an account manager for U.S. News and World Report in New York, graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and Middlebury College. Her father is an investor. The bride-to-be is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Riccobene of Ridgewood, N.J. Her grandfather, now retired, was the owner and president of the Uehling Instrument Company in Paterson, N.J.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: New Terminal For Airport At Nashville

title: FACING UP TO THE DEADLY ORDINARY
description: SKATING WITH HEATHER GRACE By Thomas Lynch. 60 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. I APOLOGIZE FOR THE EYES IN MY HEAD By Yusef Komunyakaa. 73 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $18. Paper, $8.95. ROSE By Li-Young Lee. 71 pp. Brockport, N.Y.: BOA Editions. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: MAYWOOD: STATE FINDS NO RISE IN CANCERS
description: A REPORT commissioned by the state's Department of Health at the request of residents here contends that the presence of thorium has not increased the incidence of cancer.

title: Plea to Business: Don't Dump, Donate
description: WASTE does not help a company's profit margins - or its image. But in the food industry, where much of the product is fragile and short-lived, waste is an accepted part of doing business. Or at least it was.

title: THE MYSTERIOUS MAN ABOVE THE MANTLE
description: IT was in Brussels that we met the mysterious man face to face and found some answers to questions that had long puzzled us.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Antonio;
Developments Sold at Auction
description: LEAD: WHEN the developer Bruce Lee began construction on his St. Charles condominiums in 1984, the Texas economy was booming. But when his project neared completion two years later it became clear that plummeting real-estate sales throughout the state would compound what he admits was a poor marketing decision.

title: STATE AWARDED $125,000 FOR EDUCATION ON AIDS
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT has been selected as one of 15 states by the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to receive $125,000 to help prevent the spread of AIDS among students.

title:
ART;
ROBERT SHEEHAN: PHOTOGRAPHY'S MISSING LINK
description: LEAD: IN photographer Robert Sheehan, whose color photographs from 1948 to 1958 are on display through Oct. 23 at the Davison Art Center at Wesleyan University in Middletown, we have something like the missing link. Sheehan bridges such American Scene photographers as Walker Evans and such contemporary color photographers as Joel Meyerowitz and William

title: Laxity Charged in College Integration Enforcement
description: The Department of Education has failed to enforce a Federal court order that required 10 states to desegregate their public colleges and universities, a House subcommittee charged in a report issued today.

title: Is There Life After Football?
description: ON ANY OTHER CAMPUS, the scene would have had the comfortably routine air of academic ritual. It was the first week of classes and the university president was ambling across a marble lobby exchanging small talk and greeting faculty members. There were older professors in severe suits, younger ones in blue jeans and a Rodin nude, ''Eve in Despair,'' that stood alone in the midst of the chattering crowd like an uninvited guest. There was talk of summers spent teaching abroad at Oxford and summers battling the heat at home in Dallas, books being written and books being read. But this unprecedented turnout at Southern Methodist University - virtually the entire 500-member faculty - had little to do with academic ritual. Instead, it had everything to do with the pudgy man in the dark suit slowly making his way through the group, A. Kenneth Pye, a 56-year-old former law professor, chancellor and dean at Duke University. The occasion was his first meeting with the faculty after assuming the job of president of S.M.U., which last year was ripped apart by a sports scandal producing as much discord and turmoil as any major university has faced.

title: What's Doing in Zurich
description: Fall and winter always bring at least a few clear days to Zurich, and one place to take advantage of such weather is the Quai Brucke (Quay Bridge), which spans the Limmat River where it flows out of the horn-shaped lake. To the east, across the water, you will see the ridges, glaciers and snowcapped peaks of the Alps on the horizon; turn around to find that the city skyline is now dominated by giant cranes.

title: Is Discretion Enough to Ask of Our Candidates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan And the Russians
description: President Reagan's decision to go for an arms agreement and an early summit meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev has left some of his faithful flock disgruntled. Conservative Republican senators say they will try to block the arms treaty. Right-wing commentators write gloomily about the menace of detente.

title:
GARDENING;
TO PREPARE FOR THE FROST THAT LIES AHEAD
description: LEAD: YOU might wake up any morning now to find the garden covered with frost. Cold air first settles in low places, so gardens in valleys and low-lying pockets usually are the first to be affected. Since large bodies of water retain heat more effectively than land, gardens near the ocean, Long Island Sound, the Hudson

title: THE TIE THAT BINDS IS SOMETIMES A NEIGHBOR
description: IT is more than a year since we bought and moved into our house. After almost a decade of renting, we finally signed on the dotted line and obtained that wonder of wonders: a deed.

title: Deborah M. Tate Is Married on L.I.
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Deborah Merrick Tate, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert DuPuy Merrick of Osterville, Mass., and the late Mr. Merrick, to Charles Albert Brisbane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seward S. Brisbane of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: On Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: A 1927 DINER IN FAIRFIELD IS RESURRECTED IN STYLE
description: LEAD: NEVER in its 60 years was Larry's Diner fussed over the way it is today. The barrel-roofed restaurant, a fixture on the Post Road in Fairfield from 1927 until it was hauled off to storage two years ago, is returning in grand style as the refurbished centerpiece of a new restaurant.

title: EAST'S 'GARBAGE CAN' ECONOMIES GET A WHIFF OF CAPITLISM
description: TO hear Eastern Europeans tell it, you would almost think that Frederick Hayek and Milton Friedman had dislodged Marx and Engels as the fathers of socialist economics.

title: LIFE DOESN'T END AT THE CITY LIMITS
description: THE general managers of New York City's major television stations should be encouraged to vacation on the East End. They could say goodbye for a while to Nielsens, cable and strikes. They could see the beauty of Long Island's farmland, luminous skies and sunsets by the sea. And they could see some impressive regional television on newscasts emanating from across Long Island Sound and clearly received by viewers out East.

title: A Cutback Looms in Health Insurance
description: SOME dual-career couples, accustomed to having virtually all their medical bills paid through his-and-hers health insurance policies from their separate employers, may soon be in for a rude shock. Under a model regulation drawn up by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and approved by six states - including New York - they may discover that benefits under one of the spouse's plans may be reduced so dramatically that it does not pay to keep the plan.

title: Safety Accusations Surround a Radium Plant
description: For decades, a New York-based company - believed to be the last commercial radium supplier in the western hemisphere - has been mishandling, and even losing, bits of the deadly radioactive element in the city, a two-year inquiry by a State Assembly committee has found.

title: U.S. AND CANADA IN TRADE ACCORD
description: United States and Canadian trade negotiators, racing against a midnight deadline, narrowed differences today on a trade pact that would eliminate tariffs and other barriers between the world's two largest trading partners, according to officials familiar with the talks.

title: Look Who's Coming for Dinner
description: A CANNIBAL IN MANHATTAN By Tama Janowitz. Illustrated by Tony Wright. 287 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: For Now, Quiet on Iran-Contra Front
description: EVERY once in a while, President Reagan's aides suggest that, on a particular controversy, it would be best if he just kept quiet. That was the view for months in the heat of the Iran-contra affair. Once, the President even pleaded laryngitis to avoid answering reporters' questions.

title: Balancing Blue Jeans and Pinstripes
description: IF the first generation of food bankers in the mid to late 70's brought a personal commitment to feeding the hungry, the second generation has combined that commitment with a heavy overlay of professionalism.

title: BUILDING BRIDGES THROUGH WORLD SPORT: SEOUL DREAM MOVES ON
description: WHEN Seoul's bid to host the 1988 Olympic Games was first announced in April 1979, the then-president of the Korean Olympic Committee, Park Choung-kyu, a prime mover behind the idea, was unswayed by arguments that our still developing country was not in a position to either organize or afford the Games.

title: Back Lawrence Fights Lot Division
description: LEAD: TUCKED AWAY from the hustle and bustle of the Village of Lawrence, which borders Queens at Far Rockaway, is Back Lawrence, one of the wealthiest communities on Long Island. The area is known for its Victorian mansions, the Rockaway Hunting Club and one-acre zoning. Its vast, marshy open spaces hint at what the South

title: GARDENING
description: Gardening From the Ground Up: Growing Roses One Up Productions. P.O. Box 410777 San Francisco, Calif. 94141. (800) 331-6304. 28 minutes. $19.95.

title: VIENNA STORYBOOK
description: MOST VIENNESE ARE MYTH makers - as am I, even though I'm a Mets-rooting Upper West Sider. I was born in Vienna, and am thus naturally inclined to mythopoeia, sometimes by sheer accident.

title: Mitchell-Lama
description: To the Editor:

title: Shortsighted on Long Shots
description: America pioneered in photographing the earth from space, but its pictures for civilian use are now third best, behind those of France and the Soviet Union. The Russians take the most precise photos.

title: LAWRENCE C. MERTHAN
description: Lawrence C. Merthan, a lawyer and public relations specialist, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

title: Music
description: The centerpiece of the operatic week is Friday night's opening of ''Das Rheingold'' at the Met. This is the least outwardly exciting of the four operas that make up Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, and it hardly ever sells out, so there is a good chance for late deciders to hear it, either this time or at one of the repetitions. Unthinkingly acted and badly sung, ''Rheingold'' can be a dreary chore -but it is a subtle and potentially gripping drama of actions and consequences, ambitions and compromises. In it the seeds for the whole cycle are sown, musically and philosophically.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Amherst, Mass.;
Storm Over A Golf Course
description: LEAD: THE serene beauty of the nine-hole golf course in a northern section of this university town belies the storm that has risen since its owner, David E. Maxson Sr., decided to sell the 99-acre parcel almost two years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-23

title: After 3 Years, Duarte and Rebels Plan to Meet
description: Barring a last-minute hitch, President Jose Napoleon Duarte and leaders of the guerrilla front fighting his Government are to meet here Sunday for the first time formally in nearly three years.

title: Where to Eat In Rangoon
description: Because most tourists in Burma spend only a day or two in Rangoon - a byproduct of the seven-day limit on visas - many don't venture beyond the hotels for meals. Most hotel dining rooms are not distinguished by either the atmosphere or the food.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: FREDRICA GRAY;
'A NEW DEMOGRAPHIC LANDSCAPE'
description: LEAD: THE Permanent Commission on the Status of Women did well in the last session of the General Assembly. Among the successful bills the commission supported was one allowing up to six months' unpaid parental and medical leave for state employees. Though pleased with the legislative outcome, the executive director of the state commission, Fredrica Gray, says

title: FOCUS: Housing Aid; Replacing Lost U.S. Funding
description: THE Kentucky Housing Corporation, a state agency, is using surplus cash to provide home loans to families with incomes of less than $21,000 a year.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Sikh Violence in Punjab A Threat to Indian Unity
description: The Sikh religion's holiest shrine, which used to bustle with thousands of worshipers, sits quiet and nearly empty here. Sikhs and others say fear keeps them away.

title: Against Robert Bork; His Bill of Rights Is Different
description: It's the first Monday in October and the Supreme Court convenes for its 197th term, but with only eight justices; the admired Lewis Powell retired in June. There could have been nine justices in place had President Reagan proposed someone like him, or another conservative in the tradition of Justices Felix Frankfurter or John Marshall Harlan. By now, even a Democratic Senate probably would have given consent.

title: Court's Vacancy Clouds Term That Opens Today
description: The Supreme Court, with one seat empty and the possibility of 4-to-4 deadlocks or postponed decisions in key cases, opens its new term Monday facing an array of the politically charged issues that have fueled the battle over Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination.

title: Split in 'Tombstone' Ranks
description: Wall Street's ''tombstone'' ads may look stately, but the politicking that goes on before they ever appear in print can get downright undignified.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Ages of Apple Cider
description: The farmhands included a 5-year-old, a teen-ager, a middle-aged couple and a grandmother approaching 80. City dwellers all, they had gathered in Columbia County, New York, for a rural ceremony: pressing cider from the first apples of the season.

title: Patchwork Giants Look Overmatched
description: The last time the Giants played the San Francisco 49ers was in January, when the Giants won, 49-3, in the playoffs. The Giants and the 49ers, or at least the teams wearing their uniforms, will meet at 9 P.M. Monday in Giants Stadium, and the score could well be 49-3 again, only this time with the 49ers getting the 49.

title: INSIDE
description: Curfew in Tibetan Capital

title: College Football; Florida State Might Pay a Steep Price for Its Losing Gamble
description: The week before, Johnny Majors of Tennessee eschewed the 2-point conversion play and an opportunity to win a game against Auburn. Majors ordered a placement kick and accepted a 20-20 tie in a Southeastern Conference game while some of his players and fans grumbled.

title: Trump Hints of Dreams Beyond Building
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, was looking for a good investment several years ago, so he turned to his friend, Donald J. Trump. Mr. Trump first found a small Manhattan hotel at the bargain price of $10 million. Too high, said Mr. Iacocca.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Aftershocks: The Rumbling Of Subterranean Indecision
description: Aftershocks like the one that struck the Los Angeles area yesterday are not uncommon after an earthquake as severe as the one last Thursday, specialists said yesterday.

title: Turn Up Heat on Pretoria
description: LEAD: President Reagan's report to Congress on what progress South Africa is making toward ending apartheid could consist of one word: none.

title: PETER B. MEDAWAR, SCIENTIST, IS DEAD
description: Sir Peter Medawar, the British doctor who shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1960 and later in life was recognized as a scientific philosopher and writer, died Friday in London's Royal Free Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Favorite-Son Strategy Suggested by Moynihan
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan called today on Governor Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey to run as favorite-son candidates for President as a way to keep the 1988 Democratic Presidential race open until the party's convention in Atlanta.

title: Bork Indicates No Withdrawal
description: Judge Robert H. Bork, President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee, indicated that he would not ask for the withdrawal of his nomination even if defeat by the full Senate appeared inevitable.

title: 'Fatal Attraction' Director Analyzes the Success of His Movie, and Rejoices
description: Adrian Lyne had a hangover.

title: Response to 3 Slayings: S.I. Mobilizes
description: Three recent disappearances and murders have galvanized residents of normally quiescent Staten Island into a state of mobilization.

title: Soviet Shows Chemical Arsenal
description: The Soviet Union opened its chemical warfare center here to foreign disarmament negotiators this weekend in an effort to convince the West it wants to destroy chemical weapons.

title: BAYER BESS IS SELECTED FOR HELENE CURTIS LINE
description: Helene Curtis Industries of Chicago, whose Suave line of personal care products was at Backer & Spielvogel before its merger with Ted Bates Worldwide, has announced the line has been reassigned to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker & Flynn, also of Chicago.

title: Players Cite Integrity, Dreams
description: In the locker rooms at Giants Stadium after today's Jets-Cowboys game, regular players explained their reasons for crossing the picket lines while the replacement players talked about the experience of playing in a regular National Football League game.

title: Big Aftershock Rattles California and Californians
description: The most powerful aftershock of Thursday's earthquake jolted Southern California early today, causing scattered damage and serving as a reminder of the unpredictability of the violent tremors. The death of a woman from a heart attack was attributed to the quake.

title: Union to Review Demands Tonight
description: Union representatives from the 28 National Football League teams have scheduled a meeting tonight in Chicago, with expectations rising that the union leaders will drop free agency as a bargaining demand.

title: Ballet: 'Dance for Two,' An Eliot Feld Premiere
description: ''A DANCE FOR TWO,'' Eliot Feld's latest work for the Feld Ballet, is a charming study for two of his most appealing dancers.

title: Mets' Victory Leads to 2d Spot
description: The Mets, who lost the battle for first place three days ago, fought and won the battle for second place today when they closed the season by rallying with five runs in the ninth inning to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 11-6.

title: On the Field, Jets Fall to Dallas
description: Take away the stadium, the cameras and the fancy uniforms, and the Jets-Cowboys game this afternoon might have been mistaken for a freewheeling, error-ridden semi-pro game.

title: Iran Says It Staged Naval Maneuvers in Gulf
description: Iran said today that it had staged intensive naval exercises in the Persian Gulf over the weekend, in an apparent reference to military movements that alarmed Saudi Arabia and prompted an American warship to steam toward the area of activity.

title: Jean Anouilh, the French Playwright, Is Dead at 77
description: Jean Anouilh, one of France's most prominent and enduring playwrights, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Vaudois University Hospital Center in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 77 years old.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday U.S. Balance of Trade August Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

title: Woman Is Accused of Killing Son, 3, as Her Suicide Fails
description: A 3-year old Queens boy died in his mother's arms late Saturday as she tried to kill herself and him by closing the windows of the family car and letting its engine idle, the police said.

title: Advertising; Alcon Sets TV Drive On Lenses
description: ALCON LABORATORIES is returning to television today with a $9 million campaign aimed at getting the young women who are the primary users of contact lenses to take better care of them.

title: TV Review; New 'Star Trek' Series Is Set in Post-Kirk Era
description: ''STAR TREK'' is back - not as a rerun or a feature film, but as a syndicated series called ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Trekkies will eagerly recall that the original series had its premiere in September 1966. In fact, the series was not terribly successful in terms of ratings. But its hard-core fans were devoted and fiercely protective, fending off at least one cancellation of the series with a letters campaign. The show expired in 1969 but, thanks to endless reruns, still retains a cult following with some 450 fan clubs around the world. Paramount Network Television doesn't hesitate in revealing the target audience in its publicity for this new series: the universe.

title: Dance Companies Set for Tonight's AIDS Benefit
description: Thirteen major American dance companies are to appear on stage together for the first time, tonight at 8 at the New York State Theater in ''Dancing for Life,'' a gala program to benefit groups concerned with AIDS care and research.

title: Bonn Urged To Free Shops
description: An official of the United States Federal Reserve said today that a liberalization of West German shopping laws would help spur consumption and contribute to a reduction in international trade imbalances.

title: Baseball; The Season Belonged to the Sluggers
description: The St. Louis Cardinals and the San Francisco Giants enter the National League playoff tomorrow night with pitching staffs that have the lowest individual victory totals in championship series history. That's the kind of season it was.

title: Football Diagramed on a Supply-Demand Curve
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Is Expected To Close Loophole In New Gun Rules
description: A loophole in Florida's new law on firearms that allows anyone to carry a weapon in plain view is expected to be eliminated by the State Legislature on Monday, the law's chief proponent says.

title: Music Noted in Brief; McMahon's 'Statues,' A Program of Parodies
description: Paul McMahon, a singer and songwriter, treated performance art as low-budget music video Thursday in his hourlong ''Song of the Statues,'' at Home, 44 Walker Street, below Canal Street. As he parodies songwriters from Brecht and Weill to Philip Glass, he dons various costumes and shticks as the context demands.

title: Editors at School Give Klan Photos to County
description: A high school student newspaper voluntarily turned over photographic negatives of a Ku Klux Klan rally to the Carroll County state's attorney after a local daily newspaper refused.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Arms and Imports
description: Alarmed by a spate of amendments that would limit the Pentagon's arms imports, the Defense Department has named Dennis Kloske, the Deputy Under Secretary for policy and resources, to be its ''trade and defense competition advocate.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In their only three postseason appearances, the Mets won the league championship series each time and went on to the World Series. Are they the only team to do this?

title: Lee Rambeau Is Married To Wildred David Kemp
description: Lee Rambeau, a daughter of Sallie Mae Rambeau of Winter Park, Fla., and the late Leroy Rambeau, was married yesterday to Wildred David Kemp, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Kemp of Tulsa, Okla. Justice Ivan Warner of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated at Alder Manor in Yonkers.

title: 11% Mortgage Rate by V.A.
description: The Veterans Administration said Friday that it was raising its maximum interest rate for new federally backed V.A. home mortgages to 11 percent. The rise, which will take effect Monday, will be the V.A.'s fourth rate increase this year. The agency said it was making the change to bring its rate in line with the overall mortgage market, in which rates have risen in recent weeks.

title: Kota Kinabalu Journal; Moslem Cause Celebre: A Good Christian Burial
description: Seventeen years ago, Robert Din Hatt, also known as Robert Chua, decided to renounce Christianity and convert to Islam. He called himself Rashid Din Hatt Bulanggan.

title: Fern J. Finkel, a Lawyer, Wed to Anthony Gentile
description: Fern J. Finkel and Anthony P. Gentile, an associate and a partner, respectively, in the Manhattan law firm of Philip M. Damashek, were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Justice Leonard E. Yoswein of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: Music Noted in Brief; John Briggs, Pianist, In Debut at Carnegie
description: John Briggs, a pianist from Yorkshire, England, took the unusual step of engaging Carnegie Hall for his New York debut recital Saturday evening. He brought a program to match: Big works of Schumann, Chopin, Liszt and Prokofiev along with smaller ones by Liszt, Scriabin and Saint-Saens.

title: Finley, Kumble Partner Is Joining Another Firm
description: Andrew N. Heine, a name partner in the big law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, is joining another New York firm, Curtis Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle.

title: Kurds of Iraq Are Fighting for Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY SNOWSTORM COVERS NORTHEAST
description: The earliest snowstorm on record struck New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, burying some areas in more than a foot of snow that closed roads and airports, knocked out power to more than 300,000 homes and turned russet autumn to wintry solitude.

title: Trial of Suspect in Cocaine Cartel Is Set for Today
description: Carlos Lehder Rivas, accused of being a leader of an immense cocaine cartel, goes on trial here Monday.

title: The Promise Is Kept
description: Eight years after he began as a freshman at Indiana University and six years after he left as a full-time student, Isiah Thomas recently completed his course work for a Bachelor of Arts degree.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Election in New Jersey Is Challenged
description: The longtime president of the N.A.A.C.P in New Jersey, defeated in a bid for reelection on Saturday, will try to invalidate the vote results in court, her attorney said today.

title: Metro Matters; A Life of Making The Snowballs Reformers Hurl
description: ''You can never be satisfied,'' Paul Du Brul wrote in his farewell editorial in the Hunter College student newspaper, ''because there is always so much more that could have been done. But you tried, and in this empty, half apologetic little phrase lies all the satisfaction that people who do things for others will ever have.''

title: Shift Seen On Welfare Hotel Use
description: New York City's Human Resources Administration is preparing a five-year plan that could eliminate the use of welfare hotels for homeless families, according to the head of the agency, William J. Grinker.

title: SPARSE CROWDS, HEAVY PICKETING AT N.F.L. GAMES
description: If the names were not familiar, the uniforms certainly were. They looked like honest-to-goodness Dallas Cowboys out there, and Jets and Lions and Eagles and Bears. In all respects, it looked as if the National Football League was back in the hearts, minds and television sets of football fans everywhere. In a way, it was. But these were no ordinary games played yesterday, not with most of the N.F.L.'s 1,585 regular players in the 13th day of their strike and some of them on picket lines outside the stadiums where their replacements were playing.

title: Zambian, in Appeal, Says Son Died of AIDS
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda issued a plea today for more funds to fight acquired immune deficiency syndrome, saying his son's death last year was caused by the disease.

title: Dance: Alliance Group
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS tend to be rugged individualists. Yet they do occasionally band together. One group that encourages cooperation is the New York Choreographers' Alliance, directed by Kathy Buck, Laura Grady and Susan Miller.

title: 8-Legged Exercise
description: THE Blue Jays are dead, as dead as the octopus that came hurtling out of the upper deck and landed near the Toronto dugout in the seventh inning yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Kertesz Retrospective

title: Test the Monkeys
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Officials Defend Protection of Witnesses
description: Justice Department officials say that, despite recent disputes in New York and elsewhere, a special Federal program to relocate trial witnesses has led to important criminal convictions and met with relatively few complaints from protected witnesses.

title: Witness to Shooting of 4 Is Slain
description: A witness to a Queens shootout last month that left four people wounded was shot to death early yesterday in an execution-like killing that may have been intended to prevent her from testifying before a grand jury, the police said.

title: It's About Time to Put Aviation Fund to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Note Sales Highlight Week
description: Treasury auctions this week consist of today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills, followed by four-year notes tomorrow and seven-year notes on Wednesday. The Treasury plans to sell $12.8 billion of three- and six-month bills, $7.25 billion of four-year notes and $6.75 billion of seven-year notes.

title: Ferry Rock
description: Fans returning from a concert by a British punk rock band knocked a state ferry out of commission early Saturday when they chopped apart tables and chairs with an ax and ripped tiles from the ceiling, the authorities said. Five people were arrested. The fans were returning from a concert by the British group GBH, which reportedly stands for Grevious Bodily Harm. The group's lead singer, Jimmy Wren, said Saturday that he was ''quietly proud.''

title: Juilliard Concert
description: The Juilliard Orchestra will open its concert season at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday, with a program of works by Barber, Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev. The pianist Garrick Ohlsson will be soloist for Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3; Otto-Werner Mueller will conduct. Tickets, at $8 and $5, are available at the Avery Fisher box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770. TDF vouchers are accepted on the day of the performance; free tickets will be given to students and to the elderly.

title: CHINESE CURFEW IN THE TIBET CAPITAL
description: The Chinese authorities imposed a curfew today and tried to stop at least one busload of foreign tourists from leaving this Tibetan capital after pro-independence demonstrations in which at least six people were reported killed.

title: Theater: 'The Tavern'
description: A STORM is in progress during most of ''The Tavern.''

title: 3 Stage Producers Pool Efforts To Spur Broadway Patronage
description: Three veteran theater producers have joined forces in a plan to stimulate activity on Broadway by attracting star directors and actors, reducing ticket prices and containing the cost of shows.

title: Chinese Visitor Admires Home Built for Disabled
description: An official guest from China came to the Parrinos' home here in this Westchester County village today, and as he pushed himself from room to room in a wheelchair, he commented on the wide, smooth hallways and the picture-window views of the outdoors.

title: Chinese Release Two Americans Detained During Rioting in Tibet
description: Two Americans who were detained in Tibet during violent demonstrations last week have been released, the State Department said yesterday.

title: Sri Lanka Faults Indian Troops
description: Sri Lanka accused India today of not doing its part to end ethnic violence on the island. It told Indian peacekeeping troops to put down clashes in one area or Sri Lankan security forces would do so.

title: Gore Admits a 'Careless' Account Of His Work as a Reporter in 70's
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, exaggerated his record as an investigative reporter in an interview with an Iowa newspaper, a Memphis newspaper has reported.

title: A Tribute to Lukas Foss at Town Hall
description: Lukas Foss will the guest of honor tonight at a concert featuring a New York premiere of one of his works, at 8 o'clock at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The concert is part of the hall's ''Composers and Company'' series devoted to 20th-century music, which began last month with a concert of music by David Del Tredici. A performance of music by William Bolcom is planned for the final concert in the series next Monday.

title: Lisa Elaine Soicher Wed To Gregory Slote on L.I.
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday, Lisa Elaine Soicher, the daughter of Harvey E. Soicher of Old Westbury, L.I., and Rona Soicher of Great Neck, L.I., was married to Gregory Slote, the son of Mildred Slote of Kings Point, L.I., and the late Dr. Lawrence Slote. Rabbi Herbert Richtman officiated.

title: Body Found in Freezer
description: The body of a 55-year old woman, missing since August, was found curled up in a 3-foot deep freezer in her Brooklyn apartment by her son Saturday night, the police said. The woman, Lottie Hollman of 249 Hopkinson Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, was discovered by her 27-year-old son, a police spokesman, Sgt. Ed Burns, said. The Medical Examiner's office is conducting an autopsy, the police said.

title: The League Declares a War Against Its Brawlers
description: THERE is a new peace movement afoot in hockey, one designed to eliminate the bench-clearing brawls. Although they occur with just about a third of the frequency of baseball brawls, they are perceived by hockey administrators to perpetuate the myth of their sport as a wrestling match on ice skates.

title: Correction
description: An article Saturday about the trial of John A. Zaccaro misstated the political affiliation of Joseph F. Carlino, the first prosecution witness in the trial and a former Speaker of the New York State Assembly. He is a Republican.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Senate Celebrity Room
description: A lot of star power occupied the Senate Dining Room on Friday as political stars mixed it up with the stars of stage and screen.

title: People
description: * William S. David was named publisher of Cosmopolitan magazine.

title: Mexico Moves to Keep Savings South of Border
description: A dozen Mexican banks operate in this fast-growing industrial and commercial center on the Rio Grande. For years, though, people here, like tens of thousands of other Mexicans, have routinely converted their pesos into dollars and deposited them in United States banks just across the border.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF England Upsets Scotland: England silenced a huge gallery of Scots and beat the home team, 2-1, to win the $1 million Dunhill Cup team tournament yesterday at St. Andrew's. In the consolation match, Curtis Strange shot a 10-under-par 62 against Greg Norman of Australia as the United States won third place, 2-1. In the final, Gordon J. Brand of England fired a 64 to beat Sam Torrance by 5 shots, and Nick Faldo shot a 66 to beat Sandy Lyle of Scotland by 3. Gordon Brand Jr. of Scotland had a 68 to beat Howard Clark by 5.(AP) A First for Brown: Ken Brown of Britain shot a two-under-par 68 yesterday to run away with the Southern Open in Columbus, Ga. It was his first PGA Tour triumph. Brown, a member of the European Ryder Cup squad that defeated the United States last week, held a five-shot lead entering the last round and never faltered. He finished the 72 holes at 14-under-par 266 over the par-70, 6,791-yard Green Island Country Club course.(AP) Geiberger Wins: Al Geiberger, at 50 the youngest member of the PGA Senior Tour, shot a three-under-par 67 yesterday for a two-stroke victory over Dave Hill in the Vantage Championship in Clemmons, N.C.(AP) BOXING Vasquez Takes Title: Wilfredo Vasquez of Puerto Rico stopped Park Chan-yong of South Korea in the 10th round yesterday to take away the World Boxing Association bantamweight title in a bout in Seoul. Vasquez (24-2-1) knocked Park (25-4-2) down twice before the scheduled 15-round bout was stopped at 43 seconds of the 10th.(AP) HORSE RACING Trempolino Rallies to Win: Trempolino, ridden by Pat Edderly, came from far back in an 11-horse field and captured the 66th Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe yesterday at Longchamps, outside Paris.(AP) AUTO RACING Labonte Stops Losing Streak: Terry Labonte won the Holly Farms 400 Nascar race yesterday at the North Wilkesboro (N.C.) Speedway, ending a string of 50 races without a victory. He held a lead of almost 3 seconds over Dale Earnhardt on lap 275, but the margin narrowed when the leader was slowed trying to lap Geoff Bodine. Earnhardt made his final pit stop on lap 331, and Labonte, almost a full lap ahead, made his pit stop on lap 337. He got back onto the track just ahead of the second-place car, then pulled away. He averaged 96.072 miles an hour. (AP) DOG SHOW Top Terrier of 2,126: In the largest all-terrier show ever held in the United States, Ch. Kilfel Pointe of Vu, a Lakeland terrier owned by Patricia Peters and Thomas Farrell, led a field of 2,126 at the 53d annual Montgomery County Kennel Club show yesterday on the grounds of Temple University in Ambler, Pa.

title: Washington Talk: National Security Council; Case of the Reluctant General
description: Shortly after President Reagan asked Frank C. Carlucci to become his national security adviser last December, Mr. Carlucci telephoned Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell at his post in West Germany to enlist the general as his deputy.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 4, 1987: MONDAY Central Vt Pub Service Oxford Indus TUESDAY CBI Industries Pacific Lighting Lomas & Nettleton Inv Southwest Gas Ohio Mattress Co WEDNESDAY Amer Water Wks Murphy Oil Heilig-Meyers Rite Aid Corp Houston Indus Rohm & Haas Co THURSDAY Aluminum Co America Hartmarx Corp Burlington Northern Puget Sound P & L Ford Motor Co Wisconsin Pub Serv FRIDAY First Chicago Corp Union Electric N Y State El & Gas Univar Corp

title: Miracle Finish? Incredible Flop? Tigers Win It
description: It will either be remembered as one of baseball's most inspired comebacks or one of its most embarrassing collapses. The Detroit Tigers, a team that some predicted would be among the worst in its division, captured the American League East title this afternoon with a dramatic 1-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays for a stunning three-game sweep of the season-ending series in the tightest pennant race of the year.

title: Plessey Official Leaves Board
description: Just a day after the Plessey Company and the General Electric Company P.L.C. said they would combine their global telecommunications units, Plessey's managing director, Sir James Blyth, quit the board.

title: Fallen Apples Reduce Hudson Valley's Yield
description: Ripe red apples on the ground in many New York State orchards are a sign that difficult financial times may lie ahead for some farmers.

title: APPLE FARMERS SAY 'EAT! EAT!'
description: This area is known as the apple capital of the world. And with a record harvest expected this fall, that name fits more than ever. But the big question in the orchards that dot the river valleys east of the Cascade Mountains is whether the market can absorb the bountiful crop.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have a lot of text, but we still have a few T's to cross and I's to dot.'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, on trade agreement with Canada. [ D5:1. ]

title: Man In The News; A Mexican on the Fast Track: Carlos Salinas de Gortari
description: From his father comes a passion for politics; from his mother, a delight in the intellectual rigors of economics. Throughout his short but successful career, friends say, Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sought to satisfy the demands of two often contradictory disciplines.

title: In The Nation; Bork and Blacks
description: If the nomination of Judge Robert Bork to sit on the Supreme Court is doomed, as last-minute White House efforts to raise the ''law and order'' issue suggest, the reasons lie in faulty strategy and sharply changing voting patterns.

title: DOROTHY READ THOMAS
description: Dorothy Read Thomas, the widow of James A. Thomas, the tobacco company executive, died Friday of cardiac arrest. She was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TRADE PACT IS SEEN AS ECONOMIC SPUR BY U.S. AND CANADA
description: The United States and Canada have agreed to an extensive trade pact that would stimulate economic activity in both countries by eliminating tariffs and other trade barriers before the end of the century.

title: Soviet Hails Sputnik and Cooperation
description: Thirty years after the launching of the first Sputnik began the space age, Soviet scientists celebrated with a weekend-long display of space glasnost and an appeal for international cooperation in exploring the solar system.

title: Shift at Pillsbury Raises Expectations
description: William H. Spoor has always been a name to conjure with at the Pillsbury Company. Now the 64-year-old retired chairman is creating ripples again with his appointment as head of the board's executive committee.

title: Business and the Law; New Liability For Auditors
description: ACCOUNTANTS have more to worry about in Mississippi and New Jersey than in Indiana and New York, according to a series of court decisions handed down in recent weeks.

title: Off the Field, Pickets, Pictures
description: It looked like a college pep rally or even an old-fashioned strike.

title: Every Dog (and Elephant) Has Its Day in St. John Rite
description: In much of New York City, animals are not welcome. There are ''no dogs'' signs in store windows and ''no pet'' clauses in city leases. Yesterday, however, animals were given center stage at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, a church that often draws its inspiration from the Middle Ages.

title: Chicago Journal; Nuisance Creeps In on Big Rat Feet
description: At an outdoor cafe in the fashionable Rush Street area here, a waitress told a noontime customer about the day's special. The customer shrieked in horror. It wasn't that the portions were too small, or the prices too large. Instead, it was the rat - too big, too ugly and too close for comfort - crawling across the restaurant floor.

title: Washington Talk: Capitol Hill; Modesty Becomes Newest Kennedy
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d began his career in the House of Representatives in just about the least desired suite of offices in the entire Congress but with television crews from as far away as Japan pressing at the door.

title: Tie Vote: What Happens
description: Given the pivotal position that Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. occupied at the Supreme Court's ideological center, the Court may well be unable to resolve some significant issues until the vacancy created by his retirement is filled.

title: A Fan's Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers to Return in Chicago
description: Representatives of the Chicago Teachers Union approved a two-year contract late today that ends a four-week teachers' strike, the longest in the city's history.

title: Redskins Triumph With No Regulars
description: ''Stay on strike! Stay on strike!'' a large number of Washington Redskin fans chanted today as the third quarter ended in the Redskins' game with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Do Beards Make a Statement?
