description: IT came as a surprise; it usually does. One minute he stood there, in the prime of beard, with a mustache, too. The next minute, not even an upper-lip hair was left standing.

title: Dance: Mwenzo-Africa
description: AN African legend was retold Friday night when the Mwenzo-Africa Dance Theater Troupe presented ''Nodiho'' at the Triplex Theater of the Borough of Manhattan Community College. Billed as an ''African dance opera,'' the production by a company from Zaire combined dance with song, chanting and percussion music.

title: When It Comes to Housing, Trickle-Down Theory Is a Dry Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From U.S. Statement on the Accord
description: The following are excerpts from a summary of the Free Trade Agreement issued by the Office of the United States Trade Representative: Tariffs

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 A wide-ranging trade agreement has been forged by the United States and Canada, the two countries' Governments announced. The long-sought pact would eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers before the year 2000. Page A1 Eerie silence inside a Sikh shrine and increased violence involving suspected Sikh terrorists beyond its walls symbolize the crisis considered to pose the most serious threat to India's national unity. A1 The next President of Mexico is likely to be a 39-year-old economist, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, chosen by the country's ruling party as its candidate to succeed President Miguel de la Madrid in December 1988. A1 Man in the News: The candidate chosen by Mexico's ruling party, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has paired passions for politics and economics throughout his short but successful career. A8 A prohibited propaganda blitz was operated by the Reagan Administration to ''favorably influence'' public support for the Nicaraguan rebels, a Congressional report says. A3 The Tibetan capital is under curfew and Chinese authorities tried to stop a busload of tourists from leaving Lhasa after demonstrations last week killed at least six people. A6 China has released two Americans who were detained in Tibet during demonstrations there last week, a State Department spokeswoman said. It was not clear why they were held or for how long. A6 El Salvador's President met formally, for the first time in nearly three years, with Marxist-led guerrillas fighting his Government. The meeting, in the Vatican mission, grew out of the Central American peace accord. A3 The remains of a former Moslem who converted back to Christianity on his deathbed have become the focus of a struggle in Malaysia, where religion is an issue of great sensitivity and volatility. A4 A Sputnik anniversary conference in Moscow was marked by a display of space glasnost, X-rays of a supernova, and an appeal by Soviet scientists for international cooperation in exploring the solar system. A16 Iran says it staged naval maneuvers in Persian Gulf A7 Sri Lanka faults Indian troops A7 Soviet shows chemical arsenal A10 NATIONAL A16-21, B9-10 A divided Supreme Court faces an array of politically charged issues that have fueled the battle over Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to its empty seat as it opens its new term. A1 Robert H. Bork will not withdraw as a nominee for the Supreme Court even if it becomes apparent after the Judiciary Committee vote that he has little chance of confirmation by the full Senate, a Washington lawyer said. B10 A powerful aftershock jolted Southern California, killing at least one person, causing scattered damage and serving as a reminder of the unpredictability of tremors. The aftershock measured 5.3 on the Richter scale. A16 Political penance performed in Iowa by Governor Michael S. Dukakis has been praised by some politicians as an aggressive form of damage control, but others see his Presidential campaign left with lingering wounds. A21 Elizabeth Hanford Dole embarks this week on one of the most unusual roles of her career: serving as an unpaid, full-time campaign worker in her husband's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination. A20 The Atlanta Zoo has reformed itself with more than just a name change to Zoo Atlanta. It has won accreditation that was denied after the deaths of several animals, and officials say current projects will soon make it ''a world class zoo.'' A16 Chicago Journal: Too many rats A16 Federal officials defend witness protection program A19 Cocaine tycoon trial begins today A19 Florida expected to close gun loophole A19 Gore admits ''careless'' statement A20 WASHINGTON TALK A18 Reluctant general and the National Security Council Colleagues rate newest Kennedy REGIONAL B1-6, D13 The earliest snowstorm on record struck mountainous regions of New York, Connecticut and upper New England, burying some areas under more than a foot of snow and knocking out power to more than 300,000 homes. A1 Snow in New York area was a meteorological long shot B5 A shortage of skilled tradesmen is plaguing the New York metropolitan area. Homeowners with remodeling plans are finding their dreams thwarted by a too-small supply of carpenters, masons, landscapers, plumbers and electricians. B1 Donald J. Trump denies yearning for power beyond that which he wields as a real-estate impresario, casino operator and corporate raider with a $3 billion fortune. But there are hints that indicate otherwise. B1 The education major would end at City University under a proposal by a university task force. It recommends instead that all students being trained as teachers be required to major in the liberal arts and sciences. B1 Bridgeport officials anxiously await a Federal report on the cause of a building collapse that killed 28 construction workers. The threat of scores of lawsuits is contributing to their anxiety. B2 Staten Island neighbors have formed a network of new or revitalized community anticrime groups since the disappearances and murders of three people over the last four months. B3 A plan to spur Broadway activity by attracting top directors and actors, reducing ticket prices and containing show costs is the focus of three veteran theater producers who have won rent-free use of the Ethel Barrymore Theater. C17 Animals took center stage in church as the Cathedral of St. John the Divine opened its doors to creatures ranging from an elephant to a skunk named Respect for its annual celebration of the Feast of St. Francis. B3 Plan could eliminate welfare hotels for homeless B1 Visitor admires home built for disabled B2 New York City's ratings woes B3 N.A.A.C.P. vote is challenged D13

title: GE/RCA UNIT LOSES BURNETT AS ITS AGENCY
description: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago announced Friday that it was resigning the account of the GE/RCA Consumer Electronics division because the client wished it to use a compensation system unlike those of its other clients. Also, Burnett said it was unwilling to go through an agency review.

title: ASSESSING IMPACT OF HIGH RATES
description: With interest rates creeping steadily higher, some economists are beginning to worry that the nation will be plunged into a recession next year.

title: Many Business Leaders Enthusiastic About Pact
description: Many American business leaders expressed strong support yesterday for the sweeping free trade agreement reached by negotiators for the United States and Canada.

title: Hunt Oil Sued in Yemen Deal
description: Two Texas energy companies filed a $1 billion lawsuit Friday against Ray L. Hunt and the Hunt Oil Company, charging that Mr. Hunt had unlawfully interfered with an agreement between them and the Government of Yemen.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Visitor From China
description: Deng Pufang, the son of China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is headed from New York to Washington tomorrow as the head of a delegation of the China Fund for the Handicapped.

title: Stock Exchanges Strong in Quarter
description: The world's stock markets continued to show strength in the sixth year of the bull market, although the pace of expansion slowed. In the quarter ending Sept. 30, stock prices worldwide rose by 5.7 percent, according to figures compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International.

title: State Dept. Linked to Contra Publicity
description: The Reagan Administration operated a ''prohibited covert propaganda'' operation in the State Department to ''favorably influence'' public support for the Nicaraguan rebels, according to a legal opinion made public today.

title: Denying AIDS Its Sting: A Quilt of Life
description: Entering the storefront headquarters of the Names Project here, visitors are struck by the colorful fabric panels that cover the walls and floors: red velvet, pale-blue cotton, hot-pink satin, plain denim, rich brocade, ordinary felt, plaid wool. For just a moment, the visual impact masks the reality that each panel - there are thousands of them - represents a life lost to AIDS.

title: Atlanta's Zoo Rebounds After Deaths of Animals
description: Three years ago the Atlanta Zoo was considered among the 10 worst in the nation. The cages were filthy, their inhabitants were decrepit and macabre tales were told of animals mysteriously dying, being sold off to circuses or victimized by inept and untrained workers.

title: Officials Await Study on Deaths Of 28 Workers
description: With the threat of scores of lawsuits hanging over them, Bridgeport city officials, as well as contractors, engineers and insurers involved in the collapse of an apartment building here last April, are anxiously awaiting a Federal report on the cause of the disaster.

title: Mergers in Publishing Is Theme of Symposium
description: ''The Publishing Industry's March to Oligopoly,'' a symposium on recent book-publishing mergers, will be held at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, at 8 tonight.

title: Lawyer's Trial to Start; Case Is Tied to Winans
description: David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading circle that included a former Wall Street Journal columnist, R. Foster Winans, is scheduled to go on trial today in a Federal courtroom in lower Manhattan.

title: Italy On Stage Festival
description: Turn almost any corner in New York during the coming months, and there's bound to be a bit of the Italy on Stage festival. From West 112th Street to Bowling Green, from Eastern Parkway to Fifth Avenue and the bright lights of Broadway, Italy will display its treasures of art and music, theater and film.

title: Marguerite Duras Play Set for Marymount
description: The Theatre Populaire de Lorraine, a French regional company, will give four performances of the Marguerite Duras play ''L'Amante Anglaise'' this month, at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. The play, presented jointly by the French Institute/Alliance Francaise and the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, will be performed in French, with English supertitles.

title: Cardinals Win Again
description: Not that New York fans need to be reminded, but the National League East championship wasn't the only division title the Mets lost to the St. Louis Cardinals this year. There was also the matter of the division record for home attendance.

title: Flyers and Oilers Likely to Face Off Again for Title
description: The following conference previews were written by Joe Sexton (Wales Conference) and Robin Finn. WALES CONFERENCE Patrick Division

title: Outdoors: Ambling After Grouse
description: IF putting meat on the table is an important part of your reason for hunting, you had best ignore the ruffed grouse, for there is probably no other upland bird pursued so passionately by so many with so few results.

title: What the Agreement Represents to Ottawa and Washington; Mulroney's Calculated Risks Opened Door to Settlement
description: When Canadians awoke today to news of the free trade agreement with the United States, supporters and opponents of the pact agreed on one thing: that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney had embarked on an imposing gamble with his own future, and possibly with the country's as well.

title: Consultant Wed To Sheila C. Bam
description: Sheila Catherine Bam, a daughter of Foster Bam of Greenwich, Conn., and Margaret Compton Bam of Pelham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth Alan Kosakoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Kosakoff of New York. Acting Justice Burton S. Sherman of State Supreme Court officiated at Windows on the World in Manhattan.

title: Pakistan Says Troops Died in India Fighting
description: Pakistan said today that some of its troops were killed in a clash with Indian soldiers late last month over a glacier in the disputed Himalayan state of Kashmir.

title: Hogeboom Shreds Bills, 47-6
description: Gary Hogeboom, one of the first veterans to defy the National Football League Players Association strike, threw five touchdown passes today as an experienced Indianapolis Colts team routed the strike-depleted Buffalo Bills, 47-6, before 9,860 fans at 80,000-seat Rich Stadium.

title: A Flaw In His Outlook
description: Senator Strom Thurmond was wrong a generation ago in seeking to block the confirmations of Justices Potter Stewart and Abe Fortas because they read the Constitution in a way that he didn't like. Senators are equally wrong today in opposing Judge Robert H. Bork on the same grounds.

title: Ward Leaves Hospital
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward was released from Booth Memorial Hospital yesterday and has returned home, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LAST INTELLECTUALS. American Culture in the Age of Academe. By Russell Jacoby. 290 pages. Basic Books. $18.95.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 5, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. tee - 3 P.M.

title: New 'Star Trek' Series Is Set in Post-Kirk Era
description: "STAR TREK'' is back - not as a rerun or a feature film, but as a syndicated series called ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Trekkies will eagerly recall that the original series had its premiere in September 1966. In fact, the series was not terribly successful in terms of ratings. But its hard-core fans were devoted and fiercely protective, fending off at least one cancellation of the series with a letters campaign. The show expired in 1969 but, thanks to endless reruns, still retains a cult following with some 450 fan clubs around the world. Paramount Network Television doesn't hesitate in revealing the target audience in its publicity for this new series: the universe.

title: >Economic Expansion Reported
description: The nation's industrial economy continued to expand briskly in September, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest report to be released today.

title: Film Festival; Alain Resnais's 'Melo,' From a 1929 Romance
description: IN every film he's ever made, Alain Resnais has been exploring cinema techniques with such invention that technique has sometimes become the end instead of the means. One remembers (sometimes with pleasure, but often with impatience) the look and sound of ''Hiroshima, Mon Amour,'' ''Last Year at Marienbad'' and ''Providence'' more vividly than what, finally, the spiffy style was intended to illuminate.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Hurts Jaw
description: The slight fracture of the lower jaw suffered by John Vanbiesbrouck during practice Saturday will not prevent the Ranger goalie from being available to the team for its season opener against the Pittsburgh Penguins on Thursday. But the injury does make it likely that Bob Froese, the other Ranger goaltender, will start.

title: Bridge: One of World's Top Players Is Recruited by a Great Team
description: One of the world's greatest bridge teams has, rather reluctantly, recruited one of the world's greatest players. Michael Lawrence of Kensington, Calif., who has won two world titles and written many excellent books on the game, will compete in the world championships scheduled to start Sunday in Jamaica.

title: Yanks Bid Farewell Amid Chilly Loss
description: On the last day of the season, the Yankees packed and said their good-byes. But there was an uncertainty to the final moments they shared as a team yesterday, as if they could not be sure they would all be together again.

title: Bears Crush Eagles With Ex-Bartender
description: The strike version of the Chicago Bears does not compare favorably with the regular Monsters of the Midway, but it got the same results today with a 35-3 rout of the non-union Philadelphia Eagles before only 4,074 fans.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Choir From Armenia At Avery Fisher Hall
description: The State Choir of Armenia knows how to deliver a show. At touring strength, as heard in Avery Fisher Hall Saturday afternoon, it is an ensemble of some 75 rich, firm voices, comfortable alike in rousing folk and patriotic music, operatic excerpts, backup vocals for a crooner and new music of moderate difficulty.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Bette Distler Poems To Music by Her Son
description: ''The Death of Lottie Shapiro'' is a long and elaborate song cycle celebrating the poems of Bette Distler. The music is by the poet's son, Jed; Mr. Distler, who is also a pianist, joined five sopranos in a performance of the piece's 29 numbers at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night.

title: The Fans' Verdict: It Was 'Ridiculous'
description: There were about four minutes left in the second quarter when one fan got up from his end-zone seat and began his climb to the exits. Another touchdown by the Dallas Cowboys -their third straight - quickened his pace, but it was not until he reached the parking-lot gate that he finally took off the gas mask he was wearing.

title: Bond Rally Has Its Doubters
description: The brisk bond market rally on Friday afternoon was enough to reduce note and bond yields by nearly a fifth of a percentage point, even if analysts could not point to any change in economic conditions that justified the move.

title: Bork Rejects Seeking Withdrawal of Nomination
description: Judge Robert H. Bork indicated today that he would not ask President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Supreme Court even if it became apparent after the Judiciary Committee vote on Tuesday that the tide had turned inexorably against confirmation by the Senate.

title: Kenneth J. Hollenbeck Weds Lisa K. Gornick
description: Lisa Karen Gornick, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Yale University, and Kenneth Joseph Hollenbeck, a lawyer with the Community Health Law Project, a public-interest legal corporation in East Orange, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. E. Walton Zelley, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Terrace Restaurant atop Butler Hall, Columbia University.

title: Sports of The Times; Pro Football's Sham Sunday
description: IT will be remembered as Sham Sunday, but maybe it will be the only one. When the National Football League team player representatives meet tonight at an airport hotel in Chicago, maybe they will realize that the strike is crumbling, that 38 players crossed the picket line last Friday, that dozens more will cross it this week, that it's time to realize that the club owners' resistance to free agency isn't worth the loss of salary.

title: A. Baird Hasting Dies at 91; Researcher in Biochemistry
description: A. Baird Hastings, a leading biochemist and physiologist, died of heart disease Sept. 24 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: Mrs. Dole's Role: More Than Spouse
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole embarks this week on one of the most unusual roles of her career: she will serve as an unpaid, full-time campaign worker for her husband's Presidential drive.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Iowans Unswayed by Dukakis Visit
description: ''We've had enough of Sasso,'' said Marjorie Tyler, 71 years old, her face alive with indignation.

title: Salvadoran Leader and Guerrillas Meet
description: After several delays, President Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Marxist-led guerrillas fighting his Government formally met here today for the first time in nearly three years.

title: Reading at Queens College
description: Nien Cheng, author of ''Life and Death in Shanghai,'' will read from her work today at 7 P.M. at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing. In her autobiography, Mrs. Cheng documents her imprisonment in the late 1960's, during the Cultural Revolution. The reading is part of the school's evening series. Suggested donation, $2. Information: (718) 520-7323.

title: It Was, in Short, a Meteorological Long Shot
description: For the keepers of records, the snowfall yesterday was something akin to a three-minute mile or a manned space flight to Pluto.

title: Over All Impressive in Matron Victory
description: Over All continued her dominance of New York's 2-year-old fillies and gave her trainer a sweep of the weekend's Grade I juvenile stakes by scoring a 5 3/4-length victory in the $136,900 Matron Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Market Place; New Interest In Food Stocks
description: AT a time when price volatility is beginning to make some investors nervous, food company stocks are gaining favor because they offer steady growth in revenues, earnings and dividends and a stable group of customers.

title: Remodeling Boom Outstrips the Supply of Contractors
description: It took Dorothy Herman six months to find a contractor to remodel her kitchen and build a new deck on her home here. Now she has to wait four more months before the contractor, whose work she likes, has time to renovate her bathrooms.

title: Knowing the Score
description: The Mets were taking on the Phillies in Philadelphia, the Cardinals were playing the Expos in St. Louis, and Harold Brodsky, a diehard Mets fan, was at a Broadway show in New York the other night when he got to wondering how the National League East pennant race was going. So at intermission, with no radio, television or telephone in sight, he reached into his pocket to find out.

title: As the Bork Vote Approaches
description: LEAD: I am an enthusiastic supporter of the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. This should not surprise anyone. What should be surprising is that there is such a political hullaballoo over this nomination.

title: New York Details Drive for Voters
description: New York City and Federal officials yesterday announced details of an ambitious voter registration drive, with the goal of enrolling two million new voters in New York City.

title: Panel Proposes CUNY Abolish Education Major
description: A task force of the City University of New York has proposed that all students being trained as teachers be required to major in the liberal arts and sciences instead of education.

title: Chicago Rating Raised
description: Moody's Investor Service said today it had raised Chicago's general obligation bonds to an A rating, reflecting the city's economic growth and its determination to balance its budget. The bonds had been rated Baa-1 since March 1984. The change could save the city $5 million to $6 million in interest expenses per $100 million worth of bonds over 25 years, Chicago's comptroller, Ronald Picur, said.

title: BROAD TERMS OF PACT REFLECT AMERICAN GOAL OF FREE TRADE
description: The sweeping free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada approved here late Saturday night will not only set the terms of commerce between the world's two largest trading partners but will establish a benchmark for the reforms America is seeking in the international trading system.

title: Opera: 3 Chamber Works
description: THE American Chamber Opera's triple bill Friday evening at the Marymount Manhattan College Theater offered a group of short scores that promised interest, but proved unfortunately somewhat dreary in the event. None of the pieces sent one home eager for more, except in one sense: Putting them on the stage is the only real way to test new operas, and so the company's efforts are firmly in the right place.

title: Mapping Future of Child Care
description: The solution to the growing need for child care rests with the elementary-school system, according to a prominent advocate of child welfare. He called for a comprehensive approach, in which many services, including day care, would emanate from the schools.

title: Marx at the Goal Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephen Freedman Weds Laurie Millman, Executive
description: Laurie Beth Millman, the vice president of marketing and the product group director at the Schieffelin & Somerset Company, a subsidiary of the Moet-Hennessy United States Corporation in New York, and Stephen Freedman, president of Vinmark, a wine brokerage in Marblehead, Mass., were married yesterday at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion officiated.

title: Waiting Game Is Over in Mexico As Presidential Choice Is Named
description: Mexico's ruling party today named Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a 39-year-old economist, as its candidate to succeed President Miguel de la Madrid in December 1988.

title: What Makes Physical Therapy Cost Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Surveillance Drone Delayed The Army has delayed production of its main unmanned surveillance aircraft because its operators could not spot many targets in a test. Page A16. Help for Airline Passengers The House approved consumer-protection measures for airline passengers. The Senate is expected to back similar legislation. Page A22. Tokyo Turns to Politics Japan begins the formal process of choosing a Prime Minister this week, at a time of overseas pressure to play a larger global role. Page A10. The Baseball Playoffs What a fan, or a non-fan, needs to know to prepare for the American and National League championship playoffs. Pages D32-D33.

title: Protect the Job Boom
description: Unemployment inched down to 5.8 percent in September with hardly a whiff of inflation, and the White House is crowing.

title: Stage: 'China Dream'
description: IN ''China Dream,'' a celebrated Chinese actress immigrates to the United States, is unable to continue her career and finds herself becoming nostalgic for the life she thought she had in her homeland. From this material, William H. Sun and Faye C. Fei, a husband-and-wife team of playwrights, have fashioned an unsophisticated little play that strives for wistfulness. Neither in the writing nor in Peter Schlosser's staging does the work offer ample insights into the Chinese-American experience.

title: Tibet Unrest Said to Aid Hard-Liners in Beijing
description: The biggest beneficiaries of the recent unrest in Tibet may be officials in Beijing who are opposed to the pace of China's liberalization, in the view of political analysts in Hong Kong.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Representative Jim Wright decried the White House's latest Nicaraguan strategy as ''ridiculous,'' after taking the unusual step two months ago of agreeing to collaborate with President Reagan's peace plan for Central America. Page A1 Chinese police entered a shrine, the Jokhang Cathedral in Lhasa, and occupied one floor of what is Tibetan Buddhism's holiest place, in the aftermath of pro-independence protests that are reported to have left at least nine Tibetans dead. A1 An elderly Tibetan monk wept as he told how 21 of his colleagues from the Drepung Monastery were in prison as a result of an independence march through Lhasa that erupted in violence last week. A12 Tibet unrest may benefit Beijing officials A12 A Nicaraguan Indian guerrilla who commands forces fighting the Sandinista Government has agreed to end his campaign, saying he could support the Government ''if it defends Indian rights.'' A9 The next Prime Minister of Japan will be chosen after several weeks ofintense factional struggle, scheduled to begin this week. Whoever wins willgovern during what is expected to be a delicate period for the nation. A10 The top Soviet agriculture official and a rising star of the country's Politburo arrives in the United States today to study the American way of farming and may pave the way for a similar visit by Mikhail S. Gorbachev later this year. A14 Unesco director general expected to win new term A3 Suriname leader wary of elections A3 Cairo journal A4 Sri lanka says captive Tamils killed themselves A6 China says it downed a Vietnamese fighter A12 NATIONAL A16-33, B5-6 Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination appears doomed, according to the Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd. Senator Byrd and three other previously uncommitted senators announced they would vote against Judge Bork's confirmation to the Supreme Court. A1 The Supreme Court agreed to hear arguments on whether a newspaper had a constitutional right to defy a court order barring publication of a planned article, instead of appealing the order. A1 The court refused to review a lower-court ruling barring publication of a biography of J.D. Salinger that includes quotations from letters the novelist wrote but sued to prevent from being published. C17 The first cholesterol guidelines for identifying and treating people whose blood cholesterol levels are high enough to require medical treatment were issued by the Federal Government and more than 20 major health organizations. A1 New controls on water pollution by discharge of toxic chemicals were announced by the Environmental Protection Agency. The new rules cover 66 pollutants, including organic chemicals, plastics and synthetic fibers. A20 A new Army drone has been delayed and will not be in production before 1992, military officials said. Tests conducted this summer found that operators were unable to correctly use the unmanned aircraft, known as Aquila. A16 A consumer-protection package for airline passengers that would require airlines to provide more time between connecting flights and compensate passengers for lost or delayed baggage, was approved by the House of Representatives. A22 A debate among the six Democrats seeking the Presidential nomination centered on foreign policy issues and focused pressure on Senator Albert Gore Jr.'s effort to break apart from his rivals' positions on foreign affairs. A31 After a sharp drop in fund-raising over the summer, the Presidential campaign of former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt has been forced to go deeply into debt in order to stay afloat financially. B5 Detroit journal A16 Psychological tremors from earthquake A16 Opponents disrupt hearings on power plant's future A16 Violent crime dropped last year but rate of decline is slowing A24 British to clean damaged atom plant A26 Beetles on exhibit at Harvard A28 Saudis give $5 million for camp A30 Computer enlisted in drive on marijuana A33 WASHINGTON TALK A32 War Powers Act? What War Powers Act? Data that only spies can find REGIONAL B1-4, B7, B20 The Supreme Court refused to rule on the legality of a test that has kept women from being hired as New York City firefighters, effectively ending an 8-year challenge to the system used to select firefighters. A1 A teen-ager was sentenced to six months in jail for planning her father's murder. Cheryl Pierson, of Selden, L.I., who pleaded guilty to manslaughter earlier this year, fainted when her sentence was announced. B1 A grand jury witness was killed by a shotgun blast to the head, and police said they believed it was done by someone who wanted to silence or punish the victim, 61-year-old Mildred Green, who testified about a shooting she saw. A1 The Bowery Savings Bank was sold for $200 million in cash to a Los Angeles-based company. The sale occurred less than two years after investors rescued it from imminent collapse and took it private with Federal aid. A1 The wife of Anthony Scotto, a former union local president, has been paid as much as $30,000 a year for a no-show job with the local's Political Action Fund since her husband went to prison for racketeering, according to the Waterfront Commission. B1 A Howard Beach defendant admitted he had taken a baseball bat from another man with which to hit three black men, a defense lawyer said. Murder charges against the defendant will be dropped in plea bargaining. B3 State Assembly commission records subpoenaed B1 New York City official warns of crisis in psychiatric care B3 Scientology records subpoenaed in Chambers trial B4 School employees end strike in Elizabeth, N.J. B20

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMR Corp. elected as a director Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: School Employees End 27-Day Strike in Elizabeth
description: Public-school employees, on strike here since the school year began 27 days ago, returned to work this morning without a contract just hours before court-imposed sanctions would have cost them their jobs.

title: Shotgun Blast to Head Kills Witness to a Crime in Queens
description: Six nights a week Mildred Green dispatched cabs through the drug-scarred streets of South Jamaica, Queens.

title: Stepparents Look for Society's Acceptance
description: To the Editor:

title: The Football Riddle
description: Turning the television channels Sunday in search of a football game, this reporter came across on the screen a man in a hurry who was carrying a small brown object that looked like a football. Or was it a roasted chicken?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DREAMS AND DELUSIONS. The Drama of German History. By Fritz Stern. 323 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Have astronomers been able to use the location, speed and direction of the observable galaxies to identify the probable location of the Big Bang?

title: New York State Takes Lead in Going After Garment Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: Opponents Disrupt U.S. Hearings On Seabrook Atom Plant's Future
description: Opponents of the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire today disrupted Government hearings that could determine whether the dormant plant will be allowed to operate.

title: 2 Nations Size Up Trade Pact; U.S. Prepares For Scrutiny In Congress
description: To save a free-trade pact with Canada, the Reagan Administration agreed that a Canadian-American dispute settlement panel could review acts of Congress and authorize Canadian trade retaliation if those acts ''violate the spirit'' of the pact.

title: 6-Month Term For Teen-Ager In L.I. Murder
description: Persuaded that Cheryl Pierson was sexually abused by her father, a State Supreme Court justice sentenced the 18-year-old woman today to six months in jail for her role in planning her father's murder.

title: New York Sues Reputed Mobster to Force Cleanup of Landfill
description: New York State filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday to force the cleanup of a hazardous dump site said to be owned by a group that includes a man accused as a Mafia leader.

title: Actor Gets 5 Million Saudi Gift for Ill Children
description: Saudi Arabia has made a $5 million gift to the actor Paul Newman to help establish a camp in Connecticut for critically ill children.

title: Bustling on Both Borders; A Man for One of Mexico's Crises
description: Mexico's incumbent President acted reasonably in choosing Carlos Salinas Gortari, an economist, to succeed him next year. His country remains gripped by its worst economic crisis in a half century. But the anointed technocrat will have to spend as much time attending to an equally severe crisis - the faltering political credibility of the PRI, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. This double crisis will thoroughly tax the skills of the official nominee.

title: Joint Navy Contract Seen
description: Marconi Communications Ltd., a division of General Electric P.L.C. of Britain, said today that it expects to receive a United States Navy electronics contract worth at least $3 billion in a joint bid arranged with the Rockwell International Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: photos of latest fashions from Milan (NYT/Vittoriano Rastelli); In Milan, Short Skirts Inspire Inventive Spring Openings
description: Fashion is exploding in all possible directions. Not too long ago audiences complained that Italian clothes looked alike; you couldn't tell the designers without a score card. The arrival of short skirts has changed all that. It has spurred a burst of inventiveness as designers tried to come to terms with the new proportions. It has also added an element of surprise. Ever since the spring and summer ready-to-wear openings began over the weekend, it has been difficult to predict what kind of clothes would be coming down the runway.

title: Car Crash Kills 3 Marines
description: Three marines were killed Sunday when the car in which they were riding became airborne while exiting Interstate 395 and struck a tree, breaking the auto into two pieces, the police said. The identities of the men, stationed at the Quantico Marine Base, were not immediately released.

title: GNB Battery Sale
description: Pacific Dunlop Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire 60 percent of GNB Holdings Inc., a battery maker based in Mendota Heights, Minn., for $173 million (Australian), or about $123 million (United States). The purchase would increase the Australian company's presence in the United States and make the concern one of the largest producers of batteries in the world. Pacific Dunlop said it would merge its Pacific Chloride battery operations in the United States with GNB to create a major lead/acid battery maker, with combined annual sales of $500 million in North America. The merger would put Dunlop's world battery sales at $640 million. GNB markets its batteries under the Champion, High Energy and Power Breed names.

title: Sri Lanka Says 12 Captive Tamils Killed Themselves With Cyanide
description: Twelve Tamil separatist guerrillas killed themselves today while in government custody on the Jaffna Peninsula in northern Sri Lanka, and other guerrillas attacked two Sri Lanka army camps in the area, a Government official said.

title: Caesars Casino License
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission licensed Caesars World Inc. today to operate Caesars Casino Hotel in Atlantic City for another year, on the condition that it make a good-faith effort to employ more blacks and women. The vote was 5 to 0 in favor of the relicensing.

title: Latest Lotus Correlates Ideas
description: The Lotus Development Corporation will introduce within the next month an unusual program called Agenda that incorporates several artificial-intelligence techniques. Company officials said it would enable computer users to analyze ideas and text much as spreadsheets allow them to analyze numbers.

title: Log of Earth's Climate
description: A cylinder of ice nearly a mile and a half long, painstakingly drawn from the Antarctic icecap by a Soviet and French scientific expedition, has documented 160,000 years of the earth's climate, revealing a surprisingly precise connection between changes in temperature and in the amount of carbon dioxide in the air.

title: Telephone Notes Have 9.67% Yield
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday offered $300 million of 9 5/8 percent notes, due in 1992, at a price of 99.824 to yield 9.67 percent through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Orioles in Shake-Up
description: Just one day after the Baltimore Orioles finished their American League season with the third-worst record (66-96) in their 34-year-history, there was a big shake-up in the Orioles' front office yesterday. Edward Bennett Williams, the owner, announced he had dismissed Hank Peters, the general manager for the last 12 years, and Tom Giordano, the director of the farm system. He also transfered Doug Melvin, his own special assistant, to acting director of minor league operations and scouting. ''This is the beginning of the reorganization of the Orioles' front office,'' Williams said in a statement. ''We shall have an announcement in the near future on our new front-office structure.'' Both Melvin and Peters, who had two years remaining on his contract at $200,000 annually, said they had been given no hint of the shake-up before hearing from Williams yesterday. Cal Ripken Sr., the manager, and his coaching staff said they had not been contacted about returning to the team next season, but Ripken, who was named manager after the 1986 season, said he was not worried about his future. ''I've been here 31 years,'' he said. ''The year's over. You go from there.''

title: A Magazine on a Disk
description: A FEW weeks ago this space mentioned Compute!'s PC Magazine, a publication with its articles in conventional printed form but with programs supplied on a disk sold as an integral part of the package. Well, Uptime is a computer magazine supplied entirely on a disk.

title: G.M. to Pay Big OSHA Fine
description: The General Motors Corporation agreed today to pay $500,000 in fines to settle what Government officials described as a pattern of underreporting job injuries.

title: Tigers, Cards Favored
description: The Detroit Tigers, who won the American League East title in the final days of the season with a three-game sweep of the Toronto Blue Jays, and the St. Louis Cardinals, who replaced the Mets atop the National League East, are favored to meet in the World Series, according to oddsmakers in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Fisher-Price Job
description: Waring & LaRosa, long a Fisher-Price agency, has been named to handle its Brand Licensed Products for infant and toddler businesses. The assignment was formerly at Towne Silverstein Rotter. Billing figures were unavailable.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the Italy on Stage festival in New York gave an outdated schedule for the exhibition ''Giovanni Pisano in Genoa'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It will run Oct. 30 to Dec. 6.

title: Flaws Force New Delay in Army Drone
description: The Army has delayed production of its premier unmanned surveillance aircraft after operators proved unable to use it effectively in a 17-week trial last summer.

title: Gore's Foreign Policy Not as Different as He Says, Rivals
description: The six Democratic Presidential candidates heatedly debated a wide range of foreign policy issues here tonight, with much of the pressure focusing on Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and his effort to break apart from his rivals' positions on foreign affairs.

title: Gardner to Shift
description: Gayle Gardner, who has worked as a reporter and anchor at ESPN since 1983, will leave the cable network to work at the same jobs with NBC-TV. On Jan. 1, she will be host of the network's college football bowl coverage. Gardner, 37, will be one of NBC's anchors at the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Zayre May Get Bid From DeBartolo
description: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., a prominent shopping center developer, had told the retailer that he intended to buy at least 73,000 more shares of its common stock and may later try to acquire control.

title: Electronics Sales on Rise
description: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products are expected to reach nearly $225 billion this year, a 5.3 percent increase over last year, the Electronic Industries Association said today. Consumer electronics manufacturers were expected to realize the largest gains, with projected growth of 7.1 percent, the association said. Sharp rises in the cost of labor and consumer products are expected to slow sales in 1988.

title: Careers; Financial Services Growth
description: DURING recent corporate cutbacks, public relations personnel were often among the targets. Members of corporate listening posts in Washington, where they functioned as lobbyists, lost their jobs. So did editors of employee publications at manufacturing companies.

title: Is There a Fifth Force in Nature? Research Struggles Toward an Answer
description: WHILE on the surface of the moon in 1971, an American astronaut paused before a television camera to demonstrate that Galileo in the 17th century had it right about the force of gravity when he observed that ''in a medium totally devoid of resistance all bodies would fall with the same speed.''

title: BARYSHNIKOV EXPLORES DEPTHS OF MARTHA GRAHAM'S DANCES
description: When Mikhail Baryshnikov makes his first guest appearance with the Martha Graham Dance Company tonight, his initial gesture as a frontier farmer in ''Appalachian Spring'' will be to touch the wood on Isamu Noguchi's Shaker-inspired frame of a house. What does the gesture mean?

title: In One Town, Snowstorm Blocks Mailman's Rounds
description: For the first weekday in memory, John Derrick, the rural mail deliverer here, did not complete his duly appointed rounds.

title: Taft Sale Cleared
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the transfer of broadcasting licenses held by the Taft Broadcasting Company, clearing the way for a $1.44 billion buyout of the company. Taft shareholders are selling the media company to an investor group, TFBA Limited Partnership, that includes the FMI Financial Corporation, which is headed by the Cincinnati investor Carl H. Lindner. Other partners include the Texas investor Robert Bass and members of the founding Taft family. F.C.C. approval was considered the final hurdle to completion of the transfer.

title: Babbitt Campaign Gets Big Loan to Stay Afloat
description: The Presidential campaign of former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt has had to borrow heavily to stay afloat after a sharp drop in fund-raising this summer.

title: Ms. Steinem Carries On
description: Two men are sitting in a restaurant. They see a couple of women they know at another table. One of the men gets up, walks over and says:

title: Bustling on Both Borders; Today Canada; Tomorrow the World
description: For all the ominous drama of warships in the Persian Gulf and the promise of a new superpower missile treaty, America's workaday foreign relations still depend heavily on its neighbors. Ronald Reagan acknowledged that in his speech opening his Presidential campaign in 1979; he talked at length about a ''North American accord.'' The point was made anew last weekend by an agreement on trade with Canada and by the almost-simultaneous anointing of Mexico's next president.

title: Unfamiliar Giants Fail To Stop 49ers or Tailspin
description: Before the National Football League players went on strike, the Giants lost their first two games of the season. Tonight, in their first game with a replacement team, they lost again.

title: House Voted Justice for Interned Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Clever Strategy Shows Promise Against Colds
description: SCIENCE is still a long way from a cure for the common cold. But maybe that does not matter anymore.

title: Texaco Seeks End To Creditors Panel
description: Texaco Inc. asked the United States trustee overseeing its bankruptcy proceedings to eliminate one of the two creditors committees. But officials of the Pennzoil Company, which won a $10.53 billion court judgment against Texaco in a dispute over Getty Oil and is co-head of the committee that Texaco wants to dissolve, said it would oppose the request. The committee comprises oil companies to which Texaco owes money.

title: Key Strike Hurdle May Fall
description: As the National Football League owners intensified the pressure on striking players today with several procedural changes, union leaders met here tonight on the 14th day of the strike to review their options, including dropping the demand for free agency.

title: Defendant in Park Murder Tried to Join Scientologists
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has subpoenaed Church of Scientology records about Robert E. Chambers Jr., who twice sought counseling at the organization's Celebrity Center in Manhattan.

title: Taking a Stand on Confirmation: Senatorial Voices For and Against Bork
description: Since the end of testimony about Judge Robert H. Bork before the Judiciary Committee, 20 members of the Senate, including some influential undecided senators, have announced their positions on his nomination to the Supreme Court. Following are excerpts from some of the statements of the 4 senators who favor confirmation and the 16 who oppose it. FOR CONFIRMATION Phil Gramm Republican of Texas

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''WE'RE not represented the way I'd like to be,'' said Calvin Klein, discussing his plans to open stores around the country. The first should open next spring in Dallas.

title: African Delegates Ask For Curbs Against Pretoria
description: Representatives of Botswana, Kenya and other African nations today criticized members of the Security Council who support sanctions against Iran as a means of ending the gulf war but refuse to impose similar measures against South Africa over apartheid or its occupation of South-West Africa.

title: Bridge: '86-'87 Von Zedtwitz Double Overlaps Next Year's Event
description: The end of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team championship for 1986-87 will overlap with the 1987-88 event. The entries for that and the Harter Cup close Oct. 15. Information is available from Alan Osofsky at (212) 697-9379.

title: JOURNEYMEN LOOK FOR ROSTER SPOTS
description: Lewis Brown last played basketball for Nevada-Las Vegas in 1977. The 6-foot-10-inch, 32-year-old center is now at the Los Angeles Clippers' training camp. So is David Thirdkill, who has a championship ring from the Boston Celtics, as well as Jim Lampley, Aubrey Sherrod and Willie White.

title: Finding the Marijuana Fields: A Computer Points the Finger
description: Scientists say they have developed a computer program that can predict where most illicit marijuana patches will be hidden, giving law officers a head start on the illegal growers.

title: Detroit Journal; Foie Gras and Vivaldi on Woodward
description: There are signs of life on Woodward Avenue, the once vital, tumbledown main street that some here long ago left for dead.

title: Blaze Injures 10 Firefighters
description: A fire injured 10 firefighters and caused $2 million in damage at a shopping center Saturday, the authorities said. Officials said two stores were destroyed and six damaged in the blaze, which sent flames 100 feet into the air. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

title: House Voted Justice for Interned Americans; We Were at War
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Will Review New York City Curb On All-Male Clubs
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the constitutionality of a New York City law that prohibits large social clubs from excluding women as members.

title: Polygram Issue
description: N.V. Philips said it plannned to issue 15 million shares next month in its wholly owned record-making subsidiary, Polygram N.V. About 10.5 million shares will be issued in the United States. But Philips will keep a controlling interest in the company, a spokesman said.

title: Stocks Mixed Amid Rate Worries
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as worry over higher interest rates and inflation erased an early gain on the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: New Zealand Investor Turns to U.S. Market
description: Ronald A. Brierly, a New Zealand corporate raider, has amassed a fortune acquiring small, neglected companies in old-line industries. His methods were considered so unorthodox at a time when unfriendly deals were unusual that his applications for a listing on the New Zealand Stock Exchange were rejected seven times before Brierly Investments Ltd. was listed in 1970.

title: Gibbons, Green Wins Argonaut
description: Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen Ltd. said today that it planned to buy Argonaut Group Inc. for about $620 million, a deal that apparently ends a long courtship for the workers' compensation insurer.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Dressing Woodward
description: How did Bob Woodward of The Washington Post manage to get into the hospital room of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, for a deathbed interview reported in the new Woodward book ''Veil''? Well, the irreverent Capitol Hill tabloid Roll Call has come forward with some suggestions.

title: Son Held in Mother's Death
description: A woman and her 16-year-old son were found dead in their Bronx apartment yesterday, and the woman's other son was later charged with the murders, the police said. A police spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci, said the bodies of Kathleen Wiggins, 46 years old, and her 16-year-old son, Sean, were discovered in the apartment at 1686 Clay Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx, by Thomas Wiggins, Mrs. Wiggins's estranged husband. Sergeant Venetucci said that the killings followed a dispute about money and that a television set was missing from the apartment. He said Mrs. Wiggins's other son, 18-year-old Jamal, turned himself in to the police yesterday afternoon.

title: Market Place; Movement At Pan Am
description: AFTER months of hunting for an investor to make a major infusion of capital in Pan American World Airways, a coalition of unions at the airline and their investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., may be getting closer to their goal.

title: Gianettino & Meredith Gets Jersey Blue Cross
description: A 17-agency contest for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey ad account has ended with Gianettino & Meredith of Short Hills, N.J., as the victor. Billings are expected to be about $4 million, the agency said.

title: Arkla Will Buy Entex in Swap
description: Entex Inc., a natural gas distribution company in Houston, has agreed to be purchased by Arkla Inc. in a stock transaction valued at $25.30 a share, or $572 million.

title: E.P.A. Adopts New Rules on Water Pollution
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would impose new controls to reduce the discharge of a wide range of toxic chemicals into the nation's surface waters.

title: HIGH COURT, SHORT A JUSTICE, TO HEAR 21 NEW APPEALS
description: Opening its new term with only eight members, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments in several significant cases while declining to review nearly 1,000 other appeals.

title: Eastern Air's Pay-Cut Plan
description: The management of Eastern Airlines yesterday outlined the pay cuts and work rule changes that it says it needs from the machinists' union to bring the pay of its 11,600 members more in line with the company's other unions and to make the airline more competitive.

title: Us Defines Its Readers
description: A person who switches drinks depending on his mood, or who likes to experiment with fashion, or who buys expensive goods because he feels he's worth it - that's a ''fashion-focused'' person, as defined by a proprietary study done by Simmons Market Research for Us magazine.

title: KEY RATES
Jane K. Butcher, 64, Is Dead; First Woman on M.T.A. Board
description: Jane K. Butcher, the first woman ever appointed to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died after a long illness last Thursday. She was 64 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: In a Silent Monastery, Gods, Tears and Fears
description: ''The name of this room is 'Where the Dalai Lama Stayed,' '' the old monk said, glancing over his shoulder to make sure he was not overheard. Then he sat on a small platform covered with a matted rug.

title: Chinese Police Take Over Section Of Holiest Buddhist Site in Tibet
description: Chinese policemen occupied the third floor of Tibetan Buddhism's holiest place Sunday night after two pro-independence protests, one of which is reported to have left at least nine Tibetans dead.

title: Stand-In Jets Are Still Eager
description: The replacement Jets returned to practice today, wounded and bandaged but eager for another game.

title: Chess: Van der Wiel Gambit Sinks Old Line in Scotch Defense
description: John Van der Wiel has achieved what is surely the greatest success of his career by winning the O.H.R.A. Crown-Group International Tournament in Amsterdam.

title: Telling a Mollusk's Age
description: THE search for a precise way to measure the rate at which the chambered nautilus matures has long frustrated scientists because of the difficulty of studying live specimens of the peculiar shellfish. But with the help of fallout from nuclear bomb tests, biologists have at last tracked the life history of one of the creatures.

title: 9.83% USG Stake Held By Texans
description: The USG Corporation came under takeover attack yesterday for the second time in less than a year as Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, multimillionaire Texans, announced that they owned a 9.83 percent stake and might seek control of the nation's biggest gypsum producer.

title: Business and Health; Cholesterol Drugs' Growth
description: SEVERAL recent announcements about cholesterol-lowering drugs have been encouraging both to medical specialists and investors in the companies that reported the advances.

title: Critic's Notebook; Odd Entries, Drunks and Stars in Film Festival
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SEVEN will be remembered as a year in which the New York Film Festival, in the course of celebrating its 25th anniversary, went a little batty. It offered ''Jackie Chan's Police Story,'' a work of karate-based comedy hardly in keeping with the festival's usual fare. It presented a rock documentary and concert film (''Chuck Berry Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll'') that was oddly downbeat, even depressing, and hence something of a first. And one film found connections between architecture and stomachaches (''The Belly of an Architect''). There was another (''Anna'') so cliched at heart that it could never have passed for festival material if the characters hadn't spoken with Czechoslovak accents. And the most life-affirming moments could be found in a film about hopeless drunks (''Barfly''). All in all, an odd year.

title: Suriname Leader Wary of Elections
description: Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, who seized power in the small South American country of Suriname seven years ago, says if it were just up to him there would be no elections in Suriname for at least five years.

title: Bond Funds Take a Beating
description: Bond mutual funds produced a negative return to investors during the third quarter and the mutual fund industry in general did not shine, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks the performance of 372 fixed-income funds and 1,341 funds over all.

title: NICARAGUA INDIANS AGREE TO ACCORD
description: One of the leading commanders of Miskito Indian guerrillas fighting in Nicaragua has agreed to end his campaign against the Sandinista Government.

title: One Out, One In
description: While Jonathan Boyer was calling an end to his international cycling career when he finished 68th in the Nissan Classic tour of Ireland on Sunday in Dublin, Greg LeMond was using his 44th-place finish in the same race as a building block in a comeback from injuries and illness that ruined his 1987 season. LeMond, the Californian who last year won the Tour de France, had a broken wrist and collarbone, was shot in a hunting accident and underwent an appendectomy before returning to training at the end of August. ''I felt as competitive as at least half the field, and that gave me a lot of morale,'' said LeMond. ''This is good for next year because if shows that I should not have much of a problem getting back to real form.'' Boyer, from Pebble Beach, Calif., ended his career four days before his 32d birthday. In 1981 he became the first American to compete in the Tour de France.

title: Service America
description: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation tentatively reduced the price of its Service America Corporation subsidiary by $50 million, to $450 million, in weekend negotiations with the management group seeking to buy the unit, Allegheny said. Allegheny and the group, known as the Servam Corporation, reopened discussions on the price after receiving lower revenue estimates.

title: Cuts in Staff Reported At J. Walter Thompson
description: As the result of losing Burger King's huge $200 million advertising account, J. Walter Thompson has begun to trim its staff. Sources at the agency indicate that some 100 staff members were dropped, mostly from the New York office, which handled the largest part of the work for the Pillsbury Company subsidiary.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes, due on April 14, 1998, at a price of par through various securities dealers.

title: Betting on N.F.L. Drops
description: In the first week of replacement play, the legal bookmakers here took in only about 10 percent of the $30 million to $40 million they would normally take in on a National Football League Sunday, and most said they lost money because of the predictability of the results.

title: Violent Crime Drops in '86 but Decline Is Slowing
description: The rate of violent crime dropped 6.3 percent from 1985 to 1986, the Government says in a new report, but some experts say a five-year decline in crime trends appears to be bottoming out.

title: Britain to Clean Atom Plant, Site of Disastrous Fire in 1957
description: The Atomic Energy Authority today announced the start of a cleanup operation at the plutonium-producing reactor that was the scene in 1957 of one of the world's worst nuclear accidents.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Caucus Room Farewell?
description: When Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. dropped the gavel last week to conclude the hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, he may have brought down the curtain on the last performance in the Senate Caucus Room, the scene of some of the most dramatic moments in national political history.

title: Vehicle Sales Fell 4% in '87 Model Year
description: Despite the cut-rate financing offered in late summer by the Big Three auto makers, the 1987 model year ended with total passenger vehicle sales about 4 percent below the record totals of 1986.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sweden Gains Davis Cup Final: Stefan Edberg beat Emilio Sanchez, 6-4, 8-6, 6-4, yesterday to clinch the Davis Cup semifinal for Sweden against Spain. The victory puts Sweden into the Davis Cup final for the fifth straight time. Sweden will meet India, which upset Australia in the other semifinal, in December. After heavy rains had caused a postponement on Sunday, Edberg needed just over two hours yesterday to beat Sanchez. (AP) Yachting British Team Triumphs: A British team was declared the winner yesterday in the 1987 International 6-Meter World Cup championship on Long Island Sound. A spate of protests upset the order of finish after the day's final race. Bruce Owen, skipper and owner of the 6-Meter Scoundrel, moved from third to first place in the six-race series. The deciding protest yesterday involved the 6-Meter St. Francis IX of San Francisco. By losing in the protest room, the San Francisco team moved from second to fourth in the final standing. Notorious, a Swedish 6-Meter, was second, and J. Cool, also Swedish, finished third. Twenty-three yachts from eight nations competed in the regatta.

title: WRIGHT, IN SHIFT, DENOUNCES REAGAN OVER SANDINISTAS
description: The House Speaker, Jim Wright, who took the unusual step two months ago of agreeing to collaborate with President Reagan on a peace plan for Central America, today called the White House's latest Nicaragua strategy ''ridiculous'' and a creation of ''the extreme right wing.''

title: Canadian Stake In Multifoods
description: The Bregmans and the Belzbergs, two of Canada's wealthiest families, have jointly purchased a 7.4 percent stake in the International Multifoods Corporation and said they might seek control of the Minneapolis-based concern.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 6, 1987
description: General Assembly P.M.

title: New York Official Reports a Crisis in Psychiatric Care, With State Reneging on Aid
description: On the eve of a new Koch administration effort to remove homeless people with severe mental disturbances from the streets, a New York City health official said that overcrowding in municipal psychiatric emergency rooms had reached crisis levels and that the state was not doing enough to help out.

title: Cards Opening Without Clark
description: Whitey Herzog said today that the St. Louis Cardinals would open the playoff for the National League pennant Tuesday night without Jack Clark, their injured power hitter, and predicted that Clark would not start against the San Francisco Giants until the sixth game.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is becoming increasingly difficult to avoid the conclusion that someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process.'' House Speaker Jim Wright, discussing Central America. [ A1:1. ]

title: Dancers In Benefit For AIDS
description: TWO years in the making, ''Dancing for Life'' turned out to be one of the smoothest-run benefit performances in New York history - thanks to Jerome Robbins's supervision -and also one of the most emotionally stirring.

title: Corona Chairman Delighted by Ruling
description: A ruling in favor of International Corona Resources in an Ontario appeals court means the company is the owner of a mine that is expected to be one of North America's biggest gold producers.

title: Unesco Chief Favored to Win New Term
description: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose 13 years as director general of Unesco has split the organization, is favored to emerge as the winner when Unesco's executive board begins voting for a new director general Tuesday.

title: 2 Sides in El Salvador Hold 2d Day of Talks
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Marxist-led guerrillas fighting his Government were reportedly discussing ''substantive issues'' today during their second day of talks to end the eight-year-old civil war.

title: Florida Moves to Shut Loophole in Gun Law
description: The Florida House and Senate each voted unanimously today to close a loophole in a new gun law that allows people carry weapons openly in public The bills differed slightly, which means the issue will have to be addressed again Tuesday.

title: PITINO STARTS KNICK WORKOUTS
description: Rick Pitino made his debut as coach of the Knicks this morning by conducting the first practice for rookies and free agents.

title: Interstate Acts On Alexander's
description: Interstate Properties, a New Jersey-based developer headed by Steven Roth, said yesterday that it was seeking permission from Federal regulators to buy more than 50 percent of the stock outstanding in Alexander's Inc., a 14-store retail chain based in New York.

title: Southern Queens May Get Cable, at Last
description: A joint venture between two cable-television companies was announced yesterday, paving the way for about 180,000 homes in southern Queens to receive cable.

title: USAir-Piedmont
description: USAir Group Inc. and Piedmont Aviation Inc., which agreed to combine six months ago, asked the Transportation Department to approve their merger so they could compete with the industry ''mega-carriers.'' The two airline companies asked the department to reject an adverse, preliminary ruling by an administrative law judge, Ronnie Yoder, who said last month that the $1.6 billion merger should not be allowed because it was anti-competitive. The department is scheduled to make a final decision by Oct. 30. The two companies said that the Justice Department and the Transportation Department's Office of Public Counsel could find no reason to oppose the merger.

title: Japan and Its Leader: The Guard Will Change but the Course Won't Sway
description: Japan this week begins the formal process of choosing its next Prime Minister to lead it at a time of mounting overseas pressure to play a more vigorous global role.

title: Copyright Expires On Proust's Works
description: Marcel Proust, the author of ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' who died nearly 65 years ago, became public property today with the expiration of copyright protection of his works.

title: Iraqi Jets Strike 5 Tankers; 2 Iran Missiles Hit Baghdad
description: Iraqi planes struck five tankers, one of them the world's largest, in raids Monday, on Iranian oil targets at both ends of the Persian Gulf, and Iran fired two a missiles into Baghdad, one Monday and one early today, for the first time in nearly eight months.

title: More Oil Rigs in Action
description: Thirty-three more oil and gas drilling rigs were working in the United States last week, bringing the total to 1,127, Baker Hughes said today. The previous week, the oilfield toolmaker's rig count had dropped by 7, to 1,094. A year ago the total was 818.

title: More Imports by Pontiac
description: The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac Motor division said today that it planned to increase imports of small cars from South Korea as part of an effort to reach its goal of a 14 percent gain in vehicle sales to 825,000 in the 1988 model year. Pontiac's general manager, J. Michael Losh, said his division expected to sell 110,000 of its LeMans model imported from the Daewoo Motor Company of Seoul in the new model year, up from a previous forecast of an 85,000 annual selling rate. Pontiac aims for 8 percent of the American car market in the new model year, compared with 7 percent, or 720,000 total sales, in the 1987 model year that ended Sept. 30.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Importance of Redskins
description: Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, has had season tickets to the Washington Redskins' home games for 20 years, but he boycotted the game Sunday with the St. Louis Cardinals because of the players' strike. He worries about how the strike might affect the close relationship he sees between the football team and other activity in the capital.

title: Calor Rejects Bid
description: Calor Group P.L.C., a British heating gas distributor, rejected as inadequate a takeover offer of $:821 million, or $1.33 billion, made Monday by Burmah Oil P.L.C. and SHV Holdings N.V. Burmah, a British oil company, and SHV, a Dutch energy group that is Calor's biggest shareholder, had conditioned their offer on Calor recommending it to shareholders. The companies had offered to pay about $9.33 a share for Calor. James Alexander, a Burmah spokesman, said the proposal was final and Burmah and SHV had withdrawn their offer.

title: Rangers' Plett On the Move Again
description: It had been an unsettled couple of months for Willi Plett, days spent playing hockey with unfamiliar faces, nights spent in a strange motel.

title: New Jerseyans' Claim To Liberty I. Rejected
description: The Supreme Court today refused to strip the Statue of Liberty of its status as a New Yorker. The Court, without comment, turned away a move by a two New Jerseyans to claim jurisdiction over the landmark for their state.

title: Holtzman Subpoenas Records of Assembly's Political Unit
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, subpoenaed records yesterday from the State Assembly's political arm, the House Operations Committee.

title: Two Plead Guilty to Assault In New Hampshire Rape Case
description: Two University of New Hampshire students who had been charged with rape pleaded guilty to a lesser charge today and received three-month jail terms.

title: Allegations of Racism Are Deemed Incredible
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria Leader Backs Some Housing Integration
description: President P. W. Botha said today his Government planned to permit some multiracial neighborhoods, but is not ready to scrap the law that segregates public facilities.

title: Greenspan Backs New Bank Roles
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told Congress today that banks, victimized by new technology and ''frozen'' in a regulatory structure developed more than 50 years ago, were losing their competitive battle with other financial institutions and needed to obtain new powers to restore a balance.

title: 1988 Warning Of Inflation
description: A group of business economists today predicted further economic expansion next year but warned that there would be higher inflation, too.

title: In Hard Times, A Town Turns To Garage Sale
description: Only one thing was missing from what residents here call the world's largest garage sale, and it was not the kitchen sink. Joe Groff, a tree trimmer for the Niagara Mohawk Power Company, was selling that in front of his house on Main Street for $12.

title: Jays' Pacts Renewed
description: Jimy Williams, manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, and his entire coaching staff have been signed to contracts for the 1988 season, the team announced yesterday. His staff includes Cito Gaston, batting coach; Al Widmar, pitching coach; John McLaren, third base coach; Billy Smith, first base coach, and John Sullivan, bullpen instructor.

title: Dance: Feld Revives 'Meadowlark'
description: THE Feld Ballet brought a romp for blithe spirits to the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) on Sunday night when it revived Eliot Feld's ''Meadowlark.''

title: The Snow Melts but the Pain Lingers
description: A golden autumn sun melted much of the snow that Sunday's freak storm dumped across New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, but thousands of homes remained without power, hundreds of schools and businesses were closed and road and air travel was still limited.

title: Picket-Line Passion Wanes
description: In the eerie twilight under the bobbing Goodyear blimp, striking Giants were joined by striking Jets and about 500 members of other unions to picket before tonight's game between the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Quisenberry Unhappy
description: ''I still feel that I can pitch and feel the need to pitch,'' said Dan Quisenberry, the former king of the Kansas City Royals' bullpen, who asked the Royals to trade him Sunday after finishing the season with a 4-1 record, a 2.76 earned-run average, but only eight saves in 49 innings pitched. ''I can't let that hope die within myself and have to pursue that hope somewhere else. I don't see an opportunity here. I have to hope there's an opportunity somewhere else.'' One difficulty in constructing a trade for the 34-year-old right-handed reliever is a contract that calls for a salary of $1.1 million in each of the next three seasons and a real estate partnership with Avon Fogelman, the Royals' co-owner, through 2025. . . . Steve Bedrosian (5-3, 40 saves) of the Philadelphia Phillies and Dave Righetti (8-6, 31 saves) of the Yankees were named winners of the annual Rolaids Relief Man Awards.

title: Angry Look at Colleges
description: ''THE Closing of the American Mind'' by Allan Bloom has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 23 weeks. Apparently this angry book has been mis-titled: if so many are reading it, the American mind must be wide open.

title: Mudslides; The Warning Signs
description: THE sun may be shining outside a cavernous building here at Japan's National Center for Disaster Prevention, but inside, researchers move about, umbrellas in hand, watching how soils respond to rains ranging from prolonged drizzle to torrential downpour. A platform tilts like the bed of a gigantic dump truck, until the soil within it slumps and slides.

title: TV Reviews; 'Vacation Nicaragua,' Tourism and Politics
description: COME now to a white-sand beach, modern hotel and soft tropic murmurs. Come to Nicaragua. ''Vacation Nicaragua'' says United States tourists will have a swell time; they can sit in the sun and find political redemption, too. ''Vacation Nicaragua,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is gorgeously done propaganda.

title: Powerful Machines Readied for Channel Tunnel
description: Hundreds of French and British engineers are gearing up for a brutally hot, humid and deafening grind that promises to fulfill a centuries-old dream - a tunnel beneath the English Channel.

title: Anderson's Tigers Living Up to Billing
description: In spring training this year, Manager Sparky Anderson said the 1987 Tigers were better than his 1984 team that won the World Series. He said this was the best of the nine Tigers' teams he had managed, and it would win the American League East.

title: China Says It Downed A Vietnamese Fighter
description: China said today that its Air Force shot down a Vietnamese jet fighter this afternoon after it twice intruded into Chinese air space.

title: Cairo Journal; They Dance for Mubarak, and a Cow Gives Its All
description: Portraits of President Hosni Mubarak hung from iron fence posts and wires strung across streets and even covered the dusty trees, but the polling station at the Ali Abdul Latif primary school for girls was a quiet place at 11 o'clock this morning.

title: Bailing Out Israel
description: The Israeli-American discussions on the joint security assistance program being held this week are perhaps the most significant ever between both countries. They represent a critical opportunity for America to minimize the hardship and dislocation that might result from Israel's cancellation of its Lavi jet fighter aircraft program.

title: Twins' Recovery Difficult
description: Twins born joined at the back of their heads could remain hospitalized for up to six months as doctors deal with post-operative care that is as complicated as the surgery that separated them, doctors said.

title: At Harvard, 'Beetlemania,' as in Small, Black Insects
description: Ladies and gentlemen, meet the beetles.

title: The Pendulum Slows
description: The French campaign for next spring's presidential election may well turn out to confirm a watershed in the history of republican France two centuries after the revolution.

title: New Olympic Team
description: The United States Virgin Islands, where the average temperature is in the upper 80's and the notion of snow is remote, will field a Winter Olympic team for the first time, a team spokesman, Bill Beer, announced yesterday. The nine-member squad that will travel to Calgary for the 1988 Winter Games will consist of two bobsled teams, two skiers and two lugers. ''Training is very tough without snow,'' Beer said. ''Our bobsledders needed to get bobsled drivers' licenses at a school in Innsbruck in order to qualify.'' Most team members aren't full-time athletes. The team includesa building contractor, a hotelier, a university professor, a tour operator and a real-estate developer.

title: Key to Joining Fire Dept.
description: The firefighters' physical test left standing yesterday by the Supreme Court is the key factor in deciding who joins the department.

title: Advertising; An Agency That Sells Its Talents
description: THE agency business is amazing at times for its ease of entry. All it seems to take is creative people with the ability to sell themselves to advertisers.

title: REVITALIZED TRADITION MEETS MATURITY
description: Catchers (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 5 Tony Pena (.214, 5, 44) Acquired last spring from Pittsburgh at steep cost in talent, giving Cardinals the front-line catcher they needed, but then suffered broken bone in thumb on April 10. Hit poorly and struggled to regain stature as prime defensive catcher. Began wearing eyeglasses last week. 25 Steve Lake (.251, 2, 19) Professional for 13 seasons, came to Cardinals after leaving Chicago Cubs' farm system last year. Strong defensively, made one error in 56 games behind plate and threw out 38 percent of baserunners.
