Lightly used, batted only 176 times. 19 Tom Pagnozzi (.188, 2, 9) Rookie from Arkansas University who suffered setback at AAA level last year when fractured wrist limited his season at Louisville to 30 games. Returned this season as reserve. Infielders(Position, average, home runs, r.b.i.) 22 Jack Clark (First base, 286, 35, 106) Prime power hitter on team, but suffered serious injury for third season in row when he sprained right ankle on Sept. 9 en route to big numbers. Pinch-hit twice this weekend, but remains question mark for playoff. 28 Tommy Herr (Second base, .263, 2, 83) One of five switch-hitters in lineup, now closing seventh season as resident at second base. Has not made full comeback from decline of last year, when he lost 50 points on batting average and drove in 49 fewer runs. 9 Terry Pendleton (Third base, .286, 12, 96) Outstanding glove man at third and helps anchor exceptional infield defense. Also switch-hits with effect. He has surpassed his career highs this year with 167 hits and in home runs and runs batted in, the most by a Cardinal third baseman since Joe Torre in l971. 1 Ozzie Smith (Shortstop, .303, 0, 75) To many, he is even more valuable than Clark. Switch-hitter, still the acrobatic shortstop at the top of his profession, and he keeps rolling: 182 hits (no home runs, but 40 doubles), 75 r.b.i. (the most in his 10-year career) and only 10 errors. 23 Dan Driessen (First base, .233, 1, 11) Veteran left-handed hitter playing for fifth team. Signed to minor-league contract in June, brought up on Aug. 31 and became indispensable when Clark hurt ankle 10 days later. 11 Jose Oquendo (Shortstop, .286, 1, 24) One-time rookie shortstop for Mets who has found home and many roles on Cardinals, including one pitching appearance. Has played eight positions this season, all but catcher. Another switch-hitter, and went 10 for 25 as pinch-hitter. 12 Tom Lawless (Utility, .080, 0, 0) Political-science graduate of Penn State who plays second, third and outfield, and who learned how to catch in spring training. Light right-handed bat, but makes it on versatility. Outfielders(Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 29 Vince Coleman (.289, 3, 43) First player in history to steal 100 bases in his first three seasons, and still the sprinting leadoff man who triggers the offense. He has stolen second and third in the same inning 13 times this season. Leads club with 44 infield hits. 51 Willie McGee (.285, 11, 105) Switch-hitter de luxe who knocked in only 48 runs last year and dropped 97 points in batting average (after leading league the year before). But he has rebounded big, knocked in 100 runs for first time and got 59 extra-base hits. Jammed left thumb against wall on Wednesday. 27 Curt Ford (.285, 3, 26) Left-handed hitter and sprinter from Mississippi who made Cardinals last season and returned this season as frequent right fielder. He will start against right-handers and will be one more threat to steal bases in racing lineup. 21 Lance Johnson (.220, 0, 7) Recalled on Aug. 21 from Louisville, where he won distinction as most valuable player and rookie of year in American Association after hitting .333 and stealing 41 bases in 116 games. 33 John Morris (.261, 3, 23) Left-handed hitter and right fielder from Freeport, L.I., and Seton Hall. Went 10 for 30 as pinch-hitter this season (18 for 55 in career), and knocked in eight runs in pinch role. 15Jim Lindeman (.208, 8, 28) Right-handed hitter from Bradley University who made Cardinals in spring training after hitting 20 home runs at Louisville. Twice disabled this season with back spasms. Starting Pitchers(Record, e.r.a.) 30 John Tudor (10-2, 3.84) Left-handed ace of the staff who won 34 games the last two years. His season took hard turn in April when he suffered broken bone beneath right kneecap in strange accident: He was sitting in dugout when Barry Lyons of Mets slid into him chasing foul pop. But he rejoined staff for final two months. 34 Danny Cox (11-9, 3.88) Right-hander who broke bone in his right foot in early July and joined Tudor on disabled list, giving Cardinals their worst weeks. Since returning, he pitched poorly until Thursday night, when he beat Montreal to clinch division title. 53 Greg Mathews (11-11, 3.73) Left-hander who was called up from Louisville a year ago last June, and won 11 games in final four months. Returned this year and won 11 more. Suffered flat spell as Cardinals squandered big lead in August and September. 41 Joe Magrane (9-7, 3.54) Another big left-hander, a rookie from Arizona University who is considered live-wire personality and poster boy. In spring training, he looked like sure bet to make staff, and he eventually did, but with detours. 31 Bob Forsch (11-7, 4.32) Dean of the staff at 37, he has spent entire 14-year career in majors with the Cardinals. During absence of Tudor and Cox, he helped keep team alive, even though he was pitching with groin-muscle strain. For playoffs, he will a long reliever. Relief Pitchers(Record, e.r.a., saves) 38 Todd Worrell (8-6, 2.66, 33) Continues to be the stopper, the man who pitches to protect the late lead. This is only his second full season, but he already ranks second in Cardinal history in games saved. In last 38 save situations, he has 30. 46 Ken Dayley (9-5, 2.66, 4) The left-handed stopper who made strong comeback after being disabled in July last year by sore elbow. Missed rest of season and underwent surgery in October to repair ligaments and transfer nerves. But he has won nine games in comeback, including five in July. Strikes out more than one an inning. 49 Rick Horton (8-3, 3.82, 7) Left-handed swing man who can start or relieve, and did both: 60 times as starter, six in relief. Won 10 of his last 13 decisions in two seasons. He will be one bridge to Worrell and Dayley.

title: Tax-Free State Bonds Will Benefit Con Edison
description: The New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation offered $49.1 million of tax-exempt bonds yesterday on behalf of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Issues Dip in Price
description: Prices of short- and long-term debt securities fell modestly yesterday as market participants continued to expect that a strong economy and a more restrictive Federal Reserve policy would lead to higher interest rates.

title: Reuschel Getting Another Chance
description: The last time Rick Reuschel passed this way, in places with red, white and blue bunting hung out on October days and nights, the experience was not much fun. Three years ago this month he was a Chicago Cub who could do nothing more than watch. Now he can help the San Francisco Giants reach the World Series for the first time in 25 years.

title: NATIONAL PROGRAMS ARE GETTING HELP
description: Successful college soccer coaches have finally come to realize that their players may have missions that extend beyond the collegiate horizon -and the realization has benefited the country's national programs.

title: Washington Talk: The Study of Intelligence; Only Spies Can Find These Sources
description: It takes some snooping to find the favorite bookstore of Washington's intelligence professionals. The store, the National Intelligence Book Center, doesn't advertise, and its collection of almost 700 titles is tucked away in a small, windowless room on the 10th floor of a downtown office building. It is listed in the phone book, but there is no sign of it on the street.

title: Change at Negro Ensemble
description: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced yesterday. Mr. Denmark, who formerly was managing director, takes over day-to-day artistic leadership from Douglas Turner Ward, the company's co-founder and artistic director.

title: Washington Talk: Capitol Hill; War Powers? What War Powers?
description: What has happened to the War Powers Act?

title: House Backs Air Travel Protections
description: The House of Representatives today approved a package of consumer-protection measures for airline passengers.

title: Boy's Uncle Now Charged in Deaths of 7 in Family
description: The sole survivor of a shooting that killed seven relatives was charged today with murder in the slayings. A 14-year-old family member who was among the victims had at first been blamed for the deaths.

title: Film Festival; 'Joan' and 'Human Voice,' From Roberto Rossellini
description: THE 10th anniversary of the death of Roberto Rossellini, the master innovator of the Italian cinema, will be marked by the New York Film Festival tonight at 9:15 with the retrospective showing of two films virtually unknown in this country.

title: Witness Recalls Zaccaro's Role In Cable Deal
description: The chairman of a cable television company that John A. Zaccaro is accused of trying to extort testified yesterday that he never heard or saw Mr. Zaccaro do anything wrong.

title: U.S. Defines Cholesterol Hazards And Offers Treatment Guidelines
description: The Federal Government and more than 20 health organizations today issued the nation's first detailed guidelines for identifying and treating people whose blood cholesterol levels are high enough to require medical treatment.

title: Giants Must Find A Way to Trip Up Cards' Speedsters
description: The St. Louis Cardinals seem to be people in perpetual motion. If they were commuters, they'd be running for buses; if they were travelers, they'd be running through airports. They always seem to be running. Often, they run home after having run from first base to second and from second base to third.

title: Games Deserved to Be Shown
description: Looking back, the debate over the last two weeks about whether the networks should televise the first National Football League replacement games now seems silly. Whatever their reasons - financial or legal - NBC and CBS were right to show Sunday's games.

title: Hitler's Nonelection
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; In an Elevator
description: Overheard in a crowded downtown elevator. Young Man: ''Who are we going to get for a President this time around anyway?'' Female Companion: ''I don't think any of the names who have appeared in the last year are capable of running the Government.'' In the back of the elevator, Pete du Pont, one of the Republican competitors, decided this was not the time or place to add another debate to his political schedule.

title: Reactors In Space: U.S. Project Advances
description: THE Federal Government is moving ahead with plans to put nuclear reactors and nuclear rocket engines in space for both civilian and military uses. Orbiting reactors, officials believe, will be essential for powering antimissile weapons and future scientific missions, including deep-space probes, space stations and manned outposts on Mars and the moon.

title: Canada Split on Accord; Nationalism an Issue
description: Canada was a sharply divided nation today as details of the free-trade agreement with the United States became known, with business generally supporting the pact and trade unions and nationalist groups adamantly against it.

title: Judge Delays Sentence For Former U.S. Aide
description: A Federal judge has postponed the one-year sentence imposed on C. McClain Haddow, a former Department of Health and Human Services official convicted of conflict-of-interest charges.

title: Her Quarry: Cultural Exotica
description: For 17 years, Beate Gordon has been a sort of cultural detective. She travels to Asia each summer, ferreting out virtuoso performers of traditional arts and arranging for them to tour the United States.

title: Spreadsheet Milestone
description: IN the world of spreadsheets, Microsoft Excel is the standard for the Apple Macintosh and Lotus 1-2-3 is the standard for everyone else. Until today the division was neat and clean. Lotus 1-2-3 did not run on the Mac and Excel did not run on the PC.

title: 5 in G.O.P. Delay Action On Commerce Nominee
description: Five Republican Senators opposed to confirmation of C. William Verity Jr. as Commerce Secretary have placed a ''hold'' on his nomination, thereby delaying a Senate vote on the matter and possibly inviting a filibuster if Senate leaders try to force a vote.

title: Chiropracters Praise Ruling
description: Chiropractors say they the image of their profession will improve as a result of a Federal court injunction barring the American Medical Association from ''restricting, regulating or impeding'' its members from associating with chiropractic practitioners.

title: How New York Can Aid the Arts
description: LEAD: Without the arts, New York would be just another big, noisy town. What makes the city unique is not money and wealth but the old, special symbiosis between the arts and the economy. Unless public officials step in, New York's flourishing economy may sweep away its old partner, the arts, in a plague of affluence.

title: High Court Refuses to Review Salinger Book Ruling
description: The Supreme Court yesterday let stand a lower-court ruling blocking publication of an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1987
description: Companies

title: 50 Amtrak Employees Strike But Return at Order of Judge
description: A 10-hour strike by 50 Amtrak maintenance employees disrupted rail service in parts of New York and New England today before a Federal judge ordered them back to work.

title: A Telemarketing Plan With a European Twist
description: There is nothing novel about a retailer running a toll-free number in a print ad in hopes of attracting the less adventuresome or combative shopper. It's called telemarketing.

title: Russian Agricultural Official Arriving for U.S. Farm Tour
description: Viktor P. Nikonov, a rising star in the ruling Soviet Politburo and the man in charge of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive to rejuvenate Soviet agriculture, will arrive in the United States on Tuesday for a week of farm tours and superpower diplomacy.

title: Lawyer Reveals Events In Howard Beach Case
description: A defendant in the Howard Beach murder case who is cooperating with prosecutors admitted to the grand jury that he had taken a baseball bat from another defendant to have a weapon with which to hit the three black men, a defense lawyer said yesterday.

title: S.I. Republicans, After Three-Hour Delay, Elect New County Leader
description: Staten Island Republicans elected Olga Igneri as their county leader last night, six days after their first attempt turned into a shouting, shoving melee.

title: URGE WITHDRAWAL
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, said today that he would vote against confirming Judge Robert H. Bork and called on President Reagan to withdraw the Supreme Court nomination, calling it ''doomed.''

title: Wife of Scotto Is Said to Have No-Show Post
description: The wife of Anthony M. Scotto, the former president of the Brooklyn Longshoreman's Local 1814, has been receiving as much as $30,000 a year for a no-show job with the local's Political Action Fund, according to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Young Science of Cancer Genes Begins to Yield Practical Applications
description: THE study of defective genes that help trigger cancers, one of the most rapidly advancing fields of modern biological science, is now beginning to yield its first practical applications, aiding in the selection of treatments for some cancers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Laugh Off

title: Denial Made On 'Parking'
description: Charles E. Hurwitz, chairman of Maxxam Group Inc., denied accusations today that he made an illegal arrangement with Jefferies & Company to conceal his ownership of stock in the Pacific Lumber Company in the days before he began a successful hostile takeover of the company in 1985.

title: Our Towns; The Education Of Des Paganelli: Who Will Do It?
description: Who will educate Desarae Paganelli?

title: TV Reviews; 'Intimate Contact,' Devastation of AIDS
description: TELEVISION drama is curiously reluctant to tackle, frankly and sympathetically, the devastating effects of AIDS on homosexuals. ''An Early Frost,'' broadcast nearly two years ago, was a notable exception. Otherwise, television dramas about AIDS have preferred to focus on nonhomosexual victims of the disease. Hemophiliac youngsters, for instance, contaminated by blood transfusions, are far easier subjects.

title: Bowery Savings Bank Is Sold for $200 Million
description: The Bowery Savings Bank, one of New York's oldest savings banks, was sold yesterday, less than two years after a group of investors helped rescue it from the brink of collapse, with Federal backing.

title: In a Quake Aftershock, Calls For Mental Health Aid Triple
description: Since the severe earthquake in Southern California last Thursday, calls for help to the public mental health agency's crisis intervention unit here have increased dramatically.

title: POWER-PACKED LINEUPS GO TO BATTLE
description: Catchers (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 8 Mike Heath (.281, 8, 33) Will start playoff opener against Twins' left-hander, Frank Viola, thereby putting Matt Nokes on bench for at least one game. Power numbers don't rival Nokes's, but he's a veteran who handles pitchers well and has strong arm. 33 Matt Nokes (.289, 32, 87) If not for Mark McGwire and Kevin Seitzer, Nokes might be league's best-hitting rookie. Greatest liability is on defense, however, where he was partly responsible for Jack Morris's record 24 wild pitches. Infielders(Position, average, home runs, r.b.i.) 41 Darrell Evans (First base, .257, 34, 99) Took pay cut to return to Tigers this season, but where would they be without him? First 40-year-old player to hit at least 30 homers in one season. Manager Sparky Anderson says Evans's clubhouse leadership matches Don Baylor's. 1 Lou Whitaker (Second base, .265, 16, 59) Batting average, homers and r.b.i. took sharp drop from last season while strikeouts rose to career-high 108. Has been formidable double-play combination with Alan Trammell since 1978. 3 Alan Trammell (Shortstop, .343, 28, 105) Moved into cleanup spot after departure of Lance Parrish last winter and made smooth transition. Average, home runs, r.b.i. were all career-best numbers. Might have won most valuable player award from Toronto's George Bell in final weeks of regular season. 17 Jim Morrison (Third base, .205, 4, 19) Numbers were low after trade from Pittsburgh, but he is capable of giving Tigers good defense at third. Hit 23 home runs in 1986 for Pirates, but only 4 for Tigers in 1987. 16 Tom Brookens (.241, 13, 59) May share duties at third with Morrison, although both are right-handed hitters. Made 19 errors, same as Trammell at short. 14 Dave Bergman (First base, .273, 6, 22) Capable glove, but may not see much action in playoff because of Evans. Had 4 hits, 3 r.b.i. as pinch hitter. Outfielders(Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 23 Kirk Gibson (.277, 24, 79) Not as threatening as others in Tiger lineup. Led team with 25 stolen bases and drew 100 walks, but his defense is sometimes costly. Erratic arm forced moved from right field to left this season, yet still made 7 errors. 34 Chet Lemon (.277, 20, 75) Covers deep center-field area (440 feet straightaway) in Tiger Stadium well. Produced superb numbers offensively. Had 53 extra-base hits, more than any Tiger but Trammell, Whitaker and Evans. 31 Larry Herndon (.324, 9, 47) Delivered deciding home run Sunday against Toronto but will likely share duties in right field with Pat Sheridan. Home runs have fallen off last few years, but average was a career high. Led team pinch-hitters with eight hits and five r.b.i. 15 Pat Sheridan (.259, 6, 49) Fighting late-season slump but will play against right-handers because of exceptional defense and left-handed bat. Had 18 steals. Designated Hitters (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 7 Bill Madlock (.279, 14, 50) Next to Doyle Alexander, was best acquistion this season by General Manager Bill Lajoie. Hit 14 homers in 326 times at bat and probably will start against all pitching. Four-time batting champ in National League has found new life in American League at age 36. 30 John Grubb (.202, 2, 13) Limited to just 114 times at bat, fewest in 10 seasons. Unless he is used as pinch-hitter, will spend series watching from bench. Starting Pitchers(Record, e.r.a.) 19 Doyle Alexander (9-0, 1.53) Went 9-0 after acquired in August; Tigers were 11-0 in his starts. Beat Twins twice without loss during season, allowing 4 runs in 18 innings. If he wins opener, Detroit could take series in five games. 47 Jack Morris (18-11, 3.38) Twins rejected Morris, a native of nearby St. Paul, in winter. Beat Minnesota twice this season and is 11-0 career in Metrodome. Ranked among league leaders this season in victories, e.r.a., innings (266), strikeouts (208) and complete games (13). 35 Walt Terrell (17-10, 4.05) Former Met has 47 victories in three seasons at Detroit, where Tiger Stadium is home sweet home. Was 13-2 in own park this season, 32-7 over three seasons. 26 Frank Tanana (15-10, 3.91) Left-hander might have won chance to start fourth game of playoff with six-hit shutout Sunday against Toronto. Lost spot in rotation late in season, giving up 28 runs in 27 innings but finished with three strong outings. Relief Pitchers(Record, e.r.a., saves) 39 Mike Henneman (11-3, 2.98, 7) Rookie right-hander who faces substantial task in playoff. Worked 96 innings in 55 games during season and totaled 11 victories, 7 saves. Has been effective closer, taking job away from fading Willie Hernandez. 21 Willie Hernandez (3-4, 3.67, 8) Had 87 saves in previous 3 seasons, just 8 this year. Taken to hospital over weekend with abdominal pains but probably won't be used in crucial situations anyway during series. 25 Eric King (6-9, 4.89, 9) Right-hander is No. 2 man in bullpen behind Henneman. Made 51 relief appearances and struck out 89 in 116 innings. Also walked 60. 44 Jeff Robinson (9-6, 5.37, 0) Made 21 starts, but his action may be limited to middle-innings relief against Twins. 40 Mark Thurmond (0-1, 4.23, 5) Occasionally wild left-hander will be used to face one or two left-handed batters. Had 5 saves.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Democrats Dancing
description: Any dancing at the 10th annual Democratic Gala tomorrow night will have to be in the aisles. The demand for tickets to the $1,500-a-plate affair has been so heavy that the space that had been reserved for the dance floor in the International Ballroom of the Washington Hilton hotel has been sold to accommodate more tables.

title: Sikh Tangle: A Policeman In the Middle
description: In much of India, he has become almost a cult figure, a popular symbol among the many who want terrorism crushed by force. But in the northern state of Punjab, where such terrorism is a daily fact of life, he is No. 1 on the so-called ''hit list'' of Sikh extremists.

title: Political Memo; Bush and Dole Bring Order to G.O.P
description: While the Democratic Presidential campaign has dissolved into grim uncertainty, the Republican contest, like the party itself, is considerably more orderly.

title: FIRST TWO GAMES CRUCIAL IF TWINS ARE TO GET EDGE
description: If the Twins do not win the first two games of the American League championship series in Minnesota, they most likely will be in serious trouble. The Tigers could then conceivably wrap up the playoff in Detroit.

title: Justices Uphold F.D.I.C. On Bank Underwriting
description: In a further breach of the half-century barrier separating the banking and securities industries, the Supreme Court today allowed state-chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System to underwrite corporate securities.

title: Bossy to Miss Entire Season
description: Mike Bossy, with his hands in his pockets and his delivery unemotional, announced today that he has resigned himself to a season of physical therapy in place of an 11th year of professional hockey. But even though the back ailment he has suffered with since last spring appeared to make his retirement a foregone conclusion, Bossy said emphatically that he was not ready to give up playing.

title: Court Refuses Suit by Women Over Fire Test
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear arguments on the legality of a test that has kept women from being hired as New York City firefighters since 1984.

title: Sotheby's Stake Under the Gavel
description: In the last five years, the booming art market has paid off for many artists, collectors and dealers. Now it is about to reward the well-known investors who bet on the potential of the staid Sotheby's auction house.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
Digital Audio Tape Due in Germany
description: The Sony Corporation's revolutionary digital audio tape players will be available for the first time outside Japan starting Oct. 15, a spokeswoman for the Japanese electronics giant said.The players will be sold in West Germany, selected by Sony for the first sales outside Japan of digital audio tape, which boasts almost-perfect sound reproduction.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The latest third quarter results include the April acquisition of the consumer packaging division of Boise Cascade Corp.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest periods include results of Converse Inc. acquired Sept. 8, 1986 and Highland House acquired Oct. 16, 1986. The year-ago periods are restated to include the operations of the Lane Company, acquired April 14, 1987. This transaction was accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Lawyer Says Zaccaro Told of 'Corrupt' Process
description: A former lawyer for a cable company tes-tified yesterday that John A. Zaccaro told him in October 1981 that a cable television franchise could be obtained in Queens for a substantial amount of money.

title: A Grand Tasting Of Rare Bordeaux
description: THE scene was in the wine-tasting room of Lloyd Flatt, one of the country's best-known wine collectors and certainly one of the most flamboyant. The occasion was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for 15 wine buffs to taste the wines of Chateau Ausone, a prominent chateau in St.-Emilion, in the Bordeaux region of France.

title: '88 Prices Set By Volkswagen
description: Volkswagen announced prices today for some of its 1988 models, including a cut for its Jetta two-door model that brings its price to $8,990.

title: Conakry Journal; Francs and Fromage: French Are Friends Again
description: Camembert cheese, Bordeaux wine and Parisian newspapers fill the shelves of Guinea's first supermarket. Across town, the French flag flutters in front of a newly opened trade office.

title: Mob Figure Is Found Shot to Death in Brooklyn
description: A reputed associate of the Bonanno organized-crime family was found shot to death early yesterday morning on a Brooklyn street in the latest of a series of gangland-style slayings, the police said.

title: No Tax Shift Seen by Baker
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that President Reagan remains firmly opposed to any new taxes and that any legislation to increase taxes could lead the nation into a recession.

title: Two Agencies in Deals For Graphic Designers
description: Graphic design companies are desirable acquisitions, as last week's news proves. Britain's WCRS Group, which owns Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, and Chiat/Day of New York and Los Angeles are both in the process of buying.

title: George D. Aranow, Attorney And a L.I. Community Leader
description: George D. Aranow, former chief counsel of the American Automobile Owners' Association of New York and a Long Island community leader through much of the post-World War II period, died Sunday at West Park Hospital in Philadelphia after a brief illness. He was 93 and lived in a retirement home in Philadelphia.

title: Lebanese Hijacking Suspect Is Arraigned on New Charges
description: A Lebanese suspect arrested in international waters was arraigned today on four additional charges in the hijacking of a Jordanian airliner in 1985.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We shall win one way or another, either by confirming Robert Bork or making a political issue of this process in 1988 and 1990 and beyond.'' - Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire. [ B10:1. ]

title: Canadian Said to Have Had Key Role in Spread of AIDS
description: A forthcoming book identifies an airline steward from Montreal as playing a key role in the early spread of AIDS in North America.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July and retirement of a dilutive warrant.

title: KEY RATES
Football Ratings Drop
description: The curiosity over the replacement teams that drew many television viewers to Sunday's National Football League games may have been largely satisfied.

title: INTERSPEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $353,000 for the quarter and $876,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $104,000 and $80,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Japan Will Aid Gulf Nations but Not Send Patrols
description: Japan, abandoning any thought of sending its own patrol ships to the Persian Gulf, has decided to increase its aid to gulf governments and to pay more for the maintenance of United States bases here, officials said today.

title: Boxing Notebook; Marsh Finds Profitable Life Out of Ring
description: Last month, Terry Marsh gave up his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title after he was found to be suffering from epilepsy.

title: Fairchild Chief Resigns Post
description: Donald W. Brooks, who led an unsuccessful attempt to take over the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, has resigned as the company's president and chief executive. The acquisition of Fairchild, a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., by the National Semiconductor Corporation is expected to be completed later this week.

title: Give Thanks for Indian Summer
description: Autumn is that lovely season between summer and winter, the one that starts in the latter part of September and ends three months later. It's also known as fall, and last weekend it looked as if it had passed us by.

title: Dining and Shopping in Ironbound Area
description: THE Ironbound section of Newark is rich in Portuguese foods, available in the neighborhood's many shops and restaurants. Unless otherwise noted, all are open seven days a week. Most restaurants take credit cards; reservations are usually needed for dinner. Following is a selection of some of the best. Restaurants 14.Casa Vasca, 141 Elm Street, at Prospect Street; 201-465-1350.

title: BEIJING IS BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION ON UNREST IN TIBET
description: The Reagan Administration voiced support today for China's position in the unrest in Tibet, while the Senate voted without dissent to condemn China for its recent crackdown there.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: I SHAMELESSLY love garlic, particularly when thoroughly cooked to a nutty sweetness.

title: Concert: Rotterdam Orchestra
description: IT is not by mistake that Tchaikovsky's First Piano Concerto vastly overshadows the composer's second essay in the form. The latter work is designed as a crowd pleaser, too, and contains enough flashy writing to prompt the desired ovation, as it did Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall in a version by the Rotterdam Philharmonic, with Bella Davidovich as soloist.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter figures includes results of Burton Corblin, the company's French subsidiary, on a consolidated basis. The company said in the year-ago quarter, 25 percent of the results of Burton Corblin were included as equity income.

title: Insider Study in Tokyo
description: The Finance Ministry has decided to set up a special group to study ways to revamp laws governing insider trading of stocks, a ministry official said today. The ministry hopes to form the group, composed of academics and lawyers, by the end of this month, he said. The Osaka Stock Exchange said today that some dealings in the stock of the Tateho Chemical Industries Company before the company announced huge losses were ''extremely problematic,'' but that insider trading could not be proved.

title: Head of China Fund Agency Honored by New York Group
description: For ''furthering the modernization and progress of China,'' the chairman of that country's state-owned investment corporation has been given an award by the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a New York-based coalition of religious leaders and business people.

title: No Short Cuts to Catholic-Jewish Reconciliation; Time-Honored Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Chief in Jersey Details AIDS Testing
description: The New Jersey State Health Commissioner, in outlining a program to combat the rise of AIDS in New Jersey, said today that some doctors and hospitals have been testing patients for the virus without consent.

title: Twins Seemingly Two Different Teams
description: The temperature seemed to drop as the day grew longer, but inside the climate-controlled Metrodome it felt like a balmy autumn day. There were no chilling gusts, no threatening clouds, no swirling dust storms round second base. The massive roof above provided protection from the elements. The Minnesota Twins felt safe.

title: Threat of a Hostile Irving Bid
description: The Bank of New York said yesterday that, if necessary, it would proceed with a hostile bid for the Irving Bank Corporation. It was the first time the Bank of New York had formally said that it would go forward with its previously announced bid on an unfriendly basis.

title: CONSTANCE MAROSELLI
description: Constance Maroselli, who worked for the National Basketball Association for 36 years, died Saturday night of a heart attack while on a flight from New York to Phoenix, where she was to retire. Miss Maroselli was 63 years old. Miss Maroselli began working for the N.B.A. in 1951, when the league was in its fifth season. During her years with the league, she worked in various capacities for all four commissioners: Maurice Podoloff, Walter Kennedy, Larry O'Brien and David Stern. Before her retirement, she was assistant to Bob Criqui, the league's controller.

title: BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
China Borrowing
description: The Bank of China closed a $200 million syndicated term loan, representing the first time China has borrowed in the United States. The loan was provided by a syndicate made up of 28 United States and foreign banks and arranged by IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company of New York. Formal signing ceremonies between senior members of the Bank of China and representatives of the syndicate were held yesterday.

title: PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: After undergoing five hours of spinal surgery in Inglewood, Calif., Donnie Moore of the California Angels was pronounced in good condition at Centinela Hospital. Moore, a 33-year-old relief pitcher who was on the disabled list twice this season, had a small bone spur removed. . . . The Boston Red Sox announced that Jim Rice, who missed the last 26 games of the season, and John Marzano, rookie catcher, underwent knee surgery. . . . In another surgical procedure, Tim Wallach, who hit .298 with 26 home runs and 123 runs batted in for the Montreal Expos, had a bone chip removed from his left foot. . . . William C. Battle of Ivy, Va., has been nominated to become the 50th president of the United States Golf Association. . . . Three top British runners - Hugh Jones, John Graham and Alister Hutton - have entered the Nov. 1 New York City Marathon. No British runner has won the 26-mile, 385-yard event in the race's 17-year history. . . . The Islanders made their final roster cut yesterday when they reassigned a defenseman, Jeff Finley, to Springfield of the American Hockey League. The 25 remaining players will make the trip to Los Angeles today for the team's season opener tomorrow night against the Kings. . . . The Devils assigned Steve Richmond, a defenseman, and Dan Dorion, a forward, to Utica of the American Hockey League, and sent Neil Brady, a center, back for another year of junior hockey. Richmond, 27, appeared in 44 games with the Devils last season, scoring one goal and seven assists.

title: Ambulances in New York Still Take Too Long
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Bid for Sidney Green
description: Al Bianchi made his first move as the Knicks' new general manager last night by tendering an offer sheet to Sidney Green, the 6-foot-9-inch, 220-pound Detroit Piston power forward. By making the offer to the Brooklyn-born Green, the Knicks, who are over the salary cap, could lose Bernard King, who is also a free agent.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 6
SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Pop Life
description: Dark Side of Pink Floyd Who's Pink Floyd? The answer, for the moment, is a band led by David Gilmour, the guitarist and singer for Pink Floyd since 1968, and including Nick Mason, playing drums and Richard Wright, on keyboards, both founding members. The British band finishes three nights at Madison Square Garden tonight and goes to the Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands Saturday through Monday nights.

title: Ford Left Most of His Fortune To a Private Trust, Will Shows
description: Henry Ford 2d left the bulk of his fortune, estimated at $250 million, to a private trust whose beneficiaries are unnamed, according to his will, filed here.

title: JUDGE BACKS E.P.A. ON BLOCKING MALL
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to override the Army Corps of Engineers and block a shopping mall from being built on a Massachusetts wetland.

title: MEDSTAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $135,000 for the quarter and $395,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $55,000 and $115,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Opera: 'Serva Padrona,' In Italy on Stage Festival
description: IT is an understatement to say that tradition lay behind the Teatro di San Carlo's performance of ''La Serva Padrona'' on Monday evening at the Mark Hellinger Theater. After all, the opera company, which presented Pergolesi's comedy as the first offering in an Italy on Stage festival, comes to us from Naples, where the intimate two-scene comic opera, technically known as an intermezzo, was first given 254 years ago.

title: Taper Forum Awarded Jujamcyn Theater Grant
description: A resident theater company in Los Angeles, the Mark Taper Forum, will receive the 1987 Jujamcyn Theaters Award. The award, an unrestricted grant of $50,000, was announced yesterday by Rocco Landesman, president, and James Binger, chairman of the Jujamcyn organization, which owns five Broadway theaters. The award will be presented on Nov. 23 to Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the company.

title: Testimony Begins in Insider Case
description: In opening arguments yesterday in the trial of David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in an insider trading ring, the prosecution and the defense painted contrasting pictures of a ''dishonest lawyer'' who stole millions of dollars from his clients and of a man who had been too trusting of a dishonest stockbroker.

title: POTAMKIN HITS A SNAG IN ITS SALE TO PENSKE
description: The owners of Potamkin Cadillac are encountering difficulty in selling their dealership in Manhattan to the Penske Corporation, a company that is probably best known for its auto racing operations. A major obstacle is a delay by the General Motors Corporation in giving its approval to the sale.

title: Celebrating, as It Were, Anniversary on Poverty
description: Occasionally over the years, a single book has pricked the conscience of Americans and influenced the course of the nation's history.

title: MET-COIL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $102,000 on the sale of certain assets of Ruesch Machinery Co. The company said the latest quarter loss includes a charge of $121,000 related to sales and marketing development costs for the company's joint venture in Japan.

title: Police Have Suspect in Witness's Killing
description: A teen-age friend of a youth charged in a shootout at a Queens livery company is a prime suspect in the murder of a witness who had testified about the incident before a grand jury, senior police officials said yesterday.

title: SMITH COMMUNICATIONS IS PLANNING A MAGAZINE
description: Smith Communications of Scarsdale, N.Y., which has since 1978 been supplying promotion support to marketing services companies, now plans to go into magazine publishing. Kerry E. Smith in November expects to bring out the first monthly issue of Promo, a trade publication for the sales promotion industry, on which he puts a value of $100 billion in sales annually.

title: Virgin Islands Airport Needs Federal Help
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Might Be Getting New Revival-Movie House
description: One month after closing the Regency Theater, a popular West Side revival-movie theater, the Cineplex Odeon Corporation is expected to announce today that another of its 18 Manhattan movie theaters, the New Carnegie, will be transformed into a revival house.

title: Preliminary Trade Pact With Mexico Is Shaped
description: The Reagan Administration, after concluding a sweeping trade pact with Canada, is about to sign an agreement with Mexico setting up machinery for settling trade disputes and opening negotiations to curb barriers to trade and investment.

title: A Mother's Nightmare: Girl Lost in Foster Care
description: For nearly five days recently, Sharon Cook tried frantically to find her 14-year-old daughter, who had mistakenly been caught up in New York City's vast foster-care system.

title: SEACOAST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank went public in March.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The Pentagon plans to test a missile with 12 warheads this year despite strong concerns within the Administration and Congress that such tests could complicate arms control talks with the Soviet Union and hamper military planning. Page A1 Divergent positions on Tibet's unrest were taken by the White House, which voiced support for China's position, and the Senate, which voted without dissent to condemn China for its recent crackdown in Tibet. A1 About 60 Tibetans demonstrated on the streets of Lhasa, chanting the name of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled religious leader. Armed Chinese security forces arrested the marchers, believed to be Buddhist monks in secular dress. A8 Oil pipelines being built by Iraq, Turkey and Saudi Arabia are well on their way to reducing the importance of the Persian Gulf as the primary route for moving Middle Eastern oil to the West and Japan. A1 More than 50 are feared drowned after a boat carrying illegal refugees from the Dominican Republic to Puerto Rico sank. Dominican officials said 23 people had been rescued from the boat, which went down in the Mona Channel. A1 News analysis: American power, both economic and political, is being reassessed by Western European politicians and strategists at a time of considerable uncertainty in the trans-Atlantic relationship. A15 A total ban on imports from Iran was approved by the House and the Senate. The vote on the largely symbolic ban gave members of Congress a chance to vent their anger at Iran's role in continuing clashes in the Persian Gulf. A14 A proposed cease-fire in El Salvador was announced by President Jose Napoleon Duarte in his Government's campaign against leftist rebels, but the guerrillas refused to follow suit, calling such a move tantamount to surrender. A3 News analysis: By choosing Carlos Salinas de Gortari to succeed him as Mexico's President, Miguel de la Madrid has sought to assure continuation of his administration's economic restructuring and political initiatives. A3 Conakry journal A4 Teachers strike sparks debate in Delhi A6 One author rankles two Chinas A7 Far-reaching economic changes stir in Bulgaria A10 Tea and mayhem in Zimbabwe A10 Fiji coup leader declares republic A12 U.S. Navy faces difficult mission in Gulf A14 Coast Guard units to patrol Gulf A14 NATIONAL A18-29, B7-10 A 9-to-5 vote against Judge Bork as a Supreme Court Justice by the Senate Judiciary Committee indicated further rejection by the full Senate if President Reagan continues to insist on a vote. Mr. Reagan said he would keep fighting. A1 News analysis: Judge Bork's loss in the Senate Judiciary Committee was the product of two forces. He was both an agent of his own undoing and a victim of outside pressures. B10 On Wall Street, stock prices plunged amid anxiety over rising interest rates and the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 91.55 points, or 3.47 percent, in its largest point decline ever to close at 2,548.63. A1 Airline delays declined significantly from last summer to this summer, Government figures indicate, despite predictions of tie-ups through the heavy summer travel season made earlier this year. A18 The uncle of a boy who died along with six of his relatives in Marshfield, Mo., has been charged with the murders. The police had originally believed that the boy was responsible for the killings. A1 A White House-cleared AIDS guide produced by the Department of Education urges all parents and teachers to stress ''appropriate moral and social conduct'' as the first line of defense against the disease. B7 Seattle journal A18 Officials begin crackdown on truck drivers' licenses A18 Operation PUSH clearing debts A20 TV ministers dispute need for tighter regulation A21 Bulk of Ford's estate goes to private trust A24 New hearing ordered in Alabama rights case A26 Democrats punish two states on primary rules B9 WASHINGTON TALK B8 Celebrating, as it were, an anniversary on poverty Yes, Union Station reopening as a train station REGIONAL B1-6 Mayor Koch is seeking to oust the Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, top city officials said, adding that the Mayor, armed with a report from an advisory board, had given Dr. Gross until Friday to resign or be dismissed. A1 John A. Zaccaro told a lawyer for a cable television company that a Queens franchise could be obtained for a substantial amount of money, the lawyer testified, adding that he did not think Mr. Zaccaro was requesting a payoff. B1 Anthony R. Ameruso was sentenced to 16 weekends in jail and five years' probation for lying under oath. Mr. Ameruso, a career civil servant, was New York City's Transportation Commissioner for eight years. B1 The proposed Television City project of Donald J. Trump would so overburden public transportation that a second subway entrance would be needed at 72d Street and Broadway, according to a draft environmental impact statement by the developer. B1 A murder case against an informer, Michael Raymond, who played an important role in the corruption scandals that rocked New York and Chicago last year, appears to have fallen apart with the recantation of the chief witness against him. B2 Harlem methadone clinic offers no-frills treatment B1 Police have suspect in witness's killing B3 One-year property tax moratorium proposed in Rockland B3 Girl mistakenly caught in New York's foster-care system B4 City Council panel rejects Koch nominee for tax post B5

title: LITTLE PORTUGAL: PAGE OF HISTORY IN NEWARK
description: VISITORS to the Ironbound section of Newark enter a time warp. Just three blocks from Pennsylvania Station here and a five-minute drive from Newark International Airport is an ethnic neighborhood of 40 or 50 years ago, where in the late afternoon, neighbors visit with neighbors, the women on their stoops, the men in the local bars.

title: WILL MERCER COOK
description: Will Mercer Cook, a former Ambassador to Niger and Senegal, died of pneumonia Sunday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 84 years old.

title: Brazil Asks for Aid for 58 Radioactivity Victims
description: Brazil has appealed to international specialists to help treat 58 people who were contaminated by radioactivity in the city of Goiania, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
House and Senate Vote for a Total Ban on Iran Imports
description: The House and the Senate, reacting to the continuing clashes in the Persian Gulf, today overwhelmingly approved a total ban on imports from Iran.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LEAD: WITNESSED by Bernard Sohmer early on a Friday evening: a United Parcel Service truck on East 65th Street. A package from the truck had broken open and foam packing pellets were all over the street. The driver emerged from an office building, went into the back of the truck and jumped out with a broom.

title: Mubarak Re-elected to Run Egypt
description: Egyptians voting in a referendum gave President Hosni Mubarak, the only candidate, six more years in office by a majority of 97.1 percent, the Government said today.

title: The N.F.L.'s Scarlet Asterisk
description: Somewhere, in a great box seat in the sky, Roger Maris and Ford Frick must be laughing about the football follies of 1987.

title: No Short Cuts to Catholic-Jewish Reconciliation
description: To the Editor:

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JOSEPH F. CONNOR
description: Joseph F. Connor, a retired assistant chief of the New York City Fire Department, died of lung cancer Thursday at Staten Island Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: OPTO MECHANIK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COAST GUARD DUTY PLANNED FOR GULF
description: The Reagan Administration plans to send four small Coast Guard patrol vessels and several search-and-rescue aircraft to the Persian Gulf to join the Navy there, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Vote on Unesco Chief Delayed by a Wrangle
description: The executive boad of Unesco put off voting on a new Director General today, as the board's factions wrangled over election procedures.

title: AUDIOVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
At One Methadone Clinic, Less Is More
description: It is early morning and the hallway of a Harlem drug clinic is beginning to fill. With the effusive efficiency found in a neighborhood deli, a single nurse serves each person who has come to this place of crumbling plaster and dark stairwells.

title: Peruvian Rebels Kill 3
description: Guerrillas ordered 40 passengers off a bus today and killed three policemen who were among them, the police said. They said two men and a woman, carrying machine guns and thought to be Shining Path guerrillas, stopped the bus outside Ica, a city 200 miles south of Lima.

title: Yanks' Coach Shifts
description: In a shift back from the major leagues to the college ranks, Mark Connor took over yesterday as head coach of the Tennessee baseball team after completing his second tour of duty as pitching coach for the Yankees. Connor, 38 years old, lives in Knoxville, Tenn., and was the Volunteers' pitching coach from 1974 to 1978. He replaces John Whited, who resigned last spring.

title: SHELTON SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $724,263 and $2,756,305 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $538,925 and $3,128,831 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $621,763 from a change in accounting principle. The latest year results also include the operations of Tramco Manufacturing Corporation since Dec. 6, 1986 acquisition date. Both year-ago periods' results include the operations of Hayden Inc. since Oct. 23, 1985 acquisition date. The latest year includes a provision of $330,000 related to costs and expenses associated with relocation of operations in Salt Lake City, Utah to Corona, Calif. The year-ago quarter results includes a reduction of about $285,000 of state income taxes relating to a change in estimate recorded in fourth quarter 1986.

title: MIDLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All per share results are fully diluted.

title: A Friend of H. L. Hunt Battles His Son in Court
description: As the Republican gubernatorial candidate in Texas in 1964, Jack A. Crichton knew he did not have much of a chance.

title: Film: 'Baby Boom'
description: ''BABY BOOM'' isn't much more than a glorified sitcom, but it's funny, and it's liable to hit home. The reason: a devilishly good performance by Diane Keaton as the kind of high-energy, nail-spitting female executive who strikes fear into the hearts of everyone she meets. As the sort of woman who answers a middle-of-the-night phone call by mumbling, ''I'm in a meeting; take a message,'' Miss Keaton's J. C. Wiatt embodies all that is bloodcurdling about today's success-crazed young professionals. Lest anyone consider this a sexist premise, rest assured that J. C.'s live-in male companion (''We both eat, sleep and dream our work - that's why we're together,'' says she) is even worse.

title: Cards Grab Playoff Lead With a Last-Minute Hero
description: The understudy was a smash tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-3, and won the opening game of the National League playoff.

title: Advice on Microwave-Oven Methods Disputed
description: IN a new book on microwave cooking, a well-known food expert has been accused of giving advice that could be hazardous to consumers. The expert, Barbara Kafka, is a consultant and cookbook author. The disputed advice appears in ''Microwave Gourmet,'' published late last month by William Morrow.

title: Bonds Rise Abruptly in Final Hour
description: Bond prices improved abruptly late yesterday as participants in the credit markets set aside their fears of a worldwide rise in interest rates and focused on the implications of a sharp drop in stock prices.

title: Sister Eleanor O'Byrne, 92, A Leading Catholic Educator
description: Sister Eleanor O'Byrne, a leading Roman Catholic educator, died after a short illness Sunday at Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart in Albany. She was 91 years old.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 10 described the withdrawal of an 80-page proposal for a book by Joan Braden and Les Whitten. The proposal promised a book of reminiscences by Mrs. Braden, the Washington social figure, and accounts of capital intrigues, amorous and otherwise. The Times's article said Mrs. Braden accused Mr. Whitten of referring to several romantic escapades in the proposal without her knowledge, to make the book more attractive to publishers. The article gave only Mrs. Braden's reasons for withdrawing the proposal and quoted her as saying she did not believe its sexual embellishments ''were germane to what I wanted to write about.'' Mrs. Braden was also quoted as saying that she would not collaborate with Mr. Whitten and that she would write the book with her husband of 39 years, the syndicated columnist Tom Braden. The Times erred in not seeking Mr. Whitten's account of the dispute. He says that only a small part of the proposal had to do with sexual escapades and contends that it was he who dropped Mrs. Braden as a collaborator.

title: INSIDE
description: Sessions Back in Hospital William S. Sessions was hospitalized, forcing postponement of his swearing-in as F.B.I. Director. Page A18. Zaccaro Trial Testimony

title: Multifoods Wary
description: The International Multifoods Corporation, a diversified food processing company, warned a group of Canadian investors that further purchases above their 7.4 percent stake in the company would not be welcome. Bregman Partners, a partnership that includes the Belzberg family, said late Monday that it had acquired a 7.4 percent stake in Multifoods and that it was considering seeking control of the company. Multifoods serves food service operations in the United States, Canada and Venezuela.

title: Who's Political About the Court?
description: ''Let's begin again,'' Senator Dennis DeConcini entreated the President yesterday as the Arizona Democrat joined in the lopsided 9-to-5 Judiciary Committee vote against the Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork. Nothing doing, said Mr. Reagan. ''There's no backing off. I'm going all out.'' Unchastened, he passed the word that he was disappointed with Republicans and peeved at Democrats for ''politicizing'' the confirmation.

title: Miami Is No. 1
description: The Times's 1987 college football computer ranking begins today, on page B12. Next week, and for the rest of the season, the ranking will appear on Tuesdays.

title: OVONIC IMAGING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from Saturday, Oct. 3, editions.

title: FIJI COUP LEADER DECLARES REPUBLIC
description: Lieut. Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, the leader of a military coup here last month, formally declared Fiji a republic Tuesday and proclaimed the right of the ''indigenous Fijian race'' to govern this South Pacific island nation.

title: Economic Scene; Trade Benefits For Both Sides
description: THOUGH there is tough industrial and regional resistance to be overcome on both sides of the border, high officials are ecstatic about the new United States-Canada trade agreement.

title: Officials Begin Crackdown on Truck Drivers' Licenses
description: One after another, the big rigs bumped over the state truck scales alongside Interstate 55 here, a steady procession of car carriers and cattle vans, tankers and flatbeds, westbound for the Mississippi River bridges and the open plains beyond.

title: Baseball Notebook; History Gives Tigers and Giants Edge
description: Detroit and San Francisco have never played each other in the World Series, but they will this year - if the primary playoff indicators are correct. The only contribution the Tigers and the Giants have to make to their progression to the World Series is to score more runs than Minnesota and St. Louis in four of the seven pennant-playoff games.

title: Medical Agency Begins Offering in New York
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Financing Agency is offering $710.3 million of bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company in a financial restructuring that stems from its takeover of mental health facilities previously financed by the New York Housing Finance Agency.

title: ARBOR DRUGS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said an approximately $50,000 after-tax loss on discontinued operations which was expensed in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1987, contributed to its earnings decline. Year-ago net and share earnings reflect pro forma income tax provisions that would have been reported assuming the company's wholly owned subsidiary was not an S Corporation prior to the acquisition by the company on April 29, 1986.

title: Far-Reaching Economic Changes Stir in Bulgaria
description: Bulgaria, the Soviet Union's most orthodox disciple, has ended a period of apparent hesitation that followed the accession to power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and plunged into a far-reaching program of political and economic overhaul.

title: U.S. AIDS Guide for Schools Stresses Abstinence
description: In a handbook that was cleared by the White House, the Department of Education today urged all parents and teachers to stress ''appropriate moral and social conduct'' as the first line of defense against the spreading AIDS epidemic.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Year to July 31
BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
I.B.M. Upgrades Switches for PBX's
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday revamped its line of computerized switches for voice and data communications, introducing an array of private branch exchanges, or PBX's, that supersede the mainstay products of the Rolm Corporation, its telecommunications subsidiary.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates rose modestly for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.9688 percent, up from 7.54 percent last week. Citicorp also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.1420 percent, up from 7.8584 percent.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 13, 1987.

title: 'Corridos!,' an Adaptation of Mexican Folk Tales
description: PUBLIC television goes bilingual this evening at 9 on Channel 13 with ''Corridos!

title: Goode and Rizzo Clash on TV
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank Rizzo called each other liars tonight as they clashed in their only televised debate before the Nov. 3 election.

title: Wave of Profit Taking Lowers Coffee Prices
description: Coffee futures prices fell on a wave of profit taking yesterday after reaching their highest levels since mid-May on Monday.

title: SAZTEC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to June 30
Dance: Graham With Baryshnikov, Nureyev and Plisetskaya
description: THE idea of two fellows from Leningrad being able to portray quintessential American Yankees might stretch the imagination. But that is what Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev actually pulled off last night through their first-ever joint performance in Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring.''

title: FIRST NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All per share figures are fully diluted.

title: Actors' Fund of America Raises $150,000 at Gala
description: The Actors' Fund of America, which is trying to make up large deficits, raised $150,000 Monday night at a gala benefit that brought together Washington politicians and Broadway stars.

title: Farm Loan Aid Voted By House
description: The House voted final passage today of a multibillion-dollar bailout of the Farm Credit System. The legislation includes creation of a secondary market for farm mortgage loans.

title: Talks Under Way In N.F.L. Strike
description: Labor leaders for the National Football League owners and striking players resumed negotiations yesterday afternoon, raising hopes that the strike might end soon, possibly before this weekend.

title: Waldbaum Insider Case
description: Keith Loeb, a relative of the former chairman of Waldbaum Inc., settled Federal insider-trading charges today that arose from the buyout of the supermarket chain.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I SUSPECT that almost every adult thinks wistfully of one or more foods from childhood. For a Southerner, it might be a platter of fried chicken. Someone who grew up on the Eastern seaboard might crave a piping-hot bowl of clam chowder.

title: McNeil Works Out With Teammates
description: Freeman McNeil, who has refused to join his striking Jets teammates on the picket line, worked out with them yesterday for the first time. He explained that the reason he had not been part of their pickup games was an ankle injury he suffered in the regulars' last game, a Monday night victory over the New England Patriots.

title: People
description: * George Biava, John E. Neal, Dr. Robert K. Passikoff and Thomas H. Winner have been named executive vice presidents at William Esty Co.

title: Beverly Hills Hotel Is Sold
description: A company controlled by the Sultan of Brunei, reportedly one of the world's richest men, bought the Beverly Hills Hotel from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, for $200 million, spokesmen for Mr. Davis said today.

title: Democrats Punish 2 States on Primary Rules
description: A dispute over Presidential nominating rules broke out in the Democratic Party today as South Dakota and Minnesota began paying the price for scheduling their nominating contests earlier than the national party allows.

title: New F.B.I. Director in Hospital Again
description: William S. Sessions, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was sent back to the hospital today suffering from a relapse of a bleeding ulcer. The emergency forced an indefinite postponement of his swearing-in, bureau officials said.

title: After Loss, Parcells Grim but Bearing It
description: Little more than eight months ago, the Giants won Super Bowl XXI. Now, in the new pro football season, they are 0-3 and sinking fast, and Coach Bill Parcells is openly unhappy about the quality, but not the effort, of his replacement team.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $19,000 and $371,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss The company said year-ago fourth quarter results included gains of $1,264,000 on the disposition of the two previously mentioned subsidiaries.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Koch Pressuring Gross to Leave, Officials Report
description: Mayor Koch, armed with the findings of a mayoral advisory board, is maneuvering to force out Dr. Elliot M. Gross as Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, top city officials said yesterday.

title: Arithmetic Shows Racism of Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: MERIDIAN INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $262,000 and $814,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After realized losses of $85,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $87,000 for the 6 months.

title: Tamils Kill 50 to 60 in Sri Lanka
description: Ethnic Tamil separatists went on a rampage in the eastern Batticoloa District Tuesday and early today killing between 50 and 60 majority Sinhalese villagers, police officials said.

title: MMR HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $850,000 from an intercompany tax benefit.

title: Commodore Unit Chief
description: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it had named Max Toy president and chief operating officer of its Commodore Business Machines unit. Mr. Toy formerly was senior vice president of sales and government products at Xtra Business Systems, a unit of the ITT Corporation.

title: Council Panel Rejects Koch Nominee for Tax Post
description: In an unusual act of independence that hinged on a strange parliamentary dispute, a New York City Council committee yesterday rejected a nomination from Mayor Koch for the head of a city commission.

title: Kenneth S. Uston Is Dead at 52; Famed and Banned Card Player
description: Kenneth S. Uston, one of the world's foremost blackjack players whose skills prompted casinos around the world to ban him from their card tables, died on Sept. 19 in Paris. He was 52 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Long Returns to Raiders
description: Howie Long, the All-Pro defensive end, and Bill Pickel, a starting defensive tackle, reported to the Los Angeles Raiders' practice facility today, a club employee said.

title: ITT to Sell STC Stake To Telecom
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 24 percent interest in STC P.L.C., a British manufacturer of telecommunications equipment, to Northern Telecom Ltd. for about $730 million.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 7, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HOOKER CORP. BUYS 58% OF B. ALTMAN
description: The Hooker Corporation, an Australian developer, said yesterday that it had purchased 58 percent of the retailing operations of B. Altman & Company, the New York department-store chain with six units in the metropolitan area.

title: Of Trade and Food
description: The food got mixed reviews last weekend at the marathon meetings at the Treasury Department during which the Canadian-United States free trade pact was sealed.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Five Candidates
description: Five men are said to be under consideration for the job of Assistant Secretary of State for international organizations.

title: U.S. PLANS TO TEST SUBMARINE MISSILE WITH 12 WARHEADS
description: The Pentagon plans to test the Navy's new Trident 2 missile with 12 warheads this year despite strong concerns in the Administration and Congress that such tests could complicate arms control talks with the Soviet Union and hamper military planning.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Sports of The Times column by George Vecsey in some editions of SportsMonday this week included scrambled columns of type. Readers wishing copies of the corrected column may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $112,000 and $175,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $112,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 9 months.

title: Mozambican Rebels Step Up Raids in Zimbabwe
description: Rebels fighting the Marxist Government of Mozambique have expanded their war into this lush region of sprawling tea estates.

title: G.M. Job Transfers
description: The General Motors Corporation has begun processing applications by workers at two Saginaw plants seeking jobs at Central Foundry division plants in Ohio and Illinois. G.M. said 1,066 Saginaw Nodular Iron and Saginaw Grey Iron plant workers are seeking transfers to plants in Danville, Ill., and Defiance, Ohio. It plans to transfer 159 Saginaw workers to Danville and 190 to Defiance. G.M. will close Nodular Iron, which last year employed 1,700 people, in early 1988. Some of the foundry's remaining 980 workers will take the jobs of Grey Iron workers with less seniority. Others will be transferred, and the rest may be dismissed.

title: Lasorda Keeps Job
description: Despite teams with 73-89 records the last two seasons, Tom Lasorda will return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers for a 12th season next year. Lasorda, who turned 60 last month, has been a member of the Dodger organization for 38 years.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for 13wks to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Guinness America Selling Some Units
description: Guinness America Inc., Guinness P.L.C.'s holding company in New York, said it planned to divest itself of United States wine production assets, wine brands and the marketing company of its Somerset Group Inc. unit. The company said the plans were consistent with its policy of concentrating on the spirits and brewing businesses.

title: National Gallery Show To Focus on Japan
description: Crown Prince Akihito of Japan paid a ceremonial visit to Washington Monday and the National Gallery of Art used the occasion to announce that it would mount a major exhibition of the art and culture of Japan next year.

title: What Went Wrong; Reagan's Popularity Was Not Enough To End Fears of Shift on Social Issues
description: In their speeches preceding the Senate Judiciary Committee's vote today on Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, members of the committee were unified by one impulse: the need to explain what had happened.

title: TSO Hires Official At Transamerica
description: Richard A. Greenawalt has been named president and chief operating officer of the TSO Financial Corporation, a $1.2 billion financial institution that has come far from its days as a loan service for Philadelphia teachers.

title: ON THE SUNNY SIDE OF THE STREET
description: The General Motors Corporation's latest car model holds only one person and has a top speed of about 60 miles an hour, but the fuel economy is hard to beat. The Sunraycer gets its power from a 90-square-foot array of 7,200 cells that convert sunshine into electricity.

title: Chrysler Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation said its buyer-incentive programs would expire Wednesday, the day before the planned introduction of its 1988 cars and trucks. The programs offered by the American Motors Corporation, which Chrysler acquired in August, expired on Sept. 30, along with those of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation. General Motors began the round of incentives on Aug. 5, and the other companies followed within days. All three offered buyers either cash rebates of varying sizes or financing as low as 1.9 percent for two-year loans.

title: Home Equity Loans Studied
description: The Federal Reserve Board may soon order banks and thrift institutions to give consumers more information about the terms and conditions of home equity loans, Martha Seger, a Fed member, said today.

title: An Improbable Star Does Job
description: In his two major-league seasons, Greg Mathews had sharpened his routine into a ritual. The days and hours before his assignments as a starting pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals had become clearly defined.

title: Bridge; Women's Team Champions To Miss World Title Event
description: When the world championships begin Sunday in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, the defending champions in the Venice Trophy contest for women's teams will be missing. The British team that won two years ago in Sao Paulo, Brazil, failed to qualify in the European championships, and that zone will be represented by France and Italy.

title: Sporty Bag And Shoes
description: 1.A Bag on the Go

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: A Disk-Driven Drill Sergeant
description: Peering at the image of an Army helicopter's control panel, the soldier reads the subtitles ordering him to prepare for takeoff and start the engines. He taps the video screen. If he has touched the right part of the complex panel image, the scene shifts and another order appears. If not, an ''X'' appears over his choice and a circle shows where he should have pressed.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ameruso Gets 16 Weekends On Rikers I.
description: Anthony R. Ameruso, who was New York City's Transportation Commissioner for eight years, was sentenced yesterday to 16 weekends in jail and five years' probation for lying under oath to a panel investigating government corruption.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE way he told it, it really was a funny story. He was sitting at the kitchen table, his second beer in hand, talking about having his wisdom teeth out. The dentist's office, he said, looked like a gathering of ghosts, with the dentist and his assistants draped, masked, gowned, gloved. The trays, the floors, the chair, the counter tops: everything was swathed in white. And there he was in the middle of it all, his mouth open wide, feeling as though he should have a bell in his hand, so that when he could talk again he could clang it and cry, ''Unclean!''

title: U.S. Sets Regulations On Alien Employment
description: The Justice Department today issued final regulations governing prosecution of discriminatory employment practices under the new immigration law. The regulations were sharply criticized by Hispanic groups.

title: New Pipelines Are Reducing Persian Gulf's Strategic Role
description: The construction of new oil pipelines by Iraq, Turkey and Saudi Arabia has significantly accelerated in the last six months. These new pipelines, some of which are operational, are on their way to reducing the Persian Gulf's importance as the primary route for moving Middle Eastern oil to the West and Japan.

title: House Moves to Combat Acts of Religious Hatred
description: The House of Representatives passed a bill Monday that would expand Federal authority to fight crimes that damage religious property and obstruct the free exercise of religious beliefs.

title: Trump Study Sees TV City As Disruptive
description: Donald J. Trump's Television City project would increase the daytime population on the Upper West Side of Manhattan by more than 60,000 and so severely overburden public transportation that a second subway entrance would be needed at 72d Street and Broadway, according to a preliminary draft of an environmental impact statement prepared by the developer.

title: Operation PUSH Clearing Debts, Leader Says
description: Operation PUSH, the group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to promote economic advancement for blacks, has paid off most of its debts and will balance its books within a few months, according to the group's director.

title: Reagan's Pilot Discounts Peril
description: President Reagan was never in danger when a small airplane passed near his helicopter over the Presidential ranch near Santa Barbara, Mr. Reagan's pilot has testified.

title: HEALTHVEST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company began operations and went public on May 29, 1986. For the four months ended Sept. 30, 1986, the company had net of $3,530,000, or 59 cents a share, on revenue of $4,728,000 and average shares outstanding, 5,949,000.

title: Real Estate; 8 Blocks Of 5th Ave. Awakening
description: ALTHOUGH home to two of Manhattan's most renowned department stores for more than half a century, the eight-block stretch of Fifth Avenue from the Empire State Building to the New York Public Library has never won much respect as an office district.

title: Concert: The Moscow Virtuosi
description: MOSCOW has been sending virtuosos to the West for a good century now, but the Moscow Virtuosi are something a little different: not star soloists but 19 first-rate string players, with a classical-size complement of winds, honed by Vladimir Spivakov, the violinist, to a rare fineness of ensemble. The group made its New York debut at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday with a smoothly delivered, sure-to-please program.

title: PHOTON TECHNOLGY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $43,000. The company, which went public Feb. 9, said that year-ago quarter results are not available.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The results of operations in 1987 included an extraordinary expense of $665,000 in connection with settlement of litigation during the year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Another Opening

title: Yes, Keep Sanctions Against Pretoria
description: President Reagan is the wrong person to assert the failure of economic sanctions against racial tyranny in South Africa. Who thought that sanctions, weak or strong, would end apartheid? They were meant to tell South Africans where America stands on a question of good and evil. Congress voted for sanctions over the President's objections precisely because the signals he had sent Pretoria were mixed. They still are, which is why sanctions are still needed.
