title: TRACE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $255,000 for the quarter and $475,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: America's Self-Interest in Helping Gorbachev
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarkable efforts to transform the Soviet economy - and, perforce, Soviet society - have captured the attention of the American public. That is scarcely news. But what is striking is the breadth of the developing consensus among knowledgeable Americans that it is very much in the interest of the goal of

title: 9-5 PANEL VOTE AGAINST BORK SENDS NOMINATION TO SENATE AMID PREDICTIONS OF DEFEAT
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 9 to 5 today against the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, and both supporters and opponents predicted his rejection by the full Senate if President Reagan continues to insist on a vote.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1987.

title: PMI Mortgage's Rating Is Raised
description: The rating of the claims-paying ability of the PMI Mortgage Insurance Company has been raised to Aaa from A-1, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: Oklahoma Is Accused
description: Some Oklahoma football players earned as much as $4,000 a season by selling their complimentary tickets to boosters in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, according to a published report. The accusation was denied yesterday by Coach Barry Switzer.

title: FILM: THREE FROM LINDSDAY ANDERSON
description: THERE may be a more moving film in town than ''Thursday's Children,'' but don't count on it. Lindsay Anderson's 1953 documentary runs only 21 minutes, every one of which produces a lump in the throat or a leap of the heart.

title: For Apple Lovers, the Delight Is in the Choosing
description: IT is in autumn that taking a bite of a fresh-picked apple becomes a memorable experience, after the cooler temperatures have touched this fruit of the gods. But many people miss out on how varied the experience can be.

title: TV Flipping's Effect on Ads
description: Everyone knows that a family that finds itself the possessor of a TV remote control channel changer immediately increases its penchant for flipping. But how much?

title: LOWRANCE ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to July 31
'TOGETHER TO MARS?,' U.S. AND SOVIET SCIENTISTS
description: ''TOGETHER TO MARS?'' loves its own technology.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AFTER 10 weeks and seven additional pounds, the sports enthusiast is finally playing tennis again. What happened to the summer - and to his waistline? ''My back went out,'' he said, ''and all I could do was lie around and eat.''

title: Market Place; Finding Safe, Cheap Stocks
description: AS if investors were not nervous enough, yesterday's blue-chip slaughter - the Dow Jones industrial average plunged a record 91.55 points - renewed debate over just how safe the current stock market is.

title: UNITED SERVICES ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $44,339 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $26,946 for the year. c-Net loss

title: NAVY JOB IN GULF: DIFFICULT MISSION
description: The United States Navy task force in the Persian Gulf is being hard pressed by the difficult, tedious job of protecting oil shipping from attacks by Iran, according to naval personnel and diplomats in the region.

title: Public Broadcast Group Selects New Chairman
description: Howard D. Gutin, who has served as acting chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's board of directors since March, was elected chairman today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CLEA & ZEUS DIVORCE. By Emily Prager. 259 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. Soft cover, $6.95.

title: READICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The revenue figures represent patient revenue.

title: Raquel Welch Forsakes Glamour In Drama on Dying
description: HAGGARD and wasted by disease, she slumps like a rag doll, paralyzed. The tracheotomy that enables her to breathe has deprived her of the ability to talk; she can communicate only by blinking her eyelids or twitching her head. Once an attractive woman with a full mental and physical life, she is now a drooling dependent sustained by machines, her existence reduced to only one wish: that she be allowed to die.

title: Walbro Buyback Blocked by Court
description: A Delaware court issued a temporary restraining order preventing the Walbro Corporation, which is being pursued by UIS Inc., from using the proceeds of a $35 million preferred stock sale to a friendly ally to buy back shares of its outstanding common stock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1987
description: Markets

title: Concert: The Music of Robert Ward
description: ROBERT WARD was born in Cleveland and educated in the Northeast, but in recent years he has put down roots in the South - as an administrator and teacher at the North Carolina School for the Arts and at Duke University. Sunday afternoon the North Carolina Symphony honored the American composer as one of its own, offering a program of Mr. Ward's music at Carnegie Hall. The celebration was for his 70th birthday.

title: 1-2-3 Rival Is Introduced
description: The Microsoft Corporation, as expected, yesterday introduced a version of its Excel spreadsheet program for International Business Machines personal computers. The software raises perhaps the most potent challenge yet to the Lotus Development Corporation's top-selling 1-2-3 software. At a news conference in New

title: Arnell/Bickford Gets European American
description: After doing without an advertising agency for quite some time, the European American Bank has selected Arnell/Bickford Associates to fill the void.

title: A Hunt for Better Coal Plants
description: The coal-burning electricity plant here, about 45 miles northeast of Buffalo, is considered ''state of the art.'' Federal regulators and environmental activists agree that the plant meets pollution standards for air and water.

title: Heflin, at Last Voting No, Weathers the Intense Heat on the Uncommitted
description: ''I think everybody in Alabama that had 22 cents has written me a letter,'' Senator Howell Heflin said today as he described the enormous pressure he faced as a member of the Judiciary Committee considering Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Yale Club Lets Women Take 'the Plunge'
description: For the first time, women are able to swim at the Yale Club - as long as they wear swimsuits.

title: Secretary Baker Hits the Campaign Trail
description: LEAD: The International Monetary Fund's annual meeting wouldn't be the same without an unusual proposal from Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. Two years ago, in Seoul, South Korea, he proposed the Baker Plan, a grow-and-pay strategy for debtor countries designed to make muddling through look good. The Baker

title: German Factory Orders
description: Orders for industrial goods in West Germany rose 7.4 percent in August, but economists were not sure if the official figures signaled a rebound in the most powerful West European economy. The Federal Statistics Office today attributed the rise partly to strong demand for machinery and electrical engineering goods. The Economics Ministry said orders rose a real, seasonally adjusted 7.4 percent in August compared with July, after a 1.9 percent rise in July against June. But Richard Reid, senior European economist with the brokers UBS/ Phillips & Drew in London, said, ''The August figure was erratically large and I expect it to be corrected next month.

title: Chafee's Call on Bork
description: Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island called the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., on Monday to tell him that he had decided to oppose Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Advances: Neither Rain Nor Snow Can Halt Inserts
description: DESPITE the rapid development of communications technology, American businesses and their customers still depend almost exclusively on the traditional postal system for sending documents between homes and companies - activity that accounts for 80 percent of all mail sent and delivered in the United States.

title: Chip Sanction Held Effective
description: The sanctions imposed on Japan by the United States in April following complaints that it had breached a semiconductor trade pact are working, an American industry spokesman said today.

title: Head of OPEC on Tour
description: Rilwanu Lukman, president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, left today to visit Persian Gulf oil states to bolster support for OPEC price policies. Mr. Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, told reporters that OPEC members must stay within their production quotas before oil prices can improve.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain-reduction in income taxes arising from utilization of net operating loss carryforward of $200,000. uYear-ago quarter earnings were reduced by $3,975,000, or 15 cents a share, required to terminate a distribution agreement, and had a higher effective tax rate of 41 percent in the year-ago quarter, compared with 28 percent in the latest quarter.

title: Duarte Calls Cease-Fire; Rebels Say No
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte announced today that he would order a cease-fire next month in the Government's campaign against leftist rebels, but the guerrillas refused to follow suit, calling such a move tantamount to surrender.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
60 Shout Out Dalai Lama's Name And Are Seized in Protest in Tibet
description: About 60 people shouting the name of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's former civil and religious leader, marched today to a Government office, where armed Chinese security forces quickly arrested them.

title: About New York; Urban 4-H Club: Message of Hope Amid the Sorrow
description: Since 4-H Clubs began three-quarters of a century ago, more than 45 million youths have learned the intricacies of pigs, peach pies and pesticides under their caring tutelage.

title: TRACKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 12
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $247,000 and $867,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Seattle Journal; Parched for Water in Rain Country
description: This summer the rain country's rains failed. Water rationing turned ''The

title: At Last, a Union Station Running on Schedule
description: By next fall the capital's Union Station will revert to its primary role as a train station.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $145,000.

title: Data Show Sharp Drop In Airline Flight Delays
description: Airline delays declined significantly from last summer to this summer, Government figures indicate, despite wide predictions of tie-ups through the heavy travel season.

title: New Hearing Is Ordered by Court In Alabama Desegregation Case
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered a new hearing on a judge's ruling that segregation still existed in Alabama colleges and universities.

title: Opening on a Relatively Even Keel
description: Last year, there were raised hackles in the locker room even before the Rangers embarked on their 47th consecutive season without a Stanley Cup. Ted Sator, whose abrasive manner had already precipitated the defections of Barry Beck and Mark Pavelich, also had a hostile relationship with the new general manager, Phil Esposito, who wanted things to be jolly between players and management.

title: Group Has 21.1% Of Cineplex Odeon
description: A shareholder group including the Canadian billionaire Charles R. Bronfman said it had acquired a 21.1 percent stake in the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, the second-largest motion picture exhibitor in North America. The group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought the stake for investment purposes only. In addition to Mr. Bronfman, co-chairman of the Seagram Company liquor concern, the group also includes two Montreal-based investment firms - Pentrust Holdings & Company and Claridge Investments & Company.

title: RIVER FOREST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIA FOUNDATION, BACK FROM BRINK, OPENS NEW CENTER
description: Two years ago, it looked as if the far-flung Dia Foundation, a major private financing source for certain contemporary artists, did not have much of a future. Backed by millions of dollars from a single patron, Philippa de Menil Friedrich, it was overextended in its commitments to venturesome projects. To make ends meet, it reduced expenditures and sold several Manhattan buildings that housed artists' work, along with a part of its extensive art collection. A new director was brought in, and the board of trustees was reorganized.

title: Graf Needs Surgery
description: Steffi Graf of West Germany, the top-ranked women's singles player, is suffering from serious sinus problems that will soon require surgery, according to her personal physician. The 18-year-old Graf canceled an exhibition match in Corsica against Catherine Tanvier of France Monday and checked into the University Hospital in Freiburg, West Germany, suffering from a sinus inflammation.

title: Bush, in Iowa, Clarifies Stand on Legal Abortions
description: Vice President Bush said today that he favored allowing abortions in cases of rape and incest, clarifying the stand he took in the 1984 campaign.

title: TV Ministers Dispute Need for Tighter Regulation
description: Facing Congressional scrutiny in the wake of the PTL ministry scandal, some prominent television evangelists today questioned whether there was any need for the Government to require greater financial disclosure by religious broadcasters and whether that would be proper.

title: Chicago Merc Accepts Plan
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange overwhelmingly approved a plan today to create an electronic trading system allowing investors worldwide to buy and sell financial futures and options around the clock. An exchange spokeswoman, Julie Jacobs, said 3,939 exchange members, or 88 percent, voted in favor of the new system and 526 voted against it.

title: Dow Drops a Record 91.55 Points On Interest-Rate and Dollar Fears
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday amid continued anxiety over rising interest rates and the dollar.

title: Rockland Chief Proposes 1-Year Halt to County Property Tax
description: The Rockland County Executive proposed today a one-year moratorium on collecting property taxes from homeowners and businesses.

title: From Milan: Young and Getting Younger
description: Fashion is being reshuffled as a result of the current focus on short skirts. Some of the most pleasing moments in the current week of spring and summer openings have been provided by houses that are not usually the pace-setters at showings here. Lagerfeld for Fendi

title: PERIOD OF SILENCE DEBATED IN COURT
description: In a case mixing emotionally charged constitutional issues with mind-numbing procedural technicalities, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on a New Jersey law requiring public schools to permit students a minute of silence at the start of the school day.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $9.4 million related to the initial public offering of the company's Commtron Corp. subsidiary for both the quarter and year.

title: Haiti and Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress Isn't the Word For Television City
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncoding the Labels On Breakfast Cereals
description: LEAD: SHOPPING for food is rough enough, but the slings and arrows of nutritional advice hurtling your way can really mix you up - especially when you buy cold breakfast cereal.

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $62,029. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $350,808.

title: WINE TALK
description: AN urbane middle-aged acquaintance who has discovered fine wine is hurrying to make up for lost time. He wants to know everything before the sun sets today.

title: How It Happened; Unlikely Turn By A Card Runner
description: The San Francisco Giants defused the speediest part of the St. Louis Cardinals' attack in the opening game of the National League pennant playoff tonight, but the game turned on the base-path maneuvers of the slowest runner in the Cardinals' lineup.

title: Advertising; Optimism Growing at Magazines
description: THERE is rising optimism in magazineland, where publishers trained to detect the far-off sound of incoming money perceive a distant rustling.

title: Better Training for Teachers
description: How can the best young people be attracted to the teaching profession? More money and better teaching conditions, for sure. But also a better education for teachers, and education planners have begun to focus on just that.

title: Senate Protests Soviet Tests
description: The Senate approved a non-binding resolution today condemning the Soviet test firing of intercontinental ballistic missiles last week within 600 miles of Hawaii. The vote was 96 to 0. Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming and sponsor of the measure, called the tests a ''deliberate provocation.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Combustion Engineering Inc., Stamford, Conn., a provider of systems and services for electric utilities and other industries, elected James B. Kelly executive vice president and named him and George S. Kimmel executive vice presidents of operations.

title: Charges Are Denied By a Florida Doctor In Death of Ill Wife
description: A doctor who says in an unpublished manuscript that he gave his cancer-stricken wife fatal doses of drugs has pleaded not guilty to murder charges in connection with her death.

title: U.S. Resolve And Europe; Some Allies Question The G.I. Commitment
description: At a time of considerable uncertainty in the trans-Atlantic relationship, Western European politicians and strategists have started to revise in subtle but important ways their assessment of the American economic and political power and the durability of the United States commitment to the defense of Europe.

title: One Author Is Rankling Two Chinas
description: Bo Yang is a mild-mannered, bespectacled scholar who scribbles Chinese characters on notebooks in his small study, and infuriates people throughout the Chinese-speaking world.

title: Ex-Honor Student Is Acquitted in the Slaying of 4
description: A Columbia County jury last night found a former high school honor student not guilty of murder charges in the Dec. 13, 1986, shooting deaths of four members of his household in their East Chatham home.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter results include gains of approximately $10 million ($7.5 million after tax; $2.5 million and $1.5 million, respectively in 1986) from the sale of certain assets, principally land and buildings. These sales generated total proceeds of approximately $32 million ($5.5 million in 1986) which were applied to the purchase of new fixed assets. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Honduras on Trial
description: LEAD: Though it has attracted scant attention in the United States, an extraordinary event is under way in Costa Rica. An international judicial body is trying the Honduran Government for ''disappearances'' -perhaps the most horrifying of the abuses of human rights that has plagued Central America and South America in two decades.

title: Strike Angers India Students
description: When about 2,000 teachers from Delhi University demonstrated recently against new working conditions with slogans and placards, they faced uncomfortable criticism of their two-month work stoppage from an unlikely quarter.

title: British Publisher in Asia
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, is prepared to take a minority stake in a Chinese-language newspaper in Hong Kong, he said today.

title: Japan Prince Sees Reagan
description: President Reagan and Crown Prince Akihito of Japan discussed ties between their two countries during a brief meeting today at the White House. The Prince, 53 years old, and his wife, Crown Princess Michiko, began a three-day visit to Washington on Monday.

title: SANDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an undisclosed charge for goodwill related to the acquisition of Monarch Information Systems Inc. The year-ago revenue figure is restated from $1,565,000. The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 1-for-30 reverse stock split paid in July. The company was formerly Sandsport Data Services Inc.

title: Norway Hints Oil Delay
description: Norway said today that some of its proposed North Sea oil and gas projects might have to be postponed because it does not want to make excessive investments. The Government predicted that Norway's oil and gas output would total 76 million metric tons (oil equivalent) in 1988, 12 percent above this year's forecast of 68 million.

title: In 7 Deaths, Town Knew What Experts Didn't
description: To the police, the clergy and the farm crisis experts, the killing frenzy here attributed to a 14-year-old farm boy, seemingly pushed to the breaking point by searing poverty and a relentless workload, had made a kind of tragic sense.

title: Political Marketing; Apres Debate: Trying to Put 'Spin' on the Outcome
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee knelt at the front of the stage to talk to a crowd of reporters while two other Democratic Presidential candidates stood behind him, waiting for a chance to get the group's attention.

title: No Short Cuts to Catholic-Jewish Reconciliation; Vatican and Zionism
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Henry Fineberg, 83, Dies; New York Hospitals Official
description: Dr. Henry I. Fineberg, a retired pediatrician and former deputy commissioner of hospitals for New York City, died of a stroke Sunday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
When High Officials Begin Acting Strangely
description: Never before have we had an Administration so eager to subject people to a variety of tests.

title: Hurdles Await Mexico's Next Leader
description: By choosing Carlos Salinas de Gortari to succeed him as President, Miguel de la Madrid has sought to assure the continuation of his administration's economic restructuring and political initiatives.

title: Business Committee for the Arts Marks 20th Year
description: Such major museum exhibitions as ''The Treasures of Tutankhamun,'' ''The Vatican Collection'' and ''Treasure Houses of Great Britain,'' public television series ranging from ''Masterpiece Theater'' to ''Great Performances,'' new orchestral compositions, new opera productions, new choreographic works, video and film are only a few of myriad cultural activities made possible by business support of the arts in recent years.

title: Pentagon Says It Is Facing Tough Cuts Under New Law
description: A new Pentagon analysis contends that the revised budget-balancing law has confronted Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger with the choice of dismissing large numbers of military personnel or cutting sharply into funds for operations and weapons.

title: Natalie Hinderas Memorial
description: A memorial concert for the pianist Natalie Hinderas will be held Friday at 5:30 P.M. at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Abundant Whiting

title: Murder Case Against Scandal Informer Crumbles
description: A murder case in Florida against Michael Raymond, a key Government informer in the corruption scandals that rocked New York and Chicago last year, appears to have fallen apart with the recantation of the chief witness against him.

title: Robber With Toy Gun Is Killed by Storekeeper
description: A robber wielding what turned out to be a toy gun was shot to death yesterday by the 23-year-old owner of a Brooklyn grocery store, the police said.

title: Cedric Phatudi Is Dead; Leader in South Africa
description: Cedric Phatudi, who rejected South African Government attempts to make his tribal homeland of Lebowa an independent nation, died today. He was 75 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Coming to Bookstores: The Saatchis' Story
description: And speaking of the Saatchis -these days it seems difficult not to -Weidenfeld & Nicolson, a London book publisher, has just brought out ''The Saatchi & Saatchi Story,'' written by Philip Kleinman. Mr. Kleinman, a member of London's advertising trade press, is editor of the World Advertising Review.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Putting Up the Stop Sign
description: As the parties of the second part, the dueling Bobs have taken an early lead in baseball's latest battle of nerves. When Vince Coleman of the Cardinals reaches first base in the National League Championship Series between St. Louis and San Francisco, Bob Brenly and Bob Melvin, the catchers for the Giants, face one of the most difficult challenges in the game.

title: Oil Tanker Spills 15,000 Barrels West of Canada
description: A supertanker caught in a storm in the Gulf of Alaska last weekend spilled about 15,000 barrels of Alaska crude oil into the sea 200 miles west of Canada's Queen Charlotte Islands, the United States Coast Guard said today.

title: The Rev. Peter Halligan, 63, Maryknoll Missionary in Peru
description: The Rev. Peter J. Halligan, a Maryknoll priest who was a missionary in Peru for 33 years, died of a pancreatic disease Sept. 30 in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in Lima, Peru.

title: THE STAGE: 'NEW WORKS '87'
description: EACH of the three short plays on the opening bill of ''New Works '87'' at the Cubiculo Theater intentionally withholds pertinent information. Up to a point, the approach is enticing. The more we learn about the characters and their problems, the more we want to know. In varying degrees, however, each of the Goodwater Theater Company plays leaves unanswered questions.

title: Unlock Their Cuffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting a Blanket Chest Back Into Shape
description: LEAD: The blanket chest - a version of the six-plank box, but with feet - was the forerunner of the chest of drawers and at one time the basic storage space for the American household. It was not confined to the bedroom, for it was the catchall and closet for seasonal items - the least of which might have been blankets.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ortega May Weigh End of Soviet Aid
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said yesterday that he was willing to consider the withdrawal of all Soviet and Cuban military aid if the United States agreed to negotiate directly with his Government.

title: Airbus Gets Orders In Belgium, Korea
description: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, said it had won two orders to build a total of seven planes for airlines in Belgium and South Korea. The Belgian state-owned airline Sabena said in Brussels that it had ordered five long-haul A340-300 aircraft from Airbus to be delivered in 1993 and 1994. And Korean Air has ordered two Airbus medium-haul A300-600 jets to be delivered at the end of 1988.

title: The Vast Flexibility Of Designs in Metal
description: MARIO VILLA, a Nicaraguan who is now based in New Orleans, is a 33-year-old architect who combines metals in the chairs, tables, lamps and cabinets he designs. ''Furniture From New Orleans,'' a display of his work, opens today at the Gallery of Applied Arts.

title: Boxer Has an Unusual Style
description: Not long ago, Michael Olajide Jr. was anticipating the impact his entrance would have when he steps into the ring Saturday to fight Frank Tate for the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title.

title: DATAPHAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Violin: Kavakos
description: AN estimable young violinist, Leonidas Kavakos, was introduced by the 92d Street Y Tuesday evening in a recital with Anne Epperson, a pianist. He began with the enormous Chaconne from Bach's D minor Partita, and identified himself at once as a player of clean, severe lines, concentrated energy and secure technique. It was not ingratiating playing, and the chords that throw the bow across all the strings were harshly sounded, but it was an acute, well-tuned, attention-holding performance.

title: Union Official Faces Contempt In Fraud Inquiry
description: A longshoreman's union official was cited for contempt of court yesterday and ordered to appear for questioning into whether union funds are being illegally channeled to a former union leader, Anthony M. Scotto.

title: Goode and Rizzo Claim Victory in Mayoral Debate
description: Both sides claimed victory today after Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo called each other liars and worse in the only televised debate of the mayoral campaign.

title: Homeless Girl to Go To School - Finally
description: A homeless girl from Poughkeepsie, N.Y, is to attend school today for the first time this school year as a result of a Federal court ruling yesterday.

title: Swiss Vote Insider Curb
description: Swiss legislators voted overwhelmingly today to outlaw insider trading, removing a longstanding source of tension with the United States.

title: HERBERT A. STEINBERG
description: Herbert A. Steinberg, a portrait painter and muralist, died of a heart attack Sunday in Exeter, N.H. He was 59 years old and lived in Roosevelt, N.J.

title: Ex-Wedtech Lobbyist Pleads Guilty to Corruption
description: A former Washington lobbyist for the Wedtech Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor corruption charge stemming from his efforts to give a Federal official $10,000 in cash.

title: Judge Kaufman Given The Medal of Freedom
description: In a White House ceremony today, President Reagan awarded Irving R. Kaufman, former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the nation's highest civilian honor, the Medal of Freedom.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
Talley Industries Sets Restructuring
description: Talley Industries said it plans to sell its apparel and clock-making operations to focus on its aerospace, industrial and real estate businesses. The company said the restructuring would result in an unspecified loss for the year, its first in five years. After a 30-minute halt in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Talley stock rose 87.5 cents to close at $22.625.

title: Grey Gets Levolor
description: Closer to home and slightly on the shady side, Grey Advertising, New York, has picked up the account of Levolor Lorentzen Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., maker of window blinds and similar products. The billings, expected to exceed $5 million, formerly went through Muller, Jordan, Weiss.

title: San Francisco Journal; With Giants and Heat, Quakes Are Forgotten
description: She stands like an urban seductress, San Francisco does, a stunningly beautiful city of steep hills on the bay, attracting newcomers like a Venus flytrap. They come, they stay, even with the knowledge that the city sits atop a seismic time bomb that could explode into a fearsome earthquake at any time.

title: Article 139887 -- No Title
description: A jury has awarded $520,000 to a former Government employee who sued the maker of a fire-proofing material that contained asbestos after she was diagnosed as having an asbestos-related disease.

title: 7 Indicted in Texas Savings Fraud
description: Seven Texas businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of participating in a scheme that gained more than $100 million from five savings and loan associations through the use of fraudulent real estate loans.

title: Met Opera: A Debut In 'Ariadne'
description: A SUCCESSFUL Metropolitan Opera debut was made Monday night by Barbara Kilduff, who took prizes in an impressive series of closely spaced vocal competitions last year. The young coloratura soprano sang Zerbinetta in ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' the same high-flying role that introduced her earlier this year in Vienna and Munich. She has the top notes down pat, and the stamina and pacing (crucial factors here) well in hand. As an actress she was a little reserved, but she blossomed as she went along. The voice is precisely matched to the role's tradition: small, fresh, clear and true to pitch.

title: Leeway Granted To Question Zaccaro Witness
description: The key prosecution witness in the trial of John A. Zaccaro was declared a hostile witness yesterday, after testifying that he felt Mr. Zaccaro had not tried to solicit a bribe from him.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 68 cents a share on the sales of six corrugating container plants and Mead's 50 percent interest in a linerboard mill. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $15.7 million for the quarter and $17.1 million for the 9 months.

title: George Garvy Is Dead; Ex-U.S. Bank Official
description: George Garvy, a former vice president and senior adviser of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Report In Manila Of New Coup Plot
description: President Corazon C. Aquino ordered at least three radio stations closed today because she said they had broadcast right-wing propaganda; and hundreds of soldiers took up positions around the presidential palace as the Government warned of a new plot to topple it.

title: BankAmerica Confirms Investment by Japanese
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would sell $350 million of new securities to Japanese financial companies, an action that will strengthen the ailing bank.

title: Twins Jump in Front of Tigers; Giants Tie Series, 1-1; Giants 5 Cardinals 0
description: Dave Dravecky continued to pitch zeros in postseason play today when he mastered the St. Louis Cardinals on two singles and pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 5-0 victory that squared the National League playoff at one game apiece.

title: Control of Denver Schools Eased
description: Denver's public schools have moved a step toward autonomy with a Federal judge's decision to reduce court control over the school district for the first time in an 18-year-old desegregation case.

title: 3 Giants Return, But Not for Long
description: Lawrence Taylor, Leonard Marshall and Jeff Hostetler, three of the Giants' striking players, rejoined the team today, but not for long. They changed their minds and left separately, and it seemed unlikely that any would return for at least another week.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Friday misstated the range at which advocates of gold, like Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, believe that its price should stabilize. The range is $400 to $500.

title: PANEL SAYS JUDGE SOUGHT A BRIBE
description: A report by a special judicial panel released today says there is ''clear and convincing evidence'' that a Federal district judge in Miami conspired to solicit a $150,000 bribe and should be impeached by Congress.

title: Leaders of AIDS Panel Quit Amid Feuds and Criticism
description: The top leadership of the President's AIDS commission resigned abruptly today, further clouding the panel's ability to complete its assessment of AIDS programs on schedule.

title: New Challenger
description: Bobby Joe Young of Steubenville, Ohio, has been replaced as a welterweight challenger against Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain to avoid a clash with the World Boxing Council, British promoters said yesterday. Honeyghan's defense, scheduled for Oct. 28, was to have been held under International Boxing Federation rules at a time when the rival W.B.C. is holding its annual convention in London. Although Honeyghan holds both the W.B.C. and I.B.F. titles, Young does not have a W.B.C. ranking and the council would not have sanctioned the match.

title: Advertising; Revolution In Britain: One View
description: IN the agency world there are the conglomerates, as typified by Saatchi & Saatchi and the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the colonial (or branch) networks, like those run by J. Walter Thompson, Young & Rubicam and Foote, Cone & Belding. A more recent phenomenon is what Peter Scott, chief executive of Britain's WCRS Group, describes as a creative federation.

title: MOST MAJOR BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE BY 1/2 POINT, TO 9 1/4%
description: Led by Chase Manhattan Bank and Citibank, most of the nation's major commercial banks raised the prime lending rate by a half-point yesterday, to 9 1/4 percent.

title: Imperial Oil in Deal
description: Imperial Oil Ltd., the Canadian oil company that is 70 percent owned by the Exxon Corporation, agreed to pay $680 million (Canadian), or $523 million (United States), for the assets of Sulpetro Ltd., a natural gas company in receivership since June. The Calgary, Alberta-based natural gas concern was hard hit by the slump in oil prices that followed its 1981 purchase of the Candel Oil and Gas Company.

title: Meet Me in St. Louis
description: Let's meet by the Musial statue, at the corner of Broadway and Walnut, an hour and a half before the game.

title: Jersey City Indian Community Protests Rash of Racial Attacks
description: Leaders of this city's Indian community disrupted a mayoral news conference today, demanding action to halt a rash of attacks on Indians here.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Miller Has Surgery
description: Keith Miller, the Mets' second baseman, underwent surgery yesterday to repair ligament and tendon damage to the little finger of his right hand. Miller is expected to begin therapy next week. He was recalled from Tidewater on June 16, but injured the finger sliding into third base during his first game and was placed on the disabled list June 29. He was reactivated Sept. 1, but was limited to pinch-running duty.

title: Craig Looks Good On Pena Blunder
description: Not everything was the way it seemed in the second game of the National League playoff today.

title: An Uncertain Beginning for Guatemala Talks
description: Talks aimed at ending the 25-year-old civil war in Guatemala got off to a shaky start here today, nearly stalling after only a few hours.

title: The Larger Message
description: Americans on the whole think this is a better country because the Supreme Court has condemned racial discrimination, protected privacy and said that legislative elections must follow the rule of one person, one vote. We are glad that the Court, in such bold decisions, interpreted the Constitution generously to protect individual liberty.

title: 160 Die in Sri Lanka; India Vows to Curb Attacks
description: More than 160 people were killed Tuesday night and today in a series of attacks by ethnic Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka, prompting India to warn that its forces would use ''all the force at our command'' to stop further violence there.

title: Bergesch, Rose Kept
description: Marge Schott, the Cincinnati Reds' owner, says she intends to retain Bill Bergesch, the general manager, and Pete Rose, manager, for 1988 but she expects better results.

title: Four Handsome Artemisias, and One Little Ugly Duckling
description: ONE year it was sedums, and another it was alliums - 19 kinds of the former, and 14 of the latter. From time to time, I like to plant several species within one genus close to one another, so I can get to know them as a group, observing the similarities and differences, much as one observes the same things in a family of people. This year it was artemisias. From a mail-order nursery specializing in herbs, I ordered five kinds.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: New Company and Play

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. Reagan is attempting to rewrite the plan in accordance with U.S. interests. He is now in open confrontation with the Central American presidents.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ A12:1. ]

title: Saying No to Bork, Southern Democrats Echo Black Voters
description: The opposition of Southern senators to Judge Robert H. Bork reflects a crucial political reality in the region: the electoral fortunes of many Southern Democrats depend on overwhelming support from blacks.

title: Malaysian Trade Gains
description: Malaysia's trade surplus has risen sharply this year, providing evidence that the economy is rebounding from its recession in 1985 and 1986, officials and economists said today. The trade surplus rose 39 percent, to 5.8 billion ringgit, or about $2.32 billion, in the first six months of 1987, from 4.18 billion ringgit, or $1.67 billion, a year earlier.

title: Frazier in Broadcast Job
description: Walt Frazier, the former Knick guard who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame this year, will serve as analyst on selected Knick cable television and radio broadcasts over the Madison Square Garden network this season. Frazier will discuss the Knicks' opponent and game strategy as the pregame studio guest of Greg Gumbel, the broadcast host, on telecasts. Frazier will also substitute occasionally for Ernie Grunfeld as analyst on Knick radio broadcasts.

title: The Pleasures of Freelancing
description: For a writer, freelancing can be a frustrating, uncertain and unprofitable effort, but, occasionally, it provides a windfall. The odds are perhaps a little better for a freelance hunter.

title: Russians Urging U.N. Be Given Greater Powers
description: After many years of treating the United Nations primarily as a convenient forum for berating the capitalist West, Soviet officials have begun to advocate a powerful new role for the organization.

title: Washington Talk: Embassy Row; An 'Impressive Guy' From China
description: The visit here this week by Deng Pufang, son of the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, is labeled ''unofficial,'' but his appointment calendar could not look more official.

title: Familiar Cast Aims to Erase Memory of Last Year's Finale
description: Terry Simpson sat in a seat halfway up an empty Nassau Coliseum last month, his hooded eyes staring out over the unpopulated ice. Five months had passed since his Islanders lost in seven games to the Philadelphia Flyers, ending an exciting playoff run with a disappointing 5-1 sleepwalk in the final game.

title: Data General Joins N.T.T. in Venture
description: The Data General Corporation announced an usual alliance yesterday with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the Japanese communications giant, to jointly develop a digital switching technology for sale in the United States and Japan.

title: Scientists Link an Activated Gene to Lung Cancer
description: Scientists have found evidence that a gene long associated with cancer development in laboratory experiments is activated in lung cancer tissues and, in its active state, may be a factor in development of the malignant disease.

title: Democrats Resolve Dispute With 2 States on Delegates
description: The Democratic National Committee today resolved its fierce dispute with Minnesota and South Dakota over the scheduling of their nominating contests.

title: Knicks' Bid for Green Disappoints King
description: While the Knicks continued their feverish efforts to make changes for the coming season, Bernard King said he was keenly disappointed that the first of those changes appears to have brought his once-brilliant career with the team to an end.

title: Troubled Troy Music Hall to Reopen
description: After a harrowing month that threatened not only its season but also its survival, the venerable Troy Music Hall is to reopen tomorrow night with a concert by the Albany Symphony.

title: REAGAN ADAMANT IN VOWING TO PUSH MORE CONTRA AID
description: President Reagan said today that he would fight for $270 million in renewed aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that would continue until a cease-fire is in place ''and full democracy is established.''

title: Vatican Official Assails Method Of Fertilization
description: A Vatican official told a group of medical professionals yesterday that test-tube fertilization reduces human beings to objects and degrades their ''being, value and dignity.'' But he was challenged by a leading gynecologist, a Roman Catholic who argued that the method permits devoted childless couples to have children.

title: Child Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: New Books On Herbs
description: ''For a long time, people thought of herbs only as something dry, out of a jar,'' said Pamela Lord, editorial director of the Garden Book Club. ''But now they realize they can grow them in blooming borders.''

title: The Man Under Whom the Moral Ground Shifted
description: To the Editor:

title: No Way to Treat the Homeless
description: The New York City Board of Estimate's approval of the Koch administration's proposal to build 11 transitional residences for homeless families and individuals ranks as one of the largest boondoggles in the city's recent history.

title: Basketry Becomes A Showcase Craft
description: AFTER centuries on the shelf, the humble basket is now in the spotlight. At auction houses, collectors vie for rare American Indian, Shaker and Japanese basketry; museums devote whole exhibitions to the craft, while contemporary craftsmen translate ancient basketry techniques into sculptural forms.

title: Music: 'Spectaccalo,' With Video and Sets for 'New Age'
description: ''SPECTACCALO,'' a wordless 80-minute music-video-theater piece created by Peter Gordon, composer and saxophonist, and Kit Fitzgerald, a video artist, is a downtown New York expression of what might be called ''new age'' sensibility.

title: Bill Toward 'Fire-Safe' Cigarette Is Proposed
description: A Congressman, remembering a Massachusetts family killed in a house fire caused by a cigarette eight years ago, proposed legislation today that would require tobacco companies to manufacture only ''fire-safe'' cigarettes.

title: Q&A
description: Q. As a result of an accident a board in our living room floor is badly split and warped. The floor is tongue-and-groove oak and I don't want to rip up all the boards between this one and the wall. Can I replace this one board? A. Yes. First split up the damaged board with a chisel so you can remove the pieces without damaging the boards on either side.

title: Little Wagner Has Big Hopes in Football
description: One of every six men at Wagner College plays football for the Staten Island school. That is not a ratio typical of successful programs and not just at the large Division I schools with huge student bodies but also at the Divison III level where Wagner plays.

title: Latin America Inflation High
description: Inflation rose by almost half in Latin America last spring, according to the International Monetary Fund, with annual rates topping 100 percent for the third world's three biggest debtors - Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.

title: CITY NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $3.3 million from the sale of the company's instant teller division and the sale of a leveraged lease asset for the quarter, and the 9 months includes non-recurring income of $5.4 million. c-Includes non-recurring income of $1 million and $1.1 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Hydro-Quebec, the Canadian utility, borrows often in the American bond market. Yesterday it offered $250 million of 10.70 percent bonds due in 2007 at a price of 99.106 to yield 10.81 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: City Opera: New Cast In Twin Bill
description: An alternate cast is now taking its turn at presenting the New York City Opera's version of the shabby-shocker twin bill of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' The production itself was reviewed in these pages after its premiere this past summer, and perhaps the less said about it the better. Suffice that the ensemble of singers to occupy principal roles on Tuesday evening could not overshadow its more downtrodden aspects.

title: Concert: The Royal Philharmonic
description: LONDON has more major resident orchestras than New York, but they are organized differently from the New York Philharmonic - more like the American Symphony, which is made up of freelancers who gather together with considerable but not absolute consistency from concert to concert and go off to other jobs in between.

title: Margie Inman Is Dead at 76; Walked on Wings of Planes
description: Margie Lynn Inman, who performed on the wings of airplanes in her youth and later battled local officials for the right to live in a lean-to with a menagerie of pets, has died at the age of 76.

title: Inventive Design for a Bath Showroom
description: THERE are no neatly rolled-up towels, no shell-shaped soaps spilling out of silver dishes, no huge bouquets of flowers standing next to bubble-filled tubs and no perfectly appointed scenes of dream bathrooms surrounded by landscapes of shiny ceramic tile.

title: Talking Deals; Sale of Bowery: The Debate
description: THE small group of investors that took over New York's Bowery Savings Bank have cause to celebrate. Less than two years after spending $100 million to acquire the once-troubled Bowery, the owners will double their money by selling the savings institution to H.F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles for $200 million.

title: Critic's Notebook; New York's Music Still Has Seasons
description: MUSIC critics, looking back fondly to those dear departed decades in which they enjoyed, for all practical purposes, a four-month summer vacation, can often be heard lamenting the end of the seasonal divisions of New York's musical life.

title: Curb on Eastern Bloc Envoys
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would place stringent new travel and reporting restrictions on more than 2,000 diplomats and embassy personnel of seven Soviet-bloc countries.

title: President Declares Disaster In Quake-Ravaged California
description: President Reagan today declared a major disaster in Southern California, ordering Federal aid for temporary housing and opening the way for grants and low-interest loans for reconstruction of homes and businesses.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
Smooth Transition Seen for Rockwell
description: There were no surprises yesterday at the Rockwell International Corporation as the big military contractor announced plans for changes at the top. Robert Anderson, who will be 67 years old next month, recommended to the board at a meeting in Atlanta that he step down as chairman and chief executive in February and be replaced by Donald R. Beall.

title: TV Review; A Century Of Health Research
description: ''THE HEALTH CENTURY'' finds medical research at work in different places -creating new parts for the human body, for example, or listening to the songs of male canaries. The four-part series, which marks the centennial of the National Institutes of Health, celebrates 100 years of health care.

title: Official of Suitor Gets Top Guinness Peat Post
description: Grant Adams, deputy chairman and co-founder of Equiticorp Holdings Ltd., was named chairman of Guinness Peat P.L.C. yesterday, succeeding Alastair Morton, who resigned Monday night.

title: Reagan Gets Message From Soviet on Better Relations
description: A Soviet Politburo member met with President Reagan today and conveyed what he called a ''very positive'' message from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, about potential progress in American-Soviet relations.

title: Hughes Institute Opens New Grant Program
description: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute announced $45.5 million in awards yesterday under a new 10-year program that will eventually provide $500 million for education in the medical and biological sciences.

title: Farrakhan's Group Loses Bias Lawsuit In Javits Center Case
description: A judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a lawsuit brought by the followers of the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, who had charged that the operators of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center violated the Nation of Islam's rights by refusing to rent space for a religious rally this month.

title: HBM Sells Office
description: HBM/Creamer, a subsidiary of the WCRS Group of London, is selling its Providence, R.I., office to Potter Hazlehurst of East Greenwich, R.I., effective Nov. 1. HBM/Creamer has a large Boston office and has been troubled by account conflicts with Providence. The Rhode Island office ended last year with about $17 million in billings but has had some account losses since then.

title: Computers Let a Thousand Publishers Bloom
description: Toby Rowland-Jones, a former caterer and fund-raiser, decided that the Bay Area needed a calendar of charity fund-raising events. So, about a year ago, he began to publish a magazine called Benefit using a computer in the basement of his home.

title: FRANK KLEINHOLZ
description: Frank Kleinholz, a painter known for his realistic depictions of city life and city dwellers, died Saturday in Miami Beach. He was 86 years old.

title: Dodger Doctor Busy
description: Dr. Frank Jobe, the Los Angeles-based orthopedic surgeon who performs operations on most ailing Dodger baseball players, had a busy day Tuesday at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif. He removed cartilage from the right knee of Orel Hershiser, the pitcher; from the back of the left shoulder of Dave Anderson, the shortstop; from the front left shoulder of George Hinshaw, a minor-league outfield prospect, and examined Ken Howell, the pitcher, before performing a bone scan on his right shoulder today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Mail From Farmers
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, has had some interesting reaction to his effort to limit the total subsidy farmers can get from the Government.

title: AILING F.B.I. CHIEF NEEDS MORE TESTS
description: Judge William S. Sessions, the newly confirmed Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, must undergo further tests to determine what caused intestinal bleeding that led to his second hospitalization in a week, his doctor said today.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch in Business Day on Tuesday, about opposition to the confirmation of C. William Verity as Commerce Secretary, misstated the position of Senator Robert Kasten. The Wisconsin Republican has not participated in placing the nomination on ''hold,'' and he says he does not intend to participate in any strategy to delay a final vote.

title: Bork Weighs Withdrawing Name As Reagan Aides Say Cause Is Lost
description: Administration strategists conceded today that Judge Robert H. Bork had no chance of winning confirmation to the Supreme Court, and, despite a plea from President Reagan to keep fighting, the judge told supporters he might ask for his nomination to be withdrawn before it reaches the Senate floor.

title: Devils Acquire McPhee
description: The Devils acquired George McPhee from the Winnipeg Jets yesterday for a fourth-round draft pick in 1989. The move came a week after McPhee, a 29-year-old forward, had been sent to the Jets by the Rangers.

title: Fetal Tests, Like Drugs, Need Cautious Screening; No Abortion Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Contracts Awarded On Hypersonic Jet
description: From the start, the idea has captured the imagination of aerospace scientists around the nation: an experimental craft, perhaps a successor to the space shuttle, that takes off like a plane and booms into space at hypersonic speed.

title: Brokaw Urges End To Strike
description: Warning that ''the spirit of NBC is being sapped'' by the longest strike in the network's history, Tom Brokaw and 15 other NBC news correspondents sent a letter yesterday to the president of NBC urging him to end the strike.

title: Concert: Music Today
description: MUSIC TODAY, Gerard Schwarz's series that opened its seventh season Tuesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, offers a valuable alternative to most other Manhattan new-music forums. It is certainly no wild-eyed ''downtown'' presentation. But it is also more deliberately conservative than the fiercer uptown contemporary-music groups. Mr. Schwarz has carved out a niche for himself that concentrates on reasonably accessible mainstream composers, the kind that would leap at an orchestral commission if one came their way, but also ventures occasionally toward more rigorous academics. If sometimes the selections seem more politic than passionate, the performances are usually sensibly conceived, solidly prepared and crisply executed.

title: Dance: Graham, With Stars
description: THE idea of two fellows from Leningrad being able to portray quintessential American Yankees might stretch the imagination. But that is what Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev actually pulled off Tuesday night through their first-ever joint performance in Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring.''

title: 12 Seized in Abuse Inquiry At State Psychiatric Center
description: Eleven present and one former employee at the Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn were arrested yesterday on charges of sale and possession of cocaine and marijuana or the abuse of patients.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in April 1987.

title: Mitsubishi Ruling Is Upheld
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said that a Court of Appeals in Washington had upheld a lower court ruling favorable to it in a suit brought in 1984 by the Tandon Corporation. Tandon had appealed last year's ruling by a Federal District Court in Los Angeles, which found that Mitsubishi had not infringed on Tandon's double-sided disk drive technology. Tandon said it had not decided whether to appeal the decision further.

title: 'Into the Woods' Postponed
description: The opening of the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' has been postponed. No date has been set for the new opening.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising Column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported the new position of William S. David. He has been named publisher of Sports Afield.

title: EXECUTIVE TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of assets and investments of $2,004,500 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: High Court Gets Pleas On Winans
description: The Supreme Court was urged today to uphold a disputed legal theory that has been one of the Government's most effective weapons in its crackdown against insider trading on Wall Street.

title: The Student Loan Scandal
description: Federal payments for defaulted student loans reached $1.3 billion last year. That's more than the $1.13 billion the Department of Education allotted to Head Start. In fact, it constitutes the third largest expenditure of Federal education funds. It's also a national scandal.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Bob Fosse on Sept. 24 misstated, in in some editions, his involvement with the musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' It was Abe Burrows who directed the Broadway production; Mr. Fosse choreographed it.

title: Democrats Draft Tax Changes
description: With Republicans refusing to participate, Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee began working alone today on a bill to raise $12 billion in new tax revenue to meet 1988 budget needs. Meeting behind closed doors for three hours, the Democrats tentatively approved a dozen tax changes that would meet about half of their goal.

title: Fields Decides to Rejoin Jets
description: The striking Jets suffered another serious breach to their unity yesterday when Joe Fields, the senior offensive player known respectfully as the General, rejoined the team.

title: Fetal Tests, Like Drugs, Need Cautious Screening; Miracle Tissue
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance: Eiko and Koma
description: THE collaboratively choreographed dances of Eiko and Koma have never been action-packed spectaculars. Rather, each work by these Japanese dancers has contained only a few carefully chosen images evoking the forces of nature and the struggles of life. One of the sparest of all their productions is ''By the River,'' which they presented Tuesday night at the Kitchen. Watching it, one occasionally even feared that the new, 55-minute piece would become choreographically uneventful, rather than economical. Nevertheless, the dancers' intense concentration made it ultimately compelling.

title: Tax Holiday Ending for Many Cruise Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lozano Upsets Mayotte: Jorge Lozano of Mexico upset second-seeded Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $303,400 World Championship Tennis Scottsdale Open in Arizona. Sixth-seeded Kevin Curren and seventh-seeded Eliot Teltscher both won. ''I just didn't play very well,'' said Mayotte, the 15th-ranked men's player in the world. ''I had never played Jorge before and he's very quick. He seemed to catch fire in the first set and I just couldn't break through.'' Mayotte was seeded second in last year's tournament here and also fell in the second round, losing in three sets to Sammy Giammalva Jr. Teltscher beat Jim Grabb, 6-3, 6-3, in a 77-minute match, and Curren took only 54 minutes to defeat Ricardo Acuna, 6-2, 6-2. Afternoon temperatures on the stadium hardcourts at the new Scottsdale Princess Resort approached 115 degrees for the third straight day. (AP) Second-Seeded Player Loses: Unseeded John Fitzgerald of Australia upset Scott Davis, the second-seeded player, 6-1, 6-0, yesterday in the first round of the $150,000 Queensland Open at the Brisbane Entertainment Center. Davis, ranked No. 23 in the world, lost five games on serve to Fitzgerald, a Davis Cup player, who hit winners down the line and all over the court. Top-seeded Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, took just under two hours to win his first-round match against a fellow Australian, Peter Carter, 7-6, 6-1. In other opening-round matches, John Frawley of Australia defeated seventh-seeded Gary Muller of South Africa, 6-4, 6-4; Tony Mmoh of Nigeria beat Sammy Giammalva of the United States, 6-3, 1-6, 7-5, and No. 5 Kelly Evernden of New Zealand downed Charlton Eagle of Australia, 5-7, 7-5, 6-1. In the second round, Marcel Freeman of the United States defeated sixth-seeded Peter Doohan of Australia, 6-3, 6-1; Brod Dyke of Australia eliminated his third-seeded countryman, Wally Masur, 7-6, 2-6, 6-3, and eighth-seeded Eric Jelen of West Germany turned back Darren Cahill of Australia, 6-4, 6-3. (AP) Edberg Beats Stenlund: Stefan Edberg of Sweden defeated his countryman Ulf Stenlund, 4-6, 7-5, 6-1, yesterday in the round-robin A.T.&T. Challenge in Atlanta. Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, 7-6, 6-4. Edberg, ranked No. 2 in the world, was down by 1-4 in the first set, but made the score 4-4 before Stenlund took the last two games and the set. But Edberg fought back to win the second set, winning the last two games. By the third set, Edberg was coasting, jumping to a 3-0 lead. Stenlund lost to Paul Annacone Tuesday night. John McEnroe edged Mecir, 7-5, 7-6, on Tuesday. The eight-player exhibition continues through Saturday and has a purse of $500,000, with $150,000 going to the winner. McEnroe, who has been suspended from all sanctioned events by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, is allowed to compete in exhibitions.(AP)

title: Pop: Kitaro, New-Age Music
description: KITARO, the Japanese composer and synthesizer technician, who sold out Radio City Music Hall on Monday evening, is one of the biggest stars of the ''new age'' musical movement, that broad genre of mystically inclined mood music that embraces such disparate personalities as the pianist George Winston and the Swiss electro-acoustic harpist Andreas Vollenweider.

title: Robertson Clarifies the Date of His Wedding
description: The chief spokeswoman for Pat Robertson acknowledged tonight that Mr. Robertson, a Republican Presidential candidate, and his wife were married more than five months after the date that they publicly celebrate as their wedding day and that their first child was born 10 weeks after they were married.

title: GATEWAY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All per share earnings are adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend paid on March 31.

title: RISE IN CONSUMER DEBT IS LARGEST IN 10 MONTHS
description: Americans took out $4.66 billion more in credit than they paid off in August, the biggest rise in consumer debt in 10 months, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Where Adults Play
description: WHEN they're not eating power lunches, where do some business executives go from noon till 1? To play at Burlington Antique Toys. ''We get a lot of C.E.O.'s of Fortune 500 companies that like to get away from the pressures,'' said Steve Balkin, who has owned the store for 10 years.

title: Baylor Uses Bat, Not Body
description: When Don Baylor, that 38-year-old, ambulatory brick building, came to the plate with the game on the line in the bottom of the eighth inning tonight, it wasn't too much to expect that he might try to win it not so much with his bat as with his body. It wouldn't have been the first time. The score was 5-5 in this first game of the American League championship series, and the bases were loaded with one out when Baylor was called in by the Twins' manager, Tom Kelly, to do damage. He was facing the Tigers' Willie Hernandez.

title: HERS
description: THERE are three kinds of women in the world: those who wear makeup, those who don't and those who try to look like they don't but do.

title: Rockland Tax Break Backed
description: The Rockland County Legislature unanimously endorsed in principle Tuesday a proposal to suspend the 1988 property tax by using, instead of tax revenues, a $50 million surplus accumulated in the last four years. The suspension will come up for a formal vote when the county budget is considered in December.

title: Philadelphia Electric In Dual Bond Offering
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company is offering $200 million of bonds, equally divided between 10-year and 29-year maturities. Both issues were sold competitively.

title: Still the 'Uncle' Policy
description: Good for Jim Wright, who rejects the Reagan Administration's demands on Nicaragua as ''ridiculous'' and as evidence that ''someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process'' haltingly under way in Central America.

title: Topics of The Times; A Budget Gimmick Outlawed
description: One of Congress's traditional tricks for making budget deficits look smaller has been to shift expenditures by 24 hours, so that they fall on the first day of a new fiscal year, Oct. 1, instead of the last day of the old one, Sept. 30. A year ago, for example, the Sept. 30 distribution of revenue-sharing grants to states was put over to Oct. 1. And just last week, military paychecks totaling $2 billion were issued Thursday instead of Wednesday. Guess why.

title: SHERWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,580,491 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss The company said that also recorded as income in the latest quarter were proceeeds of a Key Man Life Insurance policy in the amount of $5,765,000 resulting from the death of a corporate officer.

title: Mathura Journal; Is the Raja Ready for War, or Losing His Steam?
description: It had all the trappings of a political rally, except that the organizers insisted their cause was nonpolitical. In speech after speech, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was attacked by some of his most prominent former allies as tens of thousands of listeners applauded.

title: Special School for Special Students
description: PEOPLE have asked Neesha Nicks if she sees double, if she writes upside down, if she runs backwards when playing sports. Friends at the public school she used to attend even asked her if her dyslexia was catching.

title: New Map of Genes May Aid in Fighting Hereditary Diseases
description: Scientists have assembled a map of genetic signposts covering all 23 pairs of human chromosomes, an accomplishment that foreshadows a new era in the study of human heredity and the search for genes that contribute to many serious diseases.

title: Holly Sugar Gets $91-a-Share Offer
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation, the target of a recent series of unsuccessful takeover bids, said it had received a merger offer of $91 a share, or $102 million, from an investor group led by the Illinois financier Peter Harvey. Assuming the cash tender offer for two-thirds of Holly's shares is successful, the group, Plum Associates, proposes exchanging the remaining third of Holly's common stock for preferred shares.

title: OPEC Hints Policy Change
description: Two ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have indicated that the 13-nation group's oil price and production policy could change at its next full conference, scheduled in December.

title: Stand Up for Decency in Tibet
description: Don't be too supportive of the uprising in Tibet, the State Department insists, for it comes just as China has been easing a tradition of repression. Reacting to Congressional condemnation of Beijing, the Reagan Administration points out that too much empathy for the Tibetans and too little for China's policy will undercut that moderation. But if China's Tibet policy offends somewhat less, it continues to offend. Washington's failure to say so will surely not improve the situation.

title: Pentagon Decides Not to Send Coast Guard to Gulf
description: The Defense Department has decided not to send Coast Guard boats and aircraft to the Persian Gulf for the time being, the Pentagon said today.

title: Political Marketing; Madison Avenue Comes Back to Politics
description: Political advertising, which was lent new prestige and allure by President Reagan's campaign in 1984, is again drawing Madison Avenue image makers away from selling soft drinks and computers and into a Presidential race.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Standard Inc., a supplier of air-conditioning, heating and plumbing equipment, announced that Richard H. Francis had resigned as senior vice president and chief financial officer. James C. Huntington Jr. will replace him.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Matters; Tepid Incentive For Commuters: A $15 Subsidy
description: Drive to work and your employer can pay for your parking, tax free.

title: Monteverdi's 'Orfeo' In a Concert Version
description: The Boston Camerata will open its fourth New York season with a concert version of ''L'Orfeo'' by Monteverdi on Oct. 22 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Bechtel, Utility Set Up Venture
description: The Bechtel Power Corporation of San Francisco and the Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., said today that they had agreed to establish a joint venture to own and operate the Palisades nuclear power plant in South Haven, Mich.

title: Unesco Chief Falters in Balloting
description: Although he outpolled the eight other candidates, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose tenure as director general of Unesco has divided the organization, failed to receive a majority when the 50-member executive board voted tonight on a new leader.

title: Washington Talk: The Bork Hearings; For Biden: Epoch of Belief, Epoch of Incredulity
description: To borrow a phrase from Dickens, it has been the best of times and the worst of times for Joe Biden.

title: Glasnost as Frankfurt Book Fair Opens
description: It is common wisdom here that no one ''big book'' can dominate the mammoth Frankfurt Book Fair in the way that used to be possible before the age of instant communications.

title: MYERSON CHARGED WITH CONSPIRACY IN A DIVORCE CASE
description: Bess Myerson was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday, accused of seeking to influence the judge who presided over her companion's divorce case.

title: Consumers Held Confident
description: American consumers' confidence in the economy rose to the highest level in almost 15 years in September as people were cheered by the declining jobless rate, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Fetal Tests, Like Drugs, Need Cautious Screening
description: To the Editor:

title:
Market Place;
Stocks Face New Pressures
description: LEAD: THE stock market has been no place for the faint of heart lately. Tuesday's unprecedented 91.55-point decline in the Dow is but the latest in a series of wild swings.

title: Booklet Describes 26 Trees
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is offering a free booklet on planting trees and shrubs. The guide describes 26 trees that will grow to heights of 30 to 80 feet and have a mature spread of 12 to 60 feet.

title: Fermenting Corn Puts Grizzlies in a Stupor
description: Black bears and grizzlies are bellying up to a natural bar here and are getting drunk in the process.

title: Howard Beach Jurors Hear Divergent Views
description: With graphic detail, the prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder trial said yesterday that three black men desperately sought to flee a gang of white youths who mercilessly chased one of the blacks to his death on a busy highway and savagely beat another victim.

title: 4 Palestinians and an Israeli Killed in a Shootout in Gaza
description: Four Palestinian guerrillas and an Israeli security agent were killed in a shootout Tuesday night in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said.

title: Cruise Line to Goodby; Seagram Wines to Grey
description: There have been two account switches of national interest involving San Francisco agencies this week. Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein has boarded the Royal Viking Line, and Grey Advertising found its cup running over courtesy of the Seagram Classics Wine Company.

title: Administration Softens Medicare Appeals Plan
description: Under harsh criticism from members of Congress and advocates of the elderly, the Reagan Administration today backed away from its plan to substitute telephone hearings for face-to-face hearings in most disputes involving Medicare benefits.

title: Light Beam's Effect on Pilot Has Dissipated, U.S. Reports
description: An Air Force pilot exposed to what the Pentagon believes was a Soviet laser last week did not suffer permanent eye damage, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Democrats Clash on Foreign Policy
description: A debate here today among the six Democratic Presidential hopefuls, organized by the party to emphasize unity, turned instead into a fierce argument over military policy and over how Democrats should conduct their Presidential campaign.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: I PLEDGE ALLEGIANCE. . .The True Story of the Walkers: An American Spy Family. By Howard Blum. Illustrated. 438 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Gross Says He Sees 'No Reason to Resign'
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross said yesterday that he would not resign as the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, despite a recommendation by a mayoral advisory committee that he be replaced.

title: In Connecticut, Progress Yields To Dirt Roads
description: At nightfall, when the sun slips behind the tall maples and hickories on Long Mountain, George Clahr can amble out to the dirt road in front of his 200-year-old farmhouse and hear nothing but crickets, tree frogs and the gurgling of a nearby stream.

title: Kohl Rejects U.S. Stance
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected complaints that his country was not doing enough to spur the world's economy and warned against a ''trend toward protectionism'' in the United States Congress.

title: Music: Ursula Mamlok
description: ON Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the New York Women Composers sponsored a program of works by one of its charter members, Ursula Mamlok. Mrs. Mamlok, who has since the mid 1970s taught composition at the Manhattan School of Music, is a kind of miniaturist composer, crafting delicate, artful pieces on a small scale.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: Twins Jump in Front of Tigers; Giants Tie Series, 1-1; Twins 8 Tigers 5
description: They are young and without much experience in these kinds of games, but the Minnesota Twins did not seem shaken by their predicament tonight. On the mound, they were facing a pitcher of perfection. In the eighth inning, they were staring at a defeat.

title: REPH Debt Plan
description: The REPH Acquisition Company, which bought the Republic Health Corporation in August, said it had approved a recapitalization plan that includes itself and Republic Health. The principal purpose of the plan is to reduce the company's future cash debt service obligation through an exchange of its outstanding indebtedness for new debt and equity securities. Among other things, the plan includes a renegotiation of its $221 million bank loan to include a capped interest rate, an extended maturity date and an amended amortization schedule.

title: Rangers Set for the Moment
description: This morning, just one day before the season opener, Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager, ventured into the locker room of his club's training facility to tell the 24 players who survived camp that they had indeed made the team, and only by playing themselves off it would they lose their foothold here.

title: Jimmy Springs, Lead Singer Of the Red Caps Vocal Group
description: Jimmy Springs, who was lead singer of the Red Caps for three decades, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: Joseph B. Flavin Is Dead at 58; Lead Overhaul as Singer Chairman
description: Joseph B. Flavin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Singer Company, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. an international insurance brokerage and risk management firm, agreed to sell its Shand, Morahan & Co. division to a new corporation principally owned by Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. and Market Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Awards Group Plans National Book Week
description: The National Book Awards, a nonprofit literary and educational organization, has designated Nov. 8 to 14 National Book Week and plans readings and receptions in New York and Washington.
