Winners of awards for the best fiction and nonfiction books of the year will each receive $10,000 at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel at 8 P.M. Nov. 9.

title: Topics of The Times; How Low Is 'Low Fat'?
description: A Federal task force on cholesterol advises consumers who want to reduce the risk of heart disease to drink skim milk or milk with 1 percent milkfat. But many who find those products unappetizing choose tastier ''2 percent'' milk, also labeled ''low fat.'' How much riskier can that be?

title: Zeffirelli Told to Halt Film by Lisbon Court
description: A Portuguese court has ordered Franco Zeffirelli to stop filming scenes in Lisbon for his film ''The Young Toscanini'' because of charges of plagiarism, legal sources said today.

title: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
description: Joseph Goldstein, who taught accounting and mathematics for 36 years at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan, died of pneumonia Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 97 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Change at Negro Ensemble
description: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced this week.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 8, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Jury to Ponder Tax Shelters
description: Charles A. Atkins, the New York financier accused of engineering one of the largest illegal tax shelter conspiracies in history, was described by prosecutors yesterday as a man who descended into a ''world of fraud'' because of his own ''greed and lies.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: POLYURETHANE foam in pressure cans is a relatively recent product that home and apartment dwellers should know about.

title: CORPORATION CITES HIRING OF JACKSON
description: A national chain of business schools said yesterday that it had hired a new spokesman, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is also a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: RIGHT TO ATTORNEY IS CITED IN VERDICT
description: The constitutional right to an attorney was the crucial point that resulted in the acquittal of a teen-ager who confessed to killing four members of his family, the defense attorney said today.

title: Heart Recipient Dies
description: The Rev. John Urban, who was kept alive for nearly 11 days by an artificial heart before receiving a human heart and kidney, died after multiple organ failure Tuesday at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center of the Pennsylvania State University. He was 51 years old. Mr. Urban was the third recipient of the Penn State artificial heart. He received the donor heart and kidney on Sunday in an 11-hour operation, the first such combination surgery done at the medical center.

title: Eurotunnel Financing
description: Scandinavian banks said today that they were ready to lend $252 million to Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that wants to dig a tunnel between Britain and France. But the loan by 14 banks in Norway, Sweden, Finland and Denmark, as well as loans from other banks, depends on the outcome of a $1.21 billion public stock offering by Eurotunnel.

title: Cabaret: Anita Ellis At Ballroom
description: ''I REMEMBER radio days and wish they were back,'' the veteran pop-jazz singer Anita Ellis mused from the stage of the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, on Tuesday evening. ''I loved the privacy of it all. I could be whoever I wanted to be. This is not where I belong.''

title: Foreigners Are Facing Limit on Transplants
description: An organization of organ transplant centers has established a committee to assure that a limited number of organs will be allocated to foreigners, the panel's chairman said Tuesday.

title: INSIDE
description: Gross Says He Won't Quit Dr. Elliot M. Gross said he would not resign as the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City. Page B1. 160 Killed in Sri Lanka More than 160 people were killed in attacks by ethnic Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka. Page A8. Twins and Giants Win Minnesota won the opener of the Amer-ican League pennant playoff by rally-ing to beat Detroit, 8-5. Dave Dravecky's two-hitter beat St. Louis, 5-0, and evened the National League playoff at one victory each. Page B7. F.B.I. Chief Needs Tests Judge William S. Sessions, confirmed as Director of the F.B.I., needs more tests to find out what caused internal bleeding that led to his second hospitalization in a week. Page A19. Chief of AIDS Panel Resigns Dr. W. Eugene Mayberry, chief executive of the Mayo Clinic, quit the President's commission. The panel's vice chairman and medical staff officer also resigned. Page A18.

title: Reagan on Contras: 'Strive and Struggle'
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech to the Organization of American States today:

title: Guilty Pleas Entered by 11 In Smuggling of Marijuana
description: Eleven members of one of the nation's largest marijuana smuggling rings have pleaded guilty to drug charges and more indictments are pending, a Federal prosecutor said Tuesday.

title: House Panel Moves to Ease Restriction on Civil Servants
description: A House committee voted Tuesday for a measure that would allow civil servants to run for office and to actively take part in politics, easing stern restictions that have stood for 48 years.

title: Libya Says Political Treaty With Algeria Is Near
description: Libya and Algeria have reached agreement in principle on a treaty of political unity, Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations, Ali Treiki, said today.

title: Rock: Pink Floyd at the Garden
description: LASERS flashed. Spotlights swiveled. U.F.O.-shaped light trusses swooped across the stage. Surreal film clips lighted up a circular screen. And, incidentally, Pink Floyd played new and old songs Monday at Madison Square Garden, opening a sold-out three-night stand; the show goes to the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., Saturday through Monday.

title: 35 More Players Cross Picket Lines
description: Thirty-five more players - including some of the National Football League's top performers - broke ranks with striking teammates yesterday to rejoin their clubs in time to play this weekend's games.

title: Stocks End Mixed in Wild Day
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday in volatile trading as the market found itself trapped between buyers hunting for bargains and sellers fearful of higher interest rates.

title: Celebrating 100 Years At Pratt
description: A hundred years ago, Charles Pratt opened a school in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn to train students who were interested in design. The first class, in drawing, had 12 students.

title: B-1 EJECTION GEAR STUDIED FOR FLAWS
description: The Strategic Air Command announced today that crew ejection systems in all B-1 bombers will be inspected before each plane is allowed to fly again, suggesting that a flaw was found after a crash in which three aviators died.

title: OCE-VAN GER GRINTEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results have been converted from Dutch florins at Dfl. 2.0400 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Dole's Successor?
description: Reports on Capitol Hill have it that the White House is planning to nominate James H. Burnley 4th, the Deputy Secretary of Transportation, to succeed his former boss, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, as Secretary.

title: Daniels Fined $600
description: Lloyd Daniels, the former Nevada-Las Vegas recruit and New York City high school basketball star, has been fined $600 in Las Vegas after pleading guilty to attempting to possess rock cocaine. Prosecutors said he failed to abide by terms of a plea bargain under which charges would be dismissed if he completed a drug diversion program and did not use cocaine. He had been arrested last February.

title: AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLT INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company completed in the latest third quarter the sale of its British subsidiary, Woodville Polymer Engineering Ltd., to the Dowty Group Plc. of Great Britain for 35.9 million British pounds. The gain on the sale, net of expenses, was $40.3 million ($25.7 million after taxes); and that gain is included in both latest periods. Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months have been restated to reflect the recapitalization, treating it as if there had been an 8.3913-for-1 stock split based upon the exchange ration for shares held in the company's retirement savings plan. The company said the change in shares outstanding results from the recapitalization which took effect in October 1986.

title: Monkey Rampage Threatens Soviet Satellite
description: A monkey aboard a Soviet research satellite is creating such havoc that the mission may have to be aborted, the Soviet news agency Tass said today.

title: Stage: 'Holmes and Hands of Othello'
description: HAVING matched wits with Moriarty and other Napoleons of crime, Sherlock Holmes now attacks racism in the performing arts. At least that is one of the themes of Alexander Simmons's ''Sherlock Holmes and the Hands of Othello,'' a new melodrama at the Westbeth Theater Center.

title: Architectural Details for Table Pedestals
description: LEAD: IF you have glanced through any home magazine during the past year, chances are you have seen at least a half-dozen tables with glass tops resting on pedestals: Corinthian capitals carved in marble, ceramic columns or cast-iron griffins. Some are salvaged architectural details that are being recycled, and these are widely referred to as ''architecturals.

title: JOHN McCARTHY
description: John McCarthy, a former senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died yesterday in London, where he was undergoing treatment for cancer of the throat. He was 55 years old and had been living in Porto Ercole, Italy, since his retirement a year ago.

title: Bridge: Soviet Is One of the Holdouts In International Competition
description: The small number of countries that do not participate in international competition has diminished and is continuing to do so. Bulgaria competed this year for the first time, and the Soviet Union remains almost the only absentee.

title: Calendar; Fall Tours, Ceramics And Crafts
description: Ceramics Exhibit

title: Indonesia Coffee Quota
description: Indonesia, the world's third-largest coffee producer, said today that it was disappointed with the quota assigned to it in the accord struck Monday between coffee-producing and consuming nations. The pact, intended to limit export quotas to lift world coffee prices, assigned Indonesia a 4.75 percent share of the market. Jakarta had requested 6 percent.

title: For Spring by Armani, A Softer Approach
description: Continuing to focus on the jacket as the key to contemporary dressing, Giorgio Armani proved that fashion can be relevant without being ridiculous. Obeying the law of moderation, he raised hemlines above the knee, softened the construction of his jackets and paired them with filmy chiffon skirts. Using a pale watercolor palette, he made tailored clothes look feminine. They are womanly rather than girlish, sweet but not cloying. Nothing appeared tough or strained.

title: S.E.C. Files Brief Backing Pickens
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed an amicus brief with the Court of Appeals in San Francisco supporting an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens Jr. in its battle for control of the Newmont Mining Corporation. Newmont Mining had filed suit in Federal court in San Francisco seeking to block a tender offer by the group, Ivanhoe Partners, on the ground that the sale of $1.1 billion in ''junk bonds'' by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which would be used by Ivanhoe to purchase the Newmont shares, had not been completed when the formal bid was announced.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Communications to Tibet Cut And Foreigners Are Banned
description: Little new information was available yesterday about the situation in Tibet as telephone and telex communications were interrupted and travel there by foreigners was banned.

title: Caballe to Sing Works From Spain at Carnegie
description: The soprano Montserrat Caballe will make her only New York appearance this season Oct. 16 at Carnegie Hall, in a program devoted primarily to music from Spain. The recital begins at 8 P.M.

title: Two Roads Await Mexico's Next Chief
description: The magic that moves Mexico has worked its wonders again. A political system strained by six years of economic stagnation, high inflation and a dramatic drop in the standard of living of millions has nevertheless emerged successfully from a crucial test. For the 10th straight time in more than half a century, political power is to be transmitted peacefully and on schedule. No other Latin American country can make such a claim.

title: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4.4 million from the purchase by the Canadian Home Shopping Network of assets and subscriber base of Canadian Cable Value Network.

title: Honda Raises Acura Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company said today that prices of its 1988 Legend models would increase by an average of 4.4 percent, or $1,016 a car. The new Legend, which is sold by Honda's Acura division, ranges from $21,010 for the basic sedan to $29,127 for the LS coupe with automatic transmission. The sedan carries the new engine that was introduced in last year's coupe.

title: Equity and Law Takes French Bid
description: Compagnie du Midi, a French insurance company, appeared certain to take over Equity and Law Life Assurance Society P.L.C. after making a bid worth $:457 million, or about $750 million. The British life insurer welcomed the offer, Christopher Brocksom, its chairman, said.

title: Ansett Orders Jets As Australia Shifts
description: Australia's largest domestic carrier, Ansett Airlines, said it had ordered 27 Boeing medium-range aircraft to increase its fleet to 93. The announcement came a few hours after the Australian Government gave notice that it would move toward an ''open skies'' domestic aviation policy over the next three years, ending more than 30 years of strict regulation of the industry.

title: DESIGNERS RETHINK THE SUBURBAN GARAGE
description: LEAD: IN the eyes of many architects, the suburban house is fighting a losing battle against the attached garage.

title: Schools' Search For Chancellor Formally Opens
description: Almost two months after Nathan Quinones announced his early retirement as Schools Chancellor, the search for his replacement formally began yesterday. The Board of Education met for the first time with its advisory panel on the search.

title: Legal Group Says Bellevue Abuses Its Prison Patients
description: The Legal Aid Society has charged serious violations of prison and hospital standards in the care of jail inmates at the Bellevue Hospital Center's psychiatric unit.

title: Toll in Boat Disaster Is Estimated at 70 to 100
description: Scores of people were still missing today in the sinking of a boat loaded with Dominicans trying to enter Puerto Rico illegally. Estimates of the death toll in the Tuesday disaster ranged from 70 to more than 100.

title: G.E. Profit Rises 16.4% In Quarter
description: The General Electric Company, buoyed by strong gains in its financial services, aircraft engine and medical systems divisions, said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter rose 16.4 percent despite roughly flat sales.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Issue From Maine
description: The Maine Municipal Bond Bank is offering $59 million of revenue bonds via underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. Yields on the double-A issue range from 5.50 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 7.30 percent in 1994, 7.60 percent in 1997, 8.10 percent in 2002 and 8.60 percent in 2007.

title: Yield Rise Is Expected
description: Yesterday's increase in the prime lending rates at a number of leading banks and thrift institutions, the second rise in just over a month and the fifth this year, sets the stage for another round of yield increases for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts.

title: BRAJDAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $272,400 and $450,700 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $118,300 for the quarter and $229,500 for the 6 months.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Elusive Adjournment
description: All members of Congress would mark one date on the calendar if they could. That is the elusive date for adjournment for the year. At the start of each session, their leaders set a target date, which is rarely met. This year it was early October, but all hope for that goal was abandoned long before the summer recess.

title: Haitians Suing U.S. Over Treatment in Detention
description: A civil suit against the Federal Government in which 30 Haitian men contend that their breasts became enlarged because of their treatment in Federal detention has ended its third day.

title: Indian Rebels Out of Jungle In Nicaragua
description: Armed and uniformed soliders are a common sight in this Caribbean town, but over the weekend it was difficult to tell whether the armed men were Sandinistas or rebels.

title: JANE C. MURRAY
description: Jane C. Murray, director of communications and development for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, died of cancer of the pancreas and liver Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 48 years old.

title: Detective Is Arrested As Sexual Molester Of 2 Homeless Boys
description: A police detective was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually molested at least two 16-year-old homeless boys at his Brooklyn apartment, a police spokesman said.

title: KEY RATES
Film Festival; 'Yeelen,' Based on Myths From Mali
description: IN ''Yeelen'' a writer and director from Mali, Souleymane Cisse, re-creates the pre-modern world of the Bambara culture, where the only hint of the industrial age is the presence of a blacksmith.

title: Interest Rates Edge Upward
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers were disappointed by weaker than expected demand for new seven-year Treasury notes.

title: 5 Citadel Cadets Indicted Over Racial Hazing
description: A county grand jury has indicted five cadets at the Citadel military college on a misdemeanor charge of illegally wearing a mask in connection with the hazing of a black classmate last year, a prosecutor says.

title: 'HOROWITZ PLAYS MOZART,' DOCUMENTARY
description: SINCE his return to the American concert stage in 1985, Vladimir Horowitz has become a documentary perennial. ''Vladimir Horowitz, the Last Romantic,'' celebrated his first recital in the United States in more than two years. His much publicized visit to the Soviet Union was commemorated on television in ''Horowitz in Moscow.'' And showing tonight at 6:15 at the New York Film Festival is ''Horowitz Plays Mozart,'' a filming of his first studio recording with a symphony orchestra in 35 years.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
What Shocked Soviet In Cuban Missile Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi and Omnicom Plan Consolidations
description: Both Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi and America's Omnicom Group have announced a wee bit of consolidation.

title: U.S. Help for the Homeowner or Buyer
description: If the old homestead doesn't look quite like a castle anymore, remodeling might be the answer, or perhaps it's time to look for a new place. Either way, the Government has booklets that can help.

title: Nuveen Marketing State Bond Funds
description: Closed-end bond funds continue to proliferate, with stock offerings yesterday for $110 million of the Nuveen New York Municipal Value Fund and $180 million of the Nuveen California Municipal Value Fund.

title: 2-Year-Old Dies in Area Riven by Chilean Strike
description: A 2-year-old child was shot and killed tonight in an area where a number of protests were occurring as part of a general strike called by a labor group against the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the police reported.

title: At the Met, a Hudson Revival
description: The crowds are pouring in, and John K. Howat, the Metropolitan Museum of Art curator who organized the exhibition of paintings that is attracting them, thinks he knows why.

title: Alexander's Standstill Pact
description: Acting to quell speculation that they would compete for control of Alexander's Inc., the New York retail chain, Donald J. Trump and Interstate Properties announced a standstill agreement yesterday under which they would act jointly on expanding or selling their interest totaling 43 percent in Alexander's.

title: A Separate Workshop Might Control Clutter
description: ''I WONDER how many people keep their car in their garage,'' said Oliver Cope, an architect with David Handlin & Associates, Cambridge, Mass. ''The problem with the typical two-car garage is that half is used for the car and half for junk.''

title: Arianespace In Big Order
description: Europe's Arianespace group said today that it would order 50 of its big, new Ariane-4 rockets from suppliers to put heavy satellites into space in the 1990's, in competition with United States rocket companies. The satellite launching consortium is in a jubilant mood after an Ariane carried a payload aloft last month, ending a 15-month pause in operations after a rocket failed.

title: Dalai Lama Urges Peaceful Protest Against China
description: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual and national leader, urged his supporters today to continue their campaign against Chinese rule but to do so peacefully.

title: Falwell Groups Fined for Illegal Transactions
description: A religious corporation and a political action committee run by the Rev. Jerry Falwell have both been fined $6,000 by the Federal Election Commission because of an illegal series of transactions between the two.

title: Pressure Mounts for Action Against Radium Plant
description: Pressure mounted in Albany yesterday for action against the Radium Chemical Company, a 75-year-old supplier of the dangerously radioactive element whose factory in Woodside, Queens, has been repeatedly cited for illegal radiation emissions.

title: Shorts Riva Miniskir As New Loo For Spring
description: Everybody's talking about miniskirts here, but shorts are the big runner-up in the spring fashion race.

title: Lukas Foss to Conduct a Manuel de Falla Oddity
description: A Manuel de Falla version of Chopin? Leave it to Lukas Foss to come up with such a curiosity for the opening concerts of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's 34th season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 2.

title: Film: Baryshnikov Stars in 'Dancers'
description: ''COULD you try please to think of me as just a guy?''

title: IN DUTCHESS, ARTSCAPE WILL TRY TO MIMIC LIFE
description: As if the brilliant fall panorama were not enough, Dutchess County arts organizations plan to greet Hudson Valley explorers this weekend with a cultural extravaganza, as nature and the arts join forces.

title: Corections
description: An obituary on Sept. 26 about Richard C. Miles, a former director of McKinsey & Company, misstated his residence. It was Greenwich, Conn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The firing on the U.S. helicopter was clearly a hostile act.

title: KEY RATES
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1987
description: International A3-13, A40 Three Iranian patrol boats were sunkby American military helicopter gunships near the center of the Persian Gulf after at least one Iranian vessel opened fire on a surveillance helicopter, the Pentagon said. Page A1 The U.S. won't sell to the Saudis 1,600 Maverick antitank missiles for $360 million to insure Congressional approval of the remaining $1 billion in a pending arms-sale package. A1 Bonn is assigning three naval ships for the first time to the NATO standby force in the Mediterranean in what it termed a ''clear gesture of solidarity'' with Western forces operating in the Persian Gulf. A8 France and Britain are worried that an American-Soviet treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles might lead West Germany to agree to abolish battlefield nuclear arms under NATO command. A6 Soviet negotiators seemed to retreat in Geneva from a key compromise on a treaty to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles, according to Reagan Administration officials. A1 Poland will hold a referendum this year to seek popular backing for economic changes that could lead to belt-tightening for many Poles, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski said. A1 Nicaragua invited Washington to confer after a Central American peace plan takes effect. But President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, speaking to the United Nations, was harshly critical of President Reagan. A10 Japan will stress nuclear power in a drive for more energy independence and generate 60 percent of its electricity with reactors by the year 2030. The country's nuclear plants now generate 27 percent of its needs. A9 India will buy a supercomputer from the United States under an agreement in principle reached after New Delhi abandoned a request for a more powerful computer. D1 Chad's and Libya's war of waiting Western reporters in Tibet ousted Vienna journal Tunis hangs Moslem rebels despite death threats National A14-22, A30, A40 Liberian rules for illegal aliens toseek amnesty under the new immigration law were set by the Reagan Administration, which predicted that at least 100,000 aliens would be aided. A1 The new Secretary of Transportation nominated by President Reagan is James H. Burnley 4th, now deputy secretary. Mr. Reagan named Mimi W. Dawson, a member of the F.C.C., to succeed Mr. Burnley as deputy. A14 There was no apparent front-runner as Justice Department officials sifted names for other possible nominees amid the apparently doomed nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork for the Supreme Court. A22 News analysis: the split in the Reagan Administration between conservative ideologues and moderate pragmatists has intensified because of the apparent failure of Judge Bork's nomination. A22 The stock market retreated sharply amid worries over inflation, interest rates and next week's major economic reports. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.44 points, to 2,516.64. D1 A second researcher is infected with the AIDS virus, according to health officials. They said the laboratory worker had apparently become infected through a cut in a hand after handling highly concentrated solutions of the virus. B3 Possible health risks from dioxin in consumer paper products are relatively low in most of them, a study said. But officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said more investigation was needed. A18 One nuclear administrator should replace the five member-Nuclear Regulatory Commission, according to Senator Alan K. Simpson, the ranking Republican on the Senate Nuclear Energy Subcommittee. A16 Upholding merchant seamen in World War II, a Federal judge in Washington, Louis Oberdorfer, said the Pentagon was arbitrary and capricious in denying them military veteran status. A17 G.M. and U.A.W. reach tentative accord A14 Elkland journal A14 Falwell quits PTL ministry A14 Sessions' ailment still a mystery A14 Doubts raised about a prenatal test A19 Jackson to cancel advertising deal A21 Robertson acknowledges sowing ''wild oats'' A22 Washington Talk A20 Looking at Weinberger's stance on the Persian Gulf A Carnegie Deli in suburbia Regional B1-5, B24 The Board of Estimate in New York City faces a restructuring after a Federal appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that the board's organization violates the constitutional principle of one-man, one vote. A1 A policy on handling threats is being adopted by the New York City police. The murder of a crime witness after a death threat against her had been reported to the police prompted officials to adopt the guidelines. A1 A top city school construction official and two of his aides ran a private asbestos-removal consulting concern for seven years until they were ordered last year to end the practice as a possible conflict of interest. B1 Warning on asbestos in schools Governor Cuomo urged Democrats in New York State to back specific Presidential aspirants, even if the result was a divided delegation that would curb his leverage at the national convention. B24 A Queens woman described how she had seen a black man being severely beaten by a dozen white youths and how, after he fled his attackers, she vainly scoured the neighborhood for him in her car to help him flee. B1 Westchester's homeless would be housed for 10 years on land donated by municipalities, and the housing would then be turned over to communities, possibly for housing for the elderly, under a new plan. B1 Fall foliage colors survived in nearly every wooded area north of New York City despite Sunday's devastating snowstorm, leaving a vivid show for a day's outing in the Hudson Valley. C1 At L.I. laboratory, quiet way to discoveries B1 Inquiry on price of AIDS drug B3 Fracas erupts at Local 1199 B3 Man in L.I. patricide case gets probation B3 Zaccaro defense rests B4 Action weighed against radium plant B5

title: FALWELL QUITS, WARNING PTL MINISTRY MAY END
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell and the entire board of the troubled PTL television ministry resigned today, asserting that a ruling by a Federal bankruptcy judge had made it impossible to rebuild the ministry.

title: Victory for Conservatism
description: One of the several pleasures of writing columns is that you get thoughtful letters from all over the country. From time to time, even friends who live a few blocks away are moved to send one.

title: 'DON GIOVANNI AT 200
description: George Jellinek, the host of ''The Vocal Scene'' classical music radio program on WQXR, will present a program devoted to the 200th anniversary of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' tonight at 7:30 at Christ Church United Methodist, Park Avenue at 60th Street. The program, which is sponsored by the Vocal Record Collectors' Society, will feature excerpts from the earliest recordings of the opera to the recent and include commentary by Mr. Jellinek.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bush and the C.I.A.
description: Adm. Stansfield Turner said yesterday that George Bush in late 1976 asked President-elect Jimmy Carter if he could stay on as Director of Central Intelligence and that he promised to forgo future runs for political office.

title: 2 JOURNALISTS SENTENCED IN GREECE
description: The publisher and editor of Greece's second-biggest newspaper were sentenced to two months in prison today for printing material obtained from an illegal wiretap of the Athens bureau of The New York Times, a court spokesman said.

title: TV Weekend; 'Bretts,' Britain Between Wars, on Channel 13
description: ''MASTERPIECE THEATER'' returns this Sunday - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. - for another new season on public television. As usual, the fare is a British import and, as usual, the loyal underwriter is Mobil Oil. Actually, in this instance, the mini-series, called ''The Bretts,'' has American roots, being ''based on an idea'' by Herbert Schmertz, the outspoken Mobil executive who has been what might be called the guiding force behind ''Masterpiece Theater'' over the years.

title: Unesco Director Leads Ballot
description: In the second round of voting for a new Unesco director general, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, the group's embattled incumbent, again led the balloting, but again failed to receive a majority.

title: Sake Winery in U.S. Set
description: Kohnan Inc. a Japanese company, plans to build a $6 million winery in the Napa Valley to produce shochu, a distilled liquor made from rice, and sake, the Japanese rice wine. The project, approved Wednesday by the Napa County Planning Commission, is to be completed by September 1988.

title: 'Cannibal' Peril for G.M. Sales
description: Just about the last thing the General Motors Corporation needs these days is more ''cannibals.''

title: Memorial for an Art Dealer
description: A memorial service for John Bernard Myers, an art dealer who died July 26, will be held Thursday at 5:30 P.M. at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University, 33 Washington Place.

title: Chad's and Libya's War of Waiting
description: As Chad and Libya complete the first month of a precarious cease-fire along their border, both countries are resting, rearming and waiting.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2 million, or 7 cents a share, related to the company's second quarter special provision for possible credit losses of $85 million associated with Southeast's outstanding credits in developing countries.

title: Islanders Defeat Kings by 4-1
description: Randy Wood broke a 1-1 tie with the second goal of his National Hockey League career, and the Islanders held the Los Angeles Kings to one shot on goal in the third period for a 4-1 victory tonight.

title: Financial Corp. Bid Criticized
description: A member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that a bid made this week by the Ford Motor Company to acquire the struggling Financial Corporation of America ''is not an attractive option'' because it would cost the Government too much money.

title: Howard Beach Rescue Bid Recalled
description: A Queens woman described yesterday how she had seen a black man being severely beaten by a dozen white youths in Howard Beach and how, after he fled his attackers, she vainly scoured the neighborhood for him in her car to lead him out of the area.

title: Hewlett Offers Severance Plan
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, saying it no longer needs as many manufacturing employees, is offering a voluntary severance plan to up to 259 workers at plants in Colorado and New Jersey. The Palo Alto, Calif., company said it expects about 200 people to accept the offer, which includes payment of 6 to 12 months' worth of salary and benefits, but could handle the departure of as many as 259 employees.

title: Restaurants
description: AFTER 13 years and 50,000 chivalrous hand pecks to the ladies, Sirio Maccioni is still wowing them. A consummate impresario and choreographer, he is forever refining his international act known as Le Cirque. Like any showman riding a long-run hit, the Italian-born owner brings changes to his production ever so carefully. Those he has added in the past year, including an astonishingly versatile young chef, have boosted the restaurant's performance to four-star heights - joining the exalted galaxy that includes Le Bernardin, Chanterelle, Lutece and the Quilted Giraffe.

title: Constantine Tsatsos, Ex-Greek President And a Philosopher
description: Former President Constantine Tsatsos, a philosopher who was head of state from 1975-80, died today, his former secretary said. He was 88 years old.

title: India and U.S. Agree On Supercomputer Sale
description: India has reached an agreement in principle with the United States to buy a highly sophisticated American supercomputer after it backed away from its demand for a more powerful machine.

title: Another Man Is Slain In a Mob-Style Killing
description: A man with a police record and possible ties to organized crime was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon by two gunmen who fled in a car. The police said the killing was similar to a series of gangland-style murders in Brooklyn in recent months.

title: Tamil Rebels Said to Kill 22, Bringing 2-Day Toll to Toll to 188
description: Tamil militants today killed at least 22 people, most of them ethnic Sinhalese, as Indian peacekeeping troops fanned out to quell violence in Tamil-dominated provinces, officials said.

title: Florida Tax Deadlock
description: A special legislative session on Florida's services tax deadlocked today when Gov. Bob Martinez vowed to veto a bill that would have put the question to voters in a January referendum. Governor Martinez called a second special session on the tax just moments after the Senate voted 21 to 16 to accept a House bill. The Governor, who spearheaded passage of the 5 percent sales tax on advertising and other services in April, ordered lawmakers to resume debate in a new session Monday. Today's legislation would have watered down the tax in November and repealed it entirely as of Jan. 31 unless Floridians voted to keep the tax in a referendum on Jan. 12. The House had approved the measure by 63 to 50.

title: CHINA EXPELS WESTERN REPORTERS IN TIBET
description: Western reporters out of Tibet today after a series of independence protests over the last two weeks in which at least 14 people were killed.

title: Art: Serra Sculptures At Pace and Castelli
description: RICHARD SERRA as a sculptor can be all delicacy, all nuance, all finesse. Few things now on view in New York are as subtle as his ''Even Level'' at the Pace Gallery. It is built with two identical beams of hot rolled steel. They measure 72 inches by 8 by 4. One of them sticks out from the wall at an angle of 90 degrees and a height of 6 feet, give or take a few inches. It is, as the title suggests, perfectly level. It is suppported (or perhaps not quite supported: Mr. Serra leaves that for us to figure out) by an identical-size batten of steel that stands at a slightly irregular angle both to the wall and to the horizontal beam.

title: 5 MONTHS OF GULF CLASHES
description: Since the attack on the frigate Stark in May, there has been a series of clashes involving United States forces in the Persian Gulf . Here is a list of key incidents. May 17 - The Stark, a United States Navy frigate, is hit by two missiles fired by an Iraqi plane, and 37 American sailors are killed. Iraq calls the attack a mistake and apologizes. July 24 - The Kuwaiti supertanker Bridgeton, newly reregistered under the American flag, strikes a mine while under United States naval escort on its way to Kuwait. The ship makes port under its own power. Aug. 10 - A United States Navy F-14 is reported to have fired two missiles at an Iranian F-4 that Reagan Administration officials say was approaching a United States P-3 Orion surveillance plane keeping watch over a convoy. The rockets miss. Aug. 24 - The United States destroyer Kidd fires machine-gun bursts across the bows of two small unidentified sailing vessels after they ignore radio warnings and come within two and a half miles of four reregistered Kuwaiti tankers. The sailing vessels turn away. Sept. 21 - A United States Navy helicopter fires on an Iranian vessel, the Iran Ajr, that the Reagan Administration says was laying underwater mines 50 miles from Bahrain. Three Iranian crew members are killed and two are lost at sea.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Derek Bailey, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Free improvisation, not tied to any idiom but the connection of sound to sound, has one of its most articulate champions in Derek Bailey, an English guitarist who rarely performs here. Mr. Bailey makes his guitar generate noise rather than melody - clinks and scrapes, bongs and crackles, an occasional chord - but from those noises he builds music with its own moment-to-moment drama. He's performing this weekend with two different collaborators. Tomorrow, he'll work with Carlos Zingaro, who plays electric and acoustic violin; on Sunday, his partner will be Richard Teitelbaum on synthesizers and computer-music devices. Both concerts take place at 9 P.M.; admission is $5.

title: KOCH AND O'CONNOR MAY MAKE A VIDEO
description: He writes five newspaper columns a week, reads a weekly commentary on radio, has his own monthly television show, has been the host of ''Saturday Night Live'' and made countless cameo appearances in movies and television dramas. There has even been a musical based on his first book.

title: 6 Flags Fined $1,000 In Roller Coaster Death
description: The Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park has paid a $1,000 state fine for two safety violations in connection with the death of a roller coaster passenger June 17.

title: They Will Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night; Hitler's Idea, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Short-Term Bill Rates Jump
description: Short-term Treasury bill rates rose sharply yesterday, lifted by the market's belief that the Federal Reserve was tightening its monetary policy by yet another notch.

title: DIGITAL MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $407,000 for the quarter and $552,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Tale of Lions, Tigers and Garretts
description: When Columbia plays Princeton here tomorrow, the three Garrett brothers will be Tigers rather than Lions only through circumstances beyond their control.

title: N.F.L. TV Ratings Drop
description: The final television ratings for the National Football League games last Sunday - the first games using replacement players - showed declines of about 20 percent from the pre-strike games.

title: Walker in Role Vacated by King
description: Although Kenny Walker has been on the Knicks' roster for almost a year, he remains a considerable unknown. He was the team's first-round draft pick in 1986, a respected prospect from Kentucky who was known for his diligence and hard work. But a succession of injuries to his back and hamstring limited him to sporadic appearances last season - 68 largely forgettable games - as he struggled to cope with playing with pain.

title: Panel to Study F.S.L.I.C. Unit
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Financial Institutions, has said that the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, M. Danny Wall, will testify before the panel Oct. 15 on activities of the Federal Asset Disposition Association.

title: William McCaw, 80, Is Dead; Former Official at the U.N.
description: William McCaw, a former deputy comptroller of the United Nations, died of cancer Sept. 26 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 9, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: E-II HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $26,000,000 for both the quarter and 6 months resulting from the repayment of $800,000,000 to Beatrice Co. c-Net income Year-ago results are pro forma. The company said its interest expense increased to $41 million in the latest second quarter, ended Aug. 31, from $24 million in the year-ago quarter; the $41 million includes $8 million in non-cash interest allocated by Beatrice Co.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a restructuring charge of $3.7 million for the quarter and year.

title: Film: Caine And Field In 'Surrender'
description: JERRY BELSON, who wrote and directed ''Surrender,'' almost certainly has a better idea of what this film is about than any audience will. It may be heartfelt, but it's confused. It starts out as a satire about love and money, with Michael Caine as an unlucky-in-love celebrity author who's paying alimony and palimony too. But it then develops into a too-cute romance centering on Sally Field, who fends off her rival suitors with a snappiness Doris Day would envy. Miss Field is spunky, all right, but she's always better in more serious roles, ones that present fewer opportunities for the kind of bottom-wriggling and eye-rolling that she does here.

title: Schools Aid Left Concern Under Fire
description: A top New York City school construction official and two of his administrators ran a private asbestos-removal consulting concern for seven years until they were ordered last year to end the practice as a possible conflict of interest.

title: Film: 'Ami de Mon Amie'
description: SPECIFIC places, at specific times of year, have always been key to the methods and the manners of Eric Rohmer's splendidly singular comedies. In ''My Night at Maud's,'' the wintry, non-picturesque streets and chilly apartments of the city of Clermont-Ferrand had the effect of prompting characters to argue long into the night, as if to stay out of cold, lonely beds. The lush, midsummer Annecy countrysides in ''Claire's Knee'' were an overwhelming aphrodisiac to an otherwise rational man. In ''Pauline at the Beach,'' the sunlit crispness of the Normandy coast, at the end of the season, required that the characters stop talking around points and come to decisions before facing another autumn at loose ends in Paris.

title: U.S. SAYS COPTERS, ANSWERING SHOTS, SANK 3 IRAN BOATS 1081>
description: American helicopter gunships sank three small Iranian patrol boats near the center of the Persian Gulf tonight after at least one Iranian vessel opened fire on a patrolling helicopter, the Pentagon said. At least two Iranians were killed. The American helicopters were not damaged, and there were no American casualties, the Pentagon said. A fourth Iranian boat was thought to have escaped.

title: Pick Candidate, Cuomo Suggests To State Leaders
description: Governor Cuomo urged New York State Democrats yesterday to choose Presidential candidates to support, even if the result was a divided state delegation that would deprive him of leverage at the national convention next year.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $700,000 on assets for sale for the quarter and includes costs of $2,338,000 related to a strike for the 6 months. c-Net Income,075,678 6,455,004

title: Stealth-Project Competition Rejected
description: The Air Force has decided against opening the top-secret Stealth bomber program to wide competition, a proposal that is favored by many lawmakers, a Pentagon official said today.

title: They Will Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night; Misplaced Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: G.R.I. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $50,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: The per share earnings in the latest period reflect capital gain distribution of 50 cents a share paid in February 1987, and for the year-ago period reflects a capital gain distribution of $2.06. Assets represent net assets.

title: AWOL Pilot Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a pilot on charges of making false statements to Federal agents after flying a small plane near President Reagan's helicopter. The pilot, Ralph William Myers, 32 years old, who at the time was an Army private absent without leave, is said to have told investigators that the Aug. 13 incident occurred because he had dropped his contact lenses and could not see where he was going. The indictment contends that Mr. Myers knew he had flown into prohibited airspace.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter results include a pre-tax provision of $900,000 for estimated costs to be incurred in complying with government environmental requirements with respect to two flexible packaging properties.

title: ROBERT BENZIO
description: Robert Benzio, senior vice president and director of visual merchandising at Saks Fifth Avenue, died of AIDS last Friday at his Manhattan home. He was 50 years old.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included non-cash, one-time pretax special charges totaling $957,092,000; special charges included a writedown of oil and gas properties and a write-off of surplus railroad assets.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes one-time gains from the sale of investments of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share, and $31,358,000, or 32 cents a share, for the latest 9 months and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: The Evening Hours
description: ARMS linked, smiles synchronized, they moved with measured steps through the lobby of the Hotel Pierre to the incessant clicking of cameras, pausing before the entrance to the ballroom, turning in formation to face the photographers, smiling, smiling, Misha and Martha and Rudi and Maya choreographing their way in to dinner.

title: Art: Beuys, Palermo and Knoebel at the New Dia
description: THE new Dia Art Foundation exhibition space that goes public today should provide the New York art world with some eye-opening experiences in both the short and the long run. The short run is the present season, which is also the duration of Dia's inaugural exhibition, one that will increase local understanding of contemporary West German art. This show juxtaposes large-scale works by Joseph Beuys, who was until his death in January 1986 Europe's premier postwar artist, with those of two of his best-known students: Blinky Palermo, who died in 1977 at the age of 34, and Imi Knoebel.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter earnings includes a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $24.9 million from the settlement of certain pension obligations and the revision of certain acturial assumptions related to pension plans. The quarter also realized a pre-tax gain of $8.9 million from the sale of certain mortgage service rights.

title: As the Wheels Turn: Dueling Dugouts
description: Don't be fooled by the cowboy boots, the homespun manner, the drawl or the look of benign lassitude.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RISKS FROM DIOXIN CALLED FAIRLY LOW
description: A study of possible health risks from dioxin in commonly used paper products, made available today by the Environmental Protection Agency, suggests that the risks are relatively low in most of the products.

title: 48 Flamingos Killed By Zoo Coyote Pack
description: A ravenous pack of coyotes attacked 86 flamingos at the Los Angeles Zoo after keepers left the birds' pen open Tuesday night, and by morning only 38 birds were still alive, officials said.

title: Percussionist
description: Glen Velez, a percussionist who plays frame drums (the tambourine and its relatives), is to lead the group Handance - with Steve Gorn on Indian flute and Layne Redmond on vocals - tonight at 8 at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Admission is $10; information, 206-1050.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AUCTION announcements -especially those involving million-dollar works - have been issued with increased frequency by Christie's and Sotheby's in recent months. Christie's reported in March that it would sell a Gutenberg Old Testament from Carrie Estelle Doheny's rare-book collection on Oct. 22, a volume it expects to bring as much as $2 million. In August, the news at the Park Avenue house concerned a 64.23-carat diamond - the largest D-flawless stone ever to be auctioned. That gem is expected to bring $7 million at auction on Oct. 21.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1987
description: Markets

title: Film Festival; Boorman's 'Hope And Glory'
description: IT'S difficult to imagine anyone's remembrance of World War II as idyllic, but it's not impossible. In John Boorman's radiant ''Hope and Glory,'' the autobiographical hero is a young boy of just the right age, humor and sensitivity to savor the adventure of which he finds himself a part.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Helms's Cold Shoulder
description: Activity on the Senate floor was halted for a few minutes yesterday so that the two dozen senators present could welcome some visitors from the Soviet Union, who as members of the Supreme Soviet hold roughly equivalent jobs.

title: Lamoriello Confident After Swift Moves
description: Minutes after the end of the waiver draft by the National Hockey League on Monday, Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, expressed confidence in the players on his team.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax gain of $2.2 million from the sale of an automotive products business.

title: Edelman Will Bid For Telex
description: Asher B. Edelman, the Wall Street investor, said late yesterday that a group he heads owned 8 percent of the Telex Corporation and would offer $65 a share, or nearly $888 million, for the rest.

title: Harcourt Sale Of Units Near
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., which previously put its business publications unit and its school supply company up for sale, said yesterday that it had found prospective buyers for those operations as well as its book club business.

title: Goal Is Disallowed In Ranger Opener
description: The Rangers entered this season with a brand-new coach and an opening-night cast that featured only nine returnees from the squad that inaugurated the 1986-87 season.

title: Man Involved in L.I. Patricide Case Gets Probation
description: The boyfriend of an 18-year-old woman who was sent to jail for arranging her father's murder was sentenced today to probation for his part in the death.

title: Hellenic Festival
description: The Fourth Annual Hellenic Cultural Festival will be held from 6 to 11 tonight, and from noon to midnight tomorrow through Monday, at Public School 85 on 29th Street, between 23d Road and 24th Avenue, in Astoria, Queens. There will be a traditional taverna, serving Greek foods, as well as a pastry booth and additional stands with regional specialties. Singers, dancers, musicians and children's entertainers from Greece and New York will perform each evening. Greek-American artists will also display their paintings. The festival is sponsored by the Federation of Hellenic Societies of Greater New York. Information: (718) 335-2468.

title: Film: '3 o'Clock High,' a Showdown
description: ''THREE O'CLOCK HIGH,'' which opens today at Loews New York Twin and other theaters, is as well made as a film about a schoolyard showdown can be. It's even better made than that, which is precisely the problem. The director, Phil Joanou, has turned every shot into a portentous marvel, from the close-up view of an earring going into an ear to the 360-degree spin around the schoolyard as the nice-guy hero (Casey Siemaszko) awaits his dreaded confrontation with the mean-spirited bully (Richard Tyson). Presumably this is all part of the joke, but as jokes go it's a grim one. Too much talent, when it's brought to bear on a subject this teensy, can be worse than no talent at all.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; One Delegate's Woes
description: Politically, it has been a tough year for Dr. Michael Muftic, who, as a member of the Democratic National Committee, was in Washington this week with 2,000 other Democrats for the official start of the Presidential primary race.

title: Weekend Holidays
description: Columbus Day is Monday, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules: NEW YORK Parking: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking is suspended today and tomorrow; it is also suspended on Monday, for Columbus Day. Parade: Starts at 11:15 A.M. on Monday at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and Long Island Rail Road on regular shedule. Libraries: Closed. Schools: Closed. NEW JERSEY Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit rail and bus service on regular schedule. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Many closed. CONNECTICUT Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Closed.

title: So You Want to Appeal a Traffic Court Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Utility Suits
description: Washington's Supreme Court today ordered a trial on some aspects of bondholder suits against the Washington Public Power Supply System, its professional advisers and others involved in the system's $2.5 billion bond default on two defunct nuclear power plants.

title: A Guide to Viewing The Foliage Spectacle By Bus and Train
description: DESPITE last Sunday's devastating snowstorm north of New York City, the colors of the changing fall foliage survived in almost every wooded area, presenting opportunities for a day's outing in the Hudson Valley by bus or train, as well as by car.

title: Dart Group's Bid for Dayton
description: The Dart Group Corporation could raise nearly $8 billion to buy the Dayton Hudson Corporation if the takeover is conducted on friendly terms, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The documents said that Dart's investment banker, Paine Webber Inc., would raise financing for the deal only if Dayton's board approved the acquisition.

title: Self's Campaign Seeks A Broader Image
description: Elsewhere in the Conde Nast organization, Self magazine, under the leadership of Marianne Howatson, the company's first woman publisher, has a new campaign from its new agency, Della Femina, Udell.

title: Diner's Journal
description: COMINGS and Goings: Yvonne (Lola) Bell, the ebullient personality who was behind the Caribbean restaurant Lola at 30 West 22d Street until she left the business this summer, says she plans to open another tropical establishment, on Lexington Avenue at 62d Street, in the spring. As for the Lola-less Lola, ''the food and theme are basically the same style as before,'' said Joseph Swadley, one of the managers.

title: Broadway
description: Waiting to Go 'Into the Woods'

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUNIS HANGS MOSLEM REBELS DESPITE MANY DEATH THREATS
description: Two Moslem fundamentalists were hanged at dawn today after President Habib Bourguiba ignored appeals for a pardon and threats against Tunisian leaders if the death sentences were carried out.

title: TO COACH, ONLY GENIUSES NEED APPLY
description: The genius factor may make as much sense as anything else in examining Week 2 of replacement football.

title: Holdup Man Dies of Wound
description: A man who may have been a bank robber called the Gentleman Bandit because he usually told his victims to have a nice day died today after he was shot in an attempted bank holdup, the authorities said.

title: DFS Compton Lands Tyson
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton in New York has won a five-agency competition for the consumer advertising business of Tyson Foods, a giant chicken processing company in Springdale, Ark. The agency said the budget is about $20 million.

title: Mickey's Magazine
description: Donald E. Welch's latest entry into the kiddie magazine field will be Mickey Mouse magazine, a colorful quarterly for the 3-to-9-year-old set due out next month. It will join such Welsh Publishing Group winners as Muppet, Barbie and He-Man and the Masters of the Universe magazines and, of course, will carry advertising. A four-color page is going for $11,750 and a black and white for $9,400. That's for a circulation guarantee of 450,000.

title: Eisman, Johns & Laws Gets Canadian Club
description: Hiram Walker Inc., has decided to give its advertising for Canadian Club whisky to the Chicago office of Eisman, Johns & Laws of Los Angeles. Billings are expected to be around $7 million.

title: Dining Out Guide; New Downtown
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARQUA, 281 Church Street (334-1888) - **(April 24, 1987) Housed in a former industrial space, this minimalist TriBeCa restaurant has ocher-toned walls and Art Deco sconces and a balanced Italian menu. You might start with the cold antipasto plate of rolled veal with sweet hot mustard in aspic, roasted red peppers, onion, bean salad or grilled radicchio leaves with taleggio cheese. Pasta options -which are available in half portions -include agnolotti (spinach-filled curls in a fresh tomato sauce with mascarpone cheese), and fettuccine in a duck sauce. Main-course choices are grilled swordfish; calf's liver with onions, and chicken breast with a wine and cream sauce with olive paste and mushrooms. Main dishes $12 to $22. Fridays, noon to 3 P.m. and 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. CHELSEA TRATTORIA ITALIANA, 108 Eighth Avenue, near 16th Street (924-7786) - **(Aug. 7, 1987) The brick and whitewashed dining room is soothing, tidy and calm at this easygoing and friendly neighborhood restaurant. The menu reflects a pure and understated approach, and daily specials are offered; ingredients are unassailably fresh and pastas are authoritatively seasoned but not oversauced. Starters include mussels or clams in herbed tomato broth; half orders of pasta - cappelletti filled with vegetables in cold tomato puree; linguini with pesto sauce, and fettuccine with wild mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes. For a main dish, you might try sauteed red snapper with black olives, tomatoes, capers and white wine; sweetbreads, cooked however you prefer, and chicken breast sauteed with white wine, mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes. Entrees $10 to $19. Fridays, noon to midnight; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. RAKEL, 231 Varick Street, between Clarkson and Houston Streets (929-1630) - **(March 13, 1987) This handsome SoHo restaurant features a post-modern setting, with a cloud ceiling mural, columns and oversized tables, and an inventive menu. Appetizer choices include sauteed calf sweetbreads with jalapeno pepper sauce, topped with deep-fried spinach and champagne raisins; foie gras terrine and duck breast with black-pepper port jelly, and crab beignet with carp coulis and fresh tomatoes. Among the main dishes are marinated grilled duck breast with duck sausage, dry tomatoes, olives and basil olive oil; sauteed veal chop with caramelized shallots, and roasted lotte fish with glazed root vegetables in red wine fumee. Entrees $19.50 to $26. Fridays, noon to 2:15 P.M. and 7 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Saturdays, 7 P.M. to 1 A.M.; closed Sundays. SOFI, 102 Fifth Avenue, near 15th Street (463-8888) - **(May 22, 1987) Opened about eight months ago by Richard Lavin in partnership with Robert Baker, Sofi occupies a soaring loft space that has a rim of tables on the second story. Columns painted to resemble marble, burnt-sienna walls and brightly woven rugs enhance the decor. The menu is cross-cultural, and recommended appetizers are a salad of skate with pesto set over tomato and basil; eggplant caviar with ripe tomato confit; terrine of cassoulet with garlic croutons, and spinach linguini in amatriciana sauce. Main-course options include grilled salmon with asparagus sauce and asparagus meuniere; pan-sauteed chicken with lemon and sage, and lamb with stock sauce and eggplant-tomato-zucchini timbale. Entrees $14 to $26. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. TOMMY TANG'S, 623 Greenwich Street, between Duane and Reade Streets (334-9190) - **(Dec. 5, 1986) An East Coast version of the popular Hollywood dining spot, this unorthodox Thai restaurant occupies a moderate-size Art Deco two-level space near Battery Park City. The best of the dishes have several tastes juxtaposed. You might start with chicken sate, marinated in coconut cream laced with curry, garlic and coriander, barbecued and served with two zesty dips; Thai toast made with shrimp, pork and spices, and mee krob, which combines sweet noodles with nubbins of shrimp, pork, eggs, bean sprouts, scallions and coriander. Recommended main dishes are Thai pasta, cold spinach noodles in hot and spicy garlic-and-black-bean sauce with shards of chicken; squid rings with mint leaves and chili, and duck that has been marinated in ginger and soy and is then steamed, flash deep-fried and glazed with a sweet plum-and-sugar sauce. Entrees $5.50 to $13.50. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 6 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C26.

title: Economic Scene; The Pressures On Profits
description: TO hear Wall Street tell it, the profits of American corporations are booming. Their growth is ''nothing short of sensational,'' says Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. Numerous analysts and brokerage houses echo his enthusiasm. The superlative tossed out by David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, is ''profitflation.''

title: Goldsmith Gets Hotels
description: The John B. Coleman Company, hotel owner and operator, has assigned the Goldsmith/Jeffrey agency responsibility for the Ritz-Carlton hotels in New York and Washington, and the Whitehall and Tremont hotels in Chicago. According to the agency, billings should be about $1.5 million.

title: 'Wild Oats,' Robertson Says of Late Marriage
description: Pat Robertson, a Republican Presidential contender, said today that he had sown plenty of wild oats as a youth but that Jesus Christ had changed his life and forgiven him.

title: Why I Voted Against Bork
description: From the day in mid-July when Judge Robert H. Bork stopped by for a courtesy call until I telephoned him last week to say I would oppose his nomination, my goal was to figure out what impact Judge Bork would have on the people who came to the Supreme Court in search of their constitutional rights. At the end, having come to like and respect Judge Bork, I reluctantly decided to vote against him, because I had substantial doubts about what he would do with fundamental minority rights, about equal protection of the law and freedom of speech.

title: Burlington Plans To Sell 3 Divisions
description: Burlington Industries plans to sell three industrial fabrics divisions under a restructuring aimed at helping pay off debt incurred when it went private in a $2.5 billion leveraged buyout, the company said. Divisions to be sold have combined annual sales of $300 million and include the company's Precision Fabrics, Glass Fabrics and Industrial Fabrics divisions.

title: Taylor Appears At Striker Practice
description: Lawrence Taylor made his first appearance today at the daily informal workout held by the striking Giants, a development that was greeted with muted praise by his teammates. Leonard Marshall, who had attended several such morning exercises, did not show up, a development that was met with stony silence by his teammates.

title: Bonn's Tactical Arms Stand Worries Some NATO Allies
description: France and Britain are increasingly concerned that a Soviet-American treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles might lead West Germany to agree to the abolition of battlefield nuclear weapons under NATO command, according to senior officials in various capitals.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rothschilds to Sell Some Bank Shares
description: The Rothschild family has decided to sell a small piece of its bank in Geneva to private investors in a bid to attract talented bankers and expand the institution, Baron Edmond de Rothschild said. The offering could be worth as much as $105 million, according to officials of the Banque Privee Edmond de Rothschild S.A.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sleepy La Beef, Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, at Irving Place (777-5077). As an Arkansas farm boy, Sleepy La Beef listened to blues, gospel, and country music. After being lured to Texas by the music's siren song, he made rockabilly records in the mid-50's and hit the road, playing the clubs and bars. He's still doing it, and he seems to remember every song he's ever heard, with hot guitar licks for each one. His voice booms deeper than Johnny Cash, and his band rocks. They are playing tonight and tomorrow night around 9:30 and midnight. Admission is $10.

title: An Advance Look At the Bork Vote
description: Following is a list of Democrats and Republicans who have declared how they would vote on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork: AGAINST BORK - 53 Democrats - 48 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D.tr, DeConcini, Ariz. Dixon, Ill. Dodd, Conn. Exon, Neb. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Glenn, Ohio Gore, Tenn. Graham, Fla. Harkin, Iowa Heflin, Ala. Inouye, Hawaii tr,a01Johnston, La. Kennedy, Mass. Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Metzenbaum, Ohio Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Pell, R.I. Pryor, Ark. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W.Va. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Simon, Ill. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 5 Chafee, R.I. P ackwood, Ore. Specter, Pa.
