title: Stephen Schuetze, A Biology Professor, Is Killed by a Truck
description: Stephen M. Schuetze, an associate professor of biological sciences at Columbia University, was killed in a bicycle accident Tuesday near Payson, Ariz. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Raphael Drawings At Morgan Library
description: ''Raphael and his Circle,'' an exhibition of more than 90 drawings by the Renaissance painter and his closest followers, opens today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. The show runs through Jan. 3.

title: Proxy Fight Begins For Crazy Eddie
description: A group seeking control of Crazy Eddie Inc. is expected to mail its competing proxy statement to shareholders Friday in an attempt to oust the company's current board and replace it with its own slate of directors.

title: LARRY SPECTOR
description: Larry Spector, one of the founders of Calet, Hirsch & Spector Inc., the New York advertising agency, died Wednesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Dow Falls 34.44 Points, To 2,516.64
description: The stock market fell back sharply yesterday amid continuing worries over inflation, interest rates and the economic data due out next week.

title: Tribal Chief Acquitted In Killing of a Panther
description: The chairman of the Florida Seminole tribe was acquitted today of state charges of killing an endangered Florida panther.

title: JACKSON WILL SEEK TO CANCEL AD DEAL
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he would seek to cancel a deal he made last month to be a paid spokesman for a chain of business schools.

title: Vienna Journal; A New Yorker's Anguish in the Land of Waldheim By HENRY KAMM
description: After only 18 months as Ambassador to Austria, Ronald S. Lauder is packing his bags and his art collection and returning to New York.

title: Senate Votes to Close A New Soviet Embassy
description: The Senate, upset at both the Soviet Union and the State Department, voted today to order the Russians to move out of their new Washington embassy and rebuild it in an area where it can't be used as a base for espionage.

title: Grand House on a Small Scale
description: Miniature period houses, offering in Lilliputian scale all the details of a grand life, are always fascinating.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
They Will Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVENTUROUS PERFORMERS IN UNEXPECTED PLACES
description: THERE once was a time when musicians, dancers and actors confined themselves mainly to theaters and concert halls, auditoriums and nightclubs. But, in the age of outdoor happenings and offbeat ''performance spaces,'' performers have seemingly usurped every conceivable nontheatrical nook and cranny. And while any sunny day brings musicians and mime artists to movie lines and museum entrances, this weekend performing artists will be found in a dozen unexpected places.

title: Washington Talk: Suburbia; Pastrami, With Glitz and Politesse
description: The Carnegie Deli, the Seventh Avenue emporium whose very name evokes certain alimentary truths about New York City, has opened a branch on the edge of Washington's Beltway, in a northern Virginia suburb.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 398 money market mutual funds increased $1.82 billion, to $245.56 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 104 institutional funds were up $520.5 million, to $64.81 billion. Assets of the 201 general-purpose funds were up $1.03 billion, to $73.08 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased $273.9 million, to $107.67 billion.

title: Ford, Laden With Cash, Will Lift Dividend 33%
description: The Ford Motor Company is finally finding some uses for the large cash hoard it has been building.

title: Congress Is Again Taking Up Remolding of Nuclear Agency
description: The ranking Republican on the Senate Nuclear Energy Subcommittee proposed today that the five members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission be replaced by a single administrator.

title: Finding New Ways To Build With Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Rejects Charges Against Jersey Bishop
description: A panel of Episcopal bishops has dismissed charges that Bishop John S. Spong Jr. of Newark violated church doctrine by expressing doubts about the divinity of Jesus and endorsing premarital sex and quasi-matrimonial rites for homosexuals.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BMG Music Publishing, a unit of Bertelsmann A.G., named Nicholas Firth president.

title: Bridge: '2 Similar Sevens' Weave A Tale at Jersey Tournament
description: One of the classics of the game, ''Right Through the Pack,'' was written four decades ago by Robert Darvas and Norman de Vere Hart.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Stung by Murder, New York Police Draft Policy on Handling Threats
description: New York City police officials, shaken by the murder of a crime witness after a death threat against her had been reported to the police, said yesterday that they would adopt comprehensive guidelines for handling reported threats.

title: Michigan Star Honored
description: Jim Abbott, the University of Michigan pitcher who was born without a right hand but was an outstanding hurler for the Wolverines and for Team USA last summer in the Pan American Games, received the Golden Spikes Award yesterday as the nation's outstanding amateur baseball player. Abbott, a 20-year-old junior from Flint, Mich., who dreams of winning the College World Series with Michigan and of pitching in the 1988 Olympic Games, was honored by the United States Baseball Federation at the Downtown Athletic Club. After winning 17 of 22 decisions in his first two years at Ann Arbor, the 6-foot-3-inch, 205-pound Abbott did not allow an earned run in the Pan American Games at Indianapolis.

title: Jet Captain Details Reason for Return
description: Joe Fields, the Jets' captain, broke with his striking teammates Wednesday and crossed the picket line. Today, he spoke about his decision.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Special Delivery; Stamping Out the Stamp Lines
description: If Virginia Woolf, Sylvia Townsend Warner, Louise Bogan and Raymond Chandler - to name four splendid epistlers - had to endure what millions of Americans have had to endure just to buy a stamp, the world of literature would be the poorer by four splendid collections of letters. Rather than brave the lines at the post office, Woolf, Townsend Warner, Bogan and Chandler would probably have been plugged into their telephones, and allowed their insights to evaporate into thin air.

title: JAPAN INCREASING ITS NUCLEAR POWER
description: In a drive for energy independence, Japan plans to increase its nuclear power capacity so that by the year 2030 reactors will generate 60 percent of its electricity.

title: Washing Talk: Department of Defense; Weinberger on Persian Gulf: Cap the Chameleon?
description: A question on the minds of a number of what might be called the capital's Weinberger watchers is why the man they view as Cap the Dove on the use of United States forces in foreign engagements is acting like Cap the Hawk in regard to the Persian Gulf.

title: U.S. COURT BACKS AN ORDER TO REVISE BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a lower court ruling that ordered a change in the structure of the New York City Board of Estimate because it violates the constitutional principle of one-man, one-vote.

title: Peace Plan or Contras?
description: How does President Reagan react to the promising peace plan advanced by the five Central American governments, which calls for a regional cease-fire by Nov. 7? Mainly with stubborn anger; he'd still rather bet on the contras.

title: Twins Rock Morris and Take a 2-0 Lead to Detroit
description: When they finally gathered in their clubhouse, the Minnesota Twins seemed to be groping for the right emotions. Their evening had been full of magical moments, and it had ended when Juan Berenguer thrust his glove into the air one more time, having struck out Matt Nokes and then Chet Lemon and Pat Sheridan in the ninth inning. Each time it had been like another exclamation point for the Twins.

title: AIDS Virus Found in Second Lab Worker; Cut in Hand Cited
description: A second laboratory worker has become infected with the AIDS virus, apparently through a cut in a hand, after handling highly concentrated solutions of the virus, officials at the National Institutes of Health said today.

title: Market Place; The Setbacks In Retail Sector
description: THE recent flurry of takeover proposals in the retail industry has proved of fleeting interest to investors. The stocks of three target companies - Dayton Hudson, Zayre and Alexander's - rose on the takeover announcements but have lost value in the last few days.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday COMPOSERS LEND AN EAR

title: JOHNSTOWN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $416,000 provision for loan-loss reserves for the quarter and $956,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes provisions for loan-loss reserves of $75,000 and $393,750 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. No per share earnings were available for the year-ago period because the company went public in October 1986.

title: Stories of the City; Little Flower: Was He a Doe Or a Thinker?
description: How will Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia -perhaps New York City's most fondly remembered Mayor - be portrayed in a bronze statue that will likely be erected in Greenwich Village?

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bobby Walston, 58, Is Dead; Leading Scorer of the Eagles
description: Bobby Walston, the career scoring leader of the Philadelphia Eagles, died of a heart attack Wednesday morning. He was 58 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Twins Take a 2-0 Lead Minnesota, helped by Bert Blyleven's pitching, beat the Detroit Tigers, 6-3, in the second game of the American League pennant playoff. Page A33. Labor Accord at G.M. With no deadline in sight, the United Automobile Workers and General Motors tentatively agreed on a new three-year contract. Page A14. Bork's Backers at Odds Factions in the Administration argue over who is to blame for the evident failure of the Supreme Court nomination. News analysis, page A22. Journalists to Leave Tibet China ordered Western reporters out of Tibet after independence protests in the last two weeks in which at least 14 people were killed. Page A3.

title: LAUDNER'S NIGHT: FAR ABOVE AVERAGE
description: When Tim Laudner struck out with the bases loaded tonight in the fourth inning of the second game of the American League pennant playoff, it was not an unusual event. What Laudner did in the second inning, on the other hand, was perhaps extremely unusual.

title: At the Movies
description: Chuck Berry Self-Look

title: Memphis Mayor Wins
description: Mayor Dick Hackett easily defeated five challengers today to win a second four-year term in office. With 98 percent of the city's precincts reporting in the nonpartisan election, Mr. Hackett had 96,021 votes, as against 36,626 for his closest challenger, City Councilwoman Minerva Johnican. Ms. Johnican, who is black, had made a campaign issue of a police shooting in which four white officers killed an emotionally disturbed black man.

title: A Tribute To a Pioneer Of Folk
description: MOSES ASCH ran Folkways Records from an office cluttered with records, books and African masks and sculpture until shortly before his death in 1986. He was the company's founder and president, produced and edited recordings for release, did the sound engineering, designed the record covers, and often filled orders and answered the telephone. Somehow he found the time to talk with and encourage folk singers, jazz players, classical composers, poets, scholars, collectors and traditional musicians from around the world. Folkways and its predecessor, Asch Records, consumed almost half of Mr. Asch's 82 years. And every record Asch released stayed in the Folkways catalogue, even if it sold no more than 5 or 10 copies every decade - and some sold less than that.

title: Asbestos Study Assesses Conditions at 36 Schools
description: An environmental study of 36 New York City schools believed to be troubled by asbestos and other environmental hazards has found no conditions hazardous enough to warrant closings, but warns that closings might become needed if conditions are allowed to deteriorate, the president of the United Federation of Teachers announced yesterday.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $28,500,000 and $49,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After a gain of $10,119,000 from debt repayment. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Oct. 29.

title: Teacher at Harvard Chosen by Dukakis To Head Campaign
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today named Susan R. Estrich, a professor at the Harvard Law School, to manage his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Study Assails U.S. on Treatment of Defectors
description: A Senate study asserts that the Government has failed to interview a number of defectors from the Soviet bloc and elsewhere who could provide valuable insights about their native countries.

title: Within Administration, Two Factions Long at Odds Now Blame Each Other
description: The apparent failure of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court has touched off a Republican hunt for scapegoats. Within the Reagan Administration, two factions that have struggled for power for almost seven years - conservative purists and moderate pragmatists - have been blaming each other for days.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 27 about Gerald Adler, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, omitted a survivor. She is his sister, Ruth Travitsky, of Brooklyn.

title: Advertising; Conde Nast Magazine Casts a Net
description: CONDE NAST'S TRAVELER, which made its bow with the September issue amid a flurry of creative promotion, has got another caper up its sleeve that is novel for the magazine publishing business.

title: Rutigliano Seeks Post
description: With Doug Single taking over as the school's new athletic director, Sam Rutigliano, a former coach of the Cleveland Browns, has expressed an interest in the head coaching job at Southern Methodist University. Rutigliano, 54 years old, said that when Single was athletic director at Northwestern University, he had offered him the head coaching job. But Rutigliano said he turned it down because he did not believe he had time to put together the kind of staff he wanted. He said that he hoped Single would consider him for the S.M.U. job, but that he has not talked to him because he did not want to pressure him.

title: SESSIONS AILMENT STILL A MYSTERY
description: An intestinal examination of the newly confirmed Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, was made today but found ''nothing at all suspicious,'' his doctor said.

title: SOVIET CLUBS STEP ON OFFICIAL STAGE
description: Representatives of several unofficial Moscow political clubs took a halting step onto the official stage tonight, appearing at a news conference sponsored by a Government press-feature syndicate in an odd, sanctioned show of political independence.

title: Haitians, Too, Deserve Free Elections
description: Next month, Haiti is supposed to hold its first free presidential election in three decades. This election is the justification for the Reagan Administration's continued support of an authoritarian junta. But the danger grows that there will be no free democratic choice.

title: Poland, Planning Many Changes, Calls a Referendum on Economy
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that the Government would hold a national referendum by the end of the year to seek popular backing for several governmental and economic changes that could lead to belt-tightening for many Poles.

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect the distribution of class B common stock in August, which had the effect of a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
GEORGE R. SWIFT Jr.
description: George R. Swift Jr., a former sailboat racer for the Vanderbilts and the Morgans, died Wednesday at his home in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness. He was 68 years old. Mr. Swift, a member of the New York Yacht Club for most of his adult life, was manager of Luders Marine Construction Co. in Stamford, Conn., from 1935 until 1952. He was involved in the construction and racing of many of the best-known yachts of that period.

title: Film: 'Dogs In Space'
description: A BETTER title for ''Dogs in Space'' might have been ''Sid and Nancy Meet the Secaucus Seven.'' This is a story about 60's survivors in 1978, drugged-out musicians who look and sound as if they're straight from the 80's. The large cast of men and women live in a communal house in Melbourne, a 60's relic where garbage fills the fireplace and huge joints are passed around. Richard Lowenstein, an Australian writer and director, jumps from person to person, snippet to snippet, cuts now and then to the group's flickering television screen, and constantly overlaps music and multiple conversations. The background is energetic; too bad the foreground is just as chaotic.

title: U.S. EASES RULES ON ILLEGAL ALIENS WHO SEEK AMNESTY
description: The Reagan Administration today liberalized the rules for illegal aliens seeking amnesty under the new immigration law and predicted that at least 100,000 aliens would benefit from the change.

title: Cards Shuffle Pitching Plans
description: Danny Cox's pain in the neck, which has changed the course of the National League Championship Series somewhat, will receive an additional day of rest.

title: Added Price Seen In Bid for Dome
description: The Amoco Corporation has added about $23 million to its $3.87 billion offer to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd., a Canadian newspaper reported. A spokesman for the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of Chicago-based Amoco, would neither confirm nor deny the report.

title: Hooker Retail Names Chief
description: Michael J. Babcock, who was named president and chief executive of the Hooker Corporation's Bonwit Teller unit on Sept. 1, has taken a step up in Hooker.

title: No Sandinista Split On Peace Accord
description: To the Editor:

title: Call Trade Deficit an Economic Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Bullpens
description: The Mets let Jeff Reardon get away in a deal they would prefer to forget. The bearded relief pitcher and Dan Norman were traded in 1981 to the Montreal Expos for Ellis Valentine. But now the Minnesota Twins have Jeff Reardon after a deal with the Montreal Expos they almost let get away. And he is the primary reason why Sparky Anderson, the Detroit Tigers' manager, acknowledged that the Twins have the better bullpen in this American League Championship Series.

title: Bonn, in 'Solidarity' on Gulf, Expands NATO Naval Role
description: The West German Defense Ministry announced today that it was assigning three naval ships for the first time to the NATO standby force in the Mediterranean as a ''clear gesture of solidarity'' with the Western forces operating in the Persian Gulf.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain on a partial insurance settlement of $1,198,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $267,000. The latest quarter includes the results of Atcor Inc. since the date of its acquisition, Aug. 10. The share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: Ruling Aids Seamen Seeking Veteran Status
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Defense Department to reconsider its earlier decisions to deny veteran status to the men who sailed as merchant seamen in World War II.

title: Theater: 'El Salvador,' Drama by Rafael Lima
description: THE Cable News Network may not be thrilled to hear that it is listed in the Playbill as a former employer of Rafael Lima, the author of the new play ''El Salvador.'' The opening attraction of the Circle Repertory Company's new season, ''El Salvador'' is a bitter denunciation of television journalism as practiced by an unidentified, fictionalized network in Central America, 1981.

title: Dance: Graham's 'Canticle' Revived
description: FOR two successive nights and two galas Martha Graham's dancers had leaped and jumped, their bodies in shining gold leotards forming strange and splayed shapes in the air. One thought of mythical creatures, the flying griffins molded from the wonderful gold the ancient Scythians have left behind them.

title: DOUBTS ARE RAISED ON PRENATAL TEST
description: A new method of prenatal diagnosis may be less accurate than it has often been portrayed, according to a study and interviews with experts.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS BETWEEN RIVALS AT LOCAL 1199
description: The president of the largest hospital union in New York City was injured and hospitalized and two members of her union were arrested last night after a meeting to discuss changes in the union's bylaws erupted in a scuffle between two factions, the police said. Four other union members, all women, were also injured.

title: A BREAK FOR THE THIRD WORLD
description: WASHINGTON - A significant crack has opened in the official stance on third world debt. The major international lending agencies now admit that some very poor, very weak developing countries cannot service their debts and simultaneously resume economic growth. The agencies are asking industrial country governments to forgive debts outright, and commercial banks to accept some inevitable losses.

title: Oil Prices Turn Steady As Saudi Rumors Ebb
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products steadied on world markets yesterday in quiet trading as the oil community contemplated this week's surprising rumors that Saudi Arabia was considering selling its crude oil at discount prices.

title: SOVIET SAYS MONKEY ACTING UP IN SPACE CAN'T DAMAGE CRAFT
description: The monkey that freed it left paw and seized whatever it could aboard an orbiting Soviet spaceship cannot cause any damage, a Soviet scientist said today.

title: Surgery for Pagliarulo
description: Mike Pagliarulo, the Yankee third baseman, who led the team with 32 home runs this season, underwent successful arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove bone chips and spurs in his right elbow, the team said. The procedure was performed by Dr. John Bonamo, the Yankee physician, at New York University Medical Center. Pagliarulo is expected to begin rehabilitation in two months. . . . The Cincinnati Reds' outfielder Dave Parker, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday on his left knee. The Reds said Parker may start light rehabilitation by Monday and resume running in four to six weeks.

title: More Names Are Quietly Studied For Nomination to Supreme Court
description: There seemed to be no obvious front-runner today as Justice Department officials, outwardly vowing to fight on with Judge Robert H. Bork's apparently doomed nomination for the Supreme Court, sifted names of other possible nominees.

title: Nicaraguan, at U.N., Asks Direct Talks With U.S.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua invited the United States today to resume a dialogue with his Government after a Central American peace plan goes into effect.

title: Soviet Appears to Shun Compromise on Arms
description: Soviet arms negotiators in Geneva have surprised the American side by appearing to back away from a key compromise on a treaty to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: FILM: 'SOMEONE TO WATCH OVER ME'
description: IN ''The Duellists,'' ''Alien'' and ''Blade Runner,'' Ridley Scott earned a reputation as something of a stylist, a director whose use of striking visual and aural decoration is integral to the meaning of his work.

title: Developer Sets Venture To Expand His Business
description: For a decade, Frederick Brodsky has represented a half-dozen wealthy families from around the world on investments in the United States. Now he is broadening his business through a joint venture with Elders Finance, a leading Australian company.

title: 'Stabat Mater'
description: Pergolesi's ''Stabat Mater,'' in a performance conducted by Alberto Zedda and directed by Roberto de Simone, will be presented tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine (112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue). The performances are part of the Italy on Stage festival. Tickets: $12 and $15. Information: 662-2133.

title: G.M. and U.A.W. Reach Tentative Pact
description: Bargainers for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement on a tentative new labor contract today.

title: The Zaccaro Defense Rests Without Calling Witnesses
description: The prosecution and the defense rested their cases yesterday in the trial of John A. Zaccaro, who is accused of trying to extort money from a Queens cable television company.

title: State Studies Pricing of AIDS Drug
description: The head of the New York State Consumer Protection Board said yesterday that the board would examine whether pharmacies and the manufacturer of the only federally approved drug for treating AIDS are charging excessive prices.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Mahaffey Leads on Birdies: John Mahaffey sank long birdie putts on his last two holes yesterday to cap a five-under-par 66 and take the first-round lead in the Pensacola Open. The 16-year PGA Tour veteran had seven birdies and made putts of 30 and 20 feet on his last two holes to take a one-shot lead over Bobby Cole, Jeff Sluman, Phil Blackmar, Danny Edwards and Trevor Dodds on the 7,154-yard course at the Perdido Bay Resort. Besides his long birdies on the eighth and ninth holes, his last two holes of the day, Mahaffey also had putts of about 30 feet each for two other birdies. (AP) Tennis Kriek and an Amateur Advance: Fifth-seeded Johan Kriek and Michael Chang, a 15-year-old amateur, advanced to the quarterfinals of the Scottsdale Open in contrasting fashion yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. Chang, who upset eighth-seeded Jay Berger in Monday's first round, rallied to beat Ben Testerman, 4-6, 6-1, 6-3, in a match that lasted 1 hour 46 minutes. Kriek beat Brad Pearce, 6-3, 6-3. Chang, who is tied for 483d place in the world ranking, capitalized after Testerman, ranked 90th in the world, was penalized a point for a time violation with a 2-1 lead in the third set. Testerman never recovered his composure.(AP)

title: Suns Sign Top Pick
description: The Phoenix Suns have signed Armon Gilliam, their top pick in the collegiate draft in June and the second player chosen over all. Gilliam, a 6-foot-9-inch, 245-pound forward, is expected to contend immediately for a starting position with the Suns. He led Nevada-Las Vegas to a 37-2 record last season, averaging 23.2 points and 9.3 rebounds a game. Jerry Colangelo, the Suns' owner, said it was team policy not to reveal the terms of player contracts, but acknowledged that Gilliam's pact ''is the largest contract ever signed by a rookie with the Phoenix Suns.'' Colangelo said the contract was ''for a long period of time.'' . . . The Indiana Pacers have reached a tentative agreement with Reggie Miller, the 6-7 guard who starred at U.C.L.A. and was the Pacers' first-round draft choice. Another player to sign with the Pacers was Sean Couch, their third-round draft choice. Couch, a guard, averaged 21 points a game last season at Columbia. . . . The Washington Bullets signed Tony Campbell, the Pistons' free-agent swingman, to an offer sheet and then reached a conditional compensation agreement in exchange for Detroit's not exercising its right of first refusal, which effectively makes Campbell a Bullet.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: At Long Island Laboratory A Quiet Way to Discoveries
description: To follow Daniel Marshak through his daily life at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory is to suffer a pang of envy.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2,222,000 from reversion of the company's retirement plan. Per share results are adjusted retroactively to reflect stock splits and dividends, including the special 5 percent stock dividend paid July 8. The company said year-ago results are restated to include Central Trust Co. of Kenton County, Ky., and Oberlin Bancshares Inc., of Oberlin, Ohio, which were acquired in 1986 and accounted for as poolings of interest. The company also said the 1987 earnings benefited from increased earning assets, principally loans and leases which were up 11.8 percent over year-ago levels.

title: New AIDS Policy Proposed
description: Michigan health officials proposed today that the state collect names and addresses of the estimated 25,000 residents who have been exposed to the AIDS virus. They also said they want doctors and other health workers to notify the sex partners and those who share needles with persons testing positive, because they also may be at risk.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Gap Remains In Talks
description: For the first time in two weeks, the chief negotiators for National Football League owners and the striking players discussed the concept of free agency at the bargaining table here today.

title: FIRST FIDELITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months include a special $56 million provision taken in the 1987 second quarter for possible future loan-losses, mostly in less developed countries.

title: U.S. Withdraws Antitank Arms From Saudi Sale
description: The White House abandoned plans today to sell Saudi Arabia 1,600 Maverick antitank missiles, seeking to insure Congressional approval of the remaining $1 billion in a pending Saudi arms-sale package.

title: A Plan to House Westchester's Homeless
description: Westchester County and a not-for-profit agency headed by Andrew Cuomo, Governor Cuomo's son, proposed today a plan that would ease the county's homeless crisis while later providing housing for the elderly.

title: A Drug Against AIDS and Crime
description: It sounds like a President's dream: a way to strike powerfully against drug abuse and AIDS . . . possible to put into effect virtually overnight . . . with no need for new legislation or significant new public cost. The dream is a plan to relax rules for methadone distribution. Yet so far, the Reagan Administration hesitates to make it a widespread reality, apparently because of old arguments that have lost their force.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOLDEN ORIOLE. By Raleigh Trevelyan. 536 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $24.95.

title: Republicans in Senate Refuse to Help on Taxes
description: Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee said today that they were not yet ready to work with Democrats on tax increases to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Art People
description: Dia's Opening Night

title: New Arrest On Guinness
description: Scotland Yard said today that nine charges had been filed against Sir Jack Lyons, a business executive and financier, in connection with last year's takeover of the Distillers Company, the Scottish producer of whisky, by Guinness P.L.C..

title: About Real Estate; Princeton Project Features Open Space
description: A valuable piece of real estate -227 acres of wooded land draped over a rocky ridge that runs across northern Princeton, N.J. - has, for the last decade, seemed to defy development.

title: Wider Powers Granted Bank
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it had approved new securities underwriting powers for the First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles.

title: Pact for Fregosi
description: Jim Fregosi has been rehired with a multiyear contract as manager of the Chicago White Sox. Fregosi, 45 years old, who took over as manager June 22, 1986, after Tony LaRussa was dismissed, gave no other details of the agreement. The White Sox went 45-51 under Fregosi for the rest of the 1986 season, then posted a 77-85 record in 1987, finishing fifth in the American League West. But the club won 17 of its last 21 games. Fregosi guided the Angels to the American League West title in 1979, and has a 359-384 record as a major league manager.

title: Elkland Journal; Town Locks Out a Specter, Violence
description: Until lately, crime in this remote neck of the Ozarks had been mostly the work of a few teen-agers siphoning gasoline from a tractor or swiping watermelons from a farmer's patch.

description: Darryl Dawkins, his famed dunk shot and his sense of humor are headed for Utah.

title: Flavin's Successor Is Named by Singer
description: The unexpected death of Joseph B. Flavin has thrust William F. Schmied into the top posts at the Singer Company but he said there would be continuity of management policies.

title: REAGAN NOMINATES TRANSPORT CHIEF
description: President Reagan today nominated James H. Burnley 4th as Secretary of Transportation, declaring his rise from North Carolina trial lawyer to a member of the Cabinet in six years ''a remarkable Washington success story.''

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Year to July 25
I Think the Indians Discovered America
description: LEAD: Columbus Day has never fit comfortably among the other days of national celebration. Early in this country's history, controversy attached itself to this otherwise benign tribute to the man who is credited with ''discovering'' America. Though it took some 400 years before Columbus Day was made a national holiday, not everyone was happy once it became official.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Paris Unveils American's Statue of Soutine
description: Two of the foremost artists in Paris a half-century ago had a reunion in spirit Thursday on the same minuscule square in the Montparnasse quarter where they used to meet.

title: PITINO ACCELERATES CURRICULUM
description: They were fit, eager and curious. After three consecutive nightmarish seasons, the Knicks arrived today for their first training camp under Rick Pitino, eager to learn if the former college coach would deliver what he had promised, an all-out, aggressive style unique to professional basketball.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Palmer Leads Seniors: Arnold Palmer had eight birdies in shooting a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $250,000 Senior Challenge tournament in Roswell, Ga. Dave Hill and Buck Adams were at 67 over the par 72, 6,702-yard Horseshoe Bend Country Club course. Another shot back was Miller Barber at 68. Palmer, who has won 61 regular PGA titles and nine on the senior tour, has gone without a victory since capturing the Senior Tournament Players Championship in 1985.(AP) Colandro Ahead by a Shot: Mike Colandro of the United States, a regular on the Australian tour since 1981, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday and took the lead after two rounds in the $50,000 Queensland Open tournament in Brisbane, Australia. Colandro, who has not had a bogey in two days, has a 36-hole total of 137 and is one shot ahead of the first-round leader, Mark Nash of Australia. Nash shot a second-round 72 for a 138 score.(AP) Okamoto Sets Mark: Ayako Okamoto of Japan shot a course-record 66 yesterday to stretch her lead to three strokes midway through the $274,000 Takara Invitational golf tournament. Okamoto, the second-leading money winner on the United States L.P.G.A. tour this season with four victories, had a two-round total of 135. Jane Geddes, the third leading money winner on the L.P.G.A. tour with five victories this season, shot a 68 for 138 and was alone in second place.(AP) Tied in Japan: Graham Marsh of Australia shot a par 72 for a two-round total of 137 and retained a share of the lead with Hajime Meshiai of Japan yesterday at the halfway mark of the $411,000 Japan Open championship in Kobe, Japan. Marsh had five birdies and five bogeys. Isao Aoki, one of Japan's top golfers, shot a 68 for 138 and shared third place with countryman Saburo Fujiki, who also had a 68. David Ishii was the leading American. He was at 144 after a second-round 73.(AP) Two Share Lead: Trevor Dodds and Danny Edwards shot 67's for the second consecutive day yesterday to remain tied for the lead at the halfway point of the $300,000 Pensacola Open tournament in Pensacola, Fla. Dodds and Edwards were at eight-under-par 134, a shot ahead of John Mahaffey and Doug Tewell.(AP) Tennis Cash Upset: John Frawley of Australia upset the Wimbledon champion, Pat Cash, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Queensland Open in Brisbane. Cash, also of Australia, was the seeded No. 1. For Frawley, a wild-card entrant for the Nabisco Grand Prix event, it was his 28th consecutive victory. In another quarterfinal match, Kelly Evernden of New Zealand beat Ramesh Krishnan of India, seeded No. 4, 7-6, 6-1. John Fitzgerald of Australia also lost, losing to Eric Jelen of West Germany, 7-5, 6-3. Jelen will meet Marcel Freeman of the United States in today's semifinals. Freeman beat Brod Dyke of Australia, 6-3, 7-6. (AP)

Bork. [ 13:5. ]

title: Avis Europe Bid
description: Avis Europe P.L.C., a car rental agency, said it had made an offer for C. D. Bramall P.L.C. that values the northern England garage group at about $:94 million ($155 million). Shareholders have pledged 57.6 percent of Bramall's stock to Avis so far. Avis is offering five of its shares for every three in Bramall, valuing each Bramall ordinary share at 698 pence ($11.52). It is alternately offering 646.66 pence ($10.68) in cash for each share.

title: Mazda Export Plan
description: The Mazda Motor Manufacturing Corporation said it might export cars from its Flat Rock, Mich., plant to Japan. A spokesman said the Probe model, a car Mazda is to build for the Ford Motor Company, was being considered for distribution by Autorama, a Mazda subsidiary in Japan that specializes in Ford nameplates. The Flat Rock plant, which cost $550 million, will employ 3,500 people when it reaches peak production. Mazda became the eighth domestic automobile maker when the first car came off the Flat Rock assembly line on Sept. 1.

title: ANGRY BORK SAYS HE WILL NOT QUIT NOMINATION FIGHT
description: Judge Robert H. Bork angrily declared today that he would not ask that his nomination to the Supreme Court be withdrawn because he hoped to spare future judicial nominees the ''political campaigning'' he said had been waged against him.

description: LEAD: The Bork hearings presented a striking paradox. Though the Senate Judiciary Committee lavished its attention on Judge Robert H. Bork, Congress remains largely oblivious of the well-being of the Federal judiciary as an institution.

description: Eleanor M. Johnson, founder of The Weekly Reader, which has brought the news of the world to schoolchildren for nearly six decades, died of cancer Thursday at a nursing home in Gaithersburg, Md. She was 94 years old.

Ford's Steel Unit To Upgrade Plant
description: The Rouge Steel Company, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said it would spend more than $100 million to upgrade plant operations. The improvements will begin immediately and continue through 1988, the company said. Most of the money will go toward improving facilities and processes in the steelmaking operations, but about $7 million will be spent to convert coal-fired boilers to natural gas.

title: START OF A LIFETIME FOR STRAKER
description: The smile on his face said one thing: he was simply glad to be here. His past had been littered with injuries and disappointment, but now the rookie was finally in the big leagues, his odyssey over.

title: CARDS STRIKE LATE AND TAKE A 2-1 LEAD OVER GIANTS
description: For a while tonight, it looked as if the St. Louis Cardinals would have to settle for small consolations. In the third game of the playoff for the National League pennant, they finally stole a base, and Jack Clark finally appeared as a pinch-hitter.

title: SALOMON EXAMINING BOND UNIT
description: Faced with exceptionally stiff competition from leading New York banks, Salomon Inc. is seriously considering closing its entire municipal bond operation, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: OPERA: A NEW 'RHEINGOLD' AT THE MET
description: In this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one. Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance last evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production. If the direction and design team of Otto Schenk and Gunther Schneider-Siemssen continues along the lines of this ''Rheingold,'' the Metropolitan will have a ''Ring'' that Wagnerians can live with for a long time.

title: Large Offering Is Set by B.P
description: The British Petroleum Company said that it would issue 458.6 million new shares to be sold later this month along with the British Government's 31.5 percent stake in the company.

title: QUARTER-SHARE RESORT HOMES
description: WESLEY BROWN, a Chattanooga, Tenn., insurance broker, bought a quarter-share ownership recently at Brigantine Quarters, a resort community on Hilton Head Island in South Carolina.

title: ARGENTINA DEVALUATION RENEWS INFLATION FIGHT
description: President Raul Alfonsin's Government devalued the austral by 11.5 percent today as it prepared to begin a new drive in a two-year-old campaign against Argentina's relentless inflation.

title: Regime in Cambodia Offers Top Post to Prince Sihanouk
description: The Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia has offered a top political post to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the head of an opposition coalition recognized by the United Nations, as part of a drive for national reconciliation.

Advanced Systems is known for its interactive videotaped instruction.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
TV: 'FIG TREE' ON 'WONDERWORKS'
description: The acclaimed family-entertainment series ''Wonderworks'' returns to WNET tomorrow evening at 7 with a lovely adaptation of the Katherine Anne Porter short story ''The Fig Tree.'' Calvin Skaggs is the director and the co-executive producer, along with Patricia Perini of the Texas station KERA-TV. Mr. Skaggs's previous television credits include James Baldwin's ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.'' With ''The Fig Tree'' he is proving once again to be admirably sensitive to original source material.

title: Film: Scott Glenn in 'Man on Fire,' Thriller
description: Agents and accountants around the world must be cackling mischievously and counting up their fees: here is a thriller set and shot in Italy, with a French director and American stars. You might not expect much from this commercial contrivance, but the first line of ''Man on Fire'' is even sillier than you'd guess. Nurses and doctors run around in slow motion; someone pulls a zipper over a dead man's face; suddenly there's a voice-over from the grave: ''And so that's how I ended. A stiff in a body bag.'' Never mind that a late plot twist explains the ghostly voice; the line sets the tone for a movie that always seems about to slip into unconsciousness.

title: Carnation Settles Shareholder Suit for $13 Million
description: The Carnation Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $13 million to settle a lawsuit contending that company officials had issued false statements about negotiations when the food-products company was acquired by Nestle S.A. in 1984.

title: The Tragic Number Is 35
description: Columbia-Princeton would be just another Ivy League game, but for Columbia on Saturday, this is one last chance to avoid going into the National Collegiate Athletic Association's record book as the Division I college with the most consecutive losses.

title: Larry Phillips Is Dead at 50; Started Brooklyn Arts Center
description: Larry Phillips, the founder and director of the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center in Brooklyn, died last Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 50 years old. Mr. Phillips had pneumonia when he died. Born in Chicago, Mr. Phillips received a bachelor's degree in early childhood education from the City College of New York and studied dance for 13 years with Thelma Hill, a noted New York modern dance teacher. He was a counselor at the Bronx Psychiatric Children's Hospital, and earlier worked as a dance therapist at Our Children's Center in Brooklyn. In 1977 Mr. Phillips organized a tribute to the late Ms. Hill, out of which grew the Peforming Arts Center, which served chiefly as a producer of black dance and music programs.

The Bullets also came to terms with two veteran free agents, Michael Adams and Ennis Whately. No terms were disclosed.

title: Music: Partch's Theatrical 'Revelation' in Philadelphia

But few can claim to have actually seen one of the major works of music theater that he produced in the last decades of his life (he died in 1974).

description: A powerful explosive placed in a Volkswagen went off near a mosque in Kabul, the Afghan capital, killing 27 people and wounding 35, Radio Kabul reported today.

title: Weekend Holidays
description: Columbus Day is Monday, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parking: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking is suspended today; it is also suspended on Monday, for Columbus Day. Parade: Starts at 11:15 A.M. on Monday at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and Long Island Rail Road on regular shedule. Libraries: Closed. Schools: Closed. NEW JERSEY Sanitation: Local option. Transit rail and bus service on regular schedule. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Many closed. CONNECTICUT Sanitation: Local option. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Closed.

title: Comsat, A.T.&T. Reach Agreement

The agreement proposes to eliminate the Federal Communications Commission's role in deciding how to split transmission of A.T.&T.'s international voice traffic between A.T.&T.'s undersea cables and Comsat's network, an issue that has resulted in protracted proceedings.

In California, Truce in a Bottle Battle
description: The first truce in the two-decade war between environmentalists and the beverage industry has begun in California, and many people on both sides say it may point the way nationally to a solution to the litter problem.

title: Bonds Continue to Fall; Traders Still Pessimistic
description: Bond prices slumped further in active trading yesterday, pushing yields to their highest levels in nearly two years, as dealers remained deeply pessimistic about a wide range of economic issues.

description: It is never business as usual in the Martha Graham Dance Company as far as the audience is concerned: the eye must readjust to a conception of dance that is unlike others seen during the rest of any season.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLAND FOSTERS PRIVATE SECTOR
description: On the edge of Cracow, in a suburb called Nowa Huta, stands the immense Lenin Steel Works that 38 years ago represented a radical experiment in industrialization. In its peak year of 1979, 40,000 workers turned out 6.7 million tons of crude steel. Today, its workers number only 32,000 and its output is about 5.5 million tons.

title: Pentagon Maps Expansion Of Its Satellite Rocket Fleet
description: The Defense Department, complaining that it will be able to launch even fewer military payloads from the space shuttle than it had expected, is planning a major expansion of its capacity to launch medium and heavy satellites with its own rocket fleets, officials said yesterday.

title: 'Intolerable Position'
description: On Dec. 24, 1986, when Pat Quinn signed an agreement to become president and general manager of the Vancouver Canucks, effective June 1 of this year, he was still under contract to coach the Los Angeles Kings until May 31, 1987. John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, testified in British Columbia Supreme Court in Vancouver on Thursday that the conflict of interest created by the signing had placed his league ''in an intolerable position for this kind of business,'' and that ''Quinn had to be taken out as coach.''

description: The opening ceremonies in the world team championships take place here Saturday, with play scheduled to start Sunday. But not all those involved are accommodated at the Mallards Beach Hotel, where the games are played.

title: U.S. Says Iran Boats Hit in Gulf May Have Had American Missiles
description: The small Iranian boats that American helicopters attacked in the Persian Gulf Thursday may have been equipped with American-made Stinger anti-aircraft weapons, the Pentagon said today.

title: Irving Sets Defense and Rejects Bid

description: Ione Gaul Walker, a painter, arts patron and former art dealer, died of cancer of the throat on Monday at her home in Provincetown, Mass. She was 72 years old.

description: In a run-of-the-mill diner in New Hampshire a traveler recently asked for a cup of brewed decaffeinated coffee. And he got it. On the same trip, the customer found that menu after menu in restaurant after restaurant requested that patrons ''refrain from smoking pipes and cigars.''

description: The candidate supported by many Western nations dropped out today from the race to be Unesco's new director general.

title: A London Designer Leaves Poverty Behind
description: In conversation, Bruce Oldfield sometimes uses the royal ''we.'' This is not surprising from a fashion designer whose customer list is topped by the Princess of Wales. But it is somewhat unexpected from a man who was born, as a book he helped write puts it, ''poor, black and illegitimate.''

title: INDIA CRACKS DOWN ON REBELS DEFYING TRUCE IN SRI LANKA
description: Indian forces have gone on the offensive against the most violent of Sri Lanka's ethnic Tamil separatist groups after more than 200 people were killed in terrorist attacks, Indian and Sri Lankan officials said today.

title: AMERICAN BIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said fourth quarter losses reflect certain writeoffs taken at year-end. The increased loss for the year was due largely to non-recurring adjustments and investment necessary for future growth.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock splits in May 1987 and September 1986. The results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Philippine opposition politicians say they have reached a tentative alliance that would be ready to assume power if President Corazon C. Aquino is removed by violence or political pressure.

description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid Oct. 30.

Guatemala Peace Parley Is Over
description: Negotiations between the Guatemalan Government and rebels on ending a 25-year-old civil war broke up late today. The participants issued a statement calling the talks satisfactory, but there were no indications of progress.

title: H.R.A. Urges Using Ships as Shelters
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it was seeking proposals for ''floating shelters for homeless adults'' to be built on surplus troop ships, ocean liners, oil rigs or barges and moored at waterfront piers.

title: New Rocket for Shuttle Passes Another Trial
description: The third in a series of tests on a joint for the redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle has been declared a success by officials of Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the rocket.

title: Amid AIDS, Gay Movement Grows but Shifts
description: As gay Americans converge on Washington this weekend for a huge civil rights demonstration, leaders can point to living evidence that their movement is stronger than ever.

title: F.A.A. Fines Braniff $512,000
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had imposed a civil penalty of $512,000 against Braniff Inc. for ''operational and maintenance deficiencies.'' The airline will review the findings before paying the fine and may appeal it.

title:

description: LEAD: Two inventions regarded as useful in nuclear operations were patented this week for the Department of Energy. One automatically shuts down a nuclear reactor if the coolant liquid gets too hot.

Walking on Water
description: LEAD: Apparatus for walking on land or water was patented this week by Benjamin H. Watson of Renton, Wash. Patent No. 4,698,039 explains that the user stands on a pair of elongated floats. The floats have flaps underneath that provide propulsion when the user strides over water and fold out of the way when not needed.

description: A former Suffolk County police sergeant pleaded guilty today to charges that he tried to obtain a reduced sentence for the son of a former police official.

title: Edelman Begins Telex Offer
description: Asher B. Edelman began a $65-a-share cash tender offer yesterday for the Telex Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Tulsa, Okla., that is already about 8 percent owned by a group led by the financier.

title: Japanese Prince Visits Harlem
description: Surrounded by tinsel streamers and heavy security, the Crown Prince of Japan was honored in Harlem yesterday - a community he insisted on visiting so he could ''meet as many people from as many walks of life as possible.''

Middleweight Motion
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard, then the World Boxing Council middleweight champion, announced his retirement from the ring in May, the the middleweight crowns of all three governing bodies of the sport were vacated. Today, Michael Olajide and Frank Tate will fight for the International Boxing Federation's version of the middleweight title - the first of the three championships expected to be filled this month.

title: Clare Boothe Luce Dies at 84: Playwright, Politician, Envoy
description: Clare Booth Luce, whose richly varied career encompassed the editorship of Vanity Fair magazine, the writing of hit Broadway plays and service in Congress and as Ambassador to Rome, died yesterday morning at her home in Washington. Mrs. Luce, who was 84 years old, had been gravely ill with cancer for some time.

title: Senators Plan Tax Sessions
description: The Democratic chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said today that Democrats would begin work alone next week on tax increases to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

Steve Kuhn
description: Steve Kuhn, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Air Force Study Finds No Unusual Health Problems Among Agent Orange Handlers
description: Recent medical examinations for volunteers participating in a 20-year study have failed to uncover any unusual health problems among pilots or ground personnel who handled the defoliant Agent Orange in Vietnam, the Air Force says.

title: The U. S. Must Speak Up for Tibet
description: LEAD: The demonstrations in Tibet have not only reminded the world of that remote nation's deeply troubled existence but also underscored embarrassing deficiencies in the United States's policies toward China.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Dan Rowan on Sept. 23 incompletely described the outcome of a lawsuit brought by Mr. Rowan and his partner, Dick Martin, against George Schlatter, co-producer of their television program. Although a jury awarded Mr. Rowan and Mr. Martin $4.6 million, the decision was later overturned by the judge, Kenneth J. Gale of the California Superior Court.

title: ORTEGA VISITS THE YANKEES' BACKYARD
description: A day after he excoriated President Reagan in a fiery speech at the United Nations, Daniel Ortega Saavedra went to the South Bronx yesterday and made a firm resolution.

The quarter also realized a pre-tax gain of $8.9 million from the sale of certain mortgage service rights.

title: India Policy Shift: Tamil Conflict Poses New Risks
description: This week's sharp new violence in Sri Lanka has forced India to shift its position dramatically in the island's long ethnic conflict and side militarily with the Colombo Government. After years of sympathizing with ethnic Tamil rebels, India now appears ready to train its own guns on them.

title: FRANKFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share results are restated to reflect a 200 percent stock dividend paid in November 1986.

title: Panel Rejects Civilian Claims Of 'Black Desk'
description: Complaints that the New York City Police Department had set up a ''black desk'' and improperly monitored black political figures in the city were rejected yesterday in a report to a Federal judge in Manhattan.

title: To Fight AIDS, New York Gives Teachers Gloves
description: The New York City Board of Education, at the urging of the City Health Commissioner, is distributing 1.5 million disposable gloves to all city schools in an effort to protect teachers and other employees from contracting AIDS.

The company said included in the latest third quarter results is pretax income of $3 million from its investment in Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co.

title: 2 Men Charged in Sniper Attacks In Areas of 2 New England States
description: Two men described as best friends were charged today in a series of sniper attacks last winter on isolated homes in this area. Five people were injured in the shootings, two of them seriously.

title: Tulane Appoints Panel
description: A 16-member committee has been appointed by Eamonn Kelly, the president of Tulane University, to determine whether the university, which dropped its basketball program in April 1985 amid a scandal over gambling and violations of other rules, should resume the sport. Kelly said he hoped the committee's report would be ready by January and that its recommendation would then be forwarded to the university's senate and board of administrators. ''The board will make the final determination,'' he said.

title: TDA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After loss on disposal from discontinued operations of $136,006. c-After loss from discontinued operations of $81,158 and a loss on disposal of $378,865.

description: Three men wielding baseball bats beat a driver for a car service to death yesterday in an apparent traffic dispute on Staten Island, the police said.

U.S. QUIETLY GETS GULF STATES' AID AGAINST IRANIANS
description: The United States has quietly received significant military and intelligence support from the oil producers of the Arabian Peninsula, intended to contain Iranian threats to international shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: THIS IS KELLY'S CORNER
description: WHAT distinguishes Tom Kelly as a manager?

title: Film Festival; 'Fire From Mountain,' on Nicaragua
description: As long as ''Fire From the Mountain'' stays close to Omar Cabezas's notable book, subtitled ''The Making of a Sandinista,'' the documentary makes a forceful case in behalf of the Nicaraguan revolution. Firing off news clips that document Mr. Cabezas's vigorous prose, the movie, which plays at 6 o'clock tonight at the New York Film Festival, contrasts the poverty of Nicaragua's campesinos with the gaudy display of the Somoza set that ruled the country for decades. It rubs in the role of United States Marines in bringing the Somoza family to power and Washington's role in keeping it there. We glimpse President Nixon and Nelson Rockefeller consorting with Anastasio Somoza Debayle. The footage of Somoza's national guardsmen beating protesters and the accounts of their victims demonstrate why the guard was so hated.

title: Warhols Rising
description: Two paintings by Andy Warhol were sold Wednesday at Sotheby's in an auction of contemporary art, for prices far in excess of expectations. ''Flowers: Four Panels,'' estimated before the sale to bring up to $70,000, was sold for $220,000, and ''Portrait of Liz,'' which had a pre-sale estimate of up to $55,000, was sold for $176,000.

title: New Borland Unit
description: Borland International Inc., a personal computer software company based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said it had formed a division to develop, produce and market software for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh. Borland said the division, which will be managed by Ron Posner, vice president, sales, will cooperate closely with Apple on distributed data base and office-systems products using Apple's data communications technology.

title: SENIOR SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company went public in December 1986.

title: Newmont Ruling Deferred by Court
description: A Federal appeals court panel deferred judgment after hearing arguments about whether to block an investor group's hostile takeover bid for the Newmont Mining Corporation. Newmont is appealing a ruling that rejected its claim that the group violated Federal disclosure requirements in its $72-a-share tender offer.

title: Asia's Nuclear Danger
description: The spread of nuclear weapons capacity has been slower than most experts thought likely when the nuclear nonproliferation treaty was signed in 1968. But it has spread, largely under a veil of secrecy because the treaty created a climate of international disapproval that states prefer not to flout openly.

title: MAGRANE ENLIVENS CARDS' CAMPAIGN
description: AT the rate he was going, it appeared that it would be nothing more than a matter of time before America's introduction to Joe Magrane would be complete. There was more at stake here than merely trying to help the St. Louis Cardinals win the championship of the National League and the right to represent the league in the 1987 World Series.

title: Union Says Clubs Are Stalling Talks
description: With another weekend of games approaching and most of the National Football League's regular players still on strike, the union leadership today accused management of raising new issues at the bargaining table as a way of impeding progress in the talks.

description: After listening to arguments yesterday in Federal District Court in Newark, Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise set Nov. 23 as the date for a hearng on whether the National Basketball Association's college draft, the right of first refusal on free agency and the salary cap violate antitrust laws.

title: Florida Stiffens Gun Law
description: Gov. Bob Martinez signed a new law into effect today making it illegal to carry guns openly in Florida. The law closes a loophole in legislation liberalizing the ownership of guns, which went into effect Oct. 1. That law allowed citizens to apply for a $125 state license to to carry concealed weapons. However, the law also repealed a 19th-century law that prohibited the carrying of guns openly. That was an oversight that ''got by everyone,'' the Governor said as he signed the new law.

title: One Person, One Vote for New York

Many people don't know about it because it's hidden away between two buildings of the Fashion Institute of Technology, on 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It occurs maybe seven times a semester, with no fanfare except among students, staff and alumni of the institute.

description: WITH all the wailing about viewers not having good sports to watch because of the National Football League strike, postseason baseball seemed especially attractive this year. Viewers would be able to fill the empty hours, confident in being able to block out reality with pure pleasure.

title: Buyer Is Sought For Executive Life
description: The First Executive Corporation said it is seeking a buyer for its Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, which analysts estimate could bring between $600 million and $900 million. In March, the unit was fined $250,000 by New York regulators, who disallowed $151.5 million in reinsurance contracts, under which insurers pass on some risks to other carriers. First Executive was ordered to make a cash infusion of an equal amount, prompting speculation about a sale. As of June 30, Executive Life accounted for 20 percent of the parent company's assets of $15.5 billion.

title: HAIR DRYER SAFETY STANDARDS
description: THE numbers have been in for some time. From 1977 through 1986, 172 people in the United States were electrocuted after hair dryers that were turned off fell into bathtubs or sinks. Most were small children.

description: Verdi Square leads a double life: by day, an outdoor community center for West Side residents; by night, a refuge for drug dealers and homeless people.

title: Charge in Reagan Incident
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a pilot on charges of making false statements to Federal agents after flying a small plane near President Reagan's helicopter. The pilot, Ralph William Myers, 32 years old, who at the time was an Army private absent without leave, is said to have told investigators that the Aug. 13 incident occurred because he had dropped his contact lenses and could not see where he was going. The indictment contends that Mr. Myers knew he had flown into prohibited airspace above Mr. Reagan's ranch in the mountains near Santa Barbara.

Such a rise suggests that insiders aware of Mr. Murdoch's plans might have bought shares before the announcement.

title: Withdrawal Agonies in Afghanistan
description: Mikhail Gorbachev continues looking for a relatively painless way out of Afghanistan, just as Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon looked for a way to escape Vietnam. He wants to leave without seeming to abandon a vulnerable client regime. Thus Soviet diplomats talk about forming an interim regime including Afghanistan's former King, and with non-Communists holding half the cabinet posts. They also talk about United Nations peacekeepers to monitor compliance with a U.N.-brokered peace as 120,000 Soviet troops return home.

Puzzle of Gangland-Style Killings Eludes Brooklyn Police
description: When John Otto Heidel, a convicted forger and reputed associate of organized crime groups, was shot to death on a Brooklyn street Thursday evening, he became at least the 10th man to be killed in a gangland-style attack in the borough this year.

title: NEW MILFORD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Attack Case Lawyers Hint Three Men Were Unsavory
description: The defense lawyers in the Howard Beach murder trial began building their case yesterday that the three black men involved in the incident were unsavory people who had touched off the confrontation with several white teen-agers.

HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $170,000, or 6 cents a share, arising from reduction of tax rates on previously-deferred income.

title:
PATENTS;
Transferring Ink In Gravure Printing
description: LEAD: A Patent was issued this week on the transfer of ink in gravure printing. Patent No. 4,697,514, assigned to the Gravure Association of America, was granted to two staff members, Harvey F. George and Robert H. Oppenheimer.

title: HERITAGE FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Ministers Stumble; Jesse Jackson's Profit, and Loss
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has taken great pains this year to project himself as a serious candidate for the Presidency. But the disclosure this week of his endorsement contract with a chain of business schools raises a serious question about the judgment of this minister who would be President.

title: These 'Warhead' Were Duds
description: ''The War of the Worlds'' it wasn't. But listeners to police radio scanners got a shock yesterday when they heard an officer in Brooklyn report that he had found a ''possible nuclear warhead in a privately owned truck.''

title: FIRST BANCORPORATION OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

PATENTS;
Motorized Baby Swing
description: LEAD: A long-running, motor-driven baby swing was patented this week for the Quaker Oats Company of Chicago. The inventor named in patent No. 4,697,845 is Gordon W. Kamman. He is an engineer for Fisher-Price, a Quaker Oats subsidiary in East Aurora, N.Y., which manufactures the swing. The apparatus has a seat that supports a baby in various reclining positions.

title: Tishman's Global Strategy
description: Jerry I. Speyer, chief executive of one of the oldest and most respected real estate companies in New York, has quietly shifted his attention away from the city that made his family rich.

title: Ellen Reasoner Is Wed to a Chef
description: Ellen Reasoner, a daughter of Harry Reasoner of Westport, Conn., and the late Kathleen Carroll Reasoner, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Larrabee, a son of Mary Louise Larrabee of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Rockwell John Larrabee 3d. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport.

title: BELMONT PAIR HARD TO BEAT
description: Who is the bigger cinch at Belmont Park today, Java Gold in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup or Groovy in the $200,000 Vosburgh?

title: Jetliner Carrying 64 Just Misses Small Plane Outside Los Angeles
description: An American Airlines twin-engine jet reported that it missed a small private plane by just 50 feet shortly after taking off from Ontario, Calif., around noon yesterday, according to a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title:
PATENTS;
Protecting Aircraft From Lightning
description: LEAD: A device to protect aircraft from damage by lightning has been invented by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Charles F. Bryan Jr. of the agency's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., was awarded patent No. 4,698,723 this week.

title: DS BANCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: OHIO STATE TO AID BLACKS IN SCHOOLS
description: Ohio State University is following the lead of the New York philanthropist Eugene Lang by reaching out to black sixth-graders to assure they finish high school and go on to college.

description: IN the beginning, in 1973, there were Alex and Louisa Hargrave, a young couple extolling the wonders of the soil and climate of the Island's North Fork as the ideal place to grow quality grapes and produce fine wine.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DESIGN
description: LEAD: Le Corbusier Directed by Carlos Vilardebo. Kartes Video Communications. 46 minutes. $14.95.

title: BRISTOL FIGHTS PARK CLOSING
description: DESPITE the football strike, Bristol did some Monday morning quarterbacking last week, analyzing a surprise announcement that a Pennsylvania-based company was closing the 141-year-old Lake Compounce amusement park. Meanwhile, city officials responded to the withdrawal by revoking the company's tax breaks and tallying up a bill of $250,000.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Burlington, Vt.: Land Trust Cuts Housing Costs
description: LEAD: MARY CROTEAU and her husband, Chris, were living in a two-bedroom apartment with their three children and had little hope of finding anything better in a city that officials say is suffering from an acute housing shortage.

title: Bias Charge Upsets Manhattanville Campus
description: A complaint by a black student that he was assaulted verbally and physically at Manhattanville College two weeks ago has become a focus of attention on this suburban campus.

title: Correction
description: A caption last Sunday in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified a landmark in San Francisco's financial district. The pyramidal tower is the headquarters of Transamerica Corporation. The Bank of America World Headquarters, which includes the Carnelian Room restaurant, is a 52-story polished granite slab.

title: Amy L. Donovan Wed at Harvard
description: At the Memorial Church at Harvard University, Amy Louise Donovan, the daughter of Lee S. Donovan of New Canaan, Conn., and James R. Donovan of West Harwich, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Michael Bender 3d, a son of Suzanne D. Scolamiero of Scituate, Mass., and Mr. Bender Jr. of New York. The Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Donald Bossart, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: White House Looks Beyond Bork In Setting Aims for Senate Debate
description: In the wake of Judge Robert H. Bork's surprise decision to remain a candidate for the Supreme Court, White House officials say they are scrambling to devise a strategy not for winning confirmation of Judge Bork but for putting Democrats on the defensive and paving the way for the next nominee.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST MAN. By Maurice Blanchot. Translated by Lydia Davis. (Columbia University, $20.) First published in France in 1957, this intriguing narrative by the eminent French novelist and critic Maurice Blanchot is set in a hospital or sanitarium in which an anonymous narrator and a young woman watch ''the professor,'' an older man on the brink of death.
