description: Diane Joyce Slaine, the daughter of Sull Slaine and Nathalie Schlager, both of Peabody, Mass., was married last evening to Joel Marc Siegel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Siegel of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Miami Beach. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky and Cantor Jacob Mendelson performed the ceremony at the Temple Israel Center in White Plains.

title: Boston College Holds Off Army
description: Army ran out of time when a pass fell incomplete in the end zone at the final gun, and heavily favored Boston College hung on for a 29-24 victory today.

title: The Rising Market In Educating Executives
description: LEAD: THIS MONTH, the faculty and staff at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School will celebrate the grand opening of the Steinberg Conference Center, an on-campus, $23 million complex that includes a health club, 100 guest rooms and scores of personal computers. Yet nary a Penn undergrad will venture into the plush facility, because this sophisticated setting was designed and built to assure that Wharton gets its fair share of the droves of

title: CRIME
description: Time was when private eyes were anything but thinking men. Their brains resided in their fists, just as the brains of so many pianists are located in their finger tips. Today things are different. Most private eyes are depicted as sensitive plants, with emotional problems just like ours. They spout philosophy. They ruminate. They love the music of Mahler. They identify with the criminals. They have more self-doubt than Hamlet, and they cry all over the pages.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SEPARATE PASTS: Growing Up White in the Segregated South. By Melton A. McLaurin. (University of Georgia, $13.95.) ''As one of Wade's 'best whites,' '' Melton A. McLaurin writes, ''I was expected never to 'behave badly' toward blacks.'' The place is Wade, N.C., a village with many poor whites and many more poor blacks.

title: Free Tickets
description: The hottest tickets in town have cooled off considerably since the players strike led National Football League clubs to assemble replacement teams of dubious quality. In Denver, where Bronco games have been sellouts since 1971, the club's community relations director, Charlie Lee, came up with a way to avoid acres of empty seats at Mile High Stadium when the Broncos take on the Los Angeles Raiders tomorrow night. At Lee's suggestion, the Broncos have given away 6,000 tickets to high school students in Colorado.

title: Q & A
description: Tenancy of a Spouse Question: When my wife and I were married some 20 years ago we moved into a rent-controlled apartment that was in her name. My name was never added to her lease and since the apartment was rent controlled no subsequent lease was ever sent.

title:
DINING OUT;
MAJOR CHANGE ON PALMER SQUARE
description: LEAD: PRINCETON's venerable Nassau Inn has seen many changes over its 50 years on Palmer Square, but a major one was its recent takeover and renovation by the Omni hotel group.

title: Stamford Becomes State's Venture Capital Capital
description: WITH fewer than 105,000 residents, the city of Stamford, in southwestern Connecticut ranks fifth in terms of the state's population. But when it comes to cash, it ranks first. Of $1.3 billion in venture capital available in Connecticut, for instance, $1 billion of it is in Stamford, which ranks fourth in the nation in terms of venture funds.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls inside my house are covered with rough-sawn knotty pine. Because of some leaks, the wood along the bottom is stained dark in an irregular pattern that looks like a stock market graph. The leaks are cured, but the stains remain. How can I remove them?

title: Sara Jackson, an Actress, Weds Stephen DiLauro
description: Sara Rose Jackson, a daughter of Arthur L. Jackson of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Annette Womack Jackson, was married yesterday to Stephen DiLauro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Ferrin DiLauro of Clinton Township, N.J., and Panama City Beach, Fla.

title: Home Runs Win for Giants and Tigers; Leonard's Blast In 5th Inning Ties Series, 2-2
description: Jeffrey Leonard made playoff history tonight when he hit his fourth home run in four games and led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory that squared their series with the St. Louis Cardinals at two games apiece.

title: Michael Schmidt Weds Miss Castle
description: Carolyn Ann Castle and Michael Ottmar Schmidt were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith and the Rev. Kermit Morrison, a United Methodist minister who is the bride's cousin.

title: Ms. McCollum Has Wedding
description: At the Princeton University Chapel, Cynthia McCollum, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wayne McCollum of Etna, N.H., and John Thomas Spellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spellman Jr. of New Bern, N.C., were married yesterday by the Rev. William K. Fuller, an Episcopal priest.

title: TURKISH ELECTION IS UNDER JEOPARDY
description: A Turkish court has ruled that part of the country's new election procedure is unlawful, jeopardizing a general election scheduled in three weeks.

title: Corn Harvest Is Bounty and Burden
description: From the top of the huge concrete bins of the Albert City Elevator Company in northwest Iowa, combines can be seen this in the fields as the harvest of the most expensive corn crop in the history of Federal farm programs gets under way here and around the country.

title: MORE FROM FRANCE IN GREENWICH
description: CAN Greenwich support yet another French restaurant? Yes, when that establishment has the authority of the new C'est Si Bon.

title: FICTION
description: ALL MY TRIALS. By John William Corrington. (University of Arkansas, Cloth, $22.95; Paper, $10.95.) ''Shreveport is not a contemporary city to me; it is a . . . transparency through which I can see to an overarching past,'' confesses the narrator of this brace of skillfully constructed novellas. He is Albert Sidney Johnston Finch, a recent widower and a retired Louisiana judge whose nostalgic vision of his hometown makes clear the route that John William Corrington (the author of ''Shad Sentell'' and other novels) has chosen to follow here. Largely bypassing the new South of apartment complexes and the rootless souls who inhabit them, Mr. Corrington focuses on the Southern writer's traditional concerns of myth, memory and sense of place. In the first and longer piece, ''Decoration Day,'' Judge Finch is reluctantly drawn into the case of a childhood friend, an elderly black man who refuses to accept a belated Medal of Honor, earned 30 years earlier in the Battle of the Bulge. As the judge reconstructs what really happened to his embittered friend, he finds he can put his own troubles behind him to become involved once more. The second novella, ''The Risi's Wife,'' is a tale within a tale: the judge passes a night listening to an attorney friend spin a ''shaggy divorce story'' about a young streetcar conductor whose war experiences in the Far East transform him into a Risi (a seer) who is unable to adjust to postwar married life in Shreveport. Unabashedly supernatural, ''The Risi's Wife'' shares with ''Decoration Day'' a concern with the past and how one learns to live with it. Both works also demonstrate the writer's skill in creating overlapping plots, which occasionally seem to dovetail too neatly. Nonetheless, we are left feeling we have overheard two good stories well told.

title: GARDENER WITH A CAUSE
description: THE Nepperhan Vegetable Gardens - a community gardening project in Yonkers organized by Murray Bodin under the sponsorship of the Yonkers Rotary Club and the city's Parks, Recreation and Conservation Department - was given support last Tuesday by the visit of Paul Winkeller, the coordinator of the three-month-old State Office of Community Gardens.

title: Clothing and Crafts in Cairo
description: Cairo's exotic Khan el Khalili bazaar is an obligatory stop for visitors, but not necessarily the best place to spend money. Crowded, cluttered and chaotic, it is a bit like the old New York store S. Klein-on-the-Square, a place where customers must pick through mounds of junk before finding something worth taking home.

title: WORLDS OF SISTERHOOD
description: LEAD: SEX AND POWER The Rise of Women in America, Russia, Sweden, and Italy. By Donald Meyer. 721 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $35.

title: U.S. AND NASSAU STUDY A PHENOMENON: GREEN TIDE
description: IT was a routine Tuesday on Long Island's beaches, when suddenly a deafening noise drowned out the rhythmic sound of the waves against the beach.

title: Next Week; Should The Knicks Try to Keep King?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: WILLIAM B. BERGEN
description: William B. Bergen, a retired aerospace executive, died Friday at his home in St. Michaels, Md., of cancer of the lung and esophagus. He was 72 years old.

title: Pop Music
description: William Bolcom's musical recipe calls for a dash of almost every conceivable ingredient - gospel, jazz, blues, folk, reggae, 18th-century Baroque, 19th-century Romanticism - and out of this stew, the composer fashions expressive works that cross the bounds separating classical and popular idioms. Mr. Bolcom has been best known for his original cabaret songs and for his recordings at the piano accompanying his wife, the mezzo-soprano Joan Morris, in assorted American songs from the turn of the century.

title: Christopher M. Lieberman Weds Marta Grace Lopez
description: Marta Grace Lopez, a daughter of Rosa Cespedes of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Santiago, the Dominican Republic, and Juan Lopez of New York and Puerto Plata, the Dominican Republic, was married yesterday in Westfield, N.J., to Christopher Michael Lieberman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jason H. Lieberman of Yonkers.

title: Visiting Relative
description: Many a president and prime minister on a state visit to Washington would envy the agenda arranged for Deng Pufang, who dropped by the Capital last week for a casual look around. On his list of things to do, Mr. Deng, son of the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, had visits with President Reagan, Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz as well as dinners, luncheons and chats with a slew of the nation's most powerful Senators. Why the high level treatment for an ''unofficial'' visitor? Part of it had to do with Mr. Deng's work as head of the China Fund for the Handicapped - Mr. Deng is a paraplegic -but mostly it was the old Washington business of signal-sending. ''It is well known that Mr. Deng is close to his father,'' a State Department official explained, and the White House wanted his treatment ''to reflect the Administration's high regard for Deng Xiaoping.''

title: PUTTING IT INTO ECONOMIC PERSPECTIVE
description: ''CRAFT and business'' is frequently discussed, but rarely from the viewpoint of how crafts fit into the overall economy.

title: Computer Fails As Job-Killer
description: EVER SINCE computers were first installed in offices and factories, workers have feared that they were in danger of being replaced. Now there are worries that computers aren't replacing humans fast enough.

title: IRAN PANEL DRAFT GETS TONED DOWN
description: Conservative members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair have secured major changes in an early draft report that compared the affair to the Watergate scandal and described a ''cover-up'' within the Reagan Administration, according to Congressional officials.

title: Rome Synod Is Focusing on Women's Rights
description: The need to correct discrimination against women in the Roman Catholic Church has emerged as a major theme of a Synod of Bishops meeting here on the role of lay Catholics.

title: SUMMER TRAVEL REPORT: AIRLINES WERE LESS LATE
description: AFTER all the gloomy predictions that heavy summer traffic would cause an increase in flight delays, a report last week by the Federal Aviation Administration came as a surprise. Having peaked in June, the number of delays caused by bad weather and air-traffic control problems was down 24 percent in July through September, compared with a year ago; for September the decrease was 41 percent.

title: WHY ONE WOMAN WILL FORGO THE MINI
description: WITH frenetic ballyhoo, as though the concept were entirely new, the fashion industry has introduced its ''new look'' - a rerun of abbreviated skirts. The fashion-obsessed faithful have flocked to the couture showings, applauded their favorite designers and stampeded to buy their styles, price no object. The fashion reporters, whose jobs depend on how enthusiastically they adapt to change, have welcomed the latest designs with their usual hyperbole, including the indiscriminate use of the adjective ''sexy,'' that ultimate insult to those of us who value our womanhood. And of course, store buyers have no choice but to follow the lure of profit.

title: AN ESCALATING WAR OF WORDS OVER NICARAGUA
description: IN his three-day visit to New York last week, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua evinced the air of a man watching events play out to his satisfaction.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls inside my house are covered with rough-sawn knotty pine. Because of some leaks, the wood along the bottom is stained dark in an irregular pattern that looks like a stock market graph. The leaks are cured, but the stains remain. How can I remove them?

title: Horse Laughs Last
description: THE horse, a pacer known as Dewey Dynamo, had managed only 1 victory in 21 starts and had been ill for a month with a mysterious ailment. So when it came time for the third race at Freehold Raceway in New Jersey Friday night, his owner-driver, Jim Pfeiffer, didn't bother to waste $2 on a futile bet. He knew the horse didn't have a chance, and so did just about everybody else in the crowd of 2,200. In fact, out of a betting pool of $8,763, only $24 was bet on the Dynamo, which meant that a lot of people were quite surprised when Dewey crossed the finish line first, returning $604 for a $2 bet to win. The 302-to-1 payoff was the largest in Freehold history.

title: African National Congress Dominated by Communist Party
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAILING GRADE FOR THE PRESENT TENSE
description: PAULINE experienced many perils, but none to compare with the perils of the present tense. She was tied to tracks, left to teeter on window ledges, allowed to hang from cliffs by the lace in her pantaloons. Yet in the week while we waited for her bloomers to rip or the train to come, time held its breath as we held ours -in serial suspension; that is, we calmly ignored the pause in her plight as we went about our business, placing our modest cares in a parenthetical phrase; because, when the lace on her undies relaxed at last, when the train's hoot grew cruelly closer, or when Pauline's delicate balance seemed to have slipped beyond refooting, then her peril continued as if there had never been an interruption, not a shiver was missing, or a screech from a scream; and, in order to reassure us of this, the second episode would reprise the conclusion of the first, and so on, right through the fearful 15.

title: In Nicaragua, a Cease-Fire Decree Brings a Nervous Peace for Some
description: For the first time in the Nicaraguan conflict, Sandinista and rebel troops today held positions within shooting distance of each other, but did not attack.

title: CHICKEN FAT AND ALL
description: I REMEMBER it was 2 A.M. I had just come home from a date and was very thirsty. Everyone was sleeping. I opened the refrigerator and saw this glass of orange juice. I gulped two fast swallows and realized this was not orange juice, but unsettled chicken fat my mother had placed in the ''icebox'' after cooking chicken.

title: At Car Rental Companies, the Owners Come and Go
description: TRYING to get a fix on the $9 billion-or-so car rental industry is like carving an ice statue on a hot day. You can do it - but it's not going to hold its shape for long.

title: TWINS GAIN INSIGHTS ON THEIR FATHER
description: THREE years ago, when Carol and Elaine Anthony presented their first show as a tribute to their father, they were surprised at the response. But since then, the show has become a tradition, both for them and for viewers who find it helps them to feel close to their own fathers.

'LEAF PEEPERS' SET SIGHTS ON LITTLE VILLAGE
description: LEAD: WEST CORNWALL is a quiet village during the week, with a few shops and restaurants clustered around one of the last covered bridges in the state.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ISSUES IN THE RESTORATION OF VICTORIANA
description: LEAD: THE issue of authenticity versus boutique esthetics in the choice of Victorian exterior colors is one of the liveliest concerns confronting preservationists and property owners these days.

title: Minority Enrollment
description: To the Editor:

title: Hussein Postpones Election For New Jordan Parliament
description: King Hussein, opening a new session of Parliament, said today that he was postponing elections to the lower house for two years.

title: hOW AN ORCHESTRA FELL SILENT: POSTLUDE
description: FROM Claudio Arrau to Pinchas Zukerman, the great musical artists of the world appeared regularly with the White Plains Symphony Orchestra, which was founded in 1961 as the Music for Westchester Symphony Orchestra. Now the 25-year legacy has ended. Less than two weeks before what should have been next Saturday's opening concert, a terse press release announced that the board of directors, ''with regret,'' had voted to cease operations. The official reason: ''funding from the community has failed to keep pace with rising costs.''

title: Connecticut Official May Challenge Weicker
description: Connecticut Democrats, searching for a candidate to challenge United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. next year, have found a likely prospect in Joseph I. Lieberman, the State Attorney General.

title: Dance: A Multimedia and Multilevel Event at Grand Central
description: FANTASTIC. The Woodstock of the Eighties? ''Grand Central Dances'' - a mammoth multimedia dance event staged in the nooks and crannies of Grand Central Terminal, on the vast expanse of its main concourse, within the walkways of its huge tiered windows and even in the air - just a few feet below the station's cavernous ceiling - will certainly remain a night to remember.

title: Massachusetts AIDS Mailing
description: The state has begun mailing a booklet describing how to avoid AIDS to every household in Massachusetts. The booklet explains, in English and Spanish, what the disease is and how it spreads: through sexual contact and the sharing of infected hypodermic needles. It also urges parents not to keep the facts from their children. The mailing began last week.

title: Still a New Yorker
description: The case of Guarini vs. New York may have lacked the emotional impact associated with courtroom custody battles, but it was undeniably a monumental dispute. It ended last week when the United States Supreme Court denied a claim by two Garden State politicians that New Jersey, not New York, should have sovereignty over Liberty Island and the statue thereupon of Miss Liberty. Representative Frank J. Guarini and former Jersey City Mayor Gerald McCann argued that New Jersey should have domain over Liberty and Ellis Islands because the islands in Upper New York Bay are only 2,000 feet from their state but more than 10,000 feet from New York. Without comment, the court rejected their claim. Otherwise, it might have had to give them nearby Staten Island as well.

title: VOTERS HAVE WIDE CHOICE ON JUDGES
description: VOTERS in the county will fill the largest number of Supreme Court vacancies in the history of the Ninth Judicial District when they go to the polls in November.

title: COUNCIL FOR ARTS EXPECTS 600 AT AIRPORT
description: LEAD: FROM a concert by the opera star Roberta Peters to a tour of the Reader's Digest art collection, the galas to benefit the Council for the Arts in Westchester have enlivened the county's social and philanthropic scene. This year, for the 10th annual fund-raising event, the council has reserved space at the Westchester County Airport and dubbed the evening ''Soaring!

title: BACK HOME IN CAROLINA
description: A SOUTHERN FAMILY By Gail Godwin. 540 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Local Law 9; Court's the Battlefield Over S.R.O. Rules
description: NO outward sign identifies the parking lot and the handful of dilapidated buildings around it on the midblock between 33d and 34th Streets west of Eighth Avenue as a stage for legal hostilities.

title: OLD-TIME HOOFERS COMING TO 2 COLLEGES
description: LEAD: CHARLES ''COOKIE'' COOK rehearsed the ''Military Drill'' in his baseball cap.

title: The Job Outlook Across the Nation; NORTHWEST
description: A HOT DEMAND for jobs has risen in the Pacific Northwest in the wake of the push to clean up hazardous-waste dumps and base waste consulting companies there. Also encouraging this search for technicians, scientists, geohydrologists and biological engineers is the expectation that Washington State will soon pass stiff laws governing toxic materials. Job-search companies say the lack of experienced people is putting upward pressure on salaries.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Light His Fire
description: LEAD: THE DOORS, LIVE AT THE HOLLYWOOD BOWL Jim Morrison (in photo) and the Doors. MCA Home Video. 65 minutes. $24.95.

description: Dublin, Limerick, Killarney, Galway and even the oft-maligned Cork all possess signal Irish charms.

title: Steven Forbis, Editor, Weds Leslie Laurence
description: The marriage of Leslie Laurence and Steven Forbis took place yesterday at the Trattoria Pietro & Vanessa in Manhattan. Criminal Court Judge Richard Lowe 3d officiated.

title: Home Runs Win for Giants and Tigers; DETROIT RALLIES AFTER LOSING A 5-0 LEAD
description: A half hour went by, but Jeff Reardon did not move. He sat alone in the trainer's room, his mind still occupied with the eighth inning and the home run that had landed somewhere in the upper deck. He watched its flight for only a moment, and then he turned away quickly.

title: Open Up the U.N. Archives on Nazis
description: In Paris, a candidate for the French presidency asserts that the Nazi gas chambers were ''a historical footnote.'' In London, a new play says the Holocaust was a joint conspiracy of the Zionists and Nazis. In New York City, an institute for ''historical review'' distributes publications that ''prove'' that the destruction of European Jewry is a fabrication of Zionist propaganda. In established universities in the West, doctoral dissertations are being written to bolster these contentions. Forty years after the Holocaust, within the lifetime of many of its victims, we are witnessing an accelerating effort to distort, deny and dismiss the greatest crime in the annals of man.

title: Home Design Preview; MODERN TOUCHES
description: A NEW KIND OF MODERN furniture will be making news this fall at the Southern Furniture Market, this country's largest furniture exposition.

title: Rock Music
description: This Tuesday, Tom Waits, the strongly theatrical composer-performer-actor, makes his Broadway concert debut at the Eugene O'Neill Theater (230 West 49th St.). When Mr. Waits burst onto the Los Angeles pop scene in the early 1970's, he brought a strong flavor of Beat poetry to the confessional singer-songwriter mode. Singing in a raspy, heartfelt voice, he identified with a world of socially marginal outsiders bravely struggling to hold onto their romantic dreams. Had Mr. Waits moved in the same direction as his musical peers, he might have become a mainstream rock star. Instead, in he has delved ever more deeply into his vision of downtrodden loners.

title: HE'LL ALWAYS BE WHO HE USED TO BE
description: WANDERER SPRINGS By Robert Flynn. 340 pp. Fort Worth: Texas Christian University Press. $19.95.

title: A GRANT ESTABLISHES AN ARTIST
description: LEAD: AFTER a year of working in financial security, with a 1986 National Endowment for the Arts award affording her the luxury of ''creating art to please myself,'' Amy Zerner is now showing what impact $15,000 can have on an artist.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IT'S ALMOST a game to open a book calling itself ''New Jersey'' and wonder how it will differ from the hundred or so others (including a novel) bearing the same title.

title: Villanova 52, Cent. Conn. 20
description: Kirk Schulz completed a school-record 28 of 38 passes for 359 yards for Villanova (4-0). Central Connecticut fell to 1-4. Villanova had a school-record 45 consecutive points in the second half. A wide receiver, Robert Brady, caught 9 passes for 114 yards and a touchdown for the Wildcats.

title: The Non-Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Operateur'
description: To the Editor:

title: ON CAPTURING FOLIAGE COLOR
description: LAST weekend I secreted myself in a country hideaway three hours north of Manhattan to experience firsthand the joys of photographing fall foliage. First it rained. Then it snowed. Then it snowed some more.

title: MURDER TWIST; A SURVIVOR HELD, A VICTIM CLEARED
description: KIRK Buckner, a 14-year-old farm boy who had never been in trouble, went to his grave branded a mass murderer. And it is one of the apparitions in this town's nightmare that he might always have been remembered that way.

title: Celebrate Another Way
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Police Identify Livery Driver Who Was Beaten to Death
description: The police yesterday identified the driver of a car service who was beaten to death with baseball bats on Staten Island Friday night.

title: Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $293,500 29 Glendale Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, family room; not yet assessed. Port Chester, N.Y. $339,000 93 Brush Hollow Close 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old frame town house; eat-in kitchen, tennis court, pool, den, patio; taxes $4,054. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $220,000 3475 Ichabod Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, new roof, cul de sac; taxes $4,181. Avon, Conn. $270,000 8 Stony Corners Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old saltbox; screened porch, 1 acre; taxes $2,102. Canton, Conn. $274,900 4 Ledgewood Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; passive solar construction, panoramic views, 5 acres; taxes $3,012. Farmington, Conn. $465,000 58 Wood Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; master bedroom with vaulted ceilings, w/b stove; 0.75 acre; taxes $3,097. OTHER AREAS Short Hills, N.J. $425,000 295 Lupine Way 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, C/A, fireplace; taxes $4,591. Copiague, L.I. $252,000 7 Lagoon Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 9-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage, walk to water; taxes $4,400. Floral Park, L.I. $270,000 264-11 Williston Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old brick ranch; fireplace, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,200.

title: ON TRADE, U.S. STRIKES SOME DEALS WITH FRIENDS
description: ONE after the other, America's trading partners have been seeking special arrangements to shield them in the United States market from the threat of a surge of protectionism. First it was Israel, now Canada, tomorrow Mexico, and then possibly Taiwan or even Thailand.

title: TWO PARTY CHIEFS VIE FOR OFFICE
description: PARTY leaders, like boxing managers, usually stand outside the electoral ring cheering on their candidates. But in Hempstead this year, the party leaders are the candidates.

title:
The Job Outlook Across the Nation;
SOUTHEAST
description: LEAD: WITH a trade-related upturn in manufacturing, the Southeast is gaining greater economic growth balance between its diversified front-runners, Florida and Georgia, and its industrial states like North Carolina, Tennessee and Alabama, which were hit hard by the trade deficit.

title: NUMBER OF REALTORS UP AS SALES SLOW
description: A RECORD number of people in the state are seeking licenses to sell real estate and mortgages, even though officials say the housing boom that fueled the increase may have crested.

title: POSTINGS: Benefit Lampoon; Realtybiz
description: The folks who push the $900-a-month studios and $1,300 one-bedrooms are taking a break this week to help those who get bruised worst by Manhattan's stratospheric housing market - homeless children. In a benefit Wednesday night, some 100 brokers from 35 firms will act, sing, change sets and manipulate the lights in a musical spoof of their own industry.

title:
The Job Outlook Across the Nation;
MIDDLE WEST
description: LEAD: AFTER YEARS of reeling, heavy industry is making a comeback in the Midwest.

title: A Lone, Lonely American on the Soviet Coast
description: There are times when the loneliness of being the only American living on the Pacific coast of the Soviet Union gets to Bill Turner.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: COMPETITION: A Feminist Taboo? Edited by Valerie Miner and Helen E. Longino. Foreword by Nell Irvin Painter. (Feminist Press, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $12.95.) That women compete with one another is no surprise. That feminists also compete challenges ideals of sisterhood. Hence this comprehensive collection of feminist voices -academic, journalistic, psychoanalytic, political, personal.

title: MAPPING THE STATES OF MIND
description: A GODLESS JEW Freud, Atheism, and the Making of Psychoanalysis.

title:
DINING OUT;
ROADHOUSE FARE NEAR BREWSTER
description: LEAD: IF the ultimate success of a restaurant can be measured by the volume of its return business, then the recently opened S. W. Lauren's is here to stay despite its modest ambience and uneven kitchen. Bargain prices and fresh ingredients are hard to pass up, and the kitchen's victories, though few, are impressive.

title: City Auctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Tate Is Convincing Winner Over Olajide
description: Frank Tate, a gold medalist at the 1984 Olympics, knocked down Michael Olajide twice today on his way to a unanimous 15-round decision and the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title at the Indoor Sports Pavilion at Caesars Palace.

title: GARDENING
description: Gardening From the Ground Up: Cacti and Succulents One Up Productions. P.O. Box 410777. San Francisco, Calif. 94141. 28 minutes. $19.95.

title: A Ph.D. in R-e-s-p-e-c-t
description: BACK TO SCHOOL Starring Rodney Dangerfield (in photo), Sally Kellerman, Ned Beatty, Burt Young, Robert Downey Jr., Adrienne Barbeau. Color. 1986. HBO Video. 96 minutes. $25.95.

title: AIR INQUIRY OPENS ON NEW NEAR MISS
description: Government investigators have began looking into a near-collision Friday in which an American Airlines twin-jet airliner came within 50 feet of a private plane about 40 miles east of Los Angeles.

title: Thailand
description: To the Editor: I wish to alert travelers to Thailand about a recent credit card scam in which I was a victim.

title: From Moscow to SoHo: Soviet Author's Mystery
description: If a middle-age Soviet literary gentleman wears a pinkie ring, likes to hang out in SoHo, and wants to have an international crime-writers clubhouse in New York City, can he possibly be an officer in the dread Soviet intelligence agency, the K.G.B.?

title: Condom in College Newspaper
description: The University of Vermont's student newspaper inserted a free condom in 5,000 of its Oct. 1 issues. The condoms were part of a ''safe sex'' package that included two pamphlets, one on venereal diseases, another on AIDS.

title: FOR YIDDISH, A NEW BUT SMALLER DOMAIN
description: ON a recent afternoon in a Riverside Park playground, a slender, dark-haired man was introducing his 2-year-old boy to hopscotch. The scene was classic American father and son, except that they were speaking Yiddish.

title: TAKE THE MONEY AND SPY
description: I PLEDGE ALLEGIANCE . . . The True Story of the Walkers: An American Spy Family. By Howard Blum. Illustrated. 438 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: On Foot in Houston
description: To stand at the foot of South Boulevard in Houston is to look down what is perhaps the most magnificent residential street in America.

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER IS KEY TO RADIANT FALL COLORS
description: LEAD: A FRINGE benefit of living in the Northeast is the spectacular fall color we experience most every year. Along with that part of eastern Asia that lies in a comparable position in relation to the land mass and the ocean, we are blessed with a panoramic display of autumnal foliage color that few other regions of the earth can enjoy.

title: William Paley's Life
description: To the Editor:

title: SEWER BANS EXPECTED TO STAY
description: LEAD: THE sewer-extension ban has been one of New Jersey's most important tools in protecting streams and rivers over the last 20 years, and state officials say it is likely to remain so for several more years.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: The superiority of authentic National League baseball is obvious through scrupulously objective observation. Baseball fans everywhere should have access to the game free of the vulgar intrusion of past-prime, variously ailing half-athletes who have profited much from, but contributed nothing to, the splendor of the game.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: OPERA STAR IN ENGLEWOOD

title: Light Drinks
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale 40, William & Mary 34
description: Mike Stewart, a tailback, tossed a 3-yard touchdown pass to Dean Athanasia with 23 seconds left to win it for Yale.

title: A COMIC'S DREAMS PLAY ON BROADWAY
description: NOW that he's an established entrepreneur in the world of comedy - as the president of Great Neck-based talent management and radio syndication companies - is it any wonder that Rory Rosegarten, at 25, is producing a Broadway musical that just happens to be called ''Late Nite Comic''? The show opens Thursday at the Ritz Theater, 219 West 48th Street.

title: The Other (Software) Shoe Drops
description: TWO new software products for business-class personal computers point the direction that executive computing is headed in the near future. Both are from the Microsoft Corporation, the leading developer of software.

title: CHILDREN'S RELIGION ISSUE IN DIVORCE
description: LEAD: THE Jewish High Holy Days are usually characterized by familial warmth and tradition, but for 6-year-old Geri Kostner and her 3-year-old brother, Ryan, the days this year were marked by bitterness.

title: Students Take to Ramparts at Bastion of Decorum
description: A notoriously docile generation of college students has found something to protest at a tiny school in Maine: rules barring dormitory visits by the opposite sex.

title: EIGHT INDIANS DIE DURING NEW PUSH TO DISARM TAMILS
description: Eight Indian soldiers trying to capture and disarm ethnic Tamil guerrillas were killed in violent incidents in Sri Lanka's Jaffna Peninsula today, according to the Sri Lanka authorities.

title: Getting an Early Jump on April 15
description: IT'S getting to be that time of year again - year-end tax planning time, that is - and the 1986 Tax Reform Act, with its mare's-nest of new and transitional rules, isn't making things any easier. ''The people who used to enjoy our tax-planning sessions now see me as something akin to root canal,'' said Robert A. Clarfeld, a partner in Clarfeld & Company, a Manhattan accounting firm.

title: A SUIT THAT GOES TO WORK AND DINNER
description: Practical women have rediscovered new versions of the glamourous suits that Hollywood designers inspired in the 1940's. Today's suits have long jackets, subtle shaping and are cut from sturdy men's suiting material, such as a birdseye pattern in worsted.

title: Amy Klingenstein, Nursery Teacher, Married to Kenneth David Pollinger
description: Amy Jo Klingenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Klingenstein of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kenneth David Pollinger, the son of Barbara Kleinrock Pollinger of Trenton and Merrill R. Pollinger of Brick, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony in the garden of the bride's parents' home.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION: A MESSAGE IN EMBROIDERY
description: LEAD: The Bayeux Tapestry, a 230-foot-long, 20-inch-high embroidery depicting the Norman conquest of England in 1066, is one of the most enchanting narratives in Western art. By legend the work of William the Conqueror's Queen Mathilde and her attendants, the wall hangings are currently believed to have been commissioned by Odo, Archbishop of Bayeux and William's half brother.

title: Develop Those Existing Technologies
description: IN the Samuel Beckett play, ''Waiting For Godot,'' the central characters await the arrival of a special person - who never comes - while they watch the world pass by. The analogy with United States manufacturing management is startling. Manufacturers are waiting for new technology that will make them competitive in the global market without any risks or modifications in the way they currently do business.

title: THE CLASS OF '37
description: I've been organizing a 50th anniversary reunion of the Lindenhurst High School class of 1937. The experience is a mixture of joy, sadness and fear.

title: Claire F. O'Brien Wed To Timothy J. Brosnan
description: Claire F. O'Brien, a lawyer, and Timothy Joseph Brosnan, the staff counsel of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, were married yesterday at St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Alphonse Umana officiated.

title: SHOW PUTS 'SESAME' STAR AND CHILDREN ON STAGE
description: IT had been an ordinary Friday at Once Upon a Time, the children's bookstore in New Rochelle. Shoppers with and without toddlers in tow had come to browse or ask advice about books for their children. The store's four owners were on hand: Betsy Bober Polivy, a former magazine editor; Ms. Polivy's mother, Natalie Bober, herself an author of books for children and young adults; Jane Gelbard, Ms. Polivy's friend and Brandeis University classmate in the late 1970's, and Patricia Lukens, a quilting artist and Ms. Polivy's sister-in-law.

title: POLITICS, RELIGION AND CREATIVE THINKING IN OLD PERTH AMBOY
description: THE No. 62 bus out of Newark traveled south along Route 1. As it lumbered past the hazy outskirts of factory towns, there was no hint of the life stirring between the smokestacks.

title: Correction
description: The Investing column last week gave an incorrect status for the Mutual Shares fund. It is open to new investors.

title: Frank Stella Finds Space for Cosmic Reliefs
description: FROM THE TIME HE FIRST ELEC-trified the New York art world with a series of paintings consisting of black stripes on raw canvas, Frank Stella has been an artist who always seems to be working on the leading edge of contemporary art. The black-stripe paintings of 1959 were avatars of Minimalism; the mid-70's series of painted reliefs called ''Exotic Birds'' heralded the return of decorative painting; the increasingly three-dimensional series that have followed have spoken to grafitti art and neo-Expressionism, among other trends. It would be too much to say that where Stella goes others follow, but as a litmus for the state of painting he is closely watched.

title: Giants' Leonard Maintains Poise, But Gets His Revenge Nevertheless
description: The two faces of Jeffrey Leonard:

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
New Forays Into Factory-Built Housing
description: LEAD: THE first factory-built houses, which appeared on the market two decades ago, were small, boxy structures with flat roofs that met with more than a little skepticism from developers and home buyers.

title: Social Events
description: PARTIES WITH A PURPOSE Dinners Around Town

title: INDUSTRIES FIGHT BAN ON USING SOVIET ROCKETS
description: Two major American companies are battling the Government for the right to launch communications satellites on Soviet rockets.

title: DERRIDA DISMISSED?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane D. Maurer Weds Harlan Reiniger
description: The First Congregational Church in Madison, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jane Dorothy Maurer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles George Maurer of Madison and Ocean Ridge, Fla., to Harlan de Cernea Reiniger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Hale Reiniger of Bedford Village, N.Y., and Quidnet, Mass. The Rev. Winthrop E. Stone performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. Reiniger, a graduate of Albertus Magnus College, is an associate in the Boston real-estate firm of Hunneman & Company. Her father and her mother, Marilyn Maurer, own Maurer Real Estate in Madison.

title: Democrats Debating About Debates
description: After debating about foreign policy, economics and other issues in Iowa, New Hampshire, Florida and Washington, the Democratic candidates for President are now debating about debates.

title: Robin Wilpon to Wed Philip Wachtler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wilpon of Lattingtown, L.I., Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lynn Wilpon, to Philip Henry Wachtler, the son of Judge and Mrs. Sol Wachtler of Manhasset, L.I. and East Greenbush, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'HABITAT' INVOLVED IN 4 HOMES
description: LEAD: THE Morris Habitat for Humanity, an affiliate of the private Georgia-based homesteading organization with which former President Jimmy Carter has been involved, broke ground here last Sunday for four houses for low-income New Jerseyans.

title: FOCUS: Lubec, Me.; Winds Of Change Down East
description: TWO years ago, anyone suggesting that developers might be interested in building subdivisions here to house wealthy people would have been laughed right out of Tippy's Restaurant, the local gathering place on the town boat ramp.

title: PEEKSKILL ISSUES: PARKS, CRIME
description: LEAD: THERE was little cause for optimism in Peekskill in 1981.

title: Troyat's Nationality
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
LEGAL EAGLETS
description: LEAD: THE atmosphere was pure college, on an evening that was less than festive: amphitheater-style classroom, rain outside, fluorescent lights inside. The steady sound of a lecturer and of pens and pencils scratching. Yet there was none of the squirming, glancing at the clock or doodling in the margins associated with such scenes.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IN THE MUSIC LIBRARY. By Ellen Hunnicutt. (University of Pittsburgh, $15.95.) In these 11 stories, Ellen Hunnicutt, the author of the novel ''Suite for Calliope,'' has composed a stirring collection of variations on the theme of isolation and loss. Her characters see themselves and others as playing parts.

title: Nets Won't Rush Hopson's Career By SAM GOLDAPER
description: Some of the early arrivals for today's Princeton-Columbia football game stopped by Jadwin Gymnasium to watch the Nets practice.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TRADE OF STUDENTS STUDIED
description: ''IT is certainly our hope that we can begin the kind of learning experience that will benefit both our students and the ones that come here,'' said Dr. Alice Ilchman, referring to the proposed exchange of undergraduate students between the Soviet Union and this country that she is helping to negotiate.

title: A RISING TIDE OF VIOLENCE IN PERSIAN GULF
description: UNITED STATES helicopters sank a small Iranian vessel and damaged two others in the Persian Gulf last week, killing at least two Iranians and heightening fears that the conflict may be widening.

title: Miss Montgomery Becomes a Bride
description: At Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles, Maria Victoria Montgomery, a daughter of Mrs. Michael Montgomery of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Montgomery, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Sarnoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sarnoff of New York.

title: Tibet is Torn By Ancient Animosities
description: ON a visit to Tibet this summer, Robert Thurman watched as the Chinese authorities took truckloads of Tibetan children hundreds of miles away for schooling in other parts of China.

title: CUNY Faculty Fights Teacher-Training Plan
description: A proposal by a City University of New York task force to abolish the undergraduate major in education has met with stiff opposition from university faculty leaders, who say it infringes on the faculty's right to establish curriculum and degree requirements.

title: LONGING FOR BLACKNESS
description: COME TO AFRICA AND SAVE YOUR MARRIAGE And Other Stories. By Maria Thomas. 235 pp. New York: Soho/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: St. John's Is Upset By Pace
description: Kevin Enterlein completed a school-record 26 passes in 50 attempts for 322 yards and two touchdowns to lead Pace to a 27-22 upset of St. John's in a Liberty Conference game yesterday in Pleasantville, N.Y. Enterlein connected on an 8-yard scoring pass to Rob Fehrenbach and a 60-yarder to Alphonso Scott on the final play of the opening half as the Setters (1-2, 2-3). St. John's is 1-2 and 1-3.

title: Karen Rieger Married To Ernest B. Tracy 3d
description: Karen Bailey Rieger, the computer coordinator for the Hewitt School in Manhattan, and Ernest Bell Tracy 3d, the dean of boys in the lower school of the Rye (N.Y.) Country Day School, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Bay performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Venerable Robert A. Bryan, the archdeacon of the North Shore Anglican Diocese of Quebec and an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Streetscapes: Brooklyn Museum; A Touch of Imperial Rome Gracing Eastern Parkway
description: THE Brooklyn Museum has never even approached completion of its original master plan, designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White. But last year it held a competition for a completion on more modest lines. The museum's decision on how to treat its 1930's lobby will indicate how far the pendulum is swinging away from orthodox modernism.

title: People and Wildlife Paying the Price As Timber Demand Rises in Borneo
description: The waters of the mighty Rajang River, for centuries a major route into the heart of Borneo, run by this small town the color of milky coffee.

title: Lots of Lots, but Little for Development
description: NEW YORK'S vast and seemingly inexhaustible supply of vacant city-owned land - apparent to anyone who has ventured into the weedy steppes of Brooklyn or the wasteland prairies of the Bronx - is running out.

title: In the Wake of Glasnost, Polish Youth Is Offered State-Sponsored Rock Music
description: FIVE KIDS ARE CROWDED into a dank, low-vaulted cellar that resembles a tomb, two of them hunched over electric guitars, a third in tight zebra-striped pants and a sweat shirt that reads ''Community College.'' A fourth youth straddles a tarnished set of drums, a fifth is wrestling with the stem of a long black mike and screaming in a voice like a cymbal. The thunderous rhythms of heavy metal vibrate off the pink-painted brick walls. The group is called Vincent, short for Vincent van Gogh.

title: Child Care in U.S. Is a Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Job Outlook Across the Nation; MOUNTAIN
description: UNEMPLOYMENT RATES have been a puzzling indicator of economic health in the Rocky Mountain West during the last year. In Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and Colorado the number of people out of work has dropped, but state labor specialists do not call the change an improvement. Meanwhile, Utah's unemployment rate inched upward to 6.6 percent in August, though John Mathews of the Utah Department of Employment Security sounds more optimistic than his counterparts.

title: South Africa Seizes 16 More Linked to Banned Congress
description: The South African police today announced the arrests of 16 more black members of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: Oregon Surprises Southern Cal, 34-27
description: Bill Musgrave, the redshirt freshman who entered the game as the No. 2 passer in the nation, threw for three touchdowns to help Oregon stun Southern Cal, 34-27, and move into a first-place tie in the Pacific-10 Conference today.

title: Too Much Italian Flavor in a California Winery
description: IT IS NOT ALWAYS TRUE THAT wherever Michael Graves goes, controversy follows, but it seems that way. In the early 1980's there were the battles over the Portland Building, the decorated box Mr. Graves designed for municipal offices in Portland, Ore. In New York the arguments over Mr. Graves's proposed post-modern addition to the starkly modern Whitney Museum began the moment that design was made public in 1985, and ebbed only slightly after substantial revision of the plans.

title: Twins' Runner Gets Ensnarled In One Play's Twists and Turns
description: The play will become a footnote or a trivia question in future accounts of the 1987 American League pennant playoff, but today it might have served as the catapult that thrust the Minnesota Twins to the threshold of the World Series.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: October 11, 1987
description: Weeks On Fiction List 1 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) 8 Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, 13 $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 3 * ATASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, 2 $4.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 4 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Ballantine, 6 $4.95.) Two men, two women, passion and power- brokering in Washington. 5 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. 1 (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The hero of the "Foundation" series searches for the lost planet Earth. 6 VALE OF THE VOLE, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, 2 $3.95.) Esk, the son of an ogre and a nymph, defends the inhabitants of a paradise. 7 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. 7 (Avon, $4.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a woman's coming-of-age in 18th- century England and France. 8 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) 1 Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in "Evergreen." 9 * THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 74 Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 10 CALL TO ARMS, by W. B. Griffin. (Jove, $4.50.) 5 The Marines from Pearl Harbor to Midway; second volume of "The Corps." 11 DREAMS ARE NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline 2 Briskin. (Berkley, $4.50.) A California family dynasty out to conquer the world. 12 I AM THE ONLY RUNNING FOOTMAN, by 1 Martha Grimes. (Dell, $3.95.) Scotland Yard's Superintendent Jury on the trail of a strangler. 13 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A 14 rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 14 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Bantam, 7 $4.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 15 * O-ZONE, by Paul Theroux. (Ivy/Ballantine, 1 $4.95.) In 21st-century America, eight people enter a forbidden land of aliens and nuclear waste. Weeks On Nonfiction List 1 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph 1 Wambaugh. (Bantam, $4.95.) A case involving the 1979 murder of a high school teacher and the disappearance of her two children. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. 207 (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 KAFFIR BOY, by Mark Mathabane. (Plume/ 6 NAL, $8.95.) Coming-of-age in South Africa. 4 FATHE RHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) 24 Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 5 * NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 33 (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 6 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Berly Markham. 49 (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 7 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $4.95.) An 7 unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 8 DREAMGIRL, by Mary Wilson with Patricia 5 Romanowski and Ahrgus Juilliard. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) A behind-the-scenes look at the Supremes. 9 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Avon, 3 3 $5.50.) The confrontation between America's Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan. 10 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle 16 Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) Tales of the world's oldest profession. 11 * WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T 21 ENOUGH, by Harold Kushner. (Pocket, $4.50.) A rabbi on "the search for a life that matters." Weeks Advice, How-to and On Miscellaneous List 1 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by 7 Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More "Bloom County" cartoon strips. 2 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. 18 (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 3 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. 25 (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 4 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, 37 Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) The 1987 edition. 5 * WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 71 Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TALES OF THE CONGAREE. By Edward C. L. Adams. Edited by Robert G. O'Meally. (University of North Carolina, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $12.50.) The ''Congaree'' referred to in the title of this collection of black folk tales is the swamp found along the banks of the Congaree River in South Carolina. To the black people who once lived there, it was a land both dangerous and alluring, a place where ''God's mornin' leads to de devil's night.

title: LET NASSAU DEMOCRATS 'CLEAN UP THEIR ACT'
description: Re '' 'One-Party System' Is Root of Ills,'' letter to the Long Island editor, Sept. 13:

title: Volunteers in New York City Inspect Shelters for Homeless
description: Drifting into the Harlem Armory shelter on a recent night, the homeless men found a young man collapsed on the stairs leading to the main floor.

title: Suspect in Botched Robbery Is Wounded by Police
description: A 19-year-old man who was accused of taking a hostage in a botched holdup at a convenience store was arrested after he was shot and wounded as he fled, the police said today.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: NONFICTION
description: Of Le Corbusier's stunning but inhumane Chandigarh project in India, Nehru once said that whether or not you liked the building, ''The fact of the matter is simply this: it has changed your lives.'' His words serve aptly to capture the sometimes uneasy but always respectful tone of the 15 essays in LE CORBUSIER (Princeton University, Paper, $19.95; Garland, Cloth, $60), edited by H. Allen Brooks. None of the impressive contributors, including historian-critics (Reyner Banham, Vincent Scully), practicing architects (Alan Colquhoun, Charles Correa) or former colleagues (Andre Wogenscky, Jerzy Soltan, Iannis Xenakis), have settled for mere laudatory praise of the master's obvious triumphs, although Tim Benton and Daniele Pauly have delivered close appreciations of the Villa Savoye and the Ronchamp chapel. Instead, most of the authors have chosen to grapple with some of the tougher questions and contradictions implicit in the work of a man who loved principles and rules (the Five Points, the Seven V's), but didn't hesitate to dispense with them when more convenient in the service of his art. Indeed, the many conflicts of opinion expressed here - on the influence of monasteries in Le Corbusier's unite d'habitation, on the exclusivity of his design ideas, on whether he was an evil influence or a misunderstood visionary - only add to this collection's fascination. Clearly, the debate over Corbu's contribution to modernism is only gaining momentum or, as Norma Evenson puts it in her consideration of Corbu's devastating effect on urban planning, ''like it or not, we may have Le Corbusier to kick around for quite a while.''

title: OUT OF A DARKNESS
description: EVERYONE WHO HITS BOTTOM seems able to pinpoint the moment it happened. Mine occurred during an agitated depression a year and a half ago. I woke up one night obsessively aware of the gun that lay in a box under my bed and of my desire to place that gun in my mouth and pull the trigger.

title: ABOVE ALL, A WRITER
description: WILLA CATHER A Literary Life. By James Woodress. Illustrated. 583 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. $35.

title: Third Death in Chile Strike
description: A third person has died after being shot this week during a 24-hour strike called by opponents of the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet, the victim's family said on Friday. The victim, Carlos Valdebenito, 19 years old, was shot in the head in clashes on Wednesday.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: I hope Yale Kamisar's faulty comparison of AIDS testing with illicit drug testing, dragnet searches at airports and regulatory searches for health and safety violations will be cautiously avoided by those with judicial power (''Drugs, AIDS and the Threat to Privacy''). A person harboring the AIDS virus has not committed a criminal act by virtue of being infected, and, furthermore, poses no risk to other individuals who themselves refrain from unsafe behavior. Unlike detaining armed airline passengers to prevent hijacking or closing unfit restaurants to eliminate food poisoning, the government's ''search'' for AIDS via testing is not the sole means available to protect the public from harm. It is merely one of several measures, no other of which appears to be as politically useful to the Administration. DANIEL NAJJAR Washington

title: Basques in Spain Tense After French Ouster
description: Policemen and demonstrators clashed across northern Spain this week as supporters of E.T.A., the radical Basque separatist organization, took to the streets to protest a crackdown on members of the group across the border in France.

title: Woman Keeps Grandson, 8, In Coffin-Like Box for 2 Years
description: A boy was confined to a coffin-size box for two years because his step-grandmother feared he was brain-damaged, prosecutors said Friday.

title: Headliners; No Clear Sailing
description: With concerns over the safety of air travel paramount in the public mind, the choice of a new Secretary of Transportation is bound to be controversial. While no one was surprised last week when the White House nominated James H. Burnley 4th to succeed the departing Elizabeth Hanford Dole, there were signs that he might face some opposition in the Senate. As deputy director, Mr. Burnley has been an advocate of the Reagan Administration's deregulatory policies, which have been blamed by consumer groups for some of the airline industry's problems. He also has supported the Administration's position that Government subsidies to Amtrak be reduced.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A SUMMONS TO MEMPHIS, by Peter Taylor. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The story of Phillip Carver, called to Memphis by his sisters to stop their widowed father from remarrying, won the Pulitzer Prize. As in his past works, Peter Taylor writes about the ways we use conventions and manners to circumscribe the world, making it an easier, if duller, place to live. Last year our reviewer, Marilynne Robinson, called this a ''beautifully ironic new novel'' that ''reminds us that people, like spiders, impose geometries on thin air.'' SIDESHOW: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of Cambodia, by William Shawcross. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) In a new introduction to his account of the American role in the ''secret'' war in Cambodia, William Shawcross describes a lavish dinner party at a New York hotel in 1985, where bitter enemies are forced by politics to act like friends: the deposed Prince Sihanouk, celebrating his 60th birthday, merrily sings to the sounds of a Cambodian dance band, while representatives of the murderous Khmer Rouge look on. ''This somber and compelling study . . . tells an ugly story,'' one reviewer said in 1979. THE GOOD FATHER, by Peter Prince. (Carroll & Graf, $7.95.) In truth, Karen Ray said here in 1985, this story of two divorced men, their children and their wars with their former wives has no ''good fathers'' in it. The main character, a former radical named Bill Hooper, is annoyingly obsessive and self-centered, the reviewer said, though she admired the novel's minor characters, ''particularly the women, who are the most interesting and believably quirky.'' THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by Barbara Branden. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Ayn Rand is most widely known for her best-selling, critically disparaged novels. But her philosophy of enlightened self-interest has inspired a succession of college students, some of whom have ascended to positions in and around the Reagan Administration. Last year our reviewer, Peter L. Berger, said that Barbara Branden was too close to the subject (her husband had an affair with Rand) to write a completely successful biography, but he found ''something appealing, even a touch of grandeur,'' in her portrait of one of libertarianism's fiercest advocates. DRUNK WITH LOVE: A Book of Stories, by Ellen Gilchrist. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) Ellen Gilchrist writes stories about the many ways in which relationships fall apart, generally because of the inadequacies of men. In 1986 our reviewer, Wendy Lesser, found the author's ethnic and regional stereotypes wearing, but credited her with an ability to capture characters, at various times in their lives, as though ''taking home movies . . . with a clearly focused and artfully held lens.'' ON THE STROLL, by Alix Kates Shulman. (Academy Chicago, $8.95.) Roaming the badlands around New York City's seedy Port Authority Bus Terminal, a bag lady named Owl comes to believe that Robin, a 16-year-old runaway turned prostitute, is her missing daughter; the girl's pimp, Prince, feels possessive for other reasons. While the plot is merely sufficient, Mary Cantwell said here in 1981, ''the book's strength lies in the portraits of [ the characters ] and the evocation of the blasted landscape through which [ they ] move.'' THE GREAT DEPRESSION: An Inquiry Into the Causes, Course, and Consequences of the Worldwide Depression of the Nineteen-Thirties, as Seen by Contemporaries and in the Light of History, by John A. Garraty. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) In the 1980's, as in the 20's, the banking system is saddled with huge foreign debt (this time in Latin America rather than Europe) and we are faced with an agricultural decline accompanied by cries for protectionism. Though he is not among the doom-sayers predicting another Great Depression, John A. Garraty draws cautionary parallels in a ''timely, troubling book,'' our reviewer, Mancur Olson, said last year. ''The tragic history . . . is disturbingly pertinent to our current concerns.'' MR. BLANDINGS BUILDS HIS DREAM HOUSE, by Eric Hodgins. Illustrated by William Steig. (Academy Chicago, $7.95.) Eric Hodgins's comic novel about an advertising executive whose idyllic house in the country runs and nearly ruins his life was made into a movie starring Cary Grant and Myrna Loy. ''No ordinary joke-smith, Mr. Hodgins is light and expert,'' our reviewer, Brooks Atkinson, said in 1946. WHERE NIGHTS ARE LONGEST: Travels by Car Through Western Russia, by Colin Thubron. (Atlantic Monthly, $7.95.) Convinced that the author was too unadventurous to write convincingly about the Soviet Union, our reviewer, S. Frederick Starr, admitted that he opened the book ''with the same mixture of trepidation and condescension with which one prepares for an evening of neighbors' slides from last summer's vacation.'' But he was pleasantly surprised. ''The results are glorious,'' he said in 1984. ''A subtle and humane writer, Mr. Thubron is able to capture the fleeting words and gestures that define a culture.'' STRINDBERG, by Michael Meyer. (Oxford, $14.95.) When this biography of the eccentric Swedish playwright was published in 1985, The Times's John Gross praised the author, Michael Meyer, for being ''as admirable a guide to this problematic genius as anyone could ask. The good sense of his account is matched by its imaginative sympathy.'' TAKING CHANCES, by M. J. Farrell. (Penguin, $6.95.) Into the calm, pastoral Ireland of M. J. Farrell's novel, a beautiful interloper named Mary Fuller arrives and wrecks a marriage. While the love scenes aren't as artful as the fox-hunting scenes, one reviewer said in 1930, ''Miss Farrell's delight in the open fields [ and ] her enthusiasm for horses . . . give the story its distinctive qualities of color and movement.''

title: BACK HOME TO CAROINA
description: TENDING TO VIRGINIA By Jill McCorkle. 312 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

title: 'MOBY DICK' MARATHON: MEANINGS SURFACE IN THE WEE HOURS
description: WHEN it comes to marathon performances, there is usually a crowd at the beginning and at the end, but much less so in the middle. I figured the annual Labor Day weekend ''Moby Dick'' reading at Canio's Books in Sag Harbor would be much the same.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article July 26 on Bay Ridge incorrectly described its two Lutheran schools. The Lutheran Elementary School of Bay Ridge and Leif Ericson Day School both cover nursery through eighth grade. The article also omitted one private school, Adelphi Academy.

title: Now Frankie and Johnny Are Modern Lovers
description: ''HAVING A PLAY OF MINE done used to be the most painful process in the world. I would hide. I would get physically ill. There was no one more miserable on this planet than I was the opening night of my first play, 'And Things That Go Bump in The Night.' Now I don't feel that way,'' says Terrence McNally on the eve of the opening of his newest work, ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' beginning its run Wednesday at the Manhattan Theater Club, where it had a developmental production last spring.

title: A LA CARTE
description: SOME of the best food on Long Island is found not in restaurants or even your grandmother's kitchen, but at a private club. Traditionally, clubs have been known for their lackluster food. Most members join for the golfing, boating and tennis. Dining is a distinct afterthought required of members.

title: Teen-Aged Student Proposes To Let Inmates Select Death
description: A bill that would allow prisoners serving life sentences to choose execution instead has been submitted to the Legislature at the suggestion of a 17-year-old high school student.

title: Israeli Warplanes Raid Palestinian Bases in Eastern Lebanon
description: Israeli Air Force planes attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon today, close to the border with Syria.

title:
ART;
NEUBERGER EXHIBITS VITO ACCONCI WORK
description: LEAD: GOOD advice for a visitor to the retrospective, ''Vito Acconci: Domestic Trappings'' at the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase, would be to hurry past the tempting work in the first gallery, postponing it, and begin one's serious looking in the back gallery where the earliest pieces, beginning in 1969, are exhibited.

title: A Computer View of What Might Be
description: ONE problem for cosmetic dentists has been that patients have trouble visualizing the results of cosmetic alterations - and often back off because of uncertainty. Dentists are hoping computer technology can ease those doubts.

title:
GARDENING;
A NEW LOOK AT SHRUB COLOR
description: LEAD: A VARIED array of deciduous shrubs offer kaleidoscopic fall colors over a number of months. There is a shrub to fill a niche in every garden.

title: REMODELING - WITH A HAPPY ENDING
description: ''YOU don't know what you're in for,'' a friend who had recently renovated her kitchen said. We had just told her that we were contemplating some renovations of our own. ''The contractors are very independent,'' she went on. ''They have so much work these days that after they get started with you they disappear to go on another job and don't show up again for ages.''

title: Rochester U. Votes to End Its Ties to South Africa
description: The University of Rochester has decided to divest itself of holdings in companies that do business in South Africa, reversing a 5-month-old policy that stirred campus and community opposition.

title: CONCERTS BRING A MELODIC AUTUMN
description: THE Silvermine Chamber Music Series, which started in June, is ready to call it a season tonight with a recital by the Amsterdam Guitar Trio.

title: Ancient Places That Anchor Yeats's Poems
description: Like many unreconstructed English majors, I have a weakness for literary pilgrimages, a form of travel based on the principle that homage must be paid to genius. So I have found myself at Ernest Hemingway's house in Key West, Mark Twain's boyhood haunts in Hannibal, Wordsworth's cottage in the Lake District and Karen Blixen's house on the outskirts of Nairobi. And of course, I have made the obligatory trudge through the tourist-clogged streets of Stratford-on-Avon.

title: CHAMBER TO TANGO: TIME FOR DECISION
description: WHETHER you love chamber music or prefer the full-spectrum sound of the symphony orchestra, you have a difficult choice to make Saturday: the Vienna Chamber Trio and the Abegg Trio of Germany are playing in Ossining and Tarrytown respectively, and the season opener for the Westchester Symphony has been scheduled that same evening.

title: FOR MAMET AND CROUSE, A MOVIE IS A FAMILY MATTER
description: ON THE SET OF EACH NEW movie he produces, Michael Hausman hangs a sampler stitched with the words: ''All mistakes happen in preproduction.'' He remembers doing so with trepidation in the case of ''House of Games,'' the psychological thriller that closes the New York Film Festival tonight.

title: Ban Chemical Weapons. But How?
description: Soviet and American officials boast that they are near agreement on banning chemical weapons. Ridding the world of these repulsive weapons would truly represent progress for humankind. It is far from clear, however, that the ban can be effective and verifiable - even though the two sides now accept provisions for on-site inspections.

title: SEPARATE NATIONS: POETRY AND THE PEOPLE
description: LEAD: Czeslaw Milosz, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1980, was interviewed extensively in 1979 and 1981 by Ewa Czarnecka and Aleksander Fiut about his life and writing. Those interviews are being published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich this month as ''Conversations With Czeslaw Milosz,'' in a translation by Richard Lourie.

title: Miss Stong Wed To John Cassidy, A Fellow Lawyer
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Snow Stong and John Shaw Cassidy, who are lawyers in New York and magna cum laude graduates of Harvard University, class of '78. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: Reversing Rural Blight in the Catskills
description: FOR a century, the Beaverkill Valley in the Catskills has been a mecca for naturalists drawn by the great floral beauty covering the mountains, for sportsmen attracted by abundant turkey and deer, and especially for anglers who cast into its streams for the maddeningly elusive rainbow trout and then touted the region as a world-class fishing spot.

title: Hofstra Beats Wagner in Showdown
description: Hofstra took advantage of Wagner's listless defense in the first half to build a 24-0 lead today, then had to withstand Wagner's relentless offense in the second half for a 35-28 victory in a match of unbeaten teams. The victory gave Hofstra a record of 5-0; Wagner dropped to 5-1.

title: RENT PANELISTS RUSH TO CATCH UP
description: TWO new members of the county's Rent Guidelines Board have their work cut out for them: they have four weeks to listen to 10 to 12 hours of tapes from four noisy public hearings so they can vote on new rent levels on Nov. 4.

title: DETERMINED FEW DON'T DREAM DREAMS, THEY LIVE THEM
description: PETER REILLY, Sam DeProto and Sue Evageliou do not spend their time regretting what might have been. They are taking steps to see to it that what might have been is what will be.

title: CITY AND POVERTY UNIT FEUDING ON LONG ISLAND
description: THE 275 cartons of cheese delivered to the Long Beach City Hall one recent Thursday were not intended as a gift. On the contrary, they came from the local branch of an angry antipoverty agency that wanted to drive home a point.

title: THEATER AYCKBOURN PREMIERE
description: In recent years, Alan Ayckbourn has found an American theatrical home at the Alley Theater in Houston. That regional company has produced seven of his plays, only a few of which have been seen in New York. The Alley-Ayckbourn alliance culminated last night with the U. S. premiere of the playwright's newest work, ''Henceforward . . . ,'' directed by the author. Coming after the play's tryout in August at Mr. Ayckbourn's theater in Scarborough and before it is presented in London, ''Henceforward'' represents a considerable coup for the Alley.

title: 8 Arrested for Drugs on L.I.
description: Eight people were arrested on drug-related felony charges after the Nassau County Police conducted a sweep of the Nassau Road area. Officers from the county's Bureau of Special Operations swept through the street about 10 P.M. Friday, recovering 43 vials of crack, a large bag of crack, $2,000 in cash and assorted drug paraphernalia, according to a police spokesman, Officer Peter Franzone. The names of the eight people were not released.

title: Winning Return for Elizabeth
description: For at least one of the teams playing along the northern end of the New Jersey Turnpike, the football strike ended last week. Not for the Jets or the Giants, but certainly for the Minutemen of Elizabeth High School, who play in the shadow of the oil refineries near Exit 13.

title: WHAT WILL HAPPEN TO MY SONS?
description: OVERLOOKING the World War II invasion beaches of France, I stood and contemplated how differently I viewed war now that I was the mother of two boys.

title: HOW DO YOU GET MORE RIDERST TO USE MASS TRANSIT?
description: Robert R. Kiley M.T.A. Chairman

title: NEW PEEKSKILL LAW LIBRARY IS ALSO FOR LAYMEN
description: A LAW library where laymen as well as lawyers can look for answers to legal problems is being established in an upstairs room at the Field Library, Peekskill's public library -and the founders raised enough money in three weeks to start it.

title: Judge Bork's Victory
description: What a gutsy, judicious thing to do.

title: AT HER BEST IN DISASTER
description: CLARA BARTON Professional Angel. By Elizabeth Brown Pryor. Illustrated. 444 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $19.95. After Dec. 31, $24.95.

title: Elizabeth McNey Weds C. M. Yates
description: At the Old Chapel of the Central Moravian Church in Bethlehem, Pa., Elizabeth Ann McNey, the daughter of Mrs. Oliver Barres Zug of Bethlehem and Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Miles Yates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe E. Yates of Bentonville, Ark. The Rev. Dr. Douglas Caldwell and the Rev. Marvin Henkelmann, Moravian ministers, performed the ceremony.

title: TAXES BEING PAID IN JERSEY AMNESTY
description: The first month of the tax amnesty program in New Jersey has resulted in about $13.9 million from delinquent taxpayers, treasury officials said.

title: Killing Covered By Insurance
description: AFTER fatally shooting her husband in 1984, Constance Y. Moorehead of Linthicum, Md., was accused of manslaughter, but the charges were dropped. Investigation showed that he had beaten her often and that she had acted in self defense.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Squibb Corporation expects to list its common shares on the Paris Stock Exchange by the end of 1987. Richard N. Vurlaud, chairman and chief executive officer, said the decision to apply for a listing reflected confidence in the French economy and the importance of French financial markets.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Onalaska, Wis.; Catering To the Upscale
description: HE is the ''Charles Raymond of the 1980's,'' said a sales broker in describing David M. Evenson, a 37-year-old home builder in this town of 10,000 people near the Mississippi River, two miles north of the city of La Crosse, Wis.

title: Pleasantville Wins Its 4th
description: Pleasantville, continuing a difficult schedule by facing an opponent that had not yet yielded a point in 1987, maintained its own strong season yesterday with a 28-0 shutout of visiting Irvington.

title: Change Owners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OPERA INSTITUTE MAKES DEBUT
description: LEAD: THE new Opera-Music Theatre Institute of New Jersey, whose founder and director is the Metropolitan Opera basso Jerome Hines, made its official debut Tuesday night at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: At Yale, Aspiring Authors Flock to Fiction-Writing Courses
description: Norma Klein had her first piece of fiction published at the age of 19, when she won a short-story contest.

title: Georgine Fleming Hall Weds David DuVivier
description: Georgine Fleming Hall, an actress, and David DuVivier, a retired lawyer, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Rocky Hill, N.J., by the Rev. Samuel W. Ishibashi.

title: Seals That Offer Images of the Past
description: IN HIS PURSUIT OF ANTIQUI-ties, Martin Cherkasky carries a magnifying glass and a bag of plastic clay. But he leaves his rolling pin and toaster-oven at home.

title: Hanley's Collections
description: To the Editor:

title: Battered But Still Swinging, Reagan Enters Final Rounds
description: This opening was particularly important because the President has tried vainly for almost seven years to persuade Congress to enact his views on such ''social issues'' as abortion and school prayer. Mr. Reagan saw Judge Bork as a justice who would push the Court toward positions that Congress had repeatedly rejected. If, as expected, the full Senate votes down Judge Bork's nomination, it will be in part a repudiation of that social agenda. As Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, put it when he announced his opposition to the judge: ''The American people agree with the Supreme Court. They don't agree with Judge Bork.'' Or, he might have added, with President Reagan. The Inevitable Loss of Power

title: The Price of Ideology
description: It is a new experience for Americans to live under a Government driven by ideology. We have had activist Presidents, but not ones fastened to a theory. Franklin Roosevelt, the modern exemplar of vigor, was an utter pragmatist. Richard Nixon went to China. Lyndon Johnson urged us to reason together. And so on.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SHORT STORIES OF FRAY ANGELICO CHAVEZ. Edited by Genaro M. Padilla. (University of New Mexico, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.)
