New Mexico, a character in one of these stories reminds us, was settled by the Spanish over 200 years before the New England colonies and it was part of Old Mexico for just 25 years.

title: For Latin America, A Greening at the Top
description: IN his 1975 novel ''The Autumn of the Patriarch,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez imagined a Latin American despot so aged that he was ''older than all old men and all old animals on land or sea.'' To Latin Americans familiar with Juan Peron, Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay or Arnulfo Arias of Panama, among others, the portrayal was less a fantasy than a deft rendering of an all-too-familiar prototype.

title: Bring Big Business to the Campus
description: ONE lesson highlighted by the recent technological challenge from Japan is that America's primary competitive advantage - the capacity to innovate - is under attack. But now big business has found an ally in its battle to become more competitive - the university.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
IS THERE A BRIGHTER FUTURE FOR OUR COINS?
description: LEAD: LEGISLATION authorizing redesign of regular-issue United States coins was introduced last month by Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York. Under Mr. Rangel's bill, new designs would be placed on the reverses of five circulating coins - the cent through the half dollar - over a six-year period.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Las Vegas, Nev.;
The Dawning Of a 'Sun City'
description: LEAD: WITHIN a month Del E. Webb Communities will break ground for a $500 million adult recreational community in Las Vegas.

title: Audiences Vs. Vexing Subjects
description: SLOW, TERRIBLE DEATH, GRISLY EXPERI-ments and seemingly irrevocable pollution of the environment are hardly things about which audiences automatically want to hear. But Carole Langer's ''Radium City'' hooked the crowd anyway, and when that happens, the film maker deserves as much praise for tact as for technique. The strategy involved in making difficult subjects palatable - and more than that, transfixing - is always of interest, even when it backfires rather than succeeds. Because backfire it can. Push viewers too hard in the direction of unpleasant, potentially distasteful material (say, the violent and epithet-filled ''China Girl,'' or the inexcusable ''Surf Nazis Must Die'') and you push them right over the edge.

title: PLEA ON TRANSPORTATION: THINK REGIONAL
description: A return to the regional efforts that characterized transportation planning in the 1960's is imperative for Westchester County, Dr. William Ronan told a group of bankers and executives recently.

title: An Unmanly Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Free College Lures Nurses to Hospital
description: Benefits for nurses at the Veterans Administration Medical Center here include the usual: medical insurance, paid vacation, sick leave and a pension plan. But in an effort to alleviate a nursing shortage and retain staff, the hospital has added a new benefit: a free college education.

title: Two Who Withdrew
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls inside my house are covered with rough-sawn knotty pine. Because of some leaks, the wood along the bottom is stained dark in an irregular pattern that looks like a stock market graph. The leaks are cured, but the stains remain. How can I remove them?

title: CONDOS ALONG THE HUDSON
description: HUDSON COUNTY, long considered an urban backwater, is experiencing one of the greatest real-estate booms in recent history.

title: Catherine D. Holcomb To Wed David Costello
description: Mr. and Mrs. Horace Hale Holcomb 3d of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Davis Holcomb to David John Costello, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Costello of Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Andrew Jackson said once that one man with courage makes a majority. Obviously Bob Bork has that courage.

title: YOUNG WITTGENSTEIN
description: THE WORLD AS I FOUND IT By Bruce Duffy. 546 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $19.95.

title: Mother in Custody Case Is Released From Jail
description: A woman who spent six months in jail for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of her 8-year-old daughter was freed Thursday. A court will investigate her contention that her former husband sexually abused their daughter.

title: TAKING RISKS
description: Like many of the desk-bound of this world, Thomas Simmons seems determined to take gratuitous risks (motorcycles being chief among them), just to be sure he's alive (About Men, ''A Sense of Drama,'' Sept. 13). Too bad he can't teach his son to take risks for a stronger purpose than joy-riding -risks such as working construction, joining the Peace Corps, or living on the edge of poverty - for a dream. NANCY TAYLOR ROBSON Galena, Md.

title: U.S. Asked to Postpone Limits on Use of Pesticide
description: Under attack by farm groups, the Fish and Wildlife Service has asked the Environmental Protection agency to postpone plans to protect endangered species by limiting pesticide use in about 900 counties around the country.

title: David Lione Weds Catherine Murphy
description: Catherine Louise Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Murphy of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Cordiner Lione, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Lione Jr. of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Cesar Perotti performed the ceremony at St. Mark the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in West Hartford.

title: Cuba Has Plan to Raid U.S. Base in Case of Attack, Defecting General Says
description: A Cuban Air Force general who defected to the United States five months ago says Cuban combat pilots regularly practice for retaliatory strikes against an Air Force base in Florida.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Sparky's Golden Straws
description: LEAD: MANAGING a big-league baseball team is knowing when to take out a pitcher, knowing when to flash the bunt sign, knowing how to deal with players. It's also knowing when to grasp for straws. Psychological straws. And for Sparky Anderson and the Detroit Tigers, those straws he grasped have suddenly turned to gold.

title: Susan Crittenden Wed in Delaware
description: At the Episcopal Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., Susan Gray Crittenden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Dwight Crittenden Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Michael Vactor Chambers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Shearer Chambers of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. Adam Lewis, the church's rector, performed the ceremony.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: Robert Reich (''The Expanding Economic Vista'') is to be commended on his excellent history of the commerce clause's 200 years.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: I suppose the simplest solution would be for the home team to select the rules of play. That should be equitable as long as the rules remain vaguely recognizable to the visiting team.

title: The Extravagant Desserts of Sicily
description: Sicilian desserts are the kind that children might dream up. Thick, rich and sugary sweet concoctions made with unstinting proportions of cream, sugar, chocolate, fruit and nuts, all oozed into crispy pastry rolls, spread onto spongy layer cakes or hidden inside soft pastry pockets. Then there are the mounds of buttery cookies, the fooled-you marzipan lookalike fruit and vegetables, the ice mountains of fruit- or coffee-flavored granitas, and ice cream that barely begins with vanilla, chocolate and strawberry.

title: OWNER ALTERS PLAN TO DEVELOP CLUB
description: AFTER two years of opposition from homeowners, the real-estate developer Edward S. Gordon has changed his plans for the oceanfront site of the Bridgehampton Racquet and Surf Club, from building an elaborate tennis court enclosure on the property to subdividing it.

title: Free Agents Carry Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hail a Creator Of Rock-and-Roll
description: CHUCK BERRY, WHO will turn 61 on Oct. 18, should be able to look back on his 60th year with a feeling of accomplishment. ''Chuck Berry The Autobiography'' (Harmony Books) appeared earlier this fall and has been selling briskly. ''Chuck Berry Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll,'' a documentary film directed by Taylor Hackford, premiered recently at the New York Film Festival and is opening around the country. The soundtrack album, which was produced by Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones and includes guest appearances by Eric Clapton, Robert Cray, Linda Ronstadt, Etta James and Julian Lennon, is scheduled for a late October release by MCA.

title: Carol Jean Worley Married To Thomas Swaim in Jersey
description: Carol Jean Worley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Worley of Brookside, N.J., and Thomas Edwin Swaim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Swaim of Leonia, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J.

title: Correction
description: A review by Carl Sagan on Sept. 27 identified him incorrectly. He is the author of ''Cosmos'' and ''Contact'' and is writing a book with Ann Druyan about the human past and future.

title: Jay Johnston, Banker, Weds Claire E. Hahn
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco, Claire Elise Hahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Hahn of Jackson, Wyo., and Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to John Buckhout Johnston Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston of New Canaan, Conn., and Windermere Island, Eleuthera, the Bahamas. The Rev. Richard P. Fowler officiated.

title: Penn St. Romps Over Rutgers
description: Penn State ran up a 28-7 lead on Rutgers today and then relaxed. But Scott Erney kept throwing the football for the Scarlet Knights and put a little fear into the mind of Joe Paterno, the Nittany Lions' coach.

title: Jet Blast Causes Havoc
description: An exhaust blast from a DC-9 shot into a Midway Airport terminal, knocking down a temporary wall, bowling over two travelers and scattering others. No one was reported injured in the blast Friday. Neal Szczender, superintendent of passenger services for Midway Airlines, said the blast came from a Midway plane that was turning. He said planes routinely make the same turn. and he could not explain why one blast did so much damage.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COSMETIC DENTISTRY
description: GOING into the 1980's, the dental industry appeared headed for some trouble - brought on, ironically, by its own impressive achievement in helping to reduce tooth decay in this country by 50 percent in two decades. But just as the need for traditional dental work declined, cosmetic dentistry began to flourish. Today, more than 80 percent of the nation's 130,000 dentists do cosmetic work, and many report it is the fastest growing part of their practice.

title: Brazil Gets Help on Radiation Accident
description: Experts from the United States, the Soviet Union and elsewhere have rushed to Brazil to assist in a radiation accident now proving to be the most serious of its kind in the Western Hemisphere.

title: For Germany's Greens, Success Breeds a Schism
description: Seven years after the first scruffy Greens elbowed their way into the stodgy world of West German politics, the environmentalists are finding that success can be the bane of radical politics.

title: THE TITANS OF OLD ARE STILL GOOD SOURCES
description: THE games of the great players of yesteryear are primarily useful for inspiration and not absolute truth. Nevertheless, one must beware of rushing to fault the thinking of the titans of the game.

title: Ballet: Four Offerings From the Feld Troupe
description: THE Feld Ballet did not bill the fourth program of its current season at the Joyce Theater as a retrospective. But the selection of ballets, presented on Wednesday, did offer an enjoyable and thought-provoking look at Eliot Feld's career.

title: Miss Peppe Wed To F. M. Sterneck
description: Robin Frances Peppe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen F. Peppe of Atlantic Beach, L.I., and Pittsfield, Mass., and Frank Martin Sterneck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris H. Sterneck of St. Louis, were married yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel in New York. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

title: U.S. Hints at Hutton Indictment in Money Scheme
description: Law-enforcement officials said today that the Justice Department would ''most likely'' seek indictment of the New York brokerage E. F. Hutton & Company on charges of laundering money for organized crime.

title: Allison Hall Whipple Plans to Marry Peter Clark Rockefeller, an Appraiser
description: Mrs. George Carroll Whipple of Carmel, N.Y., has announced the engagment of her daughter Allison Hall Whipple to Peter Clark Rockefeller, a son of Rodman C. Rockefeller of New York and the late Barbara Olsen Rockefeller. A December wedding is planned.

title: Chancellor Candidates Seek Hispanic Support
description: Four educators interested in becoming New York City's next schools chancellor sought the support of Hispanic educational groups at a forum yesterday where the overriding concern of the audience was that the seven-member school board has no Hispanic members.

title: THE MOSCOW BOOK FAIR: GLASNOST HAS ITS LIMITS
description: DURING the Moscow International Book Fair last month more than 150 writers and publishers - Russians and Americans - attended an unusual reception in a Moscow restaurant held by the Association of American Publishers and its International Freedom to Publish Committee. The mix was extraordinary; prominent Soviet publishing officials and establishment writers mingled with members of the dissident Soviet intelligentsia, including a number of writers who, only a few months before, had been in Siberian exile or confined in labor camps because of their writings.

title: U.N. Lebanon Force Facing Crisis on Funds
description: The United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon faces what could be a crippling financial crisis as a result of moves in the United States Congress that threaten to cut off all American money for the operation, according to United Nations officials and diplomats.

title: CAR MADNESS IN MANHATTAN: CURE SOUGHT
description: EVERY workday 3.4 million people converge on Manhattan in movement so massive that the city's transportation commissioner, Ross Sandler, says it can only be compared to the tides. It falls to Mr. Sandler to smooth out the eddies and maintain the flow as best he can. That task has grown progressively harder since the mid-70's, when the number of commuters started to climb.

title: Miss Payne Plans A February Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Payne Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Payne to Edward J. Gerrity 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrity Jr. of Rye, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: NEW LONDON REMEMBERS O'NEILL WITH A YEARLONG TRIBUTE
description: EUGENE O'NEILL always kept a memory of New London, and his plays are filled with scenes and characters of the city where he spent many summers. Beginning this week, organizations in and near that waterfront city will remember America's only Nobel Prize-winning playwright, in a yearlong series of events to celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth next year.

title: Sooners Roll, 44-9, On 7 Interceptions
description: Seven interceptions stymied Texas, and Oklahoma raced to a 44-9 rout today behind Jamelle Holieway and Lydell Carr.

title: Hong Kong's Hottest Hot Spot
description: OF all the Western-type businesses that Beijing seems to be warming to these days, perhaps the most unlikely is a gaudy nightclub here in the commercial district where cognac sells for $113 a bottle and 1,000 ''hostesses'' sell their services to a pin-striped clientele.

title: Georgia Case Tied to Queens Radium Cleanup
description: The Federal Government and the State of Georgia in effect control the stock of a corporation that owns a factory in New York City believed to be contaminated with radium, court papers show.

title: POSTINGS: The Upzoning Solution; Queens Condos
description: John C. O'Reilly and Jack Phillips own a sheet-metal fabricating plant in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens. ''We really don't belong here,'' said Mr. Phillips of the one-story building, on 35th Avenue at 70th Street. ''This is a prime residential area.''

title: Zoo Condor Dies in 60's
description: The oldest resident of the Milwaukee County Zoo, an Andean condor believed to be 66 years old, has died. Zoo officials said Friday that an examination showed the bird, a male named Connie, died Wednesday of heart artery collapse related to old age. In 1922 Milwaukee's city engineer, George F. Staal, brought Connie and another young condor here from Argentina in 1922 and gave them to the zoo. It was estimated at the time that they were a year old. The other bird died years ago.

title: Reagan Sends Letters on Gulf to Congress Leaders
description: President Reagan sent letters to Congressional leaders today advising them that American military forces in the Persian Gulf took ''limited defensive action'' last week when they fired on Iranian gunboats.

title: DIARY OF A LOST WEEKEND
description: I'VE BEEN GOING TO CLUBS IN LOS ANGELES for longer than I want to admit.

title: UTILITIES' PRACTICES ASSAILED
description: A LARGE number of New Jersey independent tradesmen are beginning to feel like that appliance repairman in the television commercials who rarely gets any calls, and they say it is because of unfair competition from utility companies.

title: MAKING OF THE ENGLISH ARTIST
description: IT took a lot of foreigners to get British art started: Germans, Lowlanders, Italians, Frenchmen and strays from as far afield as Rostock and Prague. Most came as mercenaries and many stayed to become citizens.

title: 'WHISTLEBLOWER' ACT GETS ITS FIRST TEST
description: IN WHAT is believed to be the first suit filed under a year-old state statute, the former national sales manager of a Japanese-owned electronics company in Mount Laurel has asserted he was dismissed for complaining about defective computer parts that the company knowingly shipped to dealers and sold to the public.

title: For a 'Triple-Zero' Pact
description: LEAD: Too little attention is being paid to the likely aftershocks of the emerging ''double zero'' agreement to remove intermediate- and shorter-range nuclear missiles from Europe. In the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the pact will create a new set of problems and tensions centering on conventional Soviet military strength, particularly tanks.

title:
INVESTING;
Why This Market Cycle Isn't Different
description: LEAD: THE four most dangerous words in investing are ''this time it's different,'' according to John Templeton, the highly regarded 74-year-old mutual fund manager. At stock market tops and bottoms, investors invariably use this rationale to justify their emotion-driven decisions.

title: Campaign Finance; Du Pont and His Quest for Money: If It's Monday, It Must Be Cincinnati
description: The sixth generation scion of one of the nation's wealthiest dynasties was calling a man he had never met to ask for money.

title: SPORTS
description: The Drive for Five CBS/Fox Video. 60 minutes. $19.98.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SPANISH CIVIL WAR AS A RELIGIOUS TRAGEDY. By Jose M. Sanchez. (University of Notre Dame, $22.95.) The Pope's recent beatification of three nuns martyred during the Spanish Civil War (1936-39) has revived public controversy surrounding one of the more tragic episodes of the conflict: the killing within the Republican zone of almost 7,000 priests and nuns during the war's opening months.

title: 'WHAT WE'RE TRYING TO DO IS PROTECT ANIMALS'
description: PRISCILLA FERAL of Norwalk is the national president of Friends of Animals Inc., a 30-year-old organization that advocates animals rights. Initially started to address the growing problem of stray cats and dogs, the group now also concerns itself with the protection of wild animals and laboratory animals. The organization has 62,000 members, about 6,000 of whom live in Connecticut.

title: Michigan Upset; So Is Ohio State
description: Lorenzo White rushed for 185 yards and 2 touchdowns and the defense had 7 interceptions, 4 by the safety John Miller, as Michigan State upset Michigan, 17-11, in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: OTTAWA DEBATES U.S.-CANADIAN TIES
description: Hardly a day has gone by lately without a bitter clash over Canadian-American relations in the House of Commons, a paneled chamber where scurrying messengers in black breeches are one of many reminders of Canada's British past.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: In your special issue, you neglected to discuss the relationship between the United States Constitution and the American Indian. Indeed, you failed even to mention this problematic aspect of United States history. Your oversight was irresponsible and inexcusable. MARK S. WEINER Stanford, Calif.

title: WHO NEEDS A BLOCKBUSTER? ANOTHER WAY OF PUBLISHING
description: DAVID R. SLAVITT'S 26th novel, ''Alice at 80,'' was a resounding critical success when it appeared three years ago.

title: AIDS SPREAD SEEN IN SAME PATTERNS
description: A study of AIDS infection among patients at a New York City clinic for sexually transmitted diseases indicates that the AIDS virus is not spreading widely beyond members of known risk groups and their sex partners.

title: SYMPHONIC VOICE FROM CHINA IS HEARD AGAIN
description: TWENTY YEARS AGO, WHEN China began a decade-long descent into the violent political madness of the Cultural Revolution, Chen Zuohuang graduated from the high school attached to the Central Conservatory of Music and was shipped to a village near Shijiazhuang, 175 miles southwest of Beijing, to plant rice.

title: Miss Clancy Marries Hallett Gates 3d
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., Kathleen Ann Clancy, a daughter of Dorothy Clancy of Morristown, N.J., and Richard J. Clancy of Boston, was married yesterday to Hallett R. Gates 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gates Jr. of New York and Lyme, Conn. The Rev. James Mahoney performed the ceremony.

title: Trailing, 17-0, Penn Rallies Over Brown
description: Penn, the defending Ivy League football champion, scored 25 second-half points to rally from an early 17-0 deficit and stun Brown, 38-17, today at Franklin Field.

title: GEPHARDT INVADES DUKAKIS TERRITORY
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign of Representative Richard A. Gephardt has had some encouraging developments in recent days, with valuable endorsements and the elimination or wounding of some competitors.

title: Be Practical With World Cup
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Greeks of Stature
description: To the Editor:

title: BETHPAGE GOES TO 3-0
description: Two 50-yard passes for touchdowns gave Bethpage a 22-7 victory yesterday over the home team New Hyde Park. The Bethpage quarterback, Andy Marinuzzi, was 8 for 10 for 158 yards and two touchdowns. James Ryan, a wide receiver, was his target for both scores.

title: Massachusetts Bridal For Tobey J. Nemser
description: Tobey J. Nemser, a daughter of Joan Cooledge of Arlington, Mass., and the Rev. Rudolph Nemser of Moorestown, N.J., and Gregory Tang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chung L. Tang of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Winchester, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, minister of the Unitarian Church in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Carol Siegel Is Married To Peter Jeffrey Korda
description: Carol Nancy Siegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Siegel of East Rockaway, L.I., and Peter Jeffrey Korda, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Korda of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married last evening at the Woodmere (L.I.) Club by Rabbi Eugene Lipsey.

title: DATELINE PEKING
description: CHINA REPORTING An Oral History of American Journalism in the 1930s and 1940s. By Stephen R. MacKinnon and Oris Friesen. Illustrated. 230 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $20.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: If Patricia Bosworth, an author of some renown, could change one thing about herself, she has no doubt what it would be. It's been galling her for years and the only thing she can't figure out is why she's never done anything about it. She turns to jelly in the drivers' seat of a car.

title: ONSTAGE IN THE GLOBAL VILLAGE
description: TWENTY YEARS AFTER MARSHALL McLuhan's heyday, and a decade after he might have seemed passe, what he said seems to have come incontrovertibly true. We really do live now in a ''global village'' where nearly everyone - or at least the more sensitive among us, meaning our artists - is affected by everyone else. It is increasingly difficult today for a Western artist, who once might have stayed safely within the course of his own culture's evolution, to remain apart from the traditions of other cultures. This is the era of international artistic cross-fertilization, and on Tuesday Peter Brook's ''Mahabharata'' opens in Brooklyn as if to prove the point.

title: Best Sellers: October 11, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. 1 16 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, 2 11 $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 3 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt 8 2 Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of Pennsylvania, in the aftermath of the Civil War. 4 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, 4 2 $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program "A Prairie Home Companion." 5 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 2 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert 2 14 E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 HOW TO MARRY THE MAN OF YOUR CHOICE, 3 10 by Margaret Kent. (Warner, $14.95.) Ways to find a mate. 4 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. 4 18 (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 MINDING THE BODY, MENDING THE MIND, by 1 Joan Borysenko with Larry Rothstein. (Addison-Wesley, $14.95.) A program designed to improve your mental and physical health.

title: An Industry No One Wants
description: MANY cities are eager to attract new industry. La Mesa, Calif., appeared eager in late 1985 to get rid of an old one.

title: MASSACHUSETTS 'MIRACLE' WORKER: Ira Jackson; The Tax Man Goeth - But His Policies Live On
description: PATRONS at Sullivan's Tap, in the shadow of the Boston Garden, were settling down on a June day last year to watch their beloved Celtics on television when agents from the Massachusetts State Revenue Department burst in, snapped off the T.V. and, before anyone could say ''Red Auerbach,'' shut Sullivan's for tax evasion. The raid was the work of Ira Jackson, until recently the Massachusetts State Commissioner of Revenue. Over the past four years, the 39-year-old Mr. Jackson has brought an Eliot Ness-style zeal to the practice of tax collections here - seizing yachts in Marblehead harbor and Rolls-Royces on Beacon Hill as part of a drive that has increased tax revenues and helped to close the state's budget deficit.

title: Head of AIDS Commission Pledges Quick Reorganization of Panel
description: The new chairman of the President's commission on AIDS pledged today to get the panel reorganized and indicated that he would be filling a key staff post early next week.

title: Repairs Hinder Traffic at 3 Hudson Crossings
description: Road construction projects and unexpectedly heavy weekend traffic combined yesterday to produce some of the worst delays of the year for New York City-bound drivers at the Lincoln Tunnel and its New Jersey approaches.

title: Frances Currey Weds Roger Briggs Jr.
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday, Frances Hampton Currey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brownlee O. Currey Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married to Roger Thomas Briggs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Briggs of Wilmette, Ill. The Rev. John Andrews, rector of St. Thomas, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Reinke, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
INVESTING;
Cold Calls for Pricey Stocks
description: LEAD: INVESTORS CENTER INC., a Long Island-based brokerage firm, specializes in new issues of very low-priced stocks. Like bigger firms, it provides ''research'' on stocks it would like to sell. And like bigger firms, it puts brokers to the thankless task of making unsolicited sales calls.

title: The Reagan AIDS Strategy in Ruins
description: While the AIDS epidemic gets its grip on America, Mr. Reagan's Administration spouts, postures and neglects effective measures to curb it.

title: Jane Susan Abelow Is Wed to Bradley David Finn
description: Jane Susan Abelow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Abelow of Baldwin, L.I., was married last evening to Bradley David Finn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Finn of St. Paul. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink, a cousin of the bride, officiated at Normandie Court in Manhattan.

title: HOMOSEXUALS AND THE CHURCHES
description: LEAD: IT IS NO ONE'S IMAGE OF what homosexuals do in New York City on a Friday night. Every week, 30 men, most of them in their 20's and 30's, meet in a therapist's office on Manhattan's Upper East Side where, for an hour and a half, they study the Bible. ''Book by book,'' says Ralph Blair, a professional therapist with a master's degree in religious studies and a doctorate in counseling.

title: Islanders Crush Canucks, 7-1
description: Power-play goals by Brent Sutter, Gord Dineen, Mikko Makela and Bob Bassen sparked the Islanders to a 7-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: Boy, 2, Killed in Fire As Rescue Is Delayed
description: A 2-year-old boy died in a fire in New York City early yesterday morning as firefighting units were delayed in reaching the blaze because of illegally parked cars.

title: Rabies Outbreak Reported Confined to Wilds
description: A nine-year-old outbreak of rabies in skunks, raccoons and other wild animals is continuing, but no people have been infected with the disease in the United States in two years, researchers have reported.

title: CONGRESS AGAIN CONFRONTS HAZARDS OF KILLER CHEMICALS
description: ''THE most alarming of all man's assaults upon the environment is the contamination of air, earth, rivers, and sea with dangerous and even lethal materials,'' Rachel Carson wrote a quarter of a century ago in her celebrated book ''Silent Spring.'' Today there is little disagreement with her warnings in regard to such broad-spectrum pesticides as DDT, then widely used, now banned. But there is still hot debate over how to apply modern pesticides - which are designed to kill specific types of weeds or insects - in ways that do not harm people and their environment.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: In order to keep peace and satisfy the traditionalists, why not allow the teams participating in the Series to use their own judgment? In other words, the respective managers will have the option of using the d.h., or playing a good- hitting pitcher. National League fans and owners always argue ''there is no strategy, with the d.h.'' Let's give them a choice. To ban the d.h. from World Series play robs the fans and takes the older star from his place in the sun.

title: '42ND STREET' STAGED AT DARIEN DINNER THEATER
description: ''THINK of musical comedy, the most glorious words in the English language!''

title: No Headline
description: Arriving at Burnham Beeches, an Art Deco country house surrounded by elegant, cultivated gardens and wild forests beyond, it is hard to believe that this is Australia. So much of the Australian landscape is red, harsh and barren; by contrast this secluded, lush estate only an hour's drive from Melbourne feels like an unspoiled corner of England.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
A CLASSIC IN HER LIFETIME
description: LEAD: WELTY A Life in Literature. Edited by Albert J. Devlin. 310 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $25.

title: Data Update: October 11, 1987
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars)

title: CANDIDATES: COME LOSE BEFORE A VOTE
description: CARMELLA R. IABONI said she had never realized how many courts there were in New York state until she had to appear in most of them.

title: 'NOBODY LEAVES THE CHURCH'
description: ONCE A CATHOLIC Prominent Catholics and Ex-Catholics Reveal the Influence of the Church on Their Lives and Work. By Peter Occhiogrosso. 371 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the new television season includes an outdated passage about the CBS-TV series ''Jake and the Fatman,'' derived from a videotape of the pilot episode supplied by the network for review. In episodes that have been broadcast, the dialogue has been rewritten to use language that is not offensive; no words are bleeped out.

title: The Non-Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL IS FAR FROM QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT
description: MORTIMER B. Zuckerman's plans to develop the western arc of Columbus Circle have been officially approved by New York City. But many New Yorkers remain opposed to his proposal to replace the New York Coliseum with two multi-purpose towers, a project that some critics see as emblematic of a city government smitten by development fever.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-27

title: 'DAY OF PAINTING'
description: Armed with a box lunch, an easel and a taste for artistic adventure, 85 painters and watercolorists will descend on Cold Spring on Saturday to draw and color this little village on the Hudson River.

title: CLOSING THE DOOR ON HEAT LOSSES
description: ALTHOUGH poorly sealed windows generally are touted as the greatest source of heat leaks in an insulated home, weatherstripping a main entrance door can have the same effect as sealing several windows.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
FALL SPORT: DECORATE TILL YOU DROP
description: LEAD: IN the fall, a grown man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of playoffs. A woman's turns to decorating. This is no coincidence. Nothing gives a woman more time to contemplate gutting the entire house than a Sunday afternoon baseball game with extra innings.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: It shouldn't! Last week's great pitching duel between the Blue Jays' Flanagan and the Tigers' Morris was a typical game that magnifies why the d.h. is wrong. Just imagine the intricacies that were lost in that big game alone.

title: THE HARVEST CONTINUES
description: PUT the coldframe in order; check sash and sides to be sure they are weather durable; replace or add to the sand base, if necessary, and be sure it is level; use the frame to protect young plants, seedlings and plants of questionable hardiness. Keep up with bulb planting. Cut down stalks of perennials that bloomed. Mow as long as grass keeps growing. The Squashes

title: A WOMAN AT OLD EXETER
description: ONE OF THE FIRST THINGS people noticed when they arrived for the new fall term at the Phillips Exeter Academy was that the fence around the principal's house was down. In the dining hall, in the library, and at the supermarket in Exeter, N. H., the dismantled fence was eagerly discussed, the first tangible evidence of what the new principal would be like. ''The fact that she doesn't want a fence says something,'' observed Christine Robinson, an English teacher at the school.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: MAJOR ANDRE by Anthony Bailey. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. 200 pages. $15.95.

title: West Coast School Sweeps By WILLIAM J. MILLER
description: The 16 parents who accompanied the Palos Verdes High School boys and girls cross-country teams from California to New York for yesterday's Manhattan College Spike Shoe Club Cross Country Championships wore T-shirts that said: ''I helped a Sea King find Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.''

title: Tips on Shopping In the Audio Maze
description: AT THE ONSET OF AU-tumn, life turns indoors, and in anticipation of long evenings of music, many listeners tantalize themselves with thoughts of a new sound system.

title: Frank Aikman Jr. Dies at 77; Was L.I.R.R. Head in 1960's
description: Frank Aikman Jr., president of the Long Island Rail Road in one of its most turbulent periods, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at the Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BUS SWEEPSTAKES
description: LEAD: COUNTY buses have added a few new stops these days, including Europe and Curacao. All one has to do is put a name on a sweepstakes entry form and drop it into a ballot box on display at retail stores and other locations countywide.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
FRIENDLY STRANGERS BEARING FLOWERS
description: LEAD: GARDENING FOR LOVE The Market Bulletins. By Elizabeth Lawrence. Edited by Allen Lacy. 238 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $15.95.

title: COWARD'S 'PRESENT LAUGHTER' AT DREW
description: IN THE cavalcade of Sir Noel Coward's stage works - 27 in all - ''Present Laughter'' somehow is not thought to have come out of the top drawer.

title: ADULTS: DIPLOMAS FULFILL OUR DREAMS
description: LEAD: HANGING in the Naval Recruiting Office in Keyport is a high school diploma dated 1987. It attests that the recruiter - James S. Allen, a 25-year-old gunner's mate, first class -graduated from Cedar Ridge High School in Old Bridge.

title: Prison Boats Are on the Way
description: WITH prisons overcrowded in New York and New Jersey, prison boats - not used in this country since the Revolutionary War - have won attention as stopgap solutions.

title: LONG BEACH HOURS LAW PINCHES 7-ELEVEN STORE
description: WHEN Tanveer Ahmad Khan first decided to buy the 7-Eleven franchise on Long Beach Road in Long Beach, he never suspected that he would be forced to close the convenience store every night at 11 P.M. and not reopen it until the next morning at 5.

title: WHO NEEDS TRENDS?
description: THE PUSHCART PRIZE XII Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Henderson with the ''Pushcart Prize'' editors. Poetry edited by Jorie Graham and Robert Hass. 559 pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: The Pushcart Press. $28.

title: Art
description: As is proved by the new exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris (Park Avenue at 42d Street), Stuart Davis (1892-1964) selected his motifs carefully and did not let them go until they had yielded every possible ounce of visual juice. Titled ''Stuart Davis: An American in Paris,'' this exhibition (on view through Dec. 10) shows the artist rigorously putting one kind of image - the Parisian street scene - through its paces.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: I am puzzled that the case of the St. Louis high school newspaper was ever granted an appeal (''From Hazelwood to the High Court,'' by Mark A. Uhlig). Calling a public-school publication a ''public forum'' is sheer varnish. Do pupils buy the newspaper or is it subsidized by the board of education? If the latter, then it is not public. Readers cannot express disapproval by canceling subscriptions or not buying it. The editorial staff is subject to no real public pressure.

title: GUM-CHEWING COWS AND THE INSIDE SKINNY
description: A WORLD UNSUSPECTED Portraits of Southern Childhood. Edited, and with an introduction, by Alex Harris. Illustrated. 237 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. $16.95.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Will Metal Prices Melt?

title: Where Cotton Is Still King
description: Bill Whittington stood in the field, rocking slowly in his boots, and watched the big John Deere cotton picker heave down the snow-white rows. Once the picker had roared past, he studied the sinewy stalks. Bending down, he yanked a clump of cotton off one of them. ''The picker's missing some,'' he said. ''It never gets it all. The thing about hand-picking was, it always got it all. The cotton's looking pretty, though. Real pretty.''

title:
ART;
THE LURE OF AMBIGUITY
description: LEAD: WE are emphatically reminded of art's inventiveness when confronted by images that can be understood several ways at the same time. These are ambiguities that pull us into engaging discoveries.

title: Talks Halt as South Korean Seeks Presidency
description: As Kim Young Sam sees it, he can't lose the race for president because South Koreans consider him the man who has led the struggle for democracy here. As Kim Dae Jung sees it, he can't lose for the same reason.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE VERY RICH HOURS. By Jean McGarry. (Johns Hopkins University, $15.95.) The soul travels a perilous road, as every Roman Catholic knows, where sorrow tempers glory. So Anne Marie Kane, an Irish-American star parochial student from Providence, R.I., becomes an uneasy postulant in the heady intellectual temple of Harvard University, only to find herself out of her depth at every turn.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
NEWARK: THE RIGHT PLACE FOR THE ARTS
description: LEAD: IN A BOLD and farsighted move, Governor Kean has endorsed a consultant's recommendation that the state's Performing Arts Center be built in the heart of Newark, thus challenging a widely held opinion that visiting Newark is worthwhile only to earn a living or to use its international airport.

title: ONE IS TRADITIONAL, THE OTHER CONTEMPORARY
description: THE United States Postal Service unveiled the designs for its 1987 Christmas stamps. They will be available nationwide Oct. 25.

title: POSTINGS: $200,000 Restoration; Water Mill's Windmill
description: For a good part of the 19th century, the winds off the Atlantic on the eastern end of Long Island turned the wooden blades of the windmill that anchored the green in the hamlet of Water Mill. Wheat and corn were ground there and farm families were fed for miles around.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: Judging from your selection of commentators and Anthony Lewis's comment that finding the Constitution's meaning is ''lawyers' work,'' I was surprised that your bicentennial issue didn't suggest that the Preamble be changed to begin ''We, the lawyers. . . .''

title: EQUALITY IS NOT ENOUGH
description: AND WE ARE NOT SAVED The Elusive Quest for Racial Justice. By Derrick Bell. 288 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title:
THE TALK OF THE TOWN OF BEDFORD;
WHERE FREEDOM'S NOT JUST ANOTHER WORD
description: LEAD: THE lingering blue-gray of dawn is lifting from the Bedford Village green, restoring white to the Federalist-era structures that dot Route 22, the main street of the hamlet. The road is also the heart of the still smaller swatch of the town of Bedford that since 1973 has been designated a state and Federal Historic District.

title: KEEPING THE FAT RAT ALIVE
description: THE MELTING POT And Other Subversive Stories. By Lynne Sharon Schwartz. 230 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Dr. Clay Is Wed To C. W. Morris
description: Dr. Christina Marie Clay, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Clay of Waukegan, Ill., was married yesterday to Christopher Wright Morris, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. John B. Morris of Atlanta. The bridegroom's father and the Rev. Henri A. Stines, the bridegroom's godfather, officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Chicago.

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $246,000 5 Victoria Way 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new waterfront town-house condominium; gatehouse, balcony, deck; monthly charges $215, estimated taxes $4,500. Copiague $252,000 7 Lagoon Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 9-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,400. Floral Park $270,000 264-11 Williston Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old brick ranch; fireplace, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,200. North Massapequa $165,000 976 Park Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. Shirley $110,000 53 Alden Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Westbury $176,500 108 East Cypress Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. OTHER AREAS Short Hills, N.J. $425,000 295 Lupine Way 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, C/A, fireplace; taxes $4,591. Avon, Conn. $270,000 8 Stony Corners Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old saltbox; screened porch, 1 acre; taxes $2,102. Armonk, N.Y. $293,500 29 Glendale Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, family room; not yet assessed.

title: THE FIRST RULE IS 'BREAK THE RULES'
description: THE flouting of conventions having become a convention itself, there is little to be gained from musing on who broke what rule first.

title: CRITICISM FOR UTILITY FOLLOWS SNOWFALL
description: CHIEF Thomas Rotunda of the Ridgefield police said he knew first-hand Northeast Utilities did not play favorites in restoring power after the snow storm last Sunday that cut electricity to 75,000 residents for up to four days.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: Use both the d.h. and let the pitcher hit. By doing so, it allows the d.h. to take his spot in the lineup, keeping A.L. strategies intact, while ''old-fashioned'' N.L. baseball would still be a part of the fall classic. Of course, fans would see less of their top- and middle-of-the-lineup favorites, but this would be offset by the inherent fairness to both teams. And fairness is paramount, especially in the A.L., where it is still deemed unfair to play by the rules and let pitchers hit.

title: Miss Freehill to Wed Michael C. Hoffman
description: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Freehill of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kelly Ann Freehill to Michael Carey Hoffman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Hoffman of Barker, N.Y.

title: HUNGER PLAN IN NEW HAVEN
description: LEAD: NEW HAVEN officials, responding to a study that found a significant hunger problem in one of the city's poorest sections, are seeking ways to feed the hungry.

title: POLAND ANNOUNCES BIG ECONOMIC SHIFT WITH RISE IN PRICES
description: Poland's Government announced a package of far-reaching governmental and economic changes today mixing capitalism and socialism. It said the measures would bring higher prices and increased unemployment but would also create the conditions for advance.

title: NEWFOUND COLONIAL MUSIC SCHEDULED
description: THE director of a chamber-music ensemble retained by the New Jersey Historical Society has uncovered several obscure works from the Federal period, some of which probably have not been heard since about the time their composers died.

title: EXPORTS BECOME CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: LONG ISLAND'S foreign trade compares favorably with that of most regions in the country. Even so, the subject has become an issue in the campaign for Suffolk County Executive.

title: BAD TRIES TO BE BETTER
description: LEAD: CRAZY HEART By Thomas Cobb. 248 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Palmer Closing In: Arnold Palmer moved a step closer to his first victory in 28 months on yesterday, knocking in two eagles eagles in shooting a 67 for a four-stroke lead after the second round of the $250,000 Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga. The 58-year-old Palmer, who shot an opening round 66, was at 133, 11-under-par entering today's final round for the $37,500 first prize. Gary Player tied the course and tourney record with a 65 and was tied in second place.(AP) Tewell Ahead by a Shot: Doug Tewell shot a five-under-par 66 to take a one-stroke lead over Danny Edwards and Phil Blackmar after the third round of the $300,000 Pensacola Open in Florida. Tewell's 66 gave him a three-round score of 12-under-par 201 on the 7,154-yard, par-71 course at the Perdido Bay Resort.(AP) Tennis Noah Advances to Final: Top-seeded Yannick Noah of France defeated sixth-seeded Guy Forget, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the final of the $239,000 Swiss indoors tournament against Roland Agenor of Haiti. Agenor, ranked 47th in the international ranking, scored an easy 6-1, 6-4 victory over Andre Agassi of the United States in the other semifinal in Basel.(AP) Annacome and Connors in Final: Paul Annacone of Bridgehampton, L.I., upset top-ranked Ivan Lendl, 6-3, 6-2 in a semifinal match of the A.T.&T. Challenge in Atlanta, giving Annacone, ranked 41st in the world, victories over the world's top two players in consecutive days. In today's final, Annacone will meet John McEnroe, who defeated Jimmy Connors 6-4, 6-4 in yesterday's other semifinal. (AP) Baseball Seibu Lions Clinch: The Seibu Lions clinched their fifth Pacific League Japanese baseball championship - their third in a row - by beating the Kintetsu Buffaloes, 9-7, yesterday. The Lions will meet the Yomiuri Giants, who won their 24th Central League title Friday, their first in four years. (AP) Boxing Ramirez Retains Title: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico knocked out Cornelius Boza-Edwards of Uganda in the fifth round last night in Paris to retain his World Boxing Council lightweight title. It was Ramirez's first defense of the title after regaining it in July. In the fifth Ramirez slowed Boza-Edwards to a walk with a solid left, then continued with another left, a slow right to the head and a left to the body. Boza-Edwards finally crumbled under the multitude of punches. The Ugandan went to his hands and knees and could not get up as Referee Arthur Mercante signaled the bout was over. Ramirez, now 100-5, recorded his 81st career knockout. Boza-Edwards is 45-7-1.(AP) Hockey Team USA Wins: Peter Laviolette, Steve Leach, Scott Young and Lane McDonald each scored goals and Mike Richter made 34 saves last night to lead Team USA to a 4-2 victory over Team Canada in exhibition hockey at the Lake Placid (N.Y.) Olympic Ice Arena. After a scoreless first period, Laviolette scored the lone goal of the second period at 2:23. Leach and Young scored 4:36 apart in the third period to give Team USA a three-goal lead. Leach scooped up a pass from Allen Bourbeau along the boards, circled the net and fired a low shot just inside the far goalpost at 5:59. Young deflected a slapshot by Brian Leetch past the Canadian goalie, Sean Burke, at 10:35. Trent Young ruined Richter's shutout bid when he scored from the top of the left faceoff circle at 13:57. Claude Vilgrain scored from the slot less than four minutes later, but McDonald converted a rebound at 17:59 to ice the triumph.(AP)

title: Magic Show
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVICE ABOUT CHOLESTEROL IS FINDING AN EAGER MARKET
description: LAST winter, a company that makes a machine for quickly measuring how much cholesterol people have in their blood offered tests for $3 in downtown Indianapolis and at four suburban shopping centers. To the company's surprise, as many as 30,000 customers showed up.

title: Myth or Fact, Nessie Is Still Lure to Many
description: In the name of scientific inquiry and local tourism, two dozen sonar-equipped boats are patrolling the slate-gray waters of Scotland's largest lake in search of that most enduring of natural mysteries, the Loch Ness monster.

title: Opera: New 'Rheingold' At the Metropolitan
description: IN this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one. Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance Friday evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production. If the direction and design team of Otto Schenk and Gunther Schneider-Siemssen continues along the lines of this ''Rheingold,'' the Metropolitan will have a ''Ring'' that Wagnerians can live with for a long time.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN QUEENS DEATH OF JURY WITNESS
description: A 27-year-old man has been arrested in the killing of a taxi dispatcher who testified before a Queens grand jury about a shooting she had witnessed, the police said yesterday.

title: HEALTH BILL STALLS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: A proposal to make affordable health insurance available to all Massachusetts residents has met heavy resistance from state legislators, who call the proposal too expensive and unwieldy.

title: JAVA GOLD UPSET IN GOLD CUP
description: Creme Fraiche won the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday at Belmont Park by stealing an easy lead through staggeringly slow fractions that allowed him to post a 4 3/4-length victory over Java Gold.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Starting Up With a Converted Apartment
description: LEAD: f1520>THE view from Fairfield on the Water, a 247-unit cooperative apartment complex in Patchogue, is of the Great South Bay and, across Tuthills Creek, of the Harbour at Blue Point, a new town-house condominium.

title: Trucking of Toxic Rocket Chemical Is Assailed
description: A toxic rocket fuel component that the Air Force is shipping by truck around the country threatens a ''Bhopal on our highways,'' an environmental group has charged.

title: Calling In the Smile Designers
description: DO you dream of having a cover-girl smile? Dr. Jeff Golub of New York can create one for you. Or he can give you the smile of a barracuda - as he recently did for a film actor playing a cannibalistic visitor from outer space.

title: LABOR SHORTAGE IS SEEN
description: In discussing regional market trends, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, said: ''I don't like to hear people in Westchester talking about growth problems. The problems of growth are easier to deal with than the problems of decline. I know many other communities that would love to change places with Westchester.''

title: LAND-SWAP PROPOSAL FOR PINELANDS PUT FORTH
description: THE day in January 1979 that Robert W. Schenck bought five acres in Bass River Township, Gov. Brendan T. Byrne declared a building moratorium for the Pinelands National Reserve.

title: Riding a Boom, Downtowns Are No Longer Downtrodden
description: Like many other cities around the nation, Chicago is riding the crest of a boom in downtown investment. New office buildings, new stores, new residents and whole new neighborhoods are being added at a record pace to the heart of America's third-largest city.

title: MORE ON THE MISSILE CRISIS
description: How times change! The article on the reunion of the White House participants in the Cuban missile crisis (''Class Reunion: Kennedy's Men Relive the Cuban Missile Crisis,'' Aug. 30, by J. Anthony Lukas) reveals as a positive contribution toward peace a proposal for which Adlai Stevenson was viciously attacked and almost driven from his post as chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Spellman Routs Iona
description: While Iona Prep escaped with a victory over Mount St. Michael last week without Beau Snell, their star running back who was out with pneumonia, they were not so lucky this weekend and lost, 48-15, to Cardinal Spellman yesterday.

title: Patricia Nodell Weds
description: Patricia Anne Nodell, the daughter of Margaret A. Barber of New York and Eugene J. Nodell of New Britain, Conn., was married yesterday to David Daniel Leopold, a son of Phyllis D. Leopold of New York and Leonard G. Leopold. The Rev. Richard D. Burke performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church in Manhattan. Mrs. Leopold, the office manager for Charles W. Wolf Inc., a New York distributor of marketing materials, is a junior at the City College of the City University of New York. Her husband is the president of and the principal in Access Couriers Inc., a messenger company in Manhattan.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
Teaneck
description: LEAD: FROM the outset Teaneck dares to be different. While commercial development is common elsewhere along Route 4, strict planning a half century ago has kept the three-mile greenbelt bordering the blacktop bisecting the township free of diners, gas stations or billboards.

title: WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT ALL THE TRAFFIC CONGESTION?
description: Ross Sandler Transportation Commissioner

title: What's Doing in New Orleans
description: New Orleans is a world-class city for idling. The sultry south Louisiana climate almost demands it, the city's nickname ''the big easy'' attests it, and fall rivals spring as the prime season for it.

title: Scott Lawrence Marks Weds Robbie Robinson
description: At the Guardian Angel Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Mary Heather Robinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Robinson of Sharon, N.H., was married yesterday to Scott Lawrence Marks, the son of Peggy Dahl Peeters of New York and Sarasota, Fla., and Donald M. Marks of New York. The Rev. John Baptist performed the ceremony.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Don't Like The Weather? . . .

title: At a Trial in Sierra Leone, a Script for a Coup
description: On paper, Francis M. Minah is an African steeped in the Western traditions of law.

title: Japanese Resurgent in Experiments on Particles
description: A new particle accelerator, causing electrons and positrons to collide at energies higher than those of any other such accelerator, is restoring Japan's prewar position near the front rank of experimental physics.

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER IS KEY TO RADIANT FALL COLORS
description: LEAD: A FRINGE benefit of living in the Northeast is the spectacular fall color we experience most every year. Along with that part of eastern Asia that lies in a comparable position in relation to the land mass and the ocean, we are blessed with a panoramic display of autumnal foliage color that few other regions of the earth can enjoy.

title: If They Fall, So Will Our Stock Markets
description: A WELL-KNOWN soba (noodle) shop in Tokyo's downtown financial district closed in January of this year. Rumor has it the owner accepted a 2 billion yen ($14 million) offer from a shady jiageya, or real estate asembler, for his 450-square-foot patch of land and then used some of the proceeds to buy a gorgeous estate in the Tokyo suburbs.

title: Verbatim; Holding That Line
description: 'We won the Super Bowl because we were all together. The tighter we stay as a team, the better chance we have to dig ourself out of this hole.' - Jim Burt, New York Giants nose tackle, after discouraging teammates from crossing picket lines.

title: GOLF OR TENNIS?
description: Tennis anyone? Or perhaps golf? County Chamber of Commerce Inc. is sponsoring the first Golden Apple business community golf and tennis outing, to be held Oct. 20, at the Westchester Hills Golf Club in White Plains.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: The usual rules of hospitality should prevail - the host determines the rules, quite simply. In the A.L. ball park, there will be a d.h. In the N.L., there will not.

title: DATA BANK: October 11, 1987
College Football; Colgate Fumble Helps Lehigh Win
description: Mark McGowan passed 6 yards for a touchdown to Rich Curtis with 7 minutes 35 seconds left in the third quarter to give Lehigh a 7-6 victory over Colgate today.

title: THE INDICTMENT OF BESS MYERSON
description: FOUR years ago, when she was still Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, political ally and good friend, Bess Myerson hired a young woman named Sukhreet Gabel for a city job. Miss Gabel's mother is Hortense W. Gabel, who was then a State Supreme Court justice, and shortly afterward the judge lowered support payments that Ms. Myerson's companion, Carl A. Capasso, had to pay his estranged wife.

title: Jackson Makes Formal Bid for Presidency in 1988
description: In the heart of what he called ''the new South,'' where he is running well ahead of the other candidates, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today officially announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: FARMERS CUT BACK FOR LACK OF HELP
description: A SHORTAGE of labor is a statewide problem, but it has hit farmers particularly hard. High school students, once the main source of temporary farm help, now choose from an array of well-paying jobs. And more often than not, working on the farm does not top the students' lists.

title: In the Region:Westchester and Connecticut; 122 Houses Approved, at $1 Million Each
description: WHILE million-dollar houses make up only ''a thin slice of the market,'' the market is there, says Henry J. Paparazzo, and he is prepared to build for it.

title: Jersey in Great Need Of Physical Therapists
description: WHEN Nancy Reger decided to become a physical therapist 13 years ago, the emphasis was on rehabilitating stroke and accident victims and using heat treatments and exercises to soothe sore backs and necks. Physical therapy was called ''shake and bake.''

title: Tuition Plan Is Facing Repeal
description: A legislative committee has voted unanimously to recommend repealing a unique law that raises tuition for foreign students attending state colleges.

title: Philharmonic: Ohlsson Is Sanderling's Soloist
description: THE latest guest conductor in the New York Philharmonic's young season is Kurt Sanderling. Mr. Sanderling is a German who apprenticed under Furtwangler, Klemperer and Kleiber in the 1920's but who also spent a third of his life in the Soviet Union. His program at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday afternoon seemed a convergence of these experiences. Indeed, what we had was a German sobriety presiding over two impulsive Russian pieces - the Prokofiev Third Piano Concerto and Shostakovich's 15th Symphony.

title: Making a Living Is Now A Family Enterprise
description: PURSUING a livelihood in America is increasingly a family enterprise, where success is no longer measured by the earning power of a single job.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: OLD BOOKS

title: Maine Dam Stymies Fish and Anglers
description: The story goes that the Pleasant River, a narrow strip of water not much bigger than a stream, once was so full of Atlantic salmon that a fisherman could walk across the river by stepping on the backs of fish.

title: The Epic of a People Writ Large on Canvas
description: WHEN JACOB LAWRENCE turned 70 last month, we all had something to celebrate. Mr. Lawrence is a black

title: THE CITY SEES THE OLD, OLD CARDINALS' SHOW
description: THIS is supposed to be such a sophisticated town. The locals call it The City, and it's a $500 fine for any yokel who calls it Frisco.

title: SOMERVILLE ATHLETE IS FACING 2 CAREERS
description: IT WAS an outside pitch, one that Terry Bross certainly should not have swung at. He lunged, tore a muscle on the left side of his lower back and saw his first professional baseball season come to an abrupt halt.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week about a novelist and his role in the Sag Harbor Initiative misidentified him. He is William Demby.

title: HE TURNED AROUND AND SHE WAS GONE
description: THE CHILD IN TIME By Ian McEwan. 263 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Berkshire Boom Spurs Resorts
description: LEAD: A STRONG tourist and second-home market, combined with Berkshire County's increasing popularity as a conference site, has led to the development of several large, mixed-use resorts here in the last five years.

title: On Language; Murder Board At the Skunk Works
description: BORK SHUNNED 'MURDER Boards' and Prepped Alone'' was the headline in Legal Times. Before the Senate hearings into the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork began, according to the Washington weekly for lawyers, the White House held a session with the President's nominee to the Supreme Court to help him anticipate likely questions. ''He did one moot court over at the White House,'' a Bork friend was quoted as saying, ''but after that he canceled all the rest.''

title:
FOOD;
PLAYING WITH FIRE
description: LEAD: IN A POCKET OF HINDU INDIA IS A region called Mangalore, with a large population of Christians. Fish and meat eaters in the vegetarian south, alcohol drinkers in an abstemious country, the Mangalores have developed their own distinct cuisine.

title: A DESERT WASTELAND
description: The Food column (''Seafood of the Desert,'' Aug. 30, by Susan Herrmann Loomis) was an unintentional parody of the trendy invasion that has turned much of the Southwest into a wasteland of tourists and yuppies. Although real food can still be found in Santa Fe and northern New Mexico, it seems The New York Times would not care to say so. A roadhouse in Espanola could offer more serious fare than the evanescent offerings of the Coyote Cafe. WARREN BUCKLES Madison, Wis.

title: Case Ended In the Death Of a Panther
description: The Justice Department is dropping charges against a Seminole Indian chief who was accused of killing a panther in violation of the Endangered Species Act.

title: Sheepshead Bay, Canarsie Maintain Perfect Records
description: Sheepshead Bay and Canarsie each won yesterday and remained the only undefeated teams from Brooklyn in the Public School Athletic League. Both schools, which play in the Brooklyn A Division I, are 4-0.

title: SCHOOLCHILDREN AND STANDARD TESTS
description: In a recent essay, ''Improving Standard Tests for Children'' [ Opinion page, Sept. 20 ] , Dr. Nicholas P. Criscuolo, the Supervisor of Reading and Language Arts for New Haven Public Schools, expressed ''support'' for the Connecticut Mastery Testing Program, but concluded that the program needs ''refinement.''

title: LOUIS H. POWELL
description: Louis H. Powell, a New York City lawyer whose practice was mainly in music publishing, motion pictures and the performing arts, died of complications of diabetes at his home in Manhattan Wednesday. He was 64 years old.

title: The Job Outlook Across the Nation; FAR WEST
description: THE Silicon Valley has cooled off as California's occupational hot spot. Today, Los Angeles leads the nation in creating new jobs, and the fastest-growing job category in the state is for secretaries. New job opportunities will remain abundant in the nation's most populous state, which added 350,000 jobs last year, according to a report by M/PF Research Inc., of Dallas. Los Angeles gained nearly a third of those jobs, including 25,600 positions in the aerospace industry. The job growth was a major factor in the state's 5.4 percent unemployment rate in August, the lowest in 17 years. Analysts expect a slightly slower pace in 1988.

title: Infighting Seen as Hurting Hospital Union's Image
description: A scuffle that disrupted a meeting at Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union on Thursday was the latest outburst in a five-year struggle that, many observers believe, has seriously tarnished the reputation of the union that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. once called his favorite.

title: J. J. Helmer Wed To Miss Robinson
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Bingham Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Vincent Robinson of St. Charles, Ill., to John Jeffrey Helmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton James Helmer of Stamford, Conn. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Ronald S. James, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Christie Mitchell Weds
description: Christie Ann Mitchell, a daughter of Sue S. Mitchell of Bronxville, N.Y., and George S. Mitchell of Bernardsville, N.J., and David Harding Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Moran of Bronxville, were married there yesterday at the Reformed Church. The Rev. Dr. Robert Bedingfield performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. William Belury, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride. The bride, a graduate of Southern Methodist University, is a buyer at Harvey Electronics in New York. The bridegroom, who graduated from New York University, is a vice president of Hampton Hall Ltd., a marketing company in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER IS KEY TO RADIANT FALL COLORS
description: LEAD: A FRINGE benefit of living in the Northeast is the spectacular fall color we experience most every year. Along with that part of eastern Asia that lies in a comparable position in relation to the land mass and the ocean, we are blessed with a panoramic display of autumnal foliage color that few other regions of the earth can enjoy.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Copious Marketplace At Van Cortlandt The Marketplace at Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson is in full swing in celebration of the fall colors today and each Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 25 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Browsers and buyers will find a country scene with fresh farm produce, breads, preserves, woven willow baskets and handcrafted items such as stained-glass ornaments, hand-stenciled scatter rugs, wooden welcome signs and Blue Sponge and Rinney Pottery. There is no entrance fee for the Marketplace, a cash-and-carry place for the most part, with a few vendors accepting credit cards, with two identifications.

title: Brothers Wield Power in Starkly Different Worlds
description: One brother is the president of the Massachusetts Senate, the other a convicted bank robber and reputed racketeer.

title: LOSS OF ENERGY PROGRAM WORRIES STATE OFFICIALS
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT officials met last week to consider their options after the cancellation of a state program to guarantee utility service to welfare recipients who made regular payments on their energy bills.

title: Outdoors; Stalking the Elusive Bargain
description: SKILL and experience are far more important in most outdoor pursuits than the quality -and cost - of the gear used. However, most of us who camp, canoe, fish and hunt are to some extent enamored of equipment, and the possession, care and maintenance of a nearly perfect tool can be a deeply satisfying part of sport.

title: Vietnam Memorial Plan Disputed in Baltimore
description: A proposed memorial to Vietnam veterans in a small but historic park here has divided neighborhood residents and the project's supporters.

title: ANALYZING THE ENDGAME
description: THERE will be three United States teams taking part in the world team championships beginning today in Jamaica. Two of them will be on the sidelines for the first nine days.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: Anthony Lewis (''An Ingenious Structure'') is right that we have much to be proud of in our Constitution and independent Federal court system. He overstates his case, however, when, in referring to Brown v. Board of Education, he writes that in ''no other country has so deep and divisive an issue been left to judges to decide.'' In fact, slavery itself was abolished in England not as a result of a bloody civil war, but rather by a series of court decisions that culminated in the Abolition Act of 1833. If United States courts had followed this path, rather than the one highlighted by the Dred Scott case, Brown v. Board of Education might have been unnecessary. JOSEPH C. KAPLAN Teaneck, N.J.

title: EARLY LINE: THE '88 FIELD IN NEW YORK
description: With Governor Cuomo dismissing talk of supporting slates of favorite son or uncommitted delegates that could be transformed into Cuomo delegates, New York Democrats are now confronted with making choices among the six current Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Special Today: Careers/Section 12
description: * Making a living is becoming a family enterprise.

title: Marshall Mason Explores A New Stage
description: IT IS MORE LIKE A LONG-RUNNING marriage than many marriages. ''I'll start a sentence and Lanford will finish it,'' says Marshall Mason. ''With the two of us in rehearsal, you have two heads. The problem is, of course, having two mouths. Keeping him quiet while I'm trying to give notes to the actors is quite a job. At Circle Rep, they're used to the two mouths, but I think John and Joan have found it a little startling.''

title: Why the Intense Interest in the Moscow Ballet?
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN BALLET TOUR-ing company from the Soviet Union directed by a well-known Bolshoi star has elicited an unusual amount of interest from within the American dance public. After the Moscow Ballet, led by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, recently opened its current two-month American tour in Baltimore, a cascade of inquiries and comments, from New York to Anchorage, flowed back in response. For the record, incidentally, the closest the Moscow Ballet will come to the New York area is Trenton, when it performs at the War Memorial Auditorium on Nov. 27 and 28.

title:
ART;
FROM 'TARGETS' TO NANAS TO TAROT
description: LEAD: IN 1961, Niki de Saint Phalle astonished visitors to her first solo exhibition in Paris by inviting them to shoot her artworks with rifles. As the bullets slammed into the surfaces of her reliefs and statues, they also punctured bags of paint that splattered the works with random colors, symbolically fusing the acts of destruction and creation.

title: 25 YEARS OF UNIVERSITY PRESS BEST SELLERS
description: FROM CAIRO TO CATTLE RAISING

title: About Men; Facing a Flop
description: FEBRUARY 21, 1986. FIVE AYEM.

title: How's New York Doing? Much Better
description: NEW YORK'S economic picture is never simple, but the current situation is trickier than most. Early in the year there was a spate of announcements from major corporate headquarters that they would be departing the city, carrying hundreds of jobs to the outer edges of the suburbs or beyond. Then there were headlines saying that New York City's employment rate in recent months was the highest it had been since the early 1970's.

title: NASSAU NEEDS L.I.R.R. FENCES TOO
description: Re the article on Hewlett's struggle for a fence alongside a stretch of railroad tracks [ ''Hewlett Seeks Fences Near Railroad Tracks,'' Sept. 6 ] :

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Cairo Opens First Subway In Africa

title: A SLEUTH OF TEDDY BEARS IN BRISTOL
description: LEAD: IF your teddy bear is coming apart at the seams or if he seems to be in need of companionship, he can get the necessary medical and personal attention in Bristol next weekend at the annual Great Teddy Bear Jamboree, Show and Sale.

title: In 2167, Mule Train Is the Way to Go
description: It is the year 2167. Mom, Dad, the kids and Bruno the dog lounge around the simulated sun room of their life-support pod in Westchester. A heap of brochures litters the carpet. The family vacation looms a few weeks away. They have already decided to visit New England, where the nitrous oxide count is lower. But what to do once the mule train pulls in?

title: When Robots Govern Leaders Won't Cry
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Campanaro to Wed
description: Mr. and Mr. Frank R. Campanaro of Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christina Campanaro to Tino Juarez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Juarez of Los Gatos, Calif. Miss Campanaro, a graduate of Skidmore College, is the associate director of advertising and public relations at Oscar de la Renta Ltd. in New York. Her fiance, an actor in New York, graduated from Stanford University.

title: HOUSE FOR EX-CONVICTS IS PROPOSED IN NASSAU
description: LEAD: A DOZEN men released from the Nassau County jail would occupy the first publicly financed, privately operated halfway house in Nassau County under a plan before the county's Board of Supervisors.

title: Jessica Brodax Engaged
description: The engagement of Jessica Brodax, a broadcast specialist at RJR Nabisco in New York, and David J. Harris, an equities trader at Salomon Brothers, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Philip Brodax of Weston, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Robert Harris of New York. The future bride's father is a writer and a film maker who produced ''The Yellow Submarine.'' Her mother, Joan Brodax, is a pyschiatric social worker. The future bridegroom's father is a lawyer.

title: A Discography Of 19th-Century Italian Opera
description: IN THE ENGLISH-SPEAKING OPER-atic world, we use the expression ''bread and butter repertory'' for the works without which theaters would have to close their doors, but ''aglio e olio repertory'' might be more apt, since most of them are Italian. A lot has changed in style, standards and repertory over the last few decades, but the Italian perennials are still basic. Life would be impoverished if they were to disappear - and the period of getting to know them is one of the best times in anybody's life. Their real home is in the theater, of course, but recordings with the flavor of the theater about them are a rich resource and a wonderful introduction.

title: High School Graduates Revive Volunteer Force
description: For five years in a row, more than 90 percent of the young men and women enlisting in the armed forces have been high school graduates. Sergeants and generals alike argue that this the best evidence that the ranks can be filled with good people without a draft.

title: Jennifer Lockhart, Teacher, Is Wed To J. G. Robbins
description: Jennifer Jennings Lockhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Sanford Lockhart of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Jonathan Goodwill Robbins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Spalding Robbins of Fairfield, and Onancock, Va.

title: Where the Sun Rises First, Late Night TV Comes Last
description: What with Bangor's many cultural attractions and nightlife opportunities, Margo Cobb was saying, the citizens find little time for late-night television.

title: Dr. Marc Jeffrey Salzman Marries Marsha Diamond
description: Marsha Diamond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Diamond of Pittsburgh, and Dr. Marc Jeffrey Salzman, a son of Bobi Salzman of Vail, Colo., and Dr. Robert Salzman of Miami, were married yesterday at the St. Regis in Manhattan. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated.

title: U.S. Blocks Effort to Restart a Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is halting its review of plans by the Philadelphia Electric Company to restart the Peach Bottom nuclear plant because the company has not shown it can prevent operators in the control room from sleeping on the job.

title: Weekend Holidays
description: Columbus Day is Monday, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules: NEW YORK Parking: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking is suspended today and tomorrow; it is also suspended on Monday, for Columbus Day. Parade: Starts at 11:15 A.M. on Monday at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and Long Island Rail Road on regular shedule. Libraries: Closed. Schools: Closed. NEW JERSEY Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J.
