Transit rail and bus service on regular schedule. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Many closed. CONNECTICUT Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule. Libraries: Local option. Schools: Closed.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Punitive Paintings At one time in Florence, paintings were a form of punishment, a practice that has continued in various guises to our time. This is from ''The Stones of Florence'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich) by Mary McCarthy.

title: Knicks Trim Roster
description: MAKING his first cuts as the Knicks' head coach, Rick Pitino yesterday trimmed his crowded training-camp roster by three players. Gone are Elmer Anderson, a 6-foot-2-inch guard from St. Bonaventure; Richard Mudd, a 6-9 forward from Michigan State, and Howard Triche of Syracuse, a 6-5 swingman. They were made expendable by the signing Friday of Rory Sparrow, who reached a one-year agreement for $350,000, a large cut from his previous salary, and Ron Moore, the second-round draft choice who will earn $75,000, the rookie minimum.

title: Cohn Cleared of Conspiracy in Divorce Case
description: A judge has ruled that the late Roy M. Cohn did not participate in a conspiracy against a client - the wife of one of New York City's major property owners - in a divorce action in 1984.

title: Froese Inspires Rangers to First Victory
description: Bob Froese flailed, flopped to the ice and arched across his crease to make kick saves that were born more from instinct than intent, and he did those things well enough tonight to help the Rangers survive another slow start. They went on to defeat the Whalers, 6-2, at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: Industry Is Split Over Disclosure Of Job Dangers
description: Industry is deeply divided over pending legislation that would require the identification, notification and medical counseling of workers exposed to a high risk of cancer and other disease on the job.

title: The Senators, Judging Bork, Try to Define Conservatism
description: AS senators have fallen into line against Robert H. Bork, there has been a subtext to their explanations of why they will not support his nomination to the Supreme Court. Many of them, in criticizing Judge Bork, have also looked ahead to a new round and gone out of their way to emphasize that they are ready, willing and able to support a conservative.

title: 4,000 Refugees of Civil War Return Home to El Salvador
description: About 4,000 refugees from the civil war in El Salvador returned home today after years in Honduras.

title: ETHICS CODE FOR OFFICIALS STIRS DEBATE ON THE BOARD
description: A PROPOSED new ethics code for county officials - including disclosure of financial affairs - has become the focus of an election-year political struggle on the County Board of Legislators.

title: Listening for the Music In the Words Onstage
description: I WONDER IF ALL EFFECTIVE THEA-ter pieces, serious or otherwise, aren't in some way musical underneath. It's easy enough, for instance, to hear - and even to see - the quiet, stabbing, funny counterpoint that helps build Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy'' to such a touching climax.

title: Sunday Observer; Computer Fallout
description: THE WONDERFUL thing about writing with a computer instead of a typewriter or a lead pencil is that it's so easy to rewrite that you can make each sentence almost perfect before moving on to the next sentence.

title: Massachusetts Law Requires Insurance for Infertility Care
description: Massachusetts will become the first state to require insurance companies to pay for all medical treatment of infertility.

title: Tutu and White Rule: 'Deep Sadness and Pain'
description: The official residence of the Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town is not hard to find.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Lenox, Mass.: Berkshire Boom Spurs Resorts
description: LEAD: A STRONG tourist and second-home market, combined with Berkshire County's increasing popularity as a conference site, has led to the development of several large, mixed-use resorts here in the last five years.

title: IRAQI JETS IN NEW ATTACKS IN GULF
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked a ship in the Persian Gulf today, and Iraq said its jets hit an air base and three oil centers in Iran after a powerful explosion shook the Iraqi capital.

title: Jersey Teamsters Demand Replacement of Trustee
description: About 300 members and supporters of Local 560 of the International Brotherood of Teamsters rallied outside the union's headquarters here today, demanding elections to replace court-appointed trustees who have run the local for 16 months.

title: Far Above Par
description: A MAN who spent his career building golf courses and a woman who spent hers tearing them up have been inducted into the PGA-World Golf Hall of Fame. At ceremonies in Pinehurst, N.C., Robert Trent Jones, the 81-year-old golf course designer, was honored Friday along with Betsy Rawls, the 59-year-old former champion.

title: College Football; Pitt Stops Irish After a 27-0 Lead
description: Pitt ruined a lot of Irish pipe dreams of a national championship tonight when it built a surprisingly easy 27-0 lead in the first half and held on to upset previously undefeated Notre Dame, 30-22, in a game-long rain.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: Your special issue of The New York Times Magazine (''The Great Voyage: Two Hundred Years of the Constitution,'' Sept. 13) could not have appeared at a more opportune time for us. On the following day we became naturalized citizens of the United States. We consider ourselves very lucky to become citizens during a month of such historical importance to the United States. With the help of the excellent essays by Anthony Lewis and the other writers published in this issue of the magazine, we were able to obtain deeper understanding of how important a role the Constitution played in the history of this country, and how the ingenious concept of separate but equal branches of the Government has worked throughout the years for the benefit of the American people. Now, as new citizens, we can join the celebration of the 200th anniversary of our Constitution, and we thank The Times for an excellent history lesson. WOJCIECH A. WILCZAK MONIKA J. WILCZAK Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Clifton Tops Nutley, 15-12
description: Clifton, usually a group title contender in New Jersey high school football, took on the familiar role yesterday when it overcame Nutley, 15-12, in a battle between unbeaten teams at Nutley.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
REVISIONISM REVISED
description: LEAD: THE LINDBERGH CASE By Jim Fisher. Illustrated. 480 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $22.95.

title: Life After Salomon Brothers
description: ONE day this summer, Lewis S. Ranieri had one of the best jobs on Wall Street. The next, at the instigation of Salomon Brothers' chairman John H. Gutfreund, Mr. Ranieri was out; out as vice-chairman of the powerful company and out of Salomon Brothers altogether. The 40-year-old Mr. Ranieri went home with millions of dollars and a reputation as a brilliant competitor that he earned in 21 years as Salomon's rising star. He was suddenly, as one of his old colleagues at Salomon put it, ''outside the sandbox'' in which he had spent his entire professional life.

title: Another Uptick In Interest Rates
description: Up, up and away went the prime rate, as banks raised the key barometer to 9 percent, from 8 3/4. The increase was the fifth so far this year, and, although it was expected, it still sent a chill down the spines of the people who had been thinking about borrowing money. Short-term interest rates have been on the rise - indeed, yields in the bond market have been at or near two-year highs - and the prime has followed suit. But where in the past the prime was the rate given by banks to their best customers, in recent years it has been tied more closely to consumer rates, like home equity loans and some credit cards. The big guys have found cheaper money from banks and through commercial paper. Even so, higher interest rates, in part, help dampen interest in borrowing money to make purchases that increase demand for products and push prices up - in other words, higher rates help rein in inflation. And Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said a few small increases now might help stave off a big increase later.

LEAD: THE Governor's office has $3 million on its books that it would love to have the chance to spend. The money represents rewards, and spending it would mean that crimes have been solved and criminals have been convicted.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: I believe that each team playing in the World Series should decide for itself for each game whether it wishes to use the d.h. or not. Such a rule is fair and would eliminate the inequities to the American League team under the present system.

title: ; Pointer Named Best In Palisades Show
description: A German short-haired pointer, Ch. Robin Crest Lorien Corniche, owned by Anthony Attalla and Rita and John Remondi, was named best today in a field of 1,433 dogs at the Palisades Kennel Club Show at Liberty State Park.

title: INDIA REJECTS IDEA FOR NUCLEAR BAN
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi says he welcomes the United States Congress's recent vote to suspend aid to Pakistan because of concern about that country's nuclear program, but he rejects Washington's proposal for a treaty between India and Pakistan banning nuclear weapons.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
LORDING IT OVER THE QUADRUPEDS
description: LEAD: THE ANIMAL ESTATE The English and Other Creatures in the Victorian Age. By Harriet Ritvo. Illustrated. 347 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: TV Books' Debut Opens Media Battle
description: SCRIPTWRITERS could have a field day with this plot: Two media giants come together to discuss a joint project. The talks fall apart. Each agrees to go its separate way, but then one company hires a key employee away from the other. The battle is on. Both organizations race to get their product out first, and within a week of each other the products are unveiled. They look almost exactly the same.

title: SCHOOLS WELCOME AIDS TRAINING Catholic Approach
description: LEAD: FACED with increasing AIDS-mortality statistics, Long Island educators have reacted favorably to a State Board of Regents requirement that AIDS instruction be included in all elementary and secondary schools.

title: Derrida Dismissed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tigers Got More Than Their Money's Worth From Evans
description: LAST winter the Detroit Tigers ignored the 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in Darrell Evans produced, looked at his salary instead and decided they were in no hurry to tender him a contract for this year. Evans thus became a free agent, but no one but the Tigers expressed interest in his services. So he reluctantly accepted the vastly reduced salary they subsequently offered.

title: SITE RULED OUT FOR WAR MEMORIal
description: NEXT year, when this Camden County township dedicates its memorial to the veterans and dead of four wars, it will be on a site other than the one originally proposed - a traffic island - because, according to veterans here, no one wants to dodge traffic to get to the memorial.

title: TALKING: Street Trees; A Request May Bring One Free
description: FEW amenities add more charm to the setting of a home than a well-tended street tree or two lining the curb. On a densely built city block with only tiny front yards, a street tree can also provide welcome privacy from neighboring houses and a shield from the hot summer sun.

title: T.W.A. Pays $252,000 Fine
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has reported that Trans World Airlines has paid $252,000 to settle a civil action. Federal inspectors had cited the carrier for technical violations of F.A.A. maintenance and operational rules. The penalty, like one of $512,000 against Braniff, is small by comparison with the record $9.5 million penalty that Eastern Airlines agreed to pay earlier this year after a special F.A.A. audit found more than 78,000 safety and maintenance violations.

title: BACK TO SCHOOL, SERIOUSLY
description: IT is four o'clock. I put the finishing touches on the microwave dinner, lay out the children's pajamas, remind one child to do his homework, a second to set the table for dinner and the toddler to pick up his blocks. I greet the sitter at the door with a list of instructions, gather up my books, and I'm off - to school.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: The d.h. ought to be eliminated not only from the World Series but also from the American League regular season as well. If for no other reason than it isn't fair to compare the earned-run averages of current A.L. pitchers with those of the N.L. and past American League pitchers.

title: 'GRANNY HOUSING' FOR THE STATE'S ELDERLY IS PROPOSED
description: REPRESENTATIVE Bernard Dwyer, Democrat of Edison, has introduced legislation that could make a cottage industry out of alternative housing for the elderly.

title: Great Performers Series Single Tickets on Sale
description: Single tickets are to go on sale today at Lincoln Center for three special events in the Great Performers series: a recital by Luciano Pavarotti on Dec. 13, a 25th-anniversary concert by the pianist Andre Watts with the New York Philharmonic on Jan. 13, and a concert of opera arias by Joan Sutherland and the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by Richard Bonynge, on April 3.

title: HE MADE THE STAGE COME ALIVE
description: I NEVER FOLLOWED THE AMER-ican idea of age,'' Boris Aronson said near the end of his remarkable half-century career as a designer for the theater. ''I slowly crawled from one rung on the ladder to the next. It is not the American way. In America, you are a genius at 18 and finished at 30.''

title: Engineering in a Slump, But Future Is Bright
description: AS CORPORATE AMERICA restructures itself to meet the needs of a changing marketplace, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates have waned considerably over the last three years.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
MAPPING THE STATES OF MIND
description: LEAD: MEDICINE, MIND, AND THE DOUBLE BRAIN A Study in Nineteenth-Century Thought. By Anne Harrington. Illustrated. 336 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $35.

title: Q&A
description: SOUTH PACIFIC Question: How does one visit Norfolk Island north of New Zealand? Is it a good place to stay? Where can information on hotels and activities be obtained? - A. L. K., Austin, Tex. Answer: Norfolk Island is about 500 miles northwest of Auckland on New Zealand's North Island, but it is part of New South Wales, Australia. Some of the descendants of the Bounty mutineers were moved to North Island from Pitcairn Island by the British in 1856. Air New Zealand (800-262-1234) usually operates two flights a week to Norfolk Island from Auckland, perhaps the best gateway. The flight takes an hour and 55 minutes and the round-trip fare is about $380. The island may also be reached on a somewhat longer flight from Brisbane, Australia, with Air New South Wales. There are three flights a week and round-trip fare is about $450. Air New South Wales is represented in the United States by Qantas (800-227-4500). Both Air New Zealand and Qantas can arrange accommodations and tours on Norfolk for travelers booking flights with them to New Zealand or Australia.

title: Madagascar
description: To the Editor: Regarding the request for information on touring Madagascar (Q & A, Aug. 9): Having just returned from a two-week tour of Madagascar (visiting scientists from the Duke University Primate Center on a lemur preservation project), I feel I am able to offer some suggestions.

title: Music: The Sofia Chamber Orchestra
description: THE good citizens of Budapest and Prague seem born with a distinctive sense of how the violin should be played - with an easy, unselfconscious pliancy that outsiders copy but find ultimately elusive. This Central European tradition obviously reaches farther east as well. The Sofia Chamber Orchestra, which played at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night, understands it well. In its arrangement of the Shostakovich Chamber Symphony, the group's 13 strings gave this music's dignity and despair a speechlike quality that went straight to our hearts.

title: 'Star Wars' Could Stop a Test Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FANTASY TRADE IN SHANGHAI
description: JULIA PARADISE By Rod Jones. 123 pp. New York: Summit Books. $12.95.

title: TAKING RISKS
description: Thomas Simmons's celebration of life at the edge carries the implication that the rest of us are leading tame, backwater lives. For a person whose mind and senses are open, a ''sense of drama'' and ''joy in action'' are everywhere: running down a country road, watching a flower unfold or watching a cat play with its tail. If Simmons is a poet, he should know this. CAROL HEE BARNETT Rush, N.Y.

title:
ABOUT CARS;
Writing Some Wrongs
description: LEAD: I AM probably biting off more than I can chew, but the new model year seems like a good time to ask what is right and what is wrong with today's automobile.

title: M. S. Ungar Wed To Natalie Atlas
description: Natalie Lynn Atlas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold D. Atlas of Warren Township, N.J., and Michael Shayon Ungar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Ungar of Scotch Plains, N.J., were married yesterday. Judge Leonard S. Sachar of the Superior Court of New Jersey performed the ceremony at the Chanticler in Short Hills.

title: New Free-Agency Dispute
description: An official of the National Football League Players Association today revealed the latest of what he called several union proposals to club owners designed to address their concerns about a system of free agency.

title: '42ND STREET': SHEEN AND SNAP IN DARIEN
description: ''THINK of musical comedy, the most glorious words in the English language!''

title: Panda-Watching In a Chinese Zoo
description: Ideally, the bashful, solitary giant pandas should be seen on their own turf, in the remote bamboo forests of central China. But even scientists have difficulty finding the reclusive and increasingly rare animals.

title: Commercial Property: Office Buildings; Pumped Up Prices Driving Buyers Out of Manhattan
description: THE buying and selling of commercial buildings in Manhattan has fallen to its lowest level of the decade, according to real-estate experts. They say that high taxes and even higher hopes have prompted owners to cling to their Manhattan holdings.

title: The Clear Lesson of the Bork Nomination
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Strategies: When You Wait Upon a Line
description: Trips to Disney World challenge parents. ''Your whole sense of values gets turned upside down,'' said Betsy Davis of Demarest, N.J. ''You see a sign that says there's only a 45-minute wait for this ride, and you rush over to get into the line. Forty-five minutes! You get into this maze, and around the corner you see there are ten thousand people in line ahead of you.''

title: 61 ABANDON BOAT IN FIRE OFF SHORE
description: A charter fishing boat carrying 61 people caught fire in the Atlantic Ocean today, forcing everyone to jump overboard. But all were rescued by other vessels, the boat's captain said.

title: Susan Stern Engaged To Martin R. Kravet
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Stern of Monmouth Beach, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Leslie Stern to Martin Ross Kravet, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kravet of Manhasset, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EXPENSIVE SHOPPING

title: Tailoring a Suit To Your Taste In Irish Tweed
description: A visitor to the House of Donegal in the city of Cork may feel a bit as if he is on Savile Row. This is no wonder since the owner, Anthony Boeg, started on London's famous row of custom tailors, and is very much in that tradition. In London he might have outfitted you for the City, but in Cork the effect would be more the rakishness of J. P. Donleavy's dashing playboys or the flair of G. B. Shaw's perfect gentlemen. (Shaw spent a lot of time in County Cork.) Of course I could never afford Savile Row, and, if I could, would not show up at one of its shops in a sweater and old chinos.

title: ON THE CAMPUSES, BOYS OF AUTUMN
description: NOT all of Saturday's heroes are performing on the gridirons this fall. Some of them are playing the summer game - baseball - well into autumn.

title: Miss Kaelin Wed To Glen Holland
description: Margaret Anne Kaelin, the daughter of Nancy P. Kaelin and William G. Kaelin, both of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church to Glen Michael Holland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Holland of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Russell J. Sloun performed the ceremony.

title: College Football; Columbia Loses to Set Mark
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10 -

title: OF BURGLARS, VANDALS AND THINGS THAT GO BUMP IN THE NIGHT
description: ONE hot summer night not long ago there was at the window near my pillow a sudden racket. I leaped from the bed and grabbed a petrified stick I keep behind the door. ''Who is it? What do you want? Get out of here!'' I shouted. My wife awakened, startled. There was no answer from the outside, just the same strange noise. I found a flashlight with my free hand and threw its beam at the window, ready to fight. A huge moth continued to beat its wings against the screen.

title: Eastern Nuclear Dump
description: The Department of Energy will resume its search for a dump in the East for high-level radioactive waste, but not aggressively, a spokesman has said. The agency will review 60,000 public comments it received in response to a draft report on the search, a process that could take two years, the spokesman said earlier this month. Sites in Nevada, Washington and Texas have been nominated for the nation's first high-level waste dump.

title: Ann Sothern Dauntless
description: IDAHO IS AS FAR FROM HOLLYWOOD IN FAN-tasy as in geography. But it is to the mountains of Idaho that Ann Sothern has retreated.

title: Amy S. Gibbons Is Married To E. A. Carroll, Designer
description: At Paul's Chapel of Columbia University, Amy S. Gibbons, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Gibbons of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Edward A. Carroll, the son of Joan R. Basile of Aiken, S.C., and Edward J. Carroll of New York. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: GORBACHEV'S GROUNDWORK FOR SUMMIT No. 3
description: AS a chilly rain lashed Reykjavik exactly a year ago, the second summit between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan ended in failure. It has taken 12 months to reassemble the pieces that nearly fell into place that weekend. This time around, with more careful preparation, both sides appear to have a more realistic idea of what they want and how to get it.

title: VINEYARDS SEEKING BIRD-WAR WEAPONS
description: LEAD: THE growing number of vineyards on Long Island has been attracting the attention of birds in addition to wine connoisseurs. With Long Island directly in the path of the North American Atlantic Coast Flyway, during migration periods birds have become accustomed to making grape-eating pit stops at vineyards, most of which are on the North

title: Jazz: Judy Carmichael
description: IN the five years since Judy Carmichael arrived in New York with a repertory focused on the stride-piano compositions and solo performances of Fats Waller and James P. Johnson, she has been gradually expanding her range of material as well as the settings in which she plays. At Weill Hall on Thursday evening, she gave a concert in which she was joined by Michael Hashim on alto and soprano saxophones and Howard Alden on electric guitar. Their presence led her to material beyond the stride pieces she plays as a soloist.

title: Carol Ann Spiegel Marries Executive in Pennsylvania
description: Carol Ann Spiegel and James John Zuhusky were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jude in Erie, Pa., by the Rev. Henry Kriegel.

title: INSIDE
description: Candidates Dial for Dollars Most Presidential candidates spend much time seeking not only voters but also campaign ''shareholders'': contributors. Page 36. Tigers Win and Trail, 2-1 After losing a 5-0 lead, Detroit rallied to beat Minnesota, 7-6, on Pat Sheridan's homer. The Twins lead the

title:
The Job Outlook Across the Nation;
MIDDLE ATLANTIC
description: LEAD: FOR most of the Middle Atlantic states, the job outlook for the coming year is good. But while forecasters predict further growth for much of the region, they sound a note of caution about how much longer it can go on. ''We have had a year of continued expansion in 1987, which is no mean feat after four years of uninterrupted growth,'' said Samuel M.

title: VOTERS FACE LEVY TO BUY PINE LANDS
description: LEAD: VOTERS in Suffolk County will decide in November whether to pay a quarter of a penny in sales-tax revenues so the county can buy more than 30,000 acres of pine barrens to protect future drinking-water supplies.

title: Giants-Skins: Thrill Is Gone
description: In recent years, no rivalry in pro football has been more intense than the one between the Giants and the Washington Redskins. Their games have always been bruising, and they have invariably been keys to deciding division and conference champions.

title:
Fashion Preview;
PARISIAN PALETTE
description: LEAD: SOPHISTICATED LADY OR INGENUE, the great equalizer for the spring and summer of 1988 is length, and colors are vibrant. That is the word from Paris as the ready-to-wear collections are introduced this week.

title: MOVIES
description: Steppenwolf With Max von Sydow and Dominique Sanda. Direction and screenplay by Fred Haines. 1974. Vidmark Entertainment. 105 minutes. $69.95.

title: GREEKS LOOSEN CURB (AND TONGUES) ON RADIO
description: With the opening of a string of radio stations free of central government control, Greece is liberalizing its broadcasting laws, eroding a state monopoly that has existed for decades.

title: VERIFICATION: WILL IT WORK?
description: IT WILL PROBABLY HAPPEN sometime during the next few months, and it will probably look something like this: The President of the United States and the General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party will sit side by side on a raised dais in the classic simplicity of the East Room of the White House. Facing a room packed with journalists and senior Government officials, they will enact a solemn and familiar ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Campaign on the Move

title: UTILITY PROMOTING REBIRTH OF CITIES
description: THE Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which used a high-profile advertising campaign to help buttress New Jersey's economic resurgence after the recession of the early 1980's, has begun a new promotion spotlighting cities being reborn as growth areas.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THREE potential incinerator sites have passed the first hurdle in the selection process, and the state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission plans to further narrow the list early next year.

title: CHILDREN
description: Disney's Sing Along Songs: Heigh-Ho Walt Disney Home Video. 28 minutes. $14.95.

title: Andrea Cologne to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Eugene Cologne of Smithtown, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Dawn Cologne, to Thomas Allen Palmer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry A. Palmer of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Miss Cologne and her fiance both graduated from Iowa State University. She is an associate programmer analyst in marketing and logistics for the Chevron Corporation in San Ramon, Calif. He is with the Hewlett-Packard Corporation in Cupertino, Calif.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''No one likes higher interest rates, but it is a necessary part of the process to prevent upward pressure on prices.'' - Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist, Mortgage Bankers Association.

title: SCHOOLCHILDREN AND STANDARD TESTS
description: A way to improve standard tests is to correctly identify the recipients of the scores. The Connecticut Mastery Tests should be called Tests for Teachers When teachers use tests as curriculum goals, they invariably begin to teach to the test. The test results become the evaluation of effective teaching. This circular reasoning lets the ends justify the means.

title: Television Tests Its Limits
description: INGENIOUS. THAT'S ONE WORD FOR THE NEW television season. Efforts by the three commercial networks to get around once-rigid taboos in what is supposed to be family entertainment have become terribly inventive. On CBS's ''Jake and the Fatman,'' for instance, William Conrad plays a crotchety district attorney who is partial to salty language. The solution is to let him say what he wants while bleeping the possibly offending words on the soundtrack. Minimum skills in lip reading will leave no doubt as to what he is actually saying. The words are clearly there for those who want them, but, presumably, no one can accuse CBS of being, shall we say, duplicitous.

title: L.S.U. Surges Past Georgia
description: Tom Hodson's 5-yard touchdown pass to Brian Kinchen with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play gave Louisiana State a 26-23 victory over Georgia today in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Reborn Peronists Flex Their Muscles
description: THE triumph of the Peronists in Argentina's congressional and provincial elections last month weighs almost as heavily on the victors as on President Raul Alfonsin and his party, the Radical Civic Union.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: William Safire's assertion that the war power ''has been wrested back and forth through two centuries, and the answer seems to lie in the inability of either branch to dominate the other'' (''Tug-of-War'') seriously misstates the true nature of the power over war. In fact, as we celebrate our Constitution's bicentennial, the power to initiate and risk war has moved steadily and inexorably into the hands of the President alone.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ALL'S FAIRS As if one full-fledged, traditional fair - the Long Island Fair at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration - wasn't enough this weekend, here comes the Riverhead Country Fair today to entice suburbanites with a taste of what used to be in really rural America. So from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., the parking lot at the Peconic River will be the scene of the customary fair activities - old-fashioned contests like spelling bees (and one new-fangled mini-marathon), rides, games, exhibits and, naturally, agricultural competitions. Everything is free, except, of course, for what you buy.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hopatcong $124,000 1 Wildwood Shores Drive 2-bedroom, 1 bath, 30-year-old ranch; enclosed porch, cathedral ceiling in living room, w/b stove; taxes $1,615. Maplewood $225,000 45 Courter Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, patio, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,380. Neptune $154,900 231 Robbins Road 4-bedroom, 1 bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; Florida room in basement, fireplace, patio; taxes $2,027. Short Hills $425,000 295 Lupine Way 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, C/A, fireplace: taxes $4,591. Springfield $405,000 31 Far Hills Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 26-year-old ranch; library, den, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,501. White House Station $299,000 19 Weavers Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial: hardwood floors, fireplace, deck; taxes $2,916. OTHER AREAS Shirley, L.I. $110,000 53 Alden Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Avon, Conn. $270,000 8 Stony Corners Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old saltbox; screened porch, crown moldings, 1 acre; taxes $2,102. Armonk, N.Y. $293,500 29 Glendale Avenue, 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, family room; not yet assessed.

title: Streamlining Education Of New Nurses
description: LEAD: WITH the critical shortage of registered nurses nationwide, which is expected to grow even larger in the future, hospitals, nursing associations and colleges and universities are under enormous pressure these days to attract new people into the nursing profession. Consequently, nursing education is undergoing a number of changes.

title: Boston Plans Help for Illegal Aliens
description: The city government here has launched an effort to help illegal Irish immigrants with their legal problems, prompting questions from representatives of other immigrant groups.

title: Cable TV
description: Movie titles that don't ring an immediate bell can often slip past the most diligent readers of lengthy program listings, along with some worthwhile diversions. Take ''It.''

title: Queens College, 50 Years Old, Seeks to Rebound
description: There is a sense of energy and purpose these days on this incongruous campus of pink Spanish-mission-style buildings with red-tiled roofs deep in the heart of Flushing, as Queens College prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary today.

title: MAMET MAKE A DEBUT WITH 'HOUSE OF GAMES'
description: QUITE early in ''House of Games,''

title: TAKING RISKS
description: When are men like Simmons going to grow up? I read ''A Sense of Drama'' and could feel my stomach turn with disgust at yet another example of today's ''I-gotta-be-me'' mentality.

title: Geoffrey Mullen, A Banker, Weds Susan Patterson
description: Susan Lane Patterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Patterson Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Geoffrey Grant Mullen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mullen of Darien, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Ann Kimball performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: STATE BABY-NAMING PROPOSAL GOES AWRY
description: THE state is having second thoughts about a proposal to let a parent choose any surname - like DiMaggio, Hemingway, Reagan or Beethoven - for a child.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT GETS RARE SPY CASE
description: That Samuel Loring Morison was not a classic spy of the John LeCarre mode has never really been in dispute. But two years ago Mr. Morison, a former civilian naval analyst, was convicted under national espionage laws of disclosing classified documents to the press.

title: Miss Miller Is Married
description: Sloan Taylor Miller and Hardwick Simmons were married yesterday at l'Eglise Paroissiale in St.-Paul-de-Vence, France. The Rev. Thomas E. Duggan, a Presbyterian minister who is pastor of the American Church of Paris, performed the ceremony.

title: Fears of Nuclear Power Are Intensified by Latest California Quake
description: At the San Onofre nuclear power plant 60 miles south of here, the severe earthquake that killed six people in Southern California last week was a mere rattle, barely strong enough to be felt by the personnel and not nearly enough to interrupt the reactors' operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Corona, Queens, on Sept. 27 omitted Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic School, at 35-23 104th Avenue, in listing the neighborhood's parochial schools.

title: NOTES OF A NAG AND A ROISTERER
description: THE MADWOMAN'S UNDERCLOTHES Essays and Occasional Writings. By Germaine Greer. 305 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: The Job Outlook Across the Nation; NEW ENGLAND
description: THE GOOD NEWS for workers in New England is that salaries and wages are rising rapidly; the bad news, for their employers, is that there are generally not enough able bodies to fill job openings.

title: SICK CHILDREN GETBTHEIR WISH
description: LEAD: IT IS an unpretentious building -a converted warehouse - but to many children with life-threatening diseases it is the place where dreams can come true.

title: HISTORY
description: The Game of Monopoly American History Series. Mastervision. 60 minutes. $64.95.

title: A LITTLE SUGAR, BUT NO SALT
description: In a letter to the Long Island editor headed ''How Sweet It Isn't'' [ Sept. 20 ] , Ebinger's is taken to task for providing ''large quantities of sugary, pasty, greasy 'goodies'.'' The Brooklyn-based bakery also made a product much appreciated by our family.

title: Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
description: I'm tired of watching A.L. pitchers embarrass themselves at bat. Let's make it really interesting: when the Series is played at N.L. fields, the designated hitters should be forced to pitch. Just what kind of fastball do you think Bill Madlock has?

title: 'The Bretts': Backstage Life In 1920's London
description: THE YEAR 1927 WAS WHEN LONdon theater-goers turned on that enfant terrible, Noel Coward, heckling two of his new plays into premature oblivion. It was the year Rodgers and Hart's ''Girl Friend'' arrived from Broadway, and everyone seemed to be humming ''My Heart Stood Still,'' the song they'd contributed to a West End revue called ''One Dam Thing After Another.'' It was the year of Somerset Maugham's comedy of marital politics, ''The Constant Wife,'' and of his melodrama ''The Letter,'' which boasted Gladys Cooper as a lovelorn murderess. It was the year London saw Charles Laughton as a glum American magnate in something called ''The Happy Husband'' and John Gielgud as a musical genius in ''The Constant Nymph.'' It was the year the town's darling, Tallulah Bankhead, tore off her dress and revealed her underwear at the denouement of ''The Garden of Eden.''

title: SERIOUS FOOD IN A FRENETIC SCENE
description: FOR the last few months, Syosset has been buzzing over Mim's, a hip new Manhattan-style restaurant. First impressions include neon, potted palms and old-fashioned wicker chairs in the window. But, 10 feet inside the restaurant, the decor ends and the scene begins. Straight wooden chairs replace the wicker; plants disappear; walls and lighting are stark. It's not sleekly modern, but more barnlike with its painted wooden beams and unadorned space.

title: Ousted Teacher With AIDS Fights in Court to Get Job Back
description: A teacher has brought a legal challenge to being removed from his classroom because he has AIDS.

title: TAKING RISKS
description: I'm all for taking chances; I'm all for risks. But isn't the purpose of a risk to reach a goal, or is the purpose of a risk risk itself? I can understand perfectly Simmons's exhilaration in action, his sense of testing, but doesn't testing imply a conclusion to be reached, a new understanding, something of value gained?

title:
MUSIC;
CHORAL GROUPS SET BUSY SCHEDULE
description: LEAD: THE 1987-88 music season will feature a large variety of choral works, from traditional holiday selections to major choral masterpieces, with the performing groups ranging from chamber ensembles to 200-member choruses.

title: IRAN EMBARGO: THE MAIN IMPORT IS POLITICAL
description: THERE are no illusions either within the Reagan Administration or on Capitol Hill that an embargo against Iranian imports will have a serious economic impact. Since 1981 the United States has bought an average of three per cent of its foreign oil from Iran, and with Iran's attractively low prices and high-quality crude, other customers are certain to come forward and buy.

title: A New Type of Worry: Saving Curvaceous Q's
description: They spoke of the alphabet as an endangered species - 26 characters whose beauty and legibility are threatened by the computer revolution.

title: Dwight Norrgard Wed to Miss Daly
description: Mary Elizabeth Daly, an account executive at Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss Inc., an advertising agency in New York, and Dwight Frederick Norrgard, the vice president of Sea Safety International, a ships' supply company in Hoboken, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, the church's minister, who was assisted by the Rev. Mark Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: New Orleans Faces Suit On Free Transportation
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a Federal lawsuit in an effort to stop the city's practice of allowing Roman Catholic nuns and priests to ride free on buses and streetcars.

title: FISHERMEN'S GROUP TO PROTECT COAST
description: A fishermen's group is hiring an independent ''sound keeper'' to watch over Connecticut's coastal waters and ''bring a lot of pressure, including lawsuits,'' against polluters.

title: Folk-Rock: R.E.M. And 10,000 Maniacs
description: SOMETIMES the late 1980's seem to be the late 1960's turned inside out. Consider folk-rock. In the 1960's, it was a commercial hybrid; in the late 1980's, it has become the style of choice for iconoclasts, nonconformists and oddballs. Foremost among them is R.E.M., a band from Athens, Ga., whose asymmetrical, often obscure songs are so tuneful and its concerts so galvanizing that the band is fast reaching the mainstream pop audience almost despite itself. R.E.M.'s two-night stand at Radio City Music Hall, which opened Tuesday, sold out quickly.

title: POSTINGS: $350 Million Ski Project; Big Vanilla
description: Since last December, when a development team from New Jersey and New York bought a foundering Catskills ski area, called Davos, $7 million has gone into improved trails, as well as a new lodge, chairlifts and a snow-making system. Now 121 town houses - the first of 2,000 units that are planned - are rising at the resort, which will cover 1,000 acres on Davos Road near Route 17 in Fallsburg, N.Y., 85 miles northwest of Manhattan.

title: IN THE CLUTCHES OF THE SNOW QUEEN
description: IN THE DUTCH MOUNTAINS By Cees Nooteboom. Translated by Adrienne Dixon. 128 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $14.95.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT WOULD take something keener than the human eye to detect anything but leaves and shadows. It would take even more than the eye of a hunting hawk to pick out the small, greenish bird perched within the canopy, unless the bird moved. Movement catches a hunting eye like a flare on a moonless night.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CELEBRATION OF ISRAEL
description: LEAD: Personal memories and public achievements of leaders in Westchester's Jewish community will be highlighted in a musical documentary, ''Forty Years: A Celebration.'' The evening, which will cost $10,000 a couple or individual, will be held Nov. 7 at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase. The event is sponsored by the United Jewish Appeal/ Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, Westchester division.

title: CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
description: William Bradford Reynolds, in his article ''Power to the People,'' argues the Administration position that the courts shouldn't be creating rights. He refers to the supposed ''abuse'' of the Ninth and 10th Amendments. As an assistant attorney general presumably educated at an American law school, Mr. Reynolds should have learned that the body of law grows with time and the accumulation of judicial decisions. To throw away 200 years of American law is a dangerous and radical proposal, and that is exactly what Mr. Reynolds and the Administration are proposing. DEAN L. SURKIN New York, N.Y.

title: Miss McNamara, A Bond Trader, Weds R. J. Hugin
description: Kathleen Louise McNamara, a daughter of Francis J. McNamara Jr. of Darien, Conn., and the late Noreen E. McNamara, and Robert John Hugin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Hugin of Lakewood, N.J., were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: GOOD IDEA THAT NEEDS RECYCLING
description: I SAT at the kitchen table with a small bottle of Coke, a half-empty jar of Planters dry-roasted peanuts and Vol. 1, No. 1 of the Town of Islip's ''WRAP Report,'' a four-page flyer that had just arrived in the mail detailing the town's new recycling program. About five minutes later I had finished the Coke, the peanuts and the paper and began the process of cleanup and disposal.

title: Opera on A Grand Scale
description: ''AT FIRST, I THOUGHT I'D GO TO China,'' says Adrianne Lobel. ''But then I looked at hundreds of negatives from Nixon's trip, and I decided to work purely from the photographs.''

title: The Myth Becomes Man
description: LAST November, when he knocked out Trevor Berbick in two rounds, Mike Tyson, at age 20, became the youngest heavyweight champion in boxing history - and, at the time, a most feared one.

title: Ellen Dwyer Wed To G. R. Sansone
description: At the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh yesterday evening, Ellen Lee Dwyer and Gregory R. Sansone were married by the Rev. Stephen McCarren, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TRENTON MAPS AIDS BATTLE PLAN
description: LEAD: THE state's Health Commissioner, Dr. Molly Joel Coye, announced last week a sweeping new plan to combat AIDS, including a ''massive expansion'' of routine blood testing and counseling for those put at risk by their sexual practices or intravenous drug use.

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday of Victor Mollo, a leading writer on contract bridge, incorrectly gave the date of his death. He died Sept. 24.

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER IS KEY TO RADIANT FALL COLORS
description: LEAD: A FRINGE benefit of living in the Northeast is the spectacular fall color we experience most every year. Along with that part of eastern Asia that lies in a comparable position in relation to the land mass and the ocean, we are blessed with a panoramic display of autumnal foliage color that few other regions of the earth can enjoy.

title: Youth Is Held in Shooting Of 2 Yonkers Officers
description: Two police officers were wounded today when they tried to subdue an emotionally disturbed teen-ager who grabbed a gun from the holster of an officer, the police said.

title: McBurney Gains Tie
description: McBurney, playing its first home game ever and celebrating its first homecoming, rallied to gain a 14-14 tie with Wheatley yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A 29-year-old jockey, Joy Scott, has become the first woman to boot home a winner in the 19-year-history of the Oak Tree Racing Association meet at Santa Anita Park. Scott also did it the hard way, winning the first race on Friday aboard Smooth Bid, a 75-1 shot. . . . Clark Kellogg, the former Indiana Pacer forward who retired in August because of a bad knee, will join the club's broadcast team as a radio commentator. . . . Allison Roe, the New Zealand runner who won the women's division of the 1981 New York City Marathon and still holds the race's women's record of 2 hours 25 minutes 29 seconds, has become the first former winner to enter the 1987 race, scheduled for Nov. 1. . . . The San Diego Padres announced that Galen Cisco, the pitching coach, and Harry Dunlop, the third-base coach, would not be rehired. The club also said that Deacon Jones, the batting coach, had resigned, and that contract renewals had been offered to Sandy Alomar (first base) and Greg Riddich (dugout). . . . The Seattle Mariners, meanwhile, have decided to retain four coaches: Billy Connors (pitching), Frank Howard (first base), Phil Roof (bullpen) and Ozzie Virgil Sr. (third base). They dropped Bobby Tolan (batting).

title: SUFFOLK TO RETHINK LAW ON CANCELING CATERING
description: LESS than two months after becoming effective in August, a law limiting the cancellation fees that caterers can charge consumers is being reconsidered by the Suffolk County Legislature, a body known to favor regulation.

title: David Dunn, a Lawyer, Married to Miss Carver
description: The wedding of Catherine Carver, the assistant director of intergovernmental relations for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, and David Dunn, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Markel & Edwards, took place last evening. Rabbi Martin Zion and the Rev. Gwen Buehrens, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Americas Society in Manhattan.

title: THE GUIDE
description: BRANSOM EXHIBITION

title: Liszt, Liszt, O Liszt! From the Grave
description: SOME YEARS AGO, YOU MAY OR may not remember, hard-nosed skeptics throughout the musical world diverted themselves immensely by making fun of a British medium named Rosemary Brown. An amateur pianist, she had entered into communication with Mozart, Liszt, Beethoven and others of like fame, all of whom transmitted posthumous works and sometimes friendly messages through her. She became especially chatty with Chopin, who once broke off dictation to warn her of an overflowing faucet in her home. There was a time, I confess, when Miss Brown's spooky claims, not to mention the quality of the music she published as a result of her seances, aroused nothing but scorn in me. The piano as Ouija board? Please.

title: ADULT HIGH SCHOOLS OFFER CHALLENGE
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH it is seldom easy for a busy adult to return to school, flexible hours, accessible teachers and facilities and individualized programming, as well as recognition of the importance of life experience, make a diploma from an adult high school an increasingly realistic goal.

title: The Job Outlook Across the Nation; SOUTHWEST
description: MANY ANALYSTS are offering a cautious glimmer of hope for the Southwest as its recent downward employment spiral hits bottom. However, some disagreement exists as to how soon a significant upswing might occur - a few months or a few years. ''We've probably started to turn some kind of corner,'' said Nicolo Santangelo, chief of the economic analysis and information office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics office in Dallas, ''and we should start to see the first reason for optimism in the next couple of months. But it will depend on oil prices -that's obvious.''

title: Open Wide: Here Comes the Porcelain
description: PORCELAIN has been used by dentists for decades, but it was only a few years ago that porcelain veneers, and the bonding techniques to secure them to existing teeth, were fully refined. When that happened, the dental cosmetics business took off.

title: FALL SOUPS USE VEGETABLES AND HERBS
description: SOUPS for early fall that take advantage of the continuing harvest of vegetables and herbs should also be hearty and well-flavored. The three suggested here comply with these requirements.

title: Amid Bhutan's Peaks, Rituals And Temples
description: Cradled in a great sling of the southern Himalayas, the ancient Buddhist kingdom of Bhutan is held separate by its formidable mountains. To east and west are Indian hill states, to the south the plains of India and to the north the bleak and merciless Chomo Lhari range, an expanse of ice and sky, is the barricade of the Himalayans shouldering the Tibetan plateau.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls inside my house are covered with rough-sawn knotty pine. Because of some leaks, the wood along the bottom is stained dark in an irregular pattern that looks like a stock market graph. The leaks are cured, but the stains remain. How can I remove them?

title: STAMFORD COUPLE: BE TRUE TO YOUR ART
description: LEAD: SUCCESS has been known to send many of its recipients into a lifelong tizzy, but Morton and Myrna Hollinger of Stamford, one-of-a-kind jewelry designers, have kept their wits and remained true to their art.

title: Free to Strike And Cross Lines
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Joy Remuzzi Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Joy E. Remuzzi and Adam David Rothberg, members of the publicity department at Pocket Books in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Remuzzi of Plainview, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Prof. and Mrs. Irving Rothberg of Amherst, Mass., where his father is a professor of Hispanic languages and literature at the University of Massachusetts. Ms. Remuzzi's father, now retired, was a medical technologist at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Baltimore: A Warehouse Is Transformed
description: LEAD: SCARLETT PLACE, a new 14-story mixed-use building along the refurbished Inner Harbor here, has signed up its first commercial tenants, although a boom in downtown office construction has for the moment caused supply to outpace demand.

title: Correction
description: A Washington dispatch last Sunday about an American group's recommendations on Soviet relations carried an incorrect title supplied by the group for B. William Mader of Time magazine. He is a deputy chief of correspondents.

title: Reagan Bars Military Pay Cuts in the '88 Budget
description: President Reagan notified Congress today that the Defense Department would exempt the pay and benefits of military personnel from any cuts that have to be made under the newly revised budget-balancing law.

title: L.I. Shows Big Job Gain In Financial Services
description: JOHN ADAM KANAS, president of the booming North Fork Bank and Trust Company in Mattituck, L.I., spoke with enthusiasm about its expansion. ''In the last 18 months,'' said Mr. Kanas, ''our employment has grown from about 200 to about 450. We're adding almost geometrically to support the growth we've had.''

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 35 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the actor who plays Vincent in the CBS-TV series ''Beauty and the Beast.'' He is Ron Perlman.

title: Stacy Futterman Engaged To Bruce Katz, a Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Jack Futterman of West End, N.J., and Eileen Tepper of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Stacy Ellen Futterman to Bruce David Katz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Katz of New City, N.Y.

title: Thatcher Plans Reshaping of Britain
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher used the annual Conservative Party conference here to outline her grand design for reshaping the landscape of British politics during her third term.

title: MAMET MAKE A DEBUT WITH 'HOUSE OF GAMES'
description: QUITE early in ''House of Games,'' David Mamet's entertaining, deadpan, seriocomic melodrama about con artists, there's a back-room poker game that sets the tone for everything that comes after.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHILDREN IN THE FIELD: Anthropological Experiences. Edited by Joan Cassell. (Temple University, $27.95.) What is it like for Western children to be transplanted to an Amazonian longhouse, or a Brazilian slum? The anthropologist parents who wrote these 10 essays agree that children encourage deepened mutual trust between field workers and hosts, and provoke the anthropologists' own self-confrontation.

title: Myths About the Metropolis: Transit
description: Robert Kiley, chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and David Gunn, Transit Authority president, deserve appreciation and applause. They have shown municipal agencies everywhere how to deliver an essential service.

title: ARTIST'S VIEW OF TIME
description: Just in time for Erte's 95th birthday in November, a pocket watch he designed will go on sale at Gallery 121, 121 Spring Street in Soho, and in stores and art galleries around the country.

title: REPORT ON RECREATION PREFERENCES
description: LEAD: JOSEPH R. POTENZA, the county's deputy planning commissioner, prefers jogging to other forms of recreation. But recently he discovered that he was far outdistanced by county residents who favor such activities as swimming, bicycling, walking, tennis, golf, or just picnicking at the county's parks.

title: HOTEL ENDS ROLE IN DETENTION OF ALIENS
description: A hotel at Kennedy International Airport that has served as a temporary detention center for travelers facing deportation has severed an arrangement with the Federal Government, citing negative publicity from reports of inhumane conditions by a civil rights organization.

title: WHO HAS TO KEEP A TROUBLED COMPANY'S PENSION PROMISES?
description: THESE are nervous times for executives of the troubled LTV Corporation. This week the Federal District Court in New York will hear LTV's arguments on why it should not have to resume responsibility for its mountainous pension obligations.

title: A LONG AND WINDING REGULATORY REVIEW
description: ALACHLOR, sold by the Monsanto Company since 1969 under the trade name Lasso, is perhaps the most widely used herbicide produced in this country. Up to 84 million pounds of it is sprayed on fields of corn, soybeans and peanuts each year.

title: Bus Strike Over, Union Says
description: Union officials announced an agreement early today on a new contract for Boston school bus drivers and said the buses would begin rolling Tuesday morning, ending a monthlong strike. William J. Foley, New England district director of the United Steelworkers Union, which represents the drivers, declined to disclose the details of the agreement, but said it was signed immediately by the union and representatives of private school bus operators that serve the public schools.

title: SONO CINEMA STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE
description: WHEN Brian Fox converted what had been a pornographic movie theater into an art cinema in 1979, not many people thought he would succeed because of the location - on Washington Street in South Norwalk.

title: WHEN SHARPENED PENCILS WENT TO WAR
description: HECKLING HITLER Caricatures of the Third Reich. By Zbynek Zeman. Illustrated. 128 pp. Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95.

title: MOVIES
description: The Undergrads Starring Art Carney and Chris Makepeace. Produced and directed by Steven H. Stern. 1985. Walt Disney Home Video. 102 minutes. $59.95.

title: Lobbying Post For Nixon Aide
description: Ronald L. Ziegler, press secretary to President Nixon from 1969 to 1974, was named today as president of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

title: Washing Talk: Briefing; Environmental News
description: Environmentalists are expected to gather late Wednesday afternoon in the Rayburn House Office Building to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the publication of Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' the book that was among the earliest to warn of modern threats to nature.

title: In 1940's Spain, Anti-Semitism Was Rife
description: To the Editor:

title: Ecuador Reaches Repayment Pact
description: Ecuador has reached a preliminary agreement to reschedule $5.08 billion of debt owed to commercial banks, Finance Minister Rodrigo Espinosa said today.

title: Market Place; Doubt on I.B.M. Seen Persisting
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation has just finished a rough week on Wall Street. On Friday alone, I.B.M.'s stock fell 4 1/8, to 147 3/8.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Because people steal. There's no sense of neighborhood consciousness and stuff.'' The Rev. Jesse Jackson, on why he would not live in New York City. [ B7:5. ]

title: Louis Armstrong's Archives
description: When Louis Armstrong performed, he wore a smile that seemed a mile wide. He punctuated his singing by repeatedly mopping the sweat from his brow with a pocket handkerchief; when he played the trumpet he pointed the bell heavenward, and reflected stage lights danced in the horn's polished brass. To some, Armstrong was a great musician first and foremost; to others he was an entertainer, a clowning Southern bumpkin. But Armstrong the man has been surprisingly elusive.

title: Staffs Reduced in Amnesty Program
description: Because of the small number of people applying for permanent residency, immigration officials in the New York region are reducing and redeploying staff workers assigned to the amnesty program for illegal aliens.

title: Mountleigh Buying Stores
description: Britain's Mountleigh Group P.L.C. said Friday that it planned to buy the money-losing Spanish department store chain Galerias Preciados S.A. for $:153 million ($251 million).

title: Leaders Predict Early Bork Vote On Senate Floor
description: Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate, agreeing that Judge Robert H. Bork will not be confirmed to the Supreme Court, indicated today that the final Senate debate on his nomination might begin as early as this week.

title: DANCE: 3 FROM FELD
description: THE Feld Ballet took two trips into never-never land on Saturday night when the company presented the fifth program in its current season at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. ''Straw Hearts,'' a sunny opening ballet Mr. Feld has set to period parlor music, is a dance for summer lovers of a gentler age and time. Young girls in floating dresses are courted by young men wearing boaters. There is a woeful dreamer of a lothario, a Chaplinesque dandy played here by James Sewell. And through it all dances a tantalizingly remote Beautiful Stranger, played with just the right deadpan mystery by Lynn Aaron.

title: Nancy Beth Fischer Wed To Frank S. Levin on L.I.
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Nancy Beth Fischer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Fischer of Woodmere, L.I., and West Stockbridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank Steven Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Levin of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal and Cantor Tibor Kelen officiated.

title: Ailing Cranes Rally From Mystery Illness
description: Scores of whooping cranes and cranes of related species appear to have recovered from a mysterious illness that killed 15 of the birds at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center in suburban Laurel, Md., the Fish and Wildlife Service says.

title: Faith Florer Wed To Arthur Kleiner
description: Faith Linda Florer and Arthur Philip Kleiner were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in New York. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, the Rev. Herbert Washburn Florer Jr. of Kerhonkson, N.Y., and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman.

title: Koch Policy For Homeless Creates Fears
description: Fearful of being taken to hospitals against their will, mentally ill homeless people have been changing their routines and disappearing from their usual haunts, according to health workers who seek them out to offer food and other assistance.

title: THERMAL BAT NEEDED
description: NOT far away Darrell Evans was talking about having been ''half a step too far off'' when he was picked off third base to kill the Tigers' sixth-inning rally. More than any of his teammates, Evans was the goat of last night's 5-3 loss that enabled the Minnesota Twins to grab a 3-1 lead in the American League Championship Series that could end here today. But at his locker, Alan Trammell was talking about heroes, not goats.

title: Ilene C. Popkin Weds Mitchell Make on L.I.
description: Ilene Cathy Popkin, the daughter of Mrs. Bernard Weiler of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Mitchell Alan Make, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney Make of Lower Merion, Pa., were married yesterday at the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, L.I., by Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski.

title: Strategic Inning Left Twins Ahead
description: Darrell Evans said he was ''in shock'' when it happened. ''You don't figure that's going to happen,'' he said. ''It's probably the only thing I didn't think could happen the whole time I was at third base.''

title: Rosemary Moore Wed to J. D. Shneider
description: Rosemary Moore, a daughter of the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, and the late Jenny McKean Moore, was married yesterday to Joshua David Shneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Shneider of Carlisle, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father at the Pinewood Lodge in Hurley, N.Y.

title: Bears Roll Along With Substitutes
description: The Chicago Bears, unbeaten with their regulars, won their second straight game with replacements today, beating the Minnesota Vikings, 27-7.

title: Team Unity Could Be Casualty of Strike
description: When this is over, the players who tossed eggs, who spit, who waved shotguns, who called their teammates names, and the men who withstood all of this will do something as hard as any job in sports - play football together.

title: Cannon to Sell Certain Assets
description: Cannon Group Inc. has agreed to sell its real estate holdings for at least $300 million and lease them back from a company affiliated with a major shareholder.

title: MONTANA AND 49ERS HOLD OFF STAND-INS
description: The San Francisco 49ers won, but the Atlanta Falcon replacement team inflicted a minor embarrassment on a group of 49er regulars today by making a game of it before losing, 25-17, in front of only 8,684 fans.

title: Strike Fallout
description: The players strike may not have brought the National Football League to its knees, but as the N.F.L. limps along with replacement rosters, the strike has wreaked havoc among the nation's semipro leagues.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales U.S. Balance of Trade... August Thursday None Friday Industrial Production Producer Prices... Sept.

title: Robertson's Ex-Church Uncertain on Candidacy
description: The congregation of Freemason Street Baptist Church here voted overwhelmingly this morning to accept Pat Robertson's resignation from the ministry, but there was considerable doubt whether it would also vote for him for President.

title: Replacements Leave Giants Defenseless
description: Bill Belichick stood in the rubble of adhesive tape and excuses that filled the locker room at Giants Stadium tonight, his mind on escape, his eyes on the door. Still, he stood there, answering all the obvious questions with courteous and predictable answers.

title: SOVIET DELEGATION ON U.S. FARM TOUR
description: Nearly three decades after Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev warmly embraced Iowa growers, the Soviet Union's top agriculture policy official said he would like to send young Russian farm managers to apprenticeships with an American equipment maker.

title: U.S. Official Issues Warning On Losing 'Intelligence War'
description: The director of the National Security Agency has said the United States will lose the ''intelligence war'' unless the flow of leaks to journalists is stanched and Government agencies stop treating security problems with ''disdain.''

title: Music: New Cellist in Beaux Arts Trio
description: THE Beaux Arts Trio came to the Metropolitan Museum with its new cellist on Friday night. He is Peter Wiley, whose arrival has come with the departure of Bernard Greenhouse into retirement at the end of last season.

title: Cards Find Another Problem
description: For one week, Greg Mathews's problem did not seem to be a problem.

title: 28th Aftershock in California
description: While hundreds of earthquake victims jammed disaster relief centers today seeking funds to rebuild or relocate, a small aftershock jolted the metropolitan area. The aftershock, measuring 3.0 on the Richter scale, struck at 3:34 P.M. along the Whittier Fault, said Robert Finn, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. It was the 28th aftershock measuring 3.0 or more since the 6.1 temblor on Oct. 1, he said.

title: Advertising; Oatmeal Battle Heats Up
description: AN oatmeal war is brewing and it's going to get mighty mushy.

title: Unesco's Man Who Came to Dinner
description: A sigh of relief could be heard round much of the world a year ago when Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow announced that he would not seek a third, six-year term as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. By general consent, his incumbency has been a calamity for a once-useful agency. The United States, Britain and Singapore withdrew to protest Unesco's drift into ideology.

title: Nomination Welcomed In Mexico
description: Last Monday, one day after Mexico's ruling party named Carlos Salinas de Gortari as its standard-bearer in next year's presidential election, the stock market here rose 7.5 percent in the first 90 minutes of trading. Twice during the day the Government had to suspend trading briefly to prevent what it called a ''disorderly'' surge by the market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1987
description: The Economy

title: An Unusual Course
description: A golfer making his first outing at the Malibu Golf Course, a private links north of Los Angeles, may come back raving and ranting. The raves would be for the 6,205-yard course's challenging layout, its rolling beauty and its well-maintained fairways and greens. The rants would be for what might be regarded as a bizarre emphasis on golfing decorum.

title: U.S. Sues LTV On Pensions
description: The Federal Government filed suit against the LTV Corporation Friday in a bid to make the company take responsibility for three pension plans and to assure payment of full benefits to retirees, officials said.

title: For Sag Harbor, Debate Is an Event
description: Ideas, some new, but most old, bounced through this summer community this weekend as about 300 academics, industry leaders, politicians and artists gathered for three days of discussion and, to some, not a little celebration of ''the Hamptons.''

title: Reporter's Notebook: Foreigners in Tibet Protest
description: Over the last three weeks, Lhasa has been shaken by three demonstrations against Chinese rule, protests led by shaven-headed monks from monasteries hammered into the mountains edging the north of the city.

title: As Field for '88 Shrinks, Simon's Stature Grows
description: As the dust clears from a tumultuous month in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Paul Simon is not only still standing, in the eyes of some political professionals, but he also looks a little taller.

title: For a New Homesteader, Struggle Leads to Success
description: Twenty years ago, when Jacinto Camacho came to the United States from Ecuador, he worked two shifts a day, doing carpentry, painting and plastering.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about grants from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute incorrectly described the amount given to the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Science. It received one $5 million grant, not two.

title: Smith International Repayment Plan
description: Smith International Inc. said Friday that two creditors that had objected to the oil service company's bankruptcy reorganization proposal had agreed to a modified repayment plan. The revised plan calls for unsecured creditors to receive $145 million in notes bearing 13 percent interest, instead of 12.5 percent, and disallows Smith from issuing new notes in lieu of making interest payments.

title: A PHILADELPHIA WEDDING FOR ELAINE POTWARDOSKI
description: Elaine Potwardoski and Anthony Green were married yesterday in the Constitution Pavillion on Independence Mall in Philadelphiaby Judge Lynne Abraham of the Common Pleas Court there.

title: Acting Chief Named For Savings Insurer
description: Stuart D. Root, a former president of the Bowery Savings Bank, is heading to Washington to become acting director of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the agency that guarantees deposits in 3,100 savings and loan institutions.

title: Topics of The Times; The Luce Touch
description: Obituaries dutifully describe the obvious and the copious about Clare Boothe Luce. Almost till her death at age 84, she starred as a playwright, politician and diplomat. What doesn't get into print, indeed what eludes print, is how she was able to disarm those she well knew were disposed to dislike her, especially males determined not to be taken in by a woman they believed to be too smart and ambitious to be up to any good.

title: Marjorie Anne Harris Wed To Donald Andrew Dripps
description: Marjorie Anne Harris and Donald Andrew Dripps, 1983 graduates of the University of Michigan Law School, were married yesterday at the Hyatt Ravinia Hotel in Atlanta by Rabbi Fred Raskind. Mr. Dripps is an assistant professor of law at the University of Illinois College of Law in Champaign-Urbana. The bride was most recently an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: Salaries Begin to Rise For New Accountants
description: In a move to compete with such higher-paying employers as investment firms and commercial banks, Price Waterhouse has given its beginning accountants a 20 percent pay increase, to $30,000 a year, while eliminating overtime pay.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; TELLING STATE DEPT. HOW TO RUN FOREIGN POLICY... AND ALLOWING IT LESS MONEY
description: The vocabulary of disaster employed by the Foreign Service these days -words like ''tragic'' and ''catastrophic'' - is being applied not to crises in the Middle East or Central America, but to the State Department itself.

title: Panama City Journal; Fact of Life: Many Here Carry Guns
description: Guns have always been a part of life in this Panhandle town, even before a new Florida law seemed to invite pistol-packing on city sidewalks.

title: Giants Fizzle, So Does Crowd
description: As bad as the Giants were last Monday night in losing to the San Francisco 49ers, they were worse today. They took a 38-12 thumping from the Washington Redskins in an almost-empty Giants Stadium and became the only National Football League team without a victory in this strike-blighted season.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, elected as a director Kathleen Feldstein, president of Economic Studies Inc., a private economic consulting firm in Belmont, Mass.

title: Walton Wears Blanked Look
description: For all the sorrowful post-mortems, the most poignant commentary on the Jets' dismal performance today was the expression on Joe Walton's face after their 6-0 loss to the Indianapolis Colts.

title: HAROLD J. DRESCHER
description: Harold J. Drescher, who practiced law in New York York City ifor more than 60 years, died Oct. 5 at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Music: 'Stabat Mater'
description: GRIEF comes in many sizes and shapes, and it is for each of us to choose his own way to mourn. Saturday night's ''Stabat Mater'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine could never quite decide, and that is what turned it into such a confusing and unresolved search for proper scale.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Women's Memorial
description: For more than two years, the Vietnam Women's Memorial Project has been asking that a statue of a woman be added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in the capital to reflect the service of more than 10,000 women, mostly nurses, in the long conflict in Vietnam.

title: ALIEN LAW EFFECT ON FARM WORKERS WORRIES GROWERS
description: California agricultural groups report that fewer alien farm workers than expected are applying for legal status under the new immigration law, intensifying the debate over whether the supply of farm labor here will be sufficient in coming years.

title: Plessey-Telenet Venture
description: Britain's Plessey Company P.L.C. said Friday that it had established a joint venture with the Telenet Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of U.S. Sprint, to supply switching equipment to send electronic data by telephone. The venture, to be called Plessey-Telenet, will be 51 percent owned by Plessey but largely managed by Telenet. ''It puts this operation more on a footing with world-class opposition in an extremely lucrative market opening up in Europe,'' a Plessey spokesman said. The company said it expected sales in the first year to come to $:30 million ($49.5 million).

title: Ellen Remington Woznica Weds Dr. Kenneth Passero
description: Ellen Remington Woznica, a daughter of Joyce O'Connor Woznica of Simsbury, Conn., and Stephen Woznica of Hyde Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Passero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Passero Jr. of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. James Beckwith performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Norwalk.

title: Uneasiness Pervades Markets
description: While the economy seems healthy, with no sharp rise in inflation and good prospects for continued growth, the financial markets are beset with doubts and worries.

title: In TV and Films, as in Life, Babies Are in Fashion Again
description: LEAD: Somewhere on their way to the top, many young professionals have discovered that they cannot live on silk ties and power lunches alone. Sure, they graduated summa cum laude, bought Cuisinart food processors, took saunas at the health club and spent summers abroad. Some even married.

title: Key U.S. Bond Falls in Tokyo
description: The key United States 8 7/8 percent 30-year Treasury bond lost nearly half a point on liquidation by dealers because of the price collapse of the key December Treasury bond futures contract, dealers said today.

title: Cards Beaten By 3 Rallies
description: For a change, Jeffrey Leonard didn't hit a home run today. But that was just about the only thing the San Francisco Giants didn't inflict on the St. Louis Cardinals as they won their second straight playoff game and moved to within one of taking the National League pennant.

title: When Prosecutors Violate Confidentiality
description: A significant number of prominent criminal cases have recently been characterized by a troubling breakdown in confidentiality. Simply put, prosecutors and their agents have selectively leaked to the media damaging information about subjects of grand jury investigations and other legal proceedings that are supposed to remain secret until disclosed in open court at the appropriate time.

title: Koch to Decide Fate of Dr. Gross Within 10 Days
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would decide within 10 days whether to dismiss Dr. Elliot M. Gross as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, as recommended by a mayoral advisory committee. Dr. Gross, who faces state charges of negligence and incompetence, has vowed not to resign.

title: 'SMOKELESS' CIGARETTE STILL HARMS SMOKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Folk: Baez at Carnegie Hall
description: IN her recent song ''Warriors of the Sun,'' Joan Baez conjures a characteristically blunt vision of the tattered remains of the 1960's peace movement: We are warriors of the sun Fighting postwar battles that somehow never got won It may be crazy and it may be the final run.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Telling State Dept. How to Run Foreign Policy...and Allowing It Less Money
description: Late last Thursday evening, the Senate passed a bill that would give the State Department $3.6 billion to conduct its affairs in the current fiscal year. But as the 85 senators voting in favor of it approved the Foreign Relations Authorization Act of 1988, they were adopting more than just a broad financing measure for the State Department, its embassies, the Voice of America and the United States Information Service.

title: German Politician Facing Inquiry Is Found Dead
description: A young West German politician who has been at the center of a political scandal for the last month was found dead today in a Geneva hotel, but the Swiss police had no immediate indication of the cause of death.

title: >Getty Buys Ensor Masterpiece
