description: The J. Paul Getty Museum said today that it had acquired the masterpiece of the Belgian painter James Ensor, ''The Entry of Christ Into Brussels,'' of 1888, from a private foundation in Liechtenstein.

title: JACKSON AND KOCH DEBATE DEMERITS OF THEIR CITIES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says no, he wouldn't want to live in New York City, ''wouldn't even try it.'' The prospect of visiting the city was ignored altogether.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Tewell Wins in Pensacola: Doug Tewell shot a three-under-par 68 that included his third eagle of the tournament and won the Pensacola Open in Florida yesterday by three strokes over Danny Edwards and Phil Blackmar. Tewell shot a 72-hole total of 15-under-par 269 on the 7,154-yard Perdido Bay Resort course.(AP) Mowry Victorious: Larry Mowry shot a six-under-par 66 to win the Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga., by two strokes yesterday. Mowry finished at 13-under-par 203 over the 54 holes to earn $37,500. (AP) Tennis Gilbert Tops Teltscher: Third-seeded Brad Gilbert breezed to a 6-2, 6-2 victory over seventh-seeded Eliot Teltscher and won the $303,400 World Championship Tennis Scottsdale Open yesterday in Arizona. (AP) Noah Wins in Switzerland: Yannick Noah scored a hard-fought victory yesterday over Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 7-6, 6-4, 6-4, to win the $239,000 Swiss Indoor tournament in Basel. Noah is returning to competition after a three-month layoff. (AP) McEnroe Defeats Annacone: John McEnroe defeated Paul Annacone, 6-4, 7-5, yesterday to win the AT&T Challenge in Atlanta and collect $150,000. McEnroe, suspended from Grand Prix play, was able to compete in the AT&T Challenge because it is an exhibition. (AP) Marathon Froelick Is First: Marty Froelick of Colorado Springs, Colo., won the sixth annual Twin Cities Marathon in Minneapolis yesterday. Sylvie Bournet of Missous, France, was the first woman to finish. About 7,000 runners took part in the race, which began in 24-degree weather. (AP) Half-Marathon to Schlesinger: Dan Schlesinger won the Staten Island Half-Marathon yesterday in 1 hour 5 minutes 9 seconds. Dan Dickenson finished second in the field of 1,250. Jillian Beschloss was the first woman to finish, in 1:17:33. (AP) Auto Racing Rahal Captures 2d Title in Row: Bobby Rahal won his second consecutive CART-PPG Indy-car series championship yesterday with a victory in the Champion Spark Plug at the Laguna Seca Raceway in Monterey, Calif. Rahal averaged 118.879 miles an hour, just shy of his own race record of 119.693. Danny Sullivan finished second. (AP)

title: In Jersey City, Indians Protest Violence
description: For weeks now, Lalitha Masson has found herself standing before her open bedroom closet, filled with a bitter resignation.

title: Ballet: Graham's 'Primitive Mysteries' and 'Judith'
description: ''PRIMITIVE MYSTERIES'' and ''Judith,'' performed by the Martha Graham Dance Company for the first time this season Saturday night, are typical of the wider repertory the company has presented in recent years.

title: Poetry and Tradition:
description: On the same spot in the living room where Mario Cuomo has twice taken the oath of office as Governor, his daughter Maria was married in the Executive Mansion today to Kenneth D. Cole, a shoe designer, as 300 friends and political figures looked on.

title: No Longer Foiled
description: As swords go, the foil is a gossamer weapon, a nearly weightless ribbon whose scoring touches are a fencer's caresses. Derived from the courtier's delicate dress sword, the foil, by chivalric tradition, has been the only weapon wielded by female fencers.

title: In World Chess Match, 2 Rivals Meet Again
description: For the fourth time in three years, the world championship chess match, starting today in Seville, Spain, will pit the same antagonists against each other - the 24-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov, and his 36-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, both of the Soviet Union.

title: Officers' Wives Told They Should Quit Jobs
description: An investigation has shown that the wives of two senior officers at Grissom Air Force Base in Indiana were warned to quit their salaried jobs or their husbands' careers would be damaged, the Air Force says.

title: Outdoors; In Pursuit Of Morning Doves
description: DUCKS over decoys, quail and grouse over pointing dogs and corn-field pheasants are all superb sport for the shotgunner. But the opening of dove season each September brings not only the earliest but also some of the most enjoyable and, without question, the most challenging wing shooting of the year to millions of American hunters.

title: New Tenneco Unit Planned
description: Tenneco Inc., said Friday that it would form a new holding company over itself and its subsidiary operations. The plan for the new concern, which is to be called Tenneco Inc., is subject to stockholder approval at its Dec. 7 meeting. The current Tenneco operating division will change its name to the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company.

title: HEAD-ON CRASH KILLS 6 JERSEYANS
description: Five fraternity brothers from Trenton State College and a 20-year-old woman were killed when their cars collided head-on early yesterday on Interstate 95 outside Philadelphia, the authorities said.

title: Slow Growth in Europe
description: The European Community's economy will expand by 2.3 percent in 1988, well below expected growth rates for the United States and Japan, the community's commission said. It said in a report on Friday that the United States and Japanese economies would probably grow by 2.7 percent and 3.5 percent, respectively, in 1988, compared with 2.3 percent and 2.9 percent this year. The report said the community's economy was expected to expand by 2.2 percent this year.

title: Dole Sees Campaign Gaining and Criticizes Bush
description: The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, saying his Presidential campaign was gathering momentum, expressed confidence today that Labor Secretary William E. Brock 3d and other party leaders would play major roles in his effort to gain the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Bidder for Holly Sugar Has a Diverse Portfolio
description: Peter R. Harvey, an Illinois businessman, has amassed a diverse portfolio of investments in public and private companies that range from a maker of artificial silk flowers to manufacturers of scientific instruments and costume jewelry.

title: Syria Hopeful on French Ties
description: Syria expects to have warmer relations with France after two days of talks in Damascus with the French Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard Raimond, a Syrian Cabinet member said today. ''The Syrian and French republics are to bolster their relations and expand cooperation in all fields,'' Najah al-Attar, the Minister of Culture, was quoted by the Syrian radio as saying. She spoke at a ceremony at which Mr. Raimond opened a new French cultural center in Damascus.

title: SRI LANKA REBELS AND INDIAN TROOPS FIGHT FOR 3D DAY
description: Tamil guerrillas attacked Indian peacekeeping forces in the Jaffna Peninsula today with mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, according to Sri Lankan Government radio, and the Indians responded with heavy counterattacks.

title: Pop: Atlantic Starr, Quintet
description: ONE of the disheartening legacies of the late-70's disco boom has been its reduction of so much mainstream pop-soul music to formulas in which strong voices are packaged in cookie-cutter arrangements. Now and then, of course, a conceptual iconoclast like Prince or a great singer like Anita Baker transcends this kind of homogenization. But more often than not, contemporary pop-soul concerts are exercises in comfortable conformity.

title: TV Review; RAQUEL WELCH STARS IN 'RIGHT TO DIE,' NBC
description: RAQUEL WELCH in her most demanding major dramatic role - that's the come-on implied in the publicity surrounding the made-for-television movie on NBC at 9 this evening. But the fact-based ''Right to Die'' adds up to considerably more than just another ambitious turn for a glamorous star determined to prove that anything Farrah Fawcett can do, she can do better. Here is a film that deals candidly and indeed toughly with a profoundly serious issue, literally one of life and death, involving the removal of a life-support system. There is little pussyfooting and no phony uplift.

title: Java Gold Injured, Out for Rest of '87
description: Java Gold went lame shortly after his surprising defeat in the Jockey Club Gold Cup on Saturday and will not race again this year because he has sustained a deep bruise at the base of his right front foot.

title: Weekly Bill Auction Delayed a Day
description: The regular weekly auction of Treasury bills will be held tomorrow rather than today, when the Treasury securities market is closed for the Columbus Day holiday.

title: Defining the 'Outer City:' For Now, Call It Hybrid
description: Across the country, on the perimeters of the big metropolitan areas, gleaming clusters of office skyscrapers, department stores, hotels, restaurants and theaters have shot up in what some students of urban affairs say is a new stage in the evolution of the American city.

title: Opera: 3 Debuts in 'Turandot'
description: FIVE of the principal roles in the New York City Opera's production of Puccini's ''Turandot'' have changed hands, three of them to people making debuts with the company. On Sunday afternoon, the strongest impression was made by a singer who performed her role two years ago at the house, Edith Davis as Liu. Ms. Davis's fluid, passionate musicality and her firm, warm soprano voice, which could also be employed with unusual elegance in quiet music, stood out among the work of the new cast members.

title: Northwest Sustains A Frenetic Pace
description: Shortly before 7 A.M. recently, Cindy Seitz, a service manager for Northwest Airlines, entered a miniature control tower at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport to help oversee another day of operations.

title: No Farm-Help Dearth
description: To the Editor:

title: Trident Mischief, or Worse
description: It makes no sense for the Pentagon to test the new Trident submarine missile with more and more warheads. Yet that is precisely what Defense Secretary Weinberger has ordered. Perhaps his decision represents a mischievous effort to complicate nuclear arms talks. Perhaps worse, he may not realize that the Soviet Union would benefit more from his ploy than the United States.

title: A 2D ARREST IN MURDER OF WITNESS
description: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the execution-style slaying of a taxi dispatcher who had testified before a Queens grand jury about a shooting she witnessed, the police said.

title: D'Amato, Uncommitted, Is Senator in the Middle
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, flanked by much of New York's black political establishment, sat on the dais and listened as Don King, the boxing promoter, spoke.

title: Pact With Canada Splits U.S. Industry
description: A week after Canadian and American negotiators agreed on a free trade pact, most analysts said it would create more winners than losers in the United States.

title: Leader Faces Decision As Telex Profits Shrink
description: Stephen J. Jatras has held the top position at the Telex Corporation through the recent good times for the company. The producer of computer terminals and peripheral equipment, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., has posted seven years of rising profits.

title: 2d Seoul Opposition Leader Set to Run
description: Although stopping short of a formal declaration of candidacy, South Korea's most prominent opposition figure left virtually no doubt at a public rally here today that he was running for president.

title: DeConcini Tests Fallout Over Bork
description: A few days after he joined eight colleagues on the Senate Judiciary Committee and voted against the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, Dennis DeConcini came home to Arizona this weekend, on an inspection tour of sorts, to inventory the damage his stand had wrought among the state's wide majority of conservative voters.

title: Taking Charge of Life, and Death
description: New York State's Task Force on Life and the Law proposes to give patients the right to designate an ''agent'' to make life and death decisions should they become incompetent to do so for themselves. It's a wise initiative that sets an example for other states. It does not promote ''the right to die'' but sensibly extends people's right to take charge of their lives.

title: Pitt's Heyward Powers Ahead
description: Not only is Craig Heyward big -6 feet, 260 pounds - he is faster than one might believe, indefatigable and apparently indestructible.

title: Paris Sees Market Challenges
description: Some French stockbrokers are calling it ''our Big Bang,'' while others have dubbed it the ''petit bang.''

title: Roger Grossman Is Wed To Kathleen S. Silloway
description: Kathleen S. Silloway, a daughter of Janet L. Silloway of East Windsor, N.J., and Frank F. Silloway of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Roger Grossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Grossman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Joan O'Gorman, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Dockside Harbor restaurant in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Now Is the Time for Democrats to . . .
description: The Democrats are staggering into a Presidential election crisis, and even ''the brightest and the best'' of them aren't coming to the aid of their party.

title: Andrea Bozzi Is Wed To Alfred L. Thimm Jr.
description: The wedding of Andrea Louise Bozzi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Bozzi of New York, to Alfred L. Thimm Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thimm of Burlington, Vt., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Nicholas R. Reid performed the ceremony.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 12, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INSIDE
description: Twins and Giants Win Minnesota used sharp relief pitching to top Detroit, 5-3, and lead 3-1 in the American League baseball playoffs. San Francisco defeated St. Louis, 6-3, to lead 3-2 in the National League series. SportsMonday, page C1. N.F.L. Attendance Grows

title: Messenger To Redskin
description: Redskin, a 3-year-old chestnut colt driven by John Campbell, caught Jate Lobell, the favorite, midway through the stretch to win the 32d annual Messenger Stakes by two lengths in 1:58 last night at Roosevelt Raceway. Trained by Jerry Smith, Redskin, who went off on the second tier from the No. 11 post position, earned $223,655 to push his career earnings to $1,865,702. He paid $17.20 for $2 to win.

title: Metro Matters; Picking Giulian: A Grand Marshal With a Message
description: Updating their analysis of New York's ethnic stew, Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote in 1970 that while the cultural and social style of Italian-Americans had produced attractive families, neighborhoods and friendships, ''somehow the ethos has not gone beyond that to create a presumption of leadership in city affairs.''

title: Hill, Holliday Presents Hyatt Hotels Campaign
description: Hyatt Hotels, whose main target is the business traveler, introduces tomorrow its first campaign by its new agency, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston. Adam M. Aron, Hyatt senior vice president, marketing, said that an interesting facet of the effort is that instead of using magazines exclusively for the campaign as in the recent past, 60 percent of this year's spending will be in newspapers.

title: DAVIS MURDER TRIAL, OPENING THIS WEEK, MAY TEST POLICE MOTIVES
description: Last November, at least 30 police officers surrounded a building in the South Bronx where, they say, they hoped to question a man about the murders, two weeks earlier, of four reputed drug dealers in an apartment.

title: Working Life of the Retiree
description: Of all Americans who receive a pension, more than one in six supplements his or her income by working on the side, a new study by the Census Bureau says.

title: New York Turns Squatters Into Homeowners
description: In August 1985, squatters advised by community organizers seized 25 vacant, city-owned buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn. City officials were furious, 11 people were arrested, and the contretemps became an issue in the Democratic primary that year between Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy.

title: Memorial Quilt Rolls Out
description: The sound of sobs and the reading of names punctured the early morning quiet as pieces of material were unfurled and hooked together, creating a huge quilt intended as a personal memorial to 1,920 AIDS victims.

title: A Gold Guide Won't Take Us Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Man, 34, Is Shot and Killed After Argument at Roseland
description: A Manhattan man was shot and killed in the crowded lobby of the Roseland dance hall early yesterday after an argument that began when another man stepped on the feet of the victim's companion, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ZERO GRAVITY. By Richard Lourie. 284 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. THE framework of Richard Lourie's new novel, ''Zero Gravity,'' is amusing enough. The Soviet Union decides to send a poet to the moon. ''Theme of Project: humanization, not militarization of cosmos.'' A Polish general suffers ''severe gastric distress'' at the idea. ''The very thought of some Muscovite bard bounding from crater to crater bombarding earth with booming rhymed lies was more than the general could stomach.'' So he leaks the news to the Americans, who beat the Russians to the draw and announce that they will be sending a poet to the moon. Moscow is furious, but saves face by proposing a joint reading, which America accepts. The project lurches forward.

title: Accord With Israel Yields Trade Gains
description: Two years after the United States and Israel signed an agreement for free trade - the first such American pact with another country - commerce between the two nations has increased substantially and decades-old obstacles are beginning to be cleared. Israel has shifted some of its trading focus from Europe to the United States, and the United States may be starting to look upon Israel more as a serious trading partner and less as a charity case.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 11, MONDAY Coca-Cola Co Phillips Petroleum Dana Corp Xerox Corp L&N Housing TUESDAY Bank of NY Co Procter & Gamble Chesapeake Corp Reliance Group Hldgs ITT Corp Weyerhaeuser Co Pansophic Systems WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver PacifiCorp Bard (CR) Tokheim Corp Hillenbrand Indus Walgreen Co NACCO Industries Wisconsin Pwr & Lt PPG Industries Woolworth (FW) Co PS Group Inc THURSDAY Black & Decker Grumman Corp Bundy Corp Hannaford Bros Central & S. West Corp Interstate Pwr Cincinnati Gas & Elec NERCO Inc Conrac Corp Sherwin Williams First Wisconsin Corp Springs Indus Gillette Co Sundstrand Corp FRIDAY Acme Electric Flowers Indus Communications Satellite Illinois Tool Works Diversified Energies

title: Rangers Saved by Rallies, Goalie
description: In their first two games of a new season with a new coach, the Rangers have not performed particularly well as team, but they have neutralized mistakes with third-period scoring revivals, and have played just well enough not to lose - yet.

title: Dr. Judith Halperin Wed to Dr. Joel Neil Goldstein
description: Dr. Judith Halperin and Dr. Joel Neil Goldstein were married yesterday at the Menemsha Inn in Chilmark, Mass., by Rabbi Balfour Brickner. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Halperin of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Menemsha. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Goldstein of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: IN 1940's SPAIN, ANTI-SEMITISM WAS RIFE; Those of Salonika
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Hagy Wed To Jane Shauna Razzi
description: Jane Shauna Razzi, a marketing manager for the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, was married yesterday to W. Thomas Hagy, the associate editor of Mealey Publications, a publisher of specialized legal journals in Devon, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Collier, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Newtown, Pa.

title: Mistakes Plague Tigers in 5-3 Loss
description: The night grew colder and longer and more uncertain with each inning, but the Minnesota Twins seemed to warm to their task. They were considered underdogs when the series began four days ago, but now they are on the verge of something remarkable.

title: At 5-0, Syracuse Football Is Back in the Game
description: NO one is quite prepared to describe events here as an advanced case of Orangemania. Chances are, some people would think you were talking about a new soft drink, anyway. There is, however, no denying the Growing interest in the Syracuse football team. It is evident in the pink message slips multiplying on Dick MacPherson's desk when the coach returns from lunch or a meeting, and in the recent involvement of the city fathers, who have scheduled a pep rally for Friday evening at the city hall, in preparation for Saturday's showdown against Penn State.

title: NEW CHARGE REPORTED AGAINST JUDGE HASTINGS
description: A new Federal complaint has been filed against Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings, who already faces possible impeachment in Congress, it was reported Saturday.

title: One Tropical Forest That Can Be Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide; GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Holiday Festivities

title: Rise in Killings in Zimbabwe Brings New Curbs on Opposition
description: A surge in attacks by shadowy groups of anti-Government rebels has cast fear over white farmers near this city, and has prompted the Government, which has linked the rebels to its main political opposition, to all but ban the group.

title: Doctors Indicted in Brazil
description: Three doctors who owned an abandoned radiation therapy clinic have been charged in the release of radioactive material that contaminated 40 people, 10 of them critically. Orlando Teixeira, 37 years old, Criseide Dourado, 40, and Carlos Bezzerril, 43, directors of the Goiania Radiation Therapy Institute, were indicted Saturday on charges of causing grave injury to 10 people. If conficted, they face two to eight years in jail.

title: Jews in U.S. to Use 'Restraint' On Matters of Israeli Security
description: The head of an umbrella group of 45 American Jewish organizations has assured Israeli leaders that American Jews will not meddle in matters involving Israel's security, despite the call by one of its member organizations for an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: New York Psychiatric Wards Can't Hold Homeless Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Carney Dead; Served Ohio in House
description: Charles J. Carney, who was a labor leader before he served four terms in the House of Representatives, died Wednesday at St. Elizabeth Hospital Medical Center of a heart ailment complicated by pneumonia. He was 74 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a dispatch about Guinea's ties with France misidentified French words displayed in a classroom. They were adjectives.

title: CRIME AT KENNEDY: SCAMS, DRUGS AND THE MOB
description: With near-record numbers of travelers expected at Kennedy International Airport this year, the authorities there are reporting sharp increases in pickpocketing, luggage theft and other property crimes.

title: Paul F. Shaw Is Dead at 73; Authority on Labor Relations
description: Paul F. Shaw, an authority on international labor relations and a former vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died after suffering a heart attack at his home Friday in Williston Park, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: NEW SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1987
description: International A3-13 Guerrillas attacked India's forces in Sri Lanka's Jaffna Peninsula with mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, Sri Lankan Government radio reported, on the third day of India's peacekeeping effort. Page A1 Foreigners took part in unrest in Tibet, according to some of them. Several said in interviews that they had thrown stones at Chinese policemen or filmed the violence, and there were reports that others helped wounded Tibetans. A8 A Burma Airways plane crashed in central Burma, killing all 49 people aboard, including 14 Americans, the Government said. It was the second crash of a Burma Airways plane in less than four months. A3 Attacks by rebels in Zimbabwe have cast fear over white farmers outside the city of Gweru and prompted the Government to all but ban its main political rival. The violence has killed 14 people since June. A3 Iraq staged new attacks on Iran's oil and an Iranian surface-to-surface missile fired in retaliation exploded in Baghdad. One Iraqi attack severely damaged a Liberian-registered oil tanker, and two crewmen were reported killed. A6 Stillborn Middle East peace talks may have lasting effect as proof of the difficulty Palestinian and Jewish nationalists find when they try to put together a negotiating format that might break the current Arab-Israeli deadlock. A6 Racism seeps into French politics, particularly in the country's south, where many citizens are flocking to the side of Jean-Marie Le Pen and his calls for curbs on Arab immigration. A4 A rally for an opposition leader in South Korea left little doubt that Kim Dae Jung was running for President, although he stopped short of a formal declaration of his candidacy. A3 Footnote to Iran-contra affair A5 American Jews will not meddlein Israeli security A6 West German politician found dead A12 Soviet delegation on U.S. farm tour A13 National A14-17, B6-7 Fewer allen farm workers than ex-pected are applying for legal status under the new immigration law, intensifying debate in California over whether the supply of farm labor will be sufficient in coming years. Thousands of gay Americans and a diverse coalition of supporters marched in Washington, calling for an end to discrimination against homosexuals and for more Federal money for AIDS research and treatment. A1 An early vote on Judge Bork is being discussed by Senate leaders, who indicated the final debate on his nomination might begin as early as this week. Such a schedule is thought likely to benefit the White House. A1 DeConcini tests fallout over Bork B6 D'Amato remains uncommitted on Bork B6 Women who work as firefighters say that while life has improved for women already in the firehouse, the bright red door is still substantially closed to those aspiring to join the ranks. A1 Senator Paul Simon is the focus of increasing attention as the dust settles from a tumultuous year for Democratic Presidential candidates. ''Per-sonally, I think Simon is a sleeper,'' one politician said. B7 A major new urban phenomenon has materialized on the perimeters of metropolitan areas. Gleaming new clusters of office skyscrapers, stores, hotels, parks and theaters form what is being called the ''outer city.'' A14 The J. Paul Getty Museum acquired the Belgian painter James Ensor's masterpiece, ''The Entry of Christ Into Brussels'' from a private foundation in Liechtenstein, museum officials said. C13 Panama City journal A14 New charge for Judge Hastings B7 Robertson's former church uncertain on candidacy B7 Washington Talk A16 Congress tells State Dept. how to conduct foreign policy . . .and gives it less money Regional B1-4 Squatters who took over buildings inEast New York in 1985 have become the first test of a model for low-income housing development in which the city gives money and technical help in return for restricted rights of resale. A1 The leader of a militant black group, Joanne Chesimard, who escaped from a New Jersey prison while serving a life sentence for the murder of a state trooper, is living in Cuba as a political refugee, according to a report in Newsday. A1 Violence against Indians in Jersey City has erupted in recent weeks. Although the police say they do not know if the violence is ethnically motivated, Indians fear that it must be, and about 500 marched, calling for justice. B1 Fearful of being hospitalized against their will, mentally ill homeless people in New York City have been changing their routines and disappearing from their usual haunts, according to health workers. B1 Varying retirement ages for judges that depend on whether they are elected or appointed are being challenged by six judges whose case has reached New York's Court of Appeals. A favorable ruling could affect next month's judicial races. B3 Sharp increases in property crimes are being reported at Kennedy International Airport, and law-enforcement officials say the methods and targets of organized crime operating at the airport are shifting. B1 Larry Davis goes on trial this week on charges of murdering four men. It is the first of what promises to be a long string of criminal proceedings against him, including charges of the attempted murder of nine police officers. B3 A major Louis Armstrong archive has been acquired by Queens College. The letters, photographs, scrapbooks and other material accumulated by the late jazz trumpeter should help fill in details about the man called Satchmo. C13 Broad debate in Sag Harbor B2 Lack of response to amnesty forces staff cuts B3

title: Iraq Hits 3 Tankers; An Iranian Missile Goes Off in Baghdad>
description: Iraq staged aerial attacks on Iranian oil targets today, and an Iranian surface-to-surface missile exploded in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital.

title: 200,000 March in Capital to Seek Gay Rights and Money for AIDS
description: In a demonstration reminiscent of the civil rights marches of the 1960's, 200,000 people, gay Americans and a diverse coalition of their supporters, marched here today, calling for more Federal money for AIDS research and treatment and for an end to discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If the San Francisco Giants make it to the World Series and become champions, Kevin Mitchell, who was with the champion Mets last season, would be a member of his second consecutive Series winner, but with a different team? Has it happened before?

title: Solti Is Robbed in Hotel After Chicago Concert
description: A burglar stole a passport, $400 and jewelry from Sir Georg Solti and his wife as they slept in a hotel room, hours after a weekend celebration of the conductor's 75th birthday, the police said today.

title: A Demeaning Battle
description: Judge Robert H. Bork made no sense either in deciding to insist on ultimate defeat in the Senate or in explaining why he refused to withdraw his name from nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: TV Review; QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ABOUT AIDS, ON HBO
description: IGNORE the contrived title. ''AIDS: Everything You and

title: Natwest-First Jersey
description: Natwest Holdings Inc., a unit of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said Friday that it would buy up to 5 percent of the First Jersey National Corporation's common stock in private, open-market or other transactions. National Westminster Bank, whose National Westminster Bank USA unit agreed in August to acquire First Jersey National at $82 a share, disclosed its intentions in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The purchases ''would be made in furtherance of Natwest's ultimate objective of merging with First Jersey,'' the filing said. The merger is expected to be completed in January.

title: Peru's Banks Nationalized
description: The Government of Peru has enacted a law to nationalize private banks, ending 10 weeks of heated debate that has dominated political life and galvanized right-wing opposition to President Alan Garcia. The law, published in the official gazette, was signed Friday by Mr. Garcia and will take effect on Monday.

title: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Mandatory Retirement Challenged by 6 Judges
description: Some New York judges must retire at 70. Others may continue as judges until age 76. Still others may serve into their 80's and 90's if they choose.

title: CRASH OF AIRLINER IN BURMA KILLS 49, 14 FROM U.S.
description: A Burma Airways plane caught fire and crashed about 20 miles short of a popular tourist town in central Burma today, and all 49 people aboard died, the Government said.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; All Done on West Front
description: Restoration work on the West Front of the Capitol is finally finished. That is the good news. The better news is that the completion of the project was achieved nine months ahead of schedule and at a price of $29 million, or $20 million less than had been estimated, according to the Architect of the Capitol.

title: FUGITIVE MURDERER REPORTED IN CUBA
description: Joanne Chesimard, a leader of the black radical movement who escaped in 1979 from a New Jersey prison where she was serving a life term for murdering a state trooper, has been living in Cuba for three years and was interviewed there recently by Newsday.

title: Judith Ann Elleen Weds Neil Smith in Short Hills
description: At the Chanticler restaurant in Short Hills, N.J., Judith Ann Elleen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Elleen of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Neil Alan Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Smith of Springfield, Mo. Rabbi Z. David Levy officiated.

title: Mary Unterberg Arno Is Wed to Charles DeBare
description: Mary Unterberg Arno, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Unterberg of New York and Tinton Falls, N.J., and Charles A. DeBare, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nat Jacques DeBare of Jamaica, Queens, were married yesterday at the bride's summer home in Elberon, N.J. Mayor Joseph Frankel of Eatontown, N.J. performed the ceremony.

title: Hurricane Warnngs for Florida
description: Tropical Storm Floyd picked up strength today in the western Caribbean as its winds reached 60 miles an hour, and forecasters posted hurricane warnings for southwest Florida and the Florida Keys.

title: Merger Speculation In Interpublic Group
description: The hot rumor of last week was that the Interpublic Group of Companies is planning to merge two of its operating units: SSC& B:Lintas worldwide network and Campbell-Ewald, the Detroit agency historically linked to the huge Chevrolet account.

title: 'Default' Is Not in Bankers' Stars
description: No industry has experienced more rapid change in recent years than international finance. New financial instruments become obsolete from one year to the next. Bank strategies for coping with the debt crisis are as disposable as yesterday's newspaper. And regulations once considered the bedrock of the financial system are virtually ignored as bankers leap from one loophole to another.

title: Appraisal; Painting Provoked a Public Scandal
description: One of the great European paintings of the late 19th century, James Ensor's ''Entry of Christ Into Brussels'' was a matter of public scandal almost since the day it was painted.

title: HERMANN PREY MASTER CLASS
description: The baritone Hermann Prey will teach a master class in art songs and arias from the German repertory Thursday at the Manhattan School of Music. The class, which is to start at 7 P.M. in the John C. Bordon Auditorium, is open to the public at no charge. The school entrance is on the northwest corner of Broadway and 122d Street. Information: 749-2802, extension 452.

title: Aix Journal; Blight of Hate Creeps Over a Political Landscape
description: Across a lovely stretch of southern France best known for its sunshine and beaches, unlovely racist sentiments have seeped into the mainstream of political debate as France gears up for a presidential election next spring.

title: Business and the Law; Cut in Punitive Awards Sought
description: TWELVE days after he suffered an accident while working on his car, Lloyd M. Crenshaw had to have his right foot amputated. Mr. Crenshaw's insurer, the Bankers Life and Casualty Company, refused to pay a $20,000 benefit under his policy for loss of limb. The company insisted that the amputation was not covered by the policy, saying it resulted from a degenerative disease.

title: Erica Leshan Wed To Bruce Taterka
description: Erica Munford Leshan and Bruce David Taterka, who graduated in 1985 and '84, respectively, from Vassar College, were married yesterday in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Harris. Rabbi Susan Schnur officiated.

title: Madeleine Singer Weds
description: Madeleine Rose Singer, a research analyst at the New York University Medical Center, and John Russell Leigh, a supervising specialist with Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting concern in New York, were married yesterday at the Pierre by Rabbi Martin Zion. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd I. Singer of New York, graduated from Northwestern University. She and her husband received master's degrees in public health at Yale University. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Leigh of Hamilton Township, N.J., graduated from Rutgers University.

title: One Footnote In Iran Affair: Warmer Ties?
description: One of the enduring mysteries that is likely to remain unresolved in the Iran-contra investigations is whether there really were any Iranians hoping to have better relations with the United States.

title: DISCIPLINE OF CHILDREN FROM AFAR
description: WHEN working parents are away, their children play, go to school and often misbehave. Trying to impose discipline from afar becomes a challenge.

title: Other Events; Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Wagner's ''Rheingold,'' 8.

title: Topics of The Times; For Columbus, the Semi-Millennium
description: Centennial milestones have had a good run recently: 100 years for the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty, 200 for the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, and 400 for Roanoke Island's first colony. But those were only the warm-ups. In nineteen hundred and ninety-two, it will be 500 years since Columbus sailed the ocean blue, and the party is already percolating.

title: 'Smokeless' Cigarette Still Harms Smokers
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: 'Pulcinella, By the Teatro di Roma
description: OVER the weekend, the theatrical part of the Italy on Stage festival started to pour out on the stage of the Mark Hellinger, and the first tasting was pleasant to the palate.

title: Theater: 'Mort Sahl'
description: MORT SAHL, the comic scourge of the 1950's and 1960's, opened his one-man show last night at the Neil Simon Theater on Broadway. Though the comedian has shifted some of his animosity, age has not mollified his temperament or lessened his aptitude. He is still out there in the satiric combat zone, flailing sacred cows (and sitting ducks) with his caustic wit. One may not agree with everything he says, but there is no denying the precision of his articulation. Especially with an election year approaching, his presence is tonic (some might substitute the word toxic).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the removal of a painting from a Capitol committee room misidentified Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell. He is from Colorado.

title: Mideast Peace Bid Ends; Hope and One Arm Hurt
description: During the last few months, Israel and Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization may have come a little closer to peace negotiations than at any time since their conflict began.

title: Toyota Ads Come With A 3-D Stereoscope
description: In the wake of several well-publicized magazine pop-up ads by several advertisers that frequently angered other advertisers in those publications, Toyota Motor Sales is planning a little print extravaganza of its own.

title: Yael Ben-Ishay Is Married
description: Yael Ben-Ishay, a daughter of Professors Drori and Zina Ben-Ishay of Jerusalem, was married yesterday to David J. Shapiro, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Robert W. Shapiro of Swampscott, Mass. Rabbi Shapiro officiated at Dag Hammarskjold Tower in Manhattan. Mrs. Shapiro graduated from Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Her parents, who are physicians, are researchers and teachers at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. Mr. Shapiro, a magna cum laude graduate of Brandeis University who received a law degree from Rutgers University and an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania, is an associate at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York.

title: For Women Who Fight Fires, Acceptance and Frustrations
description: LEAD: Linda Willing, a firefighter in Boulder, Colo., whose small frame belies the conventional wisdom that fighting fires is a task for brawny men, feels good about her job and the way she has been treated since she joined the department seven years ago.

title: United States Sugar to Go Private
description: The United States Sugar Corporation, the nation's largest producer of raw cane sugar, will be acquired by the Sugar Acquisitions Corporation for $80 a share in cash.

title: The Crunch at Airlines' Hubs
description: Gerri Mudzinski, a ticket agent for Northwest Airlines at gate 28 of the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, hunched over the counter and worked quickly to board passengers on a flight to Newark due to leave in 20 minutes.

title: Talks Halted After Short Gain
description: After six consecutive days of bargaining, the longest period of time they have spent together, negotiators for the National Football League's owners and striking players broke off their talks today, almost as far apart as they were when they began last Tuesday.

title: NO FLOWER POWER
description: KEVIN MITCHELL remembers the first time he met Jeffrey Leonard, long before Leonard became nationally famous as Hac-Man and Penitentiary Face, the man with the baleful stare as well as four home runs in this playoff series.

title: INSIDE
description: Bid to End Football Strike

title: 'One of Those Creatures of 200 Million Years Ago Come Alive'; Let Them Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Twins' Pitching Risks Pay Off
description: The Detroit Tigers scored the most runs in the American League during the season. The Minnesota pitchers, however, made sure the Tigers didn't duplicate their achievement in the league championship series.

title: Who Torpedoed Judge Bork?
description: Robert Bork is an honorable man with an impressive record as a professor, lawyer and judge on the United States Court of Appeals. Yet a Senate majority seems lined up against his nomination to be a Supreme Court Justice. Why? Judge Bork angrily blames a campaign of sordid distortion of his positions. He wants to strike a blow against such campaigns and thus insists on pressing his case to a final floor vote.

title: U.S. Leasing President Bullish on Ford Link
description: For 19 years, D.E. (Ned) Mundell has been president of U. S. Leasing International Inc., which by offering everything from medical equipment to commercial aircraft, has grown into the most diverse equipment leasing company in the world.

title: Opera: Piccinni Work, 'The Accomplish'd Maid'
description: IN the 1770's, late in his career, Niccolo Piccinni had the bad fortune to find himself the unwitting champion of the operatic faction that opposed Gluck in Paris. Since Gluck stood for all that is noble, progressive and reform-oriented in opera, history has been disinclined to consider the possible merits of his unintended opponent.

title: Tom Wolfe Tries New Role: Novelist
description: t's outrageous the way people conduct their lives in New York,'' Tom Wolfe said. ''And yet I don't want to live anywhere else. I don't despair, because I find the comedy so rich. At the same time that people do vile things, they also create hilariously funny spectacles. The city dominates you if you're a player, but it never fails you if you're a viewer. It's always entertaining, and it's always funny, even in its grimmest moments.''

title: Seville Journal; Was Columbus a Whiner? You Could Look It Up
description: Christopher Columbus was a chronic whiner. Cervantes asked the Crown for permission to travel to the New World to escape debt that dogged him throughout his life.

title: Girl Mauled by Lion Undergoes Surgery For Damage to Brain
description: An 8-year-old girl, mauled by a lion that was on display at a flea market, underwent a second operation today for a cracked skull. Doctors said she faces years of follow-up treatment for brain damage.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Kirkpatrick Is Cheered in Managua
description: Clouds broke and the sun shone on Jeane J. Kirkpatrick here Sunday as she drove a wildly cheering crowd of Nicaraguans to the brink of delirium.

title: Trade Gap With Japan Gets Wider
description: Japan's surplus in trade with the United States grew in September despite a 10.5 percent increase in Japanese imports of American goods and a decline in Japan's overall trade surplus.

title: Gay Rights Leaders Agree to Establish Coordinating Unit
description: A day after staging a large march on the nation's capital, gay rights advocates voted today to create a Lesbian and Gay Congress to help coordinate grassroots political activities around the country.

title: UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2,781,000, or 23 cents a share, on the sale of securities. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Valley Bank & Trust Co. on April 2, 1987, which was treated as a pooling of interests.

title: British Fashion: A Roller Coaster
description: The Italian designers, with their strong fashion message, proved a hard act to follow. In Milan last week a new sleekly feminine fashion era was heralded by slickly tailored long jackets combined with very short skirts. In the four days of spring and summer showings here, the mood was far less decisive.

title: Cooper's Lenses
description: The Cooper Companies said that its Coopervision group had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing the first ultraviolet light-blocking contact lenses in the United States. Cooper, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has been marketing the Permaflex UV lenses in Canada, West Germany and Britain for the last year. Some scientists believe exposure to ultraviolet light may cause various forms of eye damage. The new lens absorbs ultraviolet light while allowing visible light transmission comparable with regular contact lenses, the company said.

title: Broncos Defeat Raiders
description: Joe Dudek ran for two first-quarter touchdowns tonight to lead the Denver Broncos to a 30-14 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders before 61,230, exceeding by more than 20,000 the largest crowd in two weekends of replacement games.

title: ACTMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
Gold Called Aid to New Economic Order
description: Despite the turbulence in the financial markets and the barbs of skeptics, many economists find that the United States and other leading countries are making headway in a fit-and-start effort to regain control of the world economy.

title: Jaguar Production Rise
description: Jaguar P.L.C. increased its car production 14 percent in the first nine months of 1987 over the corresponding period in 1986, to a record 35,087 units, it said today. ''Demand for our cars in all world markets has never been higher,'' Roger Putnam, Jaguar's director of marketing, said. ''We are increasing production steadily.'' Worldwide sales in the January-to-September period totaled 35,319 cars, 18 percent above the 1986 period, the company said.

title: Music: Indian Vocalist
description: UNFORTUNATELY, only a small, albeit appreciative, audience attended Saturday evening's performance at the Washington Square Church by Ajoy Chakrabarty, a young and admired proponent of classical Indian vocal music, and Samar Saha, a tabla player. To Western-trained musicians, the complexity of rhythms and microtonal melodic patterns have been among the influential and alluring aspects of Indian music. Mr. Chakrabarty and Mr. Saha wove seductively intricate rhythmic and melodic webs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS PLUS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G. Wallace Bates, 79; Headed Lobby Group
description: G. Wallace Bates, who was the first president of the Business Roundtable, an influential lobbying group, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: Company Weighs Sale of Soviet Space Photos
description: AN AMERICAN company is considering whether to distribute close-up photographs of the earth taken from Soviet spacecraft, despite fears that the move might anger the Pentagon and prompt it to withhold future business from the company.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Concern for Rain Forest Has Begun to Blossom
description: THE movement to save the richest ecosystem in the world - the tropical rain forest - is making slow but certain progress as forest dwellers and local activists join with international conservation groups to halt projects that would destroy these wet jungles along with the diverse human cultures they sustain.

title: Chess Match Opens With Quiet Draw
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, drew easily with the Black pieces today in the first game of his title match with Anatoly Karpov.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS MARKED BY STRIFE
description: Conversations between the Sandinista Government and opposition parties are entering a second week without any sign of progress.

title: Software in the Mail
description: PUTTING considerations of cost and convenience aside, probably the best source for buying software for the home or small business is a large computer products store with a knowledgeable staff. If you're laying out major money for a full-featured word processor, spreadsheet or other bread-and-butter program, and especially if you're fairly new to the world of computing, you need all the help you can get.

title: Sessions Is Out of Hospital; Swearing-In Due Next Week
description: Judge William S. Sessions, designated as the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was released from the hospital today after being treated for internal bleeding. He said he expected his delayed swearing-in to be next week.

title: Amtrak Train Hits Crane in Iowa; 126 Are Injured
description: An Amtrak passenger train, the California Zephyr, slammed into a railroad crane today, knocking the locomotives and 11 cars off the tracks and injuring at least 126 people, officials said.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Fizzler
description: Unauthorized disclosures of information are dreaded by Republican and Democratic administrations alike. But many such ''leaks'' don't work out the way the leaker expected. Here is the course of one: In his Administration's latest effort to control leaks, President Reagan ordered that all Government employees with access to secret information sign a Classified Information Nondisclosure Agreement. Anyone refusing to sign could have his or her security clearance revoked, thus getting freezed out of that job.

title: Robins Head Fined $10,000
description: The president of the A.H. Robins Company was fined $10,000 today by a Federal judge who said he was tired of the company's excuses for failing to recover illegal payments made during bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Union Pacific Cuts
description: The Union Pacific Railroad said it would eliminate about 100 jobs in restructuring its marketing and sales department. About 60 staff and management workers and 40 union workers will lose their jobs in the reorganization, the railroad said. The marketing and sales department now has about 870 people worldwide. The reductions will take place throughout the system. The change will make the railroad more responsive for its customers, said Frederick B. Henderson, executive vice president of marketing and sales. The new structure will put 45 national account managers and 110 account managers at locations close to the railroad's customers throughout the country, the railroad said.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 13, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Reagan Says He Favors Vote This Week on Bork
description: President Reagan said today that he wanted the Senate to vote this week on the gravely troubled nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court.

title: In Taiwan, Promise of Change and Mainland Links
description: After 38 years of authoritarian rule and a smoldering propaganda war with the Communist Government in China, Taiwan brims with expectations of greater democracy and renewed contacts with the mainland.

title: The Shape Of Things To Come?
description: Watch out for women in miniskirts no bigger than wide belts and men in straw boater hats with veils. Absurd? Of course. But when Vivienne Westwood speaks, the fashion world listens.

title: JAMES W. CARROLL
description: James W. Carroll, a senior editor of the Encyclopedia Americana and a former editor with United Press International, died of heart failure Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Pleasantville.

title: Forbes Ranks Richest People
description: The very rich seem to be getting much richer. Over the last year, the total net worth of America's 400 wealthiest people has grown 41 percent and the number of billionaires in the United States has almost doubled to 49, according to a survey by Forbes magazine.

title: Bridge: World Team Events Are Led By Venezuelans and Italians
description: The world team championships continued here tonight with Venezuela unexpectedly leading in the qualifying stage of the open series for the Bermuda Bowl, and an experienced Italian squad heading the women's standings for the Venice Trophy.

title: No Choice But Reform for Poland
description: Desperation, as much as the Soviet example of reform, spurs the far-reaching economic moves announced by Poland last week. Six years after crushing Solidarity, Poland remains mired in the same economic swamp that spawned past protest movements. Price structures remain irrational, coordination between centralized productive units poor and worker morale and productivity minimal.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
LILLIAN VERNON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: The net income, share earnings and shares outstanding figures for this year are on a pro forma basis. The company terminated its subchapter S tax status on Aug. 20, 1987. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes was made in the Aug. 28, 1987 statements of operations. A pro forma tax provision is being shown for comparative purposes only.

title: ELIZABETH REMSEN
description: Elizabeth Remsen, the daughter of the founder of Remsenburg, L.I., died Saturday at her home in Remsenburg. She was 90 years old. Miss Remsen's father, Dr. Charles Remsen, founded the town near Speonk in Suffolk County in the 1890's, when he decided to build a red brick Presbyterian church to commemorate a young son who had died.

title: Robinson Speculation
description: One week after the Baltimore Orioles' owner, Edward Bennett Williams, discharged General Manager Hank Peters and Tom Giordano, the farm director, published reports suggested that Frank Robinson, the Baseball Hall of Fame outfielder who is now an Orioles coach, would be named to replace Peters. Robinson would become the first black man to head a major league baseball organization. But The Baltimore Sun and The Washington Post, in reporting the prospect of Robinson's selection, said he would not handle contract negotiations as part of his job because Lawrence Lucchino, the team's general counsel, would be in charge of them. The new farm system and scouting director would be Doug Melvin, who was named last week as the interim replacement for Giordano.

title: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-After equity in net income of unconsolidated finance subsidiaries of $125,000 for the quarter and $208,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-After equity in net income of unconsolidated finance subsidiaries of $45,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the 6 months. The company was formerly Champion Home Builders Co.

title: Even Citizens Can Need Immigration Counseling
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilkinson Sword
description: Friedman Benjamin Inc., a year-old agency, has been assigned the shaving products of Wilkinson Sword, a subsidiary of Allegheny International Inc. Although Leading National Advertisers, the independent media measuring company, shows little Wilkinson activity in 1986, it is expected to increase its budget this year, the agency said. The former agency was Burton-Campbell in Atlanta.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Specter Haunts the Ukraine: The Church That Isn't There
description: ''Yes, I saw it, around there,'' said the young man, standing in the courtyard of the Church of the Nativity and pointing up. ''It was a mist - well, more of a shadow, something dark'' that flickered along the gray stones of the wall.

title: For Munsingwear, A Goal Is Fulfilled
description: Munsingwear Inc., which has seen several top executives come and go in the last several years, said yesterday that it had named William W. Compton as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: ROBERT PRICE
description: Robert Price, the American who led a local group that bought General Motors South African after G.M.'s divestment, died of a heart attack Saturday. He was 61 years old. Mr. Price, who joined General Motors Corporation in 1951, retired last year as president of G.M.'s Motors Trading Corporation subsidiary. He and a group of managers bought G.M.'s operations last year and renamed them the Delta Motor Corporation.

title: Dow Drops 10.77 More, To 2,471.44
description: The stock market suffered another loss yesterday as some programmed selling and lingering anxiety over recent rises in interest rates depressed blue chips and, to a larger extent, the broader market.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Gone is the bleakness that characterized London style not long ago. In the spring ready-to-wear collections shown here in the last four days, there was an exuberance that reflects London's new mood.

title: BROAD NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oil Production Outlook
description: This nation's crude oil output will decline again in 1988 but at a slower rate, the Independent Petroleum Association of America said today. Production will average 8.17 million barrels a day, compared with this year's estimated 8.3 million, it said. The decrease of 130,000 barrels a day would be less than the decline of 330,000 barrels a day for the last two years.

title: Officials Can't Confirm Chesimard Is in Havana
description: The law-enforcement agencies that have pursued JoAnne Chesimard since her escape in 1979 from a prison where she was serving a life sentence for murdering a New Jersey state trooper said yesterday that they had had reports of her living in Havana but had been unable to confirm them.

title: Dredging the Bering Sea for Some of What Glitters
description: She looks like a barn built by an eccentric farmer, but she shows promise of breaking a barrier that has frustrated gold miners here for most of the 20th century.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, said it would reassume full operational and commercial responsibility for its alumina refinery in Jamaica as agreed to in a 1985 agreement with the Jamaican Government.

title:
Market Place;
Ford's Strategy On Cash Hoard
description: LEAD: DESPITE its recent spending, the Ford Motor Company is still flush with cash and looking at possible acquisitions in financial services, aerospace and electronics - businesses whose cycles tend to balance the volatile auto industry, which is four years into a boom.

title: Flora Scalamandre, Silk Fabric Designer
description: Flora Scalamandre, a co-founder of Scalamandre Silks Inc., one of the largest manufacturers of silk fabrics on the East Coast, died Friday after a heart attack at her home in Plandome Manor, L.I. She was 80 years old.

title: Seoul Assembly Approves Charter Providing Direct Vote for President
description: South Korea took a major step in its democratic development today as the National Assembly overwhelmingly approved a new constitution that calls for direct presidential elections.

title: CRITICARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: National Archives; Outwittin Scholar As Thieves By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times
description: Officials at the Library of Congress and the National Archives, two guardians of national historic treasures, are wrestling with the question of how to protect the rare documents entrusted to their care while making them accessible to researchers and scholars.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $104,000 for the quarter and $644,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Badger Meter Inc., Milwaukee, a marketer and maker of products using flow measurement technology serving industrial and utility markets, elected William H. Vander Heyden executive vice president of the industrial products division and designated him as the company's chief technical officer, both newly created positions.

title: An Aggressive, Brilliant Researcher
description: DR. Susumu Tonegawa learned that he received the Nobel Prize in Medicine when he was called by a Japanese news organization at 6:30 A.M. yesterday. The news thrust into the spotlight a scientist described by colleagues as a very private man who is an aggressive, driven and brilliant researcher.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF PANAMA CITY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock form in November 1986.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jackson Apologizes For Remarks on TV
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told Mayor Koch yesterday that he apologizes if he insulted New Yorkers in a remark Sunday on CBS-TV, a mayoral spokesman said.

title: Mattel to Make Toys for Disney
description: Mattel Inc. said today that it would design and make a line of infant and preschool toys for the Walt Disney Company.

title: Iraqi Jets Raid Greek Ship in Gulf, Killing Sailor
description: Iraqi warplanes raided a Greek-owned ship in the Persian Gulf today, killing at least one crewman in their ninth attack in a week on tankers either leased by Iran or trading with it.

title: Thriving Despite Hardship: Key Childhood Traits Identified
description: A WOMAN, a paranoid schizophrenic, ate all her meals in restaurants because she was convinced someone was poisoning her food at home. Her 12-year-old daughter developed the same fears and likewise ate in restaurants. Her 10-year-old daughter would eat at home if her father was there, but otherwise went along with her mother.

title: KEY RATES
'Roza' Closes
description: ''Roza,'' a musical based on a novel by Romain Gary, with book and lyrics by Julian More and music by Gilbert Becaud, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Royale Theater. The play, directed by Harold Prince, ran for 12 regular performances and 20 previews.

title: NEW SYSTEM IS DELAYING AID TO POOR
description: A new computer system introduced at 10 New York City welfare centers to improve management is delaying welfare payments to hundreds of poor people, according to city officials.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $389,000, or 17 cents a share, in deferred interest.

title: Syria Says It Will Attend Arab Parley in Jordan
description: President Hafez al-Assad has decided to attend the Arab summit in Jordan next month after receiving assurances that it will not be limited to the Iran-Iraq war, a spokesman said today.

title: XIOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pledging Tolerance, Bush Officially Joins 1988 Race
description: Vice President Bush formally began his second quest for the Presidency today, setting a tone of moderation and pledging ''to stand for a new harmony'' and ''a greater tolerance.''

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Review; 'Nova' Examines 'Spy Machines'
description: TECHNOLOGY grows more complicated, even as its purpose stays the same. Hot-air balloons over Antietam and Manassas give way to the KH-11, a satellite that can take a picture from 570 miles in space and have the photograph in the White House in hours. ''Nova,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight (and on Channels 21 and 49 at 8 P.M.), looks at one way governments gather information. The episode, ''Spy Machines,'' is well done.

title: Tom Wolfe Tries New Role: Novelist
description: It's outrageous the way people conduct their lives in New York,'' Tom Wolfe said. ''And yet I don't want to live anywhere else. I don't despair, because I find the comedy so rich. At the same time that people do vile things, they also create hilariously funny spectacles. The city dominates you if you're a player, but it never fails you if you're a viewer. It's always entertaining, and it's always funny, even in its grimmest moments.''

title: M.I.T. Scientist Wins Nobel Prize for Medicine
description: DR. Susumu Tonegawa, a 48-year-old Japanese scientist working at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine yesterday for his discoveries of how the body can suddenly marshal its immunological defenses against millions of different disease agents that it has never encountered before.

title: REPUBLIC SAVINGS & LOAN-WISONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $89,000. Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company converted from mutual to stock ownership in August 1986.

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Tax Dispute In Florida
description: Lawmakers trickled back to the Capitol today to try again to resolve a dispute over a new services tax, as one legislator filed suit contending the Governor is holding the Legislature hostage and has exceeded his authority.

title: National Bone Marrow Registry is Seeking Donors
description: Eight years after a Colorado girl received the first transplant of bone marrow from an unrelated donor, the first nationwide computer network for such transplants has been established at the University of Minnesota.

title: Restructuring Bid for Pan Am
description: The Towers Financial Corporation, a small financial services company, said yesterday that it was seeking the support of John Lehman, the former Secretary of the Navy, to lead a restructuring effort of Pan American World Airways Inc.

title: Magazine Conference Under Way in California
description: The annual American Magazine Conference started yesterday in Palm Desert, Calif., amid the first rain since June.

title: Steve Allen Goes National With a New Radio Show
description: More than 22 television programs, 28 books, 4,000 songs and miles of one-liners later, Steve Allen has returned to radio, the medium in which he began his colorful career.

title: Rebellious Space Monkey Lands Off Course
description: A Soviet experiment in space that featured a rebellious monkey ended this morning when the descent module landed in the city of Mirny in the Siberian region of Yakutia, far from the planned landing site, the Soviet news agency Tass reported.

title: Ohrenstein Indictment Should Be Catalyst to Reform in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatrist Is Cleared in Ethics Case
description: A MARYLAND psychiatrist did not commit a ''legal violation or ethical impropriety'' when he appeared on a television program and advised patients not to take prescribed drugs under certain conditions, the Maryland Commission on Medical Discipline has ruled.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Whither Ziegler?
description: In the where-are-they-now department, Ron Ziegler, the White House press secretary in the Nixon Administration, is leaving his post as president of the National Association of Truck Stop Operators, having been chosen chairman of the board of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

title: Bo Jackson to Report
description: Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy-winning running back from Auburn, who chose baseball as his profession after leaving college, is scheduled to report on Thursday to the Los Angeles Raiders' training camp amid conflicting reports of what his future with the team will be. Jackson, who batted .235 with 22 home runs and 53 runs batted in during his first major league baseball season with the Kansas City Royals, decided last summer to give pro football a try as a ''hobby.''

title: United Press Agrees to Transmit News Releases for the U.S.
description: United Press International, the financially troubled news service, has concluded a $2.5 million contract with the Reagan Administration to transmit Government press releases to news organizations in six European cities.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a one-time charge of $40,985,000 for the acquisition of Monolithic Memories Inc. c-After an extraordinary charge of $19,934,000. The 1987 third quarter results include operations of Monolithic Memories, which was acquired Aug. 13.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $2,000 for the quarter and $772,000 for the 9 months for early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes a one-time $1.08 million after-tax adjustment in the loan-loss reserve of a subsidiary.

title: GLAXO HOLDINGS PLC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The results are in U.S. currency. The exchange rate used for conversion is $1.61 to the pound sterling, which was the rate prevailing at June 30. The share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts and each ADR represents one ordinary share. The sales in both years have been adjusted to exclude sales of companies which are not now part of Glaxo. s

title: WESTINGHOUSE CREDIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gov. Casey Out of Hospital
description: Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania went home from the hospital today, 11 days after undergoing quadruple-bypass surgery. Mr. Casey, 55 years old, had a five-hour operation Oct. 1 at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center to bypass blockages in arteries leading to his heart. Doctors said Mr. Casey would probably return to work full time in about six weeks.

title: When Democrats Had Real Flavor
description: Nearly 42 years ago, we were fresh from the Good War, some with combat experience. There were real jobs to be had, and for many of us 1948 was our first Presidential election.

title: For New U.N. Envoys, Work Is a Way of Life
description: At 7:30 A.M., Gopala Menon of Singapore starts his three-mile jog on the East Side; an hour later, Stefan Noreen hurries to his office to phone Stockholm. By 10 A.M., Grethel Vargas of Nicaragua is lobbying among her colleagues on the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
description: b-Includes a writedown of $1.3 million on surplus inventory and a charge of $700,000 for plant consolidation. c-Net loss

title: PLAYERS OFFER TO RETURN IF TALKS GO TO MEDIATION
description: The striking National Football League players tonight offered to return to work for the rest of the season if the owners would agree to negotiate with a mediator for six weeks, and then submit issues still unresolved to binding arbitration.

title: Sierra Pacific In Timberland Deal
description: Sierra Pacific Industries has agreed to buy 520,000 acres of timberland in Northern California owned by the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, the companies said. The price was not disclosed.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes costs of $1.1 million related to its Corvet application generator project. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for the effect of a 5-for-4 stock split in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend paid July 20, 1987.

title: Puzzling 'Boomerang'
description: The boomerang seems as Australian as ''Waltzing Matilda,'' but the oldest specimen may have come from a far distant part of the world -Poland. Scientists there have found a 23,000-year-old piece of curved mammoth tusk that some ancient artisan carved and polished into the aerodynamic shape of a boomerang.

title: Rothschild Bank
description: Baron Edmond de Rothschild's private Swiss bank, founded in 1924, made its first public issue of shares today. Banque Privee Edmond de Rothschild S.A. has been privately held since it was founded. The baron is a member of the French branch of the famous banking family and has led the bank since 1985. The bank issued 10,000 new bearer shares to the public at a price of 5,250 Swiss francs, or $3,494, each, in addition to which the existing shareholders will provide another 6,000 shares from their private holdings. With the total number of shares now at 90,000, the issue valued the bank at 472.5 million francs, or about $314.4 million.

title: Nets Drop 5
description: The Nets trimmed their roster to 16 players yesterday (not counting unsigned free agents Ray Williams and Albert King) by releasing five rookies from their training camp at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium. They dropped Andrew Moten, a guard from Florida; Perry Bromwell, a guard from Pennsylvania; Frank Booker, a guard from Bowling Green; Cleveland Bibbons, a forward from Southern Illinois State, and Greg Stevens, a center from Akron.

title: TIGER PROWLS NO MORE
description: HAT pulled down so low on his face he might be attending a stickup, face unshaved and so grizzled he could be walking the last mile, a toothy sneer so ill-boding it seems ready to chomp on the first inadvertent finger that comes its way, Kirk Harold Gibson thusly goes about his employment as a left fielder and slugger for the Detroit Tigers.

title: Coke Invests In a Film Deal
description: A group of five entertainment industry veterans, including Rob Reiner, the producer, said today that they had founded a new film venture called Castle Rock Entertainment that will receive $30 million in start-up money from the Coca-Cola Company, which will become a 40 percent shareholder in the new company.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1986 results have been restated to include the June 30, 1987 Bank of Banks County merger and the Citizens Bank of Toccoa merger of Dec. 30, 1986.

title: Patterns Out of the Randomness
description: STRUGGLING to understand the organized rolling currents that take shape in the atmosphere or in a pan of boiling water, two scientists in Brussels have managed to recreate them in a much simpler system - a computer model of 5,000 bouncing disks.

title: Williams Is Selling Realty Unit
description: The Williams Companies said today that it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its real estate unit, the Williams Realty Corporation, to the Trammell Crow Company in Dallas for $440 million.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Guaranteed: the Cost of College
description: Little Roxanne, just 14 months old, already shows signs of genius in the delightful way she hums along with Big Bird. You're determined to give her a shot at Harvard when she turns 18, but it's also clear that Government will be in no position to subsidize her tuition with grants or guaranteed loans. What to do?

title: Japan's Free-Trade Charade
description: The Toshiba Machine Company gave new meaning to the term ''free trade'' when it was disclosed that it had shipped sophisticated submarine propeller parts illegally to the Soviet Union.

title: SUDBURY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $963,000.

title: 4 OPEC Nations Vow To Stabilize Oil Price
description: Eighteen months after the collapse of oil prices shook the American oil and banking industries, landed a few third world countries in default and upset the world's economy, Saudi Arabia and three other OPEC nations say they will strive to hold prices at the current level of $18 a barrel.

title: Washington Talk: The Military; Now Hear This: Navy Gets Memorial
description: In this city of monuments and memorials, the Army has Pershing Square on Pennsylvania Avenue, the Marine Corps has the Iwo Jima statue just north of Arlington Memorial Cemetery across the Potomac, and the Air Force dominates much of the National Air and Space Museum. The Navy has never enjoyed a comparable place of institutional honor in the capital. But one day after the day of tribute to the hemisphere's first and foremost maritime hero, Christopher Columbus, that oversight will be remedied.

title: 'Human Smoke Detectors' a Fixture at A-Plant Near Boston
description: Donna Vohnoutka passes her hours at the Pilgrim nuclear power plant fighting the boredom that comes with the job of staring into space to see if a fire will erupt.

title: N.L. Playoffs; All Eyes on Cardinals' Injuries
description: The St. Louis Cardinals were injured, but the San Francisco Giants were wary as the National League playoff switched back to Missouri today with the Giants needing one more victory to win the pennant.

title: Brazilian Chief of Staff Dies After Parachute Fails to Open
description: Gen. Fernando Pamplona, the Brazilian Army Chief of Staff, died Sunday when he jumped from a plane and his parachute failed to open, the army said today. He was 64 years old.

title: Salvador Refugees Win Test of Wills
description: When her husband disappeared while working his tiny plot seven years ago, Victoria Mendez fled to Honduras, one of thousands of refugees seeking shelter from the violence ravaging this country.

title: Better Business Bureaus In a Staff Appointment
description: Mary-Jane Raphael, a vice president, communications and administration, at ABC-TV, is joining the Council of Better Business Bureaus as a senior vice president in charge of the National Advertising Division. She is replacing Lorraine C. Reid, who will take early retirement in December.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 4
description: b-After a charge from the reversal of a tax credit of $400,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1.8 million and the cumulative effect on prior years (to Dec. 28, 1986) of a change in method of accounting for certain manufacturing costs of $14.2 million for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $1.8 million for the quarter and $8.7 million for the 9 months. Net income figures also reflect the cumulative effect of a change in accounting methods. The company said that prior results have been restated to give effect to the acquisition of Hazleton Laboratories during the second quarter of 1987 in a pooling-of-interest transaction.

title: Vote to End Pacific Islands' Atom-Arms Ban Is Challenged
description: A legal and political battle is shaping up here and in Washington over whether residents of a tiny Pacific island group are being forced, through intimidation and the lure of economic aid, to accept an American military base and nuclear weapons.

title: Radiation Accident in Brazil Stirs Misgivings Over Nuclear Program
