description: Brazilian scientists have questioned the Government's ability to manage an independent nuclear energy program after what they described as an inadequate response by the authorities to an accident two weeks ago involving highly radioactive material.

title: Candidate's Views on Warhead and Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Reported In VW Talks
description: The Ford Motor Company is negotiating to buy a 16 percent stake in Volkswagenwerk A.G. from the West German Government, according to a West German car magazine.

title: Dance: Graham's 'Rite'
description: AMID Martha Graham's allegories for our time, ''The Rite of Spring'' stands out by its expression of cruelty. Her treatment of Stravinsky's well-known score is distinct from other versions, which look decorative and even likable in comparison.

title: Restoring a Theater to Its Decrepit State
description: Paint crumbles from walls. Fragments of friezes are chipped and mottled. Ducts are exposed. Decades of dirt encrust the proscenium. A rare plaster disease invades the ceiling.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company said it invested $6 million on new product development in the latest third quarter, compared with $2.7 million a year ago.

title: Security Pacific In Denial on Talks
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, seeking to dispel rumors, denied yesterday that it was in merger talks with Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., the big London-based investment bank. Over the weekend, London newspapers reported that Security Pacific was negotiating to merge its Hoare Govett stock brokerage operation with Morgan Grenfell.

title: PHONE-O-GRAM SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that for the year ended June 30, 1987, it reported a net loss of $4,155,000, which included a $3,795,000 charge related to writedown of assets; revenue for fiscal 1987 was $5,785,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
description: Companies

title: As Mars Beckons, U.S. Is Wary and Indecisive
description: IN the next decade or two Mars will be explored again - by the Soviet Union at least, probably with the cooperation of Europeans. But what role will the United States play?

title: Music: Pittsburgh Opera
description: The Pittsburgh Opera, which had long shared Heinz Hall with the city's orchestra, moved this season into a grand old variety theater and cinema, the former Stanley Theater. Renamed the Benedum Center and remodeled to accommodate somewhat fewer than its original 3,000 seats, it is a house for big opera; its first, Saturday night, was Puccini's ''Turandot,'' appropriately chosen.

title: Glaxo Profit Up, Stock Off
description: Britain's Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., one of the world's biggest drug companies, today reported a 22 percent jump in its annual pretax profits to $:746 million, or $1.23 billion, but that was well below analysts' expectations.

title: Our Towns; Dropping Names: Corporate Drill For '80s Success
description: American corporations hire Jon Keith to help their executives improve their name-dropping skills. ''The No. 1 corporate problem in America,'' Mr. Keith told 20 Lederle Lab employees yesterday, ''is names and faces!'' They looked suspicious. They thought it was the Japanese.

title: Utah Battles With Harvard In Bid to Obtain Indian Relics
description: Nearly 60 years ago, an archeologist unearthed thousands of Indian artifacts in Utah and gave them to a Harvard University museum. Now Utah wants the artifacts returned.

title: Charles E. Ballard, 73, Dies; Wrote Book After Killing Wife
description: Charles E. (Chad) Ballard, who was sentenced by a Indiana court to write a book after he accidentally killed his wife in 1982, died on Friday. He was 73 years old.

title: Salomon to Dismiss 12% of Staff And End Its Municipal Bond Role
description: In a retrenchment expected to be followed by other leading Wall Street firms, Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 12 percent of its work force, close its municipal bond department and re-examine its space needs in New York City and around the world.

title: Goodbye to Plain Vanilla
description: WHOEVER decided to make computers beige ought to be condemned to eat nothing but raw bean curd for the rest of his or her life.

title: Arab Dies as Anti-Israel Protests Widen
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a 35-year-old Palestinian woman today while putting down a demonstration in the West Bank town of Ramallah by hundreds of youths waving Palestinian flags and portraits of Yasir Arafat.

title: No Way Out
description: In Washington one enchanted evening, a handsome young American Navy officer spots this beautiful young woman. They eye each other hotly and soon exit to her limousine, where they proceed to tear each other's clothes off in the back seat. An excellent time is had by both. Afterwards, as they say, he asks her name.

title: EMPLOYERS PLAN SMALLER RAISES
description: Despite rising profits and lower joblessness, employers intend to give lower raises next year, according to a survey of companies with labor contracts expiring in 1988.

title: Wendy's Buffet
description: Wendy's International Inc. said it plans to invest $35 million to expand its Superbar program, a new all-you-can-eat hot and cold food buffet. Robert L. Barney, chairman and chief executive, said that incremental sales gains averaging 15 percent in Superbar company stores had encourgaed Wendy's to expand the test program. Mr. Barney said Superbar, now offered in about 380 company and franchised Wendy's outlets in 57 test markets, would be added to almost all of Wendy's 1,120 company stores.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FOUND IN THE STREET. By Patricia Highsmith. 277 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: Vietnam Could Supply Agent Orange Subjects
description: To the Editor: The Congressional Office of Technology Assessment has concluded that too few American ground troops in the Vietnam War were exposed to Agent Orange to form a data base to determine if the defoliant caused physiological harm (news story, Sept. 30).

title: Metzenbaum Is Taken Ill
description: Senator Howard Metzenbaum, Dempocrat of Ohio, was taken to Toledo Hospital today after complaining of dizziness, and doctors ran tests to determine the cause of his flu-like symptoms. Mr. Metzenbaum, 70 years old, became ill while eating breakfast at the University of Toledo with the school's president, James McComas, and was treated by a physician at the university before going to the hospital. He was released a short time later and said, ''I feel great.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
description: International A3-19

title: ARRAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: N.B.A. Owners Say They Want a Deal
description: The owners of the 27 teams in the National Basketball Association instructed their labor-negotiation committee today to intensify efforts to reach a new agreement with the players' union.

title: Amid Inquiries, Albany Changes Job Practices
description: Amid indictments and investigations, the New York State Legislature has changed longstanding employment practices that encouraged payroll padding and blurred responsibility for hiring decisions.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Leslie Journal; A Town Where Anyone Can Cut It
description: The old man in overalls sat down in front of Ellie's Flea Market, pulled a stick of wood from a bunch sticking out of a bucket, took a knife from his pocket and quietly began cutting, drawing the sharp blade along the grain and curling up long spirals of shavings.

title: Taylor to Go Back to Giants
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro outside linebacker, will abandon the strike by National Football League players and report to the team Wednesday, a source close to Taylor said today.

title: On the Corner: Reign of Crack and Violence
description: For as long as most people here can remember, the intersection of Albany Avenue and Great Neck Road has been a neighborhood hangout and, all too often, a gathering place for trouble.

title: Cannon Kills 5 in Spain
description: A cannon misfired today during the re-enactment of a 15th-century battle between Christians and Moors and five people were killed and 33 wounded. The blast in this Mediterranean coastal town occurred when a spark from the cannon detonated 66 pounds of gunpowder in a nearby box, officials said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques 5, Canadiens 2: In Montreal, Michel Goulet scored three goals and added an assist last night to lead a five-goal third-period rally for Quebec. Goulet, whose six goals tie him with Washington's Mike Gartner for the league lead, broke a 2-2 tie with 5 minutes 44 seconds to play with a shot from the slot that beat the goaltender, Patrick Roy. (AP) Red Wings 3, Canucks 2: In Vancouver, Greg Stefan provided outstanding goaltending and Gerard Gallant scored twice for Detroit. Stefan, coming off a 4-1 victory last Friday at Edmonton against the Oilers, stopped 24 Canuck shots. (AP) Horse Racing Lead Kindly Light Wins: Lead Kindly Light outdueled Barbara's Moment to win the $95,700 Athenia Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park after the two favorites were scratched in a move that frustrated many bettors. Tom Skiffington, the trainer, had entered a three-ply entry including Anka Germania, the strong pre-race favorite and topweight at 119, and Slew's Exceller, the second top weight at 116. In mid-afternoon, however, Skiffington scratched both of those horses, leaving bettors who had wagered on the entry in advance bets such as the Pick-Six stuck with the weakest part of the entry, Jacky Max, who finished last. Lead Kindly Light, a 4-year-old daughter of Majestic Light and Arabian Dancer, took the lead early and held off Barbara's Moment by a neck while slogging through 11 furlongs on a very soft turf course in 2:23 4/5. Tennis Davis Gains in Australia: Fifth-seeded Scott Davis of the United States overcame John Fitzgerald of Australia, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the Australian Indoor in Sydney. The 26-year-old American was outplayed in the first set and trailed, 0-2, in the second before recovering to outlast the Australian Davis Cup player. (AP) Cross-Country Columbia Triumphs: Columbia University, led by the first-place performance of Fred Ernst, who covered the 5-mile course in 24 minutes 44 seconds, won the team title in the 61st annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association championship with 73 points yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The victory was the Lions' first since 1927. Ernst, a 5-10, 150-pound senior from Kansas City, Mo., finished 55 yards ahead of Richie Grandquist of Rutgers, who crossed in 24:56. Janine Radice of Fordham won the women's 5,000-meter race in a meet record 18:15 and the Rams took team honors.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,735,000 for the quarter and $2,606,000 for the year.

title: Telex Reviewing Edelman Offer
description: Officials of the Telex Corporation said they would complete a review of an unsolicited $872 million buyout offer from Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, by Oct. 23 and asked shareholders not to tender their stock until then.

title: DIGITEXT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Year-ago revenue restated to reflect the current method of accounting.

title: Peru Reports Killing 30 Rebels in Daylong Clash
description: Police killed more than 30 Communist guerrillas and cocaine traffickers in a daylong clash in Peru's coca leaf-growing jungle region, the Interior Ministry said today.

title: SENATORS OPPOSED TO NEW ARMS PACT RAISE ABM CHARGE
description: Some conservative Republican senators are pressing the Reagan Administration to charge Moscow with a new arms-control violation, the opening salvo in their campaign to block approval of an emerging agreement to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: Twins Batter Tigers and Capture the Pennant
description: Even as the Minnesota Twins celebrated today, the players who happily doused themselves with champagne could not forget the sad times. Many of them had been together through the difficult years of the decade, learning as they lost and hoping that the losing would come to an end.

title: VALCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a recapitalization of the company.

title: City of Future Splits Over Homeless
description: A proposal to convert an unused building at the city animal shelter to house the homeless has upset many people here in Orange County's city of the future.

title: Detroit Tour Canceled
description: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra has canceled its performance next Tuesday at Carnegie Hall as well as its East Coast tour. The Detroit orchestra's musicians have been on strike since shortly after the beginning of the season.

title: Pact With G.M. Backed By Auto Union Council
description: The tentative agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers took an important step toward ratification today as it was overwhelmingly approved by the union's 300-member G.M. Council.

title: Dance: At Grand Central
description: THE second of the ''Grand Central Dances'' programs inside Grand Central Terminal took place Saturday night under the auspices of Dancing in the Streets, in cooperation with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Its finale was virtuoso juggling by Michael Moschen, who at various times juggled white balls, a tray, a glass, a shiny bar and flaming torches.

title: Hill & Knowlton Names President in the Pacific
description: Arnold A. Tucker has been named president and chief executive of the newly formed Hill & Knowlton Asia Pacific region, which resulted from the merging of the Australasia unit, with nine offices in Australia and New Zealand, and the Asia region, with its six offices.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Agency Is Small, But Not Shy
description: SAY this for Burkhardt & Christy Advertising: You give them an inch, and they will end up with a yard.

title: Pollster Finds Hope and Confidence
description: FALSE predictions and wrong notions about what the American people want have led to major distortions in education policies. In his new book, ''Inside America,'' Louis Harris, the public opinion analyst, describes his findings about what Americans really expect from their educational institutions.

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Publishing: Plans For Myerson Book
description: Newmarket Press has scheduled a first printing of 35,000 copies and a 14-city tour for the author, but otherwise its plans for a book it is to publish on Nov. 9 are somewhat unsettled. The book is ''Miss America, 1945 - Bess Myerson's Own Story,'' by Susan Dworkin, and Miss Myerson was recently indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that include conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Miss Myerson has denied the charges.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $651,200,000 from the sale of Group W Cable and a pretax provision of $790,000,000 for loss to cover the costs of a restructuring program.

title: Players; Giants' Shortstop Finding His Identity
description: HIS question was one of identity, not opportunity. Jose Gonzalez was a young shortstop in the farm system of the St. Louis Cardinals, looking up at a team with the shortstop considered the best in the major leagues. His friends would tell him about his limited chances of advancing in an organization that had Ozzie Smith, but the young shortstop did not seem to mind.

title: Westinghouse Profit Up 8.7%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 8.7 percent, to $184.1 million, or $1.28 a share, from $169.3 million, or $1.11 a share, a year before. Sales totaled $2.59 billion, up less than 1 percent from $2.57 billion.

title: Tax Plan Roils Germany
description: West Germany's financial markets could suffer a huge flight of capital if Bonn goes ahead with a plan to impose a new 10 percent withholding tax on interest earnings in 1989, analysts said today.

title: Kemp Buys Time on TV for Ad Pushing Bork for High Court
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp has purchased time beginning Monday night for an advertisement supporting the nomination of Judge Robert Bork. It is the first nationwide television commercial of the 1988 campaign.

title: For South African Actors, New York Is a Wonder
description: The dichotomy is striking.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This may be a minimal hurricane but no hurricane is a minimal event.'' Mark Zimmerman,

title: ALF LANDON, G.O.P. STANDARD-BEARER, DIES AT 100
description: Alfred M. Landon, the former Governor of Kansas who gained lasting fame for his landslide defeat by Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1936 Presidential election, died at his home in Topeka yesterday, 34 days after his 100th birthday.

title: Family Says German Was Slain
description: The widow and brother of the West German politician Uwe Barschel, who was forced from office because of an election scandal, asserted today that he had been murdered after meeting a mysterious informer who promised help.

title: Even Citizens Can Need Immigration Counseling; Out of the Frying Pan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: Mirmdance In 'Set Free'
description: ''SET FREE,'' which was shown Sunday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, concerned forces of liberation and repression. Miriam Hertzson's choreography for this suite of dances - some of them new, the rest of them recent works - contained bright ideas, and Mirmdance, her company, never lacked energy.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fleeing Boy Is Shot By Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty housing police officer shot and wounded a fleeing 15-year-old boy yesterday after he grabbed chains from around her neck aboard a subway car, the police said.

title: PLAN FOR MEDICARE FORCES U.S. TO LIST APPROVED DOCTORS
description: The Administration is drafting a major proposal to use price incentives and lists of selected doctors to help control the volume of physician services provided to 31 million elderly and disabled people through the Medicare program.

title: Statue Showing Women as 'Evil' May Be Moved
description: It is not simply that she is a woman, said Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President. It is that she does not like to see any group insulted, and in this case the group happens to be women.

title: People
description: * William C. Thompson Jr. was named executive vice president, multinational accounts and business development, at the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: Rangers Spoil Brooks's Visit
description: One spoke of patience, the other of perfection, but each found significance in the third game of a new season with teams they are still getting to know. The former Ranger coach, Herb Brooks, walked off with a grimace, and the new Ranger coach, Michel Bergeron, happily punched at the air after his team defeated the visiting North Stars, 4-2, and kept the Ranger record unblemished at 2-0-1.

title: Tom Wolfe Tries New Role: Novelist
description: ''It's outrageous the way people conduct their lives in New York,'' Tom Wolfe said. ''And yet I don't want to live anywhere else. I don't despair, because I find the comedy so rich. At the same time that people do vile things, they also create hilariously funny spectacles. The city dominates you if you're a player, but it never fails you if you're a viewer. It's always entertaining, and it's always funny, even in its grimmest moments.''

title: Tax Watch; A 'User Fee': What's That?
description: WHEN is a ''revenue increase'' not a ''tax increase?'' That is the multibillion-dollar question that has sparked a heated debate in recent weeks between the Reagan Administration and Congress.

title: DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $163,000 for the quarter and $301,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: COMMUNITY BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Cutbacks Anger Spaceplane Designer
description: The designer of a proposed hypersonic spaceplane said today he would take his invention abroad if British companies and the British Government did not provide additional financing for the project. He said he made the decision because Britain had decided against increasing payments to the European Space Agency.

title: GORBACHEV'S MESSAGES
description: Western experts on East-West affairs who gathered here to discuss ''the implications of Soviet new thinking'' showed consensus on what Mikhail Gorbachev is trying to do. The debate is moving on now to what the U.S. and the West in general should do about it.

title: Bergesch Out, Cook In
description: Bill Bergesch, a former Yankee general manager, was dismissed yesterday as general manager of the Cincinnati Reds after three years in the position. Murray Cook, also a former Yankee general manager, will replace him.

title: MSGR. MICHAEL FLEMING
description: Msgr. Michael J. Fleming, director of the Catholic Youth Organization in Whitestone, Queens, died of cancer Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Whitestone.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What has happened to the people who contracted polio in the 1950's who were confined to iron lungs?

title: Pitino Has a Change of Heart
description: Rick Pitino has undergone a dramatic change: He has decided he doesn't want to trade Bill Cartwright.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $17,135,000 and an extraordinary loss of $2,617,000.

title: TOTAL HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Fiscal-year results are for the 9 months the company was in operation and include $5,434,000 in non-recurring or non-cash expenses.

title: India Says It Airdropped Troops In Sri Lanka to Fight Tamil Rebels
description: India dropped airborne commandos into Sri Lanka's Jaffna Peninsula today, as intense battles continued day and night with a Tamil guerrilla army, according to an Indian diplomat here.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $42,100 for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes a nonrecurring inventory adjustment in the first quarter of $67,700.

title: Striking Starter Rejoins Jets
description: Joe Walton was cheerfully philosophic this afternoon as he discussed the Jets' 6-0 loss Sunday to the Indianapolis Colts. In fact, compared with his blue mood Sunday, Walton was practically gregarious.

title: CONSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Redford Announces Production Agreement
description: In an innovative attempt to broaden the outlets for non-mainstream films, Robert Redford will produce a series of low-budget, independent motion pictures to be financed and released directly by a theater chain, Cineplex Odeon.

title: Body of Jersey Woman Is Found; Suspect Charged
description: The body of a 25-year-old woman who disappeared in August from a shopping mall here was found today by two hunters, the authorities said.

title: Dole Ties New Hampshire Hopes to Iowa Strength
description: In a fourth-floor law office overlooking a street ablaze with autumn colors, Tom Rath, a former State Attorney General and a longtime Republican operative, busily fielded phone calls from Bob Dole's Presidential campaign organization in Washington.

title: NELLCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Police Seek Victims Of Man With AIDS
description: A man who has been charged with sodomizing a 16-year-old boy is believed to be dying of AIDS, and officials are trying to find any other victims so they can be tested for the disease.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Bork Chase
description: Judge Robert H. Bork, the embattled Supreme Court nominee, learned first hand last week the role of new technology in journalism. As he moved about Washington amid speculation that he would withdraw his nomination, his automobile was trailed by two motorcyles and a second car. On his way from the State Department to his office at the United States Court of Appeals, Judge Bork drove past the White House. In the driveway anticipating his arrival were scores of White House reporters who had been tipped that the judge was coming. How? Those in the chase vehicles carried equipment that enabled them to notify reporters at the White House of the judge's route. But the alert proved false as Mr. Bork's car rolled past 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue without stopping.

title: Town Is Stunned by Acquittal Of Teen-Ager in Killings of 4
description: Less than a week after four people were shot to death in their home here last winter, the case that Columbia County investigators were calling the crime of the century seemed all but closed.

title: Mubarak Urges Action in New Term
description: President Hosni Mubarak began his second six-year term in office today, facing the same array of seemingly intractable social and economic problems that haunted his first six years.

title: Police Shoot in Air To Disperse Strikers At Rally in Manila
description: The police fired in the air to disperse a strike rally today as thousands of workers began what militant unions called a week of protests for higher pay.

title: Why Some Katydids Don't Sing
description: Katydids in Panama have learned to dance to avoid being eaten by bats, researchers say.

title: A Concert of Favorites Of Jefferson the Violinist
description: Although he is best known as the author of the Declaration of Independence and as the third President of the United States, Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826) was a complex man of wide cultural interests, as much at home at an architectural drawing board as with a violin tucked under his chin.

title: Argentina's Woeful Services
description: The Argentines may disagree about many things, but there is one opinion almost all share: The quality of public services is wretched.

title: Congress May Agree to Pay for Repairs to Dam Not Owned by U.S.
description: Reagan Administration officials contend that Congress is on the verge of setting ''a tremendously bad precedent'' by paying to repair a dam not owned by the Federal Government.

title: HURRICAN HITS SOUTH FLORIDA: DAMAGE MINOR
description: A storm that just barely qualified as a hurricane struck the Florida Keys today, causing only minor damage and flooding. With winds gusting to 80 miles per hour, the late-season hurricane passed directly over Key West and several other islands in the 100-mile-long chain.

title: Long-Running Debate on AIDS: How Well Did Americans Respond?
description: Was the nation's initial response to the AIDS epidemic a remarkable triumph of modern science? Or was it a failure to mobilize against a disease that has primarily ravaged outcast groups like male homosexuals and intravenous drug users?

title: Nuggets Lose Moore
description: Andre Moore, the 6-foot-8-inch forward from Loyola of Chicago who was the first player selected by the Denver Nuggets in the draft, will not play this season in Denver because the Nuggets will not give him a guaranteed contract on entering training camp, but insist that to win one he must make the opening-day roster. George Andrews, Moore's agent, said his client would probably sign with a European team. . . . Ronnie Murphy and Nikita Wilson, Portland's first and second-round draft picks, signed with the Trail Blazers yesterday as did Charles Jones, a free agent.

title: Area Stores In Sales Gains
description: New York's largest department and specialty stores had an average 8.6 percent gain in sales in the city in September over the same month a year ago, a spot-check indicated yesterday. For the metropolitan area, which includes the suburbs, the average increase in sales was 9.5 percent.

title: Chemical Will Drop 170 in London
description: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 170 people in London, or 18 percent of its British work force.

title: Music: China Orchestra
description: YEARS sacrificed to one's art have their own sense of fulfillment, but years pointlessly lost from it are especially poignant.

title: Imperial Makes Bid For Holly
description: Takeover efforts swirling around the Holly Sugar Corporation intensified today when the Imperial Sugar Company offered to buy its larger rival in a deal valued as high as $108 million, topping a $102 million bid made last week by an investor group.

title: Union Urges Strikers To Reject NBC Offer
description: Striking NBC employees are being urged by their negotiating committee to reject a proposal that would end their 16-week walkout.

title: Holiday Trading Dull; Prices Mixed Overseas
description: Credit market activity was subdued yesterday because the New York cash market for Treasury securities was closed for the Columbus Day holiday.

title: AMERICAN ECOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
High Tide for Conservatives, But Some Fear What Follows
description: The American conservative movement, which by many measures is more powerful than it has ever been, is going through a season of frustration, division and discontent.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
Opera: 'Rake's Progress'
description: FOR the opera ''Rake's Progress,'' Stravinsky transformed Hogarth's engravings of a downwardly mobile young gentleman into tragic Faustian drama. The New York City Opera's production, revived Sunday evening in its first performance of the season, employed the vivid David Hockney sets first seen here three years ago, which are drawn in crosshatching to evoke the quality of the etchings and which, in their flattened-out, stylized way, perfectly evoke the chilly tone of Stravinsky's brilliant Neo-Classical score and of W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman's elegant libretto.

title: Careers; Engineers Get Broad Curriculum
description: THE Massachusetts Institute of Technology is overhauling its curriculum to give the humanities greater emphasis and to integrate engineering education more fully with science, manufacturing technology and economic, political, social and environmental factors.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Final Chapter

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GLATFELTER, P H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
M.V.P. Vote Makes Gaetti Late for Fun
description: When Gary Gaetti finally returned to the Minnesota Twins' clubhouse, he walked over to Tom Brunansky and handed him the golden bowl on a wooden base, the Most Valuable Player award for the American League Championship Series. ''You deserve it,'' Gaetti said. Shaking his head, Brunansky said, ''It's a team, man.'' Then, the right fielder, who had batted .412 with nine runs batted in and two homers, poured champagne into the bowl. Gaetti, the third baseman who had a .300 average with five runs batted in and two homers, lifted the bowl and drank some champagne. He handed it to Brunansky, who drank from it. They hugged each other, then Gaetti, the bowl under his left arm, moved to his locker.

title: Los Angeles Panic: Quake Is Predicted And Hundreds Flee
description: A foreboding sky and a psychic's prediction of a disastrous earthquake today sent a wave of panic through the downtown jewelry district, where gem operators closed booths and fled the city.

title: DOMAIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $241,000 for the latest first quarter and $354,000 for the year-ago period. Domain Technology, which went public Aug. 14, adopted a June 30 fiscal year, effective this reporting period.

title: Tax Breakdown for Mass Transit
description: The future of urban economies and air quality may depend on limiting the growth of automobile traffic into downtown areas. Yet Federal tax policy now hampers official efforts to lure commuters out of cars and into mass transit.

title: RESIDENTIAL MORTGAGE INESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago cumulative period, for which it reported net of $1,127,597, or 27 cents a share, consists of the period from April 1986, when it began operations, through September 1986.

title: Maxwell Plans Europe Paper
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, announced plans today to establish an English-language daily newspaper that would be the ''voice of Europe to the English-speaking world.''

title: Oil Rig Tally Dips by 23
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell to 1,104 last week, down 23 from a week before, Baker Hughes said today. A year ago the total was 814. It is expected to top 1,200 by December.

title: Other Wall St. Layoffs Seen
description: After making millions by helping bloated industrial giants to bolster profits through restructurings and cost-cutting moves, Wall Street's largest firms are being forced to heed their own advice.

title: 'One of Those Creatures of 200 Million Years Ago Come Alive'
description: To the Editor:

title: CERTAINTEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax non-recurring charge of $6.4 million in connection with a reserve for closing two plants.

title: Reagan Maintains He Is Still Unaware Of Iran Profits' Use
description: Despite voluminous testimony during the Iran-contra hearings last summer about how millions of dollars were raised and distributed, President Reagan has told an interviewer that he still does not know what happened to the profits from the arms sales to Iran.

title: House Democrats Seek Home Deduction Limit
description: Completing work on a bill to raise $12 billion in new taxes, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee proposed tonight to put a cap on the mortgage deduction that individuals can claim for their first and second homes. The deduction would be available only for the first $1 million in mortgage debt.

title: INSIDE
description: Recalling the Missile Crisis

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New England Apple
description: New England Apple Products of Littleton, Mass., has assigned Veryfine Juices to Chiat/Day, New York. There is a $5 million budget to promote its juices, drinks and applesauces. The company's former agency was Harold Cabot Advertising, Boston.

title: Coley Worth, 79, Dies; Actor and a Comedian
description: Coley Worth, an actor, singer, comedian and dancer in theater and television, died of pneumonia last Friday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Port St. Lucie.

title: NETWORK EQUIPMENT TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,526,000 and $2,596,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $374,000 and $545,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Senate Confirms Verity For Commerce Post
description: The Senate confirmed C. William Verity Jr. as Secretary of Commerce today but only after shutting off a threatened filibuster by a handful of conservative Republicans who oppose his support of expanded trade with the Soviet Union.

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a credit from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle of $2,887,000.

title: Seabrook Utility Has New Woes
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire moved a step closer to bankruptcy yesterday when its board voted to skip a $37.5 million interest payment due tomorrow.

title: The Sporting Class
description: At a football game decades ago, I was seated between retired Chief Justice Earl Warren and national security adviser Henry Kissinger. A Washington Redskins cornerback made a great play preventing a Dallas touchdown but was called for pass interference.

title: New Movies Battle for Theaters
description: Dozens of movies are trying to elbow their way into theaters this fall, and the jostling means both peril and opportunity for the film industry.

title: Now the Good News on Declining S.A.T. Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns Drop Gondrezick
description: The Phoenix Suns released three players yesterday, including Grant Gondrezick, who averaged 5.5 points a game as a rookie last season and was one of three players indicted last spring in a drug scandal. The 6-5 guard pleaded guilty to a witness-tampering charge and was sentenced to three years' probation. The other players dropped were Bruce Dalyrmple, a 6-4 rookie guard from Georgia Tech, and Steve Beck, a 6-3 rookie guard from Arizona State. . . . Kenny Gattison, the Suns' 6-8 reserve power forward who averaged 5.2 points and 3.5 rebounds as a rookie, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee and will be lost for the season. He injured the knee in a controlled scrimmage Monday night.

title: Law Upheld On Disclosure By Landlords
description: New York State's highest court yesterday upheld a New York City law requiring the owners of the city's most valuable residential and commercial buildings to file annual statements of their property's income and expenses.

title: Meeting Sheds New Light on Cuban Missile Crisis
description: Nikita S. Khrushchev installed missile sites in Cuba 25 years ago, unleashing what came to be called the Cuban missile crisis, apparently without deep consideration of what the American reaction to the move would be, a former Khrushchev aide says.

title: Clippers Sign Wolf
description: The Los Angeles Clippers have signed two of the three first-round selections they made in the National Basketball Association college draft last June. The Clippers are still negotiating with their first choice, Reggie Williams, the 6-foot-7-inch Georgetown swingman, but yesterday they reached an agreement on a three-year contract with Joe Wolf, a 6-11 forward from North Carolina. Over the weekend they signed Ken Norman, a 6-8 forward from Illinois.

title: At Luce Memorial Service, Love and Candor
description: In a ceremony marked by the candor she would have loved, Clare Boothe Luce, the playwright, politician and former Ambassador to Italy, was memorialized yesterday at a high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Merrill Profit Beats Forecasts
description: Merrill Lynch & Company bucked the trend of harder times on Wall Street and turned in slightly improved third-quarter results yesterday.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Music: The Winans, Gospel
description: IT is commonly and falsely assumed that the black gospel music out of which emerged secular ''soul'' in the early 1960's has languished as a revered period genre. But as the popular Detroit gospel group the Winans demonstrated at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, there is as much vitality, talent and contemporaneity in today's black church music as in the secular sphere.

title: photo of Edward Miller (Robert Chase)BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: ADVANCES; Machine Tool Research Has A New Ally
description: IT began in 1981 as an investigation sponsored by a worried Defense Department into whether the decline in the nation's machine tool industry had become a security threat. Along the way, the study bared broader fears among companies about the future of manufacturing technology in the United States. and led to the creation this year of the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences at Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: A Wary Start for Chess Title Match
description: The world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, the fourth in a row between the titleholder, 24-year-old Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, 36-year-old Anatoly Karpov, started on a note of caution Monday.

title: FIRST WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GEODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Union Is Rebuffed On Arbitration Bid
description: The National Football League owners and striking players exchanged proposals yesterday in an attempt to bring the striking players back to work. They agreed on several points, including the use of mediation, but disagreed on several others, including the use of binding arbitration.

title: Defense Asks, 'Where's Beef?' In Zaccaro Trial
description: The trial of John A. Zaccaro went to the jury yesterday after the defense charged that the state's case was so lacking in evidence as to be shameful.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: McNeil Angered By Slow Progress
description: Freeman McNeil stopped short of saying that he would become the next Jet to cross the picket line, but the veteran running back said that unless his striking teammates arrived at a solution that would salvage the 1987 football season, he might take matters into his own hands.

title: CLAYTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wright Says Award for Arias Dooms Aid for Contras
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said today that the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica today insured that Congress would not approve the Reagan Administration's request for new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Tyson Managers Block Promoter's Jabs
description: Butch Lewis, who promotes Michael Spinks, and Bill Cayton and Jim Jacobs, who are the co-managers of Mike Tyson, are battling for the hearts and minds of boxing fans.

title: SUNTRUST BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TIME WITH CHILDREN. By Elizabeth Tallent. 158 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Howard Beach Prosecution Expects 'Hostile' Witnesses
description: The chief prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder trial said yesterday that he expected that a number of witnesses he would call today would be ''hostile.''

title: Bridge: Canada and Taiwan Lead In Bermuda Bowl Contest
description: The world team championships continued here today with Canada and Taiwan heading a closely bunched field in the qualifying stage of the open series and Italy maintaining a lead in the women's series.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents gross income Sales for the latest periods totaled $8,434,000,000 for the third quarter and $23,444,000,000 for the 9 months, compared with $7,726,000,000 for the year- ago quarter and $22,015,000,000 for the 9 months. I.B.M. said an $80 million gain from the August sale of 5.9 million shares it held in Intel Corp., was reflected in its latest third quarter net earnings.

title: In Mah's Kitchen in Queens, the Cantonese Food Was Genuine
description: EVEN now, years after I moved out of my parents' house in Queens, my mother's greeting to me over the telephone is not ''Hello, how are you?'' but ''Heeka fan may?'' -''Have you eaten rice yet?''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Old, Exotic, Odd

title: Reagan Visit a Boost to Jersey G.O.P.
description: New Jersey Republican leaders said President Reagan's four-hour visit to the state today gave them just what they needed as they point toward the Nov. 3 state legislative elections with control of both houses at stake.

title: SEALRIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that year-ago third quarter earnings were reduced by a $2.8 million writeoff related to a bankruptcy of a major customer.

title: Tandem Agrees To Acquire Atalla
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Atalla Corporation, a privately held company that make transaction systems for financial concerns and retailers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Atalla, of San Jose, Calif., will operate as a subsidiary of Tandem, a manufacturer based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: 5 Shot to Death in Car Shop
description: Two gunmen burst into an auto body shop and opened fire tonight, killing five men and wounding a sixth, the police said. Two men were later taken into custody for questioning in the shootings, said Police Chief Don Francis. He said the victims were working on a car inside the shop on the city's east side when two men entered, looked around and went back outside. The pair returned with weapons and opened fire, he said.

title: Ford Shifts Duties Of Top Executives
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday announced an executive reshuffling that appparently widens the field of candidates for top executive positions in the early 1990's and emphasizes the importance of the company's financial services operations.

title: 5 Carpenters' Union Leaders Indicted in Extortion
description: Five high-level officials of the carpenters' union were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting more than $100,000 from contractors.

title: Slamming The Press, In Daylight
description: For the National Security Agency, the Government department that intercepts overseas communications, breaks codes and barely acknowledges its own existence, secrecy is more than a way of life. It is an obsession.

title: AMERICAN BANK OF CONNECTCUT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months' earnings include a special gain of $176 million, which was the estimated net gain from CPC's restructuring activities. The gain included proceeds from the sale to Ajnomoto Co. of CPC's 50 percent equity in a joint venture in Japan and a 5 percent equity in CPC's wholly owned subsidiaries in six Asian countries, along with sales of certain other investments, net of costs incurred and extimated from the sale of CPC's European corn refining business and other costs associated with the company's restructuring program. The company said earnings for its latest third quarter and 9 months include a loss from operations of $10.2 million for the company's European corn refining business.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I AM always amused by people who speak with condescension of burgers and other ground-meat dishes and who think of them as nothing more than snack food. I dote on grilled ground-meat dishes, whose flavors and texture can vary widely, depending solely on the cook's imagination.

title: Strike Grips Colombia Over Killing of Leftist
description: Rioters in the funeral procession for a slain leftist leader looted stores today and at least one person was killed as unions called a general strike to protest the assassination.

title: B.A.T. to Expand Saks 5th Ave. Chain
description: iB.A.T. Industries of London said yesterday that it plans to spend $300 million in the next five years to expand its Saks Fifth Avenue subsidiary, a chain of 44 specialty stores that caters to affluent consumers.

title: 'Elegant Gluttony' in an Age of Nouvelle
description: LEAD: WOODY CAMPBELL and Terry Williams were just a couple of lonely guys in New York whose wives, both publisher's representatives, attended the Frankfurt Book Fair each fall. The men were left with the children, the apartments and the housework.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Year-Round Schooling Is Voted in Los Angeles
description: In a move certain to be watched closely by educators, parents and operators of summer camps around the country, the Los Angeles board of education has voted to put all its 618 schools and 592,000 students on a year-round schedule.

title: Yields Up to 9.323% Set By Puerto Rico Agency
description: The Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority is offering yields of well above 9 percent for new long-term bonds underwritten by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: An Old and a New Twin Hail Victory
description: The old man in the rumpled sport coat smiled when someone stopped him in the lobby of the Minnesota Twins' office to offer congratulations. He did not engage in a conversation or dismiss the moment as unworthy of his attention. He responded briefly, then stepped into a waiting elevator and disappeared behind its doors.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3,010,000 for the quarter and $4,737,000 for the 9 months from the early retirement of debt. c-After extraordinary charges of $3,520,000 for the quarter and $17,352,000 for the 9 months from penalties on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SOLIDARITY APPEAL ON U.S. AID
description: Leaders of the banned Solidarity union announced today that they would seek court registration for a foundation to oversee the use of a $1 million grant from the United States Congress to purchase special ambulances and other medical equipment and establish diagnostic centers in industrial cities.

title: Suburban Pioneers Adjust in a Rural Jersey
description: The meadows where dairy cows once grazed and where Sam Einstein spent his boyhood hunting pheasants and Indian arrowheads are filled now with a new housing development. As its residents forge new ways of life in the countryside, they speed the reshaping of this old farming town.

title: The Heir Apparent At Random House Quits the Company
description: In a move that shocked officials of the publishing industry, Howard Kaminsky - who was widely regarded as the heir apparent at Random House - resigned as the company's publisher yesterday. He was succeeded by Joni Evans, who until two months ago had been the head of trade book publishing at Simon & Schuster, Random House's archrival.

title: Jersey Ban on Political Work Of Casino Officials Is Upheld
description: A Superior Court judge today upheld New Jersey's restrictions on the political activity of casino executives.

title: ONE LIBERTY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEY RATES
Ruse Journal; In Babel on Danube, All Tongues but One Are Still
description: The Danube is majestically broad here and its currents are strong as it gathers speed for the final rush into the Black Sea. The river is in the home stretch of its 1,770-mile course, which begins as a rivulet in West Germany and leads through Austria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Yugoslavia before reaching Ruse.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR active people, the most depressing aspect of back pain is probably the realization that a favorite form of exercise will have to be abandoned, at least temporarily.

title: Most of Europe Bars Child Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready, Set, Taxes!
description: The Internal Revenue Service is spending $7.6 million to send brochures to more than 90 million taxpayers to tell them, in the words of an I.R.S. official, ''why they should start thinking about their taxes earlier than ever before.''

title: Atlanta Planning a Dome
description: In a move to keep the Atlanta Falcons from moving out of the city, a group of business and government leaders will announce plans Wednesday to build a $158 million domed stadium in downtown Atlanta.

title: State Judge Says Plant Must Cut Radiation Level
description: A judge ordered the owners of a radium factory in Queens yesterday to comply ''forthwith'' with a state requirement to reduce radiation emissions outside the building to permissible levels.

title: Dance: Bill Coleman And Troupe
description: ''THE OTHER STORY,'' presented by Bill Coleman and His North American Experience on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, takes on sibling rivalry and the nature of same in a madcap theater-dance piece that is a messy charmer. Originally called ''Baryshnikov: The Other Story,'' the full-evening work is the story of one Barry Shenkov, an Iowa farm boy who becomes the world's greatest dancer, as seen through the eyes of an ambivalently adoring younger brother.

title: Spy's Escape Stirs Furor in Sweden
description: The escape last week of Sweden's best-known spy and the laxity it brought to light have prompted an angry public reaction here and spurred the Government to order a review of the nation's lenient penal system.

title: Issue of Apartheid Dominant As the Commonwealth Meets
description: The 49-nation Commonwealth opened its meeting here today with its attention focused strongly on South Africa, as it has been at many such meetings over the last 25 years.

title: Vaginal Sex May Be Added To Listing as an AIDS Risk
description: New York City health officials, in a new move to restrict the spread of AIDS, have urged the state to add vaginal intercourse to the list of risky practices now prohibited in commercial sex establishments. They also asked the state to extend the enforcement of anti-AIDS rules to closed areas, such as cubicles in bathhouses.

title: MARYLAND FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company converted to public ownership in June.

title: Tisch Expected To Oppose Sale
description: At today's meeting of the CBS Inc. board, Laurence A. Tisch, the company's chief executive, is expected to oppose the sale of CBS Records to the Sony Corporation for about $2 billion, according to a person close to Mr. Tisch.

title: ABINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Abington Savings converted to stock form of ownership in June 1986.

title: Music: Riverside Group
description: AN artist need not be original to be important. It is, in fact, rare that a major composer breaks new ground. Against the few genuine originals such as Gluck, Wagner, Ives and Schoenberg stands the more imposing group of those whose genius was expressed in refining rather than redefining the musical culture into which they were born. Arguments are possible, but among the refiners we may place Bach, Mozart, Schubert, Schumann, Chopin, Brahms, Verdi, Debussy - even Haydn and Beethoven. They had only to pick up the tools at hand and use them.

title: Harte-Hanks To Sell Units
description: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. said it would sell several operations, including its cable television systems, for about $500 million to reduce its debt. Harte-Hanks, based in San

title: Economic Scene; Glum Outlook On Trade Gap
description: AS an indicator of a trend, the August deficit in American trade, to be announced this morning, has little value. The deficit might rise, as it did in June and July, or it might decline - the most likely scenario. But whatever the August inning, the outcome of the game should remain the same: The nation's huge deficit in merchandise trade is not likely to shrink much in this decade.

title: Developer Says He Will Reduce 59th St. Project
description: Plans for office towers on the western arc of Columbus Circle seemed certain to be scaled back yesterday as the developer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, said he would reduce the bulk of the buildings to resolve lawsuits against the project.

title: Irving's 'Nice Guy' Chief Vows to Fight Takeover
description: Suddenly, the usually taciturn Joseph A. Rice, chairman and chief executive of the Irving Bank Corporation, is inviting reporters to see him for personal chats.

title: Reports of Parasites Rekindle a Debate About Raw Fish
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, Americans began eating significant amounts of sushi. Ever since, there have been nagging doubts about the wisdom of consuming raw fish - doubts intensified by occasional reports of fish parasites. Yet America's love affair with sushi has continued unabated.

title: Car Bomb Wounds 18 In a Zimbabwe Suburb
description: A car-bomb explosion wounded 18 people, 5 of them seriously, at a suburban Harare shopping center today. The Zimbabwean Government blamed South Africa.

title: Times When the Rhythm Method Is Unreliable
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS and ABC Rebuff Reagan
description: Two major television networks will not broadcast live today's speech by President Reagan in support of Judge Robert H. Bork. Top executives at CBS News and ABC News said yesterday that they expected the speech to be strictly partisan in nature, with little news value.

title: BROCK WILL LEAVE POST IN CABINET
description: Labor Secretary William E. Brock plans to announce in the next few days that he will quit his Cabinet post to run the Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole, Labor Department officials said today.

title: Action Urged To Prosecute Thruway Case
description: Completing a three-month investigation into business dealings by the executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority, the state's Inspector General has concluded that the case should be turned over to a prosecutor for possible action, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Dance: Maya, Flamenco
description: THE Mario Maya Flamenco Dance Theater Company is a fine troupe of Spanish dancers. Yet it is not necessarily seen at its best in New York.

title: SSC&B, Campbell Join Forces
description: THE long-expected merger of the domestic arm of SSC&B:Lintas with Campbell-Ewald was announced yesterday by the Interpublic Group of Companies, the parent of both agencies.

title: Edelman to Meet Officials of Telex
description: The New York financier Asher B. Edelman will meet with senior officials of the Telex Corporation on Wednesday to discuss his $65-a-share cash tender offer for the computer equipment concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman said that the two sides would meet at the suggestion of George L. Ball, president of Telex, which is based in Tulsa, Okla.

title: 600 in Gay Demonstration Arrested at Supreme Court
description: Hundreds of gay men and women deliberately subjected themselves to arrest today by attempting to enter the Supreme Court building to protest a 1986 decision upholding a Georgia sodomy law's enforcement against homosexuals.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LEAD: ONE morning Jacques Hess joined a restless group waiting across Seventh Avenue from Carnegie Hall for the M6 or M7 southbound bus. Eventually a bus appeared on the horizon, but the joy was temporary: the route sign proclaimed it out of service.

title: COSTA RICA LEADER WINS NOBEL PRIZE FOR PEACE PLAN
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the driving force behind the regional peace plan signed by five Central American countries two months ago, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today.

title: Prosecutor Urges Judge to Jail Goetz
description: Bernhard H. Goetz, who was exonerated in June in the shooting of four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway train, should receive a ''substantial prison sentence'' for illegally carrying the gun he used, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Cardinals Edge the Giants to Force a Seventh Game
description: One slip away from losing the National League pennant, the St. Louis Cardinals needed a tour de force to survive tonight, and they got it.

title: Avoiding Diabetes
description: To The Living Section:

title: Shamrock Offer For Wherehouse
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said it is seeking to make a friendly $14.25-a-share takeover of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., a music and video retailer with 200 outlets. Shamrock, the Roy E. Disney family's investment company, said it already owns 6.65 percent of 8.5 million Wherehouse shares outstanding. The bid would give the Torrance, Calif., retailer a market value of more than $121.5 million. Wherehouse's stock jumped $3.25 today, to $14 a share, on the American Stock Exchange today.

title: And Now, the Sound of Plastic
description: What the world needs is a paper-thin piece of plastic that can be rolled into an oddly-shaped speaker that emits tinny-sounding music. No? Well that's what Japan has and the rest of us may soon get, thanks to the Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company.

title: Market Place; A Recovery In Trucking?
description: SO far it has been a tough year for the trucking industry. Rate wars have cut revenue, fuel prices have risen 30 percent and labor costs are up about 3 percent.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: b-Includes tax credits of $975,000 for the latest quarter and $95,000 for the year-ago period; the latest quarter also includes a $1,180,000 after-tax gain from the settlement of real estate tax certiorari proceedings. c-Net income d-Includes a gain of $1,408,000, or 32 cents a share, from a change in accounting for investment tax credit.

title: Giants Wallowing In Anger, Anxiety
description: Anxiety, anger and animosity against the owners were evident in the eyes of most of the 34 Giants who emerged from a meeting here this morning that Robbie Jones described as heated.

title: MNC FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JULIUS SELIGSON
description: Julius Seligson, the national intercollegiate men's singles tennis champion in 1928 and winner of 65 straight college matches, died yesterday of a malignant melanoma at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 77 years old. Mr. Seligson's streak for Lehigh University ran from 1928 until his final match in 1930, when he was defeated by Cliff Sutter, a sophomore from Tulane, to fail in his bid for an undefeated undergraduate tennis career. Mr. Seligson forfeited the intercollegiate crown in 1929 when he failed to appear for the final.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1987
description: COMPANIES Public Service of New Hampshire moved closer to bankruptcy when its board voted to skip a $37.5 million interest payment due tomorrow. The missed payment will automatically begin a 30-day grace period after which the company could be declared insolvent. Public Service has been driven to the brink of insolvency because of its $2.1 billion investment in the Seabrook nuclear power plant, which may be blocked from opening. [ Page D1. ] The Columbia Business School and one of its newest teachers, Asher B. Edelman, an expert in takeovers, have had a clash of values. The graduate school's dean has blocked Mr. Edelman's proposal to pay $100,000 to any student whose research uncovered a company Mr. Edelman could buy. [ A1. ] I.B.M.'s quarterly profits were up 12 percent. But Wall Street and the computer industry were disappointed and suggested that I.B.M.'s mid-range computers were making few inroads. [ D1. ] Kidder, Peabody will trim its staff by at least 35 percent in its municipal securities unit, citing market conditions. A day earlier, Salomon said it would shut its municipal bond operations. [ D1. ] Sumitomo infringed on two patents held by Corning Glass for optical fiber, a Federal district judge ruled. The fiber is a thin glass wire used in telecommunications. [ D1. ] Ford Motor shuffled its management, widening the field of candidates for top executive positions in the early 1990's. [ D2. ] SSC&B:Lintas's domestic arm and Campbell-Ewald merged, as expected. The Interpublic Group owns the agencies. [ D27. ] The heir apparent abruptly resigned as publisher of Random House. Howard Kaminsky was succeeded by Joni Evans. [ C23. ] Merrill Lynch turned in slightly improved results, bucking the trend on Wall Street. [ D5. ] B.A.T. will spend $300 million to expand Saks Fifth Avenue, the 44-unit specialty store chain. [ D5. ] Occidental said Colombia had reduced a tax assessment against the company by nearly $820 million. [ D5. ] MARKETS Blue-chip stocks rallied, helping the Dow Jones industrial average to reverse its sharp slide. The blue-chip average rose rose 36.72 points, to 2,508.16, and broader market gauges also turned around. Traders are hoping for a drop in the nation's trade deficit. [ D12. ] Treasury prices rose modestly as traders and investors waited for today's report on the nation's trade deficit in August and Friday's report on producer prices for September. [ D23. ] The dollar moved higher as many traders bought the currency to adjust their positions ahead of the trade report. In New York, gold fell $3, to $458.75 an ounce. [ D24. ] Grain and soybean futures closed higher after a rally stemming from a lack of farmer selling. [ D24. ] THE ECONOMY House Democrats proposed to limit the mortgage deduction for higher-income homeowners. The deduction would be available only on the first $1 million of mortgage debt. The Democrats completed work on a bill to raise $12 billion in new taxes. [ D1. ] C. William Verity Jr. was confirmed as Commerce Secretary after the Senate shut off a threatened filibuster. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY

title: GOLDTEX INC reports earnings for Year to July 26
FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,105,000 for the quarter and $4,189,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $423,000 for the quarter and $1,698,000 for the 9 months; $178,000 in income for the quarter and $2,111,000 for the 9 months from spun-off Nycor Inc., and tax credits of $178,000 for the quarter and $810,000 for the 9 months attributed to Nycor.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,772,000 for the 9 months, and for both periods includes the settlement of certain insurance claims which increased net by $1.7 million, or 4 cents a share. The company said this adjustment was offset by provisions for disposition and termination of certain operations amounting to $2.4 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,420,000 and $7,040,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for both periods also includes a change in the method of accounting for pensions which increased net income by $588,000 for the third quarter and $3.4 million for the 9 months. The company said these gains were offset by provisions for the disposition and termination of certain operations amounting to $3.2 million for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1986.

title: Centennial Exhibition Celebrates Marianne Moore
description: An elegant centennial exhibition that opens at the Grolier Club today celebrates the poetic vision of Marianne Moore, who was born in Kirkwood, Mo., 100 years ago come Nov. 15. Until her death in 1972, Moore, with her Mary Poppins innocence and wisdom, flowing cape and trademark tricorn hat (''I like the shape - it conceals the defects of the head''), was the unofficial poet laureate of the boroughs in which she lived, wrote and flourished most of her life - in Brooklyn, at 260 Cumberland Street, and in Manhattan, at 35 West Ninth Street.

title: Canada Assails New Bid to Have Envoy Testify in Deaver Case
description: The Government of Canada said today that it was the victim of ''shocking and extraordinary'' efforts at ''intimidation'' by the special prosecutor in the perjury case against Michael K. Deaver.

title: The Search for the Loch Ness Midget
description: This year's expedition to search for the monster in Loch Ness, Scotland, was the most perilous yet. It came within a hair of actually proving that there is no Loch Ness monster.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the previously-announced sale of the company's right to acquire a partnership interest in the South Tower of the World Financial Center and related transactions, resulting in a gain of $122.6 million pretax and $100.3 million after-tax.

title: Jazz: Gruntz Concert Band On Tour
description: GEORGE GRUNTZ, a Swiss jazz pianist, composer and arranger, has been touring the United States with an orchestra of American and European musicians, many of whom are band leaders and recording artists in their own right. Last Thursday, in the first of four performances at Greenwich House, the George Gruntz Concert Jazz Band sounded more like a road band than a one-time aggregation of star soloists and studio professionals.

title: Gorbachev Pledges He'll Cut Bureaucracy in Soviet Union
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev pledged today to introduce sweeping cuts in the Soviet bureaucracy, but said he was not planning an upheaval similar to China's Cultural Revolution of 1966 to 1976.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BankAmerica Sale
description: A group of 26 Japanese banks will sign a final agreement on Friday to buy $250 million in subordinated notes that the BankAmerica Corporation is offering to help rebuild its weakened capital base. Kenichi Kamiya, president of the Federation of Bankers' Associations of Japan and head of Mitsui Bank Ltd., said the agreement would be signed in London.

title: A Speedier Chip Finally Gets a Lift
description: WHEN Cray Research Inc. last month canceled a project to develop an advanced supercomputer, the company's stock plummeted. For companies making gallium arsenide chips, however, the announcement was good news.

title: Wooing the Wealthy Reader
description: Wealthy readers have never been more popular.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $317,000 of after-tax securities gains for the latest third quarter and gains of $5.3 million, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of equity and other investment securities for the year-ago period. The results for the latest quarter also include a $1.3 million after-tax loss on the sale of NCNB's $4 million loan portfolio in Argentina.

title: New Center to Study Psychology of AIDS
description: Financed by a $19 million Federal grant, a new AIDS research center was established yesterday to concentrate on the psychosocial and psychiatric aspects of the AIDS epidemic in New York City.

title: Patrick Buchanan To Rejoin CNN as Host
description: Patrick Buchanan, who was communications director at the White House until last spring, will rejoin the Cable News Network as a host of ''Crossfire,'' the network announced yesterday.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' loss includes a $220 million second quarter addition the bank made to its reserve against loans and to certain countries with severe debt servicing problems. National Westminster Bank USA is a wholly owned subsidiary of Westminster Bank Plc.

title: Ratings Still Losing Yardage
description: TELEVISION audiences for National Football League games last Sunday and Monday were smaller than a week ago, and, in some cases, were only about half as large as those preceding the three-week-old player strike.

title: Kodak Introduces Disks With Teflon
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced floppy disks coated with Teflon to protect them from spills, smudges or stains. Floppy disks store computer information, but can easily be damaged. Kodak said its new Teflon-coated Data Life Plus disk would prevent data loss. Teflon, created by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, is a non-stick coating used on cookware.

title: WORCESTER COUNTY INSTITUION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to a stock form of ownership in August 1986.

title: Dow, Reversing Slide, Rises by 36.72
description: Blue-chip stocks rallied yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.72 points, to 2,508.16, reversing a sharp slide.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months include the second quarter addition of $160 million to the reserve for possible loan losses to reflect exposure to less developed countries.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: New Novelist

title: Patriots Get Flutie; He'll Play
description: The New England Patriots, seeking help at quarterback, acquired Doug Flutie, the 1984 Heisman Trophy winner at Boston College, from the Chicago Bears today for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Jury Finds U.S. Not to Blame For Men's Enlarged Breasts
description: An advisory jury hearing a Federal suit brought by 30 Haitian men who developed enlarged breasts while in detention camps in 1981 found today that the Government had not been negligent.

title: TV Review; 'Slow Moves,' Technique Over Plot
description: IT'S not quite clear why ''Slow Moves'' was chosen to be part of Channel 13's ''Independent Focus'' at 11:30 this evening. The series was originally designed as a showcase for independently produced films and videos with a provocative or even controversial edge. There is even a disclaimer before each broadcast to the effect that the opinions expressed are those of the independent producer. At one point, ''Independent Focus'' might have been offering, say, depictions of Cuba or Nicaragua that did not quite fit into the Reagan Administration's ''evil empire'' world schema. But political pressures and assorted public scoldings have made such offerings increasingly rare.

title: Cronkite Criticizes Rather Over Walkout
description: Walter Cronkite has said that Dan Rather deserved to lose his job for walking off the set of a sports-delayed newscast last month, and that there was no excuse for forcing the network to ''go black'' for six minutes.

title: Knicks Still Hoping to Acquire Green
description: The posturing over the future of Sidney Green has stretched to new levels.

title: Sharing War Powers
description: There is a lot of hand-wringing here over the ineffectiveness of the War Powers Act in the Persian Gulf conflict.

title: Iranian Missile Killed 32, Baghdad Says
description: A missile fired from Iran exploded next to an elementary school here this morning as pupils filed into the building for classes, and 32 people were killed and 218 wounded, nearly all of them children, officials said.

title: Saatchi Announces Senior Appointments
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's largest advertising holding company, announced two very senior appointments. Both Jeremy Sinclair, 43 years old, and Andrew Woods, 44, have been named group deputy chairmen of the London-based concern, reporting directly to Maurice and Charles Saatchi.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
U.S. and French Plays
description: ''Double Visions: France-U.S.A.,'' a series of play readings and discussions, will begin on Monday at Ubu Repertory Theater, 149 Mercer Street. The program centers on the works of contemporary French playwrights who have lived in the United States and of contemporary American playwrights who have lived in France. The readings, which will be in English, will take place on Monday and Tuesday evenings at 8, through Nov. 10. Admission is free, but reservations are necessary. Information: 925-0999.

title: Subway Hindsight
description: To the Editor:

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures have been restated.

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Youmans Enters Clinic
description: The Montreal Expos confirmed yesterday that Floyd Youmans had entered a drug rehabilitation clinic, but the team denied the pitcher was forced to do so by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth. There had been reports that Youmans was threatened with a one-year suspension by the commmissioner if he did not take part in a rehabilitation program. But the Expos' general manager, Bill Stoneman, said Youmans agreed to enter a clinic Monday for an evaluation program. Stoneman said Ueberroth's office had been advised of the situation and had offered counseling, but had never issued a directive ordering rehabilitation or threatening suspension. Youmans, 23 years old, finished with a 9-8 record and a 4.64 earned run average in 116 innings this season.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,360,000 from a lawsuit settlement for the latest period and $3,300,000 in hedging losses for the year-ago period.

title: Puerto Rico Expands New York Voter Drive
description: Saying new strategies were needed to break ''the old and damaging habit of nonvoting,'' the Governor of Puerto Rico announced yesterday that his administration would open a $500,000 campaign to register Puerto Rican voters in New York City in time for the state's Presidential primary.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RUMANIAN RECALLS DEAL FOR EMIGRES
description: Israel paid millions of dollars to the Rumanian Government over several decades to permit emigration of Jews, according to a senior Rumanian intelligence official who defected in 1978.

title: Lump in the Dark
description: To The Living Section:

title: Grand Cuisine From the Pumpkin Patch
description: THIS has been one of the most remarkable years for pumpkin growing. That's what a farmer friend and neighbor on Long Island tells me. ''The fields,'' he said, ''have been downright pregnant with pumpkins, and the numbers on each vine have been tremendous.''

title: The AIDS Memorial
description: While speeches boomed from a platform behind the Capitol at last Sunday's gay rights march, a quieter ritual took place near the Washington Monument. A quilt was spread on the grass, a huge quilt made of 2,000 panels, each commemorating one of the 25,000 Americans who have died of AIDS.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $9,428,000.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1987.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article about the new winner, Susumu Tonegawa, indicated his current activities incorrectly; he teaches some graduate courses at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In some editions, that article also included a subheading in error; the heading, about a new book, referred to the adjoining article.

title: HAITIAN CANDIDATE KILLED BY GUNMEN
description: A Haitian presidential candidate was shot to death this morning in front of the police headquarters in Port-au-Prince as he delivered a speech demanding the release of a prisoner, witnesses and diplomats said.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 6 months' loss is after an after-tax writeoff of $1.2 million for FSLIC secondary reserve. All per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 split distributed in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend, on March 27.

title: George Dennison, Novelist, 62
description: George Dennison, a novelist and short-story writer who was widely praised for his factual account of the education of poor children from minority families on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, died of lung cancer last Thursday at his home in Temple, Me. He was 62 years old.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Arias Sees Greater Chance for Peace
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez said today that he was convinced that his Nobel Peace Prize would greatly improve prospects for the Central American peace accord he wrote and sponsored.

title: I.B.M. Finally Lifts Net, But Wall St. Is Unhappy
