description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday ended a stubborn string of five consecutive quarters in which its profits declined by reporting a 12 percent increase in its third-quarter net income.

title: AMERICAN TELEVISION & COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures restated to include Manhattan Cable Television Inc., which was transferred from Time Inc. to ATC on March 18 in exchange for 9.4 million class B common shares of American Television. The results for 1987 include American Television's share of the losses in Paragon Communications. In addition, other expense for 1986 included a one-time pre-tax gain of $5.2 million received by American Television from American Express Co. in connection with the termination of an agreement which provided for the purchase of American Express' share of Warner Amex Communications Corp.

title: South African Editor Asks to Be Released
description: A detained editor, whose newspaper has become the first target of South Africa's new censorship laws, has applied to a court for his release.

title: Wisdom in WIC
description: WIC (Women, Infants and Children) is one Federal nutrition program that has never even been accused of that famous trio of offenses against Reaganism known as Waste, Fraud and Abuse. The program is unquestionably well targeted, and has saved lives, health and dollars. But sad to say, it reaches only 44 percent of those eligible - and the Senate Agriculture Appropriations subcommittee is making it very hard to reach more.

title: Indians Battling Tamils in Jaffna
description: Indian troops using heavy mortars, tanks and armored personnel carriers were battling their way through fierce Tamil guerrilla resistance today along four routes into Jaffna town, an Indian official said.

title: B. Jay Becker Dies; A Bridge Champion And Record Holder
description: B. Jay Becker, one of the leading bridge players in the world, died Friday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 83 years old. Mr. Becker won two world championships for the Bermuda Bowl as a member of United States teams -against Italy in 1951 and against Sweden in 1953. He represented the United States on four other occasions, finishing second in 1958 and 1965, third in 1960 and fourth in 1973.

title: Solace and Sustenance for AIDS Patients
description: LAST spring, Arthur Levy was suffering with just about every affliction that can befall an AIDS patient: pneumonia, cancer, kidney trouble. He thought he was going to die. Sometimes, he wanted to.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RIGHTS OF CITIZENS AND SOCIETY RAISE LEGAL MUDDLE ON AIDS
description: States around the nation are finding themselves in a legal muddle about how to control the spread of AIDS, and specifically how to balance the civil rights of people with AIDS against the goal of protecting public health.

title: The Driest Vintage: Tongue in Cheek
description: LEAD: IN the old days, most vineyards offered minimal information on the labels of their bottles. The product, they thought, would sell itself. But in California, today's vineyard owners think differently. Wine labels constitute a major public relations tool, a point-of-purchase pitch.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Alfred M. Landon in some editions yesterday misstated the year in which a Democratic or Republican Presidential candidate first won fewer states than Mr. Landon did in 1936. It was 1972, when George McGovern carried only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Sound Scavenger

title: Concert: Brooklyn Orchestra
description: UNDER its music director, Lukas Foss, the Brooklyn Philharmonic has in recent years developed an admirable reputation for mixing contemporary music into its performance schedule. The six programs that make up the Philharmonic's 1987-88 subscription season include local premieres of pieces by John Corigliano and Morton Gould as well as a concert co-sponsored by the Next Wave Festival that is devoted entirely to the works of Steve Reich.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4 million for the quarter and $7.4 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $270.6 million for the quarter and $255.6 million for the 9 months. The year-ago third quarter includes a special charge of $37.4 million for restructuring costs.

title: U.S. Suing Over Loans By Hyfin Credit Union
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have filed a lawsuit to recover $12 million in fraudulent loans given to a taxi-medallion brokerage and its owner by the now-defunct Hyfin Credit Union.

title: Colombia Cuts Occidental Tax
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that Colombia had agreed to cut a tax assessment against the company to $21.5 million, from $850 million.

title: Polish Economic Program Poses Risk to Jaruzelski
description: At a time of considerable economic and political uncertainty, Poland's leadership has thrown its weight behind an ambitious program of economic change that bears broad political risks for the regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: SMITH, A O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $729,000 and $886,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHILE grape picking is under way in vineyards, consumers have begun autumn ''cherry picking'' in wine stores. Cherry-picking is wine-buff jargon for bargain-hunting. A guide to such browsing is useful, which means it is time to update the Wine Talk vintage chart.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a charge of $130,604,000 related to the anticipated loss on long- term insurance contracts in effect at Aug. 31, 1986, the writeoff of certain intangible assets, provisions for the estimated cost associated with the planned disposition of certain Medfirst facilities and a writedown for a hospital in Mexico City.

title: IP TIMBERLANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are for class A depositary units.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said 1986 third-quarter sales included $75 million and 9-month sales included $225.4 million related to the central heating and cooling business; earnings for the 9 months of 1986 included about 10 cents a share for the central heating and cooling business.

title: Treasury Prices Up Modestly
description: Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday as traders and investors waited for two key economic statistics on foreign trade and inflation.

title: Guitar: Emanuele Segre
description: EMANUELE SEGRE, a young Italian guitarist who has been winning prizes and making records in Europe, devoted more than half his debut program at Weill Recital Hall Sunday afternoon to music of his compatriots.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a United Press International contract with the Reagan Administration misstated the news service's relationships with The Wall Street Journal and CBS News. While both organizations sent notices saying they intended to cancel their U.P.I. contracts, they later renewed some parts of the agreements and continue to receive some U.P.I. services.

title: Classroom Intruder Robs Teacher
description: A man who pretended that he had a gun walked into two elementary school classrooms in Brooklyn yesterday morning, threatened to harm the students there and stole an undetermined amount of money and jewelry from one of the teachers, the police said.

title: Beck May Retire
description: Barry Beck has scheduled a meeting with reporters in his agent's office this afternoon, at which he is expected to announce his retirement from the Rangers. Beck, a 30-year-old defenseman, has been plagued by injuries since 1985, particularly to his right shoulder, which was reinjured in an exhibition game early last week.

title: Underwater Volcano Erupts, Shaking Ship of Researchers
description: An undersea volcano in the south-central Pacific Ocean erupted directly beneath a California-based research vessel on Sunday, causing a fearful clamor as large bubbles of steam and gas shook the ship, bursting under her hull and in the surrounding water.

title: Norman Among 4 To Get a Golf Bye
description: Greg Norman of Australia, the defending champion, was one of four players to receive a first-round bye when the draw was made today for the $424,000 Suntory world match-play golf championship starting Thursday.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
With Tamil Conflict, Myths Die Out
description: As heavy fighting once again ravages the Jaffna Peninsula of Sri Lanka, forcing people who had just begun to enjoy peace back into precarious shelters, many Sri Lankans and Indians are also witnessing the destruction of myths and the ethnic alignments they supported.

title: A Soft Swipe
description: In the supersensitive new politics, negative campaigning is becoming such a touchy area that even the simple citing of an opponent's voting record requires a disclaimer.

title: Group Threatens to Publish List of War-Crime Suspects
description: A leading American Jewish organization said today that it would publish a list of 40,000 names of possible World War II criminals contained in secret United Nations archives unless the archives are opened to inspection soon.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
The U.N. Today: Oct. 14, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Islanders Trusting in Konroyd
description: When the doors closed on the hotel elevator in Los Angeles last Thursday, Steve Konroyd found himself alone with Terry Simpson. In the 12-flight drop to the lobby, no cables snapped, no lights went out and no alarms were triggered, but it wasn't an uneventful trip.

title: About Real Estate; Parking Lots Are Drawing Speculators, Not Just Cars
description: What parking lots lack in prestige, they make up for in potential - which is why real estate speculators continue to be enamored of them.

title: Greenspan's Inflation View
description: The economy's long-ailing industrial sector is rebounding smartly, but there is still no evidence of significant inflationary pressure, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today.

title: High Style On the Go
description: 1.Mah-Jongg to Go Mah-jongg tiles are highly decorative, so it is only natural that they be put to decorative use -in bracelets. The one shown here is from a collection of bracelets made with Bakelite mah-jongg tiles from the 1920's to 1950's. The tiles are strung on elasticized bands and are joined with black beads. The price is $40 at Nancy Marshall Antique Collection Ltd., 145 East 62d Street. #2.Silk Vegetables Here is a nutritious-looking centerpiece: a basket of silk vegetables. It is filled with a tomato, a mushroom, an eggplant, red cabbage, romaine lettuce, asparagus, carrots and leeks. The price is $43. Other baskets can be made to order, with individual vegetables ranging from $2 to $6. At Designpoint, 15 Christopher Street, between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. 3.Stylish Sticks The walking stick, a vision of a bygone era, is popular once again. This elegant wooden stick, made in Italy, is topped with a bird's head made of heavy carved plastic that looks like crystal. Other animal heads are also available. For $95 in traditional gifts on the seventh floor at Bergdorf Goodman, Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. 4.Saucy Saucers This demitasse set will finish your dinner party in high style. It is porcelain, and is made in France by Siecle. The white cup sits on a black and white saucer that is covered with a bold, swirling design. Two other saucer designs are also available. The price for a cup and saucer is $12 in Chelsea Passage at Barneys New York, Seventh Avenue and 17th Street. Good Looking For moments when your eyes need extra help, H. Stern Jewelers has a handsome magnifying glass that you can carry in a handbag or a briefcase. The frame is agate, and there is a choice of several fashionable colors, in shades of green, orange, blue or brown. The glasses, which come in two sizes, are $15 and $20 at H. Stern Jewelers, 645 Fifth Avenue, between 51st and 52d Streets.

title: Russians Again Vote to Oust Israel From the U.N.
description: The Soviet Union, despite overtures to Israel on other fronts, voted again today to exclude Israel from the General Assembly.

title: Rates Rise Sharply For Citicorp Paper
description: The surge in short-term interest rates generally in the past week led to increases of nearly half a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: Group Lifts Stake In Bell & Howell
description: A group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family said it had raised its stake in the Bell & Howell Company to 11.1 percent, from 9.6 percent. The move makes the Bass group the largest shareholder and set off new takeover speculation about the business-equipment manufacturer. Its stock rose by $2.75, to $70.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Harold S. Anderson, 92, Dies; Ex-Edison Museum Manager
description: Harold S. Anderson, who worked for Thomas A. Edison and later managed the Edison Museum, died of heart failure Oct. 5 at the Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center in Plainfield, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Westfield.

title: PLASTI-LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Guess on Game at Syracuse
description: Rutgers, having lost to both, is the measuring stick for Saturday's match between Penn State, the perennial Lambert Trophy champion as the best in the East, and Syracuse, which is undefeated after five games for the first time since 1959.

title: Court Hears School Censorship Case
description: The Supreme Court, seeking to gauge the extent of students' free speech rights, heard a challenge today to a principal's censorship of a high school newspaper.

title: US BANCORP (PORTLAND, ORE)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bonnett Out for Season
description: Neil Bonnett, the 41-year-old Nascar driver who broke his right leg Sunday at Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., when his car struck a wall during the running of the Oakwood Homes 500, will probably be sidelined for the remainder of the Winston Cup season. Dr. John Wassel, an orthopedic surgeon, operated on Bonnett Monday and discovered a four-inch piece of bone split off the upper femur. The leg was repaired, but the doctor said that it would be four weeks before Bonnett could begin rehabilitation and that the total recovery might take three months.

title: Busch Stadium Giveth and Busch Stadium Taketh
description: SOMETIMES when Busch Stadium is very quiet, one seems to hear faint murmurings from deep inside the retractable tarpaulin machine, below the green artificial turf near first base.

title: 2 Major Biden Backers in Iowa Joining Simon
description: Two of the top supporters of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s former Democratic Presidential campaign in Iowa plan to announce their support for Senator Paul Simon.

title: Columbia Gives 'F' to a $100,000 Lesson Plan
description: When the Columbia Business School asked Asher B. Edelman, who is expert in company takeovers, to teach a course this fall on corporate raiding, Dean John C. Burton thought students would gain some valuable lessons.

title: Owners Keep Big L.I. Bank
description: Raymond J. Dempsey, chairman of the European American Bancorp, told 600 of the bank's senior officers yesterday that the six European banks that own European American had decided not to sell the bank.

title: WALTER BRATTAIN, INVENTOR, IS DEAD
description: Walter H. Brattain, who shared the 1956 Nobel Prize in physics for the invention of the transistor, died yesterday of Alzheimer's Disease in a nursing home in Seattle. He was 85 years old.

title: GROVE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Grove Bank went public in August 1986.

title: L.I.-Grown Peppers
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Vows New Appointment As Upsetting to His Foes as Bork's
description: President Reagan acknowledged today that Judge Robert H. Bork would almost certainly not win confirmation to the Supreme Court, but he vowed to appoint a new nominee who upsets Democrats ''just as much'' as Judge Bork did.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, a Houston dispatch yesterday about Vice President Bush's announcement of his Presidential candidacy misstated his pledge on the budget deficit and misidentified his birthplace. He said he would accelerate efforts to reduce the deficit. His birthplace is Milton, Mass.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net of $2.2 million for the quarter and a loss of $15.7 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Miami Journal; Lacking Punch, Storm Delivers Wrong Message
description: Like many things that cause fear and quickly retreat, Hurricane Floyd became an object of scorn and derision today along the shores where Florida sticks its peninsula chin into the ocean, daring some storm to try to sock it.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LeMond Starts On Road to '88
description: Little by little, Greg LeMond said, it's all coming back.

title: Koch Backs Plan Requiring Cleaner Fuels for Vehicles
description: Mayor Koch said today that he would support a plan to require many of the taxis, buses and trucks that ply New York streets to burn alternate, cleaner fuels within five years.

title: Unesco Leader Almost Wins Enough Votes for Re-election
description: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, whose tenure as Unesco's Director General has divided the organization, came close to winning a new six-year term today, but still fell three votes short of a majority.

title: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months' net was reduced by a previously announced $8.1 million addition to loan loss reserves, as well as by trading account losses of $1.9 million. The company said that results for all periods have been restated for the pooling-of-interests acquisitions of First Capital Corp., on Dec. 31, 1986, and Security Financial Corp. on May 29.

title: Corning Wins Case On Patents
description: A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that Sumitomo Electric Industries of Japan had infringed on two product patents held by Corning Glass Works for optical fiber, the thin glass wires used in telecommunications.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
100 Kidder Jobs Cut in Municipals
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company said yesterday that it had decided to cut back staff in its municipal securities unit by more than 35 percent, citing poor market conditions.

People
description: * Robert J. Snyder and Lisa DuBose have been named, respectively, executive vice president, creative director and senior vice president, creative director at Kornhauser & Calene.

title: John H. G. Pell, 83, Historian
description: John H. G. Pell, a historian and financial consultant, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home on the grounds of Fort Ticonderoga, N.Y. He was 83 years old and also had homes in New York City and Newport, R.I.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Both 1986 periods' results were restated to include the accounts of four banking concerns acquired in 1987.

title: Bleak Season For the War On Apartheid
description: A police crackdown and an economic recession have set back but not broken a longstanding campaign of resistance to apartheid in this black township.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reduced by about $700,000, or 13 cents a share, as the result of the sale of the National Roll unit in August and the related termination of two pension plans. c-Includes a gain of $4.7 million, or 95 cents a share, from the replacement of an overfunded pension plan.

title: NASA's Pie in the Sky
description: LEAD: The 29-year-old National Aeronautics and Space Administration refuses to grow up. According to published summaries, a 63-page report by the former astronaut Sally K. Ride on long-term goals in space is the latest example of NASA's immaturity.

title: Mortgage Agency Adopts New Pool
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced its first issue of participation certificates backed by a pool of convertible adjustable-rate mortgages. The corporation said it was the first of the quasi-Government mortgage agencies to issue securities backed by a pool of such mortgages.

title: Only Radical Koreans Are Anti-American
description: To the Editor:

title: One Killed and 21 Injured In Explosion at Jersey Plant
description: One person was killed and 21 others were injured this morning in an explosion and fire at a plastics plant.

title: Tudor Makes One Run Count
description: His dugout was filled with aching bodies and slumping hitters. The St. Louis Cardinals had been handed one run in the sixth game of the National League Championship Series. And the thought had occurred to John Tudor, the Cardinal pitcher whose job it was to make that run count, that there may not be many more.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST CHARTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Long and Short of It
description: LEAD: In 1969, when I was in my early 20's, I wore very short skirts.

title: Latchkey Children: A New Profile Emerges
description: IN the afternoons at the Oasis After School Program at St. Matthew's and St. Timothy's Neighborhood Center in Manhattan, staff members are not given to pondering the big child-care picture. Such questions as how many latchkey children there are in America, whether they come from middle-class or low-income homes, or whether they live in cities or suburbs seem irrelevant.

title: Center Stage, From the Creative Fringe
description: Just two years ago, John Galliano's show of his spring collection was the sort of insular affair well known to those on the avant-garde fashion fringe. Though his designs were eerily beautiful, they were also twisted and artfully torn, like something a cat had clawed. Though Mr. Galliano was highly regarded, few important buyers or fashion editors paid heed.

title: U S TRUSTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iacocca to Appear
description: Lee Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation chief who has rejected the advances of Democratic leaders who think he should run for President, makes few appearances at political fund-raising events, and almost none in behalf of Republicans. But he is about to make an exception.

title: Ellis Island Gathers the Pieces of Its Past
description: A faded yellow teddy bear that passed through Ellis Island in 1920 will soon return to the main immigration building, to be displayed against the side of an open battered suitcase. The suitcase contains a German Bible with a four-leaf clover pressed inside.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special charge of $38 million for the restructuring of the company's international network. c-Net income

title: Prizing Peace, and Promoting It
description: Bernard Shaw once lamented that Nobel Prizes were like life preservers thrown long after the recipients had escaped drowning. That reproach surely does not apply to this year's Peace Prize. The award honors, and furthers, the cause of peace in Central America.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: AT the baby shower a woman confesses that, every once in a while, driving along the parkway in her car, she thinks about filling her tank and going off into the sunset, leaving the husband, the house and the two children behind. Imagine her amazement when all the guests say they've felt the same way.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Earthquake Leaves Budgets Shaken as Well
description: Randy Torres went to a disaster relief center here today with hope that he would obtain help to rebuild his earthquake-cracked home as well as resignation that any help he might receive would not cover the full cost of the damage.

title: Stress and the Lure Of Harmful Remedies
description: Although power is reputed to be the drug of choice in the nation's capital, Valium and similar tranquilizers appear to be almost as addictive.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $1,967,000 loss from discontinued dental operations.

title: And Now, the Sound of Plastic
description: What the world needs is a paper-thin piece of plastic that can be rolled into an oddly-shaped speaker that emits tinny-sounding music. No? Well that's what Japan has and the rest of us may soon get, thanks to the Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company.

title: Bush Criticizes G.O.P. Rivals on Arms Accord
description: Vice President Bush today criticized his Republican opponents, saying party loyalty demanded that they support President Reagan on an arms agreement with the Soviet Union that would eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
A Diet Need Not Exclude Meat
description: LEAD: WHEN the diet wars start, meat is often the first casualty. There is much justification for this; red meat can be a potent source of fat, calories and cholesterol. These are unworthies we are all better off without.

title: SPORTING LIFE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes extraordinary credits of $4,000 and $50,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Wallenberg Plea
description: Some members of Congress are pressing the Soviet Union to extend its ''glasnost'' policy to include some definitive word about the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who is credited with saving 100,000 Hungarian Jews from the Nazis in the last year of World War II. ''There is much debate on the true meaning of the recent Soviet glasnost,'' Representative Bill Green, a New York Republican, said at a recent commemmoration of Mr. Wallenberg's 75th birthday. ''Some Russian scholars say that the word means 'openness,' others say that it means 'propaganda.' We now present an acid test to the Soviet Union by which it can persuade us that the meaning of the word is 'openness.' ''

title: Executive Director Named for President's AIDS Commission
description: President Reagan's AIDS commission, staggered by the recent resignations of the two top panel members and two staff members, today announced the appointment of a new executive director to supervise the staff and its functions.

title: Pitcher Unable To Move 4 on Base
description: Dave Dravecky, one of the in-season additions to the San Francisco Giants' pitching staff, left no doubt again tonight about his ability from the mound end of the 60 feet 6 inches that separates pitcher from batter. However, when he stood at the other end with a bat in his hands, he left his ability and his judgment open to serious question.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Cash Overpowers Evernden: Pat Cash of Australia overpowered Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the opening round of the Australian indoor tennis championships at the Sydney Entertainment Center. The 22-year-old Australian, who is seeded third in the event and is ranked eighth in the world, put on an impressive display of serving and volleying to beat Evernden, the winner of the Queensland Open in Brisbane last week. Fourth-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia and seventh-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India also won first-round matches yesterday. An unseeded Australian, Shane Barr, upset sixth-seeded Wally Masur, 6-2, 6-3. Zivojinovic overcame Tony Mmoh of Nigeria, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1, in a match between two power-servers. Krishnan eliminated Mike DePalmer of the United States, 7-6, 7-6. Others advancing included Christian Saceanu and Eric Jelen of West Germany and Darren Cahill of Australia.(AP) Navratilova Defeats Fairbank: Martina Navratilova defeated Rosalyn Fairbank of South Africa, 6-1, 6-4, in first-round play yesterday at the $175,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament. In other matches, Bettina Bunge eliminated a fellow West German, Isabel Cueto, 7-5, 7-5; Pam Shriver defeated Claudia Porwik of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2; Zina Garrison beat a fellow American, Elise Burgin, 6-3, 6-3, and Silke Meier of West Germany defeated Catherine Tanvier of France 6-3, 4-6, 6-0. (AP) Sanchez Is Eliminated: Second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain was eliminated in the first round of the $202,500 Toulouse Open yesterday by Luis Mattar of Brazil, 6-4, 6-4. Sanchez is ranked 16th in the latest Association of Tennis Professionals list. Mattar is 71st. Third-seeded Guy Forget of France advanced easily with a 6-1, 6-2 rout over Ronald Agenor of Haiti. In other opening-round matches, fourth-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland posted a 6-1, 7-5 victory over David de Miguel of Spain, and fifth-seeded Jan Gunarsson of Sweden defeated Diego Perez of Uruguay, 6-3, 6-3.(AP)

title: What Housing Fines Could Buy
description: At the urging of President Andrew Stein, New York's City Council has voted steep raises in fines for serious building code violations - the first such increase since 1972. It's a welcome step in the right direction. But the deterrent effect of the elevated penalties depends on bolstering the city's capacity to collect.

title: House Votes Retiree Bill
description: The House approved a bill today that is intended to protect the health and life insurance benefits of retired workers whose companies enter Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Limit on Death Penalty Is Overruled in California
description: California's new Supreme Court today overruled a key decision of its liberal predecessor on the death penalty and ruled that a criminal can be executed even if he had not intended to kill.

title: Mysteries of New York Write-In Ballot Revealed
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $15 million, or 14 cents a share, pretax gain from the sale of Discover magazine for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a $351 million pretax gain, or $3.91 a share, from the initial public offering of shares in its cable television company, American Television & Communications Corp., and from the sale of its interest in Temple- Inland Inc.; the gain was partially offset by a pretax charge of $50 million related to the costs of relocating Time Inc.'s, subscription fulfillment operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. Primary share figures were not reported.

title: McEnroe Blames TV
description: John McEnroe isn't making any excuses about his behavior in the United States Open last month, which led to a two-month suspension from the Nabisco Grand Prix tennis circuit. But he remains convinced that television had a lot to do with the punishment he received for his actions during a third-round match. For years, McEnroe has argued against having a television technician sit on court with a boom mike designed to pick up the sound of the ball. ''There shouldn't be one of those mikes on the court,'' McEnroe said Monday night after a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Miloslav Mecir in the Michelin Challenge Series, an exhibition round-robin event. ''There need to be decisions by the players and they need to get together. I would receive a percentage of less money to get things done to improve the quality.''

title: About New York; Closeout Mania: Pig-Shaped Fans And Canned Kiwi
description: Howard Snyder's desk is next to a window overlooking the showroom of Odd Job Trading, so he can hear the friendly clatter of 12 cash registers. Calms the nerves, he says.

Page A1 Wright says award for Arias dooms contra aid A14 An Iranian missile hit a school in Baghdad as pupils were filing into the building for class. The explosion killed 32 people and wounded 218, nearly all of them children, witnesses and school officials said. A3 A candidate for President was killed in Haiti. Yves Volel was shot to death in front of the police headquarters as he delivered a speech demanding the release of a prisoner, witnesses and diplomats said. description: ''I'll try to find one that they'll object to just as much as they did to this one.'' -President Reagan, on next Supreme Court nominee. [ A1:4. ]

description: The stock price of American Cablesystems soared more than 60 percent today after the company announced it would be acquired and taken private by its Boston-based competitor, Continental Cablevision Inc., for $481.7 million.

title: Austrian Bid on Trade
description: Austria's Foreign Minister, Alois Mock, said today that his nation wanted ''full participation'' in the European Community's tariff-free internal market without formally joining the trade bloc. Mr. Mock spoke at a news conference during a visit to the Netherlands. The European bloc's 12 nations will deregulate all internal trade by 1992.

description: b-Net income

title: Fokker Stock Falls
description: Shares in N.V. Fokker, the Dutch aircraft maker, fell sharply on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange on news of major cash problems and costly delays in the introduction of two new aircraft. The stock, barred from trading Tuesday when the company announced it was seeking extra cash from the Government and banks, sold today for as low as 37.70 guilders, or $18.43, down more than one-third from Monday's closing price. It later recovered slightly to trade around 43 guilders, or $21, in what stockbrokers described as frantic business. Fokker, once riding high on the success of the F-27 Friendship, has run into trouble with the start-up of two craft: the F-50 propfan, set to replace the F-27, and the short-range F-100 jetliner.

title: Taiwan to Allow Travel to Chinese Mainland
description: The governing Nationalist Party removed another barrier between Taiwan and China today by announcing that Taiwan residents would be allowed to visit relatives on the mainland.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect the 25 percent stock dividend to be paid in November.

title: U.S. ACCUSED OF ALTERING RECORDS IN RACKETS TRIAL
description: A defense lawyer has accused Federal agents of altering transcripts of taped conversations to bolster the prosecution's case in a major racketeering trial in Manhattan.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Where $100 Goes a Long Way
description: There have always been questions about how much American foreign aid actually trickles down to the poor. Too often, it seems the funds disappear into bureaucratic channels, or pockets. By contrast, private voluntary organizations have built an impressive record of reaching poor people abroad -and doing so with remarkably small amounts of money.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Limit Voted on AIDS Funds
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a measure requiring federally financed educational materials about AIDS to stress sexual abstinence and forbidding it to promote homosexuality or drug use.

title: Stage: 'Burn This,' by Wilson
description: FROM his first New York appearance - as the mangy outlaw brother in Sam Shepard's ''True West'' - John Malkovich has been a combustive figure on stage, threatening to incinerate everyone and everything around him with his throbbing vocal riffs, bruiser's posture and savage, unfocused eyes. If you're going to write a play called ''Burn This,'' as Lanford Wilson now has, Mr. Malkovich is surely the man to fan its flames.

description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation's board today rejected as inadequate a sweetened $6.62 billion takeover bid from the Dart Group.

Prefight Rhetoric Pulls No Punches
description: There was name-calling and general nastiness today - a rhetorical club fight, so to speak - in the final news conference preceding Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Tyrell Biggs here Friday.

title: Van Arsdale Named
description: Dick Van Arsdale, the first player chosen by the Phoenix Suns in their 1968 expansion draft and interim head coach for the team's final 26 games last season, was named yesterday as the club's vice president. The team was sold Monday for $44.5 million to a group headed by Jerry Colangelo, the general manager throughout the Suns' history. Van Arsdale, a former Knick, has a financial interest in the new ownership group.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $250,000. The company said that income for the latest third quarter was adversely affected by expenses of about 19 cents a share as a result of the UIS Inc. tender offer.

title: Warn AIDS Patients' Partners, Health Official Urges
description: Proposing a sharp break from established policy and state regulations, New York City's top health official said yesterday that physicians and public health authorities should warn the sex partners of people infected with the AIDS virus of their substantial risk of infection.

title: Unesco Director Fails To Get Majority Again
description: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, running for a third term as Unesco's Director General, placed first again tonight in the executive board's fourth ballot and again failed to achieve the required majority - but for the first time received fewer votes than in the previous round.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results include a charge of $64,150 from Decor's disposition of municipal bonds.

title: Surgery for Barfield
description: Jesse Barfield, the Toronto Blue Jays' outfielder, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to have a small cartilage tear in his left knee repaired. The Blue Jays said Barfield injured the knee in the team's series Sept. 17-20 in New York. The Blue Jays also said that Tony Fernandez, the shortstop, is to undergo an arthroscopic examination of his left knee today. He injured the knee Aug. 8 at Cleveland diving for a ground ball. The All-Star shortstop is also recovering from a broken right elbow suffered Sept. 24 in a game against Detroit.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Guinness Case Bail at $825,000
description: Gerald Ronson, one of Britain's richest men, was remanded on $:500,000, or $825,000, bail today on eight charges stemming from the Guinness P.L.C. takeover of Distillers P.L.C.

description: I SOMETIMES have reveries about owning a cabin on a blue-ribbon trout stream.

description: A retired school psychologist arrested last week on charges of sexually molesting two boys has been accused of sexually molesting a third student.

title: Target: Driving While Drunk
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company will use its sponsorship of the World Series to present its new 30-second commercial in support of S.A.D.D., Students Against Driving Drunk.

title: CBS Income Rises Sharply
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter net income more than doubled, with its records unit reporting higher earnings than its broadcasting group for only the second time ever.

title: A Fragment of History Is Uncovered in Maine
description: After spending three years thrashing the dense woods here with machetes and pacing the rocky logging trails with metal detectors, a team of aviation history buffs has uncovered fragments of a narrow stick they believe is part of an airplane that vanished without a trace 60 years ago.

The latest third quarter net includes a net gain of $16.1 million from the sale of a food service foil and foil container business and it also reflects a loss provision of $13 million to cover costs related to a reduction in corporate staff. The latest 9 months' loss is after net restructuring charges of $387 million. It also reflects the third quarter net gain of $16.1 million and the charge of $13 million in the quarter.

title: Genuine Solution Needed for Dumping Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeast Governors Think They're on the Right Track With Turbo Train
description: The trip from Boston's Back Bay to midtown Manhattan is a choice between a 35-minute flight that air and highway traffic can stretch to four and a half hours, and a ride on a train that is almost sure to arrive on schedule as promised by Amtrak - in four and a half hours.

title: Filling Wood Pores for a Clean Finish
description: LEAD: To achieve a flawless mirrorlike finish on a piece of furniture, the wood pores must be filled to surface level. Traditionally, cabinetmakers used varnish or shellac, which made sense for woods with fine pores.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Paris dispatch yesterday about the voting for a director general of Unesco misidentified one candidate.

title: BUSH OFFENDS CYSTIC FIBROSIS GROUP
description: A chance misstatement by Vice President Bush has demonstrated the phenomenal capacity of high-level Government officials to influence the fortunes of others, even a charitable organization dedicated to helping sick children.

title: 7th Straight Yield Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday. It was the seventh consecutive advance.

title: Sears Unit to Close 40 Savings Offices
description: Dean Witter Financial Services Group, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, said it would close all 40 Sears Savings Bank branches in Sears stores in California. Sears Savings Bank would keep its headquarters office in Glendale, Calif. The 40 branches represent deposits of about $280 million out of the savings bank's total deposit base of $3.9 billion.

title: THERMWOOD CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Gannett Net Up by 7.6%
description: The Gannett Company today reported a 7.6 percent gain in third-quarter earnings, reflecting continued strength in its newspaper operations. Net income was $70.5 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $65.5 million, or 41 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The company's revenues rose 9 percent, to $751.1 million, from $689 million. John J. Curley, president and chief executive, said the results reflected the strength of newspaper operations, highlighted by USA Today, where paid advertising pages were up 21 percent.

title: Talking Deals; Latitude Seen In G.M.'s Pact
description: THE labor contract that the General Motors Corporation has tentatively worked out with the United Auto Workers appears to handicap G.M.'s efforts to cut costs because the terms include a moratorium on plant closings. But a careful reading of the contract and talks with people close to the union suggest that the agreement may be less restrictive than it initially appeared.

description: Fiscal 1987 first-quarter results are restated to reflect acquisitions made by the company in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1986.

title: Concert: Milstein At the Y
description: ABOUT 10 months ago, Nathan Milstein canceled all engagements after a fall that injured his arm, and since the great violinist is in his 80's, his admirers may have wondered with concern whether he would be able to return to his former technical command after so long a layoff.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Girls Do Not Support State On Howard Beach Incident
description: Two teen-age girls called to testify for the prosecution yesterday in the Howard Beach murder trial did not support key elements of the prosecution's account of the encounter between a group of white youths and three black men.

title: Reagan Points to a Critic, Who Points Out It Isn't So
description: While President Reagan was accusing critics of Judge Robert H. Bork of ''distortion and disinformation'' in his address on the Supreme Court nominee today, it seemed to one critic that Mr. Reagan was doing some distorting of his own.

title: P.L.O. Given 6 More Weeks To Close Washington Office
description: The State Department has given the Washington office that represents the Palestine Liberation Organization a six-week extension on an order that it be closed, a spokesman said today.

title: Ryan and 3 Others Are Back With Jets
description: The striking Jets suffered more defections this afternoon when Pat Ryan, one of the team's most popular players, led a parade of strikers into camp to join the replacement team.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Oct. 15.

title: Few Models Seen for Los Angeles School Plan
description: In putting its schools on a year-round schedule, the Board of Education in Los Angeles has taken a step that has little precedent in other countries.

description: Includes unrealized venture capital gains of 19 and 13 cents a share for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for the year-ago periods includes unrealized venture capital writedowns of 2 and 16 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Now That Titanic's Found, On to Lusitania
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; A Traveler in Search of Glasnost in Leningrad
description: A recent conversation here with two writers, Dmitri Volcheck and Arkadi Dzagomoshehenko, and a theater director, Eric Gorashevski, offers a close-up of how glasnost, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of ''openness,'' is affecting three people on or beyond the fringes of the Soviet cultural establishment.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The year-ago periods ended Sept. 27.

title: Beck Is Retiring Because of Injury
description: An action portrait of Barry Beck hangs alone on a wall in his agent's Manhattan office. Beck, the defenseman and former captain of the Rangers, is on the ice at Madison Square Garden, staring ahead intently and executing a difficult crossover step at the blue line. It is a startling photograph, one that conveys Beck's formidable power and presence.

title: Homelessness Reaches Into Rural Area
description: For Dawn Crowe and her family, home has been a cruel place these last few years.

title: Mitsubishi Motors
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said it had suspended output of four-wheel-drive Pajero vehicles intended for October shipment to the United States because American customs officials had proposed changing the Pajero's classification. A company spokesman said the Custom House in Long Beach, Calif., had proposed classifying the model as a car rather than as a commercial vehicle. Such a move could reduce Mitsubishi's exports of other cars to the United States. Under Japanese car makers' self-imposed export restraints, Mitsubishi holds car shipments to the United States to about 195,000 a year. It shipped some 30,000 Pajeros to the United States in 1986.

title: The Right to Take Risks in the Gulf
description: What if U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf should come under heavy attack from Iran? A month ago, the right response might well have been to get out of harm's way. The Reagan Administration didn't seem to know what it was doing and couldn't be trusted with a military response. Since then, by developing a coherent policy, the Administration has been earning the right to take risks.

title: Space Junk Emits Clatter From Coast to Coast
description: Today, three days after a strange object burned through the Northern California sky and landed between the homes of Everett Danforth and Charles Millerin Lakeport, Calif., the three-pound piece of metal had become the object of diplomatic discussion in Washington.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
WELL-FLUNG PIES A SMASH AT SCHOOL
description: The 20th anniversary reunion of the graduates of Clown College may not have been the world's most distinguished alumni celebration, but it could have been the funniest.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Head Sees Mega-Agency Decline
description: Interestingly enough, Charles D. Peebler Jr., chief executive of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, chose yesterday to predict the decline of the mega-agencies, with Saatchi & Saatchi leading the way.

title: 3 Killed as a Stove Fire Spreads Through Home
description: Three people died early today when a stove fire spread through a two-story house, officials said.

description: A two-alarm fire in Woodhaven, Queens, destroyed five houses and left 12 families homeless yesterday, fire officials said.

description: The St. Louis Cardinals, baseball's masters of survival, survived extravagantly tonight when they whipped the San Francisco Giants, 6-0, and won their third National League pennant in six years.

description: United Buying Services of New York, which for 30 years has enabled members of various organizations to buy discounted merchandise, is going to make its services available to to the public. It has hired the Penchina, Selkowitz agency to help.

description: Vice President Bush, detailing the economic agenda he would pursue as President, called today for cuts of nearly half in the maximum capital gains tax for individuals.

description: State Department officials said yesterday that, for the first time ever, a woman was about to be named as the United States ambassador to a Middle Eastern country.

title: BIRMINGHAM MAYOR EASILY DEFEATS 3
description: Richard Arrington Jr., this city's first black Mayor, handily defeated three rivals Tuesday to win election to his third four-year term, burnishing his image as a power in Alabama politics and a proved vote-getter.

STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rolls-Royce Order
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British aircraft engine maker, said that it was selling engines worth about $:70 million, or $115.2 million, to an Australian leasing company to power a new fleet of Boeing 757 airliners. Deliveries of the six aircraft to Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services, a subsidiary of Ansett Transport Industries, are expected to start in early 1989. The value of the engine order reflects the expected service life of the planes, Rolls-Royce said.

description: Floating Point Systems Inc., a supercomputer maker based in Beaverton, Ore., said that C.N. (Norm) Winningstad, the company's principal founder, had been elected chairman. He has been vice chairman since October 1986, and also serves as chairman and chief executive of the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation.

description: Donald J. Trump won the city concession yesterday to operate the Wollman and Lasker skating rinks in Central Park.

description: On Tuesday Vice President Bush challenged his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination to support the proposed intermediate-range missile treaty with the Soviet Union. The challenge put Mr. Bush in two places he wanted to be: for President Reagan and for arms control.

description: b-Net loss

description: ''Now more than ever I am going to insist that a negotiated cease-fire in Nicaragua is indispensable if we are to achieve lasting peace in Central America.'' - President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. [ A1:4. ]

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After a tax benefit of $52,000.

title: MARKETS PLUNGE
description: The nation's trade deficit shrank in August from its record level, but the improvement was only half as much as expected and sent prices sharply lower in the financial markets.

title: Bridge: Team From Taiwan Leads In World Championships
description: A squad from Taiwan, playing with great accuracy, led in the World Team Championships here tonight at the midpoint of qualifying play. On Tuesday the Taiwan team scored big victories over Jamaica and Britain and overtook the leaders.

title: West's Economy: Gorbachev's Stake
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's emphasis on domestic reform is the most important new fact in East-West relations. It provides the opportunity to lower tensions and to reduce the risk of confrontation that could lead to nuclear war.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the acquisition of Symtron Corp. on May 11.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter includes $2.9 million in after-tax gains from the restructuring of the company's securities portfolio.

title: New Pan Am Plan Asks Big Union Concessions
description: A group of airline experts representing Kirk Kerkorian has presented to a coalition of unions a proposal to take over Pan American World Airways that requires greater concessions from its workers than current management has asked.

title: Opera: A 'Chinese' Work, in England
description: Judith Weir is a composer practically unknown in the United States. But her first full-dress operatic score, ''A Night at the Chinese Opera,'' was enthusiastically greeted by British critics at its premiere in July. Now it has been taken on tour through southern England by the Kent Opera, for which it was commissioned by the BBC; I caught up with it at Canterbury's renovated Marlowe Theater tonight.

title: 'Burn This'
description: FROM his first New York appearance - as the mangy outlaw brother in Sam Shepard's ''True West'' - John Malkovich has been a combustive figure on stage, threatening to incinerate everyone and everything around him with his throbbing vocal riffs, bruiser's posture and savage, unfocused eyes. If you're going to write a play called ''Burn This,'' as Lanford Wilson now has, Mr. Malkovich is surely the man to fan its flames.

title: Corporate Concern for Victims of Rape
description: Seven years ago, a saleswoman for the Du Pont Company was raped by a customer. Her work performance deteriorated, but it wasn't until her boss confronted her that she reported the assault. Her boss realized then that he was at a loss to help her.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from disposal of discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the quarter and 9 months; an extraordinary loss of $200,000 from the extinguishment of debt for the both periods, and the 9 months also includes income from discontinued operations of $3.1 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $22.7 million for the quarter and $16 million for the 9 months; losses from disposal of discontinued operations of $5.4 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 9 months, and an extraordinary loss of $11.8 million from debt extinguishment for the 9 months.

title: TV Review; Two Comedy Specials, On Showtime and HBO
description: REFLECTING the boom in stand-up-comedy clubs across the country, pay-cable has been on a clever roll with a series of very funny ''in performance'' specials. Two new additions have entered the schedules: ''Elayne Boosler Broadway Baby'' on Showtime and ''On Location: The 11th Annual Young Comedians Show'' on Home Box Office.

title: Managing to Worry, and Win
description: A TELEVISION screen in the clubhouse of the National League champions showed the happy madness in the streets of St. Louis. Champagne corks were discarded on the floor of the home clubhouse at Busch Stadium, and the new hats that some of the Cardinals wore had ''World Series'' written on them.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months include $23 million of additional provisions for foreign loans.

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 5
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1.3 million and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $11.5 million. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1.1 million and $3.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ORION PICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
At Random House, After the Ouster
description: Countering charges by book industry rivals that he had effectively sidetracked talk of succession when he forced Howard Kaminsky to resign Tuesday as publisher of Random House, Robert L. Bernstein said yesterday that ''four or five'' people in the company were being groomed to succeed him.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Witherspoon Wins by Decision: Tim Witherspoon won a 10-round split decision last night against previously undefeated Mike Williams in a battle of heavyweights in Atlantic City. It was the second victory for Witherspoon since he lost his World Boxing Association heavyweight title to James (Bonecrusher) Smith last December in a one-round knockout. Judge Richard Strange scored the fight 98-92 for Williams. But Eva Shainn (96-94) and Tom Kaczmarek (97-94) gave the bout to Witherspoon. Witherspoon, now 27-3, put on a late surge of punching that left Williams (13-1) with swelling beneath both eyes and a bloody mouth. Tennis Lendl and Becker Easy Winners: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia and Boris Becker of West Germany, the defending champion, posted straight-set victories yesterday in the opening round of the Australian Indoor championships in Sydney. Lendl, the No. 1 player in the world, romped to a 6-2, 6-4 triumph over Peter Doohan of Australia, and the second-seeded Becker powered his way to a 6-4, 6-0 victory over Tim Pawsat, an American qualifier. In another opening-round match, Paul Annacone beat Paul McNamee of Australia, 2-6, 6-1, 7-5. Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion from Australia, and Scott Davis and Marty Davis of the United States won second-round matches. (AP) Mayotte Breezes Past Jones: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte breezed through Mis first-round match at the Toulouse Open, beating a fellow American, Kelly Jones, 6-4, 6-3. (AP) Evert Defeats Marsikova: Second-seeded Chris Evert beat Regina Marsikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday to advance to the second round of the $175,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany. Fifth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina also gained the second round, while third-seeded Pam Shriver and fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia gained the third round. Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, who did not play yesterday, moved into the second round on Tuesday. (AP) Soccer Seton Hall Ties Columbia; Columbia and Seton Hall, ranked seventh and eighth, respectively, in the national collegiate soccer poll, played to a 1-1 overtime tie at the Columbia soccer stadium last night. Kingsley Chin put Columbia in front with his eighth goal just 5 minutes 45 seconds into the match, but Seton Hall drew even when Pat O'Kelly scored with 2:10 elapsed in the second half. Both teams threatened to score again, but the goalkeepers, Jeff Micheli of Columbia and David Nolan of Seton Hall, made several spectacular saves. The game ended a streak of six consecutive shutouts for Columbia, which is 6-1-2. Seton Hall is 7-2-3. Horse Racing Just Smashing Wins by a Head: Just Smashing, ridden by Chris Antley, was up in the final strides to win by a head yesterday in the $42,000 Restless Life Purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Belmont Park. Grand Creation, an outsider in the field of eight, finished second, a neck ahead of Poculation, another long shot. The victory was the third in 10 starts this year for the 5-year-old daughter of Explodent-Brilliant Review, who went seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:24 2/5 to earn $25,200 for Bright View Farm. She returned $5 for $2 to win(AP) N.H.L. North Stars 4, Maple Leafs 3: Dino Ciccarelli, playing his first game after a three-game suspension, had a goal and an assist for Minnesota. Ciccarelli, who scored 52 goals last year, missed Minnesota's first three games, two losses and a tie, because he bumped a linesman during a preseason game.(AP) Blackhawks 5, Blues 3: Doug Wilson's long slap shot, his second goal of the game, broke a 3-3 tie at 4:54 of the third period. Wilson's shot past Greg Millen came on a power play after the Blues had been penalized for having too many men on the ice. (AP)

title: HARLAND, JOHN H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Center to Promote Study the of Arts in Schools
description: The Department of Education and the National Endowment for the Arts announced plans today for a national research center to promote the study of the performing and fine arts in schools.

title: 2 Die in Plane Crash; Man Jumps and Lives
description: A passenger apparently leaped from a small airplane as it crashed into a residential backyard, killing two others on board.

title: Test of Freedom
description: The Reagan Administration has taken an important step to bring American law into line with our professions of faith in freedom. It has recommended dropping from the immigration laws the sections that exclude aliens because of their beliefs or writings.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Mergers At Saatchi, Omnicom
description: CORPORATE realignments were reported yesterday at the world's two largest advertising agency holding companies, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company in London and the Omnicom Group in New York.

title: A Gift for France
description: LEAD: In less than two years, France will celebrate the bicentennial of the Revolution. In the wake of the rehabilitation of that superb French gift to the American people, the Statue of Liberty, it behooves America to do something generous and thoughtful for the people of France, our oldest ally.

title: Budget Aide Moves
description: Edwin L. Dale Jr., top press aide at the Office of Management and Budget since David A. Stockman became budget director at the start of the Reagan Administration, is moving out. Mr. Dale, once a reporter for The New York Times, is to become a counselor to C. William Verity, whom the Senate confirmed Tuesday as Secretary of Commerce to succeed the late Malcolm Baldrige.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How It Happened; Cards Got Big Hits From Light Hitters
description: The St. Louis Cardinals won the National League pennant without Jack Clark hitting a home run and without Vince Coleman stealing a base until the ending had been written. How, then, did they win the pennant?

title: Bomb Hits U.S. Office in Spain
description: A bomb exploded today outside the United States Consulate in this Mediterranean port city, wounding eight Spaniards and seriously damaging the building, the police said.

title: RJR Nabisco in 19.4% Gain
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said today that third-quarter earnings rose 19.4 percent, to $320 million, or $1.24 a share, from $268 million, or 97 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 4.6 percent, to $3.83 billion, from $3.66 billion.

title: Metro Matters; Keeping Dreyfus: Just How Much Should City Do?
description: How far should city government go to keep an industry or even a single company from leaving town?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1987
description: The Economy

title: BAKER, FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acquisitions Down 37%
description: The number of mergers and acquisitions announced in the third quarter fell 37 percent, to 568, from a record 908 a year ago, W. T. Grimm & Company, the consulting firm, said today. The company said the total value of announced deals rose 93 percent, to $70.2 billion, from $36.4 billion last year. An increase in the number of deals valued at more than $1 billion accounted for the higher total value, it said. Year-to-date, the number of acquisition announcements fell 39 percent, to 1,495, from 2,435, while total value rose to $161.5 billion, from $113.5 billion last year, Grimm said.

title: Verity Aide Appointed
description: Edwin L. Dale Jr., spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget since 1981, will become a top aide to the new Secretary of Commerce, C. William Verity Jr., Administration officials said today. Mr. Dale will be a counselor to Mr. Verity, who was confirmed by the Senate on Tuesday and is expected to be sworn in soon.

title: Vacuuming Woes
description: SOME of the things Solomon Sumner and Richard Miller have discovered clogging vacuum cleaners: stockings, wine corks, toys, thumbtacks, nails, neckties, Christmas tree decorations, plant leaves, underwear and shoelaces.

title: Problem in Shuttle Engine
description: One of the three main engines scheduled to power the first space shuttle flight since the shuttle disaster in January 1986 might have sprung a leak in test firing, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today. The spokesman said the firing of the engine on Saturday appeared to be normal but that a detailed check of the engine indicated a potential leak in the oxidizer heat exchanger. He said tests were continuing and that it would be a few days before it is known if there is indeed a leak.

title: Kemp Borrows $600,000 in Move to Raise Money
description: While the Presidential campaign of Representative Jack F. Kemp has raised a respectable $5.6 million, it was still forced to borrow $600,000 this summer because of its risky financial strategy of emphasizing costly mail solicitations.

title: A Cache of Accessories
description: WENDY M. WEAVER used to work in the Graham Gallery in Manhattan, but she wanted to own a store that sold antique and reproduction furniture and accessories. The interior designer David Easton, a friend, had an empty storefront beneath his office, and a cache of 18th- and 19th-century French and English antique furniture that he was happy to sell. They joined forces, and last month Miss Weaver, above, opened Portmerion Ltd.

title: PONCE FEDERAL BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. Groups Fight Subpoenas for Records
description: In the first challenge to the authority of the new State Commission on Integrity in Government, New York Republican leaders are resisting subpoenas for their confidential party financial records.

title: Soda Bottlers Face Charges
description: The Justice Department said today that it had filed criminal price-fixing charges against three large soft-drink bottling companies in Maryland and Georgia and four of their former top executives.

AMR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

AMR said for the latest 9 months it had a gain of $14.6 million related to the sale of certain property rights. Both year-ago periods are restated for a pension accounting change.

title: Possible Railroad Suitor Runs Property Empire
description: Howard Kaskel, leader of the investment group that has raised its stake in Kansas City Southern Industries to 9.73 percent and might seek control of the company, would be a newcomer to takeover wars. Most of the 50-year-old real estate developer's career has been spent expanding on the property empire his father, Alfred Kaskel, began building in New York in the 1930's.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter net reflects tax benefits resulting from the additional $400 million provision for loan losses made in the 1987 second quarter. The amount of the tax benefits was not disclosed. The loss for the latest 9 months reflects the impact of the addition to loan loss reserves of $400 million in the second quarter.

title: U.S. INQUIRY IN AMTRAK CRASH FINDS A KEY SWITCH WORKING
description: The switching mechanism that is the focus of an investigation into the crash of an Amtrak train in which 126 people were injured worked perfectly when tested, Federal safety officials said Tuesday.

description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,480,000 for the quarter and $1,868,000 for the year. c-Include a loss from discontinued operations of $1,796,000.

A Formal Resignation Is Scheduled by Brock
description: Labor Secretary William E. Brock has scheduled a news conference for late this morning to announce he is resigning from President Reagan's Cabinet to be chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign.

title: Apple's Profits Surge on Sales of New Products
description: Apple Computer Inc., benefiting from strong sales of new products and the rebound in the personal computer industry, today reported substantial gains in net income and revenues for its fourth-fiscal quarter and the fiscal year.

title: Prices Plunge on Trade Data Key U.S. Bond At 10.151%
description: Bond prices plummeted yesterday, as dealers sold securities heavily after the release of August's disappointing trade figures.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Piano: Olli Mustonen
description: OLLI MUSTONEN, a 20-year-old Finnish pianist of striking talent and an artistic demeanor likely to provoke frustration and even annoyance along with admiration, made his local debut Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y under the auspices of Young Concert Artists. Mr. Mustonen began with the first five preludes and fugues from Book Two of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier,'' and before the first was over it was apparent that he is a player of consequence.

title: Summit and Ultra Set Bank Merger
description: The Summit Bancorporation said it had agreed to acquire the Ultra Bancorporation of Bridgewater, N.J., in a tax-free exchange of stock valued at $250 million. The deal, subject to shareholder and regulatory approval, would create New Jersey's fifth-largest bank holding company. Assets would total $3.9 billion.

title: Manila Hotel Bomb Wounds 10
description: A bomb exploded today outside one of the capital's most popular hotels, wounding at least 10 people slightly. Officials ordered extra security at hotels and restaurants to prevent more attacks.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest third quarter and 9 months include an after-tax capital gain of $154 million from the divestiture of 104 hospitals. Those results also include a $73 million increase in allowances for doubtful accounts and a $126 million writedown of investments and properties. Revenue and earnings of the divested hospitals are excluded from the company's financial results beginning Sept. 1.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Oslo dispatch yesterday about the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize misstated the year in which the prize was given to an anti-nuclear physicians' organization. The group, the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, received the prize in 1985.

title: INSIDE
description: Exit Visa for Dissident The Soviet Government told Vladimir Slepak, a prominent Jewish dissident, that he and his wife would soon be allowed to emigrate. Page A3. Progress in N.F.L. Strike Negotiators for the owners and the players agreed on three of five conditions that would bring an end to the 23-day-old football strike. Page B15. Hard Fighting in Sri Lanka India said 30 of its peacekeeping troops had been killed trying to capture a Tamil rebel redoubt. Page A3. AIDS Warning Urged New York City's top health official said physicians should warn sex partners of AIDS patients that they are at high risk of infection. Page B1. The Beauty of Ugly What's as wide as Mike Tyson's fist, as hairy as a coconut and the inspiration of a minister? Page B1.

title: Armand Hammer in Afghan Role
description: Armand Hammer, the American industrialist who has maintained close ties with the Soviet Government since its early days, said today that he was shuttling between the Soviet Union, Pakistan and Afghanistan in hopes of producing a settlement to the Afghan war.

title: 2 Big Oil Spills Traced to One Tanker
description: Questions have been raised about the structural integrity of a tanker in the Alaska oil trade that has dumped almost 40,000 barrels of petroleum into the North Pacific in two major spills this year.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOSPITAL STAFFING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $84,000.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The New Jersey Wastewater Treatment Trust, a newly established authority to help finance the waste-water projects of municipalities, made its first debt offering yesterday. It totaled $132.4 million in two competitive issues.

title: Jazz: Weston Trio
description: Randy Weston's roots are in the music of Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, but his music also reflects the years he spent living in Africa. In traditional African music, rhythms are layered vertically, and each layer of rhythm is given its own specific timbre, its own voice. This is a difficult concept to translate into ensemble jazz, which uses independent voices to both reinforce and elaborate on a common pulse.

title: Level of Aid for Schools on Probation Is Assailed
description: The Board of Education and the Schools Chancellor have failed to provide needed support to New York City schools placed on probation, the chairman of the City Council's Education Committee said yesterday.

title: Nobel Work: Critics Come With the Job
description: For the members of the Norwegian Nobel Committee charged with selecting winners of the annual Peace Prize, the criticism and controversy that have so often accompanied the award are an integral part of the job - and perhaps part of the fun.

title: A Dole-Dole Dilemma
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, appeared in this early-primary state this week and faced up to one of the most interesting questions of the campaign: What about a Dole-Dole ticket next year?

title: Acquittal of Zaccaro Puts His Prosecutors on Spot
description: The question will be debated within legal and political circles for some time: Was the bribery and extortion case against John A. Zaccaro, the Queens businessman and husband of the former Vice-Presidential candidate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, so weak that it should never have been brought?

title: Suit Filed Over Composition Of the Federal Panel on AIDS
description: Two groups filed suit in Federal court today seeking to block the work of President Reagan's AIDS commission until it is reshaped to include members with specific kinds of cexpertise on the disease.

title: INNOVATIVE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $184,000.

title: Yiddish Theater Show Canceled Over Dispute
description: A dispute between the Yiddish National Theater and the Hotel Carter has led to the cancellation of the company's production of ''Mirele Efros,'' which was to have opened last night at a 200-seat theater in the hotel.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
THE MODEL AS MUSEUM: NO CLUTTER, NO DUST
description: ALTHOUGH their styles differ, Elaine Lewis and Woody Goldfein agree that decorating model apartments is nothing like decorating for homeowners.

title: Taylor, Rutledge Return to Work
description: The solidarity of the striking Giants was dented today when four players, including Lawrence Taylor, reported to the team.

title: NESB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock ownership in August 1986.

title: State Offering Help at Creedmoor For New York City's Ill Homeless
description: New York State announced yesterday that it would set aside a 50-bed unit at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens for homeless people with severe mental illnesses who are hospitalized involuntarily by New York City.

title: Safeway Sells Unit; Shift Set at Lucky
description: Safeway Stores Inc., which is based in Oakland, Calif., said today that it had agreed to sell its Oklahoma division to a new company formed by Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York-based leveraged buyout firm. The deal, which is contingent upon the execution of a new labor contract, includes a distribution center, three supply plants and 106 supermarkets in Oklahoma, southern Kansas and Texas. Terms were not disclosed. Separately, Lucky Stores Inc., based in Dublin, Calif., said it would transfer its 105 Eagle Food Stores to a newly formed limited partnership that includes Lucky, Eagle management, and Odyssey Partners, a New York investment firm. Under the terms of the agreement, Lucky would invest $4 million in cash for a 40 percent interest in the partnership and would transfer the assets of its Midwestern division.

title: New York Groups Assail Moynihan Welfare Plan
description: Four long-established private New York City social welfare agencies yesterday attacked welfare legislation proposed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan as a ''sham reform'' and called upon the Senate to delay action on the bill until next year.

title: BURNHAM PACIFIC PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company previously operated on a fiscal year ending Sept. 30, before converting to a real estate investment trust from a limited partnership on March 31.

title: Action Delayed On Florida Tax
description: The state's legislative leaders adjourned a second special session today without acting on the state's controversial services tax.

title: The Stage: 'Brain Cafe,' at La Mama
description: IT takes Bob - if that is his name - an hour to get a sandwich in ''Brain Cafe,'' but we know at the outset of this elegant piece at La Mama E. T. C., performed by the Otrabanda Company, that this wild singles scene is disorderly. Before anyone speaks, a counterman, a waitress and two male customers move in dumb show to Blue Gene Tyranny's music as though all their limbs came disjointed and each arm and leg were flailing to its own rhtyhm.

title: HCA Income Climbs 24%
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 24 percent, to $66.5 million, or 80 cents a share, up from $53.8 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue declined to $1.16 billion from $1.24 billion.

title: RAYONIER TIMBERLANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are in class A units.

title: Nuclear Agency Rebuts Charge It Sacrificed Safety
description: Members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today defended its recent efforts to hold down the nuclear industry's costs by requiring fewer safety-related changes in reactor equipment.

title: Chemistry and Physics Nobels Hail Discoveries on Life and Superconductors; 2 Get Nobel for Unlocking Superconductivity Secret
description: With a swiftness that echoed the rush of discovery over the last few months, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded yesterday to two scientists in Switzerland whose breakthrough just last year has touched off a torrent of research in the long-dormant field of superconductivity.

title: TBC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Record 95.46 Drop Puts Dow at 2,412.70
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday after a negative report on the nation's trade heightened Wall Street's concern about the weak dollar and rising interest rates.

title: Letter: On Foreign Trade; Act on Dumping as GATT Does
