description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan Publisher Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the dismissal of criminal charges against John McGoff, a Michigan newspaper publisher who was accused of failing to register as an agent for the Government of South Africa.

title: A Portable Sauna To Ward Off Cold
description: LEAD: IT was the cold of the Adirondack winters that inspired Maarten van Dijk's portable wood-burning sauna. Built from spruce and steel in his shop in the woods near Bloomingdale, N.Y., where he lives with his wife, Farland, and their three children, Ciona, Celka and Timon, the distinctive van Dijk & Daughters saunas have been popping up in backyards from Lake Placid to northern New Jersey and the Hudson

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
City Hospitals Overcrowded, Officials Say
description: New York City's municipal and voluntary hospitals are suddenly overloaded, with emergency rooms backed up, hundreds of patients awaiting beds and ambulances being diverted from one institution to another, officials testified yesterday.

title: New Raids by Iran and Iraq Are Reported in Gulf
description: An Iranian gunboat fired on a tanker today, shipping officials reported, and Iraq said its warplanes raided a ship near Iran's main oil terminal in the northern Persian Gulf.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Julius Seligson, the longtime championship tennis player, omitted his survivors yesterday.

title: JAN BELL MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SILICON GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits for the latest and year-ago periods.

title: CANRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid March 2. The results of operations for the latest periods include the effects of the acquisition of certain assets and the business of the Measurement Systems division of Page-Wilson Corp., effective March 29, 1987.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 15, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Collectible Crib Quilts: Miniature Artworks
description: THE passion for full-scale American quilts, which has continued apace since the 70's, has spawned an avid interest in crib quilts as well. Today, the miniature size of crib quilts -generally 30 to 45 inches square -has made them increasingly desirable as wall hangings. In fact, these miniatures may at times outshine versions of more imposing size.

title: Two More Suspects Arrested in Slaying Of Nightclub Owner
description: Two more suspects were arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the slaying last month of a midtown Manhattan nighclub operator, the police said.

title: Corporations Seek Policy for AIDS in Workplace
description: Many of the nation's largest companies met here this week to draft a policy for dealing with AIDS in the workplace that would serve as a model for employers.

title: TENDER LOVING HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $130,000 and $330,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company attributed increased revenue to internal growth and three acquisitions in the past 9 months; the company also said the acquisition of 11 offices of Professional Care Inc., for $3 million, was not complete until the end of the quarter, and therefore, third-quarter and 9-month results do not include significant revenue or expenses of the offices acquired.

title: Quick Senate Debate on Bork Rejected
description: Republican senators, insisting that they needed time to present a fairer view of Judge Robert H. Bork to the public, today refused repeated requests by the Democratic leadership for a quick debate and vote on President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.

title: A First Boston Unit's Certificates
description: The Asset-Backed Securities Corporation, a unit of the First Boston Corporation, is offering $142.7 million of pass-through certificates backed by automobile loan receivables.

title: JACKSON IS CRITICAL OF ISRAELIS ON SOUTH AFRICA ARMS SALES
description: In yet another effort to refine his position on Jews, Israel and the Middle East, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has taken Israel to task for selling arms to South Africa, accusing the the Israeli Government in a magazine article of being ''in complicity with the South African regime.''

title: FIRST INTERSTATE CORP OF WISCON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $191,000 for the quarter and $458,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $104,000 for the quarter and $327,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'Aides' Dropped Over AIDS
description: The Noble School District is dropping the word ''aide'' from job titles for district employees because of anxiety associated with AIDS. The superintendent, Bill Martin, said Tuesday that he has issued a staff memorandum to replace the word ''aide'' with ''assistant'' in the titles of teacher and library aides. ''It's very frightening,'' he said, ''it's very real and it's hard not to panic, but the main thing is we want to use some common sense.''

title: Denver Journal; City That Has Hitched Its Star to the Broncos
description: The air pollution in this city is bad, the economy is hurting and a proposed new convention center is still many years away from construction.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HISTORY IN SHERMAN PARK. An American Family and the Reagan-Mondale Election. By Jonathan Schell. 133 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. NINETEEN SIXTY-EIGHT. A Personal Report. By Hans Koning. 194 pages.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2,222,000 from reversion of a retirement plan.

title: Nuggets Sign Moore
description: Andre Moore, Denver's top draft pick, signed with the Nuggets and began practicing at their training camp yesterday. The 6-foot-8-inch, 215-pound forward from Loyola of Chicago had threatened earlier this week, through his agent, George Andrews, to play this season in Europe if he could not come to terms with the Nuggets. . . . Kenny Smith, a first-round draft pick from North Carolina, was signed to a four-year contract by the Sacramento Kings. Smith, a 6-3 guard, was chosen sixth over all. . . . The Chicago Bulls yesterday signed their first-round choice, and the fifth pick over all in the draft, Scottie Pippen, a 6-7, 210-pound guard-forward from Central Arkansas.

title: Joe Niekro Is Again Waiting After a 21-Year Wait
description: On the day the Minnesota Twins won the pennant, Joe Niekro clutched a bottle of champagne and silently toasted 21 seasons of waiting.

title: U.S. Move: Stress Parley With Rebels
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they are basing their latest strategy in Central America on the expectation that the Nicaraguan Government will not negotiate a cease-fire with the leaders of the rebels.

title:
Market Place;
After the Fall, Strategies Shift
description: LEAD: THE stock market's free fall, which has seen the Dow Jones industrial average plunge 228.29 points, or 8.6 percent, in a little more than a week, has many money managers wondering whether this might not be a propitious moment to head for the exit. Yesterday's record 95.46-point plunge did not soothe any nerves.

title: 5 Children Who Prefer Foster Parents to Mother Seek Court's Help
description: Five children are being held hostage by state officials who dragged them from a foster home they loved in order to force an unwanted reunion with an abusive and disturbed mother, the children's lawyer has told the Iowa Supreme Court.

title: Auto Sales Fall 33.5% In Period
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks declined 33.5 percent in early October, after the end of most of the Big Three auto makers' incentive programs.

title: INTEGRATED DEVICE TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Opposition Split Alienates Many In South Korea
description: A widening split in the opposition has embittered many South Koreans, who say they resent what they regard as potentially ruinous intransigence by opposition leaders who have failed to agree on a presidential candidate.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
21 Hurt in San Francisco Restaurant Explosion
description: A Chinatown restaurant was rocked by an explosion just before lunch hour today, injuring at least 21 people and sending a shower of glass and debris onto the sidewalk.

title: DYNATEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $5,000. c-Net loss

title: Ballet: Graham's 'Persephone'
description: ''PERSEPHONE,'' Martha Graham's newest work, has the prettiness of a greeting card. It is not deep, but it is inventive. The message, entwined in myths of fertility and rebirth, will be familiar to Graham audiences. Yet there is a great deal of the unfamiliar - in the very choice of music and in the window dressing.

title: Slaney Returns Jan. 23
description: Mary Slaney has decided to begin her comeback Jan. 23 at the Pacific Northwest Bell Indoor meet in Portland, Ore. Slaney was ranked first in the world at 1,500 and 3,000 meters in 1985, but has not been in a major competition since then. She took a year off for the birth of her child, Ashley, and is recovering from Achilles' tendon surgery last June. Slaney, the American women's record-holder at every outdoor distance between 800 and 10,000 meters, doesn't plan to begin full road workouts until Nov. 1.

title: Chemistry and Physics Nobels Hail Discoveries on Life and Superconductors; Three Share Prize for Synthesis of Vital Enzymes
description: Two American researchers and a French scientist were awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry yesterday for wide-ranging research that has included the creation of artificial molecules that can mimic vital chemical reactions of the processes of life.

title: HOWARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Danaher Corp., Washington, a maker of automotive products, instrumentation and precision components, named Arthur P. Byrne and John A. Cosentino Jr. to the newly created position of group executive.

title: For MCI, a Return to Health
description: A year ago, things could not have been worse for the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, and its chairman, William G. McGowan.

title: DR. GERALD EHRLICH
description: Dr. Gerald Ehrlich, a former City College professsor and former chief psychologist at Bronx Community College, died of congestive heart failure Oct. 5 at Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other rules remain in effect.

title: Missile-Gap Scare in '60 Fueled the Arms Race
description: To the Editor:

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Deaver's Prosecutor Is Criticized
description: A Justice Department spokesman today described Whitney North Seymour Jr., the special prosecutor in the perjury case against Michael K. Deaver, as ''a bull in the china shop'' who was threatening relations between the United States and Canada.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5.4 million and $12.8 million from sale of investments for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S., With U.N. Files, Tracks Down Nazi Suspect
description: The United States Justice Department has for the first time used the archives of the United Nations War Crimes Commission to track down and charge an American citizen accused of war crimes, according to officials involved.

title: CIATTI'S INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Catholic Bishops Take Stand on '88 Issues
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops declared today that they will stake out strong positions in the 1988 election campaign, endorsing no candidates but stating clearly where they stand on issues.

title: Argentina Reins In Economy
description: Argentina today announced a series of drastic economic measures, including a wage and price freeze, in the apparent hope of increasing confidence in the beleaguered administration of President Raul Alfonsin.

title: U.N. Demands Vietnamese Leave Cambodia
description: The General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today that deplores the Soviet-backed Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia and demands Vietnam's withdrawal from that nation.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
From Far and Near, Designers Flock to a New York 'Saturday'
description: FOUR Japanese designers with three mysterious boxes flew from Tokyo to New York last Wednesday for the start of Designer's Saturday. They opened their boxes in the Poltronova showroom of the International Design Center, New York, and assembled what turned out to be sinuously curved cast-aluminum chairs with screwdrivers. The taut chairs, with attenuated lines, were among the most popular introductions at New York's fall furniture market.

title: DST SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are restated to reflect a 100 percent stock split in the 1987 third quarter.

title: For U.N. Chief, Diplomacy Suddenly Gets Hotter
description: As the United Nations grapples with the Persian Gulf war and other regional conflicts, the Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, suddenly finds himself engaged in active and significant diplomacy at a level highly unusual for a secretary general of the last 20 years.

title: CAVALIER HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pop: Tom Waits On Stage
description: IF Nelson Algren had written material for a lounge act, and the lounge was a riverfront dive on some peculiarly American tributary of the Styx, the result might have resembled a show by Tom Waits, who gave the first of six concerts at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Broadway on Tuesday.

title: Jacksonville Scouted
description: Bud Adams, the owner of the Houston Oilers, paid a visit yesterday with his wife, Nancy, to Jacksonville, Fla., a city that is attempting to woo the Oilers away from their home in the Astrodome. The civic leaders of Jacksonville, the home of the Gator Bowl, gave the Adamses a tour of the city, and the main topic of conversation was a $125.8 million offer from the Jacksonville business community to Adams to move his team. ''It's a very attractive package,'' said Adams. ''That's why I'm over here today. I want to take a good look at your city.''

title: Folger in Washington Survives Its Own Drama
description: The Shakespeare Theater at the Folger Library in Washington has had more than its share of offstage drama in recent years. But two years after a tumultuous struggle to remain open, the popular Capitol Hill institution appears to have made a remarkable creative and financial recovery.

title: Republicans Join the Roster Of Arizona Governor's Foes
description: In his first 10 months as Governor of Arizona, Evan Mecham's rhetorical style and conservative politics have provoked sharp controversy among blacks, homosexuals and other minorities here. Along with many Democrats, they have mounted an ambitious campaign to recall the maverick Republican from office.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Juilliard Chamber Group
description: The Juilliard Chamber Symphony will play the Faure and Sibelius settings of the Pelleas and Melisande legend in a free concert next Thursday at Alice Tully Hall. Sixten Ehrling will conduct. Mozart's Symphony No. 41 (the ''Jupiter'') is also on the program. Although there is no charge, tickets are required; they may be obtained at the Juilliard Concert Office, 144 West 66th Street, Monday through Friday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: 874-7515.

title: 6 Enter Pleas In Fraud Case
description: Six people, including a multimillionaire developer, pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to charges that they were involved in a $500 million plot to defraud five savings and loan associations in Texas and Arkansas.

title: Labor From China, an Unhappy History
description: To the Editor:

title: GATEWAY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend issued May 1987.

title: Tamils Killed 30 Troops, India Says
description: Tamil guerrillas killed 30 Indian troops in the last 24 hours, possibly in a single operation in the Jaffna Peninsula, a spokeswoman for the Indian Government said here today.

title: Soviet to Let Key Jewish Dissident Leave
description: Vladimir S. Slepak, one of the Soviet Union's most prominent Jewish dissidents, was told today that he and his wife may move to Israel.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the pooling of Mid-Continent Life Insurance Co. in December 1986.

title: CHECKROBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company is in the development stage.

title: Moslems Clash in Pakistan
description: Pakistani police officers fired at Sunni Moslem protesters here today, killing one and wounding two, witnesses said. A doctor at Government Hospital confirmed the death in the incident, which he said occurred after police officers intervened to head off a clash between the Sunnis and Shiites.

title: Hudson Valley Site to Be Dropped for A-Smasher
description: The Cuomo administration, bowing to opposition in the mid-Hudson Valley, will withdraw its proposal to locate the Federal Super Collider project near Wallkill in Orange County, government officials said today.

title: Tax Proposal On Contracts
description: Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee today proposed eliminating a preferential accounting method used by military contractors and larger building contractors.

title: HIBERNIA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings are not available; the company converted to public form of ownership in September 1986.

title: Stuart Cohen for Civil Court Judge
description: Last month's Democratic primary in Manhattan's First Municipal Court District was too close to call: the difference between vote totals for the incumbent, Judge Lester Evens, and the challenger, Stuart Cohen, was smaller than the number of questionable ballots. That's why registered Democrats go to the polls next Tuesday for a rerun. (The district runs from the Battery to 14th Street on the West Side of Manhattan; its eastern boundary is irregular, and voters who are not certain they live within it should check with the Board of Elections.) Mr. Cohen, who has served New York City well as an administrator of city contracts and arbitrator of disputes between vendors and government, still deserves endorsement. Judge Evens, formerly a legal services lawyer, has served a full 10-year term. In that time, he was censured by the Commission on Judicial Conduct for four instances of misbehavior in the courtroom.

title: CANDIDATE'S DEATH TROUBLES HAITIANS
description: Election officials and other political leaders said today that they believed the killing Tuesday of a presidential candidate was part of a plan by loyalists of the deposed Duvalier regime to intimidate candidates and voters.

title: Don't Blame Physicians for Increase in Medicare; Costs Fall on Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Pooh
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Acquits Zaccaro of Seeking To Extort Cable Television Bribe
description: John A. Zaccaro was acquitted yesterday of trying to extort a bribe from a cable television company that unsuccessfully sought a franchise in Queens.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Official Leaves Gulf
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington ended a Persian Gulf tour today. Although the United States imports only 3 to 5 percent of its oil from gulf producers, the region is still a major supply factor, he said at a news conference. ''We learned from the 1970's that severe dislocations in supplies and prices affect us immediately,'' Mr. Herrington said.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch on Monday about a gay rights march misstated the roles of Representatives Barney Frank and Gerry E. Studds. They were introduced but did not speak.

title: Chrysler May Add Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation is considering building a stamping plant for its St. Louis mini-van assembly operations, the trade journal Metalworking News reported in this week's issue. The journal said the stamping plant would cost between $100 million and $150 million, and would ease the burden on Chrysler's stamping plants in Warren and Sterling Heights, Mich., and in Twinsburg, Ohio. Stamping plants press metal parts from sheets of steel. The St. Louis plant would make roofs, fenders, doors, body sides and other steel panels for the mini-vans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Nicaragua must end its refusal to negotiate a cease-fire with its guerrilla opponents, according to Oscar Arias Sanchez, the President of Costa Rica and the winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize. Page A1 U.S. strategy in Central America is now based on the expectation that Managua will not negotiate a cease-fire with insurgent leaders, Administration officials say, and could support an effort for contra aid. A12 The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to two scientists in Switzerland whose breakthrough last year touched off a torrent of research in the long-dormant field of superconductivity. A1 The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to two Americans and a Frenchman for research including the creation of artificial molecules that mimic chemical reactions of life processes. A14 Korean opposition squabbling is prompting many in the middle class to turn to the ruling party's candidate as a stabilizing force. A1 Tamil rebels killed 30 Indian troops in the last 24 hours in Sri Lanka, possibly in a single operation, according to a spokeswoman for the Indian Government. A3 The killing of a Haitian who was running for president was part of a plan by loyalists of the deposed Duvalier regime to intimidate candidates and voters, according to Haitian political leaders. A9 A leading Soviet Jewish dissident, Vladimir S. Slepak, was informed by the authorities that he and his wife could emigrate to Israel 17 years after he first applied to leave. A3 Japan laments the passing of the affordable home A4 U.N. chief's role gets warmer A6 New raids by Iran and Iraq A7 Shultz starts short mideast trip A8 Soviet life baffles U.S. defector A11 U.S. official defends Tibet stance A18 Taiwan eases travel ban A19 NATIONAL A20-29, B10-14, D31 The nation's trade deficit shrank in August from a record level, but the improvement was only half as much as expected and prices in the financial markets fell sharply. A1 Stocks suffered their biggest loss in history as the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 95.46 points, or 3.81 percent. D1 George Bush, espousing lower taxes, called for cuts of nearly half the maximum capital gains levy for individuals. The Vice President contended the change would spur growth and not cost the Treasury money. A1 G.O.P. senators refused requests by Democratic leaders for a speedy debate and vote on Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court. Fifty-four senators oppose his confirmation. D31 Football negotiators drew closer to ending the 24-day-old strike against the National League and returning the players to the field, possibly in time to play this weekend. B15 Sales of U.S.-made vehicles dropped 33.5 percent in early October after the expiration of most of the Big Three makers' incentive programs. D1 The structural integrity of a tanker has been questioned after it dumped nearly 40,000 barrels of oil into the North Pacific in two major spills this year. B13 Rail transportation improvements between New York and Boston could cut that trip to three hours from the current journey of four and a half, according to Amtrak officials and northeastern Governors. A20 Republicans join ranks of Arizona Governor's foes A20 Denver journal: Broncos fanatics A20 Nuclear agency rebuts charge it sacrificed safety A24 Few models for Los Angeles school plan A27 Gunmen kill 5 in Pasco, Wash. A28 New treatments may help prevent pneumonia linked to AIDS B12 Corporate parley seeks workplace AIDS policy B12 Birmingham Mayor re-elected B14 Prosecutor in Deaver case criticized D31 WASHINGTON TALK B10 Cuomo tested by experts on foreign policy savvy Bush irks cystic fibrosis group REGIONAL B1-9 John A. Zaccaro was acquitted of trying to extort a bribe from a cable television company that unsuccessfully sought a franchise in Queens. The jury returned its verdict after six hours of deliberation. A1 Business dealings by a Cuomo aide, Alexander A. Levine, the executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority, face examination by a prosecutor. A1 Physicians should warn sex partners of people infected with the AIDS virus of their substantial risk of infection, according to Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, New York City's Health Commissioner. B1 City hospitals are overloaded, emergency rooms are overcrowded, hundreds of patients are awaiting beds and ambulances are being diverted from one facility to another, officials testified. B1 Two white girls did not support key elements in the prosecution account of the encounter between a group of white youths and three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, that ended with the death of one black. B3 New York could not take over Lilco under a provision of a tax bill approved by Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee. B2 Federal agents altered transcripts of taped conversations to bolster the prosecution's case involving racketeering charges against Matthew Ianiello, his lawyer charged. Prosecutors and agents denied the accusation. B3 Donald Trump won the concession to operate the Wollman and Lasker rinks in Central Park. Mr. Trump restored the Wollman Rink in three and a half months after the city had been unable to do so in six years. B3 Homelessness grows in exurban Orange County B1 A preacher's tie voted ''ugliest in America'' B1 State offers to help New York City's mentally ill homeless B2 Moynihan welfare bill assailed B4 G.O.P. fights subpoenas for party records B6 News analysis: Was Zaccaro case too weak? B8

title: THE HUDSON VALLEY: OLD GENTILITY, NEW AFFLUENCE FORM ALLIANCE
description: IF 19th-century Hudson River artists were to visit the back porch of the New York preservationist Joan Davidson today - or those of Count Jean de Castella or the investment banker Dick Jenrette -they could paint the same luminous scenes they captured a century ago: long views of the Catskills and the Hudson that dissolve before the eyes as the light, clouds, river and sun imperceptibly shift.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The M.A. Hanna Company, a major producer of iron ore, is offering $110 million of 12 1/2 percent senior subordinated notes due 1994 at a price of 98.86, to yield 12.75 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegis Corp., Chicago, the parent of United Airlines, said it had completed the previously announced sale of its Hilton International Co. to Ladbroke Group P.L.C. for $1.07 billion.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $20,142,000.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes for the quarter a pre-tax provision of $9 million for expenses in connection with a decision by one of its subsidiaries to withdraw from the tissue heart valve business, and for the 9 months includes other income of $53.1 million which resulted from the settlement of a patent infringement judgment obtained by one of the company's subsidiaries.

title: Airbus in Talks With McDonnell
description: Airbus Industrie, the European airplane-making consortium, is holding talks with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation about cooperating on new aircraft projects, but a senior spokesman for Airbus, Robert Alizant, said an agreement is some years away. His comments followed a news conference by Maurice Blin, chairman of the French Senate Finance Committee, who said such cooperation offers one of the best ways to defuse the trans-Atlantic crisis over European subsidies to the Airbus consortium.

title: DEVILS' CHECKING HELPS TOP WHALERS
description: The Hartford Whalers, who had failed to score in the second or third periods of their first three games, all losses, scored a goal in the third period tonight, but it was not enough.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.55 percent notes due 1989 at a price of 99.954, to yield 9.575 percent, through Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The noncallable issue is rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by S.&P. and yields about 46 basis points more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Crossing The Line
description: National Football League players who crossed the union's picket lines yesterday.

title: Free Agency Still Key to Future Peace
description: Owners of National Football League teams look at the salary escalation that free agency has created in baseball and tell the striking union they won't even discuss the subject. Baseball owners look at the apparently deteriorating strength of the football union and are encouraged to take a similar approach to their players.

title: Holly Sugar Takes Offer of $95 a Share
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation, spurning a takeover bid from a smaller rival, said today that it had agreed to an increased offer from an investor group for $95 a share, or $106.4 million.

title: Panel to Certify U.S. Teachers Gets a Leader
description: A board established to set national standards for American teachers filled out its ranks by appointing 34 new members and a president today.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes for the quarter a gain of $373,000 from the sale of an office property and for the 9 months includes $348,000 from the sale of undeveloped land in Markham, Ont. c-Includes a charge of $1,350,000 from the settlement of a patent infringement suit.

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: PROSECUTOR GETS CUOMO AIDE'S CASE
description: The Cuomo administration said yesterday that it was forwarding a report on business dealings by one of the Governor's closest aides to prosecutors for possible action.

title: SHULTZ BEGINNING VISIT TO MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz leaves Thursday for a brief tour of the Middle East in which he is expected to urge Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to relax his objection to an international peace conference.

title: MICROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $253,000 and $462,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $304,000 and $564,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split which occured in May 1987.

title: G.I. Defector Disillusioned With Soviet
description: Pvt. Wade E. Roberts, embroiled in problems with the United States Army, left his base in West Germany in March without authorization and became one of the few American servicemen ever to defect to the Soviet Union.

title: AUTOMATED DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SYBRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $701,000 for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a loss from discontinued operations of $162,000 and a tax credit of $779,000.

title: Texas, to Settle Suit, Will Increase Spending for Mentally Retarded
description: After being found in contempt of court this summer over conditions at its facilities for the mentally retarded, Texas has agreed to a settlement of a 13-year-old lawsuit that will cost the state an estimated $80.6 million over the next three years.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $500 million provision related to loans to certain underdeveloped countries. c-Net income

title: VANGUARD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nominees Announced For 1987 Book Awards
description: The nominees for the 1987 National Book Awards for fiction and nonfiction, which each carry a $10,000 prize, were announced yesterday. More than 300 authors were considered for the two prizes - a greater number than in any other year, according to Barbara Prete, executive director of the National Book Awards Inc.

title: Q & A
description: Q. During heavy rain, water leaks into our basement and leaves large puddles in the corners. A waterproofing contractor said to install a drain around the inside of the foundation, and a sump pump to remove the water. What is your opinion of this drain-pump method?

title: Concert: Jeffersonia In Music
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON fashioned himself a violinist and amassed an extensive library at Monticello of scores by his favorite composers. Vineyardmusik, an early-music ensemble based at the Vineyard Theater, assembled a program Tuesday evening of works from the collection that suggested the former President's considerable foresight did not extend into the cultural realm. The concert featured pieces by Francis Hopkinson, Carlo Antonio Tessarini, John Stanley and Claude Balbastre, as well as by Haydn and Corelli.

title: Mikulski's Soapbox
description: When you are 4 feet 11 inches tall and a popular United States Senator who is highly sought after on the speaking circuit, you learn to be prepared for any situation.

title: U.S. Official Defends Stance on Turmoil in Tibet
description: The leading State Department expert on China today denied charges by lawmakers from both parties that the Administration had taken China's side in the recent unrest in Tibet.

title: Film Festival Head Asked to Resign
description: The longtime director of the New York Film Festival, Richard Roud, has been asked to resign, according to Alfred Stern, the president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $135 million associated with the decision, announced on Sept. 14, to restructure operations at Chemical Bank, the company's principal subsidiary, and certain other subsidiaries, for the quarter and 9 months; also the 9 months loss primarily reflects the $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loan losses made in June 1987 for loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling, and a related $80 million deferred tax benefit writeoff. c-Net income The latest periods had gains on sales of investment securities of $1.5 million for the quarter and $43.5 million for the 9 months, compared with the year-ago quarter of $48.6 million and the 9 months of $124.3 million.

title: 'W' STILL NEEDED BY THE GIANTS
description: IT isn't often that the fate of a sports franchise might rest on one game, but that was the weighty prospect for the San Francisco Giants as they lost the National League pennant last night, 6-0, to the gallant Cardinals.

title: KEYSTONE HERITAGE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House Bill Would Bar New York Takeover of Lilco
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has included a provision in its tax bill that would make it impossible for New York State to take over the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Tokyo Journal; Sweet Dreams of a Home and the Sour Awakening
description: For more than 25 years, Japanese have talked of ''mai homu,'' an expression adapted from ''my home'' that became a symbol of how far Japan had come from postwar poverty. But because of soaring land prices, young Japanese in the nation's capital have all but given up hope of ever owning a home.

title: DPL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.F.L. NEGOTIATORS NEAR AGREEMENT
description: The chief negotiators for the owners and the players came close yesterday to reaching an agreement on how to end the 23-day-old strike against the National Football League.

title: Body of a Woman Found on S.I. Beach
description: The body of a young woman, wrapped in a rug bound with rope, was found early yesterday on a Staten Island beach along Upper New York Bay, the police reported.

title: Digital Net Is Up 47.8% In Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, sustaining its broad attack against I.B.M., said today that net income for its first fiscal quarter rose 47.8 percent, to $269.9 million, amid strong continued demand for its VAX computer line.

title: America's Worst Tie Is a Hairy Experience
description: Ugly?

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,153,024, or 6l cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of a change in inventory accounting. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $187,398.

title: KEY RATES
AMR Profit Down 27.9%
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it had earned $87.1 million, or $1.41 a share, in the third quarter, down 27.9 percent from $120.8 million, or $1.98 a share, in the period a year ago.

title: Music, Poetry and Zen In Benefit for Homeless
description: A benefit for the homeless, with a full program of entertainment and a panel discussion by politicians, social activists and educators, is to be held at 8 P.M. Monday at the Great Hall of Cooper Union, on Seventh Street at Third Avenue.

title: QUIPP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New K Mart Team Focuses Marketing
description: Executives at the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer in the world, have always been a bit coy when asked whether the company was trying to overtake Sears, Roebuck & Company as No. 1. But its announcement yesterday of a new marketing group may be at least one indication that an effort is under way to close the $3 billion gap between them.

title: Chemical New York Has Loss
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent company of the Chemical Bank, reported a loss yesterday of $66.4 million in the third quarter. In contrast to Chemical, the Marine Midland Banks and the Bank of New York yesterday reported strong increases in third-quarter earnings.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to account for corrections in actuarial assumptions used in developing pension expenses under FAS 87.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
HUNT, J B TRANSPORT SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $35,000, net of taxes, for the quarter and $109,000, net of taxes, for the 9 months on trade-in of equipment. c-Includes gains of $860,000, net of taxes, for the quarter and $1,497,000, net of taxes, for the 9 months on trade- in of equipment.

title: Jersey Officer Killed As His Car Hits Pole
description: A police officer responding to an emergency was killed yesterday when his patrol crashed into a telephone pole, the police said.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Once Sales Tools, Now They're Home
description: AFTER the army of sales agents moves on to greener territory, the developer of a condominium is often left with an obsolete sales tool: the model apartment.

title: Gunmen Kill 5 in Pasco, Wash.
description: Two gunmen walked into an automobile body shop and opened fire with automatic weapons Tuesday evening, killing five men and wounding a sixth, who hid under a vehicle until the assailants left, the police said.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in January.

title: Ameruso Sentence Delayed
description: Anthony R. Ameruso, the former New York City Transportation Commissioner who was to begin the first of 16 weekends at a Rikers Island jail tomorrow for a perjury conviction, was granted a stay of the sentence yesterday by an appeals court judge in Manhattan. The order, signed by Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department, said Mr. Ameruso could remain free during his appeal. Mr. Ameruso was convicted in July of lying to a panel that was investigating corruption in New York City government.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the repurchase of debt of $87,000.

title: Emily Mumford, Sociologist Known for Medical Studies
description: Dr. Emily Mumford, a sociologist known for her work on the effect of psychotherapy in lowering later medical care costs, died of complications of a brain tumor Oct. 3 at her home in Manhattan. She was 66 years old.

title: Latin Panel in Dispute
description: The Senate's Central American Negotiations Observer Group, a six-member bipartisan panel set up to monitor peace talks in Central America, is suffering from infighting itself.

title: Western Auto Deal For Tire Retailer
description: The Western Auto Supply Company said it had tentatively agreed to gain control of NTW Inc., a tire retailer that is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. NTW, based in Dale City, Va., would be the second tire retailer acquired this year by Western Auto, an automotive supplies retailer and wholesaler based here. In February, Western Auto bought Tire America Inc. of Wheeling, W.Va., for $35 million.

title: France Bans Export of A Zola Work
description: The French Minister of Culture, Francois Leotard, said in Paris yesterday that the manuscript of Emile Zola's ''J'Accuse,'' the author's celebrated defense of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus in 1898, would not be allowed to leave France. The 39-page letter is the most important document in the Zola family archive, which is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in Monte Carlo on Dec. 8.

title: Astros' Wagner Quits
description: When Dick Wagner, the president and general manager of the Houston Astros, submitted his resignation yesterday to John McMullen, the owner, Wagner became major league baseball's third chief front-office executive to vacate his position in the last 10 days. Had he not resigned, it appeared he would have suffered the fate of Hank Peters of the Baltimore Orioles and Bill Bergesch of the Cincinnati Reds, general managers who were dismissed. Wagner, whose resignation will be effective on Oct. 23, completed two seasons with the Astros. Last year, the team won the National League Western Division championship, but lost to the Mets in the playoffs. This year, although the Astros were within a half game of first place on Aug. 25, they finished third, 14 games behind San Francisco. Manager Hal Lanier was publicly critical of Wagner, saying he had not strengthened the team, especially the relief pitching, through trades. ''I do feel Lanier has to mend his ways, but I just felt that John was not happy with the club and with certain things that happened,'' said Wagner, referring to the team's owner. Wagner said that he was departing on amicable terms with McMullen after reaching a contract settlement.

title: Yeager Flight 40 Years Old
description: Chuck Yeager's hometown today celebrated the 40th anniversary of his historic flight that broke the sound barrier. On Oct. 14, 1947, Mr. Yeager became the first man to break the barrier, about 700 miles an hour. Today, Mr. Yeager returned the salute in a jet fighter, taking a few low passes and a parting barrel roll overhead.

title: KARPOV BEATS KASPAROV IN 32 MOVES
description: Anatoly Karpov, in a stunning upset, won the second game of the world chess championship match today, defeating the titleholder, Gary Kasparov, after 32 moves. The 36-year-old Karpov, himself a former world champion, now leads the match by a score of 1 1/2- 1/2 points.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a charge due to retroactive elimination of tax credits of $2,252,000. c-Includes an investment tax credit of $1,435,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter, and for the year includes a tax credit of $5,755,000.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the decline in latest 9 months' earnings reflects the addition of $32 million to its loan loss reserve.

title: Experts Grill Cuomo, And He Passes, Sort
description: After months of boning up on international affairs and venturing on a field trip to the Soviet Union, Governor Cuomo of New York took the equivalent of a final exam here Tuesday night, going before an audience of 250 experts to prove that he could hold his own in discussing foreign relations.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH toilets seem complicated, they actually operate rather simply. Most difficulties are easily repaired once the trouble is correctly diagnosed.

title: MOSCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $100,200 and $230,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: 87 Arts Groups Get Federal Grants
description: Eighty-seven cultural institutions around the country will receive $27.5 million in challenge grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, the Federal agency has announced.

title: New Treatment May Help in AIDS Fight
description: New drugs and new methods of applying existing drugs promise to improve the treatment and prevention of a form of pneumonia that is the most common cause of death in AIDS patients, leading medical experts say.

title: Caller for the Academy Gets a Wrong Number
description: When Donald O. Cram was awakened today by a call from Sweden congratulating him on winning the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, he laughed heartily and then hung up.

title: Intruder Reaches Oval Office In a Group of Photographers
description: An unidentified young man slipped into a group of photographers at the White House today and made it all the way to the door of the Oval Office, just steps away from President Reagan, before being stopped.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $274,000 for debt prepayment. c-Net loss Share earnings are restated to reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid Feb. 5.

title: U.S. Is Tracing Iran's Stingers
description: Iran may have obtained a small number of American-made Stinger antiaircraft missiles by taking them from Afghan guerrillas this year, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said in an interview published today.

title: Walbro-UIS Accord
description: The Walbro Corporation, a maker of engine fuel systems based in Cass City, Mich., said today that UIS Inc. had agreed to drop a hostile takeover bid it began five weeks ago in return for the right to distribute Walbro's electric fuel pumps. UIS, a privately held concern in New York City, also agreed to sell half its holdings of Walbro stock to Walbro for $25.50 a share, $2 less than UIS had offered for them. The rest is to be sold to Walbro, at undisclosed terms, over the next four years.

title: Athens Journal; A Hinted Love Affair Becomes an Affair of State
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has become embroiled in a public scandal over a reported relationship with a former Olympic Airways flight attendant that has estranged him from his American wife and called his political future into question.

title: New Light in Albany
description: With the investigative spotlight now trained on one of his closest aides, Governor Cuomo of New York has wisely decided to stop keeping secret the reports prepared by the state Inspector General.

title: The Goalie Shuffle
description: With Bob Sauve, one of the two regulars, out with a separated left shoulder, the Devils are playing musical chairs with their goaltenders. Craig Billington was brought up Monday from the team's top affiliate, the Utica Devils of the American Hockey League, to back up Alain Chevrier in Wednesday night's 3-1 victory over Hartford. After the game, Billington was sent back to play for Utica in tonight's game against Rochester. As Chevrier's backup for tonight's game against Montreal and tomorrow night's against Hartford, the Devils brought up Chris Delianedis from Utica.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $4,820,000.

title: Bridge: Taiwan and U.S. Leading In World Team Title Play
description: World championship qualifying play continued here tonight with Taiwan leading in the open series and the United States heading the women's division.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERITOR FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes for the quarter an extraordinary charge of $13,190,000 for restructuring costs and the addition of $34 million to loan loss reserves; the 9 months include a tax credit of $1,308,000 and reflects a writedown of $330 million in good will associated with the acquisition of Western Savings Bank in 1982. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $9,603,000 and $23,436,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Baby Sitter Charged in Death
description: The police charged a baby sitter today in the Oct. 7 death of a 2-year-old boy who they said was left unattended and ran into the path of a school bus. The sitter, Geraldine Clark, 42 years old, was charged with risk of injury to a minor and operating a day-care center without a license, the police said. They said she had been caring for the child, Gregory Miller of New Britain, at the time of the accident.

title: Myerson Denies Bribery And Other U.S. Charges
description: Bess Myerson, declaring she had ''not committed any illegal act,'' denied charges yesterday that she had conspired to influence a judge presiding over the divorce of her companion.

title: DR. CARL RICHARD WISE
description: Dr. Carl Richard Wise, a former medical officer of Columbia University and retired assistant vice president of Presbyterian Hospital, died Wednesday at the Brandon Woods nursing home in South Dartmouth, Mass. He was 79 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 25, 1987.

title: Toddler Trapped in a Texas Well Cries and Sings as Rescuers Dig
description: A frightened toddler trapped for more than a day 22 feet down an abandoned well talked to her mother and cried today as rescuers pounded through solid rock with jackhammers.

title: Don't Forget James Rumsey's Steamboat
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Seeking an Arab Alliance Against Iran
description: Saudi Arabia is leading an effort to forge a united Arab front against Iran at an Arab League summit meeting scheduled next month in Amman, Jordan.

title: Film: Gish and Davis In 'Whales of August'
description: ''BUSY, busy, busy,'' says Libby (Bette Davis), the elder of two ancient, widowed sisters who are sharing what could be their last summer on the Maine coast.

title: At the Movies
description: Birth of a Director

title: Cannon Falls Short
description: Cannon Group Inc. said an $11.7 million interest payment to two sets of bondholders would go unpaid for now. However, the financially troubled movie maker said it expected to pay the interest before a 30-day default period lapses. Last week, Cannon appeared to have obtained the cash to stave off a default on its debt payments. It said it planned to sell and lease back its real estate holdings for $300 million from a Spanish company with ties to Cannon's founders.

title: House Panel Votes to Delay Cut in Homeless Family Aid
description: A plan by the Reagan Administration to cut off as much as $90 million a year in Federal aid to New York City for sheltering homeless families would be postponed for a year under a measure approved last night by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Dukakis Assails Reagan's Policy Of Escorting Persian Gulf Tankers
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis declared yesterday that the Reagan Administration should be trying to bring peace to the Persian Gulf rather than having United States Navy ships escort Kuwaiti tankers in the Gulf.

title: Times Mirror Magazine Deal
description: The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire four magazines from Diamandis Communications Inc. for $167.5 million in cash. The magazines are Field &

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REV. WILLIS A. BAXTER
description: The Rev. Willis A. Baxter, pastor of Christ's First Presbyterian Church in Hempstead, L.I., from 1951 until his retirement in 1974, died of cancer of the liver Sunday at the Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa. He was 79 years old and lived in Orefield, Pa.

title: Biggs Sees Signs of an Upset
description: Not long ago, from a speeding car on the outskirts of this city, Tyrell Biggs saw a billboard with his name and that of the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, in monumental letters. ''TYSON-BIGGS,'' it said. In that automobile, as he focused on TYSON-BIGGS, Biggs did some subliminal editing so that what he registered as the car sped by was: TY BIGGS.

title: Can the AIDS Panel Now 'Pull It Together'?
description: President Reagan's AIDS commission is off to a stumbling, acrimonious start, raising disturbing questions as to what has gone wrong and what can still be accomplished.

title: Book Sale
description: The Friends of the Epiphany Branch Library will hold their semiannual book sale from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. today and tomorrow in the library's basement at 228 East 23d Street. Thousands of volumes will be on sale, including out-of-print reference books and books for children. All proceeds will benefit the Epiphany library. Information: 673-1367.

title: Quake Damage Total Rising
description: Officials have raised the damage estimate from the recent earthquake and aftershocks to $213.6 million. Most of the increase in the damage total came from higher estimates of damage to government facilities, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said Wednesday. Earlier, the damage estimate from the quake on Oct. 1 and a strong aftershock three days later was put at $177 million. Seven deaths were attributed to the tremors.

title: 35 Held in $1 Million Parking-Meter 'Rip-Off'
description: Thirty-five employees - virtually the entire field force of the company that collects money from New York City's parking meters - were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing almost $1 million in quarters in three months.

title: Mandatory Retirement Age For Elected Judges Is Upheld
description: The State Court of Appeals today upheld New York State's law requiring elected judges to retire at age 70.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other rules remain in effect.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Of Moose and Baseball
description: The menu at a Minnesota Harvest Fest given last night by Representative Gerry Sikorski had a distinctive Upper Mississippi quality: moose meatballs, deep-fried walleyed pike and buffalo roast.

title: Economic Scene; Uneasy Market And the Future
description: IS the stock market telling us alarming news about the outlook for the American economy?

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WHO are all these people?'' a Brooklyn native mumbled. ''There is no one here from Brooklyn.'' He was being jostled by the crowd in the Majestic Theater at festivities marking the opening of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's fifth Next Wave Festival and the reopening of the renovated theater.

title: Justice Department Urges Judge To Admonish Deaver Prosecutor
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to admonish the special prosecutor in the perjury case against Michael K. Deaver for attempting to coerce the Canadian Ambassador to testify at the trial of the former White House aide.

title: Company Agrees to Cleanup Of Radium Plant in Queens
description: A radium-supply company in New York City said yesterday that while its radioactive plant in Queens posed no ''current'' public health risk, it was prepared to meet with government agencies to devise a way to close and decontaminate the 33-year-old building ''as quickly as possible.''

title: No to Higginbotham
description: The Senate has yet to vote on the disputed nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. But already the National Right to Life Committee is girding for a fight against a potential replacement, Judge Patrick E. Higginbotham, who sits with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Dallas.

title: Advertising; Mingo-Jones and Burrell Get Four CEBA's Each
description: At the 10th annual CEBA Awards, which honor the best advertising created for black audiences, the most honored agencies were Mingo-Jones Advertising of New York and Burrell Advertising of Chicago. Both are black-owned agencies that generally handle such advertising for large marketing companies.

title: A Million-Contract Day
description: For the first time in the history of the Chicago Board of Trade, more than a million futures and options contracts were traded during a single session, the exchange said today. The record-breaking day came Wednesday, when 1,031,714 contracts changed hands, surpassing the previous mark of 918,411 contracts set April 9. The Board of Trade, the industry's oldest and largest futures market, also exceeded last year's total volume today.

title: How We've Corrupted Our NATO Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: Traverse City Journal; Town That Couldn't Evade Reality
description: The stormy waters of Grand Traverse Bay seem strangely attuned these days to the tumult onshore that has divided this northern Michigan town over the issues of condoms and AIDS.

title: Soviet Emigre Starts Life as an Israeli
description: Ida Nudel's 17-year-long battle to leave the Soviet Union for Israel ended in victory today as she arrived to a welcome that included everyone from Jane Fonda to the Israeli Cabinet.

title: Sampson Signs
description: After spending half the regular season injured and most of the summer talking about testing the free-agent market, Ralph Sampson signed a six-year agreement with the Houston Rockets yesterday that will pay him $12 million. The Rockets now have the Twin Towers under long-term contracts. Akeem Olajuwon signed a 12-year contract last season that will pay him an average of $2.5 million a year. ''I don't think I have anything to prove to anybody but myself, and the only thing I have to prove to myself is to go out and play basketball,'' Sampson said. ''The only thing to be determined was if Ralph wanted to be here,'' said Charlie Thomas, the team owner. ''When we determined that, we wanted to make sure he did come back.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SPEAKING WRITERS

title: Film: 'Blue Monkey,' Larva Tale
description: ''BLUE MONKEY'' isn't much more than a standard angry-larva story, but it has been cleverly directed by William Fruet, who knows how to give it a new look. To be sure, what happens in the film is essentially familiar, as a slimy little abomination appears, grows, hatches and goes on to terrorize everyone it meets. From the standpoint of plot, there isn't that much to tell.

title: AUCTION
description: TWO large white diamonds of exceptional color and clarity are the most important stones among hundreds of gems to be auctioned Monday through Wednesday at Sotheby's and Christie's. The sales will offer works estimated by the auction houses to bring about $60 million - the highest total ever for any three-day period of jewelry sales.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' loss included the impact in the second quarter of a $204 million addition to the allowance for credit losses related to international credit exposures.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Rules on Ex-Judge's Prison Term
description: A former State Supreme Court Justice in Queens, who has served 19 months of a five-year Federal prison term for taking bribes to fix cases in his court, must serve at least three years before becoming eligible for parole, the United States Parole Commission has ruled.

title: Marconi Contract
description: Marconi Communications P.L.C., a subsidiary of the General Electric Company of Britain, said it had received an initial development contract from the United States Navy worth more than $450 million. The contract, which will be worked on an equal basis with the Rockwell International Corporation's Collins Defense Communications Systems division, is for the development of a high-frequency anti-jam communications system. The company said the contract could lead to orders amounting to $3 billion over 10 years.

title: New Reagan Policy to Cut Benefits For the Aged, Blind and Disabled
description: The Reagan Administration has adopted a new policy that will reduce welfare benefits for many elderly, blind and disabled people who receive free food, shelter, firewood or winter clothing from churches and charitable organizations.

title: Let the Nuclear Industry Eat Its Own Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,888,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a tax credit of $1,174,000. Latest quarter also includes a one- time $33.7 million pretax provision for the company's special early retirement program for non-bargaining employees; quarter also reflects the unfavorable impact on earnings of $3.1 million relating to the financial restructuring of Mack Financial Corp., as well as start-up costs of $4.2 million at the company's Winnsboro, S.C., assembly facility; quarter was also adversely affected by about $3 million in precautionary costs for a possible disruption of production by UAW employees. c-Includes a tax credit of $525,000 and $3,357,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss

title: 100 Missing in Bangladesh As Overcrowded Ferry Sinks
description: A ferry carrying about 200 passengers sank in a river outside Dhaka today, and about 100 people were missing, officials and witnesses said.

title: New Jersey Stars
description: Two New Jersey teen-agers have emerged as key players for the United States' under-20 national team in the FIFA Youth World Cup soccer tournament in Chile. Tony Meola, a goalie from Kearny, an 18-year-old freshman at the University of Virginia, turned in a spectacular performance Wednesday in a 1-0 victory over Saudi Arabia. Chris Unger, 19, of Old Tappan and Princeton University, scored the goal. Meola kept the score low in the opening game, a 1-0 loss to Bulgaria. To advance to the second round, the Americans must win their last game of the first round, tomorrow against West Germany.

title: KEY RATES
Booties and Jobs: A Club to Help Young Fathers
description: There's a lot of fun stuff for a 17-year-old like Alex Fernandez to do at the Y. He enjoys shooting hoops and lifting weights, and he likes the Teen Fathers club. It's a bunch of regular guys, and you can talk to Manny Cardona, the leader, about your feelings.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORLD SERIES '87: Cardinals' Depth Must Rise Above Twins' Dome; Defense Fortifies St. Louis Pitching
description: Injured or not, running or not, the St. Louis Cardinals have a highly flexible baseball club, a great defense, balanced pitching backed by an outstanding bullpen, talented reserves, lots of switch-hitters and a manager who knows how to use all his resources. So, with or without Jack Clark, they have the tools to win the World Series in six games.

title: Presidential Candidates and the Arts
description: LEAD: No topic is more critical in a thriving, post-industrial society like ours than the arts, which are increasingly influenced by the tone of political life and by direct Government funding. The very existence of the National Endowments for the Arts and for the Humanities reflect our commitment to cultural vigor, which I share and defend.

title: Elizabeth Dole's Jet Has Near-Collision With Another Plane
description: A private jet carrying former Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole was involved in a near-collision with another aircraft Wednesday at Lakefront Airport in New Orleans, aviation experts said today.

title: Uganda Leader Awaited
description: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, who assumed power almost two years ago after leading a five-year resistance movement from the bush, is expected to arrive Saturday for a three-day private visit, the first visit to Washington by a Ugandan head of state, according to Ambassador Elizabeth Bagaaya Nyabongo.

title: Boxing by the Boardwalk
description: IF boxing had a coat of arms, it would be a half-smoked cigar twisted into a casino ashtray. For a quarter of a century, all those big cigars were lighted in Las Vegas casinos, but now they're being puffed in this Baghdad by the Boardwalk, where tonight Mike Tyson will defend his undisputed world heavyweight championship for the first time against Tyrell Biggs.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After equity in income of continuing operations of affiliates of $109,535,000 for the quarter, and for the 9 months equity in gain on sale of discontinued operations of affiliates of $41.5 million, equity in extraordinary credit of affiliate of $17,879,000, and also equity in income of continuing operations of affiliates of $105,027,000. c-After a loss in equity of affiliates from continuing operations of $1,581,000 for the quarter and 9 months, equity in income of $160,000 for the quarter and equity in loss of $813,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cardinals Won't Have Pendleton at Third for Series
description: The St. Louis Cardinals arrived here today for their World Series encounter with the Minnesota Twins, and they brought their injury plague along with the rest of the baggage they've been toting all year.

title: N.F.L. Players End Strike but Can't Play Sunday
description: The National Football League Players Association ended its 24-day strike today by sending its members back to work, only to have them find something less than a warm reception.

title: Art: 1980's History on Canvas, in 'Morality Tales'
description: IF ''Morality Tales: History Painting in the 1980's'' sets out to praise contemporary history painting, the exhibition may end up burying it. In traditional history painting, every detail is meticulously, often overly, planned. The show at the Grey Art Gallery is sloppy in concept, selection and execution.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5,897,000 for the quarter and year related to the redemption of company debt. c-Net loss The year-ago shares outstanding do not include common equivalent shares because of their antidilutive effect.

title: Film: 'Long Live the Lady!'
description: ERMANNO OLMI, the Italian director best known here for his neo-realist dramas (''Il Posto,'' ''The Tree of Wooden Clogs,'' among others), adopts the mannerisms of Isak Dinesen in his latest work, ''Long Live the Lady!'' The film opens today at the Carnegie Hall Screening Room, inaugurating the theater's program devoted to unusual Italian films that honor the tradition of Roberto Rossellini.

title: Film: Nolte in 'Weeds'
description: THE nicest bunch of guys you could ever hope to meet turn up inside San Quentin at the start of ''Weeds,'' which at first has the look of a prison drama. And Nick Nolte makes quite an entrance, appearing in the film's first scene as a would-be suicide who leaps from a balcony, breaks both his wrists and then tries hard to hang himself in the scene after that. There is the suggestion, initially at least, that ''Weeds,'' which opens today at the Gemini and other theaters, will be grim, but it quickly takes an inspirational turn. Mr. Nolte's Lee Umstetter has a lifetime sentence and no possibility of parole, but he somehow finds the hope and wherewithal to launch a writing and directing career.

title: Union Local Urges Approval of NBC Pact
description: The leadership of the New York local of the broadcasters union on strike against NBC announced yesterday that it would recommend its members vote in favor of the contract proposed by the network.

title: Russians See Moscow Vs. Washington on TV
description: Millions of Soviet television viewers woke up this morning to hear their country portrayed as the world's worst violator of human rights in an unusual two-hour broadcast that broke a bit of new ground for glasnost.

title: A MIX OF DISCOS AND COZY CLUBS
description: Here is a sampling of Chelsea's clubs from 14th to 28th Streets, from east of Avenue of the Americas to the Hudson River. THE ANGRY SQUIRE (216 Seventh Avenue, near 22d Street, 242-9066): Traditional jazz. Sets daily at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 12:45 A.M. (Also Fridays, 6 to 8 P.M.) Cover charge: generally $4 to $8, plus a two-drink minimum. Lunch and dinner served. Jazz brunch Sundays, noon to 4 P.M. Reservations suggested. Tonight: Patricia Laing Trio. Tomorrow: Mark Ledonne and Tom Melito. Sunday: Connie Cobbs Trio. THE BALLROOM (253 West 28th Street, 244-3005): Cabaret, comedy and Off Broadway theater, as well as restaurant and tapas bar. Shows Tuesdays at 9 P.M., Wednesdays and Thursdays at 6:30 and 9 P.M., and Fridays and Saturdays usually at 6:30, 9 and 11 P.M. Cover charge: generally $10 to $15 ($25 for ''ringside''), plus a two-drink minimum. Dinner served. Reservations suggested. Tonight and tomorrow: Anita Ellis, 9 P.M., and ''Mixed Doubles,'' three comedy teams, 11 P.M. CAROLINE'S ON EIGHTH (332 Eighth Aenue, at 26th Street, 924-3499): Comedy. Shows Tuesdays to Thursdays and Sundays at 9 P.M.; Fridays at 8:30 and 11 P.M., Saturdays at 8 and 10 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. Cover charge: $7.50 on Tuesdays to Thursdays, $10 on Fridays and $12.50 on Saturdays, plus a two-drink minimum. Reservations required. This weekend's performers include Charles Zucker, Angela Scott, Stu Trivax. Every Saturday at 8 P.M.: the Groundlings. CHELSEA PLACE (147 Eighth Avenue, near 17th Street, 924-8413): Jazz and Top 40 music; restaurant. Jazz upstairs, Wednesdays to Saturdays beginning at 9 P.M. Cover charge: $10; no drink minimum. Downstairs, cocktail music from 5 to 8 P.M., and Top 40 bands from 8 P.M. to 4 A.M., seven nights a week. Dinner served. CHEVY'S (27 West 20th Street, 924-0205): Disco, with 1950's and 60's rock. Occasionally, live music. Open Mondays to Fridays for lunch, supper and dancing until 4 A.M., and Saturdays from 9 P.M. to 4 A.M. Cover charge: Free Mondays and Tuesdays before 8 P.M. ($5 after 8 P.M.), and $5 on Wednesdays to Saturdays. THE EAGLE TAVERN (355 West 14th Street, 924-0275): Irish folk music. Music on Mondays, Fridays and Saturdays, beginning at 9 P.M. Comedy on Tuesdays at 7 P.M. and Thursdays at 9 P.M. Free Mondays and Tuesdays; $4 on Thursdays (plus a one-drink minimum), $5 on Fridaysto Sundays. Tonight: Greg Ryan. Tomorrow: Christy Barry and Joe Kelly. LIMELIGHT (660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street, 807-7850): Disco. Open Sundays to Wednesdays from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M., and Thursdays to Saturdays from 9 P.M. to 4 A.M. Cover charge: $15 Sundays to Wednesdays; $18 Thursdays to Saturdays. NELL'S (246 West 14th Street, 675-1567): Disco and jazz. Open daily from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M. Cover charge: Sundays to Thursdays, $5; Fridays and Saturdays, $10. Fridays: the Shorty Jackson Band; Saturdays: the Jimmy Lewis Trio. 10/18 (515 West 18th Street, 645-5156): Disco, with live music some Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays. Usually open Wednesdays to Saturdays from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M. Cover charge: $15. Tonight: Judy Torres. Tomorrow: Promise Circle. THE TUNNEL (12th Avenue and 27th Street, 244-6444): Disco. Open daily from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M. Cover charge: $10 to $15 on weekdays, $20 Fridays and Saturdays.

title: LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,502,000 for the quarter and $3,909,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $807,000 for the quarter and $891,000 for the 9 months.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the trade deficit yesterday, as well as a stock market report in Business Day and an accompanying chart, misstated the ranking of Wednesday's 95.46-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. In percentage terms, the 3.81 percent loss was the 125th-largest decline in the 73 years that the average has been kept.

title: TV Weekend; 'Family Tree,' Comedy
description: EVIDENTLY convinced that we all could use a laugh these days, public television is bringing forth a prime-time comedy series. Yes, that's right, not another documentary on the disappearing ozone layer or the latest constitutional crisis but a bit of humor, in the form of six half-hour playlets with the umbrella title of ''Trying Times.'' The first, ''A Family Tree,'' can be seen at 10 P.M. Sunday on Channel 13. The list of talent credits for the series is certainly impressive. Phylis Geller, a public-television veteran, is the executive producer for Los Angeles station KCET. Over the years, she has been associated with an array of distinguished productions, ranging from ''The Great American Dream Machine'' to Wendy Wasserstein's ''Uncommon Women and Others'' and Tina Howe's ''Painting Churches.'' And with Jon S. Denny as creator and producer, ''Trying Times'' has recruited a stellar lineup. Among the directors: Jonathan Demme, Michael Lindsay-Hogg and Alan Arkin. Among the writers: Beth Henley, Spalding Gray, Christopher Durang and Ms. Wasserstein. Among the actors: Candice Bergen, Teri Garr, Mr. Gray, Swoosie Kurtz, Keanu Reeves, Ron Silver and Steven Wright.

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,470,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $4,759,000 for FHLB advance prepayment penalties for the 9 months. The latest quarter net includes a provision for possible loan losses of $1,070,000.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Struggles to Gain: Boris Becker of West Germany, the defending champion, moved into the quarterfinals of the $345,000 Australian indoor championship in Sydney yesterday, beating Sammy Giammalva of the United States, 6-3, 6-4. Becker, seeded second, had some difficulty coping with the powerful and accurate returns of Giammalva and had to vary his play throughout the 41-minute first set. He will meet eighth-seeded Paul Annacone in the quarterfinals today, following the American's 7-6, 7-6, second-round victory over Gary Muller of South Africa. Ramesh Krishnan of India beat Robert Seguso of the United States, 7-6, 6-4, and Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia defeated Christian Saceanu of West Germay, 6-3, 6-4. Krishnan will face top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia in the quarterfinals.(AP) Mayotte Gains in France: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte of the United States advanced to the quarterfinals of the $202,500 Toulouse Open in France yesterday by beating Nduka Odizor of Nigeria, 7-6, 6-3. Fifth-seeded Jan Gunarsson of Sweden fell to Patrick Kuhnen of West German in a second-round match, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Claudio Mazzadri of Switzerland, seeded eighth, barely survived as he edged Ben Testerman of the United States, 7-6, 6-7, 6-2.(AP) Harness Racing Sire Stakes Won in Record: Donald Dancer drove Lizzie Lee Brook to a world record for 2-year-old trotting fillies on a half-mile track, winning the $50,000 New Jersey Sire Stakes championship final Thursday at Freehold Raceway in Freehold, N.J., with a time of 1:59. Lizzie Lee Brook pulled away in the stretch, winning by 8 1/2 lengths over Lexie Lobell and R C's Night Breeze. It was the eighth victory in nine career starts for Lizzie Lee Brook, trained by Vernon Dancer and owned by Red Hill Stable of South Orange, N.J. At 2-5 odds, Lizzie Lee Brook paid $2.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Golf O'Meara Leads by 2: Mark O'Meara, who has not won on the American tour for two seasons, shot a nine-under-par 63 yesterday for a two-shot lead over J. C. Snead after the first round of the $600,000 Walt Disney World Golf Classic in Florida. O'Meara played the Lake Buena Vista course, the shortest and easiest of the three resort courses used in the event. Snead also had a bogey-free effort at Lake Buena Vista and was at 65.(AP)

title: CROSSLAND SAVINGS FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $14,363,000 for the quarter and $44,726,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $16,178,000 for the quarter and $40,499,000 for the 9 months.

title: STILL NO TREATY, SHULTZ DECLARES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a treaty with the Soviet Union eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles ''isn't buttoned up yet'' and that a summit meeting should be postponed if unexpected obstacles prevented the conclusion of the accord.

title: Advertising; Nissan Debut For Chiat/Day
description: The long-awaited Chiat/Day advertising for its new client, the Nissan Motor Corporation, will flash onto the TV screens of a waiting nation on ''Monday Night Football'' on the ABC-TV Network.

title: Advertising; G.E. Has Four Spots Ready for World Series
description: Among the advertisers on television broadcasts of the World Series will be General Electric, which has four new 60-second commercials from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn. These ads have the same high-quality production values as those of the last campaign, and although the line ''We bring good things to life'' seems not to be as dominant as it was previously, it is there.
