title: SOVIET, IN SWITCH, SAYS IT IS PAYING U.N. ALL IT OWES
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it was paying all its outstanding debts to the financially troubled United Nations, including $197 million for peacekeeping operations it has long refused to support.

title: U.S. CAUTIONS BONN THAT IT MAY FORCE THE DOLLAR LOWER
description: Against a backdrop of financial markets that have turned tempestuous over the trade deficit and interest rates, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d raised the possibility today of pushing down the dollar's value in reaction to recent increases in West Germany's rates.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A ROUSING new production called Encore, Encore has opened in the Broadway theater district. Housed in a dark stage set pierced by pinpoint lighting aimed at red carnations, this six-week-old venture is turning out some splendid contemporary American food at relatively moderate prices.

title: Breland Returning
description: Mark Breland, an Olympic gold medalist who lost the World Boxing Association welterweight title to Marlon Starling last August, will launch a comeback Dec. 5 at Caesars Atlantic City. Breland will fight Javier Suazo of Mexico in a preliminary to Evander Holyfield's scheduled 15-round defense of the World Boxing Association and International Boxing Federation junior heavyweight titles against Dwight Muhammad Qawi. Suazo has a 17-3-1 record with seven knockouts.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
What Yves Volel Gave Haiti
description: For some 17 years Yves Volel, who was assassinated in Haiti on Tuesday, was the resident revolutionary at the Dalton School in New York City. He had fled Haiti in 1965 to escape persecution by the Duvalier regime.

title: Film: 'Too Outrageous,' a Sequel
description: TEN years have passed since ''Outrageous'' first arrived, and since then what have its characters been thinking about? Their careers. Robin Turner (Craig Russell), the hairdresser-turned-female impersonator who began his nightclub routine in the earlier film, is still playing in small clubs, and his devoted friend Liza Connors (Hollis McLaren) hasn't yet fulfilled her dream of becoming a famous writer. Together, they talk a lot about making it big and being somebody.

title: Article 823687 -- No Title
description: A $1 million state grant to build a 16-bed residential care unit for homeless AIDS patients at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan was announced yesterday by Cesar A. Perales, the State Commissioner of Social Services.

title: Austria Protests Envoy's Remarks
description: The Austrian Government has protested to the State Department about a New York Times interview in which the American Ambassador to Austria suggested that the Austrian people harbor anti-Semitic feelings, a State Department official said today.

title: The Public's Right to Speedier Justice
description: The bicentennial of the Constitution and the attention focused on Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination have given us reason to look once again at the state of the judiciary as a whole. On this subject, however, debate has been overly intellectual and rarified. We have avoided the critical problems that plague participants in the legal system - judges, lawyers and litigants. And the most pressing of these are the twin demons of expense and delay.

title: Post Reporter Is Shoved By Top Aide to Speaker
description: A reporter was repeatedly shoved, then knocked to the floor today by a top aide to Assembly Speaker Mel Miller as the reporter tried to question the aide about possible improprieties involving the Assembly payroll.

title: Celtics Look at King
description: Bernard King, the Knicks' free agent who has played only six games in the last two seasons because of an injured knee, has passed a physical examination with the Boston Celtics. Dr. Arnold Scheller, Boston's team doctor, rated King's surgically reconstructed knee ''good to good plus.'' But before the Celtics can offer King an offer sheet, they must do some creative financing to get under the salary limit. King was paid $874,000 last season. Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager, said that King has not undergone a Knick physical. When asked why, Bianchi said, ''He refused.''

title: Wolff and Jerseyans
description: Hugh Wolff conducts the New Jersey Symphony in a program of works by Barber, Brahms and Beethoven tonight at 8:30 at the Count Basie Theater in Red Bank, N.J., tomorrow at 8 P.M. in War Memorial Theater in Trenton and Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Ritz Theater in Elizabeth, N.J. Tickets are $9.50 to $24. Information and directions: (201) 624-8203.

title: JOHN FLORY
description: John Flory, a producer of documentary, education and television films, died Oct. 7, at University Hospital in Cleveland. He was 77 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIAMOND SHAMROCK R&M reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss from a previously reported settlement with the Department of Energy of $9.3 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $40 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: India Slowing March on Tamils; It Will Add to Force in Sri Lanka
description: Indian troops trying to subdue ethnic Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka slowed their march toward a Tamil stronghold today to consolidate their forces, an Indian spokeswoman said here.

title: Rates Up In Wild Trading
description: After a day of wild gyrations, short- and long-term interest rates moved higher yesterday as the financial markets remained fearful about the effects of a weaker dollar.

title: Art People
description: Stella's Art

title: Seabrook Utility
description: New Hampshire's largest power company skipped a $37 million debt payment today, as expected. Public Service Company of New Hampshire directors met to discuss possible bankruptcy protection. A spokesman, John Cavanagh, refused to comment on the meeting but said the directors did not decide to seek voluntary protection immediately under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company has sunk $2.1 billion into the $5 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant, which is completed but unlicensed because of evacuation planning obstacles.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter and 9 months earnings restated to report the results of Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. under the equity method of accounting.

title: Meritor Financial Sets Restructuring
description: The Meritor Financial Group, which grew from being an obscure savings-and-loan company into a leading provider of non-bank services, announced a major restructuring yesterday.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Equipment Going to Gulf Fleet
description: The Navy said in a report today that all American warships in the Persian Gulf were being equipped with new damage control and firefighting apparatus as a result of the Iraqi missile attack on the frigate Stark in May.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A chronology on Wednesday recounting recent events in the Sri Lanka conflict misstated the month in which Sri Lanka and India signed an accord on Tamil autonomy and Indian peacekeeping forces began to land in northern Sri Lanka. The events occurred in July.

title: Belgian Leader Resigns for 2d Time in Dispute
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens offered his resignation to King Baudouin today in a language dispute involving a country mayor and his refusal to speak Flemish.

title: Shortage of Housing Keeps Children in Foster Care
description: Hundreds of children are forced to live in New York City's foster-care system solely because their parents have been unable to find suitable housing, according to a survey of private agencies released yesterday.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago results restated to include Commercial Bancshares, acquired in December 1986.

title: ONE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results include those of Bank of Hartford, acquired Feb. 23, 1986, and accounted for in a pooling-of-interests transaction. However, the year-ago per share earnings do not reflect results of Bank of Hartford because it was then a mutual savings institution with no shares outstanding.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Oslo dispatch on Wednesday about the awarding of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize misidentified one member of the prize committee. He is the Rev. Dr. Gunnar J. Staalsett, general secretary of the Lutheran World Federation. He is not a former head of the World Council of Churches.

title: ELIZABETH M. GORDON
description: Elizabeth Mary Gordon, a former supervisor of children's work at the Boston Public Library, died of cancer Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital. She was 85 years old.

title: SPATE OF FILM SERIES STARTS THIS WEEKEND
description: The New York Film Festival may have just ended, but screens around town are not going dim. This weekend, a panoply of film series gets under way, with bills to satisfy almost everyone's taste in movies.

title: Transamerica Gets Finance Company
description: The Transamerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire BWAC Inc. from the Borg-Warner Holdings Corporation for $782.5 million in cash. BWAC, based in Chicago, is a major commercial finance company whose businesses include the Borg-Warner Acceptance Corporation.

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $11,787,000 for the quarter and $135,620,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $92,501,000 for the quarter and $181,975,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest 9 months' extraordinary credit of $135,620,000 primarily represents $97.1 million in net gains from the second quarter tender of its Borg-Warner shares and $37.8 million in after-tax gains relating to the company's investment in Union Carbide Corp. The extraordinary credit of $181,975,000 for the year-ago 9 months primarily represented net gains resulting from the Union Carbide exchange offer in January 1986.

title: Medicare Tax Cap Is Target
description: Democratic tax writers in the Senate today proposed making all of an employee's wages subject to the Medicare portion of the Social Security payroll tax. At present, the 1.45 percent hospital insurance tax, paid by both employees and employers, is imposed only on the first $43,800 of an employee's annual wages.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of 64 cents a share, recorded in the second quarter, primarily reflecting completion of the sale of health technologies businesses, and other measures designed to improve productivity.

title: Deal for Cable Company Shifts Focus of Its Chief
description: Steven B. Dodge was fresh out of the Navy and was unsure whether he wanted to pursue a business career. Instead of going to business school he decided to join a bank training program to see how things worked out.

title: Prosecutor Studying Actions Of Meese While in the Cabinet
description: The special prosecutor's investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has recently been widened to include activities not only when Mr. Meese worked in the White House but also since he has been Attorney General, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $474,000 for the quarter and $27,471,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a tax credit of $6,882,000. c-After a loss of $9,428,000 for the quarter and income of $60,640,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Islanders Are Merely Perfect
description: There was a fight, which was expected. There were an assortment of foolish and nasty penalties, which for the two teams is by now rather de rigueur. In the end, though, there was absolutely no contest, which was nothing short of shocking.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Claiborne Cary, Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street (764-8930). Claiborne Cary is a cabaret performer in a classic tradition - a singer who can project gentle, appealing warmth as well as brash comedy, wrapping both extremes in a personal style that gives her performance strong individuality. She was just getting started in the early 1960's when the arrival of the Beatles wiped out cabaret, folk music and jazz, forcing Miss Cary to move out of cabaret to theater and television commercials. There she developed versatility that has enabled her to return to cabaret with broadened, more polished talents. With Buddy Barnes as her piano accompanist and occasional supporting singer, she is appearing at Jan Wallman's on Sunday nights during October. This Sunday she goes on at 6 and 8 P.M. with an $8 food and drink minimum and a $10 cover charge.

title: A Complex Trade Gap
description: Although the raw numbers show little improvement in the nation's trade deficit, Reagan Administration officials and other analysts paint a more more optimistic picture. They note, for instance, that the import totals have been swollen by price increases that conceal an underlyingshift favorable to the United States. Over the last 12 months, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, import prices have risen by 14.5 percent while export prices have gone up a much more modest 3.3 percent.

title: Supermarket For Newark: Plan Gains
description: The city's Board of Adjustment has approved a variance to permit construction of the first new supermarket here in more than 20 years.

title: G.O.P. Stand on Bork Angers Democrats
description: As the political antagonisms generated by Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court intensified today, the Senate Judiciary Committee issued a report saying he was unfit for the post because he was insensitive to individual rights and liberties.

title: Burkino Faso Leader Ousted In Coup Led by Chief Adviser
description: A group led by the chief adviser of President Thomas Sankara of Burkino Faso declared him a ''a traitor to the revolution'' today and seized the Government, the West African nation's official radio announced.

title: Queen, Expressing Sadness, Accepts End to Rule Over Fiji
description: Queen Elizabeth accepted the end of more than a century of British sovereignty over Fiji on Thursday, expressing sadness at the military takeover of power in the South Pacific nation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INSIDE
description: British Furor Over Gun Laws

title: Brock Will Leave Cabinet Nov. 1 To Join Dole's Presidential Effort
description: Labor Secretary William E. Brock announced today that he would leave President Reagan's Cabinet on Nov. 1 to run Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, saying Mr. Dole's ''extraordinary personal leadership'' and his appeal to independent voters made him the most formidable Republican candidate for the 1988 election.

title: Pickens Loses Newmont Plea
description: A state court ruled today that an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens Jr. cannot stop Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., a British company, from using its recently acquired controlling interest in the Newmont Mining Corporation to block Mr. Pickens's takeover bid.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Randy Weston, Mikell's, 769 Colum-bus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Randy Weston is a nomad. As a youngster, he traveled by subway, accompanying Thelonious Monk to house parties, studying the master's playing and awaiting his own turn at the keyboard. He gave some of the first concerts tracing the evolution of jazz from African sources, which led to a mid-60's African tour and a period of residence in Morocco. He currently divides his time between Morocco, Paris and Brooklyn; his appearances here are a rare treat. His cohorts at Mikell's are Talib Kibwe, a saxophonist, and Joe Gaines, a percussionist, who both happen to be ethnomusicologists. They have a particular affinity for Mr. Weston's colorful, cinematic music, which constitutes an emotionally and intellectually devastating autobiography, a nomad's round, unvarnished tale. Mr. Weston's trio is playing tonight and tomorrow night. Sets are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $12, with a $7 minimum.

title: BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $5.1 million, principally from the recognition of certain currency affects of the liquidation of a subsidiary, and an after-tax gain of $3.4 million from the sale of a shoe machinery business. c-Net loss and reflects a $90 million after-tax charge for restructuring. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: About Real Estate; In Connecticut, a Home Design Contest
description: When landowners consider selling tracts near their homes, their business goals may be in conflict with a desire to preserve their environment. Reconciling the conflict may be especially difficult in an area with an unspoiled rural character where most of the residents want it to be retained.

title: George Archinal Dies; Ex-Queens Legislator
description: George Archinal, a former New York State Assemblyman and Queens County Republican leader, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Glendale, Queens. He was 87 years old.

title: Man Struck in Howard Beach Recalls Start of Confrontation
description: In flat tones that contrasted sharply with the graphic scene he described, a young black man testified yesterday that 10 white youths wielding a baseball bat and other weapons confronted him and two other blacks in what the authorities say was the start of the Howard Beach racial assault.

title: 'Special Interests' Turned Upside Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucy Monroe Dies; A Celebrated Singer Of National Anthem
description: Lucy Monroe, who sang ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' at every New York Yankees opening day and every Yankees World Series between 1945 and 1960, died of cancer Tuesday at her Manhattan home. She was 80 years old.

title: MANVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes about $12.5 million of restructuring income, primarily related to the sales of the company's interests in two real estate joint ventures in the first quarter and the liquidation of a long-term receivable in the third quarter.

title: Quintuplets Born to Queens Woman
description: Alice and Angelo Cangialosi had been trying to have a baby for four years. Early this morning, Mrs. Cangialosi gave birth to five of them.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Paul Kurnit and Leonard Leokum have been named chief operating officer and executive vice president/ creative director, respectively, at Griffin Bacal.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Real Estate column on Wednesday, about speculation on parking lots, misattributed the statement that ''quite a few operators have prospered handsomely'' by selling real estate holdings and favorable long-term leases. It was made by Paul J. Massey Jr. of Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services, not by Bert Meers of LaSalle Partners.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,300,000 and $4,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,900,000 and $9,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain from the effect of an accounting change of $67,700,000.

title: Harvard Criticizes Book On Its Business School
description: Lawyers have briefed faculty members of the Harvard Business School about libel law as part of a counterattack on a new book that paints an unflattering portrait of the school and its faculty, people at the school said yesterday.

title: NACCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Need for Regulation, F.A.A. Chief Tells Panel
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration testified today that despite a ''crisis of public confidence'' in air safety, he did not believe regulation should be reimposed on the industry for safety reasons.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hughes Contracts
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it had received three contracts totaling $766 million from the Defense Department. The company said the largest of the three, a $495 million contract, calls for Hughes to produce nearly 3,300 thermal imaging systems and 1,560 laser range finder units plus spare parts for the Army's M1 Abrams battle tank over the next five years. Hughes said it had also received a $190 million production contract for weapon control systems for the Army's Bradley fighting vehicle, and an $81 million contract for more than 3,000 high-frequency radios for the Army, Marines, Air Force and Navy.

title: Hofstra Overlooks Playoffs
description: Hofstra University's football team, unbeaten halfway through its 10-game season and ranked No. 1 among 68 Division III teams in the Northeast, appears to be headed for the postseason playoffs.

title: AIDS VIRUS FOUND SLOWER TO SPREAD
description: The spread of the AIDS virus has slowed dramatically among homsexual men in San Francisco, according to preliminary results of a blood-testing program by the Federal Government.

title: What Can Be Done to Improve Building-Site Safety in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTHERING FOR PAY ASSAILED IN HOUSE
description: Mary Beth Whitehead and three other women who have given birth to babies under contract with childless couples pleaded with Congress today to outlaw surrogate mothering, at least for pay.

title: British Labor Is Bogged
description: The rule of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has become so firm, so unshakable that even some Tory supporters are coming to bemoan ''the lack of any real opposition.''

title: Highway Strip Recaptures Its Glory Days
description: A strange sound rumbles past William Massi's home on the Berlin Turnpike these days, traffic.

title: Mr. Gorbachev Rediscovers the U.N.
description: If his words have meaning, Mikhail Gorbachev is recasting Soviet policy toward the United Nations. Oratorically at least, he has seized the high ground once virtuously held by the United States. He talks of invigorating the Security Council and the World Court, of using peacekeeping forces in regional conflicts and establishing a U.N. tribunal on terrorism. And yesterday, as if to back up his words, Moscow declared it would pay all its overdue U.N. bills, including $197 million for peacekeeping operations it long opposed.

title: RISKY WORKS FROM STELLA AT THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
description: THE first thing to be said about ''Frank Stella: 1970-1987'' at the Museum of Modern Art is that it is a masterpiece of presentation. Not even the dungeonlike rooms to which the museum consigns its temporary exhibitions can spoil it, and what is waiting for us at the bottom of the escalator is an hour of euphoric buffeting that left this visitor amused, fortified and exhilarated.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $533,834,000, or $9.35 a share, net of non-recurring charges, on the sale of Himont stake in September for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also includes a gain of $90,515,000, or $1.58 a share, from the Himont public stock offering in February. c-Includes gains from the sale of various businesses of $11,464,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and $29,188,000, or 51 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: CBS GIVING PRIME TIME TO DOCUMENTARY SERIES
description: In a programming move that may result in the significant rebuilding of a CBS News staff decimated in the last two years by job and budget cutbacks, the network plans to put a regular weekly documentary series on the prime-time schedule beginning in January, CBS officials said yesterday.

title: Another Penguin-Ranger Tie
description: The game resolved very little, but it did provoke the new Ranger coach, Michel Bergeron, into his first fit of pique over his team's performance.

title: The Hypocrisy Industry
description: There is such a large measure of hypocrisy, falsehood and double-dealing in the relations among nations that we hardly notice when one more case crops up. That's life, so just walk on by.

title: New York Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Heyman Gets Rebuff at GAF
description: An independent committee of the GAF Corporation's board rejected an offer from a group headed by Samuel J. Heyman, the company's chairman, insiders said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's unfair to the players to continue making the great sacrifices they have made in the face of this blatant display of monopoly power. The player reps, therefore, voted today to send the players back to work.'' - Gene Upshaw, executive director of the National Football League Players'Association. [ A1:1. ]

title: Merrill TV Deal
description: The United Broadcasting Corporation said it had agreed to sell its three television stations for about $114 million to a fast-growing communications company backed by Merrill Lynch & Company. The stations being acquired by ML Media are KARK, an NBC affiliate in Little Rock; KDBC, a CBS affiliate in El Paso, Tex., and WTOK, an ABC affiliate in Meridian, Miss.

title: In Minneapolis, Hankies and Hysteria
description: The woman was on the phone and in a state of high anxiety in the lobby of The Star Tribune. She was calling for help.

title: SANTA FE SOUTHERN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1.4 million and $1.5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $3.7 million and $7.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a pre-tax charge of $130.6 million from impairments of oil and gas properties

title: Picturing Simon
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois recently dropped by the Washington bureau of The Chicago Tribune to help toast the newspaper's 140th year, and he encountered Jeff MacNelly, the newspaper's political cartoonist. Senator Simon told Mr. MacNelly of reading about a hope by cartoonists around the nation that Mr. Simon becomes the Democratic Presidential nominee. Mr. MacNelly agreed that he and his colleagues would consider the nomination of the Senator, who wears horn-rimmed glasses and a trademark bow tie, a bonanza for cartooning. But he told him not to count heavily on the cartoonist vote. ''There are only about 110 of us,'' he said.

title: Film: Christo, in 'Islands'
description: ''ISLANDS'' offers, among other things, a case history of the politics of esthetics, the case being Christo, the artist whose fancy it is to swathe large areas in fabrics of various hues. Albert Maysles, Charlotte Zwerin and David Maysles put their lightweight cameras and sound equipment to humorous use as they accompanied Christo into lobbying sessions with the West German Social Democratic leader Willy Brandt (about covering the Reichstag), with the Mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac, who has since also become Prime Minister (about covering the Pont Neuf), and with Miami officials (about creating floating borders made of ''a marvelous silky fabric'' for a group of islands in Biscayne Bay).

title: Knicks Trade Oldham for a Kings' Pick
description: Jawann Oldham, so unhappy with his role as a backup center and power forward last season that he asked to be traded, got his wish tonight. The Knicks sent the 7-foot-1-inch Oldham to the Sacramento Kings for the second of the Kings' two 1988 second-round draft choices. The Kings also own the Phoenix Suns' pick.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Demotes Top-Paid Official
description: Roslyn B. Payne, the highest-paid person on the Federal payroll, has been ousted from her job as chief executive of the Federal Asset Disposition Association, the embattled unit that administers loans and real estate obtained from failed savings and loan institutions.

title: STAGE: A MUSICAL, 'LATE NITE COMIC'
description: ''LATE NITE COMIC,'' the new Brian Gari-Allan Knee musical that opened last night at the Ritz Theater, is the first musical comedy in which the hero longs to be Rodney Dangerfield - and in which the heroine dreams about dancing at the Metropolitan Opera House, rather than, for example, with the New York City Ballet. It is also a show without a director. Philip Rose, who guided the show during its pre-Broadway tryout, has had his name removed from the credits. This could be compared to the captain of the Titanic having his name removed from the ship's log after the ship hit the iceberg.

title: From the Japanese, Ruffles and Whimsy
description: Under sodden skies, the French ready-to-wear showings for spring and summer came alive today with two major collections by Japanese designers. Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garcons and Yohji Yamamoto have displayed continuous growth as designers since they first showed their collections here six years ago. While their clothes would never be confused with Western classics, they are less ferocious than they were in the beginning and are a constant stimulus to avant-garde designers here and in other fashion centers. Miss Kawakubo and Mr. Yamamoto seem fearless and inventive, rare qualities in designers anywhere.

title: Cuomo Role in G.O.P. Debate
description: The Des Moines Register announced yesterday that Governor Cuomo of New York and Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois would ask the questions of Presidential candidates in debates to be sponsored by the newspaper in January.

title: Psychics Meet Wall Street
description: An excursion boat called the Dolley Madison became a ship of seers Wednesday night as 120 young professionals from Wall Street, Madison Avenue and Seventh Avenue signed on for what was billed as a three-hour psychic business cruise. Some said it was no coincidence that the Dow Jones industrial average had plunged 95.46 points a few hours before.

title: Broadway
description: 'Mahabharata' Is Selling Fast

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Trenet Sings His Farewell To America
description: CHARLES TRENET says that there are only three famous hats in the history of France: Napoleon's bicorn, Maurice Chevalier's straw boater and his own battered beige felt.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on investments by its First Colony Life Insurance Co. unit of $4,356,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $12,692,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on investments by its First Colony Life Insurance Co. unit of $6,492,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $16,643,000, or 13 cents a share, for the 9 months. The year-ago results restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension expense.

title: Advertising; Costs Dip For TV Ad Production
description: AND now for the good news.

description: OUT ON THE RIM. By Ross Thomas. 314 pages. Mysterious Press. $17.95.

AMCORE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Deep Spending Cuts Forecast In '88 Under New Budget Law
description: Military programs in the 1988 budget will have to be cut by more than 10 percent and domestic spending by almost 9 percent if $23 billion in automatic spending cuts are put into effect this year, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: Duarte Seems to Back Contra Aid Halt
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that no new military aid should be given to the Nicaraguan rebels until at least January so a Central American peace plan can succeed.

title: Chemical Bank Lifts Prime Rate 1/2 Point, to 9 3/4
description: The Chemical Bank raised its prime lending rate yesterday by a half-point, to 9 3/4 percent. The increase was the second in a week, and it brought the key rate to the highest level since the summer of 1985.

title: ROYAL TRUSTCO LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split declared in August.

title: Santa Fe Receives Bids for Southern Pacific Unit
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation received several bids yesterday for its Southern Pacific Transportation Corporation, including one from the railroad's employees.

title: Fighting to Salvage A Black Unit's Esteem
description: It has been a lonely, long-distance struggle for David K. Carlisle. But his persistence - some say pestering - has shown that one man can move the bureaucracy here.

title: Or, E Pluribus Unum
description: To the Editor:

title: A Karpov Triumph, a la Kasparov
description: Anatoly Karpov unsettled Gary Kasparov with a surprising gambit in his opponent's style to win the second game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Wednesday.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $9,802,000 on the sale of Hygeia Sciences Inc. common stock and an after-tax loss of $7,123,000 on the disposition of two wholly owned subsidiaries. c-After an extraordinary charge of $961,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time pre-tax charge of $30 million for possible losses on loans to developing countries. The year-ago figures restated to include results of Merchants Bancorp, which was acquired on Dec. 31, 1986.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coca-Cola Net Climbs 16.4%
description: The Coca-Cola Company, reporting its corporate profits for the first time in Japan, said today that strong sales of soft drinks in the Pacific region had led to a 16.4 percent increase in net income in the third quarter.

title: Plane With 37 Aboard Crashes in Italian Alps
description: An Italian airliner carrying 37 people on a flight from Milan to West Germany slammed into the northern foothills of the Italian Alps during a heavy rainstorm tonight, authorities said.

title: Campaign Finance; After Bush, Robertson Is 2d in Fund-Raising
description: The Presidential campaign of Pat Robertson reported today that it had raised $11.7 million since July 21, 1986, and announced that it would apply for Federal matching funds, a move campaign officials earlier scorned.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last December.

title: Strikers' Elation Soon Turns Into Dejection and Confusion
description: Elation, dejection and, above all, confusion marked the 24th and final day of the National Football League players' strike yesterday.

title: Two Fast Colts in Champagne
description: Now is the time of the 2-year-olds, and Belmont Park's final Saturday of racing tomorrow will feature a pair of Grade I stakes races at a mile that should clarify the shape of things to come.

title: GERMAN'S DEATH SEEN AS SUICIDE
description: The storm of speculation about the death of a beleaguered West German politician whose body was found in the bathtub of a Geneva hotel last Sunday seemed to subside today, with indications the Swiss authorities were nearing a suicide ruling.

title: DAVID J. TAYLOR
description: David J. Taylor, conference services manager of the Boston World Trade Center, died Saturday at Charlton Memorial Hospital in Fall River, Mass., of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. He was 26 years old.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax loss of $13,553,000, or 98 cents a share, on the sale of the company's Mexican carpet operations. c-Includes an after-tax charge of $4.3 million, or 31 cents a share, to restructure the company's domestic carpet business. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $623,000 for the quarter and $1,148,000 for the 9 months from the sale of investments. c-Includes capital gains of $970,000 for the quarter and $1,427,000 for the 9 months from the sale of investments.

title: U.S. Companies Want Their Tankers Protected
description: Worried that their oil tankers are now more susceptible to attacks by Iran, American companies owning or chartering ships in the Persian Gulf that fly foreign flags have asked the Reagan Administration to consider protecting them as it does American-flagged Kuwaiti tankers.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension costs by a charge of $2 million for the third quarter, and $6 million for the 9 months.

title: PHILIP MORRIS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects a pretax charge of $117,000,000 for the restructuring of General Foods Corp., partially offset by a pretax gain of $46,000,000 from the sale of the Open Pit Barbecue Sauce business. These items adversely affected net earnings and earnings per share for the quarter by $22,000,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Witness Denies Inconsistencies In Zaccaro Trial
description: The prosecution's main witness in the trial of John A. Zaccaro said yesterday that prosecutors should not have been surprised when he testified he did not believe Mr. Zaccaro had tried to extort a bribe.

title: Dow Tumbles by 57.61; Volume Climbs Sharply
description: The stock market headed sharply downward again yesterday as a spate of program selling set in during the last half-hour of trading.

title: U S Sprint Plans To Cut 2% of Jobs
description: The U S Sprint Communications Corporation, the struggling long-distance phone carrier owned by the GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., said it planned to cut 2 percent of its 13,500 employees, primarily through attrition, as part of a major reorganization.

title: Retail Sales Down 0.4% in September
description: Retail sales fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in September after a strong summer, the Government said today. Economists said the weakness was likely to continue as debt-laden consumers cut back spending.

title: Mile-Square Reef Is Begun
description: The building of the nation's biggest man-made rock reef, to be spread over a mile-square section of ocean bottom, began Wednesday. Biologists said the reef, to be completed in about 10 days, would reestablish the Santa Monica Bay as a thriving fish breeding ground. Tractors began shoving quarry rock brought by barge from Santa Catalina Island into the sea a mile off Will Rogers State Beach.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 407 money market mutual funds grew $1.16 billion, to $247.18 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 107 institutional funds fell $30.5 million, to $65.08 billion. The 207 general purpose funds rose $763.2 million, to $74 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds rose $424.2 million, to $108.1 billion.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,046,000 for the quarter and $14,824,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $8,069,000 for the quarter and $25,472,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary charges of $2,030,000 and $9,769,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Fruehauf said share earnings for the 1986 periods are not presented because the capitalization was not comparable to the new capital structure.

title: Cardinals Trying to Adjust to Closed-In Conditions
description: Whitey Herzog pushed back the bill of his cap and gazed for a moment at the roof inside the Metrodome. Then he slowly shook his head.

title: CHELSEA: WHERE THE AVANT-GARDE RUBS SHOULDERS WITH OLD NEW YORK
description: CHELSEA has perfected one of the great tricks of cultural geography: how to hide a 75-square-block neighborhood on the edge of midtown Manhattan and Greenwich Village. For years, the area has been touted as ''up and coming,'' yet, to the relief of many longtime residents, it has remained in the shadows of its more glittery neighbors. But this great chunk of western Manhattan -from the Avenue of the Americas to the Hudson River and from 14th Street to about 28th Street - includes some of New York's finest 19th-century town houses and churches, and a wealth of historic buildings like the legendary Chelsea Hotel and the idyllic campus of the General Theological Seminary.

title: Smoke-Free Places At Federal Offices Termed Inadequate
description: Federal agencies have failed to adopt policies that adequately separate nonsmoking employees from those who smoke, according to a federally commissioned report released today.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $8.5 million, a gain of $2.8 million on the sale of a product line and charges of $2.7 million for higher accruals related to compensation plans tied to the price of the company's common stock. c-Includes a gain of $9 million from a contract settlement. Preferred stock dividends exceeded net in the year-ago quarter.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Study Sees Tough Battle For Swing Vote in South
description: Voters in the South who helped elect and re-elect Ronald Reagan to the Presidency but also helped the Democrats retake control of the Senate last year show signs of voting Republican in substantial numbers in the 1988 Presidential election, a major new study said today.

title: Guitar in Brooklyn
description: Anton del Forno is to give a guitar recital Sunday at noon in the third-floor lecture hall at the Brooklyn Museum, 1200 Eastern Parkway, at Rochester Avenue. The concert, which is free, features works by Villa-Lobos, Albeniz, Sor and others. Information: (718) 783-3077.

title: No Excuse Not to Register
description: Most New Yorkers readily express their outrage at political corruption and misspent tax dollars. Far fewer follow through at the ballot box: fully 40 percent of the city's five million eligible voters don't bother to register. In Queens, less than 55 percent sign up to vote. Mayor Koch deserves praise for a new drive to improve the record.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to give effect to the 2-for-1 stock split effected as a 100 percent common stock dividend to shareholders of record May 1, 1987.

title: Film: Brazilian 'Vera'
description: ''VERA,'' the first feature film by a new young Brazilian director named Sergio Toledo, is about an unhappy young woman, reared in a Sao Paolo orphanage, who becomes convinced she is a man inhabiting a female body. The tone of the film is serious, matter-of-fact, even-tempered.

title: Iran Missile Hits A Gulf Tanker Owned in U.S.
description: An Iranian missile struck an American-owned tanker in Kuwaiti waters today, causing a huge explosion and setting the tanker ablaze, the Pentagon said. But the Reagan Administration ruled out a response because the ship was not flying the American flag and was not in international waters.

title: WORLD SERIES '87: Cardinals' Depth Must Rise Above Twins' Dome; The Big Inning Is Minnesota Strength
description: Nobody in the National League has experienced anything like the Dome. That's the Metrodome, home of the Minnesota Twins. If there's one factor that could give the Twins an edge in the World Series, that's it.

title: Wherehouse Veto
description: Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., a 200-store music, video and software retailer, rejected a $121.5 million takeover bid from Shamrock Holdings Inc., saying the company can achieve ''higher value'' by remaining independent. Shamrock, meanwhile, said it had increased its stake in Wherehouse to 10.17 percent, from 6.65 percent. Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., is an investment company controlled by the Roy E. Disney family. It had said it was prepared to sweeten its $14.25-a-share bid. Wherehouse stock closed at $13.375 today, up 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. Wherehouse is based in Torrance, Calif.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After tax credits of $5,973,000 for the quarter and $576,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dining Out Guide; Chelsea
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHELSEA CENTRAL, #227 10th Avenue, near 24th Street (620-0230) -

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $11,586,000 and $148,963,000 related to the rate allowance on cost overruns at the San Onofre nuclear plant for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for the 9 months also includes an extraordinary credit of $68,044,000 from an accounting change.

title: Royals Changes
description: Four coaches, including Hal McRae, who late last season passed up an offer to become manager of the Kansas City Royals and the fourth black manager ever in the major leagues, will not return to the Royals as batting coach in 1988. The pitching coach, Gary Blaylock, the third-base coach, Jose Martinez, and the first-base coach, Joe Jones, will also leave. Only the bullpen coach, Jim Schaffer, and Ed Napoleon, a scout, will return to the staff of Manager John Wathan. The Royals said that they asked McRae to stay as either a major-league or minor-league hitting instructor, but could not reach agreement. McRae turned down the manager offer after Manager Billy Gardner was dismissed last season. Mike Lum, a 15-year major-league veteran, will replace McRae as hitting coach. Lum was the team's minor league hitting instructor this past season.

title: DAVID DELAHANTY
description: Brother David Delahanty, president of Lewis University in Romeoville, Ill., a private institution run by the Christian Brothers, died of cancer Tuesday at the De La Salle Hall of Lincroft, N.J., a Christian Brothers medical facility. He was 52 years old. Brother Delahanty had been president of Lewis since 1982. He was a former dean of the school of education and human services at Manhattan College.

title: A.T.&T. Executive To Head Data Unit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has granted Vittorio Cassoni what he has been seeking: his own sales force to sell the company's computers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1987
description: International A3-11

title: Philharmonic
description: Miriam Fried is to be the violin soloist with the New York Philharmonic tomorrow evening at 8 in Avery Fisher Hall. Ms. Fried is to perform the Brahms Violin Concerto on a program, conducted by Feliz Kruglikov, that also includes Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony. Tickets are $7.50 to $30. Information: 874-2424.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The possibility of U.S. moves to push the dollar down was raised by Treasury Secretary Baker in reaction to recent interest rate increases by West Germany. He said Bonn's action, which was the fourth increase since July, was inconsistent with ''the spirit of our recent consultations.'' A weaker dollar would hurt the West German economy by making its exports more expensive but could also cause higher interest rates and inflation in the United States, two prospects that are already roiling the American financial markets. Mr. Baker's remarks were made as he and other Administration economic officials tried to soothe investor fears. [ Page A1. ] Chemical Bank raised its prime rate half a point, to 9 3/4 percent, saying that its cost of funds had increased. Other banks are expected to follow Chemical's lead soon. [ D6. ] An expansion of part of the Social Security tax was proposed by Democratic tax writers in the Senate. They suggested that all of an employee's wages be made subject to the Medicare portion of the payroll tax. At present, the 1.45 percent hospital insurance tax is imposed only on the first $43,800 of annual wages. [ D1. ] The highest-paid Federal employee will step aside as chief executive of the Federal Asset Disposition Association, which has sold only a tiny fraction of the loans and real estate obtained from failed savings and loan associations. But Roslyn B. Payne, who received $325,000 last year, will remain at the agency as a specialist. [ D1. ] Harvard Business School is counterattacking a book that offers an unflattering portrait of it and its faculty. Harvard lawyers have briefed professors about libel law and some faculty members say they are considering taking legal action. [ D1. ] Santa Fe Southern Pacific received several bids for its Southern Pacific Transportation unit, one of its two railroads. [ D2. ] Retail sales fell 0.4 percent in September after a strong summer. The decline was led by weakness in automobile sales, which fell 1.4 percent in September after a 5.7 percent increase in August. [ D5. ] MARKETS A day of wild gyrations in the credit markets ended with generally higher interest rates. Traders were concerned about official hints that the U.S. might allow the dollar to weaken, a move that could add to inflationary pressures and force the Federal Reserve to tighten its monetary policy. One area in which yields fell was the safe haven of three-month Treasury bills, where demand was heavy from investors apparently weary of taking risks. [ D1. ] Stocks took another sharp plunge as a wave of selling set in during the final half-hour of trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 57.61 points, or 2.39 percent, to 2,355.09. That came after Wednesday's record point drop of 95.46. Volume was the fourth-largest ever, at 263.2 million shares. The late selling wave came from program trading, said analysts, who added that the stage was set by the rise in the prime lending rate. [ D6. ] The dollar turned mostly lower as the disappointing August trade report continued to dampen sentiment toward the currency. Gold prices rose to $463.50 an ounce in New York, up $2.25. [ D13. ] Precious metals futures prices advanced but gave up some of their gains late in the session. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Meritor Financial plans a restructuring that will leave it with a $379.6 million quarterly loss and sharply curtailed expansion plans. Its main subsidiary is the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society. [ D5. ] Transamerica agreed to acquire BWAC Inc. from the Borg-Warner Holdings Corporation for $782.5 million. BWAC, based in Chicago, is a major commercial finance company. [ D5. ] Times Mirror is buying four magazines from Diamandis for $167.5 million. They are Field & Stream, Home Mechanix, Skiing and Yachting. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Although the falling stock market may be implying an economic downturn in the near future, many economists do not expect a recession until 1989. The market is right, though, to worry about thedollar. Leonard Silk. Ecomomic Scene. [ D2. ] This ''October Massacre'' of stocks has reached daunting proportions, amid a growing consensus that the five-year-old bull market may be at a critical juncture. Doubts are even emerging about the optimistic earnings forecasts that have been a principal prop of the market in recent months. Market Place. [ D1. ]

title: American Symphony
description: The American Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jose Serebrier, is to perform works by Shostakovich, Mussorgsky and Ravel and the premiere of Morton Gould's ''Flares and Declamations,'' Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. A preconcert recital at 2 P.M. is to be given by Ben Holt, baritone. Tickets are $6 to $21. Information: 247-7800.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $11,314,000.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' loss reflects an additional loan loss provision of $91 million.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a $9 million provision to cover anticipated losses on the discontinuance of Lockheed's shipbuilding operations for the quarter and a loss of $15 million from discontinued shipbuilding operations for the 9 months. c-After losses from the discontinued shipbuilding operations of $1 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 16, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Jackson and Jews Are at Odds Again
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has given a magazine interview that, while clearly meant to improve his relations with Jews, has done more to irritate than heal, initial reaction from some Jewish leaders indicated yesterday.

title: Film: 20th 'Tournee of Animation'
description: AS Mondrian-like bars of color race up and down walls, and Matisse-inspired dancers sail across the screen, it becomes clear that the ''20th International Tournee of Animation'' is not a kiddy cartoon festival. An annual compilation of the best short animated films from around the world may sound hokey or stuffy, but this year's selections are stylish and sophisticated. They so often resemble paintings come to life that the tournee may appeal to art lovers as much as animation fans.

title: EXPERIMENTAL WORKS AND CLASSICS IN THEATERS
description: Outside the Times Square-Theater Row axis, Chelsea has the highest density of theater activity of any New York neighborhood. The area is notable especially for performance spaces that present quality dance and avant-garde performance.

title: Restaurants
description: THREE-MONTH-OLD Chin Chin is the most stylish and enticing Chinese restaurant to open this year. If you have a flash of deja vu there, chances are you are familiar with Auntie Yuan on First Avenue near 65th Street, where James Chin worked as manager for five years. The other half of the eponymous duo is his brother, Wally.

title: A Second Mass Killing in Britain Raises Call for Tighter Gun Laws
description: Britain's second multiple killing in two months has increased pressure on the Thatcher Government to strengthen controls on gun ownership and television violence.

title: Mafia Runs Fulton Fish Market, U.S. Says in Suit to Take Control
description: Federal prosecutors filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to seize control of the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan, declaring that it is dominated by the Mafia.

title: Top-Secret Plane Is Said to Crash; Air Force Confirms Death of Pilot
description: A Stealth aircraft, designed to elude radar, crashed Wednesday night at an Air Force base in Nevada, Government officials said today.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wall Street's Dizzy Dive
description: The significance of America's foreign trade deficit has finally jolted Wall Street - but not, alas, Washington.

title: Market Place; Analysts Try to Put Plunge in Context
description: As ''October Massacres'' go, the stock market's current slide is already daunting.

title: Sheffield Arrested
description: Gary Sheffield, Dwight Gooden's nephew and a minor leaguer in the Milwaukee organization, may be in trouble again. The 19-year-old shortstop was placed on probation in January after pleading no contest to battery and resisting arrest during an incident involving Gooden and Tampa police officers in December. On Tuesday, Sheffield was was booked into the Hillsborough County Jail on charges of driving while intoxicated, eluding police and speeding, Sgt. Jerry Dejong said. He was released early Wednesday on $1,000 bond. If he is convicted, he could face up to five years in prison for violating his probation, according to a corrections official in Tampa, Fla.

title: Miami Upgrades
description: Administators at the University of Miami, who think faculty leaders are opposed to lenient standards for athletes, are proposing to toughen academic requirements. Among the proposals, which may take effect on Nov. 1, are requiring freshmen to pass a six-week program called the Freshman Institute before gaining admission; elimination of certain academic majors such as physical education and recreation; using a score below 900 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test to define certain students as marginal and those with a score below 700 as virtually unadmittable.

title: Edward L. Love Dies; Ex-Officer With Chase
description: Edward L. Love, who rose from bank messenger to become executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Thursday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla., where he had lived since the mid-1960's. A former Staten Island resident, he was 92 years old.

title: Lacroix's Second Tour de Force
description: Three months after he captured the attention of the fashion world with his first couture collection, Christian Lacroix has scored a second hit. Expanding into ready-to-wear, he presented a spring and summer collection today that is fresh, exuberant and will surely change the way people think about clothes for a long time to come. In the first of a series of small showings in his salon at 73 rue du Faubourg St.-Honore, he proved he is not a one-shot designer. The collection, which he simply calls Luxe, is full of the color and wit that marked his made-to-order clothes. But it is also brilliantly thought out, making its impact with economy and intelligence. Because of its focus, some believe it will have even more impact than the couture collection.

title: U.S., Facing Criticism, Drops Plan to Cut Benefits for Poor
description: Under a hail of criticism, the Administration quickly retreated today from its policy of reducing welfare benefits for elderly, blind and disabled people who receive free food, clothing or shelter from churches and charities.

title: Chip Maker's Profits Surge
description: Texas Instruments Inc., reporting strong orders in both semiconductors and military electronics, said today that its third-quarter profits jumped sharply, to $69.1 million, or 79 cents a share, from $14 million, or 14 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 13 percent, to $1.42 billion, from $1.25 billion.

title: Geologically, Uniform Doesn't Mean Gradual
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS WIN AGAIN AT HOME
description: Solid defense, sharp goaltending by Alain Chevrier and intelligent play in the last period carried the Devils to a 4-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: TYSON RETAINS TITLE IN 7 ROUNDS
description: Mike Tyson came into the ring tonight with one thought on his mind: no mercy. Tyrell Biggs came into the ring with a slogan on the back of his robe: ''Realize Your Potential.''

title: The $100,000 Final Exam
description: Outrageous! That was the widespread reaction to the tantalizing finder's fee Asher Edelman dangled before his students at Columbia Business School. How dare he introduce gross materialism into academia? The reaction is understandable when business schools are under fire for turning out students too devoted to money. But why such intense reaction? Was the offer really so gross?

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Italy Reports That 37 Died In Crash of Airliner in Alps
description: A rescue team descended from helicopters into the foothills of the Italian Alps today and found the wreckage of an Italian airliner that crashed in a rainstorm, killing all 37 people aboard.

title: American Airlines Sues Texas Air
description: American Airlines has filed a lawsuit charging the Texas Air Corporation with offering illegal tactics to persuade travel agencies to switch to Texas Air's computer reservation systems. The lawsuit, which seeks more than $100 million in damages, was filed Thursday in state district court in Fort Worth. It charged that Texas Air illegally induced travel agents who subscribe to American's Sabre reservations to switch to Texas Air's System One.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $6.5 million from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $9,315,000. c-After tax credits of $4,115,000 for the quarter and $10,846,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a credit of $2,595,000 from renegotiation of an executory contract.

title: Hours-Old Boy in California Becomes Youngest Person to Undergo Heart Transplant
description: Doctors this afternoon transplanted a new heart into a Canadian infant with a fatal heart defect just three hours after the baby had been delivered by Caesarean section.

title: COMPUTERS HANDLE VOLUME WITH EASE
description: Barely 20 years ago, when Wall Street labored with pen and pencil and messengers scurried through the city with briefcases loaded with stocks and bonds, the industry almost collapsed when trading volume approached a mere 20 million shares.

title: Sports People; Encyclopedic Jordan
description: The universal appeal of Michael Jordan has put him among 70 new entries in the World Book Encyclopedia. Jordan, the ninth professional basketball player to be included, was chosen for his scoring achievments and spectacular dunk shots, the World Book editors said.

title: INTERIM ROSTER INCREASED TO 85
description: The National Football League players who were told Thursday that they would not play until next weekend learned yesterday they would find something other than an empty locker room waiting for them.

title: The N.F.L. Thumbs Its Nose
description: Only after their strike collapsed did the National Football League players start looking like credible members of the proletariat - because the team owners behaved like incredible villains.

title: Company News; Railroad Gets Takeover Bids
description: Seven offers to buy the Southern Pacific Railroad have been put forward, ranging from $750 million to more than $1 billion, the parent Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Why No Honorifics? Newspapers Are Making a Ms.stake
description: LEAD: I must have been out to lunch when momentous changes were taking place in American newspapers.Almost universally, I read of

title: Profit Report From Schwab
description: Buoyed by increased market activity, the Charles Schwab Corporation today reported income for the third quarter of $11.5 million, or 41 cents a share, on revenues of $116.3 million.

title:
PATENTS;
A Composition to Aid Body's Immune System
description: LEAD: Dr. A. Arthur Gottlieb, president of Imreg Inc., a biotechnology company in New Orleans, was granted a patent this week for a composition stimulating the immune system of the body.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Plunge
description: Treasury bill rates fell sharply yesterday as the steep drop in stock prices led many speculators and investors to put their funds in the safest securities they could find.

title: Dance: Old and New Mix In Rod Rodgers Opening
description: The world of Rod Rodgers, a former Erick Hawkins dancer and noted New York choreographer, is a mostly tranquil one. Its passions are expressed quietly and at a somewhat cerebral distance. That distance and contemplativeness can seem maddeningly disengaged. But if no rockets went off on Wednesday when the Rod Rodgers Dance Company opened its 20th-anniversary season at the Negro Ensemble Company's Theater Four, the evening had its quiet pleasures.

title: Pop: Mary Wilson, Singer
description: Even more than the songs of the Beatles, the music that has become synonymous with mid-1960's pop nostalgia is the string of hits created for the Supremes by the Motown songwriting and producing team of Holland-Dozier-Holland. For any singer with more than half a voice, songs like ''You Keep Me Hangin' On,'' ''Stop! In the Name of Love'' and ''Back in My Arms Again'' are sure-fire crowd pleasers. And if the vocalist happens to be one of the original Supremes, so much the better.

title: MINNESOTA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Cites Faulty Alarm In Detroit Jetliner Crash
description: Because an alarm system was not working, the pilots of a jetliner that crashed in Detroit in August were not warned that their plane's wing flaps were improperly positioned, according to evidence presented today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: FIRST DIRECT RAID
description: An American-registered tanker was hit by a missile, apparently Iranian, in Kuwaiti waters this morning, Kuwaiti and American officials said.

title: 2 More Banks Lift Prime Rate
description: The Marine Midland Bank and the Republic National Bank of New York raised their prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday to 9 3/4 percent, following the lead set Thursday by the Chemical Bank.

title: Recital: Vladimir Krainev
description: In several ways, though not necessarily the most important ones, Vladimir Krainev is an extraordinary pianist. Like many other Soviet musicians, he remains relatively unknown in this country, despite having won the Gold Medal in Moscow's prestigious Tchaikovsky Competition 17 years ago. Mr. Krainev, now 43 years old, performed works by Chopin, Ravel, Scriabin and Prokofiev before a small audience in Town Hall Wednesday evening.

title: In Bucharest, History Is Being Buried
description: To the Editor:

title: VAN DORN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Subway Performers Told to Keep Their Distance
description: Performers, peddlers and proselytizers would be banned from city subway trains and buses under a policy unveiled yesterday by the Transit Authority.

title: WILLIAMS, W W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Refugees From Sri Lanka Battles Tell of Hunger and Dead Civilians
description: Caught in a battle between Indian forces and ethnic Tamil guerrillas, residents of a northern town are trying to flee by any means possible, refugees reaching here said in interviews today. They told of hunger verging on starvation and of the killings of civilians by Indian troops.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-5, 32

title: A Dilemma For Reagan: Without a Reprisal, He Might Lose Face
description: On May 27, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, one of the key Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, warned that ''the environment surrounding our Navy in the Persian Gulf is as dangerous as the exposure of our Marines in Beirut.''

title: A Chance to Forge Stronger Indian-American Ties
description: LEAD: Unlike previous Administrations, President Reagan and his advisers believe India is an important country.

title: GLEASON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an after-tax restructuring and disposal charge of $952,000.

title: Film Maker Wed To Sarah Buttrick
description: Sarah Buttrick and Hugo Cassirer were married last evening at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in Manhattan by the Rev. Ernest Hunt. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Buttrick of New York. Mr. Cassirer is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reinhold Hans Cassirer of Johannesburg.

title: Hans Gatzke, 71, Dies; Taught History at Yale
description: Dr. Hans W. Gatzke, a professor emeritus of history at Yale University, died of cancer Sunday in the Yale infirmary. He was 71 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: Ideology Isn't What Sank the Fortas Nomination
description: To the Editor:

title: Twins' Success Kindles Memories of '65
description: It seems like only yesterday, the recollections still fresh, the cheers faintly echoing in their ears. The success of the Minnesota Twins is giving a new generation of fans its first taste of victory, but it is also enabling the players in the class of '65 to savor their own championship season again. Those were the good old days in Minnesota until now.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Police Say Larry Davis Won't Discuss Drug Reports
description: The Internal Affairs Division of the New York City police has unsuccessfully tried to interview Larry Davis about his assertions of police complicity in drug sales, according to a letter from the division to Mr. Davis's lawyer.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $75,000.

title: Ex-Speaker and 4 Others Receive Roosevelt Medals
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., former Speaker of the House, and four other distinguished Americans were honored here today near the home of Franklin D. Roosevelt for maintaining the freedoms that he believed were the basis of democracy.

title: BUTLER, JOHN O CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Correction
description: A television program listing on Tuesday and a picture caption about the same program, ''Intercom:

title: Spencer Is Acquitted
description: A Palm Beach Circuit Court jury in Florida found former Brian Spencer not guilty of first-degree murder. The jurors deliberated only an hour yesterday before delivering the verdict. The judge ordered the jury not to talk to reporters.

title: Lawrence Dutton Marries Ms. Lim
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting last evening for the wedding of Elizabeth Sung-Jin Lim, a daughter of Kimberly S. H. Lim of Omaha, and the late Dr. Thomas P. K. Lim, to Lawrence Willard Dutton. The bridegroom is the son of Ruth Marjorie Dutton of Wantagh, L.I., and the late Willard Lee Dutton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl Nelson.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. Other rules remain in effect.

title: Vancouver Journal; Echoes of Empire, and a Commonwealth on Edge
description: Prime ministers and presidents attending the opening of the 28th Commonwealth Conference rose here the other day to express pleasure at meeting in this city by mountains, forests and sea. Then Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain approached the podium, brisk as usual. The way she spoke of the venue proved a harbinger of uneasy times.

title: Owners Are Seen as Winners
description: The reluctant decision of the National Football League Players Association to end its 24-day strike may be important not only for the nation's professional athletes but also for many other wage earners.

title: Baroque Vesper Music
description: A concert of Italian Baroque vesper music will be presented today at 8 P.M. at the Middle School in Hudson, N.Y., in Columbia County by the Hudson Valley Choral Society of the Clarion Concerts Orchestra. Admission: $7.50. Information: (518) 325-3847. To get there, take the Taconic State Parkway north, Route 82 and Route 9 into Hudson and follow the signs to the Fireman's Home; the Middle School is across the road.

title: Rising Art Prices Worry Museums
description: The hottest name in the art world today is Vincent van Gogh, whose works, almost a century after his suicide, are turning the market upside down.

title: Senate Panel Approves $11.6 Billion Tax Plan
description: Despite a threatened veto by President Reagan, the Senate Finance Committee today approved an $11.6 billion tax increase package, with two of nine Republicans backing the bill.

title: 2d Kim Says 'I Am Running'
description: Kim Dae Jung, one of two rival South Korean opposition leaders, said today he would run in the presidential election this year. But he also indicated that he might be willing to leave the race if he believed his candidacy jeopardized chances for the opposition to win.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $23.9 million to retire debt. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $9.9 million to retire debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Herzog Removes Clark From Roster
description: Whitey Herzog, manager of the injury-plagued St. Louis Cardinals, finally decided on the makeup of his World Series roster today - Terry Pendleton is on, Jack Clark is off - but in so doing, he reopened the controversy over the 24-man rosters that clubs have used the past two seasons.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Arizona Board of Regents has approved a four-year contract for the Arizona State baseball coach, Jim Brock, and approved a salary increase for Steve Patterson, the basketball coach. Brock, entering his 16th season, will have a base salary of $55,000, and Patterson, beginning his third season, will be paid $79,000 annually. . . . Craig Redmond, a defenseman for the Los Angeles Kings, has been suspended after refusing to report to the New Haven team in the American Hockey League. . . . Dave (Tiger) Williams, who was released by the Kings last Monday, has signed with the Hartford Whalers. The left wing, who has 235 goals and 272 assists in a 13-year career, is the National Hockey League's career leader in penalty minutes with 3,873. . . . The Nets have waived Ray Williams, a guard who averaged 15.5 points and 5.8 assists with six N.B.A. teams in a 10-year career. . . . John Roseboro, a former catcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was hospitalized in Mesa, Ariz., yesterday after complaining of chest pains, the Dodgers announced. Roseboro, 54 years old, was a four-time All-Star and member of three Dodger World Series championship teams. He is manager of a Dodger minor league team in the Arizona Instructional League.

title: Washington Post Employees Want Negotiations in Good Faith
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Image Displays
description: LEAD: A new technique for the assembly of images and their immediate display was patented this week for Computer Graphics Laboratories Inc. of New York. Patent No. 4,700,181 was awarded to Stephen Maine, Duncan Harrower and Abraham Mammen. The principal use is to overlay images on a display screen. The technique can free store owners, for example, from keeping an inventory of all the items they want to sell.

title: Dance: A Classic By Graham
description: In creating epic theater for our time, Martha Graham has understood that source material from ancient tradition should not be diluted but enriched.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I guess it's my turn.'' - Nancy Reagan. [ 1:4. ]

title: Western Group Aiding Aliens Is Reported Set to Trim Staff
description: Catholic Charities of Los Angeles, the largest charitable organization helping illegal immigrants to gain amnesty, is planning to lay off workers and close one-third of its centers, according to a published report.

title: Rev. Dennis J. Comey; Settled Labor Disputes
description: The Rev. Dennis J. Comey, a Jesuit priest who, as the arbitrator of dock disputes in the Port of Philadelphia in the 1950's became known as the Waterfront Priest, died Wednesday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 91 years old. Father Comey was the arbitrator of the Philadelphia port from 1951 to 1959, handling dock grievances and averting work stoppages.

title: CHAMBERS LOSES RULING ON STATEMENTS
description: The judge in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. ruled yesterday that all of Mr. Chambers's statements to the police about Jennifer Levin's slaying, including at least three versions of how and when he last saw her alive - could be used as evidence at the trial.

title: ARGONAUT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains on sales of investments of $12.1 million for the quarter and $19.8 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After gains on sales of investments of $500,000 for the quarter and $4.4 million for the 9 months. The 1986 figures are pro forma.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
VOLUME IS RECORD; A Crossroad For Wall St.: The Era of Euphoria May Not Be Over Yet
description: For more than five years, millions of individual investors have enjoyed one of the most prolonged bull markets in history. Even if they did not cash in their chips, they spent more freely and helped lift the economy, thanks to their new-found sense of wealth.

title: Behind the Designer, a Man With a Crystal Ball
description: ''C'est Picart chez Lacroix,'' a bespectacled, puckish man said into the phone in a small office overlooking a courtyard verdant with green-apple and lime trees.

title: Ex-Manes Aide Sentenced to a 3-Year Term on Bribery Charge
description: Michael A. Nussbaum, a friend and political associate of the late Donald R. Manes, was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison for soliciting a $250,000 bribe from a cable television executive.

title: Brown University President to Quit Post Next Year
description: The president of Brown University, Howard R. Swearer, announced today that he was resigning the post after 10 years for reasons that he said were ''entirely personal.''

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Free Transit for Clergy Is Challenged in Suit
description: A lawsuit has been filed in Federal District Court against a 140-year-old tradition of free rides for Roman Catholic priests and nuns who use this city's public transportation.

title: KIRKPATRICK IS SAID TO CONSIDER '88 BID
description: Convinced that other candidates are not forcefully pressing such issues as aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick is seriously considering running for President, associates said today.

title: Chinese Leader Faults U.S. Lawmakers on Tibet
description: Accusing them of ''ignorance and arrogance,'' China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, lashed out at several American Congressmen today for their continued statements on Tibet and the recent disturbances there.

title: MERGER TO CREATE NO. 4 CABLE CONCERN
description: In a deal that would create the fourth-largest cable television company in the United States, Denver-based United Artists Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to a merger with the United Cable Television Corporation.

title: Embattled Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Finance; Bush and Dukakis War Chests Bulge
description: The Presidential campaigns of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts each have cash reserves of more than $4 million, placing them in the strongest financial positions four months before the first voting, in the Iowa caucuses.

title: Singapore Helps Make the U.S. Competitive
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Artistic Patriarch

title: New Attitudes Ushered In by Betty Ford
description: When Betty Ford entered the Bethesda Naval Hospital 13 years ago and learned that she had cancer in her right breast, many Americans still considered mastectomy a taboo subject, too fearful or even shameful to be discussed openly.
