title: Bridge; Taiwan and U.S. Teams Hold Leads in World Title Events
description: Teams from Taiwan and the United States continued to lead here today in the two divisions of the world team championship. Both seem likely to qualify for semifinal play beginning Monday, but the qualifying contest is sure to be bitterly contested until it ends Sunday.

title: Gulf War Speculation Spurs Oil-Contract Rise
description: Futures prices of crude oil and petroleum products surged yesterday in heavy trading amid widespread anticipation that the United States would avenge a missile attack in Kuwaiti waters against a Kuwaiti oil tanker flying the American flag.

title: New Study Endorses Baseball Stadium
description: A baseball stadium in New Jersey would add $118 million to the state's economy every year and create 2,600 full- and part-time jobs, according to a study released yesterday by a group pushing for the facility.

title: Jackson Gets Knick Pact
description: Confined to the sidelines during training camp as a holdout, Mark Jackson the former St. John's playmaker who was the Knicks' top draft pick in June, signed a multiyear contract today, the team announced.

title: Building of Thruway Exit Is Delayed
description: Construction of a controversial Thruway exit in Orange County has been delayed for at least nine months by a Federal request for environmental impact statements.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BankAmerica Fee Credits
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed on a settlement with plaintiffs in a decade-old class-action suit challenging its bank overdraft fees. Under the proposed settlement, current checking account customers would receive credits to obtain overdraft protection if they do not already have it.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP SLIGHT 0.3%
description: Prices at the producer level climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in September as higher prices for food and automobiles more than offset a sizable decline in energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and for the quarter includes nonrecurring net charges of $6.2 million, primarily for the writeoff of excess machinery and equipment and the cost of reducing personnel levels, and a $7.8 million provision for deferred income taxes relating to undistributed earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries.

title: Draw in Chess Tourney
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 29 moves in the third game of their world championship chess match. The score stands at 2 to 1 in Karpov's favor.

title: TURNER FORMS NEW CABLE NETWORK
description: The board of directors of the Turner Broadcasting System yesterday announced the formation of a new cable network, Turner Network Television, to be introduced sometime next year.

title: A-Plant Misses a Record
description: A malfunctioning electrical pressure regulator caused the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear plant to shut down automatically shortly after midnight today, ending the plant's bid to become the world's longest consecutively running boiling-water reactor just two days short of the record.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: Both latest periods' earnings include a gain of about $340,000, or 11 cents a share, reflecting the company's estimate of the minimun gain expected to be realized from an insurance claim relating to the Aug. 19 fire at the company's weaving facility in Dalton, Ga.

title: Reading by Novelist
description: The novelist Mona Simpson will read from her work on Oct. 26 at 7:30 P.M. in the Fales room, third floor of New York University's Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square South. Ms. Simpson is the author of the novel ''Anywhere But Here.'' The reading is sponsored by N.Y.U.'s Creative Writing Program, the Poetics Institute and the Friends of Bobst Library. Admission is free.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 8.

title: Before the Main Event, Chess Foes Spar
description: The opening week of the world chess championship has been marked by political and promotional bantering reminiscent of the prelude to a Muhammad Ali fight.

title: Pickens to Appeal
description: T. Boone Pickens said that he would appeal a court ruling that allows Consolidated Gold Fields to maintain control over the Newmont Mining Company, a takeover target of Mr. Pickens's Ivanhoe Partners group. Ivanhoe had bid $6.3 billion for Newmont, but the company was rescued by Consolidated, a big London-based mining company that is Newmont's biggest stockholder. On Thursday, a Delaware court judge dissolved a temporary restraining order preventing Consolidated from voting the new stock. Newmont shares were the biggest percentage loser on Wall Street, falling $13, to $45.625, as investors apparently concluded that the Pickens bid is doomed.

title: Turkish Parliament Is Summoned To Resolve a Crisis Over Election
description: Turkey's Parliament was called into emergency session tonight in an effort to resolve a crisis over procedures for a national election.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months includes a gain equal to 15 cents a share which was the net contribution of a negotiated cash settlement paid to Atlas Powder in a patent infringement suit, less certain other non-recurring charges.

title: MARKET'S SLIDE AIDED BY NEW TRADING TOOLS
description: The dramatic 108.36-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday reflected not only the fears and hopes of the ordinary investor, but the workings of big institutional investors guided by computer-aided analytical tools.

title: The U.S. Military Needs to Think Small By DREW MIDDLETON; Drew Middleton retired as military affairs correspondent of The New York Times in 1984.
description: The United States has just had excellent advice from a wise and friendly counselor, Oxford University's Sir Michael Howard. Sir Michael has seen more war than most (he is a highly decorated World War II veteran) and has thought and written about it with perception (his books include ''The Theory and Practice of War'' and ''The Causes of War'').

title: Stage: Fornes's 'Abingdon Square'
description: White walls, tall French doors, spare furniture, a feeling of elegant coolness in early-20th-century New York - this could be the setting for a Merchant-Ivory film. Against the pristine background, Maria Irene Fornes tells a story swirling with undercurrents of sexuality. In ''Abingdon Square'' (a Women's Project production at the American Place Theater), what appears to be languid is actually stifling. The leading character, a 15-year-old (Madeleine Potter), seeks sanctuary and security married to a much older man. Over a period of years, she frees herself from bondage of several kinds.

title: ADVANCED MARKETING SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House Speaker Says He'll Use Blind Trust For All of His Assets
description: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that he is putting his financial assets in a blind trust to avoid any conflicts of interest.

title: Lottery Winner Playing Shy
description: The holder of the $46 million winning ticket in Pennsylvania's lottery was playing shy today, two days after the drawing. State lottery officials said no one had come forward to claim the prize which, if won by one person, would be the nation's biggest single lottery payoff. A single winner would supplant Michael Wittkowski of Illinois as the biggest lottery winner. Mr. Wittkowski, a 28-year-old bachelor, won $40 million in 1984.

title: 'Late Nite Comic' Closing
description: ''Late Nite Comic,'' a comedy with book by Allan Knee and music and lyrics by Brian Gari, will close after this evening's performance at the Ritz Theater. The play ran for 16 previews and 4 regular performances.

title: New Welfare Hotel Plan Criticized for Its Focus
description: A new plan to end the use of welfare hotels, which New York City says will significantly improve the lot of homeless people, was criticized by state officials and advocates for the homeless yesterday for focusing on temporary shelters rather than permanent housing.

title: Bally to Sell Health Clubs
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, in its second major divestment in five months, agreed today to sell its health-club chain to a new company backed by Citicorp.

title: Ben Bassett, Ex-Editor Of A.P. Foreign News
description: Ben Bassett, foreign news editor of The Associated Press for a quarter of a century, died of heart failure complicated by pneumonia Wednesday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Michael Rejoins Yanks
description: Gene Michael, who resigned last month as manager of the Chicago Cubs, is returning to the Yankees as one of the team's two chief major league scouts. Michael is a former Yankee player, manager and general manager, and was the team's third-base coach under Manger Lou Piniella until he left June 13, 1986 to take over the Cubs. With the Yankees, Michael will scout and evaluate opponents in the eastern half of the country.

title: Rowdy Leafs Ejected
description: After losing a one-goal decision to the Minnesota North Stars, five members of the Toronto Maple Leafs later managed to lift their spirits - apparently too high and too loud - at a hotel in Bloomington, Minn., and wound up spending the rest of Wednesday night at a nearby diner. The party in a room occupied by two Maple Leafs caused angry complaints to the police from other hotel guests. Five players, including Borje Salming and Gary Leeman, were ejected from the hotel by management.

title: Unesco Delays Its Fifth Ballot
description: Unesco's executive board tonight postponed its fifth and final ballot for a director general as many nations pressed Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, the incumbent, to withdraw from the race.

title: Moscow Ballet Dancer Is Said to Ask Asylum
description: A member of the Moscow Ballet, the Soviet company headed by the Bolshoi star Vyacheslav Gordeyev, has reportedly requested asylum while on tour in the United States.

title: SCHWAB, CHARLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are on a pro forma basis and give effect to the acquisition. The sale of 8 million shares in the company's initial public offering and the application of the net proceeds therefrom. The related adjustments primarily increase interest and depreciation and amortization and reduce compensation and benefits expenses. The pro forma data do not necessarily indicate future financial results, nor do they indicate what the results would have been had the acquisition or the sale of the shares occurred at the times reflected.

title: Worrell Dominates Without the Antics
description: THE art of intimidation comes out of the bullpen with many faces.

title: Man Held in Shooting of an Ex-Police Officer
description: A suspect in a shootout with a retired police officer was arrested yesterday at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx where he had come Thursday with a gunshot wound to the abdomen, the police said.

title: Patents; A Cancer Preparation
description: THE Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology of Newark received a patent this week for a preparation regarded as important in the treatment of cancer.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
For Gephardt, in Iowa All Handshakes Count
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, by his reckoning, has devoted 150 days to campaigning in Iowa in the last two years, more than any other Presidential candidate of either party.

title: Farm Workers Win a Ruling on Immigration Law
description: A Federal district judge here has ordered that immigration officers who detain farm workers must assure that those eligible to remain in the United States under amnesty do not unwittingly accept deportation as illegal aliens.

title: Mammograms: Safer and More Accurate
description: Mammography, the diagnostic technique that detected a possibly cancerous lesion in Nancy Reagan's left breast, has evolved to the point that doctors using it can not only find tumors but can also tell with increasing accuracy whether they are malignant.

title: Stage: 'L'Indiade' in Paris, Directed by Mnouchkine
description: Ariane Mnouchkine, despite her success at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Arts Festival, is still not a name well known to American theatergoers. She and her Paris-based company, Le Theatre du Soleil, have not appeared in New York. Her actors speak in French. And her works are usually very long, flamboyant cross-breedings of all manner of Oriental theater with Western means.

title: Dr. Corinne J. Weithorn, 58; A Psychologist and Lecturer
description: Dr. Corinne J. Weithorn, a developmental psychologist and university lecturer, died of cancer Friday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. She was 58 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Wherein the Writer Catalogues Her Woes
description: LEAD: Fresh from vacation, my husband zipped into the post office to collect our mail. He picked up a huge carton filled with catalogues and threw his back out. Warning: The Christmas catalogue avalanche is upon us.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to give effect to the Aug. 7 5-for-4 stock split in the form of a stock dividend.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1987
description: Markets

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SEEKS EXPORT ASSISTANCE
description: A team of American export control officials will begin a tour of 14 European capitals next week, hoping to persuade the Western allies to beef up their systems for controlling exports to the Soviet bloc, the State Department said today.

title: Deaver Prosecutor Terms Allegations False
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the special prosecutor, today accused the Justice Department and Canada of orchestrating ''false accusations'' about his attempt to persuade the Canadian Ambassador to testify at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Hoosiers Edge Gophers: Dave Schnell, the Indiana quarterback, scored two touchdowns last night to lift Indiana to an 18-17 Big Ten victory over previously unbeaten Minnesota. The game was played in Minneapolis. Anthony Thompson added 160 rushing yards, helping Indiana, 5-1 over all and 3-0 in the conference, take sole possession of first place in the Big Ten. Michigan State, which plays at Northwestern today, is 2-0 in the conference. Minnesota is 5-1 over all and 2-1 in the conference.(AP) Montclair State Wins in Upset: Anthony Colasurdo kicked two field goals and John Fiore caught a 45-yard touchdown pass last night as Montclair State upset William Paterson, 12-0, in a New Jersey Athletic Conference game in Wayne, N.J. Montclair State is 4-2 over all and 2-1 in the conference; William Paterson is 5-2 and 2-1.(AP) C. W. Post Slips by Iona: Tim Moore's 3-yard touchdown run with 1:50 to play and Pat O'Brien's conversion gave C. W. Post (2-4, 2-1 in the Liberty Conference) a 29-28 victory over Iona (2-3, 0-2) in Mount Vernon, N.Y.(AP) GOLF O'Meara Keeps Lead: Mark O'Meara shot a 68 to retain the lead after yesterday's second round of the Walt Disney World Golf Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. O'Meara was at 13-under-par 131. He was one shot in front of Bob Gilder, who made birdies from the fringe on the first two holes and went on to a 65.(AP) Impressive in England: Seve Ballesteros of Spain and Ian Woosnam of Wales posted impressive victories yesterday as the first round of the world match-play championship in Wentworth, England, was completed 24 hours behind schedule because of rain and strong winds. Ballesteros, trying to equal Gary Player's record of five match-play titles, led by two holes Thursday against Katsunari Takahashi of Japan and collected two birdies in four holes yesterday in closing the match, 4 and 2. Woosnam needed only one birdie in his last four holes for a 4 and 3 victory over Sam Randolph of the United States.(AP) TENNIS Becker and Cash in Showdown: Boris Becker, the defending champion, set up a showdown against Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, by beating Paul Annacone of the United States, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Australian indoor championships in Sydney. Ivan Lendl, ranked No. 1 in the world, also reached today's semifinals, beating Ramesh Krishnan of India, 6-2, 6-3. In the other quarterfinals, Cash, of Australia, beat Scott Davis of the United States, 6-3, 7-5, and fourth-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia eliminated Marty Davis of the United States, 7-5, 6-4.(AP) Mayotte Gains: Tim Mayotte of the United States reached the semifinals of the Toulouse Open tournament in France, beating Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-1. Ricki Osterthun of West Germany rallied to beat Luiz Mattar of Brazil, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3, in another quarterfinal match.(AP)

title: Company news; Adams Is Buying Five TV Stations
description: The Adams Communications Corporation, which owns Chicago magazine, has agreed to acquire five television stations, including one in Peoria, Ill., from the Wesray Capital Corporation, officials said. Adams, based in Tampa, Fla., will buy the stations for $126.5 million from Wesray's Forward Communications Corporation, based in Wausau, Wis.

title: Nancy Reagan Faces Test Today For Malignancy of the Left Breast
description: Nancy Reagan will undergo a biopsy Saturday morning to determine whether a ''suspicious lesion'' on her left breast is cancerous, the White House said today.

title: Opera: Freni in 'Aida' In Houston's New Hall
description: When the Khedive of Egypt, as legend has it, wanted something suitably boffo to celebrate the opening of the Suez Canal, he commissioned Verdi to compose ''Aida.'' Unfortunately, that is one of opera's more durable myths. Still, a proper ''Aida'' can be prime grand-opening material, as this city well understands. For the inaugural performance Thursday evening in the Alice and George Brown Theater of the $70 million Wortham Center, the Houston Grand Opera once again turned to ''Aida,'' just as it had 21 years ago in opening its former home, Jones Hall.

title: HARRY SNYDER
description: Harry Snyder, director of options strategies of Herzog Heine Geduld Inc., a stock brokerage concern, died of cancer of the liver Sunday at his home in Hartsdale, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Why Not Put Gold in the Basket?
description: Treasury Secretary Baker set pulses racing at the recent World Bank meetings by suggesting that international financial policies be guided in part by the price of a ''basket'' of commodities, including gold. It's not a bad idea.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Net income The company said the second quarter loss is primarily because of costs related to the acquisition of Imaging Solutions Inc. in July.

title: 8 Are Arrested In 2 Drug Raids By Task Force
description: Undercover agents working on two separate cases late Thursday seized about $140 million worth of cocaine, one of the largest single-day drug confiscations ever in New York City, officials said yesterday.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $13.1 million for the quarter and $34.9 million for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $10.8 million from the redemption of debentures. The latest periods' results include royalty income of $20 milion for the quarter and $159 million for the 9 months from patent litigation settlements. Preferred stock dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago 9 months' results.

title: D'Amato and Heinz Plan to Vote For Confirmation of Judge Bork
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York announced today that he would vote to confirm Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court.

title: Syracuse's Owens Runs With Added Incentive
description: Michael Owens, who was rated as Pennsylvania's top high school player in 1985, grew up in Carlisle as nearby Penn State forged its reputation as a national power. But he decided to attend Syracuse.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $6.3 million from costs arising from a tender offer and related to businesses discontinued in prior years, and a provision for restructuring of $3 million. c-Includes a provision for restructuring of $21.3 million relating primarily to the discontinuance of two product lines.

title: Books of the Times; Reflections on Science
description: AN URCHIN IN THE STORM. Essays about Books and Ideas. By Stephen Jay Gould. 255 pages. W.W. Norton and Company. $18.95.

title:
Patents;
A Hand-Held Printer
description: LEAD: Jerome H. Lemelson, who operates the Licensing Management Corporation in New York, received a patent this week on a hand-held, electronically controlled printing device, which can put letters and figures on objects, such as containers and products. An electronic microprocessor or microcomputer may be employed to control operation of an ink-jet or wheel printer.

title: INSIDE
description: Youngest Heart Patient A boy became the youngest person to undergo a heart transplant just hours after he was delivered by Caesarean section. Page 9. Storm Kills 13 in England The worst storm in decades raked southern England, killing at least 13 people and paralyzing business in much of London. Page 3. Kirkpatrick May Run Supporters say Jeane J. Kirkpatrick is considering seeking the Republican nomination for President. Page 7. Tyson Stops Biggs in 7 Unbeaten Mike Tyson retained his undisputed heavyweight title by knocking out Tyrell Biggs. Page 53.

title: O.E.D., in a Gigabyte Task, To Transfer to Compact Disks
description: Gigabyte is the latest word at the Oxford English Dictionary, a measure of the 1,000 million bytes needed for what will be a major event in the history of both computerization and lexicography: the transference and updating of the entire 16-volume O.E.D. onto three compact disks.

title: Carter Recommends That Reagan Invoke Act on War Powers
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the United States was acting ''in effect as a belligerent'' in the Iran-Iraq war because of the increased American naval presence in the Persian Gulf, and he called on President Reagan to invoke the War Powers Resolution.

title:
PATENTS;
Communications Device
description: LEAD: An electronic device patented this week for the AT&T; Bell Laboratories, in Murray Hill, N.J., has hollow metallic legs that hold hair-thin glass fibers. The system, which is expected to be useful in computer and telephone communication, can be employed to convey light signals to an integrated circuit chip that can hold and process information.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MERCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: U.S. Weighs Response To Ship Attack in Gulf
description: The Reagan Administration today weighed how to respond to the missile attack on an American-registered tanker in Kuwait, but officials did not commit themselves to a military response.

title: VOLUME IS RECORD; DOW DROPS 108.36
description: Stock prices collapsed across the board yesterday in record-breaking sales volume, as waves of orders from nervous investors pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to a stunning 108.36-point loss.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net of $3.7 million for the quarter and a loss of $80.5 million for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $8.3 million for the 9 months.

title: State Dept. to Establish Unit On Children Taken Overseas
description: The State Department, under pressure from several members of Congress, agreed today to establish a bureau to handle inquiries from Americans whose children have been abducted by former spouses and taken to foreign countries.

title: Film: 'Hello Mary Lou'
description: Eight minutes into ''Hello Mary Lou, Prom Night II,'' the title character is flambeed at her moment of triumph, standing on the stage of the high school auditorium, about to be crowned 1957 prom queen.

title: CALIFORNIA MICRO DEVICES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $867,000 for tax adjustments.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 55.

title: TECH-OPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $983,000 and $3,318,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: To Make Healthful Food Tasty, a Little Moderation
description: Why is it that healthful, nutritious food, the so-called spa cuisine, seldom tastes good? Most of the time this food, designed to mimic what is served at many health spas, is simply bland and dry.

title: Colorado County Drops Year-Round Schooling
description: When Joan Austin and her husband wanted to take their three daughters on a summer vacation last year, they ran into an unusual obstacle: school.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1986.

title: WHITHER THE STALEYS?
description: WHATEVER became of the Decatur Staleys, the Canton Bulldogs and the Oakland Raiders? Whatever became of the Boston Yankees, the Dayton Triangles and the Chicago Cardinals? And the Baltimore Colts or, for that matter, the New York Giants and the New York Jets?

title: Pesticide Testing Is Questioned
description: A CONSUMER organization has released a study suggesting that the Environmental Protection Agency has inadequately supervised the testing of most chemicals in household pesticides.

title: NOVA, AN ALBERTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Nova said it provided for a net loss of $21.7 million, or 12 cents a share, relative to its investment. The company said that offsetting the impact of its CNG investment writedown, it has been able to record tax recoveries and other adjustments for a net income effect of about $12 million, or 7 cents a share. The company also said that in the latest third quarter it realized a net gain of $10 million, or 5 cents a share, on the disposition of investments in oil company share which were originally acquired as part of Husky Oil Ltd.'s plan to expand its petroleum base. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Domenic Di Clerico, An Ex-Union Official
description: Domenic Di Clerico, a former president of a transportation union local, shot and killed himself Monday while playing Russian roulette with a .38-caliber postol, the Philadelphia police said. He was 64 years old. Mr. Di Clerico was found by his son John on the floor of his basement apartment in Philadelphia, the police said.

title: Live, From New York, Babbitt Polishes TV Image
description: Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, whose Presidential prospects were damaged by his shaky television performance at a Houston debate among Democratic candidates in July, has been polishing his video image with regular tapings and professional advice. On Saturday, he will even turn semipro with a guest appearance on ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: President Offers Legislative Plan To Revise Criminal Justice Laws
description: President Reagan today called for legislation to reinstate the death penalty for certain offenses, exhorting Congress to cooperate in a campaign to make the nation ''safe and secure again for our children.''

title: Jazz: Two Piano Trios
description: Two trios with surface similarities but different performing styles are sharing the bill this weekend, through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street.

title: Lear Siegler Set To Sell 3 Units
description: The Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation said it had agreed to sell three aerospace units for $97 million to the BFM Aerospace Corporation, a new company whose principals include Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier. The units are the Lear Siegler Romec Corporation of Elyria, Ohio, and the Lear Siegler Energy Products Corporation and the Lear Siegler Transport Dynamics Corporation, both of Santa Ana, Calif. The combined units had revenues of more than $100 million in the year ended June 30 and employed about 1,000 workers.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Panel on AIDS Approves Move For Top Talent
description: President Reagan's AIDS commission, acknowledging that it is already two months behind schedule and still stumbling toward its goal, today approved an organizational structure that is designed to enlist some of the nation's top medical and legal talent in carrying out its task.

title: Toddler Is Rescued After 2 1/2 Days in a Texas Well
description: An extraordinary drama in this West Texas oil town came to a joyous conclusion tonight when rescue workers pulled an 18-month-old girl to safety 58 1/2 hours after she tumbled into an abandoned water well.

title: Town House Used by Cohn Is Purchased
description: A Manhattan town house that served for many years as the law office of Roy M. Cohn has been sold for $3.7 million, with most of the money being held under court order pending the outcome of an income-tax case against the late lawyer.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEY RATES
House Approves $25 Million Plan To Warn Workers of Health Risks
description: A $25 million program to warn workers when they face high health risks from exposure to hazardous substances in the workplace has won approval in the House but faces an uphill battle in the Senate and at the White House.

title: SELVAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A Deal for Potamkin Cadillac
description: Victor Potamkin, perhaps New York's best-known car dealer, has sold the assets and leased the property of the Potamkin Cadillac Corporation, the cornerstone of his automobile empire.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,724,000 for the quarter and $6,898,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $88,000 for the quarter and $1,003,000 for the 9 months.

title: 7 Rams Ruled Ineligible
description: Seven players who returned to the Los Angeles Rams this week will not be eligible for the game Sunday in Atlanta, the club announced today. But the quarterback, Jim Everett, is expected to play.

title: Air Force Identifies Pilot in Crash Of a Top-Secret Plane in Nevada
description: The Air Force today identified the pilot who was killed in the crash of a secret plane on Wednesday but refused to disclose further information.

title: Shultz in Jerusalem for Talks on Peace Effort
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here today and held separate talks with Israel's two chief political rivals, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, in an effort to prevent a sense of stagnation from settling over Middle East peace efforts, But neither Mr. Shultz nor the aides traveling with him have expressed any optimism about the prospects here.

title: FOOTBALL STRIKE GIVES AS WELL AS TAKES
description: Months from now, when this weekend's National Football League games are just a memory for about 200 replacement players who are back to teaching or working in gas stations or just dreaming, the mail will bring a sensational windfall.

title: GLENFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5.2 million. c-Includes a charge of $1.3 million, which represented the prepayment of borrowings from the Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: Contras Attacking in Bid to Force Talks
description: Nicaraguan rebels backed by the United States have mounted a series of attacks in recent days intended to show that the country will not achieve peace until their demands are met.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: The year-ago 9 months includes a charge for litigation settlement amounting to 26 cents a share.

title: U.S. AIDES CALM, BUT WORRIED
description: Officially, the Reagan Administration maintains a facade of indifference to the ups and downs of the financial markets, but worry over the stock market's great fall this week are beginning to pierce through.

title: Deposed Leader of Burkina Faso Is Executed With 12 Aides
description: Capt. Thomas Sankara nd 12 other officials were executed and buried today, a day after Captain Sankara's chief adviser ousted him as President of this impoverished West African nation, an official said.

title: Casinos Help Illegal Gambling Thrive in Jersey, Officials Say
description: Legalization of casino gambling in Atlantic City and the establishment of a state lottery have helped illegal gambling to thrive, law-enforcement officials testified today.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter and 9 months' earnings are restated to include investment tax credit previously eliminated.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,888,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a tax credit of $1,174,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $525,000 and $3,357,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss The latest quarter also reflects the unfavorable impact on earnings of $3.1 million relating to the financial restructuring of Mack Financial Corp., as well as start-up costs of $4.2 million at the company's Winnsboro, S.C., assembly facility. The quarter was also adversely affected by about $3 million in precautionary costs for a possible disruption of production by U.A.W. employees. The year-ago quarter's restated net loss also included a one-time $33.7 million pre-tax provision for the company's special early retirement program for non-bargaining employees. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Correction
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday gave an incorrect telephone number for information about a workshop and classes at the Horticultural Society of New York. The number is (212) 757-0915.

title: West Germans Irritated By Baker's Rate Stance
description: There was widespread irritation in the West German business community today over Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's threat to push the dollar still lower in response to recent increases in German interest rates.

FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Correction
description: An article yesterday about the parole eligibility of former Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens misstated the role of a lawyer, Paul Bergman. He was the attorney for Mr. Brennan's appeal, not for the trial on racketeering charges.

title: Iranians Captured Stinger Missiles From Afghan Guerrillas, U.S. Says
description: Administration officials say intelligence has established that the Stinger missile parts found on an Iranian attack boat in the Persian Gulf this month were part of a batch supplied by the United States to Afghan guerrillas, who lost them to Iranian forces in June.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After a writeoff of $141,934,000 from the company's portion of the Zimmer Nuclear Station.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $73,777,000 for the quarter and $63,578,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after gains from discontinued operations of $3,456,000 for the quarter and $13,123,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also includes a loss of $14,148,000 from an accounting change. The year-ago results include the sales of John Wanamaker, which was sold Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Fish Market Shrugs Off Assertions of Mob Links
description: ''Now give me my $75 or I'll break your legs,'' said Richard Sabatino, taking payment for some flounder at the 108 South Street Fish Company just before dawn yesterday morning. He looked over at a reporter and laughed uproariously.

title: About New York; Veteran Corps Affirms Tradition In a New Way
description: As the Veteran Corps of Artillery snapped to attention, Gen. John E. Connelly 3d, barked, ''Shut up!''

title:
YOUR MONEY;
Positive Signs For Real Estate
description: LEAD: FOR Dr. Arnold Halpern, a Monmouth County, N.J., obstetrician, the decision to invest in real estate was easy. ''My grandfather always kept saying, 'Buy real estate,' '' he said. ''And I think real estate is the way to go right now.''

title: O.E.D., in Gigabyte Task, To Transfer to Compact Disks; How System Will Work
description: The task of computerizing the Oxford English Dictionary involved a total wordage of more than 60 times that of the complete works of Shakespeare.

title: Edna O'Brien Reading
description: The author Edna O'Brien will read from her new unpublished novel at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing, on Oct. 26 at 7 P.M. The reading will take place in the Student Union, Room 410. Ms. O'Brien, born in Ireland, has published several collections of short stories and novels, including ''The Love Object,'' ''A Scandalous Woman'' and ''Night.'' Her appearance will be one in a series of readings at the college. Information: (718) 520-7323.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about Federal aid for sheltering homeless families misstated the role of Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, on the House Ways and Means Committee. He is a committee member, not chairman.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT RISES 0.2%
description: The output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, with gains in the steel and energy industries offsetting further declines in automobile production, the Government reported today.

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Mideast Geography; How the Red Sea Got Its Name
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Reflects a change to a market-to- market method of accounting for the company's U.S. Treasury bond options and trading portfolio.

title: U.S., After Debate, Rejects Negotiations On 'Star Wars' Tests
description: The Reagan Administration has spurned a Soviet proposal to negotiate the scope of ''Star Wars'' tests, a senior Administration official said today.

title: COMPTEK RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Inquiry Is Ordered Into Death of Inmate
description: The Connecticut Commissioner of Correction has ordered an investigation into the medical care given to an inmate who died at the Morgan Street Detention Center here.

title: Lilco Exempted in Bill On Utility Takeovers
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has been exluded from a provision in the new tax bill that would block utilities from being taken over by the state.

title: Business Sales Up 1.3%; Inventory Growth Lags
description: Business sales advanced 1.3 percent in August, the biggest gain in seven months, while inventories grew at just half the rate of the previous month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Blaze Destroys Row of 8 Stores In New Rochelle
description: A smoky blaze destroyed eight stores today as it ran through a complex on East Main Street, causing more than $1 million in damage.

title: Emerson Quartet Carves Itself a Niche
description: For a long time, just a few groups dominated the small quartet scene, many of them European or at least steeped in the Central European tradition. Now, several young American ensembles with a different outlook on the same repertory have begun to join the standard-bearers, sharing prominent spots on major concert series and winning contracts with the principal record companies.

title: Miller and Aide Talk In Wake of Scuffle
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller met with his chief of staff, Norman Adler, for two hours yesterday in the aftermath of Mr. Adler's shoving to the floor a reporter who was questioning him on Thursday. But Assembly officials refused to say whether Mr. Adler would retain his post or leave.

title: MORRIS, REASONS UPSET BY LACK OF UNITY
description: Throughout the 24-day strike of National Football League players, Joe Morris was a strong supporter of the players' union. Today, the day after the N.F.L. Players Association ended the strike despite no contract agreement, the Giants' running back was bitter.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect a change in accounting methods and inventory adjustments.

title: LINEAR TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $715,000 for the latest first quarter and $497,000 for the year-ago period.

title: FRENCH LINKED TO SOVIET SALE
description: A French company improperly exported advanced American chip-making equipment to the Soviet Union, in a deal that American officials said today would improve Soviet military technology.

title: A Long Term Is Asked In Sentencing of Biaggi
description: Federal prosecutors asked yesterday for a ''substantial'' prison term for Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx, who was convicted last month of illegally accepting a free vacation and other charges.

title: MOST OF THE JETS REMAIN OUT
description: In a move designed to recover their lost pride, most of the Jets voted this morning to remain out until Monday at 2 P.M.

title: 13 Die as Fierce Storm Hits England
description: The worst storm in decades raked southern England with winds of more than 100 miles an hour Thursday night, killing at least 13 people and bringing business to a standstill today in much of London.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bath, Me.; A Revival on The Kennebec
description: THE pace of home-building and waterfront redevelopment has picked up in this shipbuilding town of 10,000 on the Kennebec River after a period in which it lagged behind development in Maine coastal villages and suburban housing centers.

title: WHAT IS GOOD FOR SECURITY MAY BE BAD FOR BUSINESS
description: FEW bureaucratic conflicts are more bitter or more deeply rooted than the feud between the Commerce and Defense Departments over control of exporting sensitive technology to the Soviet bloc nations.

title: INSTITUTIONS' EXPANSION PLANS INCH AHEAD
description: IT has been two and a half years since both the Guggenheim and the Whitney museums announced their intentions to build major additions to their buildings. The fate of the Guggenheim's plans may be decided this week, but the Whitney still has only just begun to work its way through the city's lengthy approval process.

title: Brunswick Is 5-0
description: Brunswick improved its record to 5-0 yesterday with a 20-0 victory over Dalton. A second-quarter touchdown gave Brunswick the lead as Tom Demas ran 3 yards to finish a 41-yard drive. Geoff Headington led the offense in the second half, running 4 yards and 8 yards for scores. Pieter Hartong kicked the extra points on the first two touchdowns.

title: FORTY NINER AND CLASSIC CROWN TRIUMPH
description: Forty Niner and Classic Crown, a pair of blue-blooded 2-year-olds by Mr. Prospector, proved themselves New York's top juveniles with impressive victories in the Champagne Stakes and the Frizette Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title:
Focus: Mixed Uses;
At Home High Atop The Office
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, when Montgomery-Washington Tower opened at the edge of the San Francisco Financial District, sales of the 45 residential condominiums perched above 20 floors of offices were slow. It took several months to make the first sale and nearly four years to sell out.

title: A Danish Ferry Tale
description: LEAD: Though the Tor Britannia carries passengers and cars on the North Sea between Denmark and England, the term ferryboat hardly describes her. Her chief officer calls the vessel a car-cruise liner.

title: Susan Kaufmann Planning to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Kaufmann of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Kaufmann, to Alan Edward Lewis, the son of Bernard J. Lewis of Sunrise, Fla., and the late Sylvia Lewis.

title: Reagan Expected to Select A New Envoy to Nicaragua
description: President Reagan is expected to nominate Richard Melton, a career diplomat who specializes in Latin America, as ambassador to Nicaragua, Administration officials said today.

title: Susan Michele Epstein Weds Morton J. Fertel
description: The wedding of Susan Michele Epstein to Morton Jay Fertel took place yesterday evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Neil Kurshan performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: Thank you to Barbara Tuchman for her article ''A Nation in Decline?'' (Sept. 20). How clearly she defined the decline in values and competence that threatens us as a society and as a nation. MADGE EVANS Lake Worth, Fla.

title: Youthful Dealers, Old Treasures
description: The stereotype of antiques dealers is that they have too much in common with their wares. Or, as Wheelock Whitney, a 38-year-old Manhattan art specialist who still looks like a prep-school boy with loafers and no socks, puts it, ''They're all antiques themselves.'' But in recent years, Whitney and a host of other dealers in their 20's and 30's have entered the field, proving that it doesn't require decades of either expertise or earnings to develop a business and an eye for quality.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: IS FASHION DESTINY? ASK CINDERELLA
description: EVERY time I return from clothes shopping, no matter how little or how much I buy and regardless of the amount of money I spend, I almost immediately sink into a state of depression. Based on my readings of self-help articles in women's magazines, I have unearthed many plausible explanations for this ''post-shopping depression syndrome.''

title: 'LOCAL' FARM PRODUCE: GRAY MARKET?
description: LEAD: IN October, East End farmers harvest the remainder of their crops, and farm-stand shelves groan under the weight of fresh produce. Many people forgo supermarkets and take to their cars to cruise Montauk Highway, stocking up on the relatively inexpensive fruits and vegetables, and many tourists return to points west laden with produce labeled ''local.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
BOTTLE-NOSED DOLPHIN
description: LEAD: Tursiops truncatus

title: 3 ARTS GROUPS GET U.S. FUNDS
description: LEAD: THREE New Jersey arts organizations were among the 87 selected last week to receive challenge grants from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIFE IN THE LAND OF THE LIVING. By Daniel Vilmure. (Knopf, $15.95.) This is a gratifying first novel, set one August night in a rundown Florida harbor town, with questions of faith and paternity propelling the action. The book's epigraph from Bruce Springsteen (''Nothin' feels better than blood on blood'') would appear to signal a hip new direction for Southern fiction; yet the principle underlying events here is decidedly Faulkneresque: the past not only taints the present, it destroys it.

title: The Spirit of a Rocker
description: CHUCK BERRY The Autobiography. By Chuck Berry. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $17.95.

title: Katherine Burner Weds L. S. Rice 3d
description: Katharine Avery Burner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Avery Burner of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Indian Lake, N.Y., and Louis Sanford Rice 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rice 2d of Gettysburg, Pa., were married yesterday at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N.J. The Rev. William Harvey performed the ceremony.

title: SOUNDS OF DISCORD FROM PLATO'S CAVE
description: THERE'S ALWAYS SOME-thing to be learned from a hit - something about quality, if we're lucky; something about marketing or the Zeitgeist if not. Intentionally or despite itself, a hit crystallizes a cultural moment; its popularity ratifies some pervasive feeling. So I like to keep an eye on hits, and this summer's long-running, top-of-the-pops best seller among nonfiction books, Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind'' (Simon & Schuster), is a long-running No. 1 hit that's worth a careful look - especially since it devotes a full chapter to rock criticism.

title: Holy Cross Clinches Title
description: Jeff Wiley threw for 389 yards and 3 touchdowns today as Holy Cross, ranked first in Division I-AA, routed Bucknell, 48-10, to clinch the Colonial League title.

title: Gregory Peck to Receive Award in Rochester
description: Gregory Peck is to receive the George Eastman Award for Distinguished Contribution to the Art of Film at a ''Hooray for Hollywood'' benefit ball at 8:45 P.M. on Oct. 24 at the George Eastman House, 900 East Avenue, Rochester.

title: Rising Rates May Cool Equity Borrowing
description: A HOMEOWNER who signed up for a $50,000 equity loan last year could have obtained an introductory interest rate that put the monthly cost at $300. Rate increases would have brought the monthly payments to $438 by January and, after four more increases this year, the payment would have increased to $504 this month.

title: Viola's Long Wait Was Well Worth It
description: He was supposed to be the best man at his brother's wedding today. The baseball season was going to be over, and Frank Viola was going to fly to New York and stand beside his brother, John, when he spoke his vows at St. Raphael Church in East Meadow, L.I.

title: SELECT APPLES AND PEARS WITH CARE
description: It is the time to think about apple pie again. Apples are at their peak now, with a wide choice available in the markets at low prices. Pears are coming in, too, and as winter draws nearer more varieties will become available.

title: THE ARTS IN THE FUTURE: ALWAYS THE NEED FOR A PATRON
description: WHAT are the conditions in which the arts can flourish in Connecticut today and in the year 2000?

title: BIGGS UNRAVELED BY TYSON'S POWER
description: A few weeks ago at the training camp of Tyrell Biggs in Lancaster, Pa., Biggs's trainer, George Benton, was walking his man through a fight plan that was calculated to unravel Mike Tyson.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''Alpine Voyaging From Lake to Lake'' by John Dornberg (Travel, Aug. 23). I recently returned from 10 months in Europe and the Middle East (at age 56, a previous nonworld traveler, traveling alone, most of the time staying at International Youth Hostels or places recommended by travelers I met along the way). While I was traveling on a shoestring and the cost of my entire trip was about $7,500, I nevertheless splurged and spent $45 not to go to Jungfrau (from Interlaken) because I also did not want to burrow through the mountains.

title: In Jerusalem of the 1800's
description: In Jerusalem, a city first settled some 5,000 years ago, little at tention was paid to 19th-century architecture until a few years ago, when several historically important buildings were torn down by developers. Suddenly, the charm of those century-old structures was recognized, and now many of them have been renovated and turned into galleries and restaurants and even a small theater.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: ''THERE'S the regular way to install this program into your computer, and then there's a shortcut,'' the message said as it crept haltingly across my screen, occasionally backspacing to fix a typo. ''One takes about three to five minutes, the other about two. Which do you want to try?'' ''Short,'' I typed back. ''Great,'' the return message said. ''Here goes, O.K.?'' ''O.K.'' Then I leaned back in my rocking chair, cranked up Tony Trischka's new banjo compact disk on the desktop stereo and turned control of my desktop computer over to a stranger more than a thousand miles away.

title: Permits Galore; Trade, By The Numbers
description: THE overwhelming majority of export licenses processed by the Commerce Department involve selling non-Communist countries things of less than crucial military importance. A license is needed to export thousands of commercial items that could have a military use, from ''Absorbers, Electromagnetic Wave,'' to ''Zirconium Metal Alloys.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Surplus of Houses Slows Resale Market
description: LEAD: THE Krugs have their hearts set on a six-bedroom colonial in Garden City, with an asking price of $285,000. But first they must sell their three-bedroom Dutch colonial in Mineola, for which they are asking $237,000.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TOUCH. By Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $17.95.) Diehard Elmore Leonard fans seeking a Dutch treat or at least a fix until the arrival of ''Freaky Deaky'' next year may be mystified by this 10-year-old Leonard excursion into mysticism. The master of the contemporary crime novel wrote it in 1977 and gives a candid history of its subsequent fate with several reluctant publishers.

title: NONFICTION
description: OUT OF CONTROL: Confessions of an NFL Casualty. By Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson and Peter Knobler. (Putnam, $17.95.) Fast is the way Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson grew up on the streets of Austin, Tex.; hard is the way he played professional football in Dallas from 1975 to 1979; fast and hard is the way he fell from fame as a result of alcohol and cocaine abuse. In ''Out of Control,'' written with Peter Knobler, the co-author with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of ''Giant Steps,'' Mr. Henderson is candid about his unprotected childhood, his young adulthood as a pool-hall hustler and his days as a star linebacker with the two-time Super Bowl champions, the Dallas Cowboys. Using foul language and pro football jargon, he effectively puts the reader on the playing field and reveals all: the taking of drugs before, during and after games; the coaches concerned only about players' performance; the squabbles among the Cowboys; the crunch of a hard tackle. And he painfully but compellingly describes the nightmare of his cocaine addiction. ''Out of Control'' is sobering. Although Mr. Henderson's explanation of his rehabilitation is crammed into the book's last 15 pages, with few details, he tells football fans in no uncertain terms just what kind of lives some of their heroes lead inside the locker room and outside the stadium.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
MUZIANI TO BE HONORED
description: LEAD: Hardly anyone in his Cape May County-Cumberland County district was surprised last month when Assemblyman Guy F. Muziani showed up in the State House - between chemotherapy treatments for cancer - to help his colleagues move Governor Kean's school intervention bill (the measure lost in the Senate).

title: To the One Left Behind
description: AGE By Hortense Calisher. 121 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95.

title: Bible's Pages Will Come to Light in Hungary
description: A facsimile edition of a medieval manuscript of exceptional beauty will be published next year through an unusual collaboration between the Library of Congress and a Hungarian publisher.

title: DANCE: BY ROBERT LORCA, MORE THAN FLAMENCO
description: THERE is theater that stands out for its artistic vision and for the pleasure of the performers' company. The Spanish Dance Arts Company offered such theater on Thursday at the Symphony Space, in an evening of music and dance that was like sharing a glass of wine with old friends.

title: Boy, 4, Slays His Sister, 3
description: A 4-year-old boy, playing at an uncle's security company office, picked up a .38-caliber revolver and shot his 3-year-old sister to death, the police said Friday. ''It appears to be totally accidental,'' a police spokesman said. The shooting occurred Thursday night when the boy, David Dallas, and his sister, Maggie, were at Dallas Security Patrol while relatives prepared guards for a night shift. The boy fired one shot, hitting his sister in the head, the spokesman said.

title: ARIAS FIGHTS FOR HIS PLAN
description: AS the President of Costa Rica was being congratulated last week for winning the Nobel Peace Prize, the Reagan Administration was continuing to plan for the collapse of the peace agreement for which he was honored.

title: Cuban Defector Recalls Life as a Top Officer
description: Shortly after the Communist victory in South Vietnam, a Cuban Air Force officer visited Vietnam and was given an opportunity to fly one of the American-made F-5 jets that were among the spoils of war.

title: PUMPKINS TO OUTLIVE HALLOWEEN
description: PUMPKINS will be somewhat smaller and somewhat scarcer this year. They also will cost about the same as they did last year, and, because of harder shells, could last until Christmas.

title: 5IN PORT CHESTER NAMED IN ETHICS CASE
description: FIVE Port Chester officials, including its Mayor, the Police Chief and the Village Manager, are being charged with a breach of ethics for buying condominiums before they were made available to the public at The Landmark, the former Lifesavers factory in the village.

title: Correcting an Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: A Matter of Style
description: I GRADUATED FROM high school, went to college and entered graduate school in the 1960's, and, without being a student activist, gradually absorbed the values and priorities of the liberal times - a general concern for what was fair, genuine and seemed natural. If VW station wagons, pottery and guitars were symbols of the period, so were certain haircuts, including my own.

title: Let's Legalize Farm System

HOME VIDEO;
The Joy of Sax
description: LEAD: SONNY ROLLINS: SAXOPHONE COLOSSUS Sony Video Software. 101 minutes. $29.95.

title: The Rome Shop That Vanished
description: There is a corner of Rome, a tangle of crooked streets and alleys, a hardy survival of the Renaissance famous for six centuries, that yet is unknown to most Americans. It lies west of the Piazza Navona and behind the stately buildings that line the broad modern Corso Vittorio Emanuele. The painter Raphael dwelt in this corner, so did the Florentine sculptor and silversmith Benvenuto Cellini.

title: PLAYERS MAY BE DOWN, BUT THEY'RE NOT OUT
description: The end of the players' strike against the National Football League owners Thursday began a new phase of the labor dispute, one in which the pressures may intensify and the perception of management as the winner may change.

title: In Cambridge, Stalking 'the Weirdest' and Inventing the Future
description: The sleek silver building at 23 Ames Street is formally part of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But instead of physics or engineering students, it is populated by rock stars, corporate executives, computer hackers and visionaries.

title: The Struggle for Poetry in Outer Space
description: ZERO GRAVITY By Richard Lourie. 284 pp. San Diego. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, an article last week about Edward S. Gordon's plans for the Bridgehampton Racquet and Surf Club site included a misattributed quotation. It was Ulrich Franzen who said he was concerned that ''in order to turn the club property into a profitable venture, Mr. Gordon will sell lots on the periphery of the club, leaving the club itself intact.''

title: Lebanon's Militias Providing Social Services
description: Lebanon's political and religious militias, which after 12 years of civil war have virtually replaced the central Government as the effective authorities in most of the country, have started their own networks of social services ranging from providing textbooks to operating buses.

title: Mathematics And Magic
description: FROM THE DAWN OF HISTORY, sages have intertwined numbers with magic to create the gods, demons and world views needed by the rest of us to make existence seem comprehensible. The resulting lore has led to vast bodies of superstitious rigmarole, but it has sometimes spawned the luminous visions that draw scientists toward truth.

title: 'BILOXI' BY SIMON AT ARENA
description: IN ''Biloxi Blues,'' the Neil Simon play now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, Eugene Morris Jerome, the teen-ager of ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' has grown older and joined the Army. It is 1943, and basic training is for the serious business of war, but as viewed through Eugene's eyes, the Army is a vehicle for learning to become a writer, learning about sex and falling in love.

title: Let's Back Away From a Worldwide Economic Abyss
description: LEAD: Just as the mishandling of the reparations and war debt problems between World War I and World War II helped bring on and then deepen the Great Depression, the leaders of the major economic powers today are misjudging the scale of international trade and debt imbalances.

title: PEACE MARCH TO BE HELD SATURDAY
description: IN 1984, Louisa Whitlock, a soft-spoken Bernardsville resident, walked along the Nicaragua-Honduras border with a New Jersey peace group.

Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

description: Officials of Rutgers University are making ambitious plans to develop new technologies for food production and environmental protection.

description: Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the former guard at the American Embassy in Moscow sentenced to 30 years in prison for spying, turned down a CBS News interview under pressure from the Marine Corps, according to the network and his civilian defense lawyers.

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
description: Definitely not. For two years he made laughingstocks of Dave DeBusschere and Scotty Stirling by taking the huge sum of $874,000 from the Knicks each year and not having the decency or courtesy to show his face at Knicks games to lend moral support. During this two-year period a portion of the $3,400 I paid each year for my four courtside seats helped defray Captain King's salary while he was doing his disappearing act. H. STANLEY DIAMOND New York

description: THE National Museum of American History in Washington ''touched a nerve'' - in its words - when it disclosed plans for an exhibition on the internment of Japanese-Americans in the West during World War II.

description: When President Corazon C. Aquino handed out the first 237 grants in her land redistribution program last summer, she told the recipients she felt like a poor father who has only 100 pesos to divide among his 10 children.

description: Four strong male performers dominate some rewarding vintage film fare this week - Peter Lorre, Paul Scofield, Robert Preston and George Arliss.

description: LEAD: HAVING witnessed a preview of winter, it is apparent that some guidelines for preparing vulnerable plants for winter's onslaught and repairing such damage are appropriate now.

title: Best Sellers: October 18, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. 1 17 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicans and lawyers. 2 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt 3 3 Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of Pennsylvania, in the aftermath of the Civil War. 3 * PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, 2 12 $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 4 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, 4 3 $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program "A Prairie Home Companion." 5 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) 5 5 Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 6 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) 6 9 Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 7 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 7 7 $16.95.) The ordeal of a military officer, charged with high crimes, whose family heritage covers 200 years of constitutional history. 8 * HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, 9 4 $18.95.) At a friend's funeral, three women who had it made in the 60's reflect on their past and future. 9 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) 8 20 Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 10 FREEDOM, by William Safire. (Doubleday, 10 6 $24.95.) The early years of the Civil War and Lincoln's developing commitment to emancipation. 11 THE NEW BREED, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, 11 4 $16.95.) American military men involved in a rebellion in Congo during the 1960's. 12 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by 14 7 Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) Scotland Yard's Superintendent Jury and his cronies at a London pub investigate two deaths. 13 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. 1 (Morrow, $18.95.) The effect of a violent death on the Quicks, an eccentric North Carolina clan. 14 * THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. 13 48 (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina and New York City. 15 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins 15 16 Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Love and murder at a swank California health spa. Weeks This Last On Week Nonfiction Week List 1 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, 1 $21.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 2 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul 1 12 Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service. 3 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, 3 3 $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 4 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political 2 6 Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 5 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by 5 6 Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 6 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by 4 25 Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 7 IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. 6 6 (Bantam, $18.95.) Behind the scenes during the filming of the television series "Out on a Limb." 8 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi 8 15 Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 9 THE MAKING OF "THE AFRICAN QUEEN," by 7 5 Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $15.95.) The actress's experiences with Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and John Huston while filming the classic movie. 10 STRAIGHT ON TILL MORNING, by Mary S. 11 6 Lovell. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The life of Beryl Markham, pioneer aviator and author of "West With the Night." 11 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. 10 28 Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 12 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. 9 20 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) The information -- geography, history, literature, politics -- that you need to read with. 13 CRYSTAL WOMAN, by Lynn V. Andrews. 1 (Warner, $16.95.) The author, on a quest for inner Knowledge, travels to the heart of Australia. 14 AN AMERICAN CHILDHOOD, by Annie Dillard. 13 3 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) An introspective account of the author's youth, set mainly in Pittsburgh. 15 THE RENEWAL FACTOR, by Robert H. 1 Waterman Jr. (Bantam, $19.95.) The co-author of "In Search of Excellence" discusses the importance of innovation in American business. Weeks This Advice, How-to and Last On Week Miscellaneous Week List 1 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE 1 110 DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 2 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert 2 15 E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. 4 19 (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 4 * THE TERRIBLE TRUTH ABOUT LAWYERS, by 1 Mark H. McCormack. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $17.95.) Advice from a 1954 graduate of Yale Law School on how to deal with attorneys. 5 HOW TO MARRY THE MAN OF YOUR CHOICE, 3 11 by Margaret Kent. (Warner, $14.95.) Ways to find a mate.

title: Turkey's Leader Wins An Election-Law Test
description: Despite an opposition walkout, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal overcame his most serious parliamentary challenge early today, mustering a majority of deputies to win a victory in a crisis over procedures for a national election.

title: U.S. IS REASSESSING RESPONSE ON TIBET
description: Some senior Reagan Administration officials have concluded they may not have reacted strongly enough to China's crackdown on recent unrest in Tibet.

title: CHER'S NEXT ACT
description: IN CHER'S BEDROOM, there is seating for maybe a dozen. Opposite a wall of floor-to-ceiling windows that overlook one of the Beverly Hills is a long banquette. In front of the bed two enormous armchairs don't quite surround a vast ottoman. Like the walls of the living room downstairs that, reminiscent of an ancient tomb, open up to let visitors in from the driveway; and like the huge, supposedly mystical, crystal mounted in the family room, the bedroom arrangement seems reasonable. For years now, after all, much of Cher's life, public and private, has been a spectacle, and her persona, like her furniture, a bit outsized.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Cockeysville, Md.;
Self-Contained Village Sought
description: LEAD: A LOCAL developer has seized on a little-used special zoning designation in proposing a 2,177-unit self-contained village along I-83 here, about 10 miles north of the Baltimore city line.

title: CHAMBER SERIES JOINS ORCHESTRAL OPENINGS
description: THREE orchestral openings, the start of Chamber Music Plus, and campus events highlight the concert week.

title: Rev. W. H. Brewster, Gospel Song Composer
description: The Rev. W. Herbert Brewster Sr., a leading gospel composer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Joseph Hospital in Memphis, where he lived. He was 90 years old. Two of his compositions, ''Move on Up a Little Higher'' (1946) and ''Surely, God Is Able'' (1949) were the first black gospel recordings to sell more than one million records, according to The New Grove Dictionary of American Music.

title: Elizabeth Grusky Marries Jonathan Morris, Historian
description: At the Bethel Chapel of the Asbury United Methodist Church in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Elizabeth Rudoy Grusky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Grusky of Croton-on-Hudson, was married yesterday to Jonathan Morris, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Graham Morris of London. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

title: Baby Is Awake and Moving After Transplant
description: A baby who received a heart transplant just hours after birth awoke and moved his arms and legs today on his second day of life.

title: U.S. Team Studies Tanker's Damage
description: United States military experts studied the damage aboard an American-registered tanker in Kuwait today, in an investigation that will help determine the United States response to the apparent Iranian attack.

title: Small Space for a Grand Collection
description: Some designers pride themselves on soup-to-nuts decorating - buying everything for their clients from sofas and paintings to wastebaskets and bath towels. Not Hermes Mallea and Carey C. Maloney, the three-year-old architect-designer team who call themselves the M (Group). Many of their clients are auction house experts, art dealers or collectors who have strong ideas of their own on furnishings and art. ''We never dictate what hangs on someone's walls,'' says Maloney, who is the firm's designer. ''Maybe where it hangs, but we have an unusual set of clients who are highly educated about art and antiques.''

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
DRIVER CHECKS
description: LEAD: ''If we don't get them on the immediate New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge, we will now get them at dozens of other places around the county,'' said Lieut. John Pescatore of the Bergen County Police Department.

title: Waiting for Deals
description: AFTER one-fourth of this topsy-turvy season, three of the National Football League's first-round draft picks remain unsigned. One of them, Chris Miller, the quarterback from Oregon drafted by Atlanta, said he planned to sit out the season unless the Falcons sent him to another team by Tuesday's trade deadline.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Robert A. Heinlein turned 80 this year. The title of his latest book, TO SAIL BEYOND THE SUNSET (Ace/Putnam, $18.95), comes from the conclusion of Tennyson's ''Ulysses,'' where that retired hero proclaims his desire to go down to the sea once more in search of adventure and ''a newer world.''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Exempting New Rentals From Controls
description: LEAD: THE number of rental apartments being built throughout New Jersey has been declining since the late 1970's. But now a new law is in place that state officials and developers hope will reverse that trend.

title: Roberta Kurjan Wed To Ethan H. Schwartz
description: Roberta Lee Kurjan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Kurjan of Woodmere, L.I., and Ethan H. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Frederick H. Schwartz of Evanston, Ill., were married last evening. The ceremony was performed at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club by the bridegroom's father, who is the senior rabbi of Temple Sholom in Chicago.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: The Emperor Jones With Paul Robeson. 1933. Paul Robeson: Tribute to an Artist Sidney Poitier, narrator. Written and directed by Saul J. Turell. Embassy Home Entertainment. 101 minutes, total. $39.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Dallas dispatch last Sunday about Federal fines against Braniff Inc. and Trans World Airlines omitted information about T.W.A. in some copies.

title: ROOM FOR VARIETY IN SONO
description: ANYONE who harbors doubts about the survival prospects of the redevelopment of SoNo ought to consider the steady expansion of the area restaurant scene. While none of the current establishments along Washington and South Main Streets has existed long enough to be a bellwether, the fact that all seem to be surviving and thriving augurs well.

title: STAGE: FOR COMEDY 'THE NO-FRILLS REVUE'
description: WHEN the theater successfully spoofs itself before a knowing audience, the clubby laughter one hears is different in tone from that of any other kind of laughter generated from a New York stage: It is an appreciative smirk transformed into a satisfied chuckle. The best moments of ''The No-Frills Revue,'' the director-writer Martin Charnin's tribute to the type of 50's and 60's nightclub show pioneered by Julius Monk, elicit just that kind of response.

title: Mastectomy Seen as Extreme for Small Tumor
description: Nancy Reagan and her doctors chose to remove her entire left breast despite a variety of recent findings that less extreme surgery is as effective for small breast tumors like hers.

title: Year-End Tax Tips for the Investor
description: INVESTORS scanning their portfolios for last-minute ways to cut taxes this year will find their task substantially complicated by the recent changes in the tax law. ''This year is particularly important because it's a bridge from the old law in 1986 to 1988, when the new rules fall into place,'' said Joan S. Stolpen, an attorney with the Merrill Lynch tax advisory group.

title: In Love With a 'Lunatique'
description: ANIA MALINA By Lawrence Osborne. 201 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.

title: One Flew Over the Chicken Nests
description: HERE in Ossining, only 40 minutes by train from the heart of New York City, my neighbor Carole keeps hens. In her lingo, they are the ''girls,'' a modest flock of them. There are just enough birds to supply eggs for her family of three plus a few friends. And the eggs are not really the payoff.

title: Lombardi Faces Independent
description: LEAD: JOHN A. LOMBARDI has been Supervisor of the town of North Castle since 1961, and while he has served longer than any other town leader in the county, he insists that he has ''no desire to set any records.''

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Elvis Presley's Graceland Priscilla Beaulieu Presley, host. The Congress Video Group. 60 minutes. $19.95.

title: A Shield for Bureaucrats - Or Is It Constraint?
description: SINCE, when the Hatch Act was enacted, civil servants have been forbidden to take part in partisan political campaigns or to solicit campaign funds from colleagues.

title: Susan Wu Marries
description: Susan Wu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wu of Kingston, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Eng, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kai Eng of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Gregory J. Sutterlin officiated at Augustana Evangelical Lutheran Church in East Elmhurst, Queens. The bride, a summa cum laude graduate of Mercy College, is a buyer for the Mine, a specialty apparel store in Scarsdale and Mount Kisco, N.Y. The bridegroom, a graduate of New York University, where he also received an M.B.A. degree, is a systems engineer at the International Business Machines Corporation in New York.

title: INCINERATION CRITICIZED
description: Why are Richard T. Dewling, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, and his assistant, Donald Dieiso, so intent on trashing scientists and concerned citizens who oppose incineration? Perhaps they should listen to what we have to say.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Uproar Over Plan To Treat Lepers
description: FEAR and resentment swept over Alviso, Calif., when residents learned of a plan to treat 176 leprosy patients at a community clinic.

title: FRAZIER, 3-TIME LOSER IN '81 SERIES, RECALLS ALL THE BAD HOPS
description: The only pitcher ever to lose three games in one World Series honestly is back in the Series six years later. George Frazier, however, will not lose three games this time. Unlike Bob Lemon, who managed the Yankees in the 1981 Series, Tom Kelly will not give him the opportunity to lose three games this time.

title: OWNER SIGNS ACCORD SAYING HE'LL CLEAN RADIUM PALNT
description: A radium-supply company in New York City, under fire for radiation-safety violations since 1983, pledged last night to empty its radioactive plant within two months and to accept full legal responsibility for decontaminating the premises.

title: Cadillac Tastes
description: To the Editor:

title: P. A. Knapp Weds Katherine Falise
description: Katherine Prentice Falise, a daughter of Robert A. Falise of Bedford, N.Y., and Carolyn P. Falise of New York, was married yesterday to Phillip Arpad Knapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip L. Knapp of New Canaan, Conn., and Waitsfield, Vt. The Rev. Dr. William E.
