Foley performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Richard D. Visconti, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: U.S. IS COMMITTED TO NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The United States remains deeply committed to the explosive testing of nuclear weapons despite its recent agreement with the Soviet Union on a long-range goal of banning such tests, Government scientists and officials say.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LAND AND LABOR Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Nation, will address the Economic Club of Connecticut in Stamford on Friday, urging companies to consider situating manufacturing facilities on the Navajo Reservation, which covers parts of Utah, Arizona and New Mexico.

title: Jazz
description: Although Clare Fischer has been prominent in the jazz world as a composer, arranger and keyboard artist for more than 30 years, he has done most of his work in studios close to his home in California. There have been a few periods when he left the studios to travel, notably as pianist and conductor of the singing group the Hi-Lo's in the 1950's and in the mid-70's with Cal Tjader's Latin combo. He will finally make his New York debut as a solo pianist in a concert on Thursday at Weill Recital Hall at 8 P.M.

title: Meddling Won't Help Air Travel
description: What began in the House of Representatives as a sensible response to outrage over air travel delays has turned into meddling. Air travelers as well as airlines ought to hope for greater wisdom from the Senate.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored. If he is right, what can I do to correct this problem?

title: Regina Sachs Married To Richard M. Rufolo
description: Regina Ann Sachs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brice A. Sachs of Convent Station, N.J., was married there yesterday to Richard Matthew Rufolo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Rufolo of Florham Park, N.J. The Rev. John Alexander, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth.

title: Boll's Politics
description: To the Editor:

LEAD: When he began work on the Church of the Sagrada Familia in 1883, Antonio Gaudi, the eccentric but brilliant Catalonian architect, warned that it would take years and years to complete. He was absolutely right. The genius who left his mark on Barcelona and other disciples of the Art Nouveau Movement was hit by a streetcar in 1926 and died on June 10 of that year.

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEP KING?
description: Definitely! Bernard King was the reason the Knicks were winners in the early 80's and the reason they were losers in the mid-80's. Also, how could they have the heart to let him go? He was hurt as a Knick and he came back as a Knick. ARI STRANCH Highland Park, N.J.

title: WHEN A LEVERAGED BUYOUT FAILS
description: VAUGHN PAUL and Duncan Soldner, two smalltime mushroom farmers, thought they had hit pay dirt when some bankers from Citicorp Industrial Credit wanted to help them do a leveraged buyout of Mushroom King Inc., the country's second-largest mushroom farm.

title: High Costs Deciding Who Controls Medicine
description: THE 1965 act that established Medicare began with the ringing declaration of a principle that the American Medical Association considers as fundamental as the separation between church and state: Nothing in this law shall be construed to authorize any Federal employee to ''exercise any supervision or control over the practice of medicine'' or over the compensation of any person providing health services.

title: Tourism Seen as Irksome to Whales
description: Amid indications that well-intentioned tourists may be threatening the whale population off New England, the Federal Government is considering restrictions on a whale-watching industry that has become a mainstay of the Cape Cod economy.

title: Lofty Plans for a Growing Family
description: Walter Chatham is an architect who prides himself on the unconventional: His two-year-old sleeps in an industrial-size laundry bin, his dining room has columns but no walls and he treats cheap building materials such as salvaged pillars and corrugated steel with the same kind of reverence as he would hand-gilded cornice moldings or imported marble.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Linking Pay to Profits

title: ARTIST IS DRAWN ON STAGE
description: ''I KNOW why you're here!'' she exclaims, attempting, unsuccessfully, to drive us away. After announcing that she will have nothing to do with the ''segregated'' tone of the occasion - an exhibition of art done by women - she plainly perceives that the audience will be neither antagonized nor intimidated, and proceeds, reluctantly, for an hour or so, to tell of a time in her life, centering on her relationship with her work and with Alfred Stieglitz, the photographer and cultural force whom she married in 1924, when he was 60 and she was 37.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Corporate Finance; Why Olympia & York Regained Downtown Tower
description: OLYMPIA & YORK showed its style as one of the shrewdest developers in the world of finance last month by clinching a deal to turn a downtown Manhattan office tower into a powerful piece of international currency.

title: STAGE: 'ISLE OF SWANS,' BY AUSTRALIAN
description: THINGS are definitely amiss, awry, amok on the Isle of Swans. No sooner does older sister Alexandra (Rosemary Hochschild) set foot on the sandy shore with the family handyman Tom (Lindzee Smith) in search of Isabelle (Rhonda Wilson), who has been living there with a sailor named William Clare, who has lately disappeared, than everybody starts giving out with platitudinous poeticisms and picking on each other. ''She's a queer one, that Isabelle,'' mutters Tom, an instance of the pot calling the kettle cracked. Though set on a small island off the coast of Australia around 1900, the play, by the Australian writer Daniel Keene, now at the Westside Art Theater, is entirely at sea.

title: Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Rob Reiner Applies the Human Touch
description: HE MADE HIS DEBUT AS A DI-rector in 1984 with an affectionate ''rockumentary'' that chronicled the last screeches of a fictitious -and loud - heavy-metal band. He then turned to a teen-age romance that recalled vintage Frank Capra more than the brat pack. His third effort was set in the 50's - but instead of trading on nostalgia and the Big Bopper, it focused on four boys in search of a corpse. And his latest film is a warped fairy tale that has a heroine called Buttercup, a miracle worker named Max and a hero who's mostly dead.

title: HERZOG'S DOUBT PROVES PROPHETIC
description: Whitey Herzog, managing in his third World Series in the past six years, received his answer early tonight.

title: Jersey Offers Bonuses to Find Psychiatric Hospital Nurses
description: New Jersey is offering $3,000 bonuses to attract registered nurses to work in the state's four psychiatric hospitals.

title: Petra Daniel Wed To David Laurie
description: Petra Marie Daniel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Daniel Jr. of Wickford, R.I., was married there yesterday to David Hutchinson Laurie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William David Laurie Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church by Canon Peter Spencer, assisted by the Rev. Dr. David W. Richardson, a Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride.

title: A FOND FAREWELL
description: FEW men, or women, leave this world having provided pleasure to people in many countries. This claim can certainly be made for Victor Mollo, who died last month in London at the age of 78. For more than 20 years bridge players everywhere have chuckled over the adventures at the Griffins Club of the Hideous Hog, the Rueful Rabbit and other strange denizens of that fictional locale. They appeared in Mollo books such as ''The Bridge Menagerie'' and numerous magazines. As a result, he was an easy winner some years ago when American players were asked to vote to select the most entertaining writer on the game.

title: Assault Trial's Pugnacious Lawyers
description: With belligerent questioning and pugnacious persistence, two defense lawyers in the Howard Beach case have emerged as the most aggressive of the four attorneys defending four Queens youths charged with murder or manslaughter.

title: In Goode-Rizzo Contest, Voters Count the Flaws
description: As the fight for the heavyweight political championship of Philadelphia enters its final rounds, Bad Wilson appears to be ahead of Big Frank on points.

title: Article 324787 -- No Title
description: The budgeted cost of the half-completed Taj Mahal casino hotel has soared, to $800 million from the 1983 estimate of $185 million, according to a petition filed with the State Casino Control Commission.

title: 3 DAYS AT THE FEET OF MASTER CRAFTSMEN
description: A CURATOR at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts has praised a sculptural settee by Sam Maloof, a California woodworker, as being among ''a half-dozen most beautiful examples of seating made by a contemporary American craftsman.''

title: Hinda Gottlieb Weds
description: Hinda Gottlieb, a special agent in the New York field office of the State Department, and Stephen Patrick Perdreaux, an inspector for the United States Marshal Service, were married yesterday at the Parker Meridien Hotel in New York by Judge Bernard Newman of the Federal Court of International Trade. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gottlieb of Oceanside, L.I. She graduated from George Washington University. The bridegroom, a son of Rene Perdreaux of Brooklyn and the late Marie Perdreaux, graduated from St. Francis College in Brooklyn.

title: Albany Notes; 2 Top Aides To Governor Might Leave
description: Two top members of the Cuomo administration have told the Governor that they might leave soon to take higher paying jobs with private corporations.

title: POSTINGS: Working a Tough Site; Right Climate
description: For years, the hilly, rocky topography of a four-acre site on Edsall Boulevard in Palisades Park, N.J., scared off developers. But the tremendous housing appreciation in that area, right on the Fort Lee border, has made even this prickly property enticing. Bluestone is now being blasted and retaining walls erected in preparation for 92 town-house condominiums, to be called Windsor Square.

title: Two Punk Rebels Decide That Rock Isn't So Bad
description: PUNK ROCK'S PROMISE, WHEN it arrived on the mid-70's pop scene in a burst of apocalyptic fury, was that from now on, things would be different. In England, punk anger and punk style signaled a social upheaval. But punk's most far-reaching impact was within rock itself. The music was dominated by middle-aged stars, relics of the 60's who had distanced themselves from the driven intensity and nose-thumbing irreverence of their early years. Rock's ''dinosaurs'' were concerned with craft and commercial calculation; the punks reaffirmed the primacy of passion and risk.

title: Redgrave Wins Rights Ruling in Boston Suit
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra violated Vanessa Redgrave's civil rights when it canceled a series of concerts she was to narrate, a Federal appellate court has ruled.

title: Outdoors; Sharpening Shotgun Patterns
description: WE do not shoot at birds in the dark because the law and common sense forbid it. Hunters who never pattern their shotguns are metaphorically shooting in the dark.

title: Young Hands Practice Age-Old Craft
description: Well past the half-century mark, renovators and interior designers were more likely to strip, dismantle and paint over whatever they found in a building rather than preserve it. Flat-painted walls, industrial-style lighting and wall-to-wall carpets replaced or covered the original elaborately carved mantels and trims, wood floors and intricate wallpaper patterns.

title: IN SHIFT, HERZOG LOOKING TO COX AS HIS CLINCHER
description: Shortly after St. Louis won the final National League playoff game against San Francisco, Whitey Herzog said he expected to use John Tudor as his starting pitcher in the second game of the World Series and Danny Cox as the starter in the third game. After thinking about it for 24 hours, though, the manager reversed the order.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: I believe that Mr. Dornberg erred in saying that Girar-det in Crissier ''has three Michelin stars.'' While I feel that Girardet is one of the two greatest restaurants in the world, second only to Taillevent in Paris, I have never been able to find it rated by Michelin.

title: PART-TIME DOESN'T MEAN 'CUT-RATE'
description: As a compulsive newspaper reader and a community college faculty member who is a union activist, I was immediately drawn to the essay entitled ''Part-Time Teacher: A Troubling Pattern'' by Prof. Paul Wenger [ Opinion page, Sept. 13 ] .

title: 10 Are Killed and 50 Injured As 2 Yugoslav Trains Collide
description: A freight train collided head-on with a passenger train in eastern Yugoslavia today, killing 10 people and injuring 50, the Tanyug press agency reported.

title: DOWN TO THE GREAT SHIP
description: WHERE COMES A TIME when the nature of one's interest in a tragedy becomes historical, to use the word loosely; not human, to use that word loosely. When I was 13, I was taken to Pompeii, and the guide spoke about the phenomenon and dealt only macrocosmically with the human tragedy. The people who died because Vesuvius belched up its firestorm of molten lava were entirely anonymous ''victims,'' like the victims of Napoleon's march on Russia, the men slaughtered day after festive day in the Roman Colosseum, or the cavalrymen who charged in the Light Brigade.

title: Tsvetayeva and the G.P.U. Gloomy Gus the First
description: To the Editor:

title: Maysles: Filming the Impossible
description: ''THE WHOLE THING IS based on faith,'' Albert Maysles said, ''the most outlandish faith.''

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; New Life for Du Pont Estate
description: THE former country estate of a du Pont heiress is being transformed into a $100 million office park by the Trammell Crow Company of Dallas.

title: Walter A. Nirenberg Weds Lynn Michaels
description: Lynn Ruth Michaels and Walter Andrew Nirenberg were married yesterday evening at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan by Rabbi Linda Goodman.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SAVAGES. By Shirley Conran. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous'' meets Outward Bound in this story of five women, all wives of executives with Nexus Mining International, who are forced by the chaos of a right-wing coup to take refuge in the jungles of Paui (a fictitious island off the coast of Australia) where they are vacationing with their husbands.

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
description: Bernard King is a tenacious player, a team leader, the kind of captain the Knicks desperately need. When I think of the inspirational qualities of Bernard King, I am reminded of the play of Willis Reed (who rose above the circumstances of his injured knees to lead the Knicks to two championships). Bernard King is irreplaceable. JAMES CONGDON New York

title: JET REPLACEMENTS TO BOW OUT AMICABLY
description: Maurice Turner sat in front of his locker the other day and observed the chaos inside the Jets locker room.

title: An Ill Wind in France
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Storming Heaven' Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Marshall Vows to Outlive His Critics
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court vowed today to outlive critics who have called for his retirement.

title: French Guard Steps Smartly
description: Strollers in the quiet Celestins quarter of Paris, between the Place de la Bastille and the Ile St.-Louis, are sometimes startled to turn a corner and see clattering toward them, as if from another century, a mounted troop of the Garde Republicaine, glorious in plumed helmets, white breeches and crimson-piped blue uniforms. Even blase Parisians stop to gaze at the magnificent sight, often applauding spontaneously as the men and horses pass by.

title: MOVIES
description: Along the Great Divide Starring Kirk Douglas, Virginia Mayo, Walter Brennan, John Agar. Directed by Raoul Walsh. 1951. Warner Home Video. 88 minutes. $19.95.

title: A Conference for L.I. Sound
description: ALTHOUGH Richard Taracka has seen many unusual sights while diving beneath the waters of Long Island Sound, nothing, he said, compares with the current scene.

title: Flutie's Precaution
description: BEFORE becoming the New England Patriots' replacement quarterback for today's game against the Oilers in Houston, Doug Flutie first made sure he wasn't taking away anybody's job, he said. ''I went to great lengths before making the decision about whether any veteran players would be released because of my signing,'' Flutie said. He was traded last week from the Chicago Bears to the team he grew up cheering for, and he'll start today in the Astrodome. ''I think I needed to come home; I didn't see a bright future there,'' Flutie said, speaking of Chicago.

title: Gary Eisenreich Weds Miss Stoller
description: Sally Ann Stoller, a daughter of Herbert Stoller of New York and Harrington Sound, Bermuda, and Shirl E. Stoller of San Diego, was married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in Manhattan to Gary L. Eisenreich, the son of Mrs. William F. Eisenreich of Alton, Ill., and the late Mr. Eisenreich. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: BRITAIN ASSAILED IN COMMONWEALTH
description: Outbursts by fellow Commonwealth leaders against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain marked the conclusion today of the 47-nation Commonwealth Conference.

title: Headliners; In Business
description: In one sense, the Columbia Business School course taught by Asher B. Edelman promised to be the most rewarding class offered by the university this year. Mr. Edelman, an expert on corporate takeovers who is teaching a class on the subject, announced last month that the student who scored best on the final exam could get $100,000. The exam was to take the form of identifying a company ripe for a corporate raid; the student who came up with a takeover target that Mr. Edelman decided to pursue would get a $100,000 finder's fee. But those who oversee the teaching of business at Columbia apparently draw the line at doing business in the classroom. Last week, Dean John C. Burton announced that he had ordered Mr. Edelman to withdraw the offer, which, the Dean said, ''would bias the academic atmosphere.''

title: PERSPECTIVES: 'Infill' Zoning; Balancing Needs in Low-Rise Districts
description: WOODEN barriers enclose a large construction site on Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, where excavation has begun. A prominent sign proclaims what is to come: four four-family houses.

title: James Peter Nicholas Marries Linda Packer
description: Linda Livingston Packer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Packer of Ambler, Pa., and James Peter Nicholas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Nicholas of San Diego, were married yesterday at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa., by the Rev. Richard T. Hawkins.

title: Prospecting for Smart 18-Year-Olds
description: ''THE experts tell us there's a lot of attrition at some schools because the whole process of being a freshman is so overwhelming and dehumanizing,'' said Mr. Collier of the SUNY branch at Albany. In response, colleges are increasingly providing friendly advisors, livelier teachers and better living conditions to increase retention of first-year students - which means the school needs to attract fewer of them the next time around.

title: DIANA LOEB
description: Diana Loeb, until recently vice president of the board of trustees of the Public Education Association, a nonpartisan advocacy group that monitors the performance of New York City's schools, died of lung cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old.

title: Entertaining Innovations
description: It is quite safe to make long-range forecasts. By the time reality catches up with you, everyone has forgotten what you said. It is short-term predictions that often leave you with egg on your face. Luckily, home electronics is an exception to this rule. Even short-range prophecy is relatively risk-free, because the future is so close its main features are already clear, even if details and timing are not.

title: Jersey Charged in Labor Case
description: The Communications Workers of America has filed an unfair labor practice charge against the New Jersey Department of Personnel, which is making changes in Civil Service job titles.

title: Award Made To Professor For Cell Study
description: Columbia University's prestigious Horowitz Prize has been awarded to Dr. Gunter Blobel, a cell biologist at the Rockefeller University. The $22,000 prize is given annually by Columbia for outstanding research in biology or biochemistry.

title: 2 Complex Securities Cases Prove a Trial for Jurors
description: JUST half a mile or so north of Wall Street, the Federal District Court in Manhattan has long been home to business and commercial disputes. But rarely has it seemed so much like an annex to a securities trading floor as this month, with the opening of two high-profile trials involving allegations of high financial chicanery. In courtrooms, hallways and elevators throughout the Foley Square landmark, the buzzwords these days are tax straddles, account churning and unrealized income.and unrealized income.

title: Why Russians Are Wooing the U.N.
description: FOR decades the Soviet Union grumbled whenever the United Nations sent troops to keep the peace in trouble spots around the world, usually refusing to help with either men or money.

title: 51 Die in Mozambique Raid Said to Be a Rebel Ambush
description: Mozambican rebels ambushed a convoy of vehicles Friday on Mozambique's main north-south highway and killed at least 51 people, the official Mozambique news agency reported today.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Oct. 3 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $948,000 298 West 11th Street 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-story, 4,608-sq.-ft. 1808 Greek Revival town house; double parlor, 7 fireplaces, porch and attic, wide-plank floors, 24- by 60-ft. irregular lot; taxes $5,069 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Madison Square Area $440,000 5 East 22d Street (Madison Green) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,250-sq.-ft. condo in a 4-year-old building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, terrace; common charge $343, taxes $900 (Broker: Edward Lee Cave) Upper East Side $590,000 135 East 71st Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,550-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, formal dining room, hardwood floors, separate pantry; maintenance $1,032, 50% tax-deductible (Broker:

title: IN ISLIP, BOTH SIDES USE GARBAGE ISSUE
description: THE next man elected Islip Town Supervisor might well ride into town atop a garbage barge.

title: LINDEMAN, FILL-IN FOR CLARK, LIKES THE ROLE
description: Jim Lindeman of Des Plaines, Ill., knows it may be a baseball trivia question someday: Who was the rookie who replaced the great Jack Clark at first base for the St. Louis Cardinals in the 1987 World Series?

title: Clifton Loses
description: Unbeaten Paterson Kennedy built a 17-0 lead but had to rally for two touchdowns in the fourth period to subdue Clifton, 30-26, yesterday in Hinchliffe Stadium in Paterson. It was Kennedy's fourth triumph and the first defeat for Clifton in four games.

title: WHEN PLAYING WITH FIRE BECOMES A 'CRY FOR HELP'
description: LEAD: IN MOST ways, 12-year-old Billy is like any suburban child. He likes to play and watch sports, collect and trade baseball cards and ride his bike.

title: The Rehearsal's the Thing
description: THE SHIFTING POINT 1946-1987. By Peter Brook. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Arizona Chief Assails Press on His Portrayal
description: Gov. Evan Mecham, the target of a drive to oust him from office that appears likely to lead to an election next year, says the news media have spread a ''cancerous lie'' that he is a bigot.

title: Black Ballots
description: WHOSE VOTES COUNT? Affirmative Action and Minority Voting Rights. By Abigail M. Thernstrom. 316 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Some Happy Moments, Some Very Tall Language
description: Stephen Dobyns's most recent book of poems is ''Cemetery Nights.'' His new novel, ''A Boat Off the Coast,'' will be published next month.

title:
ART;
13 Chinese Artists, Recent Arrivals All, at Sarah Lawrence
description: LEAD: ''ARTISTS From China - New Expressions,'' at the Sarah Lawrence Art Gallery in Yonkers through Nov. 22, would be more noteworthy if the artists in it still lived in that constantly changing country. The 13 artists are all rather recent emigres to the United States. All came following the notorious Cultural

title: Country Folk Dancing With an Elegant Scottish Turn
description: LEAD: THERE is country dancing and there is Scottish country dancing - the pastime of royalty. Scottish country dancing, with roots in the Scottish and French courts of the 18th century and earlier, has a precision and elegance unmatched by other forms of folk dancing, its enthusiasts say. Dances are performed without the called instructions of traditional square dancing, but some of the motions are similar: couples form lines, weave in and out among each other, promenade under a canopy of raised arms.

title: Consumer Finds Consumption All-Consuming
description: ''HELLO, as you probably can guess, I am out circulating,'' began the message on the recording machine. So the day introduced me into the way things do not work.

title: FOR SYNAGOGUE, 100 YEARS OF CHANGE
description: JENNIE ZACHS can recall the days when talking during services at the Agudas Achim synagogue in Hartford could bring a 25-cent fine.

title: City Auctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Connie Cooper Is Married To Scott Magill, Executive
description: Constance Cooper, president of Connie Cooper Designs Inc., a home furnishings company in New York, and Donald Groves Magill, a Citibank executive, were married yesterday at the Inn at Quogue in Quogue, L.I. Keith Kammerer, an acting Village Justice in Westhampton Beach, L.I., officiated.

title: HIGH-LEVEL MOONLIGHTER: Charles E. Hugel; Tackling the Top Job at Two Companies
description: LAST month, when RJR-Nabisco named as its chairman Charles E. Hugel, Combustion Engineering's chief executive, eyebrows shot up throughout the business community. Why, people asked, would an Atlanta consumer products company pick an Easterner who has no packaged goods experience, has never worked for RJR, and has his hands full running a $2.7 billion company some 900 miles away?

title: Print to Fit
description: PRAVDA Inside the Soviet News Machine. By Angus Roxburgh. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: George Braziller. $19.95.

title: Prosecutor Arrested
description: Deputy District Attorney Gary P. Kesselman, the original prosecutor in the ''Twilight Zone'' manslaughter case, pleaded not guilty Friday to a charge of lewd conduct after being arrested with a woman in a parked car here.

title: Dawn Andrea Dankner Married to Alan Rosen
description: Dawn Andrea Dankner and Alan I. Rosen were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue by Rabbi David H. Lincoln. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dankner of Suffern, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Rosen of Seaford, L.I.

title: REINVENTING THE AMERICAN AUTO
description: THE American car has been the stuff of legend - in lyrics, literature, even love - since the early part of this century. But in the last 10 years, it has been transformed more drastically than at any other time in the previous 50 years. Faced with two energy crises in the 1970's and fierce competition from Japan, Detroit is now making cars that are smaller and lighter than their 1978 counterparts but that are just as big inside and get much better gasoline mileage.

title: FAIRFIELD U. PROGRAM: 10 YEARS OF CAREER HELP
description: LEAD: WHEN Fairfield University began offering career counseling services in 1977, most of the early clients were like the woman who called and said: ''I have just relocated here, and I can't put up another set of drapes. I need to find something to do with the rest of my life.''

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: DESPITE HIS thick glasses, rumpled jacket, a tie that barely reaches past his sternum and the obligatory chalk-covered pants of a professor, he cuts a handsome figure. Striding across the room in long, sure steps, he conducts his lecture like a maestro, the rat-a-tat-tat of the chalk on the board providing a counterpoint to his high, breathy, sometimes inaudible voice. He talks of ''vector bundles,'' ''spin groups,'' ''Dirac operators,'' ''connected Lie groups,'' ''trivial modules,'' ''free loop spaces.'' At one point he pauses: ''We've been living in a finite dimensional world. Now I'm inviting you to jump into a world of infinite dimension.''

title: A Prisoner of War in the Hamptons
description: BLUEBEARD By Kurt Vonnegut. 300 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

title: Task Force On Water Outlines Objectives
description: LOCAL officials, developers and environmentalists last week got their first public look at county efforts to develop a management plan for Westchester's water supplies.

title: Ceremonial Dances
description: YEARS FROM NOW By Gary Glickman. 263 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Assessments
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Offers Plan to Revive Five Unused Theaters
description: Hoping to bring new life to at least five darkened Broadway theaters, Mayor Koch yesterday proposed the creation of a theater trust fund to be financed in part by a $1 surcharge on tickets to other Broadway shows.

title: Early Prewarnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a review of the Metropolitan Opera production of ''Das Rheingold'' misidentified the singer at center. She was Waltraud Meier.

title: Alexandra Grigg Is Wed in Capital To C. A. Beitz 3d
description: Alexandra Grigg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Grigg of Washington, was married there yesterday at the Washington Club to Charles Arthur Beitz 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Beitz Jr. of Carlisle, Pa. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the bride's grandfather the Rev. Wendell Randolph Grigg, a Baptist minister.

title: Allegra S. Harrington Marries Charles Dryden Jr.
description: Allegra Sari Harrington and Charles Curtis Reynolds Dryden Jr. were married yesterday at the North Stamford (Conn.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Melvin Smith performed the ceremony.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: Though I have the greatest respect for Barbara Tuchman and very little for Ronald Reagan, I must protest one way Mrs. Tuchman explains the President's failings: ''When a person reaches 70 or 75, consequences seem less important, and someone carrying heavy reponsibilities will have a tendency to let things go. . . .'' Such statements about the elderly are typically based not on scientific inquiry into aging, some of which has undermined this type of generalization, but rather on unexamined prejudice. Why do people who would emphatically condemn racist or misogynist stereotypes so willingly stereotype older men and women? HEATHER DUBROW Cambridge, Mass.

title: Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; London
description: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people. You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking. What you can find, however, is a hotel room - rather than a room in a pension or bed and breakfast - equipped with a direct-dial telephone, private bath and, perhaps, color television.

title: Teamsters Urged to Fight U.S. Takeover Bid
description: An influential local leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters urged more than 700 union officials yesterday to vigorously fight a threatened Federal takeover of the union.

title: OPEC Will Peg Price Rises to Inflation
description: BASED on a combination of oil market fundamentals and OPEC policies, oil prices are expected to fluctuate around an upward trend for the balance of the decade. As a result of our analysis, we expect the rate of price growth to approximate the rate of inflation. Implicit in this outlook are several assumptions: that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will continue to be a significant factor in regulating world oil markets, that its collective goals will reflect a compromise among the goals of its individual members, and that supply and demand will slowly converge.

title: MOVIES
description: Colonel Redl Starring Klaus Maria Brandauer, Armin Mueller-Stahl. Directed by Istvan Szabo; screenplay by Mr. Szabo and Peter Dobai. 1985. Pacific Arts Video. 143 minutes. $79.95.

title: Maine Indian Tribes Revive Bingo Under New State Law
description: Hundreds of people jammed a tribal community center as the Penobscot Indians played high-stakes bingo games for the first time since the practice was halted four years ago. Many paid $50 to get into the $10,000 jackpot games. Nobody won the grand prize.

title: Birth Control Device Returning for Sale in U.S.
description: An intrauterine device that has not been sold in this country for more than a year will soon be available again, according to a nonprofit research group that holds the patent.

title: In Game 3 of Chess Match, Conservative Tactics
description: Quiet, stalking play by Anatoly Karpov was met by wary resistance from Gary Kasparov to produce a draw in the third game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, Friday.

title: NATIONAL STAMP SHOW WILL OPEN ON THURSDAY
description: THE National Postage Stamp Show, sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers' Association (Asda) convenes Thursday through Sunday at New York City's Madison Square Garden. Hours Thursday are noon to 7 P.M., Friday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3.75 daily for adults; children under 14 are admitted free.

title: Bargaining in Lives
description: The Soviet Government has acted in recent weeks to resolve some longstanding emigration cases. Two weeks ago, for example, it gave an exit visa to Ida Nudel, a leading campaigner for Soviet Jews. This week officials told Vladimir Slepak, another prominent refusenik, that he and his wife could move to Israel, 17 years after they first applied.

title: WATER PLAN UPSETS PLAINVIEW
description: LEAD: A 1,000-MEMBER Plainview-Bethpage civic group and officials of the Plainview Water District fear that a state and Town of Oyster Bay recommendation to purify and recharge water underneath the closed Bethpage landfill - the largest toxic waste site on Long Island - may cause their drinking water to be contaminated.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COLLEGE RECRUITING
description: COLLEGE recruiters were once recent graduates just past acne who were given a credit card and a late-model car and pointed in the general direction of St. Louis. Their brochures described the 110 rolling acres above the Missouri, Ohio or Colorado River, the 10.5 million bound volumes in the college library, and the minimum test scores needed to enroll.

title: Johannesburg Cuts Park Use After a Melee
description: Heavy spring rains have transformed Johannesburg's well-groomed parks into green oases offering a refuge from the stresses of urban life. But the parks have also become the center of a heated dispute after a violent confrontation between whites and blacks last weekend.

title: A Sharper Image in the Making
description: UNTIL THIS MONTH, prospects had been dim for improvements of the technical quality of American television. While Japan and several European countries were eagerly experimenting with advanced transmission systems that yield pictures far superior to those seen at present, the United States appeared stuck with standards formulated 50 years ago. To modernize these standards seemed politically imprudent. What Federal administration would enact measures that render obsolete the 140 million television sets in this country, to say nothing of all the transmitters and broadcasting equipment?

title: MOVIES
description: Jour de Fete Starring Jacques Tati. Directed and written by Mr. Tati, Henri Marquet and Rene Wheeler. Produced by Fred Orain. From the Janus Collection. Subtitled. 1948. Embassy Home Entertainment. 79 minutes. $29.95.

title: TEMPLE EXPANSION WORRIES NEIGHBORS
description: LEAD: THE proposed expansion of an Orthodox synagogue in Woodmere has raised concern among neighbors who live near the building on several residential streets. Most of the neighbors are also Jewish, but only a few are Orthodox.

title: Is Ankara Underrated?
description: TURKEY America's Forgotten Ally. By Dankwart A. Rustow. Illustrated. 155 pp. New York: Council on Foreign Relations. $14.95.

title: Primer Offers Tips on PAC's To Candidates
description: Politicians may be expert at running up large campaign bills, but one Republican consultant here says many lack the skills needed to persuade prospective donors, particularly political action committees, to give them money.

title: Miss Vandeweghe To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Maurice Vandeweghe of Bel Air, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tauna Kay Vandeweghe, to Robert Kennish Mullarkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. X. Mullarkey of Locust Valley, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
description: The Knicks should definitely try to keep Bernard King. They are in desperate need of a front-court player who can set up his own shot and discourage defenses from collapsing on Ewing. RICHARD SACKETT New York

title: FESTIVE GERMAN FARE FOR FALL
description: COLD weather and German food are made for each other. October's nippy air calls for hearty food rather than summer's lighter fare. The Smithtown Haus doesn't have an Oktoberfest extravaganza, but it has added a special item to the menu and labeled it Oktoberfest.

title: LIBERAL UNIVERSITIES BATTLE FOR SURVIVAL IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: SOUTH AFRICA'S liberal English-language universities are locked in a battle for survival, caught between the demands of growing numbers of nonwhite students and the Government's insistence on a society in which white supremacy makes only limited concessions. While providing forums for anti-apartheid conferences and trying to promote a society open to all, the universities have clashed not only with the state, but also with sections of the liberal establishment and the English-language press.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AN INCOMPLETE EDUCATION. By Judy Jones and William Wilson. (Ballantine, $24.95.) Judy Jones and William Wilson were sitting around the research department at Esquire magazine one day when suddenly it struck them that their generation needed them: There were books that told people in their 30's how to dress and books that told them how to get ahead but there were no books that told them how to think.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored. If he is right, what can I do to correct this problem?

title: 15 Karmal Associates Purged From Posts in Afghan Party
description: Fifteen prominent members of the Communist Party leadership in Afghanistan who were associated with the country's deposed leader, Babrak Karmal, were removed from office today, the Kabul radio said.

title: Next Week; How Do You Assess The N.F.L. Strike?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: 3 Stabbed in Brawl Near Police Headquarters
description: Three youths were hospitalized with stab wounds after a brawl across the street from the New York City Police Headquarters on Friday, the police said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN FRANKFURT
description: The city has many names: Bankfurt, Krankfurt, Angstfurt, Mainhattan. All are pejorative and allude to Frankfurt-on-Main's postwar reputation as the city Europe loves to hate. Why? Because it became West Germany's commercial center, the country's business and financial capital.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN SNOW FALLS BEFORE THE LEAVES DO
description: LEAD: HAVING witnessed a preview of winter, it is apparent that some guidelines for preparing vulnerable plants for winter's onslaught and repairing such damage are appropriate now.

title: BUSH'S RIVALS TRY TO FAN A DISQUIET AMONG VOTERS
description: TO his Republican Presidential rivals, Vice President George Bush is a political paradox, a clear front-runner who seems teasingly vulnerable. Their problem is finding strategies to fuel voters' uneasiness - as shown in national polls - about Mr. Bush's strength and independence.

title: THE VIEW FROM: NIANTIC A MAIN STREET SHOWS THE SIGNS OF STRESS
description: FOR more than 100 years the village of Niantic has been the thriving business district of East Lyme, but business owners there say that is beginning to change.

title: The Shogun Wasn't the Problem
description: BEFORE THE DAWN By Shimazaki Toson. Translated by William E. Naff. Maps. 798 pp. Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press. $30.

title: Love With Reticence and Recipes
description: LEAD: FRIED GREEN TOMATOES AT THE WHISTLE STOP CAFE By Fannie Flagg. 403 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title:
NOTEBOOK: LITTLE ROCK, ARK.;
The New Look Of Main Street
description: LEAD: A DECADE ago, a group of retailers spent $4.5 million to convert a declining downtown Main Street shopping strip into a six-block outdoor walkway lined with kiosks, planters and fountains. From this traffic-free strip, called Metrocentre Mall, shoppers entered storefronts.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: The article about Swiss lake travel gives the wrong train station for the Ballenberg Freilicht (Outdoor) Museum. It's not Brienz - it's Brienzwiler, about three miles away, from which there is a forest path going uphill from the lakeside station to the museum. There are no taxis at Brienz. ELAINE DANN GOLDSTEIN Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; Rome
description: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people. You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking. What you can find, however, is a hotel room - rather than a room in a pension or bed and breakfast - equipped with a direct-dial telephone, private bath and, perhaps, color television.

title: NEW GROUPS BATTLE CONDO CONVERSIONS
description: LEAD: A NEW crop of tenant and landlord organizations here and in surrounding Hudson County communities, fueled by a flood of condominium conversions, has sprung into place, their goal being to stem the erosion of affordable housing - the flip side of the state's booming real-estate market.

title: A Fire Empties the RCA Building And Forces Channel 4 Off the Air
description: A smoky fire in a cable vault beneath Rockefeller Center forced the evacuation of the RCA Building early last night, knocking WNBC-TV off the air for more than 10 minutes and forcing the Washington Bureau of ''NBC Nightly News'' to prepare an impromptu edition of the program.

title: A BROKEN COUNTRY
description: Henry Kamm has made a crucial point that needs emphasis (''A Broken Country,'' Sept. 20): eight years after the killing fields, Cambodia today is still a broken country inhabited by broken-hearted, underfed and uneducated people with little hope and practically no help from the rest of the world.

title: Ms. Ashton Weds J. B. Underhill 3d
description: Betsy Finley Ashton, the personal finance correspondent of ''The Morning Program'' on CBS-TV, and Jacob Berry Underhill 3d, a former president of the New York Life Insurance Company, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., at the summer home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Howard Brougham Major of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Robert E. Neale, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Walker's Guide
description: LEAD: WILL there be a run on walking books?

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: SAUDI ARABIAN GULF WAR STRATEGY;
World Oil Prices Are on the Way Down
description: LEAD: SINCE 1973, oil prices have been heavily influenced by events in the Middle East and by unilateral Saudi Arabian production decisions. Now that the Persian Gulf War between Iran and Iraq has entered a new and menacing stage, with Iran and Saudi Arabia in open confrontation, the question of what Saudi Arabia will do in the realm of oil production is of prime importance.

title: Raymond Barton Muldaur Marries Natalie Misae Ige
description: Natalie Misae Ige, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tsutomou Ige of San Jose, Calif., and Raymond Barton Muldaur, a son of Mrs. Harold Warnock of Red Bank, N.J., and Charles E. A. Muldaur of New York and Edgartown, Mass., were married yesterday at the Unitarian Community Church in Santa Monica, Calif., by the Rev. Ernest Pipes Jr. The bride, a graduate of California State University at Northridge, is an awards assistant at the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences in Burbank, Calif., sponsor of the Grammy Awards. The bridegroom is the manager of information systems at the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in Burbank, sponsor of the Emmy Awards.

title: JACKSON'S DEBUT VICTORIOUS
description: For nearly as long as he can recall, Mark Jackson has possessed visions of this moment. Since the legendary backcourt combination of Earl Monroe and Walt Frazier helped the Knicks to their second championship, and made an immeasureable impression upon one 7-year-old in Queens, Jackson has imagined himself there countless times - guiding the Knicks.

title: CONFERENCE ON SAVING THE SOUND
description: ALTHOUGH Richard Taracka has seen many unusual sights while diving beneath the waters of Long Island Sound, nothing, he said, compares with the current scene.

title: Give Me Epic, Give Me Tragic, Give Me Cheap
description: LEAD: CUTS By Malcolm Bradbury. Illustrated by Tom Phillips. 143 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95.

title: The Accidental Affair
description: AN ADULTERY By Alexander Theroux. 396 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: TOP DOG IN THE CHASE FOR THE FRISBEE TITLE
description: AT one time or another, most dog owners have thrown a Frisbee, hoping their dog can catch the disk on the fly. Not all can, and more often than not the Frisbee misses the mark and hits the dog.

title: Square Deal for Columbus Circle?
description: BACK IN 1985, WHEN THE DE-sign for the skyscraper that has been proposed to replace the Coliseum at Columbus Circle was announced, the project, called Columbus Center, seemed certain to be built. It did not matter that Columbus Center was too big by half and was a ghastly piece of architecture to boot. What did matter was that the project had come about as a result of a zoning deal between the City of New York, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a private developer (Boston Properties), and a tenant-investor, (Salomon Inc.). The will of this public-private partnership was not about to be thwarted by any whining and complaining in the name of a more livable city. The Board of Estimate gave its approval earlier this year, and by then opponents of the project, such as this critic, seemed only to be tilting at windmills.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A SOCIALIST IN CONSERVATIVE DRAG
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Casino Control Commission is performing its duty nobly when it insists on preserving the high regulatory barriers to political activity by officials of the casino industry.

title: Giants Get Help at Last
description: Replacement football received major-league replacements today when the Giants activated Lawrence Taylor and Jeff Rutledge for Sunday's game here against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Slinking Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about physics experiments in Japan misstated the nature of electrons and positrons, elementary particles of matter. Although apparently without internal structure, both have mass.

title: Elena Bowes and Peter Marano Wed in California
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Hillsborough, Calif., Elena Bowes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Bowes of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Peter Damien Marano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco J. Marano of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Jerome Politser performed the ceremony.

title: Toddler Alert and Gaining After Long Ordeal in Well
description: Alert and recovering from a two-and-a-half-day ordeal in an abandoned well, an 18-month-old girl underwent minor surgery at a hospital in Midland, Tex., yesterday, and doctors said they were optimistic about saving her badly bruised right foot.

title: Rochester Hands Hofstra First Loss
description: Andy Milne's 38-yard field goal with eight seconds to play enabled Rochester to upset Hofstra, 31-28, yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: OUT OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: Janet Levine's article on Mvelase, the South African student at Milton Academy in Massachusetts (''Out of South Africa,'' Sept. 20), prompted me to let your readers know that Mvelase's experience is being repeated at other schools in a six-member consortium known as the Independent School South African Education Program. Milton works with the Northfield Mount Hermon School and others in providing important educational opportunities to these students.

title: Why Soccer Can't Make It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WEDGES SOUGHT FOR OPENING OF SHOREHAM
description: LEAD: STAYING home rather than fleeing during a nuclear plant accident could result in fewer deaths and injuries to people living near a plant during a major accident, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission committee has suggested.

title: THIS NEW WATERPROOF ONE EVEN HAS A 'BRAIN'
description: TWO trends in contemporary camera design have converged in the Minolta Weathermatic Dual 35. As the name suggests, it is a 35-millimeter, automatic camera impervious to the elements. It can be submerged to a depth of 16 1/2 feet and it offers a choice of two focal lengths. While there are a multitude of 35-millimeter cameras with one or the other of these features, this is the first camera to have them both.

title: Robertson Assailed for a Remark
description: Pat Robertson, a Republican candidate for President, refused today to apologize to Nancy Reagan for a remark he made Friday night that was interpreted as being critical of her.

title: Executives Who Became Entrepreneurs
description: UNLIKE some corporate executives who became entrepreneurs, neither Thomas A. Fahey nor Sheldon Jacobs is inclined to bite the hands of the corporations that once fed them. On the contrary, both Mr. Fahey, who spent 21 years at the General Foods Corporation, and Mr. Jacobs, with 25 years at ABC and NBC, praise their former employers for providing lessons that have helped them in what have become highly profitable second careers.

title: Piniella Status Unclear After Talk With Owner
description: Lou Piniella, the current Yankee manager, confirmed today that he met for at least two hours Thursday with the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, although there was apparently no resolution regarding Piniella's status. ''We talked about a lot of things,'' Piniella said of the meeting, which was conducted at Yankee Stadium. ''But beyond that, I have nothing to say.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Art for Hospital
description: LEAD: The White Plains Hospital Medical Center is getting a new look, and the public is invited to help.

title: Walcott Has Fall Off Stage at Fight
description: Jersey Joe Walcott, the former world heavyweight champion, took a fall of his own after the Mike Tyson-Tyrell Biggs fight Friday when he fell off a stage and cut his forehead.

title: Bullet Offer Sheet to King
description: Bernard King has signed an offer sheet with the Washington Bullets. A source said that the offer sheet, signed Friday, will pay him $2.3 million over the next two years. In order to retain King, the Knicks must match the offer within 15 days from the signing.

title: Looking for a Silver Lining
description: LEAD: BARRETT N. SINOWITZ, a studious-looking, barrel-chested stockbroker in the Prudential-Bache Securities office near Grand Central Terminal, was trying to reassure a client about his drug-stock holdings, which had plunged more than 20 percent in the market's two-week blood bath.

title:
TELEVISION;
REINER MORITZ: CULTURE IS HIS STOCK TRADE
description: LEAD: FOR THE WEST GERMAN BROAD-caster Reiner Moritz, it was a not atypical four-day stay in New York.At the Brooklyn Academy of

title: Beads to Brighten And Bedeck Us
description: BEADS - THE MOST basic and enduring adornments known to man -are the subject of an absorbing exhibition of exotic and familiar craft expressions, at Tambaran Gallery, 957 Madison Avenue (at 75th Street) through Nov. 15. The jewelry, beaded clothing, ritual objects, cradles and artifacts on view were produced over thousands of years in scores of cultures and were assembled by Maureen Zarember, a dealer in tribal art, who has made a dozen trips since 1982 to the Far East, Europe and Australia.

title: RALLY MAY WIDEN SOUTH KOREA SPLIT
description: With the banging of drums and the cheers of hundreds of thousands of suppporters, the opposition leader Kim Young Sam began his campaign for the presidency today, leading a huge open-air rally here that could widen the split in the opposition party.

title: Stepien Fined
description: HE changed basketball leagues, shifting from Cleveland of the National Basketball Association to Mississippi of the Continental Basketball Association, but controversy still follows Ted Stepien. Now, the former Cavaliers' owner has been fined $50,000 by the C.B.A.'s president, Mike Storen. Stepien, owner of the Mississippi Jets, failed to cooperate in the league's investigation of salary-cap violations, according to Storen.

title: Stephen Durant Is Married To Rosemary Anne Marks
description: Rosemary Anne Marks and Stephen Christopher Durant were married yesterday by the Rev. John Dillon in the Roman Catholic Church of Cure of Ars in Merrick, L.I.

title: A HODGEPODGE OF 'TREASURES' IN GREENWICH
description: GIVEN the glut of art that now prevails, a time when there wasn't enough to go around can hardly be imagined. Yet according to Audrey McMahon, this was the situation as recently as the 1920's, when she became head of the College Art Association and, as quoted by Francis V. O'Connor in ''The New Deal for Art'' of 1972, found that knowledge and appreciation of the subject went no farther west than the Alleghenies. The DeYoung Museum in San Francisco, she says, was empty and at least one Southern museum counted among its holdings the gilded baby shoes of its founder.

title: NEBRASKA ROLLS ON BY 35-0
description: Nebraska netted 617 yard, led by the quarterback, Steve Taylor, and the tailbacks, Ken Clark and Keith Jones, to extend its domination of Oklahoma State to 26 years with a 35-0 trouncing today in a Big Eight Conference game. Oklahoma State entered the game 5-0 record, its best start in 42 years.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Main Event
description: LEAD: Stephen B. Acunto of Mount Vernon, the president of the American Association for the Improvement of Boxing, didn't notice much handshaking going on at his organization's annual awards luncheon last Sunday at the Rye Town Hilton. The 220 guests at ''Boxerama-87'' had a more intimate greeting ritual.

title: NONFICTION
description: BLACK ROBES, WHITE JUSTICE. By Bruce Wright. (Lyle Stuart. $15.95.) As a judge in the New York State courts for 17 years, Bruce Wright has never minced his words about the almost inevitable racism of white Americans, and that has often led to accusations that he hates all whites. Justice Wright, now on the New York State Supreme Court, finds that somewhat ironic since his mother was white. Little nuggets of autobiographical detail are scattered throughout this slim volume, which Justice Wright describes as ''reflections and musings, if you will, on a view of America based upon an entire life spent as a black male in a white world.'' The book presumes that the reader knows something of the judge's reputation: in the 1970's he was nicknamed Turn 'Em Loose Bruce by those who disagreed with his policy on setting bail for suspects, and his public comments often created a furor. The major premise of the book, which is often rambling and repetitive, is that white judges are incapable of treating black defendants justly. ''What do they study in college or law school that might tend to qualify them to preside over the doom or liberty of strangers to their kinds of neighborhoods, of aliens to their way of life, of foreigners and outsiders to their clubs, their churches, their folkways?'' he asks. The book suffers when the judge rehashes the views of others on topics as varied as opera and the lingering impact of slavery on blacks. But in relating anecdotes about judges he has known and their treatment of defendants - nearly all of the incidents predate the 1980's - the author comes close to proving his indictment of the court system.

title: Cheryl McKissack And M. O. Hosten Wed in Nashville
description: Cheryl Joan McKissack, a research engineer for the Manhattan engineering firm of Weidlinger Associates, and Michael Orlando Hosten, an account executive for Datapoint, a computer company in New York, were married yesterday in Fisk Memorial Chapel at Fisk University in Nashville by the Rev. Robert O. Simpson, a United Methodist minister.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
STRIKE AFTERMATH: THE UNION'S NEXT STEP
description: LEAD: WITH the National Football League players' decision to return to work last week - after a 24-day strike and without a collective bargaining agreement -an individual player might justifiably ask, ''What did the strike accomplish?'' The answer, quite frankly, is that nothing was gained by the strike.

title: Policy's the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Athens
description: The Athens skyline is supposed to bristle a little with antiquity. These days, the bristling comes more from the ravages of modernity on older things, symbolized in the gantries and scaffolding atop the Acropolis, which in recent years have grown to enfold the Parthenon.

title: SELLING NEW HAVEN TO YBLE'S ALUMNI
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS of Yale University and New Haven are reintroducing Yale alumni to the city where they attended college, with an eye toward recruiting investors in New Haven.

title: Social Events
description: Art, Antiques and Shows ORT Celebration Oct. 20 - Founded in 1880 to train the Jews of eastern Europe in industry and agriculture, ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) has grown into a global network of schools and training centers for 158,000 adults and children in 18 countries. The American ORT Federation will hold its annual dinner at the Sheraton Centre, at which Senator and Mrs. Daniel Patrick Moynihan will be honored. Cocktails at 5:45 P.M. followed by dinner at 7. Tickets $300; 212-840-0303 or 516-763-4141. Art to Buy . . . Oct. 21 - The New York Fine Print Fair is coming to town, and a preview party will be held from 6 to 9 P.M. at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street to benefit the New York Public Library's print collection. More than 90 dealers will offer thousands of works, from Old Master engravings to contemporary creations in silkscreens, lithographs, woodcuts and etchings costing from a few hundred dollars to many thousands. Admission is $15 at the door. Information: 212-755-8500. The fair runs Thursday through Saturday from noon to 8 P.M., and Sunday from noon to 6 P.M. Admission $7. . . . and Stolen Art Oct. 21 - Who keeps records on stolen art, whether taken from a dealer in Athens, a gallery in Paris or a museum in New York? The International Foundation for Art Research, 46 East 70th Street, has kept track of missing paintings, sculptures and antiquities since it created the Art Theft Archive 10 years ago and now has files on 27,000 items. A 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. cocktail benefit for the foundation will be held at the Forbes Magazine Gallery at 60 Fifth Avenue (12th Street). Tickets, $225 a pair; 212-879-1780. Pier Party Oct. 21 - Along with the traditional array of furniture and furnishings at this year's Fall Antiques Show, there will be a special exhibition, Silhouettes in America 1790-1840, organized by the Museum of American Folk Art. A 6 to 10 P.M. preview party with music and an extensive buffet will be held at Pier 92 (at 54th Street on the Hudson River). Tickets $100, from 212-481-3080, or at the door. The show will run Thursday through Saturday noon to 10 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free buses leave for the show every half hour from the museum, 62 West 50th Street. Briefly Noted: Oct. 21 - Cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by a dinner-dance at the Plaza will benefit Literacy Volunteers of New York City. Tickets $300; 212-874-4098. Oct. 21 - The 39th annual dinner-dance of the Children of Bellevue will be held at the St. Regis Roof starting with 7:30 P.M. cocktails. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, will be the guest speaker. Black tie. Tickets $175; 212-561-5221. Oct. 21 - The National Corporate Theater Fund, which helps support 10 regional theaters around the country, is holding a benefit at Tavern on the Green before a preview performance of ''Into the Woods'' at the Martin Beck Theater. Tickets $85 for show alone, $125 for cocktail-buffet party and show and free bus to theater; $150 for party, transportation and better seating, and $250 for party, best seats and autographed cast album; all from 212-393-6252. Oct. 21 - The Terri Gotthelf Lupus Research Foundation will hold its annual dinner-dance at the Pierre, starting with 7 P.M. cocktails. Tickets $300, or $175 for those 25 and under; 203-852-0120. Oct. 22 - The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund will honor Felix G. Rohatyn with Oprah Winfrey acting as mistress of ceremonies at a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets $300; 212-260-1070. Oct. 22 - Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court will receive a public service award from the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Pierre. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets $500; 212-944-5700. Ball at the Waldorf Oct. 23 - The April in Paris Ball, one of the city's more elegant benefits, will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria starting with an 8 P.M. Burgundy Festival, at which a wide range of the finest wines from that area will be served. The theme of the dinner-dance will be La Belle Epoque of Paris 1890-1910. White or black tie. The evening will benefit the American French Foundation, which serves 20 charities. Tickets $400; 212-486-8833. Legends That Help Oct. 24 - The Youth Counseling League helps troubled people between the ages of 14 and 25 for low fees, or none at all, at clinics in White Plains and Manhattan. A benefit for the league, geared to the 21 to 35 age group, will be held at the Manhattan Center Studios at 311 West 34th Street. The theme will be Hollywood Legends, and guests are invited to dress as Hollywood stars or in black tie. There will be a light supper and open bar. Tickets $65; 212-473-4300. Halloween Preview Oct. 25 - Costumes are optional but merriment is mandatory at what is billed as a Caribbean Halloween bash featuring Chinese-Hispanic food, a cash bar, dancing and a raffle at Bayamo, 704 Broadway (just north of Fourth Street). The 7 to 11 P.M. evening will benefit the Jewish Guild for the Blind, which has provided services for visually impaired people of all religions and races since 1914. Tickets $45 in advance from 212-595-2000, extension 242, or $55 at the door.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A Long Fuse Burns Slowly on Israel's Borders
description: GEORGE P. SHULTZ flew into Israel last week to find the Middle East in a quite different mood from his last visit to the region two years ago.

title: Are Mcorp's Assets Spoken For?
description: LEAD: Texas banking has suffered gravely with the oil industry's troubles as bad loans wiped out several institutions' stockholder equity. While many troubled banks restructured, or made deals with big out-of-state lenders, Dallas-based Mcorp - formerly the Mercantile Texas Corporation - has doggedly gone it alone, mostly downhill in the last two years.

title: Boat, Fence And House
description: ''BASICALLY, IT STARTED OUT with a house, a boat and a fence that I built,'' says the artist Jennifer Bartlett, referring to the objects that have provided her predominant theme for the past two years. Exhibits of her work - one of paintings, one of pastel drawings, all with the three images -have already been held at the Paula Cooper Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan. Now, Ms. Bartlett is preparing a third show, consisting of five large paintings (measuring 9 feet 10 inches by 14 feet), each with a wooden, three-dimensional construct in front of it - a boat, a house or a fence - ''a reflection,'' she says, ''of whatever is the central image of the painting.''

title: TAMILS DASHING INDIAN HOPES FOR PEACE IN SRI LANKA
description: THE warfare in Sri Lanka last week turned the logic of India's original intervention upside down.

title: Men Had Reason to Fear
description: LEAD: REBECCA WEST A Life. By Victoria Glendinning. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Angry Woman Beats A Sex-Crime Suspect On Subway Platform
description: Accusing a fellow rider of fondling her, a 27-year-old Queens woman angrily dragged a 31-year-old man off a crowded Lexington Avenue subway train Friday morning below Grand Central Terminal and beat him, according to the transit police.

title: Army Appeals Court Allows AIDS Test Result in Prosecution
description: An Army appeals court has ruled that results of a test for the AIDS virus may be used to help prosecute a soldier who is accused of having sexual0relations with three people after learning he was infected.

title: Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; Paris
description: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people. You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking. What you can find, however, is a hotel room - rather than a room in a pension or bed and breakfast - equipped with a direct-dial telephone, private bath and, perhaps, color television.

title: Joseph Cardinal Hoffner, 80; Led German Catholic Church
description: Joseph Cardinal Hoffner, the former head of the Roman Catholic Church in West Germany and a strong supporter of Pope John Paul II, died in a Cologne hospital on Friday. He was 80 years old.

title: Peter Frisch Plans to Wed Catherine Lilly Next May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard McIlwaine Lilly of London and Essex, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Huse Lilly, to Peter Osborne Frisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frisch of Rye, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Rome
description: Polemics have raged over the bright colors used in the restoration of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel frescoes, but there is one Roman monument, now surrounded with scaffolding, that everyone agrees should remain dark and gloomy even after it is refurbished.

title: F.A.A. Warning on Jet System
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has issued a warning to commercial airlines that an emergency system on the Boeing 757 jet might not operate properly if both engines fail in flight.

title: Correction
description: A Washington dispatch last Sunday about a statement by law-enforcement officials that the Justice Department was likely to indict E. F. Hutton & Company misstated the company's connection to two previous incidents. The company had no legal involvement in the cases, which involved a company broker, Andy Yurowitz, and a company executive, Arnold Phelan.

title: Tamil Snipers Slowing Indian Advance
description: Indian peacekeeping troops, moving only yards a day in some places in their advance on the Tamil guerrilla stronghold of Jaffna, are being attacked by snipers in trees, bunkers and fortified houses, an Indian official said today in an unusually candid description of the fighting.

title: What's Next
description: A giant sculpture made of copper pipe and wire in a SoHo loft is angled between a pair of classical columns in a way that makes it appear to have landed from another planet. Stools carved from tree stumps decorate a late-19th-century Parisian salon. In the Connecticut woods, a modern house has recently acquired a split personality:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MURPHY IN PRINCETON Eddie Murphy will perform at Princeton University Saturday in what is billed as his final tour as a stand-up comic.

title: Today's Interest in The Gardens of The Past
description: In the world of gardening, no word is more peculiar than new. Mail-order nursery catalogues, especially the more sensational ones that like to promise miracles, tend to use it a lot, in boldface type followed by an exclamation point, or maybe three. But if a catalogue lists something as new, it generally means only that the plant so described is new to that particular nursery. Nurserymen enamored of the word are making an assumption about gardeners, namely that we look on plants as we look on automobiles and fashions in clothing and furniture design.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: MOZART AND FRIENDS

title: New Picture Emerges in Case of Larry Davis
description: A new picture emerged in a State Supreme Court hearing last week of the events leading up to the arrest last year of Larry Davis, the 21-year-old South Bronx man accused of killing four suspected drug dealers and, last November, wounding six officers in a shootout with the police.

title: PHELAN AND GAMBLE HELP TOPPLE CADETS
description: Army knew that Colgate's tailback, Kenny Gamble, was likely to have a big day at Michie Stadium today. And he did, gaining 188 yards to move into fourth place on the all-purpose career collegiate yardage list.

title: Mets' Saturdays Were Dismal
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Selection of Offbeat Concerts
description: MUSIC lovers on the prowl for offbeat programming have much to cheer about this week, because several concerts around the county have put aside the war horses in favor of less frequently heard pieces of the repertory.

title: Doctor, Counselor and Lawyer Held in Drug Case
description: A physician, a drug counselor and a lawyer were held on narcotics charges yesterday in Manhattan by housing authority police officers who said they had spotted the three suspects in a car stopped for a red light and had seen the driver sniffing what appeared to be cocaine.

title: HISTORIC JAIL GETS LANDMARK STATUS
description: LEAD: THE 1810 Burlington County Prison, known in New Jersey folklore as the Mount Holly Jail and now the Historic Prison Museum, will be commemorated as a National Historic Landmark on Wednesday.

title: CHILDREN
description: A Young Children's Concert With Raffi A & M Video. 50 minutes. $19.98.

title: TEMPORARY WORKERS AND OLSTEN'S ROLE
description: As chairman and C.E.O. of the Olsten Corporation, one of the leading suppliers of temporary services in North America, I am writing to inform you of inaccuracies and misconceptions in the recent article ''Temporary Jobs Booming.''

title: DEMOCRATS FACE LOSS OF 6 MORE JUDGESHIPS
description: SIX Democratic judges in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are in great danger of losing their judgeships in next month's election, in what has become a steady erosion of Democratic representation on the Long Island bench.

title: Rediscovering Thrift, or a New Look At the Old Ways
description: I grew up in a household dominated by old-fashioned principles of thrift. ''To buy'' was not a verb my mother liked; ''to save'' was preferable. Browsing through downtown department stores was never her habit, although no one doubted her eye at an antiques shop. She ran a tight ship -lights out when you leave the room, the thermostat at 60 degrees, save the leftovers and don't throw anything away that might prove useful.

title: Times Announces Departure Of the Editor of Its Magazine
description: The resignation of Edward Klein, the editor of The New York Times Magazine since 1977, has been announced by the newspaper's executive editor, Max Frankel.

title: Finding a Place In Disney World
description: In the old folklore, the baby is enrolled at birth for First Form in the correct prep school. In the new version, reservations for a Disney hotel in Orlando, Fla., are made at birth for the child's fifth birthday party. And this is not far off the reality mark.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL FORUM ON THE SOUND
description: ALTHOUGH Richard Taracka has seen many unusual sights while diving beneath the waters of Long Island Sound, nothing, he said, compares with the current scene.

title: BAD ADVICE ABOUT THE PROBLEMS OF RADON
description: IF New Jerseyans heed the radon advice of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, they soon may be wasting billions of dollars.

title: Liqueurs From Belgium, Steeped in History
description: Although Belgium is renowned for its hundreds of varieties of superb beer, few people are aware that the country also produces several excellent and unusual liqueurs. And though some are exported to the United States, they are usually available only in larger cities, in liquor stores with the biggest selection. So, if you wish to sample them, the best place to do so is in Belgium.

title: After Warning, Bork Witness Fell Silent
description: An aide to the Senate Judiciary Committee telephoned a law professor scheduled to testify in favor of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court to warn him that he could expect a grueling public examination of both his academic career and scholarship.

title: My Life as a Boy
description: THE greatest menace while I was growing up came from abroad, from the Germans and the Japanese, our enemies because we were American. I still remember my terror as a 9-year-old when, running in from playing on the street after school, I saw the banner headline ''Corregidor Falls'' on the evening paper in our doorway and understood that the United States actually could lose the war it had entered only months before. At home the biggest threat came from the Americans who opposed or resisted us - or condescended to us or rigorously excluded us - because we were Jews. Though I knew that we were tolerated and accepted as well - in publicized individual cases, even specially esteemed - and though I never doubted that this country was mine, I was not unaware of the power to intimidate that emanated from the highest and lowest reaches of gentile America.

title: Vagrant Is Accused of Beating Nun to Death
description: A nun who lived and worked among street people was beaten to death in her apartment, and a homeless man she had sheltered was charged with the killing, the police said Friday.

title: The Truest Believer
description: THE ARTFUL ALBANIAN Memoirs of Enver Hoxha. Edited by Jon Halliday. 394 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House Publishers. Paper, $9.95.

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: In ''Vienna's Love of the Trolley'' (Travel, Aug. 23), Paul Hofmann says, ''The Schotten in Vienna place names were medieval Irish missionaries whom the local people called Scots.'' The reason they called them that is that they were Scots. The country of Scotland, formerly Caledonia, got its name from the invading tribes of Ireland, then called Scotia, who settled in the Highlands (bringing the prefix Mac) and were known as Scots.

title: Jennifer A. Rakowski Weds Kevin Sheehan
description: Jennifer Ann Rakowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Rakowski of Vienna, Va., was married there yesterday to Kevin Sheehan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Sheehan of Vienna and Laurel, L.I. The Rev. William Schardt performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church.

title: POSTINGS: R.S.A. Seminars; The Rights Of Owners
description: The Rent Stabilization Association - the major trade group for New York City landlords - is sponsoring a series of seminars meant to help building owners, property managers and co-op and condo boards comprehend the city's tangle of housing rules and regulations.

title: Unesco Director Withdraws Bid For Re-election
description: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose 13 years as Director General of Unesco have split the organization, announced tonight that he wanted to withdraw from his race for re-election.

title: B. A. Penney Wed To Helen Wagner
description: At St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Springfield, Va., Helen Elaine Wagner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Herman Wagner of Springfield, was married yesterday to Bradford A. Penney, the legislative counsel to Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island. The Rev. Theodore G. Jones officiated. The bride attended George Mason University and is a loan settlement officer at York Associates Inc., mortgage bankers in Bethesda, Md. Her father, a retired Marine Corps colonel, is the vice president for technical services at the Planning Research Corporation in McLean, Va.

title: U.S SAID TO ALLOW DECLINE OF DOLLAR AGAINST THE MARK
description: In an abrupt shift from its policy of the last eight months, the United States is allowing the dollar to decline against the West German mark, a senior Administration official said today.

title: READINGS SERIES BROADENS ITS SCOPE
