description: CHANGES are in the air for the Maxwell Anderson Playwrights Series, which on Satuday starts its fifth season of staged readings in Stamford -- and for once the opening play is not by Maxwell Anderson.

title: Soviet Invites Inspection of Atom Power Plant
description: To allay fears about the safety of its reactors after the Chernobyl disaster, the Soviet Union has invited an international team to inspect safety arrangements at a civilian nuclear power plant, according to officials involved.

title: The President and the Children
description: Children are a nation's greatest future resource; that's why America is heading for trouble. In the next 12 weeks, President Reagan will either seize - or forfeit - his last chance to do something about it.

title: Q and A
description: Forcing a Buyout Question: Three siblings and I each own a one-quarter interest in a house on Long Island that was left to us by our late mother. We have seven years left on the mortgage and a $25,000 equity loan that two of my siblings took out to pay some bills. I am a co-signer of the loan, but I am not using the money or making payments. I have a long commute to Manhattan and would like to sell my interest to them and use the money for a down payment for an apartment in the city. When I mention this they fly off the handle. Can I take legal action to force them to buy me out? . . . A. B., Deer Park, L.I. Answer: Yes. According to Brook Boyd, an attorney with the firm of Herrick, Feinstein, New York law permits a co-owner to sue for partition.

title: When It's Time to Eat Sitting Down
description: ''GROWN-UPS'' A Generation in Search of Adulthood. By Cheryl Merser. 237 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: Barbara Tuchman's article successfully delineates the malaise afflicting this country. The New York Times Magazine itself is a prime example of our illness. Mrs. Tuchman's article should have been the cover and the lead story in the magazine. Instead, you featured Marcello Mastroianni - a perfect example of the use of image over substance and shallowness over relevance, and a significant indication that The Times will not make the effort to ''raise the level of public understanding from frivolity to a readiness to take serious things seriously . . . ,'' as Mrs. Tuchman urges. ELAINE HENDRIE Bellport, L.I.

title: Mary Johnson, Editor, Married to C. S. Dodge
description: Mary Abigail Johnson, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. David C. Johnson Jr. of Brooklyn Heights and Southport, Conn., and Christopher Stephen Dodge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen B. Dodge of St. James, L.I., and Ocean Dunes, N.C., were married yesterday in Southport. The Rev. Loring Ensign officiated at the Congregational Church.

title: Festival '87 Was High on Style
description: AT THE AGE OF 25, THE ANNUAL New York Film Festival, which closed one week ago tonight at Lincoln Center, has been running almost as long as Johnny Carson's ''Tonight Show,'' possibly for many of the same reasons. It has no overwhelming personality that turns audiences into fanatics who either love it or hate it. As Carson fans like him, festival audiences trust it. The festival exists to serve - to introduce and present acts of varying degrees of interest, which pay heed to contemporary fashions without, it seems, being subservient to them.

title: SURGEONS REMOVE CANCEROUS BREAST OF NANCY REAGAN
description: Nancy Reagan's cancerous left breast was removed today in a 50-minute operation without complications, the White House said.

title: Canarsie Falls
description: Chris Davila, a tailback, ran 30 yards for a touchdown to give Midwood a 21-14 victory over previously unbeaten Canarsie yesterday in the first week of Public School Athletic League divisional play. The winning score was set up when a Midwood saftey, Sean Leibowitz, intercepted a pass from Joe Rizzo, the Canarsie quarterback, with two minutes remaining and the score tied, 14-14.

title: The Importance Of Being Whimsical
description: When the celebrated couturier Christian Lacroix set out to create the image of his new French fashion house, he called upon the fantasist design team of Mattia Bonetti and Elizabeth Garouste. Couture-house decor, a quaint bastion of formality, will never be the same - and, if these young Paris designers have their way, neither will home interiors.

title: The Clouds Burn Off in Schenectady
description: WHEN General Electric made known its plans a few years ago to cut back its manufacturing operations in its birthplace, Schenectady, N.Y., the economic future looked pretty dim for the town that once billed itself as ''the city that lights up the world.''

title: MIGHTY CASEY
description: VEIL The Secret Wars of the CIA 1981-1987. By Bob Woodward. Illustrated. 543 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Democratic Leaders in the South Say Gore Is Gaining in Presidential Race
description: ''I believe in a strong defense; he believes in a strong defense, I'm a Southerner; he's a Southerner.''

title: Sports of The Times; Not Really the Undisputed Champion
description: UP on the Convention Hall stage, Mike Tyson was discussing his dissection of Tyrell Biggs in seven rounds. The undisputed world heavyweight champion was talking about how ''I could've knocked him out in the third, but I wanted to do it very slowly, I wanted him to remember this for a long time.'' And when Tyson was asked about his Jan. 23 title defense against 38-year-old Larry Holmes, he bragged that there isn't a ''man on this planet'' capable of dethroning him. But from behind the assembled listeners, the voice of the boxing public disputed the undisputed champion.

title: PALAZZO PLANS STUDIED
description: LEAD: ONE WOULD hardly expect to find what seems like a piece of Renaissance architecture in this congested, densely populated township that overlooks the Lincoln Tunnel and Hudson River.

title: Playing Fair With Gastineau
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: New at Adultery
description: MISS UNDINE'S LIVING ROOM By James Wilcox. 275 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: CHILDREN
description: Mr. Rogers Home Video: When Parents Are Away Playhouse Video. 66 minutes. $19.98.

title: FLIRTING WITH DEGAS
description: LEAD: HERSELF IN LOVE And Other Stories. By Marianne Wiggins. 184 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: NEW JERSEY BALLET, IN NEW WORK, LEAPS BACK TO THE CLASSICS
description: LEAD: WITH ''A Dance For You,'' the newest work in the repertory of the West Orange-based New Jersey Ballet Company, ballet has taken a stupendous leap backward.

title: Law and Medicine: Easier Access
description: NOW may be the time to go to medical or law school. Applications are down significantly, and the schools are scrambling for candidates. In 1974, when medical school applications peaked, there were 2.8 applicants for each available slot; now there are just about 2 prospects for each seat. The peak for law schools was not until fall 1980, but the valley is just as deep. Applications to law schools declined about 17 percent between 1981 and 1985, according to William J. Kennish, consultant to the Law School Admissions Council, although they increased slightly in 1986.

title: Oven-Cleaner Burns Shown In Suit Over a Hazing Ritual
description: A former University of Delaware football player says he allowed caustic oven cleaner to be poured over his head during a fraternity hazing ritual in 1980 because he ''wanted to be a brother.''

title: Pop Music
description: Nobody sings ''I'm Still Here,'' Stephen Sondheim's song about surviving the ups and downs of show business, with more knowingness than Julie Wilson. A major New York nightclub star in the late 40's and 50's, Ms. Wilson disappeared from view in the late 1970's when she departed the East Coast for her hometown of Omaha to raise two teen-age sons.

title: Miss Rundlett and R. H. Greenwood, Divinity Students, Are Married at Yale
description: Deborah Anne Rundlett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hodgman Rundlett of Bronxville, N.Y., and Richard Hopson Greenwood, a son of El Carol V. Greenwood of Houston and the late Ernestine Hopson Greenwood, were married yesterday. The Rev. Harry Baker Adams, chaplain of Yale University, performed the Protestant ceremony at the Battell Chapel at Yale, assisted by the Rev. James Curtis Gertmenian, pastor of the Valley Presbyterian Church in Brookfield, Conn., where the bride is a seminary intern.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
WHEN MURDER WAS A SCANDAL
description: LEAD: In 1823 the feckless son of a provincial merchant lured a cheating London gambler into a dark country lane and killed him, achieving a peculiar sort of immortality for himself. The trial and execution of the murderer, John Thurtell, dominated the newspapers, was taken up by the stage (one production featured the actual horse that had carried the victim to his fate) and was treated by a remarkable array of writers: Thomas De Quincey, Thackeray, Dickens and Bulwer Lytton all made use of it.

title: 5TH GRADERS BECOME STAGE TROUPE
description: LEAD: ON the day before the start of a recent three-day weekend, Roy Musgnug's fifth-grade class at the Denton Avenue Elementary School in New Hyde Park was transformed into the Poverty-Stricken Theatrical Company Deluxe.

title: 2 SCHOOLS JOIN FIGHT ON AIDS
description: LEAD: AIDS patients, who have had to go to New York or Philadelphia for experimental drug treatments, soon will have access to such therapies closer to home.

title: Dancers Have a Dream Of an Invitation to China
description: AS the Dance Theater in Westchester tries to bring to life the fantasy ''Sleeping Beauty'' at the Tarrytown Music Hall on Saturday, the ballet company may also be giving life to another fantasy: performing in China.

title: In the Middle Is the Only Place to Be
description: I WOULD like to give a cheer, a resounding huzza for that generally considered dubious position of ''being in the middle.'' By that I refer to the very comfortable circumstances of being neither at the top nor the bottom of whatever it is that you do or are.

title: PARK PLAN MOVES AHEAD DESPITE OPPOSITION
description: LEAD: DESPITE opposition, the National Park Service is going ahead with a plan to make changes at the 70,000-acre Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area.

title: Scaled-Down Equipment for A Home Office
description: If American homes undergo a radical change in the coming decades, it will almost certainly be the addition of a new room or area: an office. In fact, according to several government and industry estimates, some 10 to 20 million workers have already moved home. Although their offices' design may become of increasing concern, current considerations involve the selection of telephones, computers, copiers and other instruments of commerce.

title: T. O. Rokholt Wed To Miss Gallagher
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Denise Anne Gallagher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Gallagher of Green Village, N.J., and Trond Ole Rokholt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ole Rokholt of Strommen, Norway, were married yesterday by Msgr. John F. Corr.

title: A Tax Surcharge
description: To the Editor:

title: Plane Hits Building Near Los Angeles; Pilot Killed
description: A single-engine plane crashed into an apartment building today, killing the pilot and setting several buildings in the apartment complex afire, the authorities said.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: When Barbara Tuchman writes that ''In the Iran-contra affair, the most egregious case of incompetence . . . is the sale and delivery of arms to Iran without obtaining fulfillment of their side of the bargain,'' she misses the forest for the trees. The most egregious case of incompetence was to bargain at all. Before agreeing to send a single piece of military hardware, future lives had already been given away. ROBERT B. WILSON Philadelphia

title: STREETSCAPES: The Speyer School; 'Essentials of Wholesome Living' In a 'Settlement House' Setting
description: THE Speyer School, at 514 West 126th Street, is an empty derelict, its windows broken or blocked up, its elaborate ornament gradually decaying.

title: POSTINGS: SoHo Shopping; Moving South
description: In the assessment of Benjamin B. Braunstein, the special kinds of shops, galleries and eateries that have come to define SoHo are missing on West Broadway below Broome Street. And for no good reason.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
RESORT AIRPORT CONTROL
description: LEAD: CONTROL of Atlantic City International Airport in Pomona has erupted into a bitter confrontation between Atlantic City and Atlantic County.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN SNOW FALLS BEFORE THE LEAVES DO
description: LEAD: HAVING witnessed a preview of winter, it is apparent that some guidelines for preparing vulnerable plants for winter's onslaught and repairing such damage are appropriate now.

title: Forged In War, Etched In Memory
description: LEAD: THERE is a certain spot, high on the grounds of the county's newly acquired Lasdon Park in Somers, where the view extends for more than 30 miles, sweeping across the dense woods and clear lakes of upper Westchester, then tapering off into the gracefully sloping hills of neighboring Connecticut.

title: NOTRE DAME WINS; BROWN RETURNS A PUNT 74 YARDS
description: Tony Rice, a sophomore option quarterback who started his first collegiate game today, ran for two first-quarter touchdowns, and Tim Brown provided an insurance score with a 74-yard punt return in the final period as Notre Dame routed the Air Force Academy, 35-14.

title: What Insiders Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Faculty Faults Plan to Link 4 Schools
description: A Columbia University panel has proposed that the graduate schools of architecture, the arts, journalism and library service pool some staff and resources.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS;
VISITORS TO A SMALL PLANET: EARTH, MEET BIOSPHERE II
description: LEAD: IN the cactus-studded hills south of Tucson, scientists are building a miniature glass-and-metal world that they hope will one day serve as a Noah's Ark, allowing life to leave Earth and take root in distant soil.

title: Farrell Cruises
description: Gary Wilkos set a Monsignor Farrell school record yesterday when he passed for 378 yards in Farrell's 35-7 victory over St. John the Baptist. He completed 27 of 36 attempts in the Catholic High School Football League game as Farrell improved to 4-0. Four of Wilkos's passes were for touchdowns, and Farrell's other touchdown came when Wilkos ran the ball in.

title: Defectors Deserve Better Treatment
description: A vital but largely ignored component of our national security policy - the treatment and resettlement of Soviet and Soviet bloc defectors - is receiving some long-overdue attention this month by Congress.

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Moscow
description: The scaffolding has been rising and falling around the facade of the Bolshoi Theater this year but, as of sometime next spring, it will be up for the long haul as the home of the world-renowned opera and ballet companies undergoes a major reconstruction.

title: PLANTING CONTINUES
description: Last call to finish lawn work; seed planted this late may not germinate, but since the seed is hardy, it will remain until early spring when it should sprout, if the birds don't get it first; place conifer branches over seeded bare patches to protect them. Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing and set mower to cut low, one to two inches. Rake leaves to keep them off the grass. Jonquils

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FAMILY MUSICALE The yearly chamber music concert scheduled at 4 P.M. today in the Union Church of Pocantico Hills will be a family affair. Dr. Norman Smith, chemistry and physics teacher at Fordham University and church organist for more than 20 years; his son Stephen, a cellist; and Stephen's wife, Susan, who plays the violin, will perform string duets with and without organ, and there will be organ solos.

title: Columbia Fails To Stop Streak
description: Columbia scored two touchdowns yesterday, one on a faked punt early in the game and the other with eight seconds left, and blocked a couple of kicks. But the team's overall picture continued to be a nightmare.

title: Tsvetayeva and the G.P.U.
description: To the Editor:

title: Flag Flies in Detroit
description: IT has been 32 years since the Stanley Cup resided in Detroit. It has been 22 years since the Red Wings captured a regular-season title. There are banners marking the cups and the first-place victories in every National Hockey League city. The Red Wings posted a 34-36-10 record last season, but they have unfurled a banner from the rafters at Joe Louis Arena honoring the season anyway.

title: AH, YOUTH: WHEN ANYTHING GOES
description: SO what's the matter with youngsters today? When it comes to clothes, they seem to have this idea that it's O.K. to be a free spirit, to show some imagination, to break the rules. Or worse, to make up their own rules. Some of them look as if they reached into a dark closet and put on whatever they grabbed first. Some of them probably did.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Brookfield, Conn. $176,000 11 Hillside Circle 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; sun porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,059. Clinton, Conn. $169,500 7 Birchwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old raised ranch; overlooks marina, fenced yard; taxes $1,052. Hartford, Conn. $186,000 17 Columbia Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 87-year-old renovated rowhouse; tile kitchen floor, brick patio; taxes $1,208. Bedford, N.Y. $300,000 39 Jefferson Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old frame split level; eat-in kitchen, basement workshop, half acre; taxes $3,556. Peekskill, N.Y. $163,000 5 Dimond Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; new eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,462. Tarrytown, N.Y. $254,000 44 Le Grande Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 81-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, back porch, family room, brook; taxes $1,817. OTHER AREAS Aberdeen, N.J. $197,000 64 Forham Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced yard, patio, family room; taxes $2,990. East Hanover, N.J. $231,000 40 Surrey Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; C/A, fenced yard, hardwood floors; taxes $1,858. Medford, L.I. $106,000 315 Acorn Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800.

title: BROWN UPSETS CORNELL
description: An unexpected 66-yard touchdown run by the Bruin quarterback, Mark Donovan, and a blocked punt leading to another touchdown were the big plays as Brown upset Cornell today, 23-15.

title: INTIMATIONS OF DISASTER, AND 30-SECOND SOUND BITES
description: THERE IS A SENSE THAT SOME-thing is out of hand. Is the system working or not? Presidential candidates seem to drop like flies, while a nomination to the Supreme Court is debated in 30-second sound bites. We watch; we wait. Television keeps giving us intimations of disaster. ''That could hurt, if not destroy, his campaign,'' Ted Koppel said after revelations about Pat Roberston. Mike Wallace, interviewing Bob Woodward on ''60 Minutes,'' began by declaring that William J. Casey had died ''conveniently,'' even, ''some say, mysteriously.'' Mr. Wallace never alluded again to what seemed to be a suggestion that the former Director of Central Intelligence had been murdered, but it hung there like a cloud of swamp gas. Perhaps this didn't matter. After all, what's television all about? Increasingly, it seems to be a place to confirm our dark forebodings, even when it invites us to giggle while we brood.

title: Beguiling Nuisance Raids Northern Maine Towns
description: When Lindley Godson saw the door to his lakefront cabin ripped from its hinges and the new gas refrigerator broken apart, he knew there was only one explanation: a bear.

title: Taiwan Bridge Team Nears a Semifinal Berth
description: Taiwan was virtually assured of a semifinal place in the world contract bridge team championship open series, and the United States was equally well placed in the women's series as qualifying play resumed today.

title: Hats Big and Small
description: ''When he was 7, he would design coordinated accessories in his school notebooks,'' Philippe Model's sister, Laurence, recalled.

title: Miss Barnett Plans to Wed J. D. Schmidt
description: Mrs. Benjamin Hoffman Barnett Jr. of Haverford, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Anne Barnett to Jeffrey Dean Schmidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schmidt of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry in November.

title: NEWARK ARK FACES NEED TO MOVE AGAIN
description: KEA'S ARK, an 80-ton wooden vessel built from the Central Ward's urban debris, will have to make another voyage if it is to remain intact.

title: Israeli Censors Scored a Hit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Score On Chamber Music
description: I HAVE WONDERED ABOUT STATISTICS EVER since I took a course from a professor who spent much of the semester explaining that the poll takers who predicted Dewey's defeat of Truman were right. They had simply misinterpreted their own valid data. So, my instinct when any statistical analysis comes to hand is to hold it at arm's length. Figures may not lie, but sometimes they do not stand up very well, either.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article about bottle laws in The Week in Review Oct. 4 misstated the status of legislation in California. A recent California law, designed to encourage recycling, involves no deposit but gives consumers a penny per container turned in. It represents a compromise between the beverage industry and environmentalists.

title: MISS PFITZENMAYER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Pfitzenmayer Sr. of Chatham, N.J., have an-nouncedthe engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ane Pfitzenmayer to Gregory John Robitaille, the son of Mrs. Richard Burt of Gansevoort, N.Y., and Edwin J. Robitaille of Glen Falls, N.Y. The future bride graduated from Hamilton College, as did her fiance. She is an advertising sales representative for Corporate Finance magazine in New York. The future bridegroom is a commercial banking representative at the Bank of New York in Manhattan.

title: Cultural Highlights
description: The cultural highlights in Europe this fall and winter range from the opening of a new Chinese Export gallery in London to a dance festival in Paris and carnival in Venice. The listing is based on information from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Rome, Bonn and Madrid. Dollar figures are approximate. Telephone numbers are local unless otherwise indicated. ENGLAND A new Chinese Export Gallery opens at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London on Wednesday. The collection consists of luxury goods made by the Chinese for the Western market between about 1550 and 1900. More than 100 items will be on permanent display, including a nine-foot porcelain pagoda and other porcelain objects, carved fans, ceramics, lacquer, silk and carvings. Victoria and Albert Museum, Cromwell Road; 589 6371. Admission by donation. Open 10 A.M. to 5:50 P.M., Monday to Thursday and Saturday, 2:30 P.M. to 5:50 P.M. Sunday. Closed Dec. 24 to Dec. 28 and on Jan. 1. Starting Nov. 6, the museum will also be open on Fridays from 10 A.M. to 5:50 P.M. ''The Age of Chivalry,'' a show of English Gothic art, will be on display at the Royal Academy of Arts Nov. 6 through March 6, 1988. The exhibit traces the reigns of five Plantagenet kings, from Henry III through Richard II. Pieces have been borrowed from cathedrals and churches in England and other countries and include the 20-foot-high window from Canterbury Cathedral commemorating the pilgrimage to Sir Thomas a Becket's shrine; silver spoons belonging to Dick Whittington, who was Lord Mayor of London for three separate terms, beginning in 1397; a crown made for Henry IV's daughter, Blanche, and other objects made for kings and nobles of the period. Royal Academy of Arts, Burlington House, Piccadilly, 734 9052. Tickets are $6.50, $4.90 for students. Open daily 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Closed Dec. 24 and 25. A major show of William Hogarth's work is on view at the Tate Gallery until Jan. 3. ''Pomp, Virtue and Decorum: Hogarth and British Painting 1700-1760'' includes such Hogarth works as ''The Rake's Progress'' and ''The Election'' as well as work of his contemporaries, including Reynolds and the early Gainsborough. Tate Gallery, Millbank; 821 1313, recorded information 821 7128. Open 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday, 2 to 5:50 P.M. Sunday. Closed Dec. 24 to 26 and Jan. 1. Tickets are $4.90, $1.65 for children 8 through 18 and students. ''The Edwardian Era'' opens at the Barbican Gallery Nov. 12 and runs through Feb. 7. The exhibit will include painting, sculpture, photographs and other artifacts that contrast the life of Britain's pre-World War I aristocracy with the industrialized nation. Barbican Gallery, Barbican Center, Silk Street; 638 4141. Open 10 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday; noon to 5:45 P.M. Sunday and public holidays. Closed Mondays and Dec. 24 and 25. Tickets are $3.25. An exhibit on Sir John Gielgud will be held at London's newest museum, the Theater Museum in Covent Garden, through Aug. 28, 1988. The exhibit celebrates the 84-year-old actor and his career and includes photographs, designs, models, painting, letters and documents. The Theater Museum, Covent Garden WC2E 9DD; 836 7891, recorded information 836 7624. Open Tuesday through Sunday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Closed Monday. Admission is $3.65. A new production of Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro'' by Johannes Schaaf, with Claudio Desderi and Marie McLaughlin, highlights the season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Also this season, a new production by Elijah Moshinsky of Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail'' will be conducted by Sir Georg Solti, with Magdar Nadar and Lars Magnussen on Nov. 9 (for six performances); ''Tosca,'' with Eva Marton and Peter Dvorsky, opens Nov. 26 for six performances; Margaret Price and Giacomo Aragall will appear in ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' on Feb. 26. Performances of ''Parsifal,'' with the West German tenor Peter Seiffert, conducted by Bernard Haitink, are also on the program. The season runs through July. Royal Opera House, Covent Garden WC2E 9DD. Tickets, $48.85 to $114, depending on the production. Box office, 240 1066. ''The Barber of Seville,'' will be performed in a new production at the English National Opera, which performs solely in English. ''The Pearl Fishers,'' Jonathan Miller's staging of ''Rigoletto'' and ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' play in repertory. New productions include Stephen Sondheim's ''Pacific Overtures'' Nov. 21, 23 and 26 and ''Hansel and Gretel,'' which opens Dec. 16. English National Opera, London Coliseum, St. Martin's Lane. Tickets are $7.33 to $35.01; 90 seats with limited view are available the day of performance. Box office, open 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; 836 3161. Frederick Ashton's ballet, ''Cinderella,'' opens in a new production by the Royal Ballet on Dec. 16 at Covent Garden. Revivals of Balanchine's ''Serenade'' and Kenneth MacMillan's ''Rite of Spring'' can both be seen during their repertory season, which runs until summer. Royal Ballet, Covent Garden WC2E 9DD. Tickets are $13 to $114; Box office, 240 1066. Three new one-act ballets, ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' ''Paramour'' and ''The Private City'' will be given their premieres during the first of two Sadlers Wells Royal Ballet seasons in London, from Oct. 27 through 31. Michael Corer's ''Gloriana,'' will have its premiere during the second, from Jan. 5 through 15. The company also tours the country in a variety of classics after the October and January performances in London. Stops include: Birmingham Hippodrome, Nov. 9 through 14; Grand Theater, Leeds, Nov. 17 through 24; Apollo Theater, Oxford, Dec. 1 through 5; Empire Theater, Liverpool, Feb. 16 through 20 and the Theater Royal, Plymouth, Feb. 23 through 27. Performances in London, Sadlers Wells Theater, Rosebery Avenue; box office, 278 8916. Tickets are from $4.90 to $26. The Royal Shakespeare Theater repertory season in Stratford includes ''Measure for Measure,'' ''The Merchant of Venice,'' ''Twelfth Night,'' ''The Taming of the Shrew'' and ''Julius Caesar.'' At the neighboring theater, The Swan, one can see a rare production of James Shirley's ''Hyde Park,'' a drama written in the days of Charles I. Also at The Swan are ''Titus Andronicus,'' ''The Jew of Malta'' and Ben Jonson's ''New Inn.'' The Other Place, the third of the Stratford theaters, will stage ''Fashion,'' by Doug Lucie and a new production of ''Cymbeline,'' which opens on Nov. 4. The plays appear in repertory. The Royal Shakespeare Theater, Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire CV37 6BB at Stratford handles bookings for the three theaters; box office, 295623. Tickets for the Royal Shakespeare Theater are from $4.89 to $40.70, prices at The Swan from $4.90 to $21.15 and prices at the Other Place are $9.75 and $11.40. A Genet season is planned for the Royal Shakespeare Company performances in London. ''The Maids'' and ''Deathwatch,'' separate plays on the same program, and ''The Balcony'' will play in repertory through Dec. 5. Royal Shakespeare Company, the Barbican. Box office, 628 3351. Tickets are $12.20. ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' in the production by Peter Hall, with Judi Dench and Anthony Hopkins, appears in repertory at the National Theater during November and December. ''Entertaining Strangers,'' a new play by David Edgar, opens Nov. 16 at the Cottlesloe with Tim Piggott-Smith and Judi Dench. The play looks at the effects of the 1854 cholera epidemic on two people's lives. January brings the company's first production of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and, yet unscheduled, Peter Hall's final productions as artistic director of the theater. National Theatre, South Bank, London SE1 9PX. Box office, 928 2252, 24-hour recorded information 928 8126. Tickets are $8.96 to $21.17 at the Olivier and Lyttleton Theaters at the National and are $12.21 at the Cottlesloe. Any unsold seats are available at reduced prices two hours prior to performance. Other highlights of the London theater scene include Dorothy Tutin, Sian Phillips and Eileen Atkins in ''Thursday's Ladies'' by Lola Bellon at the Apollo, 437 2663. Tickets are $8.14 to $22; Tom Courtenay in Moliere's ''Hypochondriac'' at the Lyric, Hammersmith, until Nov. 21, 741 2311. Tickets are $8.15 to $16.30. A new play by Peter Schaffer, ''Lettice and Lovage'' with Maggie Smith and Margaret Tyzack opening at the Globe on Oct. 27, 437 3667. Tickets are $12.21 to $23.61. On Nov. 17, ''J. J. Farr,'' a new play by Ronald Harwood, with Albert Finney, opens at the Phoenix Theater, 836 8611. Tickets are $8.15 to $22. FRANCE ''Le Dernier Picasso,'' an exhibit focusing on the last 20 years of Picasso's life, will open at the George Pompidou Center in February and run until mid-May. Works on exhibit will be from the years 1953 through 1973 and will be grouped both thematically and chronologically. The show is scheduled to open Feb. 11. In celebration of the centenary of Le Corbusier's birth, the Pompidou Center has organized a show that runs through Jan. 3. The exhibit, ''The Useful Is Not the Beautiful,'' includes 60 models of his work. Among them are some of his paintings and drawings, architectural drawings, writings and urban plans are on display. The Pompidou Center, also known as Beaubourg, is open noon to 10 P.M. Monday and Wednesday through Friday and Saturday and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., closed Tuesday. Tickets are $4.10, $3.30 for students under 25. 42.77.12.33. An exhibit of the work of Fragonard is on display at the Grand Palais until Jan. 4. Paintings, drawings, watercolors and etchings are on view, over 300 in all. The centerpiece of the show is the display of all the known ''fantasy figures.'' All 15 of the known series portray richly dressed men and women. The show moves to the Metropolitan Museum of Art from February until early May of next year. The Grand Palais, Avenue du President Eisenhower, 75008 Paris; 42.89.54.10. Open Thursday through Monday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Wednesday 10 A.M. 10 p.m. Closed Tuesday. Admission is $4.60 ($3.30 on Saturday), $3.30 for students and people under 18. The reopening of the Theatre des Champs-Elysees comes after more than a year of renovation and restoration. This year, the theater plays host to various performances of the 25th International Dance Festival (see below); performances of opera and various recitals, including Teresa Berganza on Nov. 26 and Jessye Norman on Dec. 1. For tickets, write the theater at 15 Avenue Montaigne, 75008 Paris at least 21 days before the performance and include an international money order;or telephone 47.20.36.37 between 20 and 3 days before the event. Tickets are also available at the box office two weeks prior to performance. Tickets for the Berganza evening range from $6.50 to $62; for Norman, $6.50 to $53.90. A month of performances by Marcel Marceau begins Dec. 10 at the Theatre Champs-Elysees. Information about dates and times can be obtained by writing the theater. For address tickets information, see procedure listed above. Prices from $5.70 to $34.30. Bellini's ''Norma'' and Verdi's ''Macbeth'' will highlight the season at the Paris Opera. ''Norma'' will be performed Nov. 13, 16, 19, 25 and 30 and Dec. 3, 5, 8 and 11. It is a Geneva Opera production by Maximiano Valdes and Pier Luigi Pizzi. ''Macbeth,'' directed by Michael Schoenwandt and Antoine Vitez, will be performed Nov. 26, 28 and Dec. 1, 2, 4, 9, 10, 12 and 13. To reserve by mail, write at least two months in advance, giving various dates and seat choices, enclose an international money order or a check. Tickets will be held for pickup at the Opera until the day before the performance; 8, rue Scribe, 75009 Paris. Tickets are $13.90 to $89.80. The 25th Paris International Dance Festival runs through the fall at various theaters in Paris. Highlights include performances at the Theatre Champs-Elysees by the London Festival Ballet, Nov. 3 through 9; the Royal Danish Ballet, Nov. 16, 17 and 18 and the Ballet-Theatre Francais de Nancy, in a tribute to Serge Lifar, Oct. 28 to Nov. 1. The Kirov Theater Ballet (of Leningrad) will appear at the Palais des Congres from Nov. 17 to Jan. 10. For tickets to the Kirov, write: Spectacles Alat, Ballet Kirov, 23 Rue Royale, 75008 Paris. Telephone 42.66.20.75. Call to reserve seats and find out the price; once you know the amount, send an international money order; tickets can be picked up until 30 minutes prior to the show. Box office tickets go on sale two weeks before the performance. For tickets to events at the Theatre Champs-Elysees, write to the address in the item above. Tickets for the Theatre Champs-Elysees are $5.70 to $44.10; prices for the Kirov are $16.30 to $49. For further information, write: Festival International de la Danse de Paris, 28-30 Rue Edouard Vaillant, 92300 Levallois-Perret; 47.39.28.26. The Bejart Ballet Lausanne, recently renamed after a move from Brussels, will have two new productions at the Palais des Congres from Jan. 22 through Feb. 21. They are scheduled to perform two new productions, ''Souvenirs de Leningrad,'' and an as yet unnamed ballet. For tickets, write Spectacles Alat (address above), Ballet Bejart; follow the same procedures. Ticket prices have not been announced. ''Le Fantome de l'Opera'' will be performed by the Ballet National de Roland Petit in Marseille Nov. 20 through 29. At the Marseille Opera, 1 Rue Moliere, Marseille 13001; 91.55.14.99. Written requests for tickets should be received at least 10 days prior to performance. Tickets are $13.10 to $18. IRELAND The Wexford Opera Festival runs from Oct. 21 through Nov. 1 this year. Among the operas to be performed are Bellini's ''Straniera,'' Massenet's ''Cendrillon'' and Giordano's ''Cena delle Beffe.'' The festival program includes recitals, operatic scenes and a choral concert on Nov. 1 in the Church of the Immaculate Conception (known locally as Rowe Street Church). Most performances are in the Theater Royal. For further information write, Theater Royal, High Street, Wexford. Tickets can be ordered with a credit card by telephone, 22240. Tickets are $12 for a program of operatic scenes to $40 for full operas. The winter season of the International Grand Opera takes place in Dublin from Dec. 1 through 12. Three operas are to be performed, ''Rigoletto,'' Bizet's ''Pearl Fishers'' and Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale.'' All at the Gaiety Theater, South King Street, Dublin 2; telephone 771717. For more information write to Dublin Grand Opera Society, Thomas Prior House, Merrion Road, Dublin 4; telephone 608-100. Tickets are $10 to $35. Dublin's millenium celebration begins Dec. 31 with a gala concert at the National Concert Hall during which the Millenium Suite, composed by Raymond Deane, will have its premiere. Later that evening, bell-ringing ceremonies will occur throughout the city. February brings Italian Opera Night to the city. A weeklong series of events, from Feb 15 to 22, is planned. The highlight is a performance on Feb. 19 at the National Concert Hall with the Rondon Veneziano as guest performers. For a list of events for the Dublin Millenium, write the Irish Tourist Board, 757 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. BELGIUM Belgium's biennial Europalia festival focuses on Austria this year. Highlights of the festival follow. A program of events is available from the Belgian Tourist Office, 745 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10151. An exhibit on the Golden Fleece is at the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels until Dec. 16. On display are jewels and other items of the Order of the Golden Fleece, including the Potence and the Cross of Oath. Palais des Beaux-Arts, Rue Ravinstein, 23; telephone 512-5045. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., Wednesday 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission is $6.50. A Klimt exhibit at the Musee Royaux des Beaux-Arts runs through Dec. 16. The retrospective features paintings and drawings of the renowned painter of the Vienna secession, some on display for the first time. Musee Royaux des Beaux-Arts, Rue de la Regence 3, telephone, 513-9630. Open Tuesday through Sunday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission is $5.20. Masterpieces from the Albertina will be on view at the Museum voor Schone Kunsten in Antwerp through Nov. 29. Works on display include drawings by Bruegel, Durer, Fragonard, Holbein, Poussin, Raphael, Tiepolo and Watteau. Museum voor Schone Kunsten, Leopold de Waelplaats, Antwerp. Open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday; closed Monday. Admission is $3.92. Telephone, 238-5875. Music includes performances by the Vienna Philharmonic under the direction of Claudio Abbado. In Brussels, they appear in the Salle Henry le Boeus at the Palais des Beaux-Arts on Oct. 30 at 8 P.M. and in Antwerp. on Nov. 2 at de Singl, with music by Berg, Beethoven and Mozart. For further information write: in Brussels, Palais des Beaux-Arts, Rue Ravinstein 23, Brussels; in Antwerp, de Singl, Desguinlei, 25. Tickets are $4.70 to $10.40 in Brussels; $6.50 to $7.80 in Antwerp. The Mozarteum Orchestra of Salzburg, under the direction of Hans Graf, will perform works of Mozart in the Royal Conservatory of Liege on Nov. 18 at 8:30 P.M. The Royal Conservatory, Boulevard Piercot, Liege; telephone 513-7713. NETHERLANDS Amsterdam 1987 events continue, marking the city's designation as cultural capital of Europe for the year by the European Community. Among the many events affiliated with the project are these: ''Dutch Masters of Landscape'' is on view at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam until Jan. 3. The show is made up of over 80 paintings, and includes works by Albert Cuyp, Jan van Goyen, Jacob van Ruysdael, Jan Both and Rembrandt. Also on view, in the print room, are landscape drawings and etchings by Dutch artists of the same period. Rijksmuseum, Stadhouderskade, 42; telephone 568-8711. Open Tuesday to Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday and holidays 1 to 5 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission $3.10. The Stagedoor Festival runs from about Nov. 2 through 15 and will feature a variety of theater, dance and music programs. The festival events will be held at various venues, including de Balie, the Center for Politics and Culture, Kleine Komedie and the Soeterijn theater, among others. Tickets cost $3.60, $4.80 and $6. For further information about the Amsterdam 1987 events, write, Holland Festival, Kleine-Gartmanplantsoen 21, 1017 RP Amsterdam; telephone (020)-276566. A show of Vincent Van Gogh's art opens a new museum in Hertogenbosch. The Noordbrabants museum opens Nov. 3 with a show of paintings and drawings entitled ''Van Gogh in Brabant.'' Over 100 works will be on display. Noordbrabants Museum, Verwersstraat, 41; telephone 133834. Open Tuesday through Friday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday and holidays 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. Closed Monday and from Dec. 25 through Jan. 1. Admission is $4.80 and $2.40 for children under 12. SWITZERLAND ''Impressionists and Post-Impressionists From Soviet Museums II'' is on view at the Villa Favorita in Lugano until Nov. 15. This show is part of an exchange with the Soviet Union; some 40 works of the Old Masters from the Thyssen-Bornemezza collection are on view in the Soviet Union at the same time. The show in Lugano includes works from the Hermitage in Leningrad and the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow. On display are paintings by Cezanne, Gauguin, Matisse, Monet, Picasso and Renoir. This is the first time these paintings have been on public display in the West. Villa Favorita, Lugano. Open Tuesday through Sunday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission is $7.80, $5.20 for students, groups and children. Telephone, 521-741. The orchestra of the Suisse Romande offers various special concerts this season at Victoria Hall in Geneva. Programs include an evening of Beethoven and Brahms with Vaclav Neumann directing and Radu Lupu on piano, on Nov. 25; the violinist Itzhak Perlman and the pianist Bruno Canino will perform on Nov. 16; the soprano Margaret Price and the pianist Graham Johnson on Nov. 18; Armin Jordan will direct a program of Bartok, Honegger and Beethoven on Jan. 29 with Krystian Zimerman on piano, and Kurt Masur will conduct an evening of Dvorak and Brahms with the violinist Uto Ughi on March 4. For further information and tickets, write Victoria Hall, Rue Joseph-Hornung, Geneva; telephone 20-11-31. Tickets are $4.57 to $30.70. The Bern Symphonic Orchestra concert season is under way at the Casino in Bern. On Nov. 5 and 6, Yuri Ahronovitch will conduct an evening of Stravinsky, Mozart and Shostakovich, with Peter Serkin as piano soloist. On Dec. 10 and 11, Peter Maag will direct a program of C. P. E. Bach, Walton and Strauss, with Bruno Giuranna as viola soloist. On Jan. 7 and 8, Mr. Maag will conduct an evening of Elgar and Franck, with Thomas Furi as violin soloist. The Heidelberg Chamber Orchestra will perform on Jan 29. Telephone, 224242. Munzgraben 2, 3000 Bern. Tickets are $6.50 to $27.40. Performances at the Tonhalle in Zurich include an evening with the Schubert Quartet of Vienna on Nov. 29 with a program of Beethoven, Webern and Verdi; the Tonhalle orchestra performing works of Schumann with Hiroshi Wakasugi directing and Bruno Leonardo Gelber as pianist from Nov. 10 through 13; the orchestra directed by Muhai Tang, with Piotr Paleczny as piano soloist, performing works of Paderewski and Tchaikovsky from Dec. 15 through 18. Michel Plasson will direct a program of Beethoven and Saint-Saens with the pianist Martha Argerich Dec. 23, and soloists from the Berlin Philharmonic will perform Bach, Hindemith, Mozart and Rossini on Feb. 4. Tickets are $9.80 to 58.70. For information and tickets, write the Tonhalle, Claridenstrasse, 7, Zurich; telephone, 221-22-83. GERMANY The season at the Deutsche Oper in Berlin includes performances by the Royal Ballet of London on Nov. 1 and 2. ''Lichtknall,' a ballet choreographed by Lucinda Childs, to music of Erhard Grosskopf, has its world premiere at 8 P.M. Nov. 15. The ballet corps of the Deutsche Oper will perform then and on Nov. 16, 17 and 18. The house offers premieres of ''Der Freischutz'' by Weber on Dec. 19 and ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' by Donizetti on Feb. 24. Deutsche Oper Berlin. Kartenburo, Richard-Wagner-Strasse 10, 1000 Berlin; telephone, 341-4449. Tickets $10 to $55. A retrospective of Paul Klee's works are on view at the Kunsthalle in Nurnberg through Nov. 15. Works have been gathered from the Sprengel collection in Hanover and various private collections. The show, opened by Klee's son, Felix, shows various important stages in the painter's development. Nurnberg Kunsthalle, Lorenzerstrasse. 32. Open Tuesday, and Thursday to Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Wednesday 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Telephone, 162403. Admission is $1.60. The Berlin Philharmonic performs its traditional New Year's Eve Concert with Herbert von Karajan conducting, on Dec. 31 at 6 o'clock. Mr. von Karajan also conducts a program on Dec. 30. The program has not been announced. On Nov. 1, at 11 A.M., Mr. von Karajan conducts a program with works by Mozart and Richard Strauss. Daniel Barenboim will direct works of Mozart and Bruckner with Peter Timmermann as the violin soloist, at the Berlin Philharmonic on Feb. 2 and 3 at 8 P.M. Mr. Barenboim will also direct two evenings of Mozart on Feb. 9 and 10. Tickets are $15 to $50 for most events, $25 for the Barenboim concerts. Tickets for New Year's Eve are hard to get; write early or ask your hotel for tickets when making a reservation (but expect to pay a service fee). A program of Vivaldi, Mozart and Haydn conducted by Yehudi Menuhin, with the violin soloist Elisabeth Glass, will be presented by the Berlin Philharmonic on Dec. 22 and 23 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $15. Write: Berlin Philharmonisches Orchester, Matthaikirchstrasse, 1 1000 Berlin 30; telephone, 254880. A retrospective of Alberto Giacometti's work can be seen until Jan. 3 at the Berlin National Gallery. Over 110 sculptures, 40 paintings and 200 drawings will be on display. Berlin National Gallery, Potsdamerstrasse 50; telephone, 26660. Open Tuesday through Sunday 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission is $3.50. The Frankfurt Opera season opens on Oct. 30 with ''Iphigenia in Aulis'' and ''Iphigenia auf Tauris'' by Christoph Willibald Gluck, under the new music director Gary Bertini. On Nov. 15 the company presents the world premiere of John Cage's ''Europera 1 and 2.'' Other performances of the work are scheduled for Nov. 20, 23, 30, Dec. 12, Jan. 4 and Feb. 12. Write Stadtischen Buhnen Frankfurt, Untermainanlage 11, 6000 Frankfurt, attention Theaterkasse. Telephone, 236061; Tickets are $11 to $38. An exhibit of the complete works of Cy Twombly, the American artist, will be on view at the Kunsthalle in Dusseldorf from Dec. 12 through Jan. 31. Kunsthalle, Grabbeplatz 4; telephone, 131469. Admission is $1.60. Open Tuesday through Sunday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Art Cologne, an international art fair, runs from Nov. 12 to 18. Held at the Cologne fairgrounds, in the Rheinhalle, it is the most important fair for avant-garde art in Europe. Over 165 Galleries offer their selections. Admission is $6 for one day; $16 for the week. Telephone, 8211. A retrospective of the art of Joseph Beuys will be held Feb. 20 to May 1 in Berlin. Sculptures, drawings and ''environments,'' or room installations, will be included in the exhibit at the Martin-Gropius Building in Berlin, Stresemannstrasse 110; telephone, 8316001. Open 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.. Admission is $3.50. The World Cup in Rock n' Roll dancing holds finals Nov. 21 at Rudi-Sedelmayer-Halle, Am Grasweg 64, Munich 70. For tickets, write Tanzschule Steuer, Schutzenstrasse 8, 8000 Munich 2; telephone, 595142. Admission is $10 to $19. Preliminaries begin at 3 P.M.; finals at 7 P.M. AUSTRIA A new show at the Kunstlerhaus in Vienna, ''The Age of the Bourgeoisie and the Spirit of Conflict - Biedermeier and Pre-March in Vienna 1815-1848,'' opens on Dec. 17 and runs through June 12. The show looks at a period that brought both technological advancement and industrialization and social tensions to society. Items on display include fine furniture and glassware. Kunstlerhaus, Karlsplatz 5; telephone 587-96630. Open daily 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $3.90, $1.50 for students and free for children under 6. A Schubert Festival will take place in Vienna from Nov. 11 through 26. This year, performances are focused on works composed in the year 1817. The two outstanding events are a recital by Hermann Prey on Nov. 13 and evenings of piano with Alfred Brendel at the Musikverein on Nov. 11, 16, 24 and 26. The series also includes appearances by the Vienna Symphony Orchestra and chamber music at the Musikverein concert halls. Musikverein, Dumbastrasse 3; telephone 65-81-90. For tickets, write: Gesellschaft Der Musik Freunde in Wien, Bosendorferstrasse 12, 1010 Vienna; telephone (222) 65-86-81. Tickets in the Grosser Saal are $8.50 to $28.60; in the Brahms Sall prices are $9.30 to $21.60. A Mozart Festival takes place in Salzburg from Jan. 22 through 31, celebrating the composer's birthday, Jan. 27. Events include concerts, chamber music, opera, and solo presentations. Andras Schiff will perform piano works on Jan. 25 and 27 at 7:30 P.M. at the Mozarteum; the Vienna Philharmonic will perform under both Claudio Abbado and Sir Colin Davis in the course of the week at the Festspielhaus, and opera will be at the Landestheater with the Mozarteum orchestra. A mass is scheduled at the Cathedral on Jan. 31 at 10 A.M.; the mass is free. Tickets for other events are $7.70 to $108, depending on the event and seat location. Write Internationale Stiftung Mozarteum, A-5024 Salzburg, Schwarzstrasse 26, Postbox 24. Box office telephone 73154, open Monday through Friday 9 A.M. to noon and 2 P.M. to 5. The Vienna Staatsoper season includes premieres of ''Iphigenie in Aulis'' by Gluck on Nov. 15, Gluck's ballet of ''Don Juan'' and Stravinsky's ''The Rites of Spring'' on Dec. 16, Rossini's ''Il Viaggio a Reims,'' on Jan. 20 and Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin,'' on Feb. 7. Orchestra tickets are $50 to $120. To order, write, Bundestheaterverband, Goethegasse 1, A-1010 Vienna; telephone 514-440, ask for the Staatsoper; or, in the U.S.; Dial Austria, 342 Madison Avenue, Suite 948, New York, N.Y. 10173; telephone 212-661-4660 or 800-221-4980. ITALY ''The Age of Galileo: The Golden Age of Tuscan Science'' runs through Jan. 9 at the History of Science Museum in Florence. The show includes Galileo's manuscripts, which record his notes and sketches of his celestial observations, a recently discovered portrait of Galileo and other items. Open Monday through Saturday, 9:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. Open Monday, Wednesday and Friday afternoon from 2 to 5. Closed Sunday and holidays. Museo di Storia della Scienza, Piazza dei Giudici; telephone 283493. Admission is $4. A production of ''Don Giovanni,'' to celebrate the opera's 200th anniversary, opens the La Scala season on Dec. 7. Riccardo Muti is to conduct; Giorgio Strehler, the director of Milan's Piccolo Teatro, will direct, and singers include Thomas Allen and Edita Gruberova. Performances of ''Don Giovanni'' continue through Jan. 2. Other special programs include perfromances of ''Adriana le Couvreur,'' with Montserrat Caballe in March and ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' with Luciano Pavarotti in April and May. For tickets, write C.I.T. Travel Service, 666 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10103; telephone 212-397-2666 or at the La Scala box office in Milan, telephone 88791. Tickets range from $7.60 to $104. The box office is open 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 3:30 P.M. to 5:30 P.M., daily except Monday. The equestrian statue of the emperor Nerva has been restored and reassembled and is on display at the National Archeology Museum in Naples until Dec. 31. The bronze sculpture, the only known portrayal of an emperor on a galloping horse, was found some 15 years ago and has been in restoration since. The museum itself is also undergoing a facelift. National Archeology Museum, Piazza Museo, Naples; telephone, 440166. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; closed Monday. Admission is $1.60. The 250th anniversary of the San Carlo Theater in Naples will be celebrated with a gala festival on Nov. 4. Gustave Kuhn will conduct the cantata for the original opening of the San Carlo Theater in honor of King Charles Bourbon. Other performers expected to appear are Montserrat Caballe, Katia Ricciarelli, Lucia Valentini-Terrani, Lella Cuberli and Nicolai Gedda. The San Carlo Theater box officeis on Via Vittorio Emanuele III; telephone, 7972111. Teatro di San Carlo, 93 Via San Carlo, Naples 80132; telephone 418266. Open 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and 4:30 P.M. to 6:30 P.M. daily except Sunday. Open 6:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. on day of performance. Ticket prices have not yet been set. An exhibit of classical Greek and Roman statues, ''Sports in the Ancient World,'' is on view ot the Palazzo dei Conservatori in Rome through Nov. 15. The show includes ancient statues of athletes in both marble and bronze. The Palazzo Dei Conservatori, Capitoline Hill; telephone, 678-28662. Open Tuesday through Saturday 9 A.M. to 1:30 P.M.; on Tuesday and Thursday also from 5 P.M. to 8 P.M.; Saturday from 8 P.M. to 11 P.M.; Sunday from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. Closed Monday. Tickets are $3.25. ''Fortuny and Caramba: Fashion at the Theater,'' will run until Dec. 6 at the Palazzo Fortuny in Venice. The exhibit looks at the collaboration between the costume designer Mario Fortuny and an Italian theatrical concern at the turn of the century. Over 100 theatrical costumes, jewelry and other objects are on view. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 9 A.M. to 7 P.M.; closed Monday. Palazzo Fortuny, 3780 San Beneto; telephone, 5200995. Admission is $4. Carnival in Venice reaches its height on Feb. 16. Ten days of revelry, replete with costumes, precede that evening. Events include gondola races on the Grand Canal and a masked ball in Piazza San Marco. If you are planning to be in Venice at this time, reserve early, as the whole city, from hotels to restaurants and events, is booked for the entire period. For further information, call 5226356 or write: Ente Provinciale per il Turismo Venice, Palazzo Martinengo, Rialto 4089, Venice. NORWAY ''Art of Africa,'' opens Dec. 3 at the Sonja Henie-Niels Onstad Art Center in Oslo. This is the first European stop of a four-year tour in the United States and Europe. The show includes works by some 50 European and American painters. Through Jan. 17. Also on view are the 20th-century paintings donated by Sonja Henie and Neils Onstad. Henie-Onstad Art Center, 1311 Hovikodden; telephone, 54-30-50. Open 9 A.M. to 9:30 P.M., Monday through Friday, 11 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Admission $3, $1.50 for students, children and the elderly. SPAIN ''Leonardo da Vinci - Nature Studies'' will be on display at the Fundacio Caixa de Pensions in Barcelona through Nov. 8. The show includes some 50 drawings of the artist's visions of nature, plants, animals and rock formations, as well as some of his scientific drawings. Fundacio Caixa de Pensions, Paseo de Sant Joan 108; telephone, 258 8905. Open Monday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 4 P.M. to 9 P.M.; Sunday, 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Admission is $2, $1.25 for students. Boito's ''Mephistofele,'' conducted by Jose Collado, with Montserrat Caballe, will be performed at Barcelona's Gran Teatre del Liceu on Dec. 7, 10 and 13; in addition a gala performance is scheduled for Dec. 4. Write the theater at Carrer de Sant Pau, 1, Baixos 08001 Barcelona or call 318-9277 for reservations; you should go to Rambla dels Caputxins 65 to buy tickets the day of the performance. Monday through Saturday at 9 P.M; Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets are $3.30 to $250. Zarzuela performances in Madrid by the Coro del Teatro Lirico Nacional with the Orquesta Sinfonica del Madrid directed by Miguel Roa, run from Nov. 3 to 29. Productions include ''El Duo de la Africana,'' ''La Revoltosa,'' and El Ano Pasado por Agua.'' At 8 P.M. at the Teatro Lirico de la Zarzuela, Calle Jovellanos 4; telephone, 429-8225. Tickets are $2 to $12.50. The works of Mark Rothko will be on display until Jan. 3 at the Fundacion Juan March in Madrid. The show, which was on view at the Tate Gallery in London this summer, includes over 50 works. Fundacion Juan March, Calle Castello, 77; telephone, 435-4240. Open 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 9 P.M., Monday through Saturday; Sunday 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Admission is free. A concert by Montserrat Caballe will include works of Vivaldi. Rossini, Martinez-Palomo and Chapi at the Teatro Real in Madrid on Oct. 27. Plaza de Oriente 4; the telephone number is 248-1405. Tickets are $4 to $25. ARCO 88, the international contemporary art fair, will take place in Madrid from Feb. 11 through 16. The show consists of hundreds of gallery owners and artists throughout the world and displays paintings and sculpture. Pavilions 10 and 12 of IFEM A Avenida Portugal, 28011; telephones, 470-1014 and 479-5235. Open noon to 9 P.M. daily. Ticket prices have not yet been set; last year admission was $4.20. ''The Sublime Image,'' a video retrospective, runs through Nov. 2 at the Centro de Arte Reina Sofia in Madrid. The works of 39 video makers, from 1970 to the present, are shown. Works are shown in the Salon de Actos on the main floor of the center, beginning at 7 P.M. Also on display are photographs and posters. Round-table discussions will be held during the run of the show. Centro de Arte Reina Sofia, Calle Santa Isabel, 52; 28012 Madrid; telephone, 467-5062. Open 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Wednesday through Monday; closed Tuesday. The admission fee is $3.30. DENMARK The Royal Danish Ballet offers the premieres of three new ballets this season, ''Elvira Madigan,'' choreographed by Robert North to music by Sibelius and Carl Nielsen; a new ballet by Ib Andersen opens on the Old Stage on Nov. 11, and an as yet unnamed work by Constantin Patsala, to music by Mahler, will be presented later. Revivals include, Limon's ''The Moor Pavane,'' and Flindt's ''The Lesson.'' The repertory season also includes performances of six Bournonville ballets; Neumeier's ''Romeo and Juliet''; The Nutcracker,'' choreographed by Flemming Flindt; Christopher Bruce's ''Night With Waning Moon,'' and others. Performances are on both the old and new stages and share the season with the Royal Danish Opera. Operas this season include ''Don Pasquale,'' Per Norgard's ''Siddharta,'' ''La Traviata,'' and Carl Nielsen's ''Maskarade.'' Tickets for the old stage are $4.25 to $21.20; at the new stage, from $2.80 to $18.40. For tickets, write: The Royal Theater Box Office, Post Box 2185, DK-1017, Copenhagen K, Denmark. It is easiest to order with a credit card. Telephone for reservations, old stage: 01 14 17 65; new stage: 01-14-32-85. Tickets will be held until an hour prior to the performance. The 400th anniversary of Christian IV will be celebrated in Copenhagen throughout 1988. As King of Denmark from 1588 to 1648, Christian IV encouraged art and culture in northern Europe; he was interested in architecture and enjoys a reputation as the ''builder king.'' Exhibits planned include, at the Royal Arsenal Museum, a look at Christian's military accomplishments; at the National Museum, a look at navigation and trade, and at the Royal Museum, drawings by Rubens and others, as well as European art of the era, music and other events. For further information write the Danish Tourist Board, 655 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. SWEDEN The Stockholm Open tennis championships run from Nov. 2 through 8 at Kungliga Royal Tennis Court. The qualifying rounds of this event will be played on Oct. 31 and Nov. 1. For further information and tickets, telephone the Swedish Tennis Association in Stockholm, 67 97 70. Travelers flying on SAS to Stockholm can book tickets through the airline. The address for the Court is Tennishallen, Storangsvagen, Stockholm.

title: Power's Cost May Outweigh Its Benefits
description: POWER IS A TRICKY word. It hypnotizes people.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JACOB TWO-TWO AND THE DINOSAUR By Mordecai Richler. Illustrated by Norman Eyolfson. 85 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THE TAR PIT By Tor Seidler. 153 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Stylishly Forsaken
description: UNEXPLAINED LAUGHTER By Alice Thomas Ellis. 155 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95

title: PARTIES COME TO THE AID OF THEIR CANDIDATES
description: LEAD: IN years past, candidates for municipal office were pretty much on their own when it came to support from the state party organizations. The most they could expect was an appearance from the Governor at a local fund-raiser and a few tips from the old pros.

title: CONCERT: MIRIAM FRIED
description: THE first half of the New York Philharmonic's program Friday evening in Avery Fisher Hall did not bode well for what was to come after intermission - as it turned out, a really stirring version of the familiar Shostakovich Fifth Symphony.

title: YALE STUDENT GROUP SAYS THAT IN STRIKE, THEY'RE THE VICTIMS
description: LEAD: IN September 1984, three weeks after members of the class of 1988 arrived for their freshman year at Yale University, they watched as striking employees set up picket lines that would surround campus buildings for 10 weeks.

title:
MUSIC;
Ozawa Discerns a New Era
description: LEAD: AS SEIJI OZAWA BEGINS HIS 15th year with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, he finds himself in the position of a husband who has renewed his marriage vows after a period of household strife. The orchestra's music director, who turned 52 last month, says he's entering a ''new era'' with the orchestra - older, wiser and more comfortable with the players and a new management team.

title:
ABUT WESTCHESTER;
Treasures Hunt
description: LEAD: THE shoes in which Luta Hickman had paced through life were finally walking out of it. From the depths of the closet they came, to be sold in the name of charity. Mrs. Hickman sighed, smiled and shrugged: for the 30th rummage sale of St. Mark's Episcopal Church here, no contribution, however wrenching, was too great.

title: Jessica L. Stedman to Wed Andrew Guff Jr. in January
description: Gerda S. Stedman of Armonk, N.Y., and Torpola, the British Virgin Islands, has announced the engagement of her daughter Jessica Lee Stedman to Andrew Joseph Guff Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Guff of Bethlehem, Pa. The couple plan to marry in January.

title: Challenger To Martinelli Stresses 'New Leadership'
description: COUNCILMAN Nicholas C. Wasicsko sees himself as a ''David'' in this year's mayoralty race against the nine-term ''Goliath'' and incumbent Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli. But the 28-year-old challenger has won such a seemingly uneven battle before, in his only previous election effort.

title: A REVERSIBLE FAN FOR ALL SEASONS
description: A CEILING fan with a reversible motor makes as good an investment in the winter as it does in the summer.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: Barbara Tuchman cites examples of incompetence during the Reagan Administration to suggest that the United States is in decline. In fact, there have been many examples of incompetence throughout American history. The names Franklin Pierce, James Buchanan, George B. McClellan, Warren Harding, and (possibly) Jimmy Carter would easily bring this fact to mind. Yet, as a nation we have survived and prospered despite incompetence.

title:
FOOD;
STOCKING UP
description: LEAD: THERE ARE FAIR-WEATHER COOKS WHO FIND pleasure in the kitchen only when they have the time. Their creativity tends to be confined to the span from Friday dinner to Sunday lunch. During the rest of their lives, you see them lined up at gourmet take-out stores and in neighborhood restaurants.

title: ALABAMA TROUNCES TENNESSEE
description: Jeff Dunn, a freshman making his first start, threw for 229 yards, including a 90-yard touchdown, longest in the school's history, as Alabama stunned Tennessee, 41-22, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: Kidnapping Charge Is Dropped for Boston Mother
description: Prosecutors dismissed a kidnapping charge Wednesday against a mother who spent six months in prison for hiding an 8-year-old daughter she says was sexually abused by her former husband.

title: Headliners; Ingrate
description: When Stig Bergling, Sweden's best-known spy, broke out of prison recently, he did not have to carve a gun out of soap or tunnel under a wall. Mr. Bergling, a former intelligence officer who was sentenced to life in prison in 1979 for selling state secrets to the Soviet Union, simply walked out of his wife's apartment, where he had been left unguarded for an overnight visit. As Mr. Bergling remained at large last week, embarrassed officials contemplated changing Sweden's humanitarian system of incarceration, under which Mr. Bergling was granted conjugal visits and a $9,000-a-year medical pension for what were called the ''strains'' of prison life. Said the warden, Gunilla Arnerdal, ''After all we had done for him, he has made us very disappointed.''

title: At Solidarity, A Quiet Stand On Changes
description: The outlawed Solidarity trade union has given no discernible reaction to the Polish Government's proposed package of political and economic changes, announced last weekend, despite pressure on the union to respond formally.

title: Julie Robbins Is Wed to Joseph Pierson
description: Julia Severance Robbins, a daughter of Louise N. Robbins of Greenwich, Conn., and John C. Robbins of New York, was married yesterday in Greenwich to Joseph Anthony Pierson, the son of Ann Roberts Harris of New York and the Rev. Robert L. Pierson of Columbiaville, N.Y. The ceremony at the Chieftans estate was performed by the Rev. Daphne W. P. Hawkes, an Episcopal priest.

title: EMMA GOLDMAN INSPIRES A MUSICAL
description: LEAD: AT the age of 8, Leonard Lehrman decided to become a composer. Four years later, after starring as Henry Higgins in ''My Fair Lady'' in elementary school and after seeing his first work, a musical about atomic testing, produced at Roslyn Junior High School, he mapped out his career.

title: THE LEGACY: GOOD MOVE IS NOT GOOD ENOUGH
description: EMANUEL Lasker's favorite piece of advice was: When you see that you have a good move, look around before playing it; there may be an even better one.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON THEIR TOES Today, when the North Carolina Dance Theater makes its lone appearance in the New York area, Friends of the Arts really puts the acclaimed company to work. At 1:30 P.M. in a program suitable for schoolchildren, it opens the Children's Carousel series; then at 7:30 P.M., offering Balanchine's ''Valse Fantasie'' and ''Fiesta,'' a new work choreographed by the Argentine Mauricio Wainrot to Ravel's music, the theater gets the ''Dazzling Dance'' programing under way. Both performances are at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse on the Hempstead campus of Hofstra University. For ticket information call 922-0061. HORN OF PLENTY

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN SNOW FALLS BEFORE THE LEAVES DO
description: LEAD: HAVING witnessed a preview of winter, it is apparent that some guidelines for preparing vulnerable plants for winter's onslaught and repairing such damage are appropriate now.

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Paris
description: For the next 15 months, two pale yellow boxes will migrate around the Place de la Concorde in Paris. The official euphemism for these giant crates is architecture of protection, but they are in fact esthetically acceptable coverings for scaffolding that will progressively envelop eight statues of women representing eight cities of France: Lille, Rouen, Strasbourg, Marseilles, Lyons, Nantes, Brest and Bordeaux. The encasements have likenesses of statues painted on their flanks, so that passers-by can imagine what lies within. One has a door leading down to an underground parking garage as well.

title: Correction
description: A map of Switzerland on Aug. 23 located the town of Kilchberg incorrectly. It is on the western shore of Lake Zurich.

title: Why People in Space Can Outperform Robots
description: To the Editor:

title: SPLITTING HAIRS
description: TODAY, MANY WOMEN are lavishing as much attention -and spending as much money - on caring for their hair as they do for their skin. What was once a simple quest for squeaky clean hair has mushroomed into a search for texture, thickness, shine, softness and shape. ''In building a style, a woman can wind up using four or five products,'' says James W. Viera, vice president and corporate technical director of L'Oreal.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S not the kind of thing she'd announce to the world but if the subject comes up, she admits it: when she's visiting friends, she checks out their medicine chests.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $197,000 64 Forham Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced yard, patio; taxes $2,990. East Hanover $231,000 40 Surrey Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; C/A, fenced yard, hardwood floors; taxes $1,858. Livingston $250,000 66 West Cedar Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old split level; den, dining room, finished basement; taxes $3,154. Millburn $230,000 39 Parkview Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, new roof, 1-car garage; taxes $3,098. Washington Township $299,900 30 Winay Terrace West 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; pool, deck, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $4,141. West Orange $146,900 12 Caldwell Terrace 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old ranch; fireplace, enclosed porch, full basement; taxes $2,285. OTHER AREAS Bay Shore, L.I. $101,000 10 21st Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, laundry room; taxes $2,175. Peekskill, N.Y. $163,000 5 Dimond Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; new eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,462. Brookfield, Conn. $176,000 11 Hillside Circle 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; sun porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,059.

title: The Odyssey of Joel Grey
description: LEAD: ARMED WITH HIS GARISHLY-colored sticks and pots of makeup, Joel Grey peers at his face in the mirror, silently plotting that familiar transformation. The still boyish, gentle features and soft brown curls are soon obscured by the ''Juvenile Pink'' pomade he rouges over his face, the shocking blue cream he applies over his eyelids, the black goop he slicks along his hair, and the eerie ''Crimson Lake'' stain he works into a dark leering smile.

title: Opera: 'Tosca' at the Met With Eva Marton
description: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S two-year old production of ''Tosca'' lumbered onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera again on Friday. It is a monument to men's need to create things larger than themselves. Indeed, people seemed somewhat puny next to the soaring Baroque interiors, gargantuan castle parapets and a jail cell that rose and descended - Otis-elevator-like.

title: 7th Suit to Recover Hyfin Funds Is Filed
description: When the Hyfin Credit Union in Brooklyn collapsed last year, investigators estimated that more than $40 million in depositors' funds had been misappropriated or misused.

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...
description: Cross a border of any sort, and the world is largely invented anew.

title: When It's Every Country for Itself, Pity the Markets
description: IS the world economy beginning to fall apart?

title: PROPONENTS OF STATE PLAN SEEK A LOBBY
description: LEAD: AS THE State Planning Commission prepares to release a new draft of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, its supporters are beginning to recognize that the success of growth management in New Jersey may hinge on one key question:

title: SANTUCCI TAKES THE HEART
description: In the latest chapter of New York City's municipal corruption saga, John A. Zaccaro was acquitted last week of charges that he attempted to extort a bribe from a cable television company that sought unsuccessfully to win a franchise in Queens six years ago.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Building Affordable Housing, at a Profit
description: FOR more than a year Teresa Weaver, executive secretary to Mayor Thomas W. Bucci of Bridgeport, looked for a home and found nothing that she and her husband could afford.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: My hat is off to Mrs. Tuchman for speaking so boldly about the appalling state of our nation's leadership. My fear is that human nature thrives on avoidance, however, and lawlessness and incompetence don't directly reach one's doorstep unless one is specific party to a disaster.

title: When America Put Its Stamp On World Painting
description: ALTHOUGH ABSTRACT EXPRES-sionism is so familiar that it seems to have been exhibited and examined forever, ''Abstract Expressionism: The Critical Developments'' at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, is in fact the first museum attempt to survey the entire territory in more than 20 years. It is particularly welcome now, after a decade of retrospectives on all the major members of the New York School, at a time when Abstract Expressionism is being studied and fought over by generations of scholars who have no direct experience of it - who were not in any way there.

title: Comings and Goings
description: GIANNI POLI, an Italian who had never won a major marathon until he captured the event in New York last year, will defend his title in the race Nov. 1. Poli defeated a field that included the two-time defending champion, Orlando Pizzolato of Italy and the 1983 world champion, Rob de Castella of Australia. Two African stars, Ibrahim Hussein and Geoffrey Koech of Kenya, have also said they will enter this year's marathon. Hussein was fourth last year. . . . Larry Nelson, the former United States Open and P.G.A. champion, has been added to next month's $225,000 Australian Open golf championship. He replaces Ben Crenshaw, who withdrew because his wife is expecting a child. . . . Dale Berra, a former Yankee infielder, and Ronn Reynolds, a former Met catcher, have been released outright by the Houston Astros. Berra batted .178 and Reynolds .167 for the Astros this season after spending most of the time in the minors. . . . The Boston Celtics have sent Scott Wedman, a veteran forward, and Sam Vincent, a little-used guard, to Seattle for cash and a second-round draft pick next year.

title: Leatrice L. Dean, Race Horse Trainer, Weds Douglas Trowbridge Elliman 3d
description: Leatrice Levings Dean and Douglas Trowbridge Elliman 3d were married yesterday at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., by the Rev. Adam M. Lewis, an Episcopal priest.

title: SUMPTUOUS 'SAYONARA' AT PAPER MILL
description: ''SAYONARA,'' the musical version of James A. Michener's 1952 novel at the Paper Mill Playhouse through next Sunday, is purely and purposefully sumptuous, and that is the most instantly gratifying thing about it.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: In Maine, One Way To Sell a House

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
description: Based on King's performance for the past two and one-half seasons, which consisted of only six games, the Knicks should not sign him. The team has a solid nucleus with Patrick Ewing, Gerald Wilkins, Kenny Walker and Mark Jackson. Management must continue to build round these players and not around question marks. BERNARD AGUINALDO Jr. Jamaica, Queens

title: U.S. Revising Rules for Small Planes in Los Angeles
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, under attack from private pilots for closing a special air corridor over the Los Angeles International Airport, is planning new procedures to allow these pilots guaranteed passage through the heavily congested airspace.

title: A BROKEN COUNTRY
description: I read Henry Kamm's article with a sense of sadness for what has befallen the people of Cambodia. It is a story with which Americans should be more familiar.

title: THE AGE OF ABANDON: FINDING IT EASIER TO JUST GET RID OF IT ALL
description: ON a recent drizzly morning, a plague descended on our neighborhood, ravished the territory for a while -picked it clean, then was swept away on the late summer wind. It was caused by the most unnatural of creatures, yet increasingly common: the Tag Sale People.

title: Sailors Shape Up in Florida
description: Athletes who reach the Olympic level in sailing tend to be the best and the fittest. Yet they are vulnerable. A trick knee, a bad wrist or a nagging weight loss can spell disaster in the final throes of competition. A new opportunity has come along that may reduce those risks significantly.

title: Pentagon Calls 'Product Substitution' a Key Fraud Problem
description: When the crew of a Navy ship fights a fire at sea, as it did aboard the frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf last May, their equipment must work or sailors are burned and perhaps killed.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WINTER IN MOSCOW, by Malcolm Muggeridge. (Eerdmans, $8.95.) Half journalism, half fiction, this withering look at the Soviet Union was described by its author, the British satirist, who was a correspondent for The Manchester Guardian in Russia in 1932-33, as ''truth imaginatively expressed.'' ''It is quite possible that Mr. Muggeridge is more than slightly mad,'' one reviewer said in 1934, ''but his is the burning madness of a poet who has come to see the fulfillment of a dream of Utopian equality and finds a hell of human suffering.'' ADA: A Life and a Legacy, by Dorothy Stein. (MIT, $9.95.) As friend and patron of Charles Babbage, who in 1833 designed (but never built) a sophisticated contraption called the Analytical Engine, Ada, the Countess of Lovelace and the daughter of Lord Byron, is sometimes revered as the world's first computer programmer. So captivating is this myth that when the Defense Department began developing a universal computer language - an Esperanto that it hopes will someday supplant the babelesque variety of tongues now in use - it decided to name it after her. Though Dorothy Stein's biography debunks the myth of this heroine of computer science, our reviewer, Tracy Kidder, said he liked it anyway. ''This book's cast of characters could easily sustain a novel,'' he said in 1985. It ''evokes a historical period and sets a record straight.'' RETURN TO REGION, by Juan Benet. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. (Columbia University, $9.95.) Old Dr. Sebastian is living a hellish life with his retarded godson, whom he keeps medicated and under lock and key, when a mysterious woman arrives. The haunting stories they tell each other make for a ''brilliant novel by one of Spain's major writers,'' William Herrick said here in 1985. ''It is a lovely, sad book, and the translation . . . is superb.'' The same publisher has reissued another novel by a contemporary Spanish writer, translated by Helen R. Lane. In EXTRAMUROS ($9.95), by Jesus Fernandez Santos, a religious cult forms around a medieval nun who perpetrates a hoax: she has her hands pierced to fake the stigmata, the wounds of Christ that are said to miraculously appear on certain especially devout mystics. The novel won the Spanish National Prize for Literature in 1979.
