Our reviewer, David Lodge, said in 1984 that while he was put off by the ''mannered literary style,'' ''there is no doubt of the integrity of the author's artistic intentions.'' A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, $4.95.) Two corpses, their throats cut, are discovered in the vestry of a London church, and the sardonic Comdr. Adam Dalgliesh of Scotland Yard sets out to find the connection between the victims - a Government minister and a derelict. This novel by the British writer P. D. James ''is graced by one of the most felicitous prose styles I know,'' Robert B. Parker said here in 1986. ''Ms. James is simply a wonderful writer.'' LUISA DOMIC, by George Dennison. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) A Maine poet's circumscribed life is disrupted when he meets Luisa Domic, a Chilean refugee whose family was killed in a right-wing coup. In 1985, our reviewer, Howard Frank Mosher, said he admired the novel for its ability to ''celebrate rural life in contemporary America, yet . . . transcend the limitations traditionally associated with regional fiction.'' THE KOREAN WAR: Pusan to Chosin. An Oral History, by Donald Knox. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) Wedged in the history texts between World War II and Vietnam, Korea may have been America's forgotten war, but not for the people who fought it. This is ''a superb record of what war and battle are all about . . . [ told ] in the blunt Anglo-Saxon tongue,'' Drew Middleton said here last year. ''Because those telling the story are ordinary officers and men, it has a force and reality that few historians writing today will be able to match.'' THE PEDLOCKS, by Stephen Longstreet. (Primus/ Donald I. Fine, $8.95.) Written before the invention of the television mini-series, this multigenerational saga tells how a Jewish family settled in America around the time of the Civil War and eventually established a dynasty. When it was first published in 1951, one reviewer praised it as ''an opulent, crowded narrative, exuberant in its embrace of Jewish customs, cookery, fervor and fertility. It is also, now and then, a showcase for the novelist's display of sophistication.'' S. J. PERELMAN: A Life, by Dorothy Herrmann. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) As a recent collection of his letters showed, the humorist S. J. Perelman often found his life more tormenting than amusing. Last year, our reviewer, John Lahr, said Dorothy Hermann's biography ''amply documents [ that ] the writer was also narcissist-nice and erudite-empty.'' !CLICK SONG, by John A. Williams. (Thunder's Mouth Press, $9.95.) In this bitter indictment of the publishing industry, Cato Caldwell Douglass cannot get his fiction published because he is black. When the novel appeared in 1982, one reviewer criticized it for occasionally lapsing into ''stereotyping [ and ] scattershot self-pity,'' but praised it as ''a novel full of truth, savage with neurotic sophistication.'' MARY TODD LINCOLN: Her Life and Letters, edited by Justin G. Turner and Linda Levitt Turner. (Fromm International, $12.95.) For those who would prefer a tidier, G-rated American history, Abraham Lincoln's wife has always been an embarrassment. By reading over her shoulder, the editors of this voluminous but well-annotated collection of correspondence set out to establish whether she was indeed ''a shrew, a spendthrift, a madwoman.'' The result, T. H. Williams said here in 1972, is a book that offers ''countless insights into the life of the period and will be a priceless source for historians.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I WAS only passing through, buying my new monthly ticket, but nobody can just pass through the Port Washington station of the Long Island Rail Road without encountering Joe Grenier. He is as much a fixture of that station as the ticket booth.

title: LIZA MURPHY IS MARRIED TO CHRISTOPHER PETERSON
description: At the Old Paramus Reformed Church in Paramus, N.J., Elizabeth Ann Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Murphy of Ridge-wood, N.J., and Christopher John Pe-terson of Sunnyvale, Calif., were married yesterday by the Rev. An-drew Topp.

title: Art
description: In ''Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Early Work,'' at the Museum of Modern Art through Nov. 29, Peter Galassi, a curator in the museum's department of photography, has changed our way of seeing an artist we thought we knew. He has done so by focusing attention on the work Cartier-Bresson did in the early 1930's, before the photojournalism for which he is best known.

title: Ms. Tishman Engaged to Gary Inman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Tishman of New York and Warren, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Tishman, to Gary M. Inman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby R. Inman of Mount Airy, N.C. A May wedding is planned. Ms. Tishman, a graduate of the Purnell School, is the assistant to the publisher at Columbia Communications Inc., which publishes trade magazines in New York. She and her mother, Jan Tishman, own the Applewood Equestrian Center, a buyer and seller of show horses in Warren. Her father, a former vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company in New York, is a real-estate consultant and a vice president of the Cross & Brown Company in New York. The bride-to-be is a great-granddaughter of the late Julius Tishman, founder in 1898 of Julius Tishman & Sons, a realty development company from which Tishman Realty and Construction grew.

title: HOMETOWN HERO FOR RUTGERS
description: A hometown player was the hero for Rutgers today as the Scarlet Knights defeated Boston College, 38-24, before a Homecoming crowd of 30,253 at Rutgers Stadium.

title: NEWS SUMMARY/SUNDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Ellen Tanenbaum Bride of S. G. Arthur
description: The Regency Hotel in Manhattan was the setting for the wedding last evening of Ellen Leslie Tanenbaum, a daughter of Winifred J. Tanenbaum of Woodmere, L.I., and J. Jay Tanenbaum of Lawrence, L.I., to Stuart Graham Arthur. He is a son of Mrs. Donald Arthur of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Manhattan, and the late Mr. Arthur. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: A Tax Surcharge
description: To the Editor:

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: A Warmer Grave One of the most painful decisions in mountain climbing is whether to try to bring down the body of a dead comrade. This is from ''Degrees of Difficulty'' (Mountaineers Books) by Vladimir Shatayev, a Russian climber.

title: A Spirited Giulietta
description: CABIRIA (Le Notti di Cabiria) With Giulietta Masina, Amadeo Nazzari, Francois Perier, Franca Marzi, Dorian Gray. Produced by Dino DeLaurentiis. Directed by Federico Fellini. 1957. Dubbed. Video Images/Video Yesteryear. 111 minutes. $29.95.

title: RETIREMENT CHALLENGES FOR WOMEN
description: PAULINE WOODRUFF is 74 years old, lives alone in her house in Montauk and depends on the sympathy of strangers to get by. An employee of the local Highway Department brings her wood during the winter, community service workers insulated her basement ceiling, and a friendly boat captain takes her fishing occasionally, which she calls her ''great escape.''

title: The Glory of Raphael, The Grace of Boucher
description: IN EXHIBITIONS, AS IN MANY AN-other department of life, there is no mistaking the hand-sewn look. Hand-sewn tailoring calls for exceptional skills, long experience, superfine materials and fine judgment at every stage along the way. Hand-sewn work looks right, feels right, is right, and it cannot be counterfeited. (It doesn't need to be hyped, either.) Two current exhibitions struck this visitor as hand-sewn in the true sense. In one of them, we sense the stitching almost before we get inside the door. The other steals upon us in the guise of a dealer's exhibition that might or might not live up to its name, but in point of fact does so to a remarkable degree.

title: A Glimpse of Olden Days, Via Cole Porter
description: AS THE LIGHTS DIM IN THE OPEN-ing moments of the Lincoln Center Theater revival of ''Anything Goes,'' the first sound one hears is a scratchy vintage recording of Cole Porter jauntily singing his 1934 title song about a world gone morally topsy-turvy.

title: Jill Stauffer Is Married
description: Jill Stauffer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Stauffer of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Ware Cobbs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Cobbs of Greenwich and Eaton, N.H. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: New Generation Finds Strength in Borneo's Past
description: For more than a century, since explorers and missionaries first ventured into the interior of Borneo, outsiders have been captivated, awed and not infrequently humbled by the Iban people, who dominated millions of acres of tropical rain forests on one of the world's largest islands.

title: A Revival on The Kennebec
description: THE pace of home-building and waterfront redevelopment has picked up in this shipbuilding town of 10,000 on the Kennebec River after a period in which it lagged behind development in Maine coastal villages and suburban housing centers.

title: POSTINGS: 1901 Elegance;
description: In 1901, a little-known architect named William H. Boylan designed and built the Powellton - an elegant apartment building on the Upper West Side - for only $275,000. Today, under a co-op conversion plan sponsored by the Ziegelman Organization, individual apartments in the 54-unit residence are going for a considerably greater price.

title: Powerful Causes and Flawed Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: Verbatim; Missile Misjudgments
description: 'Maybe he placed the missiles without any real planning, without knowing what will happen afterwards.' Fyodor M. Burlatsky, Speechwriter for Nikita S. Khrushchev, reassessing the 1962 missile crisis at Harvard Univesity last week with advisers to President John F. Kennedy.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article Oct. 4 incorrectly quoted a statement by Fredrica Gray, the executive director of the state's Permanant Commission on the Status of Women, on the panel's legislative program in the General Assembly last year. It should have read: ''We had 35 proposals on the family-and-workplace agenda. Twenty-one were enacted. So it was an enormously successful year.''

title: 4 Teen-Agers Die in Car Wreck
description: Four teen-agers were killed when their car ran off a dark, narrow road and plunged down a 60-foot embankment of the Glen Dam reservoir, the police said today.

title: Manila Army Files Charges Against Rebels in Coup Bid
description: The military filed charges today against 68 officers and 17 enlisted men for their part in an unsuccessful mutiny Aug. 28, a spokesman said today.

title:
NOTEBOOK: DILLSBORO, IND.;
Home Sweet Missile Site
description: LEAD: HAROLD WHISMAN has transformed the underground missile storage area of an old Army base into his family's home.

title: New Collectors Search for the Unusual
description: At first the attraction is purely physical: a shapely leg, a graceful back, the silhouette of an arm, the expression of the eyes. To any novice the experience is haunting, the purchase irresistible. To the veteran, it is a symptom of the embryonic collector. Similar tales have been recorded over and over again.

title: MUSIC: NORWEGIAN GROUP
description: THE Norwegian Chamber Orchestra is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a tour of the United States, the most recent stopover being the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night. For the past six years the group's artistic director has been the English violinist Iona Brown, who played the solo part in Mozart's Concerto in G (K. 216) and presided over the rest of the program from the orchestra's first desk. We also know Ms. Brown for her years of leadership at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields.

title: Rembrandts by Invitation Only
description: With scholars now disputing the authenticity of many museum paintings long attributed to Rembrandt, the treasures of an unmarked house in Amsterdam are of particular interest. No one is likely to cast suspicion on the portraits of Jan Six, a 17th-century Mayor of Amsterdam, and his mother, that hang in the front parlor. They have remained in the Six family's possession since Rembrandt painted them more than 300 years ago.

title: IRANIAN JEWS' NEW LIFE IN GREAT NECK
description: Re: ''Iranian Jews' Request Stirs Ire in Great Neck'' [ Sept. 20 ] : We appeal to those opposing an Iranian Jewish presence in Great Neck to consider the cause and effect that brought an exotic group to their doorstep.

title: Martha Graham's Dances: From The Beginning
description: AMID THE HOTHOUSE ATMOS-phere of the Martha Graham Dance Company gala opening at the City Center - with a historic if not necessarily compatible trio of Russian guest stars - the program on display suddenly clarified a strangely overlooked aspect of recent Graham seasons: Unlike other modern-dance troupes and even many ballet companies, the Graham company has increasingly expanded the range of its repertory during the 1980's. The result is a permanent body of work that reaches back over decades, rather than mere years.

title: Minneapolis Alive to a Rock Beat as Music Groups Seek Fame and Fortune
description: After strumming the blues in an Iowa roadhouse for the last time, Eric De Wolf packed his bags and his guitar and lit out for the bright lights of the music world.

title: Sports of The Times; Blyleven And His Beard
description: WHEN Bert Blyleven first joined the Minnesota Twins in 1970, recalled Tony Oliva, now the Minnesota Twins' batting coach and then the team's slugging right fielder from Cuba, ''he was nice young man, 19 year old, but he pitch like 30 year old. He had big-league arm and big-league fastball and big-league control and he was like today, except no beard, they no allow it.''

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Honor Postponed
description: ONE of the few faces that would have been familiar to fans at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati today has declined to appear. Ken Anderson, the Bengals' five-time Pro Bowl quarterback who retired before this season, was to have been honored at halftime of the Bengals-Browns game. ''It's personally up to him, and I guess he wanted to have it when the regulars are back,'' said a team spokesman, Allan Heim. Anderson holds the single-season pass-completion record of 70.6 percent. He performed for 16 seasons. The ceremony will be held on either Nov. 1 or Nov. 8.

title: Hasenfus Case A Year Later
description: GOOD fortune seemed to ride with Eugene Hasenfus from the moment he parachuted from a cargo plane hit by defensive ground fire over Nicaragua a year ago this month.

title: 'Cursed Oaf' Strikes Back
description: GABRIEL'S LAMENT By Paul Bailey. 331 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: All Sorts of Puzzles Plus 'The Mask Man'

title: Iranian Attacks on Kuwaiti Port Called Cause for U.S. to Retaliate
description: Iran's missile attacks against Kuwait's main oil port have increased pressure on the Reagan Administration to take action against Iranian missile sites to prevent strikes that might destroy Kuwaiti fuel plants, according to Government officials familiar with the situation.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I talk to people who say they think the market has overdone it, but when I ask them if they are ready to buy, they say no.''

title: THE BEST WOMAN IN THE HALL
description: IT'S AN ORDINARY FRIDAY night at Bay Ridge Billiards, a pool hall in Brooklyn, and the place is filled almost entirely with men.

title: Greater Medicare Drug Coverage Gains in Capital
description: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that it would be willing to accept expansion of Medicare to cover the costs of certain prescription drugs provided to elderly and disabled people outside hospitals.

title: Cindy Bochner Marries
description: Cindy Allison Bochner, a legal coordinator for FCB/Leber Katz Partners, a New York advertising agency, was married last evening to William Stuart Lazar, a mortgage broker for the Hanauer Financial Corporation in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Solomon Slomowitz officiated at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edgar S. Bochner of Flushing, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lazar of Livingston.

title: INSIDE
description: Witness for Bork Is Silent The only black law professor scheduled to testify for Judge Robert H. Bork changed his mind after a phone call from Washington. Page 36. Gore Gains in the South Although Jesse Jackson stands to do well in the region, many Democrats are concentrating efforts behind Senator Albert Gore Jr., who has made defense an issue. Page 36. U.S. Anger Over Tibet U.S. officials say the Administration is trying to determine the best way to express displeasure with China over its crackdown in Tibet. Page 17. Twins on a Romp in the World Series Opener Dan Gladden of the Twins heading home after his grand-slam home run in the fourth inning of the Twins' 10-1 victory over the Cardinals. Page 46.

title: REAGAN'S HEART WINNING THE BATTLE FOR HIS MIND
description: ''LET Reagan Be Reagan'' has long been the cry of the President's conservative supporters.

title: A TASTE OF SECRET PLACES
description: I KNOW where the beach plums grow. Down a side road near a solitary, sandy beach. Behind a lonely stretch of dune. In a privately owned garden close to the seaside. On Long Island, the wild beach plums are getting scarce.

title: Mary D. Baker Marries James Morris in South
description: Mary Delilah Baker and James Malachy Morris were married yesterday at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Alpharetta, Ga., by the Rev. James Fennessy.

title: Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopper's World; Painted Pottery From France
description: To many a traveler passing through, nothing could be better than to bring home a piece of the land itself - hand-painted with the thistles of the fields, or an old vendor on a country road, or barnyard buddies cackling and crowing - a piece, for instance, of the tin-glazed earthenware called faience.

title: In Jerusalem, Soccer Is Also Political Football
description: After years of ups and downs, Jerusalem's soccer fans can be forgiven for feeling that they are no closer than they were 10 years ago to getting the new stadium that has become something of a symbol of Israel's modern strife.

title: WHALERS OVERCOME DEVILS IN OVERTIME
description: Sylvain Turgeon deflected Dave Babych's shot from the right point into the net 3 minutes 59 seconds into overtime tonight to give Hartford a 4-3 victory over the Devils. The Whalers snapped their losing streak at five games.

title: A Classical Addition To a Contemporary House
description: Rather than setting out to make their mark in a large city like many young architects, Alan P. Shope and Bernard M. Wharton chose to open their office above a restaurant in Greenwich, Conn. But like most new firms, they began small - renovating antiquated kitchens and bathrooms and adding bedrooms over a garage or onto the back of a house. Six years later, their business has grown considerably, and they are now designing many new homes as well as renovating old ones. As a result of their location, Shope Reno Wharton Associates have become specialists at coping with the varied architectural styles common to a suburban community like Greenwich - knowing to what degree it's appropriate to alter the exterior of a building, for example, and what methods are the most practical. ''It's always more economical to keep rooms where they are,'' explains Shope. ''Even when the design calls for making them larger.''

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored. If he is right, what can I do to correct this problem?

title: Twins Defeat Cardinals, 10-1, in First Game of World Series
description: Dan Gladden, the Minnesota outfielder known more for his speed than the heft of his bat, helped the Twins to a 10-1 rout of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight in opening game of the 84th World Series.

title: Trade Data Set Off A Market Plunge
description: A brutal week for stocks gave the bull market its first serious correction since 1984 and even provoked some traders to start writing obituaries for the bull. The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 235.48 during the week, to close at 2,246.73. The daily action was even more spectular with what was thought to be a record plunge of 95.46 on Wednesday, followed by a 57.61-point dive on Thursday and then the real topper, a plummet of 108.36 on Friday. As postwar corrections go, in percentage terms, this one would not even make the top 10, but that is probably little comfort to anyone who was buying stocks when the Dow set its record high of 2,722.42 a scant seven weeks ago on Aug. 25. The battered bond market took more blows, with yields on long Treasury bonds moving decisively above the psychologically important 10 percent level.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $101,000 10 21st Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, laundry room; taxes $2,175. Head of the Harbor $495,000 6 Watercrest Court 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath. 9-year-old contemporary; library, finished basement, C/A, pool; taxes $5,000. Brookfield, Conn. $176,000 11 Hillside Circle 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; sun porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,059.

title: Q AND A
description: Yugoslavia Question: I have been hearing a lot about Medjugorje in Yugoslavia. What is going on there? Do you have information about nearby resorts and about flights and groups? - P. L., New York Answer: The village of Medjugorje in southwestern Yugoslavia has become a center of religious pilgrimages since 1981 when four young people said that they had seen a vision of the Virgin Mary. The young villagers say they have continued to see the vision at the same time each day. Hundreds of thousands of Europeans and many Americans, most of them traveling with Roman Catholic church groups, visit the village and attend services in its church. Pilgrims who spend the night in Medjugorje stay in private homes, which are the only accommodations, but a Yugoslav tour company, Kompas, says it is opening the first hotel in the village this winter. It will consist of bungalow units for 300 guests and include a restaurant, bar and chapel.

title: U.S. Aid Would Be Better Spent in Philippines Than on Contras
description: To the Editor:

title: Milking a Deadbeat
description: ON THE MORNING OF Sept. 24, Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Continental Airlines, gave me a terrible scare at the breakfast table. His signature under a full-page ad in The New York Times seemed nothing less than a veiled threat to come across at last with the $236 Continental Airlines had owed me since October of 1986.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JOHN H. MARBURGER 3D;
VISION AND VALUES AT STONY BROOK
description: LEAD: JOHN H. MARBURGER 3d, the president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook since 1980, is mild in manner but put off by inexact talk and undue negativity about higher education in this country.

title: James Levine: Symphonic Conductor, Too
description: OVER THE LAST 15 YEARS, James Levine has appeared in occasional chamber and even symphonic programs in this city, has led the Chicago Symphony at the summer Ravinia Festival since 1973 and has made numerous orchestral recordings, in particular his Mahler cycle on RCA, which has recently been reissued on compact disks. But since his Metropolitan Opera debut in 1971, he has been best known to New Yorkers as an operatic conductor.

title: Going Belly to Belly For the Gluttony Title
description: In an attempt to unify the seafood gulping championship of the world, Tommy (Muskrat) Greene is matching stomachs with The Guinness Book of World Records clam-swallowing champion.

description: New ideas and new talents in home design, including these special reports:

title: 'SHOW BOAT' SONGS STILL STIR AUDIENCES
description: ''SHOW BOAT,'' based on a novel by Edna Ferber, was one of the earliest American musicals to achieve dramatic verisimilitude. To its opening-night audience in 1927, a realistic story line in a musical was a novelty, but what makes ''Show Boat'' still exciting to audiences is the almost nonstop series of hit songs that Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d wrote for the show.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Honey, I know you don't feel like dancing. So let's hold hands.''

title:
ART;
BOLD, BRIGHT AND PULSATING
description: LEAD: THERE is an exuberant, robust air about the current exhibition at the Bologna/ Landi Gallery in East Hampton. All three artists - the sculptor Basil Racheotes and the painters Josh Dayton and Donna Gans - are bold, vigorous and partial to bright pigment and pulsating, busy surfaces for their interpretations of human forms.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STARKADDER. By Bernard King. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) In the skaldic poems of Nordic mythology, originality wasn't much of a consideration; what mattered was the rhythmic or stylistic flip brought to a set of relatively unchanging elements. That's the only way to judge their modern counterpart, the so-called sword-and-sorcery genre of pop fiction.

title: Briarcliff Wins
description: The passing of Kyle Farnham led the Briarcliff Bears to a 24-20 upset yesterday over the previously undefeated Bronxville Broncos.

title: The Collapse of Fairyland
description: COBWEBWALKING By Sara Banerji. 155 pp. Bethesda, Md: Adler & Adler. $15.95.

title: What Regional Brokers Recommend
description: ''WE DON'T do the General Motors' of the world,'' said David Soshnik, director of investment research at Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, in St. Louis. The remark could serve as the motto of research departments at many of the nation's smaller, regional brokerage firms. While some of them do try to add to the total investment wisdom on large, familiar stocks, the regional firms are best known for their work on companies overlooked by Wall Street analysts.

title: Dr. Jane Ellen Brown Wed to Jon W. Green
description: Dr. Jane Ellen Brown, a psychiatrist, and Jon Warren Green, a lawyer, were married last evening at the United Nations Plaza Hotel in New York by Rabbi Abraham Klausner.

title: Study Says South Africa Prisons Breed Illness
description: South Africa has the world's highest per capita prison population, with chronic overcrowding, widespread brutality by prison guards and conditions that are frequently harsh and unhygienic, according to a survey by a South African lawyer who spent time in prison.

title: Auto Insurers in Massachusetts Raise Rates, Sue and Flee as Claims Rise
description: Massachusetts drivers, who file more property damage and theft claims than drivers anywhere else in the country, are facing double digit rate increases and a growing reluctance by insurers to continue writing policies in the state.

title: China
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently returned from a four-week trip to China and Tibet. On several occasions we flew on China Airways. On two flights we flew in what are called military charters, which I understand are special sections. These planes were clean, modern and comfortable.

title: VOLUNTEERS: BEACONS IN WORLD OF THE DEAF-BLIND
description: YOU stay where you have been asked to sit for a minute. You are blindfolded and wear padded earmuffs that exclude sound. For all practical purposes, you are blind and deaf. You sit there in utter darkness and stone silence, confident that the promise will be kept, that you will be retrieved in a minute.

title: Sharon Anderson Married in Jersey
description: Christ Church in Summit, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sharon Elizabeth Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Campbell Anderson of Summit, to James Liggitt Hoobler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James Linford Hoobler of Kennett Square, Pa., and Siesta Key, Fla. The Rev. Mark A. Wakefield performed the ceremony.

title: ISLANDERS' FIRST LOSS COME AT HOME
description: When it was over, the Islanders stood in the middle of Nassau Coliseum, refusing to leave the ice or to recognize that there was no time remaining. Finally they left, but it took them some time to accept their first loss of the season.

title: ODD ITEMS, ODDLY SHOWN, IN NEW HAVEN
description: A GNARLED tree limb embedded with bullets lies close to a framed piece of fleece said to be from Mary's little lamb. A blanket chest with a cannonball hole in one side stands next to a cabinet housing items that range from a Fiji Islands war club to a brank, an iron framework made to fit over the head of a woman to keep her from scolding.

title: ALBANY ASKS: WHO SHOULD SET RULES?
description: WHEN Manfred Ohrenstein, the minority leader of the New York State Senate, was indicted last month on charges of misusing state funds, it was more than just the latest in a series of scandals that have shaken state lawmakers this year.

title: IN CASTRO'S GULAG
description: IN THE EARLY AFTERNOON of Jan. 24, 1965, four armed men, their uniforms and shoes in tatters, rested wearily on a rugged mountain slope in eastern Cuba.

title: Where Is Architecture Headed?
description: ''Most of the people in our office, who are younger than we are, are much more conservative, and much less flexible.'' - Alan Wanzenberg, 36, a Manhattan architect, as quoted in Progressive Architecture magazine 'Modernism lasted 80 years before it was severely attacked, but post-modernism has only lasted eight years. . . . At New York City architecture schools 99 percent of the students are designing modernist buildings; the interest in Michael Graves, Philip Johnson, etc., is completely gone there.'' - Peter Pran, 51, former co-chairman of the awards committee, New York Chapter/American Institute of Architects What do these observations mean? Are younger architects really more conservative than their elders? And does being conservative mean that they are trying to turn back the clock toward modernism? The answers, respectively, are ''yes'' and ''sort of.'' Taken together, these quotations clearly suggest that young designers - student architects and those in their first years of work - are not entranced with the creative philosophy of the last few years. These comments indicate that many of them choose not to accept the now common viewpoint that it is not only possible, but desirable, for architecture to rely on the past. That view, so often called post-modernism, has become virtually the establishment attitude, and as it has taken hold, modernism's rigid, somewhat puritanical stance - its belief that purity of form and clarity of structure were often more important than either comfort or visual pleasure - has been all but abandoned.

title: TALKING: Clubhouses; Leasing Facilities to Outsiders
description: THE idea of outsiders wandering through a co-op building, a condominium or a homeowner association complex has always been troubling to the residents. That is why the rental of a facility, like a clubhouse or a community room, for use by nonresidents has long been controversial.

title: For Better Quality, Listen to the Workers
description: A LARGE part of the growing trade problem facing us today has occurred simply because the American people continue to show that they will go anywhere for quality. Unfortunately, ''anywhere'' often means straight to a department store or auto dealer to buy products or services from one of our offshore competitors.

title: A VOYAGE TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD -- WELL, ALMOST TO THE TOP
description: RECENTLY, as he has done many times, C. William Verity Jr., the then newly nominated United States Secretary of Commerce, vowed he would ''make America more competitive.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Riverdale
description: TWO young boys carrying baseball gloves and strolling along Johnson Avenue, Riverdale's bustling shopping thoroughfare, told a visitor recently that they liked living in the community, which hovers on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River. ''I would hate living in the city,'' said one.

title: Indonesia Fire Kills 21
description: Fire swept through a downtown T-shirt factory and killed 21 workers, the police said today, adding that the fire on Friday quickly engulfed the two-story building, trapping the workers on the second floor. Other workers on the first floor managed to escape.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIDOWS OF RUSSIA: And Other Writings. By Carl R. Proffer. (Ardis, $25.) Carl Proffer died of cancer before the era of glasnost began, and these wonderfully vivid memoirs -testimony to 20 years of close friendships and hard work with Soviet literary survivors - can do much to sober us up. In 1971, Mr.

title: If It Wasn't New, It Wasn't Art
description: JACKSON POLLOCK A Biography. By Deborah Solomon. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Up-and-Coming Designers: How to Find Them
description: Being a clever, sophisticated chronicler of society, the writer Dominick Dunne had naturally wanted Mario Buatta or Mark Hampton to decorate his new Manhattan apartment. The name Chester Cleaver did not immediately spring to his mind.

title: Teachers in New Jersey Strike Are to Perform Local Service
description: Teachers who staged an illegal six-day strike in Lyndhurst last spring have been sentenced to perform 18 hours of community service work. Twenty-six secretaries and custodians who joined the walkout were ordered to do 12 hours.

title: In Cuba
description: Joanne Chesimard, a fugitive black radical leader who was convicted of murder a decade ago, surfaced in Cuba last week. Now 40 years old, she has changed her name to Assata Shakur and is about to publish her autobiography, according to an interview that appeared in Newsday.

title: Hostile Tender Offers Are Bad for Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthropologist in the Coal Fields
description: ST. CLAIR A Nineteenth-Century Coal Town's Experience With a Disaster-Prone Industry. By Anthony F. C. Wallace. Illustrated. 519 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: TURF WAR
description: The Army is in the throes of a turf war with a fast-flowing stream that runs through the Fort Monmouth Golf Course. It has paid nearly $500,000 to repair bridges on the 18-hole course and lay sod on the stream bed. However, the water is so swift and deep that even the contractor for the job, MEI Environmental Services of Atlantic Highlands, wonders about the merits of the resodding.

title: FICTION
description: SAINTS AND SCHOLARS. By Terry Eagleton. (Methuen, $14.95.) ''Having a pain in my foot, in short, isn't the same as having a mongoose down my trousers.'' So argues an off-the-deep-end Ludwig Wittgenstein in this first novel by the noted Marxist critic Terry Eagleton. Other characters include the Irish labor leader and revolutionary James Connolly, Wittgenstein's sidekick Nikolai Bakhtin and, in a delightful cameo, Joyce's Leopold Bloom. The year is 1916, and all are on the run: Wittgenstein from philosophy and his teaching post at Oxford; Connolly, wounded in the Easter rising, from the British soldiers; Bakhtin from the ideological chaos of Russia; and Bloom from a failed marriage (Molly has just eloped with Stephen). The meeting place is a cottage on the west coast of Ireland. Along the way Mr. Eagleton does a quick sketch of the political and intellectual issues of the period, and the hot spots that spawned them - Vienna, Dublin and St. Petersburg. The book's main concern is with the limitations of thought when dealing with social problems. In a climactic debate, Wittgenstein criticizes the revolutionary's inhuman, philosophical purity, Connolly countering with a lively defense of historical determinism. The Falstaff-like Bakhtin objects to the humorlessness of revolution. Finally Bloom pulls himself out of his free-associating internal monologue to argue that he doesn't know any of them personally, since they only care about ideas. ''I think I'm just about the only real person here,'' he says. Mr. Eagleton's novella of ideas reads quickly and has its humorous moments; he's a lucid, witty explainer. But this is less a work of fiction than the kind of entertaining concert (''Imagine if the Irish rebel James Connolly had encountered . . .'') an enterprising professor might use to liven up his class.

title: Volunteers Mobilizing to Save Stranded Whales
description: As the season nears when the nor'easters pound Cape Cod Bay, hundreds of volunteers are being organized and trained to rescue the pilot whales and other large marine mammals that are often driven ashore by the storms.

title: Harvard Swamps Dartmouth
description: Tom Yohe passed for three touchdowns and Tony Hinz and Dave Bunning scored two each today, leading Harvard to a 42-3 victory over hapless Dartmouth.

title: REAGAN VISIT SPURS STATE G.O.P. TO ACT
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S visit to New Jersey last week put a few dollars into the state Republican campaign effort and got the party's leaders talking positively about their goals for Nov. 3. But the event also revealed some worries.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 18, 1987
PRESENT COURT SYSTEM IS TOO CONFUSING
description: On Sept. 6, you published anonymously a short, supposedly true story called ''My Night in Jail: A Driver's Story'' [ Opinion Page ] .

title: Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents London
description: For most of this year, one of London's most photographed monuments, the statue of Lord Nelson in Trafalgar Square, has been wrapped in scaffolding. For most of that time, only the cocked hat atop Nelson's head was visible above the thick green brattices attached to the scaffolding. By the end of this month, amid much hoopla, the 144-year-old statue will be unveiled again, with the cracks in Nelson's brow and sword newly plugged with epoxy resin. The 153-foot Corinthian column supporting the statue has also been cleaned from top to bottom. But the restoration of the statue and column is only the first step in a program of repairs and cleaning that visitors can expect to find going on at Trafalgar Square for the next two years.

title: Whiffs of the Past: The Subtle Art Of Packaging Perfumes In Different Eras
description: A ROSE IS A ROSE IS A rose, so what's in a name?

title: After Year, Reflections On a Form
description: PRECISELY one year - and five opening nights - after East Coast Arts made a splashy debut in New Rochelle, its artistic director, Joe Cacaci, was reflecting upon the unusual organization, with its professed purpose of showcasing and developing new plays away from critical pressure. ''We're doing exactly what we had conceived,'' Mr. Cacaci said.

title:
DINING OUT;
>A TASTE OF INDIA IN MORRISTOWN
description: LEAD: ''IT'S WORTH the wait,'' said a departing diner as he pushed his way through the crowd of people waiting to be seated at Chand Palace in Morristown one recent Saturday evening. ''It'' - very good Indian food -is indeed worth the wait.

title: JAZZ: DOROTHY DONEGAN
description: IT is incredible that a major jazz club, the Village Vanguard, has been in continuous existence in New York for more than 50 years, and that the pianist Dorothy Donegan, a major jazz star, has been in and out of New York for more than 40 of those years, without ever performing at the Vanguard until this week.

title: Family Awarded $15 Million In Lawsuit on Immunization
description: The manufacturer of a vaccine used to immunize millions of children against diphtheria and two other diseases has been ordered to pay $15 million to the family of an 8-year-old girl who suffered permanent brain damage attributed to the serum.

title: CAPITALS RALLY OVER RANGERS
description: The Rangers didn't play well enough tonight to stave off a desperate charge by the Capitals, who earned a 4-3 victory on the strength of obstinate offense in the game's waning moments. The loss was the first of the season for the Rangers, whose record is 2-1-2, and it stunned them.

title:
DINING OUT;
New Chinese Entry in Eastchester
description: LEAD: IN recent years the county has been lucky in attracting scores of Chinese restaurants that have enhanced the dinner hour with the miriad flavors of regional cuisines, particularly Hunan and Sichuan. Of late, however, that influx seems not only to have leveled off but also diminished. One need only count the few remaining dining spots on Central Avenue, once lined with Chinese restaurants, to conclude that we might be at the end of an era; the excitement over Hunan-Sichuan dishes may very well have run its course.

title: Scenes From the Kaleidoscope
description: CHINESE LIVES An Oral History of Contemporary China. By Zhang Xinxin and Sang Ye. Edited by W. J. F. Jenner and Delia Davin. Translated by the editors and Cheng Lingang, Gladys Yang, Judy Burrows, Jeffrey C. Kinkley, Carole Murray and Geremie Barme. 367 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: Burlington, Vt., Divided By Mayor's Tax Mission
description: In Burlington, a city better known for frigid weather than heated politics, a battle is under way over a crusade conducted by the socialist Mayor.

title: A MELLOWING TAIWAN SEES A DIFFERENT MAINLAND
description: WHEN the Manchus toppled China's Ming Dynasty in 1644, supporters of the Ming emperors fled to southern China and the island of Taiwan, vowing that they would soon recover the mainland. They never did, of course, although the invading Manchus were gradually assimilated into Chinese society and culture.

title:
GARDENING;
LILY BULBS WILL GROW IN A POT INDOORS
description: LEAD: ENCHANTING indoor flowers chase cold weather's doldrums. For a change of pace, I experimented successfully and learned to force lily bulbs.

title: For Swiss Elections, Little Suspense
description: The world's most stable parliamentary democracy will go to the polls Sunday and most of the world will not take notice. To tell the truth, the Swiss are not too excited, either.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A CAVERNOUS SETTING FOR SMALL TREASURES
description: LEAD: WITHIN the cavernous National Guard Armory on Western Avenue here, close to 100 antiques dealers will be clustered this coming weekend in a vast perimeter around an inner core of display booths that barely penetrate the building's gloomy heights and shadowy corners.

title: TAUNT SPUR SOONERS, 59-10
description: First-half touchdowns by Anthony Stafford, Jamielle Holieway and Lydell Carr today led top-ranked Oklahoma to its 15th consecutive victory, a 59-10 trouncing of Kansas State.

title: Katherine Ruth Slaybaugh Weds Richard Casagrande
description: The wedding of Katherine Ruth Slaybaugh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford W. Slaybaugh of Princeton, N.J., to Richard Casagrande, the son of Mrs. Tranquillo Casagrande of Wallingford, Conn., and the late Mr. Casagrande, took place yesterday in the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro of the Marble Collegiate Church in New York performed the ceremony.

title: JOSEPH BOSCO
description: Joseph Bosco, a former Assistant Attorney General of Massachusetts and former associate regional counsel for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, died of lymphoma Oct. 8 at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 79 years old and lived in Everett, Mass.

title: Vatican Plans to Reinstate Rebel Archbishop
description: The Vatican announced plans today to restore legal standing to a rebel French Archbishop and his outlawed following of traditionalist priests, in a move to mend fences with one of its most vociferous critics.

title: Taming an Oversize Building
description: From its first appearance in architects' renderings, the proposed new tower on the Columbus Circle site of the Coliseum struck New Yorkers as too much of a not-very-good thing.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: I was disappointed by Barbara Tuchman's article. Though the title teased us with an analysis of a society in decay, Mrs. Tuchman failed to deliver: the essay was little more than an invective against the incompetencies of the Reagan Administration. Surely the problem is not as simple as that. Decline involves not merely the failures of a single administration. It involves loss of faith in social institutions and the breakdown of public values. Mrs. Tuchman only touched on these issues.

title: Dutch Gentry Putting Their Homes to Work
description: Dutch aristocrats have lagged behind their English and French cousins in opening their castles and manor houses to the public. But the same motivation that led the nobility in other countries to turn their estates into tourist attractions - namely the financial strain of maintaining historic properties despite some Government subsidies for their restoration - has caught up with titled families in the Netherlands.

title: Miss Greene Wed To Peter Goodale
description: At the First Parish Church in Milton, Mass., Susan Curtis Greene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Greene of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Peter Perkins Goodale, a son of Irene Emery Goodale of Atlanta and Robert P. Goodale of Union, Me. The Rev. Michael Boardmann, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored. If he is right, what can I do to correct this problem?

title: In the Big Manila Land Plan, Steps Are Small
description: As harvesters cut their way last year through the sugar cane fields that surround this tiny sunbaked village, the tough, well-organized farmers who live here moved in behind them, seizing the land for themselves.

title: DANCE: 'CIRCE' FROM 1963 BY MARTHA GRAHAM
description: ''CIRCE,'' which the Martha Graham Dance Company presented for the first time this season at the City Center on Thursday night, is one of Miss Graham's mythological pieces with a difference.

title: Friends of Karen Plans First Health Conference
description: LEAD: FRIENDS OF KAREN, a nonprofit family-care organization in Croton Falls, will be sponsoring its first conference on Friday at the Westchester Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown. The organization helps families with catastrophically ill children.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Department of Environmental Protection, along with environmental agencies from other states, is lobbying the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to relax its rules for disposing of ash from solid-waste incinerators.

title: COPING WITH AUTUMN'S GLORY ONCE IT FALLS
description: WHILE denizens of Connecticut's hills revel in the annual explosion of autumn color, for municipal officials the view is muted by the knowledge that in a few weeks thousands of tons of leaves will be awaiting curbside pickup.

title: Cash-Lendl Final in Sydney
description: Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, scored a 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 victory over the defending champion, Boris Becker of West Germany, tonight to advance to the final of the $345,000 Australian Indoor tennis championships. Cash will play Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia.

title: Success in Eye Of the Beholder
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Seeded Players Eliminated: All four seeded players were eliminated in the quarterfinals of the world match play championship at the storm-ravaged Wentworth course yesterday in Wentworth, England. Greg Norman of Australia, the defender; Larry Mize, the Masters champion; Scott Simpson, the United States Open champion, and Nick Faldo of Britain, the British Open champion, lost as European tour stars charged through to the semfinals. Norman lost by one hole to Mark McNulty of South Africa, Mize was whipped, 7 and 6, by Britain's Sandy Lyle, Simpson went down, 5 and 4, to Severiano Ballesteros of Spain and Faldo was edged by Ian Woosnam of Wales by one hole. In today's semifinals, Woosnam will face Ballesteros, while Lyle meets McNulty.(AP) Australian Leads: Ian Baker-Finch of Australia shot a three-under-par 68 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead in the $411,000 Polaroid Cup-Golf Digest tournament in Susono, Japan. Baker-Finch, who started Friday with a four-stroke deficit, stood at 209 after three rounds. D. A. Weibring, an American, shot a 67, the day's best score. He was at three-over 216, tied for 16th place.(AP) Horse Racing French Horse Winner in England: The French-trained Triptych rallied in the stretch yesterday and won the $380,000 Dubai Champion Stakes at Newmarket, England, for the second successive year. Triptych, a 5-year-old mare, ridden by Tony Cruz, moved from fifth place to first in the final furlong and defeated Most Welcome and the jockey Pat Eddery by 2 1/2 lengths. Saint Andrews, ridden by the French veteran Yves Saint Martin, placed third. (AP) Soccer Liverpool Moves Into First Place: Liverpool moved into first place in the English League First Division standing yesterday by defeating Queens Park Rangers, 4-0. With the loss, the Rangers dropped into second place. John Barnes scored two goals for Liverpool, which won for the eighth time in its last nine games. Nottingham Forest took third place with a 3-0 home victory over Sheffield Wednesday, and Manchester United climbed to fourth after edging Norwich City, 2-1. (AP) Boxing Pical Regains Title: Elyas Pical of Indonesia regained the International Boxing Federation junior bantamweight title with a 15-round split decision over the champion, Chang Tae-il of South Korea, yesterday in Jakarta, Indonesia. Pical, 27 years old, knocked down Chang, 23, in the 13th round and went on to win the fight. Pical was stripped of the title last February after failing in an attempt to win the World Boxing Association championship against the titleholder, Khaosai Galaxy of Thailand.(AP) Williams Stops Gans in 7th: Carl Williams, the third-ranked International Boxing Federation heavyweight contender, floored Mike Gans three times en route to stopping him in the seventh round of a scheduled 10-round bout yesterday. Saturday. Williams is now 19-2 with 15 knockouts. Gans, 27, of San Francisco, who weighed 238 pounds, fell to 11-6 with seven knockouts. (AP) Bowling Macpherson Upsets Ellingsworth: Wendy Macpherson of San Diego upset top-seeded Karen Ellingsworth of Des Plaines, Ill., 205-170, to win the $40,000 Ladies Pro Bowlers Tour AMF Classic yesterday at Grafton, Va. Macpherson, 19, whose only other victory came at the 1986 United States Open, earned $8,000. To reach the title match, Macpherson rolled eight straight strikes to defeat Betty Morris of Stockton, Calif., 245-224.(AP)

title: Piece of Work
description: IN ''VEIL,'' HIS BOOK about William J. Casey's C.I.A., Bob Woodward climbs inside the head of Bobby Ray Inman, who had been our deputy chief spook and was apparently a key source for the newsman. ''After a year,'' writes Woodward, ''Inman had come to regard Casey as a 'piece of work,' a term that Casey often applied to the oddballs in their midst.''

title: MUSEUMS BRINGING A MASS OF ART OUT OF HIDING
description: THEY are like hidden museums - vast storerooms in lower and midtown Manhattan, and in darkened tunnels under Central Park, where thousands of art treasures are kept in climate-controlled environments in storage crates and plastic wrap. The stored works include medieval icons, Renaissance sculpture, German baroque furniture, ancient Chinese urns, Tibetan mandalas, and paintings and sculptures by such 20th-century masters as Picasso, Matisse, Brancusi and Moore.

title: BIRTH OF THE ARK IDEA
description: THE ARK on Bergen Street is nautical, not religious, in origin, its designer and builder, Kea Tawana, says.

title: Shultz and Saudi King Discuss Iran's Attacks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, apparently laying the groundwork for a new effort to get a Security Council arms embargo against Iran, said today that the United States had urged Kuwait to complain to the United Nations about recent Iranian missile attacks.

title: Police Seize Heroin at a Hotel
description: Heroin with an estimated street value of $5 to $8 million was seized Friday night in a hotel in midtown Manhattan as undercover police officers concluded a 10-month investigation by arresting two suspected drug dealers and their four bodyguards.

title: 'WE NEED TO CHECK FOR HAZARDS'
description: WHILE most people are aware that environmental hazards exist, Dorothy Noyes, a public health educator from Hamden, maintains that children suffer the consequences more than adults.

title: Republicans Hoping to Unseat DeMarco
description: LEAD: DEMOCRATS hold a slight enrollment edge in the Fifth County Legislative District, but Republican strategists think this is the race in which the party stands its best chance of eliminating a Democratic incumbent.

title: Struggles of Socialism
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: DANIEL WAITZMAN
description: DANIEL WAITZMAN'S flute recital Thursday evening in Alice Tully Hall set out to prove a point: Mr. Waitzman sees the history of 18th-century music as divided into two strains - what he describes variously, in an extensive and sometimes puzzling program note, as the North German, Protestant, Romantic school, and the Southern Austro-Bohemian, Catholic, Classical school. J. S. Bach belongs to the former; Mozart to the latter.

title: ZEN BAKERY BEGINS TRAINING PROGRAM
description: THE Greyston Family Inn, a nonprofit service organization begun in Yonkers a year ago by the Zen Community of New York, has started a job-training program this month for a small group of Yonkers residents. Most members of the group are homeless and unemployed.

title: A la Carte
description: THE Thai food craze hit Manhattan years ago. Until recently, Long Island had only one Thai restaurant. Once you left Manhattan, after passing a scattering of Thai outposts in Queens, the Seeda Restaurant in Cedarhurst was the sole bastion of Thai food.

title: OPERA: 'VIAGGIO A REIMS'
description: ONE had to admire the enterprise of the young Concert Opera of Manhattan, which presented the New York premiere of ''Il Viaggio a Reims'' by Rossini in concert form Friday night at Town Hall.

title: Margize Howell Wed in Atlanta to John P. Wright
description: Margaret Louise Howell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Howell of Atlanta, was married there yesterday at her parents' home to John Pearson Wright, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Wright of Newport News, Va., by the Rev. Austin Ford, an Episcopal priest.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: October 18, 1987
description: Weeks On Fiction List 1 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, 3 $4.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 2 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) 9 Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 3 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) 2 Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in "Evergreen." 4 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. 2 (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The hero of the "Foundation" series searches for the lost planet Earth. 5 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen 1 Coonts. (Pocket, $4.95.) Navy aviators in the Vietnam War. 6 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, 14 $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 7 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Ballantine, 7 $4.95.) Two men, two women, passion and power- brokering in Washington. 8 VALE OF THE VOLE, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, 3 $3.95.) Esk, the son of an ogre and a nymph, defends the inhabitants of a paradise. 9 DREAMS ARE NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline 3 Briskin. (Berkley, $4.50.) A California family dynasty out to conquer the world. 10 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. 8 (Avon, $4.95.) Romance, power and greed mark an 18th-century woman's coming-of-age. 11 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 75 Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 12 CALL TO ARMS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Jove, $4.50.) 6 The Marines from Pearl Harbor to Midway; second volume of "The Corps." 13 O-ZONE, by Paul Theroux. (Ivy/Ballantine, 2 $4.95.) In 21st-century America, eight people enter a forbidden land of aliens and nuclear waste. 14 THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. 1 (Bantam, $4.50.) Forty years in a small North Dakota town near an Indian reservation. 15 I AM THE ONLY RUNNING FOOTMAN, by 2 Martha Grimes. (Dell, $3.95.) Scotland Yard's Superintendent Jury on the trail of a strangler. Weeks On Nonfiction List 1 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph 2 Wambaugh. (Bantam, $4.95.) A case involving the 1979 murder of a high school teacher. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. 208 (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. 50 (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 4 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 34 (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 5 KAFFIR BOY, by Mark Mathabane. (Plume/ 7 NAL, $8.95.) Coming-of-age in South Africa. 6 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) 25 Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 7 * HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $4.95.) An 8 unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 8 ONE MORE TIME, by Carol Burnett. (Avon, 1 $4.50.) The comedian's autobiography, beginning with her impoverished childhood in Hollywood and taking her up to age 26. 9 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Avon, 4 $5.50.) The confrontation between America's Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan. 10 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle 17 Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) Tales of the world's oldest profession. 11 * DREAMGIRL, by Mary Wilson with Patricia 6 Romanowski and Ahrgus Juilliard. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) A behind-the-scenes look at the Supremes. Weeks Advice, How-to and On Miscellaneous List 1 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by 8 Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More "Bloom County" cartoon strips. 2 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. 19 (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 72 Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. 26 (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 5 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge 32 Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE?
description: I am a systems engineer for the Unisys Corporation's shipboard and ground systems group. We integrated and tested the U.S.S. Stark's combat system. I am also a commander in the Naval Reserve, and was graduated from the Naval Academy, so I know a bit about naval warfare. Wrong is the only way to characterize what Mrs. Tuchman wrote about the Stark in her article. Stark is an FFG-7 (Perry) Class guided-missile frigate. The FFG-7 Class was conceived, designed and built as convoy escort warships. The Stark and her sister ships were given capabilities in all naval warfare areas so they would be able to defend unarmed merchantmen without battle-group support. Contrary to what Mrs. Tuchman states, the FFG-7 class is capable of operating independently, and the design well suits the Persian Gulf area.

title: Wallace Stegner's Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: MERCEDES SOSA SINGS
description: LIKE so many non-English speaking singers of passionate temperament, Mercedes Sosa, the Argentine folk singer who performed at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, has elicited comparisons with Edith Piaf. Indeed, Ms. Sosa, like France's ''little sparrow,'' possesses a compelling populist voice, but instead of an urban music-hall tradition, her sensibility belongs to the Latin American folk movement known as nuevo cancion. Her comparatively soft-spoken singing doesn't express ferocious will power so much as embody a collective spiritual determination. Singing songs of love, she is addressing the body politic of her troubled homeland more than any lover.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Tale of Two Strikers

title: Betsy Wright Weds D. M. Hawkings Jr.
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Elisabeth Jane Wright, the daughter of Cynthia Brannock Wright of Greenwich and John McKeown Wright of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Mark Hawkings Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawkings of New York and Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: Paving the Way from Osaka to Iowa
description: ARE more American recruiters working the byways of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, than the highways of Arizona? ''It's astounding,'' but literally true, said Josef Silny, director of international admissions at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla. ''American colleges have discovered the foreign market. There aren't many who do it well yet, but some of us are state-of-the-art.''

title: Ann H. Oberhaus Weds T. P. Mackin
description: At the South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., Ann Huff Oberhaus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Oberhaus of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy Peter Mackin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Mackin of Glen Ridge, N.J., by the Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore.

title: Dance: 'Celebration' Revived After 50 Years
description: RUN, don't walk, to see ''Celebration,'' a dazzling dance choreographed by Martha Graham in 1934 that was revived Friday night for the first time in 50 years!

title: RETIREES FIND THEIR LABOR IS BACK IN DEMAND
description: ON a recent afternoon at Stew Leonard's, the huge supermarket in Norwalk, Richard Ash was busy sweeping up around the 24 checkout counters in front of the sprawling store, which says it draws about 100,000 customers each week.

title: SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
description: The Knicks must sign King. He appears much more capable of helping the Knicks win than Kenny Walker, who was himself injured last year. Salary is hardly an issue. After all, the Knicks pay Bill Cartwright, who can neither rebound nor play defense, a million dollars, and Pat Cummings, who can't do much of anything, $800,000. ERIK ENGQUIST Brooklyn

title: BERGEN CONSOLIDATING OFFICES
description: BERGEN COUNTY officials have begun a major consolidation that will put about 600 county employees under the same roof here while relieving congesting in or eliminating six separate buildings throughout the city.

title: FICTION
description: GLITTERING IMAGES. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) Susan Howatch's 12th novel takes place in pre-World War II England, just after Edward VIII abdicated to marry the divorced Wallis Simpson. The event is emblematic, for this novel is about marriage and divorce and proper behavior within a religious context. True to the formulas of romance fiction, ''Glittering Images'' is rife with bad marriages, illegitimacy and discreet sexual liaisons; yet all these goings-on seem oddly out of place within the domestic lives of Anglican clergymen. The narrator is a young intellectual cleric, Charles Ashworth, who is sent by the Archbishop of Canterbury to spy on Alex Jardine, the charismatic, liberal Bishop of Starbridge. Ashworth uncovers evidence in Jardine's household - which includes a depressive wife and her pretty female companion - of sexual scandal and a highly irregular interpretation of Anglican dogma. The revelation of the mystery of Starbridge sends Ashworth into a personal crisis of faith from which he is facilely extricated by a monk, Father Jon Darrow - his confessor-exorcist-psychoanalyst. Most popular novels are driven by a lively, fast-moving plot, but this one creaks along clumsily and is studded with insultingly obvious markers alerting the reader to every minute twist in the action and nuance of emotion. In an attempt to capture the prissy manners and sexual reticence of the age, Ms. Howatch has created sanctimonious characters stifled by convention who lack subtlety and depth. They engage in tedious theological arguments or inane, cliche-ridden exchanges about those inevitable and tired English subjects: class, social standing and the weather. Life within the cathedral close must have been very dull indeed.

title: Syracuse (6-0) Routs Penn State by 48-21
description: Don McPherson, the Syracuse quarterback, threw an 80-yard touchdown pass on the first play from scrimmage against Penn State today. And that was just the beginning of a surprisingly easy upset over the 1986 national champion Nittany Lions.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOLD BULLION COINS ANNOUNCED BY BRITAIN
description: LEAD: THE British Royal Mint has introduced its new Britannia gold bullion coinage. The program consists of four legal tender coins: a basic piece containing one troy ounce of gold plus fractional variants with gold contents of 1/2, 1/4, and 1/10 of an ounce.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A RACE ON THE EDGE OF TIME: Radar - the Decisive Weapon of World War II. By David E. Fisher. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) In the late summer and early autumn of 1940, Adolf Hitler, with most of Western Europe lying stunned at his feet, hurled the greatest air armada then known across the English Channel to break Britain's resistance.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Los Angeles Plan; Major Surgery On the School Year
description: THE year-round school schedule has been a hugely unpopular idea in the United States, but the Los Angeles Board of Education voted last week to try it in the nation's second-largest district.

title: Europe Without Price Tags
description: Whether you stay in a $450-a-day suite in a deluxe hotel on the Grand Canal or spend $40 for a double room in a pensione in a narrow alley near the Santa Lucia railroad terminal, the essence of Venice - its plaza and canals and markets - is there to savor for free.

title: Halting of Drug Flow Praised
description: Stopping illegal drugs at the border may take more drugs off the market at a lower cost than enforcing drug laws inside the United States, according to a study for the Customs Service.

title: TV Review; NBC's 'Strange Voices,' On Schizophrenia
description: TAPPING the subject of schizophrenia, ''Strange Voices'' - tonight's movie on Channel 4 at 9 - is a case of too much, too late. The same subject was handled with uncommon intelligence last December in CBS's ''Promises,'' which won a packet of richly deserved awards for James Garner and James Woods. There is plenty of room for further explorations, obviously, but ''Strange Voices'' is a misguided, bumbling attempt in that direction.

title: Nova Output to Be Cut
description: The New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. announced its third cutback in six months of Chevrolet Nova production. Nummi, the sole producer of the Nova, will reduce production to 450 of the cars a day, from 550, effective Nov. 30. The cutback is in anticipation of reduced 1988 model sales. But the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Corporation, co-owners of the venture, said they had no plans to slow production of Toyota Corolla FX automobiles or lay off any of the factory's 2,500 employees.

title: U.N. Complains Of Africa Aid Cuts
description: Cuts in foreign aid, plummeting commodity prices and rising African debt threaten hard-won economic gains made by African countries since the famine on the continent two years ago, according to a report by the United Nations.

title: Advertising; New Venture for Liza: Singing in a TV Spot
description: For her first venture in a television commercial, Liza Minnelli is appearing in a spot with four locations in New York, New York, singing a song she sang briefly in 1975 as star of the show ''Chicago.''

title: A Forecast for Israel: More Arabs Than Jews
description: Forty-two-year-old Suad al-Hadidi is a symbol of what Yasir Arafat calls the Palestinian ''demographic bomb.''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Capacity Utilization Sept. Tuesday Housing Starts Sept. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Consumer Price Index Sept. Durable Goods Sept. Real Economic Growth Third Quarter

title: Diva Pays the Duke A Musical Tribute
description: Jessye Norman is hardly the first name that comes to mind when one mentions Duke Ellington. While her plangent soprano is one of the reigning voices in opera, when it comes to popular music, she has been on the quiet side. At least, up to now. Tonight, the acclaimed diva will sing at a benefit for the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund, along with her friend and president of the fund, the pianist Bobby Short, and the Amherst Saxophone Quartet. The concert, at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, is a salute to one of the greatest jazz artists of this century. The benefit will raise money for a life-sized statue of Ellington to be installed at the northeast corner of Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. Concert tickets are $15 to $50. Information: 874-4098.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1987
description: International A3-14

title: Stage: From Brook, 'The Mahabharata'
description: MORE than nine hours after it begins, Peter Brook's production of ''The Mahabharata'' is still not over - but at least the world is coming to an end.

title: Dome-Team Advantage
description: The Detroit Tigers and the other victims of the 1987 Minnesota Twins hardly need a couple of guys with slide rules to tell them what they learned the hard way this season -that it's no picnic taking on a team playing under its own cozy roof. But in case there are still some skeptics, two sociologists have come up with convincing statistical evidence that a dome magnifies the traditional home-team advantage even as it amplifies the cheers of the crowd.

title: Aides and AIDS
description: The Noble School District in Norman, Okla., is reluctant to call an aide an aide. Last week it announced that library aides and teacher aides will be called assistants because of public anxiety over AIDS.

title: India Sending More Troops to Sri Lanka
description: India said today that it was sending 2,000 more troops to fight ethnic Tamil guerrillas in the Jaffna Peninsula.

title: Japan's New Real Estate Move
description: Benjamin V. Lambert, the independent real estate deal maker who last year sold half his company, Eastdil Realty Inc., to Nomura Securities and then disappeared from the marketplace, has come out of hibernation.

title: Nixon Memo Sees 'Jackass' In Presidency
description: Richard M. Nixon wrote confidentially to friends that the Democrats could ''nominate a jackass'' and probably win the 1988 Presidential election if the United States economy faltered, The London Sunday Times reported today.

title: For Smaller Maker, a Rough Fight Just to Survive
description: Marvin Sands, chairman of the Canandaigua Wine Company, jumped into the wine cooler business three years ago. He spent millions on machinery and promotion to make his company's Sun Country Cooler a hit. In so doing, he turned down the chance to buy out his company's outside shareholders.

title: American Ballet Theater Promotes Five Dancers
description: Five dancers with American Ballet Theater are being promoted on Nov. 1, the company's artistic director, Mikhail Baryshnikov, has announced.

title: Jean-Luc Ponty at Carnegie
description: Jean-Luc Ponty, a jazz-fusion violinist, is to perform at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 o'clock. Mr. Ponty, who has performed with Frank Zappa, Elton John and the Mahavishnu Orchestra, will play music from his new album, ''The Gift of Time.'' Tickets, $20, $22.50 and $25, are available at the Carnegie Hall box office, 57th Street at Seventh Avenue, or from Carnegie Charge: 247-7800.

title: Teachers in Chicago Approve 2-Year Contract Settlement
description: Teachers in the Chicago public school system have voted to approve a contract agreement that ended their four-week strike earlier this month, the union has announced.

title: Dance: Ballet du Nord Performs in Brooklyn
description: THE Ballet du Nord, based in the northern French industrial city of Roubaix, near the Belgian border, showed off a new aspect of France's current dance boom in its United States debut Saturday night.

title: City Council Elections Don't Need Public Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: In Moscow, Rights by the Drop
description: Ida Nudel's going-away dinner at the Vilnius Restaurant in Moscow last week must have been a joy. The ''mother of the Soviet refuseniks'' was bound for Israel after 16 years of trying. Iosif Begun, Moscow's unofficial rabbi, was there; his permission to emigrate came last month. Vladimir Slepak arrived waving the permission he and his wife had just received. They applied 17 years ago.

title: 14 Dead in Crash in Turkey
description: Two buses collided head-on near here early today, killing 14 people and injuring 26 others, the Anatolia news agency reported. The agency said one bus was carrying people home from a wedding. Aksehir is about 300 miles southeast of Istanbul.

title: Takeover Specialists Fear Proposed Taxes
description: Proposed changes in the tax law have thrust the merger-and-acquisition world into a state of fearful anticipation.

title: A Rerun That Didn't Have to Happen
description: When the ballots were tallied in last month's hotly contested civil court primary in Lower Manhattan, a mere three votes separated rival candidates Lester Evens and Stuart Cohen. That made tomorrow's rerun necessary. Regardless of who wins, the large number of irregularities in the original count represent an ongoing challenge.

title: New Soviet Clubs Find Freedom in the Rough
description: In the first minute of Tuesday night's meeting of the unofficial Perestroika Club, an argument broke out over who would serve as chairman. It was followed by an argument over the agenda, and another argument over who was authorized to speak for the group in interviews with the press.

title: Advertising; Digest Puts Emphasis On Brands
description: THE latest caper of the advertising department of the Reader's Digest is a 32-page insert in November. It will contribute an estimated $3 million to an issue with a record-breaking $16 million of advertising revenues.

title: Police in India Arrest 3 Priests at Sikh Temple
description: The police in the northern state of Punjab today detained three Sikh high priests whom officials accuse of having supported extremists there.

title: U.S. Dollar Policy Backed by Analysts
description: Many economists think that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's acquiesence in letting the dollar fall against the West German mark is the right choice and probably unavoidable.

title: The Good Old Days
description: The round of meetings involving a peripatetic phalanx of negotiators who tried in vain to hammer out a settlement presented a striking counterpoint to the days when football labor negotiations were a far, far simpler affair.

title: Progress Is Slow For Injured Driver
description: LAST Wednesday, Roberto Guerrero played a round of golf.

title: A Crack Plague in Queens Brings Violence and Fear
description: The crack trade in southeast Queens has turned middle-class neighborhoods near the Nassau County border into some of New York City's bloodiest drug battlegrounds.

title: As the Statue Turns
description: For 101 years, the Statue of Liberty has stood in New York Harbor, facing the Empire State, New Jersey at her back.

title: Give the Arias Peace Plan a Chance
description: ''I know of no safe depository of the ultimate powers of the society but the people themselves.'' Thomas Jefferson penned those words in September 1820. President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica could have written them yesterday.

title: Invitation to Dinner Prompts Reagan Call
description: When Sheila Nagy invited President Reagan to have dinner with her ''normal American family,'' she asked him to call in advance so she would have time to defrost extra meat.

title: Cards' Cox Regrets Three Big Mistakes
description: Danny Cox, the big-game pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, got into a really big game tonight. He didn't survive the fourth inning, chiefly because three of his pitches strayed higher than targeted. So, he was left with every pitcher's lament: ''I hope I'll get a second chance.''

title: Death of a Ritual: Working the Last Of Pier 42's Cargo
description: When longshoremen unload the Tropical Morn's 187,849 boxes of bananas, pineapples and coconuts at Pier 42 today, they will be performing a Manhattan waterfront ritual that began more than three centuries ago. It may be performed for the last time next month.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The stock market's big drop should be no cause for panic, members of the financial community said. Rather, they suggested, it should serve as a warning for certain policy steps that are much needed. [ Page A1. ] The drop in buying by foreign investors is worrying the credit markets. Analysts say that rising interest rates in West Germany and Japan, plus renewed weakness of the dollar, are the key reasons why American interest rates have been rising, and not an exaggerated fear of inflation. [ Page D1. ] Treasury Secretary Baker's decision to let the dollar fall against the mark is the right choice, many economists say, noting that rising West German rates and market turmoil helped force his hand. [ D5. ] Bankers are preoccupied with the next move of the market and prospects for the overall economy, judging from their conversations at the American Bankers Association convention. [ D1. ] Proposed tax law changes in the House tax bill are worrying the mergers-and-acquisitions world, although many analysts think the bill will be amended or killed. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Africa's economic gains are being threatened by cuts in foreign aid, plummeting commodity prices and rising debt, according to a United Nations report. [ D6. ] Malaysia is trying to convince the U.S. that edible palm oil is not a proven health hazard. Bills before Congressional committees would require that it be labeled a saturated fat. [ D6. ] Italy plans to sell control of its largest merchant bank, Mediobanca, in a move that experts predict could alter the relationship of the country's public and private sectors. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Pan Am's union leaders are facing a dilemma because of Kirk Kerkorian's plan to take control of the airline and give employees a sizable portion of stock in return for concessions.
