[ D1. ] A.T.&T. is expected to announce plans for a new computer work station that would use a specialty microprocessor developed by Sun Microsystems. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Corporate regulation could be strongly affected by future First Amendment challenges. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] For small investors, getting out of the way may make sense after the free fall of the market Friday. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Arms Control: Taking Stock
description: State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze prepare to meet again, this week, it is appropriate to take stock of what we have achieved in arms control efforts and what remains ahead.

title: FOR PIANIST, A NEW LIFE IN THE U.S.
description: Vladimir Feltsman leaned into the piano keyboard, filling a rehearsal room on the campus of the State University College here with the music of Franz Schubert. His audience listened intently, some followed on sheet music.

title: New Rumors of Coups Shake Nervous Manila
description: Renegade soldiers telephoned reporters before dawn today, asking them to witness their theft of an armored personnel carrier, which they drove around a university campus before abandoning.

title: Dr. Lisser Wed to Dr. Matthew Frosch
description: Dr. Amy Carol Lisser, a resident in psychiatry at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Matthew Philip Frosch, a resident in pathology at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday. Justice Marilyn R. Friedenberg of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Nancy Reagan's Prognosis: Excellent
description: Nancy Reagan's doctors said today that final laboratory tests of tissue removed during her breast cancer surgery on Saturday showed no spread of the malignancy. They said Mrs. Reagan was ''recovering remarkably well'' with an excellent prognosis for full recovery.

title: Outdoors: Warming Up to Steel
description: IF duck and goose hunters will cease their lamentations about the widening legal obligation to use steel shotgun pellets, they can adapt to and possibly profit from the steel era.

title: Protest Over Anti-Semitism
description: Thirty-five members of militant Jewish groups holding a rally to protest anti-Semitic vandalism were ejected from Temple Emanu-El today by the police at the congregation's request. Members of the Boston chapter of the Jewish Defense League and of two other groups said patrols would be started to prevent anti-Semitic vandalism. A week ago swastikas were found painted on two synagogues and two businesses in Providence. The police said the eviction was requested by Louis Rosen, the temple's executive director.

title: Improving Conditions
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Officials in Atlanta Indicted in Extortion
description: Two Fulton County Commissioners were indicted Friday by a Federal grand jury on charges of extorting thousands of dollars from developers in exchange for supporting zoning changes.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 18, 1987: MONDAY Di Giorgio Corp Eli Lilly & Co Eastern Utils Assoc Southern Co BF Goodrich Weis Markets Johnson & Johnson Whirlpool Corp Earle M Jorgenson Zurn Indus TUESDAY Amax Gold K Mart Corp Amer Cyanamid Luby's Cafeterias Bearings Inc NUI Corp Equitable Resources Inc Scott Paper Health Care Prpty Invstrs Security Pacific Honeywell Inc Southern Indiana G & E ICM Property Invstrs Inc Texas Indus Interpublic Group of Cos VF Corp Veeco Instruments WEDNESDAY AMP Inc Mexico Fund Armtek Corp Minnesota Pwr & Lt Barnett Banks NCR Corp CalFed Inc Newell Co Columbia Gas Sys Newmont Mining Crompton & Knowles Pacific G & E Dow Jones & Co Parker Drilling GenCorp Inc Pinnacle West Cap Corp Intl Minerals and Chem Republic New York Corp Jostens Inc Zero Corp THURSDAY Avery Intl Morton Thiokol Inc Bemis Co Nalco Co Chemical Carter-Wallace Natl Distilers and Chem Delta Air Lines Niagra Mohawk Power Donnelly RR & Sons Overseas Shipholding Dravo Corp Potomac Elec Power Empire District Elec Questar Corp Ethyl Corp Republic Gypsum Handy & Harman Sonat Inc Iowa-Ill G & E Thomas indus Kollmorgen Corp Triangle Indus Lamaur Inc Trinova Corp FRIDAY Central Louisiana Elec Kysor Indus Dexter Corp Loctite Corp Federal Signal Monsanto Corp Ferro Corp Nashua Corp John H Harland Ryder System Harris Corp Snap-On Tools Kaufman & Broad Home Stewart-Warner Kaufman & Broad Inc Tyler Corp SUNDAY Louisiana Pacific Corp

title: Russians Win
description: The Soviet Union dominated the Konica Cup international rhythmic gymnastics invitational, taking the team championship and sweeping the first three places in the all-round standing today. Marina Lobach won the all-round competition with 39.85 points out of 40.

title: Chief Is Set Back On Meritor Growth
description: Frederick S. Hammer, chairman and chief executive of the Meritor Financial Group, is not one to pull in his horns. But he has had to do that as the Philadelphia-based institution last week reported a big third-quarter loss and faces a restructuring that will see the sale of some $1 billion in assets.

title: LESSONS ON THE DARK SIDE OF POLITICS
description: On and off for the last year, Sam Lauter has driven around Washington in his black jeep, picking up Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his Senate office and delivering him to his numerous appointments. But now Mr. Lauter, of the Biden for President campaign, is looking for other work.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are heading for a binational state, not a Jewish state - no question about it.'' Prof. Arnon Sofer,

title: Cabby Slain at Wheel In Apparent Robbery
description: A driver of a medallion cab was shot dead early yesterday in Washington Heights in what the police called an apparent robbery.

title: PERSONAL ENSIGN CAPTURES BELDAME
description: Personal Ensign, racing's newest star, remained undefeated by returning from one week of rest to beat all of New York's leading fillies in the $303,500 Beldame Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Largent Catches 15 In Seahawk Romp
description: If regular players couldn't stop Steve Largent in 142 games, replacement players weren't going to stop him in one.

title: Bowie Refractures Leg Before Game
description: Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazer center whose injuries have kept him sidelined through much of his basketball career, was in the hospital again today with a broken right leg.

title: Lynn Ann Ackerman Wed to Daniel Marc Berger
description: Lynn Ann Ackerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ackerman of Oceanside, L.I., and Daniel Marc Berger were married yesterday afternoon at the Harmonie Club in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Philmore Berger of Oceanside. Rabbi Berger performed the ceremony.

title: A Museum's Cafe Order: A 19th-Century Sculpture
description: ''Do you have the Pan by MacMonnies?''

title: Short-Term Issues Highlight Week
description: Treasury auctions this week start with today's sales of three-month and six-month bills, continue with a two-year note issue on Wednesday and end with a one-year bill issue on Thursday.

title: Post Offered At U.S. Agency
description: The chairman of a large savings and loan institution in Atlanta has been asked to take over as chief executive of a troubled Government-owned corporation set up to sell property from bankrupt savings institutions, a Federal Home Loan Bank Board spokesman saiooFrFriday.

title: Central Intelligence Agency; Covert Workers Disappear in the Pension Shuffle
description: They dropped agents and propaganda in Communist China in night missions from Taiwan, ferried food and supplies through Vietminh antiaircraft fire to the French at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, delivered weapons to anti-Communists in Burma and Laos.

title: Privatization Of VW Nears
description: The West German Government may be getting ready to sell its stake in Volkswagen next month, after earlier hesitating on the timing of the privatization because of a currency scandal at the car manufacturer. A possible clue to Government intentions came from the nation's second-largest bank, Dresdner, which scheduled a presentation for potential new investors in VW for Nov. 2. The Finance Ministry in Bonn declined to comment on the timing.

title: Recital: Juana Zayas, Pianist
description: THERE is something saintly about taking on both books of the Chopin Etudes in public concert. It is as if for an hour or so the sins of struggling pianists everywhere are lifted from their shoulders and somehow expiated by a single act of sacrifice.

title:
Market Place;
Small Investors In Rough Seas
description: LEAD: WITH almost half a trillion dollars in stock prices having been wiped out since the market peaked in late August, the summer's euphoria has been replaced by a wintry chill.

title: Baptists War Over Hearts and Minds
description: In the eight years since fundamentalists took control of the Southern Baptist Convention, moderates in the nation's largest Protestant denomination have been able to maintain much of the control of seminaries and Baptist-affiliated colleges and universities.

title: Bankers' Problem List Grows
description: Bankers, already nervous about encroaching competition from brokers, retailers, auto makers, and others, have a new worry: The outlook for the nation's economy.

title: Giants (0-5) Fall in Overtime
description: If you like the Buffalo Bills, the game was horrible, but at least your team won. If you like the Giants, the game was worse than horrible.

title: Goal of New Program: Stir the Dying P.T.A.'s
description: James Tucker, the principal at Public School 93 in the heart of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, remembers that a decade ago his school boasted a thriving parents association. By last year, three parents regularly visited the school; this year, none have turned up.

title: Tibetans Are Prisoners in Their Own Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance: 'Interleaving,' Four Works in One
description: THE computer age could not help but affect dance sooner or later. Would Bill Young, who performed with his company on Friday evening at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, have thought of or desired to create ''Interleaving'' in any other time? The new piece is made of four separate dances, with the beginnings of the four all being performed first, all the middle parts second and their endings last.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday, about automobile sales in early October, misstated the light-truck sales of the Ford Motor Company. Ford sold 30,681 light trucks, 28.1 percent fewer than in the comparable 1986 period.

title: 4.5% Canadian Inflation
description: Canada's annual inflation rate held steady at 4.5 percent in September as another drop in food prices offset increases in housing and other sectors, the Government's statistical agency said Friday. Statistics Canada reported it was the first time in 12 months that prices had remained unchanged from the previous month. Because of Canada's booming economy, inflation has been a worry for monetary authorities, and interest rates have been pushed up to keep prices in check. The Canadian economy expanded by 6 percent in each of the first two quarters of the year.

title: '88 Arrival: $73 Million La Guardia Expansion
description: A $73 million expansion of La Guardia Airport's main terminal over the next four years, with new roads for arriving and departing traffic and an enlarged Central Terminal Building, was announced yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Bridge: Taiwan's Players Excel In World Championship
description: The semifinal stage of the world team championships will begin here Monday with Taiwan opposing the United States and Britain clashing with Sweden.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FORDS. An American Epic. By Peter Collier and David Horowitz. Illustrated. 496 pages. Summit. $22.95.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 19, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Audit Faults H.R.A. Check-Cashing Procedures
description: Nearly $1.4 million from an emergency program to shelter homeless people in New York City may have been improperly spent, according to an audit by the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Walking to Glory
description: At the age of 39, Viisha Sedlak would seem to be a mite old for a national track team, especially in an event she took up just two years ago, but then Sedlak is not an ordinary athlete and her's is not an ordinary event.

title: Juilliard Chamber Group
description: The Juilliard Chamber Symphony will play the Faure and Sibelius settings of the Pelleas and Melisande legend in a free concert Thursday at Alice Tully Hall. Sixten Ehrling will conduct. Mozart's Symphony No. 41 (the ''Jupiter'') is also on the program. Although there is no charge, tickets are required; they may be obtained at the Juilliard Concert Office, 144 West 66th Street, Monday through Friday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: 874-7515.

title: REAGAN CHOOSES THE U.S. RESPONSE TO IRANIAN ATTACK
description: President Reagan tonight summoned Congressional leaders to the White House for a briefing, hours after he had declared that he had decided how to respond to the Iranian missile attack on an American-registered ship off Kuwait.

title: Foreigners Called Key To Rates
description: As Treasury bond yields rose above 10 percent last week and stock prices plummeted, the financial markets were focused on the dangers from abroad and unimpressed by assurances from senior Government officials that interest rates were needlessly high and based on exaggerated fears of inflation.

title: Ewing and Pitino Starting in Step
description: IN the most democratic of professional basketball worlds, every player would represent just one of 12 equal parts. But there has never been a basketball democracy because the difference between success and failure is so tenuous that it is often defined as much by a player's happiness as it is by his performance.

title: Owners 28, Players ?, Fans 0
description: NOW that all the real pro football players are expected to return to work, the heart of the National Football League season is about to resume pumping. Its soul, however, has been lost.

title: IN THE AFTERMATH OF MARKET PLUNGE, MUCH UNEASINESS
description: Last week's spectacular drop in the stock market - 235.48 points, or 9.49 percent - has left investors searching for ways to hedge their bets and financial leaders hoping for new international policies to solve the problems that led to the plunge.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Three at the Gate

title: State Aide Quitting
description: Douglas W. McMinn, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, is expected to offer his resignation today.

title: RYAN'S PASSES RIDDLE ERSATZ DOLPINS
description: Pat Ryan, the 32-year-old Jet quarterback who crossed the picket line Wednesday before the players' strike ended, had not played in four weeks. He had not thrown a pass in pads until Friday, and was suffering from rotator-cuff problems. Despite all of that, Ryan dominated the Miami Dolphins' replacement defense today and led the mostly replacement Jets to a dramatic 37-31 overtime victory in front of 18,249 fans at Giants Stadium.

title: Stage: 'Comedy Faces of '87'
description: IN ''Comedy Faces of '87,'' a downtown comedy troupe, the First Amendment, has compiled a promising experiment in humor that blends the normally exclusive genres of stand-up comedy and group improvisation into a revue. With additional skits and some fine tuning, the company hopes to take the show, which plays Thursdays through Saturdays in its basement theater at 2 Bond Street, to the Village Gate next year.

title: Stocks Resume Sharp Plunge
description: Investors in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Sydney, Australia, dumped their shares today in a shocked reaction to Wall Street's massive sell-off last week.

title: AIDS Is Killing Women Faster, Researchers Say
description: Women with AIDS are sicker and are dying more quickly than men who have the disease, a finding that is shocking and puzzling AIDS researchers.

title: Louise S. Jacobs Is Married to Dr. Steven Laster
description: Louise Simone Jacobs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron S. Jacobs of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Bernard Laster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Laster of Hewlett, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Lord Baltimore Clarion Hotel in Baltimore.

title: Mediocrity Won't Do for America's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Stang Weds A Fellow Lawyer
description: Karen Anne Stang, who will join the Manhattan law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood next month as an associate, and David Glen Smith, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Latham & Watkins, were married yesterday. Judge Laurence C. Stamelman of New Jersey Superior Court officiated at the Shadowbrook restaurant in Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: Arms in an Emergency
description: Despite nearly seven years of the Reagan Administration's military buildup, a senior official says the Defense Department has still not gotten producers of weapons and equipment ready for an emergency.

title: Advertising; More T.W.A. Business For Young & Rubicam
description: Trans World Airlines, which assigned its domestic account to Young & Rubicam in May last year, now follows that with the rest of its business.

title: Dr. Fischer Is Married To Dr. Paul Rosenberg
description: Dr. Helene Fischer and Dr. Paul Rosenberg, who are physicians, were married yesterday at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn., by Rabbi Norman Koch.

title: Roberto Lorca, 49, Director Of Spanish Dance Company
description: Roberto Lorca, a Spanish dancer and founder and director of the Spanish Dance Arts Company, died of an AIDS-related illness on Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 49 years old.

title: Advertising; People
description: * L. (Kay) Schultz was named president of Simmons Major Market Research.

title: Whirlpool Deal in India
description: The Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor, Mich., said Friday that it had formed a joint venture with Sundaram-Clayton Ltd. of Madras, India, to make 100,000 washing machines and 100,000 refrigerators a year starting in 1989. Whirlpool's initial investment of $4.2 million gives it 33 percent ownership of the Indian company, the same as Sundaram-Clayton's share. The remaining stock is to be sold to the public.

title: Jacqueline Flamm Wed
description: Jacqueline Flamm, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Flamm, and Michael Eric Aslett, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Aslett, were married yesterday at the New York home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Flamm. Rabbi Philip Hiat officiated. Mrs. Aslett, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a writer of textbooks on English as a second language. Mr. Aslett, a graduate of the London School of Printing, heads a color printing concern bearing his name in Englewood, N.J. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Seoul Surplus Rise Seen
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States is expected to widen to $8.5 billion in 1987, up from $7.4 billion last year, Korea's Trade Minister said Friday. The Trade Minister, Rha Woong Bae, told Parliament that the country recorded a $6 billion surplus with the United States for the first eight months of this year. These figures suggest that South Korea will face increasing pressure from Washington, which is threatening curbs on Asian imports to the United States.

title: Guinness Case Arraignment
description: A leading British takeover expert facing charges over last year's acquisition of Distillers P.L.C., a whisky maker, by Guinness P.L.C., the brewer, was freed on $:500,000 ($830,000) bail at his arraignment Friday, the police said.

title: U.S. Judges Mark Constitution's Bicentennial
description: Leaving behind their courtrooms and legal offices, Federal judges and lawyers from New York, Connecticut and Vermont spent four days here celebrating the bicentennial of the signing of the Constitution, reviewing recent judicial achievements and swapping court tales over cocktails.

title: AVANT-GARDE FASHION: SEEING IS BELIEVING
description: Jackets are losing their shoulders, bosoms are popping out of deep decolletages and long gloves and hats are returning to fashion. These are some of the trends emerging for next spring and summer from the full schedule of ready-to-wear openings over the weekend. The avant-gardists have dominated runways in the tents at the Louvre and at other locations all over the city. Their clothes will be looked at eagerly by manufacturers from around the world and adapted or reproduced. Attention must be paid. Jean-Paul Gaultier

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Crowd Roars, And So Do Twins
description: They can measure their success in runs, hits and decibels. The noise begins, and the hits come in bunches, and the Twins win, and they return to their clubhouse with poker faces intact.

title: Malaysia Opposes Labels on Palm Oil
description: The Government of Malaysia has begun a campaign to convince American consumers and politicians that edible palm oil is not a proven health hazard.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption Thursday with an article about homelessness in rural New York misidentified the woman holding a child at a welfare motel in New Hampton. She was the child's aunt, Ruth Decker, not his mother, Barbara Decker.

title: Business and the Law; Speech Rights Of Companies
description: VIEW the world of corporate law from the perspective of the First Amendment and it could look dramatically different, a former senior lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union told an audience of Federal judges and lawyers here last Friday.

title: Gioania Journal; Glittering Toy Delights and Does Its Deadly Work
description: Full of wonder and trust, the Alves family and their friends marveled at the mysterious capsule, in no way grasping that the force that made it shine in the dark could bring a slow and painful death.

title: Palestinians Shun Shultz Meeting
description: Palestinian leaders from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip boycotted a scheduled meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today, drawing a rebuke from Mr. Shultz for acting in contradiction to their stated desire to be heard.

title: Tallgrass Technologies Gets a New President
description: The Tallgrass Technologies Corporation, which had dazzling growth with its computer accessory products after it was founded in 1981, has fallen on difficult times in the past several months and has a new president and chief executive, David F. Horton.

title: 2D PRIMARY TO BE HELD FOR CIVIL COURT JUDGE
description: A Democratic primary in which only three votes separated the two candidates will be rerun tomorrow in the Greenwich Village-City Hall area.

title: Just Another Trick In Gladden's Sleeve
description: With full respect and admiration of sorts, Tom Kelly, the Twins' manager, said of the unlikely hero, ''He's a little goofy.''

title: A.T.&T. Deal With Sun Seen
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to announce today that it plans to offer a computer workstation that would use a specialty microprocessor developed by Sun Microsystems Inc., according to sources close to both companies.

title: Rangers Dazed By First Loss
description: For the first time this season, there was bewilderment on the drained faces of the Rangers as they huddled in the visitors' locker room Saturday night and pondered the injustice dealt them by their division rivals.

title: Films Sift Home Life Of Chinese
description: There they are, cascading down the steps of a church in Cambridge, Mass., the bride in white gown and veil, the groom beaming amid a covey of colorful bridesmaids.

title: Advertising; Margeotes, Fertitta Chosen by Fur Vault
description: Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss has become the ad agency for Fred, the Fur Vault, a division of the Fur Vault. Billings are expected to exceed $4 million. The division has eight outlets in the New York area and Washington and is opening another in Scarsdale, N.Y., next month.

title: Typhoon Strikes Guam
description: A typhoon, designated Lynn, knocked out power on Guam and swept across the northern Marianas Islands in the western Pacific early today with winds over 100 miles an hour. Communities were evacuated and some damage was reported but but there were no reports of injuries on Guam or the islands of Rota, Tinian or Saipan, according to Civil Defense officials.

title: Gandhi Urged to Ease Jaffna Assault
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has come under some pressure to avert what military analysts say would be extremely heavy fighting if Indian troops complete their assault on the city of Jaffna, a senior Indian official said today.

title: Which La Guardia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Leslie Ellen Borck Wed to David Jameson
description: Dr. Leslie Ellen Borck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Borck of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Henry Jameson, the son of Hassia Jameson of Dublin and the late Noel Jameson. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Rothman at the Rye Community Synagogue.

title: Advertising; D'Arcy Masius Leaves Pitney Bowes Account
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has resigned the Pitney Bowes corporate account, which it had served since 1964.

title: Saints Kicker Key to Bears' First Loss
description: Florian Kempf joined the New Orleans Saints just in time to knock the Chicago Bears from their perch as the last undefeated team in the National Football League.

title: War Eagle Journal; Trophy-Hungry Throngs in Ozarks
description: For weeks now, hardly a room in a motel, hotel or any of the ubiquitous Ozarks bed-and-breakfast country inns and cottages within 50 miles of here has been available for this weekend.

title: Miss Bean Weds Bookstore Owner
description: Dorothy Ellen Bean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Bean of Bangor, Me., was married yesterday at the Bangor Theological Seminary to William Jackson Lippincott 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lippincott Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Ansley Throckmorton, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Sol Goldman, Major Real-Estate Investor, Dies
description: Sol Goldman, a Brooklyn grocer's son who built one of New York City's great fortunes buying and selling real estate for more than half a century, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, two months after undergoing hip surgery. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Richard Nixon learned it the hard way in 1960. Hubert Humphrey couldn't avoid it in 1968. Now George Bush is getting a taste of the unpleasant truth: it's not easy for a sitting vice president to be elected to the White House.

title: Dance: 'Light, Part 23,' By Kei Takei Troupe
description: SINCE 1969, Kei Takei has been choreographing a cycle of dances collectively known as ''Light.'' The newest instalment, ''Light, Part 23 (Pilgrimage),'' was offered by Moving Earth, Ms. Takei's company, last Wednesday night in the Synod Hall of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Radium Plant in Queens Agrees to Clean Up Site
description: A radium supply company in New York City, cited since 1983 for more than 100 radiation safety violations, has promised State Attorney General Robert Abrams that it will soon empty and decontaminate its plant in Queens.

title: Scalia Was 'Worse' Than Bork
description: Could someone explain how a majority of Senators opposes Judge Robert H. Bork but not one of them last year voted against Antonin Scalia's nomination to the Supreme Court?

title: Kerkorian Pan Am Plan Has Unions in Quandary
description: It has been almost a year since four unions formed a coalition at Pan American World Airways and hired high-priced investment bankers to help them find an investor who would buy a large stake in the company, bring in new management and give the employees a sizable portion of stock in return for concessions.

title: Robertson Upsets G.O.P. Regulars With Attacks on Key Republicans
description: In a weekend swing through the Pacific Northwest, Pat Robertson, who left his television ministry to run for President, has upset Republican Party regulars with attacks on Nancy Reagan, George P. Shultz, Howard H. Baker Jr. and Vice President Bush.

title: Advertising; Bozell Unit President
description: Timothy M. Fenton, 44 years old, will be joining Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Direct as president Monday. He is leaving McCaffrey & McCall, where he has worked since 1976, most recently as executive vice president, creative director of the direct marketing division. B.J.K.&E./ Direct is the 16th-largest direct-response agency in the United States, with billings of $50 million.

title: It's Different Out Here
description: THE first thing you notice upon stepping out of the hotel are the children. Tykes in strollers, toddlers holding onto their parents' hands, teen-agers looking in store windows.

title: World Effort Required To Save Rain Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadians Capture 4th Title
description: The Canadian national rowing team won the featured championship eights race for the fourth consecutive year, leading a north-of-the-border domination of today's finals in Boston's 23d annual Head of the Charles Regatta.

title: Future of Oilers Is Tied to Fans
description: Fan support will be a factor in the Houston Oilers' decision to stay in Houston or move to Jacksonville, Fla., the club's general manager, Ladd Herzeg, said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a dispatch from Paris on the Style page in some copies Saturday about a fashion collection by Christian Lacroix omitted the first paragraph. The article should have begun this way: ''Three months after he captured the attention of the fashion world with his first couture collection, Christian La-croix has scored a second hit. Expanding into ready-to-wear, he presented a spring and summer collection today that is fresh, exuberant and will surely change the way people think about clothes for a long time to come''.

title: G.O.P. Senator Asks Inquiry On Warning to Bork Witness
description: A Republican member of the Senate Judiciary Committee today called for an inquiry into the circumstances in which a law professor changed his mind about testifying in favor of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Flyers Edge Penguins: Dave Brown snapped a tie with a third-period goal to give Philadelphia a 3-2 victory over Pittsburgh last night, stretching the Flyers' home unbeaten streak against the Penguins to 38 games.

title: Europe Backs Subsidy Plan
description: A controversial plan to curtail world food surpluses has won qualified support from the European Community, setting the member countries on a course that conflicts with the United States, diplomats said Friday.

title: Salming Stays Out Despite Apology
description: Borje Salming did not show up at Maple Leaf Gardens when the Leafs skated this morning despite a public apology from Harold Ballard, the team's owner, that opened the door for the veteran defenseman's return after a two-game absence.

title: This Welfare Bill Is No Sham
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan spent the first half of this year tailoring a welfare reform bill to win the widest possible support in the Senate. Now he's catching flak from welfare advocates in his home state who call the bill a ''sham reform'' -short on money and benefits and long on burdensome requirements.

title: Kirkpatrick Vows to Decide Soon on '88 Race
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former Ambassador to the United Nations, said here Saturday night that she would decide whether to run for President before the first nationally televised debate among the Republican contenders on Oct. 28.

title: Cardinals Don't Like What They Hear
description: Baseball's first indoor World Series was so loud, as advertised, that the St. Louis Cardinals came up with equipment changes to shut out the sounds of the nonstop cheering, chanting and whistling of the Metrodome crowds of 55,000-plus.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about the deregulation of the French financial markets misidentified the owner of James Capel & Company, the London-based brokerage house. It is the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.

title: Teacher Quality Becomes Top School Issue
description: Two recent steps aimed at sending better-prepared teachers into public-school classrooms show that teacher quality has become the overriding issue in efforts to improve American public schools. Earlier this month, a City University of New

title: Hospital Chief's Efforts Spur a Threat
description: There are those who believe that Thomas Deiker has accomplished a lot as head of New Mexico's state hospital for the mentally ill and disabled, and there are those who hate him for the changes he has wrought.

title: Archbishop Donnellan Of Atlanta Dies at 73
description: Archbishop Thomas Andrew Donnellan, who led the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta for 19 years, died Thursday. The prelate, who was 73 years old, had suffered a stroke May 1.

title: Utah Oil Refinery Plan
description: Officials of the United States Petroleum Corporation have announced plans to build a $100 million oil products refinery here. The company's president, Gene Blendermann, a retired Exxon Corporation executive, said the plant would process ''waxy crude'' oil from eastern Utah's Bluebell and Altamont fields. Those fields were discovered and developed in the mid-1970's.

title: Navratilova Edges Evert in Brief Final
description: Martina Navratilova celebrated her 31st birthday today with a 7-5, 6-1 victory over Chris Evert in the final of the Virginia Slims women's tournament.

title: Top Aid in Assembly Resigns Post
description: Three days after he shoved a newspaper reporter to the ground, Norman Adler, the top adviser to the New York State Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, resigned yesterday.

title: AN OLD HAND FOR UNESCO'S HELM
description: When Unesco's executive board nominated Federico Mayor Zaragoza to be the next Director General, it chose someone who was familiar with the organization.

title: Blues: Jack Johnson
description: JACK JOHNSON, Frank Frost and Sam Carr, who made their first New York appearance at the Lone Star Cafe on Wednesday and Thursday, have been playing blues in the Mississippi Delta for more than 25 years. They recorded for Southern record labels in the 60's as Frank Frost and the Nighthawks, and more recently for the Chicago-based Earwig label as the Jelly Roll Kings. Mr. Frost, who plays piano, guitar and harmonica, more recently made a brief appearance in the film ''Crossroads,'' and Mr. Johnson, a singer and guitarist, has recorded an album of his own for Earwig. But mostly, these musicians play in the Delta.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is there any record for a World Series game that surpasses the major league one for a regular-season game?

title: Girl's Rescue Bolsters Texas City's Pride
description: The rescue would have been dramatic enough anywhere. But, played out in this struggling oil town with a grimy cast of hundreds, it had the tightly scripted feel of fiction. If ever a rescue effort took place at an appropriate time in an appropriate place it was here.

title: A Weaker Market for Coolers
description: Wine and malt coolers, the fruit and alcohol concoctions that just a few years ago were hailed as the savior of the alcoholic beverage industry, have hit a plateau. It seems that everyone has seen their advertising and tried them, but far fewer people are drinking them than the industry had predicted.

title: Avenging Spirit of the 60's
description: The last time chic was a skirt that measured 21 inches from waistband to hem, Emma Peel and John Steed of ''The Avengers'' fought crime in England the way David and Maddie of ''Moonlighting'' fight crime in California. Mr. Steed and Mrs. Peel were cool enough to freeze water, however; they never got horizontal; and Emma had a judo kick that could stop a mule. Her wardrobe was a monument to the British fashion industry in the 60's.

title: W. PUTNAM LIVINGSTON
description: W. Putnam Livingston, a retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company and a leader in the use of computers in the banking industry, died of Alzheimer's disease Friday at a nursing home in Keene, N.H., where he was a longtime resident. He was 82 years old.

title: Italy to Privatize Elite Bank
description: Since Italy rebuilt after World War II, Mediobanca, the nation's most powerful merchant bank, has been known as ''il salotto buono,'' the good salon. Although the Government has held a controlling interest in the bank, its board room has served as a place for Italy's top capitalists to work out deals and settle disputes among themselves.

title: Advertising; Account
description: The Advertising Council to Lowe Marschalk for the public service campaign for United Way.

title: INSIDE
description: Baptist Tensions Rising Fundamentalists, who have controlled the Southern Baptist Conventin for eight years, are seeking power at seminaries and colleges. Page A18. Nancy Reagan on the Mend Doctors said tests of tissue removed in breast cancer surgery showed no spread of the malignancy and called her prognosis excellent. Page A21. Twins Easy Winners Again The Minnesota Twins took a lead of two games to none in the World Series by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-4, SportsMonday, page C1.

title: Kuwait Is Said to Seek An Anti-Missile Defense
description: Kuwait sought Western help today to acquire a new anti-missile defense system as salvage workers confirmed that it was an Iranian Silkworm missile that blasted an American-registered tanker there on Friday.

title: Sikkim No Model
description: To the Editor:

title: How Graham Manages In a New Era of Dance
description: Martha Graham, a vital and busy force in American modern dance at the age of 93, continues to choreograph and oversee the running of her 32-member company, one of the world's leading dance troupes and currently performing at the City Center. Not much happens in the company's daily activities that escapes her notice. But American dance has changed since the days when Miss Graham - as well as Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor - presided over small companies that existed on shoestring budgets and one-night stands.

title: Koreans Hold Rally At Precinct
description: More than 300 chanting and marching demonstrators rallied outside an East Side police station house last night, protesting what they termed police brutality against the Asian community and calling for the dismissal of two officers charged with beating a 20-year-old Queens man last month after he was stopped as a traffic violator.

title: UNESCO'S BOARD VOTES TO SUPPORT SPANIARD IN POST
description: Unesco's executive board voted today to nominate Federico Mayor Zaragoza of Spain to be the organization's next director general after Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, the incumbent, announced his withdrawal from the race.

title: Hundreds Rally Against Towers At Coliseum Site
description: More than 800 people formed a line through Central Park yesterday, opening black umbrellas on cue in a symbolic protest of the shadows that would be cast at certain times in the winter by the huge office towers planned on Columbus Circle.

title: Taylor Is Frustrated by Loss
description: Lawrence Taylor had just played his first football game in a month. He had disrupted the Buffalo Bills' offense, had forced their passer to throw quickly and had overcome the Bills' apparent efforts to disrupt his concentration.

title: Relationships; Silence May Not Be Golden
description: ANNA FERRARA's chief complaint about her husband, Joseph, was that he refused to talk to her in the morning.

title: Bush's Tax Cut Idea Enlivens Debate
description: Vice President Bush's proposal for a major cut in taxes on capital gains has provided powerful political ammunition for his 1988 Presidential rivals in the Democratic Party and, potentially, for some in his own party as well.

title: Twins Roll Toward St. Louis With a 2-0 Lead
description: When the season finally moved into October, the Minnesota Twins were still in first place and still defying the critics who called them unworthy of an appearance in the postseason. But in a triumphant playoff and a stunning start to the 84th World Series, they have become baseball's darlings.

title: Indictment Over Hot Suits Has Hispanic Miami Fuming
description: From the beginning months ago, the affair was known as the Hot Suit Case.

title: Baby Without Brain Kept Alive to Give Heart
description: In a radical departure from standard medical practice, doctors in Canada last week kept alive a baby born without most of her brain so that her heart might be salvaged for a transplant operation.

title: Higher Rates For Mortgages
description: Mortgage rates have jumped to the highest level since November 1985, with the average rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate home loan climbing to 11.58 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said Friday.

title: How It Happened; Cardinals Off Stride
description: The statistics are so stark they scream off the page as loud as the Metrodome fans scream from the stands: Vince Coleman, Ozzie Smith and Tom Herr, the first three batters in the St. Louis batting order, the people who generate the Cardinals' offense, have two hits in 24 times at bat and a .083 batting average in the World Series.

title: Plunge Imperils Privatizing
description: Huge declines on the London and Paris stock markets today, touched off by Wall Street's plunge, are threatening British and French plans to sell state-owned companies, analysts said.

title: TRINOVA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $86.3 million from discontinued operations.

title: Democrats Charge F.E.C. Inaction In Complaint Against Fund-Raiser
description: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has filed suit against the Federal Election Commission, charging that it violated the law by not acting on the committee's complaint against a conservative fund-raiser who figures in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Day to Remember In Financial District
description: From the trading floors of the big brokerage firms to the stock exchanges to the shoeshine stands in the heart of the financial district, it was clear that yesterday would be a day etched in people's memories for years to come.

title: LSB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: Robert M. Young, Economist With Primerica Corporation
description: Robert Merriman Young, director of economic services at the Primerica Corporation, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan of complications from AIDS. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Russell Adjusts Historic Resume
description: William Felton Russell, at the age of 53, has embarked on a new phase of an already historic career. He is head coach of the Sacramento Kings, and he will eventually become president of the club.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROTO-ROOTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TMK-UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $20,000 for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a capital gain of $788,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $587,000 and $11,506,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $200,000 from the repurchase of long- term debt. c-Net income

title: Ration-Card Tactic in Nicaragua Doubted
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST TENNESSE NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KANSAS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,918,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $4,011,000 for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a loss from extinguishment of debt of $7,903,000 and a capital gain of $12,767,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $502,000 and $17,638,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: BUSH SEEN TAKING MODERATE STANCE
description: Vice President Bush, in an uncharacteristic political gamble, has begun to move toward the political center in the hope of capturing the Republican nomination, aides and other analysts say.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today: Oct. 20, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee

title: MENTOR GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun Wins Prestige With A.T.&T. Deal
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., a Silicon Valley computer company, got a prestigious boost yesterday when it reached agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to share technology. For the five-year-old company's young founders, the deal is only the latest step in a sustained climb toward recognition as a leading technology company.

title: The White Rat Is Fiddling
description: EARLIER this season, Whitey Herzog, the St. Louis Cardinals' manager, told a story about being called to the office of Augie Busch, the octogenarian owner of the Cardinals.

title: Costume Jewelry: Closer to the Real Thing
description: It isn't fake anything. It's real costume jewelry. And it's being worn -without apology - by women of every age and financial bracket. A teen-ager picks up a vintage rhinestone brooch in a thrift shop, and her grandmother sports a copy of the Duchess of Windsor's jeweled flamingo pin. Even Brooke Astor has been known to wear bogus gems. It's all in the name of fashion, so much so that ''costume jewelry'' is more and more referred to as ''fashion jewelry.''

title: Iranian Pledges a 'Crushing Blow' Against U.S. to Avenge the Raid
description: Iran vowed today to deliver a ''crushing blow'' against the United States in revenge for the raids on its offshore platforms in the Persian Gulf.

title: Fire Alarm on Wall Street
description: With stock prices down 22 percent in a single day and foreign investors racing for the exits, Oct. 19, 1987, ranks by most measures as the worst day in Wall Street's history.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $79,055,000. The company said year-ago results are restated due to reclassification of certain sales to other utilities. The extraordinary loss reflects charges of $12,742,000 from provision for loss on investment in a plant, and a $66,313,000 write-off of a portion of its investment in the Zimmer Nuclear plant.

title: Replacements End Season
description: The Washington Redskins closed out the third and final week of the replacement season by beating the Dallas Cowboys, 13-7, tonight on Obed Ariri's two field goals and Ted Wilson's 16-yard run.

title: SYMBION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Rumrill-Hoyt Making Executive Changes
description: Rumrill-Hoyt of Rochester, a Saatchi & Saatchi company, has had executive movement in its upper reaches. Richard D. Thomson, 51 years old, the chief executive, has moved from the president's office to the vacant chairman's chair, allowing Nicholas J. Orloff, 55, to assume the role of president. He will also be chief operating officer.

title: King Asks Minister to Form New Government in Belgium
description: King Baudouin accepted Prime Minister Wilfried Martens's resignation today and asked him to form a new government to amend the Constitution to resolve a 150-year-old language dispute. Mr. Martens said he would do so. The center-right coalition offered its resignation Thursday because of the squabble between Belgium's Flemish people, who speak Flemish, and the Walloons, who speak French.

title: CONSTAR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,000 and $58,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * General Automotive Specialty Co., North Brunswick, N.J., to Adler Schwartz for the introduction of Creditcard Keys, which consists of a set of spare keys hinged to a thin, cardlike backing.

title: Presbyterian Hospital Turns to Local Doctors
description: Beginning today, Presbyterian Hospital will try to prove that a world-famous medical center can emerge from its citadel and become a local community hospital serving poor neighborhoods in upper Manhattan.

title: Morgan Reports 3.6% Gain in Profit
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, helped by declines in its provisions for credit losses and in income taxes, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings edged up 3.6 percent.

title: Shultz Says Explanatory Note Was Relayed to Iran on Raid
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had sent a message to Iran explaining the attack on an Iranian installation in the Persian Gulf and repeating the American commitment to maintaining freedom of navigation there.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Both year-ago periods' results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Colonial Bancorp Inc. and the adoption of the FASB's statement on pension accounting.

title: Japanese Stocks Plummet
description: The Tokyo stock market suffered record losses today and the Hong Kong market suspended trading for the week as Asian investors reacted in fright to the historic collapse on Wall Street.

title: Cancer Help From the Sea
description: Two lowly marine organisms are the source of new drugs with promising anticancer activity.

title: Ration-Card Tactic in Nicaragua Doubted; Tinkering With Dollar Won't Close Trade Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERTAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Man in the News; A 'Step-by-Step' Leader for Japan: Noboru Takeshita
description: In Japan's feudal days, Noboru Takeshita once recalled, privileged people were carried on their journeys upon a litter. Naturally, there were the less fortunate who had to bear the litter, he said. And then there those whose lot in life was to make the straw sandals that the litter-bearers wore.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months includes results of Gama Foods division, acquired in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Depleted Islanders
description: When the Islanders play Calgary tonight at Nassau Coliseum they will probably be without the services of two right wings, Mikko Makela, who suffered a sprained right wrist in Saturday's 4-3 loss to the Flyers, and Alan Kerr, who has the flu. Both missed practice yesterday. Regardless of their status, Coach Terry Simpson said that he definitely would play Brad Lauer, a wing, and Ken Leiter, a defenseman, neither of whom have played in the team's first four games. Bill Smith, who started the season opener, is likely to get his second start in goal. ''The biggest thing is to realize we got off our game plan Saturday night,'' Simpson said. ''We stopped dumping the puck in and mucking it out and tried to be too fancy.''

title: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3 million and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $79 million. c-Includes a gain of $15 million for the quarter and the 9 months includes income of $44 million both from discontinued operations. The latest third quarter net includes an after-tax gain of $82 million relating to an increase in equity of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc., and the 9-month net includes an after-tax gain of $73 million on the sale of the company's remaining interest in Henley Group Inc. and other related transactions and an after-tax loss of $30 million relating to the repurchase of high-coupon bonds. Year-ago 9-month net includes an after-tax gain of $43 million related to the reversion of surplus pension funds.

title: ABI AMER BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mixed Results At 2 Brokers
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 50.6 percent in the third quarter, but the Paine Webber Group Inc. said its quarterly earnings fell 29.9 percent.

title: Killing Bucks Increases the Deer Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Retrial Granted in Suit On AIDS Misdiagnosis
description: A judge has granted a new trial in a civil case for a woman who contends her doctor misdiagnosed her as suffering from asthma when she had pneumonia stemming from AIDS.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $3.7 million of investment tax credits. c-After an after-tax charge of $21.2 million for the cost of reducing operations and implementing productivity improvements programs at the Great Northern paper division in Maine, and includes $8.1 million of investment tax credits. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in May. The latest quarter includes the newly acquired Nekoosa packaging division for the month of September.

title: Advertising; Naugles Mexican Food To Dailey & Associates
description: Dailey & Associates in Los Angeles has won the Naugles Mexican fast-food account after a four-way competition. The budget is $8 million. The other contenders, also in Los Angeles, included Grey, Campbell & Wagman and the incumbent, D.D.B.

title: Meanwhile, in Iowa ...
description: Over the weekend, Iowa City, a calm riverside town, was mostly interested in how Nancy Reagan was doing. Iowans talked politics if the foreigners insisted. But they said hog prices and farm foreclosures were more important than caucuses.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary loss of $1,482,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: IC Plans a Buyback And an Acquisition
description: IC Industries said today that it plans to buy back between $500 million and $1 billion of its common stock and spend as much as $3 billion to acquire a company in the consumer goods and services industry. To help finance a purchase, IC said it might sell the Pneumo-Abex Corporation, its aerospace and military products subsidiary.

title: Laudner Reflects On Sudden Success
description: In the early days of the postseason, Tim Laudner allowed himself to talk easily about a summer that had been, for the most part, an untimely disaster.

title: 2 Groups in NBC Union Block Contract Accord
description: A majority of NBC's 2,800 striking workers have voted to accept a company proposal, but two small dissident units of the striking union rejected the network's proposed contract, delaying a final resolution of the strike.

title: LIN BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $31,987,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $9,527,000 for the quarter and $10,775,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a credit of $2.4 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Amounts given for discontinued operations in all periods reflect income of operations and gains on sales of discontinued paging and radio businesses.

title: DOCTORS EXAMINE GIRL'S FOOT INJURY
description: Doctors inspected, cleaned and tested Jessica McClure's damaged right foot in exploratory surgery today and said it has recuperated somewhat from the stress of two and a half days in a cramped well.

title: What if Iran Attacks Again?
description: Even an armada of American and allied ships in the Persian Gulf has not deterred Iranian attacks, as the Reagan Administration hoped. And it would be unwise to assume that yesterday's U.S. raid on Iranian oil platforms will end the matter. On the contrary, this well-calibrated response to Iran's missile attack on two tankers in Kuwaiti waters prompts essential questions: What risks is the United States prepared to face in the gulf and is it prepared to take leadership?

title: CHEMICAL WASTE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.&P. Ends Offer
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said that it had withdrawn its offer to buy Delchamps Inc. for about $175 million, or $27 a share. The offer was made earlier this month. The company withdrew the offer because Delchamps did not respond favorably to it and because of market conditions, said Michael Rourke, vice president of A.&P.

title: Small Firms Seen As Most Vulnerable
description: As Wall Street firms struggled to sort out how yesterday's historic drop will affect them, some analysts expressed fears that smaller and poorly capitalized firms might find the going especially rough.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Martin Marietta said earnings for the first three quarters of 1986 were restated to reflect an accounting change, increasing share earnings by 4 cents in each quarter.

title: 'The Ring of Truth,' On Ways of Perception
description: HOW do we know what we know? Specifically, how does science know? When does hypothesis become fact because it has the ring of truth? In part, as Philip Morrison cheerfully explains in a six-part series, it happens when instruments look, measure and weigh. The series, beginning on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, examines how we examine. It is called ''The Ring of Truth.''

title: Business and Health; Overpayments On H.M.O.'s
description: IN the 1970's, new health maintenance organizations boasted that they could provide medical care for up to 40 percent less than traditional insurance plans. The savings would be enormous, H.M.O. officials assured benefit managers like Bruce I. Taylor of the GTE Corporation.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $105,000 for the quarter and $195,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months' losses are attributed to an addition to loan loss reserves of $3.7 million.

CLEVELAND (AFC) - Retained Keith Bosley and Darryl Haley, offensive linemen; Alex Carter, Mike Rusinek and Darryl Sims, defensive linemen; Tim Crawford, David Grayson, Nick Miller and Cliff Hanneman, linebackers; Major Everett, George Swarn and Larry Mason, running backs; Perry Kemp and Remi Watson, wide receivers; Bill Robinson, defensive back; Derek Tennell, tight end, and Enis Jackson, cornerback, from their replacement roster. Placed Lavale Thomas and Kevin Willhite, running backs; Jeff Drost, offensive tackle; Don King and Tony Elliott, defensive backs, and Don Summers, tight end, on injured reserve. Placed Hoby Brenner, tight end, on injured reserve.

title: ANDOVER TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Jacqueline du Pre, Noted Cellist, Is Dead at 42
description: Jacqueline du Pre, a brilliant and charismatic English cellist whose career was cut short by multiple sclerosis, died last night in London, her concert managers said. She was 42 years old.

title: Put the U.N. Into the Persian Gulf
description: We proposed on this page 104 days ago that the United Nations undertake the task of flagging, inspecting and escorting commercial vessels in the Persian Gulf. A lot has happened since then.

title: Worldwide Selling
description: Investors throughout Europe and Asia dumped shares today in a worldwide wave of distress selling.

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $2,395,000, or 87 cents a share, resulting from the sale through an initial public offering of a 25 percent interest in Valcom Inc. reduced by a charge associated with the decision to restructure the Youngstown, Ohio, tubing operations.

title: ERIE LACKAWANNA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Films About Blacklist: Hollywood's Bad Old Days
description: The blacklisting that demoralized Hollywood during the 1950's was a taboo subject for three decades. Now Hollywood is spotlighting the McCarthy era and the redbaiting that barred hundreds of producers, directors, writers, actors and technicians from working in the industry.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1986 amounts have been restated to reflect the company's early adoption of FASB Statement No. 91.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net income in the year-ago period includes an after-tax gain of $3,818,000 from the conversion of the company's pension plan to a defined contribution plan.

title: INDIA REPORTS GAIN IN SRI LANKA DRIVE
description: India said tonight that its troops had broken into the center of the Sri Lankan city of Jaffna after a 10-day military campaign against ethnic Tamil rebels it had pledged to disarm.

title: F.D.A. Allows Clinical Testing For AIDS Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has cleared the way for limited clinical trials of ribavirin, a drug its developer believes will help delay the onset of AIDS in people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Bridge: U.S. and Britain Take Lead In World Open Team Battles
description: Two long semifinal battles, each of 160 deals, began here this afternoon in the World Open Team Championships. After 48 deals in the fight for the Bermuda Bowl, the United States led Taiwan by 46 international match points while Britain led Sweden by 28.

title: 102 Dead as Indonesia Trains Hit
description: A train packed with rush-hour commuters crashed head-on into another train south of Jakarta today, killing 102 people and injuring about 300, the authorities said.

title: Tandem Offers Library System
description: Tandem Computers Inc. today introduced its first optical storage product, an optical disk library system for use with the company's minicomputer systems.

title: Market Place; Foreign Views Of U.S. Stocks
description: FOREIGNERS have consistently poured money into Wall Street's long-running bull market, but in yesterday's devastating session, many overseas investors sold actively.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The latest quarter and year results include pre-tax restructuring provisions of $4.2 million, and the prior year results include pre-tax restructuring provisions of $22.5 million.

title: Tarpley Tells of Woes
description: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks' forward, confirmed yesterday that he had been treated for cocaine and alcohol problems over the summer and said that he was having problems with his aftercare program. After he appeared late for a Sunday exhibition game with the Boston Celtics - and did not play - Tarpley talked about his problems in a meeting with Rick Sund, the vice president for basketball operations, and General Manager Norm Sonju. ''I was beginning to slip away from my aftercare duties,'' Tarpley said in a news conference yesterday. He remains with the team.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,033,000 for the quarter and $27,935,000 for the 9 months.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a one- time gain of $3,770,000 from an asset sale. The company said that disregarding the one-time gain in the year-ago third quarter, results for the latest quarter were up because of larger income from the coal business, lower headquarters expense and lower income taxes.

title: Limits on Student Press
description: SCHOOL administrators and student editors faced each other last week before the Supreme Court as a school board defended a principal's right to censor the student newspaper.

title: Korean Trade Forecast
description: Big demand for South Korea's low-priced cars and electronic goods should result in a trade surplus this year of around $10 billion, far above a ceiling set in June, the country's national press agency, Yonhap, predicted today. Bank of Korea officials would neither confirm nor deny the forecast, saying only that the bank would issue its own figures later this week.

title: GAF Buyout Group Wavers
description: Almost overshadowed by the stock market collapse, the takeover business also shook violently yesterday as Samuel J. Heyman, chairman of the GAF Corporation, said that, because of rising loan costs, he was reconsidering a $2.3 billion offer to buy the chemical company.

title: POVERTY IS LINKED TO HARM TO LAND
description: Two prominent leaders from different parts of the developing world warned today that poverty is encouraging their people to destroy the natural environment.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; A Secret Briefing
description: The briefing of Congressional leaders Sunday night on how the United States would retaliate against Iran was considered so sensitive that even after television news reports showed the leaders entering the White House, Reagan Administration officials refused to confirm that the meeting was taking place.

title: J. Walter Severinghaus, 81, Former Architect
description: J. Walter Severinghaus, an architect who played a key role in building the practice of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and such structures as One Chase Manhattan Plaza, died Friday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., after a year-long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: 'ARTIFACT' IS FOUND TO BE AN UNUSUAL METEORITE
description: A rock stored in a farmer's collection of Indian artifacts for 11 years is a 4.5 billion-year-old meteorite that could provide new information on how the solar system developed, scientists announced today.

title: Times Net Up 22.1%
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter rose 22.1 percent as revenues increased by 9.8 percent.

title: ROCHESTER TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rangers Give Up Lead Again
description: The Washington Capitals, who fancy themselves slow starters, put on a decisive finish last night by scoring four straight goals, the last into a vacant net, to defeat the Rangers, 4-2, at the Garden.

title: Advice for Shoppers
description: THE handwritten letters arrive by the fistful. ''Dear Mr. Computer Know-It-All,'' they invariably plead, ''please help. My (wife, husband, daughter, son, pet cockatoo, etc.) is or wants to be a writer and I want to buy (him, her, it) a computer for word processing for Christmas. But what do I buy (him, her, it)? I don't want to spend a lot of money. Sincerely yours, Et Cetera. P.S., Your column isn't as funny as it used to be.''

title: ANCHOR GLASS CONTAINER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $2,204,000 from the reversion of pension assets. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: COMMUNITY BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Article 778087 -- No Title
description: Stanford University has been given $6 million by Cecil H. Green, a co-founder of Texas Instruments, to help build a new earth sciences building. The gift by Mr. Green, who is 87 years old, is his second $6 million donation to the university. The first helped build an addition to the main library, which now bears his name.

title: Judge Rules School Can Open As Cleanup of Asbestos Ends
description: Clara Barton High School in Brooklyn can open to students tomorrow for the first time this school year because an asbestos cleanup has been completed, a judge has ruled.

title: BANKVERMONT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Smalley's Thrill Has Arrived
description: ''Did I tell you what happened at the play? We were at the back of the theater, standing there in the dark; all of a sudden I feel one of 'em tug my sleeve, whispers, 'Trudy, look.' I said, 'Yeah, goose bumps. You definitely got goose bumps. You really like the play that much?' They said it wasn't the play gave 'em goose bumps, it was the audience.''

title: Caesars Stake Cut
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, has reduced his stake in Caesars World Inc. to 16 percent, from 17.4 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff said that he continued to hold all shares acquired by him ''principally for investment purposes.'' Mr. Sosnoff, whose earlier offer to purchase Caesars World was defeated, has criticized the company's plan to buy back 11 million of its shares for prices ranging from $29.50 to $34 a share. On Oct. 15 and Oct. 16, Mr. Sosnoff sold 338,975 Caesars World shares for prices ranging from $22.50 to $25.25 a share.

title: SAN JUAN FIBERGLASS POOLS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Twins' Erratic Play Could Help Cards
description: After watching the Minnesota Twins maul the St. Louis Cardinals in the first two games of the World Series, John Tudor turned realistic. ''They've averaged more than five runs a game in the playoffs and the World Series,'' he said. ''If they score five runs tomorrow, they should be able to beat me.''

title: Sottomarina Journal; The Waters, Befouled, 'Cry Out for Vengeance'
description: All summer long this year the Adriatic was hot and languid and getting sicker by the day. Eventually, one little part of the sea almost died when pollutants dumped by the Po River helped kill nearly all the fish in an area of nearly 400 square miles.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects a charge of $4.2 million representing amortization of the company's capital investment in Bonneville Exchange Power.

title: Inquiries Begun on Warning to Pro-Bork Witness
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee and the Justice Department today began separate inquiries into whether potential witnesses supporting the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork were harassed by the judge's opponents.

title: Iraqi Oil Output High
description: Iraq is pumping 2.7 million barrels of oil a day, nearly double its nominal OPEC quota, an oil publication reported today. The Middle East Economic Survey said Iraq gave the figure to a quota-discipline ministerial committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that visited Baghdad last week. The committee was established last June mainly to help reintegrate Iraq into the OPEC fold, a move that could stabilize production and price agreements next year.

title: New York Revamps Social Studies
description: New York State has begun phasing in a revamped social studies program that stresses 20th-century American history at the high school level and abandons the topical methods of the 1970's in favor of a more chronological approach.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Financial Corp. Reports a Loss
description: The Financial Corporation of America today reported a $75.8 million loss in the third quarter, citing a $70 million addition to reserves for problem loans.

title: Man Arrested in Slaying
description: A 25-year-old man was ordered held without bail today after he allegedly strangled his mother to death, then barricaded himself in his house for almost six hours. The man, Robert Singleton, was charged with murder and separate assault counts related to attacks on police officers who tried to arrest him. He was arrested Sunday night when officers stormed his bedroom.

title: U.S. May Further Ease Trade Curbs on Japan
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to announce shortly a further partial lifting of trade sanctions against Japan that were levied last April after Tokyo failed to comply with a semiconductor agreement.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; 'Star Wars,' a Sequel?
description: The movie ''Star Wars'' was a smash hit, and now some imitators in military circles are hoping that some of the success will rub off on their production, which is entitled somewhat less snappily, ''S.D.I.: A Prospect for Peace.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Army's New Spokesman
description: When the United States Army was looking for a ''fine soldier'' with great speaking ability to be its chief spokesman, it turned to Brig. Gen. Patrick H. Brady.

title: PARADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $255,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $169,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary gains of $50,000 for the quarter and $393,000 for the 9 months.

title: The Stage: 'Anything Goes'
description: FORGET about the Colosseum, the Louvre museum, a melody from a symphony by Strauss - Patti LuPone is the top. As Reno Sweeney, the sassy nightclub singer in the Lincoln Center revival of ''Anything Goes,'' Ms. LuPone has her first sensational New York role since ''Evita'' in 1979, and, given that Cole Porter is the evening's buoyant guiding spirit, you don't have to fear that she'll succumb to death scenes in the second act.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: TV Reviews; 2 Specials For Young Audiences
description: TWO afternoon specials for young audiences this week are dealing with the subject of growing up, well, different.

title: Deaver Jury Selection Starts; Panel Is Questioned in Public
description: Jury selection began today in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver as the Supreme Court rejected the former White House aide's request to allow lawyers in the case to question prospective jurors in private.

title: EVERGREEN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ryan Still an Astro
description: Nolan Ryan will return to the Houston Astros in 1988 after a bizarre season in which he lost twice as many games as he won (8-16), but led the majors with 270 strikeouts and tied the Toronto Blue Jays' Jimmy Key for the lead in earned run average with a 2.76 figure. The 40-year-old right-handed fastball pitcher, who is baseball's career strikeout leader with 4,547 in 21 years, had his option picked up after meeting Friday with Dick Wagner, the Houston general manager. ''Everyone associated with the Astros is pleased that Nolan will be a member of the Astros in 1988,'' said Wagner, who is leaving the team on Friday after being at odds with the manager, Hal Lanier. The terms of Ryan's contract were not disclosed.
