title: 604 MILLION VOLUME NEARLY DOUBLES RECORD
description: Stock market prices plunged in a tumultuous wave of selling yesterday, giving Wall Street its worst day in history and raising fears of a recession.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After charges of $1,576,501 for the quarter and $8,609,168 for the year both for disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,195,739 and $4,357,389 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the loss for fiscal 1987 is after a pre-tax provision of $15 million for inventory valuation allowance.

title: NEW SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1987
description: The Market Plunge D32-34 In a collapse that rippled worldwide, the stock market suffered its worst reverse in history. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged a record 508.00 points, raising fears of an economic recession. Page A1 Most Americans are likely to be hurt by the dramatic decline in stock values, even those who own no stock at all, unless the market bounces back quickly and substantially, economists say. The biggest threat may be psychological. A1 News analysis: No Great Depression is imminent, many economists say, citing safeguards that are in place, including more Government responsibility, and that would prevent the kind of economic morass that followed the 1929 crash. A1 A global wave of panic selling dominated financial markets following Wall Street's sharp drop and comments from White House officials that Washington may let the dollar fall. Investors throughout Europe and Asia dumped shares. D33 News analysis: Shouts of panic on Wall Street echoed only faintly in the corridors of the Reagan Administration. Few people in official Washington seemed to have any prescription to offer demoralized investors. D32 Agitation stalked the streets in New York City's financial district, as strangers stopped each other to inquire about the market, traders lost their sense of humor and pandemonium reigned on the floor of the stock exchange. D1 Investors watched stock prices dive and wondered what was happening as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 508 points. Many wondered if there was anything they could do to help themselves; for some, it was too late. D1 President Reagan did not consider ordering a halt to trading as he watched today's stock market plunge, despite consultations with financial experts and White House advisers, his spokesman said. D32 International A3-14 U.S. forces struck back at Iran for attacks on American-registered vessels and other Persian Gulf shipping by blasting two connected offshore platforms that American officials said were used as a base for Iranian gunboats. A1 Iran promised a 'crushing blow' against the United States in revenge for the American attack, saying Washington was embroiled in a full-fledged war with Iran. A11 President Reagan was 'buoyant,' according to his aides, acting ''upbeat'' and ''bouncy'' and cracking jokes despite the plummeting stock market, his wife's illness and the military action in the Persian Gulf. A11 Japan's next Prime Minister is virtually certain to be Noboru Takeshita. The former Finance Minister, and a master of political compromise, was designated by the incumbent, Yasuhiro Nakasone, to be his successor. A3 Man in the News: Noboru Takeshita, the former Finance Minister nominated to be Japan's next Prime Minister, has described himself in parable form as hard-working, little noticed, uncomplaining and absolutely indispensible. A3 Scottomarina journal: Water

title: Upheaval in the Financial World: Investors' Hopes Sink As Stocks Slip
description: ''It's a crash - there's no other word to describe what's happening today,'' Errol Rothschild said as he stood in his broker's office in Bal Harbour, Fla., watching stock prices pass by in a continuous stream. ''Something's going on in the world that we don't know about. Otherwise this couldn't be happening.'' Across the country, people of all ages turned to ticker tapes, to television sets, to any source of news, as they tried to figure out what really was happening in the stock market. How deep would it fall? Would they plunge with it, to a point so low that they could never bounce back? And, perhaps most important at this stage, was there anything they could do to help themselves?

title: Media General Stake Bought
description: In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Giant Group Ltd. said today that it had purchased a 9.8 percent stake in Media General Inc. for $108.3 million and that it might seek control of the Richmond-based newspaper and broadcasting concern. Later, Reuters reported that

title: CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
NeoRx, Genentech Plan Joint Product
description: The NeoRx Corporation, a privately held biotechnology company based in Seattle, said it had entered an agreement with Genentech Inc. to develop a product that can be injected into the body for the purpose of imaging blood clots. Under the terms of the agreement, each company would manufacture its own proprietary component of the product, with Genentech responsible for marketing and NeoRx receiving a royalty on sales.

title: East Moline Journal; Friday Night High, in the Bleachers
description: ''Go!'' shouted an old man in the bleachers, dressed in the orange and black of his high school team. ''Go! Go! Go!''

description: b-Net income

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter. The company said third quarter results included $5.9 million of non- recurring after tax charges due almost entirely to the company's recent buyout of its Tilden Mine debt obligations from eight institutional lenders. The latest 9-month includes several non-recurring charges: a $23.7 million pre-tax charge in the second quarter of 1987 to reduce the carrying value of the company's 17 land drilling rigs; a $1.2 million pre-tax gain in the second quarter on the sale of the company's uranium reserves. Year-ago 9-month includes a $20.6 million pre-tax gain in the first quarter of 1986 on the sale of the company's iron ore interest in Western Australia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1987
description: THE STOCK MARKET PLUNGE The stock market had its worst day in history. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged an estimated 508 points, to 1,738.74, on trading so heavy that reporting was delayed for hours. More than 604 million shares changed hands, dwarfing Friday's record of 338.5 million shares, and the decline of 22.6 percent was far greater than the drop of 12.82 percent on Black Monday in 1929, which ignited the Great Depression. The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday's debacle was ''the nearest thing to a meltdown that I ever want to see.'' [ Page A1. ] The Tokyo stock market appeared headed for a record one-day drop today, and the Hong Kong market suspended trading for the week. [ D1. ] In United States exchanges, computers strained under a deluge of trading that their designers did not expect until the early 1990's. [ D34. ] The record plunge was fed in part by huge sales of shares in stock-oriented mutual funds, as investors switched their money into money market funds, bonds and gold. [ D33. ] Most Americans are likely to be hurt by the stock market's drop, economists say. If nothing else, people and businesses will feel poorer, which in the long run could cause a slowdown in the economy and a rise in unemployment. [ A1. ] Small investors searched for news much of the day. Many held on to their stocks, as they tried to determine what really was happening. [ D1. ] In the financial district, some participants said yesterday was a day unlike any other they had ever seen. [ D1. ] President Reagan watched the plunge with concern but at no time considered ordering a halt to trading. [ D32. ] Democratic leaders in Congress blamed the Administration's policies and urged the President to accept a deficit-reduction package that would include tax increases. [ D32. ] Leaders of America's top companies admitted they were shaken and confused by the market's fall. [ 32. ] The plunge could hit hard in New York City, where securities industry employment accounts for about 8 percent of the jobs. [ D32. ] Treasury Secretary Baker met with West German officials in Frankfurt and, Mr. Baker's office said, agreed to work to keep currency rates ''around current levels.'' But Mr. Baker decided to cut short his trip because of the market's ordeal. [ D1. ] OTHER MARKETS Treasury securities prices soared as money flowed in from investors who had sold stocks. Interest rates were lower in all maturities. Interest rates on three-month Treasury bills, for example, dropped to about 6.2 percent from 6.64 percent. [ D1. ] The dollar closed lower against all leading currencies except the Canadian dollar. But gold rose to its highest price in more than four years, at $486.50 an ounce, up $15.50, in New York. [ D26. ] Most futures prices plummeted, including those for livestock, cotton, grain and stock indexes. Precious-metals futures, meanwhile, soared as investors sought safe havens. [ D26. ] THE ECONOMY The operating capacity rate stayed at 81.2 percent in September in the nation's factories, mines and utilities. [ D2. ] COMPANIES The buyout offer for GAF is being reconsidered. Samuel J. Heyman, GAF's chairman and leader of the buyout group, said rising loan costs would require that the bid be revised or dropped. [ D5. ] J. P. Morgan's earnings edged up 3.6 percent, and Security Pacific reported an 8.3 percent increase. [ D9. ] A.T&T. reported a 5.3 percent drop in quarterly earnings, while MCI posted a 22 percent gain. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan apparently is choosing the General Dynamics F-16 as its jet fighter, and Mitsubishi is expected to build 170 in Japan. [ D5. ] The Administration reportedly will further lift the trade sanctions levied against Japan last April. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A growing number of employers are cutting their payments to health maintenance organizations. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Foreign investors were actively selling, after consistently pouring money into the bull market. Market Place. [ D14. ]

description: The Henley Group said it had ended talks with the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation about the possible acquisition of one of the company's rail lines. Henley, which owns more than 5 percent of Santa Fe's stock, has been considering a possible bid for the company's Southern Pacific Transportation Corporation unit since August.

title: Russians Aim to Build Powerful Accelerator
description: SOVIET physicists have decided to build the most powerful particle accelerator of its kind, a straight-line facility 20 kilometers or about 16 miles long. Its length could eventually be doubled.

description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a Hong Kong-based investment concern controlled by Ronald A. Brerely, a New Zealand investor, indicated that it was considering a takeover of the Calmat Company, a Los Angeles-based cement maker. Industrial Equity has raised its stake in Calmat to 19.2 percent, with purchases of 918,900 additional Calmat shares between Oct. 2 and Oct. 14, for prices ranging from $33 to $37.55 a share.

title: COAST RV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Board Sale of Stock Funds Helped to Spur Drop
description: Yesterday's historic plunge in the stock market was fed in large part by huge sales of shares in stock-oriented mutual funds. Several of the largest mutual fund management companies said the number of phone calls from investors was about double the normal volume.

title: Goal of Defense Lawyer: Make the Witness Crack
description: As the prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes saw it, Stephen Murphy, one of the defense lawyers in the Howard Beach murder trial, had engaged in ''a classic example of witness badgering.''

Mood Subdued as Striking Players Return, and Work Begins; Giants Keep 2 Replacements
description: The Giants' regulars returned to work today and learned that of the 50 remaining players who replaced them during the National Football League players' strike, only two were still on the team. And both had the day off.

title: Rubella in U.S. Is at Lowest Level Ever
description: Rubella in the United States has reached its lowest rate ever, and Federal health officials say eradication of the once-common childhood disease is possible.

title: Koch Seeks U.S. Pressure on Use of AIDS Ads
description: Mayor Koch, frustrated by the refusal of local television stations to air most of New York City's paid advertising on AIDS prevention, yesterday called for public and Federal regulatory pressure on the stations to run the commercials free.

title: Dr. Philip Levine, 87, Is Dead; Discovered Blood's Rh Factor
description: Dr. Philip Levine, a pioneering researcher in serums and antibodies who discovered the Rh factor in human blood, died Sunday at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: 2 Platforms Called Base For Raids
description: The two linked Iranian offshore platforms destroyed by American naval gunfire this morning have long served as an important base for Iran's raids against shipping in the lower Persian Gulf, according to knowledgeable Congressional and Pentagon officials.

title: Witness in Howard Beach Case Erupts During Relentless Cross-Examination
description: Under a barrage of hostile questions and sarcastic comments by a defense lawyer, a young black man said to have been attacked by white youths in Howard Beach, Queens, exploded twice with anger and frustration yesterday and refused to continue testifying.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A World in Small Scale

Preferred stock dividends exceeded net income from operations in the latest 6 months.

title: Doctors Try to Refine Breast Cancer Diagnosis
description: USING new techniques of molecular biology, medical scientists are starting to develop precise ways of determining the prognoses of women with breast cancer. As a result, experts say, the process of deciding how to treat breast cancer patients is rapidly changing from an art to a precise science.

title: Prosecutor Says Gang Terrorized Hell's Kitchen
description: A prosecutor portrayed eight defendants yesterday as key figures in a violent gang called the Westies, a group accused of committing numerous murders and systematically terrorizing the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Violin: Waterman Plays Bach
description: THE first of two Bach concerts by Ruth Waterman at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night reminded us that ''authentic'' performance is less objective science than a set of personal decisions. For this survey of the violin and keyboard literature, Miss Waterman in many ways was very up-to-date. She played on a modern violin and used vibrato to color sustained tone - choosing not to reserve it for the ornamental and accentual effects the 18th century seems to have favored.

title: WEINBERGER STATEMENT ON U.S. ATTACK IN GULF
description: Following is a transcript of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's opening statement at a briefing today on the Persian Gulf, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: Fires in West Aiding Study of Nuclear War
description: The dark pall of smoke hovering above giant forest fires recently in the West has yielded a scientific bonanza for researchers studying whether nuclear warfare would plunge the earth into a freezing ''nuclear winter.''

title: Goetz Sentenced to Six Months on Gun Charge
description: Bernhard H. Goetz, who ignited a nationwide debate about self-defense when he shot four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway train, was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for carrying an unlicensed concealed pistol.

title: A SWEDE RESIGNS OVER SPY'S ESCAPE
description: Justice Minister Sten Wickbom resigned today to take responsibility for the embarrassingly easy escape this month of Sweden's most notorious spy.

title: Democrats Urge Deficit-Cutting Plan
description: Pointing to the stock market's plunge during the last week, Democratic leaders in Congress today urged President Reagan to negotiate a deficit-reduction package that would include tax increases.

title: Two Killed in a Fight
description: A man was charged with two counts of first-degree murder today in the deaths of two men who were shot in a fight after a traffic accident. The suspect, Manuel Rivera, 18 years old, was held without bond. The fight apparently began after a car ran into several others, one of them belong to the brother of one of the shooting victims.

title: Topics Of The Times; Hiding 'Housekeeping' Slush
description: How do New York's political parties spend the tens of thousands of dollars they raise each year for so-called ''housekeeping'' expenses? The state Republican chairman, Anthony Colavita, wants to make sure voters will never find out.

title: Martin Is Named Yankees' Manager for 5th Time
description: Billy Martin, who came and went four times as Yankee manager in a 10-year span that began in 1975, was brought back for a fifth term today in another shakeup by the team's owner, George Steinbrenner. Lou Piniella, who has been the manager for the past two seasons, was named general manager by Steinbrenner.

description: The share earnings were adjusted to account for a recent 2-for-1 split of the company's common stock.

description: The Rev. Allan Boesak, a leading South African figure in the anti-apartheid movement, called yesterday for a radical reconstruction of the South African Government and strongly appealed for continued economic sanctions to force such a move.

title: Of Bluffs and Gambles
description: IF there is a computer program that plays poker with anything like the challenge and subtlety a real game can offer, I have yet to see it. What set of instructions could create such poker-playing companions as the good old boy from Alabama who seems to hold an inordinate number of winning hands, the SoHo slicker who handles the deck much too well, the yuppie puppy who only clams up when he's drawing to a four-card flush? How can you teach a machine that the time is ripe for an outrageous bluff?

title: Bowie Ponders Injury
description: Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch center for the Portland Trail Blazers, was shocked, discouraged and contemplating retirement after breaking the same bone in his right leg that he had broken a year ago. He suffered the partial fracture of the right tibia in warm-ups for an exhibition game in Oregon City, Ore., on Saturday. ''Last night I was all set to give it all up, retire,'' Bowie told The Oregonian newspaper Sunday. ''I really have to give retiring a lot of thought. I know I said last week that if I broke it again, I'd just go back and rehabilitate it and try to play again. Now I'm just not sure. I'd say now it's 50-50 whether I'll ever play again. I don't know if I want to go through surgery again. If they can put it in a short-leg cast and get it to where I can play golf and play with my kids someday, that's probably what I'll do.'' Dr. Robert Cook, the Trail Blazers' team physician, said he planned to have several other doctors examine Bowie's leg this week and conduct tests to determine the proper course of treatment for the injury.

title: Surgery for Moncrief
description: Faced with the prospect of limping through an entire National Basketball Association season, Sidney Moncrief of the Milwaukee Bucks has elected instead to undergo knee surgery today and hopes to rejoin the team in about two months. A bone spur that prevented Moncrief from extending or flexing his knee will be removed. ''It's a fairly routine knee operation for athletes,'' said Dr. David Haskell, a medical adviser to the Bucks. ''It's not a common problem, however. He can't function with this. He can't run, squat or bend his knee.'' Haskell said Moncrief may scrimmage with the team in about eight weeks and then work himself into playing shape. Moncrief's operation casts further gloom upon Milwaukee's backcourt situation. Ricky Pierce is a holdout and Craig Hodges and John Lucas are unsigned free agents.

Yesterday, after a plunge reminiscent of the worst days of 1929, one pressing question was whether the aftershocks would be as devastating to individuals and the nation.

title: The Stage: Israel Horovitz's 'Year of the Duck'
description: IN Israel Horovitz's ''Year of the Duck'' (at the Hudson Guild Theater), life imitates art - up to a point. A community theater in Gloucester, Mass., is rehearsing a production of ''The Wild Duck,'' and, gradually, the members of the company show signs of creeping Ibsenism. Led by their director and star (he has cast himself in the pivotal role of Gregers Werle), they cleanse their lives of deception, as the characters do in the original play. In ''The Wild Duck,'' truth-telling leads to tragedy. In ''Year of the Duck,'' it leads to domestic comedy.

The North Stars, whose roster has plenty of new faces - including the one behind the bench in Coach Herb Brooks - have only one victory and a tie this season. The Canadiens scored three straight goals after Brian Bellows brought Minnesota within, 2-1, at 4 minutes 7 seconds of the second period.(AP) GOLF Woosnam Wins Tourney: Ian Woosnam of Wales, the leading money winner on the European tour, ended his season yesterday by winning the world match play championship and $120,000. Woosnam's 1-up victory over Scotland's Sandy Lyle in the rain-delayed final marked the first time that the 24-year-old tournament had been won by a British player. (AP)

Baker 3d met today with top German economic officials in Frankfurt and, according to a statement from his office, agreed to work with other countries to keep currency rates ''around current levels.''

description: IN her previous novel, ''The Middle Ground'' (1980), Margaret Drabble noted that her heroine ''can never decide whether she is a special case, and as such of little general relevance, or whether she is on the contrary an almost abnormally normal woman, a typical woman of our time, and as such of little particular interest.'' It's a question that also seems to have preoccupied Ms. Drabble in her recent fiction, and her latest novel, ''The Radiant Way,'' is no exception.

title: Reports of Psychiatry Abuse Counter Talk of a Soviet Shift

title: CAUTION IS URGED BY ADVISERS
description: Investment advisers ranging from big securities firms to small financial planners were urging caution yesterday, telling their clients to avoid any major moves, either selling or buying, in the wake of Monday's stock market plunge.

title:
In the Wake of Wall Street's Crash;
Monday Wasn't So Black
description: LEAD: There's an old quip: ''The stock market is a terrific economic forecaster. It has predicted 11 of the last five recessions.'' The market meltdown does not presage another depression. With suitable policy responses, it need not even signal a significant decline in the economy.

title: Luxury Items Remain on Many Must-Have Lists
description: Investors who took a beating Monday were not backing away from big-ticket consumer purchases just yet, according to those who deal in the luxury items, allaying for now what analysts say is the biggest threat of a stock market collapse: that people will feel poorer and spend less, resulting in a severe economic slowdown.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Seminar on Bork
description: Even before the Senate formally opens debate on Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, organizers of the campaign against him have scheduled a seminar on how they defeated him.

title: Singapore Rules Relaxed
description: The Commerce Department announced today that it had eased its export licensing rules on some high-technology goods destined for Singapore. The changes, which come partly in response to complaints from Congress and American businesses about export controls, will permit shipments of certain lower-level goods such as commonly available computers to Singapore and for re-export to 19 other non-Communist countries without approval from the Commerce Department. The changes will also allow all products except super computers to be shipped to Singapore Government agencies without prior Commerce authorization. The Commerce Department said it had made the changes because Singapore had improved its own export licensing system.

title: DEMOCRATS NOMINATE COHEN FOR JUDGE IN SPECIAL PRIMARY
description: Stuart C. Cohen, an assistant com-missioner in the city's Municipal Sup-plies Division, won yesterday's special Democratic runoff primary for Civil Court judge in the Greenwich Village-City Hall area, election officials said. He defeated Judge Lester Evens, who is seeking a second term.

title: Music: Monteverdi's 'Vespers' at Basically Bach
description: RICHARD WESTENBURG'S ninth Basically Bach Festival got under way Monday night in Alice Tully Hall with an unfortunately underattended performance of Monteverdi's ''Vespers of 1610.'' Other than a general wish to see this honorable festival fare well, one's disappointment had mostly to do with a regret that so few people were hearing this fine, rarely encountered score. Mr. Westenburg's performance was sincerely intended and often effective. But the score itself is one of the great masterpieces of Western music and deserves to be heard as often as possible.

title: Unions Offer Labor Help on Automation
description: DURING the 19th century, English textile workers following the example of Ned Ludd, a Leicestershire mill hand, smashed labor-saving machinery to protest reduced wages and unemployment introduced with the automation of their trade. Today, labor leaders faced with a new wave of industrial automation and computerization are committed to more cooperative tactics than those that failed for the Luddites.

title: Tudor's Comeback: A Stylish Chapter

But he returned to generate a 10-2 record that helped the Cardinals win the National League East and threw a 1-0 shutout that tied the National League Championship Series with the San Francisco Giants at 3-3. Now the 33-year-old left-hander has lifted the Cardinals back into the World Series.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings were based on weighted average common and common-equivalent shares outstanding.

title: Market Place; Margin Debt's Downside Risk
description: MARGIN calls were cascading yesterday on Wall Street in the wake of the stock market's huge daily price declines. ''Industrywide, the margin calls are very big, but I have no way of knowing the exact number,'' said Stephen Robert, chairman of Oppenheimer Group Inc. ''Today, the volume of margin calls at our firm hit a record high.''

title: The U.N. Today, Oct. 21, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bonds Surge; Deal Makers Regrouping
description: Interest rates plummeted for the second consecutive day yesterday as the aftershocks from Monday's collapse in stock prices spread through the financial markets.

title: Gulf Nations Avoid Open Support for U.S. Attack
description: Most Arab nations bordering the Persian Gulf today avoided open declarations of support or opposition to the American raid on two Iranian platforms in the Persian Gulf Monday, while Iran's leaders called for vengeance.

title: Tensions Deepening Between Uganda and Kenya
description: A crisis in relations between Uganda and Kenya has deepened in recent months, with Uganda stationing troops at the border and Kenya pledging to retaliate against any Ugandan attempt to cross the frontier in pursuit of rebels.

title: Jessica Hahn: Shifting Views of a Sudden Celebrity
description: To psychologists, sociologists and feminists, the Jessica Hahn story has become a case study in the ambivalence and confusion with which American society regards fame and celebrity.

title: Martha Graham Seeking U.S. Funds
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has gone to Congress for financing, bypassing the National Endowment for the Arts in an unusual and controversial fund-raising strategy.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: PETER UMBRAS of Bennington, N.Y., is on line at a Manhattan Red Apple supermarket. In the next line is another man; in a third line two nuns push a cart full of groceries. The lines move slowly. The man in the next line eyes the contents of the sisters' cart. They observe him staring and look at him with puzzled expressions. Finally, in a casual but wondering voice, he says, ''Sisters, I can understand angel food cake . . . but Miracle Whip?'' The sisters laugh; the man smiles; Mr. Umbras smiles, too, and they all reach their cashiers at the same time. Dear Diary: side of Fifth Avenue at 68th Street, waiting for the light to change. Looking around the sunny park, I noticed a baby's nurse in starchy white approaching me pushing a stroller holding a baby boy, perhaps 1 or 1 1/2 years old. The nurse, pausing under an elm, reached up to some leaves at the tip of a lower branch, carefully examined several, and plucked one off. She handed it to the boy, who held it out in front of him, scarcely looking at it.

title: Kelly Makes a Faulty Move
description: Tom Kelly, Minnesota's rookie manager, did not quiver and quake before Sparky Anderson, Detroit's astute manager, in the American League playoff, and he did not wither and swoon before Whitey Herzog, St. Louis's wily manager, in the first two games of the World Series.

title: Exploring Virtues Of a Fragrant Rice
description: LEAD: BASMATI is changing the way America thinks about rice.''When I first worked at

title: Bristol-Myers's Net Up 15.1%
description: The Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that earnings had increased by 15.1 percent in the third quarter, to a record $200.2 million, or 70 cents a share, from $173.9 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,856,000.

title: UST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE PROFESSIONALS STAGGER, BUT COPE: 'I'M STILL POSITIVE'
description: Wall Street's brokers, traders, back-office experts, portfolio managers, analysts and clerks have been tested as never before in the last few days. What follows are accounts of how several professionals went about their jobs.

title: Restaurants Are Finding Greener Grass in Suburbs
description: ONE night last week, Joe and Gay Fahys of Greenwich, Conn., canceled plans to make the 45-minute drive into Manhattan for dinner, opting instead for a fine French restaurant that had just opened nearby. ''It was better this way,'' said Mrs. Fahys, who was celebrating her birthday. ''It's close to home.''

title: As Prison Opens in Jersey, Officials Support a Bond Issue
description: A new $83 million medium-security prison was officially opened here today by city, county and state officials, who used the occasion to urge voters to approve a $198 million prison bond issue on the Nov. 3 ballot.

title: Dart Group Ends Its Bid To Buy Dayton Hudson
description: The Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that it was giving up its $68-a-share takeover bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a move that is expected to result in an after-tax loss of about $70 million.

title: M-A-R-C INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
State Trooper Is Accused of Slaying a Colleague
description: - A male state trooper has been charged with murdering a female trooper, whom he once considered marrying, in an effort to collect life insurance benefits.

title: THE PROFESSIONALS STAGGER, BUT COPE
description: Wall Street's brokers, traders, back-office experts, portfolio managers, analysts and clerks have been tested as never before in the last few days. What follows are accounts of how several professionals went about their jobs.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 30, 1987.

title: Retailers Calm On Stock Fall
description: Though expressing some wariness, several retailers interviewed here at the spring fashion shows said the stock market's tumble will not affect their buying plans.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' nets includes $8.6 million, after tax, for the quarter and $17.7 million, after tax, for the 9 months as the company's share of earnings of international equity affiliates. The year-ago periods' nets included $10.4 million, after tax, for the quarter and $15.8 million, after tax, for the 9 months as the company's share of earnings of international equity affiliates.

title: Washington Talk: The Drug Problem; First, an Adviser Says, Let's Arrest the Users
description: Just after Dr. Donald MacDonald became a deputy assistant to the President early this year, he took something of an orientation tour.

title: Headland Journal; Historian's Death Penalty Obsession
description: The framed pictures of the men and a few women cover the walls of Watt Espy's house, The older ones stare out with a stiff graininess. In some frames they are arranged in groups of six or eight smaller head-and-shoulders shots, and the subjects are dressed in high collars as if posing for some ancient graduating class.

title: JUST A PAPER LOSS, THE RICHEST SAY
description: Not every rich person was in a black mood yesterday.

title: Stock Fund Selloffs Diminish
description: Many investors in stock-based mutual funds continued to sell their shares yesterday morning, but the sales tapered off in the afternoon as the market regained some ground.

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of about $12 million to reflect the discontinuance of certain product lines and other writedowns.

title: Albert King Not in Nets' Plans
description: First Bernard King went unwanted by the Knicks and signed an offer sheet with the Washington Bullets. And now, across the Hudson River, the Nets are saying that Albert King, also a free agent, might be better served playing elsewhere.

title: Officials Halt Trading In Several Futures Pits
description: In an unprecedented move, exchange officials temporarily halted trading today in several of Chicago's financial futures pits because large numbers of the stocks underlying the indexes had stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Icahn, Citing Stock Fall, Cancels T.W.A. Buyout
description: Because of the huge decline in the stock market. Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, yesterday withdrew his offer to take T.W.A. private.

title: The Pop Lif
description: Berry by Richards

title: Building Of Housing Up by 4.4%
description: Housing construction rose 4.4 percent in September, the biggest advance since last December, the Government reported today, but analysts said recent increases in mortgage rates made further improvement unlikely.

title: A.T.&T.-Telerate
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Telerate Inc. said they had agreed to form a partnership to develop and market electronic transaction services for global financial markets. The two companies said that they plan to offer a system that would give international money traders the ability to make instantaneous transactions.

title: Police in India Detain Sikhs At Golden Temple Complex
description: The police raided the Golden Temple complex in Amritsar early today and began rounding up suspected Sikh extremists, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Bonn Reduces Interest Rate
description: The West German central bank moved to calm money markets today by lowering a key financing rate. An increase in that rate last week had provoked a public scolding of Bonn by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d.

title: CMS ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The fiscal 1986 results are restated for adoption of new accounting standard on Employers' Accounting for Pensions.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL TELECHARGE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Machinery of Government Shifts to a Higher Gear
description: Washington's response to the collapse on Wall Street is intended to calm panic and restore stability to the markets. Beginning with the President, Here are the policymakers and regulators trying to guide the financial system through this crisis: President Reagan

title: THE PROFESSIONALS STAGGER, BUT COPE: 'WAIT, JUST WAIT'
description: Wall Street's brokers, traders, back-office experts, portfolio managers, analysts and clerks have been tested as never before in the last few days. What follows are accounts of how several professionals went about their jobs.

title: TV Reviews; Network News Covers the Stock Market Frenzy
description: IT took over the television coverage, of course. Meanwhile, it went awfully fast. News of the stock market frenzy was reported, along with instant reaction. The three major networks and public television presented specials; the Cable News Network was almost a global ticker tape. Anchors seemed a shade ill at ease, but economists, investment advisers and stock brokers filled in. New television stars were born on the day that NBC, for one, insisted on calling Black Monday.

title: Executives Reassure Workers and Hold to Plans
description: Whether they were putting on a brave face or really believed the storm would leave them relatively unscathed, top corporate executives did their utmost yesterday to maintain an aura of calm.

title: JWP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brauner Account
description: J.D. Brauner, a maker of butcher block tables and chairs in Long Island City, Queens, has tapped Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman to handle its million-dollar budget. A consumer print campaign will begin next week, the agency said. The previous agency was Drossman, Lehmann, Marino.

title: Oil Prices Edge Higher, After Advance by Dow
description: Oil prices edged higher yesterday, apparently taking their direction from the Dow Jones industrial average and not from the increasing violence in the Persian Gulf. A barrel of crude, which had been down 42 cents in near-month trading on the New York futures exchange on Monday, the day of the stock market's huge loss, was up 7 cents yesterday, to $19.87.

title: Northrop Has Profit
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it earned $34.1 million, or 73 cents a share, in the third quarter. The aerospace company had lost $30.5 million in the period last year after taking a $90 million write-down on its highly classified research and development contract for the Air Force's Stealth bomber program.

title: Reagan Says He Is Open to Budget Talk
description: After an extraordinary hourlong meeting with the nation's two top financial officials, President Reagan today said he was willing to work with Congress to try to break the impasse over reducing the Federal budget deficit.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the previously reported adoption in 1986 of Financial Accounting Standard No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions. The company also said the results of Giorgio are included in the latest quarter and 9 months since June 1, 1987.

title: YELLOW FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Honeywell Names Chief Executive
description: James J. Renier, Honeywell Inc.'s president, was elected chief executive yesterday in what the company called a continuation of its tradition of orderly management change.

title: Acid Wash Gives a Lift To 7th Avenue
description: THE surprisingly simple technology of washing jeans in chlorine to reduce the stiffness and abrasiveness of the cotton denim has been a boon to the often-depressed garment industry. The chlorine removes dyes, giving the garments a lighter, worn appearance while softening them.

title: WINE TALK
description: INSTEAD of pouring a second glass of Madeira, zinfandel port or late-harvest semillon after dinner, wine fanciers can settle down on cool autumn evenings to an alternative dessert: the sweet pleasures of new wine books.

title: United Artists Halts Cable Talks
description: In the wake of the stock market collapse, United Artists Communications Inc. said it was indefinitely suspending merger talks with the United Cable Television Corporation, a stock deal that was valued at about $2 billion less than a week ago.

title: Surgery for Dooley
description: Vince Dooley, the athletic director and head football coach at the University of Georgia, underwent a 90-minute procedure yesterday to clear two blocked arteries near his heart, then was given the go-ahead to be on the sideline Saturday against Kentucky. Dooley, 55 years old, was admitted to Emory University Hospital in Atlanta on Monday and had the surgery to clear the arteries feeding the heart muscle. He reportedly experienced discomfort in his chest over the weekend in Nashville, where his Bulldogs defeated Vanderbilt, 52-24. ''They successfully opened both arteries,'' said Catherine Grant, a hospital spokeswoman. ''He's fine. It went perfect.'' Dooley, whose 188 victories place him third among active coaches, is in his 24th season at Georgia, the longest stretch for any active National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I coach.

title: Brokerage Stocks Fall; Large Losses Rumored
description: The stock price of nearly every major brokerage house tumbled yesterday, as rumors circulated that a number of the firms, including E.F. Hutton Group Inc., Bear Stearns Companies and Morgan Stanley & Co., had sustained big trading losses over the last few days.

title: EDAC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,523,000.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $4,350,000 for the quarter and $19,950,000 for the 9 months. The 1987 and 1986 figures include an after-tax net gain of about $37.3 million and $26.3 million, respectively, from the sale of certain investments.

title: LARS-ERIK SJOBERG
description: Lars-Erik Sjoberg, a former National Hockey League player and the chief European scout for the New York Rangers, has died in Sweden of cancer, the Rangers announced yesterday. He was 43 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Announced that Paul Splittorff will join Royals' television crew as an analyst. TORONTO (AL) - Picked up its options for 1988 on the contracts of Jimmy Key, pitcher, and Rick Leach, outfielder. Purchased the contracts of Glenallen Hill, outfielder, from Syracuse of the International League and Matt Stark, catcher, from Knoxville of the Southern League. Assigned the contracts of Jeff DeWillis, catcher, and Otis Green, infielder, outright to Syracuse. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Agreed to terms with Dave Trembley, manager of Harrisburg of the Eastern League, and Spin Williams, pitching coach at Harrisburg, on one-year contracts. Announced that Lanny Frattare and Jim Rooker will return as the radio broadcasting team. HALL OF FAME - Jim Murray, syndicated columnist of the Los Angeles Times, was voted the J. G. Taylor Spink Award by Baseball Writers Association of America. He will be inducted into the writers' wing at Cooperstown, N.Y., in July. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Retained Kerry Parker, cornerback; Richard Tharpe, defensive end; Bruce King, fullback; Don Sommer and Tony Brown, offensive tackles; Brian McClure, quarterback; Ricky Porter, running back; Gary Wilkins and Kevin Starks, tight ends, and Reggie Bynum, wide receiver, from their replacement roster. Placed Kevin Lamar, center; Lester Baldwin and Joe Silipo, offensive lineman, and Chas Fox and Joe Howard, wide receivers, on injured reserve. Signed Tony Furjanic, linebacker. CHICAGO (NFC) - Retained Egypt Allen, Bruce McCray and Eric Jeffries, defensive backs; Jim Althoff, defensive tackle; Sean McInerney, defensive end; Brian Glasgow, tight end; Ken Knapczyk, wide receiver; Jay Norvell, linebacker; Mike Hohensee, quarterback; John Wojciechowski, guard, and Mark Rodenhauser, center, from their replacement roster. Placed Glen Kozlowski, wide receiver; Lorenzo Lynch, defensive back; Anthony Mosley, running back; Eugene Rowell, offensive tackle, and Keith Smith, defensive lineman, on injured reserve. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Retained Jitter Fields, defensive back; James Harrell and Bob Harris, linebackers; Kelly Goodburn, punter; Doug Hudson and Matt Stevens, quarterbacks, and Rod Jones, tight end, from their replacement roster. MIAMI (AFC) - Traded Greg Koch, offensive tackle, to the Minnesota Vikings for an undisclosed 1988 draft choice and an undisclosed 1989 draft choice. Waived Terrence Mann, defensive end, and David Lilja and Mark Veldman, tight ends. Placed Kyle Mackey, quarterback; Trell Hooper, defensive end, and Jim Gilmore, guard, on injured reserve. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Retained Stafford Mays, defensive end, from their replacement roster. SEATTLE (NFC) - Retained Bruce Mathison, quarterback; Jimmy Teal, wide receiver, and Eric Lane, running back, from their replacement roster. Placed Howard Richards, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Recalled Jari Gronstrand, defenseman, from Colorado of the International Hockey League. Assigned Dave Pichette, defenseman, to New Haven of the American Hockey League.

title: Piano: Elida Gencarelli
description: ELIDA GENCARELLI'S unusually slow and sensuous version of a Chopin etude revealed a musical personality that was not elsewhere apparent during her debut Monday evening in Weill Recital Hall. The Uruguayan-born pianist presented works by Soler, Domenico Scarlatti, Albeniz, Beethoven (''Appassionata''), Ginastera, Chopin and Sergio Cervetti, whose ''Candombe'' received its United States premiere.

title: Of Bork and Tactics
description: President Reagan and other supporters of Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination have shifted the focus from the nominee to the tactics used by his critics, in a strikingly vitriolic offensive.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Escorts New Convoy

title: 3-Day Market Gyrations: Selling on the Fast Track
description: Virtually every stock traded in the United States securities markets has gone through wild gyrations in the last three days. For traders at the exchanges, keeping up with the swings in any one of the stocks tested even those with years of experience.

title: Amid Turmoil, Home Buyers Are Putting Dreams on Hold
description: For most Americans, buying a home is not only the biggest purchase they will make but also their biggest dream. Yesterday, after the stock market's breathtaking plunge, many put their dreams on hold.

title: PERKINS FAMILY RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter contained 8 more days than the year- ago period. The latest 9 months contained 21 more days than the year-ago period.

title: How U.S. Companies Manufacture Trade Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Bait and Switch Is School Cook's Secret
description: THIS is a story of good cooking, skilled diplomacy and downright sneakiness. It is a cautionary tale in which a lone adult pits herself against the strong wills and determined taste buds of 300 children, age 4 to 14, and wins. It is about Anstice Carroll, cookbook author and caterer, who in 1978 became food director at the Grace Church School, a private elementary school at Fourth Avenue and 11th Street, and eventually hoodwinked students into eating food that is good for them.

title: Louis C. Miriani, 90, Former Detroit Mayor
description: Louis C. Miriani, who expanded urban renewal and construction programs as Mayor of Detroit from 1957 to 1961, died Sunday at a hospital in Pontiac after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE tried at times to analyze my lifelong passion for fish soups, and I think it is based on such things as the fantastic variety of fish and shellfish that may be used and the wide variation in flavors and textures.

description: b-Includes $4.4 million from discontinued operations, a $51.6 million after-tax gain on sale of E.F. Hutton Insurance Group Inc. and tax loss carryforwards of $36.6 million. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $4.6 million and $10.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a tax loss carryforwards of $5.2 million.

title: BETTER TIES SEEN IN VISIT BY GANDHI
description: President Reagan conferred today with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India in what American officials characterized as a new atmosphere of increased cooperation.

title: Theater: 'Tea,' End Of Trilogy
description: VELINA HASU HOUSTON, the daughter of a Japanese mother and an American father, was born in Japan during the United States occupation and grew up near Fort Riley, Kan., where many such mixed families were consigned. Her new play, ''Tea,'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, is the final work of a trilogy about Japanese war brides, ''suspended between two worlds.'' It plays out like a combination of Culture Clash 101 and True Story magazine.

title: Stanley Kramer Plans A Film on Lech Walesa
description: - Stanley Kramer will produce and direct a film based on the life of Lech Walesa, the founder and leader of Poland's outlawed Solidarity union, a spokesman for the director said today.

title: The Sense and Nonsense In Cabaret Safety Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: For Bullish Advisers, Bewilderment
description: Just weeks ago, some stock market analysts, investment advisers and others were bullish. They saw no reason to think the Dow Jones industrial average would not go over 3,000 and much higher.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Whither Weinberger?
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger ordered his spokesman, Fred Hoffman, to deny categorically and vehemently a report last week by CBS News that Mr. Weinberger wanted to resign soon. Mr. Hoffman, calling news organizations even before the report aired, said his boss would leave office only at the end of the Reagan Administration.

title: For Mozart's Librettist, a Queens Fanfare
description: It seemed an unlikely event in an incongruous place. Yesterday, a Jewish City Councilman, Italian-American dignitaries and local history buffs honored the librettist of three of Mozart's operas at a cemetery in Queens as trucks rumbled by.

description: Three Democratic Senators today jumped the gun on the formal debate on Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, confronting a conservative colleague about his role in a pro-Bork telephone campaign.

title: AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: CORRECTIONS

Results for both years include gains related to business repositioning actions initiated in 1986. These gains increased after-tax net income for the third quarter of 1987 by $16 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with an after-tax increase in last year's third quarter of $32 million, or 10 cents a share. The company said the third quarter gains increased after-tax income for the latest 9 months and year-earlier period by $65 million, or 20 cents a share, and $32 million, or 10 cents a share, respectively.

title: Nancy Reagan Due to Return To White House This Week
description: Nancy Reagan, ''looking better and better every day'' after breast cancer surgery three days ago, is expected to return to the White House by week's end, aides said today.

title: Fines for 21 Players
description: Twenty-one players with the Atlanta Hawks and the Indiana Pacers have been fined for fighting during an exhibition game last Thursday in Chattanooga, Tenn. Scott Hastings of Atlanta was fined $3,000 for throwing a punch and $500 for leaving the area of the bench. Wayne Rollins of Atlanta and Steve Stipanovich were fined $2,000 apiece for brawling and contributing to the escalation of the incident. The Pacers' Chuck Person was fined $750 for throwing a punch and attempting to instigate a fight with Dominique Wilkins of Atlanta.

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some editions yesterday, a Washington dispatch about President Reagan's mood misstated the magnitude of Monday's drop in the stock market. It was the second worst percentage decline in the Dow Jones industrial average, and the worst since World War I.

title: Release of Altered Microbes Is Approved in Tracking Test
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has approved the release of a gene-altered microbe designed to help scientists track other genetically engineered organisms in the environment.

title: Developer Sues Over Blocking Of Demolition
description: In what may be a critical challenge to the way New York City designates landmarks, the owners of three row houses on Central Park West have sued the city and told its Landmarks Preservation Commission that the panel has no authority to block their demolition plans.

title: Food Writers Add Ingredient Of Reminiscence to Recipes
description: GOOD eating invariably evokes fond memories. In several recent cookbooks, recipes are joined by reminiscences - of family, dear friends and diverting travel.

title: The Party Is Over; the Bills Are In
description: The events of the last few months have been trying to tell this country something about its mindless excesses. They have been saying you can't run a Government on credit cards, that the politics of blame won't solve our problems at home or abroad and that when the party's over the bills come in, The evidence was all around us before the crash: in the Iran-contra hearings, in the budget deficits and the trade deficits, in the adventures of the Persian Gulf, in the moral squalor of the Hart and Biden campaigns. And you could go on even to some of the backsliders in the electric pulpits.

title: DEBBIE REYNOLDS IN 'SADIE AND SON'
description: DESCRIBED in press releases as a lighthearted drama, ''Sadie and Son,'' the made-for-TV movie on CBS at 9 tonight, is the kind of glossy concoction that lacks a single convincing moment. Start with the setting. It is supposed to be New York City, and several scenes take place in the subway. Needless to say, ''Sadie and Son'' was filmed entirely on location - in Toronto. And that's only the beginning.

Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include Loral Systems Group, formerly Goodyear Aerospace, acquired in March 1987.

description: East Tennesseans will be among the first consumers in the nation to sip a new milk product containing microorganisms that are supposed to help digestion, officials of a dairy and the product's developer say.

title: Investors Sue Gap Over Disclosures
description: The Gap Inc. said four class action suits had been filed in Federal District Court in San Francisco contending that the company made ''purported misstatements and omissions'' in its public disclosures. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Gap said the suits name certain officers and directors of the San Bruno, Calif., company.

title: Senate, Split on Gulf, Debates Compromise on War Powers
description: Amid deep divisions over how to formulate policy on the Persian Gulf, the Senate began debate today on a compromise approach to the War Powers Resolution.

title: UNIVERSAL FURNITURE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax benefit of $200,000 for the quarter and tax credit of $333,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax benefit of $95,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $320,000 for the 9 months. The share data reflects a 100 percent stock dividend distributed April 24 and the public offering of 2 million shares on June 4.

title: New Opportunities, and Risks, Arise
description: This week's historic plunge in stock prices has thrown the world of corporate finance into turmoil. It has brought a halt to deals and prompted investment bankers to find new ways for corporations to take advantage of bargains in the stock market.

title: Yankee Players Surprised, Not Shocked
description: Players who have seen the changes in the past conceded today they were surprised, although not necessarily shocked, by the latest Yankee shake-up that sent Lou Piniella into the front office as general manager and brought back Billy Martin one more time as manager.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics of The Times; Inoculations Against War
description: In addition to suffering from political violence, some 350,000 Lebanese children remain vulnerable to common killers like diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, measles and polio. Even warring militias find this disturbing - so the guns have fallen silent for four days to allow inoculations by Unicef.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
KEY RATES
VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Times Aide Is Promoted
description: Nancy Nielsen has been appointed director of corporate relations and public affairs for The New York Times Company, effective Nov. 1, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: Stock Option Plans Weakened by Slide
description: Lewis Orams, a vice president of Norwest Bank in Minneapolis, is a participant in the company's long-term incentive compensation plan, which allows him to buy Norwest common stock at a particular price after a certain number of years at the company. As a result of his rank and years of service, he was given an option in July to buy 1,000 shares, although he is not yet eligible to exercise it.

title: Dance: 'Lost Luggage,' Michael Kessler Revue
description: A PEPPY little revue, ''Lost Luggage'' appears to have only one aim: to be fun. And fun it was when it was presented Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. The work, directed and choreographed by Michael Kessler and performed by his company, Future Moves, consisted of dance numbers to assorted jazz, pop and rock recordings. Some scenes did feature people with suitcases. But no great point was made of luggage as a theme. Instead, this was simply an evening of snappy dances in a mixture of jazz and balletic styles.

title: Text of President's Statement on Economy
description: Following is the text of a statement that President Reagan delivered late this afternoon on the White House lawn:

title: Sears's Net Buoyed by Allstate
description: Benefiting from a strong performance by its Allstate insurance subsidiary, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer and a leading financial services company, yesterday posted a sharp increase in its third-quarter earnings.

title: TW SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Old Jokes Strike Resonant Chord
description: The Wall Street collapse of 1987 was only hours old Monday night when an audience at the Lincoln Center revival of Cole Porter's ''Anything Goes'' was applauding and cheering 50-year-old jokes that had helped an earlier generation laugh its way through the Great Depression.

title: Parking Chief Named to Head Fire Department
description: The director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau, Joseph F. Bruno, has been named the city's Fire Commissioner.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALD F. FRENCH
description: Donald F. French, a New York lawyer who specialized in mutual-fund law, died after suffering an aneurysm Sunday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $12 million and $323 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a charge of $58 million in connection with extinguishment of interest rate hedge contracts for both the quarter and 9 months, and the quarter also includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $285 million. Year-ago results are restated. The company said results for the latest third quarter and 9 months include Caremark Inc., which was acquired on Aug. 3, 1987. The company also said recognition of the Caremark acquisition reduced share earnings for the 9-month by 5 cents a share, of which 2 cents a share reflected restated results for the first and second quarters.

title: Toyota Sales
description: A senior executive of the Toyota Motor Company said that the company expected a 6 percent sales decline in the United States next year. Jim Perkins, group vice president for sales and marketing at Toyota's American subsidiary, said the company's vehicle sales in the United States would decline to about 875,000 in 1988, from about 930,000 in 1987.

title: GENERAL CERAMICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
In Spain, Men Gather to Cook and Gossip
description: LEAD: THE fellows down at one of the gastronomic societies still talk about the day a woman pretending to be a man violated the privacy of the all-male preserve.

title: Zhao Confirmed as China's Party Leader
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang was confirmed today as acting General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: House Bars Embassy Relocation
description: The House today turned aside an effort to require the Soviet Union to abandon its new embassy on a hilltop overlooking Washington and find a site less suited to electronic eavesdropping.

title: Elegant Scent Storage
description: 1. For Heady Scents rrYou will feel glamorous day after day with this iridescent, oval-shaped perfume bottle on your dressing table. It is a signed piece, designed and blown by Josh Simpson. It is faceted on one side to reveal the inner chamber and the black glass stopper. It is $120 in the Museum Store at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. 2. Helpful Memento rrThis box can be both a personal memento and a useful desk accessory. You can cover it with the magazine or newspaper of your choice. The top is removable, and there are two drawers on the side for storage. The price is $125. The box is made to order at Serendipity 3, 225 East 60th Street. 3. Terry Cloth Comfort rrAndree Putman sees the terry cloth robe as an adventure in dressing. This one is a riot of black and white, with a comfortable shawl collar and cuffed sleeves. It costs $95 in the men's shop at Bonwit Teller; it can also be worn by women. Bonwit Teller at Trump Tower, 4 East 57th Street, and at branch stores.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pretoria Lends Helping Hand To Friends With Big Airstrips
description: High on a flank of an extinct volcano here on the island of Bioko, Hilton Lack sat down to a ranch breakfast today after radioing his daily herd report to South Africa.

title: US WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
About New York; Mirror, Mirror: Dream Factory For the Hairless
description: Tommaso Foresta operates what appears to be a barbershop of the old-fashioned variety -striped pole, two chairs, the requisite Penthouses and Playboys, a steady patter of conversation.

title: Film: 'Death in Family,' AIDS in New Zealand
description: THE death in ''A Death in the Family'' is that of a young New Zealand man named Andrew Boyd; the family is made up of the friends and lovers who tended him in July 1985, during his final days. Stewart Main and Peter Wells were two of those friends, and their drama, which opens today at Film Forum 1, is meant as a loving tribute to ''Andy'' as well as an effort to present his disease, AIDS, as a personal loss rather than a medical specter.

title: Costly Municipal Error: Free Pest Control
description: It sounds like a Yellow Pages advertisement -free extermination, and you don't even have to make a call. But the New York City Comptroller says it was a $365,000 mistake.

title: In a Jolted Washington, Anxiety and Confusion
description: Official Washington tried hard to look calm and confident today in the face of continuing frenzy in the financial markets, but uncertainty, anxiety and confusion were visible behind the mask.

title: MUSICLAND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
BERNARD L. HEGEMAN
description: Bernard L. Hegeman, a Brooklyn realtor, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 90 years old.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $130,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $319,055 and $906,962 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Article 174487 -- No Title
description: A diamond was auctioned yesterday for $3.85 million, a record at auction in the United States for a piece of jewelry.

title: Tribune Co. and Post Report
description: The Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and other media properties, reported yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 73 percent, to $33.1 million, or 42 cents a share, from $123.5 mllion, or $1.53 a share, last year. Revenues rose 8 percent, to $535 million, from $497 million.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gains on sales of loans of $11.2 million and $67.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes after-tax gains on sales of loans of $65.1 million for the quarter and $124.7 million for the 9 months.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Connors Wins Easily: Fourth-seeded Jimmy Connors posted an easy victory, but second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden had to struggle to beat one of Japan's top players yesterday in first-round matches of the $375,000 Seiko tournament in Tokyo. Edberg, ranked second in the world, defeated Tsuyoshi Fukui, ranked 379th, 7-5, 6-2, before a crowd of 4,000 at Yoyogi National Stadium. Connors, ranked fifth in the world, trounced a fellow American, Marty Davis, who is ranked 87th in the world, 6-4, 6-3. Paul Annacone advanced by beating Shuzo Matsuoka of Japan, 6-1, 7-6; Sammy Giammalva Jr. beat Steve Guy of New Zealand, 6-2, 6-1; Mikael Pernfors of Sweden defeated Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2; Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia beat Joey Rive, 6-4, 7-5, and Robert Seguso beat Brad Drewett of Australia, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Shriver Struggles: Top-seeded Pam Shriver struggled to beat Nicole Provis of Australia, 7-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the Volvo women's tournament yesterday in Brighton, England. The American made numerous errors during long base-line rallies. Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, the No. 2 seed, dropped the first set before winning her first-round match against Betsy Nagelsen of the United States, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4. Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, seeded third, beat Jo Durie of Britain, 6-3, 6-3. Bettina Bunge of West Germany overcame a South African, Rosalyn Fairbank, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2; Lisa Bonder defeated Iva Buderova of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-4; and Larissas Savchenko of the Soviet Union beat Catherine Tanvier of France, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) GYMNASTICS Soviet Union Leads: The Soviet Union took the lead after the compulsory exercises of the men's team competition yesterday at the world championships in Rotterdam. The Soviet team, led by Dmitri Bilozerchev, was far ahead with 294.05 points. East Germany was second with 289.85, and China was third with 289.8. The optional exercises will be completed today and tomorrow. Bilozerchev took the lead for the individual all-round title. He was the 1983 world champion, but is returning after a severe auto accident in 1985 that broke his leg. Soviet gymnasts took the top four individual places with Bilozerchev in front with 59.0 points out of a possible 60. In the team event, Japan, which led after the first day, is now tied for fourth with Bulgaria; both have 287.8 points. Hungary followed with 286.0, and the United States dropped to seventh with 285.6. The top 12 teams will qualify for the 1988 Olympics in Seoul.(AP)

title: Candidates for Nassau Executive Clash in Debate
description: The two major candidates for Nassau County Executive agreed yesterday on the problems that threaten the quality of life in the county but clashed over how to resolve them.

description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June.

description: A crossword puzzle solver trying to figure out an eight-letter word whose second letter is ''u'' and fifth letter ''d'' might once have been in a quandary. But help is now at hand. A new electronic spelling checker resembling a large handheld calculator can instantly retrieve words that fit a given pattern.

title: Lawyers in Haiti Hold Strike In Mourning for Slain Leader
description: Port-au-Prince lawyers have gone on strike to observe a week of mourning for a political leader killed last week in front of police headquarters, the Bar Association president said today.

description: Governor Cuomo said tonight that the plunge in stocks had ''finally jolted the American people into a recognition that there are serious economic problems in this country.''

title: U.S. Issues Asbestos Safety Regulations for Schools
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today issued what it called tough final rules requiring school systems to protect children and workers from cancer-causing asbestos in school buildings.

title: SUNWEST FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics of The Times; 'No' on Jersey's Stadium Bonds
description: On Nov. 3, New Jersey will vote on a $185 million bond issue to build a major league baseball stadium in the Meadowlands. The proposal has strong chauvinistic appeal for the Garden State. Little else recommends it. The 45,000-seat stadium is a pet project of Governor Kean, who envisions a New Jersey team in the Meadowlands by 1990 on 246 acres just south of the Sports Complex. Like the complex, it would be operated by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Way to Treat a Prisoner
description: LEAD: Anne Henderson-Pollard, while out on bail awaiting sentencing, often came to my office to discuss the situation facing her husband, Jonathan J. Pollard. He had pleaded guilty to a charge of espionage on behalf of Israel. She had pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of illegally possessing classified documents.
