description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $321,980 and $772,285 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry On Southland
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the trading in the Southland Corporation's stock in the months before the company announced that it was being acquired by the descendants of the founder of the company.

title: The Yankee Wheel Of Misfortune
description: IN the Yankee statements quoting Billy Martin and Lou Piniella on their marriage vows as manager and general manager, the predominant phrase was ''looking forward.'' Each was looking forward to his duties, each was looking forward to working with the other, each was looking forward to turning the Yankees into a championship team again. But as any historian knows, looking forward to the future means first looking to the past.

title: STRATUS COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Racist Jokes in White House Reported in a Book
description: A book written by President Reagan's first Secretary of Education asserts mid-level Administration officials made racist jokes and sexist remarks in discussions on civil rights at the White House. The President's spokesman today dismissed the allegations.

title: Straker Victory Not in Cards
description: Les Straker watched the seventh inning from the dugout, then returned to the warmth of the Minnesota Twins' clubhouse. He sat there alone, his mind occupied with the events he had just seen, before the quiet was suddenly broken by a teammate, Juan Berenguer.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Highsmith a Free Agent
description: Alonzo Highsmith, a fullback who was the first pick of the Houston Oilers and the third selection over all in the National Football League college draft, was declared a free agent yesterday and is able to sign with any N.F.L. team. Judge John Gale of the 11th Circuit Court of Dade County in Miami granted a temporary injunction allowing Highsmith to negotiate with other teams and prohibiting the N.F.L. from taking any action against a team that signs him. ''It's essentially a case of collusion between Houston and some other teams to depress the market value of Alonzo,'' said Bruce Greer, Highsmith's attorney. Joe Browne, a spokesman for the N.F.L., said that league lawyers believed the courts would restore Houston's rights to Highsmith quickly. ''We believe the state court's order was issued without notice or hearing and raises serious jurisdictional or procedural issues,'' he said. Highsmith, who has been a holdout since July 28, is seeking between $2.4 million and $2.6 million over four years. The top offer from Ladd Herzeg, the Houston general manager, has been $2.2 million with a $1 million signing bonus.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The fiscal 1986 figures restated to reflect the Dec. 31, 1986, acquisition of Walter F. Morris Co. on a pooling of interest basis.

title: Divided San Francisco Eyes Election
description: Nine years after San Francisco was plunged into despair and conflict by the assassination of Mayor George Moscone, his successor, Dianne Feinstein, is nearing the end of her eventful term as Mayor.

title: Shortage Forces Giant Moves
description: A shortage of healthy offensive linemen has helped Dan Morgan and Mike Black remain with the Giants after the rest of the replacement players departed.

title: PCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOHN PORTER HOUSTON
description: John Porter Houston, professor of French and Italian at Indiana University, died of throat cancer Oct. 13 at Bloomington Hospital, Ind. He was 54 years old.

title: Aquino Declares Start Of Strong, Direct Rule
description: Addressing doubts about her forcefulness and effectiveness, President Corazon C. Aquino declared today that she was inaugurating a period of strong, direct presidential leadership.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gorbachev Is Striving to End Food Shortages
description: Under increasing pressure to produce improvements in living standards, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is pressing the party and Government to alleviate chronic food shortages as quickly as possible.

title: Caution in the Press: Was It Really a 'Crash'?
description: Despite the screaming headlines and televised scenes of trading hysteria, Monday was a day of subtlety for many of the nation's news organizations.

title: Offer for Lister
description: The Phoenix Suns have signed Alton Lister, a free agent, to an offer sheet that would make him one of the National Basketball Association's highest-paid centers, Jerry Colangelo, the club president, said. The 7-foot, 245-pound Lister played last season with the Seattle SuperSonics, but has not agreed to contract terms and is a training-camp holdout. He was the first-round draft pick of Milwaukee in 1981 and played five seasons for the Bucks before being traded to Seattle on July 1, 1986, for a center, Jack Sikma, and draft choices. Last season, Lister's best as a pro, he averaged 11.6 points, 9.4 rebounds and 2.4 blocked shots. . . . The SuperSonics have placed three guards on waivers, including Tommy Amaker of Duke, their third-round draft pick. The Sonics also cut a rookie guard, Michael Tait of Clemson, and a free-agent guard, Ricky Wilson.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax one-time gains of $24.2 million, or $1.88 a share, from the sale of the company's interest in Detroit Cellular Telephone Co., and $6.1 million, or 47 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interests in four SportsChannel cable programming networks.

title: Theodore Brameld Dies at 83; Taught Educational Theory
description: Theodore Brameld, a retired professor of educational theory, died of pneumonia Sunday at a nursing home in Durham, N.C. He was 83 years old.

title: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There are no year-ago comparisons because the company was not publicly traded until May 1987 and because it changed its method for financial reporting following a recapitalization Dec. 28, 1985.

title: The Lonely Feeling Of Small Investors
description: Vincent H. Bacon, like many people, owns stocks. But yesterday, following the worst decline in stock market history, he did not know what to do about them.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Lookalike Ads Bother A.N.A.
description: If you were to rate concerns among the members of the Association of National Advertisers here - and just for today rule out the stock market - the sameness of advertising would rate second, just after anti-advertising legislation and regulation.

title: Yuppies' Last Rites Readied
description: For the young professionals who have known only a bull market -particularly those who work on Wall Street - the effect of Monday's stock market plunge is likely to go beyond the monetary to the psychological, experts said yesterday.

title: Infant Heart Patient Gains
description: An infant who received a heart transplant a few hours after birth is recovering well and his condition has been upgraded from critical to serious but stable, a hospital spokeswoman said Monday. The infant, Paul Holc, was delivered by Caesarean section Friday when a donor heart became available.

title: Missile Tests Called Success
description: The Air Force said Monday it had conducted two successful tests of its new Amraam missile last week, both of them involving the weapon's ability to discriminate among targets. The Air Force said the first test was conducted Oct. 14 when an Amraam, or Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile, was fired at the Pacific Missile Test Center in California. The second test was held Oct. 15 at the Eglin Gulf Test Range in Florida. The two tests brought to 37 the number of successful trials out of 45 conducted to date.

title: AIDS Threat Brings New Turmoil for Gay Teen-Agers
description: One by one, the students at Harvey Milk High School dropped flowers in a wide-mouthed vase and said a prayer for the boy nicknamed Chelsea, one of the growing number of teen-agers who have died of AIDS.

title: London's Free Fall Continues
description: Stocks plummeted on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, but other leading European markets managed to achieve some stability in a climate of deep new uncertainty after Wall Street's debacle on Monday.

title: Joseph Orgel Is Dead at 84; Writer and Retired Educator
description: Joseph R. Orgel, a writer and educator who worked in the New York City public school system for almost 30 years, died of pneumonia and heart disease Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 84 years old and had lived in Pembroke Pines, Fla., for 14 years.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Limits Set on Program Trades
description: The New York Stock Exchange placed sharp restrictions on program trading yesterday, in the first major regulatory effort to curb the explosion in computer-assisted buying and selling that many believe accelerated the market's drop on Monday.

title: 9 Killed as Military Jet Plows Into Hotel
description: The pilot of an Air Force jet struggling to make an emergency landing after losing power ejected just short of Indianapolis Airport this morning, leaving the abandoned aircraft to slam into a hotel, killing at least nine people.

title: Bridge: Semifinal Hangs in Balance In the World Championships
description: Play continued here in the world team championship semifinals tonight with only one of the four matches hanging in the balance.

title: City Board Approves Guggenheim Expansion
description: After more than two years of intense debate, the Guggenheim Museum won approval last night from the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals to proceed with its plans to build a 10-story addition to its building, at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHELTER FUNDING NOW DUE BY DEC. 23
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has announced that it will distribute $15 million by Dec. 23 to help serve children and the elderly at shelters for the homeless.

title: Malle Returns to Childhood Trauma
description: When the publicity people for Louis Malle's new film were kicking around slogans for promoting it in France, one of them came up with, ''Hands off my buddy!'' The phrase is the truculent watchword of SOS Racism, an organization that combats the anti-immigrant phobia that is being stirred up and exploited by the ultra-right National Front.

title: Shultz Expresses Frustration on Talks for Mideast
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz wound up his latest round of Middle East diplomacy today with a rare expression of frustration at the emphasis that has been placed on how to get to Arab-Israeli peace talks rather than the substance of what is to be negotiated.

title: SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: SPECTRAMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,214,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $885,000 for the quarter and $2,179,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income The company began operations in October 1986 upon its acquisition of the business of Medical Products Group of Gould Inc. in a management buyout.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The third quarter results reflect a combination of earnings from its Core businesses, a previously announced after-tax gain of $163 million from recognition of pension plan over-funding through the purchase of an annuity contract with Metropolitan Life Insurance and $139 million of tax benefits from a $3 billion provision. The latest 9 months' loss is after a provision for possible credit losses of $4,197,000,000. The year-ago 9 months' net is after a provision for possible credit losses of $1,317,000,000. The per share earnings are not adjusted for the previously declared 100 percent stock dividend which is payable Nov. 10 to shareholders of record Oct. 30.

title: Convoy Starts Amid Fear of Reprisal
description: The Navy began to escort a new convoy of Kuwaiti tankers in the Persian Gulf today as the United States braced for an Iranian response to the American destruction of two Iranian offshore platforms that American officials said had been used as bases for attacks on merchant shipping.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error yesterday, an obituary of J. Walter Severinghaus, an architect, omitted part of a sentence. It should have read, ''From 1975 to 1978, Mr. Severinghaus was president of the University Club in New York City.''

title: Cards Overtake Twins to Trail Series By 2-1
description: Far from the tumult of the Metrodome, the St. Louis Cardinals finally won a game from the Minnesota Twins in the 84th World Series tonight, and just in the nick of time.

title: Harry Conover Is Dead at 74; Retired Banker and Diplomat
description: Harry Conover, a retired banker and former Foreign Service officer, died Oct. 2 at a convalescent center in Darien, Conn., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have picked up the option year for 1988 on the contracts of Jimmy Key and Rick Leach. Key had a 17-8 record with a 2.76 earned run average, and Leach, a reserve outfielder, batted .282 in 98 games. . . . Jim Murray, syndicated columnist of The Los Angeles Times, was voted the J. G. Taylor Spink Award by the Baseball Writers Association of America and will be inducted into the writers' wing of the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., next July. . . . The Miami Dolphins shipped Greg Koch, a veteran offensive tackle, to Minnesota for two draft picks. Koch, an 11th-year pro from Arkansas, was signed as a free agent in 1986 and started all 16 games for the Dolphins. . . . Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazer center, had his broken leg placed in a cast yesterday. The former star from Kentucky suffered the refracture of his right leg Saturday before an exhibition game against Cleveland. The team's physician, Dr. Robert Cook, still hasn't determined whether surgery will be required. He said Bowie might be released from Willamette Hospital in Oregon City tomorrow. . . . Gary Pettis, an outfielder for the California Angels, will undergo exploratory surgery on his left hand next week in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Raids on Jamaican Gangs Bring 124 Arrests Nationwide
description: Law-enforcement officials are carrying out a nationwide crackdown on Jamaican crime gangs and so far have arrested 124 members of what one official called ''probably this country's most violent'' organized criminals.

title: The World Has Changed; And Then With Germany and Japan
description: As recently as 1971, one economy and one currency dominated the globe. Then, when President Nixon unilaterally scrapped the rules of international finance set three decades earlier, the rest of the world had to tag along. But now, 16 years of rapid trade and investment growth have locked the fate of the U.S. economy to that of the rest of the world, and six years of domestic budget mismanagement have eroded America's capacity to lead.

title: INTERNATIONAL MICROELECRONIC PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Trottier's Hat Trick Saves the Islanders
description: The Islander hope was for a return to Terry Simpson's fundamentalist philosophy, a reaffirmation of the coach's faith in dumping and digging and defending. The reward it promised was substantial.

title: The Market: Why Does It Matter?
description: Suddenly all everybody wants to know is what's happening to the stock market. People getting off planes rush to telephones to find out if their stocks are up or down. Bus drivers ask their passengers whether they should buy or sell. Does it really matter all that much? What is the stock market, anyway?

title: Senator Evans Won't Run in '88
description: Senator Daniel J. Evans of Washington announced today that he would not seek re-election to the seat he has held for four years.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sign of the Times
description: In Mel Krupin's restaurant on Connecticut Avenue, lunchtime customers walked past a big basket of apples fixed in the center of the dining room. A sign on the basket read: ''Apples Five Cents. Don't Worry.''

title: Ungaro's Minidresses Go to a Bare Maximum
description: This morning, Emanuel Ungaro became the first designer to receive a standing ovation during the week of spring and summer fashion openings. His clothes were the shortest, snuggest and least concealing of any designer's. As an apotheosis of the miniskirt and a tribute to the female body, his collection is not likely to be surpassed. The surprise is that today old-fashioned seductive styling exerts such power.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IN 1980 Nancy Ellen Jobes was in a car accident. She was 24 years old and pregnant with her first child; the fetus was killed in the accident and had to be surgically removed. During the surgery Mrs. Jobes died, too, at least in the way I would define that term. Her body remained in the world for seven years after her self had departed, because medical technology enabled it to do so.

title: New F.B.I. Director to Take Oath of Office Next Month
description: The swearing-in of Judge William S. Sessions as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been rescheduled for Nov. 2 after two earlier ceremonies were canceled because of problems with a bleeding ulcer.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Did '29 Crash Spark The Depression?
description: In the 58 years since the frightening stock market crash of 1929, the panic of that October day has come to serve as a symbol of the economic contraction that gripped the world during the next decade. Yet historians and economists still differ over whether the collapse of share prices caused the international catastrophe known as the Great Depression or simply reflected the underlying weakness of the domestic economy.

title: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Judge Postpones Trial Of Lyndon LaRouche
description: The trial of the conspiracy theorist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. was postponed today at least until the end of November so that one of his top associates, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, can be tried first.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1987
description: The Stock Market Turmoil

title: Dana Suesse, 76, Dies; Wrote 30's Hit Songs
description: Dana Suesse, a composer and songwriter whose hits included ''You Ought to Be in Pictures,'' died of a stroke last Friday in New York City. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GRAHAM SCHEDULE CHANGE
description: The Martha Graham Dance Com-pany has scheduled two additional performances of ''Celebration'' for tomorrow and Friday at the City Cen-ter, 131 West 55th Street. The 1934 work by Miss Graham has been re-staged this season for the first time in 50 years. ''Embattled Garden'' and ''Primitive Mysteries'' will replace ''Canticle for Innocent Comedians'' Saturday night.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books: Prairie Tales
description: ''IT has been a quiet week in Lake Wobegon.'' It's just like radio, without the sound, this collection of 36 Lake Wobegon yarns that has each one starting out with this phrase, in italics, just as it was done on the air by Garrison Keillor in his 13-year run as host of public radio's ''Prairie Home Companion.'' Now that sentence before this one might be a tad longish, but it's hard not to pick up the habit from Mr. Keillor who, with marvelous fidelity to the way people speak, tacks on predicates and throws in modifiers often enough where a reading person would not expect them.

title: Reagan Begins the Process of Imposing $23 Billion in Deficit Cuts
description: The Reagan Administration today took the first step to impose $23 billion in automatic Federal spending cuts required by the budget-balancing law.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVCE reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Judge Lets Convictions Stand in Biaggi's Trial
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to set aside the recent convictions of Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito. The judge said a ''fair and impartial'' jury had returned a verdict ''compatible with the facts.''

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Shouting Questions At Reagan
description: After a day of economic crisis and uncertainty, President Reagan commented tonight on the state of the economy. But his remarks were made not in a prime-time address to the nation or at a formal news conference, but on the back lawn of the White House, shouted at reporters over the roar of a Presidential helicopter.

title: Castro Meets Iran Aide
description: Iran's Foreign Minister met President Fidel Castro of Cuba today and discussed rising tensions in the Persian Gulf, the official daily Granma said. The talks between Mr. Castro and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, who is on a two-day offical visit here, were dominated by the American attack on an Iranian installation in the gulf on Monday, the newspaper said.

title: T. J. Ross Acquired
description: Golin/Harris Communications of Chicago has officially acquired the public relations firm T. J. Ross & Associates, which will now be known as Golin/Harris, New York. The firm, maintaining its focus on financial relations and consulting, plans to move the staff into T. J. Ross offices in the Chrysler Building, 405 Lexington Avenue, at the beginning of the year. Serving as president will be Thomas Little, former president of T. J. Ross. T. J. Ross, founded by Ivy Lee in 1904, was acquired by Mr. Little last year.

title: Fear Itself
description: ''Don't just do something -stand there,'' was the advice taken by the President of the United States, as the stock market crashed and one third of the air escaped from the nation's balloon of confidence.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months results includes a writedown of $60 million for onshore equipment and facilities. The year-ago periods include a writedown of oil field services equipment and offshore drilling rigs of $187 million.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months is after a loss of $23,134,000 from discontinued operations. Preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 9 months.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $18.8 million in tax benefits related to the special addition of $700 million to the allowance for loan losses taken in the second quarter. c-Net income The latest 9 months' loss includes the effect of the loan loss provision in the second quarter.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK OF N Y reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $6,016,000 for the quarter and $18,745,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $6,233,000 for the quarter and $15,518,000 for the 9 months.

title: HERCULES WINS MARIETTA CONTRACT
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it would award a contract, expected to exceed $500 million, to the Hercules Aerospace Company for 15 sets of solid rocket motors to power the Titan 4 launching vehicle. The motors will be upgraded to carry a heavier payload.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After net of $2.8 million for the quarter and a loss of $66.7 million for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: The World Has Changed; How to Use It, First With Congress
description: Leadership! Summit! Negotiate! The chorus from Congress may finally have got its message through to the President. Maybe he's willing to talk, he says. He should be. The yearlong stalemates on the budget deficit and the foreign trade bill helped trigger the stock market crash.

title: Oysters Served Up Every Which Way
description: Louisiana contestants brought oysters or oyster liquor from home to use in the national cook-off at the annual Oyster Festival, held this weekend at the fairgrounds near this town 85 miles south of Baltimore.

title: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings for the year-ago periods were not presented since all shares were owned by the American Express Company.

title: NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Psychological Autopsy' Will Be Presented at Trial in Florida
description: A judge agreed today to let a psychiatrist give a ''psychological autopsy'' of a teen-age stripper who committed suicide.

title: Elusive Tamil Leader Called Key to Outcome of the Battle
description: As Indian troops pressed their assault on a major Tamil stronghold in Sri Lanka, officials said today that the key to the outcome was increasingly in the hands of an embattled 32-year-old rebel commander who has long outwitted his foes.

title: Spinks Is Socked With Some Laughs
description: Michael Spinks had a few laughs Monday night when he was the object of a Friars Club roast in New York.

title: Calendar; Antiques, Lectures And Mums
description: Antiques Show at Pier

title: For Commodity Traders, a Week Like No Other
description: Herbert Malkind has had trouble sleeping this week. He woke up at 3 A.M. on Tuesday and 4 A.M. today, worried whether the trades he had made the day before on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange would hold up in the morning.

title: London Journal; For Poor, Bed and Breakfast at $34 Million a Year
description: ''Sitting in that tiny room, listening to my sister raving, I may as well be back in a prison cell,'' said Patricia Stafford, a former drug addict and robber. She is trying to get back on her feet in the confines of the oddest imaginable down-and-out shelter: a narrow bed-and-breakfast hotel room with the gleam of Victoriana on the outside and the gloom of New York's single room occupancy welfare syndrome within.

title: Reports of Planes in Near Misses Show 50% Rise
description: - The number of reports about commercial aircraft involved in near collisions increased nearly 50 percent in the first nine months of this year, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Gunmen Said to Be Sikhs Kill 11 In Delhi on Eve of Hindu Festival
description: Terrorists said to be Sikhs killed at least 11 people Tuesday night in a burst of shooting here on the eve of a Hindu festival.

title: Nofziger Loses Bid to Dismiss Indictment Under Ethics Law
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a six-count indictment charging Lyn Nofziger, the former White House political aide, with violating ethics laws.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $16.2 million for reserves established for the phase out or disposal of several investments. The year-ago third quarter results reflected a deduction of $19.5 million, or 13 cents a share, for phase out or disposal of several investments. The company said included in the latest quarter and 9-month revenue are insurance and finance revenues of $2.8 billion and $8.1 billion, respectively, and the year-ago quarter revenue included $2.4 billion and 9-month revenue included $7.2 billion. Year-ago revenue for the quarter is restated.

title: XEROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time $14 million charge related to the sale of a former subsidiary and a non-recurring $42 million gain from a change in accounting for pension costs.

title: Restoring the Luster of Brass Hardware
description: LEAD: When furniture was originally delivered from the cabinetmaker's shop, the brass hardware was immaculate, to complement the wood it adorned.

title: Lawrence Rose Dead; Retired Seminary Dean
description: The Very Rev. Lawrence Rose, dean emeritus of the General Theological Seminary, died Saturday at his home in Kent, Conn., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Interruption at Pacific Exchange
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange closed its automatic execution system for five hours this morning and blamed transmission problems for the shutdown.

title: Big Volume May Benefit Treasury
description: The Treasury could collect billions of dollars in extra revenues as a result of this week's record stock market volume, some analysts said today.

title: Deficit Discussions Start on Capitol Hill
description: White House officials and Congressional leaders began talks today to see if they could reach a compromise that would reduce the budget deficit and calm nervous financial markets.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1987
description: The Stock Market Turmoil

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Friend, Not Adviser
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST REPUBLICBANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods reflect loan loss provisions of $106.4 million for the quarter and $545.6 million for the 9 months. The year-ago figures are unavailable because First Republic Bank was formed in June after the merger between Republic Bank Corp. and InterFirst Corp.

title: Westies Informer Tells How Gang Cut Up Body
description: An informer told a jury yesterday that he had helped commit a murder for the Westies gang but that he had refused to participate in dismembering the victim's body.

title: DEBATE OVER BORK BEGINS IN SENATE
description: With the majority of senators already counted in opposition, Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination finally reached the Senate floor today, three and a half months after President Reagan had sent it to Capitol Hill.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $329,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $136,000, and the 9 months includes a gain from an accounting change of $1,703,000. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $562,000 and an extraordinary credit of $300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $300,000 loss for the quarter and a gain of $1.4 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Includes net of $9.6 million, or 24 cents a share, and $117.7 million in sales from businesses sold or classified as held for sale during the latter half of 1986 for the quarter; losses from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $10.3 million for the 9 months. The latest 9 months includes net other expense of $10.3 million, principally from minority interests in foreign earnings and other miscellaneous expense items. The year-ago 9 months also included net of $6.2 million, or 15 cents a share, principally from tax settlement and other miscellaneous income items and net of $18.5 million, or 46 cents a share, from the termination of certain pension plans. The year-ago 9 months also included net sales and net income of $427.3 million and $35.8 million, or 89 cents a share, respectively, from busineses sold or classified as held for sale primarily during the latter half of 1986.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Jaguar in the House
description: While investors on and off Capitol Hill are licking their wounds from the ravages of the stock market, one member of Congress is savoring a $125 investment that won him a $60,000 Jaguar convertible. Representative Thomas A. Luken, an Ohio Democrat, and his wife, Shirley, won the XJ-S model sports car at a church raffle in Cincinnati. The Lukens, who already own a Plymouth and a Buick, have decided to sell the Jaguar. But first they have to wait for delivery.

title: Dispute on Star Wars Device Erupts
description: The former head of arms development at the nation's largest nuclear weapons laboratory has said that Edward Teller, a key scientific adviser to President Reagan, gave ''overly optimistic'' and ''technically incorrect'' information to the nation's highest policy makers regarding the X-ray laser, a nuclear device viewed as important to the Star Wars antimissile plan.

title: Mutual Lowers Datapoint Stake
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York investment firm, and a group of its affiliates have lowered their stake in the Datapoint Corporation to 5.2 percent from 6.5 percent.

title: Artisans' Lesson: Restoring the Past
description: David Bayne loves working with wood. ''When I make something out of wood, I feel like it's a contribution, something I'm sharing,'' said Mr. Bayne, a 32-year-old resident of Northfield, Vt., who has been a cabinetmaker for seven years. He is now learning to be a furniture conservator - one of a small group of specialists committed to preserving and restoring old furniture.

title: MAYTAG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $834,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,628,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. The share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: MERRY LAND & INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $2.2 million in after-tax gains on the takeover by others of the Athens Federal Savings Bank and General Shale Products.

title: KEY RATES
Sioux Falls Journal; With Wall St. Ailing, A Midwest City Sneezes
description: On Monday, a brokerage office here had to turn off an outdoor sign that tracks the Dow Jones industrial average. The sign could record no more than a 99-point drop in the stock market.

title: LTV Granted An Extension
description: The LTV Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company in Dallas, said today that a Federal bankruptcy judge in New York had granted the company an additional 120 days to file its plan of reorganization.

title: Specialists Man the Ramparts
description: All 52 specialists on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange lost money during the enormous sell-off on Monday and Tuesday, possibly as much as $750 million, trying to fulfill their traditional role of maintaining an orderly market, John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the exchange, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $15.9 million from early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $12.9 million from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Air Force Wins Ruling
description: The Air Force has scored a victory in a contracting dispute with two computer concerns, clearing the way for bidding on what has been called the computer sale of the century.

title: Chase's Profit Up 63.4%; Staff Cuts Are Planned
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had risen 63.4 percent, but also said that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs as part of a restructuring.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes provisions for loan losses of $21.5 million for the quarter and $53.6 million for the 9 months. c-Includes provisions for loan losses of $91.1 million for the quarter and $150.6 million for the 9 months.

title: A Teen-Age Mother Overcomes the Odds
description: As a pregnant 14-year-old, Shavon Glover was determined to finish junior high school and high school, despite the drumbeat predictions of relatives, neighbors and friends that she would wind up on welfare for the rest of her life.

title: New Name: Avenue Becomes a Boulevard
description: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a City Council measure changing the name of Marcus Garvey Avenue to Marcus Garvey Boulevard.

title: Producer's New Script: A Media General Deal
description: Burt Sugarman is a film producer who has become involved in a number of diverse investments in the last four years. His most recent such non-Hollywood venture is as leader of a group that said it might seek control of Media General Inc.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,214,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,009,000 for the quarter and $4,572,000 for the 9 months, and losses on disposal of $3,726,000 and $5,126,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After a loss of $79,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,037,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Open Positions on Short Sales Rise on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Oct. 15 increased from the previous month by 13.3 million shares, or 2.7 percent, to 510.2 million.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
From the Serious To the Frivolous At Saint Laurent
description: The Yves Saint Laurent collection ended with a flurry of models twirling down the stage in ribboned satin espadrilles and pastel-colored tutus.

title: Oester Draws the Line
description: Ron Oester, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman, whose season was cut short by a knee injury, says he won't report to the team next spring unless he has a contract. Murray Cook, the club's new general manger, met with Oester briefly last Friday on whether the club would exercise its option to renew Oester's contract at $650,000 a year. Cook said that ''we haven't made any definitive decision about Ron'' and that he would be back in touch with the infielder after the World Series. Oester was hurt July 4 when the Mets' Mookie Wilson slid into second base. Oester underwent surgical reconstruction of his left knee.

title: Rates Fall In Credit Markets
description: Interest rates continued to fall yesterday as the shake-up in the stock market enhanced the appeal of short- and long-term debt securities.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The third quarter loss reflected a one-time $95 million reserve established to cover costs of a new program to dispose of or restructure certain business activities. The latest 9 months' loss included reserves of $750 million established in the second quarter to cover possible writeoffs of loans to lesser anticipated as a result of establishing a program to accelerate the disposal of non-performing assets.

title: Private View of a Passionate Collector
description: ''A COLLECTOR has discretion and makes decisions,'' said Leonard A. Lauder.

title: Top Regulator, on Patrol, Puts On a Happy Face
description: As the chief regulator of the nation's stock markets, David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, spent another hectic day today keeping track of market activity and the health of the brokerage community.

title: JOHN E. DONALDSON
description: John E. Donaldson, former director of research for the U.S. Steel Corporation, died of throat cancer Monday at his home in Pittsburgh.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The latest quarter includes a non- recurring charge of more than $4.6 million. Sysco said the writedown is on anticipated loss on investments in First City Bancorp of Texas Inc.'s preferred stock. The company also said the writedown reduced the latest first quarter earnings by 11 cents.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $4,845,000 and $5,079,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,699,000 for the quarter and $4,529,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months earnings include the Distilled Spirits Business of National Distillers Corp. from May 26, 1987, and Acco World Corp. from Aug. 7, 1987. The company also said results fro both the year-ago third quarter and 9 months included restructuring charges of $144.3 million.

title: The Dance: Dennis Wayne's Troupe
description: DANCERS has always had good dancers. Ever since Dennis Wayne founded his company, Dancers, in 1975, it has been blessed with talented dancers. The group looked as good as ever on Tuesday night when it opened a week's season at the Triplex Theater of Manhattan Community College.

title: Fallout Continues, On and Off Wall St.
description: Deficit Reduction Sought White House officials and Congressional leaders discussed compromises that could reduce the budget deficit and calm nervous financial markets. It was unclear whether President Reagan might agree to some tax increases. Inquiry on Volatility An investigation into this week's stock market activity has been ordered by the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The move prompted speculation that the commission might seek to regulate program trading. Leaders of Chicago's financial futures market vehemently opposed a similar move there. Investor Panic Subsides There was little evidence of the kind of panic selling that some had feared would develop after the market's drop. Millions of small investors looked for opportunity in the midst of the market's volatility. World Markets Climb A record climb for Tokyo stock prices continued today, providing relief to jittery investors and producing forecasts that the worst may be over for Japan's market. In London, analysts predicted that the unprecedented slide would leave investors leery. A full report on the markets and the fallout, pages D1 and D12 to D17.

title: Dukakis Campaign Aid
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has appointed a new national political director for his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, filling the last vacancy left by Paul Tully in the wake of the Biden tape affair. The job went to Paul Jensen, a 42-year-old veteran of national politics and a senior associate at Public Strategies, a Washington-based consulting firm, Mr. Dukakis announced Tuesday.

title: U.N. Team to Central America
description: The United Nations said today that it was sending a preliminary peacekeeping team to Central America to see how the organization could monitor compliance with the agreement signed by the presidents of five Central American countries in August.

title: A Bizarre Aspect To Yankee Moves
description: When George Steinbrenner makes changes in the dugout or the front office, the moves usually have a bizarre nature to them. His latest shuffling or reassignment of personnel, as he likes to refer to dismissals, has the potential to be the most bizarre ever.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Penalties Under Study
description: Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League vice president who handles disciplinary matters, is considering possible penalties for Patrick Roy, the Montreal Canadiens' goalie, in conection with a slashing incident. On Monday in Montreal, Roy came out of his net during the closing minutes of a game against the Minnesota North Stars and used his stick to pound Warren Babe, a Minnesota forward, who limped off the ice with a badly bruised ankle. Herb Brooks, the coach of the North Stars, said at a practice on Tuesday he thought the league would not suspend Roy, but that ''I'll make sure Roy gets his throat cut next time.'' Montreal plays the North Stars on Nov. 27 in Bloomington, Minn. When informed of Brooks's comment, Roy promised, ''I'll be in Minnesota.''

title: MCKESSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net of $1.8 million for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: PROSECUTORS SETTLE TURF BATTLE
description: After a six-month rivalry with his Manhattan counterpart, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney, was designated last month to seek a racketeering indictment against John Gotti, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: Washington Talk: Presidential Politics; Compassion Becomes a Republican Theme
description: Republican Presidential contenders are voicing a passion for compassion.

title: With Growing Reputation, Gotti's Swagger Is Bolder
description: As John Joseph Gotti swashbuckles through his daily rounds, investigators say he has assumed a charismatic presence within the underworld. Officials also say his conviction as head of the country's largest and most powerful Mafia family is a major priority for New York City's law-enforcement hierarchy.

title: 14 Are Arrested by U.S. in Sales of Protected Birds
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service today arrested 14 people and filed charges against 50 others in the illegal sales of eagles, hawks, owls and other protected birds.

title: Tiny Leak in Shuttle Engine
description: An engine with a tiny leak has tightened the time workers have to prepare the space shuttle Discovery for the first post-Challenger shuttle flight June 2 and may force a delay, James C. Fletcher, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Admiinistration, said Tuesday. Confirming that one of the shuttle's three main engines had a leak after a test firing Oct. 10 at the National Space Technology Laboratories in Mississippi, he said a flight delay could result if the leak proved to be common to all three engines.

title: ALBERTO CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,629,000.

title: 7-Foot Celtic Rookie Makes Impression
description: Larry Bird had 24 points and 9 rebounds Tuesday night in an exhibition game against the Atlanta Hawks. That was to be expected from the Boston Celtic captain. Danny Ainge had all of his 15 points in the second quarter. That, too, was usual.

title: 4 Goals in 3d Period Unravel Rangers
description: It has become an unwelcome custom, but once again, the third period was the period of consequence for the Rangers, who can't seem to carry sufficient intensity through an entire game.

title: When Good Pitches Lead to Bad Results
description: ALL these years later, in an unhappy postgame World Series clubhouse, the scowl on Juan Berenguer's face was familiar. It was just like the one he first wore nine years ago on the mound at Shea Stadium, in the days when the Mets were searching for hope and Berenguer was part of the search.

title: THRIFTY RENT-A-CAR SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
South Africa Divestment
description: The pace of United States divestment in South Africa grew slightly this year, but its overall economic impact was weakened by many companies simply shifting to indirect investment, a report said today.

title: Company Buybacks Increase
description: Stock buybacks by major corporations accelerated yesterday as dozens of companies went hunting, both for bargains and increased insurance against takeovers.

title: Stocks in Tokyo Continue to Climb
description: The Tokyo stock market continued to soar today, buoyed by overnight reports of Wall Street's rebound.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SAVINGS BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results reflect the acquisition of Seashore Bank Shares Inc., acquired on Sept. 1 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: US LEASING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss reflected a provision for possible loan losses of $66.9 million, compared with a loan loss provision of $66 million for the year-ago period.

title: Radioactive Gauge Stolen
description: A construction gauge containing radioactive material was stolen from a parked car, and Federal officials warned that it could cause burns and cancer if opened. The gauge, used for measuring moisture and density of highway construction materials, was stolen Monday or Tuesday in south Philadelphia, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said.

title: Report on Daniels
description: An inquiry by Nevada-Las Vegas into possible recruiting violations involving Lloyd Daniels, the former New York City high school basketball star, has received contradictory information and has reached no conclusions. The report will be sent to the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The investigation stemmed from an article in Newsday last March saying that Daniels had received cash, clothing, a car, a motorcycle and free housing from Las Vegas coaches, boosters and other representatives of the school. Robert Maxson, the Nevada-Las Vegas president, said that a four-member committee he appointed to investigate the allegations found conflicting evidence after six months of interviewing witnesses. Maxson said he met Tuesday for more than two hours with Coach Jerry Tarkanian and was told by Tarkanian that he wasn't aware of any recruiting violations. Committee members said the investigation was hampered by the refusal of Daniels to answer questions about his living arrangements and about allegations of payoffs to him. Daniels, who never played for the Runnin' Rebels, dropped out of school after being arrested in February on charges of buying rock cocaine. Earlier this month, Daniels was fined after pleading guilty to attempted possession of the drug.

title: Market Turmoil; WALL STREET REBOUND WIDENS WITH GAINS FOR MOST STOCKS; DOW UP ON HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices rebounded strongly in heavy trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average surged 186.84 points.

title: BARYSHNIKOV THE STAR OF 2 DANCE PROGRAMS
description: THIS seems to be Baryshnikov Month. The film ''Dancers,'' starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, is currently in release. Tonight at 9 o'clock, cable's Arts & Entertainment Network is offering a 1982 British documentary entitled ''Baryshnikov: The Dancer and the Dance.'' And tomorrow at 9 on Channel 13, public television's ''Great Peformances'' features Misha, as he is known to friends and total strangers, performing in ''David Gordon's Made in U.S.A.''

title: Bitter Lessons Seen in Plunge
description: The historic plunge in the stock market provided many investors with bitter lessons about the workings of national and international markets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it is going to come up like it came down.'' Robert Farrell, a stock market strategist. [ A1:6. ]

title: Greenspan, Under New Pressure, Drawing Mixed Reviews
description: Some say the honeymoon is over. Others describe it as a trial by fire. Whatever the catch phrase, nearly everyone agrees that the volatile financial markets have put Alan Greenspan, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in one of the hottest seats in town.

title: NO TEARS FOR LUPONE'S RENO
description: As Reno Sweeney, the brassy nightclub singer in ''Anything Goes,'' Patti LuPone not only gets to perform such immortal Cole Porter songs as ''I Get a Kick Out of You'' and ''You're the Top,'' but also gets to tap-dance and tango, crack jokes and cut up, yearn over one man and fall in love with another, and even - as if she had not already won its heart - to go so far as to wink broadly at the audience while stealing yet another scene.

title: Rewarding Squatters Sets a Sorry Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.6 million, or 35 cents a share, for the quarter and $8 million, or $1.08 a share, for the 9 months, as a result of the adoption of FASB No. 87. The 9 months' gain was partially offset by a non-recurring charge in the second quarter of $1,113,000 for the writedown of drilling rigs and certain related equipment.

title: TGI FRIDAY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed June 9, 1987. Figures for the latest periods reflect the results of Bayliner-U.S. Marine and Sea Ray, two boat-making operations acquired in December 1986.

title: Health Group Urges Broader AIDS Panel
description: The American Public Health Association urged President Reagan's AIDS commission yesterday to suspend its deliberations until it was reconstituted to include public health leaders, scientific experts on AIDS and representatives of major risk groups such as homosexuals.

title: Hawaiian Air Bid
description: Christopher B. Hemmeter, the hotel developer, said he might be unable to arrange financing for the proposed $100 million acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines because of adverse market conditions. Last month, his company, Hemmeter Investors Inc. of Honolulu, and HAG Inc., parent of the islands' largest airline, agreed to a $50-a-share merger. The offer expires on April 1 and has yet to be withdrawn.

title: Gen. Ho Ying-chin Dies at 97; A Nationalist Chinese Leader
description: Gen. Ho Ying-chin, a former Minister of Defense in the Chinese Nationalist Government who served briefly in 1949 as his country's Prime Minister before the Communist takeover of mainland China, died of heart and lung failure Wednesday in Taipei. He was 97 years old.

title: Mrs. Reagan Leaving The Hospital Today
description: Nancy Reagan will return to the White House on Thursday, five days after surgery for the removal of a cancerous left breast, President Reagan announced today.

title: Under Pressure, Biaggi Suspends Voting in House
description: Under an informal and unpublicized compromise, Representative Mario Biaggi has not voted in Congress since his conviction last month on charges of accepting unlawful gratuities and obstruction of justice, Congressional aides say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Blackhawks 5, Red Wings 1: Denis Savard scored two goals, including a short-handed one with 45 seconds remaining in the second period, to lead Chicago to its fifth straight victory, a 5-1 decision last night over the Red Wings at Detroit. Chicago held a 3-1 lead when Behn Wilson was assessed a five-minute penalty and an automatic game misconduct for spearing Detroit's Shawn Burr at 15:48 of the second period. With the Blackhawks killing off the major penalty, Savard took a pass in the center ice zone from Steve Larmer and worked round the Detroit defenseman, Mike O'Connell forhis sixth goal. Savard's first goal came at 6:50 into the game.(AP) Whalers 5, Sabres 3: Dave Tippett scored twice in the third period as Hartford rallied for a victory over Buffalo last night at Buffalo. Tippett scored his first goal of the season at 11:16 on a power play, scooping a backhand pass from Dana Murzyn past Tom Barrasso. Just 2:04 later, Tippett scored again. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 104, Nets 95: Charles Barkley scored on a layup off a defensive rebound to give Philadelphia the lead one minute before halftime and the 76ers kept their lead through the second half last night in a 104-95 victory over New Jersey in a National Basketball Association preseason game at Charleston, W. Va. The Nets, who had led nearly all of the first half, hit only 3 of 16 shots in the third quarter and only 8 of 28 in the fourth quarter. (AP) TENNIS Lendl and Becker Advance: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, who is still feeling the aftereffects of a fever, won their first-round matches yesterday in the Seiko tournament in Tokyo. Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, trounced Jonathan Canter of the United States, 6-1, 6-4, and Becker, the world's fourth-ranked player, battled to a 7-5, 7-5 triumph over Jim Grabb, an American ranked 78th. (AP) Jordan Upsets Garrison: Unseeded Kathy Jordan posted her biggest victory in more than a year yesterday when she upset fourth-seeded Zina Garrison, 6-7, 6-2, 6-0, in an all-American first-round match in the $200,000 Volvo Classic women's tournament in Brighton, England. Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia also won. (AP) GYMNASTICS Soviet Women Lead: The Soviet Union held off a major challenge by Rumania to lead the women's team event after the compulsory exercises yesterday at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Rumania. (AP)

title: GTE Fiber Optics
description: The GTE Corporation said its GTE Laboratories had developed a high-speed fiber-optic system that could nearly triple the number of broadcast-quality video channels that could be transmitted. The cable is made up of thin strands of glass over which phone calls, computer traffic and video signals are transmitted as light waves. GTE said the system could handle up to 60 video channels and was an important step in developing fiber-optic services for the home. The system combines high-speed lasers and photo detectors in a way usually used in satellite transmission, the company said.

title: STOCK TURMOIL ENCOURGAING ANALYSTS TO CHALENGE HIS SUPPLY-SIDE POLICIES
description: The stock market's collapse has given many economists who have been critical of President Reagan's economic policies the dramatic, tangible evidence they have sought to make their case more strongly.

title: News Session By President
description: President Reagan's news conference will be broadcast live at 8 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the address, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast. In New York City, Channel 13 will provide a tape-delayed broadcast at 11 P.M.

title: Home Improvement; PREPARING RADIATORS FOR WINTER
description: RESTARTING either hot water radiators or steam radiators at the beginning of a new heating season sometimes requires more than merely opening the supply valves.

title: College Football Notebook; Ryan Passes March Eli Down the Field
description: The circumstances are ideal for Kelly Ryan to lift, push, shove or even provoke his Yale team into a victory over Pennsylvania in the Yale Bowl on Saturday.

title: Robert Madden Hill Is Dead, Federal Appeals Court Judge
description: Judge Robert Madden Hill of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, who presided over the Billy Sol Estes trial in 1979 as a Federal District judge, died Monday on a flight from Africa. He was 59 years old.

title: AIDS Deaths in New York Are Showing New Pattern
description: Dramatically revising current official statistics, top New York City health officials reported yesterday that AIDS has killed more intravenous drug addicts than homosexuals in the city.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Cablesystems Corp., Beverly, Mass., said a merger with Continental Cablevision Inc. had been approved by both companies' board of directors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ANDOVER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings were not available as the company converted to stock ownership in May 1986.

title: 3 Ex-Customs Aides Charged With Aiding in Drug Imports
description: Three former United States Customs supervisors who are suspected of warning smugglers away from patrol boats and steering agents in the wrong direction were among 23 people charged Tuesday with importing cocaine and marijuana.

title: A WITNESS SAYS SUSPECT IN CLASH HAD A BALL BAT
description: A Queens teen-ager testified yesterday that he saw a baseball bat in the hands of another youth who, prosecutors say, had used the bat shortly before to beat a black man in the Howard Beach case.

title: Tassels and Tiebacks
description: RONNIE HENDLER is the third generation of the Hendler family, and the first woman, to work at Hyman Hendler & Sons, a ribbon and trimming shop. She is pleased about the popularity of the English country style. ''The chintzy English look is very big, so tassels fit perfectly,'' she said.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Time Up for Iran Panels
description: Under the resolutions that created them, the special Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair are to go out of existence Oct. 30. But the preparation of the committees' final report took longer than anticipated, and the report has to be declassified by the White House and then printed. As a result, the Senate and House are expected to vote next week to extend the life of the panels for a few weeks.

title: Placating the Stars of 'Whales'
description: There were no real whales in ''The Whales of August'' and no place to buy a cup of coffee on the island where the movie was made. The weather was nasty, and the director had to point his camera at whirlpools and pretend they were whales. The 90-year-old star wore four pairs of leg warmers under her summer dress, and the 78-year-old co-star butted heads with the director every day.

title: Twins Joined at Head Undergo First Surgery
description: Surgeons at Soweto's hospital have completed the first phase of an intricate surgical procedure to separate 10-month-old twins joined at the head.

title: Daughters of Eli
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Britain and U.S. to Compete In the Bermuda Bowl Final
description: Britain will face the United States in the open series when the world championship finals begin here Thursday, and it will be France against the United States in the women's division.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflects the 2-for-1 stock split which became effective June 10, 1987.

MARION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; On the Phones
description: Over the summer, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company installed a new telephone system for all the offices of the House of Representatives. By all accounts, the system has more bugs than a draft horse in July.

title: Cetus and Squibb Cancel Agreement
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said today that it was canceling an agreement under which the Squibb Corporation was to acquire a 5 percent equity stake in Cetus, as well as certain licensing arrangements between the two companies. Cetus said, however, that the core of the agreement, a research and development joint venture with Squibb, would survive.

title: Small Investors Seize the Moment, Hunt for Deals
description: As the stock ticker flashed by at a crowded discount brokerage firm in Los Angeles yesterday afternoon, Ray Bachar studied the numbers for several minutes, trying to decide what to do.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Intellicorp-I.B.M Software Deal
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had entered a joint-development agreement with Intellicorp Inc., a company specializing in artificial intelligence technology. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Goodyear Net Decreases 2%
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest tire company, said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent, to $178.7 million, from $182.3 million a year ago.

title: Integrity Panel Reviews Cuomo and Koch Reports
description: The State Commission on Integrity in Government is checking the campaign-financing reports of Governor Cuomo and other statewide officials, as well as Mayor Koch and the entire Board of Estimate.

title: American in Paris Adds a Happy Note
description: The week of French ready-to-wear openings ended on a joyous note as Patrick Kelly, an American from Vicksburg, Miss., presented a collection of lively, unpretentious clothes that made fashion look like fun. Not since the spring and summer openings began a week ago with the first ready-to-wear collection of Christian Lacroix has there been such an unforced feeling of happiness.

title: Pollyannas of Capitalism
description: LEAD: Although the huge financial shakeout we have just experienced was not inevitable, it was to some extent predictable. As 20th century history shows, a period of conservative Republican dominance leads to a failed capitalism, while a period of liberal Democratic dominance creates and sustains the conditions for successful capitalism.

title: Watching, Waiting And Often Buying
description: Robert Gore

title: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Financial statements have been restated as a pooling of interests to account for the merger with Vitramon Inc., acquired July 17. A $4,995,000 provision for restructured operations taken in the latest 9 months includes costs related to the consolidation of facilities and the discontinuance of certain unprofitable products. The latest 9 months also includes $5,389,000 from a patent infringement recovery in settlement of litigation.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $20,000,000 for both the quarter and 9 months from the sale of its snack food business, and the 9-month also includes a loss from discontinued operations of the snack food operations of $291,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $539,000 and $1,520,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $15,100,000 on the sale of a smokeless tabacco business. Year-ago sales for the quarter and 9 months includes $56.2 million and $163 million, respectively, from Metropolitan Distribution Services, which was sold in September 1986.

title: Doctor Testifies on Reasons for Girl's Suicide
description: An expert on suicide testified today that a Fort Lauderdale woman had created a psychological climate that emotionally trapped her 17-year-old daughter and was instrumental in the teen-ager's decision to take her own life last year.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dividing Perennials For Vigor In Spring
description: LEAD: FLOWERING perennials are in vogue again. But these old-fashioned plants, capable of reappearing in the garden year after year, may prove just a passing fancy if their reputation for not needing attention is taken too seriously. Tender loving care is especially required in autumn, when perennials should be protected against winter cold and given a head start for spring.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amoco Profit Up Sharply
description: The Amoco Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter profits were $412 million, or $1.60 a share, a substantial improvement over the comparable quarter last year, primarily because of higher crude oil prices.

title: Washington Talk: Religion; Bahais Open a Lobbying Operation
description: The Bahai religion, which stresses such principles as universal brotherhood and social equality, requires that its members abstain from partisan politics.

title: Mum's the Word From Yankee Leaders
description: The owner does not return phone calls. The new general manager can't be reached, either. The manager has taken up temporary residence somewhere in Manhattan, but the people who know aren't saying where.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rabbits Produce Anti-Cold Agent; Chicken Soup Stock Is Unchanged
description: Protective antibodies have been produced in rabbits against viruses of the common cold, suggesting that vaccines might someday be possible against these widespread infections, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Quake Close to San Francisco
description: A moderate earthquake rattled the San Francisco Bay area tonight, but officials said there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.

title: PULITZER PUBLISHING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tackling Everyday Economic Problems
description: Robert M. Solow was once jokingly told by his father, Milton, an international fur buyer whose work involved handling plenty of documents, ''We do the same thing - deliver papers.''

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALL-TO-WALL CARPETS: COMFORT ZONES IN A CHILLY WORLD
description: IN 1969, an industry report on the ''Wall-to-Wall 70's'' predicted a boundless future for wall-to-wall carpeting, that tried and trod-upon domestic staple that lies cushily underfoot.

title: It's Morning Again
description: The noise you heard was not just the crash of the market. It was the crumbling of public support for Ronald Reagan.

title: 2d Bus Lane Is Sought For Tunnel
description: Hoping to please most commuters most of the time, even if the rest are inconvenienced, New Jersey officials are seeking bus riders' support for a second bus lane into the Lincoln Tunnel during the morning rush.

title: Giants Living Life of Losers
description: The Giants are an 0-5 team and, like it or not, they are being treated like one by their coach and by the news media.

title: Gaetti, Brunansky Lose Their Chances
description: The moments came back clearly. Gary Gaetti and Tom Brunansky could see the fifth inning, and then the seventh, as if they had just happened. They became lost chances for the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: Bowie Optimistic
description: Sam Bowie, the often-injured center of the Portland Trail Blazers, said yesterday he hoped he could eventually resume his career. ''I feel it would be cheating the organization and cheating myself not to give it another try,'' the 7-foot-1 former Kentucky player said at a news conference just before his release from Willamette Falls Hospital in Oregon City. ''If I know myself,'' he said, ''I'll be back.'' Bowie spoke from a wheelchair with his lower right leg in a cast, the result of a fracture suffered during warm-ups Saturday night before the Blazers' exhibition opener. It was his fourth broken leg in six years.

title: Blanton's Rights Restored
description: A judge has restored former Gov. Ray Blanton's rights to citizenship despite a contention by United State Attorney Joe Brown that such action would be an ''insult'' to Tennesseans because of Mr. Blanton's criminal record as a felon. In handing down the decision Tuesday, Judge Harry Lester of Circuit Court told Mr. Blanton, ''I don't see how it would help anybody for me to deny your citizenship.'' Mr. Blanton, who was Governor from 1975 to 1979, was convicted of extortion and liquor license conspiracy in 1981 and served two years in Federal prison.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Broadway column of Weekend last Friday gave an incorrect telephone number for ''Tamara,'' a play beginning on Nov. 9 at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The number is 307-7171.

title: House Votes to Make Permanent Law Covering Special Prosecutors
description: The House voted by a wide margin today to make permanent the law authorizing special prosecutors to investigate allegations of wrongdoing against senior Government officials, setting the stage for a possible confrontation with the Reagan Administration.

title: Reagan Asks Congress To Restore Foreign Aid
description: President Reagan criticized Congress today for cutting what he said was a ''rock-bottom request'' for foreign aid.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,835,000.

title: Money Managers Seek Bargains Amid the Ruins
description: Money managers who purchased stocks during Monday's debacle and Tuesday's partial recovery snapped up blue-chip issues at bargain prices, thanks to the sharply rebounding market yesterday. One reason for their move back into stocks, these professionals said, was that prices had simply fallen too far too fast.

title: 'Replacement' Cardinals Won't Quit
description: This was before Tom Lawless ticked off the Minnesota Twins with his home-run trot last night. On Tuesday, Tommy Herr had sounded almost disappointed as he described what a nice, quiet bunch of professionals the Minnesota Twins seem to be.

title: MDC HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Proof of Gorbachev Pudding Is in Soviet Tasting; What Makes Ivan Run
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glittering Tribute to Audrey Hepburn
description: IN ''Sabrina,'' the romantic comedy she made for Billy Wilder in 1954, Audrey Hepburn is told by a fellow student in a Parisian cooking class that when people are happily in love they burn their souffles. If the 250 guests at the black-tie event honoring Miss Hepburn at the Museum of Modern Art had decided to bake souffles on the spot, there is no doubt that every one of them would have been charred.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALBANY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officials Laud Pilot's Efforts in Crash
description: The military pilot whose jet lost power and hit a hotel Tuesday, killing nine people, ''did everything he could'' to avoid the disaster before ejecting safely, an Air Force general said today.

title: NEW MIDEAST PLAN DISCUSSED BY U.S., ISRAEL AND JORDAN
description: Israel, Jordan and the United States are discussing a new proposal for Middle East peace talks in which Jordan and Israel would negotiate directly under the joint auspices of Moscow and Washington, a senior Israeli official said today.

title: MUSIC: COMPOSERS GROUP
description: SURELY the American Composers Orchestra could have assembled a better selection of works to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the American Composers Alliance than the program put together Tuesday evening in Merkin Concert Hall.

title: A. M. AL-KAISOUNI
description: Abdel Muneim al-Kaisouni, Former Egyptian Finance and Economy Minister, died of a heart attack today in London, the national Middle East News Agency reported. He was 71 years old.

The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Asset Sale By First Interstate
description: The First Interstate Bancorp today disclosed a plan to sell or spin off low-margin and problem loans and businesses to focus on potentially more profitable retail banking and lending to medium-sized companies.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Announced they will not pick up the option on the contract of Gary Lucas, pitcher, for the 1988 season. BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Announced that Larry Smith, forward, will be out at least two weeks because of a pulled thigh muscle. LOS ANGELES LAKERS (NBA) -Waived Willie Glass and Ralph Talley, forwards. PHOENIX (NBA) - Released Greg Spurling, center. FOOTBALL DETROIT (NFC) - Retained John Bostic, defensive end; George McDuffie and Charles Benson, defensive linemen; Mike Prindle, place-kicker; Thomas Boyd, linebacker; Gary Ellerson, running back, and Eric Truvillion, wide receiver, from their replacement roster. JETS (AFC) - Released Don Smith, offensive lineman. Placed Jim Haslett, linebacker; Michael Harper, wide receiver, and Gordon King, tackle, on injured reserve. LOS ANGELES RAIDERS (AFC) -Retained Zeph Lee, running back; Shawn Regent and Steve Wright, offensive linemen; Eddie Anderson, Willie Teal, Rod Hill and Greg Hill, defensive backs; Carl Aikens and David Williams, wide receivers, and Ronnie Washington, linebacker, from their replacement roster. Placed John Zogg, offensive lineman; Vic Stagliano, running back; Ted Chapman, defensive lineman; Keith Browner, linebacker, and Ricky Williams, defensive back, on injured reserve. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed James Hood, wide receiver, and Bob Williams, tight end.
