Washington Post Trading
description: For two and a half days this week, during the course of the widest gyrations in stock market history, stockholders of the Washington Post Company had no idea how their stock performed.

title: Yield Rise 8th in Row
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday for the eighth consecutive week.

title: Net at Allegis Declines 25%
description: The Allegis Corporation, which is selling off some of its businesses, said today that third-quarter earnings fell 25 percent, to $82.3 million, or $1.41 a share, from $109.8 million, or $2.43 a share, while revenue increased 15 percent, to $2.26 billion from $1.96 billion. But earnings from continuing operations rose to $77.4 million, or $1.33 a share, from $30 million, or 66 cents, a year earlier. Profit at the Allegis United

title: City Opera: 'Fledermaus' Cast Changes
description: HOW one responds to the New York City Opera's current ''Fledermaus'' production will depend on one's taste for the Americanization of European originals. For some, it's a crudely all-American romp; for me, it seemed to offer a fairly reasonable fusion of the distinct yet linked traditions of the Viennese operetta and the American musical.

title: OFFICELAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 310
description: The figures for the Toronto company are in U.S. funds.

title: Pollyannas and Capitalism
description: LEAD: Although the huge financial shakeout we have just experienced was not inevitable, it was to some extent predictable. As 20th century history shows, a period of conservative Republican dominance leads to a failed capitalism, while a period of liberal Democratic dominance creates and sustains the conditions for successful capitalism.

title: Stage: The Roundabout Offers 'Of Mice and Men'
description: FOR what John Steinbeck accurately referred to as a ''little book,'' ''Of Mice and Men'' has had a far-reaching success - as a best-selling novel, Broadway play (it was named best play of 1937 by the New York Drama Critics Circle) and Hollywood movie. In its various incarnations, it has remained, definitively, a work of its period, a time of propulsive social consciousness. In its revival at the Roundabout Theater Company, Mr. Steinbeck's dramatization of his novel retains its durability as well as a kind of folkloric innocence. Despite the familiarity of the material, the play is untarnished as a challenging exercise for actors, especially for the actor who is cast in the role of the inarticulate Lennie.

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1987.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metro Matters; Life Imitates Art In City of Wealth And Welfare
description: Sherman McCoy, who was 38 years old and owned a 14-room Park Avenue apartment and a house on Old Drover's Mooring Lane in Southampton, had taken a telephone order for zero-coupon bonds that brought him a $50,000 commission just like that when the phrase -Masters of the Universe - first bubbled into his brain, then burst.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $900,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $5 million for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1 million and $1.5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a loss of $1,712,000 from bond redemption.

title: Mecham Campaign Loan Subject of Inquiry
description: The State Attorney General is looking into Gov. Evan Mecham's failure to disclose a $350,000 loan he received before his election last fall, , The Arizona Republic newspaper reported today. State law requires such disclosures.

title: India in a New Offer to Tamil Rebels
description: India made a new offer of amnesty to Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka today if they surrendered their arms to an Indian peacekeeping force, an Indian diplomat said here. There was no immediate reply from the guerrillas.

title: Surgery for Molitor
description: The Milwaukee Brewers' Paul Molitor has undergone successful elbow surgery, club officials said. Molitor was bothered by a series of injuries last season and was placed on the disabled list twice. When he returned after the All-Star Game break, Molitor was inserted into the lineup as the designated hitter because the elbow injury hampered his throwing. He proceeded to go on a 39-game hitting streak.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
England Mourns Its Storm-Felled Trees
description: In the sunshine that followed the storm, the wounds of smashed brown limbs and torn green earth seemed to torment the English. The work of some of the greatest landscape architects of the past 200 years now lies askew across southern England as mournful arboriculturists attempt a detailed toll on the loss of tree life caused by the powerful gale that struck last Thursday night.

title: Peter Jennings in 'We The People'
description: ''WE THE PEOPLE'' has a fine sense of complexity. Truth, justice and the American way of life may sound like simple notions, but, of course, they are not. ''We the People,'' a four-part series, begins tonight by examining the First Amendment in a context in which it should be examined: an arena where ideas and impulses battle and real people get bruised. The program, on Channels 13 and 50 at 10 P.M., has vitality.

title: Louisiana Governor In Big Test
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards strutted on the stage, a cross between a defiant bantam rooster and a preacher asking the crowd to step up and be saved.

title: Forsch Was Ready for Call
description: Just to be sure, Bob Forsch had checked for any signs of trouble. He watched as Greg Mathews, the starting pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, warmed up for the fourth game of the World Series.

title: Home Beat; Little Chairs, Big Looks
description: SEVENTEEN years ago, when her son Luke was born, Suzanne Lipschutz, the owner of the Second Hand Rose antiques shop, began collecting antique children's furniture. ''First I bought the furniture for Luke's room,'' she said. ''Now I collect the furniture because the detail is so beautiful.

title: Net at Morgan Stanley Jumps
description: The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. announced yesterday that earnings in the third quarter soared 84.6 percent, on a 53.6 percent increase in total revenues.

title: NEW YORK INCREASES FINES FOR LANDLORDS IN SAFETY VIOLATIONS
description: Fines for hazardous violations in New York City residential buildings will increase, from $25 to $125 a day, under a new law signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Policy by Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Call In Loans to Brokers or Demand More Collateral
description: Leading commercial banks have been calling in loans made to stockbrokers or demanding more collateral in the wake of Monday's 508-point decline in the stock market.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter's net includes a gain of about $88 million frm the purchase of annuity contracts in settlement of a portion of Chase's pension plan obligation. It also includes a special $26 million charge for expenses relating to the restructuring of Chase's network, including a significant reduction in staff levels in domestic offices. The quarter net also includes sthe utilization of about $50 million of the federal income tax benefits which arose from the 1987 second quarter $1.6 billion special addition to the reserve for credit losses related to refinancing companies. The year-ago quarter includes a gain of $60 million from the sale of a data processing subsidiary and a special charge of $16 million provided principally for expenses associated with the restructuring of Chase's overseas network.

title: Contras Release Two Clergymen
description: - A Roman Catholic priest said today that he and another clergyman held by Nicaraguan rebels for 11 days were free, and that they had been threatened and treated poorly during their captivity.

title: HONDURAN URGING HALT IN CONTRA AID
description: President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras said today that American military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels should be suspended at least until next January.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $24,000 for the quarter and $304,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $499,000. The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months net include a gain of $1,029,000 after taxes resulting from the conversion of certain debentures into a subsidiary's common.

title: On Ex-Dissident's Visit, Amazement in Moscow
description: When Alex Goldfarb's sister Olga saw him off at the airport here in 1975, she assumed they would meet soon in the West. But her exit visa was never granted, and the prospects of a reunion faded for 12 years.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $8,300,000 and $209,400,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $4,500,000 for the quarter and a loss of $87,000,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The latest quarter and 9-month results include unusual after-tax gains of $50,600,000 and $64,200,000, respectively; the unusual net gain of $50.6 million represented an installment on the sale of its Arizona properties and the termination of a currency exchange protection agreement in Mexico. The year-ago quarter and 9-month results include an unusual after-tax gain of $113,100,000; this after-tax gain in the third quarter was the net result of a gain from a pension settlement after restructuring costs. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Opera: New Principals In the Met's 'Manon'
description: THE macabre caricature of Massenet's ''Manon'' currently offered by the Metropolitan Opera was partly redeemed Monday night by a truly memorable portrayal of the Chevalier des Grieux, sung for the first time in New York by Alfredo Kraus.

title: METROPOLITAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wright Buildings: The Future and Past
description: The agenda was twofold: to discuss the future of Frank Lloyd Wright's remaining buildings, and for those who lived in Wright-designed houses, to share restoration experiences. This weekend 160 Wright homeowners and 52 architectural historians, curators and academics met at the third annual ''Wright Places'' conference and tour, sponsored by the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio Foundation here.

title: U.N. PRAISES DANNY KAYE AT TRIBUTE
description: With pictures, words and music, the United Nations tonight payed tribute to the memory of Danny Kaye, the impish Brooklyn-born entertainer who spent the last decades of his life as the indefatigable United Nations Ambassador at Large for the world's children.

title: For Embattled Baker, a Gain in Authority
description: To much of Wall Street, the rout of the Dow was the Baker rout. James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of the Treasury, set out to fight a fire in one corner of his universe, and overlooked the smoke in another.

title: Soviet Team Arrives
description: The Soviet Union's national basketball team, whose plane trip from Moscow was delayed a day because of fog, arrived here tonight for an international exhibition series that will include the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association.

title: FMC GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its latest quarter results benefited from higher prices of gold and silver and higher production volume based on improved processing efficiencies at its Jerritt Canyon Mine.

title: McMahon Is Ready
description: Jim McMahon is not only ready to quarterback the Chicago Bears again after a layoff of nearly a year with a shoulder injury, but he also expects to assume his starting role soon. ''I feel ready to play,'' McMahon said yesterday, ''and if I do well in Tampa Bay, I'll expect to start the following week.'' Mike Tomczak started seven games last year after McMahon was injured and won them all. Tomczak also won two this season before the players went on strike.

title: The Glitz Is Gone
description: The binge is over. It couldn't go on forever -the quick fortunes, the midnight raids and computer-driven program trades, the junk bonds, poison pills, leveraged buyouts, options - all the glitz and glamour, the danger and thrill. It's over.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a write-off of deferred recapitalization costs of $10.7 million. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a recapitalization.

title: Friend of Arts Award To Go To Martin E. Segal
description: Martin E. Segal, a longtime supporter and patron of the arts, will be honored Sunday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, with a dinner and presentation of Town Hall's annual Friend of the Arts award. On the same date, Town Hall will mark its 66th anniversary. Both events will be commemorated with an all-Gershwin piano program in the concert hall by Veri and Jamanis, a husband-and-wife duo, at 4 P.M. A reception will follow in the N.Y.U. Club, upstairs in the same building, at 6:15. The dinner and award presentation for Mr. Segal begin at 7.

title: Village Restaurateur Give Up After Holding Police at Bay
description: A 42-year-old restaurant owner barricaded himself inside his Greenwich Village apartment last night, fired six shots from a .45 pistol into the air and held the police at bay for eight hours before surrendering early today, officials said.

title: C-SPAN's Spotlight Brings Quiet Corners of Campaigning Into View
description: Bruce Babbitt subscribed to it to help him learn how to look better on television. Tom Rath, adviser to Senator Bob Dole in New Hampshire, uses it to observe campaign rivals with a degree of intimacy unheard of in previous elections. And it played an important role in the disintegration of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s campaign.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $5 million and an extraordinary charge of $56.2 million. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $3.6 milion for the 9 months. There were no share earnings for the year-ago quarter and 9 months because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: DANCE: MAGUY MARIN
description: WHAT will Maguy Marin do next? To introduce her dance company's week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave's Festival, the French choreographer gave us nude dancers in ''Babel Babel.'' Fair enough. On Tuesday night, the New York premiere of her dance-theater piece ''Eden,'' gave us dancers who only looked nude. Actually, they were in fleshlike leotards with painted genitals and breasts.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Good Revolution for Federal Courts?
description: After Nov. 1, a person who commits a Federal crime will no longer be subject to indeterminate sentencing and parole. In concept, that's a welcome revolution - current sentencing and parole practices are outmoded and confusing.

title: ALLEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,692,000 for the quarter and $48,930,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $79,834,000 and $115,207,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ADOBE RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,374,000 and $10,212,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss The company said in the latest third quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Merck Offers Free Distribution of New River Blindness Drug
description: Merck & Company announced today that it had developed a drug to treat river blindness and would distribute it free to countries that request it.

title: NATO, Wary of Soviet Inroads, Considers a Post-Summit Meeting
description: Amid deepening concern over the inroads of Soviet diplomatic efforts on Western European opinion, senior NATO diplomats are exploring the idea of a meeting of alliance leaders after an expected encounter between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev this autumn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the evidence that female AIDS patients are dying more quickly than male ones omitted the identity of the organization that detected this difference in California. The Ursa Institute made the finding in a consulting project, directed by Paul Harder, for the state health agency.

title: INLAND STEEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,246,000 and $9,080,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,000,00 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Devils Slug Their Way Past Penguins
description: They packed them into the penalty boxes like sardines tonight at the Civic Arena, but nothing deterred the Penguins and the Devils from fighting.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Marines in Shorts
description: For nine years the United States Marines have had a friendly side bet with their cousins across the Atlantic, the British Royal Marines, as to which could outrun the other in the Marine Corps Marathon, a race that has become such a popular fixture in the capital that it attracts 10,000 runners from around the world.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Stennis Effect
description: Senator John C. Stennis's announcement this week that he will not run for re-election next year raised intriguing questions about the Democratic leadership in the Senate. The retirement will leave openings that could provide Senator Robert C. Byrd a graceful way to relinquish his post as Democratic leader and move into other prestigious positions.

title: Cards Turn On Power and Turn Off Twins
description: Outgunned and outscored in the World Series, the St. Louis Cardinals finally found their long-lost striking power tonight, and struck. And their secret weapon was a utility infielder named Tom Lawless who hadn't hit a home run in three and a half years.

title: SALVADOR DIVIDED OVER AID TO POLICE
description: A new package of United States aid for the police here has touched off a debate about how to improve the Government's human rights record and prompted opposition both from human rights advocates and some military leaders.

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Firms Face Losses, Small Ones Shut Down
description: A number of Wall Street firms suffered big trading losses from the stock market's plunge, although the true extent of the losses may not be known for several months, analysts say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 A new plan for Mideast peace talks isbeing discussed by Israel, Jordan and Washington, in which Jordan and Israel would negotiate directly under the joint auspices of Washington and Moscow, an Israeli official said.

title: Bregman Raises Multifoods Stake
description: Bregman Partners is still interested in the International Multifoods Corporation, despite the stock market's free fall. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Canadian partnership, consisting of the Belzberg and the Bregman families, said that it had increased its stake in the Minneapolis-based food processing company to 9.4 percent, from 7.4 percent. Between Oct. 16 and Oct. 20, Bregman Partners bought 306,500 shares. Bregman Partners has said it might seek control of the company.

title: Canadian Stocks Rise
description: Canada's stock exchanges followed Wall Street in a sharp rebound today from this week's record plunge. Preliminary figures showed the Toronto exchange's 300-stock index was up 273.1 points at the close, to 3,250.4. This represented a 9.2 percent gain from Tuesday's close.

title: HAROLD V. WEBB
description: Harold V. Webb, former executive director of the National School Boards Association, died of cancer Monday at the Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 68 years old. Mr. Webb, who lived in Wilmette, Ill., served from 1961 to 1977 as executive director of the association, which has its headquarters in Alexandria, Va., and represents 15,000 of the nation's local school boards. He later founded a firm that helped school boards find new superintendents. He was executive director of the Wyoming School Boards Association from 1953 to 1958.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June. The company said year-ago first quarter includes operations which have been sold.

title: Judge Robert H. Gollmar, 84; Presided Over 'Psycho' Trial
description: Judge Robert H. Gollmar, who presided at the trial of Edward Gein, a murderer whose case inspired the novel ''Psycho'' and the Alfred Hitchcock film of the same name, died Monday. He was 84 year old.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32 million. c-Includes tax credits of $26 million and $80 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hers
description: I SLAPPED my mother once. She did something unforgivable, and I wanted her to know it. She made me so mad that I didn't even realize I had hit her.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a provision of $700,000, or 19 cents a share for relocation costs.

title: Stop Do-It-Yourself Peacekeeping
description: LEAD: Moscow's decision to pay its United Nations dues follows Mikhail S. Gorbachev's extraordinary call for wider use of United Nations forces in ''cease-fires and armistice agreements.'' This apparent change in policy comes at a moment when America is engaged in dangerous do-it-yourself peacekeeping in the Gulf.

title: ASYLUM FOR SOVIET DANCER
description: A Soviet dancer who left the Moscow Ballet last week during its United States tour has been granted political asylum in the United States, immigration officials said today.

title: 'Rock-Dwelling Predators,' on CBS
description: WHAT have we here? A fine wildlife documentary, for one thing; an interesting choice for network prime-time programming, for another. ''Mysteries of the Rock-Dwelling Predators,'' on Channel 2 at 8:30 P.M., pre-empts, as they say, the CBS Vietnam series ''Tour of Duty.'' Lions, leopards and little furry creatures replace grunts and Vietcong.

title: Jets Trying to Let Bygones Be Bygones
description: The Jets began putting in their game plan this afternoon for the game Sunday against the Washington Redskins, but even as the players moved through the locker room and filtered out to practice, there was an unmistakable sense of a team struggling to forget the divisiveness that had surfaced during the 24-day players' strike.

title: Advertising; Difficulties In Client Relations
description: As the effectiveness of advertising increases so does the difficulty of advertising effectively.

title: Money Markets Attracting Investors
description: The stock market's record plunge on Monday spurred one of the highest weekly investment increases in money market funds in history, a private survey shows.

title: LEGAL CHALLENGES TESTED IN POLAND
description: A Polish court opened hearings today into charges that the chief Government spokesman slandered four Polish citizens by asserting that they had subversive ties to an official of the United States Embassy.

title: Newsweek Offering The Match Plan
description: Although plainly unhappy about Time magazine's announced MAX-Plan of advertising rates, Gerard Smith, publisher of Newsweek, is going to initiate a similar plan with the Jan. 4 issue. His is called the Match Plan. The essence of both plans is to reward advertisers with discounts for increasing the share of all news weekly spending in a single magazine.

title: Long Honeymoon Ends For Investors in Britain
description: Millions of Britons who had bought stock since 1979, when Margaret Thatcher came to power pledging to make Britain a nation of shareholders, were rudely introduced this week to the notion of market risk: prices go down as well as up.

title: What to Look For In Buying a Carpet
description: LEAD: WALL-TO-WALL carpeting is both a major investment and the major design statement in a room. Often it sets up the entire color scheme and dominates the decor. Carpeting mistakes can be costly, so the wise shopper will do some homework before starting out.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jewelry Market Hits a High
description: As the stock market rebounded yesterday, jewelry sold briskly at two auctions. Indeed, a pear-shaped diamond of 64.83 carats was bought at Christie's for $6.4 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a gem. The jewel was bought by

title: Program Trading Is Defended
description: As calls for curbs on program trading intensified this week, leaders of Chicago's financial futures markets voiced their vehement opposition to any such restraints.

title: How to Make Star Wars Work
description: Technology is America's strong suit in countering Soviet military might. Nowhere is that strength more evident than in the esoteric new devices being developed under the Strategic Defense Initiative, like computers, sensors, nuclear-directed energy weapons and free-electron lasers. The White House is eager to deploy a missile defense system as soon as possible. But that purpose defeats two goals -building a more effective system later, and reaching agreement to reduce offensive missiles with the Soviet Union now.

title: No MTM Offering
description: MTM Entertainment Inc., the production concern co-founded by the actress Mary Tyler Moore, joined the ranks of companies canceling stock offerings because of unsettled market conditions. MTM, producer of television's ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''St. Elsewhere,'' said it was postponing indefinitely an initial public offering of four million shares, or 22 percent of its common stock. In August the 17-year-old company had made plans to raise $100 million to $112 million, based on an offering price of $25 to $28, before Oct. 31. Because the company is under no pressure to raise money, it wants ''to wait for greater stability in the market,'' a spokesman said.

Prior year's share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which became effective May 5. For purposes of comparability, following the reorganization of July 1987, net income results, including those for 1986, are reported before preferred dividends. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Market Place; Oil Reserves Called Bargain
description: IN more settled times on the stock market, the price of oil company stocks generally move up when the price of oil does, and down when it falls, reflecting the value of the companies' reserves in the ground. If the companies' stock price declines, that can mean that the market thinks the price of oil at the wellhead is going to fall.

description: Kraft Inc. reported a nearly sixfold increase in third-quarter earnings, mainly because of strong sales of batteries and international food products.

description: Anatoly Karpov took his first timeout today, postponing until Friday the fifth game of his world chess championship match with Gary Kasparov, the champion.

description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered the New York City Department of Correction to provide the drug AZT to an inmate on Rikers Island who has AIDS.

title: Excerpts From Debate in Senate Over Bork Nomination to the High Court
description: Following are excerpts from statements by senators in the debate on the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News: Joseph R. Biden Jr. Democrat of Delaware

title: Notebook; Herzog's Advice Is a Hit
description: Vince Coleman has always said that, before he can run, he must hit. And he credits a suggestion by Manager Whitey Herzog of the Cardinals for helping to raise his batting average from .232 last year to .290 this year.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he expected to make progress on arms control during his talks in Moscow on Thursday and Friday, but he did not know how much.

description: LOUIS MUSTILLO is far from alone in his one-man show, ''Circumstances,'' at the Susan Bloch Theater. The seven characters he creates in eight short takes all create other characters who buzz around them like unswattable flies or, in a couple of cases, nightmarish aliens.

title: Least Likely Hitter Gives Cards a Belt and a Tie
description: Beside being an astute manager, Whitey Herzog is a realistic manager. He doesn't delude himself or others about his team, and that's why he could say before tonight's fourth game of the World Series: ''We're capable of being shut out every night. We're not hitting and we don't have a couple of our guys in the lineup, which makes for a hole. But we're not out of it. If we get three more shutouts, we'll be back in it.''

title: Furor Over Envoy Nominee
description: In an acid exchange today over an ambassadorial nomination before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms told Senator Claiborne Pell, ''If you railroad me, Mr. Chairman, you'll regret it,''

description: The Administration announced a policy today under which some illegal aliens may be allowed to stay in the United States if they have immediate relatives who qualify for amnesty under the new immigration law.

description: b-Includes one-time first quarter charges of $335 million.

description: The new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, said yesterday that he had ordered an investigation into the stock market's plunge and partial recovery to determine what steps ''should be taken to ameliorate future market volatility.''

description: Advice From Honduras President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras, the Administration's strongest supporter in Central America, said American military aid to the contras should be suspended.Page A10. New AIDS Data on Addicts Revising their data, New York City officials said AIDS had killed more addicts than homosexuals.Page B1. Senate Averts a Showdown The Senate voted to defer, until late this year or early next, a vote on the Administration's policy of escorting tankers in the Persian Gulf. Page A3. Cardinals Tie Series St. Louis beat the Minnesota Twins, 7-2, to tie the World Series at two games each. Page B11.

title: Press Curbs Remain, Nicaraguan Editor Says
description: When Concepcion Salazar Gonzalez began organizing relatives of Nicaraguan prisoners 10 months ago, the country's two newspapers, both of them pro-Government, studiously ignored her.

title: Reagan to Hold News Session
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally broadcast news conference, his first from the White House since March, at 8 P.M. Eastern time on Thursday. In announcing the news conference, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, hinted that if there is agreement by Thursday evening on the date of Mr. Reagan's summit conference with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, the President could have an announcement on that. Secretary of State George P. Shultz will begin talks in Moscow on Thursday on subjects including plans for the summit meeting.

title: Nobel in Economics To M.I.T. Professor
description: Robert M. Solow, a 63-year-old professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today for seminal contributions to the theory of economic growth.

title: The Right Carpet, the Right Price
description: THESE are some stores in the metropolitan area with wide stocks of wall-to-wall carpeting. Many have branches or stores, where most of the same merchandise is available, in New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennyslvania and on Long Island. The prices are per square yard and include installation and padding unless otherwise noted. ABC Carpet Company, 881 Broadway (19th Street); 212-677-6970.

title: IN THE NATION
description: With the stock market still subject to roller-coaster plunges and revivals, the economic consequences of Black Monday are not yet clear and analysts seem divided even on the question whether a recession now impends. Politically, however, a few suggestions can be cautiously ventured.

title: Crude Steel Output Up
description: Crude steel output in non-Communist countries rose 6.8 percent in September, to 36.1 million metric tons, from a year before, the International Iron and Steel Institute reported today. The sharp rise mainly reflected the fact that the USX Corporation in the United States was idle in September 1986 because of a strike.

title: Speaker Presses For Tax Change To Keep Dreyfus
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller is pressing New York City to agree to changes in its tax policy that he believes would keep the Dreyfus Corporation from moving its headquarters and back-office operations, which employ 1,200 people, out of the city.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,869,000, or 2 cents per share, from discontinued operations. Revenue represents total revenue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.A disappearing stairway leads up to my attic. How can I insulate the space over it, since brackets extend up over the attic floor and prevent the upper side from lying flush with the floor in the attic? A.The simplest way is to build a shallow ''box'' that extends up into the attic and forms an enclosure around the stairway opening. This can have a hinged door at the top -much like a trunk lid - that can be swung open as you climb into the attic. You can cover the outside of this enclosure (inside the attic) as well as the top of the access door with rigid boards of foam insulation or even with fiberglass batts. Q.I just moved into an apartment that has the radiators painted with a wall paint, not with the metallic paint that is more suited for this purpose. Is this flat wall paint toxic, and if so, how should I remove it? A.You are misinformed. First, metallic paint is not the ''right kind'' for radiators - it cuts their efficiency. Using a flat paint on the radiators makes it easier for them to radiate heat. Second, wall paint is no more toxic than any other kind of paint, so you don't have to remove it; you can just paint over it. If removal is necessary because of too many layers, strip the metal with a chemical paint and varnish remover. Q.When we moved into our apartment five years ago, it had a rough, uneven cement floor in the kitchen. Our tile dealer recommended putting down asphalt tile to smooth it over, then a self-stick vinyl tile over this. The floor has worn poorly and has bumps, nicks and scratches. What should be done to even it out? What can we put down other than ceramic tile that will last and be easy to keep clean? A.Putting down asphalt tile to smooth out a rough subfloor was a mistake; asphalt tile tends to follow the contours of the floor underneath and transmit them to the finished floor. It would be best to take all the tile up and have a professional install a proper underlayment to smooth out the bare floor. He can trowel on a latex compound sold for this purpose, or he might recommend a heavy felt underlayment. After this, the contractor can install a good grade of vinyl tile or vinyl sheet material. Both are easy to maintain and should last many years. Q.The stone foundation of my 100-year-old house is badly in need of repointing. However, several sources have said that I should avoid a ready-mix mortar or any other mix that contains portland cement because the hardness of such a mix could damage the stones over time. But no one seems to know what I should use. What do you suggest? A.This is the first time I have heard that assertion about mixes with portland cement. As far as I know, standard mortar mix, or in some cases patching cement mixed with a little hydrated lime, is what is recommended. I don't see how this can attack the natural stone. For more specific information, ask a local masonry supply house, or write the Portland Cement Association, Old Orchard Road, Skokie, Ill. 60076. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: Boeing Plane Sale
description: The Boeing Company, which is based in Seattle, said it had completed the sale of eight 737-300 aircraft worth a total of $210 million to two European airlines. Lufthansa of West Germany purchased five, while Maersk Air of Denmark purchased three. The sale brings the total number of 737's sold to 1,906, more than any other commercial aircraft.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Turkey Admits Inroads by Kurdish Guerrillas
description: The Turkish authorities are now acknowledging that Kurdish guerrillas operate from inside the country.

title: Talking Deals; Using ESOP's In Buyouts
description: ON Wall Street, where financing fads for acquisitions seem to rise and recede with almost the same volatility as the stock market, one of the latest innovations is a hybrid technique. It combines an old idea, employee stock ownership plans, with a newer one, leveraged buyouts.

title: Mitterrand Appoints New Director at Louvre
description: Michel Laclotte, an art historian and curator, was appointed director of the Louvre today by President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Jackson Trails Other Democrats in Fund-Raising
description: The Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson is in debt and has raised only $1 million, far less than the other major Democratic contenders, according to the campaign's first financial disclosure report.

title: Catching Big Salmon in Upstate Streams
description: THERE is a kind of melancholy in the air on the southern shores of New York's inland sea, Lake Ontario. Some days are still sunny and golden, but with a varnished, empty glow that is a premonition of winter.

title: Ruth Moss, a Founder And Head of Orchestra
description: Ruth Moss, a founder and executive director of the White Plains Symphony Orchestra, died at New York Hospital on Monday after a long illness. She was 60 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Vance Stickell, Ad Executive
description: Vance L. Stickell, the executive vice president in charge of circulation and advertising at The Los Angeles Times, died Monday of cancer of the colon at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 62 years old.

title: Gorbachev Foe Loses Politburo Post
description: Geidar A. Aliyev, a senior member of the Politburo who reportedly opposed the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was removed from the ruling body today, the press agency Tass said. No new members were named.

title: What Does It Matter Who Said It First?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chambers Murder Trial Turns to Jury Selection
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. began their first tentative questioning of would-be jurors yesterday. In the process, they revealed the outlines of a long and complicated trial that will involve heavy elements of sexual and scientific testimony about the death of Jennifer Levin.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Grand Met Adding Dog Food Maker
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it had approved the $25 million acquisition of the Jim Dandy Company, an Atlanta-based dog food maker, by Grand Met USA Inc., a subsidiary of London-based Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Senate Defers Vote on Gulf Escort Policy
description: The Senate narrowly approved a proposal today that would defer, until late this year or early next, a vote on the Administration's policy of convoying tankers in the Persian Gulf.

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain equal to 5 cents a share on the sale of the assets of a 20 percent owned newsprint mill. The share earnings reflect 100 percent stock dividend in June.

title: G.A.O. Study Finds Army's Security Lax On Missile Storage
description: Some United States missiles stored in Europe are inadequately protected and inventoried by the Army, which took nearly a year to find 24 Stinger missiles in its arsenal, according to a report released today.

title: Safety Problems at Reactors Listed in Memo
description: Major safety problems have been found at Government nuclear weapons reactors, ranging from fire hazards to unnecessary exposure of workers to radiation, according to a draft Congressional staff memorandum.

title: Market Turmoil; BACK IN: THE STRATEGY OF ONE TRADER
description: Harvey P. Eisen sits in his fifth-floor office at Third Avenue and 42d Street with $2 billion in stocks at his badly burned fingertips. The horror of Monday's stock market plunge has passed. On the third day of the most turbulent week in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, he has begun to buy again.

title: President of Cabot Chosen to Be Chief
description: Samuel W. Bodman, president and chief operating officer of the Cabot Corporation, an old-line chemical, energy and materials company based in Boston, will assume the additional post of chief executive in February, the company said yesterday.

title: EXCHANGE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,689,000 for the quarter and $2,771,000 for the 9 months.

title: Looking Beyond the Ticker
description: Securities markets worldwide have recouped half their trillion dollar losses, a recognition that the bricks and mortar of world production remain fundamentally sound. But make no mistake: The stock market crash reflects an equal recognition that the world economy will remain at great risk until leaders demonstrate they can face up to hard political decisions.

title: UNITED SERVICES ADVISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PUBLISHING: JONI EVANS DOES LESS TO DO MORE
description: Not yet recovered from the shock caused by the tremors last week at Random House, where Joni Evans replaced Howard Kaminsky as publisher, book industry officials are nonetheless scrutinizing the fine print in the official announcement.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
China Theory on Plunge
description: China, in its first comment on the collapse of world stock prices, said today that the drop was an inevitable consequence of the ''casino economy'' in the United States. Pu Shan, the director of the influential Institute of World Politics and Economy, said that the plunge of prices on the New York and other world exchanges had been expected for some time. His remarks were quoted in the English-language China Daily.

title: IMO DELAVAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $550,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $183,000 and $3,602,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Japan Chooses the F-16
description: Japan, as expected, has decided to develop its next fighter plane in cooperation with the St. Louis-based General Dynamics Corporation. F-16's will be built in Japan for $36 million each, Tokyo officials said today.

title: Foreigners Head Back to Wall St.
description: Foreign investors helped spur the rebound in the American stock markets yesterday, according to New York-based investment bankers.

title: Stage: Harry Shearer
description: HARRY SHEARER, the satirist who co-wrote and starred in the heavy-metal mock-documentary ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' opened a rare club appearance at Caroline's at the Seaport (89 South Street) on Tuesday by arriving on the stage swathed in bandages, in a wheelchair. Singing to the backup tracks of Michael Jackson's ''Bad,'' Mr. Shearer proclaimed in a feathery high tenor:

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $10.8 million from the sale of a 4 percent interest in a Japanese subsidiary.

title: Key Jobs Filled At BancTexas
description: BancTexas Group Inc., a recently recapitalized bank holding company in Dallas, said this week that Nathan C. Collins had been named chairman, president and chief executive.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Five More Companies Named in Toshiba Case
description: Machine tool companies in France, Britain, Italy and West Germany have been cited by Norwegian police as conspirators in the diversion of sensitive machine tools to the Soviet Union, according to a Congressional source.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $5.1 million from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 and $1.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month include after-tax securities gains of $1.62 a share and $1.72 a share, respectively. The year-ago quarter and 9-month include after-tax securities gains of 31 cents a share and $2.07 a share, respectively. The latest quarter and 9-month include the operations of Shelby Insurance Co., acquired in December 1986. The latest quarter also includes a positive ''fresh-start'' tax adjustment of 84 cents a share.

title: NYCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $106,000 and $846,000 for the quarter and 9 months, repectively, and also includes in the 9 month period a loss of $1,519,000 from extinguishment of debt. c-Includes tax credits of $178,000 and $810,000 for the quarter and 9 month periods, repectively.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2.1 million and $1.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Critic's Notebook; APPRECIATING THE MUSIC IN MUSICOLOGY
description: WILL this be remembered as the era of the musicologist? The latter half of the 20th century has produced few certifiably great composers. But it has clearly witnessed an astonishing growth in historical and theoretical information about the art form, with recordings coming to serve as a fundamental scholarly tool. Critical editions of scores, reconsiderations of performance practices, studies of non-Western music, biographical analyses and stylistic comparisons have proliferated.

title: SOO LINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an operating expense charge of $24 million attributable to the recent sale of its Lake States division.

title: Irving Bank Bid Delayed
description: The Federal Reserve has told the Bank of New York that the information in its application to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation was ''seriously deficient'' and gave the bank until next Thursday to provide additional data. The order, released yesterday, was made in a letter sent on Monday to the Bank of New York's lawyers.

title: Bomb in Danish Parliament
description: - Assailants threw a firebomb inside the Danish Parliament building today, causing no casualties but burning holes in the Prime Minister Poul Schluter's carpet, the police said. The Prime Minister was in his office at the time but was not hurt. The entrance to the building is normally locked and monitored by a television camera that the police said had failed to reveal the identity of the attackers.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,539,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $609,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,641,000 and $5,918,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latst 9-month extraordinary charge includes a $6.7 million charge related to the repurchase of $60 million principal amount of the company's outstanding 14 percent subordinated notes, offset by a $6.1 million tax loss carryforward.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter results include a pre-tax gain of $5.6 million from the sale of two railroads.

title: MINNETONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Author of 'Moms' Sues Actress Over Copyright
description: Alice Childress, the original author of ''Moms,'' a play about the comedienne Jackie (Moms) Mabley, is suing the actress Clarice Taylor for infringement of copyright and unfair competition.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a non-recurring gain of about $2.4 million, or 18 cents a share.

title: ADVEST GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Apple Investment Post
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would broaden its strategic investment activity to potential acquisitions of public or privately held companies. Apple said it had promoted Daniel L. Eilers to vice president of strategic investments, a new position; as director of strategic investments he has been responsible for the company's venture capital efforts. Mr. Eilers will report to Albert A. Eisenstat, Apple's senior vice president for corporate development, and will work to broaden the company's investments into new areas, including potential acquisitions. Since its formation in May 1986, Apple's strategic investment group has made minority equity investments in a few companies that provide products or services that could expand the market for Apple's computers.

title: With Asbestos Cleared, Doubts Linger at School
description: Tamu Fontaine returned with her classmates to Clara Barton High School in Brooklyn yesterday, glad to be among friends, but fearful that the school may still be plagued with asbestos.

title: ALLTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE incident at the heart of Tom Wolfe's hilarious first novel is no laughing matter.

title: Monterrey Journal; SATELLITE TV BECOMING MEXICO'S HOTTEST NEW DISH
description: Every day when he gets home from school, Gerardo Urteaga turns on his television set. Sometimes he checks to see if there is a baseball game on the Atlanta or Chicago stations, but usually he flips the dial straight to MTV.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 23, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A Bazaar of Birds, Beasts and Oddities In a Bazaar of Americana
description: BIRDS, beasts and bigness characterize much of the Americana at the Fall Antiques Show, a bazaar abundant with carved plumage and palatial cages, with giant-sized tennis rackets and a rocking chair, and with hand-crafted Noah's Ark creatures and a fun-house gorilla. But some of the show's finds - fish decoys, rare spoons, Mickey Mouse dishes and miniature watercolors -are small enough to be hidden away in cupboards or dark corners.

title: Some Firms Urge Cutback in Stocks
description: In the wake of this week's plunge in stock prices and its implications for slower economic growth in 1988, some Wall Street firms are telling clients to cut back on stocks and - if they stick with equities - to go with safer, high-yielding investments such as electric and telephone utilities.

title: Blue-Chip Leader for Task Force: Nicholas Frederick Brady
description: Nicholas F. Brady once described himself as the kind of man who likes to prove the experts wrong.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Bears' Good News: McMahon Returns
description: Players came and went during the strike, and some teams weathered the four-week interruption better than others. San Diego, San Francisco and Washington won all three games; Kansas City, Philadelphia, Minnesota and the Giants lost all three.

title: U.S. Calls Latest Iran Raid An Issue for Kuwait Alone
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was not committed to any action against Iran in response to the latest missile attack on Kuwait's oil installations.

title: Economic Scene; People Wonder What to Think
description: WHAT lies in the minds and bellies of the people who buy and sell stocks these hectic days, driving the market up, driving it down and driving each other crazy? The forces are so complicated and contradictory. Rationality, the normal assumption of economics, clashes with fear, the subject matter of abnormal psychology. Sophisticated judgment wars with simple prudence - and a natural desire to save one's skin. No one can be sure which is the better guide to calling the market turn. Talk with a dozen people, and one gets a dozen different reasons.

title: For Jets, It's All in the Mind
description: For all the talk about tension in the locker room, the strongest feeling among the Jets today seemed to be curiosity about the team's mental and physical readiness for the game Sunday against the Washington Redskins.

title: Stake in Macmillan
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass has acquired a 7.5 percent stake in Macmillan Inc. for $128.5 million, or about $68 a share. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group said it had bought the 1.89 million shares of the New York-based publisher for ''investment purposes'' only. Analysts said it was too early to determine whether the investment was friendly. Both the Bass family and Macmillan hold large stakes in the Bell & Howell Company, and Macmillan has said it might seek control of the Skokie, Ill., publishing concern.

title: Back to the Decibeldome
description: NOW the World Series is returning to the Decibeldome in Minnesota, where Whitey Herzog couldn't even hear himself think last weekend. Maybe that's why the Twins won the first two games, 10-1 and 8-4.

title: Tours of Art Studios
description: Visitors to the Upper West Side will be able to go through the studios of resident artists during ''Open Studios '87.'' The free open house, held over the next two weekends, is sponsored by the West Side Arts Coalition. In addition to individual studios, stops are included at the Cork Gallery at Lincoln Center and the West Side Y.M.C.A., at West 63d Street and Broadway. Maps are available at all locations. Visiting hours are tomorrow and Sunday and Oct. 31 and Nov. 1, noon to 6 P.M. Information: 316-6024 or 496-0446.

title: OPPOSITION FIZZLES IN DRIVE IN PANAMA
description: The Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega won a major test of strength today when a protest march and general strike here fizzled.

title: Exiled Soviet Poet Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: Joseph Brodsky, an exiled Soviet-born poet who writes in Russian and English, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today.

title: MONSANTO LIABLE IN '79 DIOXIN SPILL
description: After one of the nation's longest jury trials, the Monsanto Company was found liable today for failing to warn a Missouri town about the risks of a 1979 chemical spill. The jury awarded plaintiffs $16.2 million in punitive damages.

title: Cardinal Single Sends In Key Runs
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, scrapping desperately to win tonight so they wouldn't be faced with winning two at Minnesota's Noisedome, did not see any good omens in developments in the third and fifth innings of the fifth game of the World Series.

title: Predictions on a Ruling
description: The Washington legal-political grapevine is heavy laden with talk that a Federal appellate panel may soon pass judgment on the law under which at least six special prosecutors are now conducting investigations or prosecutions.

title: Spy's Signal Cited in Cuban Crisis
description: As the Cuban missile crisis unfolded 25 years ago, a Soviet military officer spying for the West sent a signal that the Kremlin planned to attack. But a mid-level agent of the Central Intelligence Agency decided not to pass the information up to the White House, according to a memoir released today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 408 money market mutual funds increased $9.64 billion, to $256.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 108 institutional funds were up $4.29 billion, to $69.36 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $4.12 billion, to $78.14 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased $1.23 billion, to $109.33 billion. A separate survey released Wednesday by another industry publication, The Money Fund Report, indicated a similar gain. The increases have been attributed to the record plunge in the stock market, which spurred investors to seek greater security for their investments.

title: Theater: 'Cabaret' and Joel Grey Return
description: THERE can't be a creepier sight on Broadway right now than Joel Grey. Back in the role of the sleazy emcee in the musical ''Cabaret,'' the actor is made up just as he was in 1966 - with patent-leather hair, rouged cheeks, purple lips and drag-queen eyelashes. He darts about like an overwound wind-up doll, twirling his cane with a spastic jerkiness. As his eyes bulge, so his tongue has a most appalling way of flopping out of his mouth. And when Mr. Grey sings, his voice is a piercing siren that doesn't so much welcome revelers to his cabaret, the Kit Kat Klub, as lure them into the hell lurking just out of view - Berlin, 1929.

title: A Century of Caring
description: The story of how the United Way was founded seems almost too good to be true. Never mind; it is true.

title: Another Dose of Uncertainty
description: Ann Lisa and William Robbins

title: Congress Applauds Offer by President
description: Congressional leaders today welcomed President Reagan's statement that he was willing to discuss tax increases and would meet ''as soon as possible'' with the leaders to set up negotiations on a deficit-reducing package.

title: Daughter Stabs Father to Death In Home on S.I.
description: A Staten Island man was stabbed to death in his apartment early yesterday, and his 22-year-old daughter was arrested after telling the authorities she had killed him because he had sexually abused her for years and had tried to assault her sexually again.

title: Poet Reflects on Fortunes of Literature
description: ''Life has a great deal up its sleeve,'' said Joseph Brodsky, who was exiled from the Soviet Union as a ''social parasite'' 15 years ago and lauded today as the winner of the Nobel Prize in literature.

title: REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Sikh Rally Faces Amritsar Curfew
description: The police imposed a curfew on this city today to prevent militant Sikh separatists from holding a rally at the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' most sacred shrine.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Gymnastics Russians Retain Title: Led by Dmitri Bilozerchev, gymnasts from the Soviet Union won the men's team title at the world championships last night in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The Soviet team dominated the competition as it scored 589.75 points as it easily defended its title. China took second with 583.35; East Germany was third at 582.80. The United States, which suffered a major blow when Tim Daggett broke his leg while attempting a vault earlier in the day, finished ninth with 572.35 points. The top 12 teams will qualify for the 1988 Olympic Games. Bilozerchev, the 1983 world champion making a comeback after a severe auto accident in 1985, led the Soviet Union to the first four places in the individual competition. He scored 118.45 points, scoring no lower than 9.85 in any of the six apparatus. (AP) Tennis Shriver to Play Maleeva: Top-seeded Pam Shriver eased into the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Volvo Classic tournament in Brighton, England, yesterday with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Sara Gomer, the last Briton in the tournament. Shriver will play sixth-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, who downed Lisa Bonder of the United States, 6-2, 6-3. Eighth-seeded Sandra Cecchini of Italy beat Larissa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-0, to gain.(AP) Connors Loses in Japan: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, Stefan Edberg of Sweden and Boris Becker of West Germany advanced to the quarterfinals of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo, but Jimmy Connors lost in the second round. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, crushed Robert Seguso of the United States, 6-2, 6-0. Edberg, ranked second, topped Johan Carlsson, 6-0, 6-2. Becker, ranked fourth, trounced a countryman, Damir Keretic, 6-2, 6-3. Connors, seeded fourth in the tournament, lost to John Fitzgerald of Australia, 6-3,6-1.(AP)

title: Film: 'The Sicilian'
description: THOUGH it's a separate novel, Mario Puzo's ''Sicilian'' functions as an extended insert within his ''Godfather'' epic, being an elaboration on what happened during the two years that the young Mafioso heir Michael Corleone was hiding out in Sicily after his brush with the New York law.

title: Blue Arrow Names A Chief Executive
description: Christopher Castleman, the former chief executive of the merchant bank Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., has been appointed managing director and chief executive of Blue Arrow P.L.C., Britain's largest employment agency.

title: Education Departments Have Grown Ominously
description: To the Editor:

title: Wider Sale To Soviet Disclosed
description: Norwegian authorities disclosed today that Norway's state-owned arms company, Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, had shipped to the Soviet Union more than 140 computers capable of running sophisticated machine tools and had cooperated with nearly a half-dozen NATO countries in shipping other high-technology equipment to the Russians.

title: Cox Looks Back And Looks Ahead
description: Danny Cox does not mind admitting that he and his teammates from the 1985 World Series still think about the unfinished business.

title: 3 Accused Of Russian Sales Plan
description: Three men were arrested today and charged with planning to sell designs for an extremely powerful supercomputer to the Soviet Union for $4 million.

title: An Australian in the N.F.L.
description: The Giants' troubled offensive line will be attacked on Sunday by an Australian rugby-player-turned-footballer who celebrates his sacks by doing the Kangaroo Hop.

title: Reagan Address Heartens Wall Street
description: A number of executives, financiers and academics said President Reagan was addressing precisely the right issue last night at his nationally televised news conference when he said he would begin negotiations with Congress to narrow the budget deficit.

title: Inouye Offers Compromise On Moving Indian Museum
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, offered a compromise today over whether the Museum of the American Indian should be moved to Washington or remain in New York City.

title: Gauging the Gashes In Legislators' Stocks
description: They are the representatives of the American people elected to share the joys and tribulations of the nation, and this week many members of Congress discovered they were sharing the plight of constituents who suffered heavy losses on the plunging stock markets.

title: Topics of The Times; Another for a Poet
description: Rarely have the Swedes displayed as much wit and sense as in bestowing the Nobel Prize in Literature on Joseph Brodsky, whose writing shimmers, just as their citation says, with raillery, parody and an amazing mastery of English idiom. What a wonderful twist in the life of a poet who was once denounced in his native Leningrad as a ''militant parasite.'' For that offense he was sentenced in 1964 to five years of forced labor in Archangel, just south of the Arctic Circle.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE'LL 'NEGOTIATE' WITH CONGRESS ON THE DEFICIT; BLAMES DEMOCRATS
description: In a bid to calm the frenzy in the world's financial markets, President Reagan announced today that he would meet with Congressional leaders to negotiate ways to reduce the budget deficit, with ''everything on the table,'' including possible tax increases.

title: Freedom of Association
description: To the Editor:

title: Vendor's Widow Sues Police
description: The widow of a street vendor who was shot and killed by New York City police officers this year in Harlem filed a $40 million lawsuit against the city and the Police Department yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DEVIL AND DR. BARNES: Portrait of an American Art Collector. By Howard Greenfeld. Illustrated. 306 pages.

title: WIFE OF BIG LOTTERY WINNER WANTS HALF OF HIS JACKPOT
description: The estranged wife of a co-winner of the state's $46 million lottery prize says she is entitled to some of the record winnings, even though her hus-band has lived with another woman for five years.

title: Dining Out Guide; New in Midtown
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARGENTEUIL, #253 East 52d Street (753-9273) - *(July 3, 1987) Named for a town northwest of Paris, this new midtown restaurant - on the site of the old Cafe Argenteuil - is set in a cozy and tranquil room decorated in flowery fabrics. The menu is French-American and the starters include sliced artichoke bottoms with sweet red pepper and chunky olive puree; cannelloni with shrimp, veal and fennel, and Roquefort beignets with apple puree. For a main dish, you may choose from roasted goosefish, or monkfish, with vinegar sauce and deep-fried shredded cabbage; rack of lamb with chanterelle mushrooms, sage and juniper with butternut squash puree, and grilled veal steak with roast Jerusalem artichokes, warm pepper salad and lemon mayonnaise. Entrees $18 to $28. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5:30 to 10 P.M. CINCO DE MAYO, 45 Tudor City Place, between 42d and 43d Streets (661-5070) - *(April 10, 1987) The flamboyant SoHo restaurant opened a smaller midtown outpost this year with a colorful and convivial dining room and well-spaced tables. Good starter choices are camarones al chipolte, sauteed shrimp in a piquant sauce made with ground smoked chilies; ceviche, the assortment of lime-marinated raw fish, and black-bean soup with do-it-yourself garnishes. Entrees rotate daily, but you might choose budin de tortilla, a Mexican casserole with alternating layers of soft corn tortillas, shredded chicken, cheese and hot chilies; menudo, tripe stew with chilies and served with dried oregano, diced onions and lime, or sauteed shrimp over a nutty and peppery pumpkin sauce. Entrees $8.95 to $19.95. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. DAWAT, #210 East 58th Street (355-7555) - *(Dec. 12, 1986) The long rectangular dining room of this stylish Indian restaurant is done in subtle pink and pale green; the lighting is flattering and the noise level low. You might start with an Indian snack called bhel poori, which combines puffed rice, wheat chips, coriander, mango powder and assorted chutneys; or choose dahi aloo poori, a mix of brittle little wafers tossed with potato cubes and chickpeas in chili-stoked yogurt and tamarind sauce. Entree options include shrimp with a blend of garlic, mustard seeds and curry; chicken jal frazie, a combination of marinated chicken and sweet red peppers, and salmon fillet, swathed in a sharp coriander chutney and then steamed in a banana leaf. Entrees $7.95 to $19.96. Fridays and Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5:30 to 11 P.M. MANHATTAN ISLAND, #482 West 43d Street (967-0533) - *(Sept. 11, 1987) Two sunny, glass-enclosed dining rooms face the rooftop swimming pool at this new restaurant on the third floor of the Manhattan Plaza Health Club. The menu is contemporary American and limited but well honed with a half-dozen or so daily specials. Recommended light options include cappellini in yellow tomato sauce with shredded basil; linguini with sun-dried tomato sauce; sesame-flavored noodles with chicken and pecans, and tuna Nicoise-style made with grilled tuna, red potatoes, tomatoes, eggs, asparagus and black olives. Main dish choices include crab cakes; lamb chops with orzo and vegetables; shrimp on skewers with cayenne pepper, and rare-cooked salmon in mustard-and-caper sauce. Entrees $6.50 to $19. Fridays through Sundays, noon to 11 P.M. MENAGE A TROIS, 134 East 48th Street (593-8242) - *(Nov. 7, 1986) Diners at this contemporary midtown restaurant are invited to ''graze.'' The dining room is done in soothing beiges with wood trim and comfortable banquettes with well-distanced tables. Most portions fall between traditional appetizer and entree size, and you can assemble a meal any which way. The eight-page menu offers any number of options: quail eggs on artichoke hearts topped with smoked salmon, oysters, scallops, lobster meat and caviar in red-pepper mousse; deep-fried pastry packages in champagne sauce, one with lobster and snow peas, others with turbot and leek, and crab and cucumber; three steamed seafood pastries, of crabmeat wrapped in leeks, scallops in cabbage leaves, and lobster in spinach in an oyster and caviar sauce; and baby filets of meat that include packages of rare-roasted lamb over tomato concasse, beef on curried eggplant, and veal mingled with wild mushrooms. Dishes $5.50 to $19. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. What the stars mean, page C28.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm putting everything on the table with the exception of Social Security, with no other preconditions. And I call on the leaders of Congress to do the same.'' - President Reagan. [ D10:3. ]

title: KEY RATES
The Crash: Ah, Yes, Pepper Remembers It
description: When the recent stock market upheavals began, Representative Claude Pepper, the oldest member of Congress, recalled vivid memories of the only comparable event, the crash of 1929.

title: Brawl Inquiry For Devils
description: The National Hockey League said today it would investigate Wednesday night's Devils-Penguins game to determine whether further punishment is necessary for four players, three of them Devils, who were ejected.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: LEAD: THE stock market plunged, but Donald J. Trump was in good cheer. ''I'm a very happy man tonight,'' the New York real-estate developer said Monday at Avery Fisher Hall at a benefit for the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund. ''Last month I sold all my stocks, so I can enjoy myself tonight, although there may be some people here who are not having a very good time.

title: Film: Paul Newman Directs 'Glass Menagerie'
description: THERE have been entertaining film versions of Tennessee Williams's works (''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof''), and there have been important ones (''A Streetcar Named Desire''). But by and large, Williams's work has never traveled easily to the screen. The playwright himself claimed to favor only ''The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone,'' disparaging all the other films adapted from his writing, and he may have seen the matter more clearly than anyone else could.

title: Very Familiar Scene at Yankee Stadium
description: The sign on the wall in the blue-and-white corridor in Yankee Stadium yesterday morning read ''Press Conf.'' The arrow below pointed to the left.

title: The Dotted Line
description: Reggie Williams, the former Georgetown star who was the fourth player taken in this year's pro basketball draft, joined the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday after missing half of the team's preseason training camp while negotiating for a contract. No terms were announced for Williams's multiyear pact, but he will reportedly be paid $800,000 a year under the agreement. . . . After receiving no offers as a free agent, Purvis Short signed with the Golden State Warriors yesterday, agreeing to a contract estimated at $1 million over two years. Short, a 30-year-old forward, averaged 25 points a game for the Warriors during the 1985-86 season, but missed 48 games because of injuries last season and wound up with an average of 18.3 points.

title: U.S. Official Urges New Aid to Pakistan
description: A senior State Department official asked Congress today to renew aid to Pakistan, despite concerns that Pakistan may be trying to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Pressure Begins To Take Its Toll On Wall Street
description: ''I don't know how much longer I can do it,'' said Stanley Silverberg, a specialist on the American Stock Exchange, as he stood off the trading floor taking long drags on his cigarette.

title: Chrysanthemum Show
description: As autumn colors reach their peak along the wooded trails of the New York Botanical Garden, some 1,500 chrysanthemums are blooming indoors for a three-week Japanese Chrysanthemum Exhibition, beginning tomorrow in the garden's Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. The flower show continues through Nov. 15. It will be accompanied by demonstrations of ikebana (Japanese flower arranging) and origami tomorrow between 11 A.M. and 3:30 P.M., and by Japanese folk and modern dance performances on Sunday from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M. The conservatory, at Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx, is open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Tuesday through Sunday, and admission is $2.50; $1.25 for students, children and the elderly (free tomorrow from 10 A.M to noon). Information: 220-8700.

title: Say Yes for Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: CARDS SWEEP AT HOME, GO TO DOME UP, 3-2
description: Danny Cox, the big-game pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, pitched an absolutely big game tonight as the Cardinals swept their third straight from the Minnesota Twins and moved to within one victory from winning the 84th World Series.

title: Office-Towers Plan Is Supported in Rally By 7,000 Unionists
description: Four days after a demonstration to protest two huge office towers planned for Columbus Circle, more than 7,000 trade union members rallied yesterday to express their support for the construction project.

title: Film: 'The Funeral,' A Comedy by Juzo Itami
description: JUZO ITAMI'S ''Funeral'' is a series of joyous contradictions. Here's a robust comedy whose subject is death, a film that is quintessentially Japanese though it recalls (without in any way imitating) the work of the quintessentially French Jean Renoir, and a tough-minded satire that is almost always sweet.

title: Film: 'No Man's Land'
description: HOW many talented actors does it take to steal a Porsche? And how many times do you want to watch them do it in the space of an hour and a half? In ''No Man's Land,'' it takes two - Charlie Sheen and D. B. Sweeney, who pilfer Porsches faster and more often than you can say ''Miami Vice clone.'' Though set in Los Angeles, the film has a familiar, television look and feel - two handsome partners, cops, criminals, fast cars and a marginal romance. The twist in the buddy-car-chase formula is that here the good guys tend to blur into the bad.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Inkhay, Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864-5400). The Andean quartet performs music from the highlands of Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Chile, Colombia, Chile and Argentina, on 26 different instruments, some of ancient origin. Members include the leader Pepe Santana, who has pioneered the presentation of traditional Andean music in New York, the Ecuadorian harp virtuoso Atahualpa Poalasin and the Bolivian multi-instrumentalists Marcelo Pena and Fredy Maranon. They will be joined by six dancers and the program includes a colorful geographic slide show. Show time is tomorrow at 8 P.M., and tickets are $15 and $12.50.

title: Wall St. Phones Were Kept Busy
description: On Monday the New York Telephone Company reported that telephone traffic in the Wall Street area remained the same as for any normal business day. But Monday was anything but a normal business day with the stock market taking a record-breaking plunge.

title: Soviet Team Eager To Play the Bucks
description: Ivan Edeshko will probably never be suitably recognized for his contributions to the development of basketball as a global sport. As a youngster in the Soviet Union he was never his team's most dominating player. And as a coach he is only beginning to emerge in his country as an influential and respected teacher of the game.

title: Stennis Leaves the Hospital
description: Senator John Stennis, the 86-year-old Mississippi Democrat, was released from Walter Reed Army Medical Center today, three days after he underwent surgery to correct a prostate gland problem. The hospital said tests following the Monday operation revealed no evidence of cancer.

title: Midi Acquisition
description: The Department of Trade and Industry in Britain has cleared the way for the takeover of the British life insurance concern Equity and Law by the French financial services group Compagnie du Midi, the French company said. The decision marks the end of the first takeover battle for a big British life insurance concern since the 1960's. Midi fought off a rival bid from Brierley Investments of New Zealand with an offer worth $760 million. Buying Britain's 20th-largest life insurance concern is a key step in the French company's efforts to become one of Europe's top financial services concerns.

title: Exiled Soviet Poet Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 22

title: A Very Small Poll Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Quartet at Weill
description: A quartet - Stephen Brown, pianist; Dinos Constantinides, violinist; Karen Hunt, soprano; Harry Sagous, oboist - will perform works by Ives, Robert Helps, Henry Cowell, Antal Dorati and Mr. Constantinides Sunday at 2 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall. Tickets are $7. Information: 247-7800.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BERLIN ANNIVERSARY

title: Corrections
description: A report in Business Day on Wednesday about the Bristol-Myers Company's earnings misstated the company's third-quarter sales and the percentage increase. Sales totaled $1.38 billion, up 9.5 percent from $1.26 billion in the third quarter of 1986.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the funeral of the cellist Jacqueline du Pre described the end of her career incorrectly. She was stricken with multiple sclerosis in 1971, but her final concerts were in 1973.

title: Republicans Agree to Permit Vote on Bork Today
description: As the number of senators opposed to Judge Robert H. Bork grew to 55, Senate Republicans agreed early this evening to permit a vote Friday on the doomed Supreme Court nomination. Senate leaders said the vote would be no later than 2 P.M.

title: BankAmerica Earns $54 Million in Quarter
