description: A little more than a year after A. W. Clausen reassumed the posts of chairman and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation, the company today reported third-quarter earnings of $54 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with a $23 million loss in the comparable 1986 period.

title: U.S. Review Of Mergers
description: Changing conditions may require the Government to reconsider some of the mergers it has allowed in recent years, a member of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Who Twisted Arms?
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Supports Cut in Big Board Hours
description: The decision by the New York Stock Exchange to curtail trading for the next three days was made during a day of intense consultations with the Securities and Exchange Commission as the two parties set up a new ''open'' telephone line between them, a commission spokeswoman said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 7 about New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, misidentified a former Chief Medical Examiner. He is Dr. Milton Helpern.

title: Conferees in an Accord To Advance Trade Bill
description: Key House and Senate conferees on the trade bill, eager to send reassuring signals to Wall Street, met officially today for the first time and quickly agreed to a compromise on granting the President new trade-negotiating authority.

title: Concert: Little Orchestra Society, at Tully Hall
description: THE Little Orchestra Society under its founder, the late Thomas K. Scherman, hewed out a place for itself in New York musical history largely through its pathbreaking programs of neglected older works such as Berlioz's ''Enfance du Christ.'' However, one might easily forget that the organization also has 50 world premieres and countless other contemporary firsts to its credit.

title: JAMES L. GREENFIELD IS APPOINTED EDITOR OF TIMES MAGAZINE
description: The appointment of James L. Green-field as editor of the New York Times Magazine was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, executive editor of The Times.

title: Teamsters Ask To Be Allowed In A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: In a move that could lead to the end of 30 years of estrangement from the American labor movement, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked yesterday to rejoin the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Quartet at Wave Hill
description: The Manhattan String Quartet will perform works by Beethoven, Shostakovich and Debussy Sunday at 3 P.M. at Armor Hall at Wave Hill (West 249th Street and Independence Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx). Tickets are $10, $8 for the elderly. Information: 549-3200.

title: Colorado's 'Shrine of Trout Fishing' Is in Danger
description: For trout fishermen like David S. Taylor, there are not enough superlatives to describe the South Platte River as it tumbles through Cheesman Canyon in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains southwest of here.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Democrats Find Caution Is Best Economic Policy
description: Democratic Presidential candidates, responding to the crisis in the stock market, have been long on calls for bipartisanship, short on specific remedies and cautious lest any misstatement be seen as an effort to take partisan advantage of the upheaval.

title: Attacker Describes Death at Howard Beach
description: A teen-ager who admits being in a group of white youths that attacked three black men in Howard Beach last December yesterday described the encounter and the death of one of the blacks, who was struck and killed by a car while fleeing onto a dark, busy highway.

title: Investor Euphoria Is Now Subdued
description: Tentative optimism gave way to nervous caution among small investors yesterday. After a wave of bargain hunting on Tuesday and Wednesday, small investors seemed more willing to watch and wait as the market took another dive, brokerage officials around the country said.

title: Film: 'The Killing Time,' a Thriller
description: JAMES M. CAIN casts a shadow over ''The Killing Time,'' which opens today at the Embassy 1 and other theaters. Unfortunately, it isn't a very long one. In a quiet little seacoast town, the kind of place where one of the two sheriffs (Beau Bridges) calls everyone but his colleague (Joe Don Baker) ''Ma'am,'' we are asked to believe that two of the film's four male principals can be contemplating deceit, frame-ups and cold-blooded murder. Talk about casting against type! Mr. Bridges turns out to be one of the schemers, and he's simply too nice for this sort of thing.

title: Times Mirror Net Down 4.6%
description: The Times Mirror Company, the large diversified media concern, said today that net income declined 4.6 percent in the third quarter.

title: Advertising; Holly Farms Shifts Account
description: Holly Farms, a marketer of brand-name poultry based in Wilkesboro, N.C., has switched its agency to Long, Haymes & Carr, down home in Winston-Salem. Left behind in New York is a ''stunned'' Grey Advertising, the agency for the last five years, which saw the client move into chicken-marketing eminence.

title: Missile Reportedly Fired by Iran Damages a Kuwaiti Oil Terminal
description: Kuwait's main offshore oil terminal was seriously damaged in a missile attack today, and Kuwaiti and American officials said Iran was responsibile.

title: Watching the Ruling
description: The case before the appeals court illustrates the pitfalls lying in the path of those who might be considered for nomination to fill the Supreme Court vacancy after Judge Robert H. Bork's expected defeat in the Senate: The views most valuable in winning nomination could cause problems winning Senate confirmation.

title: Union Carbide Reports Gains
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its third-quarter operating income rose 76 percent, to $74 million, thanks to a strong performance by the company's chemicals and plastics divisions.

title: A Printer Suffers A Slight Scorching
description: Owning stock in a medium-sized concern like Bowne & Company is a little like keeping a canary in a coal mine: if the market turns poisonous, the stock exhibits signs of distress.

title: At the Movies
description: Oliver Stone's ESP

title: Fermenta Rejection
description: Fermenta A.B., the debt-laden Swedish biotechnology group, rejected a United States company's bid for its overseas assets, in part because the Wall Street plunge might have made it harder to finance the deal. Fermenta's suitor, Trans Resources Inc., a private chemicals and fertilizers group, had offered $218 million for Fermenta's overseas assets in September. The Swedish company agreed last week to sell part of its United States operations, the Fermenta Holding Company, and two Italian fermentation units to an Australian concern.

title: Acquittal in a Self-Defense Case
description: A man who contended that his actions were justified under Colorado's self-defense law was acquitted today of charges of murdering a neighbor and assaulting two others.

title: New Topic in Hungary: Income Tax
description: The Hungarian leadership deserves the Nobel Prize for chemistry this year, goes a current joke in this capital, which has long sublimated anger and anguish in bitter quips. The leadership has created a compound of Ethiopian wages and Swedish taxes.

title: Bridge: U.S. Is Leading in Finals For 2 World Team Titles
description: The finals of the world team championships began here this afternoon, with the United States involved in both the open series and the women's series.

title: Diner's Journal
description: HE forbidding Black Rock, as the CBS building on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street is dubbed, has sprouted an exotic flower called China Grill, an offshoot of Chinoise on Main in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: New U.S.-Spanish Talks Due
description: Spain said today that it would resume deadlocked talks with the United States next month over cutting the number of American troops stationed here.

title: Robertson Election Camp Pressed With Queries on Computer Deal
description: The Presidential campaign of Pat Robertson held a news conference today to release the candidate's personal income tax statements, but soon was compelled to defend itself on questions about the campaign's finances.

title: Racing Notebook; Talent Is Thin for Turf Stakes
description: Are there too many rich, so-called international stakes races for grass horses each fall? The field for the $500,000 Man o' War at Aqueduct tomorrow suggests that the answer is yes.

title: Private Satellite Photos Offer Clues About Soviet Laser Site
description: A giant laser station under construction high atop a mountain in the Soviet Union has been photographed by private cameras in space, giving civilian experts on the military their first glimpse of the top-secret site.

title: Topics of The Times; Valentine for an Economist
description: In awarding Robert Solow its prize in economics, the Nobel committee cited the M.I.T. professor's pioneering research in growth theory. The committee could have added that Mr. Solow is the economist's economist, a delightful exception in an academy that usually saves its highest honors for the narrowest of specialists.

title: Stock Index Prices Fall As Volatility Continues
description: Trading was light today in Chicago's stock index futures pits, but the violent price swings of the last few days intensified.

title: Answer: Nothing
description: Some celebrated composers and record producers were on Capitol Hill this week reviewing songs written by local artists.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1987
description: THE STOCK MARKET TURMOIL The stock market bent but did not break. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 77.42 points, at 1,950.43, but even this was an improvement over an earlier 140-point deficit. Trading opened with a blizzard of sell orders that caused many participants to expect a rout as complete as Monday's, but a number of factors helped the market to weather the storm. Volume eased somewhat to a still staggering 392.2 million. [ Page A1. ] The New York and American exchanges will shorten trading by two hours today and on Monday and Tuesday. The Chicago Board Options Exchange also said it would close early. [ D6. ] Unhappiness was expressed about the Big Board's decision to extend restrictions on the use of computer-aided program trading. [ D6. ] Foreign investors continued to hunt for bargains on Wall Street. And many expressed the opinion that some good might result from the plunge, especially if the budget deficit is cut. [ D1. ] Robert S. Prechter's advice reaches so many investors that he may influence the market. Many analysts say that a sell recommendation issued to his clients Wednesday night touched off the panic selling Thursday morning. [ D8. ] Small investors watched and waited cautiously as the market took another dive. [ D9. ] Wertheim Schroder was on the front line of the selling blitz, as the medium-sized brokerage firm stood ready to supply its own capital to accommodate trades. [ D7. ] A. B. Tompane & Company feared losses of more than $10 million from Monday's plunge when the specialist firm accepted Merrill Lynch's takeover offer. [ D7. ] Wall Street firms are telling clients to cut back on stocks or switch to safer, high-yielding equities, such as utilities. [ D7. ] Bowne's stock has been only slightly scorched in the plunge, even though medium-size printing company may seem vulnerable. [ D8. ] Working frantic 14-hour days since last Friday is beginning to take a psychological toll, some Wall Street workers say. [ D8. ] The forces at work in the market's frantic behavior are complicated and contradictory. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The wave of stock buyback announcements continued, but some companies' stocks suffered reversals. Market Place. [ D12. ] OTHER MARKETS Short- and long-term interest rates declined sharply for the fourth consecutive day. The decline in stock prices contributed to a surge in bonds, which rose by more than three points. [ D1. ] The dollar closed mostly higher in domestic trading, and gold rose $1.25 an ounce, to $469, in late trading in New York. [ D19. ] The violent price swings in stock-index futures intensified, but the volume of trading in Chicago was relatively light. [ D19. ] THE ECONOMY President Reagan plans to meet with Congressional leaders to work on reducing the budget deficit. The President also said in a televised news conference that he had chosen Nicholas F. Brady to head a task force to investigate the securities exchanges. [ A1. ] A number of executives said they were encouraged by the President's expression of resolve to deal with the deficit. [ D12. ] Commercial banks lowered their prime rate to 9 percent, a drop of a quarter percentage point. The decrease was led by Citibank, and bankers predicted that rates would drop further. [ A1. ] INTERNATIONAL Norway disclosed that its Kongsberg arms company had shipped more than 140 sophisticated computers to the Russians -more than 10 times the number previously suspected. [ D1. ] Three man were accused of planning to sell designs for a powerful supercomputer to the Soviet Union for $4 million. [ D1. ] Congressional conferees agreed on a trade bill provision granting the President authority to negotiate trade accords. [ D2. ] The Reagan Administration curbed the export of some products to China because of its missile sales to Iran. [ A1. ] COMPANIES BankAmerica had earnings of $54 million. The company called the report a milestone after two years of heavy losses. [ D1. ] Enron will permanently close its Enron Oil subsidiary after the unit lost $85 million because of unauthorized futures trading. [ D5. ]

title: Portfolio Insurance Is Growing
description: The New York Stock Exchange's decision to extend its restrictions on the use of computer-aided program trading as a way of curbing volume and easing volatility was not warmly received by the institutions and securities exchanges that rely on such techniques to do business in the stock market.

title: A Wary Specialist Agrees to a Merger
description: Last Monday at 5 P.M. was perhaps the most tense point in the business career of Peter Haas. A senior partner with the New York Stock Exchange specialist firm A.B. Tompane & Company, Mr. Haas had no idea how large his firm's losses had been during the day when the stock market took its historic plunge. There were estimates that the figure would exceed $10 million.

title: Foreign Buyers Still Active
description: When the American stock markets collapsed this week, many on Wall Street and in Washington feared that the foreign investors who have become so important to the American economy would take their money and run.

title: Big Board, Amex Set Shorter Hours
description: The New York and American stock exchanges, responding to the frenzied pace of trading, announced yesterday that they would shorten their hours today, Monday and Tuesday, halting at 2 P.M. instead of 4 P.M.

title: Son Succeeds Father As National City Head
description: Call the National City Bancorporation in Minneapolis and chances are that David L. Andreas will answer the phone. At least he did yesterday, while his secretary was out getting lunch. The informal Mr. Andreas is the new chairman and chief executive of the bank holding company.

title: Negotiations On Kaisertech
description: Alan E. Clore, chairman of Kaisertech Ltd., said he had held discussions with unidentified parties interested in buying all or part of his 31 percent stake in the company based in Oakland, Calif. In a Securities and Exchange

title: AT CHANEL, AN ASSISTANT IS INSPIRATION
description: Victoire de Castellane, Karl Lagerfeld's assistant for jewelry at the Chanel fashion house, is just 24 years old. She proves that youth is no barrier to success. Already, she has helped to change the face of fashion.

title: New Committee's Aim Is Cuomo Candidacy
description: A draft committee to convince Governor Cuomo to run for President filed a statement of organization today with the Federal Election Commission.

title: A VAST ETRUSCAN BURIAL PLACE IS DISCOVERED NORTH OF ROME
description: Workers have accidentally discov-ered a vast Etruscan burial place while digging the foundation of a new house in this town north of rome, according to press reports.

title: Indian Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bork Hearings Showed How Democracy Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Miami dispatch about a psychiatrist's testimony on the suicide of a 17-year-old Florida girl was inadvertently omitted from some editions yesterday; a duplicate of an unrelated article appeared under its headline.

title: Flawed Witness: Handle With Care
description: It is a predicament that criminal lawyers often face: how to handle key witnesses whose less-than-pristine pasts make them vulnerable to attack when they take the stand.

title: NASA Discloses Ambitious Shuttle Schedule
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today issued the most detailed schedule of shuttle flights and unmanned space missions since the Challenger exploded in January 1986.

title: Bridgeport Still Split on Fault in Tragedy
description: After watching, on a screen, Federal officials in Washington announcing today the results of a six-month inquiry into the collapse of L'Ambiance Plaza, some lawyers, city officials and construction workers still differed on who had been at fault and whether the probable cause of the disaster had been found.

title: COURT ORDERS REMOVAL OF TICKET-FIXING JUDGE
description: The state's highest court today ordered the ouster of a Montgomery County town court justice who fixed two speeding tickets and then lied to a state judicial panel investigating his conduct.

title: ROY PLAUT
description: Roy Plaut, a founding partner of the Manhattan law firm of Lipkowitz & Plaut, died Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. Mr. Plaut, who had retired to Chapel Hill so he could attend courses at the University of North Carolina, was 85 years old.

title: Queens Parolee Is Held in Rape In Parking Lot
description: A Queens grand jury indicted a 31-year-old man yesterday in a rape last summer in a department-store parking lot.

title: Expert Blames Mother for Daughter's Suicide
description: An expert on suicide testified Wednesday that a Fort Lauderdale woman had created a psychological climate that emotionally trapped her 17-year-old daughter and was instrumental in the teen-ager's decision to kill herself.

title: Two More Held In Slaying Of Dispatcher
description: Two more suspects were charged yesterday in the slaying of Mildred Greene, a 61-year-old Queens taxi dispatcher who was killed after she testified before a grand jury about a gun battle she had witnessed outside her office, the authorities said.

title: Film: 'Prince of Darkness,' by John Carpenter
description: ''HOW,'' someone asks in John Carpenter's ''Prince of Darkness,''

title: Agent Wants Assurances for Righetti
description: If the Yankees plan on sending Dave Righetti back to the starting pitching rotation next season, they face two substantial obstacles: Righetti's intention to file for free agency Monday, plus his determination to remain in the bullpen, where he has spent the last four seasons.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AMERICANA - a major folk carving of Punch, a rare Paul Revere silver teapot, a Lincoln letter and an important pair of New York gilded and brass inlaid classical card tables -will be auctioned today at 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Enron to Close Unit After Costly Trades
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it would permanently close its Enron Oil Corporation subsidiary after learning that the unit had lost $85 million because of unauthorized trading in the petroleum futures markets.

title: A.N. Kolmogorov Dies at 84; Top Russian Mathematician
description: Andrei N. Kolmogorov, the founder of modern probability theory and one of the 20th century's most eminent mathematicians, died in Moscow on Tuesday, the Soviet press agency Tass reported yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Progress in Shultz Talks

title: Record Fines Are Imposed in Building Collapse That Killed
description: The Labor Department imposed a record $5.11 million in fines today against companies it charged with responsibilty for the collapse last April of a high-rise apartment complex under construction in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Art: Multiple Viewpoints in African Sculptures
description: THE new exhibition at the Center for African Art provides an excellent introduction to African sculpture - especially to the stylistic diversity of its carved figures and masks - but this is only the beginning. What makes ''Perspectives: Angles on African Art'' so unusual is that it also represents the multiple viewpoints from which African art is studied, interpreted, appreciated and debated. This has been accomplished by giving the show multiple curators - 10 to be exact - all with an abiding, experienced interest in African art. The curators were asked to select about 10 objects from a large pool available for loan (from a variety of public and private sources) and to explain each selection in a caption that is displayed beside it.

title: No Big Firms Seen in Trouble
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that, on the basis of information from the nation's stock exchanges, none of the major brokerage firms was in financial difficulty.

title: Chamber Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will present a concert of works by Pergolesi, Mrs. H. H. A. Beach, Shulamit Ran and Ravel Sunday at 5 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Guest performers include the pianist Peter Serkin. Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.

title: Plunge Tests a Seer's Theory of Waves
description: For the last eight years, Robert S. Prechter has worked as a shepherd in the field of investment counseling, offering to lead an ever-growing flock toward the greenest of pastures, a Dow Jones industrial average of 3,686. To get there would take some zigging and zagging through the wilderness, he has told his 16,000 followers and anyone else who would listen, but they would arrive in the promised land in 1988.

title: Truth Hidden in Fog of Sri Lanka War
description: Twelve days after Indian troops began their assault on a Tamil rebel stronghold in Sri Lanka, accounts about the operation have become a matter of contradiction, uncertainty and confusion.

title: U.S. Won't Call Mafia Figure as Witness in Racketeering Trial
description: Federal prosecutors plan to rest their case in a major racketeering trial in Manhattan without calling a key Mafia figure who was supposed to be an important witness.

title: Twins Are Down But Don't Feel Out
description: There was no gloom tonight. The Minnesota Twins did not allow themselves to consider the difficulty of their situation in the 84th World Series. They simply talked of the dome. They were going home now, they said, back to the Metrodome, their security blanket for an entire season. They are facing a one-game deficit in the Series after losing to the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-2, but there was a silver lining. The dome. ''Hopefully,'' said Kent Hrbek, the first baseman, ''we'll play the same type of ball we played there all year. We're pretty confident there. It will be a different ball game when we get back.'' Another 'Must' Situation

title:
Anchorage Journal;
AS ISOLATIONISM AND RACISM INTERSECT
description: LEAD: A nearly completed performing arts center here, already the focus of controversy for vast cost overruns, has now become the battleground for a symbolic struggle over whom it will be named for.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Andal Corp., a subsidiary of Olsher Metals Corp., appointed Michael S. Huber senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Life After Jail: Politicians Get Help From Their Friends
description: At a time when more and more local politicians are in trouble with the law, most former politicians who have served time have found that they can re-establish their professional lives.

title: New Hampshire Speech Earns Praise for Trump
description: Insisting that he is not a candidate for President, Donald J. Trump flew to New Hampshire, the state with the earliest Presidential primary, and today delivered what sounded like an impassioned campaign speech to an enthusiastic audience.

title: Defense Cuts That Won't Hurt Defense
description: The President and Congress have four weeks to put the budget together. If, despite Wall Street's warning, they still can't come to terms, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law takes effect on Nov. 20. Nominally, this meat-ax approach to deficit reduction will cut ''across the board'' - $11.5 billion from non-defense spending and the same from defense. For reasons of conscience as well as politics, Congress exempted Social Security and a few welfare programs. But the fine print reveals that the lawmakers also protected hometown pork; the Pentagon won't be allowed to save money by shutting any bases.

title: The Financial Crisis, Close to Home
description: New York City is a capital of world finance, and this week it's become a capital of financial trauma. How will the fallout affect New York and other cities where financial services play a big role in local spending and taxing? Common sense dictates serious local planning for the worst, even as Federal officials wrestle with the budget and international trade issues.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Greg Meyer, the last American to run a marathon in 2 hours 9 minutes, has entered the New York City Marathon on Nov. 1. Meyer, 32 years old, is coming back from a series of injuries that sidelined him in 1984 and 1985. . . . The season-ending statistics are in on Bob Horner, the former Atlanta Braves slugger who played in Japan this season, and the numbers pretty much match Horner's major-league performance here: 31 home runs (fifth in the league), 73 runs batted in and a .327 bating average for the Yakult Swallows. Richard Lancellotti of the Tokyo Carp, formerly with the San Diego Padres, led in homers with 39. . . . Phil Pozderac, an offensive lineman for the Dallas Cowboys who at 6-9 was the league's tallest player, has retired at 27 years old.

title: New York's AIDS Programs Shift Focus to Drug Abusers
description: Responding to a report that intravenous drug users have replaced homosexuals as the major AIDS risk group in New York City, city health officials said yesterday that the fight against AIDS was shifting to addicts and the predominantly black and Hispanic communities where they live.

title: A. H. Robins Expands Profit
description: The A. H. Robins Company, in bankruptcy proceedings, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 6 percent, mainly from its consumer products (such as Robitussin cough syrup) and sales abroad.

title: Some Basic Brodsky In Poetry and Prose
description: Columns of grandsons, stiff at attention; gun carriage, coffin, riderless horse. Wind brings no sound of their glorious Russian trumpets, their weeping trum pets of war. Splendid regalia deck out the corpse: thundering Zhukov rolls toward death's mansion.

title: Hurt in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Messages Of Calm By Wall St.
description: AMONG the things that Wall Street has today that it did not have in 1929 is the backing of a highly sophisticated advertising industry. It could make a difference.

title: Carteret, Home Talk on Merger
description: The Home Group Inc., a New York-based insurance company, and the Carteret Bancorp have held talks about their proposed merger.

title: Market Place; Momentum For Buybacks
description: THE wave of stock buyback announcements continued yesterday as several major companies sought to take advantage of low stock prices and reassure shareholders that the basic operating underpinnings were sound.

title: Soviet Journal May Publish Brodsky's Work
description: The Soviet magazine Novy Mir is negotating to publish the works of Joseph Brodsky, who was imprisoned and then banished from his native country for his poetry and who won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Arabs Expected to Weigh Cairo Ties
description: Eight years after the Arab world ostracized Egypt for making peace with Israel, a move is expected at an Arab League summit meeting next month to reinstate Egypt's formal standing with other Arab countries.

title: A Broker's Harried Day as the Big Customers Rush to Sell
description: By 9:15 A.M. yesterday, the tension was building inside the trading room at Wertheim Schroder & Company, a medium-sized brokerage firm that caters to institutional customers and wealthy individuals. Clients were flooding the firm with orders to sell stock. ''There hasn't been a single buy order so far today,'' said Robert J. Chamine, Wertheim's head of equity trading. The market had not opened yet but nerves were already frayed.

title: Playing the Casino
description: After the crash I did exactly what most people with a telephone were doing. I called some friends I respect to try to find out what in Heaven's name was going on.

title: Broadway
description: What to Do About Wall Street

title: New York Film Festival Head Forced Out
description: Richard Roud, the longtime director of the New York Film Festival, was removed from his position yesterday when the board of the Film Society of Lincoln Center voted unanimously to accept his resignation, which was requested last week. Mr. Roud has been with the film festival, a project of the Film Society, for its entire 25 years. He will become the festival's director emeritus and a consultant to the Film Society.

title: City Council Offers Bill to Ban Smoking in Most Indoor Public Areas
description: Leaders of the New York City Council yesterday introduced a bill that would ban smoking in most indoor public areas and restrict it in restaurants, stores and offices.

title: Anderson Questions Financing by Public Of Political Contests
description: The majority leader of the New York State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, yesterday warned the State Commission on Integrity in Government that public financing of election campaigns might create more problems than it solves.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Expressions '87, a Celebration of Africa in the Americas, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (307-7420). The Caribbean Cultural Center's Expressions Festival is presenting the United States debuts of two intriguing bands this weekend. Fundo de Quintal plays Brazilian samba - not the dressed-up, jazzed-up samba, but the percussive, heavily African variety. Boncana Maiga and his orchestra left their home in West Africa's Ivory Coast to study Cuban music in Cuba. Both groups are playing tonight and tomorrow night, in concerts beginning at 8. Tonight's opening act is the Chosen Few, a brass band from New Orleans. Tomorrow night, Mario Bauza and his Latin Jazz All-Stars promise to heat things up for the headliners. Tickets are $20 and $17 in advance. $24 and $21 at the door. They can be charged by calling 307-7420.

title: Our Towns; Beseeching Help From a Giant For Jersey's Poor
description: Before the big meeting, the Rev. Stephen Bouman of Bogota had several routine sick calls to make to his congregation. He visited a woman in a nursing home, one in a hospital and a couple in their 60's, newly homeless and living at the Turnpike Motel on Route 46.

title: Vatican Reduces Deficit Forecast
description: The Vatican announced today that its budget deficit this year would be about $3.6 million less than expected because of improved fund raising and cost-cutting measures.

title: Woolridge Out
description: The Nets, who were hobbled by injuries last season, have lost their leading scorer for up to four weeks, two weeks before this season is scheduled to open. Orlando Woolridge, the small forward who led the team with an average of 20.7 points a game, cut the pinkie of his right hand with scissors last Sunday at the Nets' training camp at Princeton, N.J. The wound, which required three stitches, was thought to be minor, but yesterday it was decided to immobilize the area. Two other small forwards on the Nets' roster, Tony Brown and Kevin McKenna, will be sidelined for up to two weeks, each with a strained Achilles' tendon. Keith Lee, who was scheduled to back up Mike Gminski at center and Buck Williams at power forward, is undergoing tests to determine what is causing pain in his left leg, which has virtually sidelined him since he came to New Jersey in a trade with John Bagley from the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Art: The Picassos Kept By His Granddaughter
description: THE inaugural exhibition at the Jan Krugier Gallery is devoted to an artist of whom many people may think that they have lately heard quite enough: Pablo Picasso. ''What more can there be to learn about Picasso?'' they say. The answer is, ''Plenty!,'' provided the show has an inner coherence and is not just recycled auction material.

title: Ohio Banker In Chapter 11
description: Marvin L. Warner, who was convicted this year on felony criminal charges related to the 1985 collapse of the Cincinnati-based Home State Savings Bank, which he owned, filed for protection from creditors today in United States Bankruptcy Court in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: NEC Wins Order Against Intel
description: NEC Electronics Inc., the American affiliate of the NEC Corporation of Tokyo, said it had won a court order that would stop the Intel Corporation from petitioning the United States Customs Service to block shipments of NEC microprocessors. The action stems from a nearly three-year-old lawsuit in which Intel contends that microcode, or the embedded instructions in its chips, can be copyrighted and that NEC's chips infringe on Intel's copyrights.

title: It Is Time to Act
description: There was no lack of warning, not just from Cassandras but from serious, knowledgeable people.

title: New Agent for McCray
description: Rodney McCray, the 6-foot-8-inch forward for the Houston Rockets who is a holdout, has dismissed his agent, Howard Slusher, in the hope of speeding negotiations toward a contract. ''I have nothing personal against Howard,'' said McCray, 30 years old, who has played four seasons with Houston. ''I just felt that maybe he had some other things going on that required his attention. I wanted someone who could get the ball rolling. I don't want to sit out.'' During his rookie season, McCray was advised to hold out by Slusher and missed all but one exhibition game. He spent the first half of that season attempting to catch up with his teammates. As a replacement for Slusher, McCray has hired Dave Falk, a sports agent from ProServ. McCray has been seeking an annual salary of about $1 million while the Rockets have offered about $700,000.

title: Scorned Witness Testifies From the Shadows
description: At the start of yesterday's session in the Howard Beach case, the light in the courtroom was bad. Some bulbs in the high ceiling had burned out. And the judge said he was putting a lamp at the edge of the bench to shine down on the witness so the jury could see him clearly.

title: Rates Fall Sharply Once More
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined sharply for the fourth consecutive day, spurred by speculation that the Federal Reserve would adopt a more generous monetary policy as the stock market's gyrations cause the economy to weaken.

title: Reagan Defends AIDS Panel; Plans to Replace 2 Members
description: President Reagan defended his troubled AIDS commission tonight and said he still hoped it would help find the best way to combat ''this terrible plague.''

title: Fashion Accolades in Paris
description: Jean-Paul Gaultier, the avant-garde designer who spoofs traditional clothing, was welcomed into the fashion establishment last night. He was honored at an elaborate ceremony at the Opera sponsored by the French Federation of Couture, Ready-to-Wear and Creators of Fashion, the organization of fashion trade groups. Called the Oscars of fashion, the evening was modeled on the annual West Coast event and was broadcast live on French television.

title: Market Turmoil; Big Banks Cut Prime Rate to 9% On Signs of Looser Money Policy
description: The nation's leading commercial banks lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 9 percent, a move that reflected the Federal Reserve System's determination to avert a widespread financial panic.

title: Girl Saved From Subway Tracks
description: A 15-year-old girl was pushed onto subway tracks in Manhattan as a train approached and rescued by a stranger yesterday as two other bystanders chased and held the assailant until the police arrived, the authorities said.

title: Series Notebook; Home, Sweep Home
description: Home-field advantage? To the Minnesota Twins, it's the Metrodome, known to visiting teams as the Metrodoom. To the San Francisco Giants, it's Candlestick Park, a house of horrors to visiting teams with its gale winds and wintry temperatures. To the St. Louis Cardinals, it's Busch Stadium, mostly because it's big.

title: SAFETY CALLED LAX IN PLUTONIUM UNITS
description: Workers at the Government plants that make plutonium for nuclear bombs are being endangered and sometimes injured because managers are ignoring safety requirements, safety auditors told a House subcommittee today.

title: Making Cabaret Act Look Easy
description: LONETTE McKEE is one of the few pop vocalists who can stretch from Jerome Kern to Billie Holiday to the Beatles and make it all look like a piece of cake.

title: Clabir May Sell
description: The Clabir Corporation said it was considering the sale of its entire 83 percent interest in Ambrit Inc., a food maker, as well as the Flinchbaugh division of its General Defense Corporation subsidiary. The diversified holding and management concern said it had intended to sell only part of its Ambrit stake but had received indications of interest from potential buyers of all of Ambrit. Clabir said it would offer to buy Ambrit's controlling interest in Ambrit International P.L.C., which has oil and real estate operations, to facilitate the sale of Ambrit.

title: About Real Estate; Projects Cater to Couples Moving From Big Home
description: Older buyers who have spent 20 years or more in a detached house on an acre or two of land often have difficulty coming to terms with the idea of moving into the densely populated setting of an apartment building or town house complex. They want to be rid of the problems of caring for the large house and yard, yet yearn for the space and privacy.

title: Restaurants
description: WITH theme restaurants all the rage -from dreamy Provencal to daffy tropical - Anabelle's is distinctive for its lack of a conspicuous label. It is simply a comfortable and welcoming place where the food takes center stage - and what a splendid show it can be.

title: Looking for a Leader
description: When the United States Olympic Committee executive board meets this weekend in Oklahoma City, its most important order of business will be to name an executive director to succeed George Miller, who resigned under pressure two months ago. A likely selection, according to committee officials, is Harvey Schiller, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, who was among the finalists for the job two and a half years ago when Miller was named. ''A deal has not yet been struck,'' a U.S.O.C. official said yesterday. ''And there's a 5 to 15 percent possibility one won't be. Harvey has an awfully good job right now.''

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: Robert Black will conduct the Bronx Arts Ensemble in a chamber-orchestra performance of works by Mendelssohn, Shostakovich and Meyer Kupferman on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Riverdale Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. (5625 Arlington Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx). Tickets are $8, $5 for the elderly and students. Information: 601-7399.

title: Soon, Free at Last
description: LEAD: The news from Moscow is good. Vladimir and Mariya Slepak - Volodia and Masha - are to leave the Soviet Union on Sunday. Their 17-year ordeal has ended. Another victory for glasnost? Whatever the explanation, it cannot but influence our attitude toward its author. Mikhail S. Gorbachev has given us some reasons to view his policies with less suspicion.

title: U.S. WILL PENALIZE CHINA ON MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was putting curbs on the export of some high technology products to China, in what officials said was a proportional response to continued Chinese sale of Silkworm anti-ship missiles to Iran.

title: Progress Cited in Shultz's Moscow Talks
description: Soviet and American spokesman struck a positive tone today as they reported progress in the opening round of talks between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Art: A New Direction For Susan Rothenberg
description: SUSAN ROTHENBERG'S eagerly awaited exhibition defines the direction in which she has been moving since she exhausted the emblematic images of horses and heads that established her reputation. It is her first show at the Sperone Westwater Gallery, a larger and more neutral space than the Willard Gallery, which closed last summer and with which she, more than any other artist, was identified.

title: Agency Is Out Of Power Suit
description: A Federal judge has dismissed the Bonneville Power Administration as a defendant in the litigation surrounding the $2.25 billion bond default of the Washington Public Power Supply System in 1983.

title: BOLD DANCE PROGRAMS THAT EMBRACE SOCIAL ISSUES
description: DANCE, like life, has a way of swinging between extremes. In modern dance, for instance, the socially involved choreography of the 1930's was very much a thing of the past by the early 60's, when minimalism and abstract formalism came into fashion. This weekend's varied dance offerings suggest there is a renewed emphasis on work that looks to social issues, although there are performances that range along the spectrum.

title: What? Physicians Won't Treat AIDS?
description: Doctors who refuse to care for AIDS patients are raising grave questions about the integrity of the medical profession.

title: Dooley Recuperating
description: Two days after undergoing a procedure to clear two blocked arteries near his heart, Vince Dooley was released from Emory University Hospital in Atlanta yesterday morning. ''I've never felt better,'' said Dooley, the University of Georgia football coach, as he headed for an afternoon football practice. ''My only concern, and this is the biggest I have, is I hope the attention I'm getting does not distract from the more important thing, and that's the ball game Saturday.'' Georgia will play Kentucky in a Southeastern Conference game, and doctors have said that Dooley, 55 years old, who passed a stress test before leaving the hospital, was well enough to coach. ''I intend to be there, minimize the decision-making and try not to mess up what we're going to do,'' he said.

title: Girl, 2, Survives Plane Crash
description: A whimpering 2-year-old girl was found buckled in her seat, shielded by a body, in the wreckage of small plane that crashed in heavy fog, killing her father, grandmother and another adult, officials said. The girl, Aubrey Holst, was in serious condition at Sacred Heart Hospital in Eugene.

title: TV Weekend; 'BAY COVEN,' A HALLOWEEN HORROR TALE ON NBC
description: KICKING off television's annual drive of spooky specials with Halloween tie-ins, NBC is offering this Sunday at 9 P.M. a made-for-television movie called ''Bay Coven.'' This is your basic witches' brew of odd-looking neighbors and rosary beads, overlaid with great dollops of thunder and lightning. The cast, with the exception of Tim Matheson, who is perhaps still best known for the film ''Animal House,'' seems to have been recruited from every television series you might ever have stumbled over.

title: Art People
description: Stock Market's Effect

title: Film: Cher and Dennis Quaid Star in 'Suspect'
description: AS the coming attractions might put it, ''Suspect'' brings you Cher as you've never seen her before. It brings Cher as a smart, tough, no-nonsense Washington public defender who lives entirely for her work. She even wears glasses. And she turns out to be surprisingly credible in this role, certainly a lot likelier than anything else about Peter Yates's new courtroom thriller, a genre that's a lot less novel than it sounds.

title: Korean Trade Surplus
description: South Korea recorded a $1.27 billion trade surplus in September, putting the total for the year so far at $6.93 billion, the Bank of Korea said today. The September figure was South Korea's biggest monthly surplus and indicated that the country's economy has weathered a wave of summer strikes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1987
description: International A3-11

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday mis-stated the location of McCaffrey & McCall's Rumrill-Hoyt unit. It is in New York.

title: O'Connor Turns Down Fundamentalists' Plea
description: A Supreme Court Justice today turned down an emergency request from fundamentalist Christians attempting to ban from Alabama public schools 44 textbooks that they say promote a godless religion.

title: Wickes to Sell 3 Subsidiaries
description: Wickes Companies Inc., streamlining further, said today that it planned to sell three operating units and expected to receive more than the book value of $600 million. The company plans to use the proceeds to retire debt, repurchase stock and possibly make acquisitions.

title: A Gutenberg Bible Sells for Record Price
description: A Gutenberg Bible Old Testament was purchased by a Japanese buyer at Christie's last night for $5.4 million, a record at auction for a printed book.

title: 6 Yugoslav Executives Jailed For Role in Financial Scandal
description: Six executives of Agrokomerc, the food company at the center of a major financial scandal, have been sentenced to prison terms, a Belgrade newspaper reported today.

title: Coffey Closes Door
description: Paul Coffey, the star defenseman of the Edmonton Oilers who has been under suspension and fined $250 a day while attempting to negotiate a new contract, has said that he will not return to the Oilers because his courage was questioned by the team's owner, Peter Pocklington.

title: Margaret Hoswell Dies, 57; Soprano and Voice Teacher
description: Margaret Hoswell, a soprano and member of the voice faculty at the Manhattan School of Music, died of a heart attack Friday at New York University Hospital, where she had been admitted for tests. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Audits Show SUNY Is Owed $34 Million
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today that the State University of New York had failed to collect $34 million in tuition and fees over a recent two-year period and blamed ''liberal deferral practices and lax enrollment procedures.''

title: YORK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 5 percent common stock dividend to be paid Nov. 5.

title: DAYS INNS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,840,000. c-Net income and includes extraordinary gains of $209,000 and $2,487,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt, and a tax loss carryforward of $1,300,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the latest quarter includes an unusual charge of $17.1 million primarily resulting from an adjustment to the carrying value of certain property and notes receivable.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Dance: New Leads In 'Journey'
description: There was a time when changes of cast were rare in the Martha Graham Dance Company and this proved especially true with respect to roles Miss Graham had originally choreographed for herself.

title: CONTEL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,130,000 and $8,047,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,762,000 for the quarter and $6,145,000 for the 9 months.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kuwait Is Said to Seek a Better Defense
description: Kuwait is seeking more advanced anti-missile systems and redeploying its American-made Hawk anti-aircraft missiles against the increasing threat of Iranian missiles, military experts and diplomats said today. But they said Kuwait was unlikely to build an effective screen soon.

title: EUGENE M. KLEBAN
description: Dr. Eugene M. Kleban, an educator and former executive director of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences of America, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 9 in his Manhattan home. He was 78 years old.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DETREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $995,000 and $1,147,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After realized investment losses of $178,000 for the quarter and $253,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. to Segregate 'Predatory' Prisoners With the AIDS Virus
description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons will immediately begin segregating Federal inmates who test positive for the AIDS virus and display ''predatory or promiscuous behavior,'' the Justice Department said today.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $4.6 million for the quarter and $7.9 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Kasparov Defeated in Rush at End
description: Anatoly Karpov won the fifth game of the World Chess Championship match today when the champion, Gary Kasparov, resigned after 38 moves.

title: HYCOR BIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $52,000 for the quarter and $109,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Opera: 'Nixon in China'
description: That was it? That was ''Nixon in China''? Finally, on Thursday evening, we had the world premiere of the most heavily publicized and shrewdly promoted new opera of this decade. Though grandly proportioned, the Houston Grand Opera production turned out to be a Peter Sellars variety show, worth a few giggles but hardly a strong candidate for the standard repertory.

title: Zimbabwe Parliament Picks 11 Whites for Membership
description: Zimbabwe's Parliament elected 20 new members today, including 11 whites, to fill seats that until last month were reserved for whites.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $4 million for the quarter and a gain of $17 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations and gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $252 million and $588 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also includes a gain of $270 million from a change in accounting for reversion of surplus pension funds.

title: ELMIRA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it had a net gain of $7,000,000 from proceeds from the public offering of a portion of its interest in Melamine Chemicals Inc. and from the restructuring of the employee benefit plans, which were partially offset by a provision for certain costs related to the shut-down of an Eastern Kentucky oil field. Unusual items in last year's quarter reduced net income by $13 million. Latest year earnings include a net gain of $12,470,000 from restructuring of employee benefit plans and a net loss of $3,515,000 from adjustments required by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Primary Power Making South Dakotans Heady
description: Presidential candidates used to wave at South Dakota from 35,000 feet, on their way to the big-time primaries in states like California and New Jersey, South Dakotans say. This year, the candidates are landing.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Does the Nobel Panel Have Patterns and Prejudices?
description: For writers, scientists and politicians around the world, the Nobel Prize announcement season each October is a time of suspense. Among the Stockholm intelligentsia, it is also a time of amused, half-despairing discussion about the idiosyncrasies of the judges and the horse-trading involved in picking the winners.

title: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Patents;
Big Magnet Is Used in Diagnosis
description: LEAD: A MEDICAL diagnostic technique that employs magnetic resonance spectroscopy was patented this week for the General Electric Company. It permits examination of the health of specific parts of the body while suppressing interference from background signals.

title: USG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $29,988,000 after-tax gain related to the public offering of stock in the company's Canadian unit. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,456,000 for the quarter and $3,026,000 for the 9 months, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $26,668,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: DEVILS BEAT ISLANDERS AND TIE FOR FIRST
description: The passing was crisp, the hitting was ferocious and the shooting was accurate for both teams tonight. But the Devils did everything just a little bit better and defeated the Islanders, 5-3, before a vocal crowd of 14,697 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Landing Jet Quickly Takes Off To Avoid Taxiing Small Plane
description: An American Airlines jetliner had to take off seconds after landing Thursday night to avoid hitting a small airplane that had pulled into its path on a runway, the airline said today.

title: Texts of the Statements Made by Bork and Reagan
description: Following are the statements issued today by Judge Robert H. Bork and President Reagan after the Senate voted 58-42 to reject Judge Bork for a vacancy on the Supreme Court: Bork Statement

title: DIXIE YARNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mips-Kubota Pact
description: Mips Computer Systems Inc., a manufacturer of chips and computers using ''reduced instruction set computing'' technology, said Kubota Ltd., a leading Japanese industrial company, would invest $25 million for a 20 percent stake in the Sunnyvale, Calif., concern. Under the terms of the agreement, Kubota will receive a manufacturing and marketing license for certain products under development at Mips. Mips, which is privately held, was founded three years ago.

title: Antiquarian Book Fair
description: More than 70 book dealers from the United States, England and Canada are to display thousands of volumes, maps and prints this weekend at the Eighth Antiquarian Book Fair, at the Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission is $5 for today and $3 for tomorrow. Information: 873-1650.

title: India Says Its Troops Are Nearly in Control of Tamil Rebel Center
description: An Indian official said today that Indian troops had ''more or less'' seized control of a Tamil rebel stronghold in Sri Lanka, but that the top rebel commander had escaped, perhaps with most of his associates.

title: Guide Approved For Curriculum In AIDS Classes
description: The Board of Regents approved today an instructional guide for teachers of AIDS education in New York State public and private elementary and secondary schools.

title: Helping Families Cope With Alzheimer's
description: Because of the devastating impact on families, an increasing number of states are establishing day-care and other programs to serve the estimated two million Americans who have Alzheimer's disease, an incurable process of mental deterioration that robs victims of their memories and reasoning abilities.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months' results include full-cost accounting writedowns of oil and gas properties of $9 million. The year-ago 9 months' results include writedowns of $9.8 million.

title: 2 RESIGN BAPTIST SEMINARY IN A THEOLOGY DISPUTE
description: The president and the dean of the faculty at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary have announced that they will resign in the aftermath of a factional dispute among Southern Baptists.

title: LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Corrected from Thursday, Oct. 22, editions.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $25,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $39,000 for the 9 months.

title: AMERICAN REPUBLIC BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,000 for the quarter and $3,458,000 for the 9 months.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS FINCL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $907,000 for the quarter and $2,698,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bumper Stickers, Analyzed
description: LEAD: She pulled alongside me during a heat wave at one of those intersections marked No Turn on Red. Unkempt hair rippled by perspiration, heavy arms protruding restlessly out of a discount-store house dress, the woman was not the picture of refinement. Glancing nervously at each other, we exchanged no fanciful mental messages - this in spite of the fact that when she pulled away in the faded yellow '73 Camaro, a bumper sticker told me ''Je T'Aime Paris.

title: For Further Information
description: The New York City Alzheimer's Disease Resource Center has three publications that may helpful to families: ''Caring: A Family Guide to Managing the Alzheimer's Disease Patient at Home''; ''Agendas for Action: The Aging Network Response to Alzheimer's Disease,'' and ''Where to Go for Help With Alzheimer's Disease in New York City.'' The center is at 280 Broadway (Chambers Street), Room 214, New York, N.Y. 10007; 212-577-7564.

title: Poll: Fans Favor Twins
description: More Americans want the Minnesota Twins to win the World Series than back the St. Louis Cardinals, but still more don't have a preference, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $1,473,000 from prepayment of FHLB loans for the quarter and 9 months. The latest third quarter includes gains from securities tranactions of about $100,000, compared with $4.4 million for the year-ago period. The results were restated for the acquisition of NTC Corp. in July on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Caesars Stake Cut
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, has reduced his stake in Caesars World Inc. to 5.68 percent, from 16.04 percent, selling $31.1 million worth of his common stock. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff, who was unsuccessful in a bid to purchase a controlling interest in Caesars earlier this year for $35 a share, gave no reason for the recent sales. He said he had sold the stock between Oct. 19 and Oct. 22 at $10.50 to $20 a share.

title: Borks Nomination Is Rejected, 58-42; Reagan Saddened
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  One of the fiercest battles ever waged over a Supreme Court nominee ended today as the Senate decisively rejected the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork.

title: G.N.P. UP STRONGLY IN 3d QUARTER
description: The nation's economic growth accelerated in recent months and inflation subsided, the Government said in two encouraging reports today.

title: Bridge; Weird Disaster Helps British A Bit in the Bermuda Bowl
description: The final of the world open team championship was a virtual tie when play resumed in the Bermuda Bowl this afternoon. The Americans led Britain by 29 international match points. One hundred and twelve deals have been completed of a scheduled 176.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
CONSTELLATION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jack Lemmon Receives Film Institute Award
description: Jack Lemmon, whose movie roles have ranged from the slapstick of ''Some Like It Hot'' to the drama of ''Save the Tiger,'' for which he won an Academy Award in 1973, has been named the recipient of the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award.

title: Maxeda vonHesse, 74, Former Speech Teacher
description: Maxeda vonHesse, a speech teacher whose clients included Nelson A. Rockefeller and Christian A. Herter, died of lymphoma Sept. 22 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORPORATIN OF INDIANA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's loss includes a charge of $16 million for severance pay associated with an early retirement program and layoffs to reduce salaried staff; also included was a non-recurring tax credit of $9.7 million.

title: TWINS BALK TOWARD RECORD BOOK
description: Win or lose, the Minnesota Twins have a chance to set a World Series record: most balks by one team in a Series. The Twins have already tied the 1948 Cleveland Indians' record by commiting two balks. Les Straker, who will pitch against St. Louis Saturday, was called for a balk in the third game, and Keith Atherton was called for one in the fifth game.

title: GREAT AMERICAN FIRST SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $8 million for the bank's FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: The Gifts That Gild The Wine
description: IN just about everyone's stack of Christmas catalogues - they begin arriving in the steamy days of July now - there is at least one promoting what have come to be known as wine accessories. And you thought that all you needed was a bottle and a glass.

Lender to Governor's Campaign In Arizona Is Linked to Job Favors
description: A real estate agent and a lawyer named by Gov. Evan Mecham to a state board on housing bonds were recommended for the posts by a developer who lent $350,000 to the Mecham campaign last year, The Arizona Republic reported today.

title: GENERAL DESCRIBES SOVIET LASER THREAT
description: The general in charge of American military efforts in space said today that the Soviet Union has developed lasers powerful enough to destroy low-orbiting United States satellites and damage those farther away.

title: Edelman's Stake In Foster Wheeler
description: Asher B. Edelman, The New York investor, said he and a group of affiliates had acquired about 11.5 percent of the outstanding shares of the Foster Wheeler Corporation.

title: VULCAN MATERIALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Both latest periods are after a writedown of its Frac Sands Plant of $5,871,000.

title: Correction
description: A dispatch on Monday from Goiania, Brazil, about a nuclear accident there misstated the rate of decay for cesium 137. The isotope has a half-life of 30 years.

title: President Links Economic Woes To Capitol Hill
description: President Reagan today blamed Congress in large part for the economic uncertainties that led to the stock market crisis this week and reiterated his opposition to tax increases.

title: BRISTOL FEDERAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The thrift went public in March.

title:
PATENTS;
A Device to Collect Urine Samples
description: LEAD: Dr. Richard C. Fuisz of Bethlehem, Pa., noticed the difficulty of obtaining urine samples from infants or senile adults. He was granted patent No. 4,700,714 this week for a collecting device.

description: b-Includes a gain of $25 million from the sale of certain cellular telephone interests. c-Net loss and includes charges of $18.2 million incurred during 1986 in connection with a proposed financial restructuring program terminated in September 1986, and a $6.3 million writedown of an investment. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $7,173,000, a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $6 million, and an extraordinary charge of $1,940,000. The year-ago 9 months' extraordinary charge includes $4.1 million of expenses incurred from the exchange of certain notes payable, partially offset by a $2.2 million gain in connection with the termination of a subsidiary's pension plan during the 1986 first quarter.

title: Dolphins Hunt Gulf Mines
description: Dolphins apparently trained to search for mines are the latest addition to American forces in the Persian Gulf.

PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Beijing Faults U.S. High-Tech Curbs
description: China today criticized an American decision to curb the export of some high-technology products to China, saying the move was ''not reasonable.''

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Message of Judge Bork's Defeat
description: The Senate's 58-to-42 rejection of Robert Bork sends President Reagan an important message: Don't provoke more battles like this. A nation facing a major financial crisis and an escalating involvement in the Persian Gulf needs coherent leadership, not political badgering. And crises or no, it also needs a fully constituted Supreme Court.

title: Piggott Gets 3 Years for Tax Evasion
description: Lester Piggott, one of thoroughbred racing's best-known jockeys, received a three-year jail sentence today after pleading guilty to evading income tax on $5.1 million in earnings.

title: Brady Cites Overvalued Stocks
description: Nicholas F. Brady, the Wall Street investment banker President Reagan has named to head a special task force that will investigate this week's dramatic stock market plunge, said today that he believed the main cause of the collapse was overvalued common stocks in the United States and the rest of the world.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $12,457,000 and $124,313,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, reflecting the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards applicable to United States oeprations and certain foreign subsidiaries. c-Net loss

title: Lawyers Challenge Account Of Howard Beach Witness
description: A defense lawyer declared yesterday that the prosecution's key witness in the Howard Beach trial was the ringleader of an attack by white youths on three black men and was now lying about this and other aspects of the incident to avoid life in prison.

title: Court Rejects a Loosening Of Curb on Color Additives
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that color additives with even a trivial cancer risk cannot be permitted in foods, drugs or cosmetics.

title: As Terrible Turned Worse: A Broker's Harrowing Week
description: Last Saturday. some members of Monness Crespi Hardt & Company, a small stock brokerage firm, were annoyed that they had missed a chance to take profits when the market dropped 100 points the day before. By yesterday afternoon, they felt lucky to be alive.

title: Triangle Industries To Merge With CJI
description: CJI Industries, a producer and distributor of coin and currency handling products. proposed a $35-a-share merger yesterday with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest container maker.

title: What the Market Crash Says About New York City
description: LEAD: The warning of local Cassandras that New York City's economy has become overly dependent on 500,000 volatile financial services jobs has been amplified by the stock market crash.

title: Merc Puts Daily Limits On Stock Index Futures
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange began imposing daily price limits today on its stock index futures and options contracts as an ''emergency action'' intended to calm violent price swings like those of the last few days.

title: Pirate Official Resigns
description: Malcolm M. Prine, president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, resigned yesterday, citing differences with Syd Thrift, the general manager. Prine, the former chairman and chief executive officer of Ryan Homes Inc., which shares ownership of the Pirates, said he was stepping down after two seasons ''because of a lack of a harmonious relationship.''

title: About New York; A Prophet Keeps His Mind Open Near Zabar's
description: The prophet, self-named Man, Sun, world's greatest mystic, self-proclaimed, is a little sketchy about his background, to say nothing of his credentials. However, what is known about Man, Sun, who is perhaps the most popular sidewalk therapist in the city, is that he blew into town five years ago driving a shabby blue Ford Econoline van with pine cones and green grapes scattered across the dash and the legend ''The Key to Mastering Life'' affixed to the roof. It can be assumed Man, Sun intended to stand out.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Music: Oslo Trio Performs Works of Three Composers
description: Lively performances of the standard repertory, traditionally conceived and yet freshly imagined, are probably more to be found in chamber music today than in any other broad sphere of performance. The visit of the Oslo Trio to Weill Recital Hall Tuesday evening was a case in point: their program of Shostakovich, Grieg and Mendelssohn was no more novel than their basic approach to it, but the concert was free from the shadow of purposelessness that hangs over so many ''standard'' evenings at the symphony or the opera.

title: SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago revenue figures were restated to include commodity transactions on a gross profit basis.

title: Commission Windfall Has Worrisome Aspect
description: For the nation's 70,000 individual stockbrokers, this week's torrent of selling on Wall Street was overwhelmingly disappointing. But there was a silver lining: The selling will generate millions of dollars in additional commission income for the brokers, possibly making this their most profitable week ever.

title: USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $2.1 million.

title: A Respite For Weary Dealers
description: GLEN STEVENS ''It was the same feeling as when you ride out an earthquake,'' said Glen Stevens, a stockbroker with Bateman Eichler, Hills Richards Inc. in Los Angeles. ''You're thinking, is this the big one?''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE A musical and a drama open uptown today. The drama is ''My Four Mothers,'' by Ward Morehouse 3d, which explores a man's relationship with his relatives. It is at the Jan Hus Theater, 315 East 74th Street.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nuclear Test at Nevada Site Rattles Las Vegas Buildings
description: An underground nuclear weapon test today sent tremors through tall buildings here, 85 miles from the Nevada Test Site where the weapon was exploded.

title: GEORGE ANDERS
description: George Anders, a retired New York publisher whose company published the original Weight Watchers cookbooks, died of a heart attack Tuesday at University Hospital in Tamarac, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Tamarac.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 28 about the 200th anniversary of Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn misstated its ranking among the oldest public schools in the country. Hartford High, founded 350 years ago, is among public schools that are older than Erasmus Hall.

title: Rohatyn Urges City to Abolish School Board
description: The New York City Board of Education has so failed at running the schools that it should be abolished, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, said yesterday.

title: WESTPORT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Musical on Vaudeville Team
description: ''Williams and Walker,'' a musical based on the lives of the black vaudevillians Bert Williams and George Walker, is in performance at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx. The show, which is free, is presented by the college's department of speech and theater and the National Black Touring Circuit. Performances are at 8 P.M. today and 3 P.M. tomorrow. The number for information is 960-8211.

title: Globetrotter Exits
description: Lynette Woodard, the former University of Kansas basketball star, said yesterday she was leaving the Harlem Globetrotters after two seasons because of a contract dispute. Woodard, the first woman to tour with the Globetrotters, said contract negotiations ended Oct. 5 after the team's training camp.

Korean Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States grew 27.7 percent in the first nine months of this year, to $6.77 billion, from $5.3 billion a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported today. For the year, the surplus could reach a record $10 billion, compared with $7.3 billion in 1986, association officials said. Korean merchandise exports to the United States amounted to $13.1 billion, up 30.9 percent from a year ago, while imports rose 34.5 percent, to $6.3 billion.

title: June Clara Hiroshima Wed to Richard Lentz
description: At the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., June Clara Hiroshima and Richard Raymond Lentz were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert Grippo.

description: For the first time, a Congressional committee has advanced legislation to finance public broadcasting through a Federal fee assessed whenever a commercial station is sold.

title: McAdoo Is Enjoying Success in Europe
description: To romantics, Italy has always been a country suggesting images of gondolas, soft ballads and tantalizing cuisine. To American basketball players, it has sometimes been a place of isolation and despair, a final resting ground for those who are no longer wanted in the National Basketball Association.

title: Freetown Journal; 'Little Beiruts' Multiplying in Africa
description: Fleeing Lebanon's civil war, increasing numbers of Lebanese are emigrating to West and Central Africa, sometimes bringing with them the political violence of the Middle East.

title: Pal Gabor, a Movie Director; Satirized Concerns of Youth
description: Pal Gabor, a Hungarian film director whose best-known film, ''Angi Vera,'' was released in 1979, died Wednesday of a heart attack, in Rome. He was 54 years old.

title: U.S. STEPS UP REVIEWS OF CUBANS HELD SINCE 1980
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has stepped up its review of Cuban detainees, which could mean the eventual release of thousands of people who came to the United States in the huge boatlift from Mariel, Cuba, in 1980.

Tom Kelly of the Minnesota Twins, who had a tobacco-filled bulge in the left side of his mouth, was decorating the steps with unwanted juice. A photographer sliced through a small crowd, kneeled in front of Kelly, and looked through the lens.

description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has asked the leading New York banks to be prepared to make additional loans to brokerage firms whose credit lines are being cut by regional and foreign banks, according to banking industry experts.

title: Pop: Smokey Robinson
description: Just when Smokey Robinson's star seems about to go into eclipse, the veteran singer and songwriter, whose early singles became cornerstones of the Motown musical empire, rebounds with a hit record. Mr. Robinson's latest album, ''One Heartbeat,'' has already spawned two Top-10 singles in its title cut and ''Just to See Her Again,'' both of which are archetypal Robinson ballads with a strolling pop-Latin beat and catchy singalong melodies.

title: Your Money; Margin Debt's Pros and Cons
description: BROKERAGE firms issued a flood of margin calls to their customers during the stock market's rapid recent declines. With experts estimating that the level of margin debt greatly exceeded the previous high of $44.17 billion at the end of last month, the number of margin calls was higher than ever, many securities executives said.
