MacGregor to Sell Three Companies
description: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had agreed to sell three of its businesses to the Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. for up to $73.5 million. The partnership would pay $63.5 million for Chicago-based Riddell Inc., which makes and markets football helmets and accessories; the Sports Specialties Corporation, a distributor of licensed sports caps, and the Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark. Oppenheimer agreed to pay an additional $10 million if the companies meet projected earnings levels by July 31, 1988.

title: For Cleaner City Campaigns
description: Albany may be deadlocked over campaign finance reform, but the City Council of New York still has plenty of room to maneuver. A bold plan before the Council would help curb the impact of big money on politics: all campaigns for city office would be subject to new controls and public financing.

title: ACUSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $863,000 and $3,029,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Thirst for Verse: Poetry Readings Multiply
description: Out the suburban library's window, it is a balmy fall Sunday, with bronze and purple leaves burnished to radiance by a bright sun, and, inside, the 73-year-old poet David Ignatow is reading his lines about subway trash pickers, dead poets and a son's helpless rage.

title: Ward Likens U.S. Justice To Pretoria
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward told a group of black and Hispanic state prison workers yesterday that ''institutional racism'' was pervasive in America and led the justice system to jail blacks at a rate comparable to that in South Africa.

title: Music: Chamber, at the Y
description: Chamber Music at the Y Wednesday night brought with it so many recommendable qualities: excellent musicians, a program at once diverse, original and substantial, and evidence of very thorough rehearsal.

title: Gaudi's Cathedral: And Now?
description: A visitor to Antonio Gaudi's Sagrada Familia peered at its facade as though in a trance and said the cathedral's four bell towers, reaching toward the heavens, appeared to be swaying magically and mysteriously against the blue sky.

title: ADVANCE SLOWS IN BOND MARKETS
description: The furor in the credit markets subsided yesterday, with little change in short- and long-term Treasury issues following four days of steep declines in rates totaling more than a percentage point.

title: 'Nabucco' to Be Staged in Jerusalem Next May
description: An $11.5 million production of Verdi's opera ''Nabucco'' will be presented in Jerusalem next May, the Government of Israel has announced. It will be one of the major highlights of the yearlong celebrations planned for the 40th anniversary of Israel's independence.

description: About 18 months ago, the head of performing arts at the 92d Street Y, Omus Hirshbein, approached Michael Posnick with the idea of creating a new theater company after seeing a production of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill ''Mahagonny Songspiel'' the director had staged with the Y Chamber Symphony. In the months that followed, Mr. Posnick created the Mosaic Theater, which made its debut this week with ''Berlin, Jerusalem and the Moon,'' a work that examines questions of Jewish identity in the modern world.

title: Film: 'John and the Missus,' Set in Stark Newfoundland
description: Despite its terrible title and the complete lack of fanfare with which it arrived at the Quad Cinema yesterday, the Canadian film ''John and the Missus'' is a fine little sleeper. Though it has a good-sized cast, it amounts to a one-man show. Gordon Pinsent, best known as a Canadian television actor, has adapted his own novel and written and directed this film, in which he also stars. Mr. Pinsent, who is himself from Newfoundland, is very much at home in this story of a tight-lipped, stubborn Newfoundland miner resisting the pressures of a changing world.

Executives responsible for corporate pension funds are furious because the insurance strategies did not work in many cases and their stock positions were not adequately hedged during the downturn.

description: The Soviet Union's rejection today of an early summit conference capped the worst week of Ronald Reagan's Presidency, one that also saw the battering of his reputation as an economic miracle-worker and the Senate's rejection of his nominee for the Supreme Court by a margin unmatched in American history.

title: New York Post Plans to Cut Some Editions, Eliminating Jobs

description: Although a relative calm returned to the stock market yesterday, investors from Manhattan to Maine to Oregon could not make up their minds whether it was a merely a temporary lull or the return of sanity.

description: Creme Fraiche, the little 5-year-old gelding who has made a career of derailing potential champions, did it again tonight when he caught Afleet in the final strides to win the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup by a nose at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Sidney S. Gaynor Dies; Ex-Yankees' Physician
description: Dr. Sidney S. Gaynor, a retired orthopedic surgeon who had been the team physician for the New York Yankees for more than 37 years, died Wednesday at Bartholomew County Hospital in Columbus, Ind. He was 82 years old and lived in Westport, Ind., where he had moved after retiring in 1976.

title: RANGERS MANAGE TO BE UNRELENTING
description: If only briefly, the Rangers made amends last night for a string of three defeats generated by undisciplined play and third-period collapse. They dominated the Blackhawks and emerged with a 7-3 victory and a hat trick by Ulf Dahlen, the rookie center.

title: U.S. Assesses Damage In Soviet-Linked Theft
description: A Customs Service official said today that a plot to sell supercomputer designs to the Soviet Union might have succeeded in getting some information to the Russians before it was stopped Thursday with the arrest of three men.

title: U.S. Appeals Judge Retires
description: Chief Judge John C. Godbold of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta announced today that he is retiring, effective immediately. Judge Godbold, 67 years old, a Federal appeals judge since 1966, will remain as director of the Federal Judicial Center here, the teaching and research arm of the Federal judiciary.

RESULTS PLUS
description: GYMNASTICS Rumania Triumphs: Rumania had seven perfect scores yesterday to hold off the Soviet Union and win the women's team event at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Rumania got three perfect 10's from Aurelia Dobre, the individual leader, and two from Daniela Silivas, the European champion, to break the Soviet domination of team gymnastics. Dobre had 10's on the beam, floor and uneven bars. The Rumanians finished with 395.400 points out of 400; the Soviet team scored 394.950. East Germany took third with 389.600 points. The United States finished sixth behind China and Bulgaria.(AP) TENNIS Lendl Gains: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, cruised into the semifinals of the $375,000 Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo yesterday with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Eric Jelen of West Germany. Lendl needed less than an hour to trounce Jelen, ranked No. 57. Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia also advanced when Boris Becker of West Germany had to withdraw because of a thigh injury. Zivojinovic led, 6-3, 1-6, 3-0 when Becker had to retire.(AP) Jordan Upsets an Italian: Unseeded Kathy Jordan reached her first semifinal in 16 months yesterday, upsetting eighth-seeded Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-1, 6-3 in the third round of the $200,000 Volvo Classic in Brighton, England. In another quarterfinal, third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia struggled to beat the seventh-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-3, 5-7, 6-1.(AP) BOXING Kalambay Wins Title: Sumbu Kalambay of Italy captured the vacant World Boxing Association middleweight title last night in Leghorn, Italy, with an unanimous decision over Iran Barkley of the United States. Kalamby, who is 31 years old and was born in Zaire, used a mix of left jabs and right uppercuts to overcame his more powerful and younger opponent.(AP) GOLF Sharp Sutton Takes Lead: Hal Sutton played the best round of his career, a 10-under-par 62, and took a one-shot lead yesterday after the second round of the $600,000 Tucson Open. ''Today was the best I've ever played,'' Sutton said after completing two rounds in 131, 13 under par. Sutton had eight birdies, an eagle and either hit the hole or left the ball on the lip on six other putts. Payne Stewart and Paul Azinger each shot a 63, with Stewart sinking seven consecutive birdies, one short of the record. (AP) Charles a Shot Ahead: Bob Charles shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday afternoon at the Desert Inn Country Club to take the first-round lead in the $250,000 Las Vegas PGA Senior tournament. Charles, looking for his fourth seniors victory of the year, birdied all four of the par-5 holes and added another birdie on the par-4 sixth hole to take a one-stroke lead over Al Geiberger. Geiberger, who has won twice in the last three weeks, including the rich Vantage Championship, had an eagle, four birdies and two bogeys for his round of four-under-par 68.(AP)

He devoted the entire first half of the program to the New York premiere of Hans Werner Henze's Symphony No. 7, and audience complaints at the intermission were long and loud.

title: U.S. Ends Lamberti Inquiry
description: After two and a half years of public uncertainty, a cloud lifted yesterday from Ralph J. Lamberti, the Staten Island Borough President, when Federal prosecutors said they had ended their investigation into allegations of conflict of interest. No charges will be brought, they said.

title: Out of Despair, Poems of Hope
description: When Laura Lee Nash wrote a poem called ''Looking,'' she and her two children had been homeless for two years. They were forced to leave their city-owned apartment on Grand Avenue in the Bronx when it was no longer safe to stay in what had become an abandoned building. The poem began this way: I want out. A home to call my own. Where can I go? Who can help me? What must I do? When will this stopover in a sort of hell ever end?

title: STEINBRENNER AND CLYDESDALES
description: THE World Series has been, for the most part, a fan's delight, with good pitching like John Tudor's performance, and good hitting like Dan Gladden's grand slam and good fielding like, well, like almost anything Ozzie Smith does, and the mental machinations of the managers and the way the events have swung, with the Twins dominating so thoroughly in Games 1 and 2, and the Cardinals being pumped back to life in the following three games.

title: British Searchers Find Body
description: Rescuers today found a body believed to be that of a test pilot who ejected from his fighter plane on Thursday, more than an hour before it crashed into the Atlantic Ocean. The civilian pilot, Taylor Scott, disappeared during a test of a new version of the Harrier vertical takeoff plane. The body, dressed in a flight suit and a parachute, was found in a field near the spot where radio contact with Mr. Scott was lost. The Defense Ministry said, however, that the body had not been identified and that the search had not been called off.

description: Three Jersey City narcotics detectives were arrested Thursday night on charges of stealing cash and cocaine from a police officer posing as a drug dealer.

description: b-Net income Both latest periods' losses reflect a $22 million special addition to loan loss reserves.

title: The U.S.-Spain Connection
description: A number of expletives are being uttered in Washington and other NATO capitals these days about the Spaniards. Some of the kinder ones are ''selfish,'' ''obstreperous'' and ''treasonous.''

title: Daggett Recovering
description: Tim Daggett, the American gymnast, was recovering well yesterday in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, after having undergone surgery for two broken bones in his left leg.

title: Film: 'Nightflyers' Science Fiction Thriller
description: ''This ship is alive!,'' says a telepathic crewmember on a 21st century spaceship. ''It's a seething malignant presence and it hates all of you!'' The ship's captain, whose mother is a jealous computer, has a confession of his own: ''Contact with humans will probably kill me.'' There you have the problem with ''Nightflyers''; it is the talkingest movie ever to pose as a science-fiction adventure.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7,103,000 for the quarter and $18,554,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,801,000 for the quarter and $12,838,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations included a writedown of $118 million on oil and gas properties.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter net includes the sale of non-strategic operations for a gain of $29 million. The carrying value of a 32 percent-owned affiliate was also reduced, resulting in an after-tax charge of $22 million. The continued non-accrual status of Brazilian obligations reduced earnings for the quarter by $39 million. The loss for the first 9 months reflected the second-quarter $1.1 billion addition to the allowance for credit losses relating to developing countries.

title: Public Campaign Financing Is Favored by Charter Chief
description: The head of the New York City Charter Revision Commission said yesterday that he favored public financing of municipal election campaigns and that he hoped public financing would be among the changes his commission proposes next year.

description: THE GOLDEN DROPLET. By Michel Tournier. Translated by Barbara Wright. 206 pages. Doubleday. $16.95.

description: President Reagan said today that he would not agree to strict limits on the ''Star Wars'' testing program despite Soviet insistence that the two sides make progress on this issue before a summit meeting is held.

description: A 21-year-old Staten Island man was arrested early yesterday and charged with killing a woman on Coney Island by shooting her with a bolt from a crossbow, the police said.

Robertson Urges New Policy To Increase U.S. Birth Rate
description: Pat Robertson, the Republican Presidential hopeful, said today that Government policy should encourage the birth of more American children to pay future bills and to stave off the decline of ''our culture and our values.''

Spill's Legal Odyssey

But, even as the two sides are making plans to appeal the verdict, questions are being raised about the wisdom of using lay juries in highly technical cases, about abuses by go-for-broke lawyers and about what, if anything, should be done to streamline the litigation process.

PATENTS;

description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Infant Heart Patient Gains
description: Paul Holc, the youngest recipient ever of a heart transplant, continues to make progress, according to officials at Loma Linda University Medical Center.

Ben Caldwell, a co-defendant named in the suit, has been listed in the program of the second production, throughout the run, as its author.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rises Set for Social Security
description: In the largest increase in five and a half years, benefits will jump by $21 a month, or 4.2 percent, in 1988 for the nation's 38 million Social Security recipients and the four million people who receive Supplemental Security Income, the Government announced yesterday.

title: Airbus Dispute Easing
description: The European Community today reported progress in a dispute over aid to Airbus Industrie. A London meeting next week will explore American complaints that the plane maker gets unfair government subsidies from West Germany, France, Britain and Spain.

title: Teamster Move Is Seen As Harmful to U.S. Suit
description: Law-enforcement officials and legal experts outside the Government said today that a reaffiliation by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. could undercut the Justice Department's effort to put the teamsters under Federal control.

title: Can Plantation Tune Carry Virginia Forward?
description: Virginians like to joke that it takes three of them to change a light bulb - one to screw in the new bulb and two others to wax nostalgic about the old bulb and how nice it was.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA R R reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JARDINE'S ENDS OFFER TO BROKER
description: In another reverberation from Monday's stock market plunge, Jardine Matheson Holdings, the giant British-owned conglomerate in Hong Kong, has withdrawn its $390 million offer to buy a substantial stake of the Bear Stearns Companies, one of Wall Street's most aggressive investment firms.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: Dickie Noles was traded for himself yesterday, returning to the Chicago Cubs to complete a deal under which the Detroit Tigers had acquired him for a player to be named later. Detroit acquired the pitcher on Sept. 21, but he was returned to Chicago after the two clubs failed to agree on which player the Tigers were to send to the Cubs, according to the Tigers' general manager, Bill Lajoie. Noles, 30 years old, appeared in four games for Detroit, and had two saves, no decisions and a 4.50 earned run average. . . . Andy Kaplan, 26 years old, a native of Brooklyn who for the past five years has been the assistant general manager of the Charlotte Orioles of the Class AA Southern League, has been named general manager of the St. Lucie Mets, the Mets' new affiliate in the Class A Florida State League. . . . Julie Krone, 24, who had nine mounts on the 10-race program at the Meadowlands on Thursday night, won five times to tie a track record shared by Jose Ferrer, Herb McCauley and Chris Antley. She missed an opportunity to break the record when her mount in the 10th race finished fourth. . . . Carey Scurry, a forward for the Utah Jazz, was sentenced to a suspended 90-day jail term and placed on 12 months' probation after pleading guilty yesterday in Layton, Utah, to being intoxicated while sitting in the driver's side of his car after leaving a party Aug. 9.

title: SOFTWARE PUBLISHING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Venezuelan Minister Quits

And Hoboken, the tough industrial town on the west bank of the Hudson River a few miles upriver from his offices at the World Trade Center, has made its feelings clear for some time.

description: Sales of American-made passenger vehicles rose 4.1 percent in mid-October, to 266,502, compared with 256,077 in the comparable period a year ago, the seven domestic manufacturers reported today.

description: Mary Yvonne Bebel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gontran Bebel of Freeport, L.I., and Steven Paul Schinke, a son of Mrs. Clarence W. Schmidt of Elkhorn, Wis., and the late Edward P. Schinke, were married yesterday at the First Church Baldwin United Methodist in Baldwin, L.I., by the Rev. A. Deryck Moon. The bride is an administrative aide at the Columbia University School of Social Work, where her husband is a professor. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: CHILDREN
description: How to Raise a Street-Smart Child With Daniel Travanti as host and narrator. HBO Video. 43 minutes. $9.95. Originally made for cable television, this production addresses a range of parental concerns for child welfare and safety in a fiercely earnest way that is intended to upset concerned parents and propel them into ''street-proofing'' their children.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
HOW-TO
description: LEAD: Play Bridge With Omar Sharif Featuring Dorothy Hayden Truscott. 1986. Color. Best Film and Video. 55 minutes. $29.99. Make no mistake: This is not a how-to-learn video; it is a guide for experienced bridge players who want to improve their game and bring themselves up to professional level.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Tauber of Pleasantville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sharon Allison Tauber to John Frank Mulholland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Herbert Mulholland of Monroe, Conn.

title: 10 SAFETY DEPARTMENTS ARE HIRING NONSMOKERS
description: TO reduce insurance costs, 10 Connecticut fire and police departments are now hiring only nonsmokers. But they are allowing those already hired to continue smoking.

title: HOLMES RETURNS IN 'FLIGHTS OF DEVILS'
description: MOST regional theaters, if they do new plays at all, bury them in the middle of a season weighted down by Broadway comedies, familiar musicals and classic revivals. As a refreshing change, Long Island Stage displayed the courage of its artistic conviction by opening its 13th season with a new play, ''Flights of Devils,'' by Tom McClary.

title: Knock Out Tradition
description: IT'S not a common occurrence, but it sometimes happens that a boxer is declared the winner of a bout after being knocked out in the final seconds of the last round. That is because a fighter who hits the canvas in the last 10 seconds of a bout can be saved by the bell, which, by long tradition, ends not only the round and the bout, but the referee's count as well.

title: U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT MEETING
description: The team was already hampered by the absence of its best player, Arvidas Sabonis, the 7-foot-2-inch center who is recovering from surgery on his Achilles' tendon one month ago. Then there was an arduous 26-hour wait in the Soviet Union for heavy fog to lift before traveling.

title: Don't Blame the Deficit for the Crash
description: In the aftermath of Black Monday, almost everybody is knocking the deficit. And so it has always been, usually in the face of all reason and logic.

title: LOCAL EYES ARE TO WATCH OVER HISTORY
description: CONNECTICUT, like all of New England, is steeped in history. If a new state law is put to its full use, this history will have many more people looking after it.

title: Highland Express
description: To the Editor: Often when things on a trip go wrong passengers feel a need to blame someone and that someone is usually the airline. Sometimes it's a bum rap.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE Higbee Beach parking area was stripped of vehicles. A bad sign. In October, even at midweek, the place should have been packed, unless, of course, there were no birds. Like I said: A bad sign. In fact, there was only one vehicle in the lot, a station wagon that was foreign to me. After 10 years in Cape

title: Highland Express
description: To the Editor: On Aug. 24 you carried a Travel Advisory item on Highland Express, and for some time the Travel section has been carrying advertisements for this airline. I bought seats on it because of the advertisements, and I feel it is my duty to warn others about the airline.

title: WOMEN MOVE TO THE TOP IN PUBLISHING
description: EACH fall, scores of women, many of them recent graduates of the best schools in the country, descend on Manhattan to make their marks in book publishing. Those who succeed can look forward to jobs that not only offer low salaries and infrequent promotions but also assign homework: boxes of manuscripts that must be lugged home on the subway to be evaluated and edited in what normal people would consider their spare time.

title: IN SHORT
description: TYCOON: The Life of James Goldsmith. By Geoffrey Wansell. (Atheneum, $19.95.) It was probably inevitable that the current craze for making celebrities out of businessmen would one day give us a hybrid book like ''Tycoon'': part serious biography, part fan magazine. Funny that its subject would be Sir James Goldsmith, the takeover artist once described by a friend as ''Attila the Hun with financial genius.'' Geoffrey Wansell, a British journalist who has written a biography of Cary Grant, had Sir James's cooperation on this project, but the result is a book that is best read deep between the lines. The man who emerges is a shrewd, driven gambler of undeniable intelligence and astonishing luck. Even when he was repulsed in a celebrated 1986 bid to take over the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, he walked away with a profit estimated at $93 million. He can also be a tad temperamental - kicking his car, pouncing on a newspaper photographer, tossing his breakfast tray out a window when displeased by the orange juice. Mr. Wansell duly reports these outbursts and more, but seems to view them as evidence of the man's boyish charm. Sir James clearly plays by his own rules, and whatever else he has coming to him, he deserves a better biography.

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: The ramifications of the strike of 1987 parallel last week's stock-market crash. Everyone involved got hurt: fans, owners, players, TV and vendors. But most of all the fans.

title: The World's Beneath Paris
description: Beneath the City of Light and giving it a kind of ballast there exists a vast labyrinth of tunnels, caves, quarries and canals little suspected by visitors. Of course, even the most casual tourist knows of the Paris Metro, but few have looked at it as another sort of museum in which you may observe the daily life of the city. Every weekday this smoothly functioning system whisks about 5 million passengers on their errands and effectively solves the problem of surface traffic congestion.

title: Perspectives: Housing at Newport; Condos Coming to Jersey City's Riverfront
description: AS the ''new town'' named Newport takes shape at the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City, across the river from Canal Street in Manhattan, a picture is emerging of the residential market that the Lefrak Organization will be tapping over the next few years. So far only rentals have been offered. But condominiums are coming in the next phase.

title: From the Writers' Corner: Pumping Out Success
description: I have difficulty understanding what real contribution the stock market makes to the economy beyond the capital it provides companies upon their initial stock offerings. People bet against each other just as they do in a poker game. The money swirls around, changes hands, and eventually in the early morning hours of the history of the Republic somebody at the table realizes that when the sun comes up he will actually have to go out and go to work. As I write now the market has bounced back about halfway from its big one-day loss of 500 points. That should be no more comforting to a student of reality than the original loss.

title: The Old Mill's New Life
description: THE notable Georgiaville mill complex on the banks of the Woonasquatucket River here is in line for conversion into 125 condominium units.

title: THE MIND OVER THE BODY
description: From the steady ring of our telephone ever since Daniel Goleman's article ''The Mind Over the Body'' (Sept. 27) appeared, it has become clear to us at the institute that the public feels confused and frustrated about what it can rely on in the mind-body health field.

title: PHILADELPHIA STORE WEARS NEW HAT
description: At 6 P.M. the mayor came down to cut the ribbon. There were speeches. Cocktails began; the band played. Dinner was served.

title: Nation's Development Groups to Be Studied
description: Two decades ago the Ford Foundation set out to help revitalize the crumbling Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn by creating the country's first community development organization, the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: A GUIDE TO TRAILS FOR HIKERS
description: A WALKING guide of the Greenwich area has been published by the Greenwich Audubon Society to feature 26 places certain to appeal to hikers, bird watchers and nature lovers.

title: THE HUNT BROTHERS' BILLION-DOLLAR DEBT
description: As a dentist, I know that when the Hunts forced up the price of silver artificially, it greatly inflated the price of silver-amalgam filling material. Silver is the most widely used filling material for teeth. The Hunt brothers' ''game'' cost consumers untold millions in added costs for dental care. I suggest a class-action suit to reimburse all the patients who were forced to pay more for treatment when the price of silver rose to $50 an ounce, from less than $5 an ounce before the Hunts entered the picture! ALEX FOX, D.D.S. Springfield, Mass.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: JOB CREATION IN AMERICA: How Our Smallest Companies Put the Most People to Work. By David L. Birch. (Free Press, $22.95.) According to David L. Birch, about 90 percent of America's businesses employ fewer than 20 workers each. They also provide more jobs than the Fortune 500 companies combined. In ''Job Creation in America,'' Mr.

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: We feel strongly that it is time for Pete Rozelle and the National Football League management to intervene and amend the playoff format to include more teams. In this way, the N.F.L. compensates for unrepresentative replacement teams unfairly influencing the crowning of the champion. By proportionally increasing the importance of an expanded postseason and reducing the importance of -while not canceling - the replacement games, the league can still salvage this woebegone season.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement. Any idea what the problem is now?

title: Killing and School Plan Stir Tensions in Lowell
description: Rancor and hostility toward this city's newest group of immigrants has surfaced amid an angry debate over a school desegregation plan.

title: IRAN STRIKE DISCONCERTS A RANGE OF ENEMIES
description: IRAN, an old hand at byzantine maneuvers, is resorting to an ancient tactic to deal with its many enemies: divide and rule, or at least create confusion and hesitation.

title: Kirkpatrick May Tell '88 Plans Tomorrow
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, planned to disclose Monday whether she will enter the race for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: SYMPHONY'S ACID TEST: THE BATON
description: ON Tuesday night, Sung Kwak, dressed in tails, will raise his baton in Woolsey Hall on the Yale University campus and hope that the New Haven Symphony will play along with him. After all, this will be more than a concert: it is an audition, with more than 2,000 critical listeners - the audience and the orchestra itself.

title: A Real Principal Grades the Reel 'Principal'

It showed two men standing inside a shattered window, one of them wearing a football jersey and black weight-lifting gloves, the other brandishing a baseball bat. ''At a high school where students major in arson, extortion and assault,'' the text beneath the picture read, ''the new principal and the head of security just might be crazy enough to turn things around.''

title: Highsmith in Accord
description: A week after the Houston Oilers' top draft choicew, Alonzo Highsmith, won a temporary court injunction declaring him a free agent, the running back from the University of Miami and the Oilers have reached an agreement in principle, according to lawyers representing the club.

title: 'GREED IS A NICE RELIGION'
description: LEVINE & CO. Wall Street's Insider Trading Scandal. By Douglas Frantz. 370 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

description: ''It's the nearest thing to a meltdown that I ever want to see.''

description: Helene Abby Resnick, a daughter of Mrs. Louis B. description: To the Editor:

title: The Street, Shaken
description: WALL STREET had already begun to take a long, hard look at itself; last week's market plunge shook it to its very core. It came just as many firms were realizing that the days of quick profits were ending and, in a traumatic way, it highlighted the inherent riskiness of the securities business. Now, firms already planning to retrench may become more determined to shrink their businesses and to cut jobs.

title: Court Upholds Judge's Order To Abstain From Alcohol Use
description: A judge who ordered a cocaine defendant to abstain from alcoholic beverages for three years was within his legal bounds, an appeals court has ruled.

description: LEAD: WHEN it begins at 7 P.M.

title: IN SPIRIT OF LEGENDARY GOURMAND
description: AROUND the turn of the century, a 647-pound fire chief named Barney ran a bar-hotel in Locust Valley. Today, that bar-hotel building is a fashionable restaurant that keeps alive Barney's legend as the largest fire chief in Nassau County's history.

''Magic Mark, the Jewish Juggler'' had taught him how and appreciative audiences had flung coins and bills at their feet.

title: ART REVEALS HOW CHILDREN SEE DIVORCE

''Dad'' is riding on top of an army tank shooting a machine gun at ''Mom.'' ''Mom'' shoots back, and the boy drew himself in the middle of the page yelling, ''Help!''
