title: Military Roster Increases
description: The active-duty strength of the military services increased in September from both the previous month and the year-ago level, the Pentagon said Thursday. As of Sept. 30, the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force had 2,175,713 men and women on active duty, up 8,899 from Aug. 31 and up 6,601 from the combined total of a year ago.

title: INEXPENSIVE HELP FOR BOATERS
description: The Westport Police Department's plan to to solicit $50 contributions from boaters forced to avail themselves of the services of the local Marine Rescue Unit [ ''Westport to Solicit Boater Donations,'' Sept. 20 ] appears to be yet another scheme by which the boating population of Connecticut, having been conceived by many to be all affluent and therefore all able to afford all such financial invasions, is to be expected to pay a second time for the services that it receives. Once, via local taxes, and again via ''voluntary'' contributions.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: FORCED OUT: When Veteran Employees Are Driven From Their Careers. By Juliet F. Brudney and Hilda Scott. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $7.95.) ''I was up against a blank wall, reduced to a piece of junk,'' says one of the more than 100 men and women interviewed in ''Forced Out,'' a study of problems experienced by job- seekers over the age of 50.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Vt.;
For Haystack, Liftoff at Last
description: LEAD: THE condominiums at Haystack Mountain were planned and approved 18 years ago. Now, with new owners and new financial backing, this long-stalled resort project appears at last to be getting under way.

title: SARA B. CAMPBELL, MARKETING ANALYST, ENGAGED TO JOHN KELEMEN 3D, STUDENT
description: Mr. and Mrs. Van C. Campbell of Corning, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara Blythe Campbell to John Joseph Kelemen 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelemen Jr. of Rockville, Md.

title: RUTGERS ON TOP; LOOK TO BOWL BID
description: Rutgers stirred visions of its first trip to a bowl game outside the state of New Jersey by winning, 27-14, today from an Army team depleted by injuries to its quarterbacks.

title: Film With a French Accent
description: One day in the first week of June, we students at the Alliance Francaise set out like a band of Parisian Huck Finns to see, not the world, but the movies. What freedom we had! As debutants Francophones, it didn't make much difference to us which movie - we were bound to miss most of the dialogue anyway.

title: BANK CLOSING UPSETS CUSTOMERS
description: THE announcement of the closing of a branch of the Chemical Bank in Wyandanch has drawn a reaction of frustration and anger from customers, many of whom are welfare recipients who depend on the services of the bank to pick up food stamps and cash their checks.

title: Two New Sitcoms Forgo Musty Formulas
description: THINK OF JAMES STEWART AND W. C. Fields. That's one way of approaching the hour between 9 and 10 on Wednesday evenings on ABC, the hour that stars the enormously likable John Ritter as "Hooperman" and then switches to Dabney Coleman doing the misanthropic title character in "The 'Slap' Maxwell Story." It adds up to, far and away, the best 60 minutes of the new season. The shows are innovative, outrageous and very funny, without benefit of laugh tracks. And taken together they constitute a package that could very well let Brandon Stoddard keep his job as ABC's head of programming beyond the current season. Here is Mr. Stoddard at his most impressive, attracting gifted performers, writers and producers, taking chances and running with the talent instead of musty formulas.

title: Industrialized Eastern Bloc Faces Pollution Crisis
description: Across Eastern Europe, a crisis of the environment is eroding the natural and cultural heritage, confronting Communist governments with major pollution problems at a time when economic difficulties are diminishing the financial resources to deal with them.

title: THE SENATE'S LAST WORD ON BORK
description: AFTER three weeks of hearings that changed some minds and two days of fierce debate that did not, the Senate last week voted down President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court last week.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Smithfield, R.I.; The Old Mill's New Life
description: THE notable Georgiaville mill complex on the banks of the Woonasquatucket River here is in line for conversion into 125 condominium units.

title: TWO U.S. BRIDGE TEAMS WIN
description: The world bridge championships drew to a close here today with the United States claiming a double victory. The Americans won the Venice Trophy for women's teams Friday, and their open team defeated Britain in the final of the Bermuda Bowl by 64 international match points.

title: A Romantic Finds Reality In Caracas
description: I grew up in Shanghai a privileged white at a time when China was racked by civil war and Japanese invasion, and the sight of penury next to wealth seemed as natural as rain and sun to my young eyes. But most of my adult life was spent in the more egalitarian cities of the United States and Europe, and to return after a 35-year absence to the social contrasts of what has since been dubbed the third world proved a jolt.

title: STARTING OVER: TV'S GRANT TINKER
description: INSIDE BUNGALOW I, AT HIS NEW headquarters in Culver City, Calif., Grant Tinker is taking a meeting. Right on the stroke of 10:30 A.M., an anxious writer, his agent at his heels, arrives to pitch a half-hour comedy series.

title: HOW BUTTERFLIES CAUSE HURRICANES
description: CHAOS Making a New Science. By James Gleick. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: A Sale to Help the Blind
description: IT'S time for bargain hunters to prowl the Lighthouse's annual Posh Sale of clothing donated by stars, stores, designers and manufacturers. The sale, tomorrow through Friday, will include everything from sportswear for under $50 to a Carolyne Roehm evening dress for $500.

title: TOWN MEETINGS TO DISCUSS DEFENSE
description: LEAD: WHEN President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev sign a treaty later this year to eliminate medium- and shorter-range missiles, one group of Long Islanders will be watching especially closely. And that group hopes to raise public awareness on the arms race by holding a series of town meetings where citizens can speak out on national defense.

title: Contra Aid Flier Suing Company That Hired Him
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American whose airplane was shot down over Nicaragua last year on a run to deliver weapons to the contras, has filed a civil lawsuit against the company that employed him for the mission.

title: A COMMERCIAL VENTURE
description: If Brent Staples's neighbor has started pimping in the elevator, he's probably a junkie, past caring about eviction notices (About Men, ''A Commercial Overture,'' Sept. 20). Mr. Staples should stop agonizing over the whole cosmic schmear and buy himself a good lock and an angle-iron.

title: Fantasy in Blue
description: AS BERNARD HAMMERMAN tells it, his work is art in the service of business. Co-founder, in 1946, with his two brothers, of Hammerman Bros. Inc., in New York City, and now the firm's president, he oversees the design and manufacture of some of the world's finest and priciest jewelery. ''I get these ideas in my head,'' he says, ''as to what I'd like to fit into our inventory, what I believe will sell.'' The platinum, diamond and sapphire necklace above was conceived more than a year ago, inspired by requests from jewelry store owners. ''We needed a major sapphire piece that was very strong in blue.''

title: A Shift in Policy
description: ALTHOUGH the Government managed to resist the impulse for dramatic action, such as closing the exchanges, it was forced by last week's stock market plunge to make some abrupt and important policy changes. One result could be a breakthrough in the long political impasse over the Federal budget deficit - one of the main causes, economists say, of the market's instability.

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: What strike?

title: WAGNER WINS ON LATE KICK
description: Jerry O'Riordan's 28-yard field goal with four seconds left gave Wagner a 16-14 victory over Merchant Marine Academy yesterday at Kings Point, L.I.

title: Little-Known Haydn, Well-Known Bach
description: ''THE CREATION'' AND ''THE Seasons'' have so dominated Haydn's reputation as an oratorio composer that little room has been left over for such earlier beauties as ''Il Ritorno di Tobias.'' ''Tobias,'' however, returns to us on a three-compact-disk release by Hungaroton (HCD 11669-62-2). It reminds us of the rich, if perhaps simpler, qualities of a younger Haydn.

title: D. G. MURPHY, LAWYER, WED TO MARGARET CHAN
description: The wedding of Margaret LaiPing Chan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chan Charn of Hong Kong, to Daniel Gene Murphy, a son of William Joseph Murphy and June Marie Serio, both of Chicago, took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, a letter from Albert P. Schatz on Oct. 18 misstated his comment on the assessed valuation lost under the current method of assessing condominiums in New York State. The figure of $41 million is not statewide, but for Westchester County alone.

title: BASEBALL PLAYERS GIVE 'BESTS' IN BOOK
description: LEAD: WHEN Roger McCaffrey was young, he used to trade baseball cards with his friends. Today, his next-door neighbor, who is 7 years old, will not even consider trading his cards. ''He knows they're too much of an investment,'' Mr. McCaffrey said.

title: Dismiss Indictments to Curb Prosecutor Leaks
description: To the Editor:

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: FUTURE PERFECT. By Stanley M. Davis. (Addison-Wesley, $16.95.) In the engaging study ''Future Perfect,'' Stanley M. Davis, a business consultant who has taught at the Harvard Business School, predicts the future relationships between technologies and organizations. ''Fundamental properties of the universe,'' he writes, ''are transformed into scientific understanding, then developed into new technologies, which are applied to create products and services for business, which then ultimately define our models of organization.

title: JANET O'CONNOR, A LAWYER, WEDS
description: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Janet Eileen O'Connor and George V. Cornell 3d. Msgr. Peter G. Finn officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. O'Connor of Fairfield, Conn. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornell Jr. of New Dorp, S.I., and Singer Island, Fla.

title: BALANCE OF POWER AT STAKE IN YONKERS
description: LEAD: YONKERS voters will be selecting a newly redistricted City Council next month in an election that could shift the political balance of power.

title: MISS ROBERTS IS BRIDE OF ALFRED ALTENEDER JR.
description: Katherine DuVal Roberts, the daughter of Katherine Harjes Roberts of Tryon, N.C., and the late Lieut. Cyrus Swan Roberts 4th, U.S.A.F., was married yesterday to Alfred William Alteneder Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alteneder of Perrysburg, Ohio. The Rev. Thomas Vossler performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Saluda, N.C.

title: POSTINGS: A School's Skeleton; Graduation
description: When the foundation was dug and steel structure erected on a 4.2-acre site at the intersection of Merrick and Brookville Boulevards in Rosedale, Queens, more than a decade ago, the plan was to construct a public junior high school.

title: MAKING UP AND OUT
description: LEAD: A GREEN FLASH By Winston Graham. 383 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: POLLUTION PROBLEMS IN LONG ISLAND SOUND
description: Your article on pollution in Long Island Sound [ ''Two Groups Forming on Sound Pollution,'' Sept. 27 ] was timely. A friend and I recently took an 11-day sailing cruise to Block Island and back and were shocked to learn that marinas don't provide facilities for dumping sewage from boat holding tanks or portable toilets.

title: Exotic Farming On Remote Shore
description: IN a remote corner of Maine, where farming means potatoes and lobster is king, a group of coastal residents is harvesting a different sort of crop: seaweed.

title: WHAT PRICE ADVOCACY?
description: THE TENTH JUSTICE The Solicitor General and the Rule of Law. By Lincoln Caplan. 352 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: THE HUNT BROTHERS' BILLION-DOLLAR DEBT
description: The Hunt brothers wanted to dance to the tune of high-risk/ high-profit business ventures, and now it is only fair that they pay the fiddler his due. After all, no quarter was given to the thousands of American farmers whose land was repossessed after the banks had overextended loans to them. Should the Hunts be treated differently, just because they can afford the legal guns to keep the banks at bay and their creditors satisfied? RONALD A. SMEJKAL Plattsburgh, N.Y.

title: Q AND A
description: A Reason for Eviction Question: A tenant covered by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act was offered a one- or two-year renewal lease as required by law. The tenant refused to sign the lease unless it included a provision giving the tenant the right to terminate the lease upon giving the landlord 30 days' notice. Does this refusal to sign the lease as presented give the landlord the right to terminate the tenancy upon the expiration of the present lease? . . . B. S., White Plains Answer: Yes. A tenant covered by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, which in part extended rent stabilization to some communities in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties, does not have the right to change or add to the terms of a stabilized lease agreement. Under the act, the landlord must send, by certified mail, a renewal lease at rental rates permitted by its guidelines, not more than 90 and not less than 60 days prior to the expiration of the tenant's current lease. The tenant has 30 days from the time the new lease was mailed to sign the renewal agreement.

title: Averting Blizzard of Paper
description: Wall Street is rediscovering the importance of the denizens of the back office, who process and clear the endless stream of stock transactions, allowing the stock markets to function.

title: Soviet Faults Raids on Kuwait
description: The Soviet Union today criticized what it called efforts to draw Kuwait into the Iran-Iraq war and said continued attacks on the emirate would only aggravate problems in the Persian Gulf.

title: Replaced
description: With a confluence of interests in balanced politics and balanced books behind him, Federico Mayor Zaragoz of Spain was nominated last week to succeed Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal as director general of Unesco. Mr. M'Bow, who was seeking a third seven-year term, withdrew from the contest after failing to win a majority of executive board votes in four ballots; Mr. Mayor, a biochemist who has served as a Unesco official, won on the fifth ballot. Mr. M'Bow's policies had been viewed as increasingly anti-West in Washington, which, with Great Britain, withdrew from the organization. Mr. Mayor said one of his goals would be to persuade the United States and Britain to rejoin Unesco, 30 percent of whose budget had previously come from those nations.

title: We Close Down While the Russians Open Up
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKE BACK YOUR TWADDLE
description: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF LOUISA MAY ALCOTT Edited by Joel Myerson and Daniel Shealy with Madeleine B. Stern. Illustrated. 352 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: KELLY HAS WORDS WITH A MINNEAPOLIS REPORTER
description: Manager Tom Kelly of Minnesota, a man who admittedly is not fond of the media attention he is receiving during the World Series, became involved in a heated argument with a reporter for The Minneapolis Star Tribune just an hour and a half before the game today.

title: 60 DISABLED NAMED EMPLOYEES OF YEAR
description: LEAD: IF Theodore J. Drazuk had not been confined to a wheelchair for 40 years following a bout with polio at the age of 12, he says he would have become an astronomer, driving a truck to pay for his education. Instead, he chose accounting, a more ''practical'' field. He secured a job with International Business Machines after graduating from college, rising in the company's ranks to become its program director for special tax programs at the company's world headquarters in Armonk.

title: SABINA ALIN WU IS WED TO ROBERT R. LUSARDI
description: At the Old Stone Church in Rhinebeck, N.Y., Sabina Alin Wu, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Chang-lo Wu of Houston, was married yesterday to Robert R. Lusardi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Lusardi of Fishkill, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald J. Gallagher, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: LABOR SORTING OUT ROLE IN 1988 RACE
description: The union movement, which united behind Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy in 1984, is struggling to define a new role for itself in the 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: BABY-NAMING PROPOSAL IS CALLED 'IDIOTIC'
description: I read with interest the excellent article about the state's proposal for baby-naming regulations [ Page 1, Oct. 11 ] .

title: BAYLOR'S BUSINESS IS STILL UNIFINISHED
description: At a moment that has seen baseball bats theatrically slammed to the ground and fists triumphantly shot toward the sky, Don Baylor just went about his business. ''I don't hit it and stop and throw my bat,'' Baylor said. ''I've always done it: you hit it and you run around the bases.''

title: NO HEAVY LIFTING
description: The use of speechwriters by public figures is deceptive to begin with. Is it any wonder that the additional dishonesty of stealing the script from others arouses genuine outrage?

title: Correction
description: Tables on page 25 of the Business section today, showing the week's market averages, give the net change incorrectly. A corrected table appears in this section, on page 24.

title: BUDAPEST LEADERS LOOK FOR SUPPORT
description: The Communist leadership, worried about the unpopularity of its economic austerity program, is seeking to enlist the sympathy of disaffected intellectuals, allowing unusually candid meetings to be held and even sending a top leader to address one.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LONDON
description: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle once called London ''that great cesspool into which all the loungers of the Empire are irresistibly drained.'' London is no place for loungers these days. More than anywhere else in Britain, London today shows the transforming hallmarks of Margaret Thatcher's ''spirit of enterprise.''

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: The players should have gone on strike between the sixth and the eighth games. They would not be hurt as much financially, the owners would not have time to assemble ''scabs'' and the players would have been able to stay out for the season. The owners without eight more television games would have caved in.

title: TRAVELER'S AID
description: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE The First Hundred Years. By Charles L. Robertson. Illustrated. 472 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $35.

title: OTHER VOICES: Clark Clifford; Heads in the Sand
description: Excerpts from an interview with Clark M. Clifford, a Washington lawyer who served as Secretary of Defense in the Johnson Administration:

title: THE END OF BUSINESS AS USUAL
description: THE economy will never be the same.No matter where the stock market heads in coming months, the whole process of doing business, making a living, choosing investments - even buying a house - has been radically transformed. Last Monday's market collapse was one of those pivotal events that shape everything that comes afterward.

title: WING SOMMERS TO WED R. O. BLAKE JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Feldher Sommers of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Wing Sommers to Robert Orris Blake Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake of Washington. A January wedding is planned.

title: LESS THAN PHYSICS, MORE THAN BEANBAG
description: ECONOMICS IN PERSPECTIVE A Critical History. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 324 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: Fair Lawn Reaches 5-0
description: Fair Lawn High got all of its points in the first half and then held off a Bergenfield rally to win, 21-14, yesterday in a games that matched perfect records at Fair Lawn.

title: ZEN AND THE ART OF COMPUTING
description: ACCIDENTAL MILLIONAIRE The Rise and Fall of Steve Jobs at Apple Computer. By Lee Butcher. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Paragon House. $19.95. ODYSSEY Pepsi to Apple . . . A Journey of Adventure, Ideas, and the Future. By John Sculley with John A. Byrne. Illustrated. 450 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: Blast Rips Seafront Offices of Pan Am in Kuwait
description: A small bomb went off in the seafront offices of Pan American World Airways today, as Kuwait remained tense after a missile damaged its main offshore oil terminal on Thursday.

title: Reading 'First Light'
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera: Boston Camerata in 'L'Orfeo'
description: MONTEVERDI'S ''Orfeo'' is not the first opera, but it is the first by a truly gripping composer. Appearing in 1607, it was actually the sixth attempt at this new art - one intended to prod dramatic poetry with a new energy by coloring it with the melodies and rhythms of music. It was an evolution that the Italian language with its broad vowels and elastic stresses made almost inevitable.

title: THE FRENCH CAMPAIGN FOR AN ORDINARY PRESIDENCY
description: LIKE a good detective novel, the campaign for the French presidency has opened briskly and with little indication of how it will end. Although the winner will probably not be evident until a runoff ballot between the two leading contenders in May, many French politicians and commentators have already concluded that the election will be an institutional watershed. The all-powerful French presidency, hand-tailored by Charles de Gaulle to fit his own lofty ego, may be coming to an end.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
SUCCESSFUL AUCTION FOR NORWEB COLLECTION
description: LEAD: UNITED States coins from the Norweb Collection brought $6.3 million at a two-session auction on Oct. 12 and 13 in New York. At a separate New York auction on Oct. 14, the King of Siam proof set failed to attract any bids at the minimum level of $2 million. It reverted to the consignors, who had established that reserve.

title: ORANGE IN ROMP TO 7TH STRAIGHT
description: Don McPherson threw four touchdown passes to Tommy Kane, caught a touchdown pass and set two Syracuse records all in the first half today. This made it very easy for the undefeated Orangemen to roll over Colgate, 52-6, before 48,097 fans in the Carrier Dome.

title: Smoking Aloft
description: To the Editor: I was recently on an Iberia Airlines flight fron Nice to Madrid and had requested a seat in the no-smoking section. I was seated near the front of the plane on the lefthand side. A man in the row in front of me on the righthand side began to smoke, and when I asked him to stop, he said that he was seated in a smoking section. To my amazement, he was correct - the smoking section on that plane was the entire righthand side of the aircraft. It seems that on Iberia's smaller aircraft, like the 727's, the smoking and no-smoking sections are side by side, while on larger aircraft, like the 747's, the smoking section is at the rear.

title: CHINA PARTY CONGRESS MEETS TODAY IN A TRANSITION
description: The ruling assembly of China's 46 million-member Communist Party meets Sunday for the first time in five years to grapple with a sweeping array of problems, including who will lead China, where they will lead it and how.

title: Next Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Someone Reads George Eliot
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Chief Bars AIDS List
description: Police Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker has barred officers here from compiling ''any list related to a communicable-disease patient'' after a precinct posted the names and addresses of people believed to have AIDS. Officers said the list had been posted so they could put on protective gloves and take other precautions when responding to calls involving someone with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: REAL-ESTATE PRICE RISE IS SLOWING DOWN
description: LEAD: RISING inventories of homes for sale on Long Island are putting downward pressure on prices and ending a string of years in which residential real estate in Nassau and Suffolk Counties typically rose in market value by about 30 percent a year.

title: MOVIES
description: The Bishop's Wife Starring Cary Grant, David Niven, Loretta Young. 1947. Embassy Home Entertainment. 109 minutes. $19.95. If you can resist seeing Cary Grant playing an angel, David Niven playing a bishop and Loretta Young playing Loretta Young, you're too tough a critic for ''The Bishop's Wife.'' This 1947 Christmas tale, written by Robert E. Sherwood and Leonard Bercovici from Robert Nathan's novel, is not for the hard-of-heart-or-head.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Oct. 10 MANHATTAN Chelsea $89,000 307 West 20th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 400-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; high-ceilings, hardwood floors; maintenance $395, 50% tax deductible (Broker:

title: Polish Leaders in Shake-up; Industry Chief Named
description: Poland's leadership sought to tighten control over planned economic changes today with a Government shake-up that included the appointment of a powerful Minister of Industry.

title: ANSWERS TO BASIC QUESTIONS ABOUT THE COLLAPSE
description: LAST Monday's stock market collapse left everyone from taxi drivers to professional analysts confused and groping for explanations. What follows are preliminary answers to some basic questions about what happened. Q. Why did the market plunge? A. The theories vary widely - from investor concern about America's huge budget and trade deficits to growing evidence that President Reagan has entered the lame duck period of his Administration. As with most great panics, the market's dramatic drop was most likely precipitated by a convergence of economic and political doubts. Q. Why did all of this come to a head on Monday? A. The downturn began to gather momentum in the week before the big drop, when the Dow lost a stunning 235 points, including 108 points on Friday, Oct. 16. Obviously, investors were already quite nervous about economics and politics.

title: COMPUTER TO PREDICT AQUIFER CONDITION
description: LEAD: Within the next nine months the Nassau County Department of Public Works expects to operate a computer program that will simulate conditions in Long Island's sole-source aquifer.

title: PITCHERS' FATIGUE SHOWS
description: The pitching in this World Series has not evoked memories of Sandy Koufax, Bob Gibson and Mickey Lolich.

title: All's Not Well for Town Crier
description: The town crier here stands to lose his job over accusations that he told a tourist that homosexuals and the devil had taken over a local church.

title: GIANTS RETURN TO FAMILIAR SITE BUT IN AN UNFAMILIAR ROLE (0-5)
description: It all seems familiar: the Giants 10-point favorites over the Cardinals today, another late-afternoon game at the Meadowlands, Phil Simms throwing against Neil Lomax, players named Morris, Benson, Carson and Bavaro.

title: WITH EACH RIPE PUMPKIN, HOPE
description: HOW can someone who has spent virtually her entire life in Connecticut not bask in Yankee pride while enjoying fall's beauty?

title: Stemming Thefts At Churches
description: AFTER noticing an unusual drop in collection-plate receipts, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland called in the sheriff.

title: Q AND A
description: Las Vegas Question:I want to realize an old ambition to visit Las Vegas. Who runs short trips there and what do they cost? - G. R., New York Answer:Among tour companies travel agents turn to when they arrange trips to Las Vegas are Freedom Express Tours (155 East 55th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-826-9898 or 800-922-0098) and A.O.T. Tours (212-55 26th Avenue, Queens, N.Y. 11360; 718-423-6900 or 800-221-9350). Both have year-round programs of packages of from two to seven nights that include air fare, hotel, airport transfers and discount coupons for some restaurants and shows.

title: NO BLOW-DRY, NO PERM - NOTHING BUT A HAIRCUT
description: I HAVE found a barber. A real barber.

title: Dr. Henry B. Makover; Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Henry B. Makover, a physician and educator who helped plan the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died of prostate cancer Wednesday at University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NEW HOUSE By Joyce Maynard. Illustrated by Steve Bethel. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: THE GUIDE
description: GOOD EGGS Never mind the birds and the bees; consider the fish. The naturalists at the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery do, and, since this is fall, a traditional ritual, dating back to 1883, has begun: the autumn egg-taking. That's a demonstration twice a day, Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 3 P.M., that shows visitors how eggs are extruded from the female trout and then mixed with similarly extruded milt from the male to create fertilized eggs. Incidentally, the results of all these demonstrations go on display at the Hatchery in January, when the sac-fry hatch.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Bestial Crimes Animals used to be taken much more seriously and less sentimentally by society - at one time they could be tried and sentenced for criminal acts. This is from ''The Animal Estate: The English and Other Creatures in the Victorian Age'' by Harriet Ritvo (Harvard University).

title: Esposito Gets $500,000 Fine In Biaggi Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday sentenced Meade H. Esposito, the 80-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader, to a suspended two-year prison term with two years probation and fined him $500,000 for unlawfully paying the vacation expenses of Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx.

title: Beware of Wishful Thinking About Gorbachev
description: LEAD: Pressure is mounting in the United States to respond positively to the reforms initiated by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Public sentiment reflects our traditional feelings of compassion for the Russian people and a desire to build a more secure world. But it also reflects the congenital American tendency to substitute wishful thinking for realistic analyses of foreign affairs.

title: Bishop Anoveros of Spain Dies
description: Bishop Antonio Anoveros Ataun of Spain, whose support of Basque rights in that country once produced a crisis in relations between the Spanish Church and the Franco Government, died yesterday of a lung infection in a hospital in Bilbao, a Spanish church spokesman announced. The bishop, who had suffered from Parkinson's disease, was 78 years old.

title: LIONS THRASHED AS STREAK HITS 37
description: Having lost 36 games in a row, the situation seemingly could not get worse for Columbia. But it did today as the Lions were thrashed by Bucknell, 62-20, before a homecoming crowd of 7,330 at Memorial Stadium. It was Columbia's 37th straight defeat and its 40th straight game without winning.

title: POSTINGS: Plans for East End Temple; Apartment Tower Above Synagogue
description: East End Temple, now 40 years old, has always wanted a new home, but at its current location, the southeast corner of Second Avenue at 23d Street. The only way the tiny temple could achieve this, it has argued, was to sell its air rights to a developer who would demolish the one-story structure, along with three adjacent tenements owned by the temple, and build an apartment tower above with a new, larger temple at street level. The recipient of the temple's blessing is Oskar Brecher, who formed East End Capital Partners of Manhattan to execute that vision.

title: JETS' AND REDSKINS' COACHES DON'T KNOW WHAT TO EXPECT
description: The last six weeks have been like a roller-coaster ride for Coach Joe Walton.

title: WITH RELUCTANCE, FLORIDA CLOSES 'DODGE CITY LOOPHOLE'
description: LEAD: ''THE Wild West, Florida-style,'' said the headline in one national magazine, over an article about the state's permissive new gun law. ''Come Armed,'' another magazine said. South Florida had long been known for ''Miami Vice,'' drug trafficking and crime galore; now the entire Sunshine State was being depicted as a shoot-em-up territory where virtually anyone could wear a gun right out in the open.

title: No Miracles Needed, Just Governance
description: To begin responding to the alarm set off by Wall Street in the last 11 days does not require draconian or revolutionary measures. It calls for relatively painless and obvious compromises: For America the first order of business is a sound and convincing commitment to shrink the budget deficit. For West Germany and Japan it means some stimulation of their economies. If the elected leaders of these three powers cannot manage these steps, they cannot govern.

title: PHOTOS PRESERVE FARMS AS THEY BECOME HISTORY
description: LEAD: AS farmers on Long Island are completing this year's harvest season, common sights are trucks filled with potatoes, tractors preparing the land for winter and roadside farm stands laden with a variety of produce. Because agriculture has been an important industry on the Island since its settlement, it is a painful realization that these sights of the present are becoming part of the area's past.

title: Data Update
description: NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS (In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates)

title: Commercial Property: Hazardous Materials; It Pays to Hire Experts to Look for Contamination
description: BARRY WEINER is spending nearly $25,000 to search for tainted soil, toxic chemicals and asbestos in and around an industrial building he hopes to buy near New Haven.

title: Since the Invasion, a Grenada in Flux
description: In the churches of Grenada on Sunday they will be saying prayers of thanksgiving to mark the day four years ago when American troops swept ashore to quell a spasm of violence that threatened to consume this beautiful Caribbean island.

title: THE TATTY WRECKAGE OF HER LIFE
description: SYLVIA PLATH A Biography. By Linda Wagner-Martin. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Dance: National Company of Senegal
description: DANCE lovers applauding an enjoyable program may occasionally feel like rushing down the aisles to cheer the performers or even like jumping on stage to dance along with them. Such impulses are usually resisted.

title: Jersey Gets Key U.S. Waivers In Effort to Overhaul Welfare
description: After more than a year of negotiation, New Jersey has become the first state to obtain Federal waivers so that it can begin one of the most sweeping welfare overhauls in the country.

title: THOSE FRACTIOUS REPUBLICANS
description: CHEERS ECHOED through Iowa State University's Hilton Coliseum to the brassy theme song from ''Rocky.'' A human wall in white T-shirts (''Robertson for President'') was chanting ''Go for it Pat.'' The candidate, the Rev. Marion G. (Pat) Robertson, television evangelist turned politician, smiled warmly at the emotional pandemonium he had touched off. And then he plunged into the crowd, hugging his followers.

title: HER APES WERE HER LIFE
description: LEAD: WOMAN IN THE MISTS The Story of Dian Fossey and the Mountain Gorillas of Africa. By Farley Mowat. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Warner Books. $19.95.

title: Soda Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Seal Off Sikh Shrine
description: The police sealed entrances to the Golden Temple, holiest shrine of the Sikhs, on Saturday to flush out separatists taking shelter inside the complex, officials said. They said 2,100 policemen had been assigned to control entry to the shrine in Amritsar, in Punjab state, and to cut off food and other supplies to hard-liners who have controlled the temple for months. ''This will continue until we can complete our mission,'' an official source said.

title: IS RENT POLICY HALF-BAKED? KOCH SAYS NO
description: It was a tempest in a tea cake.

title: In Brazil, Evangelicals Are on Rise
description: Most Friday evenings, members of a local Pentecostal church gather near the water's edge on Copacabana Beach for intense and emotional prayer sessions at which they try to exorcise ''diabolical'' African spirits from prospective converts.

title: PHILATELIC LITERATURE BECOMES A GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: FOR most collectors, philatelic literature, if it exists at all, centers around a few mass-distribution catalogues. But times are changing.

title: Correction
description: In an article Oct. 11 about judicial candidates, a statement by Judge Joan B. Lefkowitz, who was appointed to the Family Court in May and is seeking a full 10-year term, included an incorrect word. She said:

title: ELLEN ELIZABETH MARTIN WEDS K. S. TARATUS JR.
description: Ellen Elizabeth Martin and Kenneth Stanley Taratus Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. Daniel G. O'Hare performed the ceremony.

title: Where Have All the Folk Stars Gone?
description: READING THE MEMOIRS of Joan Baez and Judy Collins, folk-music pioneers who are both now in their late 40's, one is tempted to mourn the vanishing tradition of the folk-music heroine. Through the 60's and 70's, the image of the long-haired, guitar-toting folkie with flowers in her hair, burning with noble ideals, was a cliche that, while often ridiculed, bespoke a artistic seriousness that in the age of music video is disappearing from the pop mainstream. So far in the 80's, that tradition has spawned only one new star, Suzanne Vega, who will appear at Radio City Music Hall tomorrow and at the Ritz on Tuesday. In a pop climate where Madonna reigns supreme, Ms. Vega, who is 28, is viewed by many as a classy anachronism.

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: The owners were successful because they enacted a superior game plan. By not ''closing shop,'' management was able to provide union members with an alternative to striking without pay. And with renewed television contracts guaranteeing income, public acceptance wasn't even necessary for the replacement games to serve their purpose of breaking union solidarity.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE CUISINE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: LEAD: MOST people pass the narrow storefront entrance of Hunan Avenue without noticing it at all - a pity, because the place deserves attention for several reasons. Hunan Avenue's food is nicely wrought, inventive and prettily presented. Furthermore, although the place is popular at lunch, the restaurant's low profile keeps it relatively empty at the dinner hour when the office crowd abandons the business district of White Plains for home, thus making Hunan Avenue a good choice for diners who, particularly on weekends, find more visible eating spots noisy and packed.

title: OPERA GROUP TO STAGE ITS INAUGURAL PRODUCTION
description: THE county has traditionally supported fine orchestras, excellent choirs, top-notch chamber ensembles and all manner of innovative concert series, but all previous efforts to establish a base for professional opera in the county have been, at best, of short duration. Undaunted by this precedent, a group of opera buffs have come together to form The Westchester Opera, with performing headquarters at the Tarrytown Music Hall.

title: The Street Endures Its Cruelest October
description: October's reputation for cruelty to investors is more firmly established than ever. The late 1970's saw the back-to-back October massacres of 1978 and 1979, with the Dow posting double-digit percentage losses in each of those months. Of course there was 1929 with its Black Monday on Oct. 28. Then there was October 1987. This brutal month's third week completed the task of wiping out all the gains of what had been a stunningly bullish year. The week began with a Black Monday that eclipsed 1929's - the Dow lost an unbelievable 508 points, or 22.61 percent, with volume exceeding 600 million shares. The Dow gained back 102 points on Tuesday, with volume again above 600 million, but the strength was confined to the blue chips. Wednesday brought some encouragement, with the Dow posting a record gain of 186.84 points in a broad-based rally. Thursday had a panicky start but a rout was averted and the Dow ended down 77.42 points, in context a moderate loss. Friday's trading was curtailed by two hours and exhausted traders called it a draw, with the Dow virtually unchanged. The Dow began the week at 2,246.74 and finished at 1,950.76, a loss of 295.98, or 13.2 percent. The Dow began 1987 at 1,895.95 and peaked at 2,722.42 on Aug. 25. It is off 28.3 percent from that high. * * *

title: Leader of Fiji Coup Tightens Grip With Decree on Powers
description: Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, who proclaimed himself head of this South Pacific nation after taking power in a coup, has tightened his grip on the country by giving his military Government powers of detention without trial.

title: NANCY J. FELSTEN, A LAWYER, WEDS
description: Nancy Joy Felsten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Felsten of Bayside, Queens, and David Jacob Fishman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart S. Fishman of Hewlett, L.I., were married last evening. Cantor Ellen Math performed the ceremony at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: Streetscape: The Syms Operating Theater; A Mildly Romanesque West Side Bargaining Chip
description: THE old Syms Operating Theater, at the southwest corner of 59th Street and Columbus Avenue, is the oldest extant Roosevelt Hospital building. As Community Board 4 begins reviewing plans for two 45-story apartment towers on an adjacent hospital site scheduled for clearance, the squat, red-brick structure may become a bargaining chip.

title: DAVID GEORGE WHALEN MARRIES BARBARA BURKE
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Avon, N.Y., Barbara Ellen Burke, a legal assistant in the New York office of the law firm of Latham & Watkins, was married yesterday to David George Whalen, a senior associate at Booz, Allen & Hamilton in New York. The Rev. Charles Bennett performed the ceremony.

title: A QUICK BATTER WITH SAVORY RESULTS
description: A SIMPLE, fairly thin batter, quickly mixed in a blender or a food processor, or, for that matter, preindustrially beaten in a bowl with a whisk, becomes the basis for many expedient recipes both sweet and savory.

title: Talking: Insurance; Meeting A Lender's Demands
description: THE buyer of a single-family house is discovering that a lender may require homeowner insurance that exceeds the replacement value of the house. The reason is that market values have started to substantially exceed building costs.

title: Swiss Runner Suit
description: CHALLENGING the procedures used by international track officials in banning her from competition for using steroids, Sandra Gasser, the Swiss middle distance runner who received a two-year ban after traces of steroids were found in her system at the world track and field championships in Rome, has filed suit in Bern seeking immediate reinstatement. Gasser, who was also stripped of the bronze medal she had won in the 1,500-meter championship, contended that the procedures used by the International Amateur Athletic Federation did not conform to minimum legal standards.

title: The Networks Stay Neutral
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 3 YALE STUDENTS COMPETE FOR POST IN NEW HAVEN
description: Joel Ratner, the alderman from New Haven's first ward, does not get many telephone calls from angry constituents complaining about municipal concerns like garbage collection and leaf pickup.

title: Beach Idyll In Indonesia
description: Standing in the center of a milling mass of children piping ''Mister,'' ''Tourist,'' ''Hello,'' I watched the warriors perform their dance in helmets, athletic shorts and a bewildering assortment of jackets. Some were decorated with brilliant appliques, others were made of black, hairy material like a bear's skin, and still others had upturned shoulders like wings. While the men of Bawamataluo, a village on Pilau Nias, an island off the southwest coast of Sumatra, brandished spear and shield for the television crew from Medan, the ordinary life of the village went on. Women stood in their roof hatches spreading laundry to dry on the steeply pitched palm thatch, or raked the rice drying on mats along the main street; children flew kites made from old homework sheets or held on to the hands of tourists and asked for pens or money, puzzled by our fascination with ordinary things. Meanwhile, the chief in a batik shirt, his teeth decoratively capped with silver, kept a critical eye on the dancing.

title: N.C. STATE UPSETS CLEMSON
description: Mal Crite and Bobby Crumpler each ran for a touchdown as North Carolina State built a 30-0 halftime lead and held on to upset Clemson, 30-28, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: DREAM ON HOLD AGAIN FOR JETS' ROSE
description: SHORTLY after his 26th birthday last June, Ken Rose decided that 1987 would be the denouement of his football career. Either he would make it or he wouldn't.

title: POSTINGS: Towers Near the Airport; Next for Newark
description: A major office complex, planned for 25 acres opposite Newark International Airport, went from concept to reality in a recent ground- breaking ceremony for the first of four office towers that eventually will provide one million square feet of space. The ceremony was the latest evidence of commercial transformation in New Jersey's largest city, a development that is being closely watched by Newark officials.

title: MOMMA NEVER SAID GOOD NIGHT
description: HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER By Marilyn French. Illustrated. 686 pp. New York: Summit Books. $21.95.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: LAND'S POLAROID: A Company and the Man Who Invented It. By Peter C. Wensberg. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Despite the author's denial, he has written a corporate history of Polaroid and a biography of its founder, Edwin H. Land. Peter C. Wensberg joined the company in 1958 and rose to executive vice president before he retired in 1982, two months after Mr.

title: A NATION'S FEARS FOR PEACE AND PROSPERITY
description: IF there is one quality that sets Americans apart from most peoples, it is our optimism. But the nation's inherent belief that every problem has a solution and that things will turn out for the best was sorely tested last week by a rat-tat-tat of events that suggested even to the sunniest among us that things might be sliding out of control.

title: CITIZENS GROUPS WORK FOR A BETTER NEWARK
description: LEAD: AFTER Walter Dawkins was attacked in a robbery attempt here last July, he said he ''realized it was time to say 'Enough is enough!' ''

title: A Musical Born of South African Protest
description: THE LILTING SOUND OF Mbaqanga, South Africa's distinctive black pop music, filled Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on a recent afternoon. Six musicians, looking sharp in pressed khaki uniforms, were churning out the music's joyous rhythms, while a seventh player, Douglas Mnisi, swayed back and forth, embroidering the beat with lightning-fast runs on his electric guitar. The music had a tropical sway, something like reggae but faster, with two trumpets punctuating the light but driving rhythms. The musicians were playing on a stage set behind a high fence topped with barbed wire.

title: Hempstead Goes to 5-0
description: The Hempstead Tigers (5-0) crushed previously unbeaten Massapequa (5-1), 44-7, yesterday, extending their unbeaten streak in Nassau County Conference I to 34 games.

title: Patriarch Seeks to Rally Armenians
description: The six and a half million Armenians in the world have been a dispersed and tormented people without their own independent land. But their banner of unity has always been their church -the Armenian Apostolic.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BENEFIT FOR THE HUNGRY Sixty professional entertainers who live or have lived in Monmouth County will donate their services this evening in a concert to raise money to feed the county's hungry.

title: PRESSURE FOR GUN CONTROL RISES AND FALLS, BUT ARDOR FOR ARMS SEEMS CONSTANT
description: SIX years ago, when the Village of Morton Grove, Ill., passed the nation's first ordinance banning both the sale and the possession of handguns, it provoked sharp controversy. Such critics as the National Rifle Association warned that Morton Grove's action could be the beginning of a nationwide campaign by local communities to take away the public's constitutional right to keep and bear arms.

title: LYNN C. GARDNER BECOMES BRIDE OF NATHAN STACK
description: Lynn Carson Gardner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Gardner of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Nathan Scott Stack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: PRESCRIPTION PROGRAM FOR ELDERLY LAGS
description: A STATE program designed to aid the elderly with prescription drug costs began recently with state and county officials expressing disappointment at the low level of public participation.

title: FROM CLASSICAL TO FOLK, A VARIED CONCERT WEEK
description: VARIETY is the watchword on the concert scene this week, with large and small ensembles, new and old music, and ballads and ballet performed by Connecticut artists as well as visitors.

title: Prenatal Clinic Established at Jersey High School
description: The first prenatal clinic at a New Jersey high school has been established at the Chestnut Street School, an alternative high school here for about 125 pregnant teen-agers.

title: NEW CHIEF FOR U.S. COMMITTEE
description: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee elected two executive directors today, one to hold the job until the other succeeds him in January.

title: A VETERAN RETURNS TO WORK
description: BRAD BENSON had decided before the National Football League players' strike that, no matter what anyone else did, he would follow a certain moral code. This meant he would not cross the Giants' picket line and would not hold a grudge against those who did. Or try not to, at any rate.

title: FINDING THEIR VOICES
description: THE FIRST WAVE Women Poets in America 1915-1945. By William Drake. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Houston Hospital to Ask AIDS Test of All Patients
description: Within a few months, all patients entering the largest hospital here will be asked to take a test to determine if they are infected with the AIDS virus.

title: BOARD-ROOM BUCCANEERS
description: THE TAKEOVER GAME By John Brooks. 390 pp. New York: A Twentieth Century Fund Book/ Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: MISS AUCHINCLOSS MARRIES PAUL HERZAN
description: Alexandra Auchincloss and Paul Karel Herzan were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. James P. Morton, Dean of the Cathedral, performed the ceremony, assisted by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. and the Rev. Daniel W. Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Houdini Written and produced by JoAnne Garrett. Congress Video. 30 minutes. $14.95. Harry Houdini, one of the world's greatest escape artists, never escaped the public's inMense curiosity, even after his sudden death on Halloween, 1926; fans still flock to the Houdini Hall of Fame in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: C. P. OBERG WED TO SHERRI CARROLL
description: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sherri Lynne Carroll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew David Carroll of Bryn Mawr, to Curtis Paul Oberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Oberg of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Eugene Bay performed the ceremony.

title: THE HUNT BROTHERS' BILLION-DOLLAR DEBT
description: I am disgusted at the legal tactics the Hunt brothers are using to avoid paying the $2.43 billion they owe their creditors (''Battling a Billion-Dollar Debt,'' by John A. Jenkins, Sept. 27).

title: Snags Delay Start of Organ Transplant Plan
description: A series of bureaucratic snags and complications has delayed the effective date of a new Federal law intended to encourage donations of human organs for transplant.

title: PITT STRUGGLES PAST NAVY, 10-6
description: Craig Heyward had the game's only touchdown, ran for more than 100 yards for the seventh consecutive game and moved into third place on Pitt's career-rushing list as the Panthers defeated Navy, 10-6, today.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE UNKNOWN IACOCCA. By Peter Wyden. (Morrow, $18.95.) Little Lido Anthony Iacocca rarely smiled. As a schoolboy in Allentown, Pa., he was intense and driven, with little time for girls - likewise in college and much later, in 1986, when he jettisoned his vivacious second wife, Peggy, amid a fury of Motown gossip.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO BUOY FILIPINO ECONOMY
description: Deeply disturbed by a coup attempt two months ago against President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines, the Reagan Administration is searching for ways to bolster her country's economy and military while at the same time avoiding the appearance of interfering in her country's internal affairs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19 A missile accord could be concluded between the United States and the Soviet Union, banning medium- and shorter-range missiles, without a summit meeting between the two countries' leaders, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. Page 1

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: TWENTY years have elapsed since the publication of ''The Man Who Cried I Am,'' John A. Williams of Teaneck, its author, recalled in a recent interview.

title: SUPERVISOR VOTES IN 17 TOWNS
description: LEAD: SOME candidates in the 17 races for town supervisor this year may be seeking greater glory, but in Ossining, Tom Cambariere, who is challenging the incumbent, Barbara C. Fratianni, said he was looking for something less.

title: PATTERNED BARK CLOTH FROM TONGA
description: Throughout Polynesia, islanders have traditionally used tapa, richly patterned bark cloth, as a gift for weddings, the installation of chiefs and other special occasions. In the Kingdom of Tonga, which produces more than any other South Pacific country, tapa continues to be used in these traditional ways and has become popular with tourists as well.

title: GIVING CHANGE A CHANCE
description: THE CONSTRAINTS OF CORPORATE TRADITION Doing the Correct Thing, Not Just What the Past Dictates. By Alan M. Kantrow. 216 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: LISA STERN IS THE BRIDE OF BRAD DAVID GILLMAN
description: Lisa S. Stern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Stern of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Brad David Gillman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry M. Gillman of Oceanside, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: JOCELYN PASCAL KOSKINAS IS WED TO W. SCOTT SIMON
description: Jocelyn Pascal Koskinas and W. Scott Simon were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony.

title: POLLUTED WATER LAID TO FIRE SCHOOL
description: THE disclosure of a large plume of contaminated ground water near Old Bethpage landfill infuriated residents when it was revealed that the source of the contamination was the Nassau County Fire Service Academy.

title: TEAMSTERS GAIN A READMITTANCE TO A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: A deep rift in the American labor movement ended today when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was readmitted to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement. Any idea what the problem is now?

title: High Performance at Low Prices
description: AFTER EXPOUNDING FOR a couple of Sundays on the general principles of picking stereo equipment, we are about to dispel lingering patches of fog and get down to particulars. Besides, an itemized shopping list, however prosaic, might be useful to audiophiles heading for the store in a timely attempt to beat the Christmas rush.

title: IN 10 DAYS, VOTERS WILL DECIDE ON $68 MILLION JAIL
description: ''HELLO, how 'ya doing,'' the jovial, well-dressed man said to the startled pedestrian crossing crowded Mamaroneck Avenue at lunchtime recently. Handing her a brochure, he explained cheerfully, ''We need a new jail to keep the bad guys where they belong.''

title: 'Music Talks'
description: I am most appreciative of Michael E. Ross's review of my book ''Music Talks: Conversations With Musicians'' (Oct. 4) but would like to correct three inadvertent inaccuracies. The book includes material written between 1971 and 1986 - not 1974 and 1981. About one-third, including the profiles of the bassoonist Hugo Burghauser and the master teacher Dorothy DeLay, is previously unpublished work. About one-third was written last year - not for magazines but specifically for ''Music Talks.'' That's why, I think, it reads more like a book than like a collection!

title: FOR SOCIAL WORKER, PERSISTENCE PAYS
description: LEAD: CONTACTS are important in any profession, but when one is looking after the welfare of dozens of youngsters, whom you know can really make a difference.

title: New Brawel Rules Protect Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MONA MANGAN IS WED TO ROY N. WATANABE
description: Mona Mangan, the executive director of the Writers Guild of America East Inc., a union representing writers for film and television, was married in New York yesterday to Roy Noboru Watanabe, a partner in the New York law firm of Cohn, Glickstein & Lurie. The Rev. Philip Phan performed the ceremony at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: AMHERST BEATS WESLEYAN
description: Kevin Minicus, a halfback, scored on a 3-yard run just 1 minute 43 seconds into the game today as Amherst rolled to a 21-12 victory over Wesleyan.

title: POLICE TO MONITOR HOSPITAL DISPUTES
description: The New York City Police Department will assign special liaison officers to five city hospitals beginning Monday to resolve conficts between other officers and medical personnel.

title: 17-Week Strike Ends at NBC; Union Wins Few Concessions
description: A bitter 118-day strike against NBC ended today when two holdout units representing about 50 members of a broadcast workers' union voted to accept the network's final contract offer.

title: OTHER VOICES: David Riesman; Days of Distrust
description: Excerpts from an interview with David Riesman, professor emeritus of sociology at Harvard University:

title: SHULTZ DECLARES MISSILE PACT NEEDS NO SUMMIT MEETING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and the Soviet Union could conclude an accord banning medium- and shorter-range missiles without a summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: TODAY'S RADICALS WANT TENURE
description: THE LAST INTELLECTUALS American Culture in the Age of Academe. By Russell Jacoby. 290 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: Unbuilt Atom Smasher Sets Off Collision in West
description: The seasonal rituals of production and the quiet self-confidence of many farmers have been shaken here in California's Central Valley, where straight roads and deep creeks run past miles of walnut groves and peach orchards.

title: DATA BANK: October 25, 1987
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Summits tend to get associated with positive substance, so I'm for them. But the point is to get substantive things done, not just to have a summit. We're not trying to achieve a summit for its own sake.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ 12:4. ]

title:
OTHER VOICES: Alvin Toffler;
A Post-Panic System
description: LEAD: The following was written by Alvin Toffler, author of ''The Third Wave,'' ''Future Shock'' and other books on contemporary change.

title: LAWMAKERS TO OFFER OPTIONS ON STUDENT AID
description: LEAD: COLLEGE students in Connecticut are likely to receive some additional financial aid next year, according to several state legislators. The key debate is what form the aid should take.

title: Conservative Cuban Lobbying Group Opens Bitter Attack on Miami Paper
description: The Miami Herald, the leading newspaper of South Florida, and the Cuban-American National Foundation, an influential lobbying group made up of wealthy Cuban-born businessmen, appeared, until last week, to be the best of friends.

title: CASUAL COMFORT IN NEW HAVEN
description: A VISIT to the vegetarian cafeteria-restaurant Claire's Cornercopia in downtown New Haven is like stepping into the late 1960's or early 70's. Its relaxed, casual air evokes that era.

title: Dancers': More Than Meets The Eye
description: NOT JUST A MOVIE, HERBERT Ross's film ''Dancers'' - starring Mikhail Baryshnikov - is a fable for our time. Critics across the board have hated it. Thirteen-year-old girls, especially the thousands who hang Baryshnikov posters on their bedroom walls, will love it. As they say in the business, the camera likes him. And, as probably the only reviewer over 13 who liked the movie, I have no trouble predicting that ''Dancers'' will become a cult classic of the future.

title: HILLARY HABERMAN WEDS
description: Hillary Rachelle Haberman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Haberman of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married last evening to Jeffrey Scott Suchman, the son of Flora Suchman of Harrison, N.Y., and Leslie Suchman of Manhattan. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof in New York. The bride is a fashion editor at Women's Wear Daily, and her husband is a commercial real-estate broker for Helmsley-Spear Inc. in Manhattan. They both graduated from the Riverdale Country School and New York University.

title: Hemlines Know Which Way Is Up
description: WHEN we last left them, a few minutes ago, hemlines seemed to be going in two directions: up and down. Except, of course, the ones that weren't going anywhere. If you are confused by all this, don't worry about it. Just put on your best evening duds and get yourself to a fancy party. There you'll find that hemlines know exactly where they're headed, and that's north.

title: CENTER FOR FAMILY IS 10 AND GROWING
description: LEAD: AS the Center for Family Development celebrates its 10th anniversary this year, Olga Brom, a founder of the Bronxville-based organization, recalled the early days when it was a small and informal research-oriented program with a staff of two and Dr. Margaret Mead as its first adviser.

title: The Market Story
description: The upheaval in world financial markets last week obliterated billions of dollars of wealth. And Americans sensed that the stock market's vulnerability to jolts and aftershocks was also theirs. An Anxious Nation The Week in Review/Section 4 Even for those without investments and without economic sophistication, up-up-up eventually becomes synonymous with good times and down-down-down with bad. And there is some substance to the folk wisdom. Assaulted by uncertainty, the nation is looking to Washington this week, to a hesitant White House facing a cloudy outlook for negotiations with Congress to steady the economy. Board Rooms and Bankbooks Business/Section 3 The process of doing business, making a living, choosing investments - even buying a house - changed radically with the stock market collapse.

title: Sex, Drugs and Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: GATSBY AT THE B SCHOOL
description: IN a reflective moment toward the end of his life, William Carlos Williams brushed aside yet another question about himself and his poems, stories and novels: ''The last few years, just when I'm getting ready to kick off, people keep coming at me. They want to know who I am, and what do I mean here and there and everywhere in my writing. I wish they'd take an interest in the readers - not just themselves, but all those people who pick up the books and put in time with them.'' Later he added, ''I know what the professors think of Joe and Gurlie Stecher [ central figures in Williams's trilogy 'White Mule,' which describes the rise of a working-class couple to wealth and influence ] , but not the people who might have plenty of reasons to pay attention to those books - businessmen and their wives. Flossie [ Williams's wife ] once asked me how many successful Joe Stechers did I think would be reading [ the books ] . I said, damn few. Maybe I was wrong. I'll never know, though.''

title: DAYTOP CENTER FACES DAY IN COURT
description: LEAD: TOMORROW, the Town of Huntington will ask a District Court to shut down Daytop, a Huntington Station drug treatment center for teen-agers.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 18 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Wall St.'s Bad Time Brings Overtime
description: Wall Street went to work yesterday, hoping no hidden financial bombshells would be uncovered in the sorting of mounds of computer records that tracked last week's frantic stock market.

title: One Man's Majority
description: To the Editor:

title: Citizen Boards Battle the Utilities
description: Mike O'Hara is a consumer, one of the little guys, and he likes the idea of the little guys getting together to fight rate increases by the electric company, the phone company and the gas company.

title: LISA CHODOS WED TO W. E. NOONAN
description: Lisa Chodos and William Edward Noonan were married yesterday at the Amity Presbyterian Church in Vischer Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Bruce Cornwall performed the ceremony.

title: Rockefellers Push Bid to Promote Tourism in Hudson Valley
description: The Rockefeller family is expanding its activities in the Hudson Valley in an effort to preserve the rapidly growing region's famous vistas, historic sites and rural quality of life.

title: New Vitality In South Beach
description: THE first building of South Pointe Towers began receiving occupants here last week, ending a long struggle with financial difficulties.

title: Roosevelt Romps, 35-17
description: Top-ranked Roosevelt (5-0) just kept rolling along yesterday, crushing Suffern, 35-17.

title: IRISH GROUND GAME TRAMPLES U.S.C.
description: Notre Dame rolled up 351 rushing yards today and Tony Rice, a sophomore quarterback, directed first-half scoring drives of 88 and 90 yards in a 26-15 victory over archrival Southern California.

title: Pakistan Chief Assails U.S. on Nuclear Stand
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan today accused his American critics of double standards on the question of nuclear nonproliferation, and reiterated that Pakistan is opposed to the production or acquisition of nuclear arms.

title: Bo Jackson Debut
description: ALMOST two years after he won the Heisman Trophy, Bo Jackson will make his N.F.L. debut today when the Los Angeles Raiders face the Seattle Seahawks. That is because when the Raiders submitted their 45-man roster to the league yesterday, Jackson was on it. Vince Evans, who went all the way at quarterback for the Raiders in their three replacement games, was not on it.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
THERAPY AT THE DINER: LIFE IN THE BREAKDOWN LANE
description: LEAD: IT may be autumn in New York, but it's diner season on Long Island. At lunchtime, men go to diners for food; women go for emotional nourishment. For example, many of my lunches begin with a phone call:

title: Eating Well for Fewer Francs
description: No one knows how to stretch a penny - or should we say a centime? -like the French. Ask any Frenchman about his last restaurant meal and before he raves on about the succulent beef, the crispy golden fries, the fruity Beaujolais, he'll tell you the number of courses he had and how little he paid.

title: Putting Old Wrinkles Into a Theater's New Face
description: IT IS LITERALLY A DECADENT building, a place where crumbling plaster, broken column capitals and cracked archways have been carefully preserved, and in more than a few cases, artfully stage-managed. The Majestic Theater, two blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was built in 1903 for the live stage and became a movie house before being abandoned in 1968. It has recently reopened following a $5 million renovation, paid for jointly by the City of New York and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which will operate the space.

title: PAUL NATHAN WED TO MISS SALZMAN
description: At the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., last evening Marcy Robin Salzman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Salzman of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married to Paul H. Nathan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrado Nathan of Orinda, Calif. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: Financiers React to the Plunge - Then and Now
description: Believing that fundamental conditions of the country are sound and that there is nothing in the business situation to warrant the destruction of values that has taken place on the exchanges during the past week, my son and I have for some days been purchasing sound common stocks. We are continuing and will continue our purchases in substantial amounts at levels which we believe represent sound investment values. John D. Rockefeller Sr., Oct. 30, 1929

title:
GARDENING;
SOME TRUTHS AND MYTHS ABOUT GARLIC
description: LEAD: NOT too long ago, eating garlic was considered an unsociable act. People who smelled of this pungent food were considered lowly, not the sort that one might wish to be associated with in public. All that seems to have changed.

title: REBEL WITH A CAUSE
description: John Cougar Mellencamp's sobriquet ''Little Bastard'' might very well be attributable to his fiery demeanor (''Rebel With a Cause,'' by Timothy White, Sept. 27). Still, it seems strange that in an article titled ''Rebel With a Cause,'' no mention is made of the fact that fellow Indiana native James Dean had the same sobriquet painted on his racing car. BILL AIKEN Sea Cliff, N.Y.

title: For the Nation's Brokers, The Flood That Wasn't
description: After the stock market's week of wild gyrations, brokerage branches nationwide stayed open yesterday, ready for an onslaught of calls and visits from panicked investors. But the flood never came. Advertisments on television and in newspapers told investors of the added office hours. Work schedules of managers, brokers and support staff were revised. Early yesterday, the brokerage personnel arrived in their offices prepared to deal with an anxious public.

title: Wraiths, Spirits, Ghosts And Eerie Encounters
description: Sometimes within the brain's old ghostly house, I hear, far off, at some forgotten door, A music and an eerie faint carouse And stir of echoes down the creeking floor. - Archibald MacLeish ''Chambers of Imagery''

description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, 1 $18.95.)
