title: CHARTER CHANGE IS SEEN AS A KEY MINORITY ISSUE
description: People who crowded into a forum at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem last week agreed on one point: the planned revision of the New York City charter is the ''single most important political issue'' for the city's minority groups.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE FUTURE 500: Creating Tomorrow's Organizations Today. By Craig R. Hickman and Michael A. Silva. (NAL, $19.95.) Yesterday's exhortation for excellence in management is no longer enough, according to Craig R. Hickman, management consultant, and Michael A. Silva, a businessman. The next generation of corporate officers must be able to cope with paradox. ''The complexity manager should champion individuality and collective culture at the same time,'' the authors write. And they predict that what they call collaborative competition will replace head-to-head combat. Much of this analysis boils down to F. Scott Fitzgerald's dictum: ''The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time, and still retain the ability to function.'' But in addition to their theory of complexity management, the authors sketch a valuable history of American business and management theory. Case histories of how successful companies have adapted and grown also help to make the authors' abstract points clear. It is difficult, however, to understand just how complexity management will actually work. Excellence, as a management concept, was straightforward and, probably because of that, was widely adopted as a goal for corporations. Whether executives will be stirred by the idea of complexity management remains to be seen. But the authors do make important points about the changing relationships among Government and business, the investor and the corporation and the individual and the organization.

title: IGNORING THE PANIC WORSENS THE PROBLEM
description: MARKET analysis provides the single most reliable tool for anticipating major changes in economic trends, and to some degree, accompanying social trends as well. A particularly dramatic shift in the trend of a major market virtually always constitutes a signal that a fundamental change in the associated environment has occurred or will soon occur. For example, the dramatic eruption of gold and silver prices in 1972-73 presaged an eight-year period of spiraling inflation, just as the breathtaking two-month 44 percent collapse of gold prices and the 75 percent price collapse of silver prices from the highs of January 1980 signaled that same period's end.

title: NO HEAVY LIFTING
description: In his article ''No Heavy Lifting'' (On Language, Sept. 27), William Safire discusses the practice of Presidential aspirants ''borrowing'' the words of others. However, the title of his article evoked a statement of another current Presidential contender. In 1976, during the Vice Presidential debates, Robert Dole was asked why he was seeking the post. ''It's indoor work,'' Mr Dole replied, ''and no heavy lifting.'' GARY MULDOON Rochester

title: WHAT IS AT STAKE IN THE CENSUS?
description: ALTHOUGH two and a half years remain before the Federal Bureau of the Census begins collecting numbers from an estimated 106 million housing units and some 250 million people living in them, it is not too early to begin paving the way to guarantee accuracy for the 21st national census.

title: The Perils of Tinkering With Credibility
description: EVERY FILM REQUIRES ITS audience to make a leap of faith, but some leaps are longer than others. A lot longer. It isn't even a question of whether what we're seeing can literally be believed. One film may make its viewers accept the idea that a nobody from Palookaville can slug his way to the top of the boxing world, or that a schoolboy can travel backward in time to meet his parents as teen-agers; another may strain credulity with the sight of a simple soul making a visit to his neighborhood store. When a film persuades viewers to accept the incredible, it can provide escapism of the most liberating kind. But if it fails to be convincing about even the most mundane details, it may just lose its audience at the starting gate.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME TRUTHS AND MYTHS ABOUT GARLIC
description: LEAD: NOT too long ago, eating garlic was considered an unsociable act. People who smelled of this pungent food were considered lowly, not the sort that one might wish to be associated with in public. All that seems to have changed.

title:
MUSIC;
TRENTON'S TRINITY CATHEDRAL SPONSORING A PERSICHETTI MEMORIAL CONCERT
description: LEAD: THE composer Vincent Persichetti will be memorialized at Trinity Cathedral, Trenton, next Sunday in ''Vincent Persichetti - A Celebration,'' a program of works by and dedicated to the composer, who died last August at the age of 72.

title: PLAYING THE PERCENTAGES
description: IT seldom happens that a single slam deal presents major problems in bidding and play that world-class players have trouble solving, even in the post-mortem. One such deal, shown in the diagram, occurred at the start of the World Team Championships, which ended yesterday in Jamaica, and generated argument for several days.

title: STANFORD STOPS OREGON, 13-10
description: Brad Muster, playing for the first time in four weeks, ran 3 yards for a touchdown with 39 seconds remaining today to give Stanford a 13-10 Pacific-10 Conference victory over Oregon.

title: 'YOU LIVE HISTORY EVERY DAY'
description: CHRISTOPHER COLLIER, a history professor at the University of Connecticut, has been the Connecticut State Historian for three years. He is the author of several books, among them ''Roger Sherman's Connecticut,'' and ''Decision in Philadelphia,'' his most recent, about the Constitutional Convention, which he wrote with his brother, James Lincoln Collier. They have also collaborated on six historical novels for teen-agers, which are used in classrooms around the country.

title: NEW YORK FEMININE FLOURISHES
description: OUT OF DONNA KARAN'S inner sanctum comes the designer's favorite fitting model, the willowy Doreen Erickson. She is wearing a sort of 1930's lacy straw hat, its brim casting seductive shadows on the sweetheart-necked stretch lace top. Her waist is sashed in folded satin, culminating in a rosette bow. Delicate fan-shaped earrings tinkle from her ears, a many-charmed bracelet dangles at her wrist. Only the softly tailored pebble crepe trousers look like familiar Donna Karan attire.

title: BERGEN PHILHARMONIC STILL GROWING AT 50
description: NOV. 18, 1936. Although President Franklin D. Roosevelt had just carried 46 of the 48 states to re-election, a bleeding nation was still in the grip of the Depression and the time hardly seemed propitious for a new musical organization.

title: REAL ESTATE, REELING
description: IN Connecticut last week, two brokerage houses that planned expansions in Stamford pulled out of deals. In Los Angeles, about 25 homeowners, including some with deeds to multimillion-dollar mansions, were putting their homes on the block or trying to back out of deals. And in Manhattan, the traffic among would-be apartment owners and renters virtually came to a halt.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hyannis, Mass.; Retail, Office Space Grows
description: THE pace of residential building and sales on Cape Cod may have slowed this year, but the same cannot be said of retail and office construction.

title: Opera: A 'Rheingold' Debut
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Rheingold'' - solidly stage-directed, somewhat tackily designed, persuasively cast and surely conducted - offered a company debut Thursday night, along with several singers appearing in their roles for the first time or the first time this season.

title: Race and School Achievement Are Examined
description: A study of nearly 450 public high schools in metropolitan Los Angeles has found black and Hispanic students lagging further behind white high school students in reading, writing and mathematics.

title: 'A WILDLY IMPROBABLE GANG OF NINE'
description: ANGELS WITHOUT WINGS A Courageous Family's Triumph Over Tragedy. By Jane Vonnegut Yarmolinsky. 174 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: NASSAU EXECUTIVE CANDIDATES CONFRONT THE ISSUES
description: OFTEN agreeing on the problems but not the solutions, the Republican and Democratic candidates for Nassau County Executive clashed last week over a wide variety of issues.

title:
GARDENING;
Small Trees That Flourish Indoors
description: LEAD: DECORATIVE pots filled with trees seem more popular than ever as house plants. Unlike small plants, which can be grown on windowsills or in out-of-the-way spots, trees must be chosen and placed with great care, to fit comfortably into a home.

title: IN SHORT
description: ''ONE SMART COOKIE.'' By Debbi Fields and Alan Furst. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) Reading Debbi Fields's memoir, '' 'One Smart Cookie,' '' was a very traumatic experience for me. The book, written with the journalist Alan Furst, and subtitled ''How a Housewife's Chocolate Chip Recipe Turned Into a Multimillion-Dollar Business -The Story of Mrs. Fields Cookies,'' filled me with the dread sense of the path not taken. After all, Mrs. Fields grew up in the late 1950's in a tightly knit, middle-class Roman Catholic family - the youngest of five children. So did I. She was the sort of girl who never got A's in high school but who wore her school uniform so short that the nuns made her kneel to see if the hem touched the floor. So was I. As a kid, she spent rainy afternoons making chocolate chip cookies for her older siblings. So did I. But she grew up and rented a space in a California mall and began selling them. Now she's a very wealthy woman who can afford angora outfits and trips to Hawaii and who can order about employees all over the world, telling them the cookies are too hard or soft. ''It's productive, I think, to ask yourself what you enjoy, to take a close look at what you do in your free time,'' Mrs. Fields tells the legions of people who ask her how to make a million dollars. ''Somewhere in there a career is lurking.'' Now that the cookie idea is taken, I'm wondering whether I could get rich quick with those potholders I used to make to take the cookies out of the oven. Hot little potholders to go, anyone?

title: AIDS FORECASTS ARE GRIM - AND DISPARATE
description: AIDS is proving elusive as well as deadly. Medical experts, unable to find a vaccine or a cure, cannot even agree on how to track and forecast the epidemic's devastating path.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Hotel Rooms Are Scarce In Hong Kong

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SETTING AN EXAMPLE
description: LEAD: The Family Information and Referral Service Teams, or First, has been in in the county since 1980 and has trained hundreds of volunteers to provide information and referral services to people in need of social services. Now it is extending its expertise nationwide.

title: Mr. Muppet's Empire Is Thriving
description: JIM HENSON IS DIRECTING ON THE movie set, not quite so metaphysical as Ingmar Bergman as he tells Death what he wants: ''You look up sort of quizzically at the dog.'' And Death, a marvelous, sibilant hand-puppet concoction that seems at once hooded fetus and ethereal crone, obeys his master. In the process, he emotes dark rings around Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy, who are nowhere near this set or story.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: VOLCKER: Portrait of the Money Man. By William R. Neikirk. (Congdon & Weed, $18.95.) Just when the party gets hot in America's economy, it's the Federal Reserve Board's job to take away the punch bowl! The former Fed Chairman William McChesney Martin said that first, and Paul Volcker likes to quote him.

title: ELECTION SPENDING OUTPACES INTEREST
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey's legislative races do not appear to be generating much interest and both Democratic and Republican leaders expect a light voter turnout on Nov. 3, there has been no stinting when it comes to spending money on the campaigns.

title: THE POWERFUL ALLURE OF MIKE TYSON
description: IT is the boxing match with the distinct premise as its axis that is likely to be the most profound, and in our time the boxer whose matches are most consistently fueled by such interior (if rarely articulated) logic is Mike Tyson, the youngest ''undisputed'' world heavyweight champion in history.

title: Fieldston, Despite Two Nullified Touchdowns, Ties Riverdale
description: Homecoming was not as pretty for Riverdale as it might have hoped as it tied its rival, Fieldston, 6-6.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A PROUD HERITAGE OFTEN OVERLOOKED
description: LEAD: ENHANCED by their proximity to New York City and Philadelphia, and dominated by their influence, the work of 18th-century New Jersey artisans reflected sophisticated accomplishment without achieving more than regional identity.

title: In Bronx, Pushups Cut Dropout Rate
description: The streets of the South Bronx are still dark and deserted at 6 A.M., and the same hush pervades the hallways of South Bronx High School, a drab building in the heart of the bleak Melrose neighborhood. But the faint sounds of pop music can be heard coming from the school's gymnasium, where students are stretching their muscles to the beat.

title: The Flowering of China's Scholar-Artists
description: INTRODUCING ''THE CHINESE Scholar's Studio: Artistic Life in the Late Ming Period,'' at the Asia Society, is a hanging scroll called ''Venerable Friends.'' Painted by Xiang Shengmo and Zhang Qi, it is an imaginary group portrait of six influential literati of the Ming Dynasty. All were from Jiaxing or Songjiang in the Yangtze River delta. All were poets, painters, calligraphers and collectors. They are the main actors of this show.

title: SPORTSMANSHIP SPOKEN HERE
description: SINCE it is the most international of all sports, it has been said that soccer knows no language barrier. But don't try telling that to Steve Kassoy, the coach of the boys' soccer team at Hartford Public High School.

title: Lesson on Unity
description: AFTER assessing the National Football League strike, the heads of the unions representing professional baseball and basketball players have concluded that lack of unity among the football players had doomed their effort to win concessions on free agency and other issues from the owners.

title: Salvador Peace Talks End With a Deadlock
description: Prospects for peace in El Salvador were clouded today after a new round of cease-fire negotiations between the Government and guerrillas ended in deadlock here.

title: HISTORY LESSONS WE FAILED TO LEARN
description: THE historic drop in the stock market was the result of the bearing down of a series of fundamental forces, the coming to the fore of a variety of structural vulnerabilities and the failure of market participants either to learn from or remember the lessons of history.

title: MARY TRUITT PLANS WINTER WEDDING
description: Announcement has been made by Anne Dean Truitt of Washington of the engagement of her daughter Mary McConnell Truitt to John Lyster Hill, the son of Mrs. Cornelius F. Froeb of Chestertown, Md., and the late John R. Hill. The couple plan a December wedding.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: WOMEN VS. WOMEN: The Uncivil Business War. By Tara Roth Madden. (Amacom, $17.95.) Remember when the stereotypical woman was catty, dependent, manipulative and never to be trusted around another woman's man? Tara Roth Madden does. Ms. Madden, the director of development for the Laguna Art Museum in California, says that women in the corporate world are sabotaging themselves in a jealous attempt to sabotage one another.

title: Recital: Robison and Fisk
description: PAULA ROBISON and Eliot Fisk gave another of their appealing flute and guitar programs Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall. The two players are expert, sensitive and affable; they know how to give the audience a good time, and they make a bit of modern music go down easy, even if they do not entirely evade a certain blandness in the process.

title: Derrida as Rabbi
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Plans to Lay Off Civilians as It Cuts Budget
description: The Defense Department is planning extensive layoffs of civilian employees and deep cuts in the work of small contractors in an effort to generate a political backlash against Congress for budget cuts, according to Pentagon officials.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MYSTIC;
AFTER TOURIST SEASON, THE NORMAL SEASON
description: LEAD: EVEN before the maple leaves have finished turning from dark green to bright red, most of the tourists have said good-bye to the state's top tourist community. With the crowds gone, Mystic settles into a quieter, more serious and, as residents like to think, more normal season.

title: SPENDING FREEZE BEING CONSIDERED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: As White House aides prepared their strategy today for budget negotiations with Congressional leaders beginning next week, they were giving serious consideration to a proposal that would freeze domestic and military spending, with the exception of Social Security, at this year's levels.

title: PORT JEFFERSON HOTEL OPPOSED
description: LEAD: MEMBERS of the Brick Kiln Neighborhood Association in Port Jefferson, a major tourist attraction in the summer with its ferry service to Bridgeport, Conn., are opposing the construction of a three-story, 100-room hotel with catering facilities at the foot of Barnum Avenue on Route 25A.

title: The Other Bohemia
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY WE SHOULD TAKE ELECTRIC TROLLEY BUS
description: I've just had the opportunity to read the article titled ''State Nears Decision on Future of Congested Expressway'' [ Sept. 20 ] . Frankly, I feel that widening I-287 is a Band-Aid approach, as this is not a far-sighted solution, only an accommodation to the problem.

title: TAMIL RESISTANCE WANES
description: INDIAN troops were winning the real estate in their battle with Tamil guerrillas last week, but their main political target, Velupillai Prabakaran, commander of the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, reportedly escaped to fight another day. After a two-week siege, 8,000 Indian soldiers were said to have captured all but a few pockets of resistance in Jaffna, the northern stronghold of Sri Lanka's Tamil minority. Yesterday, the Indians said they were still encountering ''a lot of sniping.''

title: GARBAGE IS ISSUE IN 2 RACES
description: GARBAGE, which used to be out of sight, out of mind and out of political campaigns, is the major issue in the elections for supervisors of North Hempstead and Oyster Bay.

title: F. G. MEAD WED TO HELEN E. HALE
description: The wedding of Helen Elizabeth Hale, a daughter of the Very Rev. and Mrs. William Manning Hale of Syracuse and Marlborough, N.H., to Frederick Goodhue Mead, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Machado Mead of Suffield, Conn., took place yesterday. The Revs. Samuel W. Hale Jr. and Daniel B. Kunhardt, uncles of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Keene, N.H.

title: THE CZECHS' DEFIANT PLAYWRIGHT
description: I DON'T WANT TO emigrate. It's not just a feeling of responsibility to my cause or some such exalted reason. But I feel I'm simply a

title: QUEENE F. HOOPER WEDS J. S. FOSTER
description: Queene Ferry Hooper, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Upshur Hooper of Baltimore and the late Mr. Hooper, was married yesterday to Jonathan Sherill Foster, the son of N. Sherill Foster of East Hampton, L.I., and the late John R. Foster. The Rev. Frederick Hann, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's mother.

title: THE JOY OF FLUX
description: THRIVING ON CHAOS Handbook for a Management Revolution. By Tom Peters. 561 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: When Deficits Soar and Markets Plummet
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CROTON TOUR The Croton Water System, which supplies New York City with some of the purest water in the country, is the subject of a lecture and tour of the facilities from noon to 4 P.M. Saturday. Carl Picha, historian and engineer with the New York City Water Department will start the program with a slide-talk at the Southeast Museum in Brewster, to be followed by a lunch of soup and rolls.

title: MARY C. TEDESCHI IS WED IN CAPITAL
description: At St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington, Mary Catherine Tedeschi, a daughter of Mrs. Royal W. Savoy of Blossvale, N.Y., and Victor Tedeschi of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Nash Eberstadt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Eberstadt of New York. The Rev. Thomas Gannon performed the ceremony.

title: Historic Day for Surging Hoosiers
description: There were those on the Michigan side of the field who were prepared to call a halt to the Big Ten season, declare Indiana the conference champion and send the Hoosiers on their way to the Rose Bowl, even if they arrive early. After only seven games, Indiana has already had one of its most memorable seasons, and asking the Hoosiers to play on just doesn't seem fair.

title: RUSSIANS GET A GRIM VIEW OF AMERICAN LIFE
description: A CREDULOUS viewer of Soviet television might think that ordinary Americans fall into two categories. Some live in cardboard boxes on the mean streets of New York. The rest spend their days marching vainly before the White House to protest the bellicose policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: Jackson Puts Earnings At $192,090 in '86-87
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Democratic Presidential contender, has released a listing of his personal finances that puts his earnings from last year to this month at $192,090, mostly from honoraria, and his assets at $347,000.

title: BATTERED WIVES: LEARNING TO USE THE LAW
description: ''I WENT back to my husband after being away for a week,'' said a 45-year-old woman with seven children.

title: SEEING THE CITY AS ARTISTS DO
description: ''Urban VIsions,'' an Adelphi University exhibition dealing with images of the contemporary city, will reinforce convictions about realism as a technique, but its true value rests with its psychological concerns and with its insights into the artist's own attitude toward the theme. An artist's approach is usually revealing about the way we see our world.

title: YONKERS COLLEGES HAVE BORDERS SET
description: A RECENTLY adopted Yonkers zoning law will create special college/university zones around several institutions in different areas of the city.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales

title: COMPUTER MATCHMAKER FOR NEW BUSINESSES
description: LEAD: CAREY C. CURTIS of New Haven was seeking a match.

title:
DINING OUT;
A STAR IS BORN IN TEANECK
description: LEAD: SELDOM have I wished to give an Excellent rating to a restaurant as much as I do to Bronzini in Teaneck, now that Steven Santoro has taken over the kitchen.

title: Midwood Stops Sheepshead Bay Unbeaten Streak
description: Although Sheepshead Bay went into yesterday's game with a 5-0 overall record and had outscored its opponents 213 to 18, the Sharks failed to awe or impress Midwood, which beat Sheepshead, 17-6.

title: IT'S TIME FOR HARDWARE CARE
description: TAKE time to clean and do light maintenance on outdoor equipment before storing it for the winter. This not only prolongs the life of the equipment, but also guarantees an easier time next spring when you are ready to use the equipment again.

title: HIDING OF KEY EVIDENCE ALLEGED IN WELL TAINTING
description: Eight families from Woburn, Mass., who say chemicals in their water have caused six deaths from leukemia have accused one of the companies they hold responsible of suppressing key evidence during litigation last year. The families are asking for a new trial.

title: Please Take Off Those Blinders
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ONE ALLHALLOW'S EVE, NO CHILDREN CAME
description: WHEN all the days of September have dwindled and the shadows of October grow long and crisp, when the majesty of autumn murmurs in the bosom, my husband and I yield to a tropism and head for the mountains. We go to capture the splendor on film and in memory.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Oct. 4 about a town square in southwestern Poland misidentified the town. The town is Jelenia Gora.

title: Sad Small Investors
description: ''NOW that a third of my savings has evaporated, I've got a whole new outlook on the market,'' the 34-year-old New York accountant said. ''I look at it as a really bad neighbor. I'm going to move somewhere where I don't see the bum anymore.''

title: SCHOOLS, CITING NEED, ADD HEALTH CLINICS TO SERVICES
description: LEAD: THE days of the school nurse working alone in a dingy back office and armed with little more than a thermometer are quickly disappearing in schools across Connecticut.

title: ANN REED MARRIES
description: Ann Stuart Reed, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Reed of Winter Park, Fla., was married there yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church to Gregory Scott Scileppi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Scileppi of Floral Park, L.I. The Rev. Paul L. Crowell officiated. The bride is an administrative assistant in the commodities department at Interstate Securities Inc. in Charlotte, N.C. The bridegroom is a programmer analyst at the Royal Insurance Company in Charlotte.

title: DONORS SOUGHT FOR EDUCATION FUND
description: IN ITS continuing quest to provide disadvantaged children with a quality education, the Fund for Educational Advancement of the Archdiocese of Newark is mailing solicitations to 2,800 businesses and 3,000 individuals in Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Union Counties.

title: BATTERY PARK PAYS MORE THAN ITS WAY
description: THE glittering success of Battery Park City, a cluster of office and residential buildings built on landfill in the Hudson River, has begun to produce a financial return for New York City that may go a long way toward helping to finance the rehabilitation of abandoned, city-owned housing.

title: WAKING UP THE GIANT
description: THE BIG STORE Inside the Crisis and Revolution at Sears. By Donald R. Katz. Illustrated. 604 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Upgrading Derelict Housing for Homeless
description: WHILE Westchester County waits expectantly for what it hopes will be a breakthrough in its efforts to ease the problem of housing the homeless, it is finding a partial solution in an unexpected asset: its run-down and burned-out buildings.

title: TRICKLE-UP ECONOMICS: J R GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: THE original 'J R' burst on the scene in a novel in 1975, an unkempt 11-year-old whose penny stock and defaulted bond operations blossomed into a vast and perilous financial empire through his simple creed of ''get all you can'' by obeying the letter of the law and evading its spirit at every turn. What has become of him in the 12 years since? The scene is a recent Congressional hearing on the Federal budget.

title: Give Unesco a Second Chance
description: The exit of Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of Unesco is welcome in itself and for the signal it sends to entrenched bureaucrats in other international organizations. After 13 years, Mr. M'Bow had come to regard his $170,000-a-year post as impregnably tenured. But his candidacy for a third, six-year term proved so divisive that his own Government in Senegal urged him to withdraw. Tellingly, the move was seconded by Soviet envoys to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Forecast From a Successful Bear
description: LEAD: ONE stock that held like a bulwark through last week's selling deluge was the Growth Stock Outlook Trust, a closed-end investment fund trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Last week the shares closed at $9.50, up 7 percent. The main reason: GSO Trust's manager, Charles Allmon, met the crash with more than 75 percent of the fund's assets held in cash.

title: NASSAU WATER RESTRICTIONS ARE HERE TO STAY
description: LEAD: RAINY days were welcomed with quiet relief this summer as thousands of Nassau County homeowners watched their sun-parched lawns spring briefly back to life. Watering restrictions, imposed countywide as a result of State Department of Environmental Conservation caps on consumption, left many front lawns in western Long

title: Maestros In the Movies: Theme and Variations on the Musician as Hero
description: HARD AT WORK ON HIS latest movie, Franco Zeffirelli is trying to create a portrait of an artist that he thinks is suitable to an artless age. On the set one recent morning, the major challenge lay with C. Thomas Howell, the 20-year-old actor cast in the title role of ''The Young Toscanini,'' who confesses, ''Before I took this part the only classical music I had heard was in Bugs Bunny cartoons.''

title: UNSURE FUTURE FOR MUSEUM OF IVORY'S PAST
description: LEAD: ONE recent morning, a lone visitor arrived for a tour of the Ivory Museum. It was unlikely, said Edith de Forest, the curator and sole staff member, that anyone else would come that day to the little-known museum tucked away on the third floor of the old Pratt, Read factory building in the Ivoryton section of

title: Poll Finds Support For N.F.L. Owners
description: The American public sides with the owners in the National Football League strike, and football fans overwhelmingly support the decision to count the games played during the strike in the standings, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title:
ART;
IN HARTFORD, STLLL LIFES OF A RAGS-TO-RICHES-TO-RAGS CAREER
description: LEAD: A CASUAL visitor to the exhibition ''Charles Ethan Porter'' at the Old State House in Hartford will not discern the rags-to-riches-to-rags story underneath the mostly first-rate still lifes of flowers and fruit that comprise the exhibition.

title: FAR, FAR FROM PIZDO
description: LEAD: TRAVELS WITH DUBINSKY AND CLIVE By David Gurewich. 262 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: POSTINGS: Changing Times; Harlem Tour
description: Harlem is unfamiliar terrain to most urban explorers, but it is one of the city's more vibrant areas and one that is experiencing considerable development activity.

title: SAVORING FALL'S BEAUTY
description: KEEP up with bulb planting; if small bulbs such as those of anemone and puschkinia appear dried out, soak them in warm water for an hour or so before planting; drain to dry on paper towels first. Plant grape hyacinth bulbs where their recurrent foliage does not hamper other garden plants. Finish dividing and replanting thick clumps of ferns; be sure the soil is enriched with peat moss and/or compost. Why They Turn

title: WALSH MAKES HIS MOVE
description: THE CURTAINS ARE DRAWN, AS THEY must always be. ''Security,'' explains Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair; the Federal Bureau of Investigation worries that someone might spy through the windows.

title: UNFINISHED BUSINESS: REFLECTIONS ON BECOMING A GRANDFATHER
description: THE other day, my son told me that I was to become a grandfather. My first reaction was one of utter joy, for him and also for me, perhaps primarily for me. Certainly the birth would be a major milestone, a ''marker event'' in both our lives.

title: EVIE RAMOS MARRIES
description: The Hotel Pierre was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Evie Marie Ramos, a daughter of Laura N. Rey of Secaucus, N.J., and Edward Ramos of Gainesville, Fla., to William C. Monroe, a son of Anna H. Meyers of Fort Meyers, Fla., and the late Charles Henry Monroe of Manhattan. Judge Robert L. Nahman of City Civil Court officiated.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement. Any idea what the problem is now?

title: MARINA H. SHIN IS MARRIED TO REGAN CHURCH CALMER
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Marina H. Shin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Shin of Little Neck, Queens, and Clearwater, Fla., was married yesterday to Regan Church Calmer, the son of Carol Church Calmer of New York and the late Ned Calmer. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Peace Corps in a Drive to Enlist Dental and Health Students
description: The Peace Corps, as part of a drive to double its force of volunteers to 10,000 by 1992, has announced that it will arrange with universities to allow dental and public health students to perform much of their work toward a degree while serving with the agency.

title: Sri Lanka Says Indians Are Gaining on Tamils
description: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that India's two-week-old campaign against a Tamil rebel stronghold in Jaffna had succeeded in breaking the ''military hold'' of Tamil guerrillas in northern and eastern Sri Lanka.

title: TROPICAL FISH AT A LOCAL SITE
description: EXCEPT for Seth Rosenbaum and a handful of other fish fanciers, few people know that this is the time of year that a host of tropical species frequent the New York and New Jersey coasts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 14 of the Travel section today misstates the style of the Abbesses station entrance of the Paris Metro. It is Art Nouveau.

title: HOLLY B. HANES IS WED TO DR. HENRY ROSSI 3D
description: The Congregational Church of New Canaan, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Holly B. Hanes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon C. Hanes of Bernardsville, N.J., to Dr. Henry D. Rossi 3d, the son of Mr. Rossi Jr. of Peotone, Ill., and the late Jane Arnold Rossi.

title: NO HEAVY LIFTING
description: Most people share much more in common than they realize. Our aspirations for ourselves, our families, our associates and our countries are usually not too different. It is only natural, therefore, to have common ways of expressing these aspirations.

title: USING NATIVE PLANTS IN LANDSCAPING
description: PINXTER FLOWER, pink shell, and honeysuckle are some of the best landscaping shrubs available, each of them carrying clusters of fragrant, delicate flowers.

title: U.S. Sees Progress in Moscow on a Missile Accord
description: Despite their failure to set a date for a summit meeting, the United States and the Soviet Union bridged important differences on the emerging agreement to ban medium-range and shorter-range missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: ARMY BACKLOGGED ON WETLAND SURVEY
description: FACED with a backlog of 1,200 requests to outline the boundaries of wetlands in the tri-state area of South Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, the Army Corps of Engineers is encouraging property owners to have their land privately inspected.

title: FROM THE WRITERS' CORNER: Four Voices; Studs Terkel: 'On Some Other Planet'
description: AS we hear the wise men of Wall Street - confused, befuddled, lost - the image of Sidney Weinberg is evoked, a senior partner of Goldman, Sachs during the 30's and 40's. He was an adviser to presidents, including Roosevelt, Truman and Johnson. Remembering the crash of '29, he said, ''We were confused, befuddled and lost. We waited for an announcement.''

title: MASSACHUSETTS DOCTORS, IRKED BY RULES, WARN OTHERS AWAY
description: Fed up with what it considers overregulation, the Massachusetts Medical Society has sent letters to medical societies elsewhere asserting that the state is ''an undesirable location in which to practice.''

title: LINDA S. SCHBARTZMAN IS WED TO CHARLES COHN
description: The wedding of Linda Sue Schwartzman, the daughter of Allan Schwartzman and Dr. Lois Schwartzman of Westport, Conn., to Charles D. F. Cohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Cohn of Riverdale, the Bronx, took place last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Amiel Wohl officiated.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
EVERYBODY SHOULD GET A JOB
description: LEAD: HARD HEADS, SOFT HEARTS Tough-Minded Economics for a Just Society. By Alan S. Blinder. 236 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing. $17.95.

title: BETRAYALS AND OBSESSIONS
description: MIAMI By Joan Didion. 238 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Isn't It Time to Consider National Primary Day?
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
SOME TRUTHS AND MYTHS ABOUT GARLIC
description: LEAD: NOT too long ago, eating garlic was considered an unsociable act. People who smelled of this pungent food were considered lowly, not the sort that one might wish to be associated with in public. All that seems to have changed.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Some scary staples are back on TV this witch-and-goblin week - ''Fright Night,'' ''Psycho,'' ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers'' and of course ''Halloween.'' There's also the premiere of a solid thriller and an array of less familiar suspense treats.

title: POPULATION BOMB IS STILL TICKING
description: NOT a day passes in which we are not exposed to a news story that in some way deals with the deterioration of our environment. The pictures vary, but usually we see a crowd of demonstrators who are announcing their opposition to changes in their community or protesting the closing of their polluted-beyond-use beaches, the conversion of single-house properties with trees to two-house wastelands, nuclear plants, nuclear waste sites, multifamily housing, down-zoning for more industries and a score of other problems too numerous to mention.

title: Africans See Their Culture Live in U.S. South
description: When Joseph L. Opala reads folk tales written in the Gullah language of American blacks, audiences here ''just go crazy,'' the American anthropologist says.

title: Art
description: The year 1970 was a crucial one for Philip Guston, an American painter who had long been accepted and admired as an abstract expressionist. His way of playing pink against red with fat and juicy little touches was unmistakable and amounted almost to what is now called ''a signature style.''

title: Jolly Roger On the Horizon
description: AGAINST ALL FLAGS Starring Errol Flynn (in photo), Maureen O'Hara (in photo), Anthony Quinn, Mildred Natwick, Robert Warwick. Directed by George Sherman. 1952. Color. Kartes Home Video. 83 minutes. $19.95.

title: PLAYING FOR KEEPS
description: THE JAZZ AGE Popular Music in the 1920's. By Arnold Shaw. 350 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. ALL IN GOOD TIME By Marian McPartland. Illustrated. 174 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $14.95.

title: Corporate Caution
description: AS the market continued its roller-coaster ride late last week, corporate chiefs, many of whom were facing personal losses amounting to millions of dollars, found themselves in an odd position.

title: SEARCH FOR CHARLIE MCCARTHY TUNES INTO END OF THE WORLD
description: WE Americans tried hard to remove ourselves from the reality of what was going on in Europe in 1939. After all, there was a large ocean between us, The War had saved the world for Democracy and the idea that anyone would even consider another was ridiculous. Anyway, even if they did, it was not our business.

title: Jerking Us Around
description: ''When sorrows come,'' said the King in ''Hamlet,''

title: Major Infusion of Cash Kept Key Options Clearinghouse Afloat
description: First Options of Chicago Inc., the nation's largest options clearinghouse, last week needed a major infusion of capital from the Continental Illinois Corporation to meet its regulatory obligations.

title: Guest Observer; Analyzing the Cost
description: THERE IS MUSIC IN the cafes at night, and calculation in the air (to sell short a Bob Dylan phrase).

title: MANAGING PROBLEMS FOR OTHERS PAYS OFF
description: WHEN Donald J. Zinn was 24 years old, his salary was $55,000 a year. The next year, his earnings dropped to $18,000. Richard Benedetti fared even worse; he was 32, married with three children, making $60,000 one year and $18,000 the next.

title: Focus: Irving, Tex.; A Partner Rescues a New Town
description: FOR a time it looked as if Las Colinas, a 12,000-acre new town of apartments, offices and stores here in the middle of the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex, might succumb to the Texas oil bust and the region's 30 percent-plus office vacancy rate.

title: PRISONERS OF THE ECONOMY
description: LEAD: THE TRULY DISADVANTAGED The Inner City, the Underclass, and Public Policy. By William Julius Wilson. Tables. 254 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A $350 Million Project for Edgewater
description: LEAD: SINCE it closed in 1955, the Ford assembly plant in the old industrialized southern half of Edgewater has stood dormant - an empty brick shell on a pier jutting 500 feet into the Hudson River.

title: 3 WEEKS IN THE N.F.L. AND BACK TO THE OFFICE
description: LEAD: TOMORROW will be like any other Monday for Skip Lane.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Burlington, Vt., last Sunday about a tax dispute referred incorrectly to Nicola Marro, public relations director at the University of Vermont. He is a man.

title: Test Is Reported to Indicate '69 AIDS Death of Teen-Ager
description: Doctors believe a St. Louis teen-ager who died in 1969 was infected with the virus that causes AIDS, according to a newspaper report. A finding of AIDS in 1969, if confirmed, would be far earlier than the earliest known cases, identified in the late 1970's in New York City and California.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HALLOWEEN PARTY
