The confrontation between America's Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan. Weeks Advice, How-to and On Miscellaneous List 1 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by 9 Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More "Bloom County" cartoon strips. 2 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 73 Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 3 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. 20 (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 4 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet 49 Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Advice about a family problem. 5 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge 33 Publications, $4.95.) Lates edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: New World Visions: American Art and the Metropolitan Museum Volume I, 1650-1810; Volume II, 1800-1914. Home Vision. 58 minutes each volume. $39.95. If every professor of art history were as perceptive and informative (and as good-looking) as Vincent Scully, no one would study any other subject.

title: Public TV: That Delicate Balance
description: WHEN BILL MOYERS RE-turned to public television a year ago, he arrived with a slate of ambitious projects, a potful of foundation money and high expectations. However, it was not long before Mr. Moyers, who had been away for five years, was reminded of the frustrations of working in a system that is maddingly democratic, with as many bosses -317 - as it has stations.

title: Rewarded
description: Serious poets engage in the riskiest of literary business, seldom achieving anything appoaching unanimous acclaim, let alone big paychecks. So there seemed a bit of justice done last week when Joseph Brodsky, the exiled Russian poet, won the Nobel Prize in Literature. The 47-year-old Mr. Brodsky, who was deported from the Soviet Union in 1972 after serving 18 months in a labor camp for ''parasitism,'' is widely regarded as the best living Russian poet. ''This is an example of the Nobel Prize going to a really serious, committed, great poet,'' said the critic Susan Sontag. The modest Mr. Brodsky, now an American citizen who lives in New York, said the prize was ''a big step for me and a small step for mankind.'' And what will he do with the accompanying $330,000? ''Spend it,'' he said.

title:
INVESTING;
A Skeptical View of Gold as a Haven
description: LEAD: WHEN investors fear the return of high inflation or believe financial calamity is imminent, gold is the usual safe haven of choice. Yet, despite the gyrations of the stock market last week, many successful investors do not believe either of those developments is likely. So they recommend that investors stay away from gold.

title: Rock: Sonic Youth, At Cat Club
description: NAME dropping, or ''citing influences,'' is a game rock musicians and rock critics play expertly, and these days the band name that seems to get dropped most frequently is that of the Velvet Underground. But when the Velvet Underground was actually making music in New York City, some 20 years ago, the band was an underground phenomenon, adored by its cult, ignored by the majority of rock listeners. The Velvet Underground wasn't even one of the most popular local bands; Vanilla Fudge had more fans.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PIANOPLAYERS, by Anthony Burgess. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $4.95.) Anthony Burgess's 29th novel is about a man, much like the author's own father, whose piano playing provides the real-time soundtrack for silent pictures; his career falls apart with the advent of a new technology called talkies. While Ph.D. candidates might not find the book as fulfilling as Mr. Burgess's more erudite works, Gene Lyons said here last year, its ''modest charms [ include ] its vivid re-creation of the humble joys of working-class Manchester and Blackpool during the 1920's.'' INTERVENTION: How America Became Involved in Vietnam, by George McT. Kahin. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) For many historians, the manner in which the United States became involved in the Vietnam War is a case study in how the machinery of decision-making can become loosed from its moorings and run like a mad automaton, bereft of the governing influence of reality testing. Drawing on his own interviews and previously classified documents, George McT. Kahin, who teaches international studies at Cornell University, ''has produced an illuminating work about a darkening series of decisions'' that led to America's intervention in Southeast Asia, The Times's Walter Goodman said last year. ''Opponents of the Reagan Administration's truculence toward Nicaragua cannot fail to find . . . a cautionary experience.'' THE ORANGING OF AMERICA: And Other Stories, by Max Apple. (Penguin, $5.95.) Max Apple's first book contains 10 good-natured satirical stories that unearth some of the unexamined oddities of American life. ''Apple's principal asset is his startling imagination,'' one reviewer said in 1976. ''He translates the most battered of our cultural cliches into glistening artifacts.'' THINKING BACK: The Perils of Writing History, by C. Vann Woodward. (Louisiana State University, $6.95.) In this retrospective, C. Vann Woodward, who has made a career of challenging accepted interpretations of the history of the American South, trains his revisionist instincts inward and takes a critical second look at his own career. The book is a ''fascinating meditation on the role of revisionism by a practitioner,'' Linda Orr said here in 1986. ''The original energy that comes from overturning long-accepted ways of seeing the past is still there.'' JANE, by Dee Wells. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Jane, an American film critic living in London, tries to juggle three love affairs. In 1974, our reviewer, Margaret Drabble, said she felt a bit guilty about liking this ''slick, trendy'' first novel, but ''its sheer readability wins out.'' The author, she said, makes ''some serious comments on modern life, but, more important, her story and her jokes are good.'' COUNSELS OF WAR, by Gregg Herken. (Oxford University, $10.95.) Along with the development of atomic weapons has come an odd new breed of armchair warriors: the civilian scientists and strategists whose harrowing but dispassionate analyses attempt to provide a rational underpinning to nuclear war. This book ''provides a valuable survey of the main debates'' within the strategic community and ''a sense of the personalities of those who have taken part,'' Michael Mandelbaum said here in 1985. THE COLD STOVE LEAGUE, by Thomas Boyle. (Academy Chicago, $4.95.) An unsuspecting American comes to Portugal to help run a bar; instead, he finds himself caught up in an international web of murder and financial misdeeds spun by none other than the gnomes of Zurich, the secretive Swiss bankers who some paranoid investors accuse of manipulating the world economy. ''Most of the book manages to be believable,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1984, ''and the writing is lively and fast-moving. Just the thing for a pleasant hour or two under a tree.'' UNDER SIEGE: P.L.O. Decisionmaking During the 1982 War, by Rashid Khalidi. (Columbia University, $12.50.) As a Palestinian and an Oxford-trained historian who knows Yasir Arafat, Rashid Khalidi was in a unique position to evaluate the Palestine Liberation Organization's strategy during the Israeli-Lebanese war. Through interviews and an examination of P.L.O. archives, the Columbia University historian has produced a ''generally objective, lucid and incisive account [ that ] fills a critical void in the literature about the Israeli invasion,'' The Times's Thomas L. Friedman said here in 1985. ''One cannot help but be struck by what a graveyard of illusions the 1982 war turned out to be.'' ONE WAY OR ANOTHER, by Peter Cameron. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $5.95.) In a story called ''Homework,'' a boy who is depressed about the death of his dog is pondering the ultimate algebraical conundrum: ''Find the value for n such that n plus everything else in your life makes you feel all right.'' But the problem, like others posed in Peter Cameron's collection of short stories, is unsolvable; the best his people can do to extricate themselves from life's entanglements is to lie to themselves and others. ''Characters can't ease their pain in Mr. Cameron's environment,'' Victor Kantor Burg said here last year, ''but they do engage in interesting deceptions.'' ON ACTING, by Laurence Olivier. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) When Laurence Olivier sat down to record his reflections on the nature of his craft, he was determined to avoid ''boring theatrical gossip.'' The result, Fritz Weaver said here last year, ''is the work everyone hoped we would have from him. . . . In Lord Olivier, perhaps more than any other actor of this century, significance lurks, mystical lights flash; one has a sense of the large past, a kinship with kings and ministers, heroes and monsters.''

title: BRADLEY SEEKS AID FOR PRENATAL CARE
description: JUDGING by the response to a recent magazine article, Senator Bill Bradley has found overwhelming national support for his plan to spend more Government money on prenatal care.

title: Dance: Second Bill by Wayne Group
description: ONE forgives Dennis Wayne nearly everything for the choreography and opportunity he gives Gerard Alexander, a wonderful dancer, in a ballet inspired by Fred Astaire. Certainly, there was much to forgive Thursday night during the second program presented by Dancers, Mr. Wayne's company, at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street.

title: FROM THE WRITERS' CORNER: Four Voices; Susan Allen Toth: 'A Surge of Greed'
description: BROKERS hurling themselves from high windows. Men selling apples on street corners. Silent, shuffling breadlines and shouting crowds outside banks. Even for many of us who did not endure the Great Crash, images of the Depression still flicker across the years. Is that why so many people panicked?

title: ON THE TRAIL OF A ROGUE CAPITLAIST
description: VESCO From Wall Street to Castro's Cuba: The Rise, Fall, and Exile of the King of White Collar Crime. By Arthur Herzog. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: RUNNING THEN, RUNNING NOW
description: WITH the approach of the New York City Marathon next Sunday, I realized that for more than half of my life I have had distance running as my companion. Much has changed both in my own life and in the perceptions of road running.

title: LISA GRIFFIN IS MARRIED
description: At Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville, Mass., Mary Elisabeth Griffin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Griffin of Oyster Harbors, Mass., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Harry Coleman Hagerty 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hagerty Jr. of Rye, N.Y. Dom Gregory Floyd, the former headmaster of the Portsmouth Abbey School, from which the bridegroom graduated, performed the ceremony.

title: Augustana Streak at 57
description: Greg Wallace passed for four touchdown, three to Eric Welgat, as Augustana (7-0) stretched its unbeaten streak to 57 games by beating Milliken, 48-14, in College Conference of Illinois and Wisconsin game today.

title: Using Cliche Is a Mistake
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bad Week Stirs Memories of Fear and of Loss
description: The day the world nearly crashed down on Lenore Waxman is stamped indelibly on her mind.

title: WOES SAID TO PERSIST AT HOMES
description: LEAD: A DECADE after the state government, with considerable fanfare, made nursing home care a top priority, many of the same problems exist, according to current and former state officials. And the problems are heightened by societal and industry changes, the officials said.

title: THE MIND OVER THE BODY
description: In his favorable review of behavioral medicine, Daniel Goleman neglects to mention two of its most serious shortcomings: first, its obvious bias toward affluent and highly verbal patients, and, more important, the very real danger it presents to patients who do not respond positively to behavioral treatment. These unfortunate people are left not only sick, but guilty over their supposedly deficient or inflexible personalities. Not everyone is equipped to laugh his way back to health. Reduced to its essence, behavioral medicine has a real tendency to blame the victim for his or her pain. MARION HUNT St. Louis

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Aug. 23 about picnicking in the Berkshires located Tyringham Cobble in Massachusetts incorrectly. Its entrance is on Jerusalem Road in Tyringham.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Gymnastics Soviet in 1-2-3 Sweep: Dmitri Bilozerchev led a 1-2-3 Soviet Union finish in winning the men's all-round title yesterday at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He won the crown for six routines with 118.375 points. Yuri Korolev finished second with 118.350 points and Vladimir Artemov was third with 118.125 points. Aurelia Dobre of Rumania won the women's title with 79.650 points, including four perfect 10.0's. Elena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union was second and Danilea Silivas of Rumania third. Bilozerchev, 20 years old, won his second world individual title. He won his first at 16 in 1983. But an accident two years after that resulted in a compound fracture in his leg that threatened his career. (AP) Tennis Lendl and Edberg in Final: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, exchanged groundstrokes with Mikael Pernfors of Sweden and beat him by 6-0, 6-2 in a semifinal match yesterday in the Seiko tournament in Tokyo. Lendl, of Czechoslovakia, will meet Sweden's Stefan Edberg, ranked second in the world, in today's final. Edberg struggled through a tiebreaker before beating Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 7-6, 4-6, 6-2, in the other semifinal.(AP) Shriver to Play Sabatini for Title: Top-seeded Pam Shriver and No. 2 Gabriela Sabatini easily won semifinal matches yesterday in the Volvo Classic tournament at Brighton, England. Shriver needed to save 1 set point in the second set before beating unseeded Kathy Jordan, 6-1, 7-5. Sabatini, of Argentina, eliminated third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-3.(AP) Boxing Bruno Stops Bugner: Frank Bruno knocked down Joe Bugner near the end of the eighth round in London yesterday and stopped the 37-year-old Australian in their scheduled 12-round heavyweight bout. The fight ended when Bugner's corner threw in the towel after the knockdown. The 25-year-old Briton easily outclassed Bugner for his 32d victory in 34 fights. The victory improved Bruno's chances of a earning a matchup with Mike Tyson.(AP) Dog Show Bedlington Terrier Keeps Winning: The top-winning Bedlington terrier in the history of the breed in this country, Ch. Willow Wind Centurian, owned by David Ramsay of Warwick, R.I., and Allan Sheimo of Morocco, yesterday led a field of 971 at the 75 All Breed Show of the Queensboro Kennel Club at Riis Park, Rockaway. It increased his record of bests to 41. Golf Charles Increases Lead: Bob Charles battled a steady rain yesterday to post a three-under-par 69 and increase his lead to three shots after two rounds of the Las Vegas Senior Classic in Nevada. Charles, a New Zealander used to less-than-ideal playing conditions, was at six-under-par 136 at the Desert Inn Country Club. Charles Coody, who shot a 68 yesterday, was at 139, three shots off the pace. Arnold Palmer and Bobby Nichols were both at 140 after playing the par-72 course in 71. (AP) Zoeller Ahead by 2: Fuzzy Zoeller shot five birdies on the back nine yesterday and took a two-shot lead after three rounds of the Tucson Open in Arizona. Zoeller birdied the 10th through 13th holes and capped a round of eight-under-par 64 with a 10-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole. Zoeller finished three rounds in 197, 19 under par. The second-round leader, Hal Sutton, could do no better than a 68 and fell into second, two shots back at 199. Jay Haas, Chip Beck and Mike Reid shared third at 201, four strokes off the lead. (AP)

title: A DAY OF IRONY FOR CARDS
description: ''In this business,'' said Ken Dayley, who came out of the bullpen today and threw one pitch that cost four runs in the World Series, ''you're either a hero or a zero.''

title: A MASTERFUL MILLER 'PRICE' IN TEANECK
description: WHAT is it about Arthur Miller's masterful play ''The Price'' that brings out the best in some regional theaters? Two outstanding productions have been seen in the state's professional playhouses in as many years.

title: Harvard Tops Cornell to Tie for Ivy Lead
description: Tom Yohe, the junior quarterback, threw for two touchdowns on plays covering 49 and 40 yards and the Harvard defense stopped a Princeton scoring threat with two minutes remaining today as the Crimson moved into a tie for the Ivy League football lead with a 24-19 victory.

title: On Language; I'll Stand Alone
description: IN LAST SUMMER'S Iran-contra hearings, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that Director of Central Intelligence William J. Casey told him he was ''interested in the ability to go to an existing - as he put it - off-the-shelf, self-sustaining, stand-alone entity that could perform certain activities on behalf of the United States.''

title: Panel Rejects Female Figure For U.S. Vietnam Memorial
description: The Commission on Fine Arts has rejected a plan to add a statue of a woman to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in honor of nurses and other women who served in that war.

title: FOLLOWING THROUGH ON AN INNOVATION
description: MAYBE nine times out of 10 a promising innovation leads to winning the game. But there is always that 10th time.

title: Social Events
description: Celebrating the Theater Halloween Preview Oct. 25 - Costumes are optional but merriment is mandatory at a Caribbean Halloween party featuring Chinese-Hispanic food, a cash bar, dancing and a raffle at Bayamo, 704 Broadway (just north of Fourth Street). The event, from 7 to 11 P.M., will benefit the Jewish Guild for the Blind, which has provided services for visually impaired people of all religions and races since 1914. Tickets $55 at the door. Party for Street Theater Oct. 25 - For 17 years, the New York Street Theater Caravan has been exporting one of the city's best commodities to prisons, shelters for the homeless and other places where plays are rarely performed. There will be a buffet and entertainment from 3 to 6 P.M. to benefit the group at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. Tickets $20 at the door. A Remembrance Oct. 26 - Senator Edward M. Kennedy will be the featured speaker and Bobby Short will provide the entertainment at a benefit for the Simon Wiesenthal Center. The educational center, at Yeshiva University in Los Angeles, is named after the famed Nazi hunter, who will attend the black-tie event at the Marriott Marquis Hotel. Tickets, $300; 212-889-2244. Entertaining Evening Oct. 26 - An ''Evening of Entertainment'' will feature Theodore Bikel, Blythe Danner, Michael Feingold, Ronnie Gilbert, Odetta, Joanne Woodward, George Hearn, Carmen de Lavallade, Linda Hunt and others at Circle in the Square on 50th Street, just west of Broadway. Starting at 8 P.M. and concluding with a reception with the performers, the evening will benefit the Martha Schlamme Scholarship Fund. A minimum contribution of $25 is requested; 212-307-2732. Franklin's 'Lost Plays' Oct. 26 - Hardly known as a playwright, Benjamin Franklin did indeed write what he called plays but might be more accurately called discourses on the intellectual and humerous side. These ''plays'' will be read by such modern dramatic luminaries as Helen Hayes, Edward Herrmann and Matthew Broderick at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 417 East 61st Street (east of First Avenue). The evening starts with a 7 P.M. tour of the museum and concludes with a Champagne party to benefit the Writers Theater, a nonprofit company dedicated to developing new plays and adaptions. Tickets, $125; 212-869-9770. Humane Party Oct. 26 - More than 20,000 animals a year receive low-cost medical care from the Humane Society of New York. The society is holding a benefit from 9 P.M. to 2 A.M. at the newly refurbished World nightclub at 254 East Second Avenue, near Houston Street. Tickets, $30; 212-752-4842. Briefly Noted: Oct. 26 - The West Point Glee Club and Band will perform at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds from the event, which begins at 6:30 with cocktails, will benefit the West Point Preparatory Scholarship Program. Tickets, $250; 212-874-2460. Oct. 28 - The Young Adult Institute, which provides programs for retarded people in the metropolitan area, will benefit from a dinner-dance in a French bistro atmosphere. There will be strolling musicians and games of chance at the Pierre starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Tickets, $250; 212-563-7474. Oct. 28 - Artworks worth from $100 to $1,000 will be auctioned at the Netherland Club, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, to aid the Medic Alert Foundation. Cocktails will be served at the benefit, which lasts from 6 to 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $45; 212-213-4510, or at the door. Oct. 28 - There will be a children's fashion show and tea party at Bice, 7 East 54th Street, from 3 to 5 P.M. to benefit the Children's Museum, a 15-year-old institution. Tickets $100 ($75 for museum members); 212-765-5905. Oct. 29 - Roberta Flack will be the main attraction at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria to benefit Lenox Hill Hospital. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $350; 212-439-2410. Oct. 29 - The New York Exchange for Woman's Work, which sells handiwork made by homemakers, is holding a cocktail party and buffet at the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, to be followed by a performance of ''Anything Goes'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Tickets $150 ($110 for performance alone); 212-355-6110. Manhattan Evening Oct. 30 - The Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, an organization working for the civil rights of homosexual men and women, is planning a three-tier benefit. At 6 P.M., there will be cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at the City Bar Association at 42 West 44th Street. From there, guests will walk to the Martin Beck Theater on 45th Street for a performance of ''Into the Woods.'' Afterward, there will be a Champagne supper at the Parsons School of Design on Seventh Avenue at 40th Street. Tickets, $175 ($75 for pretheater party and performance); 212-995-8585. Halloween Sail Oct. 30 - Since 1969, Hospital Audiences has brought productions to more than 5 million people unable to share in the city's cultural life. A 9 P.M. cocktail party at the Water Club at 30th Street and the East River will precede a cruise around the harbor aboard the Paco Rabanne from 11 P.M. to 1 A.M. Dress: Halloween costume, black tie or informal. Tickets, $100; 212-575-7689.

title: MEASURE OF A WOMAN
description: LEAD: THE ADAMS WOMEN Abigail and Louisa Adams, Their Sisters and Daughters. By Paul C. Nagel. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Out Where Texas Is, Well, Texas Sized
description: In the early morning light, as you drive west from Pecos, the mountains in the distance look like either a densely textured, low-lying bank of clouds or a mirage. The West Texas terrain has been so hard and so flat for so long that the mountains in the distance seem as improbable as an ocean. But the mountains are real, and their cold, lonely beauty gives identity to the one part of the state where the mythic Texas of endless vistas and limitless space resonates with the most force.

title: BIRDS TAKE A TOLL ON STATE'S VINTERS
description: LEAD: IN 1978, William Hopkins was fighting to save his 200-year-old family farm when he gave up dairy farming to become the state's first licensed winemaker since Prohibition.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Bit of Japan in Manhasset

title: Rapid Transit on the Bio-Bio
description: The Bio-Bio, a 238-mile-long river in Chile, is named for the sweet ''feeo-feeo'' call of the Chilean elaenia, a local bird, but its nature is much less benign. Since the first descent in 1978 by a team of California adventurers, white water rafting enthusiasts from around the globe have responded to its call. And with reason: The Bio-Bio is considered to be the wildest commercially run river in the world.

title: New York to Open Shelter for Homeless Veterans
description: For years, Michael Gold, a Vietnam-era veteran, had watched the growing number of homeless men in New York City and wondered how many were former comrades in arms who ''just lost their ability to take hold.''

title: In Sri Lankan South, Violence Taps New Sinhalese Militancy
description: While unexpectedly bitter fighting goes on in northern Sri Lanka between an Indian peacekeeping force and a Tamil guerrilla army, a more shadowy militancy is growing in the country's once-peaceful south.

title: WATER DISTRICTS LINING OLD PIPES
description: LEAD: IN an effort to eliminate rusty water and low water pressure, New Castle this month joins Pleasantville and Yorktown and becomes the third northern Westchester water district in the last three years to begin multimillion dollar projects to clean and line cast-iron water pipes.

title: NEXT YEAR IS NOW AS CLUBS BEGIN TO SCAN THE PLAYER MARKET
description: This is the time of year when teams start planning for their appearance in next year's World Series. Whichever two teams make the most successful plans figure to provide a stronger matchup than the one created by the Minnesota Twins and the St. Louis Cardinals. No other two teams could have made it this far and presented such a weak World Series.

title: Lanford Wilson's Lonely World of Displaced Persons
description: FROM HIS EARLIEST PLAYS TO his latest, ''Burn This,'' Lanford Wilson has been firmly committed to the free expression of the individual spirit, no matter how nonconformist or even prodigal that spirit may seem to be. Outcasts populate his work - the young man in ''Lemon Sky'' who is desperately trying to find his place in his estranged father's new family; the waif in ''The Hot l Baltimore,'' who yearns for the far-off sounds of trains calling her to the road; Sally Talley in ''Talley's Folly,'' who breaks with WASP family traditions and runs away with a Jewish man.

title: READERS WRITE IN: PRO AND CON VIEWS
description: FIRST off, let me apologize. My last column, regarding what is right and what is wrong with today's automobile, touched a nerve, but the response needs to be truncated if it is to be here at all.

title: 10 Days on Vacation With a 10-Year-Old
description: Since nobody I know recommends a mother-son trip as a child-raising device, the vacation I took with my 10-year-old to Hawaii earlier this year was an experiment in more ways than one. We were two generations with different interests going nearly 5,000 miles to a place we had never been before, trying to see and absorb as much as possible in 10 days' time. My son likes animals, airplanes and anything electronic; I wanted leisurely days to be full of people, museums and beaches. A situation that demanded compromise turned into a surprisingly successful stay, in which it seemed two generations really could learn from one another.

title: Fund Switching
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: SO far, you can count the number of Beautiful People there on your thumbs, but that's understandable. It's not even on the same side of the river as Mortimer's and Le Cirque, for goodness' sake, and it lasts 11 hours! That's asking a lot, even in the name of culture.

title: Beyond Left and Right, Let's Seek Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
SOME TRUTHS AND MYTHS ABOUT GARLIC
description: LEAD: NOT too long ago, eating garlic was considered an unsociable act. People who smelled of this pungent food were considered lowly, not the sort that one might wish to be associated with in public. All that seems to have changed.

title: JANINE M. LINDEN IS MARRIED TO SAMUEL GORDON JR.
description: At the Union Club in New York, Janine M. Linden, a senior vice president and the director of public relations of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, an advertising agency in Manhattan, was married last evening to Samuel L. Gordon Jr., a senior vice president of the GECC Capital Markets Group Inc., a subsidiary of the General Electric Credit Corporation. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, officiated.

title: REBEL WITH A CAUSE
description: While politicians and the news media seem to be concerned with corporate raiders and wheeler-dealers, at one extreme, or with illegal immigrants and welfare recipients, at the other, it is ironic that only entertainers such as John Cougar Mellencamp, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen seem to care about farmers and blue-collar workers who are caught in the middle. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement. Any idea what the problem is now?

title:
ART;
A PAINTER WHO SYNTHESIZES ABLANGUAGE OF COLOR
description: LEAD: IF visitors to the current exhibition of paintings by Joseph Driscoll 3d, at the Anthony Giordano Gallery of Dowling College in Oakdale, were also witness to the recent Friedel Dzubas show at the Nassau County Museum, they may sense a certain kinship between the works of these two artists. It will therefore come as no surprise that Mr.

title: CHESS CHAMPION VICTIMIZED BY HS STYLE OF PLAY IN GAME 5
description: Gary Kasparov's macho approach to chess is glorious when it succeeds, but it can look juvenile in failure.

title: Nehemiah Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: 'PROFESSOR OF YEAR' AT SETON HALL
description: LEAD: DR. DAVID T. ABALOS, parts of whose course on Latino transformation at Seton Hall University here draw from his own Mexican-American heritage, will receive a gold medal and certificate this week naming him Professor of the Year at the university.

title: PATTERSON TRUE TO PREDICTION
description: A curious thing about Elvis Patterson is that he answers your questions before you ask them.

title: ADULT LITERACY DRIVE PRESSED
description: TEN months ago, on a Wednesday evening after work, Beverly Scott, a local resident and an employee of a New York City bank, went downtown to the United Community Corporation with an altruistic purpose and a briefcase full of instructional reading material.

title: MONA K. TAKAHASHI WEDS ALAN STRICK IN CONNECTICUT
description: Mona Kei Takahashi and Alan E. Strick were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Saugatuck, Conn., by the Rev. Theodore G. Hoskins.

title: AUTHENTIC BAROQUE FOR TODAY
description: LEAD: ERIC MILNES and Evan Johnson, the music director and concertmaster, respectively, of Music at St. John's, think that when it comes to music, old is better.

title: YALE TOPS PENN ON LATE RALLY
description: Penn gave Yale's Kelly Ryan a second chance today and that cost the Quakers the game.

title: The Big Board Battle to Contain the Damage
description: BY noon Tuesday a groggy John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, had come to his wit's end. The tiny pool of ''buy orders'' on hand at the opening had dried up. And temporarily closing the Big Board seemed like the only way to prevent the market from another debilitating tailspin on top of Monday's 508-point decline.

title: PLASTIC CONTAINERS: PROSPECTS UNCERTAIN
description: LEAD: THE plastic beverage container is an endangered species in New Jersey, and bottlers and bottle makers are fighting to save it.

title: THE JOFFREY BALLET RESTORES NIJINSKY'S 'RITE OF SPRING'
description: THE JOFFREY BALLET has often been ambitious.

title: Foreign Money
description: FOREIGN investors, once high rollers on Wall Street, are taking their new investment money elsewhere and are unlikely to return en masse until stability prevails, economists and international market specialists say. Some picked up blue-chip bargains after the market plunged, but most remain on the sidelines.

title: 'GO-IT-ALONE' RACE IRKS MEXICO'S LEFT
description: Efforts by the Mexican left to run a single candidate in the presidential election next year have been thrown into disarray by the leading contender's decision to spurn, at least for the moment, a ''united front'' to challenge the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party.

title: Going On in The Northeast
description: FISH AND FLIES Bing Crosby was one. Ernest Hemingway was another. Like Zane Grey, Daniel Webster and millions of others, they were enthusiasts of the ancient sport of fly fishing, the subject of an exhibit that opened yesterday at the Academy of Natural Sciences Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Robertson Asserts He'd Purge Bureaucracy of All but Conservatives
description: Pat Robertson, seeking to portray himself as the Republican Presidential field's champion of conservatives, told a crowd of staunch supporters here Friday night that if elected he would put conservatives in appointive positions from top to bottom and purge the bureaucracy of what he said were thousands of holdovers from the Carter Administration.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: TWINS WIN AND FORCE SEVENTH WORLD SERIES GAME
description: The Minnesota Twins tied the World Series at three games each yesterday when they ended a three-game losing streak and overwhelmed the St. Louis Cardinals, 11-5, in Minneapolis. The deciding game will be played in Minneapolis tonight at 8:25, Eastern Standard Time.

title: IN JAPAN, THE LESS POPULAR MAN WINS
description: A JAPANESE political scientist, Keiichi Matsushita, wrote a few years ago that Japan should be considered a ''half democracy.''

title: ANOTHER HAYDN ENTERS THE LISTS
description: UNTIL RECENTLY, MICHAEL Haydn languished in almost total obscurity, remembered - when at all - in footnotes to the lives of either his elder brother, Joseph, or his Salzburg colleague and neighbor, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

title: IN THE NEW YORK SUBURBS POLITICS IS SURPRISINGLY VARIED
description: IN local elections next month, the New York suburban counties closest to New York City are likely to establish their political complexions for the next few years. But while Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland counties have certain demographic traits in common, they are not, as conventional urban wisdom might suggest, all peas in a Republican pod.

title: No Industrial Proletariat Need Apply
description: ENTERPRISING ELITE The Boston Associates and the World They Made. By Robert F. Dalzell Jr. Illustrated. 298 pp. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. $27.50.

title: FUMBLING SOONERS DROP COLORADO, 24-6
description: Jamelle Holieway, a quarterback, rushed for 146 yards tonight to help Oklahoma overcome a sluggish performance and beat Colorado, 24-6, in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: No Winning In This Strike
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SITE FOR ARTS CENTER CRITICIZED
description: ALTHOUGH Governor Kean's proposal to build a $200 million Cultural Arts Center here has drawn strong praise from the Newark Preservation and Landmarks Committee, it has urged that an alternative downtown site be chosen.

title: DEVILS WIN THE BATTLES, BUT ISLANDERS GET VICTORY
description: For the Islanders, a play that drew blood at the same time it produced a goal captured the evening completely. It was painful to watch, but hard to complain about when it was over.

title: OUR FOREIGN DEBT MAKES THE JOB DIFFICULT
description: THE turmoil in stock prices hassent a clear warning to Washington: United States economic stategies need to be overhauled fundamentally and quickly. We have lost control over our fiscal and monetary policies, which threatens to destabilize the economy and deprive us of the traditional tools for dealing with inflation and recession.

title: SOUTHAMPTON SEEKS APARTMENT SOLUTION
description: MAYOR WILLIAM J. HATTRICK JR. of Southampton has thrown his support behind a bill that would allow village residents to rent accessory apartments in their single-family homes.

title: N.Y.'S MIXED SUCCESS
description: Law enforcement officials in New York City, armed with one of the toughest gun statutes in the country, have seen a rapid increase in gun crimes this year and are seizing sophisticated automatic weaponry that was rarely seen in criminal hands as recently as 1985.

title: For Times Square, Light at the Mouth Of the Tunnel
description: THE BLOCKS AROUND TIMES Square look different right now from the way they have for the last 50 years, and the change is both exhilarating and depressing. The wave of high-rise construction just north of Times Square that the city's planners have long predicted has now begun to break on these concrete shores, and it is an extraordinary moment in the history of these blocks. No new construction has yet begun, but five immense sites have been nearly fully cleared, turning the area around Times Square into what it has not been for most of this century - a spectacular open space.

title: Court Blocks Damages in Suit By Daughter in Malpractice
description: Connecticut law does not allow a relative to seek damages from medical professionals for emotional distress caused by watching a loved one become ill and die, a Superior Court judge has ruled.

title: Yank Donations For Oxford U.
description: LIKE Gibraltar, Oxford University conjures up images of stability. But in January two of the school's officials were in New York City, painting a different picture.

title: SUCCESS SPOILS ANNUAL STREET FAIRS
description: LEAD: THE unmanaged success of some Long Island street fairs may be their biggest threat to survival. Last summer, Port Washington canceled its Harbor Day Festival. This fall, Roslyn is considering doing the same with next year's September sidewalk extravaganza.

title: INSIDE
description: NBC Strike Ends Two holdout union locals voted to accept the network's contract offer and the 2,800-member broadcast employees' union stopped picketing. Page 21. Football Poll Backs Owners Forty-six percent of people surveyed on the football strike backed the owners, 26 percent the players. Section 5. News Summary, page 2 Obituaries, page 38

title: SHEREE ROMANOFF ENGAGED
description: Sheree Joan Romanoff and Dr. Harvey Saul Gold plan to marry Jan. 2, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Allan H. Romanoff of Springfield, Pa., have announced. Miss Romanoff is a research associate at the JACA Corporation in Fort Washington, Pa. Dr. Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gold of North Brunswick, N.J., is a research chemist with the Du Pont Company in Wilmington, Del.

title: Reagan Backed 'Inverted Values,' Iran Panel Says in Tougher Draft
description: A new draft of the joint Congressional report on the Iran-contra affair is more critical of President Reagan than earlier versions and concludes that he supported an ''environment of inverted values'' and ''upside-down logic,'' according to Congressional officials.

title: TWINS RALLY TO SLAM CARDINALS AND FORCE A SENVENTH GAME
description: In the relative quiet of the early afternoon, while patrons were still beginning to fill the open spaces of the Metrodome, Don Baylor stood near the batting cage and talked about the task that faced the Minnesota Twins.

title: Bronze-Age Crafts With a Twist
description: SPIRALS - CAST, COILED, twisted, engraved and hammered - dominate among the forms and embellishments of the antiquities on view in ''Origins of Design: Bronze Age and Celtic Masterworks,'' at the Michael Ward gallery, 9 East 93d Street, through Dec. 15.

title: Divorce Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CANCER'S TOLL ON POOR STRESSED
description: LEAD: EVEN before he assumes the presidency of the American Cancer Society next year, Dr. Harold P. Freeman is traveling nationwide to speak about a subject he said should be as important to all Americans as it is to him: the disproportionate impact of cancer on the economically disadvantaged.

title: DR. DEBORAH A. DRISCOLL BECOMES BRIDE OF DR. CHRISTOS COUTIFARIS IN STAMFORD
description: At the Greek Orthodox Church of the Archangels in Stamford, Conn., Dr. Deborah A. Driscoll and Dr. Christos B. Coutifaris were married yesterday by the Rev. George Poulos.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Sent Dickie Noles, pitcher, to the Chicago Cubs as the player to be named later in the trade that brought him to Detroit. MINNESOTA (AL) - Claimed Dwight Lowry, catcher, on waivers from the Detroit Tigers. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Purchased the contract of Gilberto Reyes from Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. Sent Reggie Williams, outfielder; Ron Davis, pitcher, and Craig Shipley, shortstop, outright to Albuquerque. Activated Mariano Duncan and Len Matuszek, infielders, from the emergency disabled list.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Committee for the Advancement of Agricultural Research and Technology, chaired jointly by Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. of Bedminster and Nicholas G. Marotta of Watchung, will make recommendations to the Rutgers University board of governors on helping the state's agricultural and food technology businesses.

title: REAPING THE HARVEST
description: BETWEEN MID-SEPTEMBER AND early November, segments of rural France take on an air of anticipation, anxiety and celebration. It is vendange, the grape harvest, when the status of the grapes tells much about the wine for the year. But regardless of the grapes' condition, vendange is a time for a fete, which translates, quite naturally, into good food and good times.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE DEBATE BY NASSAU CANDIDATES
description: FOLLOWING are excerpts from a debate among the four candidates for Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, Republican-Conservative; Raymond B. Grunewald, Democrat; Jack Olchin, Liberal, and Dr. Raymond J. Vuolo, Right-to-Life Party. The candidates were questioned by reporters and editors at The New York Times. Shoreham

title: Jazz: Clare Fischer, Pianist, at Weill Hall
description: CLARE FISCHER, a jazz pianist who has spent most of his career in California, combined a celebration of his 59th birthday with his New York debut as a solo pianist on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall.

title: OFFICER KILLS MAN DURING DRUG RAID
description: A man was killed by the police yesterday when he reached for a toy gun from a shoulder holster during an undercover drug raid on a peep show near Times Square.

title: NANCY HARRIET COLES, PHYSICIAN, IS MARRIED
description: Dr. Nancy Harriet Coles, a resident in ophthalmology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, and Jeffrey Alan Goldstein, who is with the investment banking and financial advisory firm of James D. Wolfensohn Inc. in New York, were married last night at the Pierre in Manhattan. Rabbi David Wolpe performed the ceremony.

title: Verbatim; Nature and the Poor
description: 'Those who are poor and hungry will often destroy their immediate environment in order to survive.

title: DOLORES BARRETT WED TO EDWARD KLEIN
description: Dolores Barrett, the senior vice president of the public-relations firm of R. C. Auletta & Company in New York, and Edward Klein, former editor of The New York Times Magazine, were married yesterday. Justice Milton Mollen, the presiding justice of the Second Judicial Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of Kitty Carlisle Hart.

title: LUC R. VAN WAMBEKE WEDS ISABELLE KELLOGG
description: Isabelle Kellogg, a daughter of Mrs. Harry Bertschmann of Basel, Switzerland, and New York, and William Thompson Ong of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Luc Roland van Wambeke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Armand van Wambeke of Brussels. The Rev. William Hague performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Two New Sitcoms Forgo Musty Formulas
description: THINK OF JAMES STEWART AND W. C. Fields. That's one way of approaching the hour between 9 and 10 on Wednesday evenings on ABC, the hour that stars the enormously likable John Ritter as ''Hooperman'' and then switches to Dabney Coleman doing the misanthropic title character in ''The 'Slap' Maxwell Story.'' It adds up to, far and away, the best 60 minutes of the new season. The shows are innovative, outrageous and very funny, without benefit of laugh tracks. And taken together they constitute a package that could very well let Brandon Stoddard keep his job as ABC's head of programming beyond the current season. Here is Mr. Stoddard at his most impressive, attracting gifted performers, writers and producers, taking chances and running with the talent instead of musty formulas.

title: Prolific James Madison
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress; Last Weeks Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Persian Gulf: Initial vote on a proposal that would require a report from President Reagan on his Persian Gulf strategy within 30 days of enactment but would delay until late this year or early next a vote on the Administration's policy of convoying tankers in the Persian Gulf. Rejected 51 to 47, Oct. 21. 2. Persian Gulf: Second vote on the same proposal. Approved 54 to 44, Oct. 21. 3. Bork Nomination: Vote to approve the nomination of Robert H. Bork as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. Rejected 58 to 42, Oct. 23. 1 2 3 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Y N Weicker (R) N Y N Delaware Roth (R) Y Y Y Biden (D) N N N Maryland Mikulski (D) Y Y N Sarbanes (D) Y Y N Massachusetts Kennedy (D) N N N Kerry (D) N N N New Jersey Bradley (D) N Y N Lautenberg (D) Y Y N New York D'Amato (R) N N Y Moynihan (D) Y Y N Pennsylvania Heinz (R) Y Y Y Specter (R) Y Y N Rhode Island Pell (D) Y Y N Chafee (R) N N N Virginia Trible (R) N N Y Warner (R) Y Y N House 1.Special Prosecutor: Vote on an amendment to a bill to make permanent the law authorizing special prosecutors. title: NEW DATA ON WIMEN AND ADDICTS
description: EVEN retrospectively, the course of AIDS is not necessarily knowable. For one thing, although the findings are so stark and so hard to explain that researchers hesitate to say much, AIDS evidently kills women more rapidly than it kills men. And in New York, city health officials announced last week, it has killed more drug users than anyone had thought.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Las Vegas, Nev., last Sunday about air-traffic rules in Los Angeles misidentified the court where the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association has filed a lawsuit. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco.

title: PRINCETON ARCHITECT HONORED
description: LEAD: BOB DYLAN'S song ''The Times They Are a-Changin' '' was picked up by the New Jersey Society of Architects to echo the theme of its 87th convention and characterize the work of Michael Graves, recipient of six awards, including the society's highest, the Excellent in Architecture award.

title: JULIE ANN EPSTEIN IS WED TO STEVEN RUBIN, LAWYER
description: Julie Ann Epstein, a daughter of Mrs. Lannie Goodman of New York and Myron Epstein of Springfield, N.J., was married last evening to Steven Dennis Rubin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Rubin of Fall River, Mass. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton.

title: LEONOR F. LOREE 2d
description: Leonor F. Loree 2d, a retired vice chairman and director of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Thursday at the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital from complications of pneumonia. He was 73 years old and lived in Millington, N.J.

title: Sports of The Times; Hometown Herbie Ties It
description: FROM his bedroom window, when he was a boy, Kent Hrbek could see the lights of Metropolitan Stadium glimmering two miles in the distance.

title: VINDICATING EDSEL
description: THE FORDS An American Epic. By Peter Collier and David Horowitz. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: Summit Books. $22.95.

title: OTHER VOICES: Martin Marty; Everywhere, Paper Cities
description: Excerpts from an interview with Martin E. Marty, a professor of history of modern Christianity at the University of Chicago:

title: FOR BISHOPS AND SANDINISTAS, THERE'S NO RECONCILIATION
description: LEAFLETS circulating in some Nicaraguan war zones show a photograph of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra shaking hands with the Roman Catholic primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo. Behind the two men, who have been vigorous adversaries for years, is a Nicaraguan flag. The message is simple: ''Come home. Accept amnesty.''

title: NAVAJO WEAVING: MAJOR EXHIBITION IN MONTCLAIR
description: ''THE Song of the Loom,'' a major exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum, focuses on a little-known style of contemporary Navajo weaving.

title: FUROR IN CALCUTTA OVER A DRESS CODE
description: A prominent musician has been ousted from an exclusive club in Calcutta after he insisted on wearing Indian-style clothes and refused to follow the club's dress code, which favors casual or formal Western attire.

title: 2 (BUT NOT 3) CHEERS FOR ETHICS COMMITTEE
description: Re: ''Campaign Reforms Studied in Suffolk,'' Oct. 4:

title: TESTING ONE'S LIMITS AND GOING THE DISTANCE
description: I returned from Florida in time to read an article by Thomas Allen Stock, ''Crossing the Sound to Bike a Shrouded Shore - A Race With Myself to Test My Limits'' [ Opinion Page, Sept. 20 ] . I competed in a tennis tournament sponsored by the Du Pont Company, where I, too, had to utilize my capabilities to the fullest.

title: POLLYANNA, EX-BUBBLEHEAD
description: ELEANOR PORTER'S ''Pollyanna'' seems in our time to be a book few people have read but everyone dislikes because of its reputation. The American Heritage Dictionary defines a Pollyanna as ''a foolishly or blindly optimistic person.'' One postwar reference book describes Pollyanna Whittier as ''possibly the most exasperating heroine in fiction. . . . She seems the epitome of everything that is priggish and sentimental.''

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE EMPIRE BUILDERS: Inside the Harvard Business School. By J. Paul Mark. (Morrow, $17.95.) ''The Empire Builders'' is a gossipy collection of anecdotes about some top professors and deans at the Harvard Business School, which, by the way, I attended. It claims to be an expose of power abuse but tends more to be a catalogue of problems facing most prestigious graduate schools: overemphasis on outside consulting, overly ambitious deans, sexism, arrogance and preoccupation with fund-raising.

title: Visions and Voices of Wordsworth's World
description: THERE IS A FINE RING TO THE title of ''William Wordsworth and the Age of English Romanticism,'' an exhibition that opens Saturday at the New York Public Library. It is several things in one. Not only does it include the original manuscripts of some of the most famous poems in the English language, but also a large group of masterpieces by Constable, Turner and others that breathe the same unpolluted pre-industrial air.

title: ...AS GORBACHEV JOLTS REAGAN'S HOPES FOR A SUMMIT THIS YEAR
description: THE patient, plodding tempo of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's diplomacy has just carried him gamely through the Middle East and the Soviet Union in nine frustrating days, yielding only subtle accomplishments amid the overwhelming impression of defeat. He reported no progress in his efforts to revive the Middle East peace process. And in Moscow, he was stunned by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's refusal to set a date for visiting Washington. The Americans thought the Soviet leader had agreed last month to schedule the trip this year.

title: Beaumont Theater Puts Out a Magazine
description: ONE of the newest productions of the Vivian Beaumont Theater appears on paper rather than on stage.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: The Monterey Jazz Festival Sony Video Software. 60 minutes. $29.95. The breezy amiability of the Monterey Jazz Festival - the nation's oldest annual jazz jamboree - is captured effectively in these excerpts from the 26th edition of the California concert series, held in 1983. Yet, this same quality seems to have worked against the musicians recorded here, resulting in performances that are too often flippant, distant or dispassionate.

title: HIGH COURT FACES ALCOHOLISM ISSUE
description: Nearly 200 years after a Philadelphia physician first advanced the theory of alcoholism as a disease rather than merely a character weakness, the issue may be faced squarely by the Supreme Court.

title: Rangers Hang In to Defeat Pesky Flyers
description: The pattern, at least from the Rangers' viewpoint, became annoying by the third period when, for the third time, they saw their go-ahead goal counteracted by one from the Flyers. Then the Rangers broke the pattern on a devious shot by Walt Poddubny and a penalty shot by Jan Erixon to secure a 5-3 victory at the Spectrum.

title: DAVID MELLER, EXECUTIVE, WEDS WENDY S. FRUMKES
description: The marriage of Wendy Susan Frumkes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Frumkes of New York, to David Robert Meller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percival Meller of London, took place last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: Prepaid Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DRAMA
description: LEAD: Philip Marlowe Starring Powers Boothe. 1983. Playhouse Video. 54 minutes. $39.98. The gritty private eye Philip Marlowe is back on the job, but this time, as his creator Raymond Chandler might have observed, he's as warmed over as yesterday's hash-browns. Powers Boothe, who plays Marlowe with the verve of a metronome and a drawl of indeterminate origin, is asked by a police pal (played by William

title: MARIJUANA RAIDS CHASE CROP INSIDE
description: Vermont's marijuana growers, stung by police raids and irked by hikers and hunters who pick their buds, are increasingly cultivating the illegal weed indoors or resorting to guerrilla farming tactics, according to the police and other experts.

title: Reagan Studying a Short List Of Candidates for High Court
description: After the defeat in the Senate of Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination, President Reagan went to Camp David this weekend with a briefing book containing the names of about a dozen possible candidates for the seat, a senior White House aide said.

title: HOW INDEPENDENT SHOULD A PROSECUTOR BE?
description: THE House voted last week to extend the independent prosecutor law, a prospect that galls the Reagan Administration, which sees the law as unconstitutional and which also has present and former aides under investigation by at least six special prosecutors. A veto has been mentioned.

title: Order Backs Military Spouses on Taking Jobs
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the armed services to adopt a policy statement stressing the right of military spouses to take private jobs.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: MONITORING of noise from aircraft serving Newark International Airport should begin by the end of the year and be completed within six months, according to officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: ADVICE ON MAMOGRAMS IS USUALLY NOT TAKEN
description: ABOUT two months ago, Dr. Leonard Davis, a radiologist in private practice in West Los Angeles, offered to do mammograms at the cut-rate price of $50 for women working at a Rockwell International plant in the San Fernando Valley. Dr. Davis, a strong advocate of mammography, the diagnostic technique that detected Nancy Reagan's breast cancer, reasoned that the price would be a strong incentive, since the test normally costs $100 to $150. Because it is a routine screening procedure, insurance ordinarily does not pay for mammography.

title:
FROM THE WRITERS' CORNER: Four Voices;
E. L. Doctorow: Pumping Out Success
description: LEAD: I HAVE difficulty understanding what real contribution the stock market makes to the economy beyond the capital it provides companies upon their initial stock offerings. People bet against each other just as they do in a poker game. The money swirls around, changes hands, and eventually in the early morning hours of the history of the Republic somebody at the table realizes that when the sun comes up he will actually have to go out and go to work.

title: Navy Giving Submarines a New Missile Role
description: The Navy has quietly created a new mission for submarines - firing cruise missiles with high-explosive, nonnuclear warheads at military targets ashore, according to Pentagon officials.

title: COLLECTOR OF HOUDINIANA RECALLS MASTER OF MAGIC
description: LEAD: SATURDAY is not only Halloween, but also the 61st anniversary of the death of Harry Houdini, the great magician and escape artist, andmagicians observe the last week in October as Magic Week.

title: Looking for Safety in Dangerous Times
description: A MAJOR challenge facing small investors buffeted by the gyrations of the stock market last week is to figure out how to position their holdings for the long haul. Psychologically, if for no other reason, many experts say, this is a time for curbing your gambler's instincts and concentrating on such safe but unexciting investment vehicles as Treasury bills and bank certificates of deposit, spurning the more speculative investments such as options and commodity futures.

title: MS. STEWART MARRIES M. GEORGE STEVENSON
description: The marriage of Constance Mary Stewart, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Dalzell Stewart of Pittsburgh, to M. George Stevenson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Platt Stevenson of Salt Lake City, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. Bruce Wheeler Thielemann performed the ceremony.

title: FROM THE WRITERS' CORNER: Four Voices; Robert Coles: Children's Questions
description: MY work as a child psychiatrist keeps me in constant touch with young people, who have their own ways of indicating interest in the world, including the social or political or economic events that take place in it. Boys and girls are especially prone to respond to the more dramatic events in the news - wars, earthquakes, accidents, robberies or murders, and needless to say, athletic contests.

title: NEW STEPS URGED TO HELP CURB AIDS
description: A panel of Federal health experts is recommending a wide range of new steps to combat the AIDS epidemic and to provide health care for its victims.

title: Graham's Company Plays the Capitol
description: THE MARTHA GRAHAM dance company season that ends tonight opened on Oct. 6 with a celebrity-studded gala benefit performance that looked both backward to the hard-won glory of its past and forward to its future. That future is dependent, Graham company sources say, on greatly increased funding, much of which the company is attempting to secure by bypassing the National Endowment for the Arts and appealing directly to Congress. A $4.1 million appropriation for the company has already passed the Senate. Though the appropriation must still be acted upon by the House, the Graham company's tactics have already sparked controversy in the arts community.

title: Chaos in Lebanon Hampering Unicef's Work
description: The activities of Unicef, as well as those of other United Nations agencies in Lebanon, have been severely hampered by the depressed economy, deteriorating public services and terrorism, agency officials say.

title: A FAMILY OF FIRSTS
description: I, too, come from a family who loved ''firsts'' (''A Family of Firsts,'' by Patricia Volk, Oct. 4). My husband thought it was an affliction. My children even loved being first to use the peanut butter. In my family, the first to tell the good news was the ultimate. My dilemma now: should I be first to tell them that you published my letter, or should I let them read it and think they are the first to know? JOYCE Y. KEATING Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: MISS SAGE WEDS NICOLAS GRABAR
description: Jennifer Sage, an architect, and Nicolas Grabar, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York by Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court.

title: Opening a Window on the Market
description: NO personal computer could have prepared an investor for the wild ride the markets took last week. Even the Big Boys, using their Big Computers, were stunned by the magnitude of the tremors that shook Wall Street.

title: Music: Leinsdorf Leads Philharmonic and Bolet
description: FOR the first of his three New York Philharmonic subscription programs this season - the final repeat is scheduled for Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall - Erich Leinsdorf has surrounded the Grieg Piano Concerto with two symphonies that, while not unknown, still count as slightly off the beaten track. But it was the Grieg that was the highlight of the Friday afternoon performance.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Ansonia/Derby
description: FOR more than 200 years, what are now Ansonia and Derby, at the confluence of the Naugatuck and Housatonic Rivers in Connecticut, were a single unincorporated community. It was a thriving shipping and shipbuilding center from which sloops carried livestock and fish to the West Indies.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY ALBISON SMITH AND JOHN GORDON
description: The engagement of Harriet Allison Smith to John David Gordon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward T. Gordon of Milton and North Chatham, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Larry B. Smith of Marshville, N.C. The couple plan to marry in December.

title: Replay
description: It was, to use a phrase coined by Yogi Berra, deja vu all over again. Last week, for the fifth time since 1975, Billy Martin was named manager of the New York Yankees. It was the 15th managerial change in the 14 years that fiery George Steinbrenner has owned the club. Martin will replace Lou Piniella, who managed the Yanks to a fourth place finish in their division this year. Piniella is to be moved upstairs to the post of general manager, a station in which Steinbrenner has been known to store ex-managers until he feels like putting them back in uniform. Martin, who is known for his barroom scraps was well as for his scrappy brand of baseball, said he was anxious to ''bring back the winning tradition that our fans expect.''

title: Yearning to Breathe Free
description: Rules of procedure can look like lawyers' technicalities. But freedom often depends on whether the rules are fair. ''The history of liberty,'' Justice Felix Frankfurter said, ''has largely been the history of observance of procedural safeguards.''

title: A FAMILY OF FIRSTS
description: Those of us who read The New York Times Magazine know we'd better fill 'er up with high-octane wit at William Safire's station because it's nothing but High Seriousness for the next 100 miles or so. The exception was Patricia Volk's wonderful ''A Family of Firsts'' remembrance.

title: THE UPPER CRUST THAT CRUMBLED
description: DREAMS AND DELUSIONS The Drama of German History. By Fritz Stern. 323 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Jingle Bell Rock In an All-Star Anthology
description: SOMETIME AROUND MIDSUM-mer, about as far away psychologically from Christmas as one could possibly imagine, commercials appear for the annual Crazy Eddie Christmas sale. Readers may feel a similar sense of inappropriateness at the October appearance of a Christmas album. But marketing timetables being what they are, this seems to be the time to release such ventures, to judge from the host of Christmas products already in the stores.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
APPLE CIDER TIME
description: LEAD: STEVE ESTIS and his wife, Janice, were buying a pumpkin for their 1 1/2-year-old daughter, Samantha. Mr. Estis, a supervisor with a construction company, placed Samantha on his shoulders and let her survey the pile of pumpkins that seemed to glow in the sunlight. Samantha liked one the size of a large apple, and her mother obliged.

title: A Plain People's Bountiful Table
description: When William Penn offered haven to the persecuted of Europe, groups of Germanic Protestants accepted his offer and settled in the gently rolling countryside of Lancaster County in southeastern Pennsylvania. Though the people became known as the Pennsylvania Dutch, Dutch is a misnomer, a corruption of the word Deutsch, or German, the language that was spoken by Mennonites, followers of Menno Simons, and the Amish, followers of a Swiss Mennonite bishop, Jacob Amman.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belle Meadfe $196,000 25 Estate Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1 1/2-year-old town house; fireplace, deck, full basement; taxes $2,652. East Brunswick $195,000 54 Agate Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split; level; patio, fireplace in living room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,620. Maplewood $336,000 28 South Crescent 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, patio; taxes $4,775. Springfield $277,000 4 Tower Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; deck, C/A, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $2,586. Summit $500,000 60 Blackburn Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, fenced yard, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $4,779. Old Tappan $299,000 48 Wilbur Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, porch, finished basement, fireplace; taxes $2,661. OTHER AREAS Sherman, Conn. $172,500 Brinsmade Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; fireplace, 2-car garage, 1 acre, walk to town center; taxes $1,130. East Patchogue, L.I. $135,000 84 Durkee Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,100.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE PURSUIT OF GROWTH: The Challenges, Opportunities, and Dangers of Managing and Investing in Today's Economy. By G. Ray Funkhouser and Robert R. Rothberg. (Tempus/Microsoft Press, $17.95.) It seems that corporate growth is best achieved in moderation. At least that's the contention of G. Ray Funkhouser and Robert R.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
MITTS, COAL BAGS, HUDSON BAY SHAWLS
description: LEAD: Charles Department Store has been in the county since 1924, in Mount Kisco, then in Bedford Hills and, finally, in Katonah beginning in 1939. The store is run by the third generation of the original owner. It has an unusual range downstairs from oven mitts to ski mitts and clothes hangers to coal bags - with areas for stationery and gift wrapping; ribbons and notions; footwear and frames; pottery and baskets; kitchen and barbecue gadgets; television sets and service; magnifying glasses and small appliances.

title: CAROLYN LESLIE RYON WED TO THOMAS C. MAYERS 3D
description: Carolyn Leslie Ryon, a daughter of Kathleen Ferenbach Ryon of Stamford, Conn., and Mortimer Ryon of Solebury, Pa., was married yesterday to Thomas Crawford Mayers 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayers Jr. of East Northport, L.I. The Rev. Peter D. MacLean performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church on Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; More Wild Cards Needed for Pro Football Playoffs
description: WHISTLES blew. Officials in black-and-white striped shirts waved their arms. The football players wearing Jets and Dolphins uniforms peered out from behind their facemasks as if they were impostors whose real identities had been discovered. Which they were. In the fourth quarter at Giants Stadium last Sunday, all those imposters suddenly stood still. All 23 of them.

title: MARINA JACKSON WEDS C. B. FLINN
description: At Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., Marina Susanna Jackson, a daughter of Irina Jackson and Cyril Albert Jackson, both of Caracas, Venezuela, was married yesterday to Comrie Barr Flinn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Flinn of Kennett Square, Pa. The Episcopal service was performed by the Rev. William B. Lane and the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: MARTHA PALMER FERGUSON, A STUDENT, BECOMES THE BRIDE OF HORACE D. TAFT
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., Martha Palmer Ferguson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. M. Ferguson of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Horace Dutton Taft, a son of Mary Jane Taft of Atlanta and the late Horace D. Taft. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: A LITTLE VISIT WITH A BIG SURPRISE
description: WE went to South Jamesport on the North Fork seeking an uneventful holiday, a departure from normal rigors, a chance to gaze out at the bay and swim and read on the beach and nod off. We were not disappointed, but the visit revealed a large surprise nonetheless.

title: Conlon Nancarrow, On a Roll
description: STRING QUARTETS HE COM-posed 40 years ago are being dusted off and performed for the first time. The MacArthur Foundation has favored him with a ''genius grant,'' encouraging him to experiment further with his spiky, uncompromising music. A leading German recording label wants to record, for the first time, his complete works for piano.

title: ANOTHER BEAST AMONG US
description: The naturalists missed one beast [ ''Naturalists List the Beasts Among Us,'' Sept. 6 ] - the goundhog, also known as the woodchuck, or Marmota monax, whichever you prefer. I don't prefer them in my yard under any name.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SPACE, FINAL FRONTIER
description: LEAD: WANTED: One indoor space, 1,000 to 2,500 square feet; needs light but users will bring own heating equipment.

title: 'THE FANTASTICKS' STAGED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: THE story about, as the narrator introduces it, ''a boy, a girl, two fathers and a wall'' - otherwise known as ''The Fantasticks'' - is at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport for a spell. What else is new?

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: To me, some of the big losers in the football strike were the networks' TV announcers. These people in their attempts to disparage the play of the replacement players gave me the impression that they believe the N.F.L. regulars never drop a well-thrown pass, never jump offside, never miss a block, never throw an interception, etc.

title: MONTCLAIR STARTING TV TRAINING
description: BEGINNING tomorrow, Montclair State College and New Jersey Network will be training students in on-air television production.

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR A RETURN TO A WORK ETHIC
description: FROM Bruce Springsteen to Lee Iacocca to the I.L.G.W.U., we're all touting America these days.

title: EVERYTHING THIS STRANGE IS REAL
description: FORTY STORIES By Donald Barthelme. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: About Men; AN UGLY FEELING
description: NOT LONG AGO, I had the chance to work for several months on an archeological salvage ship looking for a sunken Spanish galleon. I had never even snorkeled before, but I soon became, at the age of 53, one of the ship's regular divers. My wife and daughter had encouraged me to try it. ''Chance of a lifetime,'' they said.

title: USING SLIDES OR PRINTS
description: A FRIEND familiar with my feelings about unedited vacation pictures had the temerity last week to ask to see my vacation snapshots. I blushed, shuffled my feet, and allowed as how I had used black-and-white film. Since I do the processing on my own, I explained, there were as yet no prints to look at.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Opportunity for Pro Sailors
description: The professional sailor, long considered an outcast in yachting's fraternity of amateurs, moved closer to the inside fold last week through bold initiatives by the sport's national authority.

title:
OTHER VOICES: Amitai Etzioni;
The Pols of Black Monday
description: LEAD: The following was written by Amitai Etzioni, a professor at the Harvard Business School.

title: Correction
description: An article about Yiddish in The Week in Review Oct. 11 incorrectly described the publication of ''The Great Yiddish Dictionary.'' The four volumes that have been published were prepared under the supervision of lexicographers at the City College of the City University of New York and the Hebrew University. The City College role was assumed by Columbia University in 1981.

title: A Beagle in Love
description: SNOOPY'S GETTING MARRIED, CHARLIE BROWN Kartes Video Communications. 25 minutes. $11.95.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE RENEWAL FACTOR: How the Best Get and Keep the Competitive Edge. By Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Bantam, $19.95.) Can corporate managers give up the notion that change is something they do only when they are forced to? That's among the challenges Robert H. Waterman Jr., the co-author of ''In Search of Excellence,'' issues in ''The Renewal Factor.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Hempstead Opens Tap on Development
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT in Nassau County almost came to a halt late last year after the state's Department of Environmental Conservation placed limits on the amount of water the county's 41 water suppliers could pump out of the ground. Most water districts began denying water hook-up permits to any sizable new projects.

title: Music View; A TALE OF TWO OPERAS, OR WHEN NOT TO INTERFERE
description: ABOUT HALFWAY INTO THE first scene of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Rheingold'' on opening night, I became aware that surprisingly little of the staging was distracting my attention from Wagner's own shrewd way of telling his tale of moral decay and betrayal. So hardened have we become to seeing directors and designers intrude their daring little persons into opera productions that the absence of conceptual handstands and theatrical back flips can now be startling. Instead, as the premiere unfolded, I found myself absorbed as seldom before in the musical and narrative flow of this prelude to the ''Ring,'' which the Otto Schenk production was managing to clarify without resorting to cartoon jokes or specious updating. Not once during the evening did Loge pull out the Harvard Law Review. Alberich the exploiter of the colonial masses did not dress up as Uncle Sam or John Bull. Wotan and Fricka were depicted as epic but recognizably human figures, not as soapy caricatures of Ron and Nancy playing scenes from ''Dallas.'' (If no ''Ring'' director has thought of those images as yet, forgive me for suggesting them.) Nowadays, I am always taken aback to find a director showing faith enough in an opera to let the composer and his librettist have it their way. In this ''Rheingold,'' I found myself willingly overlooking many a minor flaw that might have drawn heavy, scornful attention in a more faddish staging. Take the bit of business in which Loge and Wotan trick Alberich into turning himself into a toad so they can capture him and steal his gold. This is one of those transformation scenes whose magical effect the perfect, unreconstructed Wagnerite waits for with childlike expectation, usually in vain. It should not be difficult to manage lighting cues and trapdoors so that the conspirators' net is thrown over a tiny, toady object that thereafter grows immediately into the larger toad known as Alberich. But here the trick was botched again: Alberich already appeared full-grown (or as full-grown as a dwarf can be) by the time the net fell on him. But, in the context of a seriously conceived and remarkably well sung ''Rheingold,'' such details almost deserve to be ignored.

title: Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
description: The N.F.L. strike is not over. Management will find that the negotiation of a labor contract requires give and take.

title: IN SCARSDALE, A DIG REVEALS THE PAST
description: THE Wayside Cottage is a Scarsdale landmark that has occupied its present site on the corner of Post Road (Route 22) and Wayside Lane since the early 18th century. Listed in the National Register of Historic Places, the cottage not only served as home to early Westchester families but also was used, at various times, as an inn and tavern (becoming for a while the hub of the area's social and cultural life), a church school, the headquarters of the Scarsdale Equal Suffrage Club, a community garden during World War I, a newspaper office and village library.

title: Music
description: This is a good week for vocal fans. Sunday, Carnegie Hall devotes itself entirely to singing. At 3 P.M. Leontyne Price will sing a varied program to benefit the United Negro College Fund, and at 8,the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which has for 12 years supported upcoming singers, will stage a gala concert conducted by Richard Bonynge and Daniel Oren, with members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra. The cast of singers includes Hildegard Behrens, Jose Carreras, Alfredo Kraus, Pilar Lorengar, Eva Marton, Sherrill Milnes, Samuel Ramey and Joan Sutherland. Harry Dworchak, winner of the 1987 Tucker award, will also be featured. At last report, balcony seats were still available.

title: Dance
description: More than 100 dancers, choreographers, musicians, writers and performance artists are taking part in a round-the-clock benefit for New York's hungry and homeless on Sunday at the Kiva Studio, 309 Canal Street. Viewers can come and go without reservations, and newcomers will be seated at appropriate breaks in the proceedings; a donation is requested. The gala, which also includes a raffle of art works, continues from midnight until approximately 8 P.M., and proceeds will benefit the Food and Hunger Hotline, a citywide program that assists families and individuals without food or money to buy food.

title: Measuring by Footage, Instead of Rooms
description: NEW YORK CITY is big. It's big in size; more than 300 square miles. It's big in people; more than seven million. It's big in buildings; more than 800,000. And it's big in apartments; more than two million.

title: Maryland Resort Bans High-Rise Construction
description: Not many people head for a beach resort to sit in the shade.

title: ILLINI BLOCK KICK, TIE MICHIGAN ST.
description: Scott Davis, an Illinois defensive end, blocked a last-second 28-yard field-goal attempt by Michigan State's John Langeloh to preserve a 14-14 tie in the Big Ten Conference game today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: OFFICIALS of the Seattle SuperSonics said that Dale Ellis, the guard who had been seeking a better-paying contract, had decided to abandon the effort for the time being and to play out the option year of his old contract before resuming his quest as a free agent. . . Jim Peterson, a forward for the Houston Rockets, underwent surgery to remove bone spurs from his left ankle and will be out for up to six weeks. . . . Jackie Joyner-Kerse, the heptathlon and long jump champion who won the 1986 Jesse Owens Award as the nation's top track and field athlete, is one of five world champions who have been nominated for the 1987 award. Others are Carl Lewis, the sprinter and long jumper, the hurdlers Edwin Moses and Greg Foster, and Mike Conley, the triple jumper.

title: FUTURE SHOCK IN HONG KONG
description: ONCE UPON A TIME THE BRIT-ish, masters of half the world, built a modest palace for the Governor of their easternmost possession, Hong Kong, which they had acquired as booty of the Anglo-Chinese Opium War of 1839-42.

title: HOSPITALS TRY NEW STRATEGIES TO ATTRACT AND KEEP NURSES
