description: LEAD: REFLECTING a trend that has been evident in other parts of the state and country, many Westchester hospitals are facing a growing shortage of nurses. While some administrators call the shortage critical, others say it is not too serious now but will be felt more severely in a few years. An informal survey of hospitals in the county suggests that the need for nurses has already resulted in keen competition and motivated hospitals to develop new strategies to attract and retain nursing staff.

title: EVEN FOOTBALL PLAYERS FIND LABOR'S GLORY HAS FADED
description: Vanquished in their three-week strike, the behemoths of the National Football League Players Association carry back to gridirons across the country today an expensive lesson in labor-management gamesmanship - one that has become painfully familiar in recent years to tens of thousands of their less affluent fellow tenants in the battered House of Labor.

title: Music: From Japan, Goro Yamaguchi
description: GORO YAMAGUCHI'S 1968 Nonesuch album ''A Bell Ringing in the Empty Sky'' introduced the sound of the shakuhachi, a Japanese bamboo flute, to many Western listeners. On that album, Mr. Yamaguchi's command of the instrument's varied textural resources conspired with a vivid, intimate recording to give the music a big, almost cinematic sound. At the Asia Society on Thursday, Mr. Yamaguchi's performances of traditional and classical shakuhachi music did not sound quite so epic, but they were no less captivating.

title: SAVING THE 'SLEEPY HOLLOW' CHURCH
description: THE church has stood on the same grassy knoll for 302 years, surrounded by the locust trees and ''lofty elms,'' through which, as Washington Irving wrote, ''peeks may be caught at the blue hills of the Hudson.''

title: Firebombs Thrown at Korea Candidate
description: Protesters hurling firebombs today attacked the motorcade of Roh Tae Woo, the governing party's presidential candidate, as he drove in an open jeep to a campaign rally in this central city.

title: Protecting Trees In Lake Forest
description: PEOPLE in Lake Forest, Ill., take trees seriously. For eight consective years, the National Arbor Day Foundation has designated the community ''Tree City, U.S.A.'' because of the profuse planting and nurturing of trees by its 17,000 residents.

title: THROWING MONEY ACCURATELY
description: GOVERNMENT FOR THE PEOPLE The Federal Social Role: What It Is, What It Should Be. By Forrest Chisman and Alan Pifer. 316 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: IN SHORT
description: WHAT SHOULD BANKS DO? By Robert E. Litan. (Brookings Institution, Cloth, $26.95; Paper, $9.95.) Not since just after the Depression has there been so much talk about the need to restructure the nation's financial system. Several grand plans have been suggested, but perhaps none so intriguing as that put forward by Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, in ''What Should Banks Do?'' The book will be bedtime reading only for the Paul Volckers and Walter Wristons of this world, but Mr. Litan, nevertheless, offers a highly readable history of banking regulation, a discussion of the pros and cons of further deregulation and credible arguments why his concept of banking might work. This concept -''narrow banking'' or safe banking - involves splitting banks as we know them into two distinct entities. The narrow bank is essentially a Government-insured money-market fund, through which the bank takes deposits and invests in Government securities. Since the Government is considered fail-safe, there's no risk here to the public's deposits, and bank failures would be almost nonexistent. The other part of the bank, in Mr. Litan's scheme, would be nearly totally deregulated. It would be free to do everything banks now do, such as business and consumer lending, and everything else it might want to do, from underwriting to real estate developing, even manufacturing. The Litan formula answers many concerns about the further deregulation of banking, but implementing it would be a radical step for a halting Congress.

title: Notebook; COSTLY INJURY IN GYMNASTICS
description: The United States' chances of winning a medal in men's gymnastics in the 1988 Seoul Olympics were virtually cut in half Thursday, when Tim Daggett landed badly on a vault at the world gymnastics championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Worse yet, Daggett's career may be over.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Travel Advisory on Sept. 6 described the Carte pass incorrectly. It provides entry to Paris museums and attractions at reduced admission, but not free.

title: Press Notes; U.P.I. in Impasse Over Contract With Guild
description: United Press International may be moving toward yet another crisis in its long and troubled struggle to survive.

title: Washington Talk: Bui Diem; A VOICE FROM VIETNAM HOPING TO BE HEARD
description: In the 12 years since the fall of Saigon, Bui Diem, South Vietnam's last Ambassador to Washington, has been a bit of a jack-of-all-trades: professor, writer, lecturer and, for one two-year period, a dispenser of pastrami and corn beef at Goldberg's Deli in northwest Washington.

title: Piano: Juliana Osinchuk
description: THE first entry in Juliana Osinchuk's piano program at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night pretty much summed up the solid attractions of this young Juilliard graduate. Beethoven's C-minor Variations represents rigorous organization expressed with passionate expansiveness. Miss Osinchuk's playing reached this equipoise. She sees clearly and trusts her feelings to bend phrases expressively without shattering their momentum.

title: Aquino's Mixed Success
description: LEAD: Corazon Aquino, who came to the Presidency in the Philippines on her own bravery and the votes of courageous Filipinos, has had a year and a half to experience the gall of power as well as its glory. Her tough speech to the Filipino business community last week shows that her learning curve is spiking up again, in its constant race with curves of expectation and opposition.

title: Nuclear-Waste Bill Doesn't Guard Ground Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Few Japanese-Americans Were Actually Interned; A Sense of Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Therapist to Therapist: Analyzing Dr. Ruth
description: The psychoanalyst and the analysand sat in facing black leather chairs. There was, of course, a couch. ''God forbid,'' muttered the real Dr. Ruth Westheimer, as distinct from the media personality, ''I would never lie on the couch.''

title: Wilbur D. Curtis Dies at 82; Inventor of Glass Coffee Pot
description: Wilbur Darby Curtis, the inventor of the glass coffee pot and a fiber glass-bodied automobile, the Shamrock, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 82 years old. He had been ill since August, when he suffered a stroke at his home here, according to his son-in-law, A. James Liska of Agoura.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 14 about European American Bancorp misstated the company's expected fourth-quarter provision for loan losses in the third world. The amount is expected to be $120 million to $130 million, leading to a loss of $115 million to $120 million for the quarter, and a loss of $85 million to $100 million for the year.

title: Market Turmoil; The Hours That Changed The World of Wall Street
description: The face of Wall Street has been permanently changed.

title: 20% Rise in B-1 Bomber Cost Is Reported in G.A.O. Study
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today that the Air Force's new B-1 bomber would cost over 20 percent more to bring into service than originally forecast by the Reagan Administration.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Writing to Live

title: Poetry Reading
description: Julie Agoos and Sharon Bryan will read from their poems on Nov. 4 at 6:30 P.M. at the Poetry Society of America, 15 Gramercy Park, near 20th Street between Park Avenue South and Third Avenue. The free reading begins a new series devoted to emerging writers. Information: 254-9628.

title: Meet Moscow Halfway in Space
description: America was thrown into an understandable panic when the Soviet Union launched its Sputnik, the first space satellite, 30 years ago. But Washington is overreacting to the latest shocking space threat from Moscow - an offer to launch payloads at unbeatable prices, and to sell photographs of Earth far sharper than those from Western civilian satellites.

title: U.S. Drug 'Crusade' Is Seen as Undermining Itself
description: Not enough is being done to assure that $200 million allocated for drug education last year is being used to establish effective programs in primary and secondary schools. Research indicates that the wrong type of curriculum can be ineffective or even harmful.

title: Twins, Perfect at Home, Win Series
description: From the beginning, they were an improbable team with an improbable chance. The players were gifted but woefully short on experience, the manager was merely the youngest among his peers.

title: All Options Firms Pass Cash Test
description: The chairman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the nation's largest stock options exchange, said yesterday that as of the end of last week, all of its clearing firms, numbering about 50, had enough money to meet their obligations under the exchange's regulations.

title: FULL DECK OF CARDS MISSING
description: When it was over, when the St. Louis Cardinals had lost the World Series in the final two games for the second time in three years, Whitey Herzog reflected on the slings and arrows of fortune in the big leagues.

title: Soviet Partly Lifts Veil on Its Past, Exciting Many but Irking Others
description: With the approach of the 70th anniversary of the Revolution on Nov. 7, the Soviet Union is engaged in a fractious exploration of long-veiled chapters in its history.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coats Viyella Knitwear Inc. appointed Iran Cagan senior vice president, finance and administration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 China must restructure its economy at a more intense pace if the country is to escape its poverty, the acting head of the Chinese Communist Party, Zhao Ziyang, told the opening session of the 13th Party Congress in Beijing. Page A1

title: Latecomer Becomes a Fast Finisher
description: THE afternoon sabbatical included a walk on a quiet street, only a couple of blocks from the boardwalk that reminded them of villages on the English coast. Priscilla Welch prompted her husband, David, to bring his wallet so they could buy more tea, an absolute must last Wednesday, a cool, gray and blustery autumn day. Perhaps they would also stop at the bakery they had discovered the day before, their first on the Jersey shore. David Welch, in particular, liked that idea.

title: The U.N. Today Oct. 26, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Tool Orders Jumped 29% Last Month
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rebounded significantly in September, rising 29 percent from the previous month's level, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: College Football; Clemson Hits Bump On Road to Success
description: For Clemson, the road ahead seemed golden. The Tigers were unbeaten after six games, ranked high in the polls and projected as a major-bowl participant with a chance at the national championship.

title: Survival Test Makes a City A Wilderness
description: A frigid autumn night had fallen over the high grass of the Gateway National Recreation Area in southeastern Brooklyn, and Ary Hernandez was alone.

title: Music: Chamber Works
description: FOUR musicians joined under the auspices of Mid-America Productions to give a program of American chamber music Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. It began with Ives's Fourth Violin Sonata, played with feeling, though Stephen Brown did not do enough to give definition and variety of texture to the wonderful piano part. Mr. Brown made a better impression in Robert Helps's 1966 ''Portrait For Solo Piano,'' a strongly etched, impressive piece. In Henry Cowell's ''Three Ostinati With Chorales'' for oboe and piano, Harry Sargous caught the pensive melancholy that runs through this outwardly flowing music, but the piano parts again lacked a certain incisiveness, especially in the burst of impersonal irishry that Cowell tacks on for a finale.

title: A Scholar's Suicide: Trying to Spare a Family Anguish
description: Richard Schlatter was the sort of man whose vitality and hunger for experience awed and even disconcerted his many friends and proteges. His journey from a small town in Ohio to Harvard and Oxford Universities, a Rhodes scholarship and adult prominence as a scholar and administrator at Rutgers University seemed to them a function of the life force itself.

title: Few Japanese-Americans Were Actually Interned
description: To the Editor:

title: Buyback Programs: Bid for Confidence
description: All over the United States last week, hundreds of corporate boards surveyed the devastating damage to their companies' share prices and decided on the same action: announce a stock buyback program.

title: General Motors Pact Accepted
description: United Automobile Workers members overwhelmingly approved a new three-year contract with the General Motors Corporation that protects union jobs while freeing management to seek less restrictive work rules, the union announced tonight.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply In Tokyo
description: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted today, but then recovered some of their losses late in the session in roller-coaster trading that apparently reflected worries here about Wall Street's health.

title: Western Union Profit
description: The Western Union Corporation on Friday reported a third-quarter profit of $2.6 million, in contrast to a $46.5 million loss in the comparable quarter a year ago.

title: Correcftions
description: A picture caption last Tuesday, with an article about films on the Hollywood blacklisting of the 1950's, misidentified the man at the left in a scene from ''The House on Carroll Street.'' He was William Sturgis.

title: Twins Too Weary to Cheer
description: In the back corner of a triumphant, champagne-soaked Minnesota Twins' dressing room, Greg Gagne and Tom Brunansky stood quietly and answered reporters questions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1987
description: The Stock Market Turmoil

title: Those Pyramid People Stretch Their Dollars
description: The Transamerica Corporation built its skinny pyramid of a headquarters in San Francisco and then, so it should not be a total loss, converted it into its corporate symbol as well. It became a star of all company advertising.

title: Los Angeles Is Shaken By Pacific Earthquake
description: An earthquake centered offshore was felt in Southern California on Saturday, the authorities reported.

title: Redskins Get Rare Reaction
description: The Washington Redskins heard a yell directed at them today that they had not heard for years on their home field: ''Boo!''

title: Property Claims Paid by Air Force At $50,427 in Indianapolis Crash
description: The Air Force had paid $50,427 as of noon today on 55 property claims stemming from the crash of a military jet that killed nine employees at a hotel here last Tuesday.

title: In 2 Other Assault Cases, No Resolution Yet
description: As the Howard Beach trial proceeds, two other incidents of ethnic or interracial violence that occurred in Queens at about the same time are working their way through the legal system.

title: Opera: Changes in 'Tosca'
description: TWO promising singers joined the cast of ''Tosca'' at the New York City Opera Saturday evening, and made an impression despite lackluster dramatic conditions and eccentric musical ones.

title: Rate Drop May Produce More Issues
description: Last week's sudden decline in interest rates led to a flurry of new issues in the corporate market, a trend that may continue this week, analysts said.

title: TV Review; 'THE STORYTELLER,' WITH JOHN HURT
description: FEARNOT is an amiable young man who spends a great deal of time playing the violin under his sweetheart's window. His father, a tailor, is not amused, especially when Fearnot botches an expedition to fetch a shipment of buttons. The old man kicks his son out of the house, giving him 40 shillings and an order to learn something responsible. Fearnot, totally fearless, decides he would like to learn how to be afraid, how to shudder like other ordinary mortals.

title: Dance: Graham Troupe In 'Judith' and 'Rite'
description: WHO would have thought the vulnerable nonconformist of Martha Graham's ''Heretic,'' performed just a few days earlier, could so believably become the murderous heroine of Miss Graham's ''Judith''? Or that the wild lover of ''Acts of Light'' would turn up again as the embodiment of Spring? Miss Graham is full of surprises, but so are her dancers, as they demonstrated in performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Friday and Saturday nights at City Center.

title: Concert: The Pittsburgh
description: THOSE who have watched the Pittsburgh Symphony closely over the years wonder with some regret why it does not enjoy a bigger reputation. One wondered more so after yesterday's impressive afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Judy Schaer Is Wed to Dr. Philip J. Wilner on L.I.
description: Judy Schaer, a pediatric occupational therapist, and Dr. Philip Jonathan Wilner, the chief resident psychiatrist at the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue by Rabbi Haskel Lookstein.

title: Sandinistas Pressed on 2 Key Points
description: With less than two weeks to go until the new Central American peace accord comes into force, political and diplomatic pressure is building on Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders to take two steps.

title: Just One More Tremor For California Investors
description: Around here, people know what a real earthquake is, and sometimes that helps put the stock market in perspective.

title: Many Wary on Impact Of B.P. Offering Now
description: Britain's planned sale on Friday of its 31.5 percent stake in the giant British Petroleum Company is creating concern among international financiers that the offering could set off another dramatic plunge in the London stock market.

title: MARYLAND STRAW POLL IS CAPTURED BY BUSH
description: Bice President Bush overwhelmed his oppo-nents in a Presidential straw poll Sat-urday at the Maryland Republican con-vention, but his opponents complained that the victory was tainted.

title: India Says Tamils Escaped Siege
description: The commander of Indian troops in Sri Lanka said today that most of the separatist Tamil fighters who held out against the Indian Army here for 16 days had escaped into the jungle.

title: Kate Turabian Dies; Author of Stylebook About Dissertations
description: Kate L. Turabian, author of one of the most widely read stylebooks on dissertations, died yesterday morning in her sleep at a retirement home in Los Angeles. She was 94 years old.

title: Mexico Trade Accord Near
description: Commerce Secretary Hector Hernandez says the United States and Mexico will soon sign an agreement creating a mechanism for resolving trade disputes between the two nations, according to the Government newspaper El Nacional.

title: Campaign Finance; PAC's Devise Bylaws To Limit Their Giving
description: When Senator Paul S. Trible Jr. announced last month that he would not seek re-election in 1988, he infuriated many political action committees that had helped him build a $1.4 million war chest for a campaign that was not to be.

title: Stage: 'Swing,' by Elizabeth Swados
description: IN ''Runaways,'' Elizabeth Swados created an exhilarating musical collage about the dreams and nightmares of children on city streets. In her new show, ''Swing,'' which opened Saturday in the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, she uses similar theatrical techniques on related subject matter with a result that could be characterized as nebulous. ''Swing'' is less a musical than an exercise in work process.

title: This Time Rangers Take On Hextall
description: The Flyers began their season on a note of complaint, and after being defeated by the Rangers, 5-3, at the Spectrum on Saturday night, their only solace was the promise of the return of their suspended goaltender, Ron Hextall, for the rematch between the division rivals at the Garden tonight.

title: David Sinclair Is Dead; Researcher in Physics
description: David Sinclair, a retired research physicist and a son of Upton Sinclair, the American writer and journalist, died Saturday of lung cancer at Cabrini Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Martinsville, N.J., and Manhattan.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Personal Income... Sept. Tuesday Durable Goods... Sept. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday New Home Sales... Sept. Leading Indicators... Sept.

title: A Fire Set for Training Firefighters Is Fatal to 3
description: A training session for volunteer firefighters turned deadly today, killing three volunteer firefighters and seriously burning a fourth as they tried to put out a controlled fire in an old farmhouse.

title: Recognition Eludes World War II Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Budget Is Issue For Harris's Chairman
description: The Harris Corporation, less than a month after denying reports that it might be acquired by Britain's largest electronics manufacturer, announced last Friday that John T. Hartley had been elevated to the post of chairman of the board.

title: To Texans, Plunge Is Familiar
description: While Texans watched the stock market collapse with the same mix of horror and puzzlement as the rest of the country, there was also a disquieting element of familiarity. Texas is used to booms and busts. ''A blind man could have seen the Dallas real estate market was overbuilt, but people kept building,'' said Shad Rowe, an investment adviser who heads Rowe & Company there. ''The same thing happened with the stock market.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Flying With the Contras
description: When Nicaraguan rebel leaders met with Republican senators this month, they asked whether some legislators would accompany them in their attempt to return to Managua to negotiate a cease-fire with the Sandinista Government.

title: Esther B. Fein Is Wed To David Jay Remnick
description: Esther Beth Fein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman William Fein of Monsey, N.Y., was married last night to David Jay Remnick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Remnick of Hillsdale, N.J. Rabbi Nachum Muschel, assisted by Rabbi Andre Ungar, performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; When Writers Rally
description: Writers think their tax problems are different from General Motors, but they have found that recent changes in the law treat their words like so many cylinders and spark plugs, and so they plan to rally today to try to get the law amended.

title: Koch Plans Job Benefits To Cut Relief
description: By BRUCE LAMBERT

title: A Business Lobby for Public Education
description: There, testifying at a joint hearing of the Senate and House Education committees last spring, were the senior officers of Alcoa, A.T. & T., the State Street Bank of Boston, the Pacific Telesis Group of Los Angeles and Primerica Corporation. They were not pressing for tax breaks and such but to increase funds for remedial education. According to Representative Augustus Hawkins, the voices of the businessmen counted in the House vote to extend and expand Chapter 1 of the Elementary and Secondary School Act for Disadvantaged Youth.

title: Jaffa Journal; Israel Tunes In in Force to Its Tuned-In Soldiers
description: The day was dragging in the studios of the Israeli Army radio, so the music editor, who was on the air, decided to liven up his show by making a statement about political trends in Israel.

title: Article 809187 -- No Title
description: Each of the Minnesota Twins earned $85,580.97 tonight for winning the World Series. The share fell just short of the record $86,254 earned last season by each member of the Mets.

title: How the Other Half Lives: A U.S.-Soviet Study
description: Americans spend more time eating and tending to their appearance than Russians, but Russians sleep more than Americans. Americans spend more time cleaning their homes; Russians do more cooking and laundry. Americans watch more television; Russians spend more time on child care.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Holiday Observations
description: As Halloween approaches, the United States Naval Observatory's newsletter, shifting its vision from the heavens, has some insights about the origin of the jack-o'-lantern.

title: People
description: * Cheryl Lodinger has been promoted to executive vice president at AC&R/ DHB & Bess Advertising.

title: Moment of Hope Is Finishing Fast
description: Moment of Hope completed a weekend of short-priced stakes winners at Aqueduct by taking the $181,800 Stuyvesant Handicap yesterday by 1 1/2 lengths over Wind Chill.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Edberg Upsets Lendl: In a showdown between the world's top two tennis players, second-ranked Stefan Edberg of Sweden upset top-ranked Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday for the $60,000 first prize in the $375,000 Seiko Super Classic in Tokyo. Edberg played his usual serve-and-volley game before a crowd of 11,000 on the Supreme Court of the Yoyogi National Stadium, while Lendl played mostly from the baseline. The two traded service breaks in the third and fourth games of the first set before it went to a tiebreaker, which Lendl, blasting powerful serves, won 7-4.(AP) Sabatini Triumphs: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina won her third career title when she upset top-seeded Pam Shriver, 7-5, 6-4, in the final of the $200,000 Volvo Classic women's tournament in Brighton, England. The 17-year-old Sabatini, who earned $40,000, captured the championship after twice being behind and having to save a set point in the first set. Shriver, the world's No. 5 player, dominated the early part of the match with her serve-and-volley game, racing to a 4-0 lead. But then her serve began to let down, and Sabatini hit back.(AP) Grand Prix to Swede: Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden rallied to beat Amos Mansdorf of Israel, 1-6, 1-6, 6-2, 6-3, 7-5, and win a $155,000 Grand Prix tournament in Vienna. Mansdorf, seeded sixth, appeared on his way to victory after easily capturing the first two sets. But Svensson, seeded fifth, rebounded to win the match and the $25,000 top prize. More than 30,000 spectators attended the tournament at the Vienna Stadthalle, a record in the event's 13-year history.(AP) Pate Wins Exhibition: David Pate of the United States beat Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-3, 6-4, today in the final of the $70,000 round-robin Carragreen Challenge exhibition event at Chase Stadium in Auckland, New Zealand. The result was a disappointing outcome for Evernden, who eliminated the Wimbledon champion, Pat Cash, from the series Saturday, despite a severely strained left knee. Pate, 25 years old, went through the first four-day event without dropping a set.(AP) Golf Reid Rallies to Win: Mike Reid came from four strokes back with five-under-par 67 and scored the first victory of his 11-year PGA Tour career yesterday in the Tucson Open golf tournament. Reid, 33 years old, took advantage of Fuzzy Zoeller's front-side troubles to gain a share of the top spot, then pulled away from Hal Sutton on the back side of the new T.P.C. course at Star Pass. The soft-spoken Reid won his first title with a 268 total, 20 strokes under par.(AP) Seniors to Geiberger: Al Geiberger shot a course record 10-under-par 62 yesterday to capture the $250,000 PGA Las Vegas senior classic. Geiberger, who holds the career PGA mark for 18 holes with a round of 59, had eight birdies and an eagle to better the old Desert Inn Country Club course record by two shots.(AP) Gymnastics 4 Medals for Russian: Aurelia Dobre of Rumania and Dmitri Bilozerchev of the Soviet Union added individual titles to their all-around crowns yesterday in the world gymnastics championships at Rotterdam, the Netherlands. But a dethroned champion outshone them both. Elena Shoushounova, at 18 the veteran of a young Soviet team, who was co-world champion in 1985, finished second this year to Dobre. However, Shoushounova won four medals yesterday, including golds in the vault and floor exercise. She also won a silver in the balance beam and a bronze in the uneven bars. Shoushounova and Daniela Silivas of Rumania tied for first place in the floor exercise, earning perfect 10's throughout the three rounds of competition. Bilozerchev, the 1983 champion, returned to the world championships after a career-threatening car accident in 1985 in which he fractured his left leg. He won six medals over all, four of them golds, and won his second world all-around crown.(AP) Dog Show Pekingese Is Best: Kay Jeffords's home-bred sable-colored Pekingese, Ch. Shinnecock of Chinatown, yesterday was named best in show at the Progressive Dog Club's 55th annual all-toy fixture at Loew's Summit Hotel. Discussing the 17-month-old dog, the judge, Sari Brewster Tietjen, said, ''He's in gorgeous bloom, has a big broad head and has all the stubbornness and arrogance so desirable in the breed.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have had commentators from Wall Street on television saying this is a flash in the pan. They aren't going down very well.'' - Alan Butler-Henderson, of the London brokerage of Hoare Govett Ltd. (D9:1.)

title: CABARET: A REVUE SAMPLER
description: A NIGHTCLUB act made up of songs from musical revues might be expected to focus primarily on the 1920's and 30's when revues flourished, when George Gershwin's scores for ''George White's Scandals'' included such songs as ''Somebody Loves Me'' and Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart wrote ''Mountain Greenery'' for ''The Garrick Gaieties.'' But Anya Turner and Robert Grusecki, who explored lesser-known revue songs of the past eight decades in a program called ''One Damn Thing After Another'' on Thursday evening at Jan Wallman's Restaurant Cabaret, found some of their best material in revues of recent years.

title: The 10th Man of the Twins
description: IT'S too late to change the ballots now. Besides, how could you invite an entire stadium, with its 55,376 resident jet engines, to the awards banquet?

title: Metro Matters; Turmoil at 1199: Union Wrestles With Its Demons
description: The mosaic mural at the entrance to the hospital workers' union headquarters on West 43d Street idealizes teaching, health care and racial harmony and recalls the credo of Frederick Douglass, the 19th-century abolitionist.

title: U.S. Plays Down Eagerness for a Summit Meeting
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States might not want a summit meeting if Mikhail S. Gorbachev waits too long in setting a date for it.

title: A Season Of Worry For Philanthropies
description: Charitable giving, traditionally high in the holiday season, could drop alarmingly because of the stock market downturn, according to leading authorities on philanthropy. A number of fund-raisers also warned that the market's fluctuations could put a long-term chill on giving.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Ron Whitten may be an experienced prosecutor and an accomplished golf writer, but the city attorney in Topeka, Kan., who doubles as a contributor to Golf Digest, also has a secret passion, or did, anyway, until he proclaimed it to the world in the magazine's September issue.

title: Is the South Again Democratic?
description: LEAD: ''We lost this nomination on Nov. 4, 1986.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AND THE BAND PLAYED ON. Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic. By Randy Shilts. 630 pages. St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: The Drama of Staging 'Othello' in Johannesburg
description: A production of ''Othello'' in which the Moor is played by John Kani, the Tony Award-winning black South African actor, has broken new ground here both on and off the stage.

title: In the Ivy League, A Tangle at Top
description: Behind the start of official Ivy League round-robin competition 31 years ago was the concept that the eight conference members, similar institutions playing under the same strict academic rules, would share the laurels.

title: Rebels Destroy Ethiopia Aid
description: Guerrillas have destroyed a convoy carrying food for Ethiopians threatened by famine in drought-stricken Tigre Province, aid workers in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, said today. They said the rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front blew up 16 trucks on Friday.

title: Novi Journal; Rural Town Become a Suburban Oz
description: In the mid-1960's, this town was a blip on the Michigan map, a forgotten outpost of oak trees and apple farms. Townspeople had to commute for groceries and drive 40 minutes to Detroit for clothes or dinner out.

title: More So Than Usual, Investment Signals Point Two Ways
description: Rarely have stock market investors been forced to weigh such polarized arguments. Experts cite many powerful factors that could bolster the market, and just as many that could drive prices lower.

title: Lost Liner, Lost Town
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts in U.S. Support Have O.A.S. Worried
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting the Record Straight on the Dow Drop
description: When the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 508 points in one unnerving day last week, losing 22.6 percent of its value, it marked the widely followed indicator's largest-ever percentage loss - notwithstanding initial statistics from various news services that indicated otherwise.

title: Political Fragmentation Hampers New York Region's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's in the Dugout?
description: Billy Martin's fifth incarnation as the Yankees' skipper poses some questions about the George Steinbrenner era of musical managers. Here are some of them (answers below): 1. Since his group took over the Yankees in January 1973, how many times has George Steinbrenner changed managers? 2. How many different men have served as manager under Steinbrenner? 3. How many previous Yankee managers has Steinbrenner named as manager? 4. How many Steinbrenner managers have been replaced by the manager they had replaced? 5. What Steinbrenner manager has been replaced twice by the manager he replaced? 6. In the 15 Steinbrenner years, how many times has one man managed an entire season? 7. How many two-manager seasons have the Yankees had under Steinbrenner? 8. What was the only Steinbrenner season with three managers? 9. What are the only months in which Steinbrenner has never named a new manager?

title: Contras and Nicaraguan Cardinal Meet
description: Top contra military and political officials met secretly with Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua, in New York on Saturday, according to rebel and American officials.

title: Bears Defeat Bucs
description: Jim McMahon, playing for the first time since last November, ran for one touchdown and passed for another in the final six minutes today to rally the Chicago Bears to a 27-26 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Advertising; Agencies Weather The Storm
description: THE shares of publicly held advertising agencies did about the same as the rest of the stock market last week, or slightly worse, according to Wall Street analysts. But nothing has happened to disturb the traditionally optimistic precincts of Madison Avenue.

title: Latins Seeking Lower Rates
description: Latin American diplomats have set the stage to begin combatting high interest rates in industrial nations, calling them a key factor in their region's $380 billion foreign debt burden. Enrique Iglesias, Uruguay's

title: CHEMICAL BANK OFFICIAL RESIGNS
description: The Chemical Bank said last week that Alan H. Fishman had resigned as group executive for real estate and equities to ''pursue other opportunities.'' The bank named Maurice H. Hartigan 2d, 47 years old, to succeed him. Mr. Fishman, 41, had been one of Chemical's rising executives. He joined the bank 19 years ago and held high positions, at a relatively young age. Before his real estate assignment, he was senior executive vice president in charge of Chemical's investment banking activities. That appointment came in 1983 when Mr. Fishman was 37 and was the bank's chief financial officer.

title: Lisa Azenberg Married to C. C. Hayes
description: Lisa Beth Azenberg, a daughter of Elinor Azenberg and Emanuel Azenberg, both of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Charles Hayes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher B. Hayes of Clemson, S.C. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Proposal for Nutrasweet
description: The Nutrasweet Company said Friday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve the use of the artificial sweetener aspartame in baked goods and baking mixes. In the past, the F.D.A. had said that aspartame, sold under the trade name Nutrasweet, was unacceptable for baking because the sweetener would break down at high temperatures.

title: Pilot Flying Leader of F.A.A. Cited for Climbing Too High
description: A pilot flying the head of the Federal Aviation Administration to Las Vegas, Nev., has been cited for climbing 500 feet above his assigned altitude, forcing an airliner to change course, officials said Friday.

title: Sandra J. Blitz, a Lawyer, Is Married to Scott Stern
description: At the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I., Sandra June Blitz, an associate in the New York law firm of Reid & Priest, was married yesterday to Scott Stern, a tax manager for Peat Marwick Main in New York. Rabbi Steven Folberg performed the ceremony.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: The St. Louis Cardinals won the National League pennant this year with no pitcher having more than 11 victories in the regular season. Has it happened before?

title: Schools to Be Year-Round In Experiment
description: In an experimental program, 10 elementary schools in poor neighborhoods of New York State plan to operate year-round, seven days a week, and to provide an array of special services, top state education officials say.

title: Program Trading Curb Now Widely Expected
description: A week of tumult seems to have done what two years of heated debate in Congress and the securities industry did not: It has created a consensus that new curbs on the computerized trading of stocks and futures, done in staggering amounts at blinding speeds, are all but inevitable.

title: SUNY to Seek $150 Million for Stronger Undergraduate Effort
description: The State University of New York plans to ask Governor Cuomo and the Legislature for more than $150 million over the next five years to strengthen undergraduate education, according to university officials.

title: Market Place; High Dividends A Silver Lining
description: ALTHOUGH the stock market plunge has broadly lowered the prices of equities, it has made the dividends paid on some stocks look attractive in comparison with Government securities, money market funds and bank instruments.

title: Colts Top Patriots On Trudeau Passes
description: Jack Trudeau passed for 239 yards and a touchdown and Donnell Thompson, a defensive end, returned a fumble 28 yards for another touchdown today as the Indianapolis Colts beat the New England Patriots, 30-16.

title: The Scholastic Score
description: High school athletes have been turning away from individual sports in favor of team sports over the last 10 years, but at the same time they have been demonstrating heightened individualistic tendencies that have made it harder for their coaches to mold them into teams.

title: Kaisertech Leader Is Nursing Wounds
description: Alan E. Clore, the British-born financier, is nursing two big financial wounds in the United States as a result of the stock market's plunge.

title: Brokerages: Gains and Losses
description: After a frantic week of battling the stock market, Wall Street's brokerage firms spent the weekend cleaning up the debris and trying to assess the damage.

title: Tips on Tactics For PAC's
description: Among the organizations that have developed guidelines for political action committees is the United States Chamber of Commerce, whose members have set up more than 1,500 PAC's. These are the Chamber's recommendations:

title: Graham's Maverick Fund Drive
description: Some strategic fiscal footwork by the Martha Graham Dance Company has not drawn bravos from the National Endowment for the Arts. Bypassing the endowment, which has helped support the company since 1966, the Graham company has gone directly to Congress to seek a $7 million appropriation.

title: Murder Suspect Is Arrested After Jaywalking Past F.B.I.
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, hunting an ex-convict wanted on charges of murder and assault and for questioning in a series of slayings in the San Francisco area, have arrested the suspect after he jaywalked in front of their car, the authorities say.

title: Gore Defends Brochure With a Vietnam Photo
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. says he does not believe a campaign brochure showing him carrying an M-16 rifle in Vietnam is misleading although he served in a noncombat role.

title: Boxing; Hearns Takes Aim at History
description: THOMAS HEARNS will be shooting for a place in boxing history Thursday when he fights Juan Roldan for the World Boxing Council middleweight title at the Las Vegas Hilton.

title: George M.D. Lewis, 96, Dies; War Pilot Under La Guardia
description: George M.D. Lewis, a Pennsylvania architect who served as a bomber pilot under Fiorello H. La Guardia in northern Italy in World War I, died Friday at the Community Medical Center in Scranton, Pa. He was 96 years old and lived in Waverly, Pa.

title: Recital: Leontyne Price
description: LEONTYNE PRICE has reached what she once called in an interview ''the maturest stage of vocal maturity,'' and she has said farewell to the operatic stage. But at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, in a benefit for the United Negro College Fund, she reminded everyone that the ease and luster of her high notes are still among the wonders of the world.

title: Publisher Gets A Travel Post
description: James S. Berrien of the American Express Publishing Corporation is stepping into his second job as a magazine publisher at age 35. His new responsibility is Travel & Leisure, circulation 1.1 million, a bit of a step up from Food & Wine, circulation 750,000.

title: Elly Ameling Recital
description: The soprano Elly Ameling will sing works by Brahms, Schubert, Schumann, Strauss, Wolf, Faure, Poulenc, Duparc, Obradors and other composers in her only New York recital this season, Nov. 5 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Rudolf Jansen will be her accompanist. Tickets, at $18, $16 and $12.50, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: BIPARTISAN TALKS ON CUTTING DEFICIT WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: Congressional leaders began to lay out the options today and focus on trying to reach a deficit-reducing compromise with the Administration.

title: North Castle Garners Konica USA Account
description: There was the usual end-of-the-week flurry of account assignments last week, including these:

title: New Fear in Silicon Valley
description: The stock market plunge has dismayed the nation but it has had a special impact in Silicon Valley and other technology centers - and not only because technology stocks were some of the hardest hit.

title: U.S. BLAMED AS CANADA'S STOCKS FALL
description: Toward the end of trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange last Tuesday, after the market's leading index had fallen 17 percent in two days, a group of battered traders gathered under microphones that carry the hubbub to the visitors' gallery. Amid the din, traders could be heard shouting, ''Vultures, go home!''

title: Edwards Spurns Runoff Election After Placing 2d
description: At a party that he had hoped would be his victory celebration, Louisiana's populist Governor, Edwin Edwards, withdrew from his campaign for re-election today after a second-place finish in Saturday's primary.

title: Susan Hollis Goldstein Weds Geoffrey Doban
description: Susan Hollis Goldstein, a designer for WBTL Architects in New York, and Geoffrey Robert Doban, a designer for Gruzen Samton Steinglass, New York architects, were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. Rabbi Burton Padoll performed the nonsectarian service.

title: Russian Leaders Hidden in History
description: Here are some famous figures of Soviet history who are officially ignored:

title: Martin Segal Receives Town Hall Arts Award
description: Martin E. Segal, the chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts and chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center, received the Town Hall Friend of the Arts Award last night.

title: More of the Same?
description: From the President down, Reagan Administration officials seem determined to be reassuring about the stock market crash and the underlying state of the economy. This is an inadequate response to emergency, even if the official facts seem to bear them out.

title: Pickets Are Players Again
description: Five disorienting and disillusioning weeks filled with endless talk of contract bargaining, strikebreaking and antitrust lawsuits had served to remind fans across the country that football is as much a business as a sport - and as nasty a business as it is violent a sport. Yesterday, providing small consolation for some and enormous relief for others, it was finally business as usual again in the National Football League.

title: STILL-LOWER RATES EXPECTED
description: The bond markets were quick to interpret last week's steep decline in stock prices as a financial crisis that could break the back of the five-year-old economic expansion and reverse the trend toward higher interest rates.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Wall of Silence For Families in Howard Beach Case
description: Each day they sit in the same courtroom in Queens, in separate areas of the spectator section, avoiding contact with each other, apart even as they are together.

title: The Great Textile Robbery
description: It's already an outrage: Quotas and tariffs raise clothing and textile prices in America by a whopping $20 billion a year. That means the public currently pays $86,000 for every job protected.

title: Paris Sends Troops to Tahiti After Violent Demonstrations
description: France sent nearly 500 policemen and troops to Tahiti today to restore order after clashes between striking longshoremen and the police, French officials said.

title: STARTER IN RELIEF FAILS HERZOG
description: Back in the days when the Kansas City Royals were perennial American League playoff losers to the Yankees, the Royals' manager was often accused of overmanaging, especially in the way he brought in relief pitchers. Whitey Herzog is considered a better manager today than he was in those years with the Royals, one of the best in baseball, in fact. But tonight, in the seventh game of the World Series, he made a pitching move reminiscent of his Kansas City playoff days.

title: Inmate Dies in Failed Escape
description: One prisoner died and another broke his leg Saturday night when a makeshift rope of sheets snapped as they lowered themselves from a fourth-floor jail, the police said. The man who broke his leg was caught shortly after the escape from the Bi-State Justice Building and was taken to a hospital for treatment, Chief Deputy Gary Owen of Bowie County said.He would not identify the men, saying their families had not been notified.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 25, 1987: MONDAY Armstrg World Indus Howell Corp Atlantic Richfield Koppers Co Boeing Co Lubrizol Corp Brown & Sharpe Mfg Union Camp Corp Consol Frtwys Wells Fargo Mtg & Equity Foster Wheeler TUESDAY Ahmanson & Co Loral Corp American Brands Northeast Utilities Amoco Corp Norwest Corp Ball Corp Oakwood Homes Corp Bausch & Lomb Polaroid Corp Becor Western Inc Pub Serv Co NM Black Hills Corp Rubbermaid Inc Borden Inc Santa Fe Southn Pacific Cilcorp Inc Southwestern Pub Serv Duke Power Standex Intl Corp Edison Bros Stores Tambrands Inc Enserch Corp UGI Corp Gannett Co USLIFE Corp General Instrument Wendy's Intl Glenfed Inc Wicor Inc Great Western Finl Wisconsin Energy Kennametal Inc WEDNESDAY Alltel Corp McGraw-Hill Amer Elec Pwr NCNB Corp Baker Hughes North Amer Philips Belo (AH) Corp Oneida Ltd Cameron Iron Wks Panhandle Eastern Cigna Corp Parker-Hannifin Chevron Corp Philips Indus Columbia Svgs & Ln Pulte Home Corp E.I. du Pont Russell Corp Eaton Corp Scana Corp Energen Corp SmithKline Beckman Equifax Inc Squibb Corp Hercules Inc TRW Inc Houghton Mifflin TW Services Inc Hughes Tool Union Carbide Kentucky Utilities Wrigley (Wm) Jr Lukens Inc THURSDAY Allegis Corp Lawter Intl Amer Home Prdts Norton Co Anadarko Petroleum Olin Corp Avemco Corp RLC Corp Beverly Enterprises Rollins Envr Serv Burlington Indus Sara Lee Corp Entex Inc UST Inc Golden West Finl Weingarten Rlty Landmark Bancshares FRIDAY Allied-Signal McDonnell Douglas Corp Georgia-Pacific Mobil Corp Holly Sugar Storage Equities Indiana Energy Vulcan Materials Kroger Co West Point Pepperell SATURDAY Mead Corp Wackenhut Corp

title: Jill F. Sirianni Is Wed To Benjamin Haddad
description: At Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Patchogue, L.I., Jill Felice Sirianni, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Sirianni of Patchogue, was married yesterday to Benjamin Albert Haddad, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Haddad of Los Angeles. The Rev. John Felice, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Official Seeks No Shift in Job If Giuliani Quits
description: Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, has declined an offer from Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to nominate him to succeed Rudolph W. Giuliani if the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan resigns soon, as expected.

title: PTL's Liquidation Is Raised
description: A reorganization plan drafted by PTL's creditors says the ministry may have to liquidate if donations to it by next spring are not $20 million above operating expenses, according to a newspaper report.

title: Bucks Prove Too Much for Soviet Team
description: Basketball, conceived and nurtured in the United States, is now a sport with worldwide participation. Dozens of countries of every size have borrowed American theories, copied American tactics, and have even sent their most gifted athletes there.

title: Redskins Beat Jets on Last-Minute Kick
description: After three weeks of replacement football, 53,497 Redskins fans turned out this afternoon to watch the regulars play the game. Most of them came away wondering who was worse: regulars or replacements.

title: CHILLY SEARCH FOR TROUT IN STILL WATERS
description: I OFTEN wax rhapsodic about the superb angling for trout I have had in northern New England's lakes and ponds for the last 30 years, and of how a long-time friend and I have mastered the art of stillwater fly fishing.

title: Long Uncertainty Is Feared Abroad
description: Staggered by the fallout from the plunge of prices on United States stock exchanges last week, international investors and traders are anxiously expecting an extended period of frightening uncertainty.

title: Washington Talk: Influence; EPILOGUW ON BORK: LEONARD GARMENT'S OBSESSION
description: Near midnight last Thursday, Leonard Garment was in a telephone booth in the deserted Capitol. He had just learned that Senate Republican leaders had abandoned efforts to stave off the defeat of the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork. Mr. Garment was on the phone to a reporter when a Capitol policeman told him the building was closed.

title: Inside
description: Gunfire Ends a Friendship For years in Burkina Faso, two offi-cers were friends. Now, one is dead, shot by the other's soldiers. Page A8. PAC's Guard Their Money Political action committees are devising elaborate rules on distributing money to candidates and are trying to improve their image. Page A16. Governor Edwards Bows In a turning point for Louisiana, Gov.

title: A 77-Year-Old Man Is Killed In a Connecticut House Fire
description: A 77-year man was killed in an early morning fire at his home Saturday, the police said.

title: Vikings May Face Shortage of Cheers
description: Jerry Burns hopes Minnesota sports fans have some cheering left in them for Monday night's National Football League game between the Vikings and the Denver Broncos.

title: Now, Viola Is the Best Man
description: His victory in the seventh game was only about a half-hour old. The golden bowl awarded to the most valuable player was even newer than that. Frank Viola's left arm, the one that had just helped the Minnesota Twins defeat St. Louis tonight to win their first World Series, was now being used for something just as important.

title: Relationships; Students Who Need Special Aid
description: PUBLIC SCHOOLS 138 and 401 in Manhattan are not average city schools. And the relationship that Tom Roeder and Joseph Kerest have with their pupils is quite different from that of most teachers. The men are special-education teachers who, among others, received awards last week from the New York Alliance for the Public Schools, a coalition of educators and civic and corporate leaders whose goal is to improve the city schools.

title: Bridge: American Double Victory In World Championships
description: For the third time in half a century of world championships, the open team and women's team titles here went to the same country. At final ceremonies Saturday night, the United States was presented with the Bermuda Bowl and the Venice Trophy.

title: On Ganges Plain, Modernity Is Straining Tradition
description: Life in this village and its surrounding green farmlands unfolds along the main road, where babies are born in a rudimentary health center not far from where the dead are carried to cremation grounds.

title: 2 Are Shot in Chinatown Holdup
description: Three robbers invaded a jewelry store on a crowded thoroughfare in Chinatown yesterday and, as they fled with gold chains and other loot, shot a young woman employee and a male clerk who ran to her aid from a shop next door.

title: 24.7% Hong Kong Drop
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 26 -

title: Youth's Puzzling Death in '69 May Be Early U.S. AIDS Case
description: Doctors believe a St. Louis teen-ager who died in 1969 was infected with the virus that causes AIDS, according to a newspaper report. A finding of AIDS in 1969, if confirmed, would be far earlier than the earliest known cases, identified in the late 1970's in New York City and California.

title: Helen Van Zobler Weds A. G. Cugnini
description: At the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in Tarrytown, N.Y., Helen Van Zobler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Zobler of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Aldo Godfrey Cugnini, the son of Cecilia Cugnini of Scarborough, N.Y., and Aldo M. Cugnini of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Robert Dorer, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: A FRIENDSHIP DIES IN A BLOODY COUP
description: For a decade, the two young military officers were inseparable friends. They trained together, they ate together and, eventually, they plotted together.

title: Giants' Drought Comes to an End
description: In a victory as thorough as it was symbolic, the Giants won their first game since the Super Bowl today, a 30-7 thrashing of the Cardinals.

title: Ungermann Gets an Offer
description: A Silicon Valley computer networking company said today that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer. Analysts have predicted that last week's drop in stock prices might produce a number of such offers.

title: MORE CHANGE DUE IN CHINA'S ECONOMY
description: The acting Chinese party leader, Zhao Ziyang, said today China must intensify the restructuring of its economy along Western lines if it is to escape poverty.

title: James C. Hyde Is Wed To Ms. Koch, a Writer
description: Elizabeth Aida Koch, a writer and freelance journalist, and James Case Hyde, a painter, were married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York by the Rev. Heidi Hudnut. The bride, the daughter of Dr. Aida Mitulis Koch and Joseph Koch of Trenton, graduated from Brown University. Her mother is a physician at St. Francis Hospital in Trenton, and her father is a supervisor at the Jewish Community Center there.

title: In 2 Mill Towns, a Football Game Is Everything
description: All morning long, amid the sizzle of bacon and the clatter of coffee cups, the old men in tractor caps sidled up to the counter at Vonetes's luncheonette and started their day with the same morsel of small talk: ''Going to the game?''

title: Opera: Met Season's First 'Walkure'
description: ''DIE WALKURE'' is the second work in Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle but the first to appear in the Metropolitan Opera's current restaging of the four works. It came to the house last season and returned to it on Saturday afternoon. The new ''Das Rheingold'' preceeded Saturday's performance by a few weeks; ''Siegfried'' will come later this season, and the final opera, ''Gotterdammerung,'' will be given next year.

title: Dying Forests Perplex U.S. and W. Germany
description: The photographs told a dramatic tale: panoramic shots of mountains dotted with dead and dying trees, close-ups of yellowing needles and lifeless branches.

title: Twins Beat Cards, 4-2, to Win World Series
description: As the baseball season ended seven months after it began, the regular National Football League teams returned to the field after a strike that began nearly five weeks ago.

title: Drug Smuggler, 47, Arrested After Five Years as Fugitive
description: A convicted drug smuggler who escaped from prison in Kentucky five years ago was arrested Saturday as he walked from a truck stop in Oregon with $1,500 stuffed in his artificial leg, the United States Marshals Service said.

title: The Desperate Giants
description: IN the return of real pro football, the real Giants finally stood up. Not just the real Giants who wore Super Bowl XXI rings on the picket line during the recent strike, but the real Giants who earned those rings with a 12-game winning streak.

title: Mormon Leader Recovering
description: Ezra Taft Benson, the president of the Mormon Church, was released Saturday from a hospital where he had been recovering from a mild heart attack, a church spokesman said. The 88-year-old leader of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints will continue his convalescence at home before returning to his regular dutues, the spokesman said. Mr. Benson, who was Secretary of Agriculture from 1953 to 1961, was admitted to LDS Hospital Oct. 15 with an ailment that doctors later said was caused by a minor heart attack.

title: Dance: Joffrey II Troupe In 'Beauty and the Beast'
description: ''BEAUTY AND THE BEAST'' is a lovely fairy tale, and a wise one, too, for it reminds us that all beauty does not lie on the surface and that roughness of manner may be only a mask hiding tenderness of heart. Moreover, because the basic relationships between its characters can be indicated through posture and movement, it is a story that lends itself to choreographic treatment.

title: Du Pont Pushing His Get-Tough Brand of Politics
description: The middle-aged man in the blue suit, red tie and blue shirt looks directly into the television camera and says this about the Social Security system: ''The present system gives young people a false sense of security. I'm Pete du Pont. There is a solution.''

title: Soviet Jewish Couple Free After 17 Years
description: Vladimir Slepak, a Jew who had been refused permission to leave the Soviet Union, arrived in Vienna today, ending a 17-year struggle to emigrate. ''It's like a dream,'' he said.

title: In a Changed Economy, Labor Tries New Tactics
description: The American labor movement, whose leaders open their annual convention here on Monday, is embarking on new ventures in organizing and political action as it confronts a rapidly changing work force and a national economy that has abandoned many of the rules that prevailed when labor was a dominant force in American life.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 14 about Harold S. Anderson, who was long associated with the Edison Museum, misstated his position. He was assistant curator.

title: Kirkpatrick Decides Against Presidential Bid
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, today closed the door on a bid for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, a decision widely viewed as helping the campaign of Representative Jack F. Kemp.

title: In Tweed and Earplugs: Shooting Sporting Clays
description: Under a blazing autumn sun on the rolling grounds of the Mashomack Fish and Game Preserve, the Right Honorable Earl of Shrewsbury and Waterford helped defend Britain's sporting honor.

title: Battle Rages Over a Building's Angels
description: In palmy days and scary ones, a small host of exuberant angels gazed down on the creation, devastation and rebirth of Columbus Avenue from the Evelyn, one of the oldest apartment houses in New York City.

title: KOREA CANDIDATES APPEAR TOGETHER
description: A rally that featured the first joint campaign appearance of the two main opposition rivals for this country's presidency ended in a clash Sunday night between students and riot policemen.

title: STAGE: SOUTH AFRICAN 'SARAFINA!'
description: THOUGH diligent New York audiences of the 1980's may not learn a lot about the political dynamics of the United States at the theater, they have surely become experts on South Africa. Dissident productions from Johannesburg's Market Theater, urgently telling and retelling the atrocities of apartheid, now reach New York faster than new plays from Louisville or London. Is there a danger that we'll be rendered numb by the oft-told tales of Soweto and Sharpville? Perhaps, but not as long as South Africa's defiant theater artists revel in the cultural heterogeneity that the South African Government would like to suppress. While there is indeed nothing new in the grim content of Mbongeni Ngema's ''Sarafina!,'' the latest Market Theater import to reach Lincoln Center's Newhouse Theater, the show's exuberant form is its own revelation.

title: Normal Hours Likely Soon
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which has been closing two hours early to catch up with paperwork caused by last week's trading, may get back to normal hours Wednesday, according to its chairman, John J. Phelan Jr. It closed at 2 P.M. Friday instead of 4 and will do so Monday and Tuesday - the settlement days for last Monday and Tuesday's wild sessions.

title: Business and the Law; Drop Spawns Investor Suits
description: THE tremors that shook Wall Street last week are beginning to reverberate into legal controversies, as scores of angry and unhappy customers and traders turn to their lawyers.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,300,000 for the quarter and $3,782,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $349,000 and $944,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INCALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q. Why does laundry dried outside smell better than laundry dried in a drier? A. Some substances, including laundry, undergo chemical changes when they are exposed to the bleaching action of sunlight, a process called photolysis.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Credit Card Interest, Unmasked
description: These days, creditworthy corporations pay 10 or 11 percent to borrow from banks. How come some banks charge credit card customers, even those who never miss a payment, 22 or 23 percent?

title: Witness Describes Key Point In Howard Beach Encounter
description: A defense lawyer closely questioned the key prosecution witness in the Howard Beach murder trial yesterday in an effort to show that white youths were not chasing a black man when he ran to his death on a highway.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $12,400,000, or 36 cents a share, from settlement of several of the company's pension plans. The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month results are restated downward about $986,000 and $2,412,000, respectively, because of the subsidiary's accounting discrepancy.

title: Students Who Help Professors Make Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Obstacle Reported In Bow Valley Sale
description: The Canadian Government will block the sale of Bow Valley Industries, a large oil and gas company, to British Gas P.L.C., The Toronto Star reported. The newspaper quoted an unidentified Government official as saying that Investment Canada, the agency that screens foreign investment, would allow the sale of only energy companies that are in financial difficulty. Bow Valley is a healthy company, The Star said. Investment Canada would not comment on the report.

title: GENERAL MOTORS ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: General Motors Corp. attributed the increase in earnings of its GMAC unit primarily to a previously adapted change in the rate of depreciation on leased vehicles which amounted to $65 million for the quarter. The company also said the increase for the latest 9-month resulted principally from higher average earnings assets, lower interest rates on borrowings, and the previously adopted change in the depreciation rate; this change amounted to $198 million in the latest 9 months.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,000 for the quarter and $10,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $168,000 and $248,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $105,000 for the quarter and $129,000 for the 6 months.

title: In Defiance of Einstein, Physicists Seek Faster-Than-Light Messages
description: IN earnest defiance of one of the great certainties of modern times - that nothing can travel faster than light - a group of Indian physicists has put forward a new scheme for sending faster-than-light messages.

title: 3 Scientists Share Research Prize
description: Three scientists from Australia, New York and Pittsburgh will share the $100,000 Hammer Prize for cancer research, awarded annually to scientists who have made significant contributions toward a cure for cancer.

title: Sun Microsystems Sells Chip to Xerox
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. announced today that the Xerox Corporation has become its second major customer in a week for its new high-speed microprocessor.

title: Indispensable Helium Is Routinely Squandered
description: AS its potential uses proliferate, scientists, government agencies and private interests are wrestling anew with the problem of husbanding an irreplaceable but widely wasted resource: helium.

title: Pact for Thrift
description: Syd Thrift signed a two-year contract yesterday to continue as the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager, just three days after a dispute that led to the resignation of the team president, Malcolm Prine. During contract negotiations with Thrift, Prine demanded the right to approve all hirings, dismissals and trades. But after the Pirates' board of directors sided with Thrift last Friday and voted to rehire him without such restrictions, Prine quit. The new contract reportedly increases Thrift's salary by $75,000 a year to $200,000 annually and gives him the final say on all baseball-related decisions.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: b-Net loss Year-ago third quarter and 9 months include a pretax charge of $134.856,000 associated with consolidation of manufacturing operations and workforce reductions.

title: Top Court Gets Case of a Tower Built Too High
description: New York State's highest court has agreed to hear the unusual case of an Upper East Side apartment tower that is 12 stories taller than zoning rules allow, prompting the builder to hope that he will not have to remove those floors - as ordered by the Buildings Department last year.

title: MAXTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: Fiscal year 1987 has been adjusted retroactively to reflect the acquisition of U.S. Design Corp. on May 22, which is being accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; U.F.O. Stakeout: A Polite Request To Land in Rain
description: The worst thing about being a U.F.O. photographer is it's a full-time job and you don't make a cent. ''It's ridiculous,'' said Ellen Crystall. ''I've got over 500 pictures of U.F.O.'s - I spend thousands on developing - and I get no funding at all.''

title: Du Pont's Earnings Rise 31.8%
description: E.I du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company, said today that its third-quarter net income rose 31.8 percent, to $452 million, despite another steep decline in its petroleum refining and marketing business.

title:
MARKET TURMOIL;
Few Signs of Prescience By Company Insiders
description: LEAD: The giant fall in stock prices that took individual investors by surprise was also a bolt from the blue to many corporate insiders.

title: Adams Performs 2 Roles for Giants
description: The Giants' offense has not only discovered a new threat in George Adams, but it also has become ambidextrous.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Voice Writes
description: Christopher Matthews has been known around the capital for more than a decade as ''the voice of . . .''

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The results for the latest periods include a gain of $15.5 million as a result in amendments and adjustments to certain gas sales contracts.

title: PACIFIC TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A picture in Science Times last Tuesday with an article about Mount Everest was published in error. The peak pictured was Makalu. Photographs of the two peaks are often confused; a discussion appears today on page C4.

title: Weary Cards Look Ahead
description: Ozzie Smith wearily put on a full-length mink coat early today and headed home, wrapped in splendor but also wrapped in thoughts of what it meant to lose the World Series in the seventh game for the second time in three years.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hospital Union Head Embraces Her Ex-Foe
description: The infighting that has splintered Local 1199, the largest hospital workers union in New York City, shifted yesterday when the union's president embraced her former opponent.

title: Mexico on Sidelines in Peace Efforts
description: When Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepuulveda Amor appeared before a foreign affairs committee of the Mexican Congress last week, the opposition peppered him with variations on a single theme: Why is Mexico not playing a more active role in the Central American peace process?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about historical figures who are officially ignored in the Soviet Union gave an incorrect date for the death of Sergei M. Kirov, a Leningrad Communist Party leader. He was killed in 1934.

title: FORD MOTOR CO OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Exiles Warn West on Moves by Communists
description: With commentators in the Western countries heralding political changes in the Soviet Union and China, a group of writers and scholars from many of the world's Communist-ruled countries gathered in New York over the weekend, and a different and generally less optimistic view prevailed among them.

title: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Needham Shifts VW Strategy
description: VOLKSWAGEN United States and its agency, DDB Needham, agree that they had not been on the mark with their advertising but are now.

title: Debate Intensifies as to What Part Program Trading Played in Swings
description: When the New York Stock Exchange took steps last week to take a breather from computerized program trading, the market was badly in need of a steadying influence. Volatility, another word for lurching movements that depart from the norm, had seemingly gone out of control.

title: Togo First In Africa to Back New Rulers in Burkina Faso
description: Togo today became the first African nation to give public support to the new rulers in Burkina Faso after the bloody coup there on Oct. 15.

title: Victor W. Ganz, Art Collector And Official of the Whitney
description: Victor W. Ganz, vice president of the Whitney Museum of American Art, chairman of the Battery Park City Fine Arts Committee and a distinguished collector of 20th-century art, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in New York. He was 74 years old.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring pretax profits of $213 million on the previously announced public sale of 155.6 million ordinary shares of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company in Australia, and $9 million on the public sale of newly issued shares of Asarco Australia Ltd., a gold mining and exploration company. The company said taxes of $112 million on these profits were largely offset by an extraordinary credit of $88 million resulting from utilization of all Asarco's net operating loss carryforwards. c-Net loss d-Includes a non-recurring pretax LIFO inventory profits of $8 million. Year-ago 9-month results included non-recurring first quarter income of $9 million from a rights offering by M.I.M. Holdings Ltd. and $3.6 million from a reduction of Asarco's interest in the Wiluna gold project in Australia, and LIFO profits of $12 million in the second and third quarters.

title: Big Challenge For Computers
description: When the market plunged last week, commentators pointed out that the New York Stock Exchange's ticker was running hours behind. The implication was that the exchange's computers could not keep up with the volume. But the real problem, the exchange said yesterday, is that investors can not read fast enough.

title: Guinness Mahon Names Chairman
description: Guinness Mahon & Company Ltd., the banking subsidiary of Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. has named Geoffrey Bell chairman, succeeding John Sclater, who was acting chairman. Mr. Bell was also named to the board of Guinness Peat.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Municipal Debt Rules Are Hinted
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, stated today that new regulations governing issuers of municipal debt may be introduced.

title: Steel Import Quotas Are Set
description: The United States has negotiated new speciality steel quota agreements with six nations and unilaterially set import quotas on two nations, the American trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today.

title: Queens Coalition Challenges City With Low-Cost Rockaway Plan
description: A religious and civic coalition, challenging a city plan for market-rate apartments on the beach in Rockaway, Queens, submitted a proposal yesterday to build 3,200 low-cost town houses in Arverne.

title: Reagan Bans All Iran Imports and Curbs Exports
description: President Reagan announced a ban today on all Iranian imports and tighter restrictions on American exports to Iran.

title: Tokyo Exchange Rebounds, Unperturbed by Wall Street
description: Stock prices surged here today as the Tokyo market shrugged off overnight losses on Wall Street.

title: Florida Investor Kills Broker and Himself
description: A Social Security Administration claims worker, who apparently made millions playing the stock market and faced ruin in last week's collapse, shot and killed an executive with Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith today and wounded another, then took his own life with a bullet in the head.

title: Oilers to Stay Put
description: The Houston Oilers' owner, Bud Adams, spurned an offer from Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday and announced he would keep the team in Houston. ''This is my home,'' Adams said. ''I've been here 41 years. I could have gone to Jacksonville for a lot more money.'' Adams and his family toured the Florida city several weeks ago. But Adams said he was swayed by a proposal that calls for construction of 72 luxury boxes at the Houston Astrodome to bolster other renovations planned for the stadium, now the National Football League's smallest with a capacity of 50,594. The luxury boxes are among some $50 million in improvements to the Astrodome, which will also get 10,000 more seats and new artificial playing surfaces for baseball and football.

title: Twins' Victory Brings Holiday
description: Gov. Rudy Perpich today declared Tuesday Minnesota Twins World Championship Day.

title: Trading in Index Futures Is Unusually Light
description: Trading was unusually light in the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index pit today, despite the stock market's sharp drop.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Dance: Peter Pucci
description: SOME young choreographers cram dances so full of steps that the results are jumbles.

title: Saudi Doubts Oil Price Rise
description: King Fahd was quoted today as dismissing the likelihood of an increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in its $18-a- barrel oil price before 1989.

title: Texaco Loses A Legal Move
description: The United States trustee in the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy proceedings yesterday rejected a request by the oil company to merge the two creditor committees.

title: I.M.F. Sees Greater Need
description: The International Monetary Fund's managing director said today that the fund's resources might have to be tapped more than expected to help member nations with their debt problems. Michel Camdessus said in an address prepared for delivery to the United Nations General Assembly that the I.M.F. would need financial support from other parties in addition to its own resources. ''While the fund needs to continue to respond flexibly and imaginatively to the problems of its members, it cannot do so without the strong commitment and financial support of other parties to the debt strategy,'' he said.

title: Dr. Maxwell Finland, 85, Dies; Expert on Infectious Disease
description: Dr. Maxwell Finland, internationally recognized for his study of infectious diseases and their treatment, died Sunday in Faulkner Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in the Jamaica Plain section of Boston.
