title: A New Israeli Museum Wing
description: Israeli museum officials and American art patrons introduced plans yesterday to build a major new wing for 20th-century art in Israel's premier museum of art and archeology, the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

title: World Bank Urges More Austerity by Poland
description: The World Bank has urged Poland to speed up the pace of economic change and enact even tougher austerity measures than Warsaw is planning.

title: RIEDEL ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday began offering $300 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.588 to yield 8.749 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter an 9 months reflect a change in accounting procedures related to the company's pension plan.

title: Hong Kong Suffers Wild Fluctuations
description: Stock prices fluctuated wildly in morning trading here today, after losing one-third of their value on Monday in one of the worst one-day losses ever suffered by any stock market.

title: Cuts Are Reported In Car Production
description: American auto makers have removed about 52,000 cars from their fourth-quarter production plans, an industry newsletter reported. The General Motors Corporation cut 26,000 cars and the Chrysler Corporation cut 21,000 cars, Ward's Automotive Reports said. The Ford Motor Company, which has the lowest inventories of the Big Three, is expected to reduce its production only slightly, the newsletter said.

title: C.F.T.C. To Analyze Trading
description: The head of the independent Federal agency that regulates futures cautioned today that ''one should not jump to conclusions'' that computerized stock futures trading was a cause of the plunging market.

title: NORWESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rules Changing in Takeovers
description: Almost every major takeover deal that was in the works before the stock market began its slide has been drastically revamped or canceled. Several other major deals still alive are regarded as all but dead. But arbitragers and others emphasize that, on the flip side, lower stock prices present some unusual opportunities for new deals.

title: ITT Unit Offers Noncallable Notes
description: ITT Financial, an operating unit of the ITT Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent noncallable notes due in 1992 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's, the notes yield about 87-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

title: Fall Hurts Banks' Bid To Expand
description: The stock market collapse has dealt a sharp setback to the banking industry's top-priority effort to enter the securities business, Government and industry sources said today.

title: Fire Closes Primerica Offices
description: The Primerica Corporation's headquarters were closed today after firefighters extinguished a blaze in the boiler room. Ken Koprowski, a spokesman for Primerica, formerly the American Can Company, said most of the 270 employees were told to stay home because of smoke and soot that penetrated the building. Mr. Koprowski said a few administrative employees worked today. Most workers were also told not to report on Tuesday, he said, adding that crews were hired to clean the building.

title: Philleo Nash, at 77; Was a U.S. Official In 3 Administrations
description: Philleo Nash, an adviser to President Truman on minority affairs and the Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs for five years in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died Oct. 12 of renal cell cancer at a hospice in Marshfield, Wis. He was 77 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Do's and Don'ts of Party Cooperation
description: Republican senators are influential policy-makers. Republican representatives, basically, are badgering bystanders.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $532,000 and $3,430,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain from the sale of an 85 percent stake in Devry Inc. of $37,393,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,581,000 and $6,499,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: In Sanctuary Movement, Unabated Strength but Shifting Aims
description: After a year of studying Central American issues, the 186 members of the Dominican Sisters of the Congregation of the Sacred Heart recently announced that their Roman Catholic order would provide sanctuary to undocumented aliens from the region.

title: RYAN, BECK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Net Rises for Oil Companies
description: Leading oil companies reported sharply higher earnings from exploration and production operations in the third quarter compared with the depressed levels of a year ago, after a rise of nearly 40 percent in crude oil prices since then.

title: Market Turmoil; STOCKS FALL 156, LOSS OF 8%, AFTER BIG SELL OFFS ABROAD; JOINT TALKS ON DEFICIT BEGIN
description: A new wave of pessimism overwhelmed Wall Street yesterday, prompting another big selloff in stocks.

title: Koch Drops His Fight With Priest Over a Building
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was dropping his fight with a Roman Catholic priest over the ownership of a building in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, clearing the way for the priest, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, to purchase the building as a home for runaway youths.

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,150,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: The Bradley Doctrine
description: This is the time, with the summit meeting so strangely suspended by the Kremlin, for Americans to ask themselves a question a boy of 10 put at a town hall meeting between American and Soviet citizens in New York State.

title: Avoiding Sabotage Of the Arias Plan
description: Nobody knows if the Arias plan to achieve peace in Central America will work. Everybody knows that if the Reagan-Shultz plan to provide $270 million in direct aid to the Nicaraguan rebels is now approved by Congress, the Arias plan will not work.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3 million for the quarter and $7.8 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes a $12.2 million special charge for both the quarter and 9 months. All results are in Canadian dollars. The company attributed the improved net income to higher oil prices, decreasing operating costs, lower depreciation and depletion charges, reduced interest expense and $13 million in proceeds from the sale of its Norwegian unit.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $102 million from the sale of Ford's North American paint operations and Ford Aerospace & Communications Corp.'s interest in Starnet Corp.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $451,087 from settlement of litigation.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Zukerman to Conduct
description: Pinchas Zukerman is to conduct the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra in works by Elgar, Beethoven and Ludwig Spohr, and in the premiere of a work for quartet and orchestra by Marc Neikrug, Nov. 2 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.

title: Prison Barge Arrives At East River Pier; City to Seek Another
description: A barge that New York City has leased to house prisoners arrived yesterday at an East River pier, and officials announced plans to lease a second barge from the same British company.

title: Corrections
description: The Social Events column on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a benefit for the West Point Preparatory Scholarship Program at the Waldorf-Astoria. It will be tonight at 6:30.

title: ACME STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $832,000 for the quarter and $4,166,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $3.5 million and $10.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of investments. c-Includes charges of $5.4 million for the quarter and $9.1 million for the 9 months for write-down of assets and the cost of early retirement program, and the 9-month also includes an after-tax gain of $10.6 million from the sale of investments. Revenue represent consolidated revenue.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $11.8 million and $4.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a special restructuring charge of $82.3 million for both the quarter and 9 months. The latest 9 months and year-earlier period includes pretax LIFO charges of $15 million and $12.6 million, respectively.

title: Market Turmoil; Reagan and Congressional Chiefs Meet to Lay Budget Groundwork
description: President Reagan and Congressional leaders reached a basic agreement today to pursue measures designed to reduce the Federal budget deficit by at least $23 billion. They left the details of such a package to a negotiating team that will begin work Tuesday afternoon.

title: 3 With Explosives Held at Border
description: Three men were arrested after crossing the border from Canada over the weekend and were ordered detained today on Federal explosives charges.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Lawyer as Joiner
description: In the final months of the Reagan Administration, many lawyers are leaving government for private practice. But Michael Boudin, one of the most respected lawyers in Washington, is doing the opposite, joining the Justice Department, where he will be a deputy assistant attorney general in the antitrust division.

title: Credit for Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopian Guerrillas Raid Food Convoy, Halting Drought Aid
description: A rebel attack on a food convoy in a famine-threatened area of Ethiopia has prompted officials to order an immediate halt to further shipments, relief workers said today.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $41.7 million refund of investment tax credit carryforwards, a $14.7 million credit realted to a favorable U.S. tax court ruling and $9.1 million extraordinary gain for the retirement of debt. c-Net loss and includes a special charge of $26.6 million for the quarter related to discontinued operations; the 9 months includes a special charge of $337.4 million primarily for closing Reserve Mining Co. and consolidations of operations in oilfield equipment. Also included were losses of $97.7 million for the discontinued fabricated products and services segment and $21 million for Armco's runoff insurance companies.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend declared in June 1987.

title: Cuomo Faults Rumors On Organized Crime
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that rumors that some members of his family might have had organized-crime connections were ''political garbage distributed by political garbage dealers.''

title: Fashion Designers in Europe Go Short, Shorter, Shortest
description: The major fashion trend emerging from three weeks of spring and summer openings in Europe can be summed up in one word: short. There were subsidiary themes, like the explosion of pretty colors and flower prints, especially roses. Scooped necklines and bare shoulders emphasized the feeling of extreme femininity, and long gloves and hats recalled glamour of the past.

title: FNN Moves Into the Spotlight
description: For Financial News Network, the cable television channel that covers daily stock market activity, last week presented the long-sought chance to make a reputation for itself.

title: CERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $212,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Keep the Immigration Judges in Place
description: The United States has long welcomed refugees from persecution. But new rules proposed by the Reagan Administration would make it more difficult for political refugees to remain here. The proposal ought to be withdrawn.

title: An Angry Papp Resigns From Mayor's Council
description: Angered by a plan announced last week by Mayor Koch to establish a New York Theater Trust financed in part by a $1 surcharge on tickets to Broadway shows, Joseph Papp resigned yesterday from the Mayor's Theater Advisory Council.

title: Solidarity Urges Poles to Boycott Referendum on Economic Change
description: The outlawed Solidarity union urged Poles today to boycott the country's first referendum in 41 years, saying the Government had missed its chance to give the people a genuine choice on the economy.

title: In Fallen Tamil City, Indians Find Bitterness
description: An uncertain peace has come here after two weeks of bombings, shellings and house-to-house fighting. The streets are deserted, buildings are boarded up or bombed out, and Indian soldiers lie in prone firing positions at most intersections.

title: A Strike Few Noticed: Why NBC Union Lost
description: NBC's striking technicians, writers, producers and editors will begin to come back to work next week, concluding a strike marked by ill will between the strikers and the company and bitter infighting inside the union. At the end, the only easy thing about the strike was figuring out who won: the company did.

title: Koch Weighs Hiring Freeze To Cut Cost
description: Koch Administration officials are preparing plans to freeze municipal hiring, out of concern that the stock market crisis and a possible downturn in the economy could reduce New York City revenues.

title: GM HUGHES ELECTRONIC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Series Makes Itself Heard
description: AMONG the many ways football and baseball are different is the way they sound on television. Generally, baseball, with its deliberate pace and chatty, anecdotal nature, seduces the viewer; football, with its collisions and military-like jargon, commands attention.

title: NEW LINE CINEMA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $657,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $6,523,000.

title: Kasparov and Karpov Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw today after 28 moves in the sixth game of their world chess championship match.

title: Institutional Investors Support Shorter Day
description: Judging by the relative quiet on the trading desk of Jefferies & Company, which offers its clients a chance to buy and sell when the stock markets are closed or trading in a stock is halted, institutional investors are not at all displeased by the shorter trading hours set by the exchanges.

title: Boeing Profit Down by 33.6%
description: The Boeing Company said today that its third-quarter earnings slumped 33.6 percent because of higher costs for research and development and production.

title: The Theater: 'Birds of Paradise'
description: IN olden days, as the reappearance of ''Anything Goes'' sparklingly reminds us, a glimpse of plot was something hot, but today, as the appearance of ''Birds of Paradise'' flatly confirms, anything no longer goes in a musical, not, anyhow, without Cole Porter to fill in the deficiencies.

title: European Farm Plan Dispute
description: The European Community presented a plan today to help its depressed agricultural markets, but several of the member countries complained that it preserved the community's farm subsidies, delegates said.

title: AIDS Overturns Theories On Two Medical Mysteries
description: ABOUT two and a half years ago, a dancer with a major New York ballet company sprained his left ankle - or so he thought. He stopped dancing and waited for it to heal. But it only got worse and soon his right ankle began hurting as well.

title: THOMAS E. BERRY
description: Thomas Edward Berry, an account executive, died Wednesday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and Solebury, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch from Novi, Mich., yesterday about the growth of the community described the origin of the town's name incompletely in some editions. The name embodies the Roman numeral for 6: ''No. VI.'' The town was the sixth stop on the trail from Detroit to Lansing.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday showing active stocks of last week misstated some percentage changes.

title: Landlord Can Evict Absentee Tenant From Apartment, Court Says
description: An actress who kept an apartment in Manhattan but spent most of her time in Hollywood may be evicted from her rent-stabilized apartment here, an appeals court in Manhattan has ruled.

title: THEATER: A JOURNEY
description: GIVE an aleph for audacity to A Traveling Jewish Theater's ''Berlin, Jerusalem and the Moon.'' The San Francisco group's three actor-writers take us, in the space of 80 minutes, on a journey from Jacob's wrestling match with God to Weimar Germany up to present-day America and Israel. The goal is to make a big statement on the condition of the contemporary Jew. The company doesn't have a prayer of realizing that ambition, of course, but there is enough intelligence and imagination on show by the new Mosaic Theater at the 92d Street Y to compel attention and stir thought.

title: Deaver Prosecutor Assails Administration Action
description: The special prosecutor in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver accused the Reagan Administration today of seeking ''improperly to influence the outcome'' of the case.

title: Viola Was Clearly the Right Choice
description: IT hardly seems that six and a half years have passed since the jury was out on Frank Viola. On a cold, raw Saturday - April 25, 1981 - the jury reconvened at Redman Field in Jamaica to continue its deliberations.

title: U.S. Outpost Feels Threat Of Budget Ax
description: What malaria, murder and green mamba snakes could not achieve, Washington's new spirit of cutting budgets may soon accomplish in this island capital in the Atlantic.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Lane Financial Inc. said the La Salle National Corporation, whose parent is Algemene Bank Nederland N.V., had offered about $200 million to acquire the company. Lane said the proposed price is about 2.5 times its book value. The company said its board would consider the offer on Nov. 3.

title: Senate G.O.P. Is Offered Nominees to High Court
description: The White House began the public process of choosing the next Supreme Court nominee today as Howard H. Baker Jr., President Reagan's chief of staff, presented a list of 13 names to the Senate's Republican leadership.

title: Software for Writers
description: PEOPLE who write for a living, or who write as a passion, deserve more than sympathy. They deserve good word-processing software.

title: ALASKA AIR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1987
description: Stock Market Turmoil

title: New Drop Dashes Some Investors' Hopes of Quick Recovery
description: In the last week, Joe Coleman, a sales representative at a Nashville printing company, watched the value of his stock in a wide range of companies drop by about 40 percent. Although Mr. Coleman had been convinced that the market would quickly rebound, yesterday's plunge shook his confidence.

title: BIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; O-T-C Dealers Face Questions
description: DID some dealers responsible for making markets in over-the-counter stocks deliberately fail to answer their telephones during the heat of the historic landslide in prices?

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Washington Talk: Poet Laureate; Avoiding the Pitfalls of Verse for Hire
description: Richard Wilbur, whose standing as one of the nation's pre-eminent poets earned him the Government post of poet laureate of the United States, is facing up to the fact that he has not had time to write much poetry.

title: MEDICARE PANELS ACCUSED OF LAXITY
description: Groups of doctors assigned to monitor colleagues treating Medicare patients have not penalized a single physician in 23 states and the District of Columbia, a critic said today. He contended that doctors were not serious about making sure Medicare patients got good care.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Edith Davis, Nancy Reagan's Mother, Is Dead
description: Edith Luckett Davis, Nancy Reagan's mother, died of a stroke today at her home in Phoenix, Ariz. She was 91 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Obviously a failure at this juncture would be extremely negative. But we don't intend to fail.'' - Representative

title: Market Turmoil; First Brokerage to Weigh In Puts Its Losses at $44 Million
description: In the first report of how a well-known brokerage house fared in last week's collapse of stock prices, L. F. Rothschild & Company said yesterday that it had suffered a $44 million net loss so far this month.

title: STAGE: 'ESTABLISHED PRICE' IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The general counsel of the ATF Corporation (played by Kenneth McMillan) is one of the people most responsible for the company's growth in the sporting goods market.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Jaite and Mayotte Advance: Martin Jaite and Tim Mayotte advanced to the second round of the $923,000 European Community Championship yesterday in Antwerp, Belgium. Jaite defeated Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-4, and Mayotte beat a fellow American, Kelly Jones, 6-4, 6-4. Jaite will face John McEnroe in the second round, while Mayotte will meet eighth-seeded Joakim Nystrom. McEnroe's suspension for his behavior at the United States Open does not include this tournament, which is an exhibition.(AP) Wiesner Surprises Cecchini: Judith Wiesner of Austria upset eighth-seeded Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 7-6, 6-2, in the first round of the $150,000 European women's indoor tournament in Zurich yesterday. The defending titlist, Steffi Graf, will face a fellow West German, Claudia Porvik, today. (AP) HORSE RACING Toujours Vitesse Takes Holy Catfish: Toujours Vitesse, the favorite, took the lead nearing the stretch and went on to a 2 3/4-length victory in the $33,000 Holy Catfish Purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Carrying 114 pounds and ridden by Richard Migliore, the winner covered seven furlongs on a fast track in 1:23 3/5. Miss Czara finished second.(AP) HORSE SHOW Two Blue Ribbons for Two Four One: Two Four One, an 8-year-old bay gelding ridden by Tommy Serio, became the first double blue-ribbon winner of the 29th Washington International Horse Show yesterday at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. The horse took first place in the regular conformation model class, outscoring Bavaria, ridden by Lise Quintero. Two Four One then won in the regular conformation hunter class, again beating Bavaria.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 5, Canadiens 3: Brett Hull's second goal of the game snapped a third-period tie with Montreal last night and Calgary earned its third straight victory on the road. Hull's unassisted goal at 8 minutes 30 seconds came on a shot from the middle of the left circle. The Calgary goaltender, Mike Vernon, had to make a spectacular save in the final minute - thrusting out his left pad to stop Mats Naslund's shot from the crease - to preserve the victory, which was further sealed when Hakan Loob scored into an empty net with 26 seconds to play.(AP)

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Kidder, Peabody & Co., an investment banking concern, named Clarence C. (Red) Johnson senior vice president.

title: Hodel Urging Shift in Indian Programs
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel is proposing a fundamental restructuring of the relationship between the Federal Government and the nation's 500 Indian tribes, aimed at promoting greater self-determination and less reliance on the Government.

title: Notes on Fashion
description: WHAT was most interesting about the spring fashion collections just shown by established designers in Europe was how little they had to do with the future, how easily they ignored the present, and how much they had to do with the past.

title: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Federal Court Continues 'Platoon' Videotape Ban
description: A Federal appeals court Monday continued an injunction against Home Box Office selling or renting video cassettes of ''Platoon,'' the Vietnam War film that won the 1986 Academy Award as best motion picture, and returned the case to a Federal District Court.

title: NATIONAL ENTERPRISES BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $108,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $350,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After tax credits of $601,000 for the quarter and $1,390,000 for the 9 months. The earnings in the latest 9 months did not cover the preferred stock requirements.

title: Suffolk Nominees Trade Bitter Attacks in Debate
description: The two major candidates for Suffolk County Executive agreed yesterday on the problems facing the county, but in sharp exchanges that often became personal attacks they bitterly disagreed on who bore responsibility for solving them.

title: Students Who Help Professors Make Money; Focuses the Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonprofit Arts Feel Wall St. Tremors
description: The people responsible for the business side of New York's nonprofit performing arts organizations are responding with increasing concern to the news from Wall Street. While most of the city's Off Broadway theaters, for example, are not known for the size of their stock portfolios, they do depend on the largesse of foundations - some of which have seen stunning changes in the value of their own assets.

title: Seattle Journal; Panhandler Curb: Is It an Antidote Or New Poison?
description: A vagrant pokes through the contents of a garbage can on a downtown street here, then peers at two police officers standing partly concealed in a doorway 20 feet away. A well-dressed man, the sort who usually attracts the automatic attention of this city's many beggars, comes near and the hungry look of a fox passing a chicken yard crosses the vagrant's face. But he glances at the police officers and reluctantly resumes digging in the garbage can.

title: Older Homes' Sales Up 1.2%
description: Sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in September after three consecutive monthly declines, the National Association of Realtors said today. Single-family homes sold at an annual rate of 3.45 million units in September, up from an August rate of 3.41 million units.

title: Broken Path to Summit
description: In refusing to fix a date for a summit meeting in Washington, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has broken the momentum toward improved Soviet-American relations that had developed before Secretary of State George P. Shultz went to Moscow last week.

title: A Moment to Be Savored, Quickly
description: The message on the Metrodome scoreboard was opportunistic, but also optimistic and, realistically, fanciful. Flashed on the big board during the seventh game of the World Series, it read:

title: Exchanges Battle Over Fall
description: The financial futures and options industry, bloodied by huge losses from the stock market plunge, is now waging a bitter battle with the New York Stock Exchange.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $120,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,716,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said profit for the latest 9-month period improved by more than 10 percent despite an after-tax charge of $10.2 million for the write- off of the FSLIC secondary reserve taken by the company in the second quarter.

title: EG&G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 1986 results are adjusted to reflect the acquisition of KT Aerofab Inc., acquired in the first quarter of 1987 and accounted for a pooling of interest basis.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Two Views of Hate
description: The National Rifle Association has decided that its major opponent, Handgun Control Inc., is a hate group.

title: Cardis Plans to Sell Tuneup Masters
description: The Cardis Corporation said it planned to sell its Tuneup Masters Inc. subsidiary for $78.2 million. The sale comes a little more than a year after Cardis, an auto-parts supplier, acquired Tuneup Masters for $52 million. The 282-outlet auto-repair chain had operating revenue of $41.9 million in the nine months ended April 30.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 The sale of land rights in China maybe permitted under a proposal being considered by the Government. The proposal, mainly affecting the nation's peasants, would be the first activity of its kind since 1949, an official said. Page A1

title: Prison for Ex-J.D.L. Chief in Bombing
description: A former head of the Jewish Defense League was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in Federal prison for taking part in a series of ''terrorist bombings'' in the New York area since 1984 to protest Soviet treatment of Jews.

title: PTL Fund Drive Is Proposed By Creditors Under New Plan
description: Creditors of the PTL ministry will submit a reorganization plan Tuesday that calls for raising an extra $10 million to $20 million from PTL followers, selling some of the ministry's real estate holdings and increasing visitor charges at the ministry's sprawling Christian retreat in South Carolina.

title: An Imposter, Unmasked, Stands Tall
description: THERE is a Mount Everest of the mind. A rugged monolith with snow-covered slopes, its ridges climb steeply to a single sharp peak towering over the surrounding range of Himalayan mountains. That Everest is sometimes not the real Everest but actually a nearby summit known as Makalu.

title: Kirkland Pledges to Help Teamsters Fight Any Government Takeover
description: Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., today deplored efforts by the Justice Department to put the teamsters' union under Federal control, and he pledged the federation as an ally in the union's struggle against the Government.

title: Changes Not on N.F.L. Owners' Agenda
description: The owners of the 28 National Football League teams are not expected to enact any changes in the playoff system or the tiebreaker procedures when they meet here for a day, or possibly two, starting Tuesday.

title: Careers; Fostering Engineers' Creativity
description: LAST week, professors, government officials and corporate executives met at the Stevens Institute of Technology, in Hoboken, N.J., to discuss changes needed in engineering education - creative ones that will allow engineers to prepare for the next century. Similar discussions are being held at engineering schools all over the country.

title: ROLLINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prices of Seats Tumbling, Too
description: The prices of memberships on the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange have been falling almost as fast as stock prices.

title: Bond Prices Up, but Trading Slows
description: The fierce bond market rally triggered by the collapse in stock prices continued yesterday but seemed to be running out of steam.

title: Virginia Tech Hit by Sanctions
description: Virginia Tech's basketball team cannot play in postseason games for two years and the football team will have its scholarships cut back under sanctions imposed today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued title insurance operations of $3,737,000 for the quarter and $4,919,000 for the 9 months.

title: CHINA CONSIDERING LETTING FARMERS SELL LAND RIGHTS
description: The Government is considering allowing peasants, for the first time, to sell and buy the rights to use farmland, an activity tantamount to selling the land itself.

title: Corcoran Names a Director
description: Christina Orr-Cahall, the director of the art division at the Oakland (Calif.) Museum, was named director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art and its affiliated art school today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: James Thompson, the starting quarterback for Temple, has left the team to concentrate on his studies, Coach Bruce Arians said. . . . Randy Lanier, the 1986 Indianapolis 500 rookie of the year, was arrested yesterday in Puerto Rico on Federal narcotics charges pending in Illinois, the F.B.I. announced.

title: INSIDE
description: Salvador Rights Aide Slain The president of a Salvadoran human-rights commission that has criticized the Government was killed by two gunmen. Page A3. Investor Kills a Broker A Miami man who faced ruin because of collapsed stock prices shot a Merrill Lynch executive to death and took his own life. Page D13.

title: Tax Watch; Trying to Find A Stock Culprit
description: AS Wall Street and Washington pundits try to identify the origins of last week's stock market cataclysm, some fingers are being pointed at taxes. Did the tax increase proposed by Congressional tax writers just before the market went wild help unleash the selling frenzy on Wall Street? Was the sweeping Tax Reform Act of 1986 responsible in any way? Did a new tax proposal in West Germany, blamed for a rise in interest rates there, help to ignite the global selloff of stocks?

title: African Bank In U.S. Market
description: The African Development Bank is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's, the 10-year notes yield about 1.19 percentage points more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

title: Ford Profit Up by 1% In Quarter
description: The Ford Motor Company today reported a net income of $703 million, or $2.76 a share, for the third quarter, a period that is expected to produce sharply differing results for the domestic auto companies.

title: Library Starts Road to 84-Mile Shelves Under Park
description: After years of too many books and not enough shelves, the New York Public Library is going underground.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Israeli Witness Voices Doubt On Demjanjuk Nazi ID Card
description: A defense expert raised questions today about a Nazi identity card crucial to the war crimes case against John Demjanjuk, testifying that the Russians often forged World War II documents.

title: Soviet Summitry: Too Clever by Half
description: Mikhail Gorbachev miscalculated. The Soviet leader insisted that he would meet with President Reagan again only if the United States made concessions on space-based defenses. That surprise linkage changed the issue. It had been the Star Wars program, which is also easy for Americans to assail. Mr. Gorbachev's new condition makes the issue one of capitulating to the Russians, and that's hard for Americans to accept.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Two
description: Bryan Murray, the coach of the Washington Captials, and Ron Asselstine, a linesman, have each been suspended for three games by the National Hockey League for an incident between periods of a game on Oct. 11. At the end of the first period of the Capitals' game with Buffalo, Murray confronted the officials in the area leading to the dressing rooms, the league said in a statement. Murray and Asselstine became involved in a verbal dispute and some pushing as the game officials were returning to the ice, the league said.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $23,098,000 extraordinary loss for the quarter and 9 months.

title: KEY RATES
THE DANCE: LIZ LERMAN
description: NUCLEAR wastes may remain toxic for centuries.

title: Skeletons Record the Burdens of Work
description: THE life one lives can leave an indelible mark on the bones, and anthropologists are perfecting their ability to find in human skeletons clues not only to diet and disease but also to the daily activities and occupations of people long dead.

title: Foes of Arizona's Governor Nearing Goal in Recall Drive
description: Opponents of Gov. Evan Mecham said today that they have collected more signatures on recall petitions than the 343,913 votes the Governor received in last fall's election.

title: Walton Takes Some Blame
description: Joe Walton held his weekly news conference this afternoon and spent much of the session defending his play-calling during the Jets' 17-16 loss to the Washington Redskins on Sunday.

title: KwaMhlanga Journal; Ndebeles, Sentenced to Independence, Fight Back
description: KwaNdebele, an impoverished tribal homeland of sprawling tin-roofed settlements, is being pushed toward an independence that almost no one here seems to want.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain equal to 71 cents a share from the sale of tax benefit leases acquired in prior years for the quarter and year. c-After a charge equal to 45 cents a share to provide for an environmental contingency for the quarter and year.

title: Schools Let Down U.S., Xerox Chairman Says
description: America's public schools have put the United States ''at a terrible competitive disadvantage'' by turning out workers with ''a 50 percent defect rate,'' the chairman of the Xerox Corporation charged today.

title: HENLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $75,000,000 gain from the initial public offering of a minority interest in Henley's Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. subsidiary. c-Net loss

title: New York City Loses a Ruling In Trash Battle
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled here today that the City of New York was in contempt of court for failing to halt garbage and hospital wastes from polluting the beaches of Woodbridge Township, a New Jersey community across the Arthur Kill from the city's Fresh Kills landfill.

title: In New York, a Renaissance for Marriage
description: More New Yorkers are marrying than at any time since shortly after World War II -confounding demographers, sociologists, psychiatrists and others about what, if anything, it means.

title: ROTHSCHILD, L F UNTERBERG, TOWBIN HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,298,000. c-Net income

title: The Lure of Local History Keeps a Digger Digging
description: LEAD: The letters that arrive at Ted Aber's red-shuttered trailer on a bluff above Abenaki Lake in the Adirondacks usually come from farther shores.

title: JACK ROTH
description: Jack Roth, a former reporter for The New York Times, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Police Focused On Taped Views Of Noted Blacks
description: When protests prompted the New York City Police Department to stop taping a call-in program on WLIB-AM last summer, police officials said the monitoring was intended mainly to learn about planned events in the black community.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $281,000 for the quarter and net of $8,795,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Cattle Virus Is Studied
description: The Department of Agriculture and the National Institutes of the Health are investigating a cattle virus similar to the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Intel Circuit Board
description: The Intel Corporation has introduced a circuit board to allow owners of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computers and some compatible machines to upgrade their equipment. Intel said its Inboard 386/PC, priced at $995, uses its 80386 microprocessor to increase the speed of a standard PC with an Intel 8088 microprocessor by as much as 10 times. The board adds additional memory as well, Intel said. The board will not work with PC's using Intel's 8086 chip or 80286 chip.

title: A Market View From the Inside
description: John J. Phelan Jr., at the center of a maelstrom as the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, called for action to reduce the budget and trade deficits to lower interest rates and calm market fears.

title: MASSACHUSETTS COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $100,000 for the latest quarter and $340,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Salvadoran Human Rights Activist Slain
description: The president of a Salvadoran human rights commission was killed by two gunmen today as he left home to drive two of his children to school, officials said.

title: Porter Paint Sale
description: Courtaulds P.L.C., a leading British textiles and chemical company, said it had agreed to buy the Porter Paint Company of Louisville, Ky., for $140 million. The American company specializes in heavy coating paints and is expected to have sales of about $120 million and profit of about $7.5 million this year, Courtaulds said.

title: China Won't Be at Soviet Fete Special to The New York Times
description: The Chinese Communist Party, rejecting overtures from Moscow, will not attend the celebration next week of the 70th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Soviet and Chinese officials said today.

title: Albania Criticizes Yugoslavia For Action in an Ethnic Area
description: - Albania said today that Yugoslavia's decision to send a special police unit to a strife-torn southern Yugoslav province threatened relations between the two nations.

title: Turkey Troubled by U.S.-Soviet Missile Talks
description: Turkey has begun to signal growing concern that negotiations on nuclear missile reductions in Europe will leave its conventional forces particularly exposed to superior Soviet units.

title: DU PONT DE NEMOURS, E I & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and year-ago quarter include $31 million and $21 million, respectively, from the sale of a business.

title: CONCERT: TUCKER GALA
description: BAD singing heavily outweighed good at the annual star-studded Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala at Carnegie Hall Sunday night; it was not the kind of evening to send one away with renewed hopes for the health of the operatic mainstream that Mr. Tucker served so devotedly in his lifetime. But there were breaths of fresh air to remember the evening by.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Reviews; 'Top Flight,' Chronicle of Aeronautics
description: ''TOP FLIGHT'' is an homage to the Air Force; sometimes it looks and feels like a recruiting poster. Uncle Sam wants you, so to speak, to zoom across the sky. Recruiting poster or not, however, the one-hour CBS documentary, on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight, is done with great style. There is a sense of humor, too.

title: Open Positions on Nasdaq Short Sales Down 1.8%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, in the month ended Oct. 15 fell 4.3 million shares, or 1.8 percent, to 232.2 million shares.

title: Amid the Clamor, Twins Exhilarated
description: The scenes that turned the city streets from sedate to sheer madness Monday night could have happened anywhere.

title: CNW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $2,466,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Chrysler Truck Rebate
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would offer $500 cash rebates to buyers of domestically built 1987 and 1988 Dodge pickup trucks, effective immediately. No expiration date has been set.

title: The Wolf, Long Gone, Returns to the U.S.
description: THE primal howl of the wolf, once heard from central Mexico to the Arctic, has been almost completely silenced south of the Canadian border in the few centuries since Europeans arrived on this continent.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls, Sharply Divided, Will Debate Tomorrow
description: Republican Presidential candidates head into their first debate Wednesday sharply divided on domestic and foreign policy and prepared to highlight rather than camouflage the fault lines in their party.

title: Protective Gear Issued for Postal Workers Handling Lab Samples
description: Local postal workers handling blood and urine samples in transit to testing laboratories near here have been issued protective gear including rubber gloves and masks.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
California Supports Opponents of Animal Traps
description: Near-drought conditions, resulting in more coyote attacks against livestock and household pets in rural California, have renewed a debate here over steel-jawed leg traps. But now opponents of the traps have unexpected support in a battle they had all but given up.

title: 20 MILLION IN U.S. SAID TO GO HUNGRY
description: A study on hunger released today contends that 20 million Americans do not get enough to eat every day.

title: PRINCEVILLE DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $41,240 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $180,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,564 for the quarter and $69,035 for the 9 months.

title: Potomac, Capital's Biggest Restaurant, Is Closing
description: The owner of Potomac, the biggest and most extravagant restaurant in Washington, said yesterday he was closing the 15-month-old establishment because of a dispute with the landlord. The shutdown would affect more than 200 employees and about 100 companies and individuals who have booked parties there through the holiday season and into next year.

title: World Bank Deeds Must Follow Words
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: DELTA WOODSIDE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Year-ago quarter net reflects a restatement for the recognitionof the pre-acquisition net operating loss carryforward included in the current year.

title: Institutional Managers Inactive
description: Most institutional stock managers said they were on the sidelines yesterday, neither snapping up bargains after last week's market rout nor adding to the pressure by selling further.

title: Sports of The Times; The Counterfeit Season
description: KEN O'BRIEN, the Jets' quarterback, trots back into the pocket against the Redskins and shoots a pass straight as Cupid's arrow, right into the bosom of Barry Wilburn, who is clear. The only snag is that Wilburn doesn't play for the Jets. Wilburn's with the other guys.

title: Personal Spending Off Sharply
description: Americans' consumer spending fell sharply last month, the first decline since January. Analysts said the September setback was likely to be followed by even worse news in the months ahead because of the jolt to consumer confidence from the huge declines in the stock market.

title: For Battered Women, A Milestone Case
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIPS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $20 million for the latest period and $9 million for the year-earlier period. The 1986 figure included an after- tax gain of $106 million on the sale of Occidental's 20 percent holding of the common stock of Southland Corp. The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER GROUP
description: THE Quintet of the Americas and several of its friends brought music by two true originals to the Americas Society on Friday night, one of them celebrated, the other barely known at all.

title: B.P. Delay Is Sought In London
description: With the London stock market falling sharply again today, bankers underwriting the $12.2 billion offering of British Petroleum Company shares met with Government officials this afternoon to urge them to postpone the sale.

title: Bridge: When Opponents' Behavior Gives a Clue to the Declarer
description: The laws of bridge bar you from taking into account the behavior and demeanor of your partner, but the opponents are fair game. If they look happy or sad, you can try to take advantage of that fact at your own risk. If it transpires that the happiness or sadness was due to factors unrelated to the card play, that is your misfortune.

title: 2 YEARS OF FAILURE END AS U.S. LOFTS BIG TITAN ROCKET
description: The nation's most powerful unmanned rocket returned to work with a roar yesterday, ending two years of back-to-back failures.

title: Vice President of What?
description: Continuing world financial turmoil has pushed even President Reagan grudgingly to accept the possibility of tax increases to reduce the budget deficit and rebuild confidence. That concession, though late and lame, lubricates the negotiations with Congress that began yesterday.

title: TV Reviews; Billy Joel in Soviet on HBO
description: IN tune with all the current talk of glasnost, pay cable's Home Box Office has brought ''Billy Joel From Leningrad, U.S.S.R.'' to its schedule. The hourlong program, which can be seen tonight at 11:30, is the latest presentation in a series called ''HBO World Stage,'' featuring music stars in performances around the globe. On a worldwide tour with his musicians, Mr. Joel appeared in August at the V. I. Lenin Sports and Concert Complex in Leningrad. The shows were heralded as the first time an American pop-music star had brought a fully staged rock show to the Soviet Union.

title: Burial Is Set for Kate Smith
description: More than a year after her death, Kate Smith will be buried in a cemetery near Lake Placid in accordance with her wishes, a family friend said today.

title: Ridding Mice of Diabetes
description: The gene for human insulin has been transplanted successfully into diabetic mice. Their diabetes was cured, but after several weeks, the animals died of an excess of insulin.

title: Stuart Buchan, 45, Is Dead; Writer of Novels and Stories
description: Stuart Buchan, a novelist and short story writer, died on Oct. 15 in the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 45 years old and lived in Craryville, N.Y.

title: NATIONAL SANITARY SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' net includes pro forma adjustments for the period Jan. 1 through June 17, which assume that as of Jan. 1, National Sanitary Supply had: acquired the business of Paul Koss Supply Co.; resolved the contingent payment of $10 million to the former owners; and incurred the additional costs of operating as a separate public company.

title: Gene-Altered Mice Make Human Protein in Their Milk
description: SCIENTISTS have transplanted the gene for an important human protein into female mice, causing the animals to produce the substance in their milk.

title: Marie Kryl, Concert Pianist, A Member of Musical Family
description: Marie Kryl, a concert pianist who appeared with the Chicago, Cincinnati and St. Louis Symphony Orchestras, died Sunday in Orlando, Fla. She was 90 years old.

title: Film: 'Positive I.D.'
description: ''Positive I.D.'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts of Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 14. The film is playing at the Sutton, Third Avenue and 57th Street.

title: JEFFERSON SMURFIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects equity in its 50 percent stake in Container Corp. of America on an after-tax basis of $13,016,000, or 67 cents a share for the quarter and $28,844,000, or $1.50 a share for the 9 months; the company acquired the stake on Sept. 30, 1986.

title: Science Watch; How Larvae Can Heal
description: FOR more than 100 years, physicians have known that blowfly larvae somehow keep wounds clean and prevent them from becoming infected. Now researchers know why.

title: The Kremlin's Woes
description: The news that Secretary of State George Shultz went home from Moscow without agreement on a summit meeting came as a shock to an East-West meeting of journalists here.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,672,000.

title: Browns Top Rams; Vikings Roll, 34-27
description: Felix Wright, a Browns safety, returned a goal-line interception 68 yards tonight to set up a field goal and later returned an interception 40 yards for a touchdown to help Cleveland beat the Los Angeles Rams, 30-17.

title: Rangers Hold Flyers to 2-2 Tie
description: The Flyers and Rangers played with the type of passion peculiar to each team - the Rangers doggedly, the Flyers voraciously - and they played well enough to emerge from overtime last night still linked in a 2-2 tie. But the game and its outcome were not the subjects discussed in the aftermath.

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Students Who Help Professors Make Money; Call It Exploitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Syd Thrift, general manager, to a two-year contract. BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Waived Scott Meents and Tom Sheehey, forwards. DETROIT (NBA) - Signed Vinnie Johnson, guard, to a multiyear contract. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Waived J. J. Weber, forward. SEATTLE (NBA) - Matched an offer sheet by the Phoenix Suns for Alton Lister, center. FOOTBALL DALLAS (NFC) - Waived Alex Green and Bill Hill, cornerbacks; Mike Dwyer, defensive tackle; Gerald White, fullback; Dale Jones and Jeff Hurd, linebackers; Steve Cisowski, offensive lineman; Loren Snyder, quarterback; Tommy Haynes, safety; Rich Borresen, tight end, and Chuck Scott and Cornell Burbage, wide receivers. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Waived John Haines, defensive lineman; Wes Neighbors, center; Derek Holloway, wide receiver; Bryant Jones, defensive back, and Bob Ontko, linebacker. Placed Orlando Lowry, linebacker, and Mark Boyer, tight end, on injured reserve. JETS - Waived Jay Brophy, linebacker; Sean Dykes and George Radachowsky, defensive backs; Scott Holman, wide receiver; Eric Coss, center, and John Thomas, tackle. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Jim Asmus, punter; Mark Cochran, offensive tackle; Sam Kennedy and Fred Small, linebackers; Darryl Pollard, cornerback, and John Sullivan, safety. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended Bryan Murray, Washington Capitals' coach, for three games, effective Nov. 2, and Ron Asselstine, linesman, for three games, effective immediately, for an off-ice incident between periods of Oct. 11 game. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Recalled Dwight Mathiasen, right wing, from Muskegon of the International Hockey League, and sent Brad Aitken, left wing, to Muskegon. SOCCER BALTIMORE BLAST (Indoor League) - Released Bob Ryerson, forward. COLLEGES TEMPLE - Announced that James Thompson, quarterback, has left the football team.

title: About Education; Teachers Helping Teachers
description: THIS report might be called Two Tales of One City. The first, recounted by a professor who trains new teachers, is a horror story; the second, from a report on New York City schools, celebrates the joy of teaching.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Becor Western Inc., South Milwaukee, Wis., said its board would recommend that shareholders approve the previously announced acquisition of the company by B-E Holdings Inc., a management group.

title: Peripherals; New Look of Magazines
description: UPTIME was mentioned here a few weeks ago as a computer magazine that bypasses the printed page entirely, supplying both editorial matter and ready-to-run programs on a standard disk. It differs from Compute!'s PC Magazine, which is sold as an integral magazine-and-disk package, and such other publications as Ahoy! and Compute!'s Gazette, which offer the programs printed in the magazine as separate, extra-cost disk subscriptions.

title: Australians Set Rescue of Rothwell
description: Leading Australian executives and the Western Australian state government have joined to provide a $384 million (Australian) rescue package for Rothwells Ltd., the Perth-based merchant bank, State Premier Brian Burke said.

title: Many Faces of the Mahabharata
description: It was another case of a contradiction between traditional and modern India that was not really a contradiction. While astronomers used advanced instruments to study a solar eclipse this fall, a million ordinary Hindus found a different sort of meaning, traveling to Kurukshetra for ritual baths of purification in a huge lake.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective September 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $24,462,000 for the quarter and $75,424,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $6,569,000 for the quarter and $24,714,000 for the 9 months. The company said its latest third includes charges of $13.1 million, including a $3.5 million charge for an early retirement program.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MASK OF COMMAND. By John Keegan. 368 pages. Illustrated. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95. ''THE MASK OF COMMAND'' is a book about what it means to be a general that starts off from the premise that it can mean many different things. Over the centuries kings and demagogues have doubled as generals, and generals have doubled as diplomats and priests; a commanding officer, like the army that serves under him, is always the product of a particular society, and the qualities that his position calls for vary from age to age and place to place.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share, from the sale of 200,000 shares, or about 1 percent, of the stock of Shaklee Japan K.K. c-Includes a gain of $43.8 million, or $3.32 a share, from the initial public offering of 20 percent of the capital stock of Shaklee Japan.

title: Middleweight Picture
description: Although Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan are the attractions in the showdown for the World Boxing Council middleweight title in Las Vegas, Nev., Thursday, a couple of other middleweights could be affected by the outcome. Marvin Hagler, the former undisputed middleweight champion, and Sugar Ray Leonard, the man who beat him last April and then retired, are both expected to be at the fight. And, according to the bout's promoter, Bob Arum, either man might be drawn into a future W.B.C. middleweight title match, depending on whether Hearns or Roldan wins. ''My feeling is that if Thomas wins, Marvin will come back to fight him,'' Arum said. ''Not so with Roldan. Though Marvin believes he can win against Roldan, he's indicated he won't subject himself to the physical beating you take when you fight Roldan. As for Leonard, in talking to his attorney, Mike Trainer, I got the feeling that if Roldan wins, Leonard would fight him. I don't think Leonard wants to fight Hearns again.''

title: SBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $96,600 for the 9 months.

title: EXXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 13.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 27, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Dutch Government To Assist Fokker
description: The Dutch Government said it would take a large minority stake in the aircraft maker N.V. Fokker as part of an elaborate financial aid package. Fokker would receive 527 million guilders, or about $258 million, from banks and the Government, the Economics Minister, Rudolf de Korte, told Parliament.

title: Pretoria Official Announces Arrests of Youths
description: The South African police have arrested an unspecified number of mixed-race youths between the ages of 14 and 18 who are suspected of political crimes under the 16-month-old nationwide state of emergency, a senior Pretoria official has announced.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $286,000 for repurchasing of debentures.

title: Liver Problems Halt Test of Alzheimer's Drug
description: Clinical studies on an experimental drug to treat Alzheimer's disease have been halted after about 20 percent of the test subjects experienced changes in liver chemistry, the Food and Drug Administration and the drug's manufacturer have announced.

title: Hanoi Chief and 100 Artists Trade Blunt Complaints
description: A hundred leaders of Vietnam's literary and artistic establishment have apparently told the country's new Communist Party leader in blunt terms what they think is wrong with state-supported cultural endeavors.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $550,000 for retirement of debt. c-After extraordinary charges of $550,000 for the quarter and $7,875,000 for the 9 months from retirement of debt. The company had a pre-tax loss of $10.3 million during the latest quarter on investment securities, including a reserve of $7.5 million to reduce its short-term marketable bond portfolio to estimated market value.

title: Nance Sidelined
description: After fracturing the ring finger on his right hand, Larry Nance will be sidelined from his starting forward job for the Phoenix Suns for about four weeks. Nance suffered the injury in the first quarter of an exhibition game against the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night in Las Vegas, Nev., when he hit his hand on the rim while attempting to dunk an offensive rebound. . . . Kent Benson, the Cleveland Cavaliers' forward-center, suffered a severely hyperextended right elbow in a practice session yesterday and will be out of action for three to five weeks.

title: Louis Guttman, a Leader Of Social Research in Israel
description: Louis Guttman, founder and scientific director of the Israel Institute of Applied Social Research, died of melanoma on Sunday in Minneapolis, while on a visit to the United States to deliver lectures and get medical treatment. He was 71 years old. In addition to founding the Israeli institute in 1947, Mr. Guttman was well known for having devised in the 1940's a widely used technique for measuring and analyzing public opinion that is called the Guttman scale analysis.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about two men talking outside te Queens courthouse where the Howard Beach murder trial is taking place misidentified the man at the right. He was Augustus Agate, lawyer for a defendant in a future trial arising from the Howard Beach events.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $150 million loss on the sale of Container Corp. Year-ago 9-month results include a first quarter charge of $57 million for LIFO drawdown. The company said both 1986 periods include charges of $35 million for a restructuring provision and $39 million for alternative energy property writedowns.

title: Losses at Options Unit Hurt Continental Illinois
description: In a risky acquisition gone awry, the Continental Illinois Corporation said today that it would take a $90 million charge in the fourth quarter for losses at its affiliate, First Options of Chicago Inc.

title: Private Agencies Faring Well in Plunge
description: As the stock market continued its drop yesterday, chief executive officers of private companies were congratulating themselves for being in that condition.

title: Lithuanian Farce
description: ''When Lithuania Ruled the World,'' a historical musical farce written by Kestutis Nakas and in-spired by traditional Lithuanian folk music, will be presented on Monday nights in November at 9 and 11 o'-clock at the Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, between Sixth and Seventh Streets. Tickets are $8. Information and reservations: 475-4132.

title: Pistons' Johnson Signs
description: Vinnie Johnson, the Detroit Piston guard, ended his holdout yesterday and signed a multiyear contract. Johnson will earn an average of $650,000 a season during a three-year agreement and will have an option on a fourth year, according to The Detroit Free Press. Johnson, 31 years old, averaged 15.7 points a game last season, finishing second in balloting for the National Basketball Associatin's Sixth Man Award. Johnson has only four exhibition games to work himself into playing shape before the regular season opens Nov. 6. . . . The Seattle SuperSonics have matched the reported $4.1 million, four-year offer sheet that Alton Lister, the free-agent center, got from the Phoenix Suns last week.

title: Yankees Press $10 Million Claim Against City
description: The New York Yankees filed court papers late yesterday to continue a $10 million damage suit against the city.

title: FILTERTEK COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Exchanges To Extend Early Close
description: After another frenzied day of sharp declines and heavy trading, the nation's major stock exchanges said yesterday that they would continue to close early through the end of this week.

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There are no year-ago share earnings because the preferred stock requirements exceeded net income. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: People
description: * Toni Meyer Maloney will return to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide as senior vice president, public relations.

title: A Lower Dollar vs. Recession
description: The string has finally run out for Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d. All good things do not come in a tidy package, and Mr. Baker must now choose between a lower dollar and a recession.

title: Kuwait Registering 3 Tankers for British Flag
description: British officials said today that Kuwait had registered two of its tankers to fly the British flag and was in the process of registering a third.

title: Family Dollar Lures Coast America's Chief
description: Family Dollar Stores Inc., a discount chain whose president and chief operating officer quit last month in the wake of lower earnings, has named Ralph D. Dillon to the posts.

title: High Court Case Renews Assault On Rent Control
description: Arlene Lawson and Eric A. Bracher don't know each other, but they are both bit players in a legal drama to be played out Nov. 10 when the United States Supreme Court hears a case that could provoke a new assault on rent controls.

title: Political Marketing; Kemp and Dole Ads Try 'Morning Again' Style
description: It is morning again in America for two Republican Presidential candidates, but with a new twist.

title: Righetti Files as Free Agent
description: Dave Righetti, who is concerned about the way that Billy Martin may use him next season, wasted no time in filing for free agency. Righetti's agent, Bill Goodstein, sent a telegram to the Players Association at 12:06 A.M. yesterday declaring the pitcher a free agent.

title: Rockaways Need Revitalization and Environmental Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Board's John J. Phelan Jr. Looks at the Plunge and Beyond
description: While the stock market continued its relentless decline, John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of the New York Stock Exhange, appeared calm as he sat down yesterday with a group of editors and reporters from The New York Times for a wide-ranging discussion.

title: PHONEMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $303,000 and $397,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $157,000 and $282,000 for the quarter and 9 months, repectively.

title: Thompson Appoints Manager in New York
description: J. Walter Thompson USA has appointed 38-year-old James R. Heekin 3d as general manager of the New York office as well as executive vice president and a director of the United States company. He succeeds Stephen G. Bowen Jr., who held the position for the last three years while also serving as president.

title: Mrs. Reagan as a Cancer-Patient Role Model; Misleading Figures
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Leading Contenders for Nomination to the Supreme Court
description: Laurence H. Silberman Age 52, of Washington...appointed to United States Court of Appeals for District of Columbia in 1985 by Presi-dent Reagan...served in Nixon and Ford Administrations as Under Sec-retary of Labor, Deputy Attorney General, Ambassador to Yugoslavia ...educated at Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School...prac-ticed law in Honolulu in 1960's and Washington in 1970's between govern-ment jobs and was executive vice president and general counsel of Crocker National Bank from 1979-1983... was a top foreign policy and intelligence advisor to the 1980 Rea-gan campaign...helped formulate Nixon Administration policy advocat-ing use of affirmative action prefer-ences for racial minorities, but later decided such programs led to rigid racial quotas and became a fierce critic of them... joined in recent decision finding racial hiring quotas for District of Columbia Fire Depart-ment illegal...has reputation as strong conservative on appeals court, but split with the five other Reagan appointees this summer when they fueded with five democratic appoint-ees over key procedural matters af-fecting ideological balance of power ...confirmation to appeals court was delayed by questions about Crocker National Bank's illegal failure to re-port $3.98 billion in cash transactions while he was there, and mixed rating by American Bar Association...said to be a blunt-spoken and sometimes abrasive man of strong opinions who has made enemies. Anthony M. Kennedy Age 51, of Sacramento, Calif...ap-pointed to United States Court of Ap-peals for the Ninth Circuit in 1976 by President Ford...educated at Stan-ford University, London School of Economics, Harvard Law School... practiced law in San Francisco and Sacramento...has taught part time at McGeorge Law School since 1965 ...struck down the ''legislative veto'' as an unconstitutional encroachment on Presidential powers in a major 1980 decision that was affirmed by the Supreme Court...in 1985, wrote first major appellate decision reject-ing idea that sex discrimination law to women in historically low-paid jobs that are of ''comparable worth'' to higher-paid jobs dominated by men ...upheld Navy's discharge of homo-sexual officers in 1980, noting that up-holding the consititutionality of the challenged regulations did not mean he considered them to be wise...he would be closely scrutinized by women's groups and abortion rights groups, who suspect he may not sym-pathize with their cause. Ralph K. Winter Jr. Age 52, of New Haven . . . appointed to United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit by President Reagan in 1982 . . . educated at Yale University and Yale Law School, where he has been a close friend and colleague of Judge Robert H. Bork since 1962 . . . said to maintain close relationship with Justice Thurgood Marshall, now one of Supreme Court's most liberal members, for whom he was a law clerk from 1961 to 1962 on the Second Circuit . . . taught a wide array of courses at Yale, where he was regarded as a strong conservative and advocate of free market economics, somewhat libertarian on free speech and some other issues . . . jokingly dubbed ''Bork without the beard'' by one official but is viewed as more pragmatic, less doctrinaire in judicial rulings . . . has assailed rulings that are ''based on the personal values of the judges involved rather than traditional criteria such as custom, language, history or legislative intent.'' Douglas H. Ginsburg

title: Making the Beaumont Work
description: The enthusiastic critical and audience response to ''Anything Goes'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater - following the success of ''The Front Page'' and ''The House of Blue Leaves'' there - appears to have given the lie to claims that the Lincoln Center theater was unworkable, even as its financial resources are being tested to the limit.

title: U.S. Agency Bars Drug Against AIDS Infection
description: An expert advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration has turned down approval of an experimental drug intended as treatment for an infection that kills AIDS patients.

title: Job Offices Are Planned For Schools
description: A prominent executive plans to start a group to run employment offices in New York high schools and staff them with business people who would arrange to find jobs for qualified graduates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about one brokerage firm's experience with the stock market plunge gave an incorrect title in some editions for a book by John Kenneth Galbraith. It is ''The Great Crash.''

title: West Point-Shaw
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. said that because of market conditions, its agreement to sell its carpet and rug division to Shaw Industries had been terminated. West Point, which makes household fabrics, said talks are not expected to resume in the near future. Shaw is based in Dalton, Ga.

title: CBS Reopens Talks With Sony on Unit
description: CBS Inc. has reopened negotiations with the Sony Corporation about the possible sale of the CBS Records Group to Sony for $2 billion, executives at the two companies said yesterday.

title: G.M. REVISION AVOIDS LOSS; CHRYSLER UP
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had revised some of its accounting procedures, enabling it to avoid reporting a third-quarter operating loss and improving its net income.

title: Navajos Plan Luxury Tourist Resort on Reservation
description: While the Government's top Indian affairs officials grappled with how to restructure the Federal bureacracy to give tribes more control over their destiny, the 200,000-member Navajo Nation announced today that it was taking on a new private enterprise: a joint venture with the designer Oleg Cassini to build a world-class luxury resort on the Navajo reservation.

title: Bonn Surplus Nears High
description: West Germany reported today its second-highest monthly trade surplus ever, and economists said the figures, further evidence of chronic imbalance in world trade, were likely to increase pressure on Bonn to accept a weaker dollar.

title: 5 Injured in Explosion In Jersey Science Class
description: - Five students were injured, two of them seriously, in an explosion here today during a science class at Collingswood Junior High School, officials said.

title: I.B.M. Sets $1 Billion Buyback
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, joining the hundreds of companies that have announced stock buyback programs since the market's plunge nine days ago, said yesterday that it would repurchase up to $1 billion of its stock.

title: It's Time For Ghouls Or Goblins
description: 1. To the Point

title: Music: Liege Symphony
description: THE 25-year-old Liege Philharmonic of Belgium has not visited America before this season, but record listeners have been aware of it, and of its conductor, Pierre Bartholomee, for some time.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. News Adopts Ad Reward System
description: Faced by two competitors who have introduced discount programs that reward advertisers for increasing their market share in their newsweekly, U.S. News & World Report is instead adopting a more conventional reward system.

title: Kentucky Panel Sets Bond Offering
description: The Kentucky State Property and Building Commission is tentatively offering about $61 million of tax-exempt bonds for a Toyota project. Underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers are offering the debt issue due in 2007 with a maximum yield of 8 3/4 percent.

title: The Stage: In Revival, 'Fortune and Men's Eyes'
description: TWENTY years after its first staging here, John Herbert's ''Fortune and Men's Eyes'' has been revived at the Actors' Playhouse, where it had its first run. We have seen many plays, films and television programs about sexual power struggles in prisons since then, so the shock value of this story about a Canadian boys' reformatory has virtually disappeared - and that works to the benefit of the play. Mr. Herbert's four young inmates are much more compelling emotionally when their actions do not seem quite so astonishing as they once did. And the plot of the play seems both simpler and subtler.

title: 4 American Composers Win $9,000 in Awards
description: Four American composers received a total of $9,000 in awards for new chamber music at a concert Sunday during which their works were performed at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Real Estate; New Twist For a Mall In Jersey
description: FROM a distance, the most visible feature of the new town known as Newport in Jersey City is its residential towers. So far there are only four, all of them close to the Pavonia PATH station near the Hudson River.

title: Brazilians Break Down Taboo of Silence on AIDS
description: Over the last five years, even as public awareness of the AIDS problem has grown with the rising number of cases here, Brazilians suffering from the disease have continued to seek anonymity to avoid any stigma.

title: Despite Urgings by Wall St., Bradley Still Bars an '88 Run
description: With tremors shaking Wall Street in recent days, some prominent members of the financial community have been urging Senator Bill Bradley to reconsider his decision not to run for President.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS the AIDS crisis deepens and widens, more and more people are choosing to care at home for friends, relatives and lovers who are dying of AIDS.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
1950's Standby for Entertaining in the 80's
description: TRAVELING around the country in recent months, I have been surprised by the prevalence of cocktail parties as the chosen form of at-home entertaining - surprised because the cocktail party seemed to be a characteristic of the 1950's. Although it never died, it always took second place to the dinner party, the formal supper party or even the restaurant meal as a preferred way of entertaining.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN ENERGY & PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a non-cash writedown of about $319 million as a result of writedowns of oil and gas assets.

title: Warsaw Ballet to Stage 'Giselle' in the Bronx
description: The Warsaw Ballet will make its New York debut on Nov. 5 at 8 P.M., at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue in the Bronx, as part of the Polish company's first North American tour.

title: High-Yield Bonds Keep Us Competitive
description: To the Editor:
