title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and both periods reflect a charge of $51.8 million connected with the company's restructuring.

title: INVESTOR-SLAYER LED DOUBLE LIFE
description: The Justice Department said today that the distraught investor who killed a stock broker Monday and seriously wounded another before killing himself was leading a double life in Miami under the Federal witness protection program.

title: South Koreans Endorse Plans For Direct Vote
description: South Koreans overwhelmingly endorsed a new constitution Tuesday that clears the way for the first direct presidential elections here in 16 years.

title: Sampson Takes His Post
description: In his dreams, Ralph Sampson was a center again. He was the last line of defense, blocking shots and gathering rebounds for outlet passes that started fast breaks. He was the hub of an offense that allowed him either to dominate the pivot or pass off to teammates on the perimeter.

title: Stick to the Arias Plan
description: The Central American peace accord coming into effect next week promises a healing cease-fire and a chance for democracy. This intricate plan delicately balances compromises from left and right; the entire plan would be imperiled if there were any substantial deviation from its present terms, as articulated by its chief author, President Oscar Arias of Costa Rica.

title: KOCH DECLARES A HIRING FREEZE
description: Citing concern over the plunge of the stock market, Mayor Koch ordered a major ''retrenchment'' in New York City hiring.

title: Purchase by Ogilvy
description: The Ogilvy Group has reached an agreement to purchase Thomson-Leeds, a point-of-sale advertising company, and Alert Marketing, an in-store merchandising and sales organization. They will become part of a newly created Sales Promotion Group, part of Sage Worldwide.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer Adelphia Beats Columbia, 2-0: Adelphi strengthened its bid for a regional playoff berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament when the Panthers defeated nationally ranked Columbia, 2-0, yesterday at Garden City, L.I. Dominic Pascarella, a freshman forward, scored the first goal in the game's fourth minute, then assisted on Paul Howarth's goal with 11 minutes left. Tennis Leconte and Fleurian Advance: Frenchmen Henri Leconte and Jean Fleurian qualified yesterday for the second round of the $923,000 European Community championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Fleurian defeated Tim Wilkinson, 6-1, 6-4, and Leconte beat Jimmy Arias, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. In other matches, Jonas Svensson of Sweden eliminated Thierry Tulasne of France, 7-6, 7-5, and Sergio Casal of Spain ousted Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Graf Defeats Porwik: Steffi Graf, the defending champion, breezed to a 6-0, 6-1 victory over a fellow West German, Claudia Porwik, in the first round of the $150,000 European women's indoors tournament yesterday in Zurich, Switzerland. In other first-round matches, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, seeded fourth, defeated Elna Reinach of South Africa by 6-4, 7-5; Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, seeded fifth, beat Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-4, and Raffaella Reggi of Italy, seeded seventh, topped Gisele Miro of Brazil, 6-0, 6-2.(AP) Rain Interrupts First Round: Gary Muller of South Africa, seeded seventh, beat Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3, in the first round of the $20,000 Seiko Super tournament yesterday in Hong Kong. Because of rain, only three matches were completed in the opening round. In the other matches, Christi Saceanu of West Germany beat Andrew Castle of Britain by 6-2, 4-6, 7-5, and Rick Leach defeated Wolfang Popp of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2.(AP)

title: One Fell Swoop
description: Here is a bold action that the President and Congress could take to end financial hand-wringing and lay the basis for sustained growth throughout the world: Impose a $10 a barrel fee on all oil imported into the U.S.

title: 3,000 Tamils Arrested in India
description: The police made mass arrests in southern India today as ethnic Tamils protested Indian military action against Tamils in Sri Lanka.

title: Japanese Attitude: Wary, Not Fearful
description: They are wary, Japanese investors say, but hardly nervous. They will swear off buying binges, they insist, but they are not about to go on selling sprees.

title: Durable Goods Orders Rose 1.1% Last Month
description: Orders to American factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods climbed 1.1 percent last month, the first increase in three months. But some analysts predicted the upturn would be short-lived if the stock market turmoil should cause a recession.

title: Analysis; Sri Lankan Epilogue: A Divided Land
description: By capturing the Tamil rebel stronghold of Jaffna this week, Indian Army troops signaled their determination to enforce a peace accord in Sri Lanka. Yet achievement of a genuine peace here appears to many analysts to be more distant than ever.

title: WILLIAM COOPER
description: William Cooper, president and chairman of the board of Green Bus Lines, one of New York City's largest bus companies, died Sunday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, Queens. He was 90 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Rodgers Wins Award
description: Bob (Buck) Rodgers, who guided Montreal to a surprising third-place finish in the National League East this season, was named the National League Manager of the Year by the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday. Rodgers, in his third season as manager of the Expos, received 92 points from a 24-member committee, easily beating San Francisco's Roger Craig, the runner-up with 65 points. Rodgers, the only manager named on all ballots, collected 13 first-place votes, 8 for second and 3 for third. Points were awarded on a 5-3-1 basis. Craig, who led the Giants to the National League West title, had 6 firsts, 10 seconds and 5 thirds. Although Montreal was not expected to challenge for the pennant, Rodgers kept the Expos in contention until the final days of the season. Montreal compiled a 91-71 record and finished only four games behind the Cardinals and one game in back of the second-place Mets.

title: Scars of Plunge Not as Deep as Feared
description: Initially, at least, the stock market collapse has not scarred the public psyche, the Republican Party or the President as much as some people at first predicted, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Pickens Sees Plunge Spurring Takeovers
description: Depressed stock prices could lead to new corporate takovers ''within a week or so,'' T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said here today.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE are three reasons why Prof. Orley Ashenfelter is watching with interest as capital flees the stock market and moves into liquid assets. First, he teaches economics at Princeton University. Second, he is managing editor of The American Economic Review, the scholarly journal of the American Economic Association. Third, he writes and publishes a newsletter for wine investors and collectors that is called, fittingly, Liquid Assets.

title: Baker Meets Key Senate Democrats to Discuss Possible Nominees to Court
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, met with two key Senate Democrats today to seek their views on 13 Federal judges being considered for the next nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: The U.N. TODAY: OCT. 28, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Watching the Markets
description: Some commodity experts and Congressional aides are voicing concern that the White House may be considering a change in leadership at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission while the markets are still in a state of turbulence.

title: IPALCO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $48.7 million from the sale of the assets of Indianapolis Cablevision Inc.

title: LEON ALCALY
description: Leon Alcaly, a retired mathematics teacher at the Bronx High School of Science, died of complications resulting from leukemia Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: His Optimistic Style Has Not Helped To Ease Concerns Over the Economy
description: As the stock market continues its wild gyrations and many Americans worry that the nation may be looking over the edge of an economic precipice, President Reagan's aides say he is perplexed by the calls for greater leadership from the White House.

title: Perilous Economic Cures; Some Experts See Tax Increases and Cuts In Spending by U.S. as Spurs to Recession
description: Just when President Reagan and Congressional leaders have at last started moving toward a compromise on measures to reduce the Federal budget deficit by at least $23 billion next year, with the logjam apparently broken by the stock market plunge, an unlikely alliance of normally warring economists is warning that shrinking the deficit by raising taxes and cutting Government spending would be the wrong thing to do at the worst possible time.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results for 1986 include a gain from sale of Drake bakery operations that was approximately offset by costs of asset writedowns and plant consolidations.

title: SOVIET, IN SWITCH, WILL SEEK SUMMIT, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: In a seeming about-face, the Soviet Foreign Minister will return to Washington this week to tell President Reagan that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready for a summit meeting even if differences remain over space-based weapons, American and Soviet officials said today.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Battle Opens in Tribal Court Over Custody of Navajo Boy
description: - A 10-year-old Navajo boy, involved in a long legal battle over whether he should continue living with his non-Indian adoptive parents or be returned to his Indian mother, said again today that he did not want to return to the reservation.

title: Wall St. Settles Nearly All Trades Made Last Monday
description: The settlement of trades from Monday of last week was nearly completed yesterday, and the settlement of the next day's trades was progressing smoothly, Wall Street executives said.

title: China Bars Press at Congress
description: After allowing foreign reporters to attend the first day of the Chinese Communist Party congress, the party has reverted to total secrecy about the ensuing deliberations.

title: About New York; At Radio City, Ballads and Arias For the Shower
description: So comes June in the land of marketing and some hotshot gets this idea to push soap with a contest, a singing in the shower contest. We hold regional tryouts, all on the up and up, and pick finalists and bring them to New York City. We hire Radio City Music Hall for the big finish and have a blast. Give the winner, say, 2,000 bucks - and throw in 500 for second best.

title: 3-Dimensional Creators of the Comics
description: Jules Feiffer knew what to expect from his colleagues.

title: TIMKEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $85,474,000. The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect accounting method changes.

title: Ivan Beshoff, Last Survivor Of Mutiny on the Potemkin
description: Ivan Beshoff, the last survivor of the 1905 mutiny on the Russian battleship Potemkin, a harbinger of the Russian Revolution, died Sunday, his family said today. His birth certificate said he was 102 years old, but he contended he was 104.

title: U.N. Tells Reagan It Must Have U.S. Money
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has written to President Reagan warning that the United Nations faces insolvency in a few weeks if the United States does not pay a substantial portion of its annual contribution by then, according to United Nations officials.

title: CHEVRON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter earnings included $36 million in net gains from asset dispositions, including the company's share of an Amax asset sale; year-ago third quarter included a gain of $4 million relating to asset sales and writeoffs. The company said the latest quarter earnings were also increased by $15 million, as the positive impact of windfall profit tax refunds more than offset the negative effects of a settlement of a prior year non-U.S. tax issue and a LIFO inventory drawback. Year-earlier quarter included $13 million in pension gains. The company also said in the latest 9-month, asset sales net of write-offs amounted to a net gain of $234 million, while the year-ago results included net gains of $62 million. Earnings for the latest 9-month were also increased by a net of $65 million as windfall profit tax refunds and pension settlement gains more than offset an adverse non-U.S. tax settlement and LIFO inventory drawbacks. Year-ago 9-month results were decreased by $80 million in net charges relating to the company's manpower reduction program and associated pension gains. The latest third quarter and 9-month results include foreign exchange losses of $11 million and gains of $5 million, respectively, compared with gains of $57 million ad $65 million in the corresponding 1986 periods.

title: Brazil Plans Token Sum
description: Brazil is ready to pay a maximum of $500 million as a token payment on interest it owes to banks, a senior Finance Ministry official said today.

title: SIERRA PACIFIC RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Streetwise Prosecutor
description: In the high-profile world of New York City prosecutors, Mario Merola was a streetwise exception.

title: Ankara Journal; In Homely Items, the Entombed Ataturk Lives On
description: With the reverence reserved for those who have molded destiny, Turks have paid homage for decades at a stern and towering mausoleum that is as much a national shrine as Lenin's tomb in Moscow.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates declined for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Boryla Resigns
description: Vince Boryla resigned yesterday as president and general manager of the Denver Nuggets, but will continue to work with the team on a consulting basis. Pete Babcock, who has been vice president of basketball operations, was named to replace Boryla. . . . Antoine Carr, a 6-9 forward who has played for the Atlanta Hawks for the last three years, signed an offer sheet with the Boston Celtics yesterday. Carr averaged 6.6 points a game and 3.1 rebounds last season.

title: US HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,425,000 for the quarter and $3,477,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary tax charge of $1,558,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $399,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Net loss and after a loss of $19,362,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Willhite Out for Season
description: Gerald Willhite will be lost to the Denver Broncos for the rest of the National Football League season after suffering multiple fractures of his right leg Monday night in a 34-27 loss to the Minnesota Vikings. The 5-foot-10-inch, 200-pound running back, who was scheduled to undergo surgery yesterday in Denver, broke away for a 29-yard run that took him a step from the end zone when he was pulled down by Joey Browner, the safety. On the tackle, Willhite's right foot was caught under his body and he suffered agonizing pain from two breaks in the leg before being carried off the field.

title: Dance: Joffrey Ballet Opens at City Center
description: SOMETHING for everyone is what the Joffrey Ballet provides the public, and last night's opening of the company's fall season was no exception.

title: Senate Votes Bill Protecting Aged And Disabled From Major Illness
description: The Senate tonight passed a comprehensive bill to protect more than 31 million elderly and disabled people against the costs of catastrophic illnesses, after adding a new benefit to pay for prescription drugs.

title: Investment Strategist Recommending Cautious Re-entry
description: A month ago investors were wondering whether the five-year-old bull market in stocks was nearing an end. Today Byron R. Wien is actually wondering whether the end of a bear market is at hand.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Gift Is His to Give
description: Senator Steve Symms, who received $1,000 from an openly anti-Semitic group in his re-election campaign last year, thought the controversy the contribution generated was behind him in May, when he gave the money to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in Washington and the Idaho Holocaust Council.

title: USX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter results include a $66 million gain from asset sales, including the sale of USX's former Geneva Works in Utah. In addition, accounting changes increased steel operating income by $11 million in the latest third quarter. The year-ago quarter results include a $52 million after-tax charge to write down oil inventories, pre-tax gains of $25 million for assets sales, $4 million for pension accounting changes and $141 million from LIFO inventory liquidation. The quarter also included pre-tax charges totaling $61 million to settle contract disputes and to dispose of assets.

title: A New Lease for Independent Counsels
description: Despite the number of its officials who are under investigation, the Reagan Administration shamelessly pressed a legal attack on the Independent Counsel Act and lobbied Congress against its renewal. Now the House has responded with a five-year extension of the law, by a lopsided vote of 322 to 87. As a healthy majority prepares to pass the Senate version, the President ought to put a hold on thoughts of a veto.

title: For Duck Industry, An L.I. Think Tank
description: If there's one thing American diners can't stand, it's a fatty duck. ''The major complaint people have is that ducks have too much fat and not enough meat,'' said Dr. William F. Dean, director of the Cornell University Duck Research Laboratory here.

title: Series of Soviet Films Is Set for the Modern
description: New Voices From the Soviet Cinema, a series of films by young directors with fresh views of Soviet society and by more experienced film makers who are unknown in the West, will begin on Nov. 10 at the Museum of Modern Art and run through Nov. 17.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We want to do what we must do and want to be realistic about what we're telling people we can do. If we do $23 billion in a real meaningful manner, it's a pretty good step.'' - Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico. [ D13:3. ]

title: Bridge: Honored High School Senior Has a Name That's Familiar
description: For the last 14 years the American Contract Bridge League has named a King of Bridge. The title goes to the high school senior in North America with the best tournament record, and carries with it a $1,000 scholarship that goes to an outstanding student in the winner's class.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Beating Out the Music

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Pumpkin's Other Faces: Beyond the Pie Shell
description: LEAD: BE warned that you will probably need something to do with leftover pumpkin meat, after you have baked the seeds and carved out the requisite triangle eyes and sawtooth mouth yet another year.

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter. The latest year includes a gain on the sale of a subsidiary of $1.2 million, or 6 cents a share, and a royalty agreement advance settlement of $4.4 million, or 20 cents. The prior year includes restructuring charges and other expenses related to depressed business conditions.

title: Meat Inspectors With AIDS Won't Be Removed From Job
description: Federal meat and poultry inspectors with AIDS will not be removed from their jobs unless they become incapacitated or develop contagious secondary diseases, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: At Westies Trial, Defense Lawyer Ridicules Testimony of Informer
description: A defense lawyer resorted to ridicule yesterday to attack an informer who testified that the Westies gang had carried out grisly murders and other violent crimes.

title: Soviet Offers U.S. Inspections of Additional Radar
description: The Soviet Union has offered to allow United States officials to inspect two radars that some conservative Senators assert may violate an arms control accord, according to senior Administration officials.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE heard many legends about pork. It is said, for instance, that Christopher Columbus brought eight pigs to America on his second voyage because they were nutritious and could be fattened up on shipboard scraps. Pigs have been celebrated in prose and poetry, and were subjects in the art of Gainsborough, Rembrandt and Rubens.

title: Indiana Agency's Tax-Free Bonds
description: In the tax-exempt market, a $120 million issue of the Indiana State Office Building Commission's capital complex revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Series Ratings Are Down 15%
description: Television audiences for the six World Series games played at night were about 15 percent below those for last year, ABC Sports said yesterday.

title: Where's the Thrift?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paramount Leader Jumps to Columbia
description: Dawn Steel, whose leadership helped lead to Paramount Pictures to box-office success with ''Footloose'' and ''The Untouchables,'' was named president of Columbia Pictures' motion picture operation yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1987
description: Stock Market Turmoil

title: Rangers Seek Ban on a Flyer
description: The Flyers harbor a particular dislike for Tomas Sandstrom, and their agitation over his presence near Ron Hextall's net on Monday night inspired Dave Brown to deliver a crushing crosscheck to the neck and jaw of the Rangers' Swedish forward, who spent the rest of the night in the hospital.

title: British Put Off B.P. Decision
description: The British Government, facing mounting pressure politically and from financial markets, said today that it would wait until Thursday to decide whether to postpone the $12.2 billion sale of British Petroleum Company shares.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Oct. 19 misidentified the show in which the song ''City Lights'' was introduced. It was ''The Act.''

title: Estimate Board Is Focus of Plan To Revise Voting
description: In an effort to preserve New York City's Board of Estimate, which recent court decisions have said violates the principle of one person, one vote, the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, yesterday proposed a new weighted voting formula for the board's members.

title: Trader's Survival Lessons
description: Among his peers, Richard Dennis is regarded as the most successful of the new breed of Chicago's commodity traders. But when his firm lost $10 million last week, some people expected him to experience sleepless nights and frayed nerves.

title: Eurotunnel Still Plans Stock Sale
description: The Eurotunnel consortium's said today that its public share offering was still tentatively scheduled for the second half of November, despite the turmoil in world stock markets.

title: Mrs. Reagan as a Cancer-Patient Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Edelman Filing On Foster Wheeler
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said he had filed for permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the antitrust division of the Department of Justice to increase his stake in the Foster Wheeler Corporation from his current 11.2 percent level.

title: Theater: 'Frankie and Johnny'
description: WHEN we first meet the title characters of Terrence McNally's provocative new play, ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' they are grunting through an orgasm on a Murphy bed in a dreary Hell's Kitchen walk-up. But Frankie (Kathy Bates) and Johnny (Kenneth Welsh) are hardly sweethearts. They are fellow employees of a greasy spoon -she a waitress, he a recently hired short-order cook - and this is their first and quite possibly their last date. They've been to a movie. They've made small talk. Now they've had sex. What else can they give one another? As the couple's panting subsides, Frankie hopes only that Johnny will get dressed and get out so she can resume her usual nightly ritual of watching television and eating ice cream in peace.

title: Parking Meters Tip
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange Inc., named Joseph B. Stefanelli senior vice president, options marketing.

title: Play-by-Play Woman
description: Gayle Sierens, a news co-anchor in Tampa, has been recruited by NBC Sports with the aim of having her work the play-by-play microphone for a National Football League game. In the 30 years that N.F.L. games have been televised by the three major networks, no woman has ever worked the broadcast booth. At some point soon, Sierens will call a game in the studio. Her work will be critiqued by Marty Glickman, NBC's announcer coach. It will then be decided if she will be given the announcing assignment. Sierens joined WXFL-Channel 8, the NBC affiliate in Tampa, as a sports reporter in 1977. She has done play-by-play for North American Soccer League games and an equestrian event, but has never been a football announcer.

title: TV Review; 'The Righteous Enemy,' New Facet of Holocaust
description: IS there anything new to point out about the Holocaust? There is:

title: Mets Promote Pitcher
description: The Mets purchased the contract of Jose Roman, a right-handed pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League yesterday. The Mets acquired Roman from Cleveland in a minor-league trade last May for Mike Westbrook, a minor-league outfielder. Roman spent most of last year with Tidewater. He had a 5-4 record with nine saves, and he had an earned-run average of 3.07 in 45 relief appearances. He pitched in the majors for Cleveland during part of the 1984-85-86 seasons, going 1-8 in 14 games.

title: MISSILE COUP LAID TO RUSSIAN SPIES
description: The Soviet Union, through a military intelligence operation in Greece, acquired specifications for the Stinger missile and developed an almost identical weapon, according to a Greek security official with immediate knowledge of the case. A Western official confirmed the incident.

title: Younger Crop of Democrats in Mississippi Races
description: After a bruising runoff and primary, which often pitted older candidates against younger ones, most of the faces staring down from Democratic campaign posters for next week's statewide elections are smooth and gently smiling rather than creased with age and long service.

title: Supermarket Slowdown Seen
description: In the Los Angeles market, frequently the birthplace of trends, an in-the-know agency source reported yesterday that customer traffic in the four major supermarket chains there had been down since last week's market plunge.

title: India Urges Swift Bhopal Accord With Carbide
description: The Indian Government has authorized its attorney general to settle swiftly its bitter legal dispute with the Union Carbide Corporation over compensation for victims of the 1984 gas leak at Carbide's chemical plant in Bhopal, India, a Cabinet official said today.

title: Pain in the Head
description: To The Living Section:

title: Villella Asks Forgiveness for Kirkland
description: The dancer Edward Villella has issued an impassioned plea to the ballet world to forgive Gelsey Kirkland, the prima ballerina who, in writing a book last year describing her drug addiction, criticized other dancers and their ballet companies.

title: In Maine, Bottle Law Debate Is Long Over
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERMEYER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $17,000 and $579,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary loss of $38,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $238,000.

title: TWINS ARE GIVEN A ROYAL RECEPTION
description: Hundreds of thousands of happy Minnesota Twins fans showered their heroes with millions of dollars in shredded money and waved their ever-present Homer Hankies yesterday in a World Series victory celebration.

title: PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a $331,000 tax credit. c-Net income and includes a pretax income of $4,150,000 from the sale of an option to purchase a facility.

title: Reds Hire May
description: Lee May, a first baseman who spent 16 seasons in the major leagues from 1967 to 1982, was hired yesterday as a coach by the Cincinnati Reds. The Reds announced that they have rehired all of their coaching staff except Billy DeMars, the batting instructor and third-base coach, who resigned after the season because of a dispute with the front office. The Reds did not mention what specific duties May would fill with the team, but he will probably replace DeMars as batting instructor. . . . The Reds also announced they would not pick up the option on Ron Oester's contract and had given the second baseman his unconditional release. Oester's 1987 season was cut short by a career-threatening injury to his left knee in a basepath collision with Mookie Wilson of the Mets on July 5.

title: TIE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After foreign tax credits of $123,000 for the quarter and $472,000 for the 9 months. c-After foreign tax credits of $198,000 for the quarter and $867,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes net from discontinued operations of $1,543,000.

title: QUAKER STATE OIL & REFINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $122 million in this year's second quarter related to the writedown of certain production and refining assets to their net realizable value. c-Net income

title: WHEN IS MOOKIE UP?
description: A CERTAIN young man is currently attending college in the Midwest, on the cusp between Cub-land and Cardinal-land, which is all well and good except that he has allegiance to a certain other National League East baseball team.

title: Wary Maneuvering Ends in a Draw
description: Careful, solid defensive play by Anatoly Karpov perfectly countered Gary Kasparov's positional manuevering in the drawn sixth game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Monday.

title: At West Point, Symbol of Change for Army
description: The parade ground of the United States Military Academy was a confusing scene today. As the new commandant of cadets, Brig. Gen. Fred A. Gorden, looked on, small units, representing phantom companies, marched past an empty reviewing box while White House helicopters practiced landings nearby.

title: Charge Against Officer In Stewart Case Is Dropped
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reversed itself yesterday and abandoned its attempt to prosecute a transit police officer on a departmental charge in connection with the arrest and death of Michael Stewart.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN REOURCES PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: 'Frankie and Johnny'
description: When we first meet the title characters of Terrence McNally's provocative new play, "Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune," they are grunting through an orgasm on a Murphy bed in a dreary Hell's Kitchen walk-up. But Frankie (Kathy Bates) and Johnny (Kenneth Welsh) are hardly sweethearts. They are fellow employees of a greasy spoon -she a waitress, he a recently hired short-order cook - and this is their first and quite possibly their last date. They've been to a movie. They've made small talk. Now they've had sex. What else can they give one another? As the couple's panting subsides, Frankie hopes only that Johnny will get dressed and get out so she can resume her usual nightly ritual of watching television and eating ice cream in peace.

title: Investors to Seek Control of USG
description: An investment group consisting of the Texas investors Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown said that it had decided to seek control of the USG Corporation and had hired Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. to act as its financial adviser.

title: Daiwa Executive Steps Into Breach on Wall St.
description: Until a month ago, Koji Yoneyama, a Daiwa Securities executive, was posted to Zurich and enjoying a relatively calm life. Yesterday, he was swept into the Wall Street maelstrom when his appointment as president and chief executive of Daiwa Securities America was announced.

title: Tektronix Products
description: Tektronix Inc. is planning to introduce 14 new products including some that mark its re-entry into the computer work station business, a company spokesman said. He said the company had entered that market about three years ago and then abandoned it a year later. The work station models cost between $9,995 and $51,500 and can operate independently of big mainframe computers, the company said.

title: Malaysia Arrests Political Foes
description: The leader of the main Malaysian opposition party and ethnic Chinese politicians and academics were arrested today under a law allowing detention without trial, political figures said.

title: V.H. Saladino, Interior Designer
description: Virginia Hendrick Saladino, an interior designer, died of cancer yesterday in Manhattan. She was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn.

title: Suspicious Fire at New York Post
description: A small, smoky fire caused minor damage at the offices of The New York Post in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, and the Fire Department labeled the blaze suspicious, pending further investigation.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Hrudey and Mason at It Again
description: In the minutes before overtime, Kelly Hrudey sat along the boards at the Nassau Coliseum, took a couple of deep breaths and a drink of water. Slowly and only momentarily, he then began to take in the full irony of it all.

title: PRODUCTS RESEARCH AND CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the year-ago 9-months included a non-cash after-tax writedown of about $150 million on oil and gas assets taken in the first quarter of 1986.

title: Pact to Keep Dreyfus in New York May Be Near
description: The Koch administration and the Dreyfus Corporation are close to an agreement that could keep the financial-services company and its 1,200 employees in New York City, state officials said last night.

title: Boxing Notebook; A Pay-Per-View Attraction
description: Although the fight Thursday night between Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan for the World Boxing Council middleweight title strikes some as not having the magnitude to be a closed-circuit attraction, what it does have is a nation with increased ''addressability.''

title: Deaver Lied to Cover Up Use Of Reagan Ties, Jury Is Told
description: The prosecutor in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver told the jury today that the former White House aide had lied under oath to ''cover up'' his conversion of a personal relationship with President Reagan and Nancy Reagan into an influence-marketing business that brought him hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Reviving The Dry Martini
description: VINTAGE rock 'n' roll is back. Comic books are back. Crew cuts are back. Even

title: Highland Plaids Enchant le Tout Paris
description: PARIS is certainly a bonny place this fall, what with all the plaids that are bringing a touch of the Highlands to the City of Light. Actually, tartans have long appealed to the French, who appreciate classics and have had longstanding, often political, ties to the Scots. (We all remember Mary Queen of Scots, and Bonnie Prince Charlie.) But this season there seems to be more, and bolder, plaid than ever. Plaid blazers, trousers, suits, scarfs, shawls, gloves, socks and, of course, kilts, are on view in such typically Scottish venues as the Etoile and Montparnasse. They appear in the familiar red-based patterns, or in large-pane yellow and black, or in a snappy navy and emerald green.

title: Topics of The Times; 'If You Vote for My Dancers ...'
description: Martha Graham, at 93 still a lustrous figure in the arts, constitutes a national treasure. But admiration does not justify asking Congress directly to appropriate $4.1 million for her dance company.

title: PREACHER'S ORDINATION IN DISPUTE
description: The evangelist Oral Roberts says that his ordination has been revoked by the United Methodist Church but that he learned about it only when he read about it in a newspaper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 In an apparent Soviet about-face, the Soviet Foreign Minister will return to Washington this week to say that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready for a summit meeting even if differences remain over space-based defensive weapons, officials said. Page A1

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SYSTEM INTEGRATORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After securities gains of $552,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $3.7 million, or $1.43 a share, for the 6 months.

title: Wall Street Shouts Its Plea
description: LEAD: The message from markets around the world last week was one we all had chosen to ignore: The economy has been bravely treading water these last few months, and it is only a matter of time before the riptide of the twin trade and Federal budget deficits pulls it under - unless the Congress and the President act quickly and decisively.

title: Facing Strike, Ecuador Declares an Emergency
description: - President Leon Febres Cordero declared a state of emergency tonight on the eve of a one-day anti-Government general strike.

title: Mario Merola, 65, Prosecutor In the Bronx for 15 Years, Dies
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last night, less than 12 hours after suffering what doctors called a ''massive and primary'' neurological disorder that brought on cardiac arrest.

title: Wine Coolers Teach Youngsters to Drink
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's Ida This Teacher Goes After Top Billing
description: The gray-haired, 65-year-old school teacher, wearing a demure silk dress with a simple gold necklace, stepped up to the microphone.

title: BUYING IS SPURRED BY RALLIES ABROAD; CAUTION ON DEFICIT
description: As White House and Congressional negotiators began work on a $23 billion package of deficit reductions, several leaders today sought to dampen expectations that the talks could produce larger savings in the current fiscal year.

title: Lois Heilbrun, Ornithologist
description: Lois Hussey Heilbrun, an ornithologist and past president of the Linnaean Society of New York, died of lymphoma last Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KNICKS, GREEN CLOSER
description: Following more than three weeks of speculation surrounding the Knicks, it appears that the status of Sidney Green, Bernard King and Trent Tucker should be resolved before the end of the week.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ozone Hole Raising Concern for Scientists' Safety
description: The atmosphere's protective ozone layer is so depleted over Antarctica in the springtime that there is cause for concern about the safety of scientists and support personnel there, researchers said at a Senate hearing today.

title: Market Place; I.B.M., Digital: A Comparison
description: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT's stock has ridden the roller coaster lately - tumbling $45.25, to $127 a share, last week during the market's record selloff - but some Wall Street analysts continue to prefer it to archrival International Business Machines.

title: Stage: 'Second Avenue,' Yiddish Music and Skits
description: SECOND AVENUE, like Wall Street, Lenox Avenue, Broadway and Madison Avenue, was shorthand for a very special world. ''On Second Avenue,'' a buoyant and glowing revue that opened Sunday at the Norman Thomas Theater, 111 East 33d Street, explores the world of Yiddish theater, that mix of high drama and low comedy, of polished professionalism and folk roots that was born little more than a century ago in Rumania and flourished on New York's Lower East Side.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,586,000 and $5,711,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; losses on dispositions of $7,9911,000 for the quarter and $7,991,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a tax credit of $3,374,000. c-Net income d-Includes a loss of $1,034,000 and a gain of $11,475,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations; tax credits of $3,819,000 for the quarter and $33,599,000 for the 9 monthss, and the 9-month also includes a gain on dispositions of $12,181,000 and a gain from an accounting change of $1,787,000.

title: Topics of The Times; Mayor Koch Bites a Hard Bullet
description: Mayor Koch moved decisively and appropriately yesterday to impose a 90-day hiring freeze on 5,200 positions authorized in this year's New York City budget. The continuing turmoil in world stock markets threatens payrolls, retail sales, tax receipts and real estate values in a city heavily dependent on the finance industry.

title: Constantin Alajalov Is Dead; Was Painter and Illustrator
description: Constantin Alajalov, a portrait painter, illustrator and cartoonist, died Saturday in Amenia, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: MORGAN PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Owners Clash on Stock Plan
description: A rousing debate that could lead to a radical change in National Football League ownership policies ended today with the owners tabling a vote on a measure that would allow a club owner to sell a minority interest of his club through the public sale of stock.

title: Stocks Are Down; Gin Is Back And So Is the Cocktail Party
description: THERE was that time - I think it was about 1972 -when we all said in unison, ''Oh, God, not another cocktail party,'' and stopped, for the most part, giving and going.

title: Dr. Casco Alston Jr. Is Dead; Columbia Medicine Professor
description: Dr. Casco Alston Jr., one of the first blacks hired by the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center medicine department, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: Film: From Mexico, 'Hell Without Limits'
description: ARTURO RIPSTEIN's ''Hell Without Limits,'' the 1978 Mexican film opening today at the Cinema Village, looks and sounds as if it were based on an idea for a Luis Bunuel film, which had been made, instead, by someone completely unqualified for the job.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: An Article on 'Faith'

title: What Really Happened at New York's Homeless Shelter Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Marathon Missing Big Names
description: Once again on Sunday, Fred Lebow will present the New York City Marathon, featuring a cast of thousands. Who will be playing the leading roles? Well, Lebow would probably say that the city is the star of this annual run across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge through the five boroughs. It is also true, however, that this year's marathon lacks marquee value. The biggest names are either on the sidelines or no longer threats to win.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; Picking Another Nominee: Lessons From Bork
description: When Bob Dole was asked recently to give advice to a young lawyer who might have ambitions to sit on the Supreme Court, the Senate Republican leader replied: ''I wouldn't write a word. I would hide in the closet until I was nominated.''

title: Hong Kong Loses Brokers
description: Hong Kong's futures exchange today suspended 45 brokers who apparently ran out of cash to cover immense losses from Monday's record market plunge, and stock prices rose after a rescue plan for the futures exchange was announced this morning.

title: Economists Scale Back Predictions of Growth
description: The stock market collapse could push the United States economy into low gear next year, and it has increased the chances of a recession before 1989, several economists say.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax one-time charge of $620 million in connection with its restructuring program for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and the quarter net includes an after-tax gain of $16.4 million on the sale of Santa Fe Southern Pacific stock.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
St. Louis Park Journal; A BITTER BATTLE FOUGHT ON TWO HOUSING FRONTS
description: Once Mark Tucker was just another insurance salesman living in this western Minneapolis suburb.

title: Westin To Be Sold By Allegis
description: The Allegis Corporation said yesterday that it had concluded the restructuring plan it announced in June, by signing an agreement to sell its Westin Hotels and Resorts business for $1.53 billion to a group comprising the Robert M. Bass Group of Texas and the Aoki Corporation of Japan.

title: Economic Council Chief May Remain in Position
description: To help the Reagan Administration cope with the crisis in the stock market, Beryl W. Sprinkel is close to reversing the decision he made last month to resign as the President's chief economist, according to Administration officials.

title: China Is Still Arming Iran, U.S. Says
description: Despite China's repeated denials that it sells arms to Iran, Iran received a shipment of artillery pieces and shells from China in the last two weeks, Administration officials said today.

title: RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Killing in Salvador Imperils Peace Talks
description: Rebels fighting the Government threatened today to break off peace talks because of the killing of one of the country's most outspoken human rights crusaders.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NEW YORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gifts By Mail, Made In New England
description: OUR passion for handmade products extends to food: the cheese made in someone's shed, the cookies baked in batches of 50. We are certain that handmade food is better than the mass-produced variety, and we are usually right.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Pull of Power
description: More than one woman has been heard to complain that men in Washington are so interested in power and in advancing their political or professional careers that their personal relationships suffer. Now comes some sort of evidence.

title: Top Merc Official Defends Stock Futures
description: Two years ago, Leo Melamed, chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and unofficial ambassador to the world from the realm of stock index futures, was riding high. At the Merc's annual cocktail party in New York, Mr. Melamed waved a newspaper editorial that said stock index futures were not the main cause of unusual market moves. Program trading - a complex strategy that plays the stock market against the Merc's stock index futures - had been exonerated, Mr. Melamed declared. He felt that his exchange, long known for trading in hog bellies, had finally been accepted into the New York financial fraternity.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $563,000, or 6 cents a share, for the latest year and $3,933,000, or 49 cents a share, for the year-earlier period from additional interest income resulting from the payoff of participating loans.

title: Unorthodox Steps in Inquiry on a Cuomo Relative
description: At the start of a police inquiry into the beating of Governor Cuomo's father-in-law three years ago, a detective took unorthodox steps that may have hampered the search for evidence, a review of Police Department records and interviews with investigators show.

title: Saudi Oil Plan's Aim: Calm Markets
description: A decision of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to hold oil prices steady is intended to calm financial markets and close the door to Iranian demands for higher prices, Saudi officials and oil analysts said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Buckley as Buckley
description: As the Republican Presidential candidates prepare for their first debate tonight, one of the five has been using a not-so-secret weapon.

title: Prince Aspreno Colonna, 71; Roman Noble in Papal Court
description: Prince Aspreno Colonna, patriarch of one of Rome's oldest noble families, died of a stroke Sunday, the family has announced. He was 71 years old.

title: SUN ENERGY PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The share earnings are in units.

title: Toshiba Profit Increases 36%
description: The Toshiba Corporation reported today that its profit had risen 36 percent, to $109 million, in the first half of its fiscal year, despite American tariffs on Japanese goods and anger over exports to Moscow by a Toshiba subsidiary.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the company's equity position in Piedmont Aviation's earnings of $14,712,000 for the quarter and $37,055,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago results are restated for FASB 87 pension accounting change. The equity share in Piedmont's earnings are adjusted for amortization of the difference between the cost of USAir Group's investment in Piedmont stock and the underlying equity in Piedmont's net assets.

title: Time Inc. Offers $125 Million Issue
description: Time Inc. is offering $125 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.50 to yield 9.60 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEXICAN-U.S. TRADE TALKS
description: The United States and Mexico will sign an agreement on Nov. 6 creating a framework for talks on trade and investment issues, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

title: Central Power Brings Bonds to a Quiet Market
description: New-issue activity was minimal yesterday as many corporations showed little interest in issuing new debt in an unsteady market. Corporate bond prices, following the lead of Government securities, were lower yesterday.

title: Foreign Markets' Role Grows
description: For as long as the American economy has dominated the world scene, the New York Stock Exchange has whistled the tune that foreign stock exchanges have followed.

title: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Include a non-recurring, non-extraordinary $27 million writeoff resulting from the suspension of the East Coast Offshore Exploration Program. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: USX Posts $140 Million Profit
description: The USX Corporation, supported by strong earnings in its steel and Marathon Oil subsidiaries, reported a third-quarter profit of $140 million today, in contrast to a $183 million loss in the 1986 period.

title: Advances: Infrared Rays May Improve Night Driving
description: NIGHT vision systems similar to the military devices used on such missions as tracking Iranian warships and minelayers in the Persian Gulf may make driving safer in the 1990's. Using infrared sensors, the devices could enable motorists to look well beyond the range of their headlights to see dangers ahead. The systems could also peer through rain, fog, snow and smoke better than any human eye.

title: Cecil Brown Is Dead; A News Broadcaster And Correspondent
description: Cecil Brown, a radio news broadcaster whose career was studded with drama and controversy, died of a ruptured aorta Sunday at the Medical Center at the University of California at Los Angeless. He was 80 years old.

title: Brazil Radiation Victim Dies
description: A junkyard worker who helped break open a capsule containing radioactive cesium 137 died today, the third victim. Israel Batista dos Santos, 22 years old, died after three weeks in critical condition at the Marcilio Dias Naval hospital in Rio. Last Friday, a 6-year-old girl and her aunt died of generalized infection caused by radiation. The bodies of Maria Gabriela Ferreira, 37, and her niece, Leide Ferreira, were buried Monday. The cesium 137 contaminated 243 people and some 30 tons of material, including clothes, furniture, junkyard scrap and soil.

title: Canada Wins Approval for a 'Distinct' Quebec
description: In the face of bitter but fragmented opposition, the Canadian Government has won parliamentary approval for changes to the country's Constitution that would recognize Quebec as a ''distinct society'' and strengthen its battle to shore up its French language and culture.

title: Advertising; Coupon Marketing Heats Up
description: TEN times a year Donnelley Marketing mails out brown envelopes jammed with cents-off coupons to at least 30 million American households of the not-too-rich and not-poor variety.

title: K.G.B. Runs Commerce Unit, U.S. Says
description: A State Department report, based on classified Central Intelligence Agency data, asserts that the U.S.S.R. Chamber of Commerce and Industry is headed by a K.G.B. lieutenant general and is systematically engaged in commercial espionage in the West.

title: Koch, Citing Falling Market, Freezes Jobs
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday a major ''retrenchment'' in municipal hiring, salary increases and pension contributions for New York City caused by concern over the plunge of the stock market and fears of a recession.

title: BOY'S 1969 DEATH SUGGESTS AIDS INVADED U.S. SEVERAL TIMES
description: New evidence that a St. Louis teen-ager died of AIDS in 1969 suggests that the AIDS virus may have been introduced into the United States several times before touching off the current epidemic, according to experts in disease transmission.

title: Weyer: I Missed Call
description: Lee Weyer, a veteran National League umpire, admitted today that he missed a call at first base in the seventh game of the World Series and said he would be in favor of instant-replay in certain situations.

title: Saatchi and Bozell Gain on Account Side
description: On the account front, there were developments this week involving Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton; Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt, and N. W. Ayer. Two incoming and one outgoing.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income includes losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies for 1987 and 1986, respectively, of $1,694,000 and $904,000 for the 9 months and $571,000 and $488,000 for the third quarter, respectively. Revenue represent gross income.

title: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Norfolk Will Trim 5,000 Jobs COMPANY NEWS
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation is taking a $620 million special charge in connection with a cost-cutting restructuring that will eliminate 5,000 jobs and dispose of 15 percent of its rail track, the company said today.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday described the New York City Police Department's monitoring of call-in programs on radio station WLIB-AM last summer.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $5,854,000 for the quarter and income of $65,804,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $9,408,000 and $10,019,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. The latest 9 months is after a charge of $24.3 million from the purchase of the company's common stock from Mr. Donald Trump and includes a gain of $79 million from the sale of the company's Six Flags subsidiary.

title: Missing the Point On War Powers
description: As the United States edges closer to sustained hostilities in the Persian Gulf, the War Powers Resolution should be invoked to help establish a consensus on the American presence in the region. Our policy is essentially on track, especially now that our Arab friends and European allies are beginning to provide meaningful support. It should not be derailed by an avoidable debate over the resolution.

title: Have a Baby! America Needs Taxpayers
description: Ronald Reagan has already pushed another trillion dollars of debt onto the next generation of taxpayers. Now the Republican Presidential candidate Pat Robertson offers an even more refined idea of fiscal conservatism and family values. America should breed more babies, he says, so there'll be more people to pay taxes.

title: Volcker Advocates Tax Increase
description: The stock market crisis is a warning signal that the budget deficit is too high and that it must be cut through higher taxes, Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today.

title: New York State Helps Lake Placid
description: A $5 million grant from the state of New York to the United States Olympic Committee, combined with $12 million from corporate funds guaranteed by the state, will finance new housing, dining and training facilities for athletes at Lake Placid.

title: Computer-Driven Innovations in Goo
description: Floor covering companies often throw messy liquids here and there to advertise the stain resistance of new products. Detergent makers frequently show off by dabbing grease or dirt on clothing. But when the Verbatim Corporation recently introduced a new Teflon-coated floppy disk for computers, corporate American plumbed the depths of gunk.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A.F.L.-C.I.O. And a New Obsession With Presser
description: Waiting for Jackie Presser.

title: A Mutual Fund Wizard's Hard Fall
description: George Soros, one of the most successful mutual fund operators of his generation, thinks of himself more as a philosopher than a money manager. Therefore, it came as no surprise to his friends that he took his losses in the stock market in the last two weeks philosophically, all $800 million worth.

title: Devils' Defense Foils the Flyers
description: The Devils, who were last in defense in the National Hockey League last season, continued a dramatic turnaround tonight with a 4-0 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Torture by Syrians Charged in a Report From Rights Group
description: Amnesty International charged yesterday that the Syrian security forces have tortured thousands of political prisoners in recent years, including large numbers of Palestinians seized from refugee districts in Syria or from Syrian-controlled areas of Lebanon.

title: New York Releases Plan to Transport the Disabled
description: A preliminary plan outlining a special citywide transit system for hundreds of disabled New Yorkers who cannot ride subways or buses was released yesterday by the Koch administration.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a favorable after-tax windfall profit tax adjustment of $62 million, or 57 cents a share, and included in the adjustment is an $11 million after-tax benefit from related interest income. c-Reflects a $10 million after-tax gain from the divestment of the motor freight transportation business, $24 million of earnings from divested industrial services businesses, including motor freight transportation, as well as a $24 million after-tax charge mainly related to a workforce reduction in the company's domestic exploration and production business. The latest 9 months' results include $90 million of after-tax income related to favorable windfall profit tax adjustments and associated interest income.

description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Players' Ranking Released
description: Don Mattingly, who for the past two years has generally been considered the best player in baseball, gained a new distinction yesterday. He became the first player to receive a perfect score in the seven-year history of the ranking statistics.

title: Trump Buying Resorts Stake
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, said yesterday that he would begin a tender offer for all of the remaining 167,000 outstanding shares of Class B common stock of Resorts International at $135 a share, or a total of $22.5 million, within five business days.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,675,000 for the quarter and $16,706,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,664,000 and $21,636,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $484,000 for the quarter and a gain of $18,191,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HALLOWEEN, THEN Leaves crackled under mischievous feet Stalking spirits danced in woolworth bones Menacing sharp, bent cardboard teeth Woolen underwear rubbed linen ghosts Who giggled and tripped Under moonlight and mirth Ashcan covers rattled like bones Gray cats scratched at gray winds Bloated globes winked with waxen eyes Fathers bent over philco radios Heard Europe moan Mothers stirred supper Behind starched curtains Winter held its breath until eight Then blew tiny silhouettes home Like autumn leaves SAUL KAPLAN Overheard by Arlene Stern in a hushed gallery at the Museum of Modern Art. Mother (to small child): Now, remember, what is the first rule when we are in a museum? Toddler (at the top of her lungs): NO YELLING! Dear Diary:

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHEN I was a little girl I loved Halloween because it was the only day of the year when I was beautiful. I had friends who went out dressed as hobos and clowns and witches. I never would. I was always a princess or a ballet dancer, Sleeping Beauty or Cinderella. (One year I wanted to go as Barbie. ''Out of the question,'' said my mother, and it occurs to me now that her reply worked on several levels.) It was the only day of the year when I wore satin or net or hoops; the only day of the year when my thin lips were carmine and full, and the mole on my upper lip, blackened with eyebrow pencil, became a beauty mark.

title: Bond Prices Finally Descend
description: Bond prices posted a significant decline yesterday, their first substantial reverse since stock prices collapsed on Oct. 19.

title: The Winning Ways of Blaine Trump
description: SHE'S called ''Darling Blaine'' by Suzy and ''Nouvelle Society's Ingenue'' by Women's Wear Daily. She's photographed wearing a bouffant-skirted dress, blond hair cascading over her shoulders, at the right parties and opening nights. But all that most people know about her is that she's called Blaine Trump and she's married to Donald Trump's younger brother, Robert.

title: INSIDE
description: Salvador Talks Imperiled Salvadoran rebels threatened to break off peace talks because of the killing of an outspoken human rights advocate. Page A3. Early AIDS Case Studied Experts say a 1969 AIDS case may be evidence that the virus repeatedly entered the United States but did not take hold as an epidemic. Page A15. A Job Plan for High Schools The head of the Primerica Corporation plans to open an employment service in New York high schools to find jobs for graduates. Page B1.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IT'S RAINING IN MANGO. Pictures From a Family Album. By Thea Astley. 208 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

The company said the modifications favorably affected the quarter by a pretax amount of $894 million, or $1.82 a share. About one-third of that amount relates to depreciation and amortization charges for the third quarter, with the balance applicable to the first 6 months.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months include net charges of $122 million and $233 million, respectively, for the accrual of interest on the unsecured debt of Texaco Inc. and its two wholly owned finance companies. Foreign currency translation gains included in the latest periods' nets totaled $19 million, net of income tax, for the quarter, and $3 million for the 9 months, compared with gains in the year-ago periods of $42 million for the quarter and $99 million for the 9 months. The net income for the year-ago quarter included a $20 million benefit resulting from the reversal of a LIFO inventory drawdown penalty which had been recorded earlier in 1986.

title: Detective Arrested in Assault
description: A New York City detective was arrested and suspended from duty yesterday on Federal charges of assaulting an F.B.I. agent and a military policeman who tried to break up a dispute between the detective and a woman, the police said.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: OILERS ARE BATTERED BY NORDIQUES, 5 - 0
description: Mario Gosselin turned aside 21 shots and Peter Stastny scored one goal and set up another tonight as the Quebec Nordiques beat the Edmonton Oilers, 5-0.

title: Under Fire, Spanish Socialists Defend Budget and Economy
description: Facing strong union dissent and increasing pressure, Spain's governing Socialists are defending their budget proposals as necessary for continued economic growth.

title: New Jet Goes Up Against Big Difference
description: For all of the talk about veterans being out of sync after a three-week strike layoff, some replacement players who played in the Jets' loss to the Washington Redskins Sunday had some acclimating to do, too.

title: Stage: A More Modest 'Mahabharata'
description: THERE'S another ''Mahabharata'' in town. Approaching its final weekend at the A.T.A. is a version of the Sanskrit epic one-sixth the length of Peter Brook's slam-B.A.M. production, on a stage one-fifth the size, with one-thirteenth the number of players.

title: BUYING IS SPURRED BY RALLIES ABROAD; WALL ST. RESPITE
description: A measure of stability returned to Wall Street yesterday as investors, heartened by earlier stock rallies abroad, drove prices higher.

title: Genmar Drops Minstar Deal
description: Genmar Industries said today that it had decided to abandon its plan to acquire Minstar Inc. through a new holding company.

title: Scott Paper Outlay
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would spend more than $250 million in the next three years to expand its sanitary paper business in Western Europe. The company said it would install paper-making machines in France, Italy and Spain. that will have a total capacity of 150,000 tons annually. Scott said it would also rebuild a machine in Britain and add recycled paer capability in Italy and Spain.

title: 2 Americans Reported Killed In an Ambush in Afghanistan
description: The State Department said yesterday that it had received a report that two American film journalists were killed in Afghanistan this month while making a documentary about the civil war there.

title: Washington Talk: The Senate; New Rules of Battle, But Who Will It Help?
description: The Senate awaiting the next Supreme Court nominee is a different place than it was four months ago, when President Reagan named Judge Robert H. Bork.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lawsuits Fault The Discharge Of Mentally Ill
description: On the eve of a Koch administration effort to hospitalize homeless people who are severely mentally ill, an advocacy group charged yesterday that the city and state were improperly sending psychiatric patients back to the streets.

title: Specialist On Amex Sells Firm
description: The stock market claimed another victim yesterday.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $114,400. c-After a loss of $51,100 for the quarter and net of $159,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Group Holds 7.5% Of Carson Pirie
description: An investment group, led by the New York brokerage firm Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder Inc., has purchased the equivalent of a 7.5 percent stake in Carson Pirie Scott & Company for investment purposes only.

title: Cor and Blimey O'Reilly, Cockneys Coming
description: A glossary of Cockney and other British slang is being prepared for Americans so they can tell ''a bit of Vera Lynn'' (a glass of gin) from ''brown bread'' (the state of being dead) when the most popular television program in British history, ''EastEnders,'' is shown in the United States next year.

title: Champion Parts Chief Finds Joy in Market
description: For Charles B. Schwartz Jr., chairman and chief executive of Champion Parts Rebuilders Inc., the stock market plunge has had its bright side.

title: How the Exchanges' Computers Got By
description: LAST week's frenzied activity in the nation's stock markets has focused new attention on the computers that processed and recorded the hundreds of thousands of transactions each day on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

title: Eating In: The Rush to Have It Catered
description: THE urge to be served seems to be overtaking the land, for reasons ranging from laziness to a work ethic so overwhelming that even a trip to the delicatessen is considered too time-consuming.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Talking Deals; 'Tenuous' Time For Southland
description: A multibillion-dollar leveraged buyout - financed through the sale of assets and the issuance of high-yield bonds - is a risky venture under the best of circumstances. But with the market's collapse last week and the flight of investors to safer debt issues, the prospects for successful leveraged buyouts have dimmed further.

title: Chinese Party Delegates Debate Deng's Role
description: Delegates to China's Communist Party Congress are involved in considerable debate over the future role of Deng Xiaoping, the country's senior leader, several delegates indicated today.

title: Recital: Alice Giles
description: THE constituency of the harp is select; I have never seen the auditorium of the 92d Street Y as sparsely populated as it was for Alice Giles's solo recital there Tuesday night. But Miss Giles is an assured, communicative performer and an astute program-builder. There is a certain difficulty inherent in making a whole evening's music on such a highly colored instrument without others to lend variety and context; she minimizes it.

title: EDWARD F. BLETTNER
description: Edward F. Blettner, a retired vice chairman and director of the First National Bank of Chicago and its parent, the First Chicago Corporation, died of heart failure last Friday at his home in Chicago. He was 79 years old.

description: b-After a gain of $37 million from the sale of certain timberlands, a gain of $15.2 million from the public offering of stock in a subsidiary and a reserve of $23.1 million related to the participation of a former subsidiary in a joint venture. c-After income from discontinued operations of $45.7 million, a gain of $4.6 million on the sale of certain timberlands, a gain of $47.9 million from the public offering of 17 percent of American Capital Management and Research Inc. stock, a loss of $13.6 million from a labor strike in a discontinued business and a loss of $13.2 million from the redemption of debentures. title: Bush Draws Foes' Fire in First Debate
description: The six Republican Presdential candidates faced off in their first debate here tonight, and five of them aimed sharp attacks or subtle barbs at Vice President Bush, who is far ahead of his adversaries in the public opinion polls.

title: Calendar: Walking A Ladies' Mile
description: Ladies' Mile History Walk A tour led by Judy Gold; 212-242-5762.

title: Pregnancy Task Force Hears From Teen-Agers
description: Dozens of teen-agers, including a few young women carrying their babies, came here today to tell the Governor's Task Force on Adolescent Pregnancy their side of a story that is usually filtered through adults.

title: Parley On Budget Opened
description: Reagan Administration and Congressional negotiators started discussions today over a budget compromise aimed at soothing agitated financial markets, but their initial sparring produced few conclusive results.

title: RUSSIANS AT U.S MANEUVERS
description: Four Soviet military officers arrived in West Germany today to observe United States military maneuvers in the south of the country, the Soviet Embassy said. Spokesmen for the Soviet Em-bassy and for the West German For-eign Ministry said the officers were to watch exercises involving 11,650 Amer-icans as part of confidence-building measures agreed to by the European security conference.

title: Critic's Notebook; Now, Good Music Is Where You Find It
description: A MODEST proposal: This year, instead of compiling a list of 1987's 10 best pop albums, critics should consider sharing the contents of the tapes they compile for their own listening pleasure.

title: German Leaders Fear U.S. Deficit
description: As the dollar withered today and stock markets continued in turmoil, West Germans fixed their eyes on Washington.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LIFTING and moving heavy objects requires more science than strength, and frequently more common sense than either. Even transporting such light loads as bags of groceries can cause painful backaches, if done haphazardly, without balancing the load or without regard for your anatomy.

title: Islanders Anger Their Coach
description: The Islanders (5-3-1), plagued by poor play in their own zone and erratic execution on offense in the last four games, managed just 11 shots on goal over the first two periods against the Leafs and failed to score on five power-play attempts. Mark Osborne and Ed Olczyk each scored a pair of goals for the Leafs, who had lost their previous two games by a combined score of 17-7.

title: KOREAN DIPLOMAT FREED IN LEBANON
description: A South Korean diplomat was released Tuesday after being held hostage for 21 months, officials said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LUD lies in the New Jersey flats, a town where Colonial Jews once chose to bury their dead and their ancestors have been following suit ever since. ''The cemetery came first,'' writes Stanley Elkin in his new novel, ''The Rabbi of Lud,'' ''and was out here on its own for a good many years like, oh, say, the Valley of the Kings in Egypt, but then somebody had the bright idea of bringing all death's service-related industries together under one roof,'' so Lud is a town of the dead, ''funerary, sepulchral, thanatopsical.''

title: Bamboo Repair? There's No Mystery
description: LEAD: Bamboo furniture often gives an impression of fragility, but it is much stronger than it looks. It has to be, to survive, for finding a restorer willing to cope with a bamboo piece can be difficult.

title: 3 Newspapers Seek More Access to Chambers Jury Selection
description: Three newspapers yesterday asked the judge in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. to allow greater access to the jury-selection process.

title: Citicorp Unit Seen Joining Telex Bid
description: The New York financier Asher B. Edelman said yesterday that an investment company owned by Citicorp had joined him in an $888 million hostile takeover bid for the Telex Corporation.

title: WEAPON REACTORS FAULTED ON SAFETY
description: A study of the reactors that produce fuel for nuclear bombs criticizes the Government's monitoring of safety at the aging facilities and finds that their management by the Department of Energy ''falls short of reasonable expectation'' in balancing safety and production.

title: Cuomo Aide Called Key In Sales Under Scrutiny
description: The executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority, Alexander A. Levine, was a moving force behind a computer company that was set up explicitly to sell equipment to state contractors, according to a report released yesterday by the State Inspector General.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in The Living Section yesterday with an article about catering misidentified a couple at a party catered by Molly Siple. They were Carole Hyatt, at the far right, and her husband, Gordon Hyatt, next to her.

title: Oilers Fizzle Out 2d Night in a Row
description: Chris Chelios set up all three Montreal goals, and Patrick Roy stopped 22 shots tonight as the Canadiens defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 3-1.

title: Boy Is Shot in Subway; Another Youth Is Held
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was critically wounded when he was shot in the chest on an IND subway train in a Greenwich Village station yesterday afternoon, and the transit police arrested another Brooklyn youth in the shooting.

title: Continental Sets Commercial Pullout
description: Under its new management, the Continental Illinois Corporation will be stripped of most of its traditional commercial banking activities and will concentrate on investment banking activities, Thomas C. Theobald, chairman of the bank holding company, announced yesterday.

title: Suit Says Transplant Caused Cancer Death
description: A Long Island widow has filed a $3.5 million suit charging that the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn implanted a cancerous kidney into her husband and caused his death.

title: Dancers Exploring Video's Possibilities
description: ''I think people shouldn't take video for granted. It's too important. It has infiltrated our lives in a very real way.'' The speaker was Elliot Caplan, an award-winning film maker and the director, with Merce Cunningham, of ''Points in Space,'' a video dance that will be screened tonight at 9 on the Arts & Entertainment cable network.

title: Bulls Fine Jordan
description: The Chicago Bulls fined Michael Jordan an undisclosed amount yesterday for conduct detrimental to the team. Jordan, last season's National Basketball Association scoring leader, drew the fine a day after he stormed out of a practice session, accusing Coach Doug Collins of failing to keep the correct score during a scrimmage. ''People may think this to be so trivial,'' Jordan said after the incident. ''But when you're a competitor and want to win, nothing is trivial. I always keep score in everything, scrimmages, games, whatever, and I know the score was 4-4. Doug said it was 4-3, my team losing. I know after a long, tough practice, the losing team has to run. I felt like he was stacking the odds against me on purpose.'' Admitting he deserved to be fined, Jordan explained why he walked out of the practice: ''I was afraid I would say something I would regret later. If he wants me to run, fine. Stop practice and I'll run all he wants. But why kill myself in a scrimmage and make me run?'' Collins refused to talk about the incident.

description: They found George W. Raffield face down in a field of yellow wildflowers south of town Saturday. The 21-year-old police officer had been shot twice in the back of the head with a .38-caliber revolver.
