description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, buoyed by rising demand, said today that its profits jumped fourfold in the third quarter.

description: One intractable fact chills the financial markets of the world as they struggle to regain confidence. For nearly 15 more months, barring the unexpected, the United States will have as its President a man with no grasp of economic reality and no ability to deal with it.

description: With enrollment in Hebrew schools in the United States on the decline and the number of Jews marrying out of their faith on the rise, there may be fewer future generations lighting Friday night candles.

description: In a seeming paradox, Congress is moving to expand Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for more than 31 million elderly and disabled people, even as lawmakers profess acute concern about the need to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Bridge: Some Bidding Specialists Get Chance to Show Their Stuff
description: If bridge contests were like football or hockey, with replacements permitted, one would expect some players to specialize in bidding, play or defense. In that event two pairs from the Midwest would have a strong claim to be bidding specialists.

description: For the students in Saul Bruckner's advanced course at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, American history is an odyssey in ideas, current events, language and, least of all, facts.

title: Investigators Go Forth, and Multiply
description: Every major disaster touches off an investigation, and the stock market plunge is no exception. So far, it has spawned at least seven and no one can say for certain that more will not follow.

title: THE MARKETS' SEARCH FOR POLITICAL LEADERSHIP
description: The world's financial markets, and those whose economic well-being depends upon them, are clamoring for political leadership in their time of travail. So far, the response has disappointed them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about duck research misidentified a center that serves as a kind of ''fat farm'' for ducks. It is the Cornell University Duck Research Laboratory in Eastport, L.I.

title: Ruder Is Said to Favor Shift in Margin Rules
description: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, indicated today that financial regulation would be strengthened if the Government were directly responsible for setting requirements on down payments for trading stock-index futures.

title: The Midnight Side of Wall St.
description: Past midnight on Wall Street, long after most traders and brokers have gone home, all is calm and quiet, the tension of the working day seeming to dissipate into the cool morning air.

title: Q&A
description: Q.After removing the wallpaper in my hall, I washed the walls and painted them. Later I noticed some slightly discolored, rough spots on the painted walls, possibly caused by wallpaper glue that was not fully removed. How can I correct this? A.It does sound as if you left some small spots of paste, and possibly a little wallpaper, on the wall when you washed it. After wallpaper is removed, it takes a thorough scrubbing with hot water and detergent or the application of a wallpaper stripping solution - along with some scraping, in most cases - to remove all the residue of paste and paper.

title: Darling Returns To the Classroom
description: It has been six years since Ron Darling left Yale for professional baseball. Now, after four solid years in the major leagues with the Mets, he is back in the classroom. And it seems as though he never left.

title: Burning Dollar Bills on the Sidewalk
description: Her home the last year or so was the sidewalk on Second Avenue near 65th Street in front of a restaurant vent that kept her warm. She begged quarters and burned dollars.

title: New Spirit in the Islands
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has a surplus of electrical power. Just across the Mona Passage, roughly a degree of longitude to the west, the Dominican Republic suffers an acute power shortage.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hankering for Hankies
description: As the Minnesota Twins began their unlikely drive to the championship of baseball, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune sold thousands of ''homer hankies,'' white and red handkerchiefs that fans could wave from the stands. With the team due in Washington today for celebratory appearances at the White House and the Capitol, the hankies have become prized items. Representative Martin Olav Sabo, a Minnesota Democrat, got 500 of them. The White House wanted to get in on the act, ordering 200 through the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which is headed by Senator Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota.

title: Mortgage Bonds Offered By Burlington Northern
description: Burlington Northern Inc. tapped the debt market yesterday and began offering $150 million of 10 percent consolidated mortgage bonds due in 1997, through an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Offered at a price of 99.35, the bonds yield 10.10 percent.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: b-Includes a capital gain of $5,097,000 and $15,321,000 for the quarter and 9-month periods, respectively. c-Includes a capital loss of $186,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $8,545,000 for the 9 months.

title: A Bill Of Rights For Arts
description: LEAD: Last fall, Jasper Johns's painting ''Out the Window'' was auctioned for $3.6 million, the highest sum ever paid for a work by a living artist. The painting had been acquired in 1960 for $2,250. None of the $3.6 million went to the artist.

title: NAOMI HENRY SEBNER
description: Naomi Henry Sebner, a former concert pianist who helped develop day-care programs, died of breast cancer Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Mercedes Price Rise Set
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America said it plans to raise prices on its 1988 models between 2.6 percent and 3.4 percent. The lowest-priced model, the 190-E sedan with five-speed manual transmission, will sell for $29,190, and the highest-priced car, the 560-SEC coupe with automatic transmission, will sell for $76,380 on the West Coast and $75,850 on the East Coast.

title: Music: Julie Wilson at the Kaufman
description: JULIE WILSON is one of a handful of veteran singing actresses who do a great deal more than interpret classic songs with understanding and feeling. When Miss Wilson sings, her whole body gets into the act. She flings her arms wide and clenches her fists, and her face mirrors the entire range of human emotion, from helpless love to fury to triumphant joy. But no matter what the emotion, the prevailing atmosphere is one of high drama, expressed with a physicality so intense it can seem like a test of the singer's physical limitations.

title: Trooper's Car Hits Auto Killing 3
description: Three people were killed and two others were injured yesterday when a state police car struck another auto outside an entrance to the Finger Lakes Race Track here, the authorities said.

title: 'Distaff Side,' Music Composed by Women
description: ''The Distaff Side,'' a festival of works composed by women, will open the Downtown Chamber and Opera Players' fall concert season Tuesday night at 8 o'clock, at Bernhard Mayer Auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.

Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: Fed's Goal: A Calming Effect
description: The Federal Reserve, in its role as guardian of the nation's financial system, has emerged as the first arm of Government to respond actively to the steep drop in the stock market.

title: Woodson Signs
description: Rod Woodson, the Pittsburgh Steelers' top pick in last spring's draft, has signed a contract with the team, ending his 95-day holdout. The team did not disclose financial terms of the contract signed last night. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported the contract was worth $1.8 million with a signing bonus of $700,000. Jim Boston, the Steelers' chief negotiator, said the contract will last four years with no option. Woodson, who has been at home in Fort Wayne, Ind., was to travel to Pittsburgh today, although it was not clear whether he would dress for the Sunday game in Miami. Woodson's contract had been unresolved since Pittsburgh made him the 10th player selected in the April draft.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Gilbert and Mecir Gain: Brad Gilbert of the United States beat Anders Jarryd of Sweden, and Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia swept past Jean-Philippe Fleurian of France yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the $923,000 European Community Championships in Antwerp, Belgium. Ranked 12th in the world, Gilbert won by 6-2, 6-3. Mecir, ranked fifth, won, 6-1, 6-4, in just over an hour. Gilbert will meet the winner of today's match between second-seeded Mats Wilander and Jonas Svensson, both of Sweden. Mecir will face John McEnroe of the United States or Martin Jaite of Argentina in tomorrow's quarterfinal. Fleurian, a late replacement for Emilio Sanchez of Spain, who was ill, had upset Tim Wilkison of the United States in the first round. Mecir, McEnroe, Ivan Lendl, and Wilander were among those drawing first-round byes in the one-week tournament. Potter Gains: Top-seeded Barbara Potter needed only 52 minutes yesterday to eliminate 13th-seeded Michelle Torres, 6-3, 6-2, in the third round of the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Indianapolis tournament. Two of the top eight seeds also lost, including fourth-seeded Kathy Horvath of Largo, Fla., who retired because of a back spasm after one set of her match with Michelle Jaggard of Australia. Jaggard won the first set, 7-5. In the other upset, unseeded Anne Smith of Dallas beat eighth-seeded Alycia Moulton of Sacramento, Calif., 6-1, 6-2 in a match that lasted 50 minutes.(AP) BOXING McGrory Keeps Title: Milton McCrory got up from a fourth-round knockdown and retained the North American Boxing Federation super welterweight title with a one-sided 12-round decision over Herman Cavesuela last in Las Vegas, Nev. An upset occurred in a scheduled 12-round fight for the vacant N.A.B.F. lightweight title when Primo Ramos scored a second-round knockout over Frankie Randall, who is ranked No. 1 in the world by the World Boxing Council.(AP)

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $415,000 for the quarter and $654,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $334,000 for the quarter and $623,000 for the 9 months.

title: Mario Merola and the Election
description: Mario Merola, who served for 15 years as District Attorney of the Bronx, demonstrated competence, honesty and public spirit. Despite his sudden death on Tuesday he remains on the ballot on the Democratic, Republican and Liberal lines in next Tuesday's general election. Voters can honor his memory by casting votes in his name. A majority for him would block Thomas Lavin, a relatively unknown candidate of the Conservative Party. Governor Cuomo could then appoint a replacement for Mr. Merola, allowing qualified candidates to campaign for election next November. In other Bronx races: Fernando Ferrer (D-L) has been serving with distinction as Borough President since his selection by the Bronx City Council members. He deserves voter support to fill out the remaining two years of the term of Stanley Simon, who resigned under a cloud. Jose Rivera (D-L) has our endorsement to complete Mr. Ferrer's term on the council. Lee Holzman (D-R), highly qualified in surrogate law, warrants election to the post of Surrogate, now vacant. Frank Torres (D-R-L), a civil court judge, and Joseph Giamboi (R-C), an experienced litigator, are well qualified for the two vacant seats on the Supreme Court bench. For Civil Court in the First District (Northeast Bronx), Douglas E. McKeon (D) is amply qualified by experience in private practice and service on the city's tax and taxi commissions.

title: Market Turmoil; Stock Markets Maintain Calm Despite Pressure
description: The stock market absorbed new pressures without losing its balance yesterday - on the 58th anniversary of the market crash of 1929 - and the Dow Jones industrial average managed to close with a slight gain.

title: Stirring the Slumbering Soviet Masses
description: One group protests the destruction of historic buildings in Moscow. Another calls for a nongovernmental seminar on human rights. A third restores a monastery for use as a cultural center. Such is the diversity of groups mushrooming in the Soviet Union, where even to organize on behalf of the handicapped has long been impossible.

title: Sullivan Ordered to Pay Investors
description: A Federal judge today ordered William H. Sullivan, the owner of the New England Patriots, to pay $5.1 million to shareholders in the team who charged that Sullivan persuaded them in 1976 to accept prices below the value of the stock.

title: Smith Barney Losses Seen Cutting Primerica Net
description: The Primerica Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter results would be hurt by trading losses suffered in the market plunge by its Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company brokerage subsidiary.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects a tax benefit of $7.5 million resulting from discounting property and casualty loss reserves in accordance with the Tax Reform Act of 1986. c-Reflects a tax benefit of $22.5 million from discounting property and casualty loss reserves, and a one-time second quarter tax benefit of $16.3 million, which represents deferred income taxes applicable to title insurance loss reserves which, pursuant to the tax reform act, are no longer required. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: TV Reviews; Exploring Latin Jazz And Dance
description: TWO giants in their respective artistic fields can be found on this evening's schedule.

title: Mentally Ill Homeless Taken Off New York Streets
description: The Koch administration yesterday began a more vigorous campaign to remove severely mentally ill homeless people from Manhattan streets, parks and byways where they live to try to forcibly provide them with medical and psychiatric care.

title: Successor to Chief Is Named at Cigna
description: The Cigna Corporation, a large insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, yesterday chose Wilson H. Taylor as the eventual successor to its chairman and chief executive, Robert D. Kilpatrick.

title: Smoking Curbs Divide Hearings In City Council
description: A newly proposed antismoking bill for New York City got mixed reviews before the City Council yesterday. Some Council members who primarily represent minority groups called the measure too restrictive, while the City Health Commissioner said it was not restrictive enough.

title: Self-Starting Air Raid Siren
description: The police were inundated by 2,000 telephone calls early today after an old air raid siren that had been silent for years blared out an alarm. The siren at the Elm Street Junior High School went off at 3:12 A.M. and was not shut down until 3:45 A.M.

title: Democrats Fight for County Posts In New York G.O.P. Strongholds
description: Democratic candidates are waging aggressive, well-financed campaigns for county executive posts in Suffolk and four upstate counties that traditionally have elected Republicans.

title: UNION TEXAS PETROLEUM HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest third quarter.

title: L.F. Rothschild Search Cited
description: L.F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., which was hit with a $44 million loss from the stock market plunge this month, is looking for a buyer or a substantial capital injection to bolster its financial health, according to several Wall Street sources.

title: Eaton to Sell Military Unit
description: The Eaton Corporation said today that it would sell its military electronics operations and repurchase $500 million of its common shares on the open market.

title: National to Cut 400 Employees
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would lay off approximately 400 employees as part of a consolidation of its worldwide businesses. The Santa Clara, Calif., company said the layoffs were primarily the result of a reorganization after its recent acquisition of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation from Schlumberger Ltd.

title: NEWMONT MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $500,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1.4 million for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $980,000 for the quarter and a charge of $743,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, an extraordinary credit of $891,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,046,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' net includes pre-tax gains of $338 million from the sale of shares of subsidiaries to the public and pre-tax non-recurring charges of $41 million (of which $20 million are non-cash charges). The year-ago 9 months' net includes pre-tax non-recurring gains of $38 million and gains of $43 million from the sale of shares of subsidiaries to the public. The year-ago results are restated to reflect Foote Mineral Co. as a discontinued operation, Magma Copper Co. as an investment held for distribution and the June 2-for-1 stock split of Newmont Mining common shares.

title: Two Hartfords Are at Issue In Mayor Race
description: Carrie Saxon Perry says it is ''unconscionable'' for Hartford, capital of the state with the nation's highest per-capita income, to be ranked among the poorest cities.

title: Deaths Raise Brazil's Fear Of Radiation
description: More than four weeks after it was released from an abandoned hospital irradiation machine, cesium 137 has become the focus of concerns that range far beyond its effects on the inhabitants of a central Brazilian city.

title: GIBSON GREETINGS CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House Backs Credit Card Disclosure
description: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would require credit card issuers to disclose their interest rates, fees and conditions in advertising, solicitations and application forms.

title: Prices on Bonds Fall Again
description: Bond prices slumped for the second straight session yesterday, pushed lower by the dollar's weak performance on world currency markets.

title: Washington Talk: The Economy; HOW WALL STREET LOOKS ON THE CAPITAL'S MAP
description: Separated by only 200 miles, Washington and Wall Street might as well be in different galaxies when it comes to understanding and appreciating each other's imperatives and ways of working.

title: Reading S.A.T. Leaves
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Dismissed Over MX Case
description: About 30 employees of the Northrop Corporation were removed from key management positions last summer because of falsification of test results and other irregularities in the MX missile program, a senior Northrop executive told a Congressional panel today.

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GTE Unit Indicted In Fraud Case
description: A military contractor and three of its managers have been charged with submitting fraudulent bills totaling $774,604 to the Federal Government. The indictment, handed up by a Federal grand jury, accused GTE Government Systems Inc., a unit of the GTE Corporation, of 30 counts of ''making false and fraudulent statements and representations'' between November 1982 and April 1983. The Mountain View company declined comment until it could review the indictment.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hagler and Leonard: Still in the Picture?
description: After Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan decide the World Boxing Council middleweight championship here Thursday night, the sport will have three world middleweight champions for the first time since Marvelous Marvin Hagler beat Alan Minter in 1980.

title: Music: Early Cage by Bowery Group
description: THE Bowery Ensemble's retrospective concert in honor of John Cage's 75th birthday, which took place at Cooper Union on Tuesday, confined itself to the composer's early music. The most recent piece performed was ''Sixteen Dances,'' from 1951, Mr. Cage's last major work before he began using chance procedures as compositional tools. Nevertheless, some illuminating perspectives on Mr. Cage's music, in both its earlier and later manifestations, emerged from the program.

title: U.S. Underwriters Face Losses on B.P. Offering
description: The stocks of the American securities firm involved in the $12.2 billion offering in the British Petroleum Company were hit with heavy selling yesterday in expectation of huge losses from the deal.

title: 'Unseen Worlds,' Images of Science
description: ''THE INFINITE VOYAGE'' is a matter of visuals; usually they look pretty good.

title: SANDINISTAS URGED BY ARIAS TO YIELD ON CONTRA TALKS
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the architect of the Central American peace plan, says that negotiations to put the plan into effect are ''at an impasse'' and that Nicaragua must make new concessions to enhance the peace process.

title: Brock Says Trade Bill Would Lead to Panic
description: Labor Secretary William E. Brock 3d today urged Congressional leaders to abandon efforts on a restrictive trade bill, predicting that passage of the measure would cause ''rampant panic'' in the world's financial markets.

title: Amnesty Law Passed in El Salvador
description: The National Assembly has approved an amnesty that will free hundreds of leftist guerrillas and prevent the prosecution of any members of rightist death squads.

title: Advertising; Meredith Magazines Offers Package Deals
description: In answer to advertiser demand, the magazine division of the 85-year-old Meredith Corporation has set up its first corporate-buy operation under Wes Silk, executive publisher of Better Homes and Gardens.

title: Bogota Journal; Found in the Garbage, a Precious Nugget of Pride
description: In the crowded streets of downtown Bogota, where peddlers, prostitutes, pickpockets and beggars all come to ply their trade, the pathetic figures who scavenge through garbage have long occupied the bottom of the social ladder.

title: Lions' Aide Arraigned
description: Wayne Fontes, the Detroit Lions' defensive coordinator, was arraigned Wednesday in District Court in Rochester Hills, Mich., as a plea of not guilty was entered on his behalf on a charge of cocaine possession and two drunken driving charges stemming from his arrest Oct. 21. Judge Robert Shipper set a preliminary examination for Nov. 5 and Fontes was released on $7,000 personal bond. ''The club will issue no comment because it's a private matter that will be handled through the appropriate channels,'' Barbara Saliba, a spokeswoman for the Lions, said. Coach Darryl Rogers said he knew of the charges but needed more information about the coach.

title: Rangers' Modest Streak Snapped by the Kings
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, whose four-game stand in the Ranger net is over, was matter-of-fact about the ultimate reason the Rangers were defeated last night in their own building by a team they thought they should have mastered.

title: Sottsass' Oversize Collection: Is It Furniture or Art?
description: THE new collection of furniture by Ettore Sottsass, the influential and irreverent Italian architect, is overwhelming. Not only are the pieces oversize - most cabinets are at least eight feet high, and many tables and credenzas are seven feet long - but the designs are bold and brassy.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Georgia Fire Routs 15,000
description: A smoky chemical fire here Tuesday routed nearly 15,000 people from their homes, schools and businesses and burned until equipment used to fight fires in jetliners was brought in to douse it. No injuries were reported in the blaze at a warehouse owned by a swimming pool company. The fire melted the metal warehouse, and water poured onto it appeared to have little effect. The cause was not immediately determined.

title: Music: Marimolin, Duo at Weill Hall
description: MUSICAL friendships like the one that formed Marimolin two years ago begin in a void but have the potential, at least, to create a new literature. Indeed, without a new literature this unlikely combination of marimba and violin could scarcely exist.

title: Jurors Are Told Deaver Got $250,000 for One Call
description: C. Edward Meyer Jr., a former president of Trans World Airlines, testified today that the airline paid Michael K. Deaver $250,000 in 1985 to make a telephone call to Elizabeth Hanford Dole, who was then Secretary of Transportation.

title: It's Still Right to Cut the Deficit
description: Critics, right and left, insist that it's wrong to cut the budget deficit now. Non-experts are entitled to wonder, too. Why tighten up just when the stock market is in shock and the economy may be on the brink of recession?

title: Man Kills Robber With His Own Gun
description: A 47-year-old pet shop owner shot and killed one of two gunmen who attempted to rob his store in the Fordham section of the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: Political Giving Hurt by Plunge
description: The plunge is taking a toll on politics. Fund-raisers of both parties report that potential donors have stopped giving. Page A27. It is also a blow to the economy of the New York region, which has been robust, economists and public officials say.

title: Malaysia Shuts Down 3 Papers
description: The Malaysian Government, saying it feared a racial explosion, closed three newspapers today, including the country's liveliest English-language daily, The Star.

title: Dean Witter's Eurobonds
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck and Company, announced today that it was pulling out of London's overcrowded Eurobond market.

title: Post-Marathon Pace Was Grueling for '86 Victor
description: In retrospect, winning the New York City Marathon last year was the easy part for Gianni Poli of Italy. Dueling for the lead on First Avenue with Rob de Castella, the pre-race favorite, was less demanding than the pace Poli tried to maintain since becoming an overnight hero in his country. Deciding to defend his title, he said, was based more on a sense of duty than on any real feeling he can win again.

title: Crazy Eddie Is Facing 2 Federal Investigations
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the electronics retailer, disclosed today that it is the subject of two Federal investigations - a grand jury inquiry into certain of the company's business practices and a separate investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mexico Market's Fall Is the Steepest
description: Throughout the boom months of 1987, the volatile Mexican stock market performed more spectacularly than any other in the world. But with bulls having turned to bears all around the globe, Mexico is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange.

title: Andre Masson, 91, Dies; Was a Major Surrealist
description: Andre Masson, a major Surrealist painter, for more than 60 years a powerful and invigorating presence on the international art scene and the subject in 1976 of a retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, died in Paris yesterday. He was 91 years old.

title: Raymond Ketchledge, 67, an Electronics Inventor
description: Raymond W. Ketchledge, a retired executive of AT&T-Bell Labs who helped develop the first electronic switching systems for telephones, died of cancer Friday at his home in Englewood, Fla. He was 67 years old.

title: IRAQ SAYS PLANES RAIDED 3 VESSELS
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had raided three tankers off Iran and industrial targets on the mainland.

title: 'It's Time to Act,' Constituents Say
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Republican from Utah, is not one to advocate tax increases. But since the stock market plunge, messages from home have led him to view ''selective'' tax increases as acceptable.

title: What Has 26 Legs And Runs 26 Miles?
description: Fred Lebow was not delighted to learn that one of the leading entrants in his New York City Marathon this Sunday has 26 legs.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on investments of $12,154,000 for the quarter and $51,420,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on investments of $17,137,000 and $37,914,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: High-Tech Devices That Help in Seeing
description: High technology is bringing the world into focus for people with severely limited vision. Advances in video cameras and computers are making it possible for them to read, write and work independently.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 8.

title: Stage: Updated 'Hamlet' in Hartford
description: With his production of ''Hamlet'' at the Hartford Stage, Mark Lamos continues his venturesome exploration of the plays of Shakespeare - and Richard Thomas, as Hamlet, joins the ranks of American actors with the talent to perform great roles in the classics. Mr. Thomas is so natural, in fact, that one could imagine him being equally authoritative in a traditional version of the play.

title: Metro Matters; Born in Prison And Heading There Again
description: What is to be done with Dwayne Gosso?

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Vermont Protesters Arrested
description: At least 19 people were arrested today as student protesters ended an overnight sit-in at the University of Vermont. The students were protesting recruiting by the Central Intelligence Agency, citing what they called the agency's discrimination against homosexuals.

title: At a Racers' Club, Speed Is Just One of the Lessons Learned
description: LIKE most other first-time competitors in the New York City Marathon, Andre Donegan and Keith Givens have been busy preparing for the race, working out four times a week, increasing their distance in anticipation of Sunday's grueling 26.2-mile course.

title: Teen Pregnancies Decline. Now What?
description: Finally, teen-age pregnancies are starting to fall, according to new Federal figures. They vindicate calls - repeated at hearings in New Jersey yesterday - for greater efforts by parents, schools, youth programs and health centers to encourage delayed sexual activity and birth control. Such figures are the strongest evidence yet for vigorous expansion of such programs.

title: Advertising; Net Income Rises 22.5% At Interpublic Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies released its third-quarter financial statement Tuesday, and it was good.

title: TOTAL PETROLEUM (NORTH AMERICA) LTD(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the change from the full cost method of oil and gas accounting to the successful efforts method.

title: UNION EXPLORATION PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; August B. Kinzel, 87; Ex-Metals Researcher
description: Dr. August B. Kinzel, a retired Union Carbide executive, died last Friday of cardiac arrest in La Jolla, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Peru Bank Still Closed
description: Peru's largest private bank, the Banco de Credito, remained closed today as employees refused to cooperate with Government administrators sent in under a bank expropriation law. Luis Nieri, the bank's institutional relations manager, said employees were back at their desks after a two-day closure ordered by the administrators but were refusing to work. Mr. Nieri said Banco de Credito's employees had received provisional share certificates after buying a majority stake in the institution as the expropriation law took effect on Oct. 12. The Government maintains that the share transfer was invalid and that the Credito remains in the hands of its old owners.

title: Israeli Condemns Plan By Syria on Terrorism
description: Israel's chief delegate today assailed a Syrian proposal for a United Nations conference that would distinguish between terrorism and ''national liberation,'' saying it would make a ''laughingstock'' of the United Nations.

title: Penney to Drop 3 Store Lines
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest general merchandiser, said it plans to expand its women's apparel lines and to discontinue sale of home electronics, hard sporting goods and photographic equipment in all of its stores.

title: Israel Insists That the U.S. Maintain Military Assistance
description: Despite pressures on the United States to trim its budget deficit, Israel is insisting that Washington keep its promise to maintain the level of military aid for the next two fiscal years after Israel canceled the Lavi fighter plane, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today.

title: Thatcher Pushes for U.S. Shift
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has put her Government squarely behind international demands that President Reagan reduce the Federal budget deficit even if it means raising taxes.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales represent gross sales.

title: Shopping Canal St., New York's Attic
description: FIFTEEN years ago, in an electronics surplus store on Canal Street, Elliot Willensky chanced upon a color-coded circuit board from an early computer. ''It was inadvertent conceptual art, beautiful,'' he said, ''I bought it.'' More recently, he found a rare but almost worthless Evernal battery, made in Asia, that he did not already have in what he calls his horde of industrial trivia.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1 million for a litigation settlement and a reduction of $768,000 in depreciation for a change in estimate of service lives of restaurant building and leasehold improvements.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $293,000 for the quarter and $3,092,000 for the 9 months from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary charges of $30,597,000 for the quarter and $32,712,000 for the 9 months from the early extinguishment of debt. Both latest periods include the operations of American Can Packaging Inc., acquired effective Nov. 1, 1986.

title: Plagued by Falling Enrollment, Dental Schools Close or Cut Back
description: Georgetown University's 86-year-old dental school has no first-year students this fall. Over the next three years the Washington school will be gradually shut down, unless students and faculty members win a lawsuit to block the move.

title: Choosing Plants That Thrive in Winter's Light
description: AUTUMN and winter city light is fickle. The low sun may disappear for hours behind towering structures, yet the city gardener's dream of an indoor Eden prevails.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Gave Ron Oester, second baseman, his unconditional release. Named Lee May coach. HOUSTON ASTROS-Agreed to terms on a three-year contract will Bill Doran, second baseman. METS (NL) - Purchased the contract of Jose Roman, pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Named Dean Jordan director of broadcasting. SAN FANCISCO (NL) - Reached a tentative agreement to operate their Class A California League farm club in San Jose next season. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Signed Antoine Carr, forward, to an offer sheet. DENVER (NBA) - Announced the resignation of Vince Boryla, president and general manager. Named Pete Babcock president and general manager. KNICKS (NBA) - Waived Glen Clem and Mike Morgan, guards. SAN ANTONIO (NBA) - Waived Richard Rellford, guard, and Jerome Henderson, center. Obtained Kurt Nimphius, forward-center, from Detroit for a second-round draft choice in 1988. SEATTLE (NBA) - Waived Michael Phelps and Terence Stansbury, guards and Scott Wedman, forward. COLLEGES EDINBORO - Named Stan Swank women's basketball and softball coach. GEORGIA TECH - Suspended Willie Burks, defensive tackle, for at least one week for violation of team rules. LOUISIANA STATE - Announced that Brian Kinchen, tight end, will miss the remainder of the season with a broken leg. MOUNT ST. VINCENT'S - Named Joseph Brown women's basketball coach and Donna Lipuma women's swimming coach. NEW MEXICO - Announced the resignation of Dan Plater, wide receiver coach. Announced that Steve Fairchild, quarterback coach, will coach the wide receivers for the remainder of the season. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Sent Brian Curran, defenseman, to Springfield of the American Hockey League.

title: Birth Control Beyond The Rhythm Method
description: To the Editor:

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized gains on investments of $661,000 for the quarter and $4,621,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized gains on investments of $1,691,000 for the quarter and $7,525,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $1,399,000 and $4,919,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 and $305,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding in 1986 are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 29, 1987.

title: Ford Raises Prices by 1.3%
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had raised prices of its 1988 cars by an average of 1.3 percent above 1987 models with similar equipment.

title: 5 Are Indicted in Smuggling Of Military Hardware to Iran
description: Five men were indicted here today on charges of operating a ring that smuggled millions of dollars worth of military aircraft parts to Iran and South Africa in violation of a United States Government ban, prosecutors said.

title: BRITAIN'S SECRETS FACE NEW BATTLE
description: The House of Commons is preparing for another battle over Britain's much maligned but durable Official Secrets Act. This year, however, there is a new wrinkle.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter earnings were higher by an estimated $39.4 million, or 55 cents a share, as a result of the adoption of a change in accounting for pensions and as a result of an increase in the actuarial rate on return of the pension assets.

title: Ex-Paramount Official To Head Columbia
description: - Dawn Steel, a former head of production at Paramount Pictures, has been named to succeed David Puttnam as president of Columbia Pictures, the studio announced today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; What They Don't Know
description: Distressed by what he calls ''geographical illiteracy'' among the country's youth, Senator Robert T. Stafford, a Vermont Republican, is holding a hearing today to consider what young people know and need to know about geography.

title: Honeyghan Loses Title
description: Jorge Vaca of Mexico became the World Boxing Council welterweight champion today when he dethroned Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain in a confusing and controversial finish.

title: Howard Beach Jury Told How Fake Gun Fooled Investigators
description: A police officer testified at the Howard Beach trial yesterday that an imitation pistol - so real-looking that it was sent for ballistics examination -was found at the scene of Michael Griffith's death.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields were mixed for the week ended yesterday, declining for certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds and rising for bank money market accounts.

title: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1986 results are restated for pooling of interests.

title: Market Turmoil; CENTRAL BANKERS PERMIT THE DOLLAR TO SLIDE FURTHER
description: The world's central banks allowed the dollar to slide a notch today in international markets, apparently fearful that efforts to maintain its value would rattle stock markets and undermine economies.

title: Budget Deficit Down 33%
description: The Federal budget deficit shrank by 33 percent in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, even though the United States Government spent $1 trillion for the first time in history, the Reagan Administration reported today.

title: First Lawsuit Filed In Building Collapse
description: The first suit stemming from the collpase of L'Ambiance Plaza was filed yesterday, charging the city and two officials with failing to inspect the plans and site properly.

title: Market for Humor Still Bullish
description: ''Did you notice that whenever we have a stock market crash, it happens during apple season so the brokers have something to sell?''

title: Article 879187 -- No Title
description: The Senate has approved a bill appropriat-ing $8.5 billion for a wide variety of military construction projects, includ-ing money for a Navy port on Staten Is-land.

title: New York Offering Free AIDS Treatment to Some
description: New Yorkers with AIDS who have too much money to qualify for Medicaid and who are too poor to pay for AZT treatments can get the expensive drug free under a new program, the State Health Commissioner said yesterday.

title: VISTA CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,934,000 from payment of debt for the quarter and year. c-Net income and after a loss on payment of debt of $1,361,000 for the quarter and year. Both latest periods include an unusual charge of $55,363,000 from the expense of stock option plan changes.

title: At 7-Year Lows Abroad
description: Amid growing concerns on the American economy, the dollar's value plunged today to its lowest level in seven years against the West German mark.

title: Publishing: Gorbachev Book Due Out in 3 Weeks
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ''Perestroika'' is ready to go to press, and will be on sale nationally Nov. 18. But the book, which sets forth the author's plans and hopes, is already the international publishing event of the year, with a first printing of 200,000 copies scheduled in this country and with foreign rights sold in about 15 nations, including West Germany, France, Italy, Japan, Brazil, Spain, Portugal, Israel, Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland. U.S. News and World Report bought first serial rights, meaning the right to run portions on or before the official publication date.

title: Exhibition of Quilts Pairs Old With New
description: LEAD: A QUILT in the lobby with 35 appliqued images of women, all with their backs to the street, beckons the curious passer-by to enter the American Craft Museum, where the exhibition ''Homage to the Quilt'' opened yesterday. The images on the charming quilt ''Cafe Bar'' by the Japanese artist Michiko Sonobe give a hint of the exhibition inside.

title: Soccer Notebook; Things Are Looking Good for U.S. Olympic Team
description: The United States Olympic soccer team has been virtually assured of a place among the final 16 teams that will go to South Korea next fall. After winning both games of a home-and-home series with Trinidad and Tobago, the United States team beat El Salvador, 4-2, in San Salvador 10 days ago. The winner of that three-team group, with a United State-El Salvador game to be played, goes to Seoul.

title: Going Out Guide
description: Collector's Item

title: 3 Slain Colombian Journalists To Be Awarded Cabot Prizes
description: Three Colombian journalists who were murdered after reporting on drug trafficking, a reporter for The Miami Herald and a business newspaper in Brazil have been chosen as winners of the 1987 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes from Columbia University.

title: School in Chains
description: One of the most distinguished centers of higher education in Latin America, the University of Chile in Santiago, faces destruction.

title: Market Place; Plunge Brings New Favorites
description: STOCKS that benefit from lower interest rates and slower economic growth have bounced back into favor as a result of the equity market's brutal selloff. Last summer the popularity of these groups - utilities, foods, beverages and tobaccos - began to wane as cyclical issues with prospects of sharper earnings gains took over the leadership on Wall Street.

title: U.S. Missile Signaled A Launching in 1984
description: The Air Force said today that nearly four years ago an armored car was hurriedly parked atop a Minuteman III silo after the nuclear missile inside gave off false signals suggesting it was about to launch itself.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $13.8 million, after taxes, of additional depletion charges recorded by the company's oil and gas exploration subsidiary.

title: Bank Firebombed and Streets Blocked in Illegal Strike in Ecuador
description: Workers firebombed a bank and blocked streets with burning tires today during a one-day general strike that the Government had declared illegal. Union leaders said two strikers were wounded by police gunfire.

title: 300 DEFY STOPPAGE AT PAPER IN INDIA
description: Three hundred editors, reporters and other workers returned to their jobs Wednesday at India's largest newspaper, defying a 15-day-old work stoppage that they said had been sponsored by politicians close to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Modest Rally Pushes Stock Index Prices Up
description: The market for Standard and Poor's 500 stock- index futures staged a modest rally today, touched off by a wave of institutional buying.

title: Investment Managers Look for Signs Stock Plunge Is Over
description: Professional investment managers spent much of yesterday looking, almost desperately, for signals that the stock market slide had stopped. Until they are convinced the debacle is over, many are simply not going to buy stocks.

title: Across U.S., Anxiety Without Panic
description: It was the talk of grocery shoppers like Maria Lacombe at the Lucky Store in Madera, Calif., and of customers like Carl Schobinger, in for a haircut at Hanna's Barbershop in Watford City, N.D.

title: Henley Lifts Stake in Santa Fe to 14.1%
description: The Henley Group, capitalizing on the weakened stock market to strengthen its hand in a possible takeover battle, said today that it owns a 14.1 percent stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation and is considering seeking control of the railroad and real estate company.

title: Athens Charges Greek With Giving Stinger Missile Secrets to Soviet
description: Greek judicial officials said today that a 37-year-old Greek is to stand trial on charges of providing state secrets to Soviet agents, some of which enabled the Soviet Union to copy technology used in a NATO antiaircraft missile.

title: Renault Debt Plan
description: The French Cabinet approved a plan to transform the state-owned car maker Renault into a limited liability company, involving a write-off of $2 billion in debt and no more Government subsidies. A Government spokesman said the bill would be discussed in Parliament this autumn. The Government announced last week that it was writing off 12 billion francs (about $2 billion), or nearly a quarter of Renault's debt. The decision was attacked by Renault's domestic rival, Peugeot, which complained that the Government had been too generous to Renault and that the latest move could jeopardize fair competition.

title: Burger Ineligible
description: Jeff Burger, the leading passer in the Southeastern Conference, and Jim Thompson, a tackle, were declared ineligible yesterday by Auburn for violating the National Collegiate Athletic Association's extra-benefits rule. Both accepted a free ride in a private airplane to go hunting in southern Alabama with a friend of Thompson's family Oct. 11. David Housel, the sports information director at Auburn, said that university officials were making an appeal for the restoration of the players' eligibility and that a decision should come before the Tigers play Florida on Saturday night. Burger and Thompson were kept out of the victory last week when Coach Pat Dye learned of the possible infractions.

title: A South Africa Decree Is Protested at Universities
description: Thousands of university students and faculty members demonstrated today against a Government decree that sets political conditions for the granting of state subsidies to universities.

title: TV Review; Safe From Titanic Is Opened
description: THERE it was. The door swung open. Telly Savalas looked expectant. An armed guard reached in and took out a small green box that held a sodden pouch with coins. So, what or whom did you expect to emerge from the assistant purser's safe on the Titanic - Geraldo Rivera?

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Concert: Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society
description: THROUGHOUT its history, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has distinguished itself by drawing together outstanding players devoted to ensemble performance, and in particular to the presentation of new and unusual repertory. Fittingly, the society's program Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall, the first of its 19th season, opened with several out-of-the-ordinary works, including a local premiere. As it turned out, however, the one repertory standard on the bill proved to be the concert's high point.

title: Outdoors; A Guide to Antique Decoys
description: WITH individual birds by master carvers of yesteryear fetching hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent years, collecting antique waterfowl decoys has become big business. The growing interest in the field has produced some excellent books on the subject, one of the most recent being ''Connecticut Decoys'' by Henry Chitwood, with Thomas Marshall and Doug Knight.

title: LARIZZA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $43,000 from reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and the 9 months includes a tax credit of $1,180,000. c-Includes tax credits of $645,000 and $1,272,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reagan Delay Expected On Contra Aid Request
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to delay its request to Congress for a $270 million package of military and nonlethal aid to the Nicaraguan rebels until the beginning of next year, Administration officials said today.

title: Knicks Acquire Green
description: Finally, after weeks of posturing by the Knicks and the Pistons, Sidney Green is coming home.

title: Air From Dinosaurs' Age Suggests Dramatic Change
description: Tiny bubbles trapped in amber for 80 million years have given scientists their first direct look at the earth's atmosphere in the time of the dinosaurs, a mix of gases that appears dramatically different from the air we breathe today.

title: COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax gain of $3,000,000 for both the quarter and 9 months from an equity financing by Conner Peripherals Inc., a disk drive manufacturing in which Compaq has an interest, and equity in net income of an affiliated company of $744,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the 9 months.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter and 9-month includes a $11.3 million gain resulting from amendments and adjustments to certain natural gas sales contracts, and the 9-month also includes a $5.7 million from the sale of an interest in a small U.K. gas property. Year-ago 9-month benefited from a $6 million favorable tax adjustment.

title: Latin Officials Adopt Guidelines For Carrying Out Peace Accord
description: The foreign ministers of the five Central American states that signed a regional peace treaty in August announced general guidelines today under which the accord is to be put into effect over the next two months.

title: SUNY Proposing No Tuition Increase
description: Tuition would not go up at State University of New York campuses, but most dormitory rentals would rise an average of 4 percent under a proposed budget submitted to the Cuomo administration yesterday by SUNY trustees.

title: Neighborhoods and Developers Head for War
description: To the Editor:

title: Blood Abnormality May Predict Alzheimer's
description: Scientists have discovered an abnormality in the blood that may help predict the later appearance of Alzheimer's disease, the devastating mental disorder that afflicts more than a million middle-aged and elderly Americans.

title: Stock Impact Feared Grave In New York
description: Ten days after the stock market collapse, a growing consensus of economists and officials say its impact on the New York metropolitan area will be severe. But it will be months, if not years, before the full extent of the fallout is known, the experts said.

title: A NEW CONTENDER IS SEEN FOR COURT
description: A potential nominee to the Supreme Court who has received virtually no public attention has apparently emerged as one of the leading contenders as President Reagan prepares to announce the Administration's selection Thursday.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $367,000 for the quarter and $491,000 for the 6 months.

title: Merola's Death Leaves a Void for Colleagues
description: In Mario Merola's office yesterday, his receptionist of 10 years, Carolyn Connolly, frequently found herself pausing as she answered the phone.

title: Warm Heart Of Pine
description: COMPANIES that specialize in heart of pine say that more of it is being used in homes for flooring, paneling and wainscoting.

title: The Role Of Noisy Hardware
description: THE uninvited tend not to knock. Household hardware and the noises it makes - the squeak of the door hinge, the doorknob that thumps to the floor, the squeal of the rusty nail, the clank of the hidden pipe, the window sash that suddenly slams shut - have become generic indicators for Something Terrible Is About to Happen.

title: Anheuser's Net Gains by 19.2%
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. said today that its third-quarter profits climbed 19.2 percent because of strong beer sales.

title: Judge Rules Ohio Aides Coerced Subordinates for Political Funds
description: A Federal administrative judge ruled today that three housing authority officials in Akron, Ohio, coerced subordinates into making political contributions in violation of Federal law and recommended that the officials be removed from their jobs.

title: WITCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,700,000 and $13,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $2,200,000 for the quarter and $15,200,000 for the 9 months.

title: Farm Agency Sets $1.45 Billion Issue
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering a total of $1.45 billion of three-month and six-month bonds, at a price of par, through various securities dealers.

title: Washington Talk: Ethics; NEW REASONS TO FIGHT FOR THE BILL AT LUNCH
description: ''It is the end of the civilization as we now know it,'' glowered Robert D. Novak, the syndicated columnist. ''If it wasn't so silly it would be outrageous,'' grumbled Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic Party chairman. ''I can't believe they'll make it stick,'' fumed Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post.

title: 2 U.S. Airmen Slain at Philippine Base
description: Two American airmen and two other men were shot and killed in a series of attacks outside this major military base.

title: Political Fund-Raising in Both Parties Plunges With Stock Market
description: While it remains unclear what the stock market plunge will mean for candidates' electoral fortunes, one political effect is already apparent: fund-raising has taken a nose dive.

title: TUCSON ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After non-recurring credits of $9,332,000 for the latest year and $14,150,000 for the year-ago period.

title: PRESIDENT CHIDES SOVIET OVER ARMS
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union should stop holding arms reduction talks ''hostage to measures that would cripple our Strategic Defense Initiative.''

title: Household Help: Some Questions And Answers
description: AS the ranks of working mothers - particularly those with young children - continue to swell, many of them agree that one of the prerequisites for their success is not an M.B.A. or an undergraduate degree from a prestigious school, but rather a reliable, efficient nanny or housekeeper. Knowing that there is someone at home they can count on to take good care of their youngsters, and sometimes of their home as well, allows them to concentrate on business while they are in the office.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sure-Fire Investment
description: Tom C. Korologos, the Washington lobbyist enlisted by the White House to help with the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, has been roaming Senate corridors this week with a new message for senators and anyone else within earshot: ''Invest in taxes. They're the only thing that's going up.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Woody Woodward, who 10 days ago resigned after three years as general manager of the Yankees, was named personnel director of the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday and given free rein to make trades. Bill Giles, the president of the Phillies, announced Woodward's appointment. Giles said he would become involved in personnel decisions only if Woodward and Manager Lee Elia disagreed, or a major financial policy was involved. ''If Woody and Lee can't agree, I'll be the referee,'' said Giles, who has handled all player decisions since he organized a group to buy the team in 1981. Giles said he did not give Woodward, who is 44 years old, the title of general manager because he didn't want him involved in player development and contract negotiations. . . . Larry Holmes, the former champion, can fight Mike Tyson in January for the undisputed world heavyweight championship, the World Boxing Council said yesterday in agreeing to sanction the Tyson-Holmes bout scheduled for January. It declined, however, to reinstate Holmes to the top-10-contender ranking he had when he retired.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Exercised options for 1988 on the contracts of Hubie Brooks, shortstop; Pascual Perez, pitcher, and Tim Wallach, third baseman. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Named Woody Woodward personnel director. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Named Pete Babcock president and general manager. KNICKS (NBA) - Acquired Sidney Green, forward, from Detroit for Ron Moore, forward, and a second-round draft pick in 1988 or 1989. Signed Trent Tucker, guard, to a two-year contract. SEATTLE (NBA) - Released Michael Phelps and Terence Stansbury, guards, and Scott Wedman, forward. FOOTBALL CLEVELAND (AFC) - Waived Enis Jackson, cornerback; Tim Crawford and Jeff Pegues, linebackers; Mike Rusinek, nose tackle; Larry Mason, running back; Billy Robinson, safety; Keith Bosley, offensive tackle; Emil Boures, guard; Vyto Kab, tight end, and Remi Watson, wide receiver. MIAMI (AFC) - Waived Jeff Hayes, punter. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Mike LeBlanc and Bruce Hansen, running backs, and Joe Peterson, cornerback. JETS (AFC) - Re-signed George Radachowsky, safety. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Released Dwight Garner and Greg Grooms, running backs; Alfred Jenkins, tight end, and John Mickens, linebacker. HOCKEY TEAM CANADA - Announced it had added Bob Mongrain and Merlin Malinowski, centers, to its Olympic team. COLLEGES AUBURN - Announced that Jeff Burger, quarterback, and Jim Thompson, offensive tackle, had been declared ineligible by the N.C.A.A. for violating the ''extra benefits'' rule. DELAWARE - Suspended Darrell Booker, linebacker, for disciplinary reasons. HOFSTRA - Named Mert Sells assistant men's basketball coach. INDIANA STATE - Reinstated Larry Bush, forward, to the basketball team. NAVY - Named Pete Schuyler assistant wrestling coach; Caryl Martin assistant women's track and field and cross country coach; and Dianne Boyer assistant sports information director. ST. JOSEPH'S (Pa.) - Named John Griffin part-time assistant men's basketball coach. SYRACUSE - Named Howard Triche graduate men's assistant basketball coach.

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
HERS
description: MOST Americans take speaking correct English for granted. Not I. And although I graduated from the University of California at Berkeley with a degree in journalism, spent a year in the M.F.A. film program at Columbia University, have had a novel published and now teach creative writing, sometimes I still feel insecure when it comes to speaking - and even writing - grammatically correct English. Should I blame my teachers, my parents or myself?

title: Excerpts From President's Speech at West Point
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 - Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech today at the United States Military Academy at West Point: I want to speak about relations between the American republic and democracy's main competitor, the Soviet Union - relations that are likely to shape the whole course of your careers as professional soldiers. I want in particular to discuss our present efforts for arms reduction -efforts that may soon be yielding historic results. The agenda of our relations with the Soviet Union has focused upon four critical areas. First, human rights, because freedom is what we stand for as Americans. Second, negotiated settlements to regional conflicts. Third, expanded exchanges between our peoples. And fourth, arms reduction.

title: STYLES IN HAUNTED HOUSES, FROM VICTORIAN GLOOM TO MODERN MAYHEM
description: TO Gene Wolfe, a writer of horror stories, there is something inherently fearsome about houses. You can never be sure you're alone, he mused recently. The fact that you can't see the entire house at one time is unnerving. There is always the possibility of opening the closet and finding clothes swaying mysteriously, or sneaking into the kitchen for a midnight snack to encounter a monster in the mixing bowl.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $2,398,000 from call premiums on early retirement of debt for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The latest quarter and 9 months' operating nets are after an $11.5 million writedown on assets. The 9 months' net is also after a $6.7 million premium on stock repurchases, and includes a $2.1 million gain from a pension plan accounting change.

title: Baby Brokering: Desperate Girl's Case Reveals Shadowy World
description: Pennsylvania authorities have obtained an arrest warrant for a Florida man they say uses classified advertising in rural areas to entice unwed pregnant teen-agers to give up their babies for adoption by affluent couples, many of them in New York.

title: Little Evidence of 1968 Tet Massacre in Hue
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1987
description: MARKET TURMOIL The world's central banks allowed the dollar to slide a notch, apparently fearing that further efforts to maintain its value would rattle the stock market and undermine economies around the world. Throughout the day, the central banks tempered the currency's decline by buying dollars, although traders said the official buying, though widespread, was modest. Officials said the buying apparently marks a shift in the Reagan Administration's eight-month-old policy of keeping the dollar's value steady. [ Page A1. ] Amid fears of a U.S. recession, the dollar's value plunged to its lowest level in seven years against the West German mark. [ D11. ] The stock market faced new pressures but did not lose its balance on the 58th anniversary of the 1929 crash. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.33 point, to 1,846.82. Still, most stocks lost ground and selling of smaller issues continued. Given the dollar's drop, the market's relative calm surprised some experts. [ A1. ] Administration and Congressional negotiators started talks on a budget compromise, but their initial sparring produced few conclusive results. [ D1. ] The Thatcher Government backs international demands that the U.S. budget deficit be trimmed, even if tax increases are needed. [ D1. ] Bonn thinks the budget deficit is responsible for higher rates worldwide. [ D10. ] The S.E.C. chairman suggested tighter regulation would result if the Government were directly responsible for setting rules on down payments for trading in stock-index futures. [ D8. ] The market for S.&P. 500 stock-index futures rallied modestly. [ D20. ] Stocks of U.S. underwriters involved in the British Petroleum offering were hit hard by heavy selling in anticipation they will suffer big losses on the issue. [ D1. ] The volatile Mexican stock market is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange. [ D1. ] The Tokyo stock market opened sharply lower this morning. [ D12. ] OTHER MARKETS B ond prices slumped for the second straight session, pushed lower by the dollar's decline on world currency markets. Meanwhile, short-term interest rates dropped sharply. [ D19. ] Yields declined for C.D.'s and money market mutual funds but rose for money market accounts in the recent week. [ D21. ] COMPANIES The new management of Continental Illinois will focus on investment banking and strip away most of its commercial banking activities. Thomas C. Theobald, Continental's chairman, said it would sell all its small Chicago-area banks and drop out of the unprofitable municipal securities business. [ D5. ] L. F. Rothschild is seeking a buyer or a large capital injection, according to several Wall Street professionals. According to the sources, the financially troubled firm has been working with its investment banker, Salomon Brothers, to find an acquirer. [ D4. ] Primerica said that Smith Barney's recent trading losses would hurt its fourth-quarter results. [ D4. ] Henley Group owns 14.1 percent of Santa Fe Southern Pacific, capitalizing on the weakened stock market. It said it might seek control of the railroad and real estate concern. [ D5. ] LTV and Bethlehem posted profits in the third quarter, rebounding from losses in the 1986 quarter. [ D4. ] Crazy Eddie faces two Federal inquiries: an investigation into its business practices, and a separate S.E.C. examination. [ D20. ] Asher B. Edelman said that a Citicorp unit had joined in his hostile bid for Telex. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY The disclosure of credit-card interest rates would be required by a bill approved overwhelmingly by the House of Representatives. The lone opponent was Philip M. Crane, who maintains that only states should regulate credit-card rates. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMN The leveraged buyout of Southland has been imperiled by the stock market's plunge because of investors' jitters over the ''junk bonds'' used to finance the transaction. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The new favorites in the equity markets are stocks that benefit from lower interest rates and slower economic growth: utility, food, beverage and tobacco issues. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Golfers to Play for $3 Million
description: While the real world wonders if its financial house is made of cards, the world of golf will reach a financial high this week as 30 golfers compete for a share of a $3 million purse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To permit Libya, Syria and Iran to define terrorism is to invite the fox to guard over the chicken coop.'' - Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations. [ A15:1. ]

title: Advertising; Griffin Bacal Gets Le Clic
description: Griffin Bacal Inc., a shop that is particularly at home with toys and other leisure-time products, has become agency for Le Clic videotape, a product being introduced by the Keystone Camera Corporation of Clifton, N.J.

title: Wesleyan President to Head Rockefeller Fund
description: Colin G. Campbell, the president of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., has been named president of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, one of the nation's most prestigious foundations.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Dreams of McLaughlin
description: It may already appear that John McLaughlin, the gruff-voiced political commentator, is everywhere on television, conducting a weekly interview show and presiding over the McLaughlin Group's discussion of the week's events. But there is one glaring omission on the former Jesuit's resume: he has never appeared on ''Alf,'' the sitcom about the little alien from outer space who moves in with an American family.

title: Newsletter Editor Is Ashamed and Poorer
description: Alfred Frank amassed a fortune for himself and his clients in the last seven years by buying stocks on borrowed funds. But now ''I've become an unhappy, unrich man,'' said Mr. Frank, the founder and editor of the Prudent Speculator, a stock market newsletter.

title: USX Sees Delay
description: The chairman of the USX Corporation, David Roderick, said the diversified steel and oil company is running a year behind schedule with its plans to sell $1.5 billion of assets. The company, which said on Tuesday that it had fully recovered from a steel workers' strike in 1986, had estimated at the beginning of the year that the sales would take about two years. USX has sold $300 million of businesses this year and may have agreements for several large units by the end of 1987, Mr. Roderick said, but he declined to give details.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Does It Get HBO?
description: Television came to the Senate only a little over a year ago, but life without it has already become almost unthinkable. That point was underscored last week when the Senate doorkeepers, who spend their days a few paces from the chamber itself, acquired a miniature television set with which to monitor proceedings on the Senate floor.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 29, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Too Much Focus on Budget Deficit, Experts Say
description: President Reagan and lawmakers, trying to reduce the budget deficit, may be looking through blinders, according to economists and business consultants.

title: KEY RATES
GOODYEAR CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ramada's Net Down 39.4%
description: Ramada Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 39.4 percent because of declining income from its hotel and restaurant operations.

title: Becker Is Dropped From Unicef Post
description: It is Boris Becker's belief that sports and politics should not mix. But that has not prevented the 19-year-old West German tennis star from becoming the center of a controversy that has cost him his position as goodwill ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: Books: Big Man at Fed
description: THE most remarkable thing about William R. Neikirk's commendable biography of Paul A. Volcker is that its very existence demonstrates how much has changed in the world of economics. What, after all, would have been the market for general interest books about even the most distinguished of Mr. Volcker's predecessors as head of the nation's central bank?

title: UNC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,148,000 for the quarter and $6,241,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $1,831,000 for the quarter and $6,216,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a credit from discontinued operations of $1,081,000 and a charge of $1.1 million related to the redemption of subordinated debentures.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holy Cross Rolls On in College Football
description: How good is Holy Cross, unbeaten after seven games in which it has outscored opponents by 337-81?

title: Jets Putting Hopes on The Line
description: When someone asked Mickey Shuler today if it would be difficult to forget the players' strike, the Jets' veteran tight end said that it would be tough because the team was constantly being reminded of things it was trying to forget.

title: Timeout for Kasparov In Chess Title Match
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, took a timeout today, postponing the seventh game of his match with Anatoly Karpov until Friday, match officials said.

title: School Chief Disputes Figures on California
description: Offering figures disputing the conclusions of a University of Chicago study, California's Superintendent of Public Instruction said today that the state's educational program was working and that minority students' scores proved it.

title: Baseball Needs Instant Replay
description: EVER since the first umpire missed a call, baseball's cop-out has been that bad calls even up, that each team will get its share. Over a 162-game season, maybe the bad calls do even up, maybe not. But in the World Series, especially in the seventh game, there's not enough time for them to even up. In the seventh game, the outcome can turn on a bad call that could be corrected if baseball would accept limited instant replay.

title: Synod at Vatican Is Divided Over Lay Groups
description: The rapidly growing strength of independent lay movements in the Roman Catholic Church has provoked sharp disagreements at the Synod of Bishops now meeting at the Vatican.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Nets Lose At Buzzer
description: A. C. Green scored 23 points, including the winning points at the buzzer tonight, as the undefeated Los Angeles Lakers won their sixth consecutive National Basketball Association exhibition, 110-108, from the Nets.

title: Deaths From Drunken Driving Increase
description: The number of traffic deaths caused by drunken drivers rose markedly in 1986 after a general decline in the early 1980's.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $32.1 million. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $13.8 million for the quarter and $1.3 million for the 9 months. The latest quarter includes other income of $17 million, resulting primarily from the sale of a portion of Florida lands which Williams Cos. had retained in the sale of its Agrico Chemical Co. subsidiary earlier this year.

title: U.S. Drilling Rig Data
description: The number of working rotary rigs drilling for oil in the United States last week dropped by four, to 1,130, Baker Hughes Inc. said. But the number of seismic crews searching for oil and gas in the United States increased by six in September, according to the Society of Exploration Geophysicists.

title: Glasnost Is Taking A Fashionable Turn
description: POLITICIANS and diplomats may have had trouble arranging a summit meeting, but an American trading company cut through miles of red tape to bring Russian fashions to this country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1987
description: International A3-16

title: Bell & Howell
description: Macmillan Inc. said it had increased its stake in the Bell & Howell Company to 7.7 percent, from 6.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Macmillan said it had bought an additional 106,200 Bell & Howell shares on the open market between Sept. 23, when the price of Bell & Howell stock averaged $70.77 a share, and Oct. 23, when the stock averaged $47.57.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $37 million and $147,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after a charge of $2.1 billion for pension costs and writedowns of fixed assets for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month includes a $535 million charge for idling of portions of factories and some writedowns.

title: Forty Niner Leads Weak Futurity Field
description: The nation's leading 2-year-old and the first top runner to be flown here from the Soviet Union in 21 years are among the entrants in nine major races around the country in the next four days.

title: Siamese Twins Progress
description: West German Siamese twins separated in a historic operation seven weeks ago are making substantial progress, but it may take months for doctors to fully assess their recovery, according to officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital. The twins, Benjamin and Patrick Binder, were joined at the back of their heads. Doctors said bleeding and swelling during the surgery to separate them was likely to have caused some brain damage.

title: Futures Industry Leader Defends Trade Practices
description: John Damgard's job is to defend the futures industry against critics who say that computer program trading and other practices involving stock futures caused the stock market plunge.

title: 12 Die in British Road Crash
description: Twelve people, including three children, were killed today when a gasoline tank truck exploded in a highway pileup near here, a hospital spokesman said.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $23.5 million for the quarter and realized investment gains of $1.7 million for the 9 months; the periods also include tax benefits from property casualty ''fresh start'' provisions of $25.3 million for the quarter and $46.1 million for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $32.5 million for the quarter and $55.5 million for the 9 months, and a tax credit of $20.6 million for the both periods.

title: WISCONSIN ENERGY reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Studies Back Adoption Across Racial Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble in Cowboys' Corral
description: The laconic voice from Texas was somber today, Tom Landry's voice, which has bellowed at or cajoled every Dallas Cowboy who has ever played since the franchise's creation in 1960.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $8,214,000 for the quarter and $19,416,000 for the 9 months; the year-ago quarter also includes a pre- tax gain of $110,666,000 from the sale of half-interest in Citgo. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,014,000 for the quarter and $18,725,000 for the 9 months.

title: Advertising; Promoting New York Woman
description: NEW YORK WOMAN magazine, first published in September 1986, has yet to promote itself in the advertising trade press. This is unusual.

title: INSIDE
description: Drunken Driving Toll Rises The death rate involving drunken drivers rose by 7 percent in 1986 after five years of decline. Page A18. U.S. Airmen Are Slain Two American Air Force men were among four people killed in a series of attacks outside Clark Air Base in the Philippines. Page A3.
