Case of a Baby Broker Authorities are seeking a Florida man who they say enticed pregnant teen-agers to give up their babies for affluent couples to adopt. Page B1.

title: 'Freedom' Director Cuts Film Under Pressure
description: Sir Richard Attenborough said today that he had removed lines from his new film about Steven Biko, the black South African leader who died in police custody 10 years ago, under pressure from a guerrilla group.

title: Wave of Opposition Arrests: 3 Days That Shook Malaysia
description: - Malaysians tell stories of the last 72 hours with expressions of disbelief.

title: The Rise of Cynical Chic
description: LEAD: When Leonard Bernstein gave his high five to the Black Panthers in the late 60's, Tom Wolfe, hermetically sealed in white, coined the memorable put-down ''radical chic.''

title: Guatemala Amnesty Is Passed
description: Guatemala, facing renewed fighting between the army and left-wing rebels, has approved an amnesty law complying with the Central American peace accord signed in August, political figures said today.

title: A Severed Head Is a Main Topic At Westies Trial
description: A niece of two key defendants in the Westies racketeering trial provided graphic testimony for the prosecution yesterday about the severed head of a murder victim.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Hal McRae, who turned down the Kansas City Royals' interim manag-inig job last summer, was hired yes-terday as the Pittsburgh Pirates' minor-league hitting instructor, based in Bradenton Fla. ... The Phoenix Suns have obtained James Bailey, a veteran forward-center, from the Cleveland Cavaliers for a future draft pick. The 6-foot-9-inch, 250-pound Bailey was obtained by the Cavaliers from the Nets on Oct. 8 in a three-way deal that also involved the Utah Jazz...Gary Fencik, the Chi-cago Bears; career tackling leader, said he would retire after this season, his 12th with the Bears and the Na-tional Football League. Fencik, 33 years old, is a two-time Pro Bowl se-lection. Fencik, a former Yale star, lost his starting free-safety job to Todd Bell in training camp this year.

title: U.S. Admits Safety Faults At Reactors for Bomb Fuel
description: The Under Secretary of Energy acknowledged today that safety mechanisms in the reactors for making bomb fuel were not as good as those in commercial reactors, and he indicated that the Reagan Administration would soon take the first step toward building a new reactor.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day yesterday reported that Morgan Stanley & Company, one of four American underwriters for the British Petroleum Company's share offering, could post a loss of about $120 million from the underwriting. The article said the loss could be particularly painful for Morgan Stanley because the firm had $576 million in shareholder's equity at the end of 1986.

title: Stock Fall May Affect Trade Bill
description: The stock market collapse has reshuffled yet again the complicated politics of trade legislation, raising questions about what kind of bill will emerge from a Congressional conference committee or whether there will be a trade bill at all this year.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Campaign For AFL-CIO
description: Next year Lois, Pitts, Gershon, Pon/GGK will begin to spend the dollar-a-member advertising fund that the AFL-CIO has just committed to a two-year image campaign. The total kitty will be $13 million.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of 8.75 percent noncallable notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.86 to yield 8.79 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Willis Jackson, 59, Tenor Saxophonist In Jazz and Blues
description: Willis (Gatortail) Jackson, a tenor saxophonist with a big, robust sound and a wealth of experience in jazz and rhythm and blues, died Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, a week after undergoing heart surgery and suffering complications from diabetes. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 FESTIVAL FILMS OPEN
description: Two films will open today that were originally shown at the re-cent New York Film Festival.

title: Tucker Ponders Long Wait
description: TRENT TUCKER might have been upset, perhaps even furious. After five seasons in which he was asked to perform in a system nonconducive to his skills, the 27-year-old guard had apparently been reduced to an afterthought.

title: UNITED WATER RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUCTION
description: THE first major test of how the art market is weathering the international financial crisis is expected next week in the contemporary art sales taking place at Sotheby's and Christie's. The auctions of postwar works - Rauschenbergs, de Koonings, Pollocks, Bacons and Lindners - are estimated to bring between $35 million and $46 million, the highest combined total value for such sales of paintings and sculpture in a three-day period.

title: Hearns Is First To Take 4 Titles
description: Under cloudy desert skies here, Thomas Hearns tonight became the first man in boxing history to win four world titles in separate weight categories.

title: Burglary Trial Delayed By Scheduling Problem
description: The burglary trial of Dwayne Gosso, a 26-year-old New York City man who was born in a prison and has spent much of his life in foster care, mental hospitals, rehabilitation centers and jails, was adjourned yesterday because the arresting officer was testifying in another case.

title: Managua Plan on Indians Hits Snag
description: The top exiled political leaders of the Miskito Indians and other indigenous peoples of Nicaragua asserted today that the Nicaraguan Government had reneged on a promise to begin peace talks with Indian rebel officials.

title: Capturing the Fire of 'Carmen' on Ice
description: Her athletic clock was ticking, but not so loudly that Debi Thomas could not hear the music she was using for her figure skating programs.

title: Saudi Deal Is Sent to Congress
description: The Reagan Administration submitted a compromise arms deal to Congress today that would allow Saudi Arabia to purchase $1 billion worth of jet fighters and other military hardware.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of approximately $970,000 for both the quarter and 6 months resulting from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Broadway
description: Switching a Benefit

title: VW Offering Said to Be Off
description: The West German Government has indefinitely postponed a public offering of its 16 percent stake in Volkswagenwerk A.G. because of the recent slump in the auto maker's stock, people familiar with the plan said today. Volkswagen shares have lost 29 percent of their value since the worldwide stock market debacle last week.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $22,119,000 and $41,338,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $15,996,000 for the quarter and $42,114,000 for the 9 months.

title: President's Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan in Washington yesterday on his nomination to fill a Supreme Court vacancy, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Sports of The Times; Parents of the Twins
description: LEE MacPHAIL could sit with his son at the moment of ultimate triumph while Frank and Helen Viola had to watch their son celebrate from a distance. But all three parents shared the joy of seeing somebody who used to be a child now handle the details and the pressures of being an adult.

title: Treasury Prices Stage Rally
description: Prices of short- and long-term Treasury issues rose yesterday as lower commodity prices and signs of falling interest rates abroad helped to heighten expectations of lower interest rates.

title: Computer Trading Needs Market Regulation; Keep Index Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: Unit of BASF In U.S. Gas Deal
description: A wholly owned subsidiary of BASF A.G., one of West Germany's largest chemical and plastics producers, said it would buy Houston-based Tenneco Inc.'s Mid-Louisiana Gas unit for around $80 million. The purchase would strengthen the existing position of the subsidiary, Wintershall A.G., in the Monroe natural gas field in northeast Louisiana.

title: Restaurants
description: WHEN the Harry Cipriani restaurant in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel closed abruptly eight weeks ago in a landlord dispute, many of its soigne patrons trotted down to the family's other celebrity corral, Bellini by Cipriani, on Seventh Avenue at 51st Street. This five-month-old clone was still fine tuning its engine when the new wave of customers arrived, requiring the opening of a new downstairs dining room. The kitchen had to shift into overdrive even before its break-in period was over.

title: ESSELTE BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $30,000 for the quarter and $660,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $74,000 and $378,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Dallas Green Resigns
description: Dallas Green announced yesterday that he was resigning as president and general manager the Chicago Cubs after six years. Green, 53 years old, is the fourth general manager to leave since the end of the season. John Madigan, executive vice presi-dent of the Tribune Company and owner of the Cubs, announced that he would assume the additional position of chairman of the ball club until a di-rector of baseball operations is named. Madigan said the Cubs would not name afield manager until Green was replaced.

title: Soviet Marshal Sees 'Star Wars' Giving U.S. Edge
description: Soviet analysts believe that deployment of President Reagan's anti-missile defense system, coupled with an agreement to cut long-range nuclear weapons in half, could give the United States a decisive military advantage, the chief of the Soviet General Staff has declared.

title: Financial Aid Urged for Teachers
description: Robert F. Wagner, the president of the Board of Education, last night suggested a series of financial incentives - including a loan forgiveness program - to help attract talented young teachers to the New York City public school system.

title: 10 Writers Get Awards From Whiting Group
description: Ten writers, including poets, novelists and a playwright, have each received a $25,000 award from the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, a philanthropic organization active in the field of the humanities.

title: GUARANTY TRUSTCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Newark's Mayor Backs Jackson
description: Mayor Sharpe James today endorsed the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the Democratic Presidential nomination. The Mayor said Mr. Jackson represented ''new hope and a new vision for a better America.''

title: Gene's Causative Link to Alzheimer's Is Disputed
description: New research reports sharply dispute a theory holding Alzheimer's disease to be caused by duplication of a gene that governs production of a particular protein found in the brains of patients.

title: Russian Bond Payment
description: The holders of Tsarist Government bonds issued in London before the 1917 Russian Revolution will start to receive payment on Friday as part of an Anglo-Soviet accord, Foreign Office officials said today. Payments of up to $:5,000, or $8,500, will be sent out to bondholders as a first installment, the officials said.

title: THOMAS HOPPEL INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Literary Prodigies
description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL SPERRY
description: Paul Sperry, a tenor, is to perform works by New York composers Rob-ert Beaser, John Musto, Christopher Berg, Robert Convery and Larry Alan Smith - Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Irma Vallecillo, a pianist, is to accompany. Tickets are $5, $3 for museum mem-bers and children. Information: 534-1672.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bullish Note From Navy
description: Into the grim atmosphere generated by the stock market collapse, the decline of the dollar and the budget crisis falls a slender ray of light from the Department of the Navy: James H. Webb Jr, the Secretary of the Navy, has told 600 scholars at naval institutions that they can earn more for academic excellence.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,100,000 and $14,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a tax credit of $11,700,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $7,300,000 for the quarter and $20,700,000 for the 9 months, and a tax credit of $12,300,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month reflect a $60 million strengthening of life net benefit reserves resulting in a 36 cents a share charge to net income.

title: John Oliver Killens, 71, Author And Founder of Writers' Group
description: John Oliver Killens, a writer, teacher and a founder of the Harlem Writers Guild, died of cancer Tuesday at the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old and lived in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Dance: The Original 'Sacre'
description: IN the arts, yesterday's scandal is today's classic. This maxim does not hold quite as true for ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' simply because the ballet that Vaslav Nijinsky created to Igor Stravinsky's score in 1913 disappeared from the international repertory.

title: Masks: Mad, Mythic, 'Real'
description: Fiorucci's, known for its racy miniskirts and jazzy jewelry, has an artist on the premises making Halloween masks through tomorrow.

title: Jetliner and Cargo Plane Miss Colliding by 50 Feet
description: A Pan American World Airways jetliner came within about 50 feet of hitting a DC-3 cargo plane Tuesday night shortly before they landed at St. Croix, Virgin Islands, Government and airline officials said yesterday.

title: TV Weekend; WAMBAUGH'S 'ECHOS IN THE DARKNESS'
description: IF you put it in a book, nobody would believe it. That old saw will certainly come to mind while confronting ''Echoes in the Darkness,'' a best-selling book and now a five-hour mini-series, both of which were written by Joseph Wambaugh.

title: Strike Possible At Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange is facing a possible strike by most of its clerical workers. Local 153 of the Office Employees Professional Union voted Wednesday by an 18-to-1 margin to strike when its three year contract runs out Saturday unless a new agreement is reached.

title: Morris's Injuries Alter Giants' Plans
description: The possible absence of Joe Morris could affect more than just the Giants' running game against the Dallas Cowboys Monday night. It may also have an impact on the special teams.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ANDRE RENE, the chef who opened Windows on the World, has been hired to help get Manhattan's other celebrated celestial dining room off to a high-flying start: the renovated Rainbow Room atop the RCA Building. Mr. Rene joins two other Windows alumni at the lavish new dining and dancing complex, which is to open in late December: Alan Lewis, the soon-to-depart director of Windows, who will be director of the Rainbow Room, and Joseph Baum, the restaurant consultant who is overseeing the project.

title: India Using Copters in Fight Against Tamils in Sri Lanka
description: India said tonight that its forces were using helicopter gunships against ethnic Tamil rebels in northern Sri Lanka.

title: Our Towns; Ballad of Route 1: Everyone Wants To Be Princeton
description: It was a little more than three years ago that Richard K. Rein, a writer in Princeton who thought he knew a story when he saw one, proposed a story to a local publication about the way the big hotels out on Route 1, just east of town, were competing for the good opinion of corporate travel agents.

title: Art: Bruce Nauman Retrospective
description: IN the retrospective of his drawings at the New Museum, the sculptor Bruce Nauman comes across as the complete Post-Minimalist artist, an exemplary representative of the almost frenzied experimentation that took hold of art, and especially sculpture, in the late 1960's and early 70's. During those years, younger artists built on and broke through the limitations of Minimalism, branching out into areas soon designated as Conceptual, Performance, Installation and Process art. Working with language, with his own body, with environmental structures as well as with relatively finite, if quite eccentric, sculptural objects, Mr. Nauman touched on and helped define all these terms.

title: Boiler Breakthrough Came Only in 1856
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Theatrical Ahead of the Field in Grade I Victories
description: There are 118 Grade I races on the American racing calendar this year, and 95 have been run so far. The leaders in winning these top events look nearly impossible to overtake.

title: O-T-C Market Loses Luster
description: For the last few years, the fast-growing Nasdaq over-the-counter market has been the darling of investors and corporate issuers.

title: 2 French Guards Slain in Beirut
description: Two gunmen shot and killed two French Embassy guards and seriously wounded a third today as the Frenchmen shopped in East Beirut.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about stockbrokers' earnings during the market collapse misstated the view of one analyst about job opportunities in the industry. Nancy Young, of the firm Tucker Anthony & R. L. Day, said that while staff cuts were possible, they were unlikely because the industry had already eliminated the jobs of many poor-performing brokers.

title: Art: Ferdinand Hodler, His Swiss Landscapes
description: FERDINAND HODLER may have been the most influential Swiss artist in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, but his work does not travel well. Compared with Corot, Courbet, Gauguin and Munch, Hodler's partly Realist, partly Post-Impressionist, partly Symbolist, partly Expressionist paintings seem unresolved. His work is not greater than the sum of its parts. Broken down into its parts, however, it is complex and revealing.

title: Decree Is Lifted in Ecuador
description: - President Leon Febres Cordero has lifted the national state of emergency he declared to deal with the one-day anti-Government general strike Wednesday. A Government spokesman said that Mr. Febres Cordero, who declared the state of emergency Tuesday night, had lifted it at midnight Wednesday. The decree suspended constitutional rights.

title: Stock Drop May Hurt Retail Sales
description: The stock market's plunge and subsequent gyrations could mean somewhat reduced Christmas sales for the nation's retail stores. Although sales have not yet been hurt significantly, analysts are shaving their earnings estimates for retailers.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the dollar's recent levels misstated the illustrated relationship to the British pound. The chart tracked dollars per pound, rather than pounds per dollar.

title: Czyz Loses Crown; Stopped After 9th
description: Charles Williams won the International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title tonight when the corner of the champion, Bobby Czyz, stopped the bout after the ninth round of a scheduled 15-round bout.

title: Real Estate Market Remains Rattled
description: The stock market plunge is taking a toll on the real estate industry, many buyers, sellers and agents agree. But there is little agreement as to whether the disruption is temporary or likely to be long-lasting.

title: Marathon Notebook; Moroccan Writes His Own Ticket Now
description: When he came to New York to run in the marathon last year, Nechadi el Mostafa of Morocco paid his own expenses. That alone said a great deal about his chances. Fred Lebow, the race director, picks up the tab for the very best runners. And yet, halfway through the race, there was Mostafa, among the leaders, setting a pace that would have threatened the New York record of 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds established by Alberto Salazar in 1981.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $12 million pre-tax gain from the sale of in-ground coal reserves.

title: Trick Or Treat
description: Just in time for Halloween, the stock market crash has torn away the mask of a divided world and a divided Government in Washington.

title: USG Opposes Desert Partners
description: The USG Corporation said today that it had filed suit in Federal District Court here to prevent an unwanted suitor, Desert Partners L.P., from attempting a multibillion-dollar takeover of the building-materials producer.

title: In the Crystal Ball, One Seer Looks for a Rally Next Week
description: Wall Street's bulls are irrepressible.

title: N.F.L. Will Give Networks Refunds
description: The National Football League will pay the three major television networks about $60 million to make up for lost advertising revenues during the recent players' strike, a league official said yesterday.

title: Sandinistas Again Refuse Talks With Contra Leaders
description: Despite assertions at home and abroad they have not done enough to fulfill terms of a regional peace accord that are to go into effect next week, Nicaraguan leaders today again indicated they would not accept political talks with contra leaders.

title: VIOLIN DUO AT THE Y
description: Ida and Ani Kavafian, the violinists, are to give a joint recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexing-ton Avenue. The concert includes works by Krodo Mori, Bach, Sarasate and others. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: DATA GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After a $26 million extraordinary loss from settlement of litigation for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a $18.2 million loss from the early redemption of debentures. c-After extraordinary losses of $30.9 million and $34.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from the settlement of litigation.

title: About Real Estate; Housing Is Built in a Newburgh Factory
description: Newburgh, N.Y., a once-moribund industrial city on the Hudson River in Orange County, is staging a comeback. The Key Bank will soon move into a sparkling headquarters on the river. Philip Pilevsky, president of Philips International of New York City, has proposed a sweeping redevelopment of Broadway, the city's commercial backbone. And seven housing developments are either ready for residents or in construction.

title: Group Plans to Spruce Up Area Around Grand Central
description: Businesses in a 50-block area around Grand Central Terminal yesterday announced a sweeping plan to improve the neighborhood by levying fees on all property owners in a newly formed ''business improvement district.''

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,655,000 from accounting changes. c-Net loss National Intergroup said its sales in the fiscal 1988 second quarter fell from the year-ago levels because of the June 19, 1987 sale of a 55.3 percent limited partner's interest in Permian Partners L.P. The company's remaining interest in Permian is now reported as an equity investment.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $18,676,000 from investments for the quarter and a capital gain of $28,852,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain from investments of $24,975,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $42,587,000 for the 9 months.

title: Koch Dismisses Gross, Faulting His Leadership
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he had dismissed Dr. Elliot M. Gross, whose performance as Chief Medical Examiner of New York City has been under official scrutiny for almost three years.

title: USAir-Piedmont Ruling Is Awaited
description: USAir and Piedmont Aviation said they would stick to the terms of their $1.6 billion merger agreement as the deadline approaches for the Government's ruling on the deal. Friday is the statutory deadline for Federal action on the proposed merger, which has been under a cloud since an official of the Department of Transportation recommended last month that the transaction be rejected. The department could approve the merger, reject it or demand changes as a condition of its approval.

title: A Slimmer Pavarotti Plans Recital
description: One of the more delicious experiences in life is doing a good deed while thoroughly enjoying oneself, and that is precisely the opportunity that Luciano Pavarotti will afford us this Sunday and next.

title: Alzheimer Drug Tested Despite Study Flaws
description: Federal officials began a major trial of a drug to treat Alzheimer's disease although they knew that the smaller study that prompted the trial was deeply flawed.

title: Stocks Are Broadly Higher Despite Dollar's Early Drop
description: Stock prices moved strongly and broadly higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing more than 90 points as Wall Street appeared to accept a lower level for the dollar on foreign exchange markets.

title: College Football Notebook; Army, Temple Try New Quarterbacks
description: Can anyone here play quarterback? That might be the theme for Army's game against Temple at West Point tomorrow. The Cadets have lost three quarterbacks and have two left, Morrell Savoy and Bryan McWilliams; whoever plays for the Owls will be starting for the first time.

title: Where to Search for the Spirits of Halloween
description: THE annual convention of departed New Yorkers will reune in New York tomorrow, as it does every Halloween, when the spirits of New Yorkers long gone are believed to return to the city that once knew them as flesh and blood. Now, one must regretfully concede that there are New Yorkers whose credence in such goings-on matches their belief that they will live to ride on a Second Avenue subway. But for others, whose faith lets them attempt dining at Windows on the World without a reservation, Halloween brings the hope -the ghost of a chance - that the spirits of departed luminaries will emerge for a quick visit.

title: Advertising; Big Drive To Begin For the Pill
description: ORTHO PHARMACEUTICAL, the country's leading manufacturer of birth control pills, is sponsoring an image ad campaign in behalf of the entire category. It will appear in print and on a number of TV stations, but not on the networks.

title: Money Fund Assets Up On Stock Market Shifts
description: Reflecting the deepening concern about the stock market, assets of the nation's 410 money market mutual funds increased $1.16 billion, to $258.01 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Philippine Security Tightened
description: Security was tightened at American bases today as the authorities investigated the killings of two United States servicemen and two other men outside Clark Air Base in four coordinated attacks Wednesday.

title: Bridge: In Simplified Club System, Neglected Tactic Is Used
description: A bidding concept that has been popular in Europe for half a century but neglected on this side of the Atlantic is ''canape'': bid a short suit first, and keep a long suit in reserve. Many Italian and French experts have employed it in winning world titles.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LYNN HARRELL
description: The cellist Lynn Harrell is to per-form works by Bach, Hindemith and Donald Erb tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. Tickets are $15. Information: 570-3949.

title: Obstacle to Opening of Nuclear Plants Is Cleared
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today removed a major obstacle to the opening of nuclear power plants at Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H.

title: Suspect Killed in Drug Raid
description: A drug dealer was fatally shot by a housing police sergeant last night during a raid on a Harlem apartment where drugs were sold, according to the police. Three other dealers were arrested, the police said. The raid at 55 West 129th Street began around 8:50 P.M. when detectives who had earlier made drug buys in the building returned with search warrants. Neither the sergeant nor the dead suspect were identified, but the dead man was said to have been in his 20's and from Jamaica.

title: Foes of Shoreham, Dismayed By Decision, Vow to Fight On
description: Opponents of the Shoreham nuclear power plant were dismayed by a change in evacuation-plan rules adopted today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, but they said it would have little effect on whether Shoreham is licensed to operate.

title: For Moynihan, Challenge of Campaign
description: The manager of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's re-election campaign is in her Washington headquarters, if you can call it a headquarters.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ANIMAL ESTATE: The English and Other Creatures in the Victorian Age. By Harriet Ritvo. 347 pages. Harvard

title: Washington Talk: Housing and the Poor; Priest's Proteges Honor A Persuasive Life
description: Stephen Adubato was a junior high school teacher in Newark in 1970 when a Roman Catholic priest walked into his classroom and persuaded him to quit his job.

title: Summit Hopes Ride on Talks Today
description: On the assumption that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready to set a date for his United States visit, Administration officials say they are looking toward talks Friday with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to improve the Soviet-American dialogue.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Steve Reich, the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street (360-3500). One of Steve Reich's recent compositions, ''Electric Counterpoint,'' features Pat Metheny, an inventive electric guitarist, who will be on hand to perform an excerpt from it at the Guggenheim; the entire composition will have its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music later in November. The Guggenheim performances also offer a preview of the first movement from another new piece, ''The Four Sections,'' to be performed by Mr. Reich's ensemble of musicians and members of the Brooklyn Philharmonic. The performances are Sunday at 7 P.M. and Monday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10, $9 for museum members and students.

title: Takeover Stocks Up Sharply
description: Takeover stocks climbed sharply yesterday in a generally strong stock market, encouraged by comments from Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who said he was willing to consider changes in proposed taxes on acquisitions.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTS APPELLATE JUDGE TO BECOME JUSTICE
description: President Reagan today nominated Douglas H. Ginsburg, a conservative judge who has been on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit since last November, to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court.

title: LACROIX FEVER SPREADS TO NEW YORK
description: When the audience began pelting him with carnations as he walked down the runway with his last mannequin the knots in his stomach began to unwind, Christian Lacroix said. This was midway through a gala evening Wednesday, sponsored by Bergdorf Goodman to introduce the designer's work in New York and to benefit the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and its AIDS research program. It brought fleets of limousines to the World Financial Center at Battery Park City.

title: Film: 'Hidden,' Sci-Fi
description: ''THE HIDDEN,'' opening today at the Embassy 1 and other theaters, is a jokey sci-fi horror movie about the desperate pursuit of a vile ''thing'' from outer space.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1987
description: International A3-9

title: FLUOR SEES GAIN
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that the sale of its 90 percent stake in the St. Joe Gold Corporation and other gold properties to an Australian group would bring a pretax gain of $400 million. The company said the sale of the assets to Dallhold Investments Proprietary Ltd. for $500 million in cash, which was announced in August, has been completed. Fluor said it intended to use the proceeds primarily to reduce its debt.

title: U.S. Underwriters Relieved by London Accord
description: There was a collective sigh of relief on Wall Street last night from the four American securities firms underwriting a significant portion of the British Government's sale of its holdings in the British Petroleum Company.

title: The U.N. Today: Oct. 30, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OPENINGS APLENTY AT ARTS FESTIVAL
description: The monthlong First New York International Festival of the Arts will begin next June with not one but three opening nights. It also will feature a free concert in Central Park by the Spanish tenor Placido Domingo, according to the festival's chairman, Martin E. Segal.

title: DOLLAR RALLIES FROM LOWS, CLOSES UNCHANGED
description: The dollar rebounded late yesterday after touching new lows against a number of key currencies, and it held steady today in trading in Tokyo.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago 9 months includes a writedown of operating assets and related investments of $488,733,000, after tax.

title: Bond Managers Wary Despite Rise
description: Professionals who invest in fixed-income securities have been savoring a rally in the bond market, even as their colleagues in the stock market have suffered.

title: L.F. Rothschild Search
description: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. confirmed a report yesterday that the company is seeking a substantial capital infusion to restore it to financial health after large losses from the recent market plunge. The Manhattan-based securities firm, which said earlier that it lost $44 million in the first three weeks of October, has been working intensively with its investment banker, Salomon Brothers Inc., to find either a buyer or a source for a substantial capital infusion.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,415,000 and $3,370,000 in connection with the early retirement of debt for the quarter and 9 month periods, repectively; the 9 months also includes net from discontinued operations of $55,009,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $9,222,000. d-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $1,498,000.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
At the Movies
description: Dawn Steel to Columbia

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation gained support from one of its largest stockholders for a restructuring plan the company says is critical to keeping it from bankruptcy court. The shareholder, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, holds large interests in two series of Western Union's preferred stock, out of seven that vote, said Warren Bechtel, a Western Union spokesman. The plan involves an exchange of debt for stock, the merger of Western Union and its chief subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company, and the sale of bonds.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Non-Response as Art
description: There are few better practitioners of the withering response in Washington than Charles E. Redman, the State Department spokesman, who has also perfected a fleeting smirk.

title: Sports People; Anderson Honored
description: Sparky Anderson, who led the Detroit Tigers to a 98-64 record, the best in the game this season, was named the American League Manager of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers' Association of America. Anderson, who also earned the honor in 1984 when the Tigers won 104 games and the World Series, received 11 first-place votes and a total of 90 points in balloting by a panel of two members of the association from each American League city. Tom Trebelhorn of the Milwaukee Brewers was second with 78 points and seven first-place votes, followed by Tom Kelly of the Minnesota Twins with 74 points and 10 first-place votes. Balloting was done on the basis of regular-season performance only and votes were cast before the playoffs.

title: American Air Sues British Airways
description: American Airlines accused British Airways P.L.C. of unfairly acting to exclude its Sabre computerized reservation system from the British market in order to maintain a monopoly. In a lawsuit filed in Britain's High Court and a complaint to the European Community, American said British Airways had refused to give it permission to allow travel agents who use Sabre to issue tickets in Britain for British Airways flights. British Airways' refusal ''has greatly degraded the usefulness of Sabre to a U.K. travel agent,'' American said.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Draft Revives Colts and Bills
description: Last year it was the most lopsided division in the American Conference: two playoff teams at the top, two teams with a total of seven victories at the bottom. But who's in first in the Eastern Division now? Almost everybody.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Some of Us Are Sensible
description: Somebody out there is listening to Congress, somebody named Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. In an Oct. 2 speech in Murmansk, Mr. Gorbachev focused in unusual detail on hearings held in September by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. And the subject was Mr. Gorbachev's economic reforms.

title: Cooking Light Gets Publisher From People
description: Jeffrey C. Ward, who has spent a decade with Time Inc., has been named publisher of Cooking Light, a six-issue-a-year magazine of Southern Progress, a Time property.

title: Mahabharata
description: The Indian epic poem ''Mahabharata'' is the subject of a daylong symposium with performances tomorrow at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. The seminar will begin at 9:30 P.M. with a lecture on the religious meaning of the poem; other lectures during the symposium, which lasts till 4:30 P.M., will cover the poem as theater, the folk dramas associated with the work and the current Peter Brook production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. There will also be demonstrations of Indian dance by Kala Nidhi and Ritha Devi. Admission, which includes lunch, is $50. Information: 517-2742.

title: Relief at British Decision
description: The British Government's decision yesterday to soften the immediate impact of its sale of British Petroleum shares by providing market support through the Bank of England should encourage international markets today, investment fund managers and economists said.

title: Yield Raised on Issue Of Eastman Kodak
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets yesterday announced a new, higher interest rate for a $300 million issue of Eastman Kodak Company notes that had initially been offered Monday.

title: Film: 'Gaby,' Story of Determination
description: THE heroine of ''Gaby - A True Story'' has cerebral palsy, and she communicates by moving her big toe along an alphabet board, spelling out words that way. So in one scene, in which Gaby (Rachel Levin) looks upset, her devoted father (Robert Loggia) pulls up a chair, rolls off Gaby's sock and says, ''So tell me -what's going on?''

title: SPRAGUE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Watson Leads Richest Event
description: Tom Watson certainly doesn't need the record purse of $360,000 he would take home with a victory Sunday in the $3 million Nabisco Championships. He has already won $4,085,278 on the PGA Tour, second only to Jack Nicklaus in career earnings.

title: AGENCY SAYS PARENTAL LEAVE WOULD NOT BURDEN BUSINESS
description: Granting parents periods of unpaid leave to care for newborn, newly adopted or sick children would not impose a serious burden on American businesses, according to a General Accounting Office study released at a Congressional hearing today.

title: Judge Forbids Inmate Move To Jail Barge
description: A judge in Manhattan signed a court order yesterday forbidding New York City from transferring any city jail prisoners to a temporary jail barge docked on the Lower East Side.

title: Corrections
description: The Discoveries column in The Living Section on Wednesday gave an incorrect address for Carole Stupell Ltd., which sells a Halloween lantern.

title: Ex-General to Run for House
description: James L. Dozier, a Republican who is a retired Army general once held hostage by Italian terrorists for 45 days, says he will seek the seat in the United States House of Representatives being vacated by Representative Connie Mack, a Republican who is running for the Senate seat held by Lawton Chiles, a Democrat. Mr. Dozier, 56 years old, made his announcement Monday, giving an outline of a conservative agenda heavy on military issues and a balanced budget without new taxes. He was kidnapped in Verona, Italy, in 1982.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,457,000 and $4,592,000 for quarter and 9-month periods, repectively.

title: A CHALLENGE TO GORBACHEV IS LINKED TO SUMMIT DELAY
description: A key supporter of Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused him of fostering a cult of personality at a party meeting last week, igniting a political crisis that may have caused the delay in arrangements for a summit meeting, according to Soviet officials.

title: The Theater: ''A Shayna Maidel''
description: IN ''A Shayna Maidel,'' two sisters - one a survivor of Nazi concentration camps, the other brought up as an American -meet in 1946 after a separation of almost 20 years, and in the course of a heart-rending evening, they achieve an intimacy that transcends the theatrical event. Barbara Lebow's play is about the horrors of the Holocaust; it is also a deeply personalized study of sisterhood, family and a crisis of faith.

title: YOUTHFUL CONSERVATIVE JUDGE: DOUGLAS HOWARD GINSBURG
description: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, one of the youngest men ever nominated to the Supreme Court, is known here chiefly as a strong, brainy advocate of the Reagan Administration's conservative, free-market approach to regulatory and antitrust law issues.

title: Shakespeare Marathon At Riverside Church
description: Bard-a-Thon, a weeklong festival of staged readings of plays by Shakespeare, begins tomorrow at 2 P.M. with ''The Comedy of Errors,'' at the Riverside Church, 165 West 86th Street. The series, presented by the Riverside Shakespeare Company, continues tomorrow night at 8 with ''Macbeth''; at midnight, a second reading of ''Macbeth'' by the group can be heard live over radio station WKCR/FM (89.9).

title: WOODY HERMAN, BANDLEADER, DIES AT 74
description: Woody Herman, a musician from Milwaukee who led one of the most varied, durable and successful of the big bands, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 74 years old. Mr. Herman was suffering from congestive heart failure, emphysema and pneumonia, according to a hospital spokesman. Mr. Herman was admitted to the coronary intensive-care unit there on March 26 after suffering from effects of medication taken for high-altitude sickness during a tour through Colorado and Utah, his manager, Tom Cassidy, said.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and a tax credit of $236,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $76,000. The latest quarter results were adversely affected by a provision of $1.3 million for interest expense on pending federal tax assessments for prior years, lower gross margins caused by a stronger Japanese yen, and a change in revenue mix from copier rental and after-market revenues to co

title: Allegis Announces Share Payments
description: The Allegis Corporation, which has dramatically slimmed down by selling off its hotel and car rental businesses, announced today that its shareholders would each receive at least $50 a share from the proceeds.

title: Hoboken Is Disrupted By Water Main Break
description: A water main broke here today, cutting off service to thousands of residents for about eight hours, flooding streets and causing a tie-up of traffic trying to use the nearby Lincoln Tunnel, officials said.

title: How the Mighty Have Fallen
description: LEAD: In 1974, Brazil swept aside concerns about higher oil prices and moved ahead on a path of what enthusiasts like to call ''conspicuous investment.''

title: TONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Sports People; Molitor a Free Agent
description: Paul Molitor, whose 39-game hit-ting streak was one of the highlights of the past baseball season, was one of six players who filed for free agency yesterday. Others were Chili Davis of San Francisco, Larry Hern-don of Detroit, Garth Iorg of Toronto, Joe Sambito of Boston and Glen Hubbard of Atlanta. The free-agent list now has 22 names. Molitor mossed 44 of Milwaukee's games because of injuries but nevertheless batted .353 and finished second to Wade Boggs (.363) in the American League. He has just finished a five-year contract that brought him $5,225,000 in salary and bonuses. He and Davis are Type A free agents, which means if other teams sign them, their 1987 teams will receive two draft choices in the draft next June as compensation.

title: Washington Talk: Labor Department; Two Studies Discover A Miracle: Same Thing
description: One report for the Department of Labor on what the American work force would look like at the end of the century runs 117 pages. Another report runs 63 pages. They are nearly identical except that the 117-page study cost $1.3 million, the other nothing.

title: Once Desperate, a Bronx Housing Group Earns Praise
description: On a summer evening in 1974, a small group of Bronx neighbors and church leaders created a coalition to rescue their deteriorating community.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $93,678,000 from the writedowns and recognizing unrecoverable costs of the Fort St. Vrain Nuclear Plant for the quarter and 9 months. The latest 9 months net includes a gain of $29,589,000 from an accounting change related to unbilled revenue.

title: O'Callahan Banned For Three Games
description: Jack O'Callahan, a defenseman for the Devils, was suspended for three games by the National Hockey League today as a result of an intent-to-injure match penalty he was assessed in a game against the Pittsburgh Penguins eight days ago.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
TALMAN HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (ILL) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $3,868,000 for the quarter and $8,090,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $736,000 from early repayment of notes. The year-ago share earnings are not available; the company converted to stock ownership in December 1986.

title: Jean Helion, Abstract and Representational Artist
description: Jean Helion, an influential abstract artist who later turned to representational painting, died of pneumonia in a Paris hospital Tuesday night. He was 83 years old. His canvases, both abstract and representational, hang in major institutions throughout the world, including the Metropolitan Museum and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday JOURNALISM IN PICTURES

title: Simpson Defends Benching 3
description: A subdued plane ride home, a night's sleep and a morning spent reviewing tapes of his team's 5-2 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs Wednesday night had given Terry Simpson plenty of time to reconsider his decision to bench three players after the second period.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the June write-off of $3,814,000 of the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Guilty Plea in L.I. Shooting
description: A 23-year-old man pleaded guilty Wednesday to attempted murder in the gas-station shooting of a Polish immigrant who was working to raise funds for his invalid son's surgery. Judge John Vaughn of Suffolk County Court, who accepted the plea from John Ray Rose of Riverhead, said he would sentence him to 8 1/2 to 17 years in prison, with formal sentencing set for Jan. 5. Mr. Rose and William Tyrone Duff, 24, were charged in the June 4 shooting during a robbery attempt in Calverton.

title: Mauritania Detains 50
description: Fifty people, most of them army officers drawn from Mauritania's black, non-Arab minority, have been arrested for plotting to overthrow President Mohammed Sid Ahmed Taya, Government officials said today. Those held include a former Interior Minister, Col. Anne Mamadou Babaly, who denied being party to the plot but admitted he had been approched by those involved, the officials said. Key officers of the presidential guard were also detained and will be tried by a special court at a date not yet decided, they added.

title: Utahans Win Custody Of an Indian Boy, 10
description: - A Utah couple will become permanent guardians of a 10-year-old Navajo boy under an agreement with his mother, ending a five-year custody fight, a lawyer for the couple said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $476,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $146,000 for the quarter and $468,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a tax credit of $1,489,000. The year-ago figures are restated to include the results of operations of Pulse Sciences Inc., which merged with Titan in the first quarter and was accounted for as a pooling of interests. All figures include the operations from July 1 of Advanced Digital Systems, which was acquired in July.

title: Andrew Stein Charges $40 Million in Housing Fines Are Uncollected
description: City Council President Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Department had a $40 million backlog of uncollected fines for residential building-code violations.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
FILM: 'SAMMY AND ROSIE'
description: ABOUT three-quarters of the way through ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid,'' there's a particularly rich, riotously busy montage, a succession of shots of urban decay, exuberant West Indian street singers and three separate sets of lovers who alternately reminisce and argue while, at the end of a long London night, they make their circuitous routes to bed. The tempo of the editing increases. Suddenly the screen splits - horizontally - and we see each of the three couples, layered, more or less, one pair atop another, simultaneously but in separate images, as they achieve transitory satisfaction. That's about all they can hope for.

title: When Women in Politics Choose Love or Work
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Red Who Was Right
description: A nettled Lenin once described Nikolai Bukharin as ''soft wax.'' Lenin's arch-rival, Leon Trotsky, wrote of Bukharin: ''You must always keep your eyes on him, or else he will succumb quite imperceptibly to the influence of someone directly opposed to you, as other people fall under an automobile. . . . I never took him seriously.''

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Lendl Beats Leconte: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, second-seeded Mats Wilander, Pat Cash of Australia and John McEnroe all won yesterday to qualify for the quarterfinals of the $923,000 European Community Championships in Antwerp, Belgium. Lendl outlasted Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 7-6. Cash served and volleyed past Spain's Sergio Casal, 7-6, 6-2. Wilander outlasted fellow Swede Jonas Svensson 6-4, 3-6, 10-8, and McEnroe dominated Argentina's Martin Jaite 6-4, 6-4.(AP) Garrison Wins: Zina Garrison struggled before posting a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Anne Hobbs of Great Britain, giving the United States a 1-0 lead in the opening round of the Wightman Cup challenge matches in Williamsburg, Va. Hobbs took a 4-0 lead in the first set. N.H.L. Maple Leafs 4, Penguins 0: Toronto's Russ Courtnall scored twice and Allan Bester stopped 29 shots for his fourth career shutout. Courtnall capped a three-goal first period when the visiting Maple Leafs scored on five shots against Gilles Meloche. Nordiques 4, Bruins 2: Quebec's Peter Stasny scored twice, once after a second-period brawl that resulted in nine ejections. The brawl started 16 seconds into the second period, when Boston's Willi Plett and Quebec's Gord Donnelly collided and began fighting along the boards. Referee Dave Newell called two minor penalties, 10 fighting majors, eight game misconducts and a five-minute match penalty against Donnelly for kneeing Plett in the head as he lay on the ice. Golf Bean Ties Course Record: Andy Bean of the United States shot an eight-under-par 64 to tie the course record and take a one-stroke first-round lead in the individual competition at the $464,000 United States-Japan golf matches in Kobe, Japan. The nine-man American team, led by Hale Irwin, took a 539-552 lead over the Japanese under a formula that counts the eight best scores on each side. Horse Show French Win Cup: The French equestrian team achieved its first victory in the Bank of Montreal Nations' Cup last night at the Washington International Horse Show in Landover, Md. Hubert Bourdy clinched the trophy with the only faultless round of the competition and kept France's total score at 17 faults. The United States finished second with 29 faults; Canada was third with 45.5. The French won the Gucci Trophy, the world team title, for the 18 Nation's Cup classes this year.

title: Simon Tailors Roosevelt Cloak to 80's
description: To many politicians, Senator Paul Simon's platform sounds like old-time Democratic religion: Put Americans back to work with a huge new Federal job program. Rebuild the crumbling highways and bridges. Protect elderly people from the towering costs of nursing home care.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAXUS ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of about $18 million on the sale of properties in the U.K. sector of the North Sea for the quarter, and the 9 months includes a loss of $52.7 million from discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $39 million and $79 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a one-time charge of about $64 million for lease impairments and expiring leases.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1987
description: Market Turmoil

title: BUSH WON DEBATE, REPUBLICANS AGREE
description: George Bush won by not losing.

title: Bilzerian Holds 9.9% Of Singer
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, who has made repeated takeover attempts but never ended up owning his targets, disclosed yesterday that he owned 2.1 million shares, or 9.99 percent, of the outstanding common stock of the Singer Company.

title: Presser Foresees Merger Creating 'Political Giant'
description: Jackie Presser, leading his 1.7 million teamsters back into the A.F.L.-C.I.O. three decades after the union was expelled, said today that the labor movement could now ''create the greatest political giant this country has ever seen.''

title: Ernest D. Ricca
description: Ernest D. Ricca, former Eastern executive secretary of the Directors Guild of America, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had been admitted with a heart condition. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beckman Industrial Corp., Fullerton, Calif., a maker of electronic components and microcircuits for industrial and military applications, named Carl F. Gigandet president of its electronic technologies division.

title: Morgan Grenfell Official Switching to Drexel
description: Keith R. Harris, president of the United States subsidiary of Morgan Grenfell & Company, has left to join Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Thompson Medical
description: The Thompson Medical Company said its board had received a proposal for a management-led buyout of the company from a group headed by S. Daniel Abraham, its chairman and chief executive. Under the proposal, shareholders would receive $15 in cash for each of their shares in a merger. Thompson shares gained 87.5 cents, to $10.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The company has about 7.5 million shares of common stock outstanding. Mr. Abraham said his group holds more than 70 percent of Thompson's outstanding shares. The company said its independent directors would study the offer.

title: Deaver Kept Lobbying After Warning to Firm
description: Testimony today in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver showed that the former White House aide continued lobbying Government associates in behalf of his corporate clients despite a warning to his firm by the top White House lawyer that the contacts were ''inappropriate.''

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Computer Trading Needs Market Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; No Instant Replay
description: Umpiring mistakes in the final game of the World Series have not softened Commissioneer Peter Ueber-roth's vehement opposition to the use of the television instant replays to help on close calls. ''There will be no use of instant replays as long as I'm com-missioner,'' Ueberroth said at a news conference in Portland, Ore., yester-day. ''Umpires miss calls. I think that's part of the tradition of base-ball.'' Earlier this week, Umpire Lee Weyer admitted that he had missed a call at first base in Game 7 becfause he had been blocked out. Weyer said that in such cases, a replay might not be out of the question.

title: RESPONSE OF MARKETS APPEARS ENCOURAGING
description: In deciding to let the dollar fall against major foreign currencies, the United States is taking a big gamble that the move will enable it to head off a precipitous decline in the economy and check the fall of stock prices.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $6,933,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $15,558,000 for the 9 months. c-Reflects a $2 million California tax credit, which was offset by a LIFO inventory charge of $2.5 million, and included a $1.5 million gain from settlement of a crude oil exchange agreement and the favorable disposition of claims asserted against Tosco under a former department of energy program.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Buck Clayton's Big Band, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street (533-7900). Buck Clayton, whose crisp, bristling trumpet was one of the most distinctive features of the original Count Basie Orchestra from 1936 until 1943, has formed a 13-piece band that is making its club debut this week at Fat Tuesday's. Mr. Clayton had to give up playing the trumpet more than 15 years ago, but since then he has been continuing the composing and arranging careers that he began when he was with the Count. His band is a collection of some of New York's swinging elite, including Jimmy Knepper and Joel Helleny on trombones; Spanky Davis, Paul Cohen and Johnny Letman on trumpets; Loren Schoenberg, Chuck Wilson, Doug Lawrence and Joe Temperley among the saxophones; Howard Alden on guitar, and Mark Shain at the piano with Murray Wall on bass and Wes Landers on drums. Their repertory is built around Mr. Clayton's arrangements and includes many of the tunes he wrote for the Basie band. Sets are at 8, 10 and midnight tonight and tomorrow, but only at 8 and 10 P.M. on Sunday. There is a $12.50 cover charge and a $7.50 minimum.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about handicapped students competing in the New York City Marathon misidentified the organization that donated a sports wheelchair to Keith Givens. It is the Eastern Wheelchair Tennis Association.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $3.4 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Davis Journal; Where There Can Be a Patent on Life
description: Old MacDonald had a farm, and on that farm he had some geeps.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about acid rain misstated a scientist's description of trees' contribution to acid rain. The scientist, Jack G. Calvert of the

title: Dollar Stays Near Its Lowest Levels
description: The dollar appeared to be settling yesterday into the near-record lows it reached on Wednesday as signs increased that the big industrial democracies would not try to push it up.

title: Mr. Reagan's Revenge, or Legacy
description: In announcing his second choice for the Lewis Powell vacancy on the Supreme Court, President Reagan combatively showed himself unchastened by the Senate's embarrassing rejection of his first choice. Whether Douglas Ginsburg's nomination will prove as provocative as that of Robert Bork must await confirmation hearings, but the President's defiant tone is inauspicious.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes earnings from discontinued operations of $409,000 and $11,319,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $502,000 for the quarter and $1,223,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes earnings from discontinued operations of $1,980,000 for the quarter and $6,935,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $395,000 and $2,032,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest 9-month loss includes provisions totaling $8 million to reflect future losses due to the failure of one of Clark's insurance companies.

title: Russians, Fearing Rise in Prices, Hoard Food
description: Soviet consumers, alarmed by rumors of impending price increases, have begun hoarding food and other products, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: MARKET TURMOIL;
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the largest discount brokerage in the country, said today that it had lost $22 million in the recent market turmoil, primarily because one corporate customer could not meet its margin calls.

title: Film: 'Fatal Beauty,' With Whoopi Goldberg
description: ''FATAL BEAUTY'' asks whether a woman can be just as loudly, obnoxiously macho as a man, and answers with a resounding yes. The woman is Whoopi Goldberg, the man Eddie Murphy, and the model is ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' though that film had nothing like the incessant firepower of this one. Someone dies graphically, riddled with bullets and shuddering voluptuously at each shot, on the average of every five minutes or so.

title: Hornung Is Enshrined
description: Paul Hornung, the former Notre Dame and Green Bay Packers star who last year entered the Pro Football Hall of Fame, was enshrined today in the College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Allies Urge German Rate Cuts
description: Foreign pressures on West Germany to lower its interest rates intensified today as many Western officials and economists said such a move was urgently needed to help stabilize the world's financial markets.

title: Art People
description: A Market in Question

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are deeply convinced that creating a space-based defense to cover the territory of the United States would radically step up the military threat toward the Soviet Union.'' - Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of the Soviet General Staff. [ A1:1. ]

title: Officials in Jersey See Stadium Bond Issue Headed Toward Defeat
description: A referendum on $185 million in bonds to build a major-league baseball stadium near the Meadowlands Sports Complex is in trouble, officials of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today.

title: Excerpts From Interview With the Soviet General Staff Chief
description: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from an interview Tuesday with Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of the Soviet General Staff, and from written questions and answers: ORAL INTERVIEW Q. Why does President Reagan's space defense program seem to give Soviet leaders and strategists so much political trouble, especially if so many on both sides believe it cannot work for 20 or 30 years? A. . . . It is not a matter of political obstacles caused to the Soviet leadership. The thing is, we are deeply convinced that creating a space-based ABM defense to cover the territory of the United States would radically step up the military threat toward the Soviet Union. In that case, the United States would have the strategic defense of its territory, which according to the opinion of the U.S. Administration is intended to defend only the United States from an attack on the part of the Soviet Union.

title: INSIDE
description: Managua Refuses Talks Sandinista leaders, after a special party meeting in Nicaragua today, again said they would not agree to hold political talks with the U.S.-backed contras. Page A3. Woody Herman Is Dead The leader of one of the biggest of the big bands, whose career playing the clarinet and saxophone spanned 50 years of styles from blues to rock-and-roll, died at 74. Page D22.

title: TAX RISE IS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: After a bruising partisan fight that sent an uncertain signal to Wall Street, the House of Representatives approved by one vote tonight $12 billion in tax increases to help reduce the Federal deficit.

title: B.P. Issue to Proceed; Safeguard Put on Price
description: The British Government announced tonight that it was going ahead with the $12.2 billion sale of British Petroleum Company shares, despite the slump in world stock markets.

title: Nominee Left College to Be Matchmaker
description: It is clearly the most unusual entry on the resume of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court.

title: Son Music: From Cuba To the City
description: ENCOUNTERING the Afro-Cuban son in Santiago de Cuba, in Cuba's Oriente province, on a steamy, neon-lit, music-filled night in the late 1970's, was the sort of experience one remembers for a lifetime. In a small cafe, a knot of elderly men, their wrinkled faces the color of dark mahogany, were playing two acoustic guitars, a string bass and bongo drums. A very old man was making a rich, sonorous clicking sound with a pair of wooden claves, outlining the music's rhythmic basis. The bassist and one of the guitarists sang, harmonizing decimas, 10-line stanzas in a traditional Spanish form dating back to the Middle Ages.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TSB Continues Hill Samuel Bid
description: The TSB Group P.L.C.'s said it would go ahead with its takeover of the Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., despite a stock price plunge that has wiped more than $:70 million, or $120.4 million, off the merchant bank's market value. ''The possibility of pulling out of the deal has never been raised at the board room level,' a TSB spokesman said. TSB has offered $:777 million, or $1.34 billion, for Hill Samuel. TSB said that even if it wanted to cancel the deal, it doubted that it could get British Government permission to do so. British takeover regulations also prevent TSB, which now owns 30 percent of Hill Samuel, from revising its bid price.

The Dow Jones transportation average, which is concentrated in railroad, airline and trucking issues, forged ahead 39.91 points, to 725.50, for a sparkling gain of 5.82 percent.

title: Dining Out Guide: New Uptown
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE GRECO, #1390 Second Avenue, at 72d Street (737-4300) - **(Aug. 21, 1987) A pretty little bar up front and an informal dining room with ocher walls, high ceilings and tall arching windows that look out on a lighted backyard garden provide the setting for a melange of Mediterranean cuisines. Starter options are carpaccio of salmon, glossed with olive oil and basil, and a tart layered with eggplant, tomato and zucchini. For a main dish, the chef has a masterly touch with seafood, such as a grilled salmon wth a zesty sauce of roasted red peppers, black olives and tarragon. Also recommended are medallions of lamb with a stock sauce. Entrees $15.50 to $19.50. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M. COASTAL, #300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street (769-3988) - **(June 12, 1987) A serious new fish house on the Upper West Side, this contemporary glass-fronted restaurant has a stainless-steel bar and aqua-colored walls covered with a coastline mural. If you can take the decibels, the rewards are considerable: vibrant little ceviche appetizers served in a large mussel shell; lobster bisque, and New England clam chowder. The broiled and sauteed seafood entrees are all recommended - from halibut with a choice of sauces to broiled grouper with Provencal sauce. Entrees $12.50 to $19. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M. EAST, 1420 Third Avenue, at 80th Street (472-3975) - *(March 20, 1987) This handsome, countrified Japanese restaurant features an entertaining setting with low-slung communal tables and a knee-deep pit for those who find eating in the lotus position less than comfortable. You might begin with an assortment of sushi, maki rolls or sashimi. The best main course choices are salmon teriyaki with picked ginger garnish; any of the grilled fish options, and chicken teriyaki. Main dishes $8.50 to $20. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 11:15 P.M ; Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11:15 P.M.; closed Sundays. LE FESTIVAL, #134 East 61st Street (838-7987) - **(Dec. 26, 1986) The dining room is soft and comfortable with rust-colored banquettes to punctuate the gray-felt decor, and the all-seafood theme is a timely idea. The Mediterranean fish soup is a very good starter, with morsels of snapper and bass in a saffron fish stock. For a main dish, you might choose dariole of salmon, with julienne of vegetables and set atop tomato beurre blanc; ravioli stuffed with lobster and wild mushrooms with sauteed chanterelles, or a straightforward grilled Dover sole with mustard sauce. Dinner prix fixe $40. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. PRIMOLA, #1226 Second Avenue, at 64th Street (758-1775) - **(Feb. 20, 1987) One of the more spirited and alluring Upper East Side restaurants is this Italian venture with yellow walls holding watercolors and poster art, wood wainscoting and pretty flower clusters. The menu is extensive and specials abound. You might start with a half order of pasta, perhaps the thin fedelini primavera or spinach gnocchi with a gratineed mozzarella and tomato sauce. Main course selections include grilled giant shrimp with lemon, garlic and oregano; veal sauteed with wild mushrooms, and seared baby lamb chops. Entrees $11.50 to $20.50. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to midnight; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 5 to 11 P.M. VIOLETTA, 1590 First Avenue, at 83d Street (517-7090) - **(July 3, 1987) The two narrow dining rooms that make up this little East Side Italian restaurant are long on charm and short on elbow room; they feature salmon-toned walls, mirrors and expansive floral arrangements. Most of the pastas are recommended, and options include fusilli in cream sauce with pancetta and peas, as well as spaghetti with white clam sauce. For a main dish, you might order a double thick veal chop in mustard sauce; the mixed grill of chicken, sausage and cubes of beef in lusty garlic sauce, or red snapper fillet alla Livornaise, with black olives, capers, tomato and herbs. Entrees $15 to 25. Fridays and Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 4 to 11 P.M. What the stars mean, page C24.

title: Police Chief to Retire After Series of Scandals
description: Police Chief Robert G. Schnakenberg of Clarkstown, who refused to resign last summer after scandals had rocked his department, has announced his retirement.

title: Sports People; Gooden Buys Homes
description: Dwight Gooden, whose scuffle with Tampa, Fla., olice last winter at-tracted national attention, has bought two houses in St. Petersburg, Fla., and plans to move there part time with his family. Gooden, a native of Tampa, bought waterfront houses in the Pinellas Point neighborhood. Jim Neader, Gooden's agent, said the Met's pitcher, who is engaged to be married Nov. 21, will divide time in the off-season between St. Petersburg and a home he owns on Long Island.

title: LENINGRAD SYMPHONY
description: The Leningrad State Symphony, conducted by Alexander Dmitriev, is to perform works by Liszt, Tchaikov-sky and Debussy tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Colden Center, Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing. The pianist Lazar Berman is to be the soloist. Tickets are $25 to $30. Infor-mation: (718) 793-8080.

description: A distinct turnabout has taken place between the Jets' offense and defense.

title: Sports People; Oilers Sign Highsmith
description: Alonzo Highsmith, the University of Miami running back who was the third player selected in the National Football League college draft last April has finally reached a contract agreement with the Houston Oilers and has reported to the team. No terms were announced, but according to KRIV, a television station in Hous-ton, the four-year contract was worth $2.6 million, including a $1.2 million signing bonus. Ladd Herzeg, the Oilers general manager, said yester-day, ''Our current plans are to seek a two-week exemption from the com-missioner and get Alonzo into football playing condition.''...Bruce Mat-thews, a holdout offensive tackle who was a first-round draft choice in 1983 out of Southern California, filed a suit in Los Angeles United States District Court against the Oilers and the N.F.L. yesterday with other teams. Mat-thew's four-year contract with the Oilers expired after the 1986 season.

title: Provident Notes Total $100 Million
description: The Provident Life Capital Corporation, a unit of Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company of America, is offering $100 million of 10 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.35 to yield 10.10 percent through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Salvador Rebels to Boycott Talks After Killing of Rights Advocate
description: - Leftist guerrillas said today that they would not attend a new round of peace talks with the Salvadoran Government, blaming it for the killing of a prominent human rights advocate.

title: Gephardt Defends Trade Plan
description: As members of Congress flee from trade bill provisions with any hint of protectionism in the wake of the stock market tumble, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, who has made such measures a centerpiece of his Presidential campaign, said today that he was holding firm.

title: Art: Charles Demuth In Show at the Whitney
description: CHARLES DEMUTH (1883-1935) was a connoisseur's artist. Though in no way ''major,'' he was a quirkful, many-sided and persistently inventive performer who was close to many of the most gifted people of his day and enjoyed their respect and affection. (Marcel Duchamp said that Demuth was great company because ''he didn't care where he belonged, or was, in the social scale.'' And Georgia O'Keeffe, no pushover when it came to a lasting friendship, prized Demuth as someone who was great fun to be with and ''a better friend with me than any of the other artists.'') When he had heroes, living or dead, they were the right ones, and he found new ways of celebrating them. He was a creative reader who did not so much illustrate what he read as take off from it in ways that have kept their fascination intact. Though probably still best known as a painter of flowers and fruit - and superabundantly represented in that context in his current retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art - he was also a pioneer painter (and simplifier) of the American industrial landscape.

title: 10 Homeless People Held At Bellevue Mental Unit
description: A blind woman who spent her days on an Upper West Side sidewalk and a man who lived, surrounded by rats, in a plastic bag in Central Park were among those picked up and hospitalized against their will yesterday, the second day of a Koch administration campaign to help severely disturbed homeless people.

title: E.F. Hutton Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured E. F. Hutton & Company today in connection with a purported money laundering scheme at the Providence, R.I., branch office.

title: POLITICAL GRAFT CHARGES MOUNTING IN MISSISSIPPI
description: A growing list of local elected officials in Mississippi have been indicted on charges of accepting kickbacks as a result of an undercover investigation that has shaken the state politically.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Jewel in the Kremlin
description: This intense Soviet awareness of Western views on things that matter in Moscow raises the possibility that Mr. Gorbachev will soon glimpse a portrayal of himself made for television by Grenada Television, which brought us ''Jewel in the Crown.'' It is a one-hour docudramatization of the last summit meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan a year ago in Iceland, ''Breakthrough at Reykjavik.''

title: Residents Seek Tighter Zoning For Apartments
description: Hundreds of Queens residents came to City Hall yesterday to protest a city law that, they said, encourages developers to raze habitable single-family homes and build higher density housing, thereby threatening the ''villagelike'' atmosphere of many Queens neighborhoods.

title: SEEING NEW YORK CITY THROUGH THE EYES OF ITS ARCHITECTS
description: Architects are a different breed from most New Yorkers. They are forever perusing the city, soaking up views we often overlook. Some are preoccupied with details - a ferocious-looking gargoyle, a graceful window or a wide front stoop. Others examine entire streets or neighborhoods that have a character all their own. What follows here and on page C27 are observations of New York through the eyes of many of this city's master builders. What they spot may inspire fellow New Yorkers to explore their city in divergent ways. And much of what catches these architects' fancy can't help but alter the shape of New York in the years to come. Edward L. Barnes

description: The first sign of Francois was a white laundry cart, piled with crushed paper cups, scraps of food, soiled clothing and a tattered blanket.
