title: GIANTS' PIECES DON'T QUITE FIT
description: Coach Bill Parcells considered the plight of the Giants' wide receivers and concluded, ''I've got one guy with a bad back, one guy with a broken wrist, and I've got three rookies.''

title: CBS ENTERTAINMENT CHIEF IS LEAVING THE NETWORK
description: B. Donald Grant, president of CBS Entertainment since 1980, will leave the network to form his own production company, he said yesterday.

title: Spending For Games Criticized
description: New York State officials who managed the popular Empire State Games in Buffalo were criticized today by State Comptroller Edward Regan for using a private foundation to circumvent state spending controls and paying a sportswriter to publicize the event.

title: VIOLA REAPS HIS REWARDS
description: Frank Viola's personal booster club of family, relatives and longtime friends gathered yesterday in Ballroom E of the Grand Hyatt Hotel in midtown Manhattan for a morning of sweet satisfaction. They watched their hero, the most valuable player in the World Series, receive a Volvo 740 Turbo automobile and a silver-plated trophy from Sport magazine as tangible rewards for his October pitching brilliance.

title: More Surgery for Kerr
description: Tim Kerr, the right wing for the Philadelphia Flyers who has undergone four operations on his left shoulder since June 12, will probably have surgery a fifth time. Doctors plan to remove a surgical screw that is causing an infection. Kerr said he expected the operation to take place within the next few weeks. . . . Despite a contract offer of an estimated $3 million over five years from the Edmonton Oilers, Paul Coffey has still not agreed to rejoin the National Hockey League champions. Coffey, an All-Star defenseman, has been holding out for 40 days despite having two years remaining on his contract. He became angry last week when his courage was questioned by Peter Pocklington, the team's owner, and said that he would never wear an Edmonton jersey again. . . . Nick Fotiu, a 12-year veteran released by the Edmonton Oilers after training camp, signed as a free agent to play left wing with the Philadelphia Flyers, the club announced.

title:
PATENTS;
Locating Stars
description: LEAD: A device to aid astronomers in locating stars and other celestial bodies is described in patent No. 4,702,703, which was granted this week to Robert R. Herbst of San Diego. The invention is a hollow, transparent sphere with light-reflecting spots that indicate the position of stars. A light source brightens the spots and a ring and band indicate the north and south poles and equator.

title: Albert Crary, Geophysicist, Dies; An Explorer of Both Polar Regions
description: Albert P. Crary, a polar explorer and scientist, died Thursday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C., of complications following surgery for a spinal tumor. He was 76 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Mozambique Says Rebels Killed At Least 211 Civilians in Ambush
description: Anti-Government rebels ambushed a convoy on the country's main north-south road Thursday and killed 211 civilians, the Government press agency said today.

title: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict Donovan in 3d U.S. Inquiry
description: A special Federal prosecutor said yesterday that a reinvestigation of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan had found ''insufficient corroborative evidence'' to indict Mr. Donovan on new allegations that he had lied about seeking a $250,000 kickback while in private business.

title: U.S. SKATER TRAILS CANADIAN
description: Debi Thomas of the United States, seeking to recapture the form that brought her the world figure skating title two years ago, won the short program tonight at Skate Canada, a major pre-Olympic competition, but she remained in second place over all.

description: Mike McPhee's goal with 5 minutes 29 seconds left in the third period lifted the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: Shots Fired in Berlin Escape
description: Communist border guards fired two shots Thursday at a 21-year-old East German man who escaped over the Berlin wall, the West Berlin authorities said today. The police said the man told them that border guards arrested a 21-year-old companion trying to escape with him.

description: Congressional tax proposals aimed at slowing corporate takeover activity are likely to be dropped or at least toned down in any final tax package, according to House and Senate tax aides. Such proposals are blamed by some on Wall Street for bringing on the stock market debacle.

The teamsters' motivation for returning now is transparent: the Federal Government threatens a lawsuit to oust their leaders and take over the union; affiliation with ''respectable'' organized labor offers political cover.

The authority, saying it did not want to enter a bidding war for the team, took the action based on reports that Bill Bidwill, the Cardinals' owner, had definitely decided to his franchise.

title: Witt on List
description: Mike Witt, who has averaged 16 victories a season for the past four years, yesterday became the most attractive starting pitcher to add his name to the free-agent list. The California Angels' right-hander is one of 28 players who have filed for free agency in the first week of the 15-day filing period. Also declaring for free agency yesterday were Gene Garber of Kansas City, Jerry Reuss of California and Dave Collins of Cincinnati. . . . The Chicago Sun-Times reported yesterday that Dallas Green, president and general manager of the Cubs, quit on Thursday because John W. Madigan, executive vice president of the Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs, vetoed Green's choice of Coach John Vukovich as manager. Madigan denied opposing Green on his choice of Vukovich, and told The Tribune there was no rift over the naming of a manager. . . . Phil Garner, an infielder, and Ken Landreaux, an outfielder, will not be offered contracts for the 1988 season by the Los Angeles Dodgers, the team announced yesterday. . . . Don Sutton, who ranks 11th on major league baseball's victory list, won't return to the Angels next season, the team announced. Mike Port, the club's senior vice president and general manager, said the Angels had decided not to pick up the option on the 42-year-old right-hander's contract.

title: SUMMIT SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carhaix Journal; Sowing a Language's Seed in Brittany
description: Now 50 years old, Yann Puillandre still remembers the hurt. When he was caught speaking Breton in class, his teacher would hang a wooden shoe around his neck, a stigma that could be lifted only by denouncing another schoolmate who had let slip a few words of the ancient Celtic language.

title: NEW YORK MARINE & GENERAL INSURNCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $39 for the quarter and includes realized investment gains of $20,622 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $88,011 and $216,896 for the quarter and 9 months, repectively.

title: SPEAR FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $33,978 for the quarter and $537,010 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $195,987 for the quarter and $545,620 for the 9 months.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $805,372 from the operations of a spun off subsidiary.

title:
PATENTS;
Heart Massage Device
description: LEAD: A portable apparatus to massage a heart that has stopped beating was patented this week by Pierre P. Arpin of Milpitas, Calif. The instrument is also designed to provide oxygenation of the blood. Patent No. 4,702,231 says the instrument can be carried in a suitcase.

title: KEY RATES
ANCHOR SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $32.2 million from a series of agreements with the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp. in anticipation of converting from a mutual to a stock corporation. There were no share earnings in the year-ago period because Anchor converted from a mutual to stock on April 1.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $542,000 for the quarter and $1,573,000 for the 9 months.

title: Correction
description: A listing in the Executive Changes column of Business Day last Saturday misstated the relationship of the Andal Corporation and the Olsher Metals Corporation. Olsher is a subsidiary of Andal, not the reverse.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STALEY CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,574,000 and a loss of $7,268,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-After net of $20,000 for the quarter and a loss of $28,000 for the year from discontinued operations. The prior year includes restructuring charges of $10,758,000.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $76 million for the quarter and $86 million for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $248 million for the quarter and $151 million for the 9 months.

title: Burns Claim the 10th Victim Of Jet Crash in Indianapolis
description: A salesman severely burned by fuel from an Air Force jet that crashed into a hotel died Thursday, raising the toll from the accident to 10.

title: A Contra Supplier in Costa Rica Got $375,000, U.S. Agency Says
description: A Federal agency made a $375,000 loan in 1984 to a company in Costa Rica formed by an elusive figure in the contra supply network later overseen by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, agency officials told two Senate subcommittees today.

title: NOCTURNAL RUNNERS REVIVE CENTRAL PARK
description: Long after twilight, Susan and Marcel Lipkowitz appeared at the East 90th Street entrance to Central Park. They dutifully stretched their bodies, then bolted into the night.

title: GE CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes restructuring costs of $3,013,000 and $7,280,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes restructuring costs of $2,968,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is a unit of General Electric.

title: COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $620,000 for the quarter and $1,510,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $3,000 and $995,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: SEAGULL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The year-ago figures for both periods are restated to include an acquisition made in August on a pooling-of- interest basis. All year-ago results also include non-recurring non-cash pre-tax writedowns of $35.9 million from lower accounting values of natural gas and fluid oil reserves due to reduced prices, and a $17.1 million pre-tax gain resulting from the sale of the company's interest in a hydrocarbon products pipeline.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Sets Terms of Phone Job
description: A Government shift in how it will award a multibillion dollar telephone contract has opened the door for smaller contractors to participate in the bidding.

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $26.5 million unusual gain. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: GLASNOST TRAVELS ON FOUR HOOFS
description: THE last time Nikolai Nasibov was at Laurel Race Course near Baltimore was 21 years ago.

title: MARATHONERS RUN WHEN MONEY TALKS
description: They are the Yankee Doodle Dandies among marathoners, a couple of old geezers nearing 40 and still prominent in their field. Frank Shorter, wearing a red, white and blue windbreaker yesterday, and Bill Rodgers, in basic blue, popularized distance running in the United States, each reaping a variety of financial rewards, among them clothing lines that carried their names.

title: About New York; Acting Landlord Has to Act, Well, Like a Landlord
description: The law says that if one-third of the tenants in a building petition the court out of health and safety concerns, the court can appoint an administrator, who becomes, in a sense, the acting landlord. The administrator collects the rent, maintains the building, sees to repairs -does, in short, what the landlord should have been doing. On May 2, 1983, Murray Shactman became an administrator.

title: Health Care at Home: A Mixed Blessing
description: At the rehabilitation center where Ella Gross stayed for nine weeks after she had a stroke, there was no one to help her to the bathroom in the middle of the night. That was the policy. She would lie awake and tell herself, ''I don't want to be here.''

title: FARM & HOME SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ian McCullum, 67, Director Of American Museum in England
description: Ian McCullum, director of the American Museum in Bath, died Wednesday night at his home in Claverton Manor, England. He was 67 years old.

title: Restore Support
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADING INDICATORS FELL BY 0.1% IN SEPTEMBER
description: The Government reported today that its economic forecasting index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September after seven straight monthly advances.

title: Jefferies Expects Loss
description: Jefferies Group Inc., the brokerage pioneer of round-the-clock trading off the exchange floor, said today that it expected a $5 million to $10 million loss in October because of the Wall Street plunge. Frank Baxter, president and chief executive of the Los Angeles firm, said in a statement that he did not know whether the company would post a deficit for the whole fourth quarter because of the loss. He said no layoffs were expected. Most of the loss stemmed from failed trades and to a lesser extent from the company's risk arbitrage operations, which involve speculating on takeover stocks, Mr. Baxter said.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Parade Today
description: The Greenwich Village Halloween Parade begins tonight at 6 P.M., assembling on West Street and West Houston Street, moving east on Houston Street, north on the Avenue of the Americas, east on 14th Street to Union Square and ending about 10 P.M.

title: THIS TRIVIAL, BOTTOM-ACHING THING WE CALL HIGH SCHOOL
description: LEAD: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, recently invited comment on American schooling as the department prepares for the fifth anniversary of the pulication of ''A Nation at Risk,'' a report by the National Commission on Excellence in Education.

title: War Crimes Unit Approves Unsealing of Its Files
description: The Allied War Crimes Commission approved a plan today to open the commission's sealed archives on Nazi atrocities to scholars, writers and journalists, according to diplomats.

title: A New American Pledges His Allegiance
description: Jason Matiko, five years old, taking oath at naturalization ceremony yesterday in Scranton, Pa. Jason, from Korea, was one of 37 people sworn in as American citizens at the Federal courthouse in Scranton. (AP)

title: Correction
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about a free series of staged readings by the Riverside Shakespeare Company gave an incorrect address. The series will be at the West Park Presbyterian Church, 165 West 86th Street.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $480,000 related to restructuring costs for the quarter, and the 9 months includes a pretax gain of $354,000 from the sale of a building.

title: TIMBERLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are on a pro forma basis. The company went public June 30.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $475,000 and $6,211,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes $15.6 million, or 34 cents a share, in operating profits of sold companies for the quarter and the 9 monnts is after net from discontinued operations of $91,704,000.

title: Mother Convicted of Abuse in Daughter's Suicide
description: A woman whose teen-age daughter committed suicide after being forced to work as a nude dancer was found guilty today of child abuse.

title: LIGGETT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company made its initial public offering Oct. 8. Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect the pro forma effect of the acquisition of Liggett Group Inc. by L Holdings Inc. as if the acquisition had occurred April 1, 1986; the actual acquisition date was Oct. 27, 1986.

title: DICKERSON SAYS RAMS HAVE SENT HIM TO COLTS
description: Eric Dickerson, the disgruntled running back of the Los Angeles Rams who cleaned out his locker and left camp this afternoon, said tonight that he had been traded to the Indianapolis Colts.

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $9.7 million and $23.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax benefits of $13.1 million for the quarter and $60.1 million for the 9 months. c-Includes realized capital gains of $7.9 million for the quarter and $131.3 million for the 9 months, gains on debenture repurchases of $100,000 and $400,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively and tax benefits of $58.2 million for the quarter and $128.2 million for the 9 months. The company said for the 1987 third quarter, the net tax benefit resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, principally the fresh start provision, was $36 million.

title: Ryan Beck Layoffs
description: The investment banking firm Ryan Beck & Company said it would lay off 45 of its 275 employees as part of a plan to reduce operating expenses. About 25 of the layoffs will come from the company's community capital group, which is being disbanded, a spokesman said. The group was involved in the conversion of thrift institutions from stock to mutual form.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Brad Wellman, second baseman. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced that Phil Garner, infielder, and Ken Landreaux, outfielder, would not be offered contracts for the 1988 season. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Randy Kramer, pitcher. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Waived Dennis Nutt, guard. DENVER (NBA) - Signed Elston Turner, guard. HOUSTON (NBA) - Waived Andre LaFleur and Dane Suttle, guards. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Chris Miller, quarterback, to a five-year contract. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE -Named Barclay Plager and Bob Plager Campbell Conference honorary captains and Al Arbour Wales Conference honorary captain for the All-Star Game on Feb. 9. RANGERS - Recalled Mike Donnelly, left wing, from Colorado of the International Hockey League. PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Signed Nick Fotiu, left wing.

title: Ex-Employee Wins Drug-Test Case
description: A computer programmer who was dismissed from her job with the Southern Pacific Transportation Company for refusing to participate in a random drug test of employees was awarded $485,000 in damages today by a jury here.

title: SELLARS WITHDRAWS AT MET
description: James Levine, artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, said yesterday that Peter Sellars had withdrawn as director from next season's scheduled triple bill at the Met.

title: Dollar Ends Week Near Its Lows
description: A hectic week on foreign exchange markets ended on a muted note yesterday with the dollar little changed to narrowly lower against major currencies in light trading.

title:
Patents;
Protecting Computer Privacy
description: LEAD: A PROFESSOR of computer science at Christopher Newport College in Newport News, Va., has invented a method of protecting the privacy of computer data.

title: IN COLUMBIA, RISING VIOLENCE BREEDS NEW DOUBTS
description: Within the space of a few days this month, the leader of Colombia's main leftist party was assassinated, the country's best-known sculptor was kidnapped and several prominent writers and artists were forced into exile by death threats.

title: WATSON'S PUTTING INCREASES HIS LEAD
description: Tom Watson has regained his confidence on the greens. He proved it today when he sank four consecutive lengthy putts and threatened to run away from the 29 other golfers in the richest tournament in golf history, the $3 million Nabisco Championships.

title: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 86 cents a share from accrued unbilled utility revenue.

title: Hadson to Merge With Ultrasystems
description: The Hadson Corporation, a natural gas distributor, said it planned to merge with Ultrasystems Inc., a developer of cogeneration plants, in a stock deal valued at about $86.9 million. Hadson, based in Oklahoma City, would issue 2.2 shares of its stock in exchange for each of 7.9 million outstanding shares of Ultrasystems, based in Irvine, Calif. Hadson stock closed at $5, up 50 cents, in over-the-counter trading. Ultrasystems shares closed at $8.75, up $2.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title:
Patents;
A Reactor Features New Safety System
description: LEAD: A nuclear reactor with ehanced safety features was patented this week for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh. Patent No. 4,702,879 was awarded to Stephen N. Tower and Terry L. Schulz, staff engineers.

title: Music: New Works in Tribute to Science
description: In 1887 two scientists, Albert A. Michaelson and Edward W. Morley, performed one of the most important scientific experiments of their time. It proved that the speed of light was not affected by the movement of the earth through space and that there was no mysterious ''ether'' that had been assumed to be the medium through which light traveled beyond the earth's atmosphere. The results, though puzzling at the time, paved the way for Einstein's theory of relativity, and Michaelson became the first American scientist to win the Nobel Prize.

title: Ginsburg Choice Renews Tension Between Factions in White House
description: President Reagan's nomination of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg for the Supreme Court has renewed tensions between White House factions and has frustrated Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, Administration officials said today.

title: Music: Leningrad State Symphony Plays Shostakovich at Carnegie Hall
description: The best reason for being in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening came at the close of the program, when the Leningrad State Symphony fashioned a thoroughly absorbing performance of Shostakovich's brooding Symphony No. 10. The Soviet orchestra, which in 1953 gave the work its first performance, obviously has this music in its bones.

title: Dr. Alexander S. Kohanski
description: Dr. Alexander S. Kohanski, an educator and leader of Jewish organizations, died of lung cancer Sept. 29 at Saddleback Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Laguna Hills.

title: Social Security Cuts, Too
description: In accepting the urgent need for deficit negotiations with Congress, President Reagan left one string attached to the bargain: no reductions in Social Security. Mr. Reagan's reluctance to tackle the giant program is understandable. When he broached the issue six years ago, Democratic Congressional leaders tripped over each other in their eagerness to denounce him.

title: The Proper Dismissal of Dr. Gross
description: For two and a half years, the office of New York City's Chief Medical Examiner has faced charges of incompetence and mismanagement. Mayor Koch now addresses them, properly and directly, by dismissing the chief coroner, Dr. Elliot Gross.

title: ANADARKO PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter results were restated to reflect the adoption of FASB accounting changes.

title: Boeing Officer Will Retire
description: The Boeing Company said today that T. A. Wilson would retire as chairman on Dec. 31, ending a 44-year career. Mr. Wilson, known throughout the aerospace industry simply as ''T,'' will be succeeded by Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's president and chief executive.

title: FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' results are restated to reflect two acquisitions, one for cash, the other on a pooling-of- interest basis.

title: AIDS Book Brings Fame To a Gay San Franciscan
description: ''I'm not a very good homosexual - I can't keep house, decorate, cook or dress,'' said Randy Shilts, explaining why he did not want to meet at his messy apartment. But one thing Mr. Shilts can do well is report and write, and he has written an unforgiving book on AIDS, the scourge of San Francisco.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pact on Taxes Keeps Dreyfus In New York
description: In a reversal, the Koch administration agreed yesterday to tax cuts for the mutual fund industry in exchange for a commitment from the Dreyfus Corporation to remain in New York City.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $2,349,443 and $9,657,795 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $7,058,534 and $20,364,057 for the year- ago quarter and 9 months, repectively. The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in September 1987.

title: Holly Refuses Lowered Plum Bid
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation said it had rejected a proposal by the investor group Plum Associates to lower its $95-a-share, $106.4 million tender offer to $85 a share, or $95.2 million, because of current market conditions.

title: FAMILY MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted to stock form of ownership in November 1986.

title: French and Italians Pressed to Devalue
description: European officials were expected to consider devaluing the French franc and Italian lira against the West German mark this weekend as the German currency's huge rise against the dollar intensified strains within the European Monetary System.

title: Film: 'Deranged,' Suspense, With Visions and Killings
description: Apparently Chuck Vincent, the producer and director of ''Deranged,'' doesn't want to be thought of as a sleazy guy. The production notes delicately describe him as a maker of ''quality porn'' movies (''Jack and Jill,'' Parts I and II) whose latest is a straight suspense film. ''Deranged'' proves you can dress Mr. Vincent's films up but you can't take them out.

title: Mets Raise Ticket Prices
description: The team may not have the same luster it did a year ago, but it's going to cost a bit more next season to watch the Mets from a choice seat in Shea Stadium. The club announced yesterday that the price of a box seat has been increased 10 percent, from $10 to $11, and that the price of reserved seats in the loge and mezzanine have gone from $8.50 to $9.

title: Trading Hours Will Be Longer
description: The nation's main stock exchanges said yesterday that they would return to their normal trading hours in stages.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Mecir Topples McEnroe: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated John McEnroe, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday to join Ivan Lendl, Pat Cash and Mats Wilander in the semifinals of the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Cash, who struggled past Wojtek Fibak, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, will face Lendl, who dominated Tim Mayotte, 6-3, 6-3. Mecir will face Wilander, who beat Brad Gilbert, 6-2, 6-4.(AP) U.S. Takes 3-0 Lead: Pam Shriver routed Jo Durie of Britain, 6-1, 7-5, last night in Williamsburg, Va., moving the United States to within one victory of its ninth straight Wightman Cup championship. The United States took a 3-0 lead in the seven-match challenge.(AP) Mandlikova Beats Wiesner: Second-seeded Hana Mandlikova beat Judith Wiesner of Austria, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $150,000 European indoor women's tournament in Zurich. Mandlikova will face Nathalie Tauziat of France, who struggled past Christina Singer of West Germany, 7-5, 6-4.(AP) Teltscher Tops Leach: In Hong Kong, third-seeded Eliot Teltscher, the only top-ranked player left in the $200,000 Seiko Super tournament, advanced to the semifinals, beating Rick Leach, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3. Teltscher will meet Darren Cahill, who defeated John Ross, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4.(AP) Golf Eagle Gives Japanese a Tie: Yoshitake Yamamoto shot an eagle 2 yesterday en route to an eight-under-par 64 in Kobe, Japan, that helped his Japanese team tie the score in a match against a team of golfers from the United States. Yamamoto, at 134, led the individual standing, two strokes ahead of Johnny Miller, who shot a 69 yesterday.(AP) U.S. Women in Lead: In a women's match in Tokyo, the United States team won four of seven matches yesterday to lead the Japanese team. Jane Geddes and Juli Inkster led the Americans, and Ayako Okamoto led the Japanese.(AP) Kratzert Even With Sieckmann: Bill Kratzert shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to tie the first-round leader, Tom Sieckmann, midway through the $500,000 Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla.(AP) Cross Country Record Set at Heptagonal Games: Chris Schille of Brown set a meet record of 24 minutes 8.1 seconds in the Heptagonal Games cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Dartmouth defended its team title. Schille broke the record of 24:09 set last year by Ron Harris of Navy. (AP) Horse Show High-Jumping Tie: Two horses tied at 7 feet 3 1/4 inches in the high jump yesterday at the Washington Horse Show in Landover, Md. Francis Michel Robert on Pequignet Little Maille and Michaela Murphy on Gusty Monroe tried for a new world indoor record of 7 foot 8 3/4 inches, but neither succeeded.

title: AIDS and Hepatitis Cited in Move to Cut Health Worker Risks
description: Two Federal agencies today began a campaign to reduce the risks of exposing health care workers to the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis B. A joint letter from the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Health and Human Services is being mailed to about 500,000 hospitals, blood banks, hospices, laboratories and other health care employers to urge them to follow guidelines to protect employees from accidental infection with the viruses. The two agencies share responsibility for safety in the workplace.

title: KEY CENTURION BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All results restated to account for the merger of Central National Bank of Buckhannon and the addition of Nicholas County Bank from Jan. 1, 1987, and Union Bancorp of West Virginia Inc. and Wayne Bancorp Inc. from March 13, 1987. The latter three mergers were accounted for on a purchase basis and included in Key Centurion's results from their merger dates.

title: Trial Opens in Slaying of Radio Talk Show Host
description: Four members of a white supremacist group plotted to kill Alan Berg, the Jewish host of a radio talk show, because of his religious background and argumentative personality, a Justice Department official said in a Federal court here today.

title: Stock Price Off On USG's Suit
description: Reacting to a cold response by the USG Corporation to takeover overtures received on Wednesday, the stock of the Chicago-based company fell $2.25 a share today, to close at $35.25.

title: FIRST AMERICAN SAVINGS FA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The First American Savings has its headquarters in Pennsylvania.

title: Make Room for Jersey Buses
description: For tens of thousands of Manhattan-bound New Jersey commuters, morning rush hour usually means a slow crawl under the Hudson. The New Jersey Department of Transportation sensibly proposes a second Lincoln Tunnel lane exclusively for buses.

title: Meese Testifies in Wedtech Case; Faces More Grand Jury Questions
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d faces a fourth appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating his involvement with the Wedtech Corporation after undergoing five hours of questioning today.

title: EAST WEYMOUTH SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MACLEAN-HUNTER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: NATIONAL HERITAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 14.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,487,692 from the sale of a majority stake in a Dutch unit. c-Net loss

title: INTEGON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,095,000 and $10,719,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $1,826,000 for the quarter and $5,165,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOPES HIGH AS BHOPAL TALKS GO ON
description: With reports of progress by both sides, the Indian judge hearing the Bhopal gas-leak case today stepped up the pressure on the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation to settle their dispute out of court.

title: ISRAEL: SINGLE FATHERS' PROTEST
description: In what could be a ground-breaking case, the unmarried father of a baby girl has sued the mother of his child for 40,000 shekels, about $25,000, in personal damages because, he contends, she had the child against his will.

title: Correction
description: A calendar of tours and other events in The Home Section on Thursday misstated the admission price for an antiques show at the County Center in White Plains next Thursday through Sunday. It is $4 for both adults and children.

title: Bridge;  Death of Organizer Caused Long Delay for L.I. Event
description: A considerable delay in the 1987 Nassau-Suffolk Double Knockout Team Championship had a sad reason. Michael Rosmarin, the organizer of the event and long one of the leading players in the metropolitan region, disappeared mysteriously early this year, a presumed murder victim, and his body was eventually found in the East River.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: And How Much Water?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The smiles were out this morning. We've come from complacency, to apprehension, to fear, to relief, and now to hope over the last four weeks.'' - Peter G. Grennan, of Shearson Lehman Brothers. [ 1:3. ]

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company acquired Eagle Window & Door Inc. of Dubuque, Iowa.

title: U.S. Rejects Pleas to Adjust 1990 Census for Undercount
description: The Commerce Department said today that it would not adjust its 1990 census figures to account for people who are inadvertently excluded from the national tally.

title: The Stage: 'Don't Get God Started,' a Gospel Musical
description: Late in the second act of the gospel musical ''Don't Get God Started,'' Vanessa Bell Armstrong, one of the show's two lead vocalists, steps to the front of the stage and announces, ''This is my last song, so I'm really going to sing this one.'' Mobilizing her considerable vocal heft behind Marvin Winans's gospel anthem ''Always,'' Miss Armstrong engulfs the Longacre Theater in the kind of passionate musical testimony that one expects from a gospel show but that until then has been sadly held in abeyance.

title: 4,300 Opponents of Regime Reported Held in Bangladesh
description: Security forces have detained 4,300 opposition leaders and workers in a five-day sweep intended to silence demands that President H. M. Ershad resign, opposition leaders said today. Government officials acknowledged that 519 people had been detained.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: SCRIPPS HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $22,876,000 in gains from the sale of investments in cable systems.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: Despite hints of flexibility by American and Soviet officials, an agreement to reduce long-range arms is not yet within grasp, Administration officials say.

title: Woman Held in Philadelphia In Kidnapping of an Infant
description: A woman was arrested here today for kidnapping a baby boy from his mother's Baltimore hospital room in June. The infant was being tested to confirm his identity, Federal agents said.

title: Poindexter Tells of Telephone Call From Deaver
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter testified today that Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide being tried for perjury, telephoned him at the White House to help secure a Presidential meeting for a trade envoy of the South Korean Government.

title: Don't Blame Democrats for the Unpaid U.N. Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis, Wary of Islam's Rise, Question Tilt to Iran in War
description: Israel's longstanding tilt toward Iran in the Persian Gulf war may be coming to an end. A growing number of important Israeli policy makers and strategists are starting to argue publicly, and in the corridors of power, that Israel should be supporting Iraq and not Iran - even to the point of selling weapons to Baghdad.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1987
description: Market Turmoil

title: Dr. Florence Wislocki, Psychiatrist, Dies at 83
description: Dr. Florence Clothier Wislocki, a psychiatrist and former assistant to the president of Vassar College, died of a stroke Wednesday in the Charlton Memorial Hospital in Fall River, Mass. She was 83 years old and lived in Little Compton, R.I.

title: New Capital Raised by Haas
description: The Haas Securities Corporation, which stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange last week when its capital fell below the exchange's minimum requirements, said yesterday that it had raised between $3 million and $5 million in financing from two private investors, allowing it to resume operations.

title: SCHERER, R P CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $240,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK- PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted to a stock institution in January.

title: Junius P. Wilson Jr.; A Law School Founder

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil clinched his third Formula One driving championship when Nigel Mansell of Britain, his teammate and the only driver with a chance to catch him, was forced to withdraw from Sunday's Grand Prix of Japan because of injury. Mansell was hurt during a qualifying session yesterday when his car went out of control. He was taken to a hospital in Nagoya with injuries to his back and his right foot . . . Alex Baumann, the Canadian swimmer who won gold medals in the 200- and 400-meter individual medleys at the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, announced his retirement from competition at a news conference in Toronto yesterday.

title: Police Raid Korea Campuses
description: The police raided campuses in four cities before dawn today and seized fire bombs, clubs and leaflets to try to cripple planned nationwide rallies by dissidents, opposition leaders said. The raids followed riots Friday in which students demanded that the governing party's candidate, Roh Tae Woo, pull out of the presidential race and that a neutral interim regime be set up to insure fair elections.

title: WESTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Falcons Sign Miller
description: After several months of often bitter negotiations, the Atlanta Falcons signed Chris Miller, their top draft choice, to a five-year, $2.8 million contract yesterday. Miller, a former University of Oregon quarterback, who during negotiations had requested a trade to another National Football League team, admitted at a news conference in Suwanee, Ga. yesterday: ''I did have anger and animosity because I wanted to play. I'm glad things have finally worked out.'' Miller agreed to a signing bonus of $600,000, less than most top choices receive. He will begin working with the Falcons next Tuesday. His signing left Cornelius Bennett, the former Alabama linebacker, and Kelly Stouffer, the former Colorado State quarterback, as the only 1987 first-round picks who have not come to terms with their teams. Bennett was drafted by the Indianapolis Colts and Stouffer by the St. Louis Cardinals. . . . With Tony Dorsett of the Dallas Cowboys apparently available in the trading market, the Denver Broncos might be tempted to consider a deal for the 33-year-old running back because of their loss last week of Gerald Willhite, who will be out for the season with a broken leg.

title: Star of 'Wings' Recalls 1927
description: In ''Wings,'' the 1927 movie about World War I fliers that won the first Academy Award, Charles (Buddy) Rogers brushes away a tear from the cheek of Clara Bow. The other day, 60 years later, Mr. Rogers brushed away another tear while watching the film. This time it was his own. In an evening of sentimentality and laughter, Mr. Rogers came to Washington to watch ''Wings'' again as the Library of Congress began a showing of the first 10 movies to be selected as the best pictures of the year by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. (For information on screening dates of the other films, call (202) 287-5677.) This screening was special, a silent movie accompanied not only by a pianist but also by the star commenting on its filming.

Donnelly, who had a strong training camp with the Rangers, has been the leading scorer at Denver in seven games. Larouche left practice Tuesday with a sore lower back and will probably not be available for this weekend's games.

title: After Nobel Prize, Caviar for Russian Poet
description: Joseph Brodsky returned to New York University yesterday, greeting friends and reading some poems as he has done many times before. But this time, the mood was a good deal more jocular than reverential, with hugs and congratulations and excitement, not to mention caviar and champagne instead of the salami sandwiches served on other such occasions.
